title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lintas: New York Starts Cold Cream Campaign
description: Lintas: New York has announced an ad campaign for a new cold cream. The cream, called Difrinse, is the first water-rinsable cold cream developed by Noxell. In a new television spot, a clown is depicted taking off its makeup as a narrator notes that the cream rinses off with water, leaving ''softer, cleaner skin.'' Unmasked, the clown turns out to be a beautiful woman. The new campaign comes on the heels of another change in Noxell's advertising; last week, the company switched its Noxzema Shave Cream account to Leo Burnett from Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The F.B.I. is a proud organization. It has sometimes been difficult for us to recognize that there is the potential for injustice in our own ranks.'' - William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. [ A1:4. ]

title: U.N. Clears Last Hurdle to Free Namibia
description: The last obstacle to the start of a United Nations plan to give Namibia independence was overcome today. African countries received assurances that the world organization would buy as little as possible from South Africa for the peacekeeping force it will send to oversee the transition to independence.

title: National Trustco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After securities gains of $622,000 for the latest first quarter and $27,000 for the year-ago period. The company recently changed its name from National Victoria & Grey Trustco Ltd. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Drug Agent Killed in Car On S.I. Street
description: A Federal drug enforcement agent was shot and killed last night during a meeting with an underworld drug contact in a car on Staten Island.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. North Stars 4, Capitals 3: Dino Ciccarelli scored a power-play goal with 16 seconds left in regulation time as Minnesota scored twice in the final minute. Brian MacLellan tied the score with his 15th goal of the season with 55 seconds left. Washington's Scott Stevens took a roughing penalty 29 seconds later and Ciccarelli poked a rebound over Don Beaupre, the Washington goalie, for his 32d goal. Minnesota came back from a 3-0 deficit. The victory ended the North Stars' 0-8-1 streak in the Capital Centre since their last victory there, on Oct. 23, 1982.(AP) Canucks 3, Nordiques 2: Steve Bozek scored with 2:22 remaining to give Vancouver, playing on the road, its eighth victory in nine games. Using Stan Smyl as a screen, Bozek fired a low shot past the Quebec goalie, Mario Gosselin, for his 13th goal. N.B.A. Cavaliers 115, Pistons 99: Larry Nance and Ron Harper each scored 14 points in the second half and Cleveland outscored Detroit, 34-17, at the free-throw line at home.(AP) Celtics 112, Hornets 87:Reggie Lewis and Kevin McHale scored all of Boston's points in the first period, then the Celtics used a 26-4 tear in the second quarter at Charlotte. McHale had 19 of his 21 points in the first half, and Lewis got 15 of his 28. (AP) TRACK Lewis Wins in Spain: Carl Lewis avenged two losses to Cuban sprinters by winning the 60-meter dash in the Seville indoor meet yesterday in Spain. Lewis won in 6.64 seconds, beating Andres Simon of Cuba. Mark Witherspoon of the United States was third, followed by another Cuban, Ricardo Chacon. The Cubans beat Lewis at 60 meters in indoor meets in San Sebastian and Oviedo this month.(AP) SOCCER U.S. Loses in Semifinals: Nigeria beat the United States, 2-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the World Youth Cup tournament in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, after 30 minutes of overtime. Nigeria will meet Portugal in the final of the 19-and-under tournament in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Friday. Portugal defeated Brazil, 1-0, in the other semifinal. The Americans and Nigeria were scoreless at halftime and tied at 1-1 at the end of regulation time, but Nigeria scored the clincher in overtime. The goalkeeper, Kasey Keller, starred for the Americans as he dived and stretched to hold off the Nigerians. Mutiu Adepoju, thwarted by Keller on many occasions, scored Nigeria's first goal in the 48th minute. But Steve Snow of the United States tied the match, 1-1, on a penalty kick in the 53d minute. Adepoju booted in the winner in the third minute of the first 15-minute overtime period. The teams were scoreless in the second 15-minute period(AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL Christ the King, Rice Gain: Christ the King, ranked third in the nation, jumped off to a 12-0 lead in the first five minutes and then coasted to a 78-59 victory over All Hallows in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association semifinals at St. John's University. The Royals (24-1), ranked first in the state by the New York Sportswriters Association, handled the Gaels (18-8) despite the fact that Jamal Faulkner, Christ the King's 6-foot-8-inch all-America center, did not score his first points until were 1 minute 15 seconds were left in the third period. He finished with 10. In the other semifinal, Rice eliminated Xaverian, 71-68. Ron Arnold, the 6-4 senior forward, scored 23 points and grabbed 7 rebounds and had 3 steals, all game-highs. Dennis McCullough, the 5-8 junior point guard, scored 13. TENNIS Gilbert, a Late Entry, Advances: Brad Gilbert, a replacement for the tournament favorite, Boris Becker, upset Stefan Edberg, 7-6, 6-1, 6-3 in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis Finals in Dallas. Edberg was playing his first match in five weeks after suffering back spasms at the Australian Open. W.C.T. officials called Gilbert at his Oakland, Calif., home Monday night when Jimmy Connors, the first alternate, failed to arrive in Dallas. Becker dropped out because he was ill.(AP)

title: Edwards Barred
description: Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards of England, a ski jumper who gained international fame through his inept jumping, has been barred from competing in World Cup events, at least through the end of the current season. The British Ski Federation said it had decided to keep Edwards on lower-level events for the time being. Edwards is expected to return to action soon after recovering from a shoulder injury suffered as he was training in December. ''Although Eddie is again fit to jump - and I am delighted to hear the good news - it would be inappropriate for him to launch straight into these high-level World Cup events,'' said John Leaning, the federation's Nordic competition director in London. ''We consider it more logical and sensible for him to ease back into the lower-level 70-meter European events, which take place in early March.'' (AP)

title: CHILD ATROCITIES ATTRIBUTED TO IRAQ
description: Hundreds of children in Iraq have been imprisoned, tortured or executed in a Government campaign ''deliberately targeting the children of political opponents,'' Amnesty International said in a report released today.

title: White House Staff Makes Series of Tactical Errors
description: The scalding fight over the nomination of John G. Tower underscores what even some White House aides privately acknowledge: President Bush's independent-mindedness and his appointment of a largely inexperienced White House staff have produced one tactical misstep after the other.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: AS a grandfather of four girls, ranging from 8 to 10 years old, and a ravenous 15-month-old boy, I have learned a great deal about the food preferences of youngsters. My clan is unusually adventuresome. The girls, for example, have developed an uncommon passion for escargot, which they ask me to prepare whenever they visit.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: BAKING with flour is not the microwave oven's best trick, nor is browning. But when you want to do one or both of these things, the microwave oven can be a great aid in preparation that would otherwise take more time or be more annoying. The filling for a lemon-orange meringue pie can be made in the microwave oven. The crust is conventionally baked and the meringue is once again browned under the broiler. The lemon curd is easy to make in a microwave oven and does not scorch. It also contains no gelatin. It can be made ahead of time and left to chill overnight. The crust can also be baked ahead of time. For a nice variation, add orange sections and orange zest. Lemon-Orange Meringue Pie Preparation time: 30 minutes, plus time for making lemon curd and chilling crust Cooking time: 25 minutes 2 cups lemon curd (see recipe) 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour 2 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt 3 ounces cold lard 3 ounces chilled unsalted butter, cut into small pieces 3 tablespoons cold water 1/4 cup orange marmalade 2 juice oranges, optional 4 egg whites pinch cream of tartar pinch kosher salt 1/4 cup granulated sugar.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Agent Shot Dead

title: A Gang Gives a Name to Students' Fear: Decepticons
description: A loosely organized street gang with fewer than 60 members and a name inspired by a cartoon has taken on near-mythical status among high school students in New York City, the police and school officials say.

title: Review/Television; Coming of Age in the World of 1950
description: After a couple of weeks of presenting movies already released theatrically - one was made in Canada in 1985 - ''American Playhouse'' is getting back to material produced specifically for television. ''Love and Other Sorrows,'' on Channel 13 at 9 this evening, is an adaptation of a 1958 short story by Harold Brodkey. On one level, it is a coming-of-age story, but you won't find any of the programmed laughs or heart tugs that even a first-rate series like ''The Wonder Years'' feels compelled to dole out each week. ''Love and Other Sorrows'' assumes you are grown up and don't require coddling.

description: Naomi Brauer Koshkin and Jack Barry Friedman were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Longview, Tex., by Rabbi Bernard Honan. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Benjamin B. Brauer of New York and the late Mr. Brauer. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mendel Friedman of Shreveport, La.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mr. Bush Storms Asia
description: For a ballplayer who never hit .300 at Yale, George Bush compiled some impressive statistics in his first Presidential trip abroad: 18,095 miles, 21 individual sessions with heads of state, five official dinners. All this in little more than 100 hours of frenzied diplomacy that left Mr. Bush still pinballing around and his entourage on tilt.

title: Bush Fails to Win Any New Votes As Senate Fight Over Tower Boils
description: President Bush held a series of meetings today with uncommitted Democratic senators but apparently failed to produce any new votes for the nomination of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense.

title: Consumer Spending In Surge
description: In a sobering report on the economy, the Commerce Department said today that consumer spending climbed even faster than initially estimated for the fourth quarter of last year, while business investment fell by a larger amount.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14 Dozens of Venezuelans were killed in rioting Monday that was prompted by measures imposed to satisfy creditors, the nation's President said. He suspended constitutional guarantees and imposed curfew. Page A1 Salvadoran army declares truce to back Duarte A9 Washington called on the P.L.O. to refrain from attacks on Israeli targets if it wanted to continue its discussions with the United States. A1 An official report on drug trafficking has praised Mexico for increasing its anti-narcotics efforts, Administration officials said. It also evaluated the efforts of other nations. A8 An Iranian-British diplomatic split became more likely as Iran threatened to sever ties unless Britain withdrew support in the next week for Salman Rushdie. A10 Two bookstores are firebombed; Rushdie tie is explored A10 Soviets ask intermediary role in Rushdie case A10 Not all Soviet elections are tossups. In some parts of the nation, particularly places like the Ukraine that have strong nationalist movements, politicians are sticking to tradition and running unopposed. A10 Private home ownership in China as a way to solve tremendous shortages has been the aim of a slowly developing program that seems to be taking off nationally this year. A5 The children of war in Mozambique have witnessed atrocities or been forced in some cases to become killers. The Government is trying to reunite families and heal wounds.

title: EATING
description: LEAD: THIS is what really happened with Adam and Eve: Many years ago, in a popular restaurant called The Garden, a young couple on their first date sat contentedly after a magnificent meal. The maitre d'hotel, a long, thin fellow with a greenish complexion pushed a loaded pastry cart to the side of the table and asked the young woman, rather sibilantly, if she would like dessert.

title: At a Manhattan Elementary School, Lunch Is a Lesson in Itself
description: AT 11 on a recent morning at the Studio Elementary School on the Upper West Side, Sasha Weintraub's hands were gooey with a paste of flounder, potatoes, carrots and onions. The 10-year-old student had been making fish cakes for the past half hour. She, along with Max Levine, 6, and their teacher, Ruth Marinaro, were preparing lunch for school's 45 students.

title: Where to Eat on the Edge
description: LIKE dandelions pushing through a cracked sidewalk, restaurants throw roots in some of the most unlikely corners of New York City. And almost invariably, where restaurants succeed, urban homesteaders are sure to follow - along with higher rents.

description: New England Monthly, an award-winning magazine and one of the most prominent new consumer publications of the last five years, is being sold to Telemedia Inc., Canada's largest publisher of consumer magazines.

description: Bernard Pagezy, chairman of Compagnie du Midi, France's second-largest insurance company, lost out today to Claude Bebear, Midi's vice chairman, in a battle for control of the company.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Foreign Affairs; Afghanistan Pullout: Joy and Worries Overlap
description: The morning after the last Soviet combat troops left Afghanistan, an intelligence official told a friend: ''Feb. 15 was the first day in history that the Soviet empire was smaller at sunset than at sunrise.''

title: Cone Criticizes Mets
description: David Cone, who won 20 games and lost only 3 last season, berated the Mets today for playing a ''blackmail game'' when they broke off salary negotiations and said that they would unilaterally renew his contract later this week.

title: About New York; A Toast or 2 or 20 From the Welsh To Their Saint
description: The Rev. Cyril Jenkins recalled the one time he met Dylan Thomas, that quicksilver bard of the Welsh soul. ''He was a little under the weather,'' Dr. Jenkins said. So the poet was sick? ''He was not in a creative mood at the time,'' came the vague answer.

title: Interest Growing In 'Natural' Beef
description: SINCE January, when countries in Europe decided to stop buying American beef that was grown with hormones, some American consumers have searched stores for beef advertised as being natural or hormone-free, believing that it is safer to eat.

title: Faiyazuddin Dagar, An Indian Singer, 55
description: Faiyazuddin Dagar, a singer whose family has been performing its own tradition of Hindu classical music for 19 generations - since the 15th century - died of a heart attack Feb. 7 in New Delhi. He was 55 years old.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Police Gaining on Speeders Again
description: LEAD: Highway police will soon be able to use lasers in their hunt for speeders, if a Colorado company has its way.

title: S.E.C. Will Keep Cambrian Shares
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to tender its stock in the British mutual fund that used to be headed by Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen Wall Street investor. The Leucadia National Corporation, a New York holding company, has already acquired 73 percent of the voting securities of the mutual fund, Cambrian & General Securities P.L.C., under its friendly takeover offer.

title: Dissident Priest Loses Battle To Keep Post at Catholic U.
description: A District of Columbia court ruled yesterday that the Catholic University of America was not obliged to retain the Rev. Charles E. Curran as a teacher of theology. Father Curran, suspended from his teaching duties after the Vatican declared him ineligible to teach Catholic theology, had filed a lawsuit accusing the university of violating his contract as a tenured professor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bloom Gets Buitoni
description: Nestle Foods has taken its pasta business south in switching the account for its subsidiary Buitoni to the Bloom Agency in Dallas. Bloom already handles the accounts of several Nestle products through Carnation, a Nestle subsidiary. Buitoni was made part of the Carnation unit after Nestle acquired the Italian company last year. It had farmed its advertising out to several agencies on a freelance basis before selecting Bloom.

title: Seaport Project Again Opposed By Its Neighbors
description: Having been turned down three times in its efforts to build a new tower in the old South Street Seaport Historic District, Milstein Properties returned yesterday to the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission with a proposal that was lower - but not small enough to suit its many opponents.

title: Left in the Lurch in China
description: President Bush started off right when he invited Fang Lizhi to join 500 guests at the barbecue at which he was host in Beijing Sunday. That would have upheld America's values in much the same way Ronald Reagan did last spring when he ignored Moscow's objections and held a reception for Soviet dissenters. The invitation to Mr. Fang, China's best-known democratic dissident, seemed to prove that America's leaders understand that effective diplomacy doesn't require acquiescing to repression abroad.

title: Lasmo Oil Deal
description: The British oil company Lasmo said it would buy International Thomson Organization Ltd.'s British North Sea interests for $:358 million, or $623 million. Lasmo, formally called the London and Scottish Marine Oil P.L.C., is one of Britain's largest independent oil and gas exploration companies. It said the purchase of Thomson North Sea Holdings from Canada-based Thomson would almost double its North Sea production to 49,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day. In December, Lasmo sold its 25.2 percent stake in Enterprise Oil P.L.C. to France's Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine.

title: Gervin Treated
description: George Gervin, the former Spurs' forward who led the National Basketball Association in scoring four times, was treated at a hospital in San Antonio last Saturday for what the police investigated as an apparent drug overdose, The San Antonio Light reported yesterday. According to a police report, Gervin told an officer that he snorted what he ''thought was cocaine'' and later said he did not know what it was, the paper said. Gervin, 36, had been receiving drug counseling in Virginia. (AP)

title: Early Bush, Early Folly
description: Despite the superficial ''approval'' rating he has just received in the polls, George Bush is getting off to a poorer start than even his detractors had expected once he shed the Reagan incubus. His first month in office has been more notable for floundering than leadership, for a sense of confusion than a sense of direction.

title: FPS Computing reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Johnson Era Begins for Cowboys
description: Jimmy Johnson, the man wearing the black hat, returned to Texas today after taking over as head coach of the squeaky-clean Dallas Cowboys. This was not the homecoming he expected.

title: Where Restaurants Lead, Crowds May Follow
description: THE Priory restaurant in Newark sits on the edge of vast wreckage and ruin. Yet at lunch time the converted stone church that houses the restaurant fills with people from all over the city, lured by the atmosphere and a menu that features seafood and Southern cuisine.

title: Remembering Vietnam
description: President Bush has suggested that the nation put the Vietnam War behind it, but many young people in the United States are eagerly delving into that tumultuous time as they try to understand the divisions of their parents' youth.

title: How to Tell Who Rings Your Phone
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it would offer customers a caller identification system that would display the number from which an incoming call was originating before the call was answered.

title: Only a Symbol for Civil Rights
description: The Republicans appear to have blown a big chance to mend fences with racial minorities. Embarrassed by the victory of a former Ku Klux Klansman on the Republican ticket in Louisiana, they had a splendid opportunity to reach out. The Bush Administration could have chosen an impressive new chief of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division. Instead, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has recommended the nomination of a civil rights nonentity.

title: Salvadoran Army Declares Truce to Back Duarte
description: The Salvadoran Army declared tonight that it would begin a cease-fire at midnight, apparently in an effort to increase the political pressure on leftist guerrillas to stop fighting.

title: Panel Finds Judge's Acts Merit Ouster
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct determined yesterday that Judge Irving W. Levine should be removed from the Civil Court in Brooklyn because of judicial misconduct in the handling of a case involving a friend of Meade Esposito, the convicted former Brooklyn political leader.

title: Bill Strauss, 74, WQXR Announcer And News Director
description: Bill Strauss, whose voice was familiar to radio listeners during the nearly four decades he served as an announcer and later news director for WQXR, died of cardio-respiratory failure Saturday at the Salem Hills (N.Y.) Nursing Care Center, where he lived for the past year. He was 74 years old and had been a longtime resident of Somers, N.Y.

title: G.M. and Hughes Institute Settle Dispute on 1985 Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation today settled its dispute with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute over G.M.'s 1985 purchase of the Hughes Aircraft Company through a series of financial arrangements that could be worth more than $2.5 billion to the institute through 1995.

title: A.T.&T. And Zenith In TV Deal
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Zenith Electronics Corporation yesterday announced a joint agreement to develop a system for high-definition television, which provides pictures twice as sharp as existing television.

title: Frozen Faces Watching Frozen Faces
description: One set of figures on display at the Whitney Museum's branch at 42d Street and Park Avenue consists of sculptures in wood, metal and ceramic. These are mostly stylized ''Urban Figures'' created by artists including Alison Saar, John Ahearn, Alex Katz, Jonathan Borofsky and George Segal.

title: Erixon Tries Not to Worry
description: The small, circular weights of the traction equipment hang at one end of the Lenox Hill Hospital bed, tugging continuously at Jan Erixon's midsection and at his doubts and fears as well. Immobilized physically, Erixon's thoughts can't help but take his mind places it would rather avoid.

title: About Education
description: rrIf confessions of doing things badly could remedy dismal situations, great mathematics and science teaching should be just around the corner. Report after report has shown that American students are straggling near the tail end of all international math and science competitions.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Convicted
description: A Phoenix Municipal Court judge yesterday convicted Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers' center, of two misdemeanor offenses that arose from a shoving incident in a shopping mall last April 21. Judge John L. Wiehn set sentencing for March 29. The 41-year-old defendant, who is in his 20th year in the National Basketball Association and has announced his retirement, could be fined up to $1,750, sentenced to 10 months in jail and put on five years' probation in the convictions on single counts of criminal damage and assault. Wiehn does not have to impose all or any of the penalties. Abdul-Jabbar told police that Fernando Nicolia, a tourist from Rome, was annoying him. According to the police records, Nicolia was following Abdul-Jabbar in the mall with a video camera when Abdul-Jabbar turned on the tourist and stiff-armed the camera. Nicolia, who has filed a civil suit over the incident, charged that he suffered a bruised eye and a scratched ear. (AP)

It's a place shaped by success, which can take many forms. It is, for instance, the kind of place where Woody Allen, Francis Coppola and Martin Scorsese might join forces to make a film together, simply because they are Woody Allen, Francis Coppola and Martin Scorsese.

title: Twisty Path to a Shutdown
description: Since last spring, when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced an agreement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, hopes for an end to the stalemate have repeatedly risen, only to fall again. These are some of the important dates in this saga of reversals: May 26, 1988: Two months after the Long Island Lighting Company rebuffed a $7.45 billion takeover offer by the Long Island Power Authority, Mr. Cuomo and the utility announce an agreement in principle to close Shoreham and help Lilco regain financial health. Dec. 1: After months of debate, including a brief session in September, the Legislature fails to endorse the settlement, declaring it too expensive for Lilco customers. Lawmakers insist that they are being forced to ratify the agreement just so the Governor can share political responsibility. Mr. Cuomo declares the deal to be dead. Dec. 5: A Federal jury finds that Lilco lied to state regulators to obtain rate increases and awards Suffolk $22.9 million in damages. Dec. 9: Mr. Cuomo and Suffolk County officials announce they are trying to fashion a new settlement. Any new accord, they say, would build on Mr. Cuomo's settlement and use the racketeering verdict to bring Lilco back to the table. Dec. 21: The judge in the racketeering case, Jack B. Weinstein, raises the stakes by bringing in a mediator, Kenneth R. Feinberg. Mr. Feinberg, a Washington lawyer, was instrumental in settling the Agent Orange herbicide case for Judge Weinstein. Jan. 31, 1989: Mr. Cuomo, apparently in a reversal, says he no longer insists that the Legislature agree to a deal to close Shoreham, except for a reduction in Lilco's gross-receipts tax. Legislative leaders refuse to guarantee passage. Feb. 11: Judge Weinstein dismisses the racketeering case, ruling that Suffolk's contention that Lilco had lied to obtain rate increases should have never been tried under Federal law. Mr. Feinberg outlines a proposed settlement. Feb. 23: Negotiations between Suffolk and Lilco to settle the racketeering suit collapse. The talks had been seen as important because an accord would have brought great pressure on Mr. Cuomo to find a way to close the plant. Feb. 28: Mr. Cuomo and Lilco sign an agreement to close Shoreham permanently. No legislative approval is needed, but the accord is contingent on approval by the Lilco board.

title: Agents' Trial to Begin
description: A defense attorney yesterday sought to have the former sports agent Lloyd Bloom tried separately from his colleague, Norby Walters, on Federal charges including racketeering and extortion. Both men are accused of using cash and threats to line up college athletes as clients. At a brief hearing, United States District Judge George Marovich said he would rule on the motion today before empaneling the jury. Marovich also postponed until today a ruling on a move by prosecutors to introduce new evidence, and on a request by the defense attorney Robert Gold to remove himself as Walters's attorney if that evidence is allowed. Prosecutors said Monday that they might seek new charges against Walters, who faces counts of wire fraud, mail fraud and extortion. Bloom faces similar charges. But United States Attorney Anton Valukas told Marovich yesterday that they would instead seek only to submit the new evidence. Gold said the evidence could cause him to remove himself from the case by requiring him to testify in Walters's defense.(AP)

title: Trial of North Stalled Again; Defense Moves for Dismissal

title: Bruno Gives Challenge At Big Welcome Home
description: Frank Bruno returned to London yesterday in a rowdy homecoming and said he wanted another shot at Mike Tyson's heavyweight title. Bruno was quickly escorted from Heathrow Airport after reporters broke through the barricades and fans converged on Bruno and a friend, Laura Mooney. Bruno called the welcome ''unbelievable'' and said: ''I'm just sorry I didn't bring the title home.'' Arriving from Las Vegas, Nev., the 27-year-old Bruno said, ''I'm too young to retire. I would love to meet Tyson again, this time in London. I hope it will be this summer.'' Bruno was stopped in the fifth round of their championship fight Saturday night. ''I reckon I would stop Tyson next time,'' said Bruno. ''I learned a lot from the fight, and I proved he's only human. He can be hurt.'' (AP)

In fact, it was big news all over the nation.

One result was that institutional investors continued to stand aside, which reduced trading activity and may have exaggerated price moves.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene: The women's locker room of the Vertical Club, one of the more fashionable midtown gyms. The time: A few days before Lent. Dramatis personae: Lorinda Ash and two women whose heart-to-heart conversation she overhears. The women, it soon becomes apparent, are: single, middle-aged, a tad overweight, as well as unhappy with their romantic involvements, their too-small apartments, the high cost of living in New York, their unrewarding jobs. First woman: So what are you planning to give up for Lent? Second woman: What have I got to give up, Lean Cuisine?'' SICK TOGETHER My wheeze answers his dry hack. He chills. I bear-hug, raise thermostat. Clammy, we kick covers. Sneezes ring staccato. Crumpled tissues, mucous-moist, snowflake the carpet. Cleanse thermometer. Monitor digital temperatures plummeting, ascending, plummeting - a stock market gone wild - swimming in teas, soups, humidifer humming. MERILEE KAUFMAN Dear Diary:

title: 69 More Aliens Arrested on a Flight from Los Angeles to New York
description: After apprehending 79 people suspected of being illegal aliens on a flight from California here Monday morning, immigration officials boarded the same Eastern Airlines flight at the Los Angeles airport Monday night and detained another 69 aliens.

title: Chinese Face Epochal Wait For Housing
description: At an electronics company here, 20-year-old employees face a 73-year waiting list to get housing.

title: Central America Sweep
description: Absence of policy guidelines and appointments for key posts are creating particular unease in Central America. The most important and pressing decisions are on the people who will be named to manage relations.

title: Lloyd William Daly, Professor, 78
description: Lloyd William Daly, retired professor of Greek and Latin literature at the University of Pennsylvania, died Sunday at the home of his daughter, Caryl Johnson, in Englewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Englewood.

title: Belmoral Mines Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $143,000. c-Net income and the quarter included a tax credit of $1,162,000. The company said the latest fourth- quarter and year results included a writedown of investments of $6,446,000. It was not immediately clear whether that writedown was a pre-tax or after-tax amount. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Laser Precision reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Magnitude' Is a Very Big Word
description: rrI rolled over in my mind the word ''magnitude.''

title: St. Louis in Bid For N.F.L. Team
description: An investment group announced today that it would seek a National Football League expansion franchise for St. Louis and that an exhibition game between the New England Patriots and the Seattle Seahawks would be played at Busch Stadium this summer.

title: Innotech Aviation Enterprises Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Petrolite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Colvin R. de Silva, Sri Lanka Politician, 82
description: Colvin R. de Silva, a founding member of Sri Lanka's leftist movement and a former Cabinet minister, died Monday. He was 82 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Appointment at Turner For 'Coordinated Effort'
description: To unify its disparate advertising, promotion and public relations operations, the Turner Broadcasting System has named Arthur R. Sando, 41 years old, vice president of marketing and communications.

title: Inquiry Gets to Its Heart: Johnson
description: An inquiry into drug use by Canada's elite athletes moved into a new phase today, one expected to shed light on the circumstances leading to the disqualification of the sprinter Ben Johnson from the Seoul Olympics last year.

title: ERC International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Angna Enters, 82, Dancer, Mime And Artist Known for Characters
description: Angna Enters, a dancer and mime, painter and writer, died on Saturday at the County Manor Nursing Home in Tenafly, N.J. She was 82 years old.

title: Emerald Magnate Slain At Home in Colombia
description: The head of a Colombian emerald mine was slain with 18 others at a housewarming party on Monday.

title: New York Bonds Back Medical Site
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency is tentatively offering $65.5 million of project revenue bonds for the main campus of Beth Israel Medical Center through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Nurse, Removed From Feeding Tube, Dies
description: Carol McConnell, a 57-year-old emergency-room nurse whose family won the right to remove her from a life-sustaining feeding tube, died of pneumonia today at her oldest daughter's weekend home in North Stonington, the daughter said.

title: Western Capital Investment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and $8.5 million for the year. c-Net income

title: 4 Guardian Angels Surrender
description: Four Guardian Angels surrendered to the police today on charges of assaulting three teen-agers while patrolling a South Philadelphia neighborhood, officials said. Charges against the four, who range from 12 to 16 years of age, were filed Monday after a three-day investigation. The incident occurred Friday night in front of a vacant house that Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, said was used by drug dealers.

title: S.P.I.-Suspension & Parts InFdustries Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Nissan in Venture
description: The Structural Dynamics Research Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, the big Japanese auto maker, have formed a joint company to provide engineering consulting services in the Far East. The joint venture marks the first time Nissan has teamed up with an overseas company to begin a new business activity. Nissan owns 70 percent of the new company, to be called the Estech Corporation, and Structural Dynamics owns 30 percent. Estech, to be based in Yokohama, Japan, will provide engineering consulting and problem-solving techniques related to product design and manufacturing.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Orders Release Of Brawley Records
description: A State Supreme Court judge has ordered New York State to release some records from its investigation into a leak of material from the grand jury in the Tawana Brawley case.

title: Gloomy Cloud Hovers For the 1990 Season
description: The way Jack Morris sees it, he and his Detroit teammates should not expect to be pitching and hitting, as they were today, at Marchant Stadium next spring. Next spring, Morris suspects, there will be no baseball.

title: Dozens of Venezuelans Killed In Riots Over Price Increases
description: Venezuela's President said dozens of people had been killed and hundreds wounded in rioting today and Monday over economic measures imposed by the Government to satisfy its creditors.

title: In Mexico, an Annual Ritual To Lobby the U.S. Congress
description: In what is fast becoming an annual ritual, the Governments of the United States and Mexico have started a joint offensive to convince American senators and representatives that Mexico's war against drug trafficking is worthy of Congressional blessing.

title: Cucos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 15
description: b-Net loss and after a $1,028,917 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Data-Design Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $698,000 charge from the redemption of debt and a $258,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes. c-Net income d-Included a $310,000 tax credit. The company said it recorded a reserve of $1.2 million in the latest second quarter to cover potential losses on the sale of property in Idaho, Arizona and California, and possible losses that may be incurred as the result of strategic divestitures.

title: Guardcor Investments reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $41,487. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Firm Outlines Its Structure
description: Three executives who left Salomon Brothers last fall yesterday announced details about the new firm they have established. William J. Voute, E. Craig

title: Montefiore Is Accused In Bronx Patient Death
description: A criminal complaint filed by the Emergency Medical Service against a Bronx hospital has focused renewed attention on the crisis of overcrowded emergency rooms and the efficiency of New York's ambulance service.

title: Golan Quits Cannon Group To Form His Own Company
description: Menahem Golan, the former head of Cannon Group Inc., has resigned his remaining posts to form his own film production company, Cannon said yesterday.

title: Open Desktop Is Introduced
description: Five leading computer and software companies jointly announced Open Desktop, a software product that is intended to provide users of personal computers based on the Intel Corporation 80386 chip with many of the features of technical work stations. Open Desktop will be available in the third quarter of this year, with prices starting at $995.

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $3 million for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars. The company was not public a year- earlier.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Espey Manufacturing & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from a change in accounting principle of $102,774.

title: Firefly Lights the Way To New Medical Tests
description: The chemical ingredients that make firefly tails light up on summer evenings are being marketed commercially as fast-acting detectors of infections in medical tests and for measuring the active ingredients in some pharmaceuticals.

title: Groupe Harricana Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Afghans Said to Defect From Army to Rebels
description: Thousands of Afghan soldiers and militiamen defected to the guerrilla side the day after the last Soviet soldier left Afghanistan on Feb. 15, Western diplomats said today.

title: Home Resale Drop Is 7.4%
description: Sales of existing homes fell 7.4 percent in January after a sharp jump in activity in December, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Happy Birthday, Hamburger! (Perhaps)
description: NO one knows for sure when the hamburger made its debut.

title: Economic Scene; A Breakthrough On Poverty?
description: COULD this be the year Congress comes to the aid of the working poor?

title: Development Groups Urged
description: The David Sarnoff Research Center, formerly the RCA Laboratories facility in Princeton, N.J., today called for the formation of consortiums to develop optoelectronic integrated circuit technology.

title: Great Pacific Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Peruvian Ship Runs Aground In the Antarctic and Spills Oil
description: A Peruvian research ship that ran aground in the Antarctic is leaking oil, a Chilean Navy spokesman said on Monday.

title: Formica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $6,330,000 and $8,506,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. The company said the net for 1988 included $15.5 million, or $1.18 a share, attributable to the sale of Australian and New Zealand subsidiaries in June 1988. The company also said share net for the 1987 year is after preferred dividend requirements of $1,078,000. There were no preferred dividend requirements in the fourth quarter of either year or in the 1988 full year.

title: South Africans Protest Curbs on Freed Detainees
description: Two weeks after the Government announced that a ''substantial'' number of prisoners held without trial would be freed, lawyers and civil rights workers are protesting the imposition of harsh restrictions on those who have been released.

title: Review/Piano; Music From a 96-Year-Old Master
description: One way musicians express the joy of having Mieczyslaw Horszowski still among us playing the piano so beautifully is to think of different ways to describe the extraordinary span of time his career has covered.

title: Boston Plan Would Allow Choice of Schools
description: The Boston School Committee, dividing along racial lines, has adopted a plan that would allow parents to choose the schools their children attend. Blacks have vowed to fight it, charging it would resegregate the city's schools.

title: Interphase Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Imagine Films reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Interstate Sees Losses at Unit
description: The Texas unit of First Interstate Bancorp will continue to lose money this year, the company's chairman, Joseph J. Pinola, said. Asked whether losses at Allied Bancshares Inc. of Houston would approach the $199.7 million shortfall as of November, Mr. Pinola said: ''Of course not.''

title: A Chinese Tradition
description: To The Living Section:

title: Basic American Medical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $500,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net loss The company said its latest fourth quarter included a $2.4 million gain from the sale of its mobile diagnostic company, which was offset by a $1.1 million charge for estimated future professional liability costs, and a $600,000 increase in the provision for bad debts at Omni Manufacturing Inc. The year-ago fourth quarter included an $8.6 million charge relating to a hospital in Puerto Rico and a shareholders agreement. The latest year net included a $3.4 million pretax gain on the sale of assets related to the company's retirement living communities managment business and a $2.4 million gain on the sale of the company's mobile diagnostics company. The gains were offset by an $8.1 million pretax adjustment to the reserve for estimated loss on the disposal of certain operations.

title: New Approach To Math Lesson
description: In response to studies showing poor performance by American students in science and mathematics, a major scientific organization says it has an outline of a lesson plan intended to teach students to rely more on reason than rote.

title: Bush Staff Under the Gun
description: The Tower battle points up the inexperience of many aides to President Bush, and even they admit they have made tactical errors. Page D27.

title: Cablevision Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior quarter results included a $15,296,000 charge relating to the company's early extinguishment of its subordinated debentures. The company said increases in interest expense of $79,014,000 and depreciation and amortization of $70,832,000 (which were primarily the result of acquisitions), along with a copyright settlement for prior years of $13,114,000 and losses generated by the company's programming operations, were the primary contributing factors to the wider loss for 1988. The company also said its revenue increases resulted mostly from the company's acquisition of A-R Cable Services Inc. in January 1988, the sportschannel acquisitions in August 1987 and other less significant acqusitions in 1987 and in 1988.

title: Real Estate; Theater-Hotel Partnership in Times Square
description: AMONG the challenges faced by city planners, developers and architects in the sweeping redevelopment of Times Square has been preserving the theater district's unique character while accommodating the demands of commercial development.

title: IMMIGRANTS TO GET VISAS BY LOTTERY
description: Hundreds of thousands of foreigners are expected to participate this month in a lottery with highly coveted prizes: 20,000 visas for permanent residence in the United States.

title: Should Tonys Include Off Broadway?
description: A dispute is growing that could affect the future and the prestige of the Tony Awards, one of the crucial factors in the success of any Broadway play that wins.

title: Ford Motor of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1.6 million for the quarter and a special charge of $40.2 million for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * National Education Association, to the Kamber Group, Washington.

title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves
description: A State Department report on drug trafficking has praised the three-month-old Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico for substantially increasing its anti-narcotics efforts, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Jefferies Disputed Again On His GAF Testimony
description: In his second day on the witness stand in the GAF stock manipulation trial, the director of trading at Jefferies & Company yesterday continued to contradict the testimony of Boyd L. Jefferies, the firm's founder.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday and a correction yesterday about an interfaith group issuing a statement denouncing the death threat against Salman Rushdie misidentified the dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He is the Rev. James Parks Morton.

title: Top California Yield Is 7.15% In $300 Million Bond Sale
description: California priced its first general obligation bond issue of the year yesterday, with $300 million of the debt securities in competitive bidding.

title: IRAN AND BRITAIN MOVE NEAR BREAK
description: Iran and Britain moved closer today to a break in diplomatic relations, as Iran threatened to sever ties unless the British Government withdrew its support in the next week for Salman Rushdie and his right to publish his novel ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Daley Wins Primary in Chicago; Mayoral Vote Is Racially Divided
description: Richard M. Daley, son of the political boss who ruled this city for 21 years, won the Democratic mayoral primary tonight in the most racially divided vote here since black candidates began running for City Hall in the 1970's.

title: Mercantile Stores Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said its latest fourth quarter net reflected a pretax LIFO charge of $2,049,000, compared with a charge of $5,420,000 in the year-ago fourth quarter. The earnings for 1988 reflected a pretax LIFO charge of $7,719,000, compared with a charge of $8,051,000 in 1987.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF your interest in wine goes beyond picking up a couple of bottles of white zinfandel for the weekend, there are a couple of wine newsletters for sophisticated enthusiasts that might be of interest: Liquid Assets and The New York Wine Cellar.

title: Connecticut Sells $175 Million Issue
description: Connecticut priced $175 million of general obligation debt yesterday through competitive bidding, won by underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.

title: Tour Bans Square Grooves
description: Saying that the use of square or U grooves in golf irons ''has changed the nature of the game,'' the PGA Tour Policy Board today declared clubs with square grooves illegal for use in PGA Tour events starting Jan. 1, 1990. Thus, all competitiors in a tour event must use clubs with the traditional V grooves.

title: South Carolina to Ban Waste From 32 States
description: South Carolina will ban 32 states and Puerto Rico from disposing of hazardous waste in the state beginning Wednesday, state health officials announced today.

title: Mozambique Seeks to Heal Young Minds
description: Until last week, when Goncalves Sebastiao, 13 years old, returned here to his mother's reed hut, home had been but a distant memory blurred by the trauma of being an unwilling participant in war.

title: Automatix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
BellSouth Appoints A 2d Vice Chairman
description: LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation has promoted F. Duane Ackerman to vice chairman for finance and administration, succeeding John B. White Jr., who is retiring at the end of March after 41 years with the company.

title: February Prices to Farmers Off 0.7%
description: The prices that farmers got for raw products declined seven-tenths of 1 percent in February from January levels, but still averaged 14 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Xylogics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Spending On TV Rises
description: Total spending on broadcast television advertising almost reached $25 billion in 1988, the Television Bureau of Advertising said yesterday. Advertisers spent $24.9 billion on the medium last year, the highest amount ever and an increase of 7.1 percent over 1987.

title: Two Bills on Steroid Use
description: All high school athletes in New York State would be tested for use of anabolic steroids under one of two steroid-control proposals being considered by the Legislature.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack
description: Acknowledged use of crack by high school seniors fell in 1988 for the first time, part of an overall downturn in drug use by young people in the United States, a national study reported today.

title: Efforts to Allow Choice Of Schools Stir Debate
description: Will allowing parents to enroll their children in the public school of their choice improve the overall quality of schools? Or will it worsen the social and educational disparities that undermine the chances of millions of youths to get a good education?

title: Nunn Admitted Guilt In '64 Traffic Accident
description: Senator Sam Nunn's opposition to Defense Secretary-designate John Tower has focused new attention on a 1964 incident in which Mr. Nunn, then 26 years old, pleaded guilty to leaving the scene of a traffic accident.

title: Coach Leaves Hospital
description: Norm Stewart, the coach at the University of Missouri, was released from Columbia Regional Hospital in Missouri Tuesday, two weeks after undergoing surgery for colon cancer and a diseased gallbladder. Stewart walked out of the hospital, his physician, Dr. Jay Ward, said. ''He's doing a little better each day,'' said Ward, who added that Stewart's convalescence will be six weeks to two months, removing any possibility that Stewart could coach in post-season play. Missouri was ranked third when Stewart became ill on Feb. 9. This week the team, which is 3-4 in his absence, is ranked No. 7.(AP)

title: Review/Piano; Trios by Beethoven
description: As part of Town Hall's new programming initiatives, the Raphael Trio is presenting the complete Beethoven piano trios over four concerts this season. The survey, which includes various scores not in the standard canon but which eschews the possibly apocryphal piano-trio arrangement of the Second Symphony, offered its third installment Monday night, with the fourth scheduled at the hall (123 West 43d Street) on April 10.

title: The 77th Neediest Cases Drive Ends With Record Donations
description: Amid growing public concern over the plight of the poor and the homeless, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 77th annual appeal Tuesday, having for the first time collected more than $4 million in a single campaign.

title: Fear of Shoreham
description: Issues arise now and again that truly test political leaders. So it has been with Shoreham, the Long Island Lighting Company's unopened nuclear power plant, and Mario Cuomo, New York's Governor. With the saga of Shoreham approaching its end - the plant's closing - it can only be said that Mr. Cuomo has failed his test.

title: Afrikaner Church Head Presses Pretoria on Rebels
description: The head of the country's biggest Afrikaner church has urged the South African Government to drop its insistence that the outlawed African National Congress renounce violence before talks between the two parties can begin.

title: Mass Murderers Prefer Semiautomatic Rifles
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: South Africa Commutes 16 Death Sentences
description: The South African Government has commuted the death sentences of 16 prisoners, including that of a dissident who was the subject of clemency appeals by the United Nations, the Justice Ministry said today.

title: Cape Verde: From Colony to a Success Story
description: A visitor to this tidy, seaside capital finds services that are memories in the rest of Portuguese-speaking Africa - taxis, public telephones, garbage collection, bustling markets and restaurants offering fresh lobster.

title: Literary Figures Join In Support of Rushdie
description: More than 1,000 of the world's most prominent writers, publishers and booksellers appealed to governments today to act to insure that Iran withdraws its death threats against Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: I.B.M. and Polygen Reach Agreement
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had reached an agreement for the Polygen Corporation of Waltham, Mass., to develop enhancements to its software for the chemical and pharmaceutical industries to use on I.B.M. mainframe computers and work stations. I.B.M. will also assume a minority interest in Polygen, which is privately held.

title: Builders Transport Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year included a gain from an accounting change of $1,347,000. The company said the losses reflected an increase in net interest expense of $815,000 in the quarter and $2,493,000 for the year.

title: F W Woolworth Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28

Currents;
Who's Doing What, Where and When
description: LEAD: MARK HAMPTON is currently redecorating President Bush's private office and the family sitting room at the White House. . . . Karen van Lengen, an architect in New York, won the competition to design an addition to the American Memorial Library in Berlin. . . . Elle Decor, the American version of the French magazine Elle Decoration, will make its debut this fall.

title: Talking Deals; Wall Street Finds A Big New Game
description: THE sale of the Dallas Cowboys, brought to a conclusion for as much as $150 million with an assist from Salomon Brothers, illustrates that when the business is sports, Wall Street wants a bigger piece of the game.

title: Reviews/Music; A Flutist's Recital, Lightly
description: Harold Jones, a flutist who has played and taught throughout this area for more than 20 years, presented a fluent but lightweight recital Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Dillard Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
BRIEFS
description: * Alliance Semiconductor Corp., San Jose, plans to use a mothballed American Telephone and Telegraph Company plant near Kansas City, Mo., to manufacture computer memory chips and other products.

title: Likud Is the Big Winner in Israeli Municipal Elections
description: The right-wing Likud party, which holds the senior role in the national Government, won a striking series of victories in municipal elections across Israel on Tuesday.

title: Cellcom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $374,254 from the sale of discontinued operations and a $272,417 tax benefit. c-Net loss The latest first quarter reflects the favorable effect of an accounting change.

title: Topics of The Times; Why Shrink Democracy?
description: Though registration drives have added hundreds of thousands of new names to New York City voter rolls, the total number of registrants isn't growing. The reason: State law requires enrollment to be canceled if an individual hasn't voted in four years. A new lawsuit by a coalition of civic and civil rights groups challenges that misguided policy.

title: CONVICTION VOIDED IN TEXAS MURDER
description: A Texas appeals court today set aside the murder conviction of Randall Dale Adams, who has spent 12 years behind bars proclaiming his innocence.

title: A New Breed of Design Store For a New Breed of Shopper
description: LEAD: UNTIL recently, whether you wanted a contemporary chair by Philippe Starck, a leading French designer, or fabric by Cowtan & Tout, the traditional English fabric house, you had to order it through a decorator or architect. Even seeing such items was difficult, since they were hidden away in showrooms that maintained a strict to-the-trade policy.

title: Weekends in Jail for Synagogue Fire
description: A 16-year-old who was convicted of setting fire to a synagogue in Brooklyn last year was sentenced yesterday to spend weekends in jail and perform 200 hours of community service and was ordered to write an essay about the history of the Jewish people.

title: Tokyo Orders a Cut in Buying of Iranian Oil
description: The Japanese Government has quietly directed the nation's oil companies to reduce by a third the amount of oil they buy from Iran.

title: Postcards, Photos and Memories
description: Following is a list of events at New York City museums and galleries marking the 1939-40 and 1964-65 World's Fairs. New-York Historical Society From April 15 through Aug. 20, the society will display memorabilia from the 1939 World's Fair. Address: 170 Central Park West at 77th Street. Hours: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday-Sunday; 212-873-3400. Queens Museum ''World's Fair Anniversary Weekend'' will be held April 29 and 30 at the museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the site of both fairs. There will be films, slide shows and walking tours. Visitors can also see the permanent display, ''Panorama of New York City,'' which opened at the '64 fair.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY In the first 20 days of February, net deposit outflows at the nation's savings and loan institutions were at a monthly rate of $5.2 billion, while in January the outflow was about $7 billion. Bank Board officials said the report reflected some regained confidence by consumers in the industry. [ Page D1. ] Many Americans will be filing their tax returns by computer under a new filing service that allows qualified tax preparers and financial institutions to submit returns of clients electronically as long as no money is owed. By doing so, taxpayers receive their refunds in 17 business days on average. [ D1. ] Americans' personal income in January rose 1.8 percent, the largest gain in more than a year. Personal consumption spending, meanwhile, edged up 0.1 percent. [ D4. ] Construction spending rose 0.4 percent in January as work on nonresidential buildings offset a downturn in government projects. [ D4. ] The Bush Administration is worried about Japan's ''lack of commitment'' to a 30-month computer chip pact with the U.S., but did not threaten to impose any new sanctions. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL The Japanese Government has quietly directed its oil companies to reduce by a third the amount of oil they buy from Iran. The cutback, to begin in April, is one more sign that the controversy over ''The Satanic Verses,'' by Salman Rushdie, will jeopardize plans to rebuild Iran's economy. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Several large advertisers have pulled their campaigns on the Fox Broadcasting's top series, ''Married . . . With Children,'' in response to protests by a Michigan housewife. [ A1. ] Huge crowds poured into Sears, Roebuck stores around the country as the company introduced its new low-price policy. But not everyone was impressed with the discounts. [ D1. ] A comparison of prices on a number of popular items shows that Sears undercut the prices of its rivals in some instances. [ D6. ] Bank of New York agreed to sell five banks in New York to Midlantic for $291 million. The move was part of its efforts to reduce its size after last year's merger with Irving Bank [ D1. ] Frank Lorenzo, the head of Texas Air, sought to win the support of Eastern's pilots in a videotaped appeal and made a formal proposal that would provide pay raises but also concessions. [ D1. ] Emhart filed legal claims against its suitor, Topper, and hired its own investment bankers for a possible takeover battle. [ D4. ] Texas Eastern is selling its exploration and production holdings to Enterprise Oil of Britain for $1.4 billion. [ D7. ] American Continental's deal to sell its Lincoln Savings and Loan subsidiary has collapsed. [ D2. ] Semi-Tech Microelectronics Far East has raised its offer to acquire SSMC to $34 a share, or a total of $184 million. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stocks were pushed lower by a late selling spree and the Dow ended with a 15.35-point loss, closing at 2,243.04. [ D8. ] Treasury note and bond prices sagged in light trading. [ D17. ] The dollar rose strongly against most other currencies but traders are not sure the increase will hold. [ D18. ] Copper futures prices soared amid supply concerns. [ D18. ] Yields for money market mutual funds rose as fund managers continued to thrive on higher short-term rates. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The sale of the Dallas Cowboys illustrates that when the business is sports, Wall Street wants a bigger role. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Investors in Greenwich Pharmaceuticals are betting that the company's only product may succeed. Market Place. [ D8. ] Several media directors dispute the notion that inordinate influence is being wielded by media planners. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses on the repurchase of debt of $6 million for the quarter and $174 million for the year. c-Net loss The Farm Credit System said the major factor for the improved 1988 results was a negative loan loss provision of $680 million, compared with $196 million in 1987. The 1988 net also included the recognition of losses of $255 million relating to the Federal Land Bank of Jackson, which was placed into receivership on May 20, 1988.

title: Jordan Seeks I.M.F. Aid
description: Jordan will ask the International Monetary Fund for a standby credit and is working on a general restructuring of its foreign debt, the central bank's deputy governor, Maher Shukri, said Tuesday. Jordan is paying interest on all its commercial debt but is rolling over principal payments, he said. The nation faces debt repayments this year of more than $900 million. Its foreign debt totals almost $6 billion.

title: Katy Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,476,000 and a gain of $80,184,000 from the sale of assets. c-After a loss of $3,096,000 from discontinued operations. The latest periods' share earnings reflected the payment of $468,035 in preferred stock dividends for the quarter and $1,954,107 for the year. This compared with the year-ago periods' of $496,611 for the quarter and $1,996,556 for 1987.

title: Profit Taking Brings Prices Down
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds sagged in light trading yesterday, as market participants chose to take profits generated by the mild rally earlier this week.

title: Arkansas School Segregation Suit Reported Settled
description: Arkansas would pay $104 million over the next 10 years and encourage desegregation around the state under a proposed settlement in a six-year-old Federal court case, according to reports today in both Little Rock newspapers.

title: Officials Don't Enforce Parks Curfew
description: More than six weeks after a 1 A.M. curfew was reimposed on virtually all New York City parks, officials said they are not enforcing it systematically and have no plan to do so anytime soon.

title: Wider British Trade Gap
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened to $:2.09 billion, or $3.63 billion, in January, from a revised deficit of $:1.76 billion in December, the Government said today. The January gap compared with a deficit of $:1.45 billion a year ago, the Department of Trade and Industry said. The figures showed that exports totaled a record $:7.37 billion in January, but imports also set a record, at $:9.47 billion. The December merchandise trade deficit was previously reported as $:1.66 billion.

title: Topics of The Times; Farewell, Cruel Feberrery
description: If Richard Green has his way, there will come a day in New York City when no schoolchild is ever again guilty of calling a library a ''liberry.'' Mr. Green is Schools Chancellor, and ''liberry'' is what he calls a ''speech demon.'' So is ''axe'' for ask, and ''youse'' - without which it is probably impossible to make a gangster movie. Out with all such demons, Mr. Green says.

title: Laser Photonics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $365,625 from the settlement of a patent claim.

title: India Reduces Its Military Budget As Links With Neighbors Improve
description: India has reduced its military budget for the first time this decade, an aide to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said today.

title: Construction Spending Up 0.4% in Month
description: Construction spending rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent in January as work on nonresidential buildings like factories and offices offset a downturn in activity on government projects.

title: J>apan Output Up 1.2%
description: Japan's industrial production in January rose by 1.2 percent from December and by 9.4 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said on Tuesday.

description: Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage, said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Chase Manhattan Corporation to buy Rose & Company Investment Brokers, Chase's discount brokerage subsidiary.

description: b-Included a $10,542,000 charge for an accounting change.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Nature is neutral, sometimes good and sometimes evil. It is good when it produces foods that nourish or chemicals, like penicillin, that cure. It is bad when it dishes up microorganisms that sicken or chemicals, like botulinum toxin, that kill.

title: Review/Dance; Dissociation in Merce Cunningham Premiere
description: For Merce Cunningham, movement has a value of its own, and one movement is equivalent to another. If we think we discern meaning in Mr. Cunningham's choreography, that is because we have attached interpretations to what we see.

description: Kiki Vandeweghe made his Knick debut tonight. It was not one the highly publicized 6-foot-8-inch forward, or the Knicks, were hoping for. But if Vandeweghe's shooting was poor, most of the other Knicks were not much better as they were soundly thrashed by the Milwaukee Bucks, 121-111, in their first visit to the new Bradley Center. The loss, the Knicks' third straight on the road, dropped their season record to 37-19.

description: An injured 6-year-old boy died Saturday in a Brooklyn hospital less than 90 minutes after his father took the comatose youngster to the emergency room, and the father has been charged with murder in the death, the authorities announced yesterday.

The company also said 1987 results included a pretax $19.6 million gain on the sale of an investment.

title:
Currents;
Au Courant Nightspot on Sunset Strip

description: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery will be delayed at last two days until March 11 because of a crushed electrical part on a main engine, officials said today.

description: In scenes reminiscent of the busiest days of Christmas, huge crowds poured into Sears, Roebuck stores around the country yesterday as the company introduced its new low-price policy.

title:
Currents;
Baths For Tarzan And Jane
description: LEAD: FOR those who prefer to wash up with a sense of abandon, Watercolors Inc. is marketing two new products: a terra-cotta sink and a Tarzan towel rack.

title: Last Civilian Photography Satellites to Shut Down
description: Running out of money for the program, the Federal Government yesterday ordered the shutdown of the last two American satellites in a series that pioneered the photography of the Earth from space and offered a valuable tool for crop forecasting, mineral exploration and forest management.

title: Witness Says North Knew Ban on Aid Covered Him
description: Oliver L. North knew that a Congressional ban on Government help to the Nicaraguan rebels applied to his activities on the contras' behalf, a retired major general who raised funds for the rebels testified today.

title: Currents; Their Master's Voices
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT enthusiasts can now collect something besides this year's biography. It's ''Prairie House,'' a cassette tape of songs about the pioneering American architect. While Wright so often compared architecture with music, this may not be quite the type he had in mind.

title: Tatham-Laird Gets Stouffer's Lean Cuisine
description: The Stouffer Foods Corporation said yesterday that advertising for its Lean Cuisine line had been switched to Tatham-Laird & Kudner from the Pittsburgh office of Della Femina, McNamee, WCRS. The Della, Femina office had handled the brand since its introduction in 1981. Leading National Advertisers, an independent market research service, said Stouffer spent $7.2 million in the first nine months of 1988 on advertising for Lean Cuisine.

title: The Cascading Joys of Starring in a Smash
description: The day after ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' opened to rave reviews, Jason Alexander did not enter the Imperial Theater by the stage door on West 46th Street. Instead, he maneuvered through the nearly impassable lobby on West 45th Street ''and I snuck in past the box office,'' he said. ''I just wanted to see the lines.'' The lines. Hundreds of people were waiting for tickets to Mr. Robbins's compilation of moments from 10 of his Broadway shows, from ''On the Town'' to ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' That was Monday, the day the show sold $530,000 worth of tickets - a record, more than ''Phantom of the Opera'' and ''Les Miserables'' on the mornings after their debuts.

title: Cousins Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on the sale of properties of $65,000 and $321,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included gains on the sale of properties of $67,000 for the quarter and $285,000 for the year. The company said the 1988 results do not include a profit of about $10.5 million on the sale of land in Georgia in December 1988 which, due to accounting rules, the company expects to recognize in future periods.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a debate over whether the Tony Awards should include Off Broadway plays identified the men shown in an incorrect order. Clockwise from bottom left were Harvey Sabinson, Bernard Jacobs, Peter Stone and Alan Eisenberg.

title: How Tower Responds
description: Following are excerpts from a question-and-answer session with John G. Tower held after he addressed the National Press Club: Q. Senator Mitchell of Maine this morning announced his opposition to your nomination. The majority leader's vote carries a great deal of weight. Can your nomination make it in light of it? A. I believe that the majority leader also said that individual senators should make up their own minds, or words to that effect. So, I don't believe that he's trying to put the hammer on anyone . . . Q. Senator Hollings this morning said you had made pledges to abstain from alcohol before and broken them. Can we believe the latest one? A. I don't know what Senator Hollings is referring to. I don't recall any such. But the fact is this is not a pledge, it is an oath that I have taken - have taken for, to, and before the American people. And I regard such oaths as sacred. And I can assure you I will abide by it. Q. You said Sunday you've never broken a pledge in your life. Does this include wedding vows? A. As a matter of fact, I have broken wedding vows. I think I am probably not alone in that connection. Q. As head of the Tower Commission investigating the Iran-Contra affair, you gave George Bush a clean bill of health. Some say your nomination is a payoff for that and that's why he is sticking with you in the face of strong opposition. Your comment? A. I think that when you consider the fact that the commission was made up of three people, Brent Scowcroft and Ed Muskie in addition to myself, that that would be sort of impugning the integrity of Brent Scowcroft and Ed Muskie. . . . We found nothing to implicate the Vice President. I might add that the joint Congressional committee found nothing to implicate the Vice President. I wonder what kind of payoff they're going to get. Q. . . . Do you think that the lack of affection of your former colleagues is playing an inordinate role in your current crisis? A. I have heard various commentators say that some of my old colleagues had some scores to settle with me and were prepared to settle those scores. I don't believe that's true. . . . I believe it might be true that I'm not universally popular with all of them, but I don't think that would be considered a motivation for their vote for or against me . . . Q. Do you believe, as some apparently do, that the opposition to you is mostly partisan? . . . A. I think it remains to be seen whether or not the opposition turns out to be totally partisan. . . . I think if it turns out that way, that it's a significant development in American politics. I think it raises the question: Is character assassination a legitimate and acceptable means of the exercise of political power? If that question is answered in the affirmative, we have ushered in a new and rather ugly phase in American politics. Q. Senator, what has angered you most about the way your nomination is being considered? A. . . . I suppose one thing that I think engenders some resentment is the fact that there was no clearly defined standard against which I should be judged. The standard seemed to be developed and seemed to evolve to fit the situation. Now, several senators have said that the Secretary of State must adhere to a higher standard than members of the United States Senate. I accept that. I accept that the Secretary of Defense must adhere to a higher standard than members of the United States Senate. But my question is, how much lower an acceptable standard is there for members of the Senate? Is it an acceptable standard for senators late in the evening who've had a few drinks in the hideaways and offices of the Capitol, a few steps away from the Senate chamber, to come onto the floor late in the evening and vote on vital issues of nuclear deterrence? Is it an acceptable standard for senators to accept honoraria, PAC contributions, and paid vacations from special interests who have a vested interest in the legislative process? I think, in the course of formulating a standard for the Secretary of Defense or indeed for any other Cabinet officer, that it is time that the Congress articulated what its own standards are.

Some of the groups scheduled to march through the grounds of the zoo, located at Rock Creek Park, will include people wearing gorilla suits and others dressed as a lion, giraffe and panda, elementary school children wearing masks, and a zoo keeper carrying a red-tailed hawk and walking beside a Vietnamese potbellied pig.

title: Greek Cypriots Seek Accord
description: President George Vassiliou of Cyprus said today that the country's Greek Cypriots were ready to make major concessions to Turkish Cypriots to end the Mediterranean island's 14-year division. President Vassiliou, speaking at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London, also called on Western European countries to help reunite Cyprus and achieve withdrawal of 29,000 Turkish troops estimated to be in the north. ''The Greek community is willing and ready to make very extensive concessions in the field of power-sharing with the Turkish Cypriot community,'' he said.

It was near the fort, sandwiched between Spanish and English settlements in a buffer area called the ''Debatable Lands,'' that the English fought and defeated the Spanish in the Battle of Bloody Marsh in 1742.
