title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Agassi Withdraws to McEnroe: Andre Agassi withdrew during the second set of his quarterfinal match against John McEnroe last night, saying later that he aggravated a muscle pull on the upper portion of his left leg during their match in Dallas. Agassi won the first set, 6-4, after breaking McEnroe's serve in the match's opening game. But after falling behind by 3-0 in the second set, Agassi informed Umpire Gerry Armstrong he had had enough, gathered his equipment and walked off to the boos of the Reunion Arena crowd. Agassi was not limping noticeably during the match. He said that he incurred the injury during the United States Pro Indoors in Philadelphia last weekend and had considered defaulting before last night's match. ''I'd been icing it, hoping it would go away,'' said Agassi, who ranked fourth by the A.T.P. computer. ''Bill Norris warmed it up. But then slowly it started to get stiff and I couldn't change direction or move well.'' McEnroe went off to loud cheers. He first waved to the crowd, then threw up his hands in a gesture of confusion and frustration. 'It's very bizarre. It's unbelievable,'' said McEnroe, who does not count the 19-year-old Agassi among his closest friends on the tour. ''If we have anyone standing by the finals, it'll be a plus.'' McEnroe suggested that Agassi should have tried to continue in what was expected to be the most interesting of yesterday's two quarterfinals. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl met Jakob Hlasek in the late match last night.(AP) N.H.L. Kings 5, Sabres 4: Steve Kasper scored twice in the third period last night in Buffalo and Luc Robitaille had the game-winning goal as the Kings broke a four-game streak without a victory. Kasper and Robitaille beat the goalie, Jacques Cloutier, during a 67-second span late in the final period as the Kings rallied from a 4-2 deficit in the third period to win. Kasper's first of the night made it 4-3 early in the third period, his second tied, 4-4, at 15:16 and then Robitaille finished the rally at 16 minutes 23 seconds when he banked a shot from behind the net off Cloutier's legs. (AP) Flyers 4, Jets 4: Rick Tocchet scored his second goal of the game with 1:58 remaining in regulation time for the tie. Thomas Steen had the goal for Winnipeg at 5:35 of the third period.The Flyers swarmed the rookie goalie Bob Essensa and outshot the Jets, 18-7, in the third period.(AP) N.B.A. Celtics 104, Hawks 90: Kevin McHale and Robert Parish led a fourth-quarter charge last night that enabled the host Celtics to end the Hawks' four-game winning streak. In the final period, McHale had 14 of his 23 points, and Parish had 9 of his 23. Boston's lead, which reached 13 points late in the third quarter, fell to 80-78 on a fallaway jumper by Moses Malone with 7 minutes 46 seconds to play. McHale scored the next 4 points, but Atlanta's Reggie Theus got the next 4, making it 84-82. A free throw by Parish started a 7-0 run in which McHale followed with two foul shots, Parish dunked and Reggie Lewis hit a jumper, increasing the lead to 91-82 with 3:54 to go. Atlanta was led by Dominique Wilkins with 23 points. Boston hit 67 percent of its first-half shots, and Atlanta made 39 percent. (AP) Pistons 96, Jazz 85: Vinnie Johnson set a club record by scoring 19 consecutive Detroit points in the second quarter at Auburn Hills, Mich. Johnson, who finished with a season-high 34 points, was 8 for 10 from the field in the second period and hit 6 straight shots in one stretch. The 19 straight points broke the team record of 16 set by Isiah Thomas against the Knicks in the 1984 playoffs. Mark Aguirre added 16 points for Detroit, all in the first period, and Bill Laimbeer had 14 points and 13 rebounds. Karl Malone led Utah with 27 points. The Pistons improved their record to 24-2 when opponents score less than 100 points. (AP)

title: Venezuela Mostly Quiet After Protests
description: Downtown streets here were generally deserted today as Venezuelans began a cautious recovery from two days of violent protests against higher gasoline prices and other Government austerity measures that took effect Monday.

Weyrich, president of the Free Congress Foundation, surprised a number of people, including fellow conservatives, when he leveled charges of excessive drinking and untoward behavior with women against John G. title: Aurelio Buargue de Holanda, Author, 78
description: Aurelio Buarque de Holanda Ferreira, the author of a 1975 dictionary that became the best-selling book in the Portuguese language, died at home here on Monday. He was 78 years old and had suffered from respiratory problems and Parkinson's disease.

title: Home Improvement
description: ELECTRICITY in a house or apartment is supplied by paths of wiring called circuits. By making a map of them, you can know at a glance which circuits serve which outlets. You can also determine whether any circuits are overloaded, which can create a fire hazard.

description: Americans' personal income in January showed its largest gain in more than a year, rising 1.8 percent, but people chose to save, rather than spend, much of the extra money, the Government said today.

title: Senate Confirms Sullivan and Watkins

Sullivan easily won confirmation today as Secretary of Health and Human Services, with the Senate voting 98 to 1 to place the 55-year-old physician and educator in charge of the Government's largest agency. The Senate then voted 99 to 0 to confirm James D. Watkins, a retired admiral and former Chief of Naval Operations, as Secretary of Energy.

title: Reviews/Music; Before the Modern Piano

But his performances were so deftly shaded and splendidly transparent that one could put the more historically appropriate sounds of the harpsichord and fortepiano out of mind with only the slightest twinge of guilt.

The Industry Joins Debate On Planners

title: Q&A
description: Q. In periods of high humidity, our toilet sweats a lot on the outside - so much so that I have to put towels on the floor to catch the dripping water. Is there some way we can solve this problem? A. When you talk of the toilet sweating, I assume you are referring to the toilet tank behind the bowl. What happens in humid weather is that cold water entering the tank chills the outside of the tank so that when warm moist air in the room contacts the chilled surface, condensation forms - much in the way that a glass of ice water ''sweats'' on a summer day. The best way to prevent this is to install a mixing valve that will add a very small amount of hot water into the cold water line before it enters the tank (a plumber can install such piping). A less expensive method that often works is to line the inside of the tank with one-inch-thick pieces of plastic foam insulating board. This will keep the outside of the tank from getting so chilled and will thus reduce condensation problems. Incidentally, anything you can do to lower humidity inside the house will also help (for example, make sure there is an exhaust fan in the kitchen and bath). Q. We have lived 10 years in our brick-veneer house and now I find cracks in three different places in our foundation, with some of the cracks continuing up into the brick coursing on the walls above. I can find no evidence of cracks in the footings, nor does there seem to be any evidence of shifting or movement. Since these cracks just occurred for the first time, could the recent drought and consequent change in soil conditions be the cause of this problem, and can you suggest any way to correct this problem? A. Even though you can see no visible signs of movement in the footings, it is possible that extreme drying out of the soil or other ground conditions could have caused some settling. The main thing now is to see if the cracks continue to spread or grow larger. In most cases of this kind they will stabilize so that all you have to do is fill them with patching cement or hydraulic cement. If the cracks continue to get worse, it may be a good idea to call in an engineer to check the structure.

title: The 'Perplexing' Killing of a Drug Agent
description: About an hour after a Federal drug agent radioed colleagues that he was driving to a new site to meet a drug dealer, he was found shot to death on a dark stretch of Staten Island where agents had last seen him.

description: The Soviet troops may be gone, but they have left a lethal legacy behind in Afghanistan: up to 30 million mines, scattered like deadly seeds across the Afghan landscape.

description: The Bank of New York Company, pursuing a plan to reduce its size after last year's merger with the Irving Bank Corporation, yesterday announced an agreement to sell five banks in New York to the Midlantic Corporation, a bank holding company in Edison, N.J.

title: Review/Theater; An Idyll Is Smashed In 'Nest'

In ''The Nest'' by Franz Xaver Kroetz, the two go through their daily routine. When Kurt comes home from work, his wife automatically gives him a bottle of beer. They have dinner and settle down with television, then convert their couch into a bed and go to sleep. The scene is West Germany but it could be any small town in the United States.

title: G.M., Dukakis Talk
description: The General Motors Corporation's chairman, Roger B. Smith, and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts met today to discuss the future of G.M.'s Framingham, Mass., plant, which the company plans to idle indefinitely in August. Governor Dukakis, who also met with United Auto Workers leaders, told reporters after the meetings that he is optimistic that G.M. will be able to find a use for the plant. A G.M. spokesman said Mr. Smith told Governor Dukakis the decision to idle the plant was based on market conditions. Many analysts expect that the auto maker will have to close three or four plants in addition to Framingham's.

title: Reviews/Television; Hirohito: An Assessment of Guilt
description: The final respects paid by Western dignitaries last week to the late Emperor of Japan capped Hirohito's achievement in emerging from World War II without blemish, the one Axis leader who not only was spared the title of war criminal but also became identified with the transformation of his country into a Western-style democracy. The argument of ''Hirohito: Behind the Myth'' is that he got off much too easily.

Every motion picture seems to have a sound track featuring songs from the 1950's and 1960's. The Beach Boys had a No. 1 record recently and the Brady Bunch returned to television. On Sunday, NBC showed the film of the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston heavyweight title fight in 1964, the bout that helped make the man now called Muhammad Ali a legend.

title: New Xerox Copiers
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced new copiers today, including two low-volume models and a copier with a beveled edge that can make copies from books without ruining bindings. The machines were displayed at the company's manufacturing center here. The low-volume copiers, the 5012 and the 5014, make 12 copies a minute and represent Xerox's attempt to increase its presence in the low-volume market. The 5012 costs $2,325. The 5014, which has reduction and enlargement capabilities, costs $2,850. The new copier designed for book copying, the 5042, costs $9,470.

Tower for 14 years, and the two Senators overcame differences of party to forge a working relationship of respectful accommodation. So it was not a small thing when Mr. Tower called Senator Bentsen at his home Monday night to ask for his support.

The analysts cited Sears's huge overhead as an obstacle. But a comparison of prices on a number of popular items shows that the Chicago-based retailer has not only come close to matching the competition in many cases but in some instances has undercut its rivals' prices.

title: Reviews/Music; Ingenue Is Not Extinct
description: ''Together Again (for the First Time),'' an intimate musical revue in which Jo Sullivan, Frank Loesser's widow, officially presents their daughter Emily on the New York stage, reminds one that although the musical comedy species known as the ingenue may be endangered, it is far from extinct. The show, at the tiny Kaufman Theater, is a good-natured family musicale in which Miss Sullivan, her longtime accompanist, Colin Romoff, and her 23-year-old daughter, Emily Loesser, carry on a breezy informal dialogue that mixes music with friendly advice and chatty reminiscences.

description: In retrospect many New Yorkers may revere Mayor John V. Lindsay and Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, but 18 years ago each was guilty of a sin of commission.

description: MANY clay artists today have distanced themselves from the utility of the pot by exaggerating or abstracting its traditional form, playing energetically with visual references and treating exteriors in unexpected ways.

Reviews/Music; Cheryl Riley's Song Becomes A Morality Play
description: Cheryl (Pepsii) Riley struck a public nerve with her first single, ''Thanks for My Child,'' a ballad in which a single mother insists, ''Even though my man has left me behind/I don't regret a thing for having you.'' It reached No. 1 on Billboard's black singles chart; it was also condemned for encouraging unwed motherhood. At the Bottom Line on Tuesday, Ms. Riley took pains to say the song was not written to promote teen-age pregnancy, to promote single parenthood or to make absent fathers feel guilty - just to give the child love.

title: The Deficient Deficit Commission
description: The National Economic Commission's majority report on balancing the budget is a shamelessly superficial summary of President Bush's proposals. It endorses them all and rejects higher taxes. A minority report by six Democrats is more analytical and more critical of Mr. Bush. But it ducks the tax question, too. The enterprise thus ends, just as Mr. Bush had hoped, as a bipartisan flop.

title: Sanders to Be Excused From Spring Workouts
description: Barry Sanders, the Heisman Trophy winner, has been excused for spring practice at Oklahoma State to explore his National Football League options, Coach Pat Jones said yesterday. Sanders also requested that he continue to be unavailable to reporters until a later date, said Steve Buzzard, sports information director. ''My responsibility will continue to be in the best interests of the youngster and his family,'' Jones said. Sanders, a junior who rushed for 2,628 yards and scored 39 touchdowns last season, both National Collegiate Athletic Association records, said previously that he had decided on whether to apply for the N.F.L. draft. But he has not disclosed his decision. His father, William, visited with N.F.L. officials last month to discuss his son's options. But he told The Associated Press last night that he was surprised his son was not going through spring drills. ''I talked to Barry on Monday night and he said he was going out for spring football,'' Williams Sanders said from his home in Wichita, Kan. ''He said he was going to be out running with everyone else.'' Sanders could become the first third-year college player ever allowed to participate in the regular N.F.L. draft. Since Sanders has never been redshirted, he would not be eligible for the regular N.F.L. draft this spring unless he decided to challenge the legality of the draft in the courts or unless the league changes its longstanding policy of not drafting underclassmen. In January, the N.C.A.A. placed Oklahoma State on four years' probation, barring the Cowboys from bowl games for the next three years and live television for the next two years.(AP)

description: LEAD: Stocks were pushed lower yesterday by a late selling spree that analysts attributed to falling bond prices.

title: Daniel Steinberg, Lawyer, 79
description: Daniel Steinberg, a lawyer and businessman, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday at Northwest Regional Hospital in Margate, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: In Defense of Virtue
description: Washington, to hear some worldly politicians and commentators, is caught up in a frenzy of sanctimony. What excesses they see being committed in the name of higher public morality! John Tower feels compelled to pledge temperance and confess violating wedding vows. Secretary of State James Baker grudgingly sells stock worth millions. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, painfully cuts his ties to a family corporation. Even petty pieties are demanded: William Bennett, the new drug czar, is driven to give up cigarettes.

title: Budd Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter was hurt by a one-time cost associated with the conclusion of wage agreements, although it did not disclose the size of the cost. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. MEETING ON INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION AGAINST APARTHEID IN SPORTS - 10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council POPULATION COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mexico May Allow Vote by Nationals in U.S.
description: As part of a sweeping overhaul of the country's electoral code, the Mexican Government is considering a politically explosive proposal that would grant voting rights to several million Mexican nationals living in the United States.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Key U.S. Index Adds Indicator
description: The Commerce Department's next index of leading economic indicators will include a University of Michigan measure of consumer optimism, it was announced on Tuesday.

title: Emhart Sets Defenses on Topper Bid
description: The Emhart Corporation, the manufacturing concern facing an unsolicited $2.4 billion bid from Topper L.P., filed legal claims today against its suitor and hired its own investment bankers for a possible takeover battle.

title: Review/Dance; Bryan Hayes In 'Crossing'
description: Dancegoers who saw Bryan Hayes's ''Crossing Slowly,'' as performed by Bryan Hayes and Dancers Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio might have found themselves wondering not what time it was, but what century. As its title implied, this was a study in slow motion. Although it lasted only 70 minutes, it seemed to take forever - and that remark is meant as praise.

title: Although Dollar Advances, Traders See No Clear Trend
description: The dollar rose strongly against most other currencies yesterday, but traders are not sure the increase will hold.

title: Devils Fall to 0-6-2; Lemieux Has 3 Assists
description: With a number of their key players spending most of the night in the penalty box, ejected or injured in the dressing room, the Devils had little chance tonight against the Penguins.

title: Turcotte Mimics Idol With a 3-Goal Night
description: Darren Turcotte, downright elated to have matched the feat, couldn't have cared less that he failed to duplicate the fanfare. Turcotte, after all, has just got used to playing with Guy Lafleur, and therefore is in no position to worry about trying to top him.

title: Coach Tells a Canadian Inquiry Johnson Used Steroids Since '81
description: In four hours of riveting testimony today, Ben Johnson's coach said the 27-year-old sprinter had used anabolic steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs since 1981.

title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS
description: Global production of coca, marijuana, opium poppies and hashish increased sharply in the last year, partly because of political and economic instability in drug-producing countries, the State Department reported today.

title: Report Seems Timed to Discredit Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Mass Murderers Prefer Semiautomatic Rifles; Swiss Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Victim of Nameless Accusers
description: There are good reasons to reject John Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense. His Senate record of support for ever more military spending, and then his earnings of nearly $1 million in two years as a ''consultant'' to weapons manufacturers, make him a symbol of the waste and greed that mar our military procurement system.

title: Help for the Seekers Of Missing Stemware
description: STACY DAVIDSON expects a lot of phone calls after the Easter and Passover holidays. ''Many people help their friends clear the table and break a piece of crystal,'' she said.

title: Reviews/Music; Hatred's Lethality in Verdi's 'Forza'
description: The Washington Opera is closing its season with a new production of Verdi's ''Forza del Destino,'' offered in rotation with Tchaikovsky's ''Pique Dame'' at the Opera House of the Kennedy CenterThese operas, although stylistically a world apart, make an interesting pair: both explore man's powerlessness against fate (or at least against what the principal characters perceive as their fates), and both show the triumph of impure drives (greed in the Tchaikovsky, blind hatred in the Verdi) over rationality and love.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Reject Army's Cease-Fire Plan
description: Prospects for the first peace talks in 18 months between the Government and leftist rebels dimmed today when the rebels rejected an army offer to stop fighting for three months.

title: Retired Officer Is Wounded In Lobby of Bronx Building
description: A 42-year-old retired police officer was shot and seriously wounded last night by a gunman in the lobby of a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: Kelsey-Hayes Canada Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Europe Upset By U.S. Step
description: The European Community said today that the United States' latest move to increase subsidies for farm exports suggested that Washington was not committed to serious reforms.

title: Sullivan Is Confirmed, 98 to 1
description: The Sentate confirmed Dr. Louis W. Sullivan as Secretary of Health and Human Services, with only Senator Jesse Helms voting no. Page B11.

title: Budget Panel's Failure Explained
description: The co-chairmen of the bipartisan commission on the Federal budget, which was unable to agree on how to cut the deficit, said today that the panel could have produced a politically acceptable plan if not for last year's election campaign and a court ruling that required all meetings to be open to the public.

title: Tests to Be Discussed
description: The president of the United States Olympic Committee said in Washington yesterday that the Soviet Union and the United States, in an effort to expand their agreement on reciprocal steroid testing, would discuss setting up testing sites in each country for use by the other nation's testers. The United States Olympic official, Robert Helmick, said he would like to see testing sites in Moscow staffed by American scientists and sites in the United States staffed by Soviet scientists. Both teams would have the power to administer random tests for steroids on a year-round basis at events such as time trials or track meets, he said. American and Soviet officials are scheduled to meet March 20 to iron out the fine points of their pact, which calls for random drug testing in the years leading up to the 1992 Olympics. ''We want to build up confidence in our athletes that the Soviets aren't using steroids while building up the Soviets' confidence that we aren't using them,'' Helmick said. (AP)

title: Western Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $215 million in restructuring charges largely from equipment write-offs and provisions for severance pay and other anticipated costs related to the disposition of the company's network services business for the quarter and the year loss of $1,018,000,000 consisted mainly of asset write-offs and provisions for other nonrecurring charges in connection with the reorganization of the company's business operations. c-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $152,785,000 for both the quarter and year on the extinguishment of debt resulting from financial restructuring in December 1987. The latest fourth quarter and year revenue both are after elimination of $19.7 million in revenue from Worldcom International private line service business. A contract for the sale of the business was reached in September 1988.

title: For Collectors, the Passion Never Ends
description: AS a 9-year-old, Herbert Rolfes visited the 1939-40 New York World's Fair and took home a few sensible mementos: a child's walking stick, a bookmark and a pair of bookends. Mostly, he took home memories.

title: C. L. Alexander Sr., 91; Managed Housing
description: Clifford L. Alexander Sr., for many years resident manager of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Riverton housing development in Manhattan, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 91 years old and lived in Riverton.

title: Strawberry Threatens To Leave Camp
description: The comparative calm of the Mets' camp was shattered today when Darryl Strawberry carried his campaign for a new contract into a new dimension by threatening to walk out ''if they don't have this worked out by tomorrow.''

title: Washington's War
description: A war is being waged in the nation's capital. Not a war of ideas (conservatism has adopted the lethargy of liberalism) and not a war of words (the debate about the Nunn ambush of the President's power to manage the Pentagon has not yet reached the level of skirmish).

title: Charles A. Hoffman, Pediatrician, 73
description: Dr. Charles A. Hoffman, a pediatrician, died Monday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Queens.

title: TV Notes
description: A February Broom

title: Colorado Prime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Reviews/Music; Pianist and Many Voices
description: Isn't it curious how a world of rapid communication has made so many far-flung places look alike and yet created so many different kinds of music? At Anthony de Mare's piano recital at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night, one looked without success for a 20th-century lingua franca - the kind of common coin with which composers of two centuries ago conducted their musical business.

title: F.B.I. Report on Tower Provokes Bitterness as Senate Opens Debate
description: The dispute over the Federal Bureau of Investigation's report on John G. Tower erupted with extraordinary bitterness today as the Senate began debate over his nomination as Secretary of Defense.

title: 6 Indicted in 9 Murders Linked to a Drug Gang
description: Six members of what the police and prosecutors described as a large and violent drug gang were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury in nine murders, seven attempted murders, several assaults and other crimes.

title: Candidate for F.T.C.
description: Janet D. Steiger, the chairman of the Postal Rate Commission, is considered the leading candidate for chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, which enforces antitrust laws, along with the Justice Department. She would succeed Daniel Oliver, a conservative Republican whose term ended in September.

title: Baker's Staff Incomplete 6 Weeks Into Bush Era
description: Six weeks into the Bush Administration, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d still does not have much of his senior foreign-policy team in place. But whose fault is it? State Department veterans and leading members of Congress say that Mr. Baker and his aides have been slow in making crucial appointments - particularly those of assistant secretaries for various geographical regions - and in pushing the paperwork for confirmation through the bureaucracy.

title: I.R.S. Grace Period Satisfies Few Critics of Benefits Rule
description: The Internal Revenue Service said today that the nation's three and a half million employers have until July 1 to begin complying with an ambitious new law covering benefit plans, and it said no penalties would be imposed this year so long as honest efforts to comply with the measure are made.

title: Economic Scene; The Darker Side Of the Budget Gap
description: THE National Economic Commission, created by Congress in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash in hopes of working out a bipartisan solution to the budget problem, died this week. It was the victim of electoral and post-election politics and, according to commission members, an inability to ''horse-trade'' in private to reach compromise agreements.

title: Horizon Gold Shares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $92,000 and $135,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included a charge of $104,600 for the quarter and a tax credit of $15,600 and a gain from extinguishment of debt of $23,588 for the 9 months.

title: Reviews/Theater; When One Tenor Is Much Like Another
description: A farce should be cleverly built, energetically directed and buoyantly acted, but there is one thing it absolutely must be: consistently funny. As staged by Jerry Zaks and performed by a cast led by Philip Bosco and Victor Garber, ''Lend Me a Tenor,'' the jolly play by Ken Ludwig at the Royale, is an impeccable example of how to construct and mount a farce -up to a point. ''Lend Me a Tenor'' is all things farcical except hilarious.

title: Boy Brings Handgun To Brooklyn School
description: A 14-year-old junior-high- school student was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday after a school security guard spotted him with a .22-caliber handgun, the police said.

title: No New Penalty for Johnson
description: John Holt, general secretary of track and field's ruling body, said today that the International Amateur Athletic Federation would take no further action against Ben Johnson despite testimony showing the Canadian sprinter was taking drugs long before his Olympic disqualification last year.

title: Used Mercedes Warranties
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America said today that it had begun issuing warranties on some of its used cars in an effort to support their resale prices.

title: Robert M. Grosse, Investment Banker, 52
description: Robert M. Grosse, an investment banker, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Bondville, Vt. He was 52 years old and also had a home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 4 Arab Guerrillas Slain By Israelis in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops patrolling in south Lebanon this morning shot and killed four Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas making their way to the Israeli border, the army said.

title: U.S. Agency Agrees Not to Single Out the Hispanic
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, under a settlement reached in Federal District Court, has agreed that its agents will not single out Hispanic-looking people to see if they are illegal aliens.

title: Farm & Home Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Rain Suspends Play: Only half of the 144 golfers in the $700,000 Honda Classic were able to complete their first rounds yesterday before thunderstorms suspended play with 72 players on the course. Among those who finished, Tom Byrum had the best score with a seven-under-par 65 on the Tournament Players Club at Eagle Trace in Coral Springs, Fla. The storm hit in midafternoon after all was calm on a course noted for windy conditions. ''It's a shock to play here with no wind,'' said Fred Couples, after he came in with a 66, scores later matched by Ted Schulz and Fulton Allem. Sandy Lyle, the Scot who won the Masters last year, was two shots behind Byrum at 67 and Curtis Strange, the 1988 United States Open champion, was at 68. The 72 golfers with incomplete rounds will return at 7:15 A.M. today to finish their first rounds before the second round can be played. Charles Leads Seniors: Bob Charles, the Seniors Tour Player of the Year for 1988, turned to his trusty putter yesterday to shoot a four-under-par 68 over the windswept Mountain Course and take a two-stroke lead over Miller Barber in the first round of the Vintage Invitational in Indian Wells, Calif. Don January, Gary Player, Lou Graham, Dale Douglass and J.C. Goosie shared the third spot with 71s at the Vintage Club.(AP) TENNIS McNeil and Savchenko Are Upset: Two second-round upsets eliminated top seeded Lori McNeil and second-seeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union from the $100,000 Virginia Slims of Oklahoma tournament yesterday in Oklahoma City. McNeil's doubles partner, Betsy Naglesen beat the defending champion McNeil 6-4, 2-6, 6-4. Naglesen trailed, 1-4, in the final set before rallying. Savchenko of the Soviet Union beat Manon Bollegraf of the Netherlands, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Nordiques 2: Cam Neely scored his 30th goal of the season and Ken Linseman got his 20th last night to lead Boston to a victory over Quebec and into second place in the Adams Division. The victory extended the Bruins' unbeaten streak to six games and moved them 2 points ahead of the third-place Buffalo Sabres with a game in hand. Boston, home for the first time after a six-game trip, outshot the Nordiques, 45-20, including seven shots during a five-minute scoreless power play.(AP) Whalers 2, Canucks 1: The defenseman Ulf Samuelsson, who assisted on the tying goal, scored the game-winner at 8:13 of the third period in Hartford. (AP) Blues 6, Kings 4:Gino Cavallini scored from the blue line on a hard slap shot with 6:05 remaining and Peter Zezel added an insurance score with 1:34 left. Steve Duchesne registered his first three-goal N.H.L. performance for the Kings, scoring twice in 41 seconds. (AP) Canadiens 3, Flames 2: Brent Gilchrist scored from the top of the faceoff circle midway through the third period as the Canadiens edged the Flames in a game Thursday night between the N.H.L.'s front-runners at Calgary. The victory was Montreal's second of the season over the Flames in the Saddledome and moved the Canadiens a point from league-leading Calgary. The Flames, who have lost only four games at home, have 96 points compared to Montreal's 95. The teams engaged in scuffles in front of their benches in the game's final minutes. Police were called to stand guard behind the Canadiens' bench. With the game tied at 2-2, Calgary played the first two minutes of the third period two men short after the Flame bench was given a penalty prior to the period starting. Montreal also killed off a penalty in the third period when Craig Ludwig was sent off for holding. Referee Bill McCreary left the ice to a chorus of boos from the sellout crowd of 20,002 after the second period. (AP) BASEBALL White Sox 3, Red Sox 2: Harold Baines's eighth-inning infield single scored the winning run to give Chicago a victory over Boston yesterday in the exhibition opener in Sarasota, Fla. Chicago strung together four straight hits during a two-run eighth-inning rally. Roger Clemens pitched three perfect innings for Boston while the White Sox starter, Jerry Reuss, allowed one hit in his three-inning stint.(AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL Senior Ties Home-Run Mark: Ray Shepherd tied an National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics record with four home runs in one game to help South Carolina-Aiken to a 23-0 victory over Voorhees yesterday in a game called after six innnings because of rain. Shepherd, who hit 25 homers a year ago, hit home runs in each of the first four innings. Shepherd, a senior left fielder, drove in eight runs.(AP)

title: West Germans Raid Spy Ring That Violated U.S. Computers
description: The West German police said yesterday that they had broken up a major computer spy ring that worked with Soviet intelligence agents to steal United States military computer passwords, software and other data. Five people were arrested as investigators searched more than 15 houses and apartments in three cities.

title: Flag Exhibit Upheld In Chicago by Judge
description: A Cook County Circuit Court judge ruled today that an American flag spread on a gallery floor could remain on display at the School of the Art Institute here.

title: Review/Art; Jean Helion, An Unsung Frenchman
description: Too few people know Jean Helion's work, but those who do tend to think of it as a puzzlement. Helion's career divides into two parts, the first his activity as a leader of the abstract art movement in Paris during the 1930's, the second his conversion to representational painting during the 40's, a phase that continued until his death in 1987 at the age of 83.

title: Reviews/Film; Of Butchers and Love
description: Meat obviously means a lot to Malcolm Mowbray, whose 1985 ''A Private Function'' was about a purloined pig and whose new comedy, ''Out Cold,'' has as its principal setting a butcher shop. But Mr. Mowbray's tastes are more sophisticated than they may sound. ''Out Cold,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is a droll, clever, essentially British comedy that happens, almost by accident, to be set in California, a place for which Mr. Mowbray has no high regard. The setting becomes one more of the many quiet absurdities with which ''Out Cold'' abounds.

title: Law Students at N.Y.U. Rally Against Race Bias
description: A multi-racial coalition of New York University Law School students, concerned about a series of racial incidents on the campus, are holding sit-ins and rallies that they vow will continue until their demands for a better climate for minority group members are met.

title: Xoma Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Response to PGA Groove Ban
description: The United States Golf Association, the accepted governing body for the rules of golf in this country, expressed its regret yesterday that the PGA Tour had banned all makes of irons with square grooves starting Jan. 1. The square, or U-shaped, grooves, which have been in use since 1984 when the U.S.G.A. changed its equipment rules to permit them, have enabled golfers to impart an inordinate amount of spin on balls, according to PGA Tour officials.

title: Shamrock Lawsuit
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in Delaware against the Polaroid Corporation's plan to buy back $1.1 billion in stock. The suit contends that Polaroid has given its shareholders misleading information about its future earnings and possible damage payments arising from the patent-infringements case with the Eastman Kodak Company. Polaroid denied the allegation, but the case will be argued on March 15 so that a decision can be made before the buyback offer expires March 20. Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., has made a $45-a-share hostile bid, valued at $3.2 billion, for Polaroid.

title: Flipping for Dollars
description: The Cincinnati Reds settled a contract dispute with Kal Daniels yesterday when the team's owner, Marge Schott, flipped a coin in the parking lot of the training complex in Florida and the outfielder won. Jon Braude, a Reds spokesman, said that Schott had called heads but that the coin had come up tails. As a result, Daniels, who had walked out of training camp Wednesday, will be paid $325,000, the lowest figure he said he would accept. . . . Joe Magrane, whose 2.18 earned run average led the National League last year despite a 5-9 record, settled his salary dispute with the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday, agreeing to a $150,000 one-year contract with incentives worth $50,000.(AP)

title: Review/Art; After All These Years, Still Hoping to Shock
description: Like so many artists who emerged in Europe and the United States around 1960, Hermann Nitsch has based a career on taking the action in action paintings to extremes - on canvas, in performance and in real life. In 1959, when he was 21 years old, this Austrian artist christened his activities the Orgies Mysteries Theater, making the announcement in a rented beer hall in Vienna to an audience of one.

title: Tiffany & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $644,000 from the early repayment of debt.

title: Go-Video Accord Set With Samsung
description: Go-Video Inc. has reached an agreement with the Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea to produce a dual-deck videocassette recorder under its name. Go-Video also agreed to drop Samsung as a defendant in an antitrust lawsuit pending in United States District Court here.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Co. appointed Allen D. Wheat chairman of its principal foreign subsidiary, Bankers Trust International Ltd.

title: Discover Card In Visa Link
description: The credit card processor Visa U.S.A. has agreed to an electronic link with Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover card that could lead to greater acceptance of Discover by merchants, a Sears spokesman said today.

title: Specialist in Diagnostics Now President of Chiron
description: Having built a specialty diagnostics business within a very large company, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Gregory Lawless now intends to do the same for a vastly smaller concern, the Chiron Corporation, a leader in biotechnology.

title: Review/Film; High-School Romance
description: About 20 minutes into ''Dream a Little Dream,'' a couple of teen-agers, Bobby and Lainie (Corey Feldman and Meredith Salenger), collide at high speed. As they lie unconscious, Bobby absorbs the spirit or persona of a mystically inclined neighbor (Jason Robards) and Lainie may be imbued with the qualities of his wife (Piper Laurie), though the movie is not clear on that point. But then, it is not clear about much else either, except that the youngsters have a romance that echoes the romance of the older folks, who periodically look each another in the eye and say ''I love you'' and ''I love you, too.'' You can watch them beginning today at the D. W. Griffith and other theaters.

title: Suspect Eats Drug and Dies
description: A man who said he swallowed seven grams of cocaine to avoid arrest died Wednesday of an overdose two hours later, the police reported today. He was identified as Samuel M. McBeth, 36 years old, of Fostoria.

title: Allegheny & Western Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Probert Arrested On Drug Charge
description: Bob Probert, a Detroit Red Wings forward, was charged today with smuggling 14.3 grams of cocaine across the United States-Canadian border.

title: Video Festival
description: The Brooklyn Museum will begin its Eighth Annual Thomas A. Edison-Black Maria Film and Video Festival Sunday at 2 P.M. The videos run from the purely artistic to documentaries on social injustice. The program is free, with a suggested museum contribution: $3; students $1.50, and the elderly, $1. The museum is at 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. Information: (718) 638-5000, extension 330.

title: Administration Seeking to Raise Minimum Wage, With Exemptions
description: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole will outline a Bush Administration proposal on Friday to raise the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour over three years, but with a $3.35 hourly ''training wage'' for some new workers, Administration officials said today.

title: Violence Ebbs in Venezuela, but Crisis Burns On
description: While soldiers sought to stamp out remaining pockets of unrest in the hilly shantytowns surrounding Caracas, most of Venezuela went back to work today, pondering the causes of the violence that has shaken the country since economic austerity measures were imposed Monday.

title: Market Place; A New Variation On Money Funds
description: WITH interest rates rising, there is a great temptation for investors to run for cover, which is one reason mutual fund companies say withdrawals have been on the rise in both bond and stock funds since the markets began to weaken last month.

title: Fear Rules the Salvadoran Refugees
description: When darkness descends on these rugged mountain highlands, the Salvadoran refugees encamped here can look down across the Honduran-Salvadoran border to see what they have fled.

title: Review/Opera; 'Telemacco,' Gluck Rarity
description: Without New York's expansive cultural atmosphere, splendid events like Gluck's ''Telemacco'' at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon might not happen. In this concert version by Bart Folse's Pro Arte Chorale and La Stravaganza Classical Orchestra, all the necessary instincts for survival in a very competitive concert business have found the right subject and the proper means.

title: Chrysler Raises Dividend 20%
description: Following the lead of the two larger American automobile makers, the Chrysler Corporation raised its annual cash dividend today by 20 percent.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Happy Day

title: Buyout for Sherrill
description: Jackie Sherrill, the former Texas A&M athletic director and football coach, received more than $500,000 and a house when he resigned with his program on probation last Dec. 12, the university said yesterday. The school said it had agreed to pay Sherrill's corporation, J.S.J.S. Inc. of Pennsylvania, $542,000 in cash to buy out his contract. Texas A&M also consented to release the lien it held on Sherrill's home in College Station, Tex. Sherrill agreed in the document to return all property owned by Texas A&M, including automobiles and credit cards. The universoty's statement said it paid off Sherrill's contract with revenue generated by the athletic department. (AP)

title: Two Yanks Are Injured
description: The Yankees played an intrasquad game today before opening their exhibition schedule on Friday, but all it did was lengthen their injury list.

title: US Intec reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,363,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,000 for the quarter and $32,000 for the year.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''BR'ER RABBIT TAILS,'' a program of songs and stories by Don Oliver, 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday at the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street. Admission: children and the elderly, $2.50; others, $5. Information: 777-3240. ''CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS,'' a show by the Puppetworks, with music of Saint-Saens and others, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue and Carroll Street, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. ''PRESTO! A MAGIC SPECTACULAR,'' a program of magic by Father Jerry and a presentation by Kenny Warren, a ventriloquist, and his partner, ''Leroy Kool,'' 8 tonight, at St. Stanislaus School, 61-17 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens. Tickets: $6 in advance, $7 at the door. Information: (718) 326-2185 or (718) 326-1476. ''ALICE IN WONDERLAND,'' a play by the Prince Street Players, 1 P.M. Saturday at the Triplex, 199 Chambers Street. Tickets: $5. Information: 618-1980. MAPLE SUGARING, a demonstration of the process, including Indian, Colonial and modern methods, 1 to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Entrance fees: under 16 years old and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (203) 322-1646. STORY HOUR, a free one-hour program for children 3 to 7, 11:30 A.M. Sunday, at Books of Wonder, 464 Hudson Street. Information: 989-3270. ''THE VELVETEEN RABBIT,'' a musical based on the story by Margery Williams, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow, and 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. ''THE VELVETEEN RABBIT,'' a puppet show by Terry Snyder, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at the Puppet Playhouse at the Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a play with music, adapted from the Hans Christian Andersen tale by Randolph Pearson, who is also the director, with music by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays, and 3:30 P.M. Sundays, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 666-1716. ''THE GIRL WITH THE ENAMEL EYES ('COPPELIA' SUITE),'' a show by the Neubert Ballet Company and the Children's Ballet Theater, 3:30 P.M. Sundays, Studio 819, Carnegie Hall. Tickets: $10. Information: 246-3166. ''ARLECCHINO'S HEART OF GOLD,'' a play with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show with audience participation, presented by Brian McGovern and Imam, at 2 P.M. Saturdays at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a play about a shy dragon in Central Park and a funny zoo keeper, written by Miranda McDermott and performed by child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, at 3 P.M. Saturdays at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations: 734-5195. ''THE THREE LITTLE PIGS,'' presented by the Little People's Theater Company, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, and ''Humpty Dumpty Falls in Love,'' 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 765-9540. ''IT'S TOUGH TO MAKE A NICKEL,'' a 40-minute living-history play about immigrant children living in tenements on the Lower East Side, 1 P.M. Sundays at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street. Tickets: children, $5; students and the elderly, $6; others, $7. Reservations: 431-0233.

title: Unit of G.M. Signs Pact With Hewlett
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company signed an agreement to develop new integrated computer products. Hewlett-Packard, a company based in Palo Alto, Calif., that makes computer systems, will contribute hardware and Electronic Data, a Dallas-based computer-services company, will provide software.

title: Suit Tests Michigan Ban on Abortion Funds
description: A 15-year-old Detroit girl who was left pregnant after being gang-raped is challenging the legality of the state referendum in November in which Michigan voters cut off all public funds for abortions, except where the woman's life is endangered.

title: Sytek to Hughes
description: Sytek Inc., which produces computer networks for large companies, agreed to be acquired by the Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation. Sytek, a private company based in Mountain View, Calif., is 57 percent owned by the General Instrument Corporation. General Instrument said it would receive about $50 million for its stake. Under the accord, Sytek will become Hughes LAN Systems, a unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company.

title: COURT TOLD NORTH AIDED REBELS IN '85
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency operative testified today that he took part in a June 1985 meeting in Miami in which Oliver L. North helped contra leaders plan their war against the Nicaraguan government.

title: Hospitals Viewed Near Limit In Coping With AIDS Crisis
description: New Yorkers could lose access to medical care unless the overcrowded health-care system is expanded quickly to deal with the rising number of AIDS patients, a mayoral panel warned yesterday.

title: Suit at U.S. Shoe
description: Six shareholders of the United States Shoe Corporation have sued to block the planned sale of its footwear division to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners for $422.5 million. The suit, filed on Wednesday in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court here, contends that the company's chairman, Philip G. Barach, and its directors have breached their fiduciary duties by agreeing to sell the division. A spokesman for U.S. Shoe, whose retail outlets include the Casual Corner women's clothing chain and the Lenscrafters optical centers, declined to comment on the suit.

title: Sun Coast Plastics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from the reversal of a tax credit of $23,000. The prior year does not include the results of Plastics Manufacturing Co., which was acquired in January 1988.

title: Dataram Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
S.E.C. Sets More Disclosure By Individuals in Takeovers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment two rules requiring fuller disclosure by individual investors who participate in corporate takeovers.

title: Injured Actor Still Opposes Laws on Helmets
description: Gary Busey, the actor who has been an outspoken opponent of laws requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets, says his near-fatal crash did not change his mind.

title: Norwegian Ensemble
description: The Bergen Wind Quintet, a Norwegian ensemble comprising the principal wind players of the Bergen Philharmonic, is to play music by Anton Reicha, Harald Saeverud, Finn Mortensen and Carl Nielsen at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $12. Information: 222-2433.

title: FPI Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $8.1 million. c-Included tax credits of $5.3 million and $27 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Devils Ask for Review Of Slashing Incident
description: The Devils have been unhappy with they way they have been treated by officials all season, and they hope the latest incident will prove their case.

title: The Right Way to Count Panchen Lamas
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 455 money market mutual funds increased by $1.63 billion, to $294.06 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 138 institutional funds' assets decreased by $1.70 billion, to $72.73 billion. Assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $2.39 billion, to $95.19 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds' assets rose by $938.6 million, to $126.14 billion, the institute said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey's Eclipse Car Spots To Be Seen on Cable
description: Grey Advertising said yesterday that it would show its well-publicized 90-second television spots for the Mitsubishi Eclipse on three cable networks - WTBS, MTV and the Arts and Entertainment Network.

title: A Son's Ambitions and a Father's Doubts
description: The father stood a few feet away from the son, who stepped to the top of the pitcher's mound, stared toward home plate and then heaved one pitch after another to a man wearing a catcher's mitt. The father neither moved nor spoke. Sunglasses hid his eyes and his emotions. After a few minutes, he walked away without a word.

title: 'Blunder' at Beijing Dinner: U.S. Chides Embassy
description: A senior White House official said today that inviting a prominent Chinese dissident to a dinner in Beijing last week honoring the country's leaders had not been President Bush's idea, and he suggested that the resulting contretemps was the fault of the American Embassy there.

title: France Asks Slower Buying of Iranian Oil
description: France quietly signaled its major oil companies today to slow the purchase of Iranian oil, according to the French news agency and oil industry sources here. It thus apparently joins a move by Japan, which has ordered similar cutbacks.

title: Review/Film; Reading, Writing and the Riot Act
description: It isn't easy to give a good performance while hollering through a bullhorn, but it can be done. And Morgan Freeman manages it in ''Lean on Me,'' in which he plays Joe Clark, the controversial high-school principal from Paterson, N.J. Mr. Freeman marches through the film at full blast, berating the students of Eastside High School in the tough, bombastic style for which Mr. Clark became well known. The film never wonders what it is in Mr. Clark's makeup that makes him rely almost exclusively on such bullying tactics, preferring instead to admire him as a galvanizing force.

title: The Old Vices Are Out And New Morality Is In
description: Raymond Strother, a Democratic political consultant, recalls wistfully that the rules of good behavior in politics used to be very simple.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Mina Fung has been promoted to senior vice president of Grey Advertising.

title: Clark P. Lattin, 73, Engineering Executive
description: Clark P. Lattin Jr., former president of the M. W. Kellogg Company and Pullman Inc., died of cancer Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in Portsmouth, Va. He was 73 years old and lived in Portsmouth.

title: Resignation at Allegheny
description: Allegheny International Inc. said today that Thomas J. Albani, its 46-year-old chief operating officer and executive vice president, resigned Wednesday after the signing of the agreement for Allegheny to be acquired by investors led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. ''It's only proper that the prospective new owners should be able to select their managers,'' Mr. Albani said.

title: Letters Clash With Account Of Ex-Official
description: When Mayor Edward I. Koch let Joseph DeVincenzo, a former aide responsible for the Talent Bank, resign with his full pension, the administration was in possession of documents that appeared to establish a conflict with Mr. DeVincenzo's testimony to a state investigative commission.

title: EQK Green Acres LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Restructuring Brings Two Departures
description: Two senior executives have left Saatchi & Saatchi Holdings, the United States holding company for Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., after a recent restructuring.

title: Aequitron Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Senators Mark Congress's Rich Past Before Facing the Painful Present
description: The debate began shortly before 1 P.M. with the rising of Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, fired with the righteous indignation of the ''trial lawyer from a small town'' that he proudly proclaimed himself to be.

title: Making and Honoring History
description: The debate over the Tower nomination carried a grim sense of history, a sense underscored as Congress celebrated its Bicentennial. Page A22..

title: CCL Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2.6 million and a charge of $4.8 million on the sale of a business. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $3.6 million and a $47.2 million writedown. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: No Clear Winners or Losers Emerging Yet in Lilco Pact
description: If the Shoreham nuclear power plant is abandoned under the agreement announced Tuesday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, will the Long Island Lighting Company's one million customers be getting a better deal than if the reactor had operated? And what about the shareholders?

title: Review/Dance; Serene and Bemused Cunningham
description: ''Cargo X,'' which had its local premiere with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday night, is one of Mr. Cunningham's mixtures of serenity and bemusement.

title: Britain, in Talk Aimed at Iran, Calls Rushdie Book Offensive
description: Two days after Iran threatened to break off diplomatic relations, Britain's Foreign Secretary today sharply distanced the Government from Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses.'' He said the book was not only offensive to Muslims but had also compared Britain to Hitler's Germany.

title: Zycad Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $440,000 from an accounting change. c-After tax credits of $1,025,000 for the quarter and $2,693,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: Review/Film; A Writer With a Block and a Bottle
description: As his comedies accumulate -some a lot less funny than others -Blake Edwards appears to be bent on becoming the definitive chronicler of life as lived by a small group of privileged, mostly superfluous Southern Californians.

title: Marvin A. Block, 86, Expert on Alcoholism
description: Dr. Marvin A. Block, professor emeritus at the State University of New York at Buffalo and an early advocate of medical treatment for alcoholics, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Buffalo General Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: Top Military Contractors
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is still the nation's biggest military contractor while Tenneco Inc. has vaulted from 13th to fourth position on the list, the Pentagon reported today.

title: GAF Holders Back Management Bid
description: The GAF Corporation's shareholders overwhelmingly approved a $1.47 billion buyout by a group led by the company's chairman and chief executive, Samuel J. Heyman. Of 27.8 million outstanding shares, more than 19 million supported the buyout.

title: A Jersey Enigma: Do Satanists Lurk Among Us?
description: George Fallon, the undersheriff of Camden County, N.J., is a lawman to the core, and he finds it a little hard to take the black arts of Satan worship altogether seriously.

title: Adams Resources & Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Urban Developer Sells Zero Coupons
description: The Urban Development Corporation is offering $155 million of zero-coupon debt securities in the taxable market through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

description: The Charleses Prepare

title: Emons Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $276,976 and $345,471 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $93,269 for the quarter and $244,866 for the 6 months.

title: 7 Hurt in Rikers Disturbance
description: Three prisoners and four guards suffered minor injuries when 150 inmates barricaded themselves inside two prison dormitories at the Rikers Island House of Detention for Men for more than an hour last night, officials said.

title: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $2 million from the repayment of indebtedness at a discount. c-Net loss and after a loss of $82,276 from discontinued operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do understand that the book itself has been found deeply offensive by people of the Muslim faith. We can understand why it has been criticized. It is a book that is offensive in many other ways as well. We are not upholding the right of freedom to speak because we agree with the book.'' - Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Foreign Secretary, speaking about ''The Satanic Verses.'' [ A1:2. ]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; French Firm In New York Alliance
description: FORGING an international alliance with political undercurrents, a large French advertising agency, acquired an interest yesterday in a small New York shop.

title: Bonn Asks Talks Now on Short-Range Arms
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany called today for immediate East-West negotiations to cut short-range nuclear missiles.

title: Champion Retiring
description: Dmitri Bilozerchev, a star gymnast in the Soviet Union, has decided to bow out of competitive sports, according to a report in Tass, the official Soviet news agency. The 22-year-old Olympic champion was quoted as saying that throughout his 15-year career he has been under constant psychological and physical strain and has been plagued by injuries. He said he was going to become a coach.

title: New-Home Sales Up 4.9% In January
description: Sales of new single-family homes increased by 4.9 percent in January, the biggest gain in seven months, but analysts said the rise resulted in part from unusually mild winter weather.

title: U.S. Regulators Seize 37 Ailing Savings Units in 6 States
description: In the broadest sweep yet this year, Federal savings and loan regulators today placed 37 insolvent institutions in six states under their direct control.

title: F.D.A. Approves the Use of an Experimental Drug for AIDS Patients' Eye Infections
description: Under pressure from officials at the National Institutes of Health and from AIDS patients and their advocates, the Food and Drug Administration has decided to allow patients with the disease to receive an experimental drug for eye infections, even if they are not enrolled in clinical trials to test the drug.

title: Restaurants
description: When Amsterdam's Bar and Rotisserie opened in 1984 on the Upper West Side, it created a feeding frenzy of uniquely Manhattan proportions, resulting in a nightly mob scene that made Saturday afternoon at Zabar's seem like a serene stroll through the Cloisters. The formula for success was as ingenuous as it was ingenious: serve comforting American food - rotisserie-cooked chicken, fish and beef - at moderate prices in a gregarious setting.

title: History on Disks
description: The Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, plans to make some of the library's vast collection accessible to thousands of schools and libraries across the country.

title: Dionne Is Staying In Denver for Now
description: Phil Esposito, the general manager of the Rangers, announced yesterday that Marcel Dionne would remain with the organization's minor league team in Denver until next Monday. Esposito, who admitted that the latest decision merely postponed an inevitable one about the future of Dionne, said he was considering a wide range of options. Those alternatives, Esposito said, include sending Dionne to another team by Tuesday, the National Hockey League's trading deadline. Dionne, third on the N.H.L.'s career-scoring list, could also accept a financial buyout package or return to play for the Rangers. Esposito met with Coach Michel Bergeron for more than an hour yesterday to discuss Dionne's role.

title: Just Like the Movie
description: The President's choice of a nominee for a Cabinet-level position leads to division and controversy in the Senate. He stands by the unpopular nominee. He fights for confirmation. Familiar? It happened in Allen Drury's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel ''Advise and Consent.''

title: Calprop Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared in October 1988.

description: b-Net income Prior year results included a $60,000 gain from debt retirement.

description: The company said 1988 earnings included $985,000 in earnings from Rayrock Yellowknife Inc., which is 23.8 percent owned by Discovery. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 To relieve Poland's foreign debt, negotiators for the Polish Government and the Solidarity labor union have agreed to issue a joint appeal to help lift the financial quarantine. Page A1

title: Oil Soars on Word of Shifts In Import and Export Policy
description: Prices of crude oil soared yesterday, buoyed partly by reports that France would join Japan in reducing petroleum imports from Iran and partly by rumors that the Soviet Union and other non-OPEC nations would cut their oil exports.

title: Brown Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,851,000 and a charge of $18,000,000 on the disposal of assets. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and $6,688,000 for the year.

title: Review/Rock; Grim Metallic Tidings From 2 Bands
description: Bulletins on corruption, war casualties, drug addiction, nuclear threats, embattled freedom of speech and homicidal rampages turn up regularly in the news. They were also heard from the stage Wednesday when Metallica and Queensryche performed at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., to a sold-out house filled with raised hands and fists.

title: Minnetonka Weighs Sale to Enhance Value
description: The Minnetonka Corporation, which makes Calvin Klein cosmetics, said today that it was considering selling the company, which analysts said could bring up to $400 million.

title: American Learnings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bindley Western Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included extraordinary charges of $4,000 and $105,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Botha to Resume Duties Later This Month
description: President P. W. Botha, who is recovering from a stroke suffered six weeks ago, today squelched speculation about his possible retirement by disclosing that he plans to resume his official duties later this month.

title: Van Dorn Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times; Watching TV and Being Rootless in the South
description: Love Life By Bobbie Ann Mason 241 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Reviews/Film; At War With Faith
description: When Maurice Pialat approaches more psychological subjects, as he has in such films as ''A Nos Amours,'' ''Loulou'' and ''Police,'' his deceptively straightforward manner and his ability to suspend judgment can have the look of naturalism (though his scrutiny is so keen that it becomes extraordinarily penetrating over a period of time). But ''Under the Sun of Satan'' is about faith, and it's a more difficult, mysterious film in every way. Even so, Mr. Pialat has employed as plain a directorial style as ever. So the miraculous, the visionary and the diabolical fuse here in a film that grapples simply and powerfully with the unknown.

title: Excerpts From Senate's Debate on the Nomination of Tower
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate's debate today about John G. Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense, as recorded by The New York Times: Sam Nunn Democrat of Georgia

title: Notes and Bonds Up in Active Day
description: A further rise in the dollar and active buying by overseas investors helped push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds by as much as three-quarters of a point in brisk trading yesterday.

title: Consumers Packaging Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its previously reported restructuring in 1988 was reflected in non-recurring unusual expenses of more than $66 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Experts Form Global Guides For Testing AIDS Vaccines
description: AIDS experts meeting under the auspices of the World Health Organization have established guidelines for the testing of AIDS vaccines, W.H.O. officials said today.

title: Vandeweghe Scores 23 As Knicks Defeat Heat
description: Let it be recorded that with 3 minutes 25 seconds remaining in the opening quarter last night, Kiki Vandeweghe scored his first points as a Knick, on an 18-foot jump shot from the corner coming off a pick by Charles Oakley.

title: Animal-Rights Case: Terror or Entrapment?
description: In the early hours of Nov. 11, the police arrested a Queens woman, saying she had planted a bomb at the Norwalk headquarters of the United States Surgical Corporation. The bomb plot - called a protest against the company's use of dogs in surgical training - was quickly condemned by the company as an example of growing fanaticism in the animal-rights movement.

title: 7 Companies Given Awards
description: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization, presented its third annual America's Corporate Conscience Awards last night to five corporations that it regards as exemplifying corporate social responsibility. Two other companies received honorable mention.

title: Wiley, John & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Women's History Month
description: In and near Manhattan, National Women's History Month is being celebrated with special activities. Many are listed in the free Women's History Month calendar published by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, 52 Chambers Street, Suite 207, New York, N.Y. 10007; 566-3833. Here is a selection of events: TODAY ''DESIGNING WOMEN: WORKS BY LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTS AND SCULPTORS IN NEW YORK CITY PARKS,'' Tweed Gallery, City Hall Park, 52 Chambers Street (360-3410). An exhibition of photographs, drawings and plans of work by Emma Stebbins, Anna Vaughn Hyatt Huntington, Bessie Potter Vonnah, Sally James Farnham, Harriet Whitney Frishmuth, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, Helen Elise Bullard, Clara Stimson Coffey, Beatrix Jones Farrand, Maud Sargent, Betty M. Sprout and Janet Darling Webel; curator, Heidi Fried. Through March 29. The gallery is open weekdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free. JANET GOLDNER, sculpture, SoHo 20 Gallery, 469 Broome Street (226-4167). Through March 11. The gallery is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 6 P.M. Free. NEW MUSEUM OF CONTEMPORARY ARTS, 583 Broadway, near Prince Houston Street (219-1355). ''Overlooked/Underplayed: Videos on Women and AIDS'' and ''Until That Last Breath,'' an exhibition of Ann Meredith's photographs of women who have AIDS. Through April 16. The gallery is open Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M., and Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Suggested admission: $2.50; $1.50 for artists, students and the elderly. ''TURNING LEAVES: THE PHOTOGRAPH ALBUMS OF TWO JAPANESE AMERICAN FAMILIES,'' New York Chinatown History Project, 70 Mulberry Street (619-4785). Through March. The gallery is open Mondays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Suggested admission: $2. METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART, Uris Auditorium (879-5500). Film presentations of ''Anonymous Was a Woman'' and ''Quilts in Women's Lives,'' 1 P.M. today; ''The Artist Was a Woman,'' 3 P.M. tomorrow. Admission to the program is free; the suggested admission to the museum is $5; $2.50 for students and the elderly. ''FROM THE WOMEN'S LIBERATION ARCHIVES,'' Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street, ground-floor meeting room (777-9241). A free exhibition of documents, photographs, posters, songs and videotapes of the last 20 years, on view from 7 to 10:45 tonight, is to accompany a discussion about abortion in the church sanctuary at 8:30 P.M., sponsored by the Redstockings of the Women's Liberation Movement. Admission to the abortion discussion is $6. TOMORROW NEW YORK FEMINIST ART INSTITUTE, Women's Center for Learning, 91 Franklin Street (219-9590). ''Feminist Love and Courage,'' a workshop conducted by the writer Phyllis Chesler, 4 to 8 P.M. Admission: $50. ''Dream Workshop: Exploring the Ultimate Personal Creation,'' a workshop conducted by Jill Morris, a writer, that explores using dreams, drawing on aboriginal and American Indian methods, 2 to 5 P.M. March 18. Admission: $30. ''WOMEN IN ART: IMAGES,'' Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, Crown Heights section. A lecture by Hazel Rodriguez of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with illustrations of works from the museum's collection. For information and dates for the traveling program, call (718) 735-4400. 2 P.M. Free, with $2 admission to the museum. ''CROSSING THE BARRICADES,'' Queens Botanical Garden, 43-50 Main Street (718-886-3800). A series of dramatic vignettes on women's lives by the award-winning New York Street Theater Caravan. 2:30 P.M. Free. ''WOMANDANCE,'' Vital Arts Center, 33 East 18th Street, third floor (475-1065; 475-1297). A celebration by the Eleo Pomare Dance Company of the history of blacks and women. ''Pomare Women'' is to be presented at 7:30 P.M.; Robin Becker is to perform at 5 P.M. March 12. Admission to each concert: $5. SNUG HARBOR CULTURAL CENTER, Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. (718-448-2500). Alessandra Belloni sings 14th-century love songs, Veterans Memorial Hall, Snug Harbor, 8 P.M. Admission is $10. ''Beth Ames Swartz: A Moving Point of Balance,'' opening reception for an installation that is both environmental and participatory. At the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, Main Hall Building. Through April 16. Gallery hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission to the reception is free. The suggested admission to the gallery is $1. SUNDAY STEPHANIE SAMARAS, soprano, Queens Borough Public Library, Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica (718-990-0700) at 2 P.M. Sunday. Free. Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue and 53d Street (496-1409). International Women's Writing Guild is to present a panel discussion on publishing and writing, 2:30 to 6 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $10. Information: 737-7536. ''Wonderful Older Women,'' a talk by Lou Glasse sponsored by the Older Women's League, Greater New York Chapter, at 2 P.M. Sunday. Admission: $2. Information: 496-1409. ''MOVERS AND SHAKERS: WOMEN WHO HAVE MADE A DIFFERENCE,'' American Association of University Women, 111 East 37th Street (684-6068). A staged reading from biographies of and works by eight women involved in American history, 3 P.M. Sunday. Free.

title: New Rail Line to Atlantic City
description: Amtrak will open the first major new rail route in its 18-year history when it begins service to Atlantic City on May 23. The Atlantic City Express will include five round trips on weekdays and several more on weekends, said Amtrak's vice president of marketing, Timothy P. Gardner. One direct line will originate in Washington and another will start in New York, Mr. Gardner said. Officials said today that they expect 1.4 million new riders a year. Amtrak has added new cities to its existing rail network but has never before created a new route, said an Amtrak spokesman, John Jacobsen.

The program includes J. S. Bach's Harpsichord Concerto in D minor (BWV 1052), J. C. Bach's Sinfonia in B flat (Op. 18, No. 2) and C. P. E. Bach's Symphony No. 1 in D minor (Wq. 183) and Oboe Concerto in E flat (Wq. 165). Randall Ellis is to be the oboe soloist. Tickets are $15 to $20. Information: 996-1100.

title: 5 Nominated for PEN Fiction Awards
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer is one of five authors whose books were nominated for the ninth annual PEN/Faulker Award for the best work of fiction published in 1988. Mr. Singer, winner of the 1978 Nobel Prize for Literature, received the PEN/Faulkner nomination for ''The Death of Methuselah'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), 20 stories from the 1970's and 1980's about displaced intellectuals and Yiddish journalists in Warsaw and New York.

title: Legislators Expect Extension Of Using Cameras in Courts
description: The chairmen of two New York State legislative committees expressed confidence yesterday that the Legislature would extend an experimental law allowing television cameras and photographers in the state's courts.

title: Program Called Feasible in New York
description: Administrators of drug abuse programs in New York said yesterday that if a proposed liberalization of rules on the use of methadone was adopted, all of New York City's approximately 200,000 heroin addicts could be receiving daily doses of the synthetic narcotic in a matter of weeks.
