title: 2 Argentine Loans Delayed
description: The World Bank today held up $350 million of installments on two loans to Argentina on the ground that the country had failed to meet all conditions in making economic reforms.

title: BUSH RULING NEAR ON EASTERN STRIKE
description: President Bush's senior advisers believe he should allow a strike to begin at midnight Friday against Eastern Airlines, Administration officials and industry executives said today.

title: Check Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Everex Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Gems and Minerals
description: ''A Festival of Gems, Jewelry, Minerals and Fossils'' will take place at the New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street, today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Contemporary and estate jewelry will be on display and can be purchased; the Lapidary and Gem Society of New York will demonstrate stone cutting and gem faceting. Recent finds of fossils and meteorites will also be on sale. Admission is $3.50; $2.50 for children. Information: (201) 775-5615.

title: Pillar of Chip Industry Eroding
description: Industry and Government officials are expressing increasing concern over the erosion of the little-known but crucial American industry that supplies the silicon wafers, etching equipment and other machinery and materials used in making computer chips.

title: Chip Makers to Seek Joint Ventures
description: The American semiconductor industry has taken further steps to re-enter the market for dynamic random access memory chips, a field of high technology effectively abandoned to Japan in the mid-1980's.

title: Houston Journal; In the Eye of a Storm, Oasis of Peace and Quiet
description: Shirley Johnson lives in a dark, cramped two-bedroom apartment with her two children and two nieces. It is one of a thousand such apartments in Allen Parkway Village, a 37-acre low-income housing complex that is a maze of squat brick buildings and bare playgrounds. Downtown is a short walk across a road.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of computer problems at The Associated Press, the Cash Prices table is not available.

title: Review/Art; Turbulent Restatements From Robert Colescott
description: A necessary museum show is ''Robert Colescott: A Retrospective, 1975-1986,'' which has just arrived at the New Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: U.S. AIDES CRITICAL OF SOVIETS ON IRAN
description: State Department officials asserted today that the Soviet Union appeared to be trying to exploit the Salman Rushdie affair to improve ties with Iran and delay any Iranian reconciliation with the West.

title: Slow Bangladesh Growth
description: Bangladesh will be even poorer next year as economic growth slows because of flooding and a trade imbalance, the World Bank reported this week. It said the economy would grow only 1.2 percent in the fiscal year that began last July 1.

title: Dividend Is Declared By Shaklee
description: The Shaklee Corporation, a target of takeover speculation, today declared an extraordinary cash dividend of $20 per share of its common stock. The action was seen as a way of rewarding company shareholders and discouraging takeover interest in the company.

title: Datakey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $333,000 and $1,224,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $195,000 for the quarter and $382,000 for the year.

title: Three Young Singers Make Show Tunes Hum
description: IF the American musical comedy is an endangered species, its precarious state cannot be attributed to a shortage of talented singers. Not only in New York, but around the country where light-opera companies and community theaters perpetuate the classic shows of Broadway's golden age, young performers are emerging who have been bitten hard by the musical-theater bug.

title: Stocks Rise Sharply as Dow Jumps 22.67
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved sharply higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 22.67 points to close at 2,265.71.

title: Police Officer Is Shot to Death In Flatbush AreaZ
description: A 24-year-old police officer was shot and killed early this morning in a shootout with a gunman on a street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Greyvest Financial Services Inc reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Distinctive Jazz From Two Singers
description: Of all the musical arts, singing is the most personal. The full brunt of a narrative sung by a person on stage, eyes flashing with hidden tales of jealousy or joy, can land in the lap of an audience. This weekend, two of jazz's most distinct singers - Abbey Lincoln and Leon Thomas - both eclectics who have seen jazz move from the big-band era into more political and varied contexts, will be performing rare concerts. Both of them have played important roles in expanding the possibilites of jazz singing.

title: Hearx Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest first- quarter figures included the results of Sehas Inc., which was acquired by Hearx in July 1988.

The company said in the latest quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: New York Pulling Out of 13 More Welfare Hotels
description: With New York City moving ahead in its plan to stop using welfare hotels to shelter homeless families, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced yesterday that the use of 13 more hotels would be ended by September.

title: Johnson's Coach Casts Doubt On Sprinter's World Record
description: Ben Johnson's coach testified today that anabolic steroids were a major component of the sprinter's training program leading to the 1987 world track and field championships in Rome, where Johnson set a world record in winning the 100-meter dash.

description: * Dep Corporation, to Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, for its consumer products, with a budget of $8 million.

Soviet Press Praises Walesa in a First Interview
description: Breaking an eight-year taboo, a Soviet publication has printed a long and surprisingly amiable interview with Lech Walesa, the Polish labor leader who was regularly excoriated in the Soviet press before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader.

title: New Proposal Made By Eastern Airlines In Machinist Talks
description: Nearing a strike deadline, Eastern Airlines made a new proposal today in the long-deadlocked contract talks with its machinists' union.

title: The Film Forum To Be Razed For Office Space
description: Film Forum, a lower Manhattan twin movie theater that shows foreign, classic and independent movies, will be demolished within a year to make way for a 20- to 25-story office building, Karen Cooper, the theater's director, said yesterday.

title: Suspect Still Hunted In Drug Agent Death
description: The police continued to hunt yesterday for a paroled prisoner wanted in Tuesday's fatal shooting of Everett Hatcher, the first Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent killed in New York City.

title: CNA Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included capital gains of $25,843,000 and $141,987,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After capital losses of $9,248,000 for the quarter and $27,762,000 for the year.

title: Dotronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U. S. Reported Talking with Salvador Rebels
description: A newspaper said today that State Department officials have held secret talks with guerrillas in El Salvador in an attempt to reach a negotiated settlement of the conflict in that country.

title: Car Dealers Lose Ruling
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that Detroit-area auto dealers broke Federal antitrust laws by agreeing among themselves to close showrooms on Saturdays and most weekday evenings. The dealers were ordered to remain open 64 hours each week for a year.

title: American International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net realized gains of $4,181,000 and $41,861,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included net realized gains of $14,431,000 for the quarter and $97,478,000 for the year.

title: Gulf Resources & Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $142,000 for the quarter and $287,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $740,000. d-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $1,255,000. The company said the latest quarter net from continuing operations included a gain of $5.7 million, or 61 cents a share, from the final settlement with the Internal Revenue Service regarding tax returns for the years 1972 through 1980. The company also said the prior year net from continuing operations included a gain on the sale of an investment in Imperial Continental Gas Association of $44.6 million. The latest year results included a charge of $800,000 from an anticipated loss on the sale of the company's Great Salt Lake Minerals & Chemicals Corp. unit to a newly organized company.

title: Acme United reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Carlyle Group Lifts Stake in Fairchild
description: The Carlyle Group, a Washington investment firm, has raised its stake in Fairchild Industries to 13.5 percent from 9.9 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Carlyle said that ''based upon a review of available alternatives,'' it believed Fairchild's stock was an attractive investment at current market prices.

description: b-After a $1,360,000 gain from an accounting change. c-Net income and included gains from the repurchase of debentures of $315,000 and $1,378,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Rushdie and Others
description: Here are a few items recently in the news:

title: Sallie Mae to Sell Nonvoting Shares
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, said it expects to sell two million nonvoting common shares through a public offering in the United States domestic market and Euromarket after Monday.

title: Darman Calls Savings Numbers Optimistic
description: The budget director, Richard G. Darman, told Congress today that the long-term assumptions on interest rates and other economic factors underlying the Bush plan to bail out the savings and loan industry were optimistic and ''almost certain to be wrong.''

title: New Help for Contras To Be Sought in April
description: The Bush Administration will formally submit a request to Congress next month to continue nonmilitary financing for the Nicaraguan insurgents, a senior White House official said today.

title: Moscow Journal; 'The People's Paper' Feeds on Facts and Gets Fat
description: It has the ambiance of a college newspaper office, a warren of raggedy, overcrowded rooms with pop music posters taped to the wall, too few telephones and a staff of earnest, underpaid apprentices.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., said it had received a contract from Aerospatiale of France to supply equipment for the new Airbus Industrie A330 and A340 aircraft. The potential long-term value of the contract could exceed $100 million.

title: Derwinski Confirmed as Veterans Secretary
description: The Senate voted 94 to 0 to confirm Edward J. Derwinski tonight as the first Secretary of Veterans Affairs.

description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. American Festival Cafe

title: Imco Recycling reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cone and Mets Settle
description: David Cone, who got into a salary dispute with the Mets after winning 20 games last season, agreed today to sign for $332,500, two days after the Mets threatened to renew his contract unilaterally at $310,000. ''We met halfway,'' the 26-year-old pitcher said. ''That's all I can ask. And once I sign, it's behind me.''

title: 75 Boat People Flown Home in Effort to Reverse Tide
description: Wearing new clothes and carrying bundles of small souvenirs of their brief life here, 75 Vietnamese boarded a jet for Hanoi today, volunteers in the first full-scale effort to return boat people to their own land.

title: Coeur D'Alene Mines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No. 6 Syracuse Surprised By Barros, Boston College
description: Dana Barros scored 31 points for Boston College tonight and made two free throws with 1 minute 41 seconds left as the Big East Conference's last-place team stunned sixth-ranked Syracuse, 90-87.

description: Here we have it, plain, painful and perfidious, in a State Department report to the Congress of the United States:

description: To the Editor:

description: b-After net of $17,600 for the quarter and a loss of $236,800 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a gain of $63,200 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $326,700 for the quarter and $2,478,200 for the year; the year also included a gain of $114,400 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title:
About Real Estate;
Waterfront Project in East Hampton
description: LEAD: The view from a 110-acre waterfront site under development at Northwest Harbor in East Hampton, L.I., is of a pristine landscape little changed since the town's earliest settlers, who came from Connecticut, landed here in the mid-17th century.

title: Wal-Mart Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the costing of inventories under the LIFO method reduced net income $55,921,000, or 10 cent a share, this year, compared with $28,732,000, or 5 cents a share, last year.

title: Goldfield Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Can Lawyers Be Forced to Represent the Poor?
description: When a Federal District Court in Iowa asked a young member of its bar to handle a civil rights suit on behalf of two state prisoners, the lawyer, John E. Mallard, assumed he was free to decline.

title: Yugoslav Communist Seized
description: The former Communist Party chief of Kosovo province was arrested today as the Yugoslav police began rounding up organizers of ethnic Albanian unrest, the official press agency Tanyug reported. The former official, Azem Vlasi, was arrested with a former member of the provincial party's Politburo, Ekrem Arifi, and two directors of a zinc mine where workers staged a sit-in last week.

title: Jaguar Pay Offer Fails
description: Workers at Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury car maker, have narrowly rejected a pay offer by the company and have scheduled a ban on overtime starting this weekend and weekly one-day strikes after Monday.

title: Why Banks Pay Less on Funds
description: Although money market accounts at banks were designed to be competitive with money market mutual funds, the only similarity between the two these days is their name.

title: Review/Film; Nick Nolte As a King, Self-Made
description: In John Milius's ''Farewell to the King,'' Nick Nolte plays Learoyd, a renegade American soldier who, having escaped the Japanese invaders of the Philippines in 1942, has somehow managed to sail to Borneo. There, in rain forests that are trackless, beneath mountains that tower and beside waterfalls that cascade, he forges a kingdom by uniting primitive tribes that are innocents.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. for the latest periods were $1.56 for the fourth quarter and $6.27 for the year. This compared with $1.74 a share and $5.56 a share for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings for the latest periods were 83 cents for the quarter and $3.46 for the year, compared with the year-ago quarter of 94 cents a share and $3.05 a share for 1987. The latest fourth quarter's net income was after a charge to the chemicals segment of $120 million, after tax, relating to a provision for environmental clean-up at the Rocky Mountain arsenal site in Colorado. The corresponding quarter in 1987 benefited from a gain, also in the chemicals segment, of $220 million, from the sale of an interest in a consumer products business. The 1987 figures have been restated for the effects of accounting changes. Sales represent sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mobile-Home Loans Back Freddie Mac Certificates
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is making its first offering of pass-through certificates of participation backed by loans for new and used mobile homes.

title: Cuomo Gets the Respect But Dangerfield, the Votes
description: Asked to name the people they would most like to hear give a speech, students at the University of Florida here put Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York among the top five - but declined to make him the No. 1 vote-getter, an honor that went to the comedian Rodney Dangerfield.

title: Review/Pop; McGuire Sisters' Harmonies
description: Listening to the McGuire Sisters' three-part harmonies at Rainbow and Stars on Tuesday evening, one was swept back in memory to the mid-1950's when the trio from Miamisburg, Ohio, epitomized a square all-American togetherness.

title: INSIDE Coach Cites Steroid Role
description: Coach Cites Steroid Role

John A. Michaels, Stockbroker, 47
description: John A. Michaels, a stockbroker and a managing director of the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc., died of heart failure Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Wallace Computer Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

Don't Inflame the Housing Crisis
description: New York's Department of City Planning proposes to close a loophole that has allowed builders in all boroughs but Manhattan to fudge on floor area allowances. It's a misguided move; for the sake of expanding the housing stock, the loophole ought to be held permanently open, not closed up.

title: John P. McGrath, 82, Lawyer, Banker and Developer, Is Dead
description: John P. McGrath, a lawyer, banker and real-estate developer who served as New York City's Corporation Counsel and as a member of the Waterfront Commission of New York and New Jersey, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Samson Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings are in units.

title: Computer Trade Group
description: A new computer industry trade group to promote the Sparc microprocessor technology created by Sun Microsystems Inc. was announced here at Uniforum, a conference for users of the Unix operating system.

title: High Court Plea on Detroit Papers
description: Opponents of a partial merger of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press asked the Supreme Court today to delay completion of the business agreement so there will be further time for appeal.

title: Another Cost-Cutter To Head Phelps Dodge
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, said yesterday that Douglas C. Yearly, an executive vice president, would become chairman and chief executive, replacing G. Robert Durham, who is retiring in May.

title: Under Contract in College Sport
description: Federal prosecutors pursuing a novel legal strategy may have laid the foundation for a revolution in college sports. While the immediate result seems to benefit schools, the ultimate outcome could be a fairer deal for the athletes.

title: Koch Won't Oppose Challenge to Purge of Voters
description: New York City officials, led by Mayor Edward I. Koch, said yesterday that they would not oppose a legal challenge to the removal from the voting rolls of 312,000 mostly black and Hispanic people who did not vote in the last four years.

title: BCE Development Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said after preferred share dividends, there were no earnings for common shareholders in the latest period. Share earnings are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Feb. 14 about the program ''Back to Chernobyl,'' on a visit to the site of the Soviet nuclear disaster, misstated the college affiliation of Dr. Hans Bethe. He is a faculty member at Cornell, not M.I.T.

title: 4 Newspapers Offer Reward in Bombing
description: The four major New York City newspapers will each provide $10,000 for a reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible for the firebombing of The Riverdale Press newspaper in the Bronx.

title: Critical Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AME Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter included a pretax gain of $66,505 on disposition of fixed assets, compared with a loss of $1,721 a year- ago.

title: Albany Asks Localities to Practice a Modest Form of Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: Studying Japanese Is a Waste of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Land Sought as Buffer Around Parks
description: With conservationists saying the days of creating large new national parks in the lower 48 states are largely over, nature preservation groups have stepped up a campaign to protect areas around existing parks or add smaller parcels to the wilderness system.

title: Transcisco to Seek Sale of PLM Stake
description: Transcisco Industries said it would seek to sell its 35.7 percent stake in PLM International Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Transcisco said it believed it could get the best price for its stake by selling the shares of the financial-services concern in one block.

title: Charges Filed
description: Formal accusations were filed yesterday by the racing board in California against D. Wayne Lukas and Laz Barrera, who each train a horse that tested positive for cocaine. Lukas and Barrera are expected to have a hearing within 15 days before an administrative law judge, who will then issue non-binding recommendations to the state board. The trainers, who have maintained that they did not give their horses any cocaine, still bear the responsibility under the state's ''absolute insurer'' rule, which essentially states that a trainer is responsible for the well-being of all horses in his care.(AP)

title: Baby Taken in Foiled Robbery Is Recovered
description: A 5-month-old baby, who was kidnapped after his parents crashed through a window in their apartment to escape a robbery attempt, was recovered yesterday at a Brooklyn subway station, where the police arrested a man who tried to collect a ransom.

title: Consolidated-Tomoka Land reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sony Seeks TV Grant From U.S.
description: In a development that could lead to widespread debate over Government sponsorship of foreign research efforts, the Sony Corporation of America said yesterday that it had submitted a bid to the Defense Department for contracts to develop a high-definition television system.

title: SOLIDARITY PLANS TO JOIN THE REGIME IN ASKING DEBT AID
description: Negotiators for the Government and the Solidarity union have agreed in principle to issue a joint appeal for relief of Poland's crushing foreign debt, diplomats and members of the two negotiating teams said today. Such a plea that would challenge Western governments to lift the last vestiges of the financial quarantine imposed after martial law was declared seven years ago.

title: KEY RATES
Garvey Resigns Post
description: One week after two women said he had fathered their children, Steve Garvey, the former major leaguer, has resigned as a trustee at the University of San Diego. Officials at the Roman Catholic university released a statement yesterday confirming Garvey's resignation but gave no reason. Dan Petrie, a spokesman for Bishop Leo Maher, chairman of the university's board of trustees, said Garvey attended the board's annual retreat at La Quinta, Calif., last weekend and turned in his resignation after a talk with the bishop. (AP)

title: Jersey Lawmakers Plan Retailiatory Tax on New Yorkers
description: In the latest border hostilities between New York and New Jersey officials, state legislators here today introduced ''retaliatory'' bills to raise income taxes for some of the 100,000 people who live in New York but work in New Jersey.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Cosmico

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant misstated the position of the New York Power Authority trustees. They are not in favor of the Governor's proposal.

title: Safer Cigarettes
description: Premier, RJR Nabisco's smokeless, ashless, tarless cigarette, has gone up in smoke. Sales in two test markets fell far short of expectations and the financially pressed tobacco giant was unwilling to risk millions in search of a market.

title: U.S. Calls on Sudan To Sign a Cease-Fire It Rejected Last Year
description: The United States said today that the Sudanese Government should immediately accept a comprehensive cease-fire agreement that it spurned in December, and an American official warned that continued fighting there would lead to a ''tragic repetition'' of last year's famine.

title: Philip Morris Notes Offered at 10.15%
description: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $250 million of 10.15 percent notes due in 1990 at an initial price of 100 through the First Boston Corporation, as sole underwriter.

title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'
description: ''Heart of Midnight'' is a suspense melodrama that makes even less sense than its title. It's about - and seen through the eyes of - a young woman who may or may not be crazy. This gives the director license to be bizarre without having to justify anything.

title: Reviews/Theater; Artist or Monster? The Life and Myth of Ezra Pound
description: Of all the great contemporary literary figures, Ezra Pound is the most contradictory. He was a poetic genius (by his measure and that of others) and an inspiration behind modernism in the arts - as well as a fanatical racist and anti-Semite. In ''Incommunicado'' (at the Wilma Theater here), Tom Dulack makes a bold dramatic assault on Pound's outrageous life and myth. Though the play has rough edges, it has an urgency and a seriousness of purpose in dealing with an exceedingly controversial subject.

title: Meridian Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Henderson Remarks Raise Rhoden's Ire
description: In his two years with the Yankees, Rick Rhoden successfully avoided the bottomless pit of turmoil in which the Yankees wallowed. Now that he has moved to another league, though, the pitcher has lost his immunity from persecution. He has been showered with fallout from the Yankees' latest episode.

title: Jail Influx Brings Plan For 2 Barges
description: With a surge of arrests, most of them on drug charges, adding 200 inmates a week to New York City's overcrowded jails, the City Correction Department proposed yesterday a package of emergency measures that include housing prisoners on barges moored on both sides of Manhattan by the early summer.

title: Chile's Navy Tries to Control Oil Spill From Peruvian Ship
description: The Chilean Navy today floated a ring of booms around a grounded Peruvian ship to contain an oil spill that has created a slick more than a half-mile long in the Antarctic, a spokesman said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: A United States Bankruptcy Court judge approved a $4 million agreement for Yugo America Inc., the importer of the Yugoslav-made minicars that has filed for bankruptcy protection. The accord, approved by Judge Vincent J. Commisa, replaces an interim pact and is expected to keep Yugo operating for four months.

title: Senators Complete Hearing on Bennett for Drug Job
description: In Senate hearings that ended today, William J. Bennett faced nearly as many questions about his outspoken stands in his previous Cabinet post as about his goals in leading the fight against drugs.

title: Henry Gerard Bruns, Broker, 84
description: Henry Gerard Bruns, a retired investment broker and railroad executive, died Wednesday at his home in New London, N.H. He was 84 years old and had lived in Montclair, N.J., before moving to New Hampshire in 1977.

title: Esquire Radio & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2,569,000 gain from a litigation award.

title: 12 EUROPE NATIONS TO BAN CHEMICALS THAT HARM OZONE
description: In an unexpectedly strong move, the 12 European Community countries agreed today to eliminate by the end of the century their production and use of chemicals that harm the atmosphere's ozone shield.

title: Pantasote Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $682,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss The latest fourth quarter and full year results included a gain of $2.1 million related to the termination of the salaried employees pension plan, and a charge of $500,000 for the expected cost of environmental cleanup at two plants previously sold by the company. The 1987 full year results included a $7 million reserve for potential warranty claims relating to the company's former U.S. roofing products business, which was discontinued in 1985.

title: Legislation Backs U. S. Troop Cuts in Europe
description: Two members of Congress announced legislation today that would compel the withdrawal of some American troops from Europe.

title: News Corp. May Form Unit
description: News Corporation Ltd., the Australia-based international conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said today that it was considering forming a separate company to acquire and develop media and communications businesses.

title: Quiksilver Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Airlines Plan to Add Service to Offset a Strike
description: With a strike against Eastern Airlines threatened for 12:01 A.M. Saturday, other airlines and Amtrak said today that they would step up service to offset any reduction in Eastern's 1,040 flights a day worldwide.

title: Shearson Unit May Be Sold
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. said on Wednesday that it had held discussions with potential buyers of one of its money-management subsidiaries.

title: Adding Polish to Promise
description: Dixieland Brass would be the early star of most racing seasons, certainly the focus of any other Florida Derby Day. But on Saturday at Gulfstream Park, he will be a secondary attraction.

title: Review/Art; Going Beyond Slickness: Sculptors Get Back to Basics
description: IN a season when the New York art world may seem to be wrapped in slick surfaces, status and money, three surprising sculpture shows, in three different boroughs, zero in on a more naked and physical reality. Each show is, in a way, exclusive. All 11 artists in one are black; all six artists in another are women; in the third, the four artists are men. Yet all three shows are involved with big feelings and a search for experience that is shared and elemental.

title: Paris Board Picks Globex
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that the futures exchange in Paris had agreed to join Globex, the after-hours trading system recently approved for financial futures markets.

title: Judges Shouldn't Have to Worry About Income; Like the Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta Affirmative Action Plan Is Upset
description: Georgia's highest court, relying on a recent United States Supreme Court decision on affirmative action, today overturned a widely copied program that has guided Atlanta construction contracts to minority groups.

title: U.S. to Ease Methadone Rules For Addicts to Combat AIDS
description: In an effort to slow the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug abusers, Federal health agencies yesterday proposed a major liberalization in the availability of methadone to addicts seeking treatment.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

title: Review/Television; Could Hitler Have Won? A Look at His Mistakes
description: The meat of ''How Hitler Lost the War'' is sandwiched between a stale account of the rise of the Nazi leader and a thick slab of cliches (''It is our obligation to remember so that it will never happen again.'') The 90-minute documentary on Channel 13, at 10:20 P.M. Sunday, advances the argument that Germany would have won World War II if the Fuhrer had heeded the advice of his generals. The case is made mainly by former Wehrmacht and Luftwaffe officers who, viewers will not be surprised to notice, take pains to distance themselves from their onetime chief.

Mr. Meneses, who is from Brazil, won the gold medal at the 1982 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. Miss Licad, who is married to Mr. Meneses, is from the Philippines and won the Leventritt International Competition in 1981. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: Review/Dance; Cheryl Jones in Feld's 'Echo'
description: Cheryl Jones, one of the most affecting dancers of the Feld Ballet, returned to the company on Wednesday in the solo work ''Echo,'' and gave a performance of memorable lyricism and nuance. Miss Jones, who had been on a leave of absence from the company, was the dancer for whom Eliot Feld created ''Echo'' in 1986. Karen Kain, a guest artist from the National Ballet of Canada, has done all the New York City performances of the piece, and will dance it tonight and tomorrow. But ''Echo'' is a dance that seems especially suited to Miss Jones's delicacy and sure technique.

Meeting Postponed By Pennwalt Board
description: The Pennwalt Corporation disclosed that its board of directors had voted to postpone the company's annual meeting, which had been scheduled for the last week of April. Pennwalt is trying to fend off a hostile $850 million bid from Centaur Partners, a New York investment firm. Centaur has requested that Pennwalt call a special meeting of its shareholders on March 30, so that it can try to place its own directors on the company's board. Pennwalt is seeking a court order to block that meeting.

title: Bridge

title: A Bold Effort to Save the Ozone Shield
description: Banning widely used chemicals is hard enough, especially in advance of proven harm. Environmentalists have long wondered whether political leaders could find the will to curb the chemical threat to the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere. But within the space of two days, the European Community and the United States, each of which accounts for roughly a third of global production, have taken giant strides toward such a ban.

title: Figure in Barry Inquiry Held In Caribbean on Drug Charge

title: Oglivie Out 2 Months
description: Ben Oglivie, a former outfielder for Milwaukee who spent the last two seasons playing in Japan, was attempting a comeback with the Brewers this spring. But the 40-year-old Oglivie injured his right knee in a workout on Tuesday and learned yesterday that he would miss the rest of spring training while undergoing two months of rehabilitation.(AP)

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 485,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Melvin E. Sims, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was part of an authorization on Jan. 25 of more than two million tons under the Export Enhancement Program. Mr. Sims said the wheat is scheduled for April shipment.

title: BUSH BACKS DEAL TO JOIN JAPANESE IN BUILDING AN F-16
description: The Bush Administration expects to notify Congress next week that it will go ahead with a $1.2 billion venture with Japan to make an advanced version of the F-16 fighter for the Japanese military, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Opera; Reason on Holiday (but in Love Isn't It Always?)
description: The Metropolitan Opera revived one of its more charming productions and introduced a fine mezzo-soprano when the company staged the season's first performance of Massenet's ''Werther'' on Thursday evening. Making her debut in the role of Charlotte, Kathleen Kuhlmann sang easily and sweetly and without strain, and she looked entirely at home in the role of the reticent lover. If we are to accept that an impetuous young man would commit suicide when rebuffed by a woman he barely knows, then Ms. Kuhlmann's Charlotte makes a reasonable cause.

title: N.B.A. Fines Mahorn
description: Rick Mahorn of the Pistons has been fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association for elbowing Mark Price of the Cleveland Cavaliers in the head in a game Detroit won Tuesday, the league announced yesterday. ''Throwing an elbow can be just as damaging as throwing a punch, and if it is deliberate, the penalties will be just as severe,'' said Rod Thorn, a league vice president. The fine is the largest ever imposed by the league for elbowing.

title: Mark M. Ravitch Is Dead at 78; A Surgeon, Professor and Author

title: Water Works, and Wars
description: LEAD: Ashokan Reservoir is beginning to look parched again, a complexion it seems to have worn more times than not in recent years. The problem with Ashokan, the second-largest of New York City's 19 reservoirs, is less a lack of rain than the public it is being called upon to serve. Out of touch with the reservoir system they're draining, New Yorkers use four times as much water per person than do residents of the Ulster County hamlets surrounding Ashokan, a giant basin here in the pretty foothills of the Catskill

title: Jets Sign a Free Agent
description: The Jets made their second investment in the National Football League free-agent market yesterday when they signed a safety, Rob Sterling, who was a rookie with the Philadelphia Eagles last season and was left unprotected as a free agent. The 5-foot-11-inch Sterling was sidelined for the year with a neck injury after being drafted on the sixth round out of the University of Maine. ''He's got speed, size and intelligence,'' said the Jets' pro-personnel director, Jim Royer.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; FINANCING A CAR
description: The rule of thumb for any car buyer is still to make the largest down payment possible, then to pay off the loan as quickly as possible. But because the price of most automobiles is now $10,000 or higher, there are more options, and financing periods have increased to an average of about 60 months. Remember that after 1990, interest rates on auto loans will longer be tax-deductible at all, unless the car is financed througha home-equity loan, whcih can put your home at risk. Car manufacturers like General Motors, Ford and Chrysler offer financing, and their current rates begin at about 5 perenct, but that's only for the first two years. By the fifth year of a 60-month loan, the rate will have escalated to about 10 percent. Here's a look at other types of car loans and their rates. Current Rate Year Ago Equity Loans 13.00% 10.00% Bank car loans 11.95 10.98 Credit unions 10.47 10.20 (Sources: The Bank Rate Monitor and Ford Motor Credit)

title: Vatican Orders Nuns in Jersey to End Protest
description: The Vatican yesterday ordered two cloistered nuns and two former nuns to end their five-month protest at a monastery in Morris Township, N.J., and leave the building.

title: EASTERN LINES UP NEW WORK FORCE
description: Officials of Eastern Airlines said yesterday that the company would contract out much of the maintenance on its airplanes to independent companies to help deal with the strike by its machinists' union.

title: Video of Park Melee
description: A video of last August's Tompkins Square Park violence will be shown at the Dia Art Foundation, 77 Wooster Street, at 7 o'clock tonight. The video, by Clayton Patterson, is nearly four hours long. Admission is free. Information: 431-9232.

title: RESULTS
description: TENNIS Graf and Mandlikova Advance: Top-seeded Steffi Graf and sixth-seeded Hana Mandlikova will face each other in a semifinal match of the United States hardcourt championships after winning their quarterfinal matches yesterday in San Antonio. Graf of West Germany defeated eighth-seeded Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., 6-3, 6-0. Mandlikova of Australia eliminated unseeded Camille Benjamin of Bakersfield, Calif., 7-5, 7-5.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 133, Hornets 109: Dominique Wilkins scored 35 points before sitting out the final 16 minutes as Atlanta crushed visiting Charlotte last night. (AP) Jazz 107, Heat 95: Karl Malone scored 34 points against Miami, whose 8-48 record is the worst in the league. (AP) Celtics 107, Mavericks 106: Dennis Johnson hit a go-ahead 3-point shot and a driving layup in the last two minutes for Boston. The Mavericks are now 0-9 in Boston.(AP) Pistons 96, Cavaliers 90: Isiah Thomas made two baskets to key a decisive 6-0 burst in the fourth quarter and Joe Dumars scored all 10 of his points in the final 5 minutes 10 seconds to decide a game between the league's top two teams.(AP) Bulls 102, Bucks 96: Michael Jordan scored 11 of his 28 points in a 19-9 spurt in the fourth quarter. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 4, Penguins 2: Mike Gartner and Michal Pivonka scored in a 69-second span in the second period last night, helping the Capitals end a home losing streak at four games. (AP) Oilers 7, Jets 4: Mark Messier and Jari Kurri scored twice each as visiting Edmonton won its fifth consecutive game.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Kingdom Wins Hurdles Event: Roger Kingdom of the United States surged ahead on the last hurdle to win the 60-meter hurdles race yesterday with a time of 7.43 seconds and clinch the first gold medal at the world indoor championships in Budapest. In the women's 60-meter dash, Nelli Cooman of the Netherlands beat Gwen Torrence of the United States for the gold medal. Cooman was just five hundredths of a second off her world record in winning the dash in 7.05 seconds, the fastest time this year and another championship record. Torrence set an American record by clocking 7.07. In the 200-meter dash, the American Kevin Little won the bronze medal after Robson da Silva of Brazil, the second-place finisher, was disqualified. (AP) SOCCER Portugal 2, Nigeria 0: Avel Silva scored in the final minute of the first half and Jorge Couto scored with 14 minutes left yesterday to give Portugal a 2-0 victory over Nigeria in the final of the FIFA Youth World Cup for players under 20 years old. The United States lost, 2-0, to Brazil in the third-place game in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.(AP) SKIING 12th Victory for Schneider: Vreni Schneider won the women's slalom in Furano, Japan, yesterday to set a World Cup record yesterday with her 12th victory of the season. Rudolf Nierlich of Austria won the men's giant slalom. (AP) SWIMMING Berkoff Breaks Records: David Berkoff of Harvard broke his own United States and National Collegiate Athletic Association records in the 100-yard backstroke final yesterday at the Eastern Seaboard championships at Harvard's Blodgett Pool. Berkoff had a time of 47.33 seconds. COLLEGE BASKETBALL Robert Morris 63, Long Island U. 52; Scott Shepherd scored 19 points and Vaughn Luton had 15 and 8 rebounds for top-seeded Robert Morris (20-8) in the semifinals of the Northeast Conference tournament. L.I.U. finished 9-19. (AP)

title: De Palma to Direct 'Bonfire'
description: Brian De Palma is to direct the film version of Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' for Warner Brothers, the studio announced yesterday. The movie will be produced by Jon Peters and Peter Guber, whose productions include ''Rain Man'' and ''The Color Purple.'' Michael Cristofer, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his play, ''The Shadow Box,'' will write the screenplay. Production is to begin this summer, although the cast has yet to be announced.

title: Pohl Flirts With PGA Record But Is Scorned Late in Round
description: Dan Pohl and his gallery at the Honda Classic thought that with five holes to play today he had a good opportunity to tie or break Al Geiberger's PGA Tour record of 59 for 18 holes.

title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

The bomb was retaliation for the arrest of several local merchants for selling counterfeit Rolex watches, the authorities said.

description: After more than five years of violence that killed 8,500 people and brought terror and destruction to their abundant and beautiful island, many in Sri Lanka are now hoping cautiously for a new beginning.

title: Lawyers Against Homelessness
description: The once-startling idea that poor people need legal counsel has become nearly a settled value in modern society, yet every day in every city the courts order evictions of people who don't have lawyers and can't afford them. Many of these tenants have valid legal defenses but the housing courts enter eviction decrees anyway, often not realizing that the law favors the tenant.

title: Sandberg to Set Mark For Second Basemen
description: Ryne Sandberg, through a contract agreement he reached with the Chicago Cubs yesterday in Mesa, Ariz., positioned himself to become the highest-paid second baseman in baseball history when he signs a two-year contract extension worth a guaranteed $4.6 million. Sandberg, who batted .269 last season with 19 home runs, will receive a $900,000 signing bonus, a $1.1 million salary next year and $2.2 million in 1991. The Cubs have an option for 1992 at $2.1 million. If they do not exercise it, they must pay the second baseman $400,000. Sandberg, a five-time All-Star who is being paid $890,000 in 1989 in the final season of a six-year contract, can also earn $250,000 each season in bonuses. . . . Mark McGwire of the Oakland Athletics, the American League rookie of the year in 1987, signed a one-year contract yesterday that will pay him $420,000 this season. The first baseman batted .260 with 32 homers and 99 runs batted in last season. Also signed yesterday was Cory Snyder, the Cleveland outfielder. He will earn $340,000.

title: Review/Dance; Cunningham's 'Eleven' With the Voices Muted
description: ''Eleven'' turned out to be one of Merce Cunningham's controversial dance works last year when it had its premiere at the Joyce Theater. On Thursday night it was seen for the first time at the City Center (131 West 55th Street), where the Merce Cunningham Dance Company is performing through next week. The change in venue may well make for a change in perception. Those who felt the accompanying sound of two men talking distracted from the dancing will now see movement come to the fore.

title: Gay Marriages: Make Them Legal
description: LEAD: ''In sickness and in health, 'til death do us part.'' With those familiar words, millions of people each year are married, a public affirmation of a private bond that both society and the newlyweds hope will endure. description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,500,000 for the quarter and $1,538,000 for the year, and the year also included a loss of $68,000 from operations of a discontinued segment.

title: Al's Formal Wear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the net in both quarters equaled less than one cent a share.

title: Bird Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $345,000 and $2,419,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss Year 1988 included a pretax gain of $1,602,000 from the sale of certain operations. Year 1987 included a pretax gain of $3,815,000, primarily from a joint-venture agreement.

title: Bailey Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $24,000 and $1,134,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: McEnroe Topples Lendl
description: John McEnroe continued his best start since 1985 when he reached the WCT Finals championship with a 6-7, 7-6, 6-2, 7-5 victory tonight over top-seeded Ivan Lendl.

title: Historical Society Names Head of Museum
description: The New-York Historical Society has named Holly Hotchner to a new position as the director of its museum. The appointment is part of an administrative reorganization of the society, which was shaken last summer by disclosures that its finances had been mismanaged and some of its paintings and manuscripts had deteriorated in storage. Ms. Hotchner will remain the society's chief conservator, a position she has held for nearly five years.

title: Zentec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $249,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and after a tax credit of $140,000 and a gain from a change in accounting principle of $240,000.

title: Koch's Lawyer Says Testimony by Aide Causes Him Concern
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch's lawyer said yesterday that he had ''concerns'' about whether Joseph DeVincenzo, a former mayoral aide, had told the truth when he denied forwarding to the Talent Bank cover letters from politicians who endorsed job applicants.

title: Goetz Parole Denied; Must Serve Till September
description: Bernhard H. Goetz's legal tactic to get out of jail early backfired yesterday when his application for early release was rejected by the New York State Parole Board.

title: Indian Anger Over Bhopal
description: In a rare emotional outburst, India's Supreme Court, under growing attack for settling the Bhopal gas disaster case between the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation for $470 million last month, today denounced pressure and agitations to reverse the verdict.

title: Calstar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Concorde Career Colleges reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
McFarlane Is Fined $20,000 and Sentenced to 2 Years' Probation
description: Robert C. McFarlane, a Congressional aide who rose to be President Ronald Reagan's national security adviser, was fined $20,000 and sentenced to two years' probation today for withholding information from Congress about the Iran-contra affair.

title: Beware The Tides Of March
description: You thought March Madness was a clever phrase describing the college basketball tournament. This week it has taken on a new meaning as the feeling grows that sports is spiraling out of control, like a decadent empire on the eve of a great fall.

title: Realist Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $36,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $54,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $74,000 for the quarter and $390,000 for the year.

title: Fix the Thrifts, or Pay and Pay
description: How much will it cost to clean up the savings and loan mess? The best answer at this point is a bundle, and it will be higher still if the thrifts continue to prevail with the help of their pals in Congress. Rather than haggle over the cost, it is far more important that Congress move quickly to reshape the thrift business.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $244,440 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Student, 13, Brings Handgun to School
description: A 13-year-old public school student was arrested yesterday after bringing a loaded .25-caliber handgun stuffed in his bookbag into a Brooklyn junior high school, the police said.

title: Red Eagle Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Village Super Market Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
Venezuela May Halt Debt Payments
description: Days after Venezuela was rocked by street violence over new austerity measures, President Carlos Andres Perez said today that his Government might be forced to suspend all payments on the country's $33 billion in public and private foreign debt.

title: School Board Elections Draw Few New Faces
description: Despite efforts by New York City school and community leaders to encourage more people to seek election to community school boards, only 668 candidates have filed qualifying petitions to run, virtually the same number as for the last election, three years ago.

title: Ehrilch Bober Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $81,000 and $221,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MAI Sets Proxy Fight At Prime Computer
description: Frustrated so far in its four-month-long effort to gain control of Prime Computer Inc. through a hostile $1.3 billion tender offer, MAI Basic Four Inc., announced today that it would undertake a proxy fight to gain control of the Natick, Mass., company's board of directors.

title: Unearthing an Elizabethan Theater
description: Julian Bowsher, a senior archeologist with the Museum of London, stood in the middle of a construction site, surrounded by dirt, earth movers and big clumps of chalk. ''What we find here might well change the history books,'' he said, striding across the site in his muddy boots.

title: Leading Indicators Climb 0.6%
description: The Government's main economic-forecasting index climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the second consecutive sizable increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Charles Gillespie, 60, Held 5 Years by Hanoi
description: Charles Gillespie Jr., a retired Navy captain who was shot down over Vietnam and spent five and a half years in Hanoi as a prisoner of the North Vietnamese, was killed Tuesday in the crash of a civilian plane. He was 60 years old.

title: Drugs Are Absolutely Everybody's Problem; Let's Go to the Source
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotels Letting Guests Choose Checkout Times
description: The bane of many hotel guests is the early hour at which they must check out of their rooms so the hotel can get them ready for the next occupants. Those catching evening planes after business meetings or anxious to freshen up before the end of the day are among the people particularly inconvenienced by normal checkout hours, usually from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M.

title: Reviews/Music; A Matinee by Masur
description: In the second week of his visit with the New York Philharmonic, Kurt Masur is leading the orchestra in music by Sergei Prokofiev and Richard Strauss, with Philip Myers, the orchestra's principal hornist, as the soloist in Strauss's Horn Concerto No. 1.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press on Thursday, about ethnic strife in Yugoslavia, misidentified the flag carried by a Serbian youth outside Parliament. It was the flag of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, not the Yugoslav national flag.

title: Nucorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest quarter and year results reflected the sale of Nucorp's 50 percent interest in an oil and gas operation.

title: Following His Father
description: John Kelly, son of the late Dan Kelly, will take his father's place as a play-by-play announcer for the St. Louis Blues in their home game against the Detroit Red Wings today, and may become a regular broadcaster for the team next season. Dan Kelly described Blues games for 20 years before his death last month. The younger Kelly, who is in his first season as a broadcaster with the Rangers, worked one Blues game last season.(AP)

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results were increased by 14 cents a share from a reduction in LIFO reserves. The 1987 quarter and year results were increased by about 13 cents a share for year-end adjustments for inventory valuation reserves and accrued expenses.

title: Review/Theater; A Love Story Set in Stalin's Russia
description: ''The Paper Gramophone,'' which is having its American premiere at Hartford Stage, is both an artifact of Stalinist Russia and a gentle love story about the purity that can survive in a repressive environment. Given its dramatic limitations, it is a touching evocation of a young woman's attempt to reach beyond despair to a kind of idealism.

title: Save the Salmon From Poachers
description: At the beginning of the year, Federal agents broke a multi-million dollar salmon smuggling operation with a ''sting'' that apprehended a Japanese fish broker and an American businessman. Both were charged with attempting to import fish, illegally taken by Taiwanese fisherman on the high seas, into Japan. The case serves to underline that in the Pacific Northwest, Canada and Alaska, salmon fishing and processing is a big business - and a business in big trouble.

title: Connaught Biosciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $900,000 and $4,400,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Delta Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gooden Suit Settled
description: Dwight Gooden of the Mets filed two lawsuits in connection with his arrest for assault in Tampa, Fla., on Dec. 13, 1986. One was settled this week when Tampa General Hospital said it would pay Gooden a sum less than $10,000 for releasing information on his blood-alcohol level, an action Gooden said ruined his chances for commercial endorsements and hurt his reputation. The other suit, against three Tampa police officers, is scheduled to go to trial in Hillsborough Circuit Court onMarch 27. (AP)

title: Worthen Banking reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter results included recovery of $400,000 from the bankruptcy estates of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman. The year-ago quarter and year results included recovery of $12.1 million from the bankruptcy estates of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman; the year also included a $2.4 million extraordinary gain on the termination of the corporation's defined benefit pension plan. Latest year results included $7,400,000 from the settlement of stockholder derivative lawsuits, $4,900,000 in net from the recovery from the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman bankruptcy estates and $900,000 income from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Letter: On Science Policy; Bush Needs a Rational Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Islamabad Journal; A Feminist Unswerving In a 'Very Macho' Land
description: Ask any Pakistani feminist to name the most accomplished woman in national politics today, and the answer may not be Benazir Bhutto but Abida Hussain.

description: b-After a special charge of $4,251,000. c-Included a special gain of $6,297,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Gunman at I.R.A. Rite Jailed For Life in Killing 3 Mourners
description: A Protestant man was imprisoned for life today for attacking an Irish Republican Army funeral and killing three mourners with bullets and grenades.

title: Cobb Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said $767,000 of the latest 6-month loss is attributed to the London Mine, of which $533,000 is non- cash fixed asset cost recovery through depreciation and depletion. The balance of the loss is due to reduced oil and gas prices and production levels.

title: Edward L. Ballard, Executive, 47
description: Edward L. Ballard, a former director of inventory control for Saks Fifth Avenue, died Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan after suffering complications from a heart transplant performed on Jan. 1. He was 47 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: The Lesson of Vietnam Is Still to Be Learned

description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year loss reflected a non-recurring charge of $6,000,000 taken at the end of the quarter to cover the cost of disposing of 18 unwanted locations.

title: Canal Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter net was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements. The 1988 revenue has been reclassified to conform with the current year's presentation.

title: 'Meet or Beat' Pledge: But What Does It Mean?
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's new pledge to ''meet or beat the competition's price'' is an increasingly common strategy used by retailers to back up their claims of everyday low prices.

title: 11 Students Set to Study On a Kibbutz
description: In an unusual learning experiment, a group of Brooklyn high school students, most of whom have never journeyed beyond their own neighborhoods, will begin 10 weeks of classes next week on a kibbutz in Israel.

title: Patents; Melanin in Sun Lotion
description: Frances C. Gaskin, a nursing teacher in Albany, has developed a sun-tanning lotion incorporating melanin, the skin pigment that absorbs ultraviolet rays. Dermatologists have long known that melanin can protect the skin, but Ms. Gaskin said no one had determined how to dissolve the compound to incorporate it into a cosmetic composition. Ms. Gaskin said she was negotiating with several companies to license the compound.

title: Ohio Art Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
North Defense Allowed Inquiry on Superiors
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that defense lawyers could explore the roles of Ronald Reagan and George Bush in aiding the Nicaraguan rebels so that Mr. North could prove his contention that his activities were sanctioned by his superiors.

title: Republic Automotive Parts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

Giving Public U.S. Data: Private Purveyors Say No
description: The Federal Maritime Commission has become the focus of an unusual dispute over its plan to make the information it collects more accessible to the public.

title: Despite Promises, Retailers Hold Off on Matching Sears
description: Several of the largest American retailers promise not to be undersold by Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Officer Slain In a Struggle In Flatbush
description: A 25-year-old plainclothes police officer on the lookout for street robberies was shot and killed in Brooklyn early yesterday, possibly with his own gun, as he and his partner struggled with two men they had tried to question.

title: Portec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter included a tax credit of $248,000. The latest year included a tax credit of $1,003,000, a pre-tax gain of $3,022,000 related to the sale of substantially all of the assets of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Portec Lease Corp., and an expense of $2.5 million related to a judgment and associated legal expenses rendered against the company in federal court.

title: Dynamics Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $321,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary charge of $4,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $100,000 for the year. Latest quarter and year continuing operations included the company's proportionate share, $4,832,000 of a charge by CTS Corp. to CTS' continuing operations. The company said year-ago quarter and year included a charge of $1,734,000 to establish a reserve for unrealized losses of the company's then current marketable securities. The company also said the latest year included a gain of $3,964,000, or 98 cents a share, from a patent award.

description: b-Net income

title: D. T. Corwin Jr. to Wed Amy Ludlow
description: Mr. and Mrs. George C. Ludlow of Elizabethtown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Chamberlain Ludlow, to Douglas Thomas Corwin Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Corwin of Washington, Pa. No date has been set for the wedding.

title: PRO & CON: A U.S. Proposal to Relax Agricultural Trade Barriers; Can a Free Market Insure the World's Food Security? THE WORLD
description: IN the name of agricultural self-sufficiency, nations pay a high price in the form of farm subsidies, foreign trade restraints and the stockpiling of mountains of grain.

title: Afghan Invasion Began in Political Murder; Like Iran, Not Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Dirty War Grows Dirtier In El Salvador
description: The tape-recorded threat, apparently from a left-wing group, arrived at the radio station here and was quickly broadcast: Unless the right-wing Mayor resigned within 48 hours, he would be killed.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS;
RECENT RELEASES: CLASSICAL
description: LEAD: Stephen Albert: 'RiverRun' National Symphony Orchestra, Mstislav Rostropovich, conductor. Delos D/CD 1016; CD only.

title: The Idealist vs. the Bureaucrat
description: AND now the Paper Mill Playhouse, the showplace of splashy musicals and establishment comedies, has caught up with the state's new-play craze and come up with ''Beyond a Reasonable Doubt,'' which runs through March 19.

title: Patients' Rights
description: MY DOCTOR put me on a beta blocker,'' a friend told me last week. ''I hate the side effects, but I couldn't argue with him.'' Many, perhaps most, patients feel that way: they don't really have much say in the matter. Yet, according to a famous New York Court of Appeals decision in 1914, ''Every human being of adult years and sound mind has a right to determine what shall be done with his own body.'' A doctor who does anything to the patient without consent can be sued for having committed battery, malpractice and civil-rights violations (unless the patient is incapable of giving consent).

title: Lisa Sachs to Wed Richard S. Baum
description: An August wedding is planned by Lisa Sachs and Richard Steven Baum, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Sachs of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: The addition of Kiki Vandeweghe will certainly improve the team. I think he is a great shooter. There is no question in my mind that Kiki can shoot the lights out. He can bring to this already respected club a new, positive dimension. In my mind, he will be the 1989 Knick version of Mychal Thompson's addition to the Lakers. OMER AKYOL Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Lumet Is Honored by Directors Guild
description: Sidney Lumet has been named an honorary life member of the Directors Guild of America, the guild's national board announced Thursday. Mr. Lumet began his career as a movie director with ''12 Angry Men'' in 1957; his films include ''The Fugitive Kind,'' ''A View From the Bridge,'' ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' ''Fail-Safe,'' ''The Pawnbroker,'' ''Serpico,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''Network'' and, most recently, ''Running on Empty,''

title: After His Dog's 'Approval,' the Time Is Right to Remarry
description: IT is an image branded on our minds and memories. Gary Cooper, in the movie ''Sergeant York,'' is silhouetted against an evening sky, sitting on a ledge studying the Bible and trying to make sense of a world torn by global conflict.

title:
ART;
Kendrick's Energetic Sculptures
description: LEAD: THE spotlight is on Mel Kendrick these days. In addition to ''Essays,'' an exhibition of 16 small wood sculptures at the Lehman College Art Gallery, a wooden box of his from the 1970's, with slats that deviate from the straight and true, is a key piece in the survey of geometric abstraction at the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Mega Firms
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Forced Flowers Bring Spring Indoors
description: LEAD: THERE is no better way to escape the winter blahs than to fill your house with forced spring flowers from your own garden.

title: Steroid Testimony: What Effect?
description: The stunning testimony this week by a leading Canadian track coach that Ben Johnson and other athletes regularly used drugs to enhance their performance may have only minimal effect on worldwide efforts to reduce drug use.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Making House and Land a Joint Venture
description: LEAD: A VERMONT house and barn built around 1830 and being reconstructed on a two-acre lot in Wainscott is an example of how builders and people who own land are forming joint-venture development partnerships.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls. I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over. What kind of adhesive should be used, and what paint can then be used over the canvas? Can the canvas be removed later?

title: At Collar or Wrist, Jewelry for Men Glitters Once Again
description: Dogs, not diamonds, are a man's best friend. However, men are not immune to the lure of a few appropriately placed baubles. From cuff links to tie bars to collar pins, masculine details that once were traditional have returned in force to business and formal dressing.

title: Title Search
description: TITLES ARE IMPORTANT to novelists and should be important to the readers of novels.

title: BOGGS AFFAIR FALLOUT COULD SEND RED SOX OFF TO SLOW START
description: Conflict. The theme prevails throughout baseball, and spring training has hardly begun. It comes in an assortment of sizes and kinds. It always has, always will.

title: Texas-Oklahoma: Tests Weighed
description: The University of Texas is considering including mandatory steroid testing in a new contract for the Texas-Oklahoma football series, DeLoss Dodds, the Texas athletic director, said today.

title: Christopher Charles Hart, Executive, Weds Campbell Lane in Connecticut
description: Campbell Noble Lane, a daughter of Mrs. W. Henry Lane of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., and William Noble Lane 3d of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Christopher Charles Hart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Edward Hart Jr. of Laguna Niguel, Calif. The Rev. James D. Paget performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield.

title: It's Academics
description: Topping the 1989 GTE Academic all-America men's basketball team are Michael Smith of Brigham Young University and Alec Kessler of the University of Georgia. Smith, a 6-10 senior center from Hacienda, Calif., averaged 26 points a game and Kessler, a 6-10 junior forward was the leading rebounder in the Southeastern Conference with an average of 10.1 a game as well as averaging 20 points.

title: Using a Blimp for Pollution Control: No Reason to Giggle
description: A RECENT newspaper article detailed the commissioning by the United States Navy of a giant blimp to be used in conjunction with sophisticated radar equipment and listening devices for the nation's defense. The blimp, which will be nearly the size of three football fields, will, when fully equipped, cost $170 million.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Stephen C. Byelick;
Local Effects of Savings and Loan Crisis
description: LEAD: FOR months, there have been news reports about the banking crisis among savings and loan institutions, particularly those in Texas and California. The financial problems are so large that the Federal agency that insures deposits at savings associations - the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation - itself is threatened with bankruptcy.

title: Semifinal Features Bronx Showdown
description: Steve Post, the Stevenson coach,thinks that his basketball team is underrated.

title: Risa Klein to Wed
description: Risa Meryl Klein, the daughter of William Klein of Sands Point, L.I., and Cynthia Blueweiss of New York, and Robert Andrew Greene, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Greene of Basking Ridge, N.J., plan to be married May 6. Miss Klein, a graduate of Brandeis University, is in the account management department of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, a New York advertising agency. Mr. Greene, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a sales manager in New York for the Kronish Agency of the New England insurance company.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the founding congress of the first Soviet bar association referred incorrectly to the name it selected. The congress adopted an amendment changing the name from the Soviet Advocates' Association to the Soviet Advocates'

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
High Cards, Bigger Egos
description: LEAD: HE (eyes blazing, face reddening): What are you doing? You should have made two diamonds! She: I threw off a good trick. All I have to do is trump - He: You should have made it. You're a moron! What did you have in diamonds? The six? You should have played the six.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday about ''Day One,'' a TV drama about the building of the first atomic bomb, James F. Brynes was misidentified, and his involvement in the decision to drop the bomb on Japan was incorrectly described. He was Secretary of State under President Truman and argued in favor of using the bomb.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: The Knicks aren't just winning without a 30-point-per-game forward; they're dominating. I don't know what Rick Pitino or Al Bianchi studied in college, but it sure wasn't chemistry. CLIFF COURTNEY New York

title: Clare C. Franklin To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garrett Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Clare Carruthers Franklin to Victor V. Duran, the son of Victor Duran Acosima of Mexico City and Janice Duran of Potomac, Md.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Brunch; Suburban Delights
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. C. J. Thorne

title: 'Wire's Edge,' Account of SS Women, in Norwalk
description: ''WE'RE doing the best that we can under the most difficult of circumstances,'' says Christel, ever the pragmatist. ''And everyone does his part for the greater glory of the Reich.''

description: AT first blush, a loft building on East 22d Street that has been converted into a residential co-op has little in common with a privately owned country club and golf course on Staten Island.

title: WHEN THE CZAR DEFERRED TO ELIJAH
description: YIDDISH FOLKTALES Edited by Beatrice Silverman Weinreich. Translated by Leonard Wolf. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $21.95.

title: FICTION
description: FIFTY YEARS OF ETERNAL VIGILANCE: And Other Stories. By Carolyn Thorman. (Peachtree, $14.95.) The characters in Carolyn Thorman's first collection of stories are quirky Lithuanian- and Polish-Americans with varying attitudes about the benefits, and costs, of assimilation. They wouldn't understand the word, but they know everything about the idea. In ''Society for the Benefit of the Daughters of Vilnius,'' Valiute Kalaikas watches dumbfounded as the name of her organization is changed to the Southeastern Baltimore Women's Club. Valiute, however, gathers up her courage when, a few minutes later, she is appointed secretary. ''It just so happens I don't read or write English,'' she tells the shocked social climbers, ''so I'll be doing Daughter business in Lithuanian.'' Ms. Thorman's interest in the Old World's uneasy peace with the new is most gracefully expressed in the title story. Its heroine, an old woman named Aldonna, is upset at the thought of being buried under a synthetic urn and plastic lilies. So she contracts for candles, pine branches, flowers and ribbons on her grave. She wants them provided for eternity. ''I don't contract for eternity,'' replies Radas, the Polish landscaper who does maintenance work at the cemetery. So they compromise on 50 years. In person, Ms. Thorman's characters would probably be prickly, even unappealing. But she makes them intriguing and sympathetic. Unfortunately, the disjointedness of the immigrant theme often makes ''Fifty Years of Eternal Vigilance'' difficult for the reader; just when we're comfortable with one set of eccentricities, we're presented with a whole new one. My guess is that Ms. Thorman's characters would do better if they were given the elbowroom of a novel.

title: Crucial Talks on Reducing Conventional Arms Open This Week in Vienna
description: Western and East bloc nations will open conventional arms talks next week in Vienna aimed at reducing the risk of war and easing more than 40 years of military confrontation in Europe.

title: Venezuela
description: To the Editor: Reading your Dec. 11 article ''At Large in the Caribbean,'' I noted that the Venezuelan island of Margarita was not on the map. Margarita is a bona fide Caribbean resort island. It has direct scheduled and charter airline service from North America and other Caribbean destinations.

title: Inflation Is Looking Like It's Going to Cost
description: HOW much inflation is too much? And when the people who make economic policy in Washington decide the answer to that question, what happens then?

title: Lisa Amy Stern Engaged to Marry Craig Steven Lax
description: Lisa Amy Stern and Craig Steven Lax are planning a September wedding, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Martin T. Stern of Manhasset, L.I., have announced. Mr. Lax is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Lax of Englewood, N.J.

title: Olive Oil Replaces Butter in Many Dishes
description: MORE and more, I find myself using olive oil for cooking instead of butter. For someone raised in the English tradition of butter on everything - even baked beans - this is something of an accomplishment. But nowadays I find that I like olive oil even on something as butter-prone as a baked potato.

description: The closed and competitive world of symphony orchestras has been shaken in recent weeks by an extraordinary show of political pressure to change the hiring practices of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.

title: HE HAD HER IN THE PALM OF HIS HAND
description: LEAD: ON THE OTHER HAND A Life Story. By Fay Wray. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

description: LEAD: UNDER a measure that became effective Jan. 1, the State of New York, for the first time in its history, now requires Indians to add taxes on cigarettes sold to non-Indians.

title: The Waiting Game: Student Is a Pawn
description: WE are waiting for the letter that will notify us that my daughter, a high school senior, has been accepted at one of the colleges of her choice. I am finding this whole period less than amusing.

title: Shoreham: The Hydro Option
description: The letter from Herbert Jaffe (''What if Shoreham Doesn't Open?'' Feb. 19) contains several errors and at least one omission.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Cos Cob Power Plant; The Preservationists Seem to Be Running Out of Steam
description: THEY'RE taking it in little steps at the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, asking only that the Town Selectmen consider reusing the old Cos Cob Power Plant. But the Selectmen have resisted anything but demolition of the 1907 Mission-style structure for a new housing development.

title: >'Ageless' Composer Is Honored
description: LEAD: AS far as Elie Siegmeister is concerned, the current celebration of his 80th birthday ''could go on and on.''

title: WITH CLENCHED SOUL
description: MASCAGNI By David Stivender. Illustrated. 372 pp. White Plains, N.Y.: Pro/Am Music Resources. $35.
