title: A Magazine Became a Giant
description: Time Inc. is the nation's leading magazine publisher, the owner of Time, Life, Fortune, Money, Sports Illustrated and People, whose collective circulation exceeds 17 million copies and whose names have become household words.

title: SOLIDARITY WITH THE DOOMED
description: LEAD: THE GOVERNMENT OF THE TONGUE Selected Prose 1978-1987. By Seamus Heaney. 170 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Mysteries Of Cassette Love
description: There's a world of difference between the ones worth having forever and the ones that are only good for an evening of fun. I refer, of course, to videocassettes, and to the remarkable lack of overlap between titles that become popular rentals and titles that are sold. What is it that makes ''Lethal Weapon'' (No. 23 on Billboard's Top 40 sales chart last week) a candidate for anyone's permanent library, whereas ''Die Hard'' (last week's No. 1 rental) is only a one-night stand? Does the person willing to rent ''Arthur 2 on the Rocks'' (No. 21 rental) have anything in common with the one who buys ''Top Gun'' (No. 21 sales)? Who's been renting ''Return to Snowy River'' or buying permanent copies of ''Dr. Zhivago''?

title: Washington Expects a Tax Bill, but a Minor One
description: There will be a tax bill this year, but it is unlikely to involve any major overhaul of the tax code or substantial new tax increases. So goes the prevailing wisdom among tax policy makers and lobbyists as the Bush Administration and Congress take their first tentative steps toward negotiation on the budget for the 1990 fiscal year.

title: Mega Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: SHARE OF HONOR. By Ralph Graves. (Holt, $19.95.) From 1942, when the Philippines fell to the Japanese, until Douglas MacArthur led the liberating invasion in 1944, America's principal colony lay under harsh, often brutal occupation. Ralph Graves, Time Inc.'s former editorial director, who grew up in Manila as the stepson of the United States High Commissioner and took part in the liberation of the islands as an Army Air Forces sergeant, uses the occupation as the framework for his first novel, ''Share of Honor.'' This fast-paced and wide-ranging story follows the fortunes of both Filipinos and Americans as they resist the enemy as spies, guerrillas and prisoners of war - or accept it. The Japanese are also brought in, as well as an American intelligence officer on MacArthur's staff, who acts as a chorus to Mr. Graves's well-researched portrayal of the imperious and imperial MacArthur. Mr. Graves also skillfully reminds the reader that the prewar Philippines were for many Americans a lovely, cheap tropical haven from the stresses and storms of Depression-era America. Mr. Graves's good guys may be a trifle too good and oversimplified, but this very readable novel contains graphic, detailed and dramatic descriptions of prison camps, battles, the urban and rural occupation conditions and, of course, that enduring scar on United States-Japanese relations, the Bataan Death March.

title: England's Rothschild Chateau
description: MY first great architectural encounter beyond American shores took place on an autumnal weekend in the Loire Valley in France. Silhouetted against a gray sky was the majestic roof line of the 16th-century Chateau of Chambord, with its symmetrically massed turrets, towers and cupolas. It made a lasting impression on someone reared on the simplicity of American Colonial architecture. Not long ago, a similar image surfaced in England on another autumn day as I looked down an avenue of oaks near Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire to the grand roof patterns of Waddesdon Manor. Here the exhuberant stacking of high-pitched roofs, cupolas, decorated chimneys and pedimented dormers read like a compendium of best ingredients from the French Renaissance chateaus of Francois I. Baron Ferdinand de Rothschild, who built Waddesdon between 1874 and 1889, wrote in a memoir about his own formative experience in seeing the old chateaus of the Valois, and he had the good fortune to be able to act upon it. In a sense, the Rothschilds are Europe's most European family. Having intermarried and moved from city to city, the family has always subscribed to European culture as a whole rather than that of one country. These descendants of a Frankfurt banker, Mayer Amschel Rothschild, who established the original family banking firm in five European cities, have been statesmen in their own countries. As collectors, and scientists, their family homes became repositories of culture and knowledge, so much so that in the world of interior design, one may even refer to le style Rothschild, a timeless period, but with roots in 17th- and 18th-century France.

title: Asbestos Expert Asks Labor to Press for Research
description: The doctor was blunt with the asbestos workers and labor leaders. ''We can tell you who's going to get it and when he's going to get it,'' Dr. Irving J. Selikoff said. He was talking about cancer.

title: Northern Italian in a Colonial Setting
description: THE quasi-Colonial decor may be a surprise to those crossing the threshold of Casagrande, but it should not dilute one's enjoyment of this northern Italian restaurant in Wallingford, just off Exit 66 of the Wilbur Cross Parkway.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Soft Housing Market Expected to Linger
description: LEAD: THE state's residential market entered 1989 with rising mortgage rates and a lingering oversupply of new and resale houses that will result in a continued soft market for most of the year, according to real estate professionals.

title: Figure in an Inquiry On Capital's Mayor Faces Drug Charges
description: One of the central figures in a pair of Federal investigations of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was arrested in the Virgin Islands on Friday on charges of selling cocaine to undercover agents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: Opulent Enamels From China Recall An Imperial Taste
description: Chinese Cloisonne enamels - wildly colorful, frequently outsized and embellished with gilded dragons, elephant heads and mythical beasts - represent an imperial taste rarely exhibited in New York. A comprehensive selection of 80 fishbowls, urns, vases, candlesticks and incense burners, assembled over 40 years by Pierre Uldry, a Zurich banker, is on view at the Asia Society Galleries, 725 Park Avenue (at 71st Street), through May 16.

title: The Kirov Claims Its Balanchine Legacy
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE DIED IN 1983, BUT two weeks ago his legacy returned to the land and city of his birth. For the first time, works by the master choreographer - ''Scotch Symphony'' and ''Theme and Variations'' - were danced by the Kirov Ballet, direct descendant of the company in which Balanchine himself performed in the early 1920's. It was on the present Kirov stage, in the theater then known as the Maryinsky, that Balanchine appeared as a student in walk-on roles and then as a promising young professional dancer before emigrating to the West in 1924. Today's dancers study at the school where he along with such other luminaries as Pavlova, Nijinsky and Ulanova trained.

title: Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age; Sexist Generalization
description: To the Editor:

title: Zapping A Season Of Opera
description: If life were as easily controlled as a movie on the VCR, who could resist the urge to toy with those buttons? Reverse and fast forward would probably get the most play, though an occasional Faust might opt for the stop mode or at least the slo-mo. Looking back at the new productions offered this season by the Metropolitan Opera, I myself find the erase button most tempting. Zap: there goes ''Salome.'' Zap, zap: bye-bye ''Erwartung'' and ''Bluebeard's Castle.'' In a charitable mood, I might reluctantly spare ''Giulio Cesare'' and ''Aida,'' though neither stands out in memory as a momument to the arts of operatic direction and design.

title: WORKS IN PROGRESS
description: LEAD: IT IS PERHAPS THE ONLY SCIENtific research that employs Donald Duck as a lab assistant. At the Smith-Kettlewell Eye Research Institute in San Francisco, Dr. Anthony M. Norcia is recording the brain responses of infants to visual stimuli flashed on a computer screen. He is trying to learn what babies see, a mystery, of course, because they can't tell us.

title: Bronx Apartment Fire Kills 2
description: Two people died from smoke inhalation early yesterday after fire raced through their ground-floor apartment in a five-story building at 36 Bedford Park Boulevard in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx. The police said the victims, Bernadette Dolan, 31 years old, and Robert Dolan, 39, were believed to have been smoking in bed. No others were injured in the one-alarm fire, which was brought under control at 2:45 A.M., and damage was confined to the one apartment, the police said.

title: THE CASE FOR TAKEOVERS
description: Thank you for running Carl C. Icahn's ''Case for Takeovers'' (Jan. 29), in rebuttal to the article by Robert Reich on leveraged buyouts. It is interesting to note that Mr. Reich is from Harvard's school of government, not its business school. That might explain his comfort with keeping incompetence in companies.

title: Ousted Omaha Mayor Seeking Re-election
description: Former Mayor Mike Boyle, defeated in a 1987 election on the issue of removing him from office, has announced that he will run again for the city's top job.

title: P.L.O. Rejects Warning by U.S. on Attacks
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization today rejected warnings by the United States against further attempted guerrilla raids on Israel.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Bamberg
description: To the Editor: Olivier Bernier's article ''Discovering Old Germany in Bamberg'' (Travel, Jan. 29) is most illuminating. However, if my memory serves me right, when I visited the Bamberg cathedral many years ago, I was shocked by two juxtaposed statues, one representing Christianity, with smiling lips, the other, blindfolded, representing Judaism.

title: Two Corporate Plans for Road Compete
description: LEAD: THE recently announced plan by the Schulman Realty Group to build a 1.2-million-square-foot office complex at 1000 Westchester Avenue includes a road proposal that could jeopardize one put forth by the nearby Centre at Purchase office complex.

title: GRAND OLD ATHENS IN THE LAND OF GRAND OLE OPRY
description: There are a fair number of new skyscrapers in this growing city, including one by the slick New York firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox that endeavors, with mixed success, to give distinction to this city's skyline. It may be the best new tower in town, but it cannot, alas, hold a candle to the two buildings that mark Nashville as truly special: the Parthenon and the Opryland Hotel. Here is where Nashville arrives, for better or for worse, on the architectural map.

title: The Networks Fight Back, Finally
description: Once upon a time, a giant roamed a vast kingdom, telling tales that made people laugh and cry, and helping merchants peddle their wares. But after a slew of little fable makers appeared, telling tales just as the giant did, he was forced into battle to reclaim his treasured place in the kingdom.

title: A Champion Partnership in Dance
description: DAVID ROSINSKY, a dancer, sometimes twirls his partner, Michele Evans, so that her body barely skims the floor. At other times, he spins her above his head in a move that the two call the ''helicopter.'' In another move, Mrs. Evans seems to kneel on Mr. Rosinky's shoulder. ''I don't know what to call that, but it's interesting,'' Mr. Rosinky said.

title: Yachtwomen As Commodores
description: I recently read about the lady commodore of the Mastic Beach Yacht Club [ ''Long Island Journal,'' Jan. 8 ] .

title: One Man's Joke
description: To the Editor:

title: CEZANNE: CREATING THE FUTURE SINGLE-HANDED
description: If ever a show had competition, it is ''Cezanne: The Early Years 1859-1872'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The competition in question is not from any other artist, but from Cezanne himself - or, to be precise, from the supreme importance of late Cezanne in the accepted hierarchies of art.

title: Jeanne Marie Galvin Plans To Wed Richard Smith Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Galvin of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Point Lookout, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Jeanne Marie Galvin to Richard Stanley Smith Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of West Hartford, Conn. An October wedding is planned. Miss Galvin is a clinical research associate at Pfizer Central Research, a division of the Pfizer pharmaceutical company in Groton, Conn. She graduated from Duke University and received a master of science degree at the University of Connecticut. Mr. Smith, a graduate of Duke and its law school, is an associate at the Hartford law firm of Murtha, Cullina, Richter & Pinney.

title: FROM GEORGE TO SHINING GEORGE
description: THE AMERICAN AGE United States Foreign Policy at Home and Abroad Since 1750. By Walter LaFeber. Illustrated. 759 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Reviews/Music; A Program Built on 'Pierrot Lunaire'
description: It is not hard to imagine what so impressed Stravinsky when he heard Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire'' for the first time in the winter of 1912. Three-quarters of a century later, a listener can still be made to feel unsettled by the music's urgency and strangeness.

title: A Hunger to Write
description: Born in 1921 in Robinson, a small town in rural Illinois, James Jones was a curiously American phenomenon: the great novelist who comes out of nowhere, equipped only with talent and a fierce determination to write. Jones's love of literature was untutored, innate. Without money for college - his father was an alcoholic dentist whose fate is described in these letters - and without prospects, Jones enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1939 and was shipped off to Hawaii. Transferred to the infantry, he was subjected to the ordeal of hand-to-hand combat at Guadalcanal. It was during these traumatic years that he acquired the material for two of his greatest novels, ''From Here to Eternity'' and ''The Thin Red Line.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: No-Smoking Area Not Smoke-Free, Study Finds

title: Venezuela Aid Package Taking Shape
description: The Bush Administration expects to complete arrangements to extend an emergency $450 million loan to the Government of Venezuela ''in a few days,'' a senior Treasury official said today.

title: WAITER, THERE'S AN EAR IN MY STEW
description: THE END OF TRAGEDY Four Novellas. By Rachel Ingalls. 191 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls. I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over. What kind of adhesive should be used, and what paint can then be used over the canvas? Can the canvas be removed later?

title: Grant to Cooper Union Honors Founder's Spirit
description: As a poor teen-ager, Albert Nerken dreamed of becoming an engineer, prospering and doing ''something for society,'' in the spirit of Peter Cooper, the 19th-century inventor, industrialist and philanthropist.

title: Miss Donaldson Plans to Marry a Physician
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Donaldson Jr. of Millington, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Donaldson, to Dr. J. Michael Haering, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Haering of Bethlehem, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Ex-Migrant Worker Struggles to Keep Farm Museum Alive
description: WENTWORTH T. PHILLIPS said he had always banked on simple basics like self-sufficiency and knowing the skills of the laboring class to make it in life. Based on those tenets, he founded the Bloomfield Farm Implement Museum in 1980. As he will explain over and over, he started his museum with ''the kids, the kids, the kids,'' especially inner-city children, in mind.

title: Timing Crucial in Shoreham Accord
description: LEAD: WHEN Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced a new accord with the Long Island Lighting Company last week to close the $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear-power plant, the clock began running on what may be the final attempt to resolve Long Island's most perplexing issue.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Cuisine and a Cozy Atmosphere
description: LEAD: TRANSPLANTED New Yorkers who miss the casual coziness of the Italian restaurants in Little Italy may wish to check out Rispoli's, a year-old restaurant tucked away off the main street in Montclair. However, to find Rispoli's by car is sometimes an art in itself. If you are going east on Bloomfield Avenue, you actually have to drive through a parking garage in Park Street until you reach the other side, which is North Fullerton Street.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boylston, Mass.;
Attracting Professionals
description: LEAD: A SMALL subdivision of upscale single-family homes rising in this suburb of 3,800 residents east of Worcester will help meet a demand from professionals in that city and on the new Interstate 495 high-tech corridor.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: KNIGHT: A Publisher in the Tumultuous Century. By Charles Whited. (Dutton, $21.95.) Although he was born to newspapering, John Shively Knight once credited his success at turning a family-owned newspaper in America's Rust Belt into the $1-billion-a-year Knight-Ridder multi-media organization to ''trying to find people who're better newspapermen than I am.

title: 'The Government of the Tongue'
description: If I could come on meteorite!'' In the poem ''Exposure,'' Seamus Heaney longs for contact with a bright heavenly body, comet or meteorite or falling star, but finds only ''these sparks'' with ''their meagre heat,'' the stanzas whose composition makes him miss the comet.

title: To Givers, a Word of Thanks
description: What makes people contribute to a charity that offers no glitz or galas or personal recognition? The question arises because of the remarkable course of the 77th annual appeal on behalf of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund collected over $4 million - which exceeds even last year's record by more than $250,000.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Columbia, Md.;
New Homes For New Town
description: LEAD: KENDALL RIDGE, the newest neighborhood in this planned town, is rising rapidly on the northeast side, with 1,077 new homes and apartments to be completed in the next three years.

title: Upper West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: In Albany, the Line Against The Death Penalty Falls Back
description: THE New York State Legislature has voted to restore the death penalty so many times and the Governor has vetoed it so many times - 12 times in the last 12 years - that by now the process has become an annual ritual.

title: Heel, Step, Step, Shuffle: Tap Shoes and a Dream
description: JUST how tap dancing soothes ragged nerves, no one could quite say. The dance students at one of Shirley Gigante's recent Monday-night classes at the White Plains Intermediate School, sponsored by the White Plains Department of Continuing Education, were having fun and that was part of it. They were getting exercise and that was important, too. But why was everyone smiling so broadly at the end of the hour?

title: Look Out, Trump, It's Kobayashi's Turn
description: The Pacific Basin works like a mirror. The United States looks across it and is reminded of its own decline. Japan looks east, sees a wounded giant, and wonders if it is looking at its own future.

title: Sports of The Times; Strawberry: One Kiss, One Homer
description: Was Darryl Strawberry warming up for an exodus to Los Angeles by planting a show-biz smooch on Keith Hernandez's cheek?

title: Horror in Iraq
description: When a worried Iraq sought Western intervention against an intolerant, revolutionary Iran, it advertised itself as a moderate, civilized society. The West stepped in, for its own good reasons, but few were fooled by the Iraqi masquerade. Saddam Hussein's Baghdad dictatorship is one of the world's most barbaric tyrannies.

title: A Shakespeare Wallah Expands His Stage
description: GIVEN THE OPPORTUNITY FOR time travel, Mark Lamos would immediately project himself back to the Elizabethan age. He would walk right up to the Globe Theater to see how Shakespeare was performed in his own time. As a director who has worked his way imaginatively through a third of the Shakespearean repertory, Mr. Lamos could also offer a few suggestions. Drawing on his own productions, he might propose:

title: THE WORLD: Fallout Over Rushdie; The Muslim Presence In Western Europe Is Suddenly Starker
description: TELEVISION magnifies reality, and the image on French television screens a week ago was shocking. In the heart of Paris, at the Place de la Republique, some 1,500 Muslims, many of them Pakistanis, screamed into television cameras for the death of Salman Rushdie. With close-up camera work, the smallish crowd suddenly seemed to represent a fanatic Islamic fifth column that had surfaced in France just as it is celebrating the 200th anniversary of its republican, anticlerical revolution. The footage was shown again and again for several days.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Yale; A Class in Itself? Mastering the Art Of the 'Gut' Course
description: Call it beginner's luck, or maybe just precociousness, but in only two semesters Anne Sclater has mastered an art her peers typically spend years cultivating: the search for the perfect ''gut.''

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the reaction of American Muslims to the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' referred incorrectly to the position taken by a group of American writers. They favor further publication of the book by Viking Penguin.

title: Hofstra to Offer Offbeat 'Merchant'
description: LEAD: IF theater is ''an event that stimulates thought and response,'' and that's how Peter Sander defines it, then the first Shakespeare Festival to come under his supervision as the new chairman of Hofstra University's department of drama and dance should fit his bill.

title: The Debt Crisis Sets Off a Latin Time Bomb
description: REMEMBERING the good times that accompanied Carlos Andres Perez's first term in office in the late 1970's, many Venezuelans were so delighted to return him to power in last December's elections that they ignored his repeated warnings that a painful period of austerity lay ahead.

title: Vrdolyak Is Apparent Winner Of Chicago Mayoral Primary
description: Former Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak, who began a write-in campaign for Mayor less than a week before the Republican mayoral primary, has apparently won the nomination.

title: Q and A
description: Condo Guides

title: Taxes Never Take Retirement
description: Even the best laid retirement plans can unravel unless the needs of the tax collector are considered along with those of the retiree. Most retirees count on their savings, Social Security and company pension plans - all of which may be subject to taxes.

title: Deductions Still Flow From Owning a Home
description: A taxpayer's home is still where the deductions are. The tax laws, which have squeezed out ways to cut taxes in most other areas, still grant beneficial treatment to those with shelter, including a second home.

title: A Sense Of Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SOLELY SHOSTAKOVITCH

title: Chartres
description: To the Editor: Joan Gould's article on Chartres (Travel, Dec. 18) was a perfect description of what I had seen only a few weeks before. I would like to echo her recommendation of Malcolm Miller as a guide and to emphasize that he is more than ''just a guide.'' He is an inspired teacher and exudes the charm (with his British accent) of an actor. However, our group was with him for only one hour at which time another group was waiting.

title: Actions Taken On Youth Drinking
description: ON Friday and Saturday nights, a few Sparta police patrol cars head out from the heart of this 38-square-mile rural township in search of teen-age drinking parties in residential neighborhoods. The police hope to head off problems before they happen.

title: Alison Good Engaged To Wed Douglas Ross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen Hovey Good of Summit, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for Mr. Good's daughter, Alison Hovey Good, and Douglas Miller Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lamb Ross Jr. of Milton, Mass.

title: Renewal Efforts And Hempstead Politics
description: The article ''A Troubled Hempstead Debates its Renewal'' (Jan. 22) mistakenly states that both Hempstead residents and businesses affected by the redevelopment proposal have the support of the three ''Democratic'' members of the Village's Board of Trustees.

title: Chartres
description: To the Editor: We eagerly anticipated a tour by Malcolm Miller, but found a notice on the cathedral bulletin board that he would not be there that day. Since the notice also offered his home telephone number, I called him and tried to persuade him to come over. He answered the telephone, and I said that ''we were two ladies who had come all the way from New York just to hear him.'' He was cordial and amused but said it was his day off.

title: Abuse on TV: Help for Victims
description: Re: ''Talk Shows: Morbid Curiosity'' (Letters, Feb. 19). Writer Marjorie Cavanagh states that she is in agreement with Geraldine M. Fox's prior article, ''Abuse on TV'' Jan. 29, in that ''afternoon and evening expose and talk shows are not in the business of educating the public.'' I am in partial agreement with Ms. Cavanagh insofar as, for example, interviews with Ted Bundy and his ilk go. (The prime-time value of his ''words of wisdom'' escapes me).

title: Crack Over Bridge Approach Snarls Jersey Traffic
description: Manhattan-bound traffic was badly snarled on the George Washington Bridge last night when several lanes were shut down after the discovery of a crack in a steel beam over a roadway leading off the bridge.

title: Applying Old-School Expertise to a Period Trend
description: FRIENDS of Robert D. Turner are fond of saying that the 43-year-old Yonkers police and fire dispatcher was ''born in the wrong century.''

title: Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense Of Canada Geese
description: We take issue with the individuals who expressed their distasteful view of the Canada geese in the Long Island parks (''Canada Geese: Thriving Immigrants Prompt a Backlash,'' Feb. 19). We look forward to feeding these beautiful, fascinating creatures each weekend, and find the droppings a minor inconvenience that we tolerate so that we may share their park.

title: James W. Gaynor, 79, Ex-Housing Official
description: James W. Gaynor, a former New York State Commissioner of Housing and Urban Renewal, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the Palm Beach Gardens (Fla.) Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Tecuesta, Fla.

title: New King of Malaysia May Assert More Influence
description: The election this week of a former chief of the Supreme Court as Malaysia's new King is expected to reinforce the constitutional nature of the monarchy and act as a constraint on the country's aggressive Prime Minister.

title: Some Taxpayers Use Ingenuity for Better Returns
description: Many of the old deductions are gone and others are going under the new tax rules. But there are still ways to save on taxes. Here are three approaches. A Young Family

title: A Short Course in Travlish
description: BEFORE you rent that rustic villa in an unspoiled and secluded section of Tuscany, reserve space in the cozy bed and breakfast with the individually decorated rooms or send off your deposit to a centrally located modern hotel in the heart of Florence, you might want to brush up your Travlish, because like all living languages, Travlish is in a constant state of flux.

title: The Office: A Haven From the Pressures at Home
description: WHEN we talk about pressure in our lives we often put it in terms of our jobs. Our work creates lots of pressure.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
THE LOOKS FROM MILAN
description: LEAD: As Romeo Gigli, one of the trend-setting designers in Milan says, ''Fashion doesn't need a strong change every six months. If you have a style, you evolve it.'' Gigli's evolution-not-revolution sentiment sums up the feeling in Milan as the fall 1989 collections get underway this weekend. ''No revolution in shapes,'' adds Gianfranco Ferre.

title: Orchestras Call the Tune In New Opera Disks
description: Usually the first thing that will strike a listener making a historical survey of opera recordings is the increasing prominence of the orchestra. These days, in fact, record buyers building an opera collection on CD have become accustomed to the ear-catching sonics that only a prominently recorded orchestra can provide. And since popular operas have already been recorded many times over the years, new versions must find a way to compete with older ones, and heightening the dramatic impact of the orchestra is one way to do that.

title: Dancing Teachers: A Vote Against
description: As a father of three children in Long Island schools, I am fed up with teachers who write paeans about their teaching, as Ms. Cortese did (Letters, Jan. 29). I'm against tap-dancing teachers and Revue Night sponsored by the P.T.A.

title: Review/Music; Expanding the Repertory For Flute-Harp-Soprano
description: The Jubal Trio has, for the last 14 years, extended the comparatively limited repertory for flute, harp and soprano by commissioning new works and rescoring the accompaniments of standard vocal literature. The trio - Christine Schadeberg, soprano; Sue Ann Kahn, flutist, and Susan Jolles, harpist - brought some of its recent endeavors along these lines to Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: French Castle Holds Relics of Medieval War
description: In an amber-colored castle clinging to an amber cliff, towering far above the Dordogne River in southwest France, a military museum of the Middle Ages has opened.

title: Latin Refugees Fleeing Texas for Mexican Haven
description: To their utter astonishment and consternation, Mexican immigration officials have in recent days apprehended Nicaraguans, Salvadorans and other Central Americans swimming across the Rio Grande from Texas.

title: For a Cause Celebre, The Art of Building a Career
description: When the pianist Vladimir Feltsman arrived here from the Soviet Union in August 1987, New York's music professionals advised him not to procrastinate. He had a year, they said, to warm himself in the spotlight of international politics. Then the light would go out with alarming suddenness, leaving only his talents at the piano to sustain him.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio State; The Coffeehouse Returns, Offering A Change of Pace
description: The aroma of exotic coffees rises above the hum of conversation and soft music. Cigarette smoke curls toward the ceiling.

title: Guillem Joins Royal Ballet
description: Sylvie Guillem, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, has joined the Royal Ballet of London for three years as principal guest artist. She is expected to dance at least 25 performances a year, beginning with ''Swan Lake'' on April 15. She will do guest appearances in Paris.

title: Teaching the True Meaning of Writing
description: I HAVE been teaching remedial writing at the college level for almost 15 years. I have taught learning disabled students who struggle to get a sentence from inside their head onto a piece of paper without leaving out or reversing words or letters.

title: Arena of Big-Time Athletics Is Showcasing a Younger Act
description: High school athletics have become the latest entree on the American sports menu, served up to help satisfy the voracious appetite of the fan. As a result, scholastic athletes are on the verge of becoming as important to the billion-dollar sports industry as their college brothers and sisters - and just as vulnerable to big-time exploitation.

title: THE NIGHT STALIN DIED
description: ON MARCH 6, 1953, AT 5 IN THE MORNING, THE telephone rang. I picked up the receiver and heard the voice of Yaroslav Alexandrov.

title: Laying Floor Tiles
description: RESILIENT floor tiles made of vinyl, asphalt or cork are easier to apply than many other types of finish flooring. Little skill is required to attach them, and, because the tiles are manageable in size - most are 12 inches or less on each side - trimming is less of a chore than it is with sheet vinyl or carpeting.

title: Things That Go Buzz in the Night
description: WHEN the buzzing began under my bed in the middle of the night, I thought at first that my dreams had been enriched by a new realism. When the buzzing continued and I realized I was not dreaming, I thought I had left the telephone off the hook. When I found the receiver in place, I became, in quick order, annoyed, mystified and a little unnerved.

title: Mud on the Senate Floor; In the Tower Debate, All Parties Blame One Another for Disclosures That Sting
description: There are times when Washington takes a mud bath, splashing about indecorously in full view of the whole country, and almost everyone here agrees that this week was one of those times.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Short Cuts To Style: Jackets With Flair
description: When it comes to jackets and trousers, the line has to be drawn somewhere. The question is, where?

title: O'Rourke Offers View Of County's Next Decade
description: A CONFIDENT and optimistic County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke pledged new initiatives in dealing with the problems of homelessness, the environment and drug abuse last week in a wide-ranging review of Westchester's needs in the 1990's.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Patchogue $ $120,000 105 Hedges Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,100. Islip Terrace $ $145,000 54 Sea Cliff Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old ranch; basement, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $3,200. Massapequa $ $225,000 22 Swan Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; fireplace, 1-car garage, deeded beach rights; taxes $3,500. Medford $ $122,000 2712 Connecticut Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 105-foot by 80- foot lot; taxes $1,700. Sayville $ $213,000 59 Saxton Avenue 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 87-year-old colonial; fireplace, Florida room, front and rear porches; taxes $3,300. Williston Park $ $210,000 89 Princeton Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; new kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Springfield, N.J. $ $250,000 314 North View Terrace 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, family room, fireplace, deck; taxes $3,405. Armonk, N.Y. $ $525,000 43 Evergreen Row 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; swim and tennis club membership, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,222. West Simsbury, Conn. $ $178,000 186 West Mountain Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, new kitchen, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,582.

title: Rates Are Down, Complexities Up
description: As Americans get ready for their annual April tax-filing ritual, the once-heralded concept of simplification seems to have fallen through the cracks. Even those who turn to professional preparers are having to devote extra hours to learning enough about the tax laws to get all their financial records in order.

title: Plus Ca Change . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Targeting Successful Women
description: LEAD: WHEN Merna Popper began publishing Women's News seven years ago, she said, there was a lot written about women's rights and women's potential. But there was very little information about how women could climb the business ladder to success.

title: Johnson Ad Is Canceled
description: A Swedish brewery and soft drink producer has canceled a fruit juice commercial featuring Ben Johnson, the banned Canadian sprinter, after a boycott threat.

title: Peruvian Rebels Said to Kill 39 Villagers in Revenge Act
description: Shining Path guerrillas killed 37 men in a rural village by cutting their throats, and shot to death a mother and her baby when the woman tried to flee, a Peruvian military official said today.

title: Review/Dance; Romance, Rapture and Brahms in Feld's 'Intermezzo'
description: ''Intermezzo,'' revived by the Feld Ballet on Thursday at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street), heralded Eliot Feld as a major new talent at its 1969 premiere. The ballet's score is piano music by Brahms, performed sensitively here by Peter Longiaru. And so there were inevitable comparisons to two other ''piano ballets'' of the decade, George Balanchine's ''Liebeslieder Walzer'' and Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering.'' But Mr. Feld holds his own in that august company.

title: THE LESSONS OF ST. JOE'S
description: It is clear that Anthony DePalma is one of the few who flourished in the Catholic school system; however, I find his nostalgia infuriating.

title: Brentwood Sifting Health Curriculum
description: LEAD: A MISUNDERSTANDING between a parent and a school secretary has opened up a disagreement in the Brentwood School District. As a result, the district is reviewing its entire health curriculum.

title: China's Newest Movie Location? The United States
description: LEAD: Although most Americans have never heard of him, to a billion people, Xie Jin is a household name. He is one of China's foremost film directors. Mr. Xie (pronounced ''Shay'') just wrapped a six-week shoot in New York, the first mainland Chinese film ever shot in the United States.

title: Rutgers Panel Seeks Ways to Assure Gay Rights
description: IN what Rutgers is calling the most broad-based effort ever to address the concerns of homosexuals on an American campus, the university is examining virtually every facet of campus life, from curriculum and living arrangements to bereavement policies and health benefits, to assure the safety and rights of its gay students and faculty members.

title: A DANDY AND A TERROIST
description: FELIX FENEON Aesthete & Anarchist in Fin-de-Siecle Paris. By Joan Ungersma Halperin. Illustrated. 425 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: A 'Masters Show'
description: EVERY year, the J. Richards Gallery here has what it calls a ''masters show.'' The gallery, at 64 East Palisades Avenue, is a brightly lighted storefront, and its masters are strictly 20th century.

title: Bush's Director of Drug War Reports a Big Gain in Assets
description: William J. Bennett, President Bush's nominee to become the nation's first director of the fight against drugs, has more than quadrupled his assets since resigning as Education Secretary last September.

title: State Taxes Stir a Fight
description: Residents of New York City still have the unenviable distinction of paying the highest combined Federal, state and local tax rates in the nation - 41 percent for those in the 33 percent Federal bracket and 36.6 percent for those in the 28 percent Federal bracket.

title: A New Kind of Rock
description: On a fringe of mainstream rock, a new style is coalescing. The loose network of college (and a few commercial) radio stations, rock-club disk jockeys and active music fans that sent R.E.M. into the Top 10 has nurtured an ''alternative rock'' that's more melodic than post-punk hard-core rock yet looser, more unruly and less formulaic than big-budget productions such as Bon Jovi. In a few years, alternative rock (probably with a better name) is likely to be just one more commercial genre, but for the moment rock careerists share it with misfits, idealists and other do-it-yourselfers.

title: Passing to Pros
description: Because of what he described as a lifelong dream of playing in the National Football League, Timm Rosenbach, the nation's most efficient passer while at Washington State last season, has decided to forgo his final season of college eligibility to pursue a professional career. ''I have weighed all the facts and I'm confident that I have done what is best for Timm Rosenbach,'' he said in announcing his intention of making himself available for the N.F.L. draft April 23 and 24.

title:
GARDENING;
Forced Flowers Bring Spring Indoors
description: LEAD: THERE is no better way to escape the winter blahs than to fill your house with forced spring flowers from your own garden.

title: FICTION
description: WE'RE NOT HERE. By Tim Mahoney. (Delta, Paper, $7.95.) Many Vietnam novels stagger out of the souls of American soldiers who can describe their suffering but have trouble getting beyond it. Tim Mahoney's second novel is a compelling exception - a Vietnam story so good that it rivals what is still probably the best Vietnam novel, Graham Greene's 1955 work, ''The Quiet American.'' Greene's American was an idealistic meddler working for democracy just as France was quitting Vietnam and the United States was beginning to take its place. In both novels the same fortified watchtowers are manned, waiting for the Communists to attack, but in Mr. Mahoney's book the sentinels are mostly stuffed dummies. American soldiers, under the Henry Kissinger-Le Duc Tho peace agreement of 1973, are not supposed to be in combat areas, but a few, like Sgt. Bill Lemmen, are still fighting the war. Lemmen loves Hoa, a Vietnamese woman, and loves the simplicity of life in the soft, wet, green Mekong Delta. He realizes that in Vietnam he is somebody, whereas ''in America,'' he tells Hoa, ''we would be poor. We'd end up in a trailer court.'' Gradually Lemmen admits that his side is losing the war, that he must try to leave and take Hoa with him. Graham Greene wrote that there would be Vietnamese carrying buckets on the ends of poles after there was no longer a London or a New York. In the same spirit, Tim Mahoney's Sergeant Lemmen thinks about ''the kind of kid who grew up to be VC. A kid who would walk barefoot through smelly, leech-ridden, snake-infested water, grab a snake, throw it in a bucket, eat it for breakfast. Whatever gave Americans the idea they could defeat such people?''

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS;
RECENT RELEASES: CLASSICAL
description: LEAD: Russian Songs Paata Burchuladze, bass, with Ludmilla Ivanova, piano. London 421 417-2; CD only.

title: Nancy Kaneb to Wed George Soule
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Kaneb of Weston and Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ellen Kaneb to George deLancey Soule, a son of Richard H. Soule of Canterbury, N.H., and Emily M. Soule of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: New Haven to Honor Women in Art
description: FEMALE artists from Connecticut and throughout the country will dance, recite poetry, display paintings and sculptures, give music recitals and deliver comedy routines as the New Haven Women in the Arts celebration gets underway this month.

title: Costa Rica
description: To the Editor: We were planning a two-week vacation in Costa Rica this winter with about half of our time on Isla Jesusita, a small island off the Pacific Coast scarcely mentioned in guidebooks. For three weeks we and our travel agent tried to call the 800 number for the Costa Rica National Tourist Bureau in Miami. Usually there was no answer, occasionally we got a busy signal, and once both we and our travel agent heard a recorded message saying that if we left a request for information, it would be sent to us. We never received the information.

title: PASTIMES: CHESS
description: A player's first experience in the candidates matches for the world championship is almost always a bitter one. It is too hard a task to master the tension of such an auspicious occasion.

title: RECENT RELEASES: POP/JAZZ
description: Boy George: 'High Hat' Virgin 91022, all three formats.

title: Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age; Pity the Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound Advice And Protection For Players
description: Much has been written and said during the last couple of years about abusive and even criminal behavior by sports agents in dealing with their clients or prospective clients. While negative publicity is usually more interesting to readers, I submit that the vast majority of sports agents are providing necessary and significant service to their clients.

title: An Opening In Tunisia, A More Open North Africa?
description: WITH the caution induced by things strange and new, Tunisia's opposition parties are looking forward to an election that they depict as a test of a kind of North African glasnost.

title: On Capitol Hill, A Struggle For the Record
description: JOHN W. WARNER of Virginia, senior Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, gripped a tome on constitutional law in one hand and punched the air with the other, throwing the history and theory of American government into his party's defense of John G. Tower.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS;
RECENT RELEASES: CLASSICAL
description: LEAD: Mozart: The Horn Concertos Lowell Greer, natural horn, and the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra, Nicholas McGegan, conductor. Harmonia Mundi HMU 907012; all three formats.

title: On the Range With Cowboys Of Hawaii
description: THE minivan pulled away from the Parker Ranch Visitor Center in Kamuela, on the Big Island of Hawaii. Ten minutes out of sunny Kamuela in the Waimea uplands and we were surrounded by cool mists that roll down the slopes of Mauna Kea onto an unbroken stretch of undulating grasslands. Pastures filled the horizon, emerging from the high mists and falling away to a far-off sea.

title: Law Aims to Limit Property Taxes of the Elderly
description: Each time Kathy Conway, a real estate agent, sells another house in Queen Village she feels as though she were selling her soul. Ms. Conway, who was born and reared here, has seen hundreds of longtime homeowners, many of them elderly, join an exodus from this increasingly fashionable waterfront neighborhood because they could no longer afford to pay sharply rising property taxes.

title: Strickland Stars As Jackson Sits
description: With Rod Strickland running the offense as Mark Jackson sat on the bench playing cheerleader, the Knicks hardly missed their injured point guard last night.

title: Some Plants Are Ideal For Water Conservation
description: There has been little snow pack this year, and gardeners are worried. What does a dry winter mean for plants?

title: Week's Choices Range From Opera to Pop
description: Vocal music will hold its own against the instrumental competition this week. The options range from grand opera to a pops songbook, not to mention a recital by Roberta Peters combining both.

title: South Africa Racial Toll Put at 4,000 in 4 Years
description: More than 4,000 South Africans have died in politically inspired violence in the last four and a half years, according to statistics released this week by a university research group.

title: A Window on the World Goes Only to He Who Waits
description: I CAME down out of the trees to join corporate America. I mean that quite literally. I was a tree surgeon for nearly two decades before I dropped into a Fortune 100 company eight years ago.

title: Erica L. Tukel Is Married To Dr. David Franklin Wax
description: Erica Lauren Tukel and Dr. David Franklin Wax were married in Manhattan last evening at the Stanhope by Rabbi Ronald Brown. Mrs. Wax is the daughter of Mrs. Henry Davis of Merrick, L.I., and the late Robert Tukel. Dr. Wax's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Morton Wax of Great Neck, L.I.

title: In Jazz, Young Players Turn to the Old Hard-Bop
description: Throughout the 1980's, promising young jazz musicians have been looking back. Defying the notion that music evolves in one immutable direction - that as one era's style succeeds another, there is inevitably progress in art - they devote themselves to the jazz approaches of the 1950's and 1960's. Recent albums by or featuring Ralph Peterson, Wallace Roney, Marcus Roberts and Mulgrew Miller show a generation mastering one of the most complex musical languages ever conceived. Simultaneously, they raise the same question as other revivalist efforts do: What's new?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RIVALS. By Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $18.95) Italian restaurants, Calvin Trillin has written, are divided by the discerning eater into two classes: those where the waiter's name is Vito or Luigi, and those where the waiter's name is Dwayne. I was barely half a chapter into ''Rivals'' when I came up with the Dwayne Principle's literary corollary: no reader of a book that introduces in the first 10 pages a heroine and hero named, respectively, Flame and Chance can complain that he hasn't been adequately warned of what lies ahead.

title: Giving Due Credit To Registered Nurses
description: The Jan. 29 article ''Comforting Young Victims of Aids'' describes the work of a nurse, Bessie Bryant, but never mentions her professional title, R.N., for registered nurse.

title:
GARDENING;
Forced Flowers Bring Spring Indoors
description: LEAD: THERE is no better way to escape the winter blahs than to fill your house with forced spring flowers from your own garden.

title: Days of Our Lives: Calendar as Diary
description: ''I NEVER travel without my diary,'' Oscar Wilde wrote. ''One should always have something sensational to read in the train.''

title: Chartres
description: To the Editor: Joan Gould's article noted that the city of Chartres is a convenient starting point for excursions to other places of interest nearby. For the reader of Marcel Proust, one such place is, of course, Illiers, the town imaginatively rendered as ''Combray'' in ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' Now officially designated as Illiers-Combray, it is just 15 miles from Chartres and easily reached by car or train.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: Graphic design is one of the most pervasive and diverse aspects of our visual environment, and the sheer volume and variety of graphic material presents a formidable challenge to design historians and critics. In GRAPHIC STYLE: From Victorian to Post-Modern (Abrams, $49.50), Steven Heller, an art director for The New York Times, and Seymour Chwast, a designer and illustrator, succeed admirably in providing what they modestly describe as an ''annotated chronology'' of graphic design since the mid-19th century.

title: Special Education: Choosing the Words
description: I am one of the fortunate special educators to teach in a school chosen by the State of New Jersey to pilot the Plan to Revise Special Education. It is because of my dedication to the success of this new plan and to the needs of my students that I take such offense to the authors' choice of words in the Jan. 29 article ''In Special Education, State Is Making Progress'' (Opinion page).

title:
FILM;
Kathy Baker Makes Them All Say 'Yeah!'
description: LEAD: Here is David Jones, who directed Kathy Baker's latest film, ''Jacknife'' (which opens Friday at the Plaza), speaking about the actress and her plummy role as Robert De Niro's girlfriend and Ed Harris's sister: ''I saw Kathy on the stage in New York and was astounded by her talent. She was my first idea for the part.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field World Marks Tumble: Paul Ereng of Kenya, the Olympic champion, broke Sebastian Coe's six-year-old world mark in the men's 800 meters yesterday, and Javier Sotomayor of Cuba set a world record in the men's high jump at the world indoor championships in Budapest. Two other world marks also fell: Elly van Hulst of the Netherlands slashed nearly six seconds off the women's 3,000-meter best and Kerry Saxby of Australia lowered the mark in the women's 3,000-meter walk. Sotomayor cleared 7 feet 11 1/2 inches in his first jump to win the gold medal. That beat the mark of 7-11 1/4 set by Carro Thraenhardt of West Germany last year. In the men's 800-meter race, Ereng surged ahead off the last curve and powered home in a time of 1 minute 44.84 seconds. That beat the mark of 1:44.91 set by Coe on March 19, 1983, in Cosford, England. Van Hulst, the European indoor champion, was clocked in 8:33.82, which lowered the mark of 8:39.79 set by Zola Budd two years ago. Saxby's time of 12:01.65 in the women's 3,000 walk beat the mark of 12:02.02 set by Beate Anders of East Germany on Jan. 29. (AP) Finney of Maryand Sets Meet Record: John Finney of the University of Maryland set a meet record of 17 feet 4 1/4 inches to win the pole vault at the 68th I.C.4-A indoor track and field championships at Princeton's Jadwin Gym yesterday. He broke the mark of 17-1 1/4 set by Geoff Stiles of Harvard in 1979. Princeton's Vincent Smith and Al Dyer finished 1-2 in the long jump. Smith's winning mark was 24-9 1/4. Nnenna Lynch Leads New York Athletes: Nnenna Lynch, Felicia Edwards and Aaronda Watson led New York City athletes to seven gold medals yesterday at the Eastern State girls indoor championships at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. Lynch of Hunter College High School won the one-mile run in 4 minutes 55.24 seconds, Edwards of New Dorp, S. I., took the 600-yard run in 1:21.93 and Watson was the winner of the 1,000-yard run in 2:39.07. Other New York City victors were Kate Doyle of St. Francis Prep in the high jump at 5 feet 5 inches; Sue Francis of Tilden in the 300 in 35.99 seconds; Charlene Neptune of Clara Barton in the two-mile run in 10:55.43 and Tilden's one-mile relay team in 3:55.01. Boxing Hill Beats Czyz to Keep Title: Virgil Hill retained his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title yesterday, scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Bobby Czyz at Bismarck, N.D. It was Hill's fifth defense of his belt, which he won in September 1987. Czyz had been attempting a comeback after losing his world title more than a year ago. Hill, 24-0, was a 1984 Olympic silver medalist. There were no knockdowns. Czyz saw his record fall to 34-4.(AP) Horse Racing Rose's Cantina Aqueduct Winner: Rose's Cantina, ridden by Eddie Maple, came from off the pace to score an easy six-length victory in the $83,250 Next Move Handciap for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. To the Hunt was runner-up in the field of five, two lengths ahead of No Butter. Scorned Lass, the favorite, and Galway Song completed the order of finish. Rose's Cantina covered the mile and three-sixteenths on the fast track in 1:59 4/5 to earn $49,950 for her owner, Carl Icahn. She returned $5.20 for $2 to win. Bowling Aulby Rolls Last-Frame Strike for Victory: Mike Aulby of Indianapolis rolled a strike in the final frame of the title game to capture the Professional Bowlers Association $150,000 Showboat Atlantic City Open yesterday with a 195-182 decision over Curtis Odom. Aulby eliminated Steve Hoskins, a rookie, 212-206, after Hoskins beat Pete Weber, 217-182. Aulby then downed Bob Benoit, 196-192 to earn a berth in the final.(AP) Dog Show Springer Spaniel Best in Show: Ch. Telltale Royal Stuart, the liver and white English springer spaniel owned by Celie Florence and Delores Streng, was gaited to best in show yesterday by George Alston at the raceway in Monticello, N.Y. For the 5-year-old, it was the 62d top award, four short of the record for the breed. Golf Littler, Charles and Barber Are Tied: Gene Littler created a three-way tie for the lead when he shot a four-under par 68 yesterday in the third round of the Vintage Invitational seniors tournament at Indian Wells, Calif. Little joined Bob Charles and Miller Barber at the top, with 54-hole scores of 212. (AP) Lacrosse Johns Hopkins 14, Syracuse 13: Johns Hopkins defeated Syracuse in the opening game for both at Baltimore. A late rally fell short for the Orangemen, who were undefeated in 15 games last season and won the national championship. Adam Wright, with three goals, led the Blue Jays who trailed by 9-8 at the half. Skiing Schneider's 3d Earns Slalom Title: Vreni Schneider, who has won 12 World Cup races this season, didn't mind finishing third yesterday in a women's slalom race at Furano, Japan, because the loss to her Swiss teammate, Maria Walliser, meant nothing. The placing, however, gave Schneider the overall World Cup ski title. Schneider's finish gave her 15 points, raising her season total to 326, an unbeatable 77 more than Walliser. Two more races will be held in Japan next week with each victory worth 25 points. (AP) Women's Basketball Providence and UConn Gain Final: Andrea Mangnum scored 26 points and Providence held off a rally to beat Villanova, 68-64, in a semifinal game of the Big East tournament yesterday at South Orange, N.J. The Lady Friars will go to the championship game today when they play Connecticut, which defeatedBoston College, 65-45.Villanova (18-11) trailed by 13 with 7:10 to go, but went on a 13-2 run to pull within 2 points with 1:49 left after Diane Decker hit a 3-pointer. Providence (22-9) iced the game with four seconds left when Shanya Evans hit both ends of a one-and-one.,,(AP)

title: POSTINGS: Islandia Redux; Can a Utopia Run Out of Land for Housing?
description: Fifty years ago a social visionary named Austin Tappan Wright dreamed up a Utopian community named Islandia, which he placed through a series of writings somewhere in the southern seas near Antarctica. Then, 25 years ago Levitt & Sons built a 500-house community in southern Long Island, and, borrowing from Wright's fictional ideas, named it Islandia.

title: Railway Lines Facing Strikes
description: Federal labor law governing transportation workers allows striking unions to picket companies not directly involved in a contract dispute.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THERE are small signs of spring that I search for. I need them to mark the passage of time. I need them for the assurance they bring. Each is another small victory and they mount, these vernal victories, day by day, one atop another, until the sheer weight of them flips the earth on her axis and winter disappears.

title: High-Tech Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LESSONS OF ST. JOE'S
description: Anthony DePalma refers in his article to signing a waiver so his son could attend a tree-planting memorial at his public school for a classmate who had died of cancer. He was ''struck by how forced it seemed,'' how ''rigid and unnatural,'' in contrast to the way he had seen death handled in a parochial school.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Locust Valley
description: WHEN the free-wheeling super-rich settled in Locust Valley during the early 1900's they built secluded estates and extravagant country clubs and wrote tough zoning laws to protect the rural Long Island North Shore community from urban encroachment.

title: And Now, a Wave of Flexible Annuities
description: The tax code includes few real shelters with universal appeal. Some are high risk; others place limits on how much you can shelter or how much you can earn in order to qualify.

title: A La Carte: Bread
description: BREAD is more than the staff of life. To diners at a restaurant, it is a preview of the meal to come.

title: RECENT RELEASES: CLASSICAL
description: Massenet: Thais Andree Esposito, Robert Massard, Orchestre Radio-Lyrique conducted by Albert Wolff. Le Chant du Monde LDC-278 895/96; two CD's

title:
Long Island Interview: Richard B. Setlow;
Genetic Repair: The Role of DNA in Daily Life
description: LEAD: RICHARD B. SETLOW, a biophysicist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, was recently honored with a Presidential citation, gold medal and $100,000 for his contributions in the fields of radiation biophysics and molecular biology. Dr. Setlow's discoveries and research during almost three decades have had a tremendous impact on diverse fields, from environmental studies to cancer research and genetics.

title: Health Care Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion's Young Coterie: Looks With a Kick
description: Even before the fashion powerhouses show their fall collections in the coming weeks, more than 100 young contenders have had their say at last week's Fashion Coterie in New York.

title: Military Upset at Tone of Tower Battle
description: ''A sham,'' ''ludicrous,'' and ''kabuki theater'' are some of the ways service personnel characterize the battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense. But while a sampling of attitudes at posts around the country shows differences of opinion, it shows no strong support for the former Senator.

title: Cable TV Operators Are Guilty of Greed
description: Cablevision's positions in the MSG dispute are defenseless. MSG is not ''expensive'': including the new Yankee contract, it costs less than $1 per month per subscriber. It is also not ''specialty programming'': 9 of the 10 most-watched cable programs in 1988 were sports.

title: Now, a Rush to Speed Up Protection of Ozone
description: JUST two years ago when 31 nations met in Montreal and agreed to cut the production of chlorofluorocarbons in half by the turn of the century, the accord was hailed by environmentalists as an unprecedented example of international cooperation. Now, with evidence accumulating that the chemicals are indeed eroding the protective ozone layer, the United States and the members of the European Community are rushing to impose even more drastic measures.

title: Baker to Express Bush's Stance to Shevardnadze
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to meet this week with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Vienna in the first high-level talks between the Bush Administration and the Soviet Union.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Notorious Velleities
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Wins Fifth W.C.T. Title
description: John McEnroe shook off the fatigue of a four-set match he played only 12 hours earlier and earned a record fifth World Championship Tennis finals title today with a methodical 6-3, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Brad Gilbert.

title: Outdoors; One-Stop Shopping for Adventure
description: One way to bring a vague yearning for an unusual fishing, camping or hunting trip to fruition is to visit any of the several outdoor-oriented shows that bloom in late winter in the Northeast.

title: ECCENTRICITIES
description: At first glance, it all looks terribly proper: the early 19th-century secretaire topped with a pair of terra cotta busts; a William IV sofa in front of windows facing the street, and a simple mirror over the fireplace. On closer inspection, however, these rooms have a special brand of humor, an eccentricity and flair that is completely personal. The ground floor of this 1835 house, situated in London's East End, is the first portion finished by the owner, David Roos, a London-based decorator. ''At first I was afraid it was all getting a bit too serious,'' says Roos. ''And then one night when I was watching something mad on television it came to me. I thought, 'What these rooms need are Wagnerian flames skirting up all around their edges.' '' So Roos's team of craftsmen painted gold and blue flames above the conventional baseboards.

title: Many in Their 50's Tend Aging Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Fit in Economy Class
description: WHEN Ruth Bocour of New York took an economy-class flight to California some years ago, her leg began to hurt and she thought she had a charley horse. Mrs. Bocour, a former professional dancer who now helps injured people improve mobility, said that when the plane stopped in Las Vegas, she ''walked around like crazy'' and tried to exercise the leg to get the cramp out, but to no avail.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: We think that the acquisition of Kiki Vandeweghe will not substantially help the Knicks. The Knicks are a fast-breaking, pressing and trapping team that has good shooters and doesn't need another shooter to mess up the chemistry.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese and Japanese in One Location
description: LEAD: ONE doesn't often find a restaurant that offers both Chinese and Japanese food; and, as a matter of fact, the ultimate wisdom of coupling these two disparate cuisines under one roof escapes us. Obviously Sakura, which is near the Plaza Cinema, is the place to go when a diner craves sushi and the diner's companion won't eat raw anything.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Binghamton; Radio Station Fears Controls In Klan Incident
description: Walt and Joyce Bialkowski are not students. They are members of the Ku Klux Klan, though, and they wanted to be heard on WHRW-FM, the student-run radio station of the State University of New York at Binghamton, after reading that it had a history of airing unpopular views.

title: The Civilian Conservation Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Hope to Avoid Turmoil With Merger
description: Working together to create the world's largest media company, the chief executives of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. sought to insure that the merger would cause little of the turmoil that has accompanied many mergers and acquisitions in the 1980's.

title: 'A Hot Time In the Tundra' One Night
description: Icy winds blew in from the north, but the costumes and dancing at the American Museum of Natural History matched the party's theme, ''A Hot Time in the Tundra.'' The occasion was the Junior Committee's annual fund-raising event late last month. A few penguins and a Santa Claus roamed through the crowd, but most partygoers came to the Land of the Midnight Sun in sexier dress. Some of the dancing was close, tight and visibly influenced by the film ''Dirty Dancing.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Gurnee, Ill.;
A Horsy Suburban Setting
description: LEAD: A SUBDIVISION here designed with the horsy set in mind has drawn buyers attracted more by its equestrian atmosphere than by the potential of keeping horses.

title: Washington's War on Terrorism Captures Few Soldiers
description: IN 1985, President Reagan declared that terrorists who harmed Americans would have to answer for their crimes in Federal court. In Clint Eastwood style, he warned the airplane hijackers, hostage takers and truck bombers of the world, ''You can run, but you can't hide.''

title: Photography After Daguerre is Celebrated at the Wadsworth
description: THE official birth of photography took place in March of 1839, when Louis Daguerre revealed his daguerreotype at a scientific convention in Paris. Six months later, details of the process had reached the United States and within a couple of years there were daguerreotypists at work the world over, producing mirror images of people and places on silvered copper plates.

title: Egypt Presses for New Government in Sudan
description: As a political crisis deepens in the Sudan, Egypt, its northern neighbor and onetime ally, has broken publicly with the leadership in Khartoum and wants to see it replaced by a new administration ready to talk peace with rebels in the south, according to highly placed officials here.

title: Q and A
description: Rules in Condominiums

title: A Chip With Supercomputer Power
description: Intel plunges boldly into the world of reduced instruction set computing. THE Intel Corporation has introduced a new chip, the i860, that is believed to be the first commercial microprocessor to incorporate more than a million transistors on one piece of silicon. It is also the first to handle data in 64-bit chunks. This latest chip, introduced last week, represents an enormous increase in computing power over Intel's previous top-of-the-line microprocessor, the 80386.

title: HE DID NOTHING FOR MONEY
description: STANISLAVSKI By Jean Benedetti. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Routledge. $25.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Edmund M. Kelly, a Publishing Aide, And Diana Stratton-Crooke Will Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Stratton-Crooke of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Diana Stratton-Crooke to Edmund Murphy Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Kelly of Scarsdale. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Jane M. Roberts And Serge Denis To Wed in April
description: Mrs. Geoffrey Roberts of New Orleans has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jane Mary Roberts, to Serge Henri Denis, the general manager of the Hotel Parker Meridien in New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Georges Denis of Caen, France. An April wedding is planned. Miss Roberts, also the daughter of the late Mr. Roberts, is a department manager at Asprey in New York. She graduated from the University of New Orleans. Her father was the president of J. P. Florio, a subsidiary in New Orleans of the Texas Transport and Terminal Steamship Agency.

title: Projecting the Traffic a Development Brings
description: AS developers increasingly face stringent review procedures for construction projects, a major issue that prompts community opposition is concern about how a project will affect local traffic.

title: Strawberry's Big Bat Speaks Loud and Clear
description: ''What's done is done,'' Darryl Strawberry was saying, after his one-day exile was done. ''I'm back.'' He was back, all right. With flourishes, a hug and a kiss for Keith Hernandez and a mighty three-run home run for the Mets, he was back today, ending his walkout, burying his contract blues, turning boos into cheers and even stealing the show from Tommy Lasorda and his ''team of destiny.''

title: Mr. Carter Regrets
description: Francis D. Carter, Esq., is representing Fawaz Yunis in his Washington trial for hijacking a Royal Jordanian airliner carrying American citizens, among other passengers. Whatever the verdict, Mr. Carter has already shown a gift for selective apology.

title: Prospects; The Budget Panel Fizzles
description: The National Economic Commission, a bipartisan panel appointed by the President and Congress in the aftermath of the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, failed to come to an agreement last week on a blueprint for cutting the Federal budget deficit. The failure of the commission means that next October it is more likely that Congress will be forced to accept the automatic cuts of the Gramm-Rudman Act, a process known as sequestration. Four experts talk about the consequences of the commission's failure. Henry Kaufman President, Henry Kaufman & Company Inc.

title: Vocal Programs In the Spotlight
description: WITH the approach of the Easter holidays, the yearly surge in vocal programs has arrived. In fact, this week is neatly bracketed by choral concerts, starting at 4 P.M. today as the Congregational Choir under John Schuder sings the Durufle Requiem at the Church in Scarsdale (723-2234).

title:
THE VIEW FROM: RIDGEFIELD;
A Town With a Passion for Signs in Black and White
description: LEAD: WITH its wide, tree-lined main street, tasteful shops and elegant old homes, Ridgefield, settled in 1708 and situated in northern Fairfield County, still retains much of its small-town, New England flavor.

title: Thatcher Puts a Lid On Censorship in Britain
description: Charter 88 arrived on the newsstands of Britain with the rhetorical force of a Tom Paine tract.

title: A Critic's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Beinner to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Beinner of River Vale, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Sue Beinner, to Michael Ditchik, the son of of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Ditchik of Island Park, L.I. An April wedding is planned. Ms. Beinner, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, graduated from Washington University and the Boston University School of Law. The future bridegroom, an associate at the New York law firm of Bivona & Cohen, attended the University of Pennsylvania and graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and the Boston University School of Law.

title: Breakthrough on Methadone
description: Methadone, a drug that blocks the craving for heroin while allowing the addict to lead a normal life, has suffered controversy since the 1960's. A new Federal decision to make it more accessible could strike a blow against AIDS and drug abuse.

title:
MUSIC;
Guitar and Orchestra? Why, Certainly
description: LEAD: MOST classical guitarists seem to be part of an informal movement to persuade symphony managers to legitimize the guitar as a solo instrument.

title: RECENT RELEASES: POP/JAZZ
description: Danielle Dax: 'Dark Adapted Eye' Sire 25818-1, all three formats.

title: St. Peter's Reaches Final
description: A reversal of a decision by the officials in the waning seconds of overtime helped St. Peter's reach the final of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament today with a 77-76 triumph over Iona.

title: Electronic Filing Speeds Refunds
description: Once every 15 minutes the smiling face of Bob Mirsberger, Manhattan director of the I.R.S., flashes on an electric color billboard over Times Square with an enthusiasic exhortation to ''Make Your Taxes Less Taxing By Filing Early & Electronically.'' This year, some two million taxpayers will take that advice to heart by having their tax data sent by computer and modem as part of the Internal Revenue Service's electronic filing program.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Walter Thayer, 78, Herald Tribune President, Dies
description: Walter N. Thayer, a lawyer, partner in the Whitcom Investment Corporation and former president of The New York Herald Tribune, died of pneumonia yesterday at New York Hospital. Mr. Thayer, who was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan, had been admitted to the hospital more than three weeks ago. He had suffered from emphysema for several years.

title: Charges of Corruption Spur School Vote Drive
description: Responding to recent allegations of misdeeds and corruption in some of New York City's school districts, school officials are striving for a large voter turnout in the May 2 school board elections, hoping to reduce the influence of politicians and special-interest groups.

title: Ultra Violet on Viva
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: Maybe you were in this world in a previous incarnation, and maybe not. If you were, you were undoubtedly royalty, or one of Napoleon's generals, or a famous courtesan who had only to be seen to be desired.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pawtucket, R.I.;
Old Textile Mill Going Condo
description: LEAD: A BOSTON developer is using lower prices and special incentives to lure first-time home buyers to condominiums taking shape in a converted 1860 textile mill in this blue-collar city.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boylston, Mass.;
Attracting Professionals
description: LEAD: A SMALL subdivision of upscale single-family homes rising in this suburb of 3,800 residents east of Worcester will help meet a demand from professionals in that city and on the new Interstate 495 high-tech corridor.

title: For Aging Planes, A New Strategy Of Prudent Repairs
description: AMID heightened concern over the condition of aging commercial planes, aircraft manufacturers and the airlines are developing a new approach to maintenance.

title: THE COMPANY WE KEEP
description: THE CIA AND AMERICAN DEMOCRACY By Rhodri Jeffreys-Jones. 338 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: Shades of McCarthyism
description: George Bush now has on his desk a little noticed executive order that threatens to revive one of the excesses of the McCarthy era. The order, prepared in the final days of the Reagan Administration, would scrap the appeals process for Federal security clearances. This, in turn, would allow the Government to deny clearances to Federal workers or to the employees of Government contractors, without any explanation.

title: A Sweet Sacrifice for Lent
description: TWO caramels, four Tootsie rolls, four lollipops and a napkin full of jellybeans! Well, that wasn't enough. I knew my friend, Irene, had more than that, and noon on Holy Saturday was still two weeks away.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Fordham; 1,000 Expected At Conference About Service
description: There's more to education than classroom learning and career potential. Several hundred students at Fordham University have been demonstrating that to such an extent that a national organization for community service has chosen the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx as the site for a conference this week.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHURCHILL'S BLACK DOG, KAFKA'S MICE: And Other Phenomena of the Human Mind. By Anthony Storr. (Grove, $19.95.) The eminent British psychiatrist Anthony Storr presents us with a pastiche of theory, speculation and fact in ''Churchill's Black Dog, Kafka's Mice: And Other Phenomena of the Human Mind'' that, chapter by chapter, sparkles with penetrating insight and first-rate writing but fails in its cumulative effect.

title: Carrie Anderson Weds S. J. Salter
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Carrie Elizabeth Anderson, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Anderson of New York, was married yesterday to Steven James Salter, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Salter of San Francisco. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Lyme-Disease Aid Sought
description: EFFORTS to stem Lyme disease could be strengthened under a bill co-sponsored by Congressional legislators from Westchester County, which last year reported more new cases of the debilitating infection than any other county in the nation.

title: Preserving a Farm: The Broader View
description: I read with great interest the Jan. 15 article about the possible demolition of the Stout homestead in Neptune Township (''Residents Try to Save a Farm Dating to 1832''). As a granddaughter of John Robert Stout (documented in John McAleer's biography of Rex Stout), I am a direct descendant of Penelope Stout and was named after her 48 years ago.

title: The Guggenheim in MAssachusetts?
description: WHEN I FIRST SAW THESE mills, I thought they were too big.''

title: PRUDENTIAL COMES FOR A VISIT
description: A COUNTRY OF STRANGERS By Susan Richards Shreve. 239 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: MECHANICS' STRIKE VIRTUALLY SHUTS EASTERN AIRLINES
description: Striking machinists, joined by pilots and flight attendants, all but paralyzed Eastern Airlines' operations yesterday, grounding nearly 90 percent of its planes and stranding passengers at scores of airports across the nation and in Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: Race Overrides All In the Chicago Race
description: POLITICAL division along racial lines is hardly unique to Chicago.

title: Hey, There! It's Richard Adler
description: IN 1954, the American musical comedy lit up Broadway. This was the middle of the musical's acknowledged golden age, a joyful time that was to dwindle in a decade or so.

title: Judicial Standoff Keeps a Convicted Man Free
