description: When William Schank was sentenced to life in prison for the brutal murder of a baby in Alabama, he had little hope of seeing his home state of New York again.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Boston College; Getting Your Grades At the Teller Machine
description: As if getting good grades were not hard enough, sometimes just finding out what grades you got when can be a major achievement. Not at Boston College, which has installed a machine that dispenses academic records the way an automated teller machine dispenses cash.

title: Review/Recital; A Pianist From Brazil
description: Claudio Richerme, a Brazilian pianist, devoted most of his Thursday-evening program at Weill Recital Hall to music by two of his country's best-known composers, Mozart Camargo Guarnieri and Heitor Villa-Lobos.

title: Wolfpack Prevails In Four Overtimes
description: Rodney Monroe scored 26 points today and made shots that put North Carolina State into two of the four overtime periods as the 20th-ranked Wolfpack outlasted Wake Forest, 110-103, in the longest Atlantic Coast Conference game in history.

title: Fiona Fulton Becomes Bride
description: Fiona Jane Fulton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey E. Fulton of New York, was married yesterday in Providence, R.I., to Mark Richard Sanders, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyle G. Sanders of Waukesha, Wis. The ceremony at the Central Baptist Church was performed by Terry Stanfield, a minister of the Providence Church of Christ.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Menu; The Warmth of Pork and Noodles
description: Sunday lunch or Sunday dinner: something easy to shop for, easy to prepare, easy to eat and satisfying in winter's brisk weather. Here is a recipe that is as easily done as said. And below it there is a game plan to help.

title: Plan for Homeless Offers Hope
description: That there exists continued difficulty in providing adequate housing for the homeless should not come as a surprise (''State Plays Bigger Role for Homeless,'' Jan. 22). There is clear precedence for this problem. Historically, there have been enormous problems coordinating and centralizing social services, including housing, for former psychiatric patients, many of whom are represented in our homeless population.

title: From Bumpers to Hoods, Detroit Opens the Door for Plastics
description: Plastic producers have had a tough time shifting out of low gear as they try to sell Detroit on the plastic car. Over the last decade, auto makers have increased their use of plastics in car interiors and in small parts to make them lighter and more fuel-efficient. But they have been unable to justify plastics for body panels and structural frames because in large-scale production they cost more than steel.

title: PASTIMES: BRIDGE
description: In social games, using either four-deal scoring or the traditional rubber bridge scoring, it is common for a player to fail in a part-score contract by three or more tricks. The opponents are left regretting that they failed to pull the trigger, doubling to collect a large penalty instead of a small one.

title: THE LAX HABITS OF THE FREE IMAGINATION
description: A brief cautionary tale: one day some years ago, after I had published a book, I was asked for permission to excerpt a piece from it in an anthology. Delighted, I wrote back. As it happened, I used this anthology in a course I taught. I admired its selections, and found the study questions helpful. Not that I used the study questions much, I suppose, but I directed my students to them from time to time. I was pleased about being included in the next edition of the book, imagining students not just reading my work, but studying it. About a year later, the anthology arrived. Snappy new jacket (better than the first edition, I thought), well-designed pages, clean type.

title: MY LOVE HAS BUTTER ON HER HAIR
description: MOTHER RUSSIA The Feminine Myth in Russian Culture. By Joanna Hubbs. Illustrated. 302 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $29.95.

title:
ART;
An Abstract Universe
description: LEAD: DURING the formative years of his art career, Frank Wimberley's visits to the Museum of Modern Art taught him that achievement comes through taking risks, and this has been a guiding principle throughout the last two decades.

title: Joe the Barber, a Tradition, Is Gone
description: JOE the barber is gone. He left town before we were able to say goodbye. He has given up his tiny barber shop in suburban Westchester to seek a new life. To quote the grandmother in ''Crossing Delancey,'' he's gone ''to live in Florida with Red Buttons.''

title: BEST SELLERS: March 5, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 2 1 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay find themselves enacting the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 3 9 2 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 15 12 3 THE BOY WHO COULDN'T STOP WASHING, by Judith L. Rapoport. (Dutton, $17.95.) A psychiatrist's account of the symptoms and treatment of an obsessive-compulsive disorder. 16 * 1 RICHARD BURTON, by Melvyn Bragg. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) EIGHTY-SIXED, by David B. Feinberg. (Viking, $18.95.) Mr. Feinberg's first novel is a harrowing first-person narrative of gay life in New York City and what AIDS has done to it since 1980. ANY OLD IRON, by Anthony Burgess. (Random House, $19.95.) The 20th century as experienced by a Welsh family torn between the desire for the absolute and the desire for dinner, with three wars and King Arthur's sword thrown in: a novel of ideas, big ideas. SECOND CHANCES: Men, Women, and Children a Decade After Divorce, by Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) This handsomely interwoven combination of social science and clinical interviews confirms that divorce is a necessary evil with unpredictable effects on children. A CASUAL BRUTALITY, by Neil Bissoondath. (Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown, $18.95.) A first novel (by a Canadian born in Trinidad), rich in sensibility, that concerns the contingencies of Indian life in the Caribbean and the complexities and tragedies, political and personal, of the island republic of Casaquemada. CITY: Rediscovering the Center, by William H. Whyte. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Commonplace assumptions about urban life are punctured in nearly every chapter of this study, which finds, after 16 years of research, that the heart of the urban agora still beats. FATHER AND SON, by Peter Maas. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) An Irish-American teen-ager finds himself involved in an I.R.A. gun-smuggling plot in this vigorous, intelligent political thriller. JOHN DOLLAR, by Marianne Wiggins. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A quirky, provocative historical novel (by the wife of the British-Indian novelist Salman Rushdie) in which a group of British would-be Robinson Crusoes encounter cannibals, leaving their surviving children - girls only - to re-create a civilization.

title: Golfing Talk Causes a Stir
description: LEAD: Gary McCord, who carries a microphone on courses these days when he isn't carrying a set of clubs, has caused a big stir in the ranks of PGA Tour officials.

title: Miss Dickey Plans To Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Dickey Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Heather Ingham Dickey to John Andrew Schneeberger, a son of Mrs. Howard J. Schneeberger of Williamsville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Schneeberger. An April wedding is planned.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
S.A.T. Exams: One Size Doesn't Fit All
description: LEAD: A PECULIAR mystique surrounds society's one-size-fits-all philosophy. Like Cinderella's sisters, desperate to squeeze into the wrong slipper, we sometimes try vainly to mold ourselves into an ill-fitting preconception.

title: Upper West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls. I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over. What kind of adhesive should be used, and what paint can then be used over the canvas? Can the canvas be removed later?

title: Donnah Ellen Brown Wed To M. A. Winger, Physicist
description: Donnah Ellen Brown, a daughter of Sara Jane Drescher of Hollywood, Fla., and Robert S. Brown of Hamden, Conn., was married in Hollywood last evening to Mark Alan Winger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Winger of Elyria, Ohio. Rabbi Robert Frazin performed the ceremony at Temple Solel.

title: 'Within the Plantation Household'
description: To the Editor:

title: Guide to Estimated Daily Expenses in 30 Places Around the World
description: A sampling of per diem rates set for February 1985, 1988 and 1989 by the State Department for Government employees traveling abroad on official business. The rates are based on the cost of ''adequate, moderately priced meals and lodging'' including tax and tips, plus such incidentals as laundry and dry cleaning. While the figures do not necessarily correspond to what a traveler would spend, they provide a guage for comparing costs in different cities and for seeing how the strength of the dollar has changed from last year at this time and since early 1985, when the dollar was at its highest point in recent years.

title: Poetry Born of an Indomitable Spirit
description: LEAD: Last year when he was a senior at Midland Park High School, Bill Nicholas wrote a poem for his English class. It was the first time a poem of his had been exposed to analysis and possible criticism, and the experience changed his life.

title: Leader of Union at Center of Strike Is Accustomed to Being in Spotlight
description: The role of lightning rod is nothing new for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which has cultivated a reputation for being one of the most militant and left-leaning unions in the nation.

title: Retirement Plans
description: Because of the changes wrought by the 1986 tax act, William H. Sterling and his wife, Marion, can no longer deduct the $4,000 they contribute each year to individual retirement accounts.

title: Christmas in March For the New Sears
description: Sears began its new life as an ''everyday low prices'' retailer. All 800 stores were closed Tuesday to mark down the prices on 50,000 items. The change was heavily promoted, and Sears store managers said that when the doors opened at midday Wednesday the crowds were bigger than during the Christmas season. The company's retail performance has been lagging for some years, and it hopes the strategy will draw back the customers it has been losing to the discounters. The nation's biggest retailer also thinks the ''everyday'' policy can save it money by sharply reducing the number of special sales events, which require extra labor and advertising expenses. *

title: Wind Shuffles Leaders in Honda
description: Dan Pohl came face to face with the winds of Eagle Trace today, and he suffered for it.

title: Goodbye to Shoreham, Again, Maybe
description: WITH a motto of ''never say never,'' followers of the many twists and turns of the Shoreham nuclear power station are by nature a cautious group. But after the announcement last week of Gov.

title: Training for Joy Before Medals
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: Robert Reich may smell reform in the Cambridge air, but there certainly isn't any in the air over the Potomac. In testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady asserted their beliefs that Wall Street's enthusiasm for the leveraged buyout has reached its peak. Both men stressed caution and vigilance as substitutes for direct legislative action. Mr. Brady said: ''I think it's leveling off, but we can't say for sure. . . . We ought to watch a little longer.''

title: Review/Theater; Oedipus and Dionysus, Set to Music
description: There may be more to Dionysian ecstasy than meets the eye in Ellen Stewart's ''Dionysus Filius Dei,'' performed by the Great Jones Repertory Company at La Mama. But since there are no words in this ''dance opera'' except a minimal vocal score in Greek provided by Elizabeth Swados, what eludes the eye often escapes comprehension and baffles the emotions.

title: Prolific White-Tailed Deer Pose Problem
description: LEAD: WHITE-TAILED deer are coming into focus as a wildlife problem on Long Island, where officials expect them to reproduce in record numbers this spring.

title: NONFICTION
description: TARK: College Basketball's Winningest Coach. By Jerry Tarkanian and Terry Pluto. (McGraw- Hill, $17.95.) Jerry Tarkanian is, according to his fellow coach Abe Lemons, ''the most misunderstood coach in the country.'' The reputation that has dogged Mr. Tarkanian from his early days at Long Beach State through his present stint at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, is that he is not above using shady recruiting practices. In fact, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has investigated Mr. Tarkanian twice and in 1977 ruled that he be suspended from coaching for two years - a decision that Mr. Tarkanian appealed all the way to the United States Supreme Court. With the able help of Terry Pluto, co-author of ''48 Minutes: A Night in the Life of the NBA,'' Mr. Tarkanian gives his side of the story. The result is ''Tark,'' an informative, entertaining, eminently readable book that offers a look at the real Tark: his successes as a high school and junior college coach; his years at Nevada, where he has produced teams consistently in the Top 10, resulting in a program that ''usually clears about $3 million annually''; his close, familial relationship with his players; his personal struggles against the N.C.A.A. (including tips on how to reform it); and a primer of how to successfully recruit and coach a team of players of sometimes limited ability. Mr. Tarkanian is not afraid to tackle controversial subjects, like illegal recruiting, telling of the time Sidney Green, now with the New York Knicks, was offered $15,000 in cash to attend a particular school. As Mr. Tarkanian notes: ''The biggest problem in college basketball is that too many kids are being bought. The coaches know it, the kids know it, and I'm sure the NCAA knows it.''

title: Rabbi Says Paraguay Vows To Find Nazi War Criminals
description: A Jewish group met with Gen. Andres Rodriguez on Friday and said the military ruler promised to find two Nazi war criminals believed living in this country.

title: Accuser of Tower Says Senate Treats Nominee Unfairly
description: Paul Weyrich, the conservative Republican lobbyist whose testimony set off much of the opposition to John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense, said today that the nominee has been treated unfairly in the Senate confirmation process because he has not had a chance to confront his accusers.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 5, 1989
'Carrie's Choice,' A World Premiere
description: ONE of the most rewarding aspects of the season at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is that it always includes a world premiere.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MAKING HEIRLOOMS During a career that spanned 32 years, George Wells was a kind of rug maker to the rich and famous. Audrey Hepburn, Richard Rodgers, the Rockefellers, the Du Ponts and a more-contemporary local celebrity, the soprano Kiri Te Kanawa, all had rugs custom-made at Mr. Wells's Ruggery in Glen Head.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; Soviet Professor Brings First-Hand Look at Glasnost
description: The anchorman of the weekly Soviet television news program ''Good Evening, Moscow'' has been saying ''Good afternoon, Madison'' all semester. As a visiting Fulbright scholar, the anchorman, Boris Notkin, has been teaching a course here on ''Mass Communication and Glasnost.''

title: North Stars Edge Islanders
description: Frantisek Musil's first goal of the season, at 13 minutes 13 seconds of the third period, snapped a 3-3 tie and lifted the Minnesota North Stars to a 4-3 victory over the Islanders today.

title: Hanson's Meteoric Rise
description: Once again, Hanson P.L.C. has Wall Street guessing. In the past few months, Hanson Industries, the British conglomerate's American arm, has bought 9.8 percent of the shares of the Cummins Engine Company, the diesel engine maker based in Columbus, Ind. And with Cummins's shares trading in the mid-60's, up from $50 in mid-December, before Hanson began its purchases, Wall Street sniffs a takeover battle - although Hanson says the shares were acquired for investment purposes.

title: Middle East Backsliding
description: What progress there may have been last year in moving the Arab-Israeli conflict toward negotiations seems to be unraveling. Time is reinforcing hard-liners on both sides.

title: PASTIMES: CAMERA
description: A batch of press releases from the recent Photo Marketing Association gathering in Dallas has formed a foot-high pile on my desk. It's debatable whether this is a boon for a camera columnist, but for photographers, it's good news. Here's a survey of the latest products:

title: Lydia E. Schafhauser To Wed H. C. Sangree
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schafhauser of Summit, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lydia Eva Schafhauser, to Harry Charles Sangree, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sangree of Craigville, Mass. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: PASTIMES: NUMISMATICS
description: War usually takes a toll on coinage. For example, copper cents were replaced by ones made of steel during World War II.

title: Residential Resales

Inc.) Wonica)

title: Computers Are Linking Citizens and City Hall
description: Under a new municipal system, a citizen here with access to a computer can send an angry letter electronically to City Hall, see whether the library has a certain book or check the bus schedule.

title: A Tale of Nazis Stage in Norwalk
description: ''WE'RE doing the best that we can under the most difficult of circumstances,'' says Christel, ever the pragmatist. ''And everyone does his part for the greater glory of the Reich.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The negotiators are en route back to Miami, if they can get a flight.'' - Robin Mattel, chief spokesman for Eastern Airlines. [ 26:1. ]

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Fear of Aflatoxin; The Debate About The Carcinogens That Man Didn't Make
description: IN the war against chemicals that cause cancer, most of the attention has been on man-made substances like pesticides and preservatives. Increasingly, however, some scientists are arguing that the public has been infected with a bad case of chemophobia. Most cancers, they say, come from natural causes - the food, sunlight, plant poisons, tobacco and other things people encounter every day.

title: Upper West Side
description: To the editor:

title: Not So Mythical
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARA'S GIFT 109 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.
description: Among contemporary American writers there are many accomplished stylists, for ours is an age of intense literary activity, much idiosyncratic virtuosity and invention. The general assumption may be that ''realism'' is not an experimental literary convention but simply ''the way things are''; but practicing writers know that all genres, all visions, all artful employments of language are conventions, freely available to the virtuoso. Of presumed ''realists'' no contemporary of ours is more consistently brilliant and defiantly risky than Saul Bellow, our genius of portraiture.

title: Afghan Invasion Began in Political Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Oath Prescribed for Teachers of Catholic Theology
description: In a move that could provoke a sharp reaction from Catholic colleges and universities, the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith has published an oath of fidelity to all official church teachings that will be required of teachers of Catholic theology as well as church officials.

title: Italy Lawmakers Seek U.S. Convict's Release
description: Almost 300 Italian lawmakers have begun a campaign to win freedom, or at least deportation, for an Italian woman who was convicted in New York of Federal conspiracy and racketeering charges related to the 1981 Brink's armored-car holdup and triple murder in Rockland County.

title: 'Kiddie Tax' Makes Saving for College Harder
description: Parents should begin setting aside money for their children's college educations as soon as possible, financial planning experts say. Tax changes have killed many of the popular devices that once helped to increase the value of college funds.

title: TALKING: Roommates; Co-ops Face Loss Of Control
description: NEW YORK CITY co-op boards have traditionally enjoyed the right to screen incoming residents and even restrict occupancy to shareholders and members of their immediate family. That right was always underscored and confirmed by the terms of the proprietary lease.

title: Correction
description: A discography on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the pianist Vladimir Feltsman misidentifies the orchestra and conductor for a Prokofiev series on CBS Masterworks, and the works involved. The recordings, of the First and Second Concertos, are by the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: The acquisition of Kiki Vandeweghe by the Knicks is a two-edged sword.

title: STYLE MAKERS: Oribe; HAIR STYLIST
description: Women who fancy $125 haircuts by Oribe are now making appointments for January 1990. This is chancy, they realize, since when the big day arrives, the Cuban-born stylist may be off in exotic climes arranging models' tresses for high fashion photography. Even if Oribe (pronounced or-REE-bay) happens to be at one of his two uptown Manhattan salons, he may decide, as he did the other day, not to cut.

title: Shevardnadze and Baker: Two Southerners Who Can Deal
description: How much could a Princeton-educated Texas millionaire have in common with a Communist Party apparatchik who made his reputation breaking underworld racketeers in the rough-and-tumble Soviet region of Georgia? In the case of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the answer is a lot.

title: Iranians Send Antidote for Viper Bite in U.S.
description: Physicians treating a snake-bite victim whose need for rare medicine prompted White House intervention received the serum from Iran today, but a hospital spokesman said it might not be used.

title: Partial Eclipse Tuesday
description: The sun will be partly obscured for millions of Americans Tuesday morning, the United States Naval Observatory reported Thursday. People in Hawaii and most of the western two-thirds of the United States and Canada will be able to see the eclipse as the new Moon passes between the Sun and the Earth. For Alaskans, about 70 percent of the Sun will be covered, said astronomers at the McDonald Observatory of the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Beds for Less Than a King-Size Budget
description: THE last time I took an auto trip around France, 25 years ago, we usually stayed in the local Hotel de la Poste, or above the restaurant where we ate, picking a more expensive place every couple of days to take a shower. But since then, chains of motels, have created new choices for the budget-conscious.

title: Through the Form 1040, Step by Step
description: Both those who turn to a professional for tax preparation and those who go it alone can benefit by studying an expertly prepared return. It will help taxpayers organize this year's records and may suggest tax strategies for future years, as well as aid in filling out the forms.

title: Pressure Is On for Guidry and John
description: There could not have been more than two dozen spectators in the stands when Ron Guidry walked from the bullpen to the mound and made his pitch to win a job with the Yankees today.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CURBING MEDICAL EXPENSES;
Tie Payments to Science, Not Hunches
description: LEAD: Case management, the process by which outside review agencies monitor the medical care received by corporate employees, is largely done by third-party administrators. But these third parties are really fourth parties. The doctor and patient are the first two parties, and they don't count for much anymore.

title:
GARDENING;
Forced Flowers Bring Spring Indoors
description: LEAD: THERE is no better way to escape the winter blahs than to fill your house with forced spring flowers from your own garden.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WORKSHOP ARTISTRY

title: Solo or Package? The Choice Is Yours
description: SOONER or later just about every traveler buys a package or tour. Even diehard solo travelers are tempted by the variety of arrangements offered by tour companies and airlines. Today the package need not shape a vacationer's entire trip, locking him or her in a mobile cocoon. It often offers a compromise, mixing hotels and local transportation with freedom to explore, dine out and take side trips. In some cases, an overseas package may consist only of a hotel room for several days and a few frills.

title: Elisa B. Hirsch to Wed M. A. Gordon in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack Hirsch of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisa Beth Hirsch, to Matthew Adam Gordon, a son of Larry Gordon of Glenview, Ill., and Barbara Anderson of Chicago. A May wedding is planned.

title: BEAUTIFUL DAY. GOT MARRIED. LEARNED CANOE LASHINGS
description: KENETI South Seas Adventures of Kenneth Emory. By Bob Krauss. Illustrated. 419 pp. Honolulu: A Kolowalu Book/University of Hawaii Press.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: The story of the journey to Rike's grave in Switzerland (Travel, Jan. 1) brought back memories of a similar pilgrimage I made as a Texas schoolgirl years ago. Lacking a car, I asked in Zurich if a train conductor could make a special stop for me, and if I could then reach the church by foot. He did, and for a while I walked behind a young herdsman gently guiding his cattle with a stick through Raron's narrow streets. Finding the poet's headstone - ''Rose, or pure contradiction'' (I prefer the translation ''paradox'') - was unforgettable.

title: STYLE MAKERS: Judy Smilow and David Tisdale; DESIGNERS
description: About four years ago, Judy Smilow took a course by the designer David Tisdale at the 92d Street Y. The subject was anodizing aluminum for use in jewelry. ''I liked the idea of combining the precious with the not-so-precious, like diamonds and aluminum,'' said Mr. Tisdale, recalling the course Ms. Smilow took. ''But who knew we would end up being partners?''

title: Web of Laws Ensnares An Immigrant Investor
description: When Jack Pointeau came from his native France eight years ago and eventually settled in this small west Texas town, he did everything by the book. He applied for an investor's visa, which is granted to people who intend to invest in the local economy. He renewed that visa every year. He opened a business and paid his taxes.

title: Morris Helps Nets Win Back Respect
description: When the Nets looked in the stands tonight, they saw many fans in the sellout crowd of 20,048 dressed in Boston Celtic green. And during pre-game introductions, the Celtics received as many cheers as the Nets did.

title: Where Turnabout Has Proved Fair Play
description: TRENDY steakhouses offer so much fish nowadays that once uniformly red-meat menus are but a blush and a hint of their former selves.

title: For AIDS Inmates, Prison in a Prison
description: To prisoners, Dorm 7 at the Limestone Correctional Facility here is a prison within a prison, a white masonry-block barracks in which Alabama segregates all prisoners who tests indicate carry the AIDS virus.

title: POSTINGS: Fairview Conversion; 4 Buildings, New Uses
description: A $4 million renovation is under way in Fairview, N.J., that will convert four buildings used over the last 25 years as truck terminals, garment factories and warehouses into a mixed-use office-commercial complex.

title: Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Almost Spring, and That Means Proxy Fever
description: LEAD: When corporate shareholders read the 1989 proxy statements that will soon fill their mailboxes, they will find a record number of resolutions to vote on.

title: SIZZLING SUMMERTIME WEAR
description: Per usual, the American child this spring is being offered a panoply of designs and colors uniting fun and comfort.

title: Art for the People: Bringing It All Back Home
description: AS a teacher of poetry in the schools, a kind of itinerant salesman of a rather dispensable commodity, I travel from district to district. This gives me an unusual opportunity to fathom the character of nondescript places like Elwood, Medford, Selden, East Northport; large expanses of development laid out in rectilinear grids, with a main artery of shopping malls.

title: COUNTRY LOVE AND NAKED LAUNDRESSES
description: LEAD: THE WATCH By Rick Bass. 190 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Barely Bilingual
description: To the Editor: ''Abroad And Barely Bilingual'' described my delight mixed with trepidation when among strange tongues where I make it a rule always to carry a piece of paper in my pocket bearing the name of my hotel. This served me well in downtown Tashkent when boarding a trolley I learned by agitated gestures of the ticket taker after reading the name of my hotel, that I was on the right trolley going in the wrong direction. Signaling the conductor to stop, he ushered me across tracks where he waited with me for the proper conveyance to arrive. After informing that conductor of my destination, I believe he wished me a happy journey before rushing back to his own waiting trolley. So on this day too, speechless, I made it back to my hotel in good order. MALVINE COLE Jamaica, Vt.

title: Aiming to Serve
description: Robert C. McFarlane was an enigmatic player in the Iran-contra drama. A former Marine Corps officer who became national security adviser to President Reagan, he led a secret mission to Teheran in 1986, with a cake and a Bible signed by the President, in a fruitless quest to trade weapons for hostages. In 1987, as the scandal unfolded, he attempted suicide because of a sense, he said later, ''of having failed the country.'' Last week, he became the first figure in the affair to be punished. He received two years' probation, instead of a possible four-year prison term, and a $20,000 fine. He pleaded guilty last year to misleading Congress with assurances that Oliver L. North was obeying its ban on aiding the Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. McFarlane, who is expected to be a prosecution witness at Mr. North's trial, said, ''I'm proud to have served my country.''

title: PATERNAL COMBUSTION
description: LEAD: WATCHING THE BODY BURN By Thomas Glynn. 300 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Dependency Leads to Abuse
description: The trouble with the sports agent industry is that the foxes are in the hen house.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Frank Pallone Jr.; An Environmentalist's Broader Mission
description: FRANK PALLONE JR. of Long Branch is a freshman Congressman and the first one from New Jersey elected to the House of Representatives largely through the efforts of the environmental movement. His Third Congressional District takes in some 500,000 residents in coastal Monmouth and Ocean Counties, from Keyport to Seaside Heights.

title: IN WAS HITLER'S PORNOGRAPHER
description: TOURS OF THE BLACK CLOCK By Steve Erickson. 320 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: Memories Are Made of This
description: When I was a young girl, my favorite afternoons were spent at the counter of the local drugstore. Sipping away on ice cream sodas, I read romance novels and gossiped with my friends. The stools in the drugstore are long gone, but my desire for those perfect ice cream confections remains.

title: Panel Seeks More Family Doctors
description: A New York State panel has recommended sweeping changes in graduate medical education that would ease the shortage of family physicians by dramatically reducing the number of residents trained as specialists.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about efforts to prevent bias on college campuses incompletely identified a participant in a training program. Renell Jackson is a 28-year-old student from Yonkers in his second semester at Westchester Community College.

title: A Bit More for Your Money in Europe
description: NOTWITHSTANDING all of the dollar's pirouettes over the past year, Americans traveling to Europe this spring or summer will be delighted to discover that their vacation money will buy more baguettes, bratwurst, paella and pasta than it did last year.

title: Unesco Courts U.S. With Drive for Literacy
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has announced that 1990 has officially been designated ''International Literacy Year.''

title: Jolie Galen Kahn Wed To Laurence D. King
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck in Kings Point, L.I., last evening, Jolie Galen Kahn, the daughter of Regina C. Kahn and Alan E. Kahn, both of New York, was married to Laurence David King, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chancis King of New York. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: Warranties for New Homes; Law Aids Buyers
description: New York State has a new law intended to give buyers of new homes increased protection against defects such as leaking roofs and faulty plumbing by defining the legal responsibilities of contractors. While state law already had held contractors liable for deficiencies in new homes even in the absence of a formal warranty, the law that went into effect Wednesday defines what is included in the implied warranty. It also sets limits of up to six years, depending on the component of the building, on the builder's liability.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: OFF THE RECORD: An Oral History of Popular Music. By Joe Smith. Edited by Mitchell Fink. Warner, $22.95.) Joe Smith's ''Off the Record'' is not a book to plunk down with on a lazy Sunday and read cover to cover. An anecdotal history of the music industry by the people who made it, this is a book for browsing.

title: THE UNFLAPPABLE OLD MAGICIAN
description: HAROLD MACMILLAN Volume One: 1894-1956. By Alistair Horne. Illustrated. 537 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: Theater Club to Honor Flannery O'Connor
description: The Manhattan Theater Club is to pay tribute to Flannery O'Connor at its annual benefit, tomorrow at 8 P.M., with readings from her works by Stockard Channing, David Dukes and Frances McDormand. The writer's friends and associates Robert Giroux, the chairman of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, and Sally Fitzgerald, who edited her letters and essays, are to be the hosts.

title: Going Hoarse for Literature
description: LEAD: FLAUBERT A Biography. By Herbert Lottman. Illustrated. 396 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Secondary Office Space; In a Sluggish Market, the Pressure's On to Renovate
description: WITH Manhattan office users slowly absorbing a wave of new construction, the owners of less-than-stellar older buildings are coming under intense pressure to renovate their space, sometimes dramatically, to compete in a sluggish rental market, industry professionals say.

title: Agencies Without Bosses Keep Going - But Where?
description: FOR a few months every four or eight years, career civil servants demonstrate that the machinery of Government works well in many respects when nobody is quite in charge. For day-to-day operations, a Cabinet seems unnecessary: Social Security checks are issued, taxes are collected and research on AIDS continues.

title: New Brews for Local Palates
description: LEAD: THE beer business is returning to the state. Nathan Hale Golden Lager was introduced last month and other brands are planned by the New Haven Brewing Company and the Hartford Brewery Ltd.

title: Raising the Level
description: When he went back to Canada from the Seoul Olympics last October after testing positive for drug use and being stripped of his gold medal for winning the 100-meter race, Ben Johnson said he did not knowingly take drugs.

title: Fife and Drum Corps Spans Generations
description: LEAD: IN 1928, a Boy Scout troop was founded in a predominantly black neighborhood of this city. Like the members of many Boy Scout troops, the participants in Troop 16 wanted to march in the town's Memorial Day parade, and so, the following year, a drum corps and color guard was organized.

title: Beirut Crossing Opens, Giving Rise to Hopes
description: In a country inured to trauma during 14 years of war, several events in recent days have given rise to guarded optimism here that the barriers that divide the capital and the nation may be breached.

title: Two Orton Veterans, Once More Into the Breach
description: AT THE MANHATTAN THEATER Club's loft in downtown Manhattan, a rehearsal for Joe Orton's ''What the Butler Saw'' begins with the assistant stage manager being put into a straitjacket. She is only demonstrating it for the benefit of the actors, but it's a necessity that the late Joe Orton - once an assistant stage manager himself - would have found deliciously apropos. By the time the director, John Tillinger, releases his actors for lunch, three of them are similarly trussed, two have been shot, half are drugged and everyone has been declared insane.

title: Harvard Accused of Lag on Minority Hiring
description: Almost a decade after the faculty of Harvard University applauded a report saying the school hired too few women and members of minority groups, a new study has found little progress, according to a report issued here.

title: Social Events; Artists' Retreat
description: March 5 - An artistic sampling of what the Millay Colony for the Arts is all about will be offered at a benefit reception at the Victoria Munroe Gallery, 415 West Broadway (near Prince Street) from 4 to 7. The colony, the former home of Edna St. Vincent Millay, is a 600-acre retreat in Austerlitz, N.Y., where artists can spend a month without cost working at their craft. Since 1974, more than 500 artists in the fields of writing, music and the visual arts have stayed in the colony's rustic cabins. Joel Janowitz will display his landscape paintings at the benefit, and ''Whence It Comes,'' a new work for cello and percussion by Laura Kaminsky will be performed as will a scene from a play by Edward Louis Gold and the poetry of Joe Henry. Barbara Feldon and Anthony Zerbe will read selections of other poetry and prose. Tickets, $40 at the door. Information: 212-226-0040. Purim Ball

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Hair Wild, Eyes Naked

title: Our Kind of Chess
description: To the Editor:

title: Oaxaca
description: To the Editor: Having spent time in Oaxaca nine years ago, I read with interest your story (Travel, Jan. 1) about the decision of the Mexican Government to expand tourism in that mountainous state.

title: Crippled Oil Ship Floats Free
description: An oil tanker that ran aground off the Hawaiian island of Oahu floated free Friday night after salvage workers lightened the ship's load to prevent more crude oil or fuel from spilling into the Pacific Ocean and washing up on Hawaii's beaches. The 800-foot Exxon Houston ''suddenly just started floating,'' a Coast Guard spokesman said, and the ship was towed to deeper water. State and Federal agencies began a cleanup of oil along a section of shoreline 15 miles west of Honolulu. A state natural resources official said there was no immediate evidence of injury or death to marine life or birds.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Swing Your Partner THE Sandinistas weren't there. But at a contra dance, someone is sure to ask, said Chart Guthrie of Port Jefferson.

title: Denise E. Gill Is Engaged To Douglas Hazzard Nash
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Gill of Rochester of the engagement of their daughter Denise Elizabeth Gill to Douglas Hazzard Nash, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Clyde L. Nash Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The couple plan to marry in July.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tampa, Fla.;
An Old Saw Contradicted
description: LEAD: NEW figures compiled by a company that monitors housing in Florida show that a sluggish market persists in Tampa, one of the nation's liveliest markets in the early to middle 80's. Nevertheless, the average sales price is rising. According to Alam Housing Reports, new-home sales in 1988 totaled 2,567, down roughly 18 percent from 1987 sales of 3,028.

title: America's Answer to Japan's MITI
description: While Congress debates how or whether to help American industry compete in the emerging market for high-definition television, a small arm of the Department of Defense is already poised to dispense money to companies and universities to help in development of the technology.

title: BEEHIVE IN BOMBAY
description: SWIMMING LESSONS AND OTHER STORIES FROM FIROZSHA BAAG By Rohinton Mistry. 250 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: SYMPATHY FOR THE ARCHANGEL
description: AUTOBIOGRAPHY Volume Two: 1937-1960. Exile's Odyssey. By Mircea Eliade. Translated by Mac Linscott Ricketts. Illustrated. 224 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $19.95. YOUTH WITHOUT YOUTH AND OTHER NOVELLAS By Mircea Eliade. Translated by Mac Linscott Ricketts. Edited and introduced by Matei Calinescu. 288 pp. Columbus: Ohio State University Press. $18.95.By Robert Irwin

title: A NEW LIFE FOR THE DANCES OF A SOVIET MASTER
description: After a lifetime of ignominy in his homeland and anonymity abroad, the late Soviet choreographer Leonid Jakobson is being rediscovered by American audiences. Last month, in a special gala performance honoring the New York Public Library's dance collection at Lincoln Center, Johan Renvall, an American Ballet Theater principal, performed Jakobson's virtuoso solo ''Vestris.''

title: From Bizarre To Beyond In Bangkok
description: ALMOST everyone who goes to Bangkok pays at least one visit to the National Museum, situated in an old palace and several modern buildings not far from the Grand Palace. Many also take in the Jim Thompson House, a Thai-style residence that displays the art collection of the American who revived the Thai silk industry and mysteriously disappeared in Malaysia in 1967.

title: North Africa's Family Meal
description: COUSCOUS is the kind of dish nouvelle cuisine set out to defy. No matter how it is judged - by sheer volume, by the ferocity of its spices, or just by the whole ceremony of eating it - the North African specialty built on mounds of semolina, vegetables, lamb or chicken is not for the faint-hearted. It is the kind of meal worth planning and waiting for: whatever else, couscous in its traditional form is no light snack.

title: Pharmaceutical Company Shares Its Harvest of Achievement
description: LEAD: IN a recent week at Merck & Company here, scientists revealed a development that could lead to a treatment for AIDS, the company received Federal approval for a new drug to control high blood pressure, and 70 educators and community leaders in New Jersey previewed a television documentary, proposed and financed by

title:
INVESTING;
Low Prices but No Bargains
description: LEAD: Even before last week's announcement that new orders for machine tools had dropped 22.4 percent in January from a year earlier, machine tool stocks had been falling. To some analysts, the order drop is only another reason not to buy the stocks of companies that derive most of their revenues from the power-driven tools used to cut or shape metal parts.

title: Raiders Settle Suit With N.F.L.
description: The Los Angeles Raiders and the National Football League reached a settlement today in the multimillion-dollar antitrust suit involving the league's efforts to block the team's move from Oakland in 1982.

title: Statte's Fiscal Crisis Trickles Down to the Towns
description: WHEN Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed his state budget last month, the Monroe Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Donald W. Maloney, realized he had a problem, a $583,000 problem.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Princeton; Sit-In Protesters Take Appeal To the Alumni
description: When 2,000 Princeton University alumni returned for the annual Alumni Day lunch last month, they were greeted by students passing out literature describing a ''movement towards student empowerment.'' That was three days after 40 of the students held an all-night sit-in at Nassau Hall, which holds the offices of top administrators.

title: LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: Robert B. Reich's article ''Leveraged Buyouts: America Pays the Price'' (Jan. 29) says all the things that my friends and I - people of average income and investment - have felt about this legalized thievery for years. The biggest crime is that the brokerage houses, the executives settling gently to the ground in their golden parachutes and the huge law firms who do all the paper shuffling are the only winners. Discount the little fellow who is talked into buying the junk bonds. He will suffer when these papier-mache intrigues fall of their own weight.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IRA SAYS GOODBYE Written and illustrated by Bernard Waber. 40 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Chartres
description: To the Editor: I was at Chartres last June 23 and was able to see the labyrinth uncovered for the first time in many visits. This was due to the presence of members of a Druid cult who removed the chairs.

title: SCANDAL'S SHADOW TAINTS TAKESHITA
description: For the first time since Japan's ever-widening political scandal came to light eight months ago, it is threatening Japan's two best-known political figures: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and his predecessor, Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: 'Within the Plantation Household'
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Shoreline Be Saved Along Barrier Beaches?
description: LEAD: FROM Halsey Neck Lane in Southampton Village to the more urbanized Atlantic Beach about 80 miles west, a sandy chain of barrier beaches and islands is all that stands between the quiet communities of the South Shore and the turmoil of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE BLACK HEART: A Voyage Into Central Africa. By Paul Hyland. (Holt, $22.95.) Late-19th-century notions of Central Africa, revealed to us in Joseph Conrad's ''Heart of Darkness'' and in journals and popular accounts of such explorers as Stanley and Livingstone, have attached themselves to the Western imagination with all the tenacity of myth. Central Africa, one of the last question marks on the colonial map, was the continent's mysterious core, symbol of the bleakest chambers of the Western heart. Inspired by such notions, the British poet and travel writer Paul Hyland and his wife, Noelle, embarked on a journey up the Congo River (known in Zaire as the Zaire River), retracing the steps of 19th-century adventurers. Traveling by riverboat and dugout, the Hylands struggled up the Congo to Lubunga, site of Conrad's ''Inner Station,'' now an ''undistinguished tin-roofed town.'' They then journeyed to the Lake Mweru region, where Mr. Hyland's great-uncle, a missionary, had dived into the local culture with an anthropologist's zeal. Throughout his account, Mr. Hyland summons the spirits of those who preceded him, often in choppy, disjointed evocations that confuse rather than enlighten. He is at his best when he describes the Zaire of today: remote villages rich in tradition, teeming, discordant cities and the Zairian people themselves, who seem alternately enthralled and amused by the visitors. Occasionally Mr. Hyland glimpses the absurdities of ''the old white myths'' he has set out to examine. In light of Zaire's current problems, including poverty and AIDS, the heart of darkness becomes a much less romantic concept.

title: POSTINGS: Foreclosed Properties; Fantasy Sale
description: Have you always wanted to own your own polo field in Texas? Or a horse-training farm in California? Or perhaps a Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge in beautiful Knoxville, Tenn.? Or an office building in booming Anchorage?

title: Lines Form at Caracas Morgue to Identify Kin
description: Under drizzling gray skies, families gathered outside the city morgue here today for a turn to identify loved ones killed in violent street protests this week against new Government austerity measures.

title: True Fans Find Idols
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Anne Fadiman, a Writer, Wed to George Howe Colt
description: Anne Fadiman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Fadiman of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Captiva, Fla., was married yesterday to George Howe Colt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Colt of Dedham, Mass. Dr. Robert Berson, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated at the couple's New York home.

title: Fine Turntables Survive Quietly In the Age of the Compact Disk
description: A WHILE BACK, PEOPLE IN the hi-fi trade jokingly referred to LP turntables as ''dinosaurs'' - a species about to become extinct. But they mistook the nature of the beast, and nothing of the sort has happened.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold Borough $ $147,500 12 Cottage Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; den, w/w carpeting, Florida room; taxes $2,200. Jackson $ $143,500 59 Butterfly Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; dining room, 2-car garage, hardwood floors; taxes $2,630. Seaside Heights $ $107,000 201 Fremont Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fenced yard, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,066. Short Hills $ $395,000 4 Inverness Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old split-level; deck, fireplace, c/a, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,920. Springfield $ $250,000 314 North View Terrace 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, family room, fireplace, deck; $3,405. Toms River $ $105,000 575 Alfred Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; patio, w/w carpeting, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,139. OTHER AREAS East Patchogue, L.I. $ $120,000 105 Hedges Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,100. Armonk, N.Y. $ $525,000 43 Evergreen Row 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; swim and tennis club membership, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,222. West Simsbury, Conn. $ $178,000 186 West Mountain Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, new kitchen, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,582.

title: 'I HAVE PREENED, I HAVE LIVED'
description: SELF-CONSCIOUSNESS Memoirs. By John Updike. 257 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Review/Dance; Incorporating the Elements Into Choreography
description: Dancers explored the mysteries of space in ''The Weatherfields,'' which Steve Krieckhaus, a Philadelphia-based choreographer, presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. That Mr. Krieckhaus regarded the stage as a symbol of the world itself was implied by the way he incorporated ice, leaves, wood and candles into the action and created a taped score that included the sounds of rain, wind and thunder. Yet although his dancers' journey was serious, it was only intermittently interesting.

title: Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age; Pioneer Programmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Care of Parents
description: Some people who are contributing to the support of aging parents or disabled relatives can look to basic tax devices to cut their costs. Someone who furnishes more than half a family member's support can claim that person as a dependent and take an additional personal exemption, provided that person's gross income does not exceed the amount of the exemption, $1,950 this year.

title: The Trial
description: It could be a story by Kafka.

title: DATABANK: March 5, 1989
A Costly Defeat for St. John's
description: Gary Massey scored the final 8 points of Villanova's decisive 13-1 run in the second half tonight and the Wildcats went on to a 74-60 Big East Conference victory over St. John's.

title: RECENT RELEASES: CLASSICAL
description: Beethoven: Diabelli Variations Sviatoslav Richter, piano. Philips CD 422 416.

title: Riots Break Out in Colombia After Leftist Leader Is Slain
description: Riots broke out in some suburbs of the Colombian capital after gunmen shot dead a leader of the leftist Patriotic Union party, the police and witnesses said today.

title: Fast Spread of Ticks Surprises Experts
description: LEAD: TICKS infected with the Lyme disease organism are spreading ''extensively and more rapidly than expected'' into lower New York State and across Long Island, according to the State Health Department official monitoring the trend.

title: Molloy Star Honored
description: In a conclusion that seemed foregone long before the season began, Kenny Anderson of Archbishop Molloy in Queens has been named high school basketball player of the year by Parade Magazine. The 6-foot-2-inch guard, who has announced he will attend Georgia Tech next year, also became the second three-time member of Parade's all-America team, joining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who was known as Lew Alcindor when he attended Power Memorial High School in New York 25 years ago. Among the nine other players chosen to the first team by a panel of college coaches and recruiters was Bob Hurley Jr. of St. Anthony High in Jersey City, whose father coaches the team, ranked first in the nation.(AP)

title: Mississippi Seeks to Save Freed Slave's Home
description: A movement is under way to preserve the home of a pre-Civil War black man whose violent death went unpunished because of discrimination.

title: Cara Marie Navin And John Moxley To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Navin Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cara Marie Navin to John Winston Moxley, the son of Dorthy E. Moxley of New York and Lake Tahoe, Calif., and the late John David Moxley. An April wedding is planned. Miss Navin, the vice president of advertising and promotion for Beauty Handbook, a quarterly magazine in New York, graduated from the Kent Place School and Wheaton College. She is a member of the New York Junior League. Her father is a vice president and the corporate secretary of the ITT Corporation in New York and a trustee of the New York Law School.

title: Do Some Rockers Hide Out in Dated Styles?
description: I like Lucinda Williams's eponymous album on the Rough Trade label as much as the next person: This is serious, satisfying singing and playing and composing in a gritty folk-blues-rock idiom. But even her most fervent admirers concede that she sounds familiar; indeed, her very familiarity in this slick, syntho-pop era seems deeply comforting.

title: Trammell in Accord
description: Acting as his own negotiatior, Alan Trammell agreed yesterday to a $6.5 million, three-year contract extension with the Detroit Tigers that runs through the 1992 season. In a five-minute session, Trammell suggested a figure to Bill Lajoie, the Detroit general manager, who agreed and shook hands on it.

title: STYLE MAKERS: Derek Ungless; ART DIRECTOR
description: Derek Ungless turns 40 tomorrow, and the slender British art director of Vogue said it does not bother him at all.

title: Mr. Woodcuter, Spare That Tree!
description: A BAY WINDOW overlooking the Supreme Court park is a pleasant place to sit at breakfast, especially early on a holiday morning, when Constitution Avenue is devoid of traffic. At times like this, Capitol Hill is so quiet you can hear your heart beating, and if you are lucky enough to have a great glossy pine growing close to your house, you will sometimes catch another sound, the purest in nature: wind hissing through needles.

title: Crowd in Brooklyn, Angered at Slashing, Beats a 16-Year-Old
description: A crowd of Hasidic Jews surrounded and beat a black teen-ager who they believed had just slashed a Hasidic woman and her son during a robbery in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn Friday night, the police said.

title: Lisa M. Goldenberg Married
description: Lisa Meryl Goldenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Goldenberg of East Hills, L.I., was married yesterday evening to David Michael Barse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Barse of East Hills. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Probert Banned After Arrest
description: Bob Probert, the troubled Detroit Red Wings forward, was expelled from the National Hockey League yesterday, two days after he was arrested and charged with smuggling cocaine.

title: Changing Team Chemistry Adds Risk to Equation
description: How important is chemistry in the National Basketball Association?

title: THE ENDLESS WAR: THE RETURN OF THE KHMER ROUGE
description: AT DUSK, WHEN ALL THE WESTERN relief workers have left for the day, blue Chinese-made trucks drive up to Site 8. Nudging the Thai-Cambodian border, Site 8 is run by the Khmer Rouge. Soldiers in green Chinese-made fatigues supervise the loading and unloading of the sullen cargo - men and women compelled under guard to carry Chinese ammunition, weapons and mines to Khmer Rouge forces fighting inside Cambodia.

title: 'Self-Consciousness'
description: When a memoir by a writer as well known as John Updike appears, it inevitably arouses curiosity. But this is not a tell-all autobiography. It consists of six discontinuous chapters: total recall is evidently not proposed. Mr. Updike's method is Lytton Strachey's in ''Eminent Victorians'': to intuit a life by taking samples of it, making forays into its hinterland and asking the reader to assume that gaps between the specified items could readily be filled by more of much the same substance.

title: Starlight's Stars Brighten A Ballroom
description: Across town at the New York Hilton, stars glittered at the Starlight Foundation's New York benefit. More than 1,200 people attended a dinner and show, which included dancing and singing by Melba Moore and Ben Vereen. Mr. Vereen performed on stage and off, whirling through the ballroom and on and off several chairs.

title: Run for Your Life
description: A courageous but obscure traveler from named Nathaniel Bishop from my hometown of Medford, Mass., rowed a small boat called a ''sneakbox'' 2,000 miles from upper New York State to New Orleans in 1877 or so. When he got there, exhausted, and tied his boat to a jetty, a group of young drunks congregated and threw bottles at him.

title: Kathryn Gressens Wed in California
description: At the Chapel of the Sacred Heart Schools in Menlo Park, Calif., Kathryn Anne Gressens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Gressens of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel James Crawford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Crawford of San Carlos, Calif. The Rev. Edward Phelan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. Mrs. Crawford, who attended Boston College, is an administrative assistant with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. Her father retired as the president of GTE International, the communications concern, in Stamford, Conn.

title: THE RIGHT TO BE DISGUSTING
description: JERRY FALWELL V. LARRY FLYNT The First Amendment on Trial. By Rodney A. Smolla. 336 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

title: Review/Music; Verdehr Trio Promotes A Rare Configuration
description: The premise of the Verdehr Trio's series at Merkin Concert Hall, according to their program notes Monday night, is that the violin-clarinet-piano combination - used by Bartok in his ''Contrasts'' but by few other composers - ''has the qualities inherent in a major chamber music medium.'' Through commissions, arrangements and recordings, the three players (Walter Verdehr, Elsa Ludewig-Verdehr and Gary Kirkpatrick) are endeavoring to establish it as such.

title: OILFIELD PRACTICES VIEWED AS THREAT TO LAND IN ARCTIC
description: Improper and careless management of chemical and oil wastes on Alaska's North Slope is seriously damaging the delicate tundra environment there, according to an unpublished draft report by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: PASTIMES: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: Prune, prune, prune, everything from grapevines, to summer-flowering shrubs to overgrown hedges to small trees; leave the tending of large shade trees to professional arborists who have the ropes, saws, equipment and knowledge to tend them. Keep up with seed planting indoors. Finish planning the garden. This is a good month to have power tools and mowers serviced before the spring rush. On Pruning

title: State AIDS Council Attacks Cuomo Over Delays
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came under attack last week from state officials who accused him of holding up funds already set aside for AIDS services and postponing programs planned to begin this year.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: EVENING OF TORME On Tuesday, the State Theater in New Brunswick will present an evening to remember: Mel Torme singing, with George Shearing on piano.

title: Review/Rock; The Blackhearts, a Jett-Propelled Band
description: There is nothing subtle about Joan Jett. At the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, where she is winding up her latest tour with a five-night stand, Ms. Jett and her band, the Blackhearts, simply pounded out song after song whose titles tell their stories - ''Bad Reputation,'' ''Do You Wanna Touch Me,'' ''I Love Rock-and-Roll.''

title: A Fresh Twist for an Oft-Told Romantic Tale
description: The Basel Ballet's recent season at the City Center was a reminder that the dance world is filled with ghosts in search of choreographic flesh. These wraiths are ballet scenarios or musical scores that continue to haunt choreographers, sometimes for centuries.

title: FICTION
description: KILL THE POOR. By Joel Rose. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $8.95.) Sharp, savage and extremely well written, this provocative first novel examines a politically troublesome and ethically troubling issue - the gentrification of impoverished urban neighborhoods - with the stylistic flair and easy nihilism characteristic of New York's downtown scene. Joel Rose, editor of the literary magazine Between C & D, brings an interesting historical perspective to his tale of conflict between middle-class whites and the poor (but not necessarily virtuous) people they're squeezing out of the Lower East Side. His protagonist, Jo-Jo Peltz, knows the area intimately: his grandmother came there from Hungary in 1903; his mother was born on the very block where he and his pregnant wife buy an apartment; the synagogue he attended as a boy is across the street, though now a looted ruin. Jo-Jo's family can't believe he would go back to the slum they spent most of their lives working to get out of. And indeed little seems to have changed, except that now young professional couples compete with drug dealers and muggers for control of the streets - and vie with welfare families for possession of the area's crumbling buildings. Mr. Rose vividly captures the volatile atmosphere of this bizarre and intriguing neighborhood, where gossipy street-corner camaraderie and random violence coexist and, on occasion, overlap. There's not a lot of depth to his characters, nor to his social philosophy; he seems to accept dog-eat-dog as the natural rule of human existence and never considers the possibility that blame might be assigned and solutions found for the tensions of the Lower East Side. Still, he uses his biting humor to compel the reader to consider the nasty particulars of a contemporary problem, and that's no small achievement.

title: RECENT RELEASES: POP/JAZZ
description: 'Honkers and Bar Walkers, Volume One' Delmark Dl-438, LP only.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CIVIL TO STRANGERS: And Other Writings, by Barbara Pym. Edited by Hazel Holt. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) This posthumous collection of unpublished fiction includes the title piece, a novel written in 1936, about an exotic Hungarian whose arrival shakes up a quiet Shropshire village. ''What we value most in Barbara Pym - her humor, her love of detail, the pleasure she took in what she called the 'trivial round and common task' - is all here, in writing that is at once restrained and fluent,'' Patricia T. O'Conner said in The Book Review last year. SEASON TICKET: A Baseball Companion, by Roger Angell. (Ballantine, $4.95.) In his pieces for The New Yorker, Roger Angell writes so well about baseball thatJU his prose is savored even by people who don't like the game. ''The next best thing to being at a baseball game is reading Roger Angell, our laureate of the pastime,'' Joel Conarroe said here last year. In this collection, ''he creates a sense of baseball's 'elegant and arduous complexity, its layered substrata of nuance and lesson and accumulated experience.' '' The publisher has also reissued Mr. Angell's earlier book, LATE INNINGS: A Baseball Companion ($4.50). When it was published in 1982 our reviewer, Mark Harris, said the author ''never draws upon the stock of jargon that has been gathering for a century. He sees things by looking at them, not by remembering what has been so often said about them.'' SHAME, by Salman Rushdie. (Vintage International, $9.95.) In a country that is ''not quite Pakistan,'' the author of ''The Satanic Verses'' tells ''a sort of modern fairy tale'' about a warrior who seems a lot like Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq and his rival, a fictional stand-in for Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. In 1983 our reviewer, Robert Towers, said Mr. Rushdie's style is ''a source of delight, a bright stream of words that lifted me happily past the most threatening snags and whirlpools of this impossible tale.'' DANGEROUS DOSSIERS: Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors, by Herbert Mitgang. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Using the Freedom of Information Act, Herbert Mitgang, a Times cultural correspondent, obtained secret files the Federal Bureau of Investigation kept on Sinclair Lewis, William Faulkner, Thomas Mann, Dorothy Parker and some 30 other literary suspects. ''If Susan Sontag meets with writers in Eastern Europe, or if William Styron shows up with Daniel Ortega Saavedra in Costa Rica, can the F.B.I. really be far behind?'' Elinor Langer wrote here last year. ''The great importance of [ this book ] is that it makes it impossible not to ask such questions.'' LAST LETTERS FROM HAV, by Jan Morris. (Vintage, $6.95.) A veteran travel writer visits a strange Arabian city that exists only within the geography of her mind. ''Jan Morris is to other travel writers what John le Carre is to other spy novelists,'' Thomas M. Disch said here in 1985. ''She has the knack of her fellow masters . . . of being able to barge in on strangeness and feel immediately at home.'' THE ZURICH AXIOMS, by Max Gunther. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) Diversification is not always good, writes the author of this book on secrets of the Swiss bankers, and one should never take long-range plans too seriously. In 1985 our reviewer, Jan M. Rosen, called this investment guide ''an amusing and useful counterpoint to the conventional wisdom.'' THE IDEAL, GENUINE MAN, by Don Robertson. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) A good ole boy from Houston whose wife is dying of cancer becomes a mass murderer. In 1987 our reviewer, Christopher Shaw, said this novel is ''rendered largely in the drawl of low-life Texans, with occasional flashes of vivid language. The prose has whiffs of Charles Bukowski and Stephen King.'' HOUSE OF DREAMS: The Collapse of an American Dynasty, by Marie Brenner. (Avon, $4.95.) If the members of the Bingham family had been able to communicate with one another as well as their newspaper, The Louisville Courier-Journal, communicated with the people of Kentucky, then perhaps one of the great journalistic dynasties would not have fallen apart. ''Without question there are all the dramatic ingredients here to make one reflect on fatal flaws and the working out of divine retribution,'' The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said when this story of the family's decline was published last year. JAPANESE TALES. Edited and translated by Royall Tyler. (Pantheon, $12.95.) When these stories from medieval Japan were published in 1987, our reviewer, Marian Ury, said, ''Few readers who start the book will be able to resist going through to the end. The Grimms' tales have become English classics, and it is quite possible that Mr. Tyler has created something similar.'' SHORES OF REFUGE: A Hundred Years of Jewish Emigration, by Ronald Sanders. (Schocken, $14.95.) From the pogroms of czarist Russia and the Holocaust to the era of the Soviet refuseniks, Ronald Sanders tells the story of Jews who successfully fled persecution. This is a ''fascinating and in many ways comforting book,'' Martin Gilbert said here in 1988. THE BEAN TREES, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95) When the rear tires of her Volkswagen blow out, Taylor Greer finds her calling. She decides to settle in Tucson, Ariz., working at Jesus Is Lord Used Tires, which doubles as a sanctuary for Central American refugees. Last year our reviewer, Jack Butler, called this first novel ''a remarkable, enjoyable book, one that contains more good writing than most successful careers.''

title: Review/Dance; A Choreographic Look At 18th-Century France
description: History danced back to life on Friday night in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. This miracle was accomplished through a mixture of research and imagination. The New York Baroque Dance Company, directed by Catherine Turocy, and Concert Royal, an early-music ensemble directed by James Richmond, joined forces in ''Dance in Revolution,'' an evening commemorating the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

title: Injured Rangers Stay on Top
description: For the Rangers, the injuries have hit hard and often recently, depleting their defense and disarming their attack. Their consolation has been that for all their recent injuries, there has been almost no damage to their position in the Patrick Division.

title: Just Cutting Care Won't Cut Costs
description: In pursuit of a painless method for containing hospital costs, American industry now has a new white knight: utilization review. A rapidly-growing breed of cost-management companies - under contract to employers and insurers - that decide if hospital admissions are justified, monitor length-of-stay and carry out other cost-containment functions.

title: More and More in Private Soviet Medical Clinics, the Doctor Is Out for Good
description: Galina Pokrovskaya rushed into the offices of the privately operated Filatovetz children's cooperative clinic, frantically looking for a neurologist for her son, Andrei.

title: 'Day One': A Primer on the A-Bomb's Birth
description: Unlike the atomic bomb whose creation it chronicles, ''Day One'' doesn't get the Geiger counters clicking. Tonight's play, at 8 on CBS, is not without force, particularly toward the conclusion, when scientists, military men and Washington officials come into conflict over the rush to ready a bomb to drop on Japan. But much of the three hours chugs worthily along like a high-school history aid.

title: Make No Mistake: It's a Remake
description: To the Editor:

title: Traditional Sex Roles Plague the Computer Age; Encouragement Needed
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WINNERS AND LOSERS: The 1988 Race for the Presidency - One Candidate's Perspective. By Paul Simon. (Continuum, $17.95.) Paul Simon's run for the Democratic Presidential nomination began late and ended early, but it garnered the Senator from Illinois ample material for a revealing, provocative book about how Americans pick their Presidents.

title: Who Is Eligible To Vote May 2
description: All registered voters in New York City as well as all ''parent voters'' are eligible to vote in the community school board elections on May 2.

title: Couple Organizes Class Reunions
description: LEAD: DAVID and Cynthia Fox are in the business of bringing people together every decade or so.

title: A LIFELONG CASE OF 'THE MORBIDS'
description: THAT SINGULAR PERSON CALLED LEAR A Biography of Edward Lear, Artist, Traveller and Prince of Nonsense. By Susan Chitty. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Your Taxes Business/Section 3
description: As the filing deadline approaches -April 17 this year - taxpayers are finding new complexities. A special section on problems from Form 1040 through retirement strategies. Pages 15-27.

title: Voracious Gypsy Moths Rising Again
description: After three years in decline, gypsy moths, which have devoured millions of acres of foliage in past years, are expected to return in strength this spring to plague the trees of the Northeast.

title: Alternative Tax Trap
description: There is actually good news concerning the alternative minimum tax, namely the A.M.T. credit, which goes into effect for the first time this year. With careful planning, professionals say, it could significantly reduce many taxpayers' liabilities. The bad news is that, with the restructuring in tax rates, the alternative minimum tax will apply more broadly than ever before.

title: Audited? No Need To Panic
description: Few phrases cause as much terror as ''tax audit.'' It conjures up visions of sinister agents disallowing deductions and imposing penalties and back taxes that rival a New York condominium in cost.

title: In St. Croix's Heart, Artists in Wood
description: IN the heart of the rain forest, 15 miles from Christiansted, St. Croix's largest town, a group of artisans designs and builds one-of-a-kind utensils, clocks, bookends, mirrors, tables and sculptures from mahogany and other native woods.

title: Bangladesh Ferry Capsizes; At Least 23 Reported Dead
description: A crowded ferry capsized today in southern Bangladesh, and least 23 people were drowned, news reports said. Many other people were missing. Three bodies were recovered from the hull of the ferry after rescue teams hauled the boat out of the swift currents of the Kancha River, the United News of Bangladesh said. The 20 other bodies were found during a search of the accident site, the agency said.

title: THE CASE FOR TAKEOVERS
description: Carl Icahn's rhetoric belies his actions. In 1987, he attempted, unsuccessfully, to take over USAir, the most consistently profitable and well-managed airline in the industry.

title: Running on Less Can Pay Off
description: If gambling fever made Darrell Waltrip and his crew take the chance that won the Daytona 500 last month, the man they may have caught it from was Gary Nelson, a former crew chief for Waltrip's teammate, Geoff Bodine, and someone always willing to go the extra mile on fuel consumption.

title: U.S. Seeks to Ease Harbor Crowding
description: LEAD: GROSVENOR ELY, owner of the Ely Boatworks, said he did not think the Five Mile River was overcrowded with moorings. ''A knowledgeable skipper can make it through there with no problem,'' he said.

title: Lisa Beckerman Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Gaye Beckerman, a daughter of Carolyn C. Chapman of Union City, Tenn., and Ross P. Beckerman of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday in Coral Gables, Fla., to Rodney Lee Stenlake, a son of Mae Stenlake of Washington, N.J., and the late Harold Stenlake. Judge Barry J. Stone of the Florida Fourth District Court of Appeals in West Palm Beach performed the ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: Title Game of Sorts Grows in Brooklyn
description: When the Public Schools Athletic League decided for the first time to rank the final eight teams in the basketball quarterfinals instead of playing four borough championships, it meant there would probably not be a Brooklyn championship game this year.

title: Executive Network Seeks Business Ties
description: LEAD: NETWORKING is not a new idea, but a group of people who work in Westchester believe that they have come up with a fresh way to make business connections in the county.

title: Review/Theater; The Political Circe Of the Gang of Four
description: Before she became the wife of Mao Zedong and, subsequently, the most powerful woman in China, Jiang Qing was an actress. One of her favorite roles was Nora in ''A Doll's House,'' which she played in Shanghai in 1935. Beginning with these facts and Jiang's trial as one of the notorious Gang of Four, Leslie Mohn has created an irreverent, freewheeling political escapade titled ''White Boned Demon.'' The title refers to Jiang, who, after her downfall, was attacked as a Circe-like temptress. The play, a production of the Red Eye Collaboration - a Minneapolis equivalent of the Mabou Mines - is now at Theater for the New City.

title: The Princeton Corridor: Boom Runs Out of Gas
description: IT could be Dallas without the skyscrapers or Denver without the mountains. But what Route 1 does have in common with those cities as it runs through central New Jersey is lots of brand new office space crying out for tenants.

title: Solidarity Aides Assert Warsaw Stalls Talks
description: Solidarity accused the Government today of stalling at talks on Poland's future as four-week-old negotiations encountered new difficulties.

title: Sports of The Times; Why the Mets Lost Langston
description: He's the best pitcher not enough people know. Mark Langston works for the Seattle Mariners, so he toils in obscurity. Almost in exile.

title: 'It Isn't a Simple, One-Way Answer'
description: STUART F. SPICKER, professor of community medicine and health care at the University of Connecticut, specializes in medical ethics. He is not the holder of a medical degree, but of a doctorate in philosophy.

title: Big Screens and Little Ones
description: Warner Communications Inc., born in the Hollywood of the early 1920's as Warner Brothers, today is the largest record and television production company in the United States and one of the biggest film production companies in the world.

title: IN QUOTES
