description: ''Someone had to use the product for at least a week to get used to it, and that's an extraordinary requirement for a consumer. We live in the world of instant gratification.'' Lawrence Adelman, analyst at Dean, Witter on the smokeless cigarette.

title:
ART;
Exhibition Continues the Spirit of Valentine's Day
description: LEAD: WE won't see Valentine's Day again until next Feb. 14, but its spirit lingers on at the Wunsch Arts Center's Sabbeth Art Gallery in Glen Cove, where ''Red Hearts and Flying Cupids,'' an exhibition of valentines, will be on view through March 19.

title: This 'Chocolat' Is Bittersweet
description: LEAD: The French film director Claire Denis is sitting in a Left Bank brasserie, bored by her turbot, bored by the Parisian smart set parading by. She is a slight, almost frail-looking figure, wrapped in layers of gray and black sweaters, as if this mild day in Paris still chilled her right to the bone.

title: High Notes in High Places
description: LEAD: TRAVELING to Italy last August, I hoped, in 38 days, to attend as many performances of opera, dine on as much Italian food, consume as much fine wine and speak well as much of the language as I could. Given these gilt-edged ambitions, it may seem odd that I arranged to purchase no opera tickets in advance.

title: 2 Men Charged in Slaying Of a Policeman in Flatbush
description: Two men were charged yesterday in the slaying of a plainclothes police officer who, the authorities said, was killed with his own gun in a struggle with the suspects on a Brooklyn street early Friday.

title: Kate H. Compton, A Banker, Weds Peter A. Lareau
description: Kate Hurlbut Compton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Robert Compton Jr. of Andover Township, N.J., and Peter Armour Lareau, the son of Mrs. George Arthur Lareau of New Bedford, Mass., and the late Mr. Lareau, were married in New York yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers and the Rev. Robert H. Malm, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Treacherous Times in the Bond Market
description: Beware of long bonds and intermediate notes, money managers are both preaching and practicing. They have been selling large amounts of these securities in recent weeks, which explains why the yields of both issues have moved up sharply. In the past month, the yields of 30-year bonds have risen to 9.13 percent, up from 8.7 percent, while the yields of seven-year Treasury notes have increased to 9.34 percent from 9.01 percent.

title: Polishing Thier Image with Consumers, Even First Graders
description: Plastics may well have shaken their image as cheap and tacky materials. But now, with mounting concern over the heaps of plastics piling up in the country's landfills, manufacturers are struggling to deflate the notion of plastics as polluters.

title: INSIDE
description: Arms Talks Set to Begin

title: MAPPING THE TRACES MAN LEAVES ON THE LAND
description: Although they share a surname and a reverence for the American West, one would be hard pressed to find two more dissimilar landscape photographers than Ansel Adams and Robert Adams. The widespread popularity of Ansel Adams's pictures is rooted in a purposeful exclusion: he photographed primarily in wilderness preserves and eliminated all signs of human presence. Robert Adams's images focus on the frontier between the human and natural worlds, showing us what the land looks like once it has become inhabited. Consequently they are both more convincing and more disturbing.

title: Irish Player Died Of a Heart Defect
description: A congenital heart defect caused the death of Bob Satterfield, a reserve offensive and defensive back on the Notre Dame national champion football team who collapsed and died suddenly at a nightclub in Niles, Mich., Jan. 19, a Medical Examiner's report said.

title:
The View From: The Child Care Association;
Providing Children a Home Environment Away From Home
description: LEAD: DURING the winter, some of the children arrive when the sun is barely up and leave after it has set. In the early morning, participants in programs run by the Child Care Association of Scarsdale eat hot waffles or cold cereal, orange juice and milk. The grownups - teachers, aides and the director - put out boxes of Rice Crispies and Raisin

title: Leeanne Olicker to Wed
description: The engagement of Leeanne Chari Olicker to Dr. Joshua Port, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Port of Altoona, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Olicker of Williston Park, L.I. A May wedding is planned. Ms. Olicker, a legal assistant at Tighe, Evan & Ehrman, a Pittsburgh law firm, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Port, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the University of Pittsburgh Hospital, graduated from Penn, where he also received an M.D. degree.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: END MAY BE NEAR FOR ITALY'S LEADER
description: In office almost 11 months, Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita is at a point where most postwar Italian leaders have begun to reach for their coats and head toward the exit.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The oil base paint applied to my concrete ceilings three years ago is peeling, but the same paint is not peeling from the walls. I was told that this is due to a faulty concrete mix when the building was put up 35 years ago. A friend suggested I cover the ceilings with canvas that could then be painted over. What kind of adhesive should be used, and what paint can then be used over the canvas? Can the canvas be removed later?

title: Parents Test Telephone Report Card
description: WHEN Katherine Coyne of Guilford wants to find out how her son in the fourth grade or daughter in kindergarten are doing in school, she does not have to schedule special conferences with their teachers.

title: 2 Parties Follow Separate Primary Paths
description: DEMOCRATS and Republicans are following different paths as they prepare to choose their candidates for governor in the June 6 primary. Most Democratic leaders appear to have already settled on a standard-bearer, while a potentially divisive race is shaping up in the Republican Party.

title: Snuffing It Out
description: If a Ford Edsel could be rolled and smoked, it might be called the Premier. The ''smokeless'' cigarette that the R. J. Reynolds Company spent $325 million to develop and promote was taken off the shelves last week after a notably cool reception from smokers and the heated opposition of health groups. Smokers said the product did not burn like a cigarette; the user inhaled air that was heated by a glowing charcoal-like lump and then passed over rolled tobacco and an aluminum ''flavor capsule'' containing nicotine. Nor did it taste like a cigarette.

title: Rushdie's Book Is an Insult
description: In preparation for the Middle East negotiations that led up to Camp David and the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty, I tried to learn as much as possible about the Moslem faith.

title: Retired Sergeant Sticks by Statement About Tower
description: A retired Air Force sergeant continued to insist today, despite efforts by some senators to discredit him, that the dignitary he saw under the influence of alcohol on two occasions at an Air Force base in Texas was John G. Tower.

title: Baryshnikov Crawls Into Kafka's Maze
description: AS MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV AWOKE ONE morning from uneasy dreams, he found himself transformed in his bed into a Broadway actor. And even though he was afraid, he liked what he saw. He liked it even better than ballet.

title: Car Theft Is Epidemic
description: Yesterday, five minutes after I read the article concerning the car-theft situation at Green Acres Shopping Center [ ''Car Theft Fraud Rampant at Nassau Shopping Mall,'' Feb. 19 ] , our family left for the Roosevelt Field movie complex, discussing your article during the entire trip. We realized we'd not patronized Green Acres in years, and felt doubly secure in sighting two mounted policemen on horseback as we arrived at Roosevelt Field.

title: Correction
description: The essay ''And Now, a Word From Our Creator'' on Feb. 12 omitted several words from the first two sentences. The passage should have read: ''An enlightened contemporary minister of a Protestant church in an upscale academic community is about to enjoy a dinner his wife is preparing on the backyard charcoal grill when he hears the voice of God. The Rev. Swain Hammond, a somewhat aloof intellectual graduate of Yale Divinity School, is shaken and disturbed by this experience he neither expects nor wants.''

title: Smoking Bill Draws Criticism From All Sides
description: IN an unusual display of unanimity, tobacco-industry representatives, local business owners and health advocates took turns Wednesday night condemning a county legislative bill to regulate smoking in Westchester's public spaces.

title: Islamic Militants Threaten Nigerian Nobel Winner
description: Islamic militants have threatened to kill Wole Soyinka, the author and Nobel laureate, for his defense of Salman Rushdie and the British author's right to publish ''The Satanic Verses,'' according to diplomats and news reports here.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Routes to Affordability in Westchester
description: LEAD: USING lotteries, density bonuses and subsidies as tools, several Westchester communities are helping to create housing that is affordable by municipal and school employees and by elderly and moderate-income residents.

title: Barely Bilingual
description: To the Editor: I read with enjoyment and a sense of familiarity Carol Asher's article ''Abroad and Barely Bilingual'' (Travel, Dec. 25). I share her sense of adventure in trying to decode and use an unfamiliar language, but an additional interest is the insight it gives into ambiguities that are generally overlooked in everyday use of a familiar language. The realization that such ambiguities exist has led me to be more careful when I search for translations in my foreign language dictionaries.

title: Why We Need to Know So Much About a Nominee's Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Fitzgerald, Student, to Wed Jeffrey S. Jones
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Fitzgerald of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Ellen Fitzgerald to Jeffrey Scott Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jones of Bethesda, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: For Investors, More to Learn
description: Investing and taxes used to be a simple matter. If taxpayers made money on investments, they paid a tax. If the money was made by selling a security held longer than six months, the profit was considered a long-term gain and they paid a reduced tax. And if they borrowed money to pay for the investment, they generally got to deduct the interest.

title: The Science Nobody Knows
description: WERE you, like me, among the adult populace who tut-tutted over the failure of our youth to understand basic economics, as disclosed in a recent national survey? More than half of the 8,000 high school students tested could not define terms like profit and inflation.

title: Flach Promotes Stereotypes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Consumers Prefer Apples and Squash Pure, Not Pretty
description: A GROWING number of consumers are questioning whether the blemish-free fruits and vegetables at their supermarkets are as good for them as they look. Concern is rising about pesticide residue on produce, and the merchants responding to the concern are not just health or specialty stores.

title:
LIFESTYLE;
Clubs Are Easier to Get Into, but a Hip Look Still Counts
description: LEAD: Clubs come and go, but in the last decade one thing has stayed constant: for most people, admission to the most popular clubs has been up to the arbiters of hip stationed at the door.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about regulation of the savings industry misstated the affiliation of Paul M. Horvitz. He is a professor at the University of Houston.

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: Kiki Vandeweghe? For a first-round draft pick? You gotta be kidding.

title: BUYOUT BARON: William F. Farley; Taking Over in a One-Company Town
description: At an emotional rally in the small textile town of Lanett, Ala., last fall, the chairman and chief executive of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the area's largest employer, vowed to keep his company out of the hands of a certain Northern industrialist: William F. Farley.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Hamburg
description: Hamburg is a city best savored in the evening fog, when its crown of thin spires shimmers through the branches of great oaks leaning over the Outer Alster, the larger of the two lakes around which the city lies, and gulls swoop low over the rowing shells gliding silently past.

title:
FOCUS: PHOENIX;
Home Buyers Are Calling the Tune Around Phoenix
description: LEAD: Although the economy in this metropolis is healthier than that of other Southwestern cities because it is not tied to any one element, such as oil, it is suffering from overbuilding. That's bad news for Phoenix but good news for second-home buyers.

title:
FOCUS: Phoenix;
Slow Market Benefits Second-Home Buyers
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the economy in this metropolis is healthier than that of other Southwestern cities because it is not tied to any one element, such as oil, it is suffering from overbuilding. That's bad news for Phoenix but good news for second-home buyers.

title: Ellen DiNoto Marries Arthur Colozzi
description: Ellen Michelle DiNoto, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. John DiNoto of Freeport, L.I., was married there yesterday to Arthur L. Colozzi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Colozzi of Bayside, Queens. The Rev. Ralph Sommer performed the ceremony at Our Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE LEFT SIDE OF CHILDHOOD
description: LOYALTIES A Son's Memoir. By Carl Bernstein. 262 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Karel J. Littman Becomes a Bride
description: At Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York, Karel Joyce Littman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Littman of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Richard L. Weinshank, a son of Zelda Weinshank of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Herman Weinshank. Rabbis Marshall T. Meyer and J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony. Nora Littman, the bride's sister, was the maid of honor, and Fred Weinshank was best man for his brother.

title: Insurance and the Cost of Infertility
description: AS medicine develops more remedies for infertility, a new issue is being examined by employers and insurers, Congress and the states:

title: Question Of the Week; How Will Vandeweghe Affect The Knicks?
description: Kiki Vandeweghe will both help and hurt the Knicks. Kiki is a great shooter and will pour in the forward points that the Knicks have sorely missed. He and Johnny Newman will divide the playing time and both will get their share of time and points.

title: Arlene L. Seipel MarriesEarl E. Ditmars in Texas
description: Arlene L. Seipel, a planning manager for American Airlines at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, and Earl E. Ditmars, who retired from American as the vice president of research, forecasts and traffic, were married yesterday at the All Saints Lutheran Church in Arlington, Tex. The Rev. Scott Cigich performed the ceremony. Mrs. Ditmars, a graduate of Hunter College, is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Henry Seipel of New York.

title: PASTIMES: STAMPS
description: Two pieces of postal history - one a rare Italian folded letter from 1825, the other a common United States postal card from 1887 - tell two tales of tragic women and their families.

title: A TRAIN COLLISION KILLS 5 IN BRITAIN
description: At least 5 people were killed and 80 injured today when two passenger trains collided south of London, sending several train cars plunging down a steep embankment, the authorities said.

title: Union City Journal; 2 Passion Plays Thrive On a 'Friendly Rivalry'
description: ''WHAT thinkest thou, Nicodemus, can be the meaning of this sudden summons of the Sanhedrin?''

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y.$525,000 43 Evergreen Row 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; swim and tennis club membership, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,222. Chappaqua, N.Y.$605,000 8 East Place 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 37-year-old colonial; tennis court, hot tub, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $9,341. Rye, N.Y.$355,000 6 Cowles Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 61-year-old stucco Tudor; enclosed porch, sun room, fireplace; taxes $4,400. Madison, Conn.$415,000 Michele Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new antique-colonial reproduction; Palladian windows, moldings, 1.5 acres; taxes not yet available. West Simsbury, Conn.$178,000 186 West Mountain Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, new kitchen, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,582. Westport, Conn.$795,000 14 Sandpiper Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new waterfront contemporary; crown moldings, exceptional views, 0.5 acre; taxes not yet available. OTHER AREAS Jackson, N.J.$143,500 59 Butterfly Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; dining room, 2-car garage, hardwood floors; taxes $2,630. Seaside Heights, N.J.$105,000 201 Fremont Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fenced yard, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,066. East Patchogue$120,000 105 Hedges Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,100.

title: Adults Relish the Simplicity of Stickball
description: Every Saturday morning, come rain or shine and regardless of the previous evening's revelries, five or six young men gather at a schoolyard on the East Side of Manhattan to swat at a well-worn tennis ball with a broomstick.

title: FICTION
description: PAUSE BETWEEN ACTS. By Mavis Cheek. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) When her trendy television-director husband leaves her for another woman, Joan Battram finds, to her surprise, that she likes living alone. Her problem is that no one will leave her alone. Though this London schoolteacher strives mightily to discourage them, her neighbors and acquaintances insistently invite her out, her parents fret and phone, a muscular young colleague pursues her slavishly, her ex-husband changes his mind and, finally, the famous, meltingly handsome West End actor Finbar Flynn stumbles into her life. This series of unwanted attentions - and Joan's efforts to fend them off - form the fragile comedic skeleton of the British writer Mavis Cheek's first novel. Unfortunately, the skeleton soon collapses under a heap of quickly accumulating annoyances. The dark sarcasm of Joan's first-person narration becomes tedious, and the single metaphor she uses to depict her emotional state (ice) recurs so often that it wears very thin indeed. Most important, the world she sketches is quite unrecognizable. What bitter, recently divorced woman ever found herself plagued by too much attention? What kind of teacher never meets a student or spends an evening grading exams? And where do you get a metabolism that allows you to swill vodka and gobble chocolates yet remain so marvelously slim that matinee idols can't keep away from you?

title: Producers Share Research To Whip the Competition
description: Manufacturers of plastic products say the shortage of qualified polymer scientists and engineers is hampering their ability to compete with foreign rivals. Only a dozen graduate-level programs offer polymer studies in the United States, and the lack of professors prevents them from being expanded, said Frank N. Kelley, dean of the College of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering at the University of Akron.

title: Libraries Struggle with Society's Ills
description: LEAD: LIBRARIES may be quiet havens, but they are not immune to the ills of the society outside their walls. Tight budgets, a shrinking labor pool, latchkey children, idle teen-agers and the information explosion are all causing consternation among library officials and are affecting library services.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Outing; In Armonk, History, And Doughnuts
description: Would you drive an hour for a homemade doughnut? Would you enjoy a day at an old blacksmith's shop or feeding a few ducks? Armonk, N.Y., a hamlet in the Westchester County town of North Castle, offers a quaint destination for any city dweller in the mood to get out of town.

title: Threats From Imports - and Environmentalists
description: Even Mr. Robinson's friend might marvel at just how prevalent plastics have become since his prediction about their promising future in ''The Graduate.'' Last year, sales of resins - the raw materials that plastics are made from - grew to $28 billion. That was up 30 percent from 1984.

title: Partial Merger of Newspapers Delayed Again
description: A Supreme Court Justice today blocked at least until March 17 the partial merger of Detroit's two daily newspapers. The merger was to have begun Monday.

title: In New York City, There Are Many Ways to Be Poor
description: ABOUT 890,000 people are on New York City's welfare rolls, more than half of them children. But the statistic is only part of the picture of city poverty, and the whole is decidedly unclear.

title: Easy Goer Rallies To Win The Swale
description: At 4:30 this afternoon, Easy Goer and Dixieland Brass were the top two prospects for the Kentucky Derby May 6. By 5:30 P.M., Easy Goer looked like a stronger favorite than ever, but Dixieland Brass's career was apparently over.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Although she announced her retirement from track and field last week, Florence Griffith Joyner is the favorite to win the Sullivan Award, the nation's top award for amateur athletes, tomorrow night. Her sister-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, was the winner in 1986. . . . Gary Hogeboom, the former quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys and Indianapolis Colts, has agreed to contract terms with the Phoenix Cardinals. He agreed to a four-year contact worth more than $3 million to serve as a backup to Neil Lomax.

title: Ratings Give Rank to the High Schools
description: These days, the country's No. 1 high school basketball team is St. Anthony of Jersey City. Who says so? The sports editor of the LaPorte (Ind.) Herald-Argus. His name is Dave Krider, and he has become the nation's basketball star-maker, even though he rarely sees any of the teams he selects.

title: The Poison in the Corn
description: Last summer's drought left a legacy of poison that threatens the country's food supply. Dry weather spurred the spread of the fungus that makes aflatoxin, a highly potent inducer of liver cancer. Dangerous amounts of aflatoxin contaminate a fifth or more of the Middle West's 1988 corn crop, much of which is still in storage. Food companies and governments have multilayered defenses in place to screen against the poison, but these now face a vigorous assault.

title: Dr. Ryan Marries Fellow Physican,Dr. R. J. Johnson
description: Dr. Caroline Anne Ryan and Dr. Richard J. Johnson were married yesterday by the Very Rev. Frederick B. Northup at St. Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Seattle. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Francis Ryan of New York and Alpine, N.J. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Richard Johnson of Minneapolis.

title: Time Inc. and Warner to Merge, Creating Largest Media Company
description: Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. announced yesterday that they plan to merge, creating the largest media and entertainment conglomerate in the world.

title: Veteran Sleuths Are Donning Revamped Gumshoes
description: ''Oh yeah. I like old things.'' Peter Falk is talking real slow, as if savoring the thought. ''I like antiques. I like old golf clubs. I like old sweaters. I like spaghetti the third day, when the sauce sticks to the plate, sticks to the pasta.'' Mr. Falk himself clings to things. He still has the 22-year-old raincoat that he wore in every episode of the original ''Columbo.'' And a few days ago, he tried on his scarred old ''Columbo'' shoes. ''They made me some new ones with leather that was softer and probably more expensive,'' he says, ''but, you know, the old guys are more comfortable.''

title: Debts Make Israelis Rethink an Ideal: The Kibbutz
description: For most of the last 20 years, a third of the members of this Negev kibbutz have walked down the hill, past the cow shed and the chicken coop, to work in their own little factory, making drill bits and impact-wrench sockets.

title: THE LESSONS OF ST. JOE'S
description: What nostalgia! Five days later, and I'm still carrying around Anthony DePalma's article ''The Lessons of St. Joe's'' (Feb. 5). I, too, learned many lessons at St. Joe's.

title: Agouron Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Optek Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After a tax credit of $32,300.

title: Mancini's Mission: Stop a 'Pest'
description: NOT long ago, while training for his World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight title match against Hector Camacho here tonight, Ray Mancini was shadowboxing when he spied a reporter watching him.

title: Abrams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
High Cost of Land an Unwelcome Suburban Neighbor
description: The soaring cost of land is bringing unwelcome redevelopment to suburbia, making it profitable for developers to buy and demolish single-family houses for the land under them.

title: Charles Scott Sr., 67, Civil Rights Attorney
description: Charles S. Scott Sr., an attorney who helped integrate public schools nationwide by bringing suit in the landmark Brown versus Topeka Board of Education case, died Friday. He was 67.

title: Malrite's Buyout Price Disturbs Wall Street Analysts
description: Now that the leveraged buyout of Malrite Communications Group Inc. has been completed, Wall Street analysts are grumbling that the company's outside shareholders never had much of a chance.

title: In Hong Kong, Money to Spare
description: Hong Kong announced another record budget surplus last week, prompting some economists to remind financial officials of the British crown colony that even in a sassy, free-wheeling, capitalist economy, the Government is not meant to be a profit-making organization.

title: Business and the Law; Foreign Lawyers Migrating to U.S.
description: EAGER to follow the rapidly growing United States investments of their clients, foreign lawyers are beginning to flock to American shores. And economic and regulatory forces are encouraging the trend.

title: Perceptronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: How the Deal Was Done
description: The size, shape and leadership of the proposed company were determined in a month of negotiations that followed two years of talks.

title: Ceramics Process Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year losses included a pretax restructuring provision of $2.2 million.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is it true that there was one year during the 1960's in which the most valuable players in both baseball leagues and both football leagues wore No. 32?

title: Outrage Follows Talk by Official On Gay People
description: Leaders of gay- and lesbian-rights groups around New York State have expressed outrage over comments made last week by Peter L. Broderick, the Niagara County District Attorney, who called homosexuals ''queers'' and ''sick people'' and said they ought not to receive special consideration when they are victims of bias-related crimes.

title: Wean Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year results include gains of $267,000 and $790,000, respectively, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Burlington Journal; Exit a Socialist, to Let History Judge
description: In March 1981, as Ronald Reagan settled into the White House, an avowed socialist captured the Mayor's office here with a 10-vote margin over the entrenched Democratic incumbent.

title: Medical Management of America reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Group to Meet On Beef Issue
description: A group of United States and European Community officials who will try to settle a trans-Atlantic trade dispute over hormones in beef will meet here Monday and Tuesday, United States officials said Friday.

title: Italian Bank Under Inquiry
description: Sixteen senior bankers, one of them a Cabinet minister, have been told they are being investigated about irregularities in the balance sheets of an Italian merchant bank, judicial officials said on Saturday.

title: Review/Music; Gipsy Kings With Flamenco
description: The high point of the Gipsy Kings' sold-out show at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night came during its second half, when the group's main guitarist, Tonino Ballairdo, performed an exquisite solo filled with rolling arpeggios and jagged rhythms. He was joined by the group's singer, Nicholas Reyes, and together they began the mosaic-like, irregular rhythms and deep passion of flamenco music. Mr. Reyes, separated from the barrage of the group's rhythm section, could clearly enunciate the texturally brutal singing of flamenco; joined by three of the group's guitarists clapping complicated cross rhythms, he brought the audience to its feet.

title: Spain's Banks Cautious After Failed Merger
description: As two large Spanish banks picked up the pieces after their planned merger officially fell apart last week, bankers across the country began to consider the repercussions of the thwarted deal.

title: Man Kills Wife, Son And Then Himself
description: A New York City correction officer died from gunshot wounds early yesterday after her husband shot her with a shotgun in their Brooklyn home, also shooting and killing their infant son and then killing himself, the police said.

title: Oklahoma Star Arrested
description: Mookie Blaylock, an Oklahoma guard, was arrested today after a report of an argument at a convenience store, the police said.

title: Boycott Gives Workers Strong ToolZ
description: Eastern Airlines' striking machinists, in threatening to picket railroads and other airlines, are rolling out the most powerful weapon still available to labor unions, a weapon that Congress and the courts have taken away from most workers over the past 40 years.

title: Reviews/Music; Sonatas on Cello and Piano
description: The sonata program of Antonio Meneses and Cecile Licad, cellist and pianist, at Weill Recital Hall Friday evening was the kind of honorable, solidly played concert that sustains musical life on a night-to-night basis in New York. If those are lukewarm words for a pair of accomplished artists whose capabilities are well known, it was hard to feel that their own responses to the Mendelssohn, Britten and Brahms they played were much more than high-level workaday. They had the pieces securely in hand, but did little to search out their secrets.

title: Hipotronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
13 Palestinians Wounded on Eve of Holiday
description: Thirteen Palestinians were reported shot and wounded today in clashes with soldiers in the occupied territories after Muslim fundamentalists declared a week of increased resistance to mark a religious holiday.

title: Republicans Were First
description: To the Editor:

title: Furnishings 2000 reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Homeless Need Homes, Not Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teacher Is Charged With Desecrating Flag
description: A teacher here for a seminar became entangled in a controversy over the use of an American flag in an art exhibit when she was arrested Saturday for walking on the Stars and Stripes.

title: 11 Killed in Tibet as Rioters Clash With the Police
description: Chinese policemen fired on pro-independence rioters in Tibet yesterday after some 600 attacked Government and Communist Party offices, the Government reported.

title: Filtertek Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $260,000. The share earnings reflected class B stock requirements.

title: The Single-Room Solution
description: For many years, single-room-occupancy hotels provided squalid shelter in New York City, and many New Yorkers were glad to see rising real estate values encourage their destruction. But that dislocated thousands of poor New Yorkers, many of them mentally ill.

title: U.S. Antidrug Effort Floundering, Ex-Cocaine Dealer Tells Students
description: Max Mermelstein says the Federal Government's antidrug efforts suffer from a severe lack of coordination that causes conflicting agencies to trip over each other in their pursuit of drug traffickers.

title: Fort Worth's Grace Notes
description: Leave others to argue which music competition is best; the Cliburn is hands-down the most gracious, with a hospitality that is both relentless and meticulous. Pride in all things Texan and Fort Worthian radiates from the legions of affluent volunteers who accommodate contestants and make this system run.

title: STRIKERS HOLD OFF TRAIN DISRUPTIONS AFTER JUDGE ACTS
description: Machinists striking Eastern Airlines yesterday withdrew an immediate threat to picket the nation's railroads in the face of a Federal court order, giving hundreds of thousands of commuters a reprieve from widespread rush-hour disruptions this morning.

title: A Big Payoff for 'Lonesome Dove'
description: Augustus McCrae and Woodrow F. Call, two larger-than-life former Texas Rangers from a dusty Rio Grande town called Lonesome Dove, are riding at the head of one final roundup - this time, of perhaps the biggest herd of cash ever generated by a television mini-series.

title: Poulenc's 'Carmelites'
description: The Manhattan School of Music will present Francis Poulenc's opera ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' on March 15 and 17 at 8 P.M. and on March 19 at 2:30 P.M. The rendering of a novice nun's spiritual struggles during the French Revolution, in an English translation by Joseph Machlis, is to be staged by Lou Galtiero and conducted by Louis Salemno. The performances will take place in the John C. Borden Theater at the Manhattan School, Broadway and 122d Street. Tickets are $12 and $8. Information: 749-2802, extension 498.

title: The Railroads at Risk
description: Federal labor law governing transportation workers allows striking unions to picket companies not directly involved in a contract dispute.

title: '69 Mets, Day by Day
description: It is conceivable that future historians will not regard the 1969 Mets' season as the apotheosis of human endeavor, representing the ultimate triumph of hope over expectation.

title: For Japan, Military Challenge Is Balancing Might and Image
description: Forty-four years ago Emperor Hirohito's imperial forces began some of the last, desperate missions of World War II on a muddy airfield here north of Tokyo. Today, as gleaming fighters scream off a runway 60 times a day, the same site marks both the rejuvenation and the limits of Japan's modern military.

title: Police Investigating 2 Brothers in L.I. Killing
description: Two brothers who lived at the house where a 13-year-old girl was found stabbed to death have not been ruled out as suspects, the police said today.

title: Berkshire Gas Co reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE TIME-WARNER DEAL Concern about the power of a merged Time and Warner has been raised by industry experts, who noted that the major television networks and other entertainment companies might find it more difficult to compete. [ Page A1. ] Time and Newsweek go to press at the same time, but only Newsweek carries a report of the merger in the current issue. [ D11. ] The mantle of succession would fall on Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., the president of Time Inc. since July 1986. He would succeed the chairman of Time, J. Richard Munro, in 18 months and the chairman of Warner, Steven J. Ross, in five years. [ D9. ] The path to the merger pact was fraught with problems during the two years it took to bring it about, but in the end it was a recognition that the opportunity to form the company was passing quickly that led the management of both companies to act. [ D9. ] The deal lays the foundation for another publishing empire, one that will be better able to compete with the foreign giants. [ D8. ] Will this marriage be a success? Wall Street wonders. Market Place. [ D6. ] To advertisers, the deal is of more speculative than immediate interest. Advertising. [ D11. ] THE ECONOMY U.S. economic growth in February was the slowest in two years, a survey of purchasing managers concluded. [ D1. ] Farmers will till more land this year. After the drought, the U.S. is reducing the acreage it pays farmers to keep idle. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A threat to picket the nation's railroads has been withdrawn for now by machinists striking Eastern Airlines. [ A1. ] Secondary boycotting, which is legal only in the airline and railroad industries, is the most powerful weapon available to labor unions. [ B8. ] The nation's health insurers are showing signs of recovery after losing more than $5 billion in the last two years. [ D1. ] The oil industry has been urging the Environmental Protection Agency to take steps this week that would lessen the effects of state gasoline regulations intended to reduce smog. [ D1. ] Several mutual funds have had a burst of new business, surprising officials at some of the companies that offer them. [ D1. ] Lilco's chairman suggested that the Shoreham plant be transferred to New York State and criticized U.S. energy policy. [ B1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS CBS, Motown and Qintex stand to make a lot on ''Lonesome Dove,'' the mini-series based on Larry McMurtry's saga. [ D1. ] Television advertisers have become more skittish as criticism of some TV shows has increased. Television. [ D8. ] Outside shareholders of Malrite never had much of a chance, Wall Street analysts say of the company's buyout. [ D8. ] The New York Post stepped out in its Sunday finest to compete with the three metropolitan Sunday papers. [ D8. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Poland's only publicly held company is skating along the edges of what is politically and economically permissible. [ D12. ] Hong Kong announced another record budget surplus, prompting some economists to remind financial officials there that the government is not meant to be a profit-making concern. [ D12. ] Bankers across Spain began to consider the repercussions of the thwarted merger to create Spain's largest bank. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Foreign lawyers are beginning to flock to the U.S., encouraged by economic and regulatory forces. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Interest rates are likely to remain fairly stable this month, barring unwelcome inflation news, analysts say. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Coach's Drug Use Shaped Philosophy
description: By last Thursday afternoon, nearing the end of his third day on the witness stand, Charlie Francis had dark circles under his eyes. His voice was falling; his attention to the questions was flagging.

title: Boxers Settle Weigh-In Dispute
description: Hector Camacho and Ray Mancini were scheduled to weigh in at 2:30 Monday morning for their World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight title fight Monday evening.

title: States' Rules On Gasoline Are Resisted
description: The oil industry has been urging the Environmental Protection Agency to take steps this week that would lessen the effects of gasoline regulations by eight Northeastern states that are scheduled to take effect May 1.

title: At Time, It's Not a Story
description: The proposed merger between Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. may be one of the biggest business stories of the year, but readers of Time magazine will not see it in the issue that comes out today.

title: Family Leave Proposal Lacks Wage Provision
description: To the Editor:

description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock paid in October 1988.

title: London Talks Hear Call for '97 Ban on Anti-Ozone Chemicals
description: An official of the European Community's executive commission said at a 124-nation environmental conference here today that the European nations could eliminate production and use of chemicals that damage the ozone layer of the atmosphere as early as 1996 or 1997, three to four years ahead of the goal they set on Thursday.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Buffton Chief Adds Chairman's Post
description: LEAD: Robert H. McLean, co-founder, president and chief executive of the Buffton Corporation, has been named chairman as well. He succeeds Hampton Hodges, who will remain a director.

20 Years After Decentralization, Restructuring of Schools Is Urged
description: Twenty years after a bitter and racially divisive teachers' strike led to the decentralization of New York City's schools, lawmakers, parents and educators are again urging that the nation's largest school system be restructured.

title: Boredom and Rain End Racist Rally
description: All this weekend's ''Aryan Woodstock'' had in common with the 1969 original was a lot of mud. The one here had no music and its message was not love.

title: INSIDE
description: Circumcision Benefits Seen For the first time, the American Academy of Pediatrics said circumcision protects against kidney and urinary tract infections. Page A14. A New Mideast Approach Secretary of State Baker is trying to work out a Mideast settlement involving the Israelis, the Soviets and the P.L.O. Page A10. Pianists Playing to Win The problem: many fine pianists and few performing opportunities. The Darwinian solution: contests, like the Cliburn in Fort Worth. Page C13. College Pipeline Rashard Griffith, a 6-10 basketball player, has been the subject of a fierce recruiting fight - as an eighth grader. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: Miami Picks Erickson
description: A chance to win a national championship was too good an opportunity to pass up, Dennis Erickson said today in announcing that he would leave Washington State to become the head football coach at the University of Miami.

title: Academy Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $509,000 and $3,494,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss of $2,491,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $357,000 for the quarter and $743,000 for the year, and tax credits of $448,000 and $1,972,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: An Entertainment Engine Takes Shape
description: From Warner, strenth in products; from Time, channels in depth RECORDED MUSIC (Warner) Warner Bros. Records: Artists include Phil Collins, Stevie Nicks, U2. Electra Entertainment: Artists include Tracy Chapman, Anita Baker. WEA Corp.: Nation's largest record and home video distributor. WEA International: Distributor of Warner labels outside United States. WEA Manufacturing: Manufacturing arm for Warner records group. Warner Special Products: Marketer of special compilation albums. Warner/Chappell Music: World's largest music publishing company. Ivy Hill Corp.: Packaging company for the record group and others. MOVIE AND TV PRODUCTION (Warner) Warner Bros.: Hits include ''Dangerous Liasons'' and ''The Accidental Tourist.'' Warner Bros. Television including Loriamar: Telecvision production company thathas 17 shows in prime time of 31 on television, including ''Dallas,'' ''Knots Landing'' and ''Falcon Crest.''. Warner Home Video: Largest producer of home video cassettes. Licensing Company of America: Unit that leases right to use names, logos and other rights for clients like the National Hockey League. CABLE PROGRAMMING AND DISTRIBUTION (Time) Home Box Office: HBO and Cinemax programming channels provide Hollywood releases, sports events, made-for-TV movies, and comedy and musical specials for pay-TV, HBO is sold to 7,000 cable systems and Cinemax to 5,000. HBO Video: Videcassette distributor. LOCAL CABLE SYSTEMS (Time, Warner) From Time American Television and Communications: Nations' second-largest owner of cable outlets, 82 percent owned by Time, with 4 million basic subscriberts in 32 states. From Warner Warner Cable Communications: Fifth-largest cable operator; wholly owned by Warner, with more than l.5 million subscribers in 32 states. BHC INC.: Operator of seven television stations in antion's major markets, including Los Angleles and San Francisco; 42.5 percent owned by Warner. PUBLISHING ENTERPRISES (Time, Warner) From Time Magazines: Time, Life, Sports Illustrated, Sports Illustrated for Kids, People, Money, Student Life, Fortune (Time Inc. Magazines, wholly owned); Southern Living, Cooking Light, Progressive Farmer, Southern Accents, Travel South (Southern Progressive Corporation, wholly owned). Working Woman, McCall's, Working Mother, Baby (Working Woman/McCalls Group, 50 percent owned); Parenting, Asiaweek, Hippocrates, President, Fortune France, Fortune Italy, Yazhou Zhoukan (Joint ventures) Special Reports, business and health periodcals, posters with advertising (Whittle Communications, 50 percent owned). Books: Time-Life Books: publisher of series of books on various topics. Book-of-the Month Club: A leading direct-mail seller of books. Oxmoor House: Book-publishing of paperback books and some hardcovers. DC Comics: Nation's oldest publisher of comic books, whose properties include Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman. Mad Magazine: Popular satirical magazine. Warner Publisher Services: Leading distributor of magazine, paperback books and comics.

title: Cellular Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ask the Children: Is Mississippi Still Burning?
description: Twenty-five years ago next month, Aaron Henry, a Mississippi druggist, wrapped up a week of civil rights rallies and colloquia at Queens College with a warning. Dr. Henry, who led a coalition of rights groups, told students he was disturbed by ''the thundering silence of the good people'' in response to the unfinished task facing America, a task, he said, that ''her children must accomplish.''

title: Time-Warner Merger Raises Concerns on Power of a Giant
description: Time was when the Ford Motor Company's huge River Rouge plant was a wonder of the industrial economy. Iron ore was fed through one end of the sprawling complex, and Fords rolled out the other.

title: Tale of 2 Alvins
description: Two Alvins are better than one - at least as far as Canter, Achenbaum Associates Inc. is concerned. The consulting firm headed by Alvin Achenbaum has acquired Hampel Creative, a creative consulting firm started by Alvin Hampel. Mr. Hampel, who was chairman and creative director of the old D'Arcy, McManus & Masius, will become a partner in Canter, Achenbaum. Mr. Achenbaum said his firm sought Mr. Hempel's marketing expertise in positioning new brands and developing new products. Mr. Hempel previously worked with clients like Procter & Gamble and General Electric.

title: Surprise in El Salvador
description: There are signs that all sides in El Salvador's eight-year civil war - a war that has cost 70,000 lives and devastated the economy - are groping for a way out. That's welcome, even if the signals are decidedly mixed.

title: 2 at New Orleans Base Accused of Espionage
description: A supply clerk and a storekeeper at the Naval Air Station here were arrested on charges of espionage and stealing $150,000 worth of classified military parts and electronic components, a Navy spokesman said Saturday.

title: Purchasers Say Growth Is Lagging
description: The nation's economic growth in February was the slowest in two years, a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers concluded.

Big Cocoa Surplus Seen
description: Record world cocoa production this season is likely to lead to the biggest surplus ever and a substantial rise in stockpiles, Gill & Duffus, a cocoa merchant, said Friday. The company estimates world cocoa production from October 1988 to September 1989 at 2.31 million metric tons, 5.4 percent more than last season and 199,000 tons more than world demand. This would be the fifth season in a row that production has surpassed consumption, the company said. The stockpile at the end of September is likely to be 896,000 tons, it said.

title: Susan Katz Rosenbaum Is Married
description: Susan Katz Rosenbaum and Charles Scott Slotkin were married yesterday evening at the Community Synagogue in Rye, N.Y., by Rabbi Robert Rothman.

title: Stock Mutual Funds Regain Favor With Wary Investors
description: Although investors have continued to be wary of most stock mutual funds, several funds with long-established records have experienced a burst of new business this year.

title: Chekhov Goes to Moscow by Way of Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music appeared to have scored a hit today with its opening performance of ''The Cherry Orchard,'' believed to be the first English-language production of the Chekhov classic ever brought to the Soviet stage by an American troupe.

title: Female Mushers Drive Toward Success
description: THE field for the Iditarod this year, the 1,152-mile trans-Alaska dog-sled race that began Saturday in Anchorage in 13-degree temperatures and winds gusting to 46 miles per hour, included 49 drivers and teams. Of the five women entered, two - Susan Butcher and Elizabeth (Libby) Riddles - have won the race the last four years.

description: WCBS's Rating Woes

title: Review/Television; And Baby Makes Two
description: Most movies fit neatly into one of three categories: The good, the bad or the dreadful. The made-for-television movie has evolved into something different. It can be good, bad and dreadful all at the same time.

description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Without Fervor, Texans Back Tower
description: John G. Tower had to fight Tom Landry for the headlines here last week. Mr. Landry, the longtime coach of the Dallas Cowboys who was just dismissed by the club's new ownership, often won the fight.

title: High-Stake Strike: Seeking Control
description: ''At a certain point it became a fight for dignity,'' said Rick Chapman, one of the leaders of the pilots' union at Eastern Airlines. ''It's no longer just going to work and collecting a paycheck.''

title: Saatchi Regains Dexatrim
description: Saatchi & Saatchi recaptured a major pharmaceutical account on Friday, as the Thompson Medical Company said it would switch the advertising for its Dexatrim brand to the agency.

title: Head of Lilco Sees Failure Of U.S. Policy
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company today called the two-decade saga of the utility's $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant a ''glaring example of failed national energy policy'' and, at the same time, suggested that Lilco would soon agree to end the controversy by transferring the plant to New York State.

title: Rax Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
description: b-Net income Latest second-quarter and 6-month results included a charge of about $2.5 million, principally associated with the sale, closing, or refranchising of 11 restaurants. An additional $1 million was provided for further promotional and advertising costs and allowances against royalties. Prior-year 6-month results included a tax credit of $292,000.

title: Venezuela Unrest: Lesson for Leader
description: Speaking in this riot-torn capital late last week, Venezuela's new President, Carlos Andres Perez, said that the three days of violent street protests should teach world leaders an important lesson about the dangers of third world debt.

description: Not only is Ryszard Karger the only Polish business executive who must worry about paying dividends but also his chief project, developing a free-trade zone in this Baltic seaport, has him skating along the edges of what is politically and economically permissible in Poland these days.

title: Review/City Opera; Poodle Skirts, Elvis And Labor Relations
description: One of Beverly Sills's innovations as general manager of the New York City Opera has been the introduction of musical-theater works into the opera house. Her endeavors along these lines have not met with consistent success, partly because opera and musical theater are only distant cousins, despite superficial similarities, and music composed for one form is awkwardly served by voices trained to sing the other.

title: Korea Trade Surplus Down

description: The wedding of Denise Critelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Critelli of Berkeley Heights, N.J., to Robert Ernst Esberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andreas A. Esberg of New York, took place yesterday at the Martinsville (N.J.) Inn. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: Time-Warner Combination Joins Giants In Publishing
description: Virtually overnight, the deal between Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. laid the foundation for another book and magazine publishing empire.

title: Cool Welcome
description: They love Jari Kurri in Edmonton, Mats Naslund in Montreal, and the Stastnys in Quebec, but Canada has yet to open its arms to Alpo Sunonen of Finland, who a month ago became the first European head coach of a North American professional hockey franchise.

title: Review/Music; A Precise Jessye Norman
description: If one added up all the things that Jessye Norman does well as a singer, the total would assuredly exceed that of any other soprano before the public. At Miss Norman's recital before a packed house at Carnegie Hall Saturday night, tones were produced, colors manipulated, words projected and interpretive points made - all with fanatic fineness.

title: GTI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 year results included a one-time pension plan termination gain of $445,000.

title: Pacific Northern reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1,049,214 special charge. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: George Mason Wins First Indoor Title
description: George Mason University came from far behind today to win its first team title in the IC4A indoor track-and-field championships at Princeton's Jadwin Gym.

title: Overhaul Seen at Telmex
description: Telmex, the Government-owned telephone company, will undergo a $15 billion restructuring over five years because of complaints about poor service, news reports said.

title: Blue Jays Enjoying A Better Attitude
description: A noticeably different atmosphere pervades the Toronto Blue Jays' spring camp this year. ''Everyone is more relaxed,'' Ernie Whitt, the Blue Jays' veteran catcher, said today. ''There's nothing exciting happening compared with last year. Our concentration is on baseball.''

title: Missing Pilot Is Found Dead
description: Rescue workers this morning located the wreckage of a twin-engine plane that crashed last Wednesday in woods near the Lake Placid Airport in a sudden snowstorm, killing the pilot. The body of Paul Field, 60 years old, of Orchard Park was taken to Lake Placid Hospital, where an autopsy was to be performed. The front of the Beechcraft Baron was destroyed, and only the tail section was partly intact, searchers said.

title: Investors Tile Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $498,135 from a tax adjustment.

title: Southern Starr Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fight Is On in Massachusetts Over Plan to Cut Arts Money
description: ''It was like being told that civilization had come to an end,'' said Anne Hawley, executive director of the Massachusetts Council on the Arts and Humanities.

title: 'SMART' MACHINES READY TO ASSUME MANY NASA DUTIES
description: Increased reliance on the artificial intelligence of advanced computers to run missions is helping the nation's space agency cope with impending retirements of experienced personnel that threaten to cripple its operations. And in some cases it turns out the ''smart'' computers do the jobs better than skilled people.

title: A Teen-Ager's Progress: Student to Crack Dealer to Murder Witness
description: The tall, husky teen-ager, dressed in a fashionable sports jacket with an Italian cut, recalled in a Queens courtroom how he had gone from being a $2-an-hour supermarket stockboy to a $1,500-a-week crack distributor.

title: Cosmetic & Fragrance Conepts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Banks in a Label War With Thrift Institutions
description: What's in a set of Federal initials? If they are F.D.I.C or F.S.L.I.C. and you represent a commercial bank or a savings and loan association, the right initials may make a difference worth a lot of money.

title: Competitions That Crown International Stars
description: Some of the major piano competiotions held around the world. Ludwig van Beethoven International Piano Competition Vienna Held every four years. Next is this year. Applicants must be 17 to 32 years old. Six prizes. First prize is approximately $5,000, concert engagements and a Bosendorfer piano. Entry fee is $60. Previous winners include Mitsuko Uchida (1969) and John O'Connor (1973). Queen Elisabeth International Music Competition Brussels Held every three years. Nex in 1991. Applicants must be 17 to 30 years old. Twelve prizes that range from $1,300 to $7,800. Entry fee is $105. Previous winners include Leon Fleischer (1952), Viadimir Ashkenazy (1956) and Malcolm Frager (1960). Harvey Leeds International Piano-forte Competition Leeds, Yorkshire Held every three years. Next in 19960. Applicants must be under 30 years old. First prize is about $10,000 and concert engagements. Entry fee is $71. Previous winners include Redu Lupu (1969), Murray Perahia (1972), Dmitri Alexeev (1975), Ian Hobson (1981) and John Kimura Parker (1984). Concours International Marguerite Long-Jacques Thibaud Paris Held every three years. Next is this year. Applicants must be 16 to 30 years old. Six prizes that total approximately $40,000. First prize is about $12,000 and concert engagements. Entry fee is $50. Previous winners include Samson Francois (1943), Aldo Ciccolini (1949) and Viadimir Feltzman (1971). Arthur Rubinstein International Piano Master Competition Tel Aviv Held every three years. Next is this year. Applicants must be 18 to 32 years old. Prizes of three gold imedals with $10,000. Previous winners include Emanuel Ax (1974) and Jeffrey Kahane (1983). International Frederic Chopin Piano Competition Warsaw Held every five years. Next is 1990. Applicants must be 17 to 28 years old. Prizes are a gold medal and $2,000, a silver medal and $1,500, a bronze medal and $1,000 and cash awards of $800, $600 and $400. Entry fee is $100. Previous winners include Bella Davidovich (1949), Maurizio Pollini(1960), Martha Argerich (1965), Garrick Ohlsson (1970) and Krystian Zimerman (1975). Van Cliburn International Piano Competition Fort Worth Held every four years. Next is this year. Applicants must be 18 to 30 years old. First prize is $15,000, Carnegie Hall recital and orchestral debuts, American recital and orchestral tour. European debuts and European orchestral and recital tour. Second prize is $10,000, a New York City debut and an American concert tour. Third prize is $7,500 and a U.S. concert tour. Other prizes total $15,000. Entry fee is $35. Previous winners include Radu Lupu (1966), Vladimir Viardo (1973), Andre-Michel Schub (1981) and Jose Feghali (1985). International P.I. Tchaikovsky Competition Moscow Held every four years, Next in 1990. Applicants must be 17 to 32 years old. First prize is $4,000, three concert engagements in Moscow and other concerts. There are two second prizes of $3,200 and two third prizes of $2,400; all have several concert engagements. Prizes are awarded in rubles, which cannot be taken out of the country. Entry fee is $6.25. Previous winners include Van Cliburn (1958), John Ogden (1962), Andrei Gavrilov (1974) and Barry Douglas (1986).

title: NMR of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $360,000. c-Net loss The prior-year third quarter share net was less than one cent.

title: Two Top Men and the Heir Apparent
description: The courtship had progressed over two years of bicoastal lunches and dinners, long afternoon conversations and, at one point late last summer, a public parting of the ways that seemed to dash all of it.

title: Lesson of AIDS Cases in Soviet Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale by Bank of New York
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell four banks in New York to NBT Bancorp Inc., a bank holding company based in Norwich, N.Y. The terms of the deal and the purchase price were not disclosed.

title: McCallister Wins the Honda
description: Blaine McCallister, who plays right-handed from tee to green, then putts left-handed, broke free of a tightly packed field midway through the back nine today and won the $800,000 Honda Classic with a tournament-record score of 22-under-par 266.

title: Behind Stalin's Green Fence: Who Filled the Mass Graves?
description: When a high green fence and a guardhouse appeared, half a century ago, in a mossy pine forest near this Ukrainian settlement, the villagers knew enough to speculate in silence.

title: Outdoors: Preparing for Trout
description: THIS is the month in which fishermen are advised to prepare for the advent of ice-free angling, and a full measure of enthusiasm is as important as repairing leaking waders and sorting out flies or lures.

title: Facing Rear Adds Little Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: 78 Protesters Seized At Abortion Clinic
description: A protest at a Danbury abortion clinic Saturday ended with the arrest of 78 demonstrators for blocking access to Medical Options Inc., the police said.

title: Friedman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Middleby Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Tax Code Will Send Research Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmers Plan for a Bumper Crop
description: With crop prices high and inventories low, Jim Howe will increase his spending on wheat, barley and sugar beet seed crops by 17 percent this year in the rich Red River Valley of eastern North Dakota.

title: Treasury to Auction 3 Bills This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills and ending Thursday with an auction of new one-year bills.

title: Jackson's Refusal to Back Daley Angers Some in Party
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who said he expected other Democrats to back him if he won the 1988 Presidential nomination, is now being strongly criticized here for supporting a black third-party hopeful against the Democratic mayoral nominee, Richard M. Daley.

title: Writers and Editors Ponder the Bible
description: Burton L. Visotzky, a professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, said he feels like Gunther Gebel-Williams, the lion tamer, when he presides over a dozen or more secular writers and editors one night a month at the back of the school cafeteria. They discuss the Bible.

title: Report of U.F.O. Lures 4,000
description: The prospect of seeing a U.F.O. lured more than 4,000 people to this town of 1,300 in northeast Alabama Friday night, but for all the hoopla no unidentified flying objects were sighted. Visibility was difficult because of clouds and light rain. Fyffe got on the U.F.O. circuit Feb. 10, when a woman reported seeing a strange light in the sky and the police later reported seeing a large lighted object passing silently over them. Numerous other sightings have been reported since then.

title: B.E. Rosenberg And Karen Shaer Exchange Vows
description: Karen Beth Shaer, an associate at the New York law firm of Lankler Siffert & Wohl, and Benjamin Edward Rosenberg, an associate at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, also a New York law firm, were married yesterday. Rabbi Roland Matalone performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York.

title: A Second Yalta?
description: In foreign affairs, Moscow is on the march.

title: Dest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $247,000 for the quarter and tax credits of $54,000 for the 9 months. The company said prior year results are restated to include Gulfstream Micro Systems Inc., acquired in November 1987, and accounted for as a pooling of interests. The company also said its loss for the quarter included provisions for inventory and receivables adjustments relating to its lower level of sales.

title: Health Insurers Rebound as Rates Increase
description: With a lift from sizable rate increases, the nation's health insurers are showing signs of recovery after having lost more than $5 billion in the last two years.

title: Books of The Times; A Child of American Radicals
description: Loyalties A Son's Memoirs By Carl Bernstein 262 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: There's Method in Bonn's Messiness
description: LEAD: American officials visiting Western Europe these days must have some problems sorting out their various impressions. They could well be excused for being somewhat confused, particularly by stopovers in West Germany, the country that NATO pundits most like to fret about.

title: Bulging War Chests Protect Seats in House
description: Although close contests for seats in the House of Representatives have become a rarity in the New York metropolitan region, the amount of money that many House members have put away to wage those contests has increased sharply, giving local Representatives some of the largest war chests in the nation.

title: Santa Anita Cos reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss Results for 1987 included a writedown of $17.5 million on the company's investment in and advances to a Minnesota race track and a $2,464,000 gain on the sale of real estate.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bucks 103, Cavaliers 98: Cleveland went 2-for-16 from the field in a 9-point fourth quarter yesterday and Terry Cummings scored 26 points to lead Milwaukee as the Bucks ended the Cavaliers' home winning streak at 22 games.(AP) Jazz 85, Hawks 83: John Stockton and Bobby Hansen scored 20 points each and Karl Malone sank two free throws with 43 seconds left to give visiting Utah the victory.(AP) Rockets 88, Lakers 83: Sleepy Floyd scored 9 of his 22 points in a third-quarter comeback and hit a crucial jumper with 14 seconds to play as Houston stopped its losing streak at seven games and ended the Lakers' winning streak at four.(AP) Bullets 114, Hornets 101: Jeff Malone scored 34 points and Washington reserves fueled a 14-1 fourth-quarter burst, leading the Bullets to their fourth consecutive victory.(AP) Pistons 109, Heat 100: Isiah Thomas and Vinnie Johnson each scored 22 points for visiting Detroit.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Connecticut 84, Providence 65: Kris Lamb scored 20 points and hit six 3-point goals yesterday, and Kerry Bascom, the Big East player of the year, added 17 points and 12 rebounds as Connecticut won the conference tournament in South Orange, N.J. Connecticut (24-5) earned its first berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament.(AP) SCHOOL BASKETBALL August Martin 69, Beach Channel 36: August Martin, the defending New York State Federation girls champion, romped past Beach Channel in the Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinals yesterday at Hunter College. Martin (24-1) advanced to tomorrow's semifinal opener at 4 P.M. against Martin Luther King (22-0) at Hunter. Medina Turner's 30 points led King to a 78-58 victory over Manhattan Center for Science and Math (21-4). John F. Kennedy (19-0) won the Bronx title with a 56-45 victory over Evander Childs (19-6). Kennedy will play John Jay tomorrow at 6 P.M. John Jay (20-2) defeated South Shore, 42-34, in the Brooklyn matchup. N.H.L. Capitals 3, Canucks 0: Kelly Miller, Neil Sheehy and Dave Christian scored and Don Beaupre turned away 24 shots yesterday as Washington overcame 11 penalties.(AP) Whalers 3, Maple Leafs 0: Peter Sidorkiewicz stopped 21 shots for his third shutout of the season. Hartford outshot Toronto, 49-21.(AP) Nordiques 8, Sabres 2: Peter Stastny had two goals and his brother Anton added three assists in Quebec's rout.(AP) Oilers 4, Penguins 2: Jimmy Carson had a goal and an assist and Esa Tikkanen scored twice for Edmonton, which has won six successive games.(AP) TENNIS Graf Takes Title: Steffi Graf defeated Ann Henricksson, 6-1, 6-4, yesterday to win the final of the United States women's hardcourt championships in San Antonio. Graf, the world's No. 1-ranked player, won the $40,000 top prize at the McFarlin Tennis Center.(AP) HORSE RACING Open Mind Wins Again: Open Mind ran down Seattle Meteor and Surging to win the $200,000 Bonnie Miss Stakes yesterday at Gulfstream Park in Florida. The winner, a New Jersey-bred daughter of Deputy Minister, owned by Eugene V. Klein and trained by D. Wayne Lukas, beat Seattle Meteor by three lengths. Open Mind ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:43 4/5 under Angel Cordero Jr. and paid $2.80 for $2 to win. TRACK AND FIELD Gold Medals for Conley and Myricks: Mike Conley of the United States won the triple jump and placed third in the long jump yesterday in the world indoor championships in Budapest. Larry Myricks of the United States won the long jump.(AP) ROAD RACING Victory for Centrowitz: Matt Centrowitz of the Bronx won the New York Road Runners Club's 29th annual Bob Preston Memorial five-mile run in 24 minutes 57 seconds yesterday in Central Park. Gillian Beschloss of the Warren Street Athletic Club was the women's winner in 28:54. GOLF Rizzo Wins by Four Strokes: Patti Rizzo shot 72 yesterday and won the $350,000 Daikin Orchid Ladies Golf Tournament in Tokyo, the inaugural event on the Japan women's tour, by four strokes over a fellow American, Sherri Turner. Rizzo finished with a five-under-par 211 total. (AP) Barber Tops $2 Million Mark: Miller Barber shot a 69 yesterday, finishing with a seven-under-par 281 to capture the Vintage Invitational Seniors tournament at Indian Wells, Calif. The $55,5000 for first place moved Barber's yearly total to $170,055 and his Seniors career total to $2,014,429, making him the first Senior player to go over the $2 million mark.(AP) GYMNASTICS Johnson Takes Three Events: Brandy Johnson of the United States won three gymnastics events yesterday and placed second in the other to easily capture the women's portion of the McDonald's American Cup in Fairfax, Va.(AP)

title: Traders Held In Australia
description: Three people were arrested on Friday and charged with insider stock dealing. Other arrests are expected soon.

title: Clear Leader For the Derby
description: THREE colts went to the races at Gulfstream Park on Saturday looking like candidates for the Kentucky Derby on May 6, but only one of them came home that way. At least it was the right one. Easy Goer made the kind of 3-year-old debut that Secretariat, Seattle Slew and Affirmed did in the 1970's en route to becoming the last three winners of the American Triple Crown. The son of Alydar was 10 lengths back with three furlongs to go Saturday in the Swale Stakes, then kicked into high gear and won off by 8 3/4 lengths. He didn't turn a hair amid the mayhem of the largest crowd in Gulfstream's 50-year history, bounced off the track with verve and looked just as good yesterday morning as he did in the winner's circle Saturday.

title: Fun and Exercise In Collapsible Form
description: WHEN the game starts to get hot, Morris Wexler's feet do a little shuffling dance over the carpet and he returns the ball so deftly that it just tops the net and then staggers unpredictably into the opponent's court, making it impossible to return. He lets out a whoop of glee. ''You've got to place your shots,'' he told a visitor watching the game.

title: Afghan Rebel Leader Voices Confidence in Unifying a Fractious Movement
description: He heads a government without a country under its control, and his Afghan partners often need to be reminded that their enemy is the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul instead of one another.

title: On Tap: Ethics Agency
description: Buried in the Bush Administration's budget for next year is evidence that President Bush intends to make good his pledge to strengthen enforcement of ethical standards.

title: Phonemate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $320,000 for the quarter and $808,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $204,000 and $601,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The 1987 fourth quarter and year included a $661,000 pretax loss on patent litigation.

title: Choose Your School
description: There was a time, especially in small towns, when schools were a hub of every community. Parents knew their children's teachers and the principal on a first-name basis. Parents were very involved in schools, and schools were more responsive. Today, society is more com-plex and many things have changed. Parents aren't nearly as involved as they should be. Schools have become much more institutionalized, much more rigid and often unresponsive to parents.

title: Market Place; In Media Merger, Tandem Control
description: WILL this marriage be a success? That was the question swirling around Wall Street in the wake of the announcement that Steven J. Ross and J. Richard Munro plan to be co-chief executives of a combined Time Warner Inc.

title: Jets' Hopes Wane As Islanders Win
description: Alan Kerr scored two goals and assisted on another today as the Islanders defeated the Winnipeg Jets, 4-3, and dealt another blow to Winnipeg's dwindling playoff hopes.

title: Syracuse Stuns Hoyas
description: If ever a crowd willed a team to victory, it happened today at Syracuse.

title: Insider Inquiry In Pillsbury Bid
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating possible insider trading in the securities of the Pillsbury Company by a former partner in the Dorsey & Whitney law firm, the law firm said last week.

title: Convergent Solutions reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $191,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Top Goal at Oxford
description: Not many people thought Jack Callaway would ever play soccer again after he developed Hodgkin's disease, a form of cancer, almost three years ago after his sophomore year at Yale. Callaway, who is from Manhattan, had his spleen removed that summer and commuted from New Haven to New York five days a week for radiation treatments at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center during the fall of his junior year.

title: Drexel Real Estate Expert Leaves to Join Lazard Freres
description: A real estate expert at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Arthur P. Solomon, has moved to Lazard Freres & Company as a general manager. He is joining an old acquaintance, Harvey Schulweis, as co-manager of the firm's real estate business.

title: Cracked Beam Is Found, Snarling Bridge Traffic
description: Commuters crossing the George Washington Bridge into Manhattan can expect delays today, as repair crews shore up a cracked steel beam over a roadway leading off the bridge.

title: Moog and Bruins Stop Rangers, 5-0
description: Bruins went unchecked and pucks went unstopped and so midway through the third period last night most of the crowd at Madison Square Garden went unimpeded for the exits. It was an unhappy progression, one that if not reversed could well find the Rangers soon headed unceremoniously out of first place in the Patrick Division.

title: Valspar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Problems Beset Two Years of Talks
description: Time Warner Inc. is coming into the world like an elephant, two years in gestation and a giant at birth. The path from conception to delivery was fraught with problems, including conflicts between the parents about who would bear the most responsibility for the upbringing.

title: Boston Digital reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and included a provision for an unrealized gain of $45,000 on marketable securities. c-Net loss and included a provision for unrealized loss of $351,000 on marketable securities.

title: Cheerleader Found Innocent Of Murdering Her Newborn
description: A high school cheerleader was acquitted of murdering her baby by slashing his throat, after she testified that after she gave birth she found the boy was not breathing and tried to give him a tracheotomy to help him breathe.

title: Eplett Dairies Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest fourth quarter included a $750,000 special charge from discontinued product lines. Inventory writedowns of $940,000 and reserves against two accounts of $860,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Nordson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Albany's Revolving Door
description: A court challenge to New York State's new government ethics code casts an embarrassing spotlight on the Legislature's tolerance for influence-peddling by former employees.

title: Frostbiters Undaunted By Winter Conditions
description: IN the blustery, raw days of March, when most sailors only dream the taste of salt air, small bands of insatiable racers launch themselves in tiny dinghies to negotiate miniature courses on Long Island Sound.
