title: Stable Rates Expected for March
description: Barring additional unwelcome inflation news, credit market analysts say interest rates are likely to remain fairly stable for the rest of March.

title: Pediatricians Find Medical Benefit to Circumcision
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics said yesterday for the first time that there are medical advantages to circumcision, the most commonly performed operation on males in the United States.

title: Tower, With Family Near, Begins A Counterattack at the 11th Hour
description: Penny Tower Cook was fussing over her father, smoothing his hair, straightening his tie, dusting off his Savile Row jacket. ''I don't usually wear pink shirts,'' John G. Tower said apologetically, holding up a powder-pink cuff with a gold State of Texas cufflink attached.

title: Technalysis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York Post Dresses Up for Sunday
description: The New York Post stepped out in its Sunday finest yesterday, a newly attired competitor to the three metropolitan Sunday papers.

title: Sudan's Leader Asserts Army Backs Coalition
description: The Sudanese Prime Minister said today that he had received assurances from the army, which openly challenged his leadership two weeks ago, that it supported a new broad-based government he has pieced together.

title: Interior Is Not Inferior, Lujan Reminds Nunn
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has taken offense, more or less seriously, over something Sam Nunn said in a Senate debate the other day.

title: Reviews/Music; Contrasts From 2 Pianists
description: Arianna Goldina and Remy Loumbrozo made stronger arguments for the duo-piano medium on Saturday afternoon than have many technically stronger and more perfectly calibrated colleagues.

title: Lobbyists Pay for Trips As Clean Air Bill Looms
description: Industries with large stakes in clean air legislation have been flying staff members of influential Congressional committees around the country on what the industries call education tours. In some cases the staff members have spent a night or two at Walt Disney World or in New Orleans' French Quarter. The trips, which are legal under Senate and House rules, come at a time when President Bush and Democratic Congressional leaders are vowing to break a decade-long stalemate and pass clean air legislation this year. There have been five such industry-sponsored trips in the last two months.

title: Hospitals Take Budget Woes to Congress
description: Representatives of New York's hospitals and their workers met here today with New York members of Congress to protest proposed budget cuts that, they contend, threaten a sharp deterioration in hospital care in New York City and the state.

title: Almost Executed, by Mistake
description: Randall Dale Adams once came within a week of execution for murdering a Dallas police officer. Now it turns out he never should have been convicted. His sentence to death by lethal injection was subsequently commuted to life imprisonment mainly because the Dallas County District Attorney didn't want to endanger the conviction with a new trial. Thanks largely to a film maker who helped demolish the case against him, Mr. Adams is on the verge of release.

title: Shutout by Burke Halts North Stars
description: Sean Burke made it abundantly clear very early in the game that he was in the mood to play. His goaltending got progressively better, and it reached its peak toward the end.

title: Baker Operating on 3 Tracks in Mideast
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appears to be developing a three-track approach to Middle East peacemaking, with one track dedicated to the Israelis, one to the Palestine Liberation Organization and one to the Soviet Union.

title: Hershiser Is Still in Groove
description: Picking up where he left off, Orel Hershiser zipped three shutout innings against the Mets today in his first game since he closed last season in the greatest blaze of shutout pitching in baseball history.

title: Old Bathhouse Defended As Brooklyn Landmark
description: An abandoned bathhouse in Brooklyn, decrepit testament to the social progress of the 1930's, is nearing demolition even as last-minute appeals portray it as a valuable part of the Robert Moses legacy.

title: Accounts
description: * Waterbury Hospital Health Center division of psychiatry to Sudler & Hennessey, New York, a division of Young & Rubicam.

title: West Berlin Journal; Out of the East, Hordes (of Weekend Capitalists)
description: Though long prepared to stand fast against a military onslaught from the East, West Berlin authorities have been caught off-guard by new weekend invasions of thousands of Polish flea marketeers lured to this island of capitalism by the chance for a quick mark.

title: Corporate Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Group Will Import Unapproved Drugs For Treating AIDS
description: Boldly trying to press the limits of Food and Drug Administration policy, a New York group will announce today that it has set up an elaborate network to import prescription drugs not available in the United States for use by people with AIDS.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arco Chemical Co., Newtown Square, Pa., elected E. Kent Damon Jr., David T. McLaughlin and James A. Middleton to its board.

title: Firefighter Is Killed; Blaze Hurts 9 Others
description: One firefighter was killed and nine others were injured while battling a blaze in a vacant building that formerly housed a department store, a fire captain said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Japan's military must fill demands that are contradictory: show Washington it is assembling a sophisticated force on a par with the West's while satisfying Asian neighbors that Japan is not a threat. Page A1

title: Recruiting Extends Its Reach
description: AS an eighth grader at Marcus Garvey Elementary School in Chicago, Rashard Griffith should be enjoying a relatively simple life. Instead, he and his mother have spent the last eight weeks screening phone calls and dodging an expanding contingent of recruiters and reporters.

title: Camacho: Is Luster Lost?
description: SIX days before Hector Camacho was to fight Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini for the World Boxing Organization's junior-welterweight title, he put on his gold sequined loincloth shorts -what Tarzan might have worn to the disco - and posed for a photographer at the far end of Bally's Casino Resort here.

title: A Loss in Jerusalem
description: Few have toiled harder for the peace of Jerusalem than Teddy Kollek, the city's Mayor for 24 years. He deserved better than the results of last week's local elections in Israel. While winning his own seat on the City Council, his party, One Jerusalem, lost its majority chiefly because the vote was boycotted by Arabs in East Jerusalem.

title: Huntway Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The per unit data not applicable; partnership went public on Nov. 10, 1988.

title: Candelaria Still Has Doubts
description: The ice that the trainer wrapped around John Candelaria's right knee today was a reminder that the season will not be an easy one. Every game Candelaria pitches will be followed by the same ritual.

title: Color Systems Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Nuclear Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included results of Nutech Inc., which the company acquired on Oct. 3.

title: Topper Seeking Data on Emhart
description: Topper L.P., which has offered $2.4 billion for the Emhart Corporation, said last week that it should be able to see non-public information on the manufacturing concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Topper said, ''If others are being afforded access to any such information, we believe that it is incumbent upon Emhart's management and board of directors to grant Topper L.P. that same opportunity.''

title: Television That Makes Advertisers Dive for Cover
description: WHEN you pay $100,000 or $200,000 for 30 seconds on the air, you prefer not to offend anybody.

title: Bridge
description: In the annual match between teams of 12 played Saturday at Harvard University, the home squad lost to Yale 87-93 in victory points. The top Harvard foursome, with a nucleus that will challenge for the Intercollegiate title in Reno next week, played convincingly, but Yale had greater depth.

Rouse of Lumberton, Miss., to Dr. Douglas Thomas Dieterich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Dieterich of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke performed the ceremony.

description: b-After a tax credit of $86,000.

title: Former Heroin Addicts Give And Get Help in AIDS Project
description: Often dressed in his pajamas and bathrobe, Robert, a former heroin addict with AIDS, spends much time alone in a $7-a-day hotel room in the Bowery or in the building's lobby.

description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Productivity 4 Qtr. Consumer Credit Feb. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Employment Feb.

title: Capital Mayor's Coalition Unraveling
description: There was a time in the nation's capital when Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. seemed politically unassailable because of the unusual biracial coalition that had come together to support him.

title: Richard B. Morris, Colonial Historian, Dies at 84
description: Richard B. Morris, a pre-eminent Colonial and American constitutional historian and a former chairman of the history department at Columbia University, died of melanoma, a type of skin cancer, Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Indiana Loses at Buzzer To Illini
description: Nick Anderson hit a 35-foot shot at the buzzer today to give eighth-ranked Illinois a 70-67 comeback victory over No. 3 Indiana. The Illini ended a 15-game Hoosier winning streak at home and kept alive their own hopes for a share of the Big Ten Conference championship.

title: Quaker Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: To the Editor:

title: Piano Competitions: New Path to Success
description: Competitions began, no doubt, with two cave men and one piece of raw meat. Not much has changed in 10,000 years, though in these lethal fights for survival, death for the loser has come to be less sudden, more lingering; the bleeding is inner and psychic, not the kind you get on your shirt. Struggles for pre-eminence may in fact be sharper and more pervasive today than prehistory ever dreamed of, and art is not exempt.

title: Ditch Reflects Deep Border Tensions
description: No more ambitious than a local public works project, the Federal Government's plan to dig a four-mile-long earthen ditch on the dusty flatlands here has sent diplomatic aftershocks up and down the 2,000-mile Mexican border.

title: Afghan Army Fires on Guerrillas to Protect Convoy
description: Afghan Army units resumed firing today on guerrillas hidden in the hills north of Kabul, ending almost two weeks of calm around the Afghan capital.

title: SRI LANKA INVITES RIGHTS ADVOCATES
description: The Government of Sri Lanka will no longer bar international human rights organizations from visiting the country, Colombo's new Foreign Minister said Saturday.

title: Ring In the New (Job)
description: Samuel K. Skinner said Friday that one of the pleasures of leaving his Chicago law practice behind to become Transportation Secretary was that he could also leave his telephone paging device behind.

title: Time-Warner Bid for Global Marketing
description: THE theory is simple: assemble a communications conglomerate that can create and distribute editorial matter and video programming - as well as sell advertising against it - across all media on every continent.

title: Congress Seeks to Reduce Greenhouse Effect; Warming and Cooling
description: To the Editor:

title: 26 Airlines Fined for Failures In Arms Detection Screening
description: The Government said today that it had fined 26 airlines a total of $1.18 million for failure to detect fake weapons smuggled past security, but officials said detection had improved markedly over the last two years.

title: SOVIETS PROPOSE THREE-STAGE CUTS IN EUROPEAN ARMS
description: The Soviet Union opened an East-West conference today with a broad proposal for a three-stage reduction in nonnuclear weapons and military personnel in Europe.

description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year reflected a $277,000 writeoff for a planned equity offering that was withdrawn and establishment of a $545,000 reserve for a possible loss on certain investments.

title: Jackson Has Surgery To Repair Injured Knee
description: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' playmaker, underwent arthrosopic surgery yesterday afternoon to repair torn cartilage in his right knee.

title: Soviets Delay Joining New Ozone Pact
description: The Soviet Union said today that it needed more evidence that certain chemical compounds destroy the ozone layer before it joined plans by the United States and other countries to ban them by the end of the century.

title: Bridge
description: A year ago Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., apparently set a world record for the oldest winner of a substantial competitive event of any kind. Playing in Pittston, Pa., with Edwin Utan of Scranton, Pa., he won a two-session Open Pair Championship at the age of 95.

title: Review/Television; More Jokes And Angst On ABC
description: The new series ''Anything but Love'' gets out of the starting gate with some formidable assets. The stars are Jamie Lee Curtis and Richard Lewis and there are unmistakable signs of instant rapport. More important, ABC is trying out the show as part of its already formidable Tuesday night lineup. ''Anything but Love'' is on at 9:30 P.M., preceded by ''The Wonder Years'' and ''Roseanne'' and just before ''Thirtysomething.'' A strong time slot can be half the survival game.

title: First City Financial Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains from the sale of two businesses totalling $102.5 milion. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Gulfstream Is Big Test For the Breeders' Cup
description: Gulfstream Park closes after today's racing, but not for the year. The track will run its shortest and latest meeting ever eight months from now, when it reopens Nov. 3 for a three-day stand centered on the seven Breeders' Cup races Nov. 4.

title: 3 Die in Occupied Territories
description: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians during protests in the occupied territories today, and a third Arab died in a Gaza Strip prison. Palestinians reported that an Arab man was beaten to death in prison during interrogation. The authorities confirmed that an inmate had died, but gave no explanation and said an investigation had been opened.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Corrected from Saturday, March 4.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Food for Thirst
description: Just as the tides of temperance seemed to be cleansing the capital of its wicked ways, temptation is at the gates again.

title: Results Plus
description: SLED-DOG RACING Swenson in Lead: Rick Swenson, a four-time champion, was the first racer to reach the highest checkpoint in Iditarod race as leading mushers made their way through the rugged Alaska Range early yesterday. Swenson, driving 18 dogs through the darkness, arrived at Rainy Pass checkpoint at 5 A.M. He was followed 4 minutes later by Joe Runyan of Nenana. Susan Butcher, a three-time champion, arrived at 5:22 A.M., and DeeDee Jonrow of Bethel arrived four minutes later. None of the four leaders has taken the 24-hour layover required during the race. Three other mushers were on the trail from Finger Lake to Rainy Pass, which is 226 miles into the race and at 3,400 feet elevation. Martin Buser, who was out front when the first mushers pulled into Finger Lake late Sunday, declared his 24-hour layover and had not moved by early yesterday. Under the rules of the race, mushers are required to make a 24-hour stop at one of the race's 24 checkpoints; at the others, they take whatever length of rest they believe they and the dogs need. However, mushers are allowed to use the strategy of declaring a 24-hour layover, then leaving after a couple of hours, in hopes of getting a jump on their competitors. (AP) HORSE RACING Aqueduct cancels program: Aqueduct Race Track canceled yesterday's card because of the weather. Racing will resume tomorrow.

title: Market Place; Have Japanese Stocks Peaked?
description: IS Japan's stock market finally peaking, just as skeptical foreigners finally give up their doubts and begin to buy Japanese shares?

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter and year-earlier period included income tax benefits from recognition of operating loss carryforwards of $3,300,000 and $2,050,000, respectively. Revenue represents net sales and other income.

title: The S & L Sticker Standoff
description: While Congress grapples with the main elements of the savings and loan crisis, a sticker standoff between banks and thrifts highlights the pettiness of competing interests. At issue is whether the S & L's may display the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's logo after they come under F.D.I.C. jurisdiction. They want to use it in window stickers and advertising. Banks say no. The Treasury Department waffles - just when it ought to back the S & L's.

title: Tower Wins His First Supporter From Democratic Ranks in Senate
description: In the first breach of Democratic ranks in the battle over John G. Tower's nomination to be Secretary of Defense, Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama announced today that he would vote for Mr. Tower's confirmation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When the world realizes New York has not got any empty hospital beds, people will think twice about moving here. It's a frightening thought.'' J. Richard Munro, chairman of Time Inc. and a member of a private commis-sion on AIDS in New York City. [ B5:4. ]

title: 18 Lawyers Defecting From Shea & Gould
description: Continuing its pattern of aggressive expansion, the law firm Myerson & Kuhn said yesterday that it would open a Los Angeles office with 18 lawyers who are defecting from Shea & Gould.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Study Cases Involving Mentally Ill
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide what level of protection the Constitution affords the mentally ill against involuntary confinement and involuntary medication by state employees.

title: Drug Charges Dropped Against 7
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed charges against seven of 14 men who had been charged with a sprawling conspiracy that the Government had said involved international cocaine and heroin trafficking tied to the Sicilian mob.

title: The F.B.I.'s Not the Issue. Tower Is.
description: Some Senate Republican supporters of John G. Tower have come to the desperate extreme of hoisting the Federal Bureau of Investigation on their partisan petard. And even some of my Democratic colleagues have been critical of the F.B.I. role in this matter. But the F.B.I. and its investigation are not the problems in this nomination.

title: AIDS Drives Jobs Away, Report Says
description: New York City's health care crisis, worsened by the AIDS epidemic, will drive away businesses and jobs unless state and local officials act now to relieve the overcrowded system, a privately financed commission on AIDS said yesterday.

title: A Good-News Column
description: The teachers at the academy on the hill like to say it is the only drug-free high school in the country. It probably is, but it's more than that.

title: Appointee at Salomon Has Brash Reputation
description: Lee H. Kimmell, 39 years old, who has been named to head the merchant banking efforts at Salomon Brothers, is a figure with a colorful reputation on Wall Street. He is viewed from inside and outside the firm as a smart investment banker who built Salomon's financial institutions advisory business into one of the most profitable areas of investment banking at the firm.

title: Olajuwon Fined
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rockets' all-star center, was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for punching Michael Cage of Seattle in the SuperSonics' 118-108 victory over Houston last Friday. The incident occurred with 3 minutes 46 seconds to go in the first half. Cage put Olajuwon in a hammerlock after Olajuwon grabbed an offensive rebound. His intent was to stop an easy basket. Olajuwon broke free from Cage's grasp, and struck Cage in the mouth, opening a gash that took four stitches to close. (AP)

title: Datavision reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S.E.C. Upheld On Magazine
description: The Supreme Court today turned down the free-speech arguments of a financial magazine accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of violating an anti-touting provision of Federal securities law.

title: In Milan, a Softer and Brighter Autumn
description: Common sense rather than revolutionary spirit dominates the fall and winter fashion showings here. The clothes collections shown over the weekend looked serviceable, not outrageous.

title: Japan's View on U.S. Chips
description: Japan is not obligated to increase American semiconductor makers' share of its computer chip market, an official of the Japaneses Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: School Embezzlement Charged
description: Warrants were issued Friday for the former student body president of San Francisco State University and three other students accused of embezzling $9,000 from the student government, the district attorney's office said. Each faces a felony charge of theft of public funds, said George Beckwith of the district attorney's special prosecution unit. The students are accused of conspiring to set up a fraudulent billing system that charged the student government for services that were never delivered.

description: With Lionel Simmons on top of his game tonight and Doug Overton proving that La Salle is much more than a one-man team, the Explorers put the hopes of St. Peter's for a trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament on hold for another year.

Nor, in the long run - perhaps even in the short - will it much matter whether Eastern Airlines lives or dies. But as these questions dominated the headlines and broadcasts of a journalism that thrives on today:

title: Alcatel in Talks to Sell Equipment to Soviets

title: Gasoline Prices Rise
description: The price of leaded gasoline rose by more than a penny a gallon in the last two weeks, an industry analyst, Trilby Lundberg, said on Sunday. A nationwide survey of gasoline stations last Friday found that the average cost, with taxes, of all grades of gasoline was 99.22 cents a gallon, up about a half-cent from Feb. 17, Ms. Lundberg said. For the same period, leaded gasoline at self-service stations rose 1.11 cents a gallon, she said.

For two years Marlene Mendelsohn, a substitute teacher, has run a kaffeeklatsch a week, raising $100,000 to pay lawyers and anti-incinerator experts. In her garage she has 37 boxes of files; in the laundry room is a stack of clippings to be filed; by the kitchen phone she keeps crates of her best files handy for emergencies.

Self-run and flexible, the orchestra is a model of free enterprise: ready for important artistic challenges but not above less edifying enterprises when the money is right. Its ability to respond quickly and substantially to almost any musical situation has been long an object of respect.

Weirton said it a large majority had approved plans for a public offering of up to 1.5 million shares, or about 23 percent of the stock.

In a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Parretti said he would raise his stake in Cannon to 62.5 percent, from 39.4 percent, and change its name to the Pathe Communications Corporation. Mr. Parretti, who is Cannon's chief executive, also controls Pathe Entertainment Inc.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Greenspan the Witness
description: As if Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, didn't have his hands full trying to curb inflation by restraining a stubbornly vigorous economy, he has had to appear with unusual frequency before Congressional committees.

title: Goldsmith Teams With Rothschild
description: The British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith formed a partnership with Jacob Rothschild, a member of the European banking family, to make takeover bids. No targets were announced, but Mr. Rothschild did not rule out hostile bids. The takeover vehicle will be a new company, Newco, which is linked to Mr. Rothschild's Anglo Leasing P.L.C.

title: Review/Television; Living a Year Among the Criminals
description: ''One Year in a Life of Crime,'' on HBO at 10 P.M., brings you as close as you may care to get to the wasted lives of Mike, Rob and Fred, three New Jersey shoplifters in their 20's. Jon Alpert, a venturesome television reporter, tags along on their forays up and down the aisles of the stores that supply them with anything from bedsheets to silverware to burglar alarms, which they promptly dispose of at knockdown prices.

description: b-Included a gain on investments of $9,553 for the quarter and a loss on investments of $20,696 for the year. c-After a loss on investments of $15,481 for the quarter and a gain on investments of $82,345 for the year.

title: Yankees Overcome Gooden And Ojeda
description: After four years of strained relations and no games, the Mets and Yankees opened an era of good will here today 1,100 miles from New York, and wasted no time behaving like natural enemies: Dwight Gooden buzzed a fastball high and tight at Rickey Henderson, who then singled, stole a base, scored a run and led the charge that beat the Mets, 6-4.

title: American Air
description: American Airlines plans to spend as much as $3.5 billion for up to 100 small jets and 200 turboprop commuter planes, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported. The small jets, which seat about 100, would cost up to $2 billion, and the commuter planes, which seat between 35 and 50 passengers, would cost up to $1.5 billion, the newspaper said.At American, a spokesman said no final decisions had yet been made.

title: News Shows With Ads Are Tested in 6 Schools
description: A daily television news program with commercials began a five-week test run beamed into classrooms yesterday as protests from educators mounted.

description: Derek Harper scored 13 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Dallas Mavericks past the Nets, 105-99.

title: Congress Seeks to Reduce Greenhouse Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: 52 Illegal Aliens Found
description: Fifty-two illegal immigrants, many with plane tickets and most of them from Brazil, were arrested at a place where smugglers keep such aliens, the authorities said today. The action Sunday night brought the number of such aliens arrested over the weekend to 89. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has been concentrating for a week on stopping them from using commercial airlines.

title: LETTER BY JACKSON HINTS AT A SHIFT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, under fire for backing a third-party candidate in Chicago's mayoral race, appeared to suggest in a letter to an Illinois Congressman that he might be willing to abandon his candidate if the state's Democratic Party pledged to support him in a 1992 Presidential bid.

title: U.S. Deplores Violence in Tibet
description: The United States today criticized China's use of force to quell demonstrations in Tibet but has not yet expressed its views directly to the Chinese authorities, the State Department said.

title: NASA Turns From Custom Design to Standard Models
description: WITH custom-built spacecraft growing so expensive, new vehicles for American planetary missions will take on the mass-produced look more commonly associated with Detroit. Nearly all of them in the next decade and beyond will come in one of two standardized models - either a no-frills runabout for neighborhood trips to the inner solar system or a larger sedan for long journeys to the outer planets.

title: APL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; Baryshnikov in 'Metamorphosis'
description: It's hard to guess who will suffer most at Steven Berkoff's theatrical version of ''Metamorphosis'': devotees of Franz Kafka, whose story is distorted into Marxist kitsch by this adaptation, or fans of Mikhail Baryshnikov, whose stage debut as a dramatic actor, however dignified, amounts to little more than a sideshow to the loud circus surrounding him. But at least one constituency, albeit a smaller one, should be happy -the Berkoff cult. The director doesn't even have to appear in the flesh to upstage Kafka and Mr. Baryshnikov throughout this piece's interminable (and intermissionless) 100 minutes.

description: A Long Island man was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for stabbing his estranged wife 33 times in 1986. She survived the attack.

title: Inside Story: Doc Dusts Rickey
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. rrThe rivalry between the Mets and the Yankees resumed yesterday with a Dwight Gooden fastball aimed in the direction of Rickey Henderson's chin. It was all a misunderstanding, but a rather emphatic way of resuming the New York series, dormant since 1985. Like superpowers unable to decide on the shape of a peace-conference table, the Mets and Yankees did not meet at all for three seasons. The Mets' resurgence just might have had something to do with Yankee recalcitrance, but George Steinbrenner had not wanted his pitchers batting in exhibitions if they would not be hitting during the regular season. When the Texas Rangers moved away from Pompano Beach, a huge gap was left in the Yankee schedule, just as the Mets announced plans to move to the east coast of Florida. Lou Piniella, in his brief term as nominal Yankee general manager, worked with Joe McIlvaine of the Mets to get the teams together again. The teams resumed with a 6-4 Yankee victory yesterday, and they will meet five more times, including twice in New York just before the regular season. Spring training had been quiet up to now, with Henderson claiming that drinking had damaged the Yankees last year, and Keith Hernandez and Darryl Strawberry working on their slugging percentage during the taking of the team picture. The first game between the Mets and Yankees in four years was not important enough for Strawberry or Gary Carter to be in the lineup. Steinbrenner was said to be in Pittsburgh. And the Yankees did not bring Don Mattingly and three other weary or gimpy regulars on the hour-and-half haul to the Mets' camp in the middle of nowhere. The developers who paid for the new Prima Vista interchange on Interstate 95 couldn't come up with the last $4.98 for a sign indicating it goes to the Mets' complex. One of the Yankee buses overshot the exit yesterday morning, and the driver tried to turn on the grassy embankment and got stuck. The other bus rescued the players, and deposited them at the ball park. The sellout crowd was settling into its seats as Gooden started his windup and Henderson stepped away from the plate and called time out. "Knowing Rickey, you don't know what he's thinking at any time," Gooden said later. Somehow, Gooden gained the impression that Henderson was trying to unsettle him, as if this were the first game of the Subway World Series. Henderson got back into the box and had to scramble away from a fastball. "I tried to go low and away," Gooden said with a straight face. Henderson limbered up and got back into the box and spanked a fastball for a base hit, went to second on a balk, stole third and later scored. His manager, Dallas Green, liked Henderson's response to the brushback. By then, Gooden had learned that Henderson had stepped out because his bat had made contact with the glove of Mackey Sasser, the catcher. But it was more fun this way. Actually, Gooden said, the inside pitch to Henderson was just another drill in his spring-training regimen, like running and hitting and fielding practice. In his first few years in the major leagues, Gooden said, he had pitched inside just often enough to throw 95-m.p.h. fear into the batters. "You've got to pitch inside," Gooden said. "Not knock the guy down. If you let the batters know, they'll take advantage of it." Gooden had been looking forward to pitching to Mattingly, but the slugger had played nine innings twice already, and was spared the trek. So Gooden had to pitch to Mattingly in his mind. "Fastball, right down the middle, first pitch," Gooden said. "Hopefully, he'll be taking it. Fastball away. Then, it depends whether he hits the first pitch." Gooden's out pitch? "I might have gone for a curve." Sometime in the next five games, we may have Gooden against Mattingly, like the old days when Newcombe pitched to DiMaggio, Reynolds pitched to Campanella, as the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Yankees played a home-and-home series. One year, the Yankee manager, Casey Stengel, led young Mickey Mantle out to the right-field wall in Ebbets Field and tried to tell him how to play the bizarre caroms. Mantle looked at Stengel as if he were nuts, not believing the Old Man had once patrolled that very turf as a National League outfielder. "He must think I was born old," Stengel quipped. Met fans don't seem to despise Yankee fans, and vice versa, the way Dodger fans and Yankee fans used to feel about each other. But with five games in the next month, that could change. - SPORTS OF THE TIMES

title: KEY RATES
Roughhouse Tactics Spoil College Image
description: With numerous roughing and high-sticking penalties called, the two Harvard and Rensselaer playoff games over the weekend did not live up to college hockey's image of fast skating with no fighting. A total of 135 minutes in penalties were called, with 22 infractions last Friday night and 29 on Saturday. But the Crimson survived, winning by 7-3 and 5-4.

title: Expansion to Europe Considered by N.F.L.
description: A springtime National Football League, based in Europe and composed partly of draft choices and backups, could be ready to start as early as next year, Mike Lynn of the Minnesota Vikings said yesterday.

description: Commuters encountered morning rush-hour delays of up to 90 minutes crossing the George Washington Bridge into Manhattan yesterday, and more delays were expected today as crews repaired a cracked steel beam that prompted the closing of a main roadway leading off the span.

description: An untreatable fish disease, never before found in North America, has been detected at two salmon hatcheries in the Pacific Northwest, prompting biologists to kill nearly four million eggs and young fish in an effort to halt the spread of the virus.

title: American Stores Co reports earnings for 13wk to Jan 28
description: The company said the most significant adjustment for the year and the quarter relates to the acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc., which has been included in the operations results of American Stores Co. since June 2, 1988. Lucky Stores Inc. had a negative impact on earnings per common share of $1.97 for the year and 71 cents in the fourth quarter. This reduction is due to the interest expense relating to the financing of the purchase and the amortization of the write-up of Lucky's assets. The negative impact is less than anticipated as the Lucky operating results continue to exceed budgeted levels. The company also said the LIFO inventory adjustment reduced earnings per common share by $1.03 in the current year, versus 48 cents in the prior year. For the quarter, the LIFO impact was 27 cents per common share, compared with 9 cents last year. The increased expense is due to the greater inflation in the cost of product in the current year than was experienced in 1987.

title: Elderly Suffer Mental Ills Without Hope of Aid, Congress Panel Told
description: Many of the elderly have mental health problems requiring some form of help but they are not getting any, a Congressional panel was told today.

title: Shoreham Staff Girds for Uncertain Future
description: Morning at the Shoreham nuclear power plant: Today, just as they have every day for the last four years, 1,000 workers run through their rituals of readiness. Machinists check pipes and valves, electricians fix broken ventilation fans and control-room operators test the instruments that monitor the workings of the vast machine.

title: Honor for Wade
description: Virginia Wade of Britain, who won the women's singles title at the first United States Open, held at Forest Hills in 1968, and who won at Wimbledon on the tournament's 100th anniversary in 1977, has been elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame. Gerald Patterson of Australia, a Wimbledon men's singles winner in 1920 and 1922, was also elected, 22 years after his death. Induction ceremonies will be at the Newport Casino on July 15 during the Volvo Tennis/ Hall of Fame championships.

title: Takeshita Now Admits World War II Aggression
description: Two weeks after suggesting that it was ''up to historians'' to determine whether Japan had been the aggressor in World War II, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita reversed himself today, saying Japan had been guilty of ''aggression by militarism.''

title: Friend of Defendant Turns Witness in Police Slaying
description: Less than two hours before a New York City police officer was murdered, one of the men later charged with the execution-style shooting drove past the officer's car and pointed him out to a friend, the friend testified yesterday.

title: Redemption Option On Farm Bonds
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $150 million of consolidated systemwide bonds, due in 1992, with an optional principal redemption provision, through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Great Expectations
description: The new University of Miami football coach, Dennis Erickson, said yesterday that he realizes he will face high expectations from Hurricanes fans, who have had two national championships to celebrate in the last six seasons. ''We'd better not lose over two games,'' Erickson said at a news conference shortly after he arrived in Miami. ''I know what the expectations are.'' Erickson, the coach at Washington State the last two seasons, was named to the Miami job Sunday. Erickson replaces Jimmy Johnson, who was named to succeed Tom Landry as head coach of the Dallas Cowboys. Gary Stevens, the Miami assistant coach who was passed over in favor of Erickson, was named yesterday as quarterbacks coach for the Miami Dolphins. Stevens, 45, replaces David Shula, who resigned Feb. 27 to accept an assistant coaching position with the Cowboys.(AP)

description: When Kenny Anderson was asked to summarize his basketball career at Archbishop Molloy High School, the high-scoring all-American from Queens offered a penetrating insight into the current state of high school sports. Reflecting on the hours of study, practice and competition he had put in during his four years, Anderson concluded that his experience had essentially been like work.

description: AS the world moves toward a ban on ozone-destroying chemicals to head off an epidemic of skin cancer, experts searching for substitute chemicals predict that the technical and economic cost of the change will be high.

description: Knight-Ridder Inc., a leading newspaper chain, said today that it would ask stockholders to approve defensive steps against hostile takeover attempts. The company, whose papers include The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer, seeks charter amendments that would require approval by 80 percent of the common stock for certain mergers and certain foreign ownership arrangements.

title: Shaklee Expected To Rebuff Jacobs
description: The Shaklee Corporation will probably resist any attempt by the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs to buy the company, analysts said. Mr. Jacobs made a conditional offer on Friday to acquire Shaklee for $40 a share in cash, or a total indicated value of more than $500 million. But he will cut his payment in half if the San Francisco company proceeds with a $20-a-share special dividend.

description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today sharply criticized his party's 1988 Presidential campaign as being devoid of ideas and urged the Democrats to emulate former President Ronald Reagan's consistent sense of political purpose.

description: PHYSICISTS theorizing about ''strange matter,'' so far never seen in a laboratory, have proposed that it could be used to fuel reactors that would generate energy far more efficiently than any now available, and without radioactive byproducts.

title: Reviews/Orchestra; Ensemble From Munich
description: Two contrasted giants of musical nationalism occupied the Bavarian Symphony Orchestra of Munich and its music director, Colin Davis, at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening. The program of Sibelius and Mussorgsky was interesting in itself, in that visiting German orchestras are usually called upon to represent themselves in familiar German classics, and it was also a good one. The Finn's haunting ''Swan of Tuonela'' and his fierce final symphony (No. 7) were balanced after intermission by the wonderful tone poem that introduces ''Khovanshchina'' and the celebrated ''Pictures at an Exhibition.''

title: Tokyo Office For Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers A.G., the West German banking arm of the American securities firm Salomon Inc., has won Finance Ministry permission to set up a representative office in Tokyo, a representative of the firm said today. The office is the first step in Salomon's plan to open a bank branch here, the spokesman said. Branches may conduct foreign-exchange trading and offer services that are prohibited in Japan for securities companies. The Finance Ministry has not allowed foreign banks to open branches until they have had a representative office for two years. The offices can only gather information and may not solicit business. The ruling by Justice Herman Cahn of New York State Supreme Court clarifies a letter of agreement between Lord, Geller and the firm formed last March by several of its top executives, which allowed the new agency to solicit personnel from the older firm, but prohibited it from pursuing existing Lord, Geller clients. Justice Cahn's letter leaves in place the prohibition against Richard J. Lord and Arthur W. Einstein Jr. from soliciting or serving Lord, Geller clients.

description: As the House ethics committee begins evaluating the results of an eight-month investigation of Speaker Jim Wright, House Democrats and Republicans are bracing for a bitter partisan fight that is likely to have ramifications far beyond whatever judgment the panel delivers.

title: Griffith Joyner Gets Sullivan Award
description: Florence Griffith Joyner, who set two world records last year and won three Olympic gold medals, was named the 1988 Sullivan Award winner as the nation's top amateur athlete. Griffith Joyner, 29 years old, of Los Angeles, joins her sister-in-law, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, on the list of Sullivan winners. Joyner-Kersee was the 1986 winner. ''Every award means a lot, but this award is the most prestigious,'' said Griffith Joyner at a ceremony last night in Indianapolis. ''It's like the Oscar of acting to me.'' The winner is selected by past winners, the news media, the United States Olympic Committee executive board and members of the Amateur Athletic Union board. Griffith Joyner, who announced her retirement from competition last month, set world records in the 100- and 200-meter dashes last year and then won Olympic gold medals in both events. She also helped the United States earn an Olympic gold medal in the 400-meter relay and ran on the 1,600-meter relay team that set an American record while claiming a silver medal.(AP)

Iran-Contra Testimony The jury in the trial of Oliver L. North heard testimony about the affair for the first time, despite objections by the judge. Page D24. Pretoria's Power Struggle South Africa's ailing President and the man who replaced him as party leader are heading for a clash over who will lead the country. Page A3. Scandal in Japan A former chairman of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone was charged with bribery in the Recruit stock scandal in Japan. Page D1. The Cost of Saving Ozone As the world moves toward a ban on chemicals that destroy the ozone, experts say the technical and economic cost of the substitutes will be high. Science Times, page C1. On Justice in Dallas A case in which a man narrowly escaped execution for a murder has stirred new questions about law and order. Page A19. College Pipeline For the top-level high school athlete, the grind of practice, travel, competition, study and recruitment often feels like a job. Page B9.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: A Life of Giving Voice To the Voiceless
description: ''Listen,'' said Alan Lomax, pushing a button on his cassette player. ''This is a musical family.'' Out came the voices of Central African pygmies, vocal lines ricocheting and intertwining, then a Soviet Georgian chorus, just as complex and exuberant, then Genoa fishermen, with their own kind of intricate counterpoint -one musical style taking three far-flung forms.

title: Golden Corral Realty Corp reports earnings for
description: The company attributed the earnings decline primarily to the expiration, on Oct. 15, 1987, of the obligation of Golden Corral Corp., the lessee of all of its properties, to pay rent sufficient to provide the company with operating cash flow of $1,850,000 per year.

title: Southern California Water reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $1,367,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Article 718389 -- No Title
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering $400 million of floating-rate notes, due Sept. 14, through various securities dealers.

title: Concern Seeks Workers With AIDS
description: A New York City company that provides photocopying and other office services to businesses has been established to hire people afflicted with AIDS or the AIDS virus in an effort to restore a sense of normalcy to their lives.

title: North Trial Jury Hears Testimony On U.S. Arms-for-Hostages Plan
description: Over the judge's objections, the jury in the trial of Oliver L. North heard testimony for the first time today about the Reagan Administration's arms-for-hostages initiative with Iran. Although the arms sales and subsequent diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels are at the heart of the case, the Iran initiative had been mentioned only fleetingly before today in the trial of Mr. North, a former National Security Council aide.

title: Creative Training Nurtures Hurdler
description: When Monifa Taylor was 7 years old, her father strung a piece of cardboard between two chairs in the backyard, and a hurdling career began. When she was 9, she trained in a Pathmark parking garage in the Bronx, and the chairs were replaced by shopping carts. When she was 10, Robert Taylor built wooden hurdles, and his daughter and her friends jumped over them in the same garage.

title: Ivaco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,720,000 for the latest year and $3,173,000 for the prior year and special charges of $1,877,000 and $5,014,000 for the latest year and year- earlier period, respectively. The company said some 1987 figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Giant Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Northwest Drug Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a special gain of $87,500. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Turner Corp. President Gets Additional Position
description: The Turner Corporation, the nation's largest building contractor, said yesterday that Alfred T. McNeill, the president and chief executive, had been named to the additional position of chairman.

title: B.P. Guaranteeing Unit's Debentures
description: BP America Inc., a subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C, is offering $250 million of guaranteed debentures, due in 2004, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Oklahoma Review
description: The University of Oklahoma is still reviewing an incident that led to the arrest of the Sooners basketball star Mookie Blaylock, and won't make any decisions on him before the investigation is completed, Donnie Duncan, the athletic director, said yesterday. The police in Norman, Okla., said they arrested Blaylock, 21 years old, on a charge of public intoxication outside a convenience store Sunday following an argument between Blaylock and a female companion, who also was ar-rested. (AP)

title: Marietta Journal; Winds of Change Rock A Classic Rocking Chair
description: Joel Chandler Harris used to rock on a Brumby while he contemplated Br'er Rabbit and his other tales of the South. Jimmy Carter took five Brumbys to the White House.

title: Chess
description: The Pan-American intercollegiate championship for 1988 was won by the Harvard team in New Brunswick, N.J., on Dec. 30 with a score of 7 1/2 out of 8 matches. This was the first time that Harvard has won outright, although it has entered every year since the origination of the competition for four-man teams in 1946 and tied for the championship twice, in 1975 and 1986.

title: Liqui-Box Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Northern reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $1,049,214 special charge. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: James E. Doyle Is Dead at 86; Co-Founded Advertising Agency
description: James Edwin Doyle, a founder of the Doyle Dane Bernbach advertising agency, died of emphysema Sunday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Doyle, who was known as Ned, was 86 years old.

title: Bittersweet Snow
description: Yesterday, New Yorkers awoke to something they may have given up hope of seeing this winter. A few might have cheered. Winter was back to normal. If Christmas isn't Christmas without presents, and no New Year's Eve party a party unless several guests act silly, then a New York winter isn't winter unless, at least once, it snows. This turning city needs its still points, and a soft white blanket is one of them.

title: If Eastern Loses, the Public Loses
description: Short of cash and grounded by union pickets, Eastern Airlines will probably be sold or forced into bankruptcy. Should the public care?

title: Moore-Handley Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year included a $83,000 charge from an accounting change.

title: Washington Talk: The Environment; Clean Air Backers Like Way Wind Is Blowing
description: Almost every year for the last eight years legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act has been introduced in Congress, and each time it died.

title: Molecular's Deal With Shionogi
description: Molecular Biosystems Inc. said Shionogi & Company would market Molecular's ultrasonic medical-imaging product in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea. Shionogi, the third-largest Japanese pharmaceutical company, committed $31 million to the product, Albunex, bringing the worldwide financing for it to $109 million.

title: Emory S. Basford, Educator, 90
description: Emory S. Basford, a retired chairman of the English department at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., died Wednesday at Asbury Village, a retirement community in Gaithersburg, Md., his residence since 1970. He was 90 years old.

title: Some Addicts Find Medication Can Ease Craving for Cocaine
description: DRUGS commonly used to treat depression can help some cocaine users remain abstinent during the initial period when their cravings are overwhelming, recent studies show. And if they take cocaine while using antidepressants, one new study indicates that the pleasurable effects of cocaine are blunted.

title: Dow Up by 20.53; Bond Strength a Factor
description: Stocks rose yesterday, buoyed by the strength in bond prices and the dollar.

title: Blame the System, Not the Senate
description: The process of choosing the key appointees in any new administration is a serious one. Even though George

title: HERO Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included special gains of $26,639 for the latest year and $98,620 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Japan Ready to Share Burden, But Also the Power, With U.S.
description: For decades this country has been content to let the United States take the economic and political lead while Japan grew wealthy in its shadow. Now Japan is willing to shoulder more of the cost of America's international commitments, so long as it receives more decision-making power in return.

title: A Power in Mattresses Goes Private
description: After dominating the nation's bedding business for much of the last three decades, the Ohio Mattress Company, known for its Sealy and Stearns & Foster brands, is being sold by the family that founded it 82 years ago.

title: 2d Departure At Shearson
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. experienced another important departure yesterday -its second in three weeks -when its vice chairman, Peter J. Solomon, resigned to pursue other interests.

title: But Did They Floss?
description: THE simple toothpick may have been one of the first ''tools'' of human design.

title: 'Hizzoner!' Closes
description: ''Hizzoner!,'' a one-man play by Paul Shyre about Fiorello H. La Guardia, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street. Directed by John Going and starring Tony Lo Bianco, the show ran for 13 previews and 12 regular performances.

title: Gap Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 28
description: The company said the 1988 fiscal year earnings included an after tax charge of $4 million stemming from the restructuring of Banana Republic operations.

title: Books of The Times; A Picaresque Search for Father and for Self
description: Moon Palace By Paul Auster 307 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Rig Count Climbs a Bit
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased by four last week, to a total of 761, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, was 978. The count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Tri-Star to Become Part Of Columbia Pictures
description: Dawn Steel, who became president of Columbia Pictures 18 months ago after David Puttnam's departure from the studio, has consolidated her power.

title: Arrow Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $5,672,000 and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $7,791,000. c-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $4,917,000 and $12,932,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior year loss from continuing operations included a gain on the sale of property of $13,390,000. The company said the latest year reflected the inclusion electronics distribution businesses of Ducommun Inc.

title: Soviet Student's Odyssey To Columbia's Class of '92
description: Getting into Columbia University turned out to be surprisingly easy for Anna Meytina, a student from Leningrad. Getting to the United States was not. To take her place in the class of 1992, Miss Meytina had to give up her Soviet citizenship, leave her country alone and spend three uncertain months in transit, first in Vienna, then Rome. She arrived in New York Jan. 11, four months after classes began.

title: EASTERN SLASHES ALL BUT 3 ROUTES AND LAYS OFF 5,000
description: Eastern Airlines shut down operations on all but three routes yesterday and laid off 5,000 workers, saying it could not maintain a full flight schedule because nearly 90 percent of its pilots were honoring picket lines set up by striking machinists.

title: European Astronomers Unable to Detect Pulsar
description: EUROPEAN astronomers, working in an observatory in the Chilean Andes, say they have been unable to sight a fast-rotating pulsar or extremely dense star whose birth was reported last month.

title: Agents' Trial Begins In Racketeering Case
description: Opening statements were made today in the Federal racketeering trial of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom.

title: O'Rourke Ends Standoff As He Plans Campaign
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke ended a political standoff in the Republican Party and a weekend of intense speculation by announcing today that he intended to seek re-election this year.

title: Siblings of Retarded
description: Studies on the interaction between children with Down's syndrome and other children in the family show that the disability does not prevent the retarded child from having normal sibling relationships; in fact, a more positive interrelationship was noted.

title: Petroleum Heat & Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
On an L.I. Street, Questions and Anger Over Slaying of a Girl, 13
description: Two days after 13-year-old Kelly Tinyes was found stabbed and strangled in a neighbor's basement, there are plenty of questions but no arrests. And residents on the quiet one-way street where she lived and died are hurt, frustrated and angry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * The actress Meryl Streep; Zimmerman, Fiman & Dixon, an agency in Santa Monica, Calif., and Harmony Pictures have collaborated on Mothers and Others for Pesticide Limits, a direct-response advertsiing campaign for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Snag Over Repayment Shouldn't Hold Up Westway Jr. Planning; Highway-Related Use
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Wilkinson Inc., to Friedman, Benjamin, for its Cricket lighters.

title: National Gas & Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflected a 7 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: 'Ghetto' Previews
description: ''Ghetto,'' a play with music by the Israeli playwright Joshua Sobol, is to begin previews April 7 and open April 30 at Circle in the Square. ''Ghetto'' is the story of a theatrical troupe operating under Nazi rule in the Jewish ghetto of Vilna, Lithuania. It is being directed by Gedalia Besser, who staged the original production in Haifa in 1985.

title: Good Signs on Arms Cuts
description: The Soviet-bloc and Western arms proposals unveiled in Vienna today agree on several important principles, boding well for the new talks to cut conventional weapons in continental Europe.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Of Vines and Snakes
description: The Congressman said he was bothered by reports that the Province of Ontario had rejected for itself the stipulation of the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement that tariffs affecting the products of Oregon's 260 vineyards would be reduced.

title: Suitor Responds To Arvin's Suit
description: An Indonesian businessman, Ismanto Wanandi, asserted that he was not interested in Arvin Industries' military-related businesses and that any attempt by him to seek control of the Columbus, Ind., company would not include those businesses.

title: Apple Offers A New Model Of Macintosh
description: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced a model of the Macintosh, the IIcx, which is a smaller and less expensive version of its top-of-the-line IIx model.

title: Overturned Murder Conviction Spotlights Dallas-Style Justice
description: For the second time in five years, justice in Dallas is under a national spotlight. First it was Lenell Geter, a young black engineer who was freed from prison in 1984 after being given a life sentence for an armed robbery he did not commit. Now it is Randall Dale Adams, who narrowly escaped being executed for a murder conviction that was unanimously overturned this week, 12 years after his trial.

title: Brasilia Journal; For Brazil's Political Elite, Rock-Bottom Ratings
description: When television cameras entered Brazil's Congress recently to record an episode of a new soap opera, more than one legislator worried whether the story of a corrupt womanizing politician would have viewers struggling to distinguish fact from fiction.

title: Arkansas Youth Wins the Science Talent Search
description: A 16-year-old high school senior from Arkansas today won the 48th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the pre-eminent competition for aspiring scientists.

title: Doskocil Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,150,000 and $2,418,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $637,000 for the quarter and $815,000 for the year, and tax credits of $345,000 and $2,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest year results included the consolidation of certain Wilson Foods operations purchased in October 1988.

The company said during fiscal 1988, the company discontinued two profitable businesses; the oilfield equipment manufacturing operations of Dyer Equipment, a division of Strathcona Steel Inc., and the steel fabrication operations of Strathcona Steel, which resulted in the $3,132,000 provision. Results are in Canandian dollars.

title: ERC Environmental & Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said net income did not cover preferred stock requirements in any period.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aequitron Medical Inc., Minneapolis, a medical equipment manufacturer, named Curtis J. Olson interim president and chief executive. He succeeds George A. Jackson, who has resigned.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Cooper Fills Top Position
description: Arthur C. Bass, a former president of the Federal Express Company, today was named the president and chief executive of the Cooper Companies, which makes medical diagnostic systems.

title: Metro Datelines; 7 Injured in Fire In Office Building
description: Seven people were slightly injured when fire broke out yesterday on the 15th floor of a 16-story brick office building at 26th Street and Broadway, officials said.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I can understand how to collect hydrogen and oxygen by electrolyzing water, but how are rare gases obtained? A.Many rare gases do not form compounds, but are distributed in the air in tiny amounts.

title: Picturetel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Security Financial Corp of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included realized capital losses of $4,129, compared with realized capital losses of $4,705 for year-ago period. The latest year included realized capital gains of $13,909, compared with realized capital gains of $74,398 for prior year.

title: U.S. Fines Rockwell $5.5 Million
description: Imposing one of the largest penalties ever on a military contractor, a Federal judge fined the Rockwell International Corporation $5.5 million today for defrauding the Air Force of $446,000 on a navigation-satellite contract.

title: Levi Strauss President
description: Thomas W. Tusher was named the president of Levi Strauss & Company today and a member of the board of Levi Strauss Associates, which owns the jeans maker. Mr. Tusher, 47 years old, executive vice president and chief operating officer since 1984, retains the chief operating role. He becomes the second president who is not a descendant of Levi Strauss, the founder. The other was Robert Grohman, who was president and chief executive from 1981 to 1984.

title: Metro Datelines; D.E.A. Chief Faults School Drug Plans
description: Robert M. Stutman, head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in New York, said yesterday that city school officials were dragging their feet in putting together a city-wide drug education program.

title: U.S. High Court to Review Yonkers Councilmen's Fines
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the contempt citations issued last summer against the four Yonkers City Councilmen who refused to approve legislation to carry out a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Asamera Minerals Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents mineral revenue. The company began operations on July 1, 1987. On a pro-forma basis, 1987 net from operations was $2,769,000, or 12 cents a share. After a tax credit of $2,466,00, final net was $5,235,000, or 22 cents a share. Mineral revenue was $30,466,000.

title: Clothestime reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income

The company said 1988 results were adversely affected by a work stoppage in its wiring devices group, lower sales in power supplies and strength in the Canadian dollar. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Computer Identics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter included a restructuring charge of $1,322,000.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: PHYLLIS RUBIN, a purchasing coordinator at Avon Products, is walking along West 56th Street on her lunch hour when a man suddenly steps in front of her. ''Would you mind answering a few questions for a consumer research group?'' he asks the somewhat startled Miss Rubin.

title: Trace That Call No More!
description: Douglas Brown writes all the way from England to protest the latest telephone gizmo, a device that lets its owner know the number from which an incoming call is being placed.

title: Computalog Gearhart Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The 1988 net included a non-recurring gain of $904,000, or 14 cents a share, on the August 1988 sale of the assets of the company's Southeastern Box Co. subsidiary. b-After an extraordinary gain of $306,000, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of land for the quarter and year.

title: Dow Declines 4.11 Points in Quiet Trading
description: LEAD: The stock market pulled back in quiet trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.11 points to close at 2,290.71.

title: 3 Democrats Map Strategies to Depose Koch
description: With the Democratic primary for mayor more than six months away, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, stood in front of a storefront clubhouse deep in Bensonhurst the other night, his trim gray hair glinting in the fluorescent light as he talked about love, bigotry, municipal corruption and his 2-year-old grandson.

title: Airline Dispute: Rite of Passage for Bush
description: The strike at Eastern Airlines has suddently pitted President Bush against organized labor in a major test of wills that could have substantial and lingering impact on the Bush Presidency as well as an already weakened labor movement. At stake for the White

title: Griffin Gold, AIDS Worker, 33
description: Griffin Gold, a founding member and past president of the People With AIDS Coalition, a privately supported group, died of AIDS yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Aid to Public Schools Is New Group's Aim
description: A group of prominent business executives has formed a new foundation to channel money into New York City's public schools.

title: Unit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $29,400,000 reduction in the carrying value of certain drilling equipment.

title: Review/Film; Boswell of the Rust Belt
description: Tony Buba, the director of ''Lightning Over Braddock: a Rustbowl Fantasy,'' seems particularly fond of the television reports about him that have aired on various Pittsburgh stations, so fond that he includes snippets of them in his film. For one thing, Mr. Buba no doubt likes being known as Braddock's Boswell, the premier (if only) film maker to have devoted his career to immortalizing this Pennsylvania steel-mill community now in an advanced state of decline. For another, the sameness of the television reports surely amuses Mr. Buba, whose own approach owes nothing to anyone else's.

title: Pollution By Kodak Brings Sense Of Betrayal
description: If ever there was a company town, this is it. Since its founding more than a century ago, the Eastman Kodak Company has given steady paychecks to generations of workers and an identity to the city of Rochester. Today, Kodak employs 47,000 people, almost one tenth of the region's labor force.

title: An Angry Judge Unseals a Transcript
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday unsealed the transcript of a court proceeding Monday in which he assailed prosecutors as incompetent and inept and blamed them for forcing him to set drug dealers free.

title: Taiwan Inflation Rises
description: Inflation rose to 4.07 percent in February, the highest official rate in almost seven years, the Taiwan Government announced today, but private economists said the real level could be about 15 percent. The economists said official figures did not take into account increases in property prices.

title: Community Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Slogan Barred To Pizza Hut
description: A district judge in Texas has forbidden Pizza Hut to use an advertising slogan that another pizza restaurant chain said was a copy of its own slogan.

title: Charge and Countercharge As GAF Trial Nears End
description: In a two-and-a-half-hour summation yesterday, a Federal prosecutor asserted that the vice chairman of the GAF Corporation ''made a terrible mistake'' and broke the law when he tried to manipulate the price of the Union Carbide Corporation's stock in the fall of 1986.

title: Car Bomb Breaks Beirut Lull; 2 Are Dead and 20 Wounded
description: A car bomb blew up near the American University Hospital in West Beirut today, killing two women and wounding about 20 other people, the police said.

title: Pattern Processing Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CB&T Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
To Some, Koch Book Is Artful Politics
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch's new book, an exploration of social and moral issues with John Cardinal O'Connor, has convinced political experts that he is going to focus much of his re-election campaign on conservative but wavering voters.

title: WHISTLE-BLOWERS WIN BUSH BACKING
description: President Bush, looking for ways to mend fences with Congress, has agreed to support a bill to protect whistle-blowers that was vetoed by President Regan last year, Congressional sponsors of the legislation said today.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Advertising column of Business Day on Feb. 27 misidentified the agency that handles the Noxell Corporation's Noxzema skin cream account. It is Lintas: New York, not Burnett.

title: Civil Rights Caravan to Mark Deaths
description: Twenty-five years after the slaying of three young men drew the nation's attention to the civil rights movement, a new Freedom Summer caravan is being planned to commemorate the deaths, organizers said today.

title: Capital Gains Tax Defeats the Small Investor; Effect on Stock Market
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 Nations Agree to Join Ozone Pact
description: Twenty countries were reported today to have said they would join an agreement that calls for a 50 percent reduction on production of ozone-destroying chemicals by the end of the century. United States and British officials pledged to help developing countries acquire new technologies to replace the chemicals.

title: Fathom Oceanology Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Arafat Cannot Negotiate Peace
description: LEAD: Enabling Yasir Arafat to negotiate with Israel over the future of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip may pave the way to peace - not because he represents the Palestinians in the territories Israel occupied in 1967, but because he does not.

title: '88 Inflation Up, I.M.F. Reports
description: The inflation rate in industrial nations rose in 1988 for the second consecutive year, the International Monetary Fund said in a report released this week.

The 36-voice ensemble, which is directed by Stanley Sperber, sang a program of mostly sacred settings and folk music on Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, as part of a North American tour.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Bush Gets Smart on Guns
description: Until now, President Bush has turned a deaf ear to the rising rattle of automatic rifle fire in Washington D.C. and other big cities. But his designated drug czar, William Bennett, seems to have captured his attention. For that both men deserve credit.

description: b-Net loss

title: Reuschel Agrees
description: Rick Reuschel, who would have been eligible for free agency after this season, has agreed to a one-year contract extension through 1990, the San Francisco Giants announced yesterday. Reuschel, a 39-year-old right-hander, was 19-11 last season and tied for the National League lead with 36 starts.

title: 'A Prayer for Owen Meany'
description: When the film version of John Irving's ''World According to Garp'' appeared, people who hoped to be intellectually fashionable sniffed and claimed, ''I never liked the book in the first place.'' Since the huge commercial success of the novel, in 1978, Mr. Irving has often been snobbishly and mistakenly dismissed as merely popular.

title: Review/Television; The Dark Side of an American Political Phoenix
description: When Richard M. Nixon told reporters after his defeat in the 1962 California gubernatorial contest, ''You won't have Nixon to kick around anymore!'' his prophetic powers were at low ebb. In the succeeding years, he would invite ever more energetic kicking around, culminating in August 1974, when he was virtually kicked out of the White House.

title: Publishers Swear Off Acidic Paper
description: Dozens of publishers and authors gathered at the New York Public Library yesterday to call attention to a villain turning millions of books to dust: acidic paper.

description: Poland's Government said today that Soviet forces were responsible for a massacre of Polish officers during World War II.

Joseph, the chief executive of Drexel Burham Lambert Inc., in which Mr. Joseph described provisions of the firm's plea agreement with the Government as ''clearly unfair.''

description: President Bush, fighting a growing perception in Washington that his Administration is adrift, today gave a spirited defense of his new team and his policies, declaring that they were in fact ''on track'' and that he had total confidence in his staff and its initial agenda.

description: Wariness on Europe '92 West Germany's unionized workers fear that the unified European Community planned for 1992 could erode their privileged status. Page D1. Iran Cuts British Ties Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain a week after demanding that London denounce the author of ''The Satanic Verses.'' Page A3. title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Prairie View Protest
description: The president of Prairie View A. & M. University, Percy Pierre, refused yesterday to dismiss the football coach, Haney Catchings, and players who said they would not play for the coach said they would bring forth charges of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations. Catchings denied any violations, saying of his players: ''They will do anything they can to take a shot at me.''

title: Skeletons in the Attic
description: LEAD: Millions of American Indians lived in this country when Columbus first landed on our shores. After the western expansion, only about 250,000 Indians survived. What happened to the remains of those people who were decimated by the advance of the white man? Many are gathering dust in American museums.

title: Wheaton Assesses First Coed Year
description: Footballs arch high over the lawns at Wheaton College these days. Dormitories are noisier. Students now hang around on weekends. There is an all-male rock group. It calls itself ''Outnumbered.'' After 155 years as a women's college, this small liberal arts college in southeastern Massachusetts is nearing the end of its first year as a coeducational school.

Critics of Bush Savings Plan Face Senate
description: Confronting an often angry group of senators, officials of the savings and loan industry's two largest trade groups said today that they opposed key elements of the Bush bailout plan, particularly proposals that would require their industry to pay for a large amount of the cleanup.

title: COURT SAYS PILOTS CAN OBSERVE LINES IN EASTERN STRIKE
description: A Federal judge in Miami refused to order Eastern Airlines pilots today to cross the picket lines of striking machinists, leaving Eastern's operations virtually paralyzed for a fourth day. The airline said that unless the pilots returned to work soon it would be forced into bankruptcy.

title: Regional Wineries Produce Winners
description: IN contests last week, a dry 1987 riesling made by King's Road Vineyard won the Governor's Cup in competition with 94 other New Jersey wines, and an off-dry '87 gewurztraminer from Sakonnet Vineyards was voted the best-of-show grape wine among 49 New England wines. Eastern wine makers are increasingly mastering the vineyard and cellar techniques required by such cool-climate vinifera grapes as riesling and gewurztraminer, which yield crisp, fruity, well-made wines in northern Europe, especially in West Germany and Alsace, France. The wine makers are also mastering such hybrids as seyval blanc and vidal blanc, which can provide fresh, appealing minor wines that remind consumers of vins de pays, the regional wines savored in France's countryside. New Jersey and New England vintners are wrestling with the problems of drawing attention to their small industries and of gaining recognition.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: I FIND myself buying turkey breast at the supermarket more and more as a substitute for high-priced veal in all sorts of recipes, and the results have been extraordinarily successful. A recent dish that underscored the versatility of turkey breast was a scaloppine layered with cheese and prosciutto and served in a Marsala sauce.

It said, however, that the income was insufficient to offset its administrative and other expenses. The company said its net for the latest six months primarily reflects the sale of its facility.

title: Abbott Makes Debut As Angels' Pitcher
description: ''There were a few butterflies out there,'' Jim Abbott admitted in Phoenix yesterday after facing a big-league lineup for the first time and struggling for two innings as his California Angels beat the Oakland Atheltics, 9-4. ''I got caught up in who was out there, rather than what I could do.''
