The public relations arm of Ogilvy & Mather, which is made up of Adams & Rinehart, O&M Public Relations and Ogilvy & Mather Public Affairs, will now be known as the Ogilvy Public Relations Group.

title: A Friend in Need
description: It was John G. Tower who hired Robert C. McFarlane for the staff of the Senate Armed Services Committee back in 1979, and the Defense Secretary-designate stood up for Mr. McFarlane again before the former national security adviser was sentenced Friday.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Books, Then Records; Flames Climb Higher
description: When Southern California enters a battle, it does so with its own style, and so it is with the uproar over the novel ''The Satanic Verses.'' The newest twist is the contribution of a radio talk show host who has declared as the enemy not the novel's author, Salman Rushdie, nor his antagonist, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, but a rock singer, Cat Stevens.

title: Alamco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said results also included $500,000 of pretax income largely due to a substantially reduced level of interest expense as a result of the debt restructuring. In addition, the company realized a net $300,000 tax benefit caused by the company's ability to recognize the tax benefits of pre-restructuring 1988 operating losses.

title: The Singing Chef: Jean Stapleton Plays Julia Child
description: At just about the same time in televison history that Edith Bunker was attempting to civilize her husband, Archie, Julia Child was trying to teach the rest of us how to cook.

title: Reviews/Music; Brahms, Not by the Book
description: At the head of Brahms's First Sonata for Violin and Piano stands a concise cluster of instructions to the performers: they are to play vivace ma non troppo (lively but not too much so), piano (softly), mezza voce (half-voice) and dolce (sweetly). Shlomo Mintz and Yefim Bronfman, who gave all three Brahms sonatas Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, answered every requirement but the first: their playing missed the underlying liveliness and tension that should inform this tranquil-looking music.

title: Moneygram Service Grows
description: The American Express Company yesterday announced the international expansion of its consumer money transfer service, American Express Moneygram.

description: Ryder System Inc. yesterday announced the appointment of David R. Parker as president of its vehicle leasing and services division, which accounted for $3.1 billion of the company's $5 billion in sales last year.

title: Justice Department Signals a Tougher Stand on Mergers by Airlines
description: Acknowledging that some airline mergers have led to higher fares, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division suggested today that competition is no longer vigorous enough to permit much further consolidation.

title: Judge in North Case Assails U.S. Over Handling of Secret
description: The Federal district judge in the trial of Oliver L. North has criticized the Government's handling of secret documents and threatened to disregard any secrecy claims that he concludes are frivolous.

title: Review/Comedy; 2 Who Spoof Worlds Old and New
description: What might Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' sound like if it were turned into a musical comedy by Irving Berlin? How about ''Fun With Dick and Jane'' as a psychological puzzle devised by Stephen Sondheim? And what sort of show-stopper might John Kander and Fred Ebb create for Helen of Troy were they to tackle a musical version of the ''Iliad''?

title: Israelis Kill Arab in West Bank
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian today in Nablus, in the West Bank, while hunting for the killers of a soldier who died there 10 days ago, the army said.

description: While snowflakes swirled, scattered by harsh winter winds, and three police helicopters flew in tribute yesterday, 5,000 police officers from around the metropolitan region, family members and friends mourned the death of the first New York City police officer killed in the line of duty this year.

description: Thomas V. Jones, the chairman and chief executive of the Northrop Corporation, has been subpoenaed to appear before a Congressional subcommittee investigating its efforts to sell its F-20 fighter plane in South Korea, Congressional staff members said on Monday.

title: Judge Implies Jailed Defendants Made Calls to Terrify Witnesses
description: The judge at the trial of three men charged with murdering a police officer in Queens suggested yesterday that the defendants had sought to intimidate witnesses by telephone from jail.

title: Islanders Lose to Bruins; Gilbert and Larson Traded
description: Upon losing his fifth goaltending outing in five attempts as an Islander, the rookie Jeff Hackett wreathed his body in towels and launched an uncomfortable search for the right words to describe his plight. Here were his coach, Al Arbour, and his predecessor and advisor, Billy Smith, congratulating him on yet another job well done, yet for a losing cause. It was hard for Hackett to decide whether he should be downhearted about the stream of losses or encouraged by the appreciation of his teammates and superiors. In the end, he was both. ''I've got to keep forgetting about my record,'' said Hackett. ''I've got to look at my other stats and not worry. There's only been one game, in Buffalo, where I felt I didn't play well. If I can just keep playing like this, the win will come, and it'll be that much sweeter when it comes. But I hope it comes soon.'' Tonight, Hackett, despite stopping 26 of Boston's 28 shots, found himself on the losing end of a goaltenders' duel with the seasoned Rejean Lemelin, who stopped all but one of the 24 shots sent his way by the Islanders. 'We Deserved a Tie'

When the Alternative Route Is the Way to Go

For the colleges and the professional leagues, which need these stars, such academic problems are potential leaks in the pipeline that provides them with a steady supply of talent.

title: Jordan Group Expands Into Newspapers
description: JAMES P. DOLAN, who learned the newspaper business under the tutelage of Rupert Murdoch, has joined the Jordan Group in New York to guide the publishing consulting firm's expansion into the newspaper business.

title: 2 Announce Campaigns for Jersey Governor
description: Assemblyman Alan J. Karcher announced today that he would seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He attacked government policies that he said favored the rich, and he challenged Democratic primary opponents to debate him.

description: The latest first quarter results included a gain of $5.1 million from a change in accounting and a net gain of $5.6 million from the sale of a 50 percent interest in the company's domestic theatre operations.

title: Swedish Electronic Mail
description: Sweden's public telephone company will offer computer terminals instead of telephone directories to customers next year, opening the way for electronic mail and other services, a spokesman said today. France has had such a system in place for several years.

title: Pan Am Victim Honored
description: A Justice Department Nazi-hunter who died in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland last December will be honored today by the Israeli Government. At a ceremony at the Israeli Embassy, the Yad Vashem commemorative medal will be presented to the family of Michael S. Bernstein, former assistant deputy director of the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigation, which investigates war crimes.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about the removal of police powers from five Metro-North officers referred incorrectly to the status they will have after their case is heard by arbitrators. If the officers, who were involved in improper videotaping in Grand Central Terminal, are reinstated by the arbitrators, they could be recertified for police work. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of another officer dismissed in the case. The officer, Lieut. Joseph Angelo, lost his police powers also.

title: Wine Talk
description: AN Italian sparkling wine, a gewurztraminer from Alsace, France, and two cabernet sauvignons, one from California and one from Israel, were the gold medal finalists in a recent wine competition in New York. Aside from quality, the wines had only one thing in common, and the wine from Israel should be the tip-off: they were all kosher.

title:
Market Place;

description: The students made it to Conestoga High School in Lancaster, Pa., today, trudging through about five inches of snow, even if snow and ice kept President Bush at home.

title: Dillard to Buy D. H. Holmes
description: Dillard Department Stores Inc. agreed to acquire the D. H. Holmes Company for stock with an indicated value of about $40 million. Dillard owns 146 department stores in the central and southwestern United States. Holmes operates 18 department stores and two clearance centers in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: New York State's Medical Financing
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency made a $114 million debt offering yesterday to help finance improvements in mental health installations through competitive bidding.

title: Jackson Returns to Work
description: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' playmaker who underwent surgery Monday afternoon to repair torn cartilage in his right knee, began his rehabilitation program yesterday at the team's training base at SUNY- Purchase.

title: Federal Express's Afternoon Delivery
description: The Federal Express Corporation will begin an overnight service on April 1 that delivers documents and small packages in the afternoon instead of midmorning at a slightly reduced rate, the company said. The new Fedex Standard Overnight service promises next-afternoon delivery for packages up to five pounds, arriving by 3 P.M. in most areas or 4 P.M. in more remote locations. The current Priority Overnight delivery program promises deliveries by 10:30 A.M. in most locations.

title: Evidence Is Lacking on Texas Visit
description: The bulk of available information suggests that John G. Tower did not visit Bergstrom Air Force Base in the years that a former sergeant said he saw Mr. Tower drunk on the base. But documents that could help establish the full truth are incomplete or were destroyed years ago.

title: LESSONS
description: Asian-American students are widely viewed as a ''model minority'' who adapt quickly and successfully to American ways. Students like Richard Yao are the reason why.

title: Blame the Law, Not the Strike
description: Should Eastern Airlines strikers be permitted to hold other airlines, rail freight and even commuter rail lines hostage to their demands? Surely not, but under the Railway Labor Act, which covers labor relations in both the rail and airline industries, sympathy walkouts are apparently legal. Congress needs to act promptly to prevent this abuse of the right to strike.

title: Review/Music; From Yemen and Iran
description: Sunday's concert at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, featuring Jewish musicians from Yemen and Iran, offered two radically different types of music. As played by the singers and percussionists Sara Harat and Sara Malachi, the Yemeni music, filled with flowing steppe-like melodies and meant for weddings and dancing, had a raw, functional quality to it. When the Iranians Mansouri Nisan, a violinist, and Fridon Golestani, a singer and drummer, played their refined, sophisticated music, it was meant for listening.

title: Senate Backs U.N. Delegate
description: The Senate voted 99 to 0 today to confirm Thomas Pickering to be United States delegate to the United Nations. Mr. Pickering, who will succeed Vernon A. Walters, most recently served as Ambassador to Israel. In his 30-year career as a Foreign Service officer, Mr. Pickering has also been Ambassador to Jordan, Nigeria and El Salvador. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Austin Loses as Comeback Begins: Tracy Austin, one of the world's top players before nagging injuries led her to virtually give up tennis five years ago, began her comeback on a sour note yesterday, losing in a first-round match of the $250,000 Virginia Slims tournament at Indian Wells, Calif. Austin, 26 years old, battled seventh-seeded Nicole Provis of Australia gamely through the first two sets before losing, 7-5, 5-7, 6-1. Austin, the United States Open champion in 1979 and 1981, gave up competitive tennis after being bothered by recurring neck and back problems. Her last previous singles competition had been in February 1984. Austin took the opening four games of the match. But, suddenly having trouble getting her second serve in, she dropped the next four games and wound up losing the set, during which she had five double faults. Austin came back to take the second set, using well-placed groundstrokes. Provis took command in the third set after losing the first game. Chris Evert, the tournament's top-seeded player, begins play today, meeting Hana Mandlikova of Australia. Mandlikova defeated Akiko Kijimuta of Japan, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday.(AP) HORSE RACING Mi Selecto Romps: Mi Selecto splashed through the slop to score an 11-length victory at Gulfstream Park yesterday in the $300,000 Pan American Handicap, a race that lost much of its significance when it was switched from the grass to the dirt and Sunshine Forever was scratched. The Pan American is usually the year's first Grade I grass race, and the early entries drew Sunshine Forever, last year's champion grass horse. In mid-afternoon, though, Gulfstream management pulled the race off the grass, even though this was the closing day of the meeting. Safety considerations were cited.The change in surface made a Grade I winner of Mi Selecto, who had not won a race on the dirt since a maiden victory a year ago. Pay the Butler finished second in his first career start on the dirt. Fabulous Indian, who was overtaken by the winner after six furlongs, held third, and Green Barb, the 9-to-5 favorite, was fourth. Mi Selecto paid $11.40 for $2 to win and ran the mile and a quarter in a very respectable 2:01 3/5 under Jose Santos. Mi Selecto, owned by William Agusti Jr., has won 6 of 21 career starts and has earned $485,855.

title: Review/Opera; Aprile Millo Takes On a Callas Vehicle
description: For New Yorkers long in the tooth, ''Il Pirata'' is probably best recalled as a concert vehicle for Maria Callas, who revived the rarely heard Bellini opera in 1959 at Carnegie Hall after her contract had been canceled by the Metropolitan Opera. (The performance survives, appropriately enough, on a pirated recording.) Otherwise, ''Il Pirata'' does not have much recent history hereabouts, partly because it is the work of a composer who, at age 25, was only beginning to find the flowing but dramatic style that would ripen into ''I Puritani,'' ''La Sonnambula'' and ''Norma.'' Then, too, there is the libretto, with its band of happy-go-lucky pirates, confused lovers and ensemble numbers that might have been shanghaied by Gilbert and Sullivan. The final pages are given over to an extended mad scene by the heroine, Imogene. She loves a pirate but, to provide the plot with the necessary complexity, marries his deadly foe and bears a child. There is nothing left for her but to fire off a cabaletta and fall into a fatal swoon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Shares of Time Inc. surged $9.25 as rumors swirled that other bidders would appear and undermine its plan to merge with Warner Communications. Although industry experts acknowledged the possibility that another suitor could emerge, most believe that the chances of that happening are small. [ Page D1. ] A Federal Court ruled that Eastern Airlines pilots could continue to refuse to cross picket lines of striking machinists, keeping the airlines' operations paralyzed for a fourth day. But an industrywide slowdown by pilots has barely affected the nation's air transportation system. [ A1. ] Microsoft said earnings would be lower in the third quarter, the first drop since it went public three years ago. Wall Street was shocked by the news: Microsoft's shares plunged $8.50. [ D1. ] Boeing is trying a novel way to bolster its assembly lines. Struggling to meet demand for its new 747-400 jumbo jet, it will borrow up to 670 workers from Lockheed for six months. [ D1. ] First Union will acquire the Florida National Bank in a deal worth $849 million. [ D2. ] Lawyers for the Milken brothers disclosed statements from a tape recording of Drexel Burnham Lambert's chief, in which he described provisions of the firm's plea agreement with the Government as ''clearly unfair.'' [ D5. ] Salomon became the special adviser to Texaco shareholders, beating out Rothschild, which thought it had won the job. [ D4. ] GAF's vice chairman ''made a terrible mistake'' when he tried to manipulate the price of Union Carbide's stock, the U.S. prosecutor said in closing remarks to jurors. [ D5. ] A suspect in the Du Pont extortion case recruited his lover, who had access to company secrets, court papers assert. [ D5. ] G.M. announced increases in its buyer incentives, but at the same time reduced rebates on some models. [ D4 ] American Express said it would expand its money transfer service into Europe, Asia and Australia. [ D4. ] Federal agencies will be asked to aid the Landsat system, the earth-sensing satellites whose financing is threatened. [ D22. ] THE ECONOMY

title: Review/Dance; Twyla Tharp Goes to Paris
description: The proscenium above a front curtain in the Paris Opera House bears the seal of Louis XIV and the insignia Anno 1669, the year he founded the Academy of Music and Dance that is now the Paris Opera. It is this academy and the codification of ballet rules by the Sun King's dancing masters that is the obliquely considered subject of Twyla Tharp's first and lively work for a foreign ballet company.

title: Milan's Season Grows Brighter and Bolder
description: The cavalcade of color on the runways here is continuing as the fall and winter fashion openings pick up momentum.

title: Under Fire, as Usual, From the Third World
description: Three blocks west of the White House, the International Monetary Fund stands as a tower of financial rectitude, the base for 1,600 technocrats who call the shots in scores of third-world countries.

title: Iran Breaks Off Relations With Britian
description: Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain today, a week after Teheran demanded that the British Government denounce the author Salman Rushdie and his novel ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Cypress Fund Spurns Conversion
description: Cypress Fund Inc., a closed-end mutual fund, said its board had rejected a demand by a group of investors to convert the fund to open-end status. But the fund said it would repurchase up to 1.35 million of its 8.92 million shares in the open market and said it would begin paying out at least 10 percent of its net asset value to holders each year, with part of the payment representing a return of capital.

title: 3 Slain in Northern Ireland
description: Gunmen shot and killed three men at a village gas station today and drove away, the authorities said. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility, saying in a statement that the gas station, in Coagh, 50 miles west of Belfast, was a stronghold of the Ulster Volunteer Force, an outlawed Protestant group.

title: Words by Hamilton, Music by Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Sandinistas Seek the Help of Venezuelan
description: Rebel leaders said today that a broad front of Nicaraguan opposition groups had asked the Venezuelan President to help establish a formula for insuring fair elections in Nicaragua next year, as called for by an agreement among Central American presidents.

title: Tony Battle Over Robbins's Show
description: In a dispute that involves the two biggest theater owners on Broadway, the Tony Awards administration committee is scheduled to meet tomorrow to decide whether ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' will be eligible in the category of best musical. Millions of dollars are riding on the decision because it is almost certain to affect the financial future of both the Robbins show - a compilation of numbers from 11 of his musicals from 1944 to 1964 - and the other potential nominees.

title: Food of the Future Is Ethnic and Fast
description: The meals of the future are likely to emerge from a melting pot by way of the microwave, and will be easy enough for a child to prepare, a group of 470 chefs, cooking teachers and food professionals were told this week.

title: Topics of The Times; Battling Bias at the F.B.I.
description: Faced with repeated findings of discrimination in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Director William Sessions had to do something about affirmative action. Whether he has done enough won't be clear for a while, but his recent actions promise improvement.

title: Wanted: A Lift for China's Can Industry
description: HENRY N. NASS, a New York City businessman whose work frequently takes him to the Far East, realized late last year that something was missing in China. In a nation of one billion people ravenous for modernization - television, satellites, fast food - there was almost no sign of one of the most common consumer objects in the West: aluminum beverage cans.

title: Altron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year both included an after-tax gain of $274,000 from the disposition of a Puerto Rican facility.

title: Court's Fear of AIDS Is Cited In Reversal of a Jury Verdict
description: Maryland's highest court has reversed the murder conviction of a man who was tried in a courtroom where the court officers wore protective gloves because they believed he was infected with the deadly virus.

title: Review/Theater; A Farce in the British Tradition of the 1950's
description: Every season, at least one British farce takes a long lease on a West End theater under a marquee festooned with effusive comments (''I loved it!'' Daily Mail). One can tell almost everything about the plays from the apparently interchangeable titles: ''No Sex Please, We're British,'' ''Not Now, Darling,'' ''Move Over, Mrs. Markham'' and ''Run for Your Wife!'' The last three were written or co-written by Ray Cooney.

title: Dodd Decides To Back Tower In Defense Post
description: In an extraordinary chapter to a tale both personal and political, Senator Christoper J. Dodd of Connecticut today announced his support for John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, apparently leaving the Republicans just three Democratic votes short of salvaging the imperiled nomination.

title: Rates Go Down At Citicorp Sale
description: For the first time since January, interest rates fell at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Nutmeg Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Oak Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $277,000. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $1,436,000, an extraordinary charge of $66,000 and the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,559,000. Latest-quarter results included a gain of about $4,900,000 from patent settlements. The 1988 results included $9,700,000 of income from patent settlements and gains on the sale of properties, and $4,400,000 of income from the reversal of certain reserves. The 1987 results included income of $18,200,000 from the settlement of a patent case, and $2,529,000 from extraordinary gains.

title: First Mercantile Currency Fund Inc reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income Revenue for latest year was negative and for 1987 was positive. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Humphrey Will Leave Senate
description: Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, who describes himself as the most conservative voice in the Senate, announced Monday that he would not seek a third term.

title: Socialists Retain Mayoralty in Burlington, Vt.
description: The socialist party of Mayor Bernard Sanders was victorious today as a former community development director was elected to succeed the four-term Mayor.

title: The Nephew Who Doesn't Cry Uncle
description: For the Milwaukee Brewers' 20-year-old shortstop - who might be the American League rookie of the year - learning to hit a fastball has never been that much of a problem. Gary Sheffield was 8 years old when he first swung at his uncle's fastball. But his uncle was not another pot-bellied fellow out there in the backyard, puffing while chasing a plastic ball that his little nephew squibbed past him.

title: Standard Motor Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Procedures Tested for a Chemical Arms Ban
description: The United States and other countries negotiating a ban on poison gas and other chemical weapons have started making mock inspections of their national chemical plants to test procedures for verifying a treaty outlawing such weapons, a French official said today.

title: Group I Software reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The figures reflected a 5-for-4 stock split in November.

title: Alabama Black Mayor Loses In a Congressional Primary
description: A Mayor lost his bid today to become the first black elected to Congress from Alabama in this century, as voters in a mostly white district endorsed his politically moderate opponent for the Democratic nomination.

title: First Union to Acquire Florida National Bank
description: The First Union Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it would acquire the Florida National Bank of Jacksonville in a deal worth $849 million. In doing so, First Union would nearly double its operations in Florida and become the state's second-largest bank.

title: British Spending Drop
description: Britain's spending boom appears to be slowing, based on the latest Government figures. The Treasury said Monday that retail sales had dropped by 2.4 percent in January, revised from a provisional 1.5 percent fall. Sales had risen in December by three-tenths of a percent. Britain also said that new consumer credit in January was $:3.49 billion ($6.04 billion), down from December's $:3.52 billion.

title: Tide Charts To Help Fight Beach Debris
description: Federal and state officials said yesterday that they think they can use their knowledge of tides and other currents to predict where floating garbage is likely to appear in the waters around New York City in the summer and remove much of it before it washes onto beaches.

title: Dr. Halpern Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Michele Halpern, a fellow in infectious diseases at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and Dr. Seth Aloe Cohen, a resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai, were married yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland. Rabbi Georges Vadnai officiated at the Synagogue of Lausanne.

title: Real Estate; Warehouse Demand High In New Jersey
description: ALTHOUGH the office market in New Jersey is anemic, brokers and property owners say the demand for light industrial and warehouse space in the state is robust.

title: Consolidated Energy Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included losses of $115,000 and $3,392,000, for the quarter and year, respectively, in equity from interest in a hotel partnership and a gain of $2,484,000 on the sale of the investment in the hotel partnership for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $3,121,000 on the sale of oil and gas properties. c-Net loss d-Included equity losses from interest in a hotel partnership of $1,235,000 for the quarter and $3,626,000 for the year.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: VIRGINIA HORNER, veteran of many midwinter muskrat-ham-and-oyster dinners to benefit the Mount Vernon Volunteer Fire Company of the Maryland Eastern Shore, knows that muskrat is not everyone's idea of a great meal. ''Some people who've never eaten muskrat come in with a kind of funny look on their face,'' said Mrs.

title: Jury Hears Bid by Agent to Sign Iowa Star
description: In a secretly recorded conversation, Norby Walters, an agent on trial here on Federal charges of mail fraud and racketeering, was heard persuading Ronnie Harmon to sign a contract in March of his junior year at the University of Iowa.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Rick Reuschel, pitcher, on a one-year contract extension. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Signed Brooke Steepe, guard, to a second 10-day contract. FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Derrick Shepard, wide receiver, to a two-year contract. PHOENIX (NFC) - Agreed to terms with Michael Adams, cornerback, on a three-year contract. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Larry Williams, offensive lineman, to a three-year contract. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Stephen Hobbs, wide receiver, and Martin Mayhew, cornerback. HOCKEY EDMONTON (NHL) - Traded Jim Weimer, defenseman, and Alan May, right wing, to Los Angeles for Brian Wilks, center, and John English, defenseman. HARTFORD (NHL) - Traded Torrie Robertson, left wing, to Detroit for Jim Pavese, defensemen. Signed Brad Shaw, defenseman, for the remainder of the season. ISLANDERS (NHL) - Traded Reed Larson, defenseman, to Minnesota and Greg Gilbert, forward, to Chicago for future considerations. MINNESOTA (NHL) - Traded Dino Ciccarelli, forward, and Bob Rouse, defenseman, to Washington for Mike Gartner, forward, and Larry Murphy, defenseman. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Traded Patrick Mayer, defenseman, to Los Angeles for Tom Tookey, center. Assigned Scott Bjugstad, right wing, to Muskegon of the International Hockey League. RANGERS (NHL) - Acquired Lindy Ruff, defenseman, from Buffalo for a fifth-round draft choice in 1990.

title: 'Mommy Career Track' Sets Off a Furor
description: To the outrage of many feminists and the applause of much of the business world, the head of a group devoted to advancing women's careers has written in the Harvard Business Review that corporations ought to recognize two different groups of women managers: those who put career first and those who need flexible a schedule to be with the children.

title: Lubbock Is to His Liking
description: President Bush swore by the people of Lubbock, Tex., today that his young Administration was doing ''just great,'' and it seems he was on solid ground in doing so.

title: Bank Yields Continue Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts rose in the week ended yesterday, continuing to reflect the general tone of short-term interest rates.

title: Cambodian Wants U.S. Aid to Emphasize Arms
description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh said today that on a trip to Washington next week he would urge that a greater portion of American aid to his non-Communist Cambodian faction be allocated for ''lethal'' military assistance.

title: First Medical Devices Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bernard F. Huppe, 77, a Medieval Scholar
description: Bernard F. Huppe, a medieval scholar and a founding professor of Harpur College, later the State University Center at Binghamton, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Heinz Earnings Increase 13.1%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that it had a 13.1 percent gain in third-quarter profit because of higher sales volume, price increases and acquisitions.

title: Victoria Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for 1987 were restated because of a previous accounting error.

title: Metro Datelines; Suit Is Filed in Jersey On New York Taxes
description: The 80 members of the New Jersey Assembly and several taxpayers filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday aimed at blocking New York State from collecting higher income taxes from about 250,000 New Jerseyans who work in New York.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We have seen every imperfection in an essentially good man dragged into the pitiless glare of television while his lovely daughters sat there and were subjected to it. It has been a high price to pay for public service. I will vote for John Tower's confirmation.'' - Senator Lloyd Bentsen.

title: Stevenson-Lincoln P.S.A.L. Final Again
description: It's official. The Public Schools Athletic League Class A basketball championship game in the Felt Forum next Monday night will be a rematch of the final last year - Adlai Stevenson against Abraham Lincoln.

title: Tibetans' Houses Raided by Chinese Troops
description: Security forces dragged Tibetans from their houses today as thousands of Chinese troops took up posts around Lhasa today after three days of anti-Chinese riots, travelers said.

title: INSIDE
description: Charting Arms Talks

title: Pat Cummings Is Out
description: Pat Cummings, the Miami Heat forward-center, has been sidelined for the rest of the season by a stress fracture in his left tibia.

title: Rare Labor Unity; Strike Is Renewing Unions' Solidarity But Is Unlikely to End Their Decline
description: Some people are heralding the Eastern Airlines strike as the rebirth of the labor movement in the post-Reagan era. But even if the machinists and pilots manage to win, their victory is not likely to reverse the long-term trend away from union power.

title: Threat of Major Air and Rail Disruptions Is Easing
description: The threat of widespread disruptions to rail and air travel eased yesterday when a job action by pilots again failed to slow traffic and a Federal ban on secondary boycotts of railroads withstood an initial appeal.

title: U.S. Grants Visas to Three P.L.O. Members
description: The United States said today that it was granting visas to three Palestine Liberation Organization members so they could attend a Middle East conference at Columbia University this weekend.

title: Blaylock Suspended
description: Oklahoma officials suspended the starting guard Mookie Blaylock for one game yesterday, the second-ranked Sooners' opener against Colorado in the Big Eight Conference post-season tournament at Kansas City on Friday. The suspension was imposed after a review of the details surrounding his arrest by the police in Norman, Okla., early Sunday.

title: The Case Against John Tower
description: John Tower is qualified by long experience in the Senate to be Secretary of Defense. He is being painfully subjected to a rain of rumors about his private life, many of which are untrue or irrelevant. The President is entitled to expect the Senate will confirm his Cabinet nominees. Yet despite all that, Mr. Tower's nomination fails the test the Senate must apply, and it fails the test set by President Bush himself. Here are some points that emerge from the long controversy.

title: Sullivan Backs Needle Trading To Fight AIDS
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, today endorsed programs for exchanging hypodermic needles, in communities that want them, to help stop the spread of the AIDS virus by drug addicts who share contaminated syringes.

title: Russian Is Banned
description: Lyudmila Filimonova, a Soviet speed skater, has been banned for 15 months after failing a drug test taken at the European championships in January, an International Skating Union official said yesterday in Berlin.

title: Continental Materials reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
John Crawford Memorial
description: A memorial service for John M. Crawford Jr. is to be held in the Astor Court of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 2 P.M. Monday. Mr. Crawford, a collector of Oriental art and a trustee of the museum, died of cardiac arrest on Dec. 21 at the age of 75.

title: Balfour Maclaine Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Elderly Patients Need Medication Coordinator
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Up In New York
description: After generally dismal results in January, sales rose on average at several of New York's biggest retailers in February. The improvement averaged 4.6 percent in the city and 7.6 percent in the metropolitan area from the year before.

title: Campbell Resources Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $6,798,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,659,000 and a special charge of $11,191,000. The company said 1988 results included an unusual charge of $58.4 million relating to the writedown of the carrying value of resource properties. It said extraordinary charges of $6,798,000 in 1988 and $11,191,000 in 1987 are related to its discontinued coal operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ruling by Judge Blocks Purging of Voter Rolls
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday that bars the New York City Board of Elections from purging voter-registration rolls.

title: Political Debt and a Son's Enduring Loyalty
description: Since it began in the early 1970's, the political career of Senator Christopher J. Dodd has been punctuated by the echoes of his father, Thomas J. Dodd.

title: Transfering Memories From Film to Video
description: A BLACK-AND-WHITE film, circa 1940, is playing in Alexander Shahgholi's office: a family picnic in summer, with children wrestling, fathers barbecuing and mothers chatting. Mr. Shahgholi is not feeling nostalgic; he is transferring an eight-millimeter film to videotape, one of the specialties of his nine-year-old firm, International Video Services.

title: Review/Pop; A Leprechaun's Search
description: Van Morrison is one of rock music's quirkier elder statesmen. The singer and songwriter from Belfast, who is giving his first solo New York concerts in three years at the Beacon Theater through tonight, has never presented himself as a glamorous rock rebel, though his music is suffused with a defiant, searching passion. At 43 years old, he resembles nothing so much as a glowering leprechaun who seems almost to resent the adulation of a cult that has remained solid long after he stopped having big hits in the early 1970's.

title: Piedmont Mining Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israeli Study Group Sees Eventual Arab State
description: After six months of investigating the options for settling the Israeli-Arab conflict, a leading Israeli strategic studies center concluded in a study made public today that an independent Palestinian state should eventually be established in the occupied territories.

title: Home Improvement
description: NOT for nothing has molding been nicknamed ''the carpenter's friend'' by many professionals. Besides its use as decorative trim, molding can be applied quickly and effectively to cover a multitude of construction sins like gaps, mismatched edges and ragged seams between building surfaces.

title: Bush's Anti-Drug Chief Gets Job of Weighing Rifle Policy
description: As if planning the national battle against illegal drugs were not enough work, President Bush has also given William J. Bennett the responsibility to figure out what to do about semiautomatic assault rifles.

title: Chairman Is Selected At Worlds of Wonder
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the toy company that had a quick rise before entering bankruptcy proceedings in 1987, is getting a new chairman and chief executive as it nears the end of its reorganization.

title: Leo Plofker, 67, Helped Design Skyscrapers
description: Leo Plofker, a structural engineer who was responsible for the skeletal design of several skyscrapers in New York and other cities, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Little Neck, Queens. He was 67 years old.

title: Koch to Fight Any Subpoena for Private Testimony
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he would be pleased to testify publicly before a New York State commission investigating his administration's Talent Bank but threatened to fight in court any subpoena for him to testify in private.

title: Reviews/Dance; Fleeting Patterns Evoke An Ephemeral World
description: Merce Cunningham has long been fascinated by the curious patterns dancers can make as they pass through space. Therefore it was only appropriate that he should call his newest work ''Field and Figures.'' A choreographically, scenically and musically dense production, it received its New York premiere by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Tuesday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Layered with sights and sounds, ''Field and Figures'' demanded close attention; nevertheless, it proved rewarding to contemplate.

title: Commonwealth Mortgage of America LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago second quarter share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title:
BASKETBALL;
Myers Is Another Find for Bianchi
description: LEAD: Every move has been just right.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about talks between the Polish Government and the Solidarity union described a loan to Poland imprecisely.

title: Cutting Arms in Europe: It's Down to the Details
description: Western and Soviet-bloc nations will take a new approach to an old problem when they formally open talks on Thursday on cutting conventional weapons and reducing the risk of war in Europe.

title: Letter: On Shoreham; Closing Means Lower Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Guards in U.S., F.B.I. Says
description: A senior official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that members of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps financed by Teheran have entered the United States posing as students.

title: Board to Study Disputed Tower Plan
description: Having been debated and reshaped and debated again, a proposal to build a luxury apartment tower over the West Side Y.M.C.A. will come to the New York City Board of Estimate today carrying a narrow rejection from the local community board.

title: Gemini Technology reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: T.W.A.'S CHAIRMAN WANTS TO DISCUSS ACQUIRING EASTERN
description: Carl C. Icahn, the corporate takeover specialist, said yesterday that he would begin talks with striking machinists about taking over Eastern Airlines if Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent company, the Texas Air Corporation, gave him permission.

title: A Nintendo Labyrinth Filled With Lawyers, Not Dragons
description: Nintendo, whose home video games have millions of young people battling dragons and navigating dungeons and mazes, is scrambling to escape from a growing legal labyrinth of its own.

title: Equity Silver Mines Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $3,700,000 provision toward meeting the mine's post-closure costs. c-Net loss and included a $18,566,000 writedown and a $7,319,000 gain on a silver sale. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Canada Southern Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Marten Transport Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
From Ireland's Past, Ghosts of Grand Manors
description: AN exhibit, ''Vanishing Irish Country Houses,'' with 60 photographs of manor homes now decayed or demolished, is at the New York School of Interior Design, 155 East 56th Street, through April 7.

title: Biotech Research Laboratoies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 8 Amazon Nations Denounce Pressure to Save Rain Forest
description: Seven Amazon countries have united behind Brazil to denounce foreign pressure to save rain forests, saying they would not take orders from abroad on their environmental policies.

title: 3 Are Fined at Chicago Merc
description: Three brokers at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, all members of a prominent broker group, have been fined and suspended for violating exchange rules, their lawyer said today.

title: Royal Riley, Prosecutor, 82
description: Royal Riley, a retired assistant district attorney in Queens and a former newspaper reporter, died of complications from emphysema on Friday at Booth Memorial Medical Center in Queens. He was 82 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Hamptons Bancshares Inc reports earnings for
description: The company said the decrease in net resulted from the deferral of $237,197 in income due to mandated accounting changes. It also cited expenses related to the relocation of its headquarters.

title: FUND-RAISING TRIP BY NORTH DETAILED
description: On a trip to Texas in 1985, Oliver L. North told the oil magnate Nelson Bunker Hunt that he was prepared to lie to Congress and risk jail to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, a fund-raiser for the contras testified today.

title: Illinois Keeps Big Ten Title Hopes Alive
description: Nick Anderson scored 29 points and Kendall Gill, playing for the first time in six weeks, ignited a decisive first-half scoring run to lead fourth-ranked Illinois to a 118-94 Big Ten Conference victory over No. 15 Iowa tonight.

title: Elbit Computers Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable year-ago figures are unavailable because the company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31, in compliance with Israeli law.

title: Constance Everett Ware, College Official, 57
description: Constance Everett Ware, vice president for development at Trinity College, died Tuesday at Hartford Hospital after a long illness. She was 57 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Seven Oaks International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss from $1,625,000 and $2,768,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included a loss from $375,000 and $1,329,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: An Ill-Starred House Is Sold
description: Representative Porter Goss, Republican of Florida, has bought a house here with an ill-starred recent history. He has paid $350,000 for the Capitol Hill town house of former Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, Republican of New York.

title: Stuart Hamblen, 80, Singer and Candidate
description: Stuart Hamblen, a gospel and country singer who wrote inspirational songs and once ran for President as a Prohibition Party candidate, died today at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. He was 80 years old.

title: Treminco Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company was not in commercial production a year earlier. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Paradise Fruit reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
16 States Failing to Pay Medicare Costs of the Poor
description: Sixteen states have not complied with a Federal law requiring them to pay the out-of-pocket costs of Medicare for up to two million of the elderly poor, according to a study presented today at a news conference.

title: Pick an Ancestor (A Handsome One) From Old Portraits
description: ''DON'T you think that one looks just like Andre Previn?'' asked Stephanie Hoppen, a London dealer in paintings and prints. ''That one could be Donald Sutherland's twin. And that's the one we call Farmer Giles, obviously a wealthy country man who's come up in the world and went to a good tailor.''

title: Senator Asks Study of Time Deal
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, chairman of the Senate antitrust subcommittee, is urging the Government to examine closely the proposed combination of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. for adverse effects on competition and choice of programming.

title: Douglas Paves Way for Syracuse
description: Although he is often the smallest man on the court, few college basketball players have enjoyed a bigger season than Sherman Douglas of Syracuse.

title: Hawthorne Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest fourth quarter and year results reflect change in method of accounting for loan origination fees and related costs.

title: China Buys More Wheat
description: Private exporters have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices under the Export Enhancement Program, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The sale increased to more than 7.8 million tons the amount of wheat sold to China for 1988-89 delivery under the program.

title: Edward Powers, 75, Agent in Brinks Case
description: Edward Powers, the F.B.I. agent who helped solve the $2.2 million Brinks armored car robbery in 1950, died Tuesday. Mr. Powers, who was later chosen for his law-enforcement background to manage the first modern American lottery, was 75 years old.

title: Aid Cleared For Airbus
description: The European Community today approved a West German subsidy package for the European Airbus that could increase the United States' frustration over government aid for the aircraft project.

title: Finland's Insider Bar
description: The Finnish Parliament approved legislation Tuesday to outlaw insider trading. The Security Markets Act would be the first law regulating Finland's stock exchange, and it would provide for a maximum penalty of two years in prison for using privileged information to profit in market transactions. The act must now receive presidential approval. Under current practice, the stock exchange polices itself.

title: BankAmerica to Take Reserve for Defaults
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would take an additional reserve against its first-quarter earnings to cover losses related to student loan defaults that were developing into a messy legal affair involving several major banks.

title: Former Top Bureaucrat Held in Japan Scandal
description: Japan's bribery and influence-peddling scandal spread to the country's usually highly respected bureaucracy today as prosecutors arrested a former high-ranking official of the Labor Ministry and charged him with accepting bribes.

title: Digimetrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Handiwork That Also Is Handy
description: WHEN function is a factor in a craft artist's work - when the piece must hold soup in addition to being expressive - there are limitations on how far the material and the imagination can be worked. Nonetheless, a broad latitude for self-expression remains, as demonstrated in several sprightly ceramics shows - two modern ones and a historical exhibition.

title: Mixing Sports Art and Classicism
description: NEXT year the 12-year-old New England Sports Museum in Boston will have an elegant new home - the Custom House, built in 1837, at the foot of State Street.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Theater; A Subversive Farce From Joe Orton
description: There are no butlers in ''What the Butler Saw,'' the play the English writer Joe Orton completed only weeks before he was murdered in 1967. Orton's title, with its prurient whiff of Edwardian peep shows, is generic: it announces a low farce rife with fallen trousers, sexual indiscretions, mistaken identities, lewd puns. And in John Tillinger's riotous production at the Manhattan Theater Club - New York's first exposure to Orton's unexpurgated text - ''What the Butler Saw'' doesn't disappoint. Here at last are the two hours of nonstop laughter that theatergoers have been pursuing all season.

title: Ex-Chief of Child Center Rebuts Sex Charge
description: The former director of the Western New York Children's Psychiatric Center assailed a state watchdog agency's finding that she and her staff had done nothing to stop sexual activity among patients.

title: GTE Awarded Army Contract
description: The GTE Corporation, which operates the largest United States independent phone network, has been awarded a $945.8 million contract for Army communications equipment, the Defense Department said. The contract is for the Army's new Mobile Subscriber Equipment program, a spy-proof battlefield telephone and teleprinter system being designed and built by GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., and Thomson-CSF of France.

title: Jacob Kossman, 79; Defended Racketeers
description: Jacob Kossman, a criminal lawyer whose clients included prominent racketeers, died Sunday at Fox Chase Cancer Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: HEALTH: Psychology; Experts Find Extramarital Affairs Have a Profound Impact on Children
description: Children suffer when their parents engage in extramarital affairs, even when the parents succeed in keeping the affairs secret, therapists and sociologists are finding.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE teacher's comment on my second-grade report card mentioned that I had a great deal of difficulty accepting criticism. ''No, I don't! She's wrong!'' I snapped at my mother when she asked me about it.

title: Rabbit Software reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1988 figures included the results of CTI Data Corp. from its acquisition on May 17. The company announced last month a preliminary 1988 loss of about $4.7 million. It said the actual loss for 1988 was greater than forecast due primarily to an additional reserve taken against certain receivables. The company also said that the 1988 loss reflected the company's continued investment in product development, sales, marketing and other corporate infrastructure.

description: b-Net loss Prior year included $1,289,000 one- time gain reflecting a payment from Great American Bank of San Diego in compensation for relinguishing the use of the Great American Name, and additional expenses associated with the final disposition of a branch office.

title: Judson Philips, 85, Author, Dies
description: Judson Philips, who wrote more than 100 mystery and detective novels under the pseudonym Hugh Pentecost as well as his own name, died of complications resulting from emphysema Tuesday in the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Canaan, Conn.

title: Isco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Q&A
description: Q. My bathroom is next to the bathroom in the next apartment, and we hear noise through the wall. A soundproofing company said I would be wasting money on soundproofing and suggested putting a radio in the bathroom. Have you any other suggestion? A.I'm afraid the soundproofing contractor was right. Short of major alterations (tearing out the wall and rebuilding it for greater acoustical insulation) there is little you can do. Q.We burn wood in our brick fireplace and use a little coal as a fire base. The wood, mostly from gum trees, is seasoned outdoors for a year. This year in damp weather we have gotten an unpleasant aroma from the fireplace, like half-burned wood. I always let the fire burn out completely and then push the ashes and fire remains into the ash pit under the fireplace. Even though I clean the pit, the smell comes out on rainy days. What can I do? A.Have a professional chimney cleaner thoroughly clean the chimney, firebox and ash pit. An accumulation of soot and ashes inside the fireplace or the chimney is the most likely cause of the odor. A good cleaning should take care of this. Burning coal with the wood, incidentally, may contribute to the problem. Q.The ceiling in my dry basement room has blistered badly, in my opinion because a poor-quality primer was used when the house was built 30 years ago. I am chipping away the blistered paint and will use dry wall compound to fill in the chipped areas for a smooth surface. Before painting I want to apply a primer to hold the resurfaced areas in place and keep the unblemished paint from blistering. Paint stores have recommended water-based primers, oil-based primers and varnish. Which is best? A.You expect a lot from a coat of primer. No paint primer will hold resurfaced areas in place, nor keep paint from blistering. Primers are for sealing a surface and insuring a good bond for succeeding coats of paint; they are not adhesives or binders that will hold plaster or patching compounds in place. Oil-base or water-base primers will work, but I don't advise varnish or shellac. Incidentally, dry wall compound is fine for patching dry wall, but not if the ceiling is plaster; if it is, use spackling compound or patching plaster for smoothing in the low spots. Q.The contractor refinishing our parquet hardwood floors with two coats of polyurethane said there was no need for a coat of wax to prevent scratches. Previously our floors lasted for over 20 years, but they had a coat of wax over the polyurethane. What do you advise? A.Many manufacturers of polyurethane finishes say waxing is not needed, because a good polyurethane forms such a hard finish. But I think waxing helps prevent scratches, especially where people walk in from outdoors with dirt on their shoes. A light coat of wax, thoroughly buffed, helps prevent scratches and makes the floor easier to clean.

title: Senate Panel Approves Minimum Wage Increase
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved legislation today to raise the minimum wage $1.30 an hour to $4.65 after rejecting a Bush Administration plan for a smaller increase coupled with a lower wage for newly hired workers.

title: Business-Card Collector
description: THE Personal Punch, a device that cuts two holes into a standard business card so that it can slip into a Rolodex, is Robert Merrick's answer to a common problem.

title: Venturi a la Carte: A Signature Series In Florida
description: On a wintry afternoon in Philadelphia recently, the architect Robert Venturi was sitting with a 39-year-old builder, Warren Pearl, discussing tiles and backsplashes. Mr. Venturi, one of the country's most influential architects, is the designer of the new extension of the National Gallery in London and the man generally credited with being the spiritual father of the postmodern movement. Mr. Pearl is a New Yorker with a tendency to quote the discount clothier Sy Syms (''an educated consumer is our best customer'') and a gift for catchy phrases (''Hang your Picasso in a Pearl'').

title: Articles of Faith: Lawn Shrines Embody Devotion
description: IN 1973, Rose Scarcella of the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, learned that her son had Hodgkin's disease. His doctors predicted that he would live only five more years.

title: I.M.F. Position On Venezuela
description: The International Monetary Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, asserts that economic stabilization measures in Venezuela ''are proving even more painful'' because they were ''too long postponed.''

title: I.R.A. Admits Error in Slaying 2 Protestants
description: The Irish Republican Army, which has been warned by its political wing to avoid killing innocent civilians, said today that it had mistakenly slain two Protestants in an attack in Northern Ireland that was intended to kill militant loyalists.

title: Qantel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included about $4 million in fixed royalties that expired April 30. Latest nine-month results included a reversal of $957,000 for a previously established reserve for estimated losses on the disposition of certain operations. Year ago non-month results included a reversal of $3,335,000 for a previously established reserve.

title: Toyota Wins Ruling On Use of Lexus Name
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan said today that Lexus, Toyota's new luxury-car division, did not infringe upon the trademark Lexis, a computerized legal library operated by the Mead Corporation's Mead Data Central subsidiary.

title: Nolwen de Janze Clark, Fashion Designer, 65
description: Lady Clark, the widow of the art historian Kenneth Clark, died at her home in Parfondeval, France, on Tuesday, after heart surgery. She was 65 years old.

title: Agency Head Rebuts Reports
description: Alan C. Nelson, the immigration commissioner, has circulated a memorandum to his staff asserting that published reports that he was being replaced were ''based on rumor,'' his aides said today.

title: Western Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
National Security Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $625,000 tax credit.

title: Total Energold reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included special charges totalling $32.3 million and $10.6 million for the latest and prior years, respectively. The company said the 1988 charge is mainly from a $34 millionw ritedown of mineral properties, reflecting impairment of economic profitability at its two producing gold mines. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Correction
description: An apparition in a gray fedora hat and a large cigar stopped by to growl that the St. Valentine's Day Massacre in Chicago, ascribed here last week to Dutch Schultz, was the work of Al Capone.

title: Review/Concert; The Sounds of Movies
description: As a benefit for itself, Robert Redford's Sundance Institute presented a lavishly produced concert Monday at Avery Fisher Hall entitled ''A Night of Great Movie Music.'' The concert called attention to the institute's laudable work in reassembling and recording significant scores from film history and also offered some intermittently appealing music in mostly adept performances by the American Symphony. But there were some oddities and curious omissions and overweening pretensions, too.

title: Landmark Housing Deserves Landmark Status
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home in College: Commuters Seek To Balance 2 Lives
description: LEAD: FOR Eric Young and his twin sister, Julie, commuting to college and living at home is a lot more complicated than it looks on television sitcoms.

title: Cascades Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Included a special gain of $12,626,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Fragile Recovery Found In Sub-Saharan Africa
description: Sub-Saharan Africa, long considered the world's most depressed region because of droughts, famines, civil strife and failures in leadership, has begun a fragile but sustainable economic recovery, the World Bank said today.

title: Books of The Times; Why Updike Writes and What He Writes About
description: Self-Consciousness By John Updike 257 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: I.B.M. Confirms Shipping Delays
description: The International Business Machines Corporation acknowledged that an analyst was correct in reporting that the company had experienced delays in shipping its 3090-S mainframe because of a problem in manufacturing some key logic chips. A spokesman for I.B.M. said that the problem was behind the company now and that it would not have an impact on the computer maker's earnings for the year.

title: Metro Datelines;
description: A Federal court jury in Manhattan has awarded $800,000 to a man who said he was brutalized by a New York City police officer in 1983.

title: Review/Opera; Cast Changes in 'Salome'
description: The two newcomers to the Metropolitan Opera's ''Salome'' - Katarina Ikonomu, who made her house debut in the title role Saturday night, and Neil Rosenshein, who has been singing Narraboth since the opening, which he missed because of illness - sang their parts in the ranting style that has become all too standard at the house when voices of the desired easy projection cannot be found.

title: 2 Manhattan Hospitals Shut Pharmacies Used by Needy
description: Citing what they call serious financial difficulties, two large private hospitals in upper Manhattan have closed outpatient pharmacies that subsidized the cost of medicine for thousands of poor people.

title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack
description: A new breed of street-corner confidence men has joined the purveyors of counterfeit Gucci bags, Rolex watches and Chanel No. 5, say law-enforcement officials in New York City: fake-crack peddlers.

title: I.B.M. Gives Scholarship Fund $2 Million
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has given the Boston Latin School a $2 million scholarship fund, one of the largest amounts ever given to a single public school.

title: F.T.C. Said to Have Sought Suit Against Rales Brothers
description: The Federal Trade Commission recently asked the Justice Department to file a suit that would force the Rales brothers, Washington-based investors, to disgorge the trading profits they accumulated in their hostile bid for Interco Inc., a St. Louis furniture and apparel company, an industry newsletter said.

title: Jaffna Journal; If the War Has Ended, Why Are So Many Dying?
description: The arid Jaffna Peninsula, the center of Sri Lankan Tamil culture and once the seat of independent Tamil kings, is living under foreign military occupation, breeding new tensions to replace those that brought the soldiers here.

title: United Insurance Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a capital loss of $322,000 and $771,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a capital loss of $216,000 for the quarter, and a capital gain of $208,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: Baker, Derwinski - Worse Than Tower
description: LEAD: Tough cases make bad law. That venerable law school adage has repeatedly come to mind during the battle over John G. Tower's confirmation as Secretary of Defense.

title: Satellites Offer Chance to Monitor Volcanoes
description: A new study shows that two space satellites threatened with shutdown for budgetary reasons can be used to monitor volcanoes and possibly to predict when they will erupt.

title: Byron Francis West, Banker, 61
description: Byron Francis West, a banker and securities broker, died of leukemia on March 2 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Wycombe, Pa.

title: Review/Music; Remembering Villa-Lobos
description: The Villa-Lobos Music Society periodically reminds us of music that too often slips from our attention. The latest nudge came Sunday at Weill Recital Hall when the soprano Meg Bussert and the pianist Alfred Heller gave us an afternoon's worth of the Brazilian composer's music.

title: Colonial Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2,014,000 credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CBI Industries, Oak Brook, Ill., a diversified industrial manufacturer, said William A. Pogue had announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive.

title: Western Canada Pact
description: The British Columbia provincial government said Tuesday that Canada's four Western provinces had reached an agreement to curb internal trade barriers. The Regional Development Minister, Elwood Veitch, said the pact, effective April 1, would insure that local contractors bidding on government contracts did not receive preferential treatment over those from outside the province. Mr. Veitch said the agreement would affect contracts worth about $10 billion (Canadian).

title: Howard University President Threatens to Arrest Student Protesters
description: The president of Howard University threatened to arrest hundreds of students today as they continued a sit-in protest even after winning their main demand: the resignation of the chairman of the Republican National Committee, Lee Atwater, as a trustee of the school.

title: Rymer Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $315,000 and a gain of $1,064,000 from early retirement of debt. c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $611,000. In the latest fourth quarter, net was exceeded by preferred stock requirements.

title: Fur Venture in Moscow
description: The Jindo Corporation, South Korea's largest fur coat producer, said today that it would enter a partnership with a Soviet company to open stores in the Soviet Union. It would be the first business venture between the Soviet Union and South Korea. Jindo officials said their company, which produces 400,000 fur garments a year, signed a contract on Tuesday in Moscow with Interlink of the Soviet Union to set up the venture with an initial investment of $800,000.

title: Papandreou, Linked to Scandal, Charges Plot
description: A Greek political and financial scandal has widened with allegations that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou received millions of dollars in covert political payoffs. The Prime Minister fought back today by accusing opponents in the West of conspiring to overthrow him to stifle Greece's independent foreign policy.

title: Deal Reported Between Teamster Official and U.S.
description: As the Government's huge case against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters moved toward a trial scheduled to begin Monday, lawyers said yesterday that an agreement had been reached on settling the civil lawsuit's claims against an important union official.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Are Higher
description: Treasury note and bond prices moved higher yesterday after President Bush's chief economist suggested that the Administration has not ruled out tax increases as a way of cutting the budget deficit.

title: Carnesecca Tries to Save Redmen
description: Lou Carnesecca has always downplayed a coach's role in determining the success of a team. The 64-year-old St. John's coach reiterated his point in a recent autobiography when he recalled a 55-loss season while he was coaching the New York Nets and the team was forced to play without Rick Barry, the All-Star forward.

title: Debate on High-Definition TV Policy
description: The issue of Federal sponsorship of foreign research into the emerging field of high-definition television took center stage at Congressional hearings today.

title: Ronson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year results included income of $105,000, or 7 cents a share, realted to the recognition of previously deferred income; the year results also included income of $92,000, or 6 cents a share, resulting from an abatement of interest and penalties for prior years' taxes. Year-ago fourth quarter and year results included an expense of $110,000, or 7 cents a share, related to the early cancellation of a long-term lease agreement; the year also included income of $100,000, or 7 cents, related to a 1986 grant by the company of a non-exclusive licensing agreement for neodymium technology.

title: DOLE EXPECTS LOSS
description: The battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense all but ended today as Senate Democrats apparently secured a majority of votes against confirmation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bozell's Korean Deal
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt announced yesterday that it had signed an exclusive affiliation agreement with Korea First Advertising, the largest ad agency in South Korea, with the equivalent of $200 million in billings last year. Under the agreement, K.F.A., a subsidiary of the Samsung Group of Companies, will use Bozell's international network for advertising outside South Korea. Bozell will also begin exploring acquiring an equity stake in the Korean agency. One of the first results of the agreement was also announced yesterday: Bozell will become the worldwide agency for Samsung's corporate account.

title: Lawyer Is Suspended For Keeping Money
description: The State Supreme Court has suspended a lawyer for a year for pocketing Girl Scout cookie proceeds belonging to her daughter's troop.

title: Tel Electronics Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Rangers' Fortunes Are Taking A Dip
description: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, had sat in his office Tuesday afternoon, his face drawn, his mood darkly morose. Injury reports and recent results had left him depressed, convinced that even trades couldn't cure his team's ills.

title: Day of Decision: Mixing Politics And Conscience
description: At 2:52 P.M. today, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas left his office, where the receptionists faced a switchboard humming with the voice of the people, all of them with an opinion on John G. Tower's fitness to be Secretary of Defense.

title: Personal Health
description: ''I do not choose to run.'' - Calvin Coolidge

title: Co-Winners for Religion Award
description: The $400,000 Templeton Prize, the major award in the field of religion that was embroiled in controversy last year, was awarded jointly yesterday to a Scottish clergyman and a German physicist.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: FIFTEEN years after graduation, my high school class held a reunion. We dined on our choice of roast beef au jus or baked stuffed shrimp and the only one of us to have gotten a divorce stared at the rest with defiant eyes. Clearly, she thought herself a Scarlet Woman. Or, rather, thought we thought her one. Eleven years after graduation, my college class held a reunion. We all slept in the new dorms - with cinder-block walls instead of our pockmarked plaster - and the only one of us not to have married paraded her girlfriend and stared at the rest with defiant eyes. I never went to a high school or college reunion again: there was always too much pain in the room.

title: Silcorp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1,655,000. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said lower earnings wee mainly due to losses by its U.S. division and market competition in Canada.

title: Hospital Aide Charged in Rape of Patient
description: A cleaning aide at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan was arrested late yesterday and charged with raping and sexually assaulting a psychiatric patient at the hospital in January, the police said.

title: Pretoria's Rulers Looking Past Botha
description: South Africa's ruling National Party is grappling with one of its most awkward conundrums in four decades of power: how to rid itself gracefully of the leader it no longer wants.

title: Regan, Under Fire, Comptroller Tends to Job, Not Image
description: In his 10 years as New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan has watched the fortunes of many elected officials rise and fall and, for the fortunate ones, rise again. The experience, he says, has helped him maintain perspective as his own political prospects recently began to dim.

title: Fendi's Revolution: Feather-Light Reversible Furs
description: The fashion revolution that is both desired and feared each season took place more than halfway through the fall and winter showings here. It happened in furs, not clothes.

title: Britain, Citing Death Threats, Expels 20 Iranians
description: Citing Iranian death threats in the Salman Rushdie affair, the British Government said today that it would expel 20 to 30 Iranians living here and warned British citizens to stay out of Lebanon.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Missed Connection
description: The annual White House Radio and Television Correspondent's dinner usually lures the President, the bulk of the Administration as well as all those television stars who appear on the White House lawn each morning and evening. This year, however, the prize guest won't come to dinner. President Bush is planning to spend the night of the event, March 16, in Colorado Springs addressing the National Business Hall of Fame dinner.

title: Royalton Hotel Is Called Biased Against Hasidim
description: The American Jewish Congress has contended that the Royalton Hotel on West 44th Street discriminated against Hasidim and other Orthodox Jews because the way they dressed did not fit the hotel's trendy image.

title: Shea & Gould Paring Office
description: The law firm of Shea & Gould said yesterday that it would scale down its office in Los Angeles to ''a small nucleus.'' A third of the lawyers there announced earlier this week that they were defecting to the new firm of Myerson & Kuhn.

title: Associated Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1987 included gains from non-recurring sales of interest in certain cellular partnerships and from the sale of an investment. Year-ago share earnings figure are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split, effected in the form of a dividend, declared Jan. 3.

title: Amgen Beats Japanese on Protein Patent
description: Amgen Inc., a small biotechnology company, said today that it had been awarded the first United States patent covering the biological materials and the genetic engineering process used to produce a naturally occurring protein in the human body that stimulates production of white blood cells.

title: Consumers Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net realized gains on investments of $323,000 for the quarter and $466,000 for the year, and tax credits of $24,000 and $107,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After net realized loss of $23,000 for the quarter and net realized gains of $381,000 for the year, both on investments, and an extraordinary charge of $28,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $264,000 for the year.

title: Property Trust of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $33,000 on the sale of investments.

title: Woman in Coma Faces Move
description: A comatose Long Island woman, who received an abortion last month after a bitter legal battle that reached the nation's highest court, will be moved to a rehabilitation center in New Jersey, the woman's family said. The woman, Nancy Klein, who is North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, is to be transferred Thursday to the Johnson Rehabilitation Center in Edison. She suffered severe brain damage in a car accident on Dec. 13. Last month, Mrs. Klein's husband went to court to seek an order to authorize an abortion for his wife who was 17 weeks pregnant. The request led to a court battle that ended in the United States Supreme Court.

title: 3 White Youths Held in Attack On Black Man
description: An 18-year-old black youth walking home from work was taunted with racial epithets, then severely beaten by three young whites near 34th Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Do All Cabinet Officers Have to Be Celibate, Teetotaling Joggers?; Alcohol and Alcoholism
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggle Naught Availeth
description: A viable corporation must be more than a collection of assets. When employees believe management is interested only in the profit from dismemberment, loyalty dies and the company dies with it.

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD Kingdom Ties Foster's Mark: Roger Kingdom of the United States tied Greg Foster's world indoor record of 7.36 seconds for the 60-meter hurdles yesterday at a meet in Piraeus, Greece. Foster set the record in Los Angeles on Jan. 16, 1987. Kingdom took the lead at the start and was never threatened. Arthur Blake finished second in 7.63.(AP) SKIING Schneider Ties Record: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland tied the World Cup record of 13 victories in one season by winning a giant slalom yesterday in Shiga Kogen, Japan. Schneider could break the record for victories in a single season in the year's final race, a slalom on Saturday. Schneider, who won the women's overall title last week, is unbeaten in six World Cup slalom races this season. Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, who is retiring at the end of this season with 86 World Cup victories, set the single-season record of 13 triumphs in 1979.(AP) TENNIS Mandlikova Upsets Evert: Chris Evert, playing just her third match of the year and losing for the second time, was upset yesterday by Hana Mandlikova, 3-6, 7-6, 6-0, in the $250,000 Virginia Slims tournament at Indian Wells, Calif.
