The top-seeded Evert dominated the first set, lost after having match point in the second set, then wilted in the 104-degree temperature. The unseeded Mandlikova, a native of Czechoslovakia who lives in Australia, tied the match by taking the second-set tiebreaker, 7-2. In another upset, Lori McNeil, seeded fifth, was eliminated by unseeded Terry Phelps, 6-1, 6-2. (AP) Edberg and Gilbert Advance: Second-seeded Stefan Edberg and Brad Gilbert, seeded sixth, won their second-round matches yesterday in the Eagle Classic in Scottsdale, Ariz. Fourth-seeded Thomas Muster of Austria was eliminated by unseeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel. Mansdorf, who is ranked 23d in the world, won by 7-5, 6-2. Edberg needed only 77 minutes to beat Horst Skoff of Austria, 7-5, 6-3.(AP) N.B.A. Celtics 104, Bulls 95: With Michael Jordan missing because of an injury, Boston opened a 21-point lead in the first quarter last night to beat Chicago. Jordan, who had played 235 consecutive games, did not make the trip after suffering a groin injury in Chicago's 90-88 loss to Philadelphia Tuesday night.(AP) Pistons 112, SuperSonics 96: Isiah Thomas scored 27 points and sparked a decisive 9-0 fourth-quarter burst last night as Detroit posted its fifth straight triumph. Derrick McKey scored 21 points and Dale Ellis had 18 for the visiting SuperSonics.(AP) Mavericks 99, Trail Blazers 92: Adrian Dantley scored 23 points, and Rolando Blackman had 22 to lead Dallas at home. Portland scored 7 consecutive points to close to 85-84 with 3:20 to play. The Blazers started the run on Terry Porter's technical free throw with 4:09 remaining. Dantley drew the technical when he grabbed the leg of the Blazers' Jerome Kersey after Dantley had fallen to the court. He came up swinging and both players scuffled briefly. But the Mavericks then went on a 6-0 run to regain control.(AP) Nuggets 112, Hornets 99: Alex English scored 31 points as the visiting Nuggets handed Charlotte its fifth straight loss, the expansion Hornets' longest losing streak of the season. Kelly Tripucka, whose first basket of the night gave him his 10,000th career point, scored 21 points to lead Charlotte. (AP) Lakers 127, Heat 87: Byron Scott scored all of his 16 points in the first quarter, including four baskets during a stretch when Los Angeles made 12 straight shots. Tony Campbell led the visiting Lakers with 19 points to tie his season high. Miami's starters scored only 39 points.(AP) Bullets 119, Hawks 111: Bernard King scored 23 of his 31 points in the second half and Jeff Malone added 30 as Washington won its seventh-straight game at home. Atlanta played the second half without Doc Rivers, who suffered a slight concussion in the second period. (AP) COLLEGE HOCKEY Iona 5, Trinity 3: Iona won the South division championship of the Eastern College Athletic Conference for the first time last night. Three goals by Ron Vaill were decisive for Iona, two coming after Trinity had tied the score at 3-3 in the third period at the Playland Rink at Rye, N.Y. Iona will play Southeastern Massachusetts, which beat Curry last night for the North division title, on Saturday at New Bedford, Mass. N.H.L. Canadiens 3, Capitals 2: Mats Naslund's goal midway through the third period last night enabled Montreal to win its third consecutive game. The Canadiens moved past Calgary into first place in the overall league standings. The loss kept the visiting Capitals 2 points behind the Rangers in the Patrick Division. (AP) Whalers 7, Oilers 3: Kevin Dineen scored three goals, and Ron Francis had a goal and three assists for Hartford at home. Dineen, who scored twice in a 2:39 span in the second period, completed his third career hat trick by scoring into an empty net with 10 seconds to play. Hartford's fifth victory in six games kept the Whalers 2 points behind third-place Buffalo in the Adams Division. Referee Dan Marouelli briefly suspended play at 15:46 of the first period when an electric problem caused the overhead lights to dim. (AP)

title: Deutsche Bank Sells EAB Stake
description: The Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest bank, is selling its stake in EAB, formerly known as the European American Bank, to the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank, the Dutch banking company said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Valuing Assets Of Eastern Air
description: WITH Eastern Airlines on strike and reported to be on the verge of filing for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws, some of its securities moved up a bit yesterday amid hopes that a buyer for the airline's assets might be found.

title: France Seeks More Power For Its S.E.C.
description: The French Government backed a legislative package today that would give greater enforcement powers to France's principal stock market watchdog, the Commission des Operations de Bourse, and would give companies new anti-takeover tools.

title: New York Fed Describes Its Efforts to Control Dollar
description: In a clear confirmation of the strength of the effort by the United States to control the course of the dollar, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that it had bought $2.4 billion at the end of last year to support a decline in the currency. Then, almost immediately, the bank turned around in January and sold almost $1.88 billion more to try to slow a rally.

title: See Spot. Spot's a Table. Spot Is $450.
description: DAN HALE designs furniture for the lighthearted: an end table in the shape of a Dalmatian, candlesticks inspired by the television show ''The Jetsons.''

title: Richard O'Connor, 70, Former Judge in Jersey
description: Richard R. O'Connor, a lawyer and former New Jersey judge, died Monday in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Cox in Altercation
description: Danny Cox of the Cardinals, upon arriving in St. Louis yesterday from Florida to have his pitching elbow examined, knocked over a television cameraman at Lambert Airport and then walked away, a videotape of the incident showed.

title: Jim Abbott: Baseball's Real Phenom
description: He's nonroster left-handed pitcher whose wooden locker is in the rear of the California Angels' clubhouse, back where the rookies dress. But the shelf of Jim Abbott's locker was stuffed with more than 100 letters. ''One week's fan mail?'' somebody asked. ''That's just today's,'' Jim Abbott said.

title: Paul J. Etzel, Executive, 90
description: Paul J. Etzel, a former president of Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc., a realty company in Manhattan, died of complications from emphysema Monday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 90 years old.

title: Money Fund Yields Rise
description: Yields for money market mutual funds were up modestly for the week ended yesterday.

title: Correction on Guns
description: A Topic yesterday referred to the AR-15 rifle as fully automatic. It is semiautomatic, requiring a trigger pull for each shot.

title: S. Carolina Challenges U.S. on Waste
description: South Carolina, long a disposal site for hazardous waste from elsewhere, is striking back by banning waste from those states that do not allow disposal or treatment within their own borders.

title: Circo Craft Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Prospects Are Slim For Mets' Prospects
description: Jeff Innis, a sidearm pitcher who studied psychology at the University of Illinois, allowed no runs in spring training last year and still didn't make the Mets. This spring, he is spending his free time reading murder mysteries, but gets most of his suspense wondering what he'll have to do to make the best pitching staff in baseball.

title: Review/Dance; A Massine Revival by the Paris Opera Troupe
description: A powerful revival of a ballet that was presumably relegated to the history books has emerged as an astounding eye-opener here.

title: Ukraine Intellectuals Lead Challenge to Communists
description: Ukrainians by the millions turned on their television sets the other night to witness a wondrous sight, a popular Ukrainian literary critic in fiery debate with a senior ideologist from the republic's Communist Party.

title: Visions of the Pros Come Early
description: In the early 1960's, a New York City teen-ager named Lew Alcindor was the most coveted high school basketball player in the country, a spindly 7-footer expected to dominate the college and, eventually, the pro game. At the time, Joe Lapchick, the revered old coach of the Knicks and St. John's, was among those who predicted Alcindor's success.

title: Applicants for the Grants
description: The following is a list of the applicants who have applied for Defense Department grants to develop high-definition television systems, as provided today by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Pentagon: Adams-Russell Electronics Company's Communications Programs division Advanced Display Technologies Inc. Alphasil Inc., Amerasia Technology Inc. American Semiconductor Equipment Technologies A.T.&T. Technologies Inc. Ampro Corporation CAE-Link Corporation's Link Flight Simulation division Cardinal Technologies Inc. Chromachron Technologies Corporation John C. Claxton Collimated Displays Inc. Commtech International David Sarnoff Research Center Inc. Del Rey Group Digipro Inc. Display Technologies Ear Three Systems Manufacturing Electronic Image Systems Inc. Electronic Systems Products FAI Fiberview Corporation General Electric Company Harris Corporation's Semiconductor Sector High Resolution Sciences Inc. Honeywell Inc. Hound Magnetics Hughes Aircraft Co. Industrial Products division Hughes Aircraft Co. Ground Systems Group Hughes Aircraft Co. Research Labs ITT Semiconductors International Business Machines Corporation Innovative Solutions and Support Interstate Electronics Corporation Jupiter Technologies KLA Instruments Corporation MRS Technology Inc. Magnascreen Corporation Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Research Laboratory of Electronics Micrion Corporation Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company's Ceramic Tech Center Newco North American Philips Corporation's Philips Laboratories Optics 1 Inc. Ore Inc. Osborne Associates Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc. PCO Inc. Peak Systems Inc. Pentastar Electronics Inc. Photonics Technology Inc. Planar Systems Inc. Projectavision Inc. Qualcomm Inc. Raychem Corporation SAIC-CSM division Selsys Corporation Solarex Corporation Sony Corporation of America Spire Corporation Staplevision Inc. Symbolics Inc. Tandy Corporation Tektronix Inc. Texas Instruments Inc. Transera Corporation Trident International Inc. Ultratech Stepper Westinghouse Corporation Zenith Electronics Corporation

title: Autolatina Halts Brazil Operations
description: Autolatina, Latin America's biggest auto maker, said it was temporarily suspending Brazilian production of trucks and of two luxury cars because of a shortage of components. The company, which brings together Ford Motor and Volkswagen in Brazil and Argentina, said 4,000 workers at its two truck plants in Sao Paulo would be given holidays for two weeks starting next Monday.

title: Our Federal Prison System Can't Bear Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Says She Saw Men Fire at Officer
description: A young woman testified yesterday that she was on the street working as a prostitute when three men accused of murdering a police officer in Queens ''pulled out guns'' and one or more of them shot him.

title: SOVIETS TO ACCEPT WORLD COURT ROLE IN HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Underscoring its new support for international organizations, the Soviet Union said today that it would accept the binding arbitration of the International Court of Justice in disputes over five important human rights agreements.

title: Tyson Fighter of Year
description: Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, was named the fighter of the year for 1988 yesterday by the Boxing Writers Association of America.

title: Jeep Venture Company Set
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the French auto maker Renault S.A. plan to set up a separate company to operate their joint venture that will produce the JJ small Jeep in North America and Europe, Chrysler officials said today The venture will be similar to Diamond-Star Motors, Chrysler's venture in Bloomington, Ill., with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. Chrysler builds the new Laser and Mitsubishi the Eclipse at the plant, which opened last year.

title: New Device Is Saving the Limbs Of Some Young Victims of Cancer
description: After nearly a decade of research, doctors and engineers have developed a device that may spare thousands of children with bone cancer the additional trauma of amputation.

title: Recoton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $653,000. c-Net loss

title: Transalta Utilities Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $50 million reduction in the carrying cost of the investment in Canada Northwest Energy Ltd. Preferred share dividends were $61.7 million versus $80.9 million. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in February 1988. Figures are in Canadian funds. Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Doctorow's People: Old Souls, New Bodies
description: E. L. Doctorow, whose new novel ''Billy Bathgate'' has won glowing reviews and has already reached the No. 4 position on The New York Times best-seller list, was reflecting the other afternoon about the colorful characters who populate his work.

title: Volt Information Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $5,355,000 from an accounting change.

title: Do All Cabinet Officers Have to Be Celibate, Teetotaling Joggers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernstein's Teacher, 89
description: Helen Grace Coates, who was Leonard Bernstein's piano teacher and then, for 46 years, his personal secretary, died Feb. 27 at her home in New York City. She was 89 years old.

title: Bond to Sell Stake in Lonrho
description: The Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond said today that he was seeking to sell the Bond Corporation's 19.8 percent stake in the British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. because the two sides had been unable to hold ''a meaningful dialogue.''

title: Singing in the Capitol
description: To the Editor:

title: Kasler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Paxar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the year. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $47,000 and $85,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Devils Defeat Blackhawks
description: Aaron Broten scored the tie-breaking goal early in the third period and added an insurance goal to complete a five-point game as the Devils overcame a two-goal deficit to beat the Chicago Blackhawks, 7-5, tonight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The U.S.S.R. will accept arbitration by the International Court of Justice in disputes over five important human rights agreements, underscoring its new support for international organizations. Page A1

title: Dollar Wise, Penny Foolish
description: There's something to value in a penny - a virtuous symbol of thrift, a poignant reminder of the way we were. But what's it worth? Not much.

title: Trust Company of West Names a New President
description: Trust Company of the West, a large Los Angeles-based money management company, said yesterday that it had named Thomas E. Larkin Jr. president and chief operating officer in a change intended to strengthen the operations and administrative side of the company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kobs & Daft Is Chosen To Promote New Coins
description: Word leaked out yesterday that the United States Mint is soon to announce the selection of Kobs & Draft Advertising to handle the introduction of commemorative coins honoring the bicentennial of Congress. Kobs & Daft is the direct-marketing agency of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. In the final round of competition for the $6.5 million account, K.&D. was said to have bested Grey Direct and Wunderman Worldwide.

title: SunResorts Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company also reported results for the full year ended Aug. 31, 1988. For the year, net income was $1,722,000, or 23 cents a share, compared with $3,381,000, or 44 cents a share. Revenue was $30,893,000, compared with $29,067,000 in fiscal 1987. Fiscal 1987 included a tax credit of $831,000.

title: Dow Tops 2,300, but Selling Trims Gain
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average topped 2,300 before wide program selling apparently cut the gain. The session ended with a 4.83-point increase to close at 2,295.54.

title: How to Have a Tree Planted in the City
description: IF there is a bare square of earth cut out of the sidewalk near your building begging for a tree, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation has some suggestions.

title: 2 Pillsbury Chains To Be Sold
description: Fulfilling a promise, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that it would sell Pillsbury's Steak & Ale and Bennigan's restaurant chains for $431 million.

title: In New York, A Fence Has Its Obstacles
description: Albert and Elizabeth Watson want to build a fence. They have been trying for two and a half years, with two architects, in six hearings, under 10 government bodies, and they are ready to spend more than $20,000 to do it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Rush Job On Whittle's School Fight
description: AS Christopher Whittle battles the educational establishment for the opportunity to broadcast commercials into the nation's high schools, he has behind him an aggressive advertising duo: Roy Grace and Diane Rothschild.

title: Advance Circuits reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Hialeah Opens Meeting
description: Leave It Be, the second longest shot in a field of nine, caught Hushi in the final stride to win the $70,000 Gold Beauty Handicap yesterday on opening day at Hialeah Park in Florida.

title: Report Is Urging an Overhaul of U.S. Latin Policy
description: The General Accounting Office, an independent investigative arm of Congress, is calling for major changes in United States policy toward Central America, saying the policy of the last eight years has not produced stable democracies or economic growth in the region.

title: Washington Talk: The Supreme Court; Justices' Rulings Have a Ripple Effect on the Law
description: Two weeks ago the Supreme Court, in a case involving child abuse, decided that public officials need not save people from privately inflicted harm. But this was not the last judicial word on whether the Constitution ever imposes a ''duty to rescue.''

title: Reviews/Television; Miss Marple Looks for the Corpse
description: Public television is in a pledge period and as a result its schedules are in a tizzy. At Channel 13, regular programming is being pre-empted or shifted to odd hours in favor of specials the station deems more likely to appeal to viewer pocketbooks. Even ''Mystery,'' one of the system's more enduring and dependable series, can get kicked around. This Saturday, the entire two hours of Agatha Christie's ''4:50 From Paddington'' will be broadcast on Channel 13 not in prime time, but at 3:35 in the afternoon.

title: What Kind of Judges?
description: The American Constitution might have foundered, long ago, if its Framers in 1787 had not taken special care for the independence of those who were to have the main responsibility to interpret and enforce it. That is, Federal judges.

title: Bridge
description: Some veteran New York bridge players, brooding on the menace of transportation problems this week, wondered whether the task of reaching the Spring Nationals, beginning tomorrow in Reno, would match the problems they had in 1966. Several of them, battling an airline strike, spent 36 hours then on a bus to go from Chicago to the Summer Nationals in Denver.

title: Bush's Lip Service on Drugs
description: I respect President Bush's humanity in visiting Everett Hatcher's widow in New York City today. Mr. Hatcher, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was shot to death on Staten Island last week, was deeply committed to the war against illegal drugs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an appeal for the Venezuelan President to help establish electoral procedures in Nicaragua misidentified a newspaper that reported a visit to Managua by a Venezuelan delegation. It was the official Sandinista paper, Barricada.

title: Atari Plans To Divest Retail Unit
description: The Atari Corporation said today that it planned to dispose of the Federated Group Inc., a consumer electronics retailer it purchased in 1987. As a result, the company said it had established reserves and taken a write-off of more than $100 million, resulting in large losses for the fourth quarter of 1988 and for the year.

title: Talking Deals; Texaco's Security Is Still Questioned
description: AFTER spending $1.6 billion for Texaco stock and a year and a half battling the company, Carl C. Icahn signed a standstill agreement promising not to attack Texaco Inc. for seven years. But some investors are now wondering whether that pact does, indeed, shield the nation's third-largest oil company from a takeover raid.

title: Gasoline Additive Aids In Treating Gallstones
description: Doctors exploring a new use for a gasoline additive have reported further evidence that it quickly and safely dissolves large gallstones, offering an alternative to surgery for thousands of people.

title: Japan Spending In U.S. Realty
description: Japanese investment in United States real estate rose nearly a third last year, with California attracting more investment than any other state and Los Angeles more than any other city.

title: Shift Is Seen in U.S. Policy to Ease Repayment Costs for Third World
description: Prompted in part by the debt-related violence in Venezuela last week, the Bush Administration has decided to encourage bank creditors of third-world nations to reduce the value of the debt and therefore the countries' cost of making payments on it, officials say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Metro Datelines; Faculty Urges Ouster Of Head of Adelphi
description: The Adelphi University faculty has asked the trustees to dismiss the school president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos.

title: Our Federal Prison System Can't Bear Scrutiny; It's Not Working
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Index Rebounds
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported increased shipments and orders, a trade group reported today.

title: Coach Says Johnson Knew Effects
description: On the sixth day of Charlie Francis's testimony before a Canadian Government inquiry into the use of performance-enchancing drugs by athletes, the attorney for Ben Johnson tried to show that the sprinter was manipulated into using steroids by Francis, who recognized Johnson's potential by 1984.

title: University of Iowa Official Defends School's Actions on Harmon
description: Fred Mims, the University of Iowa assistant athletic director, told a Federal jury today that if the university had known that Ronnie Harmon entered into an agreement to be represented by sports agents during his junior year and accepted money from them, in his opinion it would not have permitted Harmon to play football in his senior season.

title: LSB Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for Northwest Federal Savings & Loan are included from its acquistion in March 1988.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Coleco Industries, West Hartford, Conn. said its board had authorized management to explore a sale of the toy company to solve its financial problems, but no potential purchasers have been identified.

title: New York Legislature Acts to Shift Money to Cover Budget Shortfall
description: The Legislature acted today to close the New York State budget gap by transferring almost $400 million from reserve funds to use for operations.

title: Review/Music; Danish Radio Big Band
description: Big brassy chords and burnished ensembles are the pride of the Danish Radio Big Band, which opened a three-night stand Monday at Sweet Basil. The 20-piece band led by its pianist, Ole Kock Hansen, played with gleaming precision in a set that included blues-flavored tunes (two by Thad Jones, who led the band in 1977-78 and in 1984), ballads and post-bop pieces that could slip into convoluted counterpoint or move into marches with a rock-funk beat.

title: Massachusetts Arts Council Given Reprieve
description: The Massachusetts Council on the Arts and Humanities, which was threatened with extinction by proposed budget cuts, appeared to have been rescued by a compromise yesterday in the State Legislature. But in a move that angered supporters, its $19.5 million budget stands to be reduced by half.

title: PCL Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $224,000 and $1,231,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds. Year-ago revenue figures were restated.

title: Radio Shouts of 'Scab' Are Reported by Pilot
description: An Eastern Airlines pilot said today that his communications with four sets of air traffic controllers were deliberately disrupted on Monday while he took off from Atlanta, forcing him to miss a crucial course change.

title: AL Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lubbock Journal; 'Move Aside, Peoria,' Says West Texas Town
description: In suggesting Tuesday that the political mood here is a good barometer of mainstream America, President Bush overnight elevated this town, hitherto best known as the home of Buddy Holly, to a curious prominence rivaling that of Peoria, Ill.

title: Wajax Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $8,005,000 and $11,178,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included a gain of $165,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss of $296,000 from discontinued operations for the year. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said results have been restated to reflect its decision on March 3 to sell its Pitman Manufacturing group unit in the near future.

title: Jersey Youth Accused of Strangling Mother
description: A 16-year-old boy accused of strangling his mother was released today to the custody of his father, the boy's lawyer said.

title: OMI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5,502,000 charge for an accounting change. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $19,000 and $7,577,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, related to refinancings of long-term obligations. d-Net loss Latest quarter results included a $12,812,000 gain from the sale of a 51- percent stake in a foreign subsidiary. Latest year results included $12,812,000 gain on the sale of a 51-percent interest in a foreign subsidiary; $2,859,000 in income from the receipt of pension reversion funds, net of a provision of $842,000 for prepaid employee compensation; and a $7,467,000 gain from insurance proceeds related to a vessel casualty and from the sale of vessels. Prior year results included a $999,000 gain from disposal of vessels. Per-share net figures were reduced by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Canadian Roxy Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Collier Is Signed by Jets
description: The Jets signed Steve Collier, a Green Bay Packer offensive tackle, yesterday. Collier is the Jets' third addition from the National Football League's pool of 619 unrestricted free agents. In 1987, Collier played 10 games and started 6.

title: Sudan Army Believed Waiting To Oust Mahdi Government
description: The political situation in the Sudan has worsened to the point that both Sudanese and Western officials say they are waiting for the army to step into the breach.

title: Indal Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $6.1 million loss from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Candelaria's Knee Gives Yanks a Pain and May Require Surgery
description: Pitching was their priority, but today it became the Yankees' first significant worry of the spring. John Candelaria, the team's best starter in 1988, remains troubled by a sore right knee that could require surgery and force him to miss at least the start of the season.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Better Late . . .
description: Pierre Charles L'Enfant, the French architect who designed the Federal city in Washington, never saw his grand plans fully realized. The only notable tribute to him in the District of Columbia today is L'Enfant Plaza, a rather sterile hotel and office complex that he would probably have disdained.

title: Calendar: Three Walking Tours
description: A Choice of Three, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.

title: Angolan Oil Output Cut
description: The Angolan Government announced Tuesday that it would cut back oil production by 5 percent in the second half of this year, the state press agency Angop reported.

title: ETHICS DISCLOSURE FILED WITH PANEL
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, President Bush's nominee to be Deputy Secretary of State, made $915,000 last year working for the consulting concern of Kissinger Associates and has taken various steps to disqualify himself from future matters at the State Department that might involve the concern or its clients, according to documents released today by the Office of Government Ethics.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today General Assembly MEETING OF DONORS TO THE CAMBODIAN HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE PROGRAM -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Another Setback for Seabrook
description: The Governor of New Hampshire announced yesterday that the state would seek to block low-power testing at the Seabrook nuclear plant because of doubts about the plant's ever being allowed to operate at full power. The new position reverses more than 15 years of staunch state support for the Seabrook reactor.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Focus on the Sudan
description: Representative Gary L. Ackerman has long maintained interest in Africa. Now he is focusing on the oppression of blacks in the Sudan.

title: Corporate Foods Ltd reports earnings for 53wks to Dec 31
description: Year-ago consisted of 52 weeks ended Dec. 26. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. PRELATES OPEN TALKS IN VATICAN
description: A long-awaited meeting of American Roman Catholic archbishops with Pope John Paul II and his Vatican aides opened here today with a warm welcome from the Pope and a denial by Bernardin Cardinal Gantin, who heads the Vatican's Congregation for Bishops, that the meeting would be confrontational.

title: Reviews/Dance; Stories of Mixed Emotional Signals
description: Emotions can be such dangerous weapons that people often guard against them. Yet all psychological suits of armor may contain chinks that passion can sneak through.

title: More on the Strike
description: United in Enmity - It may not be the rebirth of the union movement, but the Eastern strike is a rare display of labor solidarity. The reason? Frank Lorenzo. News Analysis.

title: Metro Datelines; A Producer Denies Swindling Investors
description: The Broadway producer Adela Holzer pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that she swindled investors out of more than $1 million.

title: Commonwealth Mortgage Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9 months included aftertax gain of $1,430,207 from the sale of mortgage loan servicing rights. There were no such sales in the latest third quarter and 9 months. The company attributed the increase in its latest 9 months earnings to an increase in gain on sale of loans and increased mortgage loan origination volume.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Legal Backbone
description: The House of Representatives is getting more representative, in the view of Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of upstate New York. Once dominated by lawyers, the 435-member House has only 184 members with legal backgrounds, Mr. Gilman said. ''The number of lawyers has gone down because people from all facets of private life have become active in government,'' Mr. Gilman, New York Law School Class of '50, said at a luncheon meeting of his law school alumni this week.

title: Bow Valley Resources Servces Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $76,865,000 special charge. The company said it decided to discontinue offshore drilling activities and divest itself of all or a major interest in its Vertech Treatment Systems operations. The $76.9 million special charge is from the writedown in the carrying value of the assets associated with the discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New York Cancer Specialist Says Bush Has Chosen Him as Physician
description: Dr. Burton J. Lee 3d, a New York cancer specialist, says he has been selected as President Bush's personal physician and expects the appointment to be announced shortly.

title: Alexander Bookstaver, 77, Unions' Adviser
description: Alexander Bookstaver, a retired banker and financial consultant to unions, died of a liver ailment Tuesday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 77 years old.

title: Kay Jewelers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid later this month.

title: TV Notes
description: ABC's Tuesday

title: Politics of a Polish Forest; Indictment of Soviets in Katyn Massacre Reflects Warsaw's Opening to Opposition
description: Poland's accusation that Soviet forces carried out the Katyn Forest massacre of Polish officers in World War II, overturning what for 45 years had been the official explanation of the mass murder, reflects a widening search by the Communist leadership for forms of legitimacy as it seeks accommodation with political opponents.

title: Chief Medical Officer For U.S. Resigns Post
description: Dr. Robert Voy, the embattled chief medical officer for the United States Olympic Committee, has resigned, effective March 17.

title: Metro Matters; A New Giuliani: From Tough Guy To Statesman
description: In 1974, after testifying as a character witness for an indicted fellow Congressman, Representative Edward I. Koch was asked by a prosecutor whether he hadn't appeared in that very same courtroom a few months before and vouched for the veracity of another indicted Congressman, too. ''Yes,'' Mr. Koch replied. ''And wasn't he convicted?'' the prosecutor asked. ''Yes,'' Mr. Koch said. Years later, the Mayor had forgotten the name of the prosecutor, but he vividly remembered his personal reaction to the courtroom interrogation. Mr. Koch recalled that he felt like a jerk.

title: Reviews/Dance; With a Foolish Hat, Fancy Footwork
description: Lauri Nagel dressed herself in a foolish, faded little hat with a perky feather, a gray fake-fur coat and white socks for the opening dance on a program of her pieces Friday night at Performance Space 122.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pop Life column yesterday about the ''Masters of the Folk Violin'' concert misstated the date. It is Saturday, not Sunday, at 8 P.M. at Julia Richman High School, 317 East 67th Street.

title: Reviews/Television; Soviet Writers Revel in New-Found Freedom
description: The birth pangs of the new literary freedom in the Soviet Union are explored tonight in an enlightening documentary. ''The Arts and Glasnost: The Writers,'' at 10 on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, confirms the abiding passion for literature of a people who have been starved by decades of censorship and bureaucracy and reports on how writers are managing in the era of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: The Car Boom Sweeping Europe
description: European auto makers are experiencing the same giddiness that children feel watching someone blow up a balloon - they are delighted to see car demand in Europe expand to record levels, but they are scared that their balloon might burst at any moment.

title: Learning Better Ways To Give Ski Instruction
description: rrMost skiers would rather ski than take lessons to learn how to ski. Surveys conducted by Sports Research Inc. of Princeton, N.J., show that only 3 of every 10 skiers take lessons, and among first-time skiers, less than half take lessons, even though many ski areas offer free lessons to new skiers.

title: Chairs Share the Glory With a Chinese Menu
description: WHEN Mo Liu decided to open Sino, a restaurant in Greenwich Village, he wanted the design to be as modern as the ''Euro-Chinoise'' menu (clams with garlic butter and Chinese chives, quail with Chinese plum sauce).

title: F.D.I.C. Chairman Asks Changes in Rescue Plan
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation walked a careful line in Congressional testimony today in seeking changes in the Bush bailout plan for savings institutions, changes that would expand the regulatory authority of the agency.

title: Rebels Say They Attack Big Afghan City
description: Afghan rebel spokesmen said today that the battle for Jalalabad, the eastern Afghan city, had begun and asserted that two army posts east of the city had been captured.

title: Cupboards Of Bavaria
description: SINCE the 1600's, Bavarians have handpainted their furniture for the same reason other people do - to make a plain wood like pine look rich. But they are not minimalists. What gives Bavarian painted furniture its identity is its extravagant layering of pattern upon pattern.

title: Times Co. Sees Profit Drop
description: The New York Times Company will report sharply lower first-quarter earnings as a result of profit declines in its newspaper, magazine and forest products operations, Walter E. Mattson, the company's president, said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Settles Toth Case
description: Four senior officials and two former directors of the Toth Aluminum Corporation today settled Federal civil charges that they had failed to file timely reports of more than $23 million in trades of the company's stock.

title: At The Movies
description: Feature-Film Debut ''I have incredible trepidation,'' said Gary David Goldberg.

title: Corrections
description: A report in ''At the Nation's Table'' in The Living Section on Wednesday about tiramisu gave an incorrect telephone number for the Ristorante Milano in San Francisco. Its number is (415) 673-2961.

title: Bush Vows Prompt Cleanup Of Federal Nuclear Wastes
description: President Bush today vowed to ''waste no time'' starting a cleanup of tons of radioactive waste and widespread soil contamination from the Energy Department's 12-state nuclear weapon complex.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aeromaritime, Paris, a unit of UTA French Airlines, ordered two 737-300 Boeing jets for a total of $60 million, Boeing Commerical Airplanes said.

title: Review/Art; Sad Memory and Hope From Louise Fishman
description: Louise Fishman is known for lean abstract paintings with muscular blocks of color. Paint is applied in many layers, often with a palette knife, until color stirs and glows. Her fields of squares and rectangles have clear roots in Cezanne, Mondrian and the expressionist abstraction of the 1940's and 50's, but they also have something of the matter-of-factness of the 60's. The not always resolved tension between logic and intuition, pragmatism and mysticism, is one of the themes of her work.

title: Reviews/Film; Seeking Romance In 'Paradise'
description: Thanks to a philandering husband and a death in the family, a sensitive, boring Australian wife named Maria (Wendy Hughes) is given carte blanche to do what she may well have wanted to do in the first place. In ''Echoes of Paradise,'' Maria ventures to the turquoise waters and unspoiled beaches of Phuket, Thailand, for some much-needed respite. In Phuket, feeling furious at her husband, George (Steven Jacobs), and badly in need of adventure, Maria becomes involved with an exotic, long-haired Balinese dancer named Raka (John Lone), who dances exquisitely and gives terrific neck rubs. For a woman in Maria's position, Raka is just what the doctor ordered.

title: Tax Rise Voted in Connecticut
description: After weeks of haggling, Democrats on the General Assembly's tax committee agreed today on a $118 million package of tax increases. They include a new tax on soft drinks and higher cigarette and alcohol taxes.

title: Bork Says His Ordeal Set Stage for Tower's
description: Robert H. Bork says the Senate's questioning of him was a Supreme Court nominee in 1987 set a precedent for the treatment John G. Tower received in confirmation hearings for Secretary of Defense.

title: Big Ten Title To Indiana
description: Eric Anderson scored 19 points last night as No. 6 Indiana beat Wisconsin, 75-64, clinching the Hoosiers' record 10th Big Ten Conference championship and the automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Maytec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and year included a gain of $143,000 and $230,000, respectively, on the sale of assets.

title: Loser-Pay-All System Curbs Frivolous Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: With Politicians Mediating, Howard Protest Ends
description: With some of the nation's top black politicians acting as mediators, students and officials at Howard University reached an agreement early today that ended a five-day campus protest over the management of the predominantly black school and the appointment of the Republican national chairman to its board.

title: Jews, Too, Died In the Katyn Forest
description: LEAD: With Poland's accusation that it was Soviet forces that massacred Polish officers - not the Nazis, as Stalin had claimed - the Katyn Forest tragedy is coming full circle.

title: Toronto Dominion
description: The New York branch of the Toronto Dominion Bank is offering $150 million of 10 percent notes due 1999 at a price of 99.55 to yield 10.07 percent through Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable for five years, the notes yield about 83-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Dayton Hudson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The company said earnings for the latest quarter and year included a pre-tax charge of $35 million from the closing of Branden's, the company's home furnishings test strategy.

title: Give an Owl A Home: Kill a Rodent
description: The New York City Parks Department, convinced that there is more than one way to skin a rat, has a new plan to fight one of civilization's oldest problems by building boxes from which barn owls can fly nocturnal raids on rodents.

title: Jefferies Still Trying To Swing Out of Slump
description: It's not exactly a crisis yet, with spring training only one week old. But Gregg Jefferies, the whiz kid who went 35 for 109 last September and hit six home runs in a clattering debut in the big leagues, went 0 for 4 again today. He has one infield single in 19 times at bat in his first spring as a regular with the Mets.

title: Accounts
description: * Borden Inc. to Solin Associates, for its Aunt Millie's family style spaghetti sauce, with a budget of $3.5 million.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Die in House Fire Attributed to Arson
description: A fire fed by a flammable liquid that had been poured on a stairway trapped and killed a woman and her two sons in a three-story frame house yesterday, officials said.

title: Slain Agent Also Helped Prison Inquiry
description: A Federal agent who was killed last week while on a narcotics investigation on Staten Island was simultaneously involved in an undercover operation to determine whether corruption existed in an early-release program for prisoners, Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about nutrition labeling carried an incorrect description of an inquiry involving the Campbell Soup Company. The company has not been fined by nine state attorneys general over health claims made for its products. The issue is still under investigation in the nine states and by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: 5.5% Bass Stake In Bay Financial
description: Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass, the Fort Worth investors, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they own 5.5 percent of the Bay Financial Corporation, a Boston real estate concern, only as an investment.

title: Lorenzo Defends Bankruptcy as Eastern's Last Hope
description: LEAD: Frank Lorenzo said he had heard it all before - the charges that he is a callous deal maker out for his own gain - but the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that the criticism is the price he pays for bringing tough management to a once-sheltered industry.

title: Officer on Foot Patrol Is Stabbed in Midtown
description: A police officer walking foot patrol in midtown Manhattan was stabbed in the back and seriously wounded last night when a man suddenly came up behind him and attacked him, the police said.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Time for Toots

title: Fay's Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Prior quarter and year share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend distributed on June 28, 1988.

title: Quayle and the Camel
description: The Vice President of the United States makes one of the more important and sensible speeches on the Middle East heard in public for a long time. The country reacts pretty much the way the farmer did when he saw a camel for the first time. He shook his head, said there was no such animal and walked away.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS,'' a musical by the Gingerbread Players, with book, music and lyrics by Carol Weiss, directed by Fred Guinther, music direction by by Ben Sloane, 7:30 tonight, 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Queens. Admission: $4.50. Reservations and information: (718) 268-6021. PURIM ARTS CARNIVAL, a program of puppetry, klezmer music, costume and mask-making, dance and theater performances, 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Hebrew Arts School, 129 West 67th Street. Admission: $1. Information: 362-8060. ''THE MAGIC OF MARIONETTES,'' a journey into the land of fairy tales through the art of marionettes, with Marlene Alterman, Ellen McDermott and Celia Riahi, 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Rudolf Steiner School, 15 East 79th Street. Admission: children, $3; adults, $5.50. Information: 879-1101. ''GAMES FROM THE PAST,'' an hourlong program with Felicity Bell, who will lead children in games from the 18th and early 19th centuries, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street. The museum is open from 1 to 5 P.M.; admission: $2; free for children. Reservations necessary for the games program: 838-6878. ''CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS,'' a show by Puppetworks, with music of Saint-Saens and others, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. LEE MURDOCK FOLK CONCERT, program of song and guitar music, 8:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Entrance fees: under 16 years old and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (203) 322-1646. STORY HOUR, a free program by Rosemary Wells, an author, who will give readings from her latest book, ''Max's Chocolate Chicken,'' noon to 2 P.M. tomorrow, at Books of Wonder, 132 Seventh Avenue, at 18th Street. Information: 989-3270. ''CINDERELLA,'' a puppet show by Betty Nelson, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a play with music, adapted from the Hans Christian Andersen tale by Randolph Pearson, who is also the director, with music by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Reservations: 666-1716.

title: Environmental Control Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for prior year periods are pro forma, reflecting higher federal corporate income tax rates that would have been recorded if certain units had not elected to be taxed as S corporations.

title: CANADA RULES OUT NEW CRASH INQUIRY
description: After reviewing a narrow split by the official investigation board on the cause of a 1985 airplane crash in Newfoundland in which 248 American soldiers died, Canada's Transport Minister has rejected calls to name a special judge to look further into the matter.

title: Chronic Shoulder Injury Forces Horner to Retire
description: At the age of 31, after 218 home run in 10 major league seasons, Bob Horner announced his retirement yesterday in Miami, where he had been trying to catch on with the Baltimore Orioles as a free agent. The right-handed power hitter, who slammed four home runs in one game for the Atlanta Braves July 6, 1986, said his left shoulder had not healed sufficiently from an operation last Aug. 6. That was one in a series of physical problems that had troubled Horner, the National League rookie of the year in 1978.

title: U.S. Savings Bailouts Pass Halfway Point
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of 45 insolvent savings and loan associations with assets of $13.6 billion today, bringing to 118 the number of sick institutions that it has seized in accord with President Bush's savings bailout plan.

title: Judge Refuses to Open Proceeding
description: A Federal judge who rebuked prosecutors this week and then sealed the transcript of his remarks refused a request yesterday to open a proceeding in which lawyers questioned jurors to determine if they had been prejudiced by wide publicity about the judge's comments.

title: Protective Life Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago earnings are restated for accounting changes. The NASD halted trading in Protective Life Corp. pending news. Last sale was 13 1/4.

title: Statements After Defeat
description: John G. Tower

title: Jersey Water Main Bursts, Disrupting 60 Communities
description: A huge water main, installed just last year, split in half in the predawn darkness today, leaving three quarters of a million people without water until noon, disrupting hospital procedures and forcing the closing of scores of schools.

title: Tower's Final Day of Limbo Ends With Defiant Farewell
description: Minutes after the Senate rejected him for the job he had sought for most of a decade, John G. Tower stood for the first and last time behind a lectern emblazoned with the seal of the Secretary of Defense of the United States.

title: BSN Reviews Plan For Athlone Seats
description: The BSN Corporation, which owns 4.95 percent of Athlone Industries, said it was reviewing ''the feasibility and desirability'' of seeking control of the manufacturer of sporting goods and other products through representation on its board. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, BSN, a sporting goods company based in Farmers Branch, Tex., said it had offered unsuccessfully in Janurary to buy Athlone's Dudley Sports unit. BSN also said it had held preliminary talks about selling two of the company's steelmaking units.

title: 4 Ex-AIDS Officials Indicted in the Theft Of Centers' Money
description: Four former officials of the state-financed AIDS Outreach Program in New York City have been indicted on charges of stealing $350,000 from the progam, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

title: Y.&R. Ex-Chairman Seen as Bush Choice
description: Edward Ney, the former chairman of Young & Rubicam, may be the next United States Ambassador to Canada, The Globe and Mail in Toronto reported yesterday.

title: Coach, Player Honored
description: Joe Marsh of St. Lawrence was named ECAC Hockey's coach of the year and Lane MacDonald of Harvard was named the most valuable player on the eve of the league's tournament in Boston. Marsh coached the Saints to 27 victories, the most in that college's history. MacDonald led Harvard to a 26-2 record, the best for the Crimson in 52 years.

title: Harelm's Promise
description: Physically, Harlem has been a symbol of urban ruin. Its decline over 70 years from a masterpiece of urban elegance and lucid city planning to a ruinous array of broken buildings and garbage-strewn lots could not have been more complete if it had been legislated or decreed. Yet the paradox of Harlem is that even in the midst of what has become a physical wasteland, there is a creative energy that is alive and palpable.

title: International Totalizator Sysems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a $21,000 tax charge for the quarter and a $245,000 tax credit for the year.

title: Marcus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Nine-month figures represent 36 weeks.

title: Eddie Palmieri
description: The pianist Eddie Palmieri is leading his Latin-jazz group tonight through Sunday at Indigo Blue, 221 West 46th Street (221-0033). Sets tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., Sunday at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Happy Coats, Happy Staff

title: Norton Simon Resigns From Art Museum Post
description: Norton Simon, the retired industrialist, has resigned as president and trustee of the Pasadena art museum that bears his name and that houses his immense art collection, a museum spokesman said today.

title: Topics of The Times; Good Reason for Higher Tolls
description: In a victory for common sense, a Federal judge has rebuffed a bid by the Automobile Clubs of New York and New Jersey to roll back tolls on four hectic interstate crossings: the George Washington Bridge, the Bayonne Bridge, the Goethals Bridge and the Outerbridge Crossing. The auto clubs' lawsuit, repeating one they lost in 1979, challenged the 1987 increase in tolls from $2 to $3.

title: Cassiar Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the Similco Copper Mine, which was acquired in June, contributed $45,687,000 to 1988 revenues. The debt of the Cassiar operation, outstanding since 1981, has been reduced to $14,162,000 as of March 1 and the company said it should be fully paid by the end of 1989. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Candelaria Feels Better
description: The good news: John Candelaria's damaged right knee showed minimal swelling overnight, and today the Yankee pitcher said he felt better after having fluid drained from the knee on Wednesday. But Candelaria also said he learned two days ago that there was the possibility he had a cyst in the knee, and he said that if he does, it might require arthroscopic surgery.

title: From Armani, a Tailored Look That's Softer
description: This is the season Giorgio Armani discovered the curve.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Meeting for Volunteers
description: A dozen or more countries have established overseas volunteer programs since the United States created the Peace Corps in 1961, but there has been little interaction among the participants from different nations over the years. That is changing.

title: On Stage
description: 'Pimpernel' on the Way

title: LTX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Auctions
description: A Daughter's Heritage

title: Jets Sign Former Chief
description: The Jets yesterday signed the Kansas City Chiefs' starting outside right linebacker, Tim Cofield, who was left unprotected in the free-agent draft. For the Chiefs, who finished 4-11-1 last season, it was the sixth player lost in the draft, most in the league.

title: Merrill to Urge I.R.A. Changes
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest investment firm, said yesterday that it would urge the Federal Government to allow tax-free withdrawals from Individual Retirement Accounts in certain circumstances.

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Review/Recital; Ysaye Sonata By Violinist At Tully Hall
description: Leonidas Kavakos hit his full stride late in the evening at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday, delivering a firmly shaped and atmospherically colored account of Ysaye's beautiful Fifth Sonata for Solo Violin. Here the young Naumburg prize winner consolidated his formidable technical skills and matched them persuasively with a sense of musical purpose.

title: LVMH Chief Wins Ruling In Fight With Vuitton Head
description: Bernard Arnault, the new chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, won a court battle today that is expected to speed his efforts to oust Henry Racamier as chairman of Louis Vuitton, the luggage maker that is an LVMH subsidiary.

title: Washington Talk: The Cabinet; New Transport Chief Pursues the Big Picture
description: Almost every day, it seems, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner finds his way onto a morning television program, a weekend broadcast interview or the nightly news.

title: Books of The Times; Descent From a Flawed Paradise
description: The Whiteness of Bones By Susanna Moore 277 pages. Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Credibility of Prostitute At Issue in Queens Trial
description: A defense lawyer yesterday sought to impugn the credibility of a former crack-using prostitute who had provided important evidence against four men accused of murdering a police officer in Queens.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Enclave of exclusivity trumpets its high purpose in trial law, though critics hold their noses
description: Twenty-five lawyers formed a semicircle around the lectern, standing solemnly as the famed New York litigator Leon Silverman gave the fraternity's time-honored charge.

title: U.S. Sprint in Atlantic Cable Deal
description: In a move to expand its international presence, the U S Sprint Communications Company today announced an agreement to buy a 50 percent stake in the first private telecommunications cable linking the United States and Europe.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comfed Bancorp Inc., Lowell, Mass., a bank holding company, said Gerald Schuster had resigned as vice chairman.

title: Unicorp American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Prior-year results are restated for an accounting change. The company said the latest year's incresed loss was primarily attributable to the offsetting effects of interest expense totaling about $11 million on indebtedness incurred to acquire Lincoln Savings Bank; a $13.5 million decrease in gains on sales of real estate investments; an increase in the loss on sale or writeoff of investments, and $21.5 million of net income of Lincoln Savings Bank. Latest-year results also include gains of $6.4 million on the sale of three real estate properties. Lincoln also recorded gains on sales of loans and investments totaling $7.1 million during 1988, of which $4.1 million occurred in the fourth quarter.

title: Redmen Are Eliminated As Barros Sets Record
description: A couple of weeks ago, Matt Brust, St. John's 6-foot-5-inch senior, was asked to describe his defensive tactics against Dana Barros, the high-scoring Boston College guard Brust had ''held'' to 30 points in a dramatic overtime victory at Alumni Hall.

title: Chavez, Mayweather Back in On-Again Stage
description: Julio Cesar Chavez's on-again, off-again bout against Roger Mayweather, the World Boxing Council superlightweight champion, is now set for May 13.

title: Court Upholds Law Denying Tax Break for a Golf Course
description: The Maryland Court of Appeals has upheld a law denying a property tax break to the Burning Tree Club unless the prestigious golf course accepts women as members.

title: UNR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $1,100,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. There were no discontinued operations in the quarter. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $807,784 for both periods, and tax credits of $3,200,000 and $5,700,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior-year results included a gain of $1,341,928 from the sale of an equity investment in Midwest Communications.

title: Bleak Day for Eastern Ticketholders
description: Ralph Kornblatt called his travel agent weeks ago and bought a $580 nonrefundable ticket for a round-trip flight to Atlanta on Eastern Airlines. The flight was scheduled to leave La Guardia Airport tomorrow at 9:05 A.M.

title: Topics of The Times; Soviet Progress, U.S. Delay
description: The Soviet Union strikes a blow for world law and human rights. Not many months ago, readers would have blinked in disbelief at such a statement. Yet Moscow now says it will accept the binding adjudication of the World Court in cases arising from five basic human rights agreements, including the 1948 convention condemning genocide. With other states in the Soviet bloc likely to follow suit, this is a substantial boost for the Hague Court.

title: Why A New Missile?
description: Secretary of State Baker has agreed to go to Moscow in May to discuss the resumption of strategic arms limitation talks. He will get the most promising response then and in the later negotiations if he states a U.S. position that includes:

title: TV Weekend; Big Bands and Swing In Memories and Song
description: This being a pledge week, public television is turning more than ever to adorable animals and soothing nostalgia. Those are the commodities, programmers insist, that most inspire viewers to become subscribers. This week, we had separate documentaries on cats and dogs. This weekend, Channel 13 is focusing on the popular music and stars of the 1930's and 40's.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Feb. 28 and an article last Monday, both about mutual funds, misstated the net cash flow into equity mutual funds in January. The Investment Company Institute says the figure, not including reinvested dividends, was $72 million.

title: Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter losses were due to purchase price accounting adjustments relating to the acquisition of Speedring Cos., diminished margins at the Micronics subsidiary due to disruptions caused by government audits, and additional cancelled jobs at Coast Aerotech related to a chemical fire.

title: Air Express International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $895,000 and $2,815,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: People
description: * Harvey Hoffenberg, has been named an executive vice president and executive creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

title: Man Tied to Art Thefts In Northeast Is Arrested
description: A man believed to be linked to a series of thefts of decorative artworks from museums throughout the Northeast was arrested by F.B.I. agents on Tuesday afternoon at a Madison Avenue gallery. George Athanasotos, a 34-year-old Brooklyn man who had attempted to sell eight of 16 antique English watches stolen from the Baltimore Institute of Art on Feb. 25, was charged with interstate transportation of stolen property and arraigned yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Article 704289 -- No Title
description: A Federal judge today fined Ashland Oil $2.25 million for a 1988 oil spill that fouled two rivers and disrupted water supplies in three states.

title: The Sounds of Brazil, Citified in Sao Paulo
description: FOR some Americans, Brazilian music means Afro-Brazilian carnival processions and sambas in the street; for others, it means the whispered vocals, sly harmonies and delicate guitar work of the bossa nova. Still others are catching up with the tropicalia movement of the 1970's, when young, politically progressive Brazilian songwriters reacted to the broadening of rock with their own electrified pop; a selection recently appeared on ''Beleza Tropical: Brazil Classics,'' compiled by David Byrne of Talking Heads. There is also a growing American audience for the liquid voice and open-hearted melodies of Milton Nascimento and for some of Brazil's other extraordinary singers - Maria Bethania, Djavan, Simone, and Gal Costa (who is to appear Wednesday at Carnegie Hall with the bossa nova pioneer Antonio Carlos Jobim).

title: A Former Jersey Mayor Tearfully Pleads Guilty
description: The former Mayor of Wayne, N.J., tearfully pleaded guilty today to conspiring to extort $50,000 from a developer seeking approval for an $18 million condominium project.

title: Wholesale Club Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Aboard the Shuttle, Leg Room and Extras
description: Just before takeoff, the flight attendants dutifully repeated the standard safety pantomime with seat belts and safety information cards. But this morning, the performance was before 158 empty seats and just 19 passengers.

title: TIS Mortgage Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures are not available because the company began operations on Aug. 26, 1988.

title: Ex-U.S. Sergeant's Spy Case Is Said to Grow in Seriousness
description: A United States Army espionage ring in West Germany that was broken up last summer was larger and more serious than first realized, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation is now investigating as many as five former soldiers as part of the case, according to Government officials and documents.

title: Our Towns; For Girls' Team In Boys' League, Hope, Then Glory
description: When Jodi Levine graduated from fourth grade last year, her dad put up a basketball hoop in the driveway. Jodi loves hoops. In a school essay, she wrote that her ambition is to be a Knick. ''I have the skill,'' she wrote. ''I have the speed. I know I'm a little short, but I can handle it.''

title: In Miami, No Songs For Castro
description: Denise de Kalafe, a Brazilian pop singer, went to Cuba in 1981 at the request of her government to sing at an international festival. ''Just a few love songs,'' the 38-year-old singer said this week. ''Nothing political. No - what's the expression? - big deal.''

title: How They Voted
description: Following is the 53-to-47 roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected President Bush's nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense. Voting yes were 3 Democrats and 44 Republicans. Voting no were 52 Democrats and one Republican. Adams, D-Wash., no; Armstrong, R-Colo., yes. Baucus, D-Mont., no; Bentsen, D-Texas, yes; Biden, D-Del., no; Bingaman, D-N.M., no; Bond, R-Mo., yes; Boren, D-Okla., no; Boschwitz, R-Minn., yes; Bradley, D-N.J., no; Breaux, D-La., no; Bryan, D-Nev., no; Bumpers, D-Ark., no; Burdick, D-N.D., no; Burns, R-Mont., yes; Byrd, D-W.Va., no. Chafee, R-R.I., yes; Coats, R-Ind., yes; Cochran, R-Miss., yes; Cohen, R-Maine, yes; Conrad, D-N.D., no; Cranston, D-Calif., no. D'Amato, R-N.Y., yes; Danforth, R-Mo., yes; Daschle, D-S.D., no; DeConcini, D-Ariz., no; Dixon, D-Ill., no; Dodd, D-Conn., yes; Dole, R-Kan., yes; Domenici, R-N.M., yes; Durenberger, R-Minn., yes. Exon, D-Neb., no. Ford, D-Ky., no; Fowler, D-Ga., no. Garn, R-Utah, yes; Glenn, D-Ohio, no; Gorton, R-Wash., yes; Gore, D-Tenn., no; Graham, D-Fla., no; Gramm, R-Texas, yes; Grassley, R-Iowa, yes. Harkin, D-Iowa, no; Hatch, R-Utah, yes; Hatfield, R-Ore., yes; Heflin, D-Ala., yes; Heinz, R-Pa., yes; Helms, R-N.C., yes; Hollings, D-S.C., no; Humphrey, R-N.H., yes.. Inouye, D-Hawaii, no. Jeffords, R-Vt., yes; Johnston, D-La., no. Kassebaum, R-Kan., no; Kasten, R-Wis., yes; Kennedy, D-Mass., no; Kerrey, D-Neb., no; Kerry, D-Mass., no; Kohl, D-Wis., no. Lautenberg, D-N.J., no; Leahy, D-Vt., no; Levin, D-Mich., no; Lieberman, D-Conn, no; Lott, R-Miss., yes; Lugar, R-Ind., yes. Mack, R-Fla., yes; Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, no; McCain, R-Ariz., yes; McClure, R-Idaho, yes; McConnell, R-Ky., yes; Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, no; Mikulski, D-Md., no; Mitchell, D-Maine, no; Moynihan, D-N.Y., no; Murkowski, R-Alaska, yes. Nickles, R-Okla., yes; Nunn, D-Ga., no. Packwood, R-Ore., yes; Pell, D-R.I., no; Pressler, R-S.D., yes; Pryor, D-Ark., no. Reid, D-Nev., no; Riegle, D-Mich., no; Robb, D-Va., no; Rockefeller, D-W.Va., no; Roth, R-Del., yes Rudman, R-N.H., yes. Sanford, D-N.C., no; Sarbanes, D-Md., no; Sasser, D-Tenn., no; Shelby, D-Ala., no; Simon, D-Ill., no; Simpson, R-Wyo., yes; Specter, R-Pa., yes; Stevens, R-Alaska, yes; Symms, R-Idaho, yes. Thurmond, R-S.C., yes. Wallop, R-Wyo., yes; Warner, R-Va., yes; Wilson, R-Calif., yes; Wirth, D-Colo., no.

title: 3 Arabs Killed and 12 Hurt In the West Bank and Gaza
description: Three more Palestinians were killed and 12 were wounded today, the second day of a general strike to mark the start of the 16th month of the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: The Judge Who Spoke Too Soon
description: Judge John Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in New York may have a strong complaint against prosecutors appearing before him in an ongoing drug conspiracy trial. But by scolding them out of turn he has embroiled himself and news organizations in a needless confrontation over the right of the press and public to know how justice is being dispensed.

title: ISRAELI LEFTISTS TO SEE P.L.O. AIDES
description: Several left-wing members of Parliament along with leaders of the Peace Now movement will take part in a symposium in New York this weekend that will also be attended by members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: General James H. Rumbaugh, 49, Director of Army Medical Center
description: Army Maj. Gen. James H. Rumbaugh, commander of Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died after making a parachute jump in Honduras, the Pentagon said today. He was 49 years old.

title: Birch Headquarters to Move
description: The John Birch Society has announced plans to move its headquarters to this northeastern Wisconsin town, the birthplace of the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

title: Gap Said to Be in Talks On Men's Wear Chain
description: The Gap Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel retailers, is negotiating to acquire its first men's wear chain, American Eagle Outfitters, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Equion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $161,000.

title: Plasma-Therm Inc reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Community Action Reduces Drug Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: For Democrats, the Price of Victory
description: Now, with any kind of luck, the Bush Administration can begin. The Tower affair cast a shadow over almost all President Bush's 50 days in office. The battle produced a few heroes and some serious casualties. But the damage need not be permanent, if all sides turn quickly to urgent tasks postponed during the long weeks of bitter debate.

title: Johnny Carson to Stay As 'Tonight' Show Host
description: Johnny Carson is to stay on as host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC for at least another year - his 28th -through Sept. 1990.

title: U.S. Expels Soviet Diplomat
description: The Unites States detained a Soviet military attache, accused him of espionage and said it was expelling him. Page A10.

title: China's Failure in Tibet
description: Since 1950, China has shown Tibet the rawest face of imperialism - destruction of thousands of monasteries, suppression of the Tibetan language and culture and widespread settlement by Chinese colonists. This has resulted in the death of perhaps a million Tibetans.

title: New Snags For Japan Jet Project
description: New differences between the Commerce Department and the Pentagon over safeguards for technology are delaying Bush Administration agreement to cooperate with Japan in developing and producing an advanced version of the F-16 fighter.

title: 2 Committees Urge Congress to Stop Abuse at Adult Care Centers
description: The Federal Government should immediately establish minimum standards for residential institutions that house elderly, disabled or mentally ill adults, two Congressional committees declared today.

title: Northrop Accused of Selling U.S. a Faulty Missile System
description: The Northrop Corporation's cruise missile guidance system was never properly tested, and many of the nearly 1,800 nuclear missiles aboard the United States bomber fleet may not work, according court papers unsealed today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 In Poland, a tentative agreement on restoring Poland's second chamber of Parliament was reached by the Government and the Solidarity union. Members will be chosen in open and free elections. Page A1

title: Super Rite Agrees To Buyout Plan
description: Super Rite Foods Inc. agreed to be purchased by a management group that includes its chairman, Alex Grass. The agreement is worth $127 million in cash, plus preferred stock and warrants, up from an offer of about $118 million. The chief financial officer, William K. Schantzenbach, said the stock and warrants had not been valued yet. Super Rite's stock fell 12.5 cents today in over-the-counter trading, to $24.875.

title: Army's Old Foe Rides High in Brazil
description: When Brazil's armed forces toppled President Joao Goulart in 1964, they were no less intent on ousting the powerful man behind the throne, Leonel Brizola, a crowd-pleasing Socialist who had dreams of succeeding his brother-in-law in elections the following year.

title: Surging Rutgers Gains N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Playing in its most important game in six years, Rutgers added another chapter tonight to what has been one of the more remarkable success stories in college basketball this season.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is offering $350 million of notes due 1994 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Underwriters gave the notes a 10.05 percent coupon and priced them at par, to yield about 70 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: Public Health Hampered In Fight Against AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST CABINET VETO SINCE '59; BUSH CONFERS ON NEW CHOICE
description: The Senate today rejected President Bush's nomination of John G. Tower to be Secretary of Defense, the first time in 30 years that a President was denied his choice of a Cabinet member.

title: Bush Seeks Mandatory Execution In Slaying of Federal Law Officers
description: Opening a new effort to publicize the nation's drug problems today, President Bush renewed his call for a mandatory Federal death penalty in cases where law-enforcement officers are killed.

title: Indictments on Drug Money
description: Thirty-three people were charged Wedjesday with hiding in jewelry businesses as much as $5 million a day in Colombian drug money profits. In announcing two Federal indictments, United States Attorney Robert Bonner said more than $1 billion had been laundered since 1986. Many of the suspects were arrested last month in raids on the jewelry district in downtown Los Angeles.

title: Mayerling Journal; Lurid Truth and Lurid Legend: A Hapsburg Tale
description: One hundred years ago, the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne brought a 17-year-old mistress to his hunting estate in this sylvan village, shot her through the head and turned the gun on himself. Or did he? Was Prince Rudolf murdered, as die-hard monarchists hold? Or was he really killed in a drunken brawl with the uncles of his mistress, young Mary Vetsera? Or did he shoot himself when Mary bled to death after a secret abortion? Was he deranged, as his father declared? A drug addict? Syphilitic? With the 100th anniversary of the deaths at Mayerling, one of Austria's most durable mysteries has been revived with the sort of fascination the Austrians lavish on the juiciest of scandals. A stack of new books and a television program have reopened all the old theories and added a few brand-new ones. Convent Where Lodge Stood

title: Review/Film; Keeping Love Alive, Indefinitely
description: Corinne (Cybill Shepherd) and Louie (Christopher McDonald) are madly in love, which is unhappy news for Louie's best friend, Philip (Ryan O'Neal), since Philip loves Corinne too. But as the lovers are celebrating their first wedding anniversary, Louie is hit by a car. After this, he is gone but not forgotten, since Corinne spends the next 23 years mooning over Louie's memory (''My psychiatrist says I suffer from the halo effect'') and leaving little snacks beside his picture. As for Philip, he spends 23 years mooning over Corinne, never getting anywhere with her but never bothering with other women either.

title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage
description: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which found itself in a national spotlight yesterday as President Bush kicked off an anti-drug crusade, is the nation's primary agency - but far from the only one - in a diversified war against cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs.

title: Review/Film; Brandauer In Szabo's 'Hanussen'
description: Istvan Szabo's ''Hanussen,'' the Hungarian movie opening today at the Paris, is a foreign film for people who suppose they are having a thinking experience when all they are doing is reading English subtitles.

title: Richard Diamond And Ellen Minsky Exchange Vows
description: Ellen Minsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Minsky of Brookville, L.I., and Richard B. Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Diamond of New Hyde Park, L.I., were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz officiated.

title: Heldor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $1,540,000 for the latest quarter and $1,216,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Judge Limits Punitive Claims for Products
description: A Federal judge declared today that multiple punitive damage suits against manufacturers and distributors of harmful products were unconstitutional. Repeated punishment for a single course of conduct violates the right to due process, he said.

title: North Accuser Questioned Sharply On Varying Accounts of a Meeting
description: Oliver L. North's defense lawyer today hammered away at inconsistencies in the testimony of a fund-raiser who said Mr. North vowed to lie to Congress, even to go to jail if necessary to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: INSIDE
description: Test-Tube Babies: a Survey

title: Partial Solar Eclipse in West
description: A partial eclipse of the Sun occurred Tuesday across western North America, where amateur astronomers gathered to view the event through telescopes.

title: Bowne & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said fierce price competition reduced profit margins in the latest quarter.
