title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY PLAYWRIGHT'S OLD CLOTHES

title: Measurement Specialties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; Flashing Aphorisms By Jenny Holzer at Dia
description: In the large, darkened spaces of ''Laments,'' Jenny Holzer's new installation piece at the Dia Art Foundation, the artist's hauntingly pessimistic words flow between floor and ceiling in columns of moving colored light. The same phrases also sit, stately and still, carved into the granite and marble tops of 13 stone sarcophagi.

title: Henry Thomas Burns, Obstetrician, 95
description: Dr. Henry Thomas Burns, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist who practiced for many years in New York City, died Monday at his home in Dorset, Vt. He was 95 years old and had also lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Consumer Debt Posts A Slim Rise
description: Growth in consumer installment credit, which can sometimes foretell the direction of the economy, was slim again in January as Americans took on $4.36 billion in new debt, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: WestMarc Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $328,000.

title: Dow Slips 4.11 Points in Listless Trading
description: The stock market turned in a listless performance yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.11 points to close at 2,291.43.

title: South Africa's Ruling Party Fails to Persuade Botha to Step Down
description: South Africa's governing National Party today offered President P. W. Botha a facing-saving solution to the leadership crisis but failed to persuade him to yield power.

title: Health Chief Seeks Better Care for Poor
description: The new Secretary of Health and Human Services said today that his top priorities were improving health care for the poor, providing health insurance for the 37 million uninsured Americans and strengthening preventive medicine and health education.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 458 money market mutual funds rose by $1.2 billion, to $295.24 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $39.6 million, to $72.69 billion. The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $19.9 million, to $95.14 billion. The 94 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.26 billion, to $127.41 billion, the institute said.

title: Wajax Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $8,005,000 and $11,178,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included a gain of $165,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss of $296,000 from discontinued operations for the year. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said results have been restated to reflect its decision on March 3 to sell its Pitman Manufacturing group unit in the near future.

title: 30 Nations Move to Deter Boat People
description: Stiffer requirements to discourage Indochinese from seeking refuge in other countries seem inevitable after a three-day conference of 30 nations in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

title: Jane Maas Resigns Post
description: Jane Maas, whose 1986 book, ''Adventures of an Advertising Woman,'' was a woman's answer to David Ogilvy's classic primer on the business, resigned Wednesday as president of Christopher Thomas/Muller Jordan Weiss.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hot Seat in Thrift Crisis
description: Last year, as the savings and loan crisis unfolded, M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, came under intense criticism from Congress, especially for underestimating the size of the crisis and for some of the billion-dollar rescues of sick institutions.

title: Robert Mapplethrope, Photographer, Dies at 42
description: Robert Mapplethorpe, a photographer whose widely exhibited pictures combined classical beauty with sometimes shocking subject matter, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Players Say They Signed With Agents in School
description: Testifying before a Federal jury today at the trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, two National Football League players admitted they signed contracts and accepted loans from the agents before their senior seasons.

title: Spanish Bank May Get Bid
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. of West Germany said Wednesday that it planned to make a friendly takeover bid for the Banco Comercial Transatlantico of Barcelona. The Deutsche Bank already owns 39.05 percent of the bank, known as Bancotrans. Terms of the possible bid were not disclosed.

title: Measles Cools Basketball Fever
description: The elevator stopped on the lowest level of the parking garage of the Civic Center: a downtown shopping mall and the site of the Hartford Coliseum. A quick glance to the left, then the right, revealed that no one was around. That was good. It would be better to be as inconspicuous as possible.

title: Universal Medical Buildings LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: EASTERN REQUESTS BANKRUPT STATUS TO CUT STRIKE LOSS
description: Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in Federal court yesterday in an effort to conserve cash and gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work.

title: Review/Film; How a Notorious Liar Might Have Lived
description: Taking the story of one of the most notorious liars of legend, Terry Gilliam, the director and a member of the Monty Python troupe, has made ''The Adventures of Baron Munchausen.''

title: Edward Powers, 75, Agent in Brinks Case
description: Edward Powers, the Federal agent who helped solve the $2.2 million Brinks armored car robbery in 1950, died Tuesday in Fort Myers, Fla. Mr. Powers, who was later chosen to manage the first modern American lottery, was 75 years old.

title: Old Copyright Treaty: New Shield for U.S. Artists
description: After more than 100 years of semi-isolation, the United States has finally joined in a major international agreement that safeguards the integrity of literary and artistic works.

title: Safelite Glass Investor Gets Chance to Be No. 1
description: Robert H. Morosky helped build the Limited into a major chain of women's clothing stores, but he did so as No. 2 to Leslie H. Wexner, the chain's chairman. Now he wants to build a chain of stores that sell auto glass, and he wants to do it as No. 1.

title: Fluor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Backlog at Jan. 31 was $6,998,000,000 versus the year-ago $5,138,400,000. The company said the increased earnings were due to an accelerating contribution by Fluor Daniel, its engineering and construction operation. It said investments in coal and lead also resulted in improved earnings.

title: Residential Mortgage Investents Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Killer Ruled Eligible For Work Payments
description: A New York State appeals court ruled today that a former Rochester schoolteacher who suffered job-related psychological problems and killed his supervisor 19 years ago should be given workers' compensation.

title: Graham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $63,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,323,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a gain from an accounting change of $347,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $544,000 and $1,272,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Dining Out Guide: Easter Dinner
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Ambassador Grill

title: 3-D Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter and full- year figures are not available because the company did not have sales prior to Jan. 1.

title: Truce May Be Closer in Florida
description: John Brunetti, the owner of Hialeah Park, and Douglas Donn, the president of Gulfstream Park, both visited Hialeah's press box Wednesday. Not only were no blows exchanged, but each man also had nothing but bouquets to toss at his sworn enemy.

title: Enseco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year included a credit of $868,000 from an accounting change. The latest quarter and year loss included a writeoff of $2,399,000 related to an accident at a company facility and the decision to discontinue its gas analysis business.

title: 'Murphy's Law' Series Is Canceled by ABC
description: ABC canceled its second show in a week yesterday, announcing that ''Murphy's Law,'' ABC's 10 P.M. entry on Saturday night, would end after the broadcast of March 18.

title: Chrysler Incentives To Counter G.M.
description: Countering the discount program announced by the General Motors Corporation earlier this week, the Chrysler Corporation introduced a more generous incentive program to take effect on Saturday. Discounts will increase on 15 car and truck models, decrease on 7 and stay the same on 16. The increases in rebates range from $100 for the Omni and Horizon models, which will carry a $500 discount, to $1,250 for the 1988 Conquest, whose rebate will total $2,000.

title: U.S. Charges Russian With Spying And Says He Will Be Sent Home
description: The United States said today that it was expelling a Soviet military attache who was detained Wednesday night and accused of espionage.

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Wilson Sings Porter

title: Market Place; Wickes Investors Left in the Cold
description: BUYING a warrant on a company's stock is a little like placing a bet in Las Vegas on which baseball team will win the World Series. It is a wager on sustained performance over a long period, and the payoff can be great if the buyer's forecast is correct.

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months have been restated to reflect the consolidation of Montana Refining Co., a limited partnership, which was previously accounted for using the equity method. Year-ago quarter and 6 months share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1988. The company said the drop in revenue in the latest quarter adn 6 months is principally due to lower product prices and lower volumes sold.

title: Dog Days of Summer, in March
description: In one of the year's slowest sessions, prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly yesterday.

title: Police Call Death of a Bronx Boy a Murder
description: The death of a 17-month-old Bronx boy this week was ruled a homicide after an autopsy revealed that he was beaten to death, the police said yesterday.

title: Scientists Discover Site of Cold Virus Attacks
description: Scientists reported yesterday that for the first time they had completely analyzed the site at which cold viruses attack human cells. The successful analysis raises the long-range possibility of designing a new class of drugs to combat these widespread causes of human illness.

title: AMERICAN TO LOSE VATICAN BANK JOB
description: An American Archbishop who was at the center of an Italian banking scandal will step down soon as head of the Vatican Bank, and supervision of the bank will pass to a new commission of five cardinals.

title: The Tea Ceremony, as the English Do It
description: To the Editor:

title: Bass Brewing Adds 38 Canada Hotels
description: The British brewing conglomerate Bass P.L.C. agreed to buy the Canadian hotel chain Commonwealth Hospitality Ltd. from Scotts Hospitality Inc. of Toronto for $285 million (Canadian), or about $237.5 million (United States). The purchase involves 38 hotels in Canada totaling 8,742 rooms. Thirty-two of the hotels operate under franchise from the Memphis-based Holiday Corporation, two operate as Briarwood Hotels Inc. and four are under license from the Radisson Hotel Corporation.

title: Atari Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $106.3 million for the quarter and $124.2 million for the year. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $13.3 million. The company said the decrease in operating income for the year and particularly the quarter was mostly attributable to Dram shortages combined with escalating dram costs. The company also said that to insure that going forward Federated Group, now treated as a discontinued item, will no longer have any negative financial impact on the company, as of Dec. 31, 1988, established reserves and recorded writeoffs related to Federated of more than $100 million.

title: Diet Center Inc. Is Suit Target
description: A class action lawsuit brought by 102 franchisees of Diet Center Inc., a chain of weight-loss centers around the country, was filed yesterday against the franchisor and its owners: the Thomas H. Lee Company and a limited partnership of Merrill Lynch and Mr. Lee. The suit was brought after

title: Simple Shrine Symbolizes Hindu-Muslim Rift
description: Every day, khaki-uniformed policemen armed with rifles and bamboo staves ring a simple whitewashed shrine here that has become a symbol of the Hindu-Muslim rift in India.

title: Offering by P.&G.
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due 1990 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes were priced to yield about one-half of a percentage point more than two-year Treasury notes. Underwriters said the issue is noncallable for one year. The notes are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Skolniks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $287,500 from an accounting change. The company said its earnings during the first half of fiscal 1990 will begin to reflect savings associated with a new bagel factory.

title: Drexel Pact Said to Save Bond Unit
description: Under a compromise plan to be put before the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval shortly, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street house best known for its prowess in high-yield ''junk bonds,'' is expected to be able to keep most of its junk bond headquarters in Beverly Hills, Calif., a person close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Egypt Accused Of Big Advance On Poison Gas
description: Egypt has made a major effort to improve its ability to produce poison gas by acquiring the main elements of a plant from a Swiss company, Swiss and American officials say.

title: New Saatchi Division
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Promotions Inc., the promotions arm of the British-American conglomerate, said yesterday that it had formed a new division to generate promotional campaigns for entertainment and consumer product companies. The division will be called Saatchi & Saatchi Entertainment.

title: Strategies For Social Visionaries
description: ''I TRIED this experiment with my kids,'' Tony Schwartz, a media consultant, said yesterday. ''I would burn toast in the morning, and with a stopwatch I'd tell how long it took the children to tell me the toast was burning. Then I would burn toast on another day when the radio was playing, and it took much longer for them to tell me about the toast. Their sense of smell was being lessened by the occupation of their senses with the radio.''

title: Corning Name Change
description: The Corning Glass Works said today that it would ask shareholders at its annual meeting on April 27 to approve a name change to Corning Inc. to reflect the non-glass portion of its operations. The company said it derived one-third of its sales in 1988 from non-glass businesses.

title: Computer Stars on Collision Course
description: The wizards at Sun Microsystems Inc., which makes engineering work stations, have long viewed the Macintosh personal computer of Apple Computer Inc. as a nice toy, not a serious machine. At the same time, the marketeers at Apple have long scoffed that they sell more machines in a month than Sun sells in a year.

title: Turnovers Thwart Nets
description: Alvin Robertson had 29 points, including 13 in a third-quarter stretch that broke the game open, as San Antonio took advantage of the Nets' season-high 32 turnovers for a 112-98 victory tonight.

title: Metro Datelines; Panel Presses Koch To Testify in Private
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch was urged by a New York State commission yesterday to testify in private about his administration's Talent Bank, ''so that we can avoid the necessity of serving subpoenas.''

title: Amrep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,500,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago periods are restated to reflect adoption of FAS 94, which had no effect on net income, and FAS 96, which increased net income by $3,500,000, or 53 cents a share, in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Quiet Time in Trading Circles
description: Dale Murphy, Wade Boggs, Mark Langston, Sandy Alomar Jr. They are the players mentioned most often this spring, the names incessantly brought up in talks about possible trades before the start of the season.

title: Consolidated Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
In Vitro Fertilization Clinics Vary Widely in Success Rates
description: The first national survey of clinics that offer laboratory fertilization services to infertile couples has found wide variation in their success rates, a Congressional committee said today.

title: Music by Amram
description: David Amram, the composer, will present a concert of his music at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 97th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program includes ''Zohar,'' for unaccompanied flute; a Wind Quintet; the New York premiere of ''Blues for Monk,'' for unaccompanied horn, and ''Native American Portraits,'' for violin, piano and percussion. The performers include Susan Carlson, flutist; the Galliard Quintet; Anthony Cecere, a hornist; Eric Lewis, a violinist; Heidi Upton, a pianist, and David L. Smith and Mr. Amram, percussionists. Mr. Amram will also demonstrate various Middle Eastern instruments. Tickets are $10. Information: 860-1863.

title: Acura Legend Ad Shows Appreciation of Shapes
description: As the son of an architect who wrested soaring shapes from steel and concrete in structures like the Gateway Arch, Eric Saarinen is a likely candidate to tinker with commonly accepted ways of presenting cars in television ads. In a new ad for the Acura Legend Coupe, the younger Saarinen shows an appreciation of elegant shapes.

title: Pistols an Issue in Texas
description: Ordinary citizens would be allowed to carry concealed pistols under a proposed bill to sell gun permits to ''law-abiding Texans.'' State Senator Ken Armbrister, the bill's sponsor, said Wednesday that the bill would let people buy $125 licenses ib they had no history of alcohol or drug abuse or trouble with the law. ''Only law-abiding Texans would be able to get one,'' Mr. Armbrister said.

title: Real Estate; Pre-Retirement Homes In Jersey Grow Fancier
description: When pre-retirement condominiums were first being developed 20 years ago on the farmlands of central New Jersey, the emphasis was on simple one-bedroom, one-bath ranch houses no larger than 900 square feet. Now, as new units are added to these developments, they are becoming communities of decidedly more elaborate dwellings.

title: Urgent Relief for Mexico
description: The Bush Administration has abandoned the Baker plan for third world debt with its faulty premise that more debt can solve the problem of too much debt. In its place, the Administration appears to have endorsed debt reduction in the form of interest relief, debt relief or a combination of both. The change is welcome.

title: Metro Datelines; Cost of AIDS Plan Put at $1.6 Billion
description: A five-year state plan to combat AIDS could cost $1.6 billion, according to documents made public yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office.

title: David Goodman Lawyer, 91
description: David Goodman, a lawyer who practiced real-estate law in Manhattan for more than 60 years, died of heart failure Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Columbia Names Dean Of Business School
description: Meyer Feldberg, president of the Illinois Institute of Technology and former dean of the business school at Tulane University, has been named the dean of the Columbia Business School, effective this July.

title: An Exhibition of Instruments at the Met Museum
description: ''This exhibition represents the highlights of the perhaps 1,000 instruments we have acquired since 1980,'' said Laurence Libin, the curator of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's musical instruments department, as he removed tissue paper from a group of clarinets made in Greenwich Village more than a century ago. ''What we want to show is the diversity, quality and variety of the material we have been collecting.''

title: Groundwater Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Review/Art; Spanish Sensuality In Paintings by Zuloaga
description: Anyone who is interested in the social as well as in the esthetic history of 20th-century painting should drop by the Spanish Institute, where a well-chosen retrospective of the Spanish painter Ignacio Zuloaga (1870-1945) fills two floors with paintings and drawings. These are works that in their day enjoyed an exceptional apotheosis in this country. And they still retain a period flavor that we can cut like a rock-hard piece of Spanish cheese.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Feb. 18 about swimming pools misstated fencing requirements for outdoor residential pools in New York State. Barriers at least four feet high are required by state law.

title: Latin American Loan Issues Up
description: Prices of bank loans to Latin American countries rose sharply yesterday in the over-the-counter market, where these discounted loan agreements are traded. The sharp price gains of more than 10 percent for some countries' debt were in expectation of the Treasury's plan for Latin American debt relief to be announced today.

title: Is Life in New York City Really Getting Worse?
description: The rush-hour crowd was waiting for an uptown train at the Times Square subway station one recent evening, noisily entertained by a saxophonist. A cardboard box in front of him beckoned for contributions.

title: Review/Music; A Purist Approach to Modernism
description: In the sense that both groups perform 20th-century music nearly exclusively, the Arditti String Quartet is the British equivalent of America's Kronos Quartet. But there are big differences, as indicated by the Arditti's marathon three-hour-plus concert Wednesday night at Town Hall.

title: Eastern's Workers Are Fighting for Their Rights; Specter of Rail Stoppage
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro Bono
description: * Campbell-Mithun-Esty, New York, owned by Saatchi & Saatchi, will handle a national awareness, membership and fund-raising campaign for Boys Clubs of America.

title: Genzyme Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $152,000 and $229,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $54,000 for the quarter and $147,000 for the year.

title: John Eastman Jr., Arts Administrator, 73
description: John Eastman Jr., an arts administrator, died of heart failure Wednesday on the island of St. Martin in the West Indies. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hastings Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: US Facilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Flutists
description: Robert Dick and Marielana Arizpe, two flutists, are to play new-music solos and duets at 9 P.M. tomorrow at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Tickets are $6.

title: Road to a New Debt Policy: Fed-Treasury Tug-of-War
description: The Government's shift toward a more benevolent treatment of the developing world's debtors is unlikely to go as far as the Bush Administration wanted because of opposition from the Federal Reserve, people involved in the plans and other officials say.

title: William E. Barnes, 56, A Literary Agent, Dies
description: William E. Barnes Jr., an agent for film, literary and theatrical personalities, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pact on Yankee Games
description: Several suburban cable companies yesterday added Yankee broadcasts to their basic package on the Madison Square Garden Network, which includes Knicks and Rangers games. John Malone, head of the group that signed the deal, said there would be ''a modest basic subscriber rate increase.''

title: Review/Film; Caught and Not Caught in Cameroon
description: The new French film ''Chocolat'' is so fine that a lot of people may want - or assume - it to be about more things than it is.

title: Officers Pinned in Patrol Car After Pursuing a Stolen Auto
description: Two New York City police officers were injured yesterday when they were pinned in their patrol car after it collided with a stolen car they were pursuing on Staten Island.

title: Reviews/Film; De Niro as Vietnam Vet and Angler in 'Jacknife'
description: There may be no such thing as a typical Robert De Niro film, but certainly ''Jacknife'' is atypical, since it gives Mr. De Niro so little chance to shine. He appears here as Joseph (Megs) Megessey, a boisterous, glad-handing Vietnam veteran who shows up unexpectedly at the home of an Army buddy named Dave (Ed Harris).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I depart from this place at peace with myself, knowing that I have given a full measure of devotion to my country.

title: Protecting Athletes From Adults
description: Where is Bruce Gehrke now that we really need him? For those who never had the pleasure, the late Bruce Gehrke was a legend at Mineola High School on Long Island, a winning coach and a zealot about protecting athletes from outsiders, namely me.

title: Kitty Dukakis Seeks Privacy To Recover from Alcoholism
description: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, said today that she was an alcoholic and appealed to the news media to let her pursue her recovery in private.

title: British Now Lie Low With Rushdie
description: Some British literary figures who spoke out and signed petitions for Salman Rushdie after the Iranian death threat against him for writing ''The Satanic Verses'' are now beginning to think that a quieter approach would be better both for them and for him.

title: Ex-Unisys Official Admits Paying Bribes to Get Pentagon Contracts
description: In a significant advance in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing fraud, a former vice president of the Unisys Corporation pleaded guilty today to bribing a Defense Department official, drawing from a secret $5 million fund set up with Unisys money.

title: NIGERIA AND ISRAEL MAY RESTORE TIES
description: In a move that might mark a significant shift in strategic alignments in Africa, Nigeria's military Government is considering restoring diplomatic relations with Israel, according to diplomats and news reports here.

title: French Ease Currency Rules
description: The French Government announced today that it was lifting all foreign-exchange controls on companies in France.

title: Campeau Plans Shifts At Federated
description: In another effort to consolidate its operations and cut expenses, Federated/Allied department stores said yesterday that it would set up a centralized regional credit center in a Cincinnati suburb to take over the credit activities of its Ohio stores and its three New York area department stores.

title: Referee Angers Arbour
description: When the game was over and nobody had managed to win it tonight, Coach Al Arbour angrily blamed his team's inability to post a 4-3 regulation victory and its ensuing submission to a 4-4 overtime tie with Philadelphia on a poor performance by the referee Don Koharski.

title: Board of Estimate Sets a Midnight Curfew for Itself
description: The Board of Estimate, whose twice-monthly meetings have been known to end only with the dawn, voted unanimously yesterday at the respectable hour of 8:20 P.M. to prohibit itself from voting after midnight on any item in the future.

title: Restaurants
description: Brive Robert Pritsker, the chef and proprietor of Brive on East 58th Street, is like a brilliant yet puckish schoolboy, capable of dazzling the class with his lightning intellect, yet at the same time prone to scattering tacks on your seat when you go to the water fountain. His genteel town-house restaurant, with its pale yellow walls, Oriental rugs and antique furnishings, suggests tradition and consistency. The eccentric and sometimes outlandish food suggests anything but.

title: Herman Kogan Dies; Chicago Writer Was 74
description: Herman Kogan, a writer whose books celebrated the personalities and institutions of Chicago, died of a heart attack Wednesday while walking near his home in New Buffalo, Mich. He was 74 years old.

title: Reuter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Whitehall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Survival Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: How Eastern's Rivals Are Faring
description: The airline industry has generally absorbed the passengers affected by the strike at Eastern Airlines as a threatened slowdown by pilots across the rest of the industry failed to materialize. Most of Eastern's competitors report increased traffic on previously scheduled flights and some have added extra flights to meet overflow from Eastern. Seats are reported hard to find on flights to Florida and Caribbean destinations served largely by Eastern. Here is an airline-by-airline breakdown: American: Overall traffic ''above forecast'' for current period. New York to San Juan traffic reported heaviest, with some flights full. Adding two round-trip New York-San Juan flights using widebody aircraft on March 11 and 18 to handle traffic from cruise ships. Seats on connecting flights to Caribbean islands scarce. TWA: Reports ''significant increase in traffic'' on New York to Florida and St. Louis to Florida routes. Adding flights during rest of March and April. One extra New York-Miami flight, March 9,10,11. From 12 through April 29 added flights between New York and Miami, Orlando, Tampa, West Palm Beach, Sarasota and For Myers. Delta: Added five flights last Sunday from San Juan and Miami; has ''limited flexibility'' to add more if demand warrants. USAir: Flies to Florida locations from Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Baltimore. Has not added flights and reports heavy bookings on those previously scheduled. Some seats remain but most discount fares are gone. Pan American: Added capacity to New York-Washington and New York-Boston shuttles; two or three flights an hour if needed. Wide-body aircraft added to New York-Boston run. Extra flights added to routes from New York-Tampa, Orlando and Miami routes in February; space available. Continental: Added four flights daily from LaGuardia to Miami, including one wide-body. most flights to Florida out of Newark; some full, seats available on others. Northwest: Flies to Florida from Midwestern cities. Reports a ''pick up in traffic'' since strike, but seats are still available, particularly on connecting flights. Will now accept Eastern tickets without special endorsement.

title: Riverside Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its latest quarter and year revenue included pretax realized invesment gains of $94,000 and $2,072,000, respectively; year-ago quarter and year revenue included pretax realized investment gains of $324,000 and $1,253,000, respectively.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: EASTERN'S BANKRUPTCY Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in an attempt to conserve cash and to gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work. Meanwhile, Eastern continued to operate limited flights. [ Page A1. ] Thousands of Eastern ticket holders, confused and angry, turned travel agents' offices into chaos. [ A18. ] Frank Lorenzo said the criticism he is facing is the price he pays for bringing tough management to a once-sheltered industry. The embattled chairman of Texas Air, which owns Eastern, said the current hostilities had taken their toll. [ A18. ] COMPANIES A former Unisys vice president pleaded guilty to bribing a Defense Department official, drawing from a secret $5 million fund set up by Unisys. Federal prosecutors said the guilty plea by the official and two other men would move the Pentagon fraud inquiry forward ''at a tremendous pace.'' [ A1. ] U S Sprint agreed to buy a 50 percent stake in the first private trans-Atlantic telecommunications cable, in a move to expand its international presence. [ D1. ] Drexel will keep most of its ''junk bond'' operations in Beverly Hills, Calif., under a compromise plan to be put before the S.E.C., a person close to the case said. [ D1. ] Northrop is charged with having never properly tested its cruise missile guidance system, and many nuclear missiles aboard U.S. bombers may not work, according to court papers. [ D3. ] At Ford Motor, one Ford retired from active management, and he indicated that two others of a younger generation would be named to the auto maker's board soon. [ D3. ] Federated/Allied will set up a centralized regional credit center in a Cincinnati suburb for its Ohio and New York stores. [ D3. ] LVMH's new chairman won a court battle that is expected to speed his efforts to oust the head of Louis Vuitton. [ D4. ] The Gap is negotiating to buy American Eagle Outfitters, people close to the talks said. [ D3. ] Emhart rejected a takeover offer from Topper. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL A U.S.-Japanese deal to develop an advanced version of the F-16 fighter is being delayed by differences between the Commerce Department and the Pentagon. [ D1. ] The U.S. shift on third world debtors, toward more benevolent treatment, is unlikely to go as far as the Administration wanted because of opposition from the Fed, officials say. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY The F.D.I.C. took control of 45 insolvent savings and loans with assets of $13.6 billion, bringing to 118 the number of sick institutions it has seized in accord with the Bush bailout plan. [ D1. ] Consumer installment debt grew only slightly in January, in what economists said could be an early sign of a slowdown. [ D4. ] MARKETS Today's unemployment report was on the minds of many participants in the financial markets. Stocks were listless, and the Dow average slipped 4.11, to 2,291.43. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in one of the year's slowest sessions. [ D12. ] The dollar drifted lower in dull trading. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The U.S. and Japan have a ''special relationship'' that has become crucial to the economic development and security of both nations. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Investors in Wickes warrants made a bet, and now they say the rules have been changed on them. Market Place. [ D6. ] Tony Schwartz divulged his theories and trade secrets to help groups use radio and TV ads for social change. Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Jurors Are Asked to Acquit Officers in False-Arrest Case
description: A Federal court jury was urged yesterday to acquit two New York City transit police officers who are charged with falsely arresting eight people in the subways.

title: Kabul Homecoming: The War Looms Ever Larger
description: When Capt. Ghulam Siddiq first glimpsed Kabul today from 24,000 feet, the loss of a leg to a guerrilla rocket in Afghanistan's 10-year civil war was momentarily forgotten. Reaching between the rows of seats on the TU-154 airliner that had carried him from Moscow, he squeezed the arm of a fellow passenger and grinned.

title: Economic Scene; U.S. and Japan: Revising the Ties
description: ''OF the world's 10 largest banks, 10 are Japanese,'' said Charles Manatt, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in addressing a conference here at Duke University on the evolving United States-Japanese ''special relationship.''

title: Baker J Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Davis Returns
description: Robbie Davis is riding again, having accepted two mounts at Santa Anita Park Wednesday almost five months after riding the horse that trampled and killed a fellow jockey, Mike Venezia, last Oct. 13 at Belmont Park. Davis, 27 years old, was so upset by the accident that he would not return to the race track and considered retiring after having won 1,357 races and earned more than $37 million. His return was not auspicious as Hickory Crest finished fourth and Swifterthanthewind third. (AP)

title: Carlesimo Coach of Year
description: A little more than a year ago, the Seton Hall the basketball program seemed in need of new direction and a new head coach. In five years under P. J. Carlesimo, the Pirates had finished no higher than seventh in the Big East.

title: Metro Datelines; Incinerator in Jersey Is Fined $180,000
description: A Warren County garbage-to-energy incinerator has been fined $180,800 for air pollution violations, New Jersey State environmental officials said yesterday.

title: Matco Mart Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $100,150. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Back on the Water
description: The Circle Line sightseeing boats begin their 1989 season of daily three-hour sails around Manhattan today. The boats, which have been sailing since the mid-1940's, depart at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. from Pier 83, at 43d Street and the Hudson River. The number of daily cruises is to increase to 12 by the summer, and evening cruises are to begin on June 10. Tickets are $15; $7.50 for children. Information: 563-3200.

title: William Clay Ford Retires; Two in Family May Get Posts
description: William Clay Ford, vice chairman of the Ford Motor Company, retired today from active management and several policy-making committees at the No. 2 auto maker. At the same time, he indicated that his son William Clay Ford Jr. and nephew Edsel Ford 2d would be appointed to committees of the board within the year.

title: Oppenheimer Capital LP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: There are no comparable year-ago nine-month figures because the partnership began operations on July 9, 1987. Share earnings are in units.

title: Fred Meyer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The latest fourth-quarter results are after a $5.7 million LIFO charge, compared to a $900,000 LIFO charge in the previous year's fourth quarter. The latest-year results are after a $10.3 million charge for LIFO, compared with $4.6 million in 1987.

title: Pall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Year-ago figures were restated to reflect the acquisition of RAI Research Corp. on Sept. 30, 1988, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Johnny Winter Playing
description: Johnny Winter is to lead his blues band, with Buddy Guy and Junior Wells and their band and Dr. John playing piano solos, at 8 tonight at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street (496-7070). Tickets are $20.

title: Honolulu Journal; Apartment Owners Live On Time Bomb Leases
description: Nearly a century and half after King Kamehameha III, under pressure from foreign newcomers, declared the great division of crown lands, land ownership remains the ugliest issue in this most feudal of American states.

title: Abramowicz to Coach
description: Danny Abramowicz, who set all the Saints' major pass receiving marks during his seven-year career with New Orleans, has been named head coach of the Jesuit High School Blue Jays in that city for next season. He was selected from a field of 26 applicants to replace Frank Monica, who resigned to become an assistant coach at Tulane University.

title: Rangers' Losing Streak Grows to 4
description: Brian Mullen, still dazed after having been checked hard in the first period, probably had it easier than his teammates. For reality was a terribly painful thing to have a good handle on in the Ranger locker room tonight.

title: I.B.M. to Sell 3M A Tape Operation
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will sell its magnetic tape manufacturing building and equipment in Tucson to the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the companies said. The 3M Company will supply tape cartridges for I.B.M.'s 3480 magnetic tape subsystem, to be sold under I.B.M. and 3M brand names.

title: Eastern's Workers Are Fighting for Their Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Mark Lamos's Cleaned-Up Version of Shakespeare's Vice
description: The setting of ''Measure for Measure'' is a city teeming with vice. Prostitution and alcohol plague the populace, unchecked by the state's lax law enforcement. Although the city is Vienna, we recognize the scene from closer to home. The questions raised - primarily, Where does justice intersect with morality, and how can it be obtained? - are always with us. And so one initially assumes that the director Mark Lamos is up to something smart in his staging of ''Measure for Measure'' at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. The reigning Duke (Len Cariou) wears a dark suit and summons aides with a Touch-Tone phone. The production's ''Vienna'' is represented by a stage wall splattered with contemporary graffiti. Its inhabitants are racially diverse.

title: Big East Starts Its Annual Run With 4 Games at Garden Today
description: For the last six years, the Big East has brought its four-day tournament to Madison Square Garden with promises of unusual twists and outstanding competition. Without exception, the conference has kept its word.

title: KEY RATES
Sigma Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Reggae and Rebels
description: Gregory Isaacs, a reggae singer, is to perform 10:30 P.M. Sunday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Rebel Souls open at 9 P.M. Tickets are $20.50.

title: Jewish Culture Reviving Under Gorbachev
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Had Control, Coach Insists
description: Ben Johnson's attorney today continued his attempt to show that the sprinter was incapable of making decisions on his own and that he was a foil of a manipulative coach. But much of his cross-examination of Charlie Francis, Johnson's coach for 12 years, failed to produce his desired effect.

title: POLAND'S SENATE TO BE RESURRECTED IN ELECTION PACT
description: Spokesmen for Poland's Government and the Solidarity union said tonight that they had reached broad tentative agreement on restoring Poland's second chamber of Parliament, with members chosen in open and free elections, and on instituting an office of president with broad powers for foreign and security affairs.

title: Novell Inc reports earnings for
Nine Who Have the Certain Something
description: Merce Cunningham observed recently that there seemed to be more and more dancers these days -and good ones. Technical expertise, and even bravura dancing, have become relatively familiar ingredients and may be enjoyed in diverse programs throughout New York City. But there are also dancers who, for all their virtuosity, draw the eye with some mysterious extra essence. And among the many good dancers to be seen this weekend, nine stand out in that special way in performances on concert dance stages and on Broadway.

title: U.N. Rights Panel Takes Limited Action on Cuba
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission agreed today to maintain loose surveillance over Cuba's human rights performance for another year in a decision that appears to fall short of what the Bush Administration was seeking.

title: Stake Raised In Infotech
description: Avacus Partners, an investment group led by the Dutch investment firm of Reiss & Company, disclosed this week that it had raised its stake in Infotechnology Inc. to 9.2 percent from 8 percent.

title: Rock Date
description: Miracle Room, an avant-garde rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $6.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 106, Kings 96: Charles Barkley had 25 points and Ron Anderson added 18 last night as Philadelphia handed Sacramento its 12th loss in 14 games. A jumper by Kenny Smith brought the Kings within 81-74 with 10:27 to play. But Derek Smith, acquired by the 76ers last month after being released by the Kings, sparked an 11-2 surge and a driving layup by Gerald Henderson gave the 76ers a 92-76 lead with 7:34 to play. The Kings never got closer than the final score. SKIING Furuseth Wins Giant Slalom: Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway raced to his second World Cup victory in two weeks yesterday and became the season champion in the giant slalom. Furuseth had a time of 2 minutes 33.70 seconds to beat Hubert Strolz of Austria by 1.76 seconds in the final giant slalom of the season, in Shiga Kogen, Japan. He picked up 25 points to finish with 82. That figure put him in a tie with Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, but Furuseth was awarded the gold medal because he had two second-place finishes and Zurbriggen had one. Each won one giant slalom. (AP) GOLF Roberts Leads Nestle: Loren Roberts overcame cold blustery conditions and shot a five-under-par 66 for a one-shot lead over Nick Price yesterday in the first round of the Nestle Invitational at the Bay Hill Club in Orlando, Fla. Tom Kite, Tom Purtzer and Ted Schulz were another shot back. COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Cal State Fullerton 68, San Diego State 60: Cathy Werth scored 22 points and Gena Miller had 19 points and 12 rebounds yesterday as the Titans won their Big West Conference tournament opener. Julie Evans led San Diego State (21-7) with 16 points and Chana Perry of the Aztecs (23-8), who entered the tournament second in scoring in the Big West with a 23.7 average, was held to 10 points.(AP) TENNIS Lendl, Sanchez Gain: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and fifth-seeded Emilio Sanchez both breezed into the quarterfinals at the $415,000 Eagle Classic of Scottsdale, Ariz., yesterday and Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia upset eighth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov. Lendl eliminated Christo van Rensburg of South Africa 6-0, 6-2 in the final second-round match. Sanchez of Spain beat Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-3, 6-3. Unseeded Jim Courier eliminated Johan Kriek, 6-1, 6-1. (AP)

title: Owner's Bid Rejected
description: Edward Gaylord's attempt to acquire a majority interest in the Texas Rangers was rejected yesterday by American League owners meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Bush's Fierce Loyalty Raises Debate On Whether It Hinders His Judgment
description: Ask George Bush about loyalty, and he will offer an old Richard Nixon maxim: ''We are not going to paint our tails white and run with the antelopes.''

title: Federal Agency Urges Curbs On Seating Near Plane Exits
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is proposing to limit seating in rows next to airplane exits to people able to operate exit doors so that they could help speed evacuation of the plane in an emergency.

title: Senate Confirms Bennett to Lead the War on Drugs
description: William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, won Senate confirmation today as head of the war on drugs. Lawmakers urged him to waste no time in developing a strategy to combat illegal narcotics.

title: Flight International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months share earnings reflect the issuance 1,108,000 common shares in the second quarter of fiscal 1989.

title: East Orange Mayor Charged In Theft of Golf Course Funds
description: Mayor John C. Hatcher Jr. of East Orange was indicted today on charges that he and another man took at least $75,000 in membership and rental fees paid to the city-owned golf course.

title: State Dept. Reports Arab Militants Held 2 Embassy Attaches
description: The State Department said today that armed members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, a radical Palestinian group with headquarters in Damascus, detained two defense attaches attached to the American Embassy in Syria for eight hours last Friday.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Sears Receivables Financing Group Inc., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, is offering $500 million of Sears credit-account pass-through certificates through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Robbins Show Eligible For Top-Musical Tony
description: The Tony Awards administration committee ruled yesterday that ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' is eligible for the award as best musical. The decision makes the show, at least for now, the prohibitive favorite in a category that carries the potential of millions of dollars in ticket sales.

title: MHI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Vigil for Tibetan Rights
description: A citizens group has scheduled a demonstration near the Chinese Embassy for today to show support for human and political rights in Tibet.

title: K Mart Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
Damages in Pipeline Case
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said today that a Federal jury in Beaumont, Tex., had awarded $345 million in damages from the Santa Fe Corporation and its Santa Fe Railroad Company in a lawsuit that accused Santa Fe of illegally conspiring to interfere with the construction of a coal-slurry pipeline by a joint venture Texas Eastern led.

title: ADS WARN OF BANKRUPTCY'S COSTS
description: Personal bankruptcy may have lost much of its stigma, but a consumer counseling organization is warning in a national television ad campaign that it is has not lost all of its sting.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by the President and His Nominee
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush and Representative Dick Cheney in Washington today when Mr. Bush announced his nomination of Mr. Cheney to be Secretary of Defense, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENTS

title: RESULTS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 123, Hornets 90: Byron Scott scored 25 points for Los Angeles last night and James Worthy had 20 as Charlotte, playing at home, suffered its sixth straight loss. The outcome was never in doubt. The Lakers, who made 58 percent of their shots in the game, led by 37-21 after the first period and built their lead to 41 points early in the fourth quarter. Seven Lakers scored in double figures, and Los Angeles outrebounded Charlotte, 52-34. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, playing in his first and last game at the new Charlotte Coliseum, got the Lakers going with 6 points and 5 rebounds in the first six minutes when Los Angeles opened a 19-9 lead. Abdul-Jabbar, who is retiring at the end of the season, was given an oversized rocking chair from the Hornets in a pre-game ceremony.(AP) Bullets 114, Kings 97: John Williams and Ledell Eackles led a balanced attack for Washington, which won its eighth straight at home. The loss was the third straight for Sacramento, the fourth straight on the road. All 12 Washington players scored, 7 in double figures.(AP) SLED-DOG RACING A Prize for Butcher: Susan Butcher won $3,000 worth of silver ingots yesterday for being the first musher to reach the halfway point of the Iditarod Trail race in Alaska, but Martin Buser moved into the lead hours later. Butcher won the money by reaching the ghost town of Iditarod two minutes ahead of Joe Runyan. Buser didn't arrive until two hours later, but he rested only two and a half hours before pushing on for Shageluk, 540 miles from the finish.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Americans Set Relay Record: The United States' 1,600-meter relay team of Clarence Daniel, Chip Jenkins, Ken Lowery and Mark Rowe set a world indoor record last night with a time of 3 minutes 5.21 seconds. The United States, competing in a three-way meet with Britain and the Soviet Union in Glasgow, broke the record of 3:05.9 held by the Soviet Union. (AP) GOLF Three-Way Tie for Lead: Mark Calcavecchia shot a two-under-par 69 yesterday to move into a three-way tie for the lead after the second round of the Nestle Invitational in Orlando, Fla. Calcavecchia, who has won two tournaments this season, finished two rounds over the Bay Hill Club course with a three-under-par 139. He was tied with Loren Roberts, the first-round leader, and Davis Love 3d. Love had Friday's best round, a 67. Roberts shot a 73. Dan Pohl, Tom Kite and Larry Rinker were tied at 140, one stroke back.(AP) TENNIS Lendl Advances: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and fifth-seeded Emilio Sanchez breezed into the semifinals of the Eagle Classic of Scottsdale tournament yesterday in Arizona. Sixth-seeded Brad Gilbert was upset by Amos Mansdorf. Lendl, ranked No. 1 in the world, had little trouble beating Goran Ivanisevic, a Yugoslavian teen-ager, 6-4, 6-4. Mansdorf, an Israeli, beat Gilbert, 5-7, 6-3, 6-0. In the other third-round, late-afternoon match, Sanchez, a Spaniard, eliminated 18-year-old Jim Courier, 6-3, 6-3.(AP)

title: From Benazir Bhutto, a Life Story of Drama and Paradox
description: Daughter of Destiny By Benazir Bhutto Illustrated. 411 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21.95

title: West Berlin Social Democrats and Greens in Pact
description: West Berlin's Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens reached a power-sharing agreement today that clears the way for the first ''Red-Green'' left-wing coalition to rule the city.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 32.

title: Egypt Denies Swiss Machinery Was Acquired to Make Poison Gas
description: Egypt denied today that it had acquired Swiss technology to improve its ability to manufacture chemical weapons.

title: Violinist Named Adviser
description: The violinist Shlomo Mintz has been named music adviser of the Israel Chamber Orchestra, the Mayor of Tel Aviv, Shlomo Lahat, who is also the orchesta's chairman, has announced. Mr. Mintz, who was born in the Soviet Union and raised in Israel, said he would conduct, perform as soloist, and play in chamber ensembles with the orchestra.

title: Judge Derides Steinberg For Giving Interviews
description: The judge who presided over Joel B. Steinberg's murder trial derided Mr. Steinberg yesterday for asking for a Probation Department pre-sentencing interview after he had three times refused the department's requests to interview him while granting interviews to reporters.

title: On Campus, Flirting with Farrakhan
description: LEAD: During the first week of February, the black students' association at Princeton University announced it had raised $10,000 to pay the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, to speak to them. The speech never materalized because the association failed to comply with Princeton's rules that require students to pay a major part the cost of providing security for outside speakers.

title: Archivists Of the Arts Organize
description: Leslie Hansen Kopp has her favorite horror stories about the preservation of cultural history.

title: Countdown Starts for Flight Of Space Shuttle on Monday
description: The countdown began early today for the nation's 28th space shuttle mission, scheduled for launching at 8:07 A.M. Monday. It is the nation's third shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster more than three years ago.

title: New Candidate Tally Shows 703 in School Board Races
description: Revising its earlier announced figure, the New York City Board of Elections said yesterday that 703 candidates had filed nominating petitions to run in the May 2 elections for community school boards.

title: New Poland: Is Either Side Doomed?
description: As Poland's Communists agreed Thursday to restore the upper house of Parliament, some may have wondered whether the move was an unwitting preparation for the party's ultimate political demise, or just a clever step toward co-opting an unwary Solidarity trade union.

title: Mark IV to Sell Unit to Dutch
description: Mark IV Industries agreed today to sell its rubber subsidiary to a Dutch company for $242.5 million and plans to use the proceeds to reduce debt incurred when it acquired the Armtek Corporation in October. The sale of its Baton Rouge, La., Copolymer Rubber and Chemical Corporation to DSM N.V. is expected to be completed within the next two months, Mark IV said. Copolymer, which was part of the Armtek group, manufactures and markets synthetic rubber and specialty polymers, It had sales of about $222.3 million for the year ended Sept. 30. Mark IV paid $575 million for

title: A Way to Go From A to B
description: Ever get to San Francisco and decide to visit a friend in Sausalito? How do you drive there?

title: Georgetown Erases Boston College and Moves Into the Semifinals
description: Georgetown, displaying perhaps its most ferocious defense of the season, broke away early and spent the rest of the game swatting away Boston College shots last night en route to an 82-52 victory in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden. Dana Barros had predicted it. Shortly after scoring 38 points against St. John's on Thursday, the Boston College backcourt ace warned that the Eagles had a mountain to climb last night against Georgetown.

title: Group Gains 7.2% Stake in Anacomp
description: A group led by Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth investor, has acquired 2.6 million shares, or a 7.2 percent stake, of Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis-based software and data-processing concern, for investment purposes only. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it planned to hold talks with the Anacomp management and might meet with other shareholders.

title: Review/Music; Mehta Conducts Israelis
description: The Israel Philharmonic is a fairly frequent visitor to New York, but its concerts are always welcome. That is not because it is a brilliant virtuoso ensemble at the absolutely top international level. It is because, at its best, this orchestra offers deeply musical, songful performances that evince a spirit and a personality more important than mere virtuosity.

title: Vermont Stuns Harvard in Overtime
description: Vermont, a sixth-place team in the league standing this season, upset Harvard in overtime tonight, 3-2, in the ECAC tournament at Boston Garden.

title: Review/Dance; Recalling the Spirit of Doris Humphrey
description: It isn't very often that the works of Doris Humphrey are presented in New York. And so we are in debt to the Philadelphia Dance Company, which performed on Monday night at the Borough of Manhattan Community College's Triplex Theater, in a program of three works by that pioneering American modern dancer as well as dances by Jose Limon and Eleanor King. The question arises, however, as to exactly what we are seeing.

title: A Raider and Owner The Unions Respect
description: There are those who say that Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., should stick to the business where he made his reputation - corporate raiding. And there are those who say that for a corporate raider, he makes a pretty good airline man.

title: Coach Is Hospitalized After Maryland Wins
description: Minutes after his team recorded a stunning upset in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, Coach Bob Wade of Maryland was stricken with chest pains and rushed from the locker room at the Omni to a hospital here.

title: 45 People Are Reported to Survive The Crash of a Jetliner in Ontario
description: An Air Ontario jetliner carrying 69 people crashed in thick woods just after taking off in heavy snow yesterday from Dryden, Ontario, an official for the airline said.

title: Eastern Shuttle's Bargain Fare Draws Thousands
description: After flying virtually empty for a week, the Eastern Airlines shuttle was chock-full of passengers yesterday as thousands of riders took advantage of the airline's new $12 one-way fare.

title: Bresler's Ice Cream
description: The Bresler's ice cream chain has been purchased by an investor group including the division's president for an undisclosed sum from its parent company, Oberweis Dairy Inc. The Bresler's division, which will become Bresler's Industries, is the franchisor of more than 300 Bresler's Ice Cream and Yogurt Shops nationwide. The investment group includes Bresler's president, David Lasky; Alan Marti, a senior vice president and director of operations, and several Chicago business executives. The new owners said they planned to expand the suburban Des Plaines, Ill., company's franchises nationally and possibly internationally. Bresler's was founded in 1929 in Chicago.

title: Seton Hall Shuts Down Connecticut
description: Sometimes Seton Hall seems like a team on an eternal quest for respect. Last season the Pirates were obsessed with getting it; they entered this season trying to build on it. And even after Coach P. J. Carlesimo received his second straight Big East coach of the year award on Thursday, he hinted that the reason he got it was that people still didn't believe Seton Hall was for real.

title: Cuomo and Abrams Tell Ethics Panel of Fund-Raising
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and New York Attorney General Robert Abrams, testifying publicly for the first time about their fund-raising practices, told a state ethics commission today that they deplored asking special-interest groups for money but felt they were forced to use such methods to win re-election.

title: STEIN SEEKING SUPPORT OF G.O.P. AND LIBERALS
description: Andrew J. Stein, a Democrat, has virtually abandoned his New York City mayoral ambitions for this year and is now seeking Republican and Liberal Party endorsements that would guarantee he is re-elected City Council president in a landslide.

title: Bonnies' Coach Out
description: The contract of Coach Ron DeCarli, whose St. Bonaventure team had a 13-15 record for the second season in a row, will not be renewed, according to Lawrence J. Weise, the athletic director.

title: Seven Arrested in Robberies Of Madison Avenue Stores
description: Seven young men were arrested on robbery charges yesterday after they threatened employees and snatched merchandise from three Madison Avenue stores, the police said.

title: Famous Writers Under Attack . . .
description: No sooner had the Famous Writers spoken out in support of the beleagured Salman Rushdie, and declared themselves outraged by an attempted act of international terrorism on the part of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini than the Insufficiently Famous Writers leaped to attack them.

title: Zimbabwe Defense Minister Quits in Corruption Scandal
description: The Zimbabwean Defense Minister said today that he would resign after admitting that he had lied to a judicial inquiry into a corruption scandal involving the sale of scarce new cars.

title: Now as Always, the Battle of the Sexes Is News; Byron Demythified
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Rights Panel Avoids Cuba Issue
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission ended its annual session today without making provisions to review human rights abuses by Cuba again next year, as the Bush Administration wanted.

title: KEY RATES
Flowers, Rich and Poor
description: This year's New York Flower Show, which has been brightening a Hudson River pier since last week and ends today, is bigger and prettier than ever. It also gives the visitor yet more cause to wish for big bucks. On display are a gazebo, a greenhouse, a conservatory, a lily pond, a Japanese tea house and a Chinese pagoda - all in appropriate settings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 11, 1989
description: International

title: Kinney Chief Makes Bid For a Posner Company
description: An investment group led by Andrew N. Heine, chairman and chief executive of Kinney System Inc., said yesterday that it had offered to pay $572 million for the DWG Corporation, which is headed by the Miami financier Victor Posner.

title: Trustee Weighs Polaroid Move
description: The Labor Department has advised the trustee for the Polaroid Corporation's employee stock ownership plan that it should exercise its own judgment in deciding whether to tender the shares in the plan, an official of the trustee said yesterday.

title: New York State Unemployment Rate Rises, From 4.9% to 5.1%
description: The unemployment rate in New York State rose slighty last month, and the New Jersey rate remained unchanged, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: New York State Agencies Are Judge, Jury and Court of Appeals
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Bungling as a Fine Art
description: Devotees of the five previous installments of the endless ''Police Academy'' series will probably like this new one. It has a few good gags and the same energetic, spirited silliness of its predecessors. But if you have found the others to be more predictable than clever, this new one, subtitled ''City Under Siege,'' won't make you a fan.

title: Harold S. Ladas, Professor, 59
description: Dr. Harold S. Ladas, a professor of psychology at Hunter College, died of cancer Tuesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Students Reach Out to Help the Poor
description: ''So, honey, what's your name?'' the man in the soup kitchen asked in his version of a streetwise flirt.

title: Punish the Criminals, Not Lawful Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: Now as Always, the Battle of the Sexes Is News; The Rake Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Cloud Nine Consort
description: A Cloud Nine Consort - Gary Trosclair, trumpeter; Alan Moverman, pianist and synthesizer player; Erik Friedlander, cellist, and Geoffrey Gordon, percussionist - is to perform at the Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, at 15th Street, tonight at 8 P.M. The program includes compositions by three of the ensemble's players, Mr. Trosclair, Mr. Gordon and Mr. Moverman, as well as works by Beethoven, Somei Satoh and McGregor Boyle. Tickets are $5. Information: (718)-965-9221.

title: Rate of Jobless In a Sharp Drop To 15-Year Low
description: The nation's unemployment rate dropped sharply in February, to 5.1 percent, as the economy continued to generate jobs at a brisk pace, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Patents; Financing Inventors' Lawsuits
description: Waging war over water beds may not seem important. But if Charles P. Hall wins his forthcoming patent trial, the self-proclaimed father of the modern water bed could revolutionize the way inventors finance court battles over patent infringement.

title: Soviet Arms Control Expert Tells Congress of Cutbacks
description: A senior Soviet arms control expert told Congress today that the Soviet Union was engaged in the most sweeping restructuring of its military since the 1920's, and he provided some details.

title: A European Arms Pact?
description: Every arms control negotiation combines a concern with the details of what is to be agreed to and, since arms control is not an end in itself, the broader political purpose sought by either side. The negotiations on conventional forces in Europe that have begun in Vienna are no exception.

title: Falwell Bids Employees Give 10% of Earnings to Church
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell told the 2,000 employees of his religious network today that they would be required to be members of his church and donate 10 percent of their income to it.

title: Patents; New Supercomputer Called Much Speedier
description: Two aerospace engineers at Princeton University won a patent this week for a new supercomputer that they contend is 100 times as fast as the current state-of-the-art machines. The computer is a parallel processing machine, in which complex problems are broken down into component parts and solved simultaneously by separate processors.

title: Debt-Policy Shift Set on 3d World
description: Acknowledging ''realities we cannot deny,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady today proposed a major shift in the goals of the industrial world's third-world debt policy.

title: Offer to Brazil By World Bank
description: The World Bank has offered Brazil a credit of $1 billion in the next 18 months for the power sector, the Brazilian Government said today.

title: Newcomer Claims the Title In 35-Pound Weight Toss
description: Christoph Koch of Northeast Louisiana, who has been throwing the 35-pound weight for less than two months, became the first winner of a final at the 1989 National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships today at the Hoosier Dome.

title: A Wiser Fate for Shoreham
description: When Long Islanders sweat in the dark during next summer's electricity blackouts, as now seems possible, they'll likely wonder whom to blame. The answers will be: (1) Gov. Mario Cuomo, (2) Suffolk County and (3) themselves.

title: Macon Wins Award
description: Mark Macon of Temple, who last year was selected as the Atlantic 10 Conference's top freshman basketball player, was voted the conference's player of the year yesterday. Macon, the first player to receive both awards, finished his second season with 1,234 points and was joined on the all-conference first team by Steve Berger and Darryl Prue of West Virginia, Tom Hovasse of Penn State and Tom Savage of Rutgers.(AP)

title: Review/Theater; Vacation, Incest and the H-Bomb, in 3 One-Acters
description: According to its stated credo, the Manhattan Class Company is ''dedicated to finding, developing and producing a new generation of playwrights and theater artists.'' Such goals and objectives are to be heartily applauded, but judging by Evening A of the company's 1989 festival of new one-acts, someone needs to organize a search party.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters in some copies yesterday about violence in the Israeli-occupied territories misstated the number of deaths. Two Palestinians died - one after a clash in Gaza City and one near Ramallah.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I think it's time to let emotions heal now, let the scars begin to heal.'' - Senator Sam Nunn. [ 10:2. ]

title: Fred Mogubgub, 61, Film and TV Animator
description: Fred Mogubgub, an artist and animator, died of bone cancer on Thursday at his home in Cliffside Park, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Robert B. Betts, 66, Ex-Chief of Ad Agency
description: Robert B. Betts, former chairman of the William Esty advertising agency, now Campbell-Mithun-Esty, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bank Board Chief Assailed On Savings-Crisis Record
description: An official of the General Accounting Office told a Congressional hearing today that the liabilities of the savings industry's insurance fund now exceed its assets by $56 billion, four times the total of a year ago.

title: Now as Always, the Battle of the Sexes Is News; Carpetmonger Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward H. Mahla, 74, Lawyer for Shipowners
description: Edward H. Mahla, a lawyer specializing in maritime law, died of cancer Wednesday at Calvary Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: S.I. Ferry Malfunctions Delay Commuters
description: Thousands of commuters were delayed in Manhattan last evening after the Staten Island Ferry developed electrical problems in a landing slip and in one of its ferries.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6, 28 Skepticism over a European market to be unified in 1992 is growing among Western European politicians and citizens as hard decisions loom on pivotal issues, like a European central bank. Page 1 Jonas Savimbi has ordered torture and murder of high-ranking Angolan dissenters for many years within the ranks of his U.S.-backed guerrilla movement, former supporters asserted. 1 Apartheid was flatly condemned in South Africa by the main Afrikaner church for the first time. It occurred during a landmark five-day meeting with the church's mixed-race and black counterparts. 1 Sudan agrees to food relief but skepticism persists 4 An airport in a strategic Afghan city was reopened by the Government just days after guerrilla forces said they had taken it, the Kabul Government said. 3 The Soviet military is restructuring itself in the most sweeping manner since the 1920's, a Soviet arms control expert told Congress, providing some details about the effort. 6 Pope names three Bishops for Lithuania 6 News analysis: The move in Poland to restore the upper house of Parliament has raised questions about the Communist Party: Is it unwittingly preparing its political demise, or just cleverly co-opting Solidarity? 5 A West Berlin power-sharing pact was reached by Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens, clearing the way for the first ''Red-Green'' coalition to rule the city. 28 Israel's Foreign Minister visits the United States with a schedule of high-level meetings and a mandate to find out if Washington expects a serious peace initiative next month. 3 Egypt denies Swiss machinery was aquired for poison gas 6 An Air Ontario jetliner crashed just after taking off in heavy snow from Dryden, Ontario. At least 45 survivors were reported among the 69 passengers. 5 The U.N. body for human rights ended its annual session without making provision to review human rights abuses by Cuba again next year, as Bush officials had wanted. 5 National 7-10, 32 President Bush's Defense nominee is Representative Cheney of Wyoming, Mr. Bush said, moving swiftly after the Senate's defeat of John Tower. 1 News analysis: The new nominee is, unlike John Tower, universally liked and admired. The quick announcement represents the President's bid to regain momentum. 10 Man in the news: Dick Cheney is a respected politician with a straight-arrow image, a reputation for toughness and a heavy resume. But he has had little direct involvement in military affairs. 10 Eastern Airlines has permission from a Federal bankruptcy judge to continue paying non-striking employees, the airline said. That permits it to continue limited flights. 1 Will that ticket for Eastern fly? Thousands of ticket-holders are asking what to do, and officials are finally providing some answers. But hopes for immediate refunds are dim. 8 Shuttle flight bargain draws thousands 8 Eastern and union struggling for loyalty of pilots 8 February unemployment dropped by three-tenths of a percentage point to 5.1 percent, the Government said, and joblessness of more than six months was at a nine-year low. 1 New York jobless rate passes 5% 32 Interest rates rise on reports of job growth 38 Robert McFarlane in the North trial testified that President Reagan told him not to tell Congress about the $1 million that a third country contributed monthly for the Nicaraguan rebels. 1 A captian's wife escaped a bombing of her car that the F.B.I. suspects was a terrorist attack. She is married to the captain whose ship mistakenly shot down an Iranian airliner last July. 1 Programs to give addicts needles to stem AIDS spread have touched off conflict between Health Secretary Sullivan (for Federal aid) and the new anti-drug chief, William Bennett (against it). 7 A Bush ethics panel recommended several ways to tighten ethics rules, including a uniform limit on outside income and the use of special prosecutors to investigations. 7 A program to detain immigrants from Central America was defended by the immigration commissioner, who dimissed Congressional concerns that the plan was unfair. 9 Countdown for a shuttle launching began. The 28th shuttle mission's liftoff is scheduled for 8:07 A.M. Monday. It is the third flight since the Challenger disaster. 7 Warrant officer gets 40 years for spying 9 Regional 29-32 Governor Cuomo told an ethics panel that he deplored asking special interests for money but felt forced to do so to win re-election. New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, testified likewise. 29 A Broadway subway train crashed into a parked train on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, jolting hundreds of passengers and transit workers, derailing both trains and halting subway service for much of the day. 29 Alison Gertz has never injected drugs or had a blood transfusion. She is a 23-year-old professional who describes herself as ''not at all promiscuous.'' She has AIDS and is going public about it. 29 News analysis: A Federal ruling that unlimited punitive damages for the same wrongdoing are unconstitutional is important, lawyers said. The issue is already before the United States Supreme Court. 30 ''Tilted Arc'' is to be removed today from a lower Manhattan plaza. The vast sculptural expanse that provoked heated artistic controversy will be stored in Brooklyn. 29 City Council President Andrew Stein of New York City abandoned his mayoral ambitions this year but is laying the groundwork for a mayoral candidacy in four years. 31 Ward takes steps to improve services for Latinos 31

title: Eastern and Union Vie for Loyalty of Pilots
description: A tug-of-war has begun between the pilots' union and Eastern Airlines for the loyalty of pilots in the week-old strike by machinists that has paralyzed the airline.

title: Moving Day Arrives for Disputed Sculpture
description: The vast sculptural expanse of ''Tilted Arc,'' which provoked one of the greatest artistic controversies in recent New York City history, is to be removed today from the lower Manhattan plaza for which it was commissioned. It will be taken off to storage in Brooklyn.

title: Stuck With Tickets? Some of the Options
description: Eastern Airlines spokesmen, travel industry officials and consumer experts yesterday began to provide some answers to the questions asked by the thousands of worried Eastern ticket-holders who have been swamping the offices and telephone lines of their travel agents, hoping for a refund or a flight on another airline. Ticket-holders hoping for an immediate refund are out of luck, these officials said, and people willing to pay more to reach their destinations on time should use another airline. Here are answers to some of the most frequently asked questions about how the strike is affecting ticket-holders: Refunds on Tickets

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Richard Bruce Cheney; Bush's Safer Choice
description: In nominating Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming as Secretary of Defense today, President Bush picked a well-respected politician with a reputation for toughness and a powerful political resume, but with relatively little direct involvement in military affairs.

title: Gino P. Cofacci, Chef, 75
description: Gino P. Cofacci, a retired pastry chef, died of cancer March 1 in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Recital; Troyanos Sings Mahler
description: For several years now I have thought on and off about writing a fan letter to Tatiana Troyanos, who gave a song recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. ''Dear Ms. Troyanos,'' it would say, ''thanks for showing up tonight and singing your part.''
