It could come after any one of the dozens of Metropolitan Opera evenings in which the mezzo-soprano has performed with passion and sincerity, has focused everyone's attention on the meaning of the piece, has put her heart and energies into her work and communicated to the public, no matter how dreary, unprepared, preoccupied or simply blank her colleagues may have been.

title: Immigration Official Warns Aliens May Be Held in Jail
description: Brushing aside Congressional critics who say the Federal Government's policy of detaining Central American refugees is unfair and ineffective, the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service has warned that if illegal immigrants continue to cross the border he will house them in jails and military stockades.

title: Afghanistan Says Airport Is Reopened as Battle for Eastern City Continues
description: The Government announced that the airport in a strategic contested city was open again today, just days after guerrilla forces said they had taken it.

title: Kermit Beahan, 70, Bombardier On Plane That Dropped A-Bomb
description: Kermit K. Beahan, who dropped the atomic bomb on Nagasaki, Japan, died of cardiac arrest Thursday at St. John Hospital in nearby Nassau Bay, a day after undergoing prostate surgery. He was 70 years old and lived in Clear Lake, a Houston suburb.

title: Review/Music; A Leinsdorf 20th-Century Sampler
description: Erich Leinsdorf has always been good at assembling programs, and for his current subscription concerts with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, he has put together an ingenious one. The music is all from the 20th century, but conservatively so - nothing after 1942 or overtly dissonant, but two late Romantic scores along with two neo-Classical ones.

title: Europe, Facing Tough Decisions, Now Cautious on a Single Market
description: After an initial period of high excitement about the creation of a single market of 320 million consumers by the end of 1992, Western European politicians and citizens have started to register skeptical and even frightened accents as hard decisions loom on pivotal issues.

title: Announcing Divorce, Rep. Kennedy Drops Bid for Dukakis Job
description: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, who was considered an early favorite in the 1990 race to succeed retiring Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, announced today that he and his wife are separating and that he will not run for governor.

title: Now as Always, the Battle of the Sexes Is News
description: To the Editor:

title: Main White Church In South Africa Says Apartheid Is Sinful
description: The main Afrikaner church has for the first time unequivocally condemned apartheid.

title: Guidepost; Preparing for Planting
description: Cabin fever ends. Gardening begins again. What to do first? The yard needs a thorough spring cleanup: remove dead grass, leaves and twigs, dropped tree fruits and other debris of winter. Cut back overgrown hedges, shrubs and small trees. All this gives you a head start before planting, which won't start until next month after the soil dries out. Don't throw all those trimmings out; if they're small enough to decompose easily, add them to the compost pile. Here are the tools you'll need for the basic cleanup. Rakes: Steel tines are strongest; bamboo is gentler on the turf, but won't clean dead grass out as well. Rubber tines are new and have a wide swath but are clumsier to handle. Bent handles are easier on your back and less awkward to maneuver. Pruners: Folding saws with steel blades and wooden handles cut branches and small trees and store easily. Long-handled loppers reach easily into shrubs to grip and cut branches. Short-handled snippers trim twigs and some shrubbery. Gloves: Heavy-duty material with latex coating offers the most protection. For lighter work, goatskin is more comfortable and washable. Cloth is not practical for yard work.

title: Army Spy Gets Long Term and $50,000 Fine
description: An Army warrant officer who admitted receiving more than $100,000 from 1983 to 1988 to provide classified military information to East Germany and the Soviet Union was sentenced today to 40 years confinement and was fined $50,000.

title: Your Money Long-Term Care And Insurance
description: Growing old gracefully is costly in America, and it is becoming costlier as medical costs escalate and employers aggressively seek ways to control the costs of health-care benefits, particularly for retirees. Indeed, much of the Conference Board's 1989 Employee Benefits Conference in New York earlier this week was devoted to health care.

title: Review/Music; Soviet Soprano Returns As Tatyana in 'Onegin'
description: Reading the entrails before the season's first performance of ''Eugene Onegin'' on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Opera, even a cautious seer might have predicted a dire outcome for Tchaikovsky's beloved work. The scheduled Tatyana, Mirella Freni, had taken ill and gone back to Italy to recuperate. (She is expected to return to the cast for the third performance, on March 18.) In Miss Freni's place, portraying Pushkin's heroine, was Makvala Kasrashvili, a Soviet soprano who made her Metropolitan debut in the same part in 1979 but had not been engaged here since. Of the nine other principals, seven were singing their roles for the first time with the company.

title: Drive to Strip 'North' From 'Dakota' Gains
description: A committee of the Legislature has voted 7 to 3 to rename North Dakota just plain Dakota, junking an ''unimaginative, unattractive, ordinary'' word.

title: WITH TIRES
description: To most people, tires are boring. They are black. They are round. They hold air - sometimes - and they are just there.

title: INSIDE
description: Managua Prisoner Release

title: Yanks Lose in Bid for Dykstra but Beat Mets on the Field
description: Right now, there is no deal. The Mets and the Yankees met, talked, and drew up lists of players, but when the two sides emerged late this morning, they squelched any possibility that a trade might take place.

title: Francis Urges Cleanup
description: As he ended eight days on the witness stand yesterday at a Canadian inquiry into drugs and sports, Ben Johnson's coach said he hoped his testimony detailing the use of steroids by the world's fastest sprinter and other athletes he trained would lead to a cleanup of track and field.

title: Mr. Atwater's Vow to Blacks
description: There were bad omens both for the Republican Party and black voters in the resignation last week of Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman, from the board of trustees of Howard University. He quit in the face of a student protest that, he feared, might lead to bloodshed.

title: Prof. Albert Fein, 58, Urban Studies Expert
description: Prof. Albert Fein, a historian and an authority on the work of the landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58 years old.

title: John Cassidy Jr., Executive, 76
description: John Tobin Cassidy Jr., a retired shipping executive, died of heart failure Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Fort Worth. He was 76 years old and lived in Fort Worth.

title: Subway Crash In Manhattan Injures 50
description: A crowded Broadway-local subway train slammed into a parked revenue train on the Upper West Side of Manhattan early yesterday, jolting hundreds of passengers and transit workers, derailing both trains and halting subway service for 35,000 riders much of the day.

title: Eagle Industries Ends Ransburg Bid
description: Eagle Industries today dropped its $22.50-a-share bid for the Ransburg Corporation, an Indianapolis-based industrial equipment maker, after reviewing information furnished by Ransburg. A lower bid by Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $21 a share, or a total of about $170 million, will proceed, however. Illinois Tool Works, based in Chicago, makes industrial components and other specialty products.

title: Philip D. Reed, Former Chairman Of General Electric, Is Dead at 89
description: Philip D. Reed, a former chairman of the General Electric Company and a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died yesterday at his home in Rye, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: I.M.F.-World Bank Harmony Sought
description: At a time when their relations are strained, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have been thrown into the front line in a global battle to try to reduce the stock of debt, last valued at more than $1.3 trillion, that is crushing economies of the third world.

title: Housing Completions
description: Completions of new homes and apartment buildings in the nation declined 2.3 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.49 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Israel to Use Talks to Gauge U.S. on Mideast Peace
description: Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens begins a weeklong visit to the United States today with a heavy schedule of high-level meetings and a mandate to find out whether Washington expects Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to proffer a serious peace initiative when he visits the White House next month.

title: Frederick Moseley Jr., 75, Former Banker
description: Frederick R. Moseley Jr., former executive vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died of bone cancer yesterday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Jericho, L.I.

title: New Curbs On Gasoline By E.P.A.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, acting to reduce urban smog, announced new rules today to limit gasoline fumes this summer.

title: Dr. Frank Curran, Veteran Psychiatrist And Professor, 84
description: Dr. Frank J. Curran, a Manhattan psychiatrist, died Wednesday at New York Hospital after being hit by a car. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan. From 1945 to 1947, he was chief psychiatrist at St. Vincent's Hospital. He resigned from the post after Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, then a professor at Catholic University, denounced psychoanalysis as an escapist substitute for confession. Dr. Curran also withdrew from other posts in the Archdiocese of New York, as psychiatric consultant in the Chancery Office and expert in the archdiocesan matrimonial court.

title: Sudan Agrees to Food Relief but Skepticism Persists
description: Under increasing international pressure, the Sudanese Government says it has agreed to large-scale deliveries of relief food intended to avert a repetition of the hundreds of thousands of deaths from starvation that occurred last year.

title: Unlikely AIDS Sufferer's Message: Even You Can Get It
description: Alison L. Gertz wasn't supposed to get AIDS.

title: NORTH TRIAL TOLD OF REAGAN ORDER
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, testified today that Ronald Reagan told him not to tell Congress about contributions to the Nicaraguan rebels from a third country.

title: Private Care Managers: One-on-One Assistance for the Aged
description: As the number of Americans over age 65 increases, services to meet their needs are growing rapidly.

title: An Attempt To Recover; Bush Seeks to End Rancor Over Tower
description: The caterwauling battle over the nomination of John G. Tower to be Defense Secretary, which ended in the Senate's defeat of Mr. Tower on Thursday, robbed President Bush of precious political and governmental energy at a crucial moment.

title: Pope Names 3 Bishops for Lithuania
description: Pope John Paul II named three resident Bishops today for Soviet Lithuania, a step seen as an important symbol for Roman Catholics in that Baltic republic and also a hint that progressively closer relations may be developing between Moscow and the Holy See.

title: Finding Someone to File the Insurance Forms
description: Because Medicare and other insurance programs require filling out complicated forms and following complicated procedures, the elderly, the very people these programs are supposed to help, frequently fail to take advantage of them. So medical-claims companies will step into the breach - for a fee.

title: Ex-Allies Say Angola Rebels Torture and Slay Dissenters
description: Former supporters of Unita, the United States-backed Angolan guerrilla movement, have asserted that the group's leader, Jonas Savimbi, has ordered the torture and killing of high-ranking dissenters in his ranks over many years.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Talks
description: A Soviet-American trade conference will be held in San Franciso on May 23 to discuss the development of trade between the West Coast and the Soviet Far East. San Francisco's Mayor, Art Agnos, said Thursday that the conference would draw high-ranking regional business experts and scientific experts from both the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Lindsay String Quartet
description: The Lindsay String Quartet, an ensemble from England, is to perform Haydn's Quartet in G (Op. 54, No. 1), Britten's Quartet No. 3 (Op. 87) and Beethoven's Quartet in F (Op. 135) on Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $12. Information: 874-6770.

title: James Satterwhite, 52, Social Worker, Is Dead
description: James Satterwhite, a social worker and educator, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rates Soar On Big Rise In New Jobs
description: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury debt issues plunged after the Government reported an unexpectedly large increase in new jobs last month.

title: Eyeball To Eyeball With Eternity
description: About 15 years ago Evel Knievel, who used to break his bones for a living, came to Manhattan to promote his forthcoming attempt to raise motor sports to an unparalleled height. He would attempt to soar across the mile-wide, 600-foot-deep Snake River Canyon in a steam-powered, open-pit, rocketlike contraption called a Sky-Cycle.

title: Vera Vento Weds Dr. Eugene Jacobs
description: Vera Cecelia Vento, a psychotherapist, and Dr. Eugene Leslie Jacobs, a psychiatrist, both in private practice in New York, were married yesterday. Justice Stanley Sklar of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated in his chambers.

title: Ueberroth Requests Ticket-Price Freeze
description: While meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., with major league club owners for the last time before leaving office March 31, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday asked the 26 teams to impose a voluntary freeze on ticket prices for the next three years, which he said would amount to forgoing about $200 million.

title: Audi Gets a Lift From Safety Study
description: Audi of America says it feels vindicated by a Federal study concluding that drivers' ''misapplying'' their feet to gas and brake pedals was the principal cause of sudden, uncontrolled acceleration in some Audi 5000's.

title: Excerpts From Brady Remarks on Debt
description: Following are excerpts from the text of Treasury Secretary's Nicholas F. Brady's remarks today to the Brookings Institution and the Bretton Woods Committee conference on third-world debt:

title: Judge Accepts Insanity Plea From a Former Prosecutor
description: A former Federal prosecutor was judged not guilty by reason of insanity today in an agreement with the Government over a case in which she delivered anonymous threats to herself and a Federal magistrate, while pursuing the extradition of two Sikhs accused of terrorism in India.

title: Changes at Drexel Continue
description: Continuing the personnel changes that began earlier this year, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday announced new appointments and shifts in the operating structure of parts of the firm.

title: After Tower: High Road and Low
description: President Bush has acted quickly and adroitly to transcend the Tower fiasco by nominating Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming as Secretary of Defense. Mr. Cheney is smart, generally knowledgeable about national security, very conservative, a party loyalist, honorable and exceedingly popular among Democrats and Republicans. Mr. Bush added to this healing decision yesterday by relegating the bitter debate over John Tower to ''history.''

title: Nicaragua Gives Date for Freeing 1,894 Prisoners
description: The Nicaraguan Government announced today that it would pardon 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard by March 19.

title: Burn Rushdie Book, Iran Says
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said today that the furor over the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' could be resolved by burning all existing copies of the book and banning it forever.

title: Ward Lists Steps to Improve Services in Hispanic Precincts
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, replying to the complaints of a coalition of more than 30 Hispanic groups, will take steps to improve police services in precincts with large Latino populations, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTS A LEADER IN HOUSE FOR DEFENSE POST
description: Moving swiftly to select a new Secretary of Defense after the Senate's defeat of John G. Tower, President Bush announced today that he would nominate Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, a popular and respected member of the Republican leadership.

title: Stenmark Retires
description: Ingemar Stenmark, the slalom and giant slalom specialist who won a record 86 World Cup races in his 16-year career, retired yesterday after a final race. The Swedish star missed a gate just seconds after he started the first run of a World Cup slalom race in Shiga Kogen, Japan. But Stenmark, who turns 33 in a week, was not disappointed. ''It's a sunny day, a good day to end,'' he said. ''I'm tired and want to stop.''(AP)

title: Pittsburgh Storms Back To Defeat Villanova
description: After Pitt's coach got angry last night, the players got even.

title: Tibetan Asks Deng to Lift Martial Law
description: The Dalai Lama appealed today to Deng Xiaoping, the senior Chinese leader, to use his influence to lift martial law in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.

title: Mullen Cleared to Play
description: Brian Mullen, who was blindsided in the first period of Thursday night's 3-2 loss in Detroit, has been cleared to play tonight against the Capitals in Landover, Md.

title: VW Cutting Costs
description: The West German car maker Volkswagen A.G. says it plans to import parts and engines from China and East Germany to lower its high production costs at home. ''Early next year we will start exporting engines from Shanghai to Europe for our own use,'' said Dr. Carl Hahn, management board chairman of Volkswagen A.G., West Germany's biggest car producer and the fourth biggest in the world. In addition, he said, an engine plant in East Germany will start supplying engines this year. Dr. Hahn was interviewed at the Geneva International Motor Show, which runs until March 19.

title: Time Out for Coach
description: Coach Bernie Bickerstaff of the Seattle SuperSonics was reported to be in stable condition yesterday after he was hospitalized Thursday for exhaustion and dehydration.

title: Ruling Raises the Question: Are Unlimited Damages Safeguards or Overkill?
description: The Constitution says that criminals may not be tried twice for the same crime. But is it unconstitutional for a corporation that has willfully manufactured or distributed an unsafe product to be punished repeatedly for it?

title: Iowa TV Station for Sale
description: Iowa's first television station, KWQC-TV of Davenport, has been offered for sale by Palmer Communications Inc. William Ryan, president and chief executive of Palmer, a privately held communications company based in Des Moines, said this week that Palmer had hired Howard Stark, a New York television broker, to sell the station. Palmer officials said it is worth more than $45 million. Palmer agreed last month to buy KTVY-TV of Oklahoma City from Knight-Ridder Inc. Terms of that sale were not disclosed.

title: American Jews Can Disagree Over Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bush Aides at Odds on Giving Needles to Addicts
description: Aides to William J. Bennett, head of the Bush Administration's anti-drug effort, have protested plans by the Department of Health and Human Services to support local programs that give drug addicts hypodermic needles in an effort to stem the spread of AIDS.

title: Corrections
description: Headlines on Thursday with a front-page article about a massacre of Polish officers in World War II, and with the article's continuation, located the Katyn Forest incorrectly in some editions. It is in the Soviet Union.

title: Dow Off 9.29, to 2,282.14, on Jobless Report
description: LEAD: The stock market retreated yesterday in the face of a Government report on employment that increased fears that the Federal Reserve may push up interest rates to curb inflationary pressures.

title: Housing Group Protests an Eviction by Columbia
description: Members of Housing for All demonstrating outside Low Library at the university yesterday. They were protesting the eviction of a former student, Irving Ruderman, from a university apartment on West 119th Street in which he had been living since 1971. A university spokesman, Fred Knubel, said Mr. Ruderman was evicted because he had not taken classes at Columbia since moving in. Mr. Ruderman was first ordered evicted from the apartment by a city court in 1978. (NYT/John Sotomayor)

title: Bush Ethics Panel Would Limit Officials' Extra Income
description: A commission created by President Bush recommended several proposals today to tighten Federal ethics laws and regulations, including a uniform limit on outside income accepted by members of Congress and other senior Federal officials.

title: Reflections by (and Plaudits for) Gregory Peck
description: With the usual pomp and more than the usual respect, Hollywood crowded into a ballroom Thursday night to honor Gregory Peck, whose screen image - from his first starring role as a priest in ''Keys of the Kingdom'' to his Academy Award-winning role as a small-town Southern lawyer defending a black man in ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' - has been composed of equal parts of decency, virtue and moral strength.

title: Syracuse Turns Back Providence
description: It took all the resilience Syracuse had to survive its Big East tournament opener yesterday against Providence.

title: Principal to Be Suspended Over Strippers
description: Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School portrayed in the film ''Lean on Me,'' has been ordered suspended by the superintendent of schools because he arranged a school assembly at which strippers performed, officials said.

title: Teeth, Picked
description: Last fall, University of Michigan anthropologists showed that human tooth size has been shrinking twice as fast in the last 10,000 years as in the previous 90,000. Why? One night a Neanderthal threw a flash-frozen hunk of mammoth on the fire and rendered redundant the kind of choppers one needs to make mincemeat out of raw flesh.

title: Eleanore L. K. McGroarty, Philanthropist, 83
description: Eleanore Lucille King McGroarty, a Brooklyn philanthropic leader, died of a stroke Wednesday at Greenwich Woods (Conn.) Medical Center. She was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: The Brats of Spring
description: The idea of baseball players as boys is embedded in popular mythology, thanks to the works of Ring Lardner, who spent a lot of time with ballplayers a long time ago and was fascinated by their childishness.

title: A Sultan With His Feet Planted in Two Worlds
description: Among the leaders of the Islamic faith, there are some who, in their zeal and absolutism and loathing of Western ideals, seem products of another era. Ibrahim Dasuki, the new Sultan of Sokoto, is not one of them.

title: About New York; Kitty Genovese: Would New York Still Turn Away?
description: ''For more than half an hour 38 respectable, law-abiding citizens in Queens watched a killer stalk and stab a woman in three separate attacks in Kew Gardens.'' - The New York Times, March 27, 1964 So began a story that shook this city's soul. Except for one man who called the police after the woman was already dead, none of the 38 lifted a hand for Catherine Genovese, Kitty to the neighborhood. Apathy had taken on a human face and that face belonged to Kitty.

title: Bridge; As spring nationals begin in Reno, pairs championship ends.
description: For 3,000 bridge players, today was a beginning - the beginning of the spring nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. For a few, it was also an ending, the end of the Grand National Pairs Championship. It began last summer at the grassroots level and progressed to the final, played here Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Soviets Denounce Expulsion Of a Diplomat From the U.S.
description: The Soviet Union today denounced the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat from the United States but stopped short of pledging retaliation. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, called the expulsion of the envoy, Lieut. Col. Yuri N. Pakhtusov, a provocation but did not say what effect the episode might have on relations.

title: On L.I., Appropriately, a Tribute to Motoring
description: When the industrialist William K. Vanderbilt Jr. completed a 48-mile toll road from Queens to Lake Ronkonkoma in Suffolk County in 1911, his pet project became the nation's first modern parkway.

title: Illinois Central Agrees To Prospect Merger
description: Six weeks after receiving the offer, the Illinois Central Transportation Company agreed today to merge with the Prospect Group for $20 a share, or roughly $435 million.

title: Blast Wrecks Van of Skipper Who Downed Iran Jet
description: The wife of the captain of the U.S.S. Vincennes, the Navy missile cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet in July, escaped uninjured this morning in what Federal agents suspect was a terrorist bombing.

title: U.S.-European Trade Talks
description: Top American trade negotiators met today with officials of the European Community for talks that are expected to focus on the contentious issue of farm subsidies.

title: Nissan Price Rise
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said it would raise the price of its two-door Pathfinder models by an average of $1,500 effective Monday in response to a recent Treasury Department ruling that the vehicle was intended primarily for commercial use and was therefore subject to a 25 percent import duty. The price of the basic model rises 11 percent, to $15,399, and the overall price increase represents less than half of the added burden of the duty. Nissan said the remainder of the cost would be borne by the company's subsidiary in the United States and by its dealers.

title: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE LETS EASTERN PAY NONSTRIKING STAFF
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had received permission from a Federal bankruptcy judge to continue paying its nonstriking employees, a corporate life-saving maneuver that permits the beleaguered airline to continue its limited flights.

title: Have a Ticket on Eastern?
description: Thousands of travelers with tickets for Eastern flights are asking, and finally getting, answers to their questions about refunds. Page 8.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Why Some Hands Get So Cold
description: LEAD: UNTIL LAST FALL, THE patient had no idea anything was wrong. She considered it a nuisance that, in a cool room, her hands might tingle and feel numb for a few minutes, or turn pale or blue. Lots of people have cold hands. But her friend's comment at a football game alarmed her: ''Your hands are so white!

title: Poll Finds Public Favors Sharp Cut in Arms Funds
description: At a time when concern about war and international tension is as low as it has been at any time in the last 50 years, the American public favors sharp reductions in military spending to reduce the budget deficit while it opposes cuts in Medicare and Social Security, according a poll released last week.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits. To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave. I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment. Would car windshield-washer fluid be a better alternative ?

title: Return of an Impudent Original
description: The arrival of SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS ON the video shelves (MCA Home Video, $29.95) is happy news for fans of Preston Sturges, which should mean everybody who likes movies. This 1942 satire on Hollywood's pretentions to social significance features Joel McCrea as a director of such items as ''Hey-Hey in the Hay'' who poses as a tramp in order to experience Life - and to his confusion and our edification, actually experiences some of it.

title: Dokes Is Stopped By Holyfield in 10th
description: Evander Holyfield won the Continental Americas heavyweight title tonight when he stopped Michael Dokes at 1:41 of the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout at Caesars Palace. It was a furiously waged punching match, with both fighters landing haymakers from the opening bell.

title: FROM DICKENS TO BECKETT IN GRAND CENTRAL
description: ''How picturesque they are, the missed trains!'' This line by the 19th-century poet Jules Laforgue set the tone for much of the modern poetry that followed him. At 10:30 on a Tuesday night, Grand Central Terminal seems to be filled with people who have missed their trains and who have given up the idea of transition or of making connections. For them, this is only a terminal, a permanent transience. Though they have their own literature, their missed trains are no longer so picturesque.

title: WORDS FOR SALMAN RUSHDIE
description: In a response to the crisis of Salmana Rushdie,28 distinguishedwriters born in 21 countries speak to him from their common land - the country of literature. For expressing their ideas publicly in the past many of these writers have suffered censorship, exile - forced or self-imposed - and imprisonment. Some have been politically active on behalf of the rights of writers under totalitarian regimes. Many are on the record here and in their own countries in support of Mr. Rushdie, the Indian-born British author of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' who was still in hiding in England with a price on his head when The Book Review went to press. He has been accused by the Iranian revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of slandering Islam in his novel. The Ayatollah has called for his death. Mario Vargas Llosa Peru.

title: It's Not Easy Being Green
description: HAVE you ever heard the grass say ''Ouch!'' when you step on it? I have. In squeaky voices, the slender stalks of green shout in fragmented choruses, sounding much like the cacophony you hear when entering a large cafeteria, only octaves higher.

title: Anthologies Can Be A Bargain
description: It's still too early to tell whether the cheering ''New York Stories'' will be a box-office hit, but one can hope.

title: Debuts; Flutist, Cellist and Pianist in Recitals
description: Jan Benson

title: High-Society Satire for Hire
description: In the strange and enchanted career of Christopher Mason, a 27-year-old wag from England who belts out designer songs on baby grands along the avenues, Park and Fifth, last week proved more eventful than most.

title: Donaldson Out
description: James Donaldson, the Dallas Mavericks' center, will miss the remainder of the season to undergo surgery to repair a tendon in his right knee that was torn Friday night against Houston. Donaldson averaged 9.1 points and 10.8 rebounds in 53 games.(AP)

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MURDER IN LITTLE EGYPT. By Darcy O'Brien. (Morrow, $19.95.) Whether Dr. John Dale Cavaness murdered two of his four sons out of meanness or simply for money (he had them insured), he remained a hero to his patients until he hanged himself in prison in 1986 while awaiting execution. ''Murder in Little Egypt,'' a meticulous account of Cavaness's life and crimes by Darcy O'Brien, is an implicit indictment of a culture that condones and encourages violent behavior in men.

title: Tokyo
description: To the Editor: Upon returning from a recent trip to Tokyo I was delighted to read Jared Lubarsky's ''Exploring the Heart of Old Tokyo'' (Travel, Oct. 23). Travelers should know that they can stay in the Asakusa View, a Western-style hotel in Asakusa adjoining the Asakusa Kannon Temple. The hotel has an attraction no other hotel in Tokyo offers: a huge wooden bath on the top of the building overlooking the Shitamachi section of the city. I sat there, looking out over a traditonal Japanese roof garden as a gorgeous red sun set. I could have been anywhere in the Japanese Alps, where the owners, the Yanai family, have a ryokan. In the Tokyo hotel there are authentic tradtional guest rooms on the same floor as the bath, and out the front door is the heart of old Tokyo. JACKSON N. HUDDLE STON JR. Seattle

title: Reviews/Music; Jazz Reminiscences in Red Rodney Tribute
description: The sold-out ''Tribute to Red Rodney,'' part of the Highlights in Jazz series at Loeb Student Center of New York University, was a relaxed, low-key variety show on Thursday night that culminated in a round of reminiscences by the drummer Roy Haynes and the saxophonist Jimmy Heath and in a set by Mr. Rodney and his group.

title: U.S. PSYCHIATRISTS FAULT SOVIET UNITS
description: American experts who recently completed the most extensive foreign inspection ever permitted in Soviet psychiatric hospitals said today that they found a system still wide open to abuse.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PARTIAL PAYMENTS: Essays on Writers and Their Lives. By Joseph Epstein. (Norton, $18.95.) Most of the essays collected in ''Partial Payments'' by Joseph Epstein, who is editor of The American Scholar and teaches writing and literature at Northwestern University, originally appeared in two leading neoconservative journals, The New Criterion and Commentary.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: So Strawberry is a bit of a baby. Every fanatic fan is a bit of a baby (even I, a 64-year-old grandmother) - that is what makes us so crazy about baseball. No way should Strawberry be traded. Darryl generates excitement every time he comes to bat. He has the capacity to elicit our wildest fantasies, sometimes less than heroic, he identifies us with our failures. EDYTHE BERNSTEIN New York

title: Review/Jazz; Eddie Bert, A Trombone, And Friends
description: Eddie Bert, a trombonist, brought a quintet to Birdland on Thursday night that included two musicians more familiar from old Miles Davis and Charlie Parker records than from recent appearances on New York stages: Davey Schildkraut on tenor saxophone (he played alto in the 1940's and 1950's) and Duke Jordan on piano. In its first set, the quintet ambled through standards and be-bop tunes with sure-footed ease, poised on the cusp of swing and be-bop.

title: People Meet on Plan; Opinions Do Not>
description: TWO farmers in plaid shirts sat quietly through the entire meeting, just in front of Jan Thompson from the Save Our Swamp group of Paterson, an organization that was formed to defend a wetland called Dismal Swamp.

title: West German Neo-Nazi Speaks of a Revival
description: On the wall above Michael Kuhnen's sofa is a blank space where a color portrait of Hitler and two red, white and black swastika banners recently hung.

title: Novel on Dictatorship Aimed at Youth
description: LYLL BECERRA DE JENKINS says the story of living under a Latin American dictatorship needs telling.

title: Guardian Angels (the Originals) on Stage in Rome
description: The subject was guardian angels, and you can be sure that Curtis Sliwa's name did not come up once.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Waltham, Mass.;
Squeezing In 567 Condos
description: LEAD: THIS city of 60,000 about eight miles west of Boston is seeing a sizable spurt of residential development with three major projects under way that will produce 567 condominium units by 1992.

title: Rockefeller Archive Center Selects Scholar
description: LEAD: THE Rockefeller Archive Center here recently initiated a scholar-in-residence program, and for the 1988-89 academic year has chosen a historian, Dr. James A. Smith of Larchmont, as its first scholar.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE MEN FROM THE BOYS: Rites of Passage in Male America. By Ray Raphael. (University of Nebraska, $19.95.) How does a young boy attain manhood - or learn what it is all about - in a society where there are no formal rituals to facilitate his passage? Ray Raphael, the author of ''The Teacher's Voice,'' explores this question in ''The Men From the Boys: Rites of Passage in Male America.'' He conducted in-depth interviews with 100 American men from various walks of life who had set out to test their virility by joining the Army, competing in sports, enduring the indignities of fraternity hazing, sleeping with as many women as possible, climbing mountains or working arduous hours in the emergency rooms of hospitals. We hear both the triumph and the anguish of these men as Mr. Raphael re-creates their personal tales and concludes remorsefully that these rituals simply do not do the job. Unlike primitive rites of passage that made it possible for every boy to achieve a heightened sense of self-worth, our rituals are too idiosyncratic, too restrictive and too competitive to really work. Too often they are designed as tests rather than rites of passage, and only a few men can pass them. As a result, Mr. Raphael sums up, we have turned into a nation of ''makeshift'' males: ''Some young males find ways to manage the transition successfully, while others try but do not succeed. . . . Our pluralistic culture gives only a loose and pluralistic response to the problems faced by developing young men.'' This is not an entirely new argument, but Mr. Raphael's book is provocative and well researched, his anecdotes are often compelling and we cannot dispute his recommendation that we have to redefine manhood as a state of maturity, rather than a display of power, and negotiate new rituals that will be accessible to all young boys.

title: Syracuse Rallies to Frustrate Seton Hall
description: For all that Seton Hall had accomplished in the last two years, including a school-record 26 victories this season, the Pirates approached yesterday's Big East Conference semifinal game against Syracuse as a litmus test, not so much of skill but of ingenuity and fortitude.

title: Getting Around Fees on Singles
description: FOR a person traveling alone, among the sour notes embedded in the small type of any tour brochure is the phrase ''single supplement.'' The supplement is the extra charge that the tour operator imposes upon a person occupying a room alone on a tour where double occupancy - two in a room - is the standard. The single supplement is everywhere to be found, but some tour operators make an effort to eliminate or reduce it.

title: Free-Agent Deals: There's Still Time
description: In the five weeks of the National Football League's new free-agency system, about 10 percent of the 619 eligible players have signed or agreed to contracts with new teams. The Jets have signed 3 players and lost 3 of their 27 free agents. The Giants have lost 2 of their 27 and have signed none.

title: STRIKE AT EASTERN PROMPTING WORRY ON DEREGULATION
description: Amid concern that a strike and bankruptcy could lead to the disappearance of Eastern Airlines, members of Congress and the Bush Administration are exploring whether the deregulation of the nation's airlines has led to insufficient competition in the industry.

title: Cutting Deficit Is Our Only Acceptable Course; Against Capital Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Fordham; Journalism Class Is Devoted Solely to Murrow's Life
description: Edward R. Murrow might have sniffed at anyone's taking, muchless giving, a course on his work and life. But last spring, Fordham University's department of communication offered the first course in the nation exclusively about Mr. Murrow, who, through his outspoken reporting and documentaries, became the leading radio and television journalist of his time.

title: Cutting Deficit Is Our Only Acceptable Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Colleges Offering Child Care on Campus
description: LEAD: MARY LAVERY-PERRY, a 36-year-old mother of two from Norwalk, has long dreamed of a career as a nurse. When she read about the opening of the Campus Child Development Center and Institute at Norwalk Community College last month, she decided to enroll her 4-year-old son and begin a two-year program at the college to become a registered nurse.

title: The Razzle-Dazzle World of Kabuki
description: WHEN DUSTIN HOFFMAN was preparing for his role in the film ''Tootsie,'' he bewildered Utaemon VI, Living National Treasure and the Kabuki theater's most senior onnagata, or ''man-actress.'' ''What do you do to hide your

title: Building Break-Ins Fall Using Stucco Sealant
description: The city agency responsible for opening the doors of housing opportunity in New York is beginning to boast these days of its ability to seal them up, as well.

title: Ornamental Alliums Deserve a Place
description: Allium flowers come in a wonderful spectrum of colors: from bright yellow to warm red, from delicate blue to soft white and from gentle pink to rich purple. The forms also vary. In some cases, these flowers suggest a pompon, in others they spread out on thin branches and look like a starburst of fireworks. In bud stage, some form at the end of gracefully curved stems and resemble swans.

title: Visiting a Club Med Fit for Children
description: LEAD: FOR me, the notion of vacationing at Club Med was always akin to eating out at Burger King: not the sort of choice you make if you've got other options. Club Med, I figured, was like most huge, successful franchise operations: safe, reliable and relatively inexpensive, but also bland, predictable and utterly unexotic.

title: Inmate on Leave Held in Death Of His Ex-Wife
description: Lisa Bianco, an advocate for battered women who had been beaten for years by her former husband, took little comfort in his imprisonment for brutally attacking her two years ago. Instead, she lived in daily fear that he would make good his threats to kill her.

title: Podie Lynch Plans Bridal
description: Rose Parsons Lynch of New Canaan, Conn., and R. Vincent Lynch of Dallas, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Rose Peabody Lynch, to James Alexander Torrey, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clare M. Torrey of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Orioles Deal Morgan
description: The Baltimore Orioles traded the right-hander Mike Morgan to the Los Angeles Dodgers for the outfielder Mike Devereaux yesterday. Devereaux, 25 years old, spent most of last year at Class AAA Albuquerque, where he batted .340 with 13 home runs and 76 runs batted in. Morgan, 29, who has a 34-68 career record, underwent foot surgery last Aug. 18. He said he is healthy. (AP)

title: Unkind Cuts
description: To the Editors: So six years from hence Joe Papp's to present To those who sat through His Shakespeare to-do A shirt with the scrawl Of ''I've seen it all.'' But one must rebut ''Except what was cut.'' THOMAS CARON Union City, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Conservative Choice

title: Clothes Swapping in the 80's: My Bow for Your Black Hose
description: They traded poodle skirts in the Fifties, miniskirts in the Sixties and bell-bottom pants in the Seventies. And although the look may have changed over the years, clothes swapping is still very much in style among women in their 20's.

title: Nicaragua Announces a Date For Releasing 1894 Prisoners
description: The Nicaraguan Government announced Friday that it would pardon 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard by March 19.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits. To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave. I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment. Would car windshield-washer fluid be a better alternative ?

title: Flip Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: GRACE ABOUNDED
description: LEAD: A TINKER AND A POOR MAN John Bunyan and His Church, 1628-1688. tr,br1By Christopher Hill. 394 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: FICTION
description: A MATTER OF DAYS. By Albert Lebowitz. (Louisiana State University, $15.95.) Albert Lebowitz, an attorney who lives in St. Louis, has applied much ingenuity to fashioning an intertwined series of nine stories, each with the word ''day'' in the title, in which a small pool of characters make repeat appearances. Phyllis Stein and her dog Uriah deal with a squirrel in the attic in the first story, ''Mother's Day.'' We meet Phyllis's husband, David, a lawyer in his 30's, ill at ease in body and mind, in the second story, ''Day Labour.'' Unattractive, painfully conscious of his Jewishness in an oppressively gentile world, David struggles with tormenting questions of love and identity in subsequent narratives. In ''His Days Are as Grass,'' Phyllis's cold and loveless brother, Solon Pepper, obsessively palpates a small tumor in his neck and, emotionally paralyzed by the prospect of cancer, refuses his sister the sympathy she seeks from him. He watches his fiancee's passion turn to madness in the epistolary exchange that makes up ''Dear Days.'' And both dog and God have their days in the final two stories of the collection. ''A Matter of Days'' is the sort of work that gives experimental fiction a bad name. The characters exist only as an excuse for labored word play, purposely stilted dialogue and clotted ruminations - not to mention obtrusive alliteration, unattractive neologisms and gimmicky shifts of tense. Like solipsistic Solon Pepper, the book makes an art out of repelling friendly attention.

title: Julia Ann Petitt Weds Lance H. Choos in Darien
description: Julia Ann Petitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phil Andru Petitt of Darien, Conn., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Lance Harvey Choos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Melvin Choos of Highland Park, Ill. Ann Mandel, the First Selectman of Darien, officiated.

title: One More Time, Koch Bares His Soul
description: WITH his first book, ''Mayor,'' Edward I. Koch landed simultaneously on the best-seller list and in hot water, not that he seemed to mind. In a catalogue of confrontation and conflict that some found both mean and entertaining, Mr. Koch wrote of making President Carter turn gray, Representative Charles B. Rangel sweat, former Deputy Mayor Herman J. Badillo twitch and then City Council President Carol Bellamy cry.

title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War
description: SINCE May 1985, when Francis C. Hall was named commander of the Police Department's 1,300-member narcotics division, drug arrests in New York City have risen steeply, to 3 of every 10 arrests, and the number of armed attacks on police officers has risen to unheard of levels.

title: Nancy L. Watkins Marries William Shott in Hartford
description: Nancy Leigh Watkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Watkins of Hartford, was married there yesterday to William Walker Shott, the son of Mollie B. Shott of Sun Valley, Idaho, and George B. Shott of San Francisco. The Rev. Peter B. Grandy performed the ceremony at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church.

title: ON A CAMEL MOVING FORWARD IN TIME
description: LEO AFRICANUS By Amin Maalouf. Translated by Peter Sluglett. 360 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: RICO GOES TO CONGRESS;
Keep the Teeth in the> White-Collar Law
description: LEAD: America is suffering through a white collar crime wave. But just as investigations into wrongdoing on Wall Street, the Chicago commodity markets and the savings and loan industry are beginning to yield results, the securities, commodities, accounting and other industries have gone to Congress asking to be retroactively relieved of liability under the civil racketeering laws.

title:
GARDENING;
Construction Can Be Hazardous to Trees
description: LEAD: A MAJOR problem for those who build or purchase a new house on a wooded site is that the trees often die over a two- or three-year period following construction. Most often, the wooded setting was a major factor in the decision to buy the property. To have this setting deteriorate is a disappointment, to say the least, and it usually represents a significant loss in the market value of the property and a sizable cost for tree removal.

title: Leaky Basements
description: SPRING rains and thawing temperatures often cause basement walls to develop leaks.

title: Diana Ford Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Diana Frances Ford to Scott Ward Seaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Seaton of Pepper Pike, Ohio, has been announced by the father of the future bride, Sir John Ford of Guildford, Surrey, England, and Hutchinson Island, Fla. The wedding is planned for June 3 in Guildford.

title: CALL MY AGENT!
description: Among the stack of books Morton Janklow is proprietorially clutching in the photograph illustrating the article ''Call My Agent!'' is ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb,'' by Richard Rhodes. Mr. Rhodes is now a Janklow client, but the agent for his prize-winning history of the development of atomic weapons was not Mr. Janklow. It was my husband, the late John Cushman, to whom the book is dedicated and whose firm, JCA Literary Agency, continues to represent the work. JANE CUSHMAN President, JCA New York, N.Y.

title: Israel's Border Police Replace Gaza Troops
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that specially trained border policemen were replacing Israeli Army reservists in the Gaza Strip.

title: A Farmer Takes a Knife And Fills an Art Gallery
description: The usual visitors to the Emerson Art Gallery at Hamilton College here are being joined these days by farmers, children, vintage-car buffs and people whose hobby is whittling.

title: MCFARLANE'S CAREFUL LANGUAGE
description: I find the letter by Leonard Garment, Robert McFarlane's counsel, morally offensive and, sadly, too characteristic of the Washington mindset (Letters, Feb. 12, in response to ''Bud McFarlane: Semper Fi,'' by Brock Brower, Jan. 22).

title: STAMFORD THEATER OPTS FOR A DARING IMAGE
description: IN his determination to prove that Stamford is a theater town, Steve Karp is not playing it safe.

title:
MUSIC;
Pianist to Make Ensemble Debut
description: LEAD: THE first major collaboration between the renowned Austrian-born pianist Alfred Brendel and the acclaimed Orpheus Chamber Orchestra will feature four Mozart piano concertos in performances around the country, concluding this week with performances in New York tomorrow and Saturday and in Princeton on

title: Sociologist Studies Weekenders
description: THE influx of weekenders in the town of Washington is often cited for problems ranging from the high price of real estate to the lack of parking spaces in front of the local grocery. Now, a New York sociologist who is herself a weekender is trying to separate fact from fiction by studying exactly how weekenders are changing the nature of the small Litchfield County town.

title: Back on the Water
description: The Circle Line sightseeing boats have begun their 1989 season of three-hour sails around Manhattan. The boats leave Pier 83, at 43d Street and the Hudson River, at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. The number of daily cruises is to increase to 12 by the summer; evening cruises are to begin on June 10. Tickets are $15; $7.50 for children. Information: 563-3200.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Low-Income Housing; Rent Supplement Review Nears
description: THE rhetoric on housing in Washington this year centers on homelessness and what the Federal Government should do about it. But when it comes to solutions that involve spending Federal money, it will be no surprise if the emphasis in Congress is put on how to make existing rental housing more affordable to low-income people.

title: Roughed Up And Ready
description: As the official basketball supplier for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company makes a point of providing new balls for the various N.C.A.A. tourmanents.

title: Seeing Ground Zero in Nevada
description: AT 5:30 in the morning, the Zeus Room of the Alexis Park Hotel in Nevada was packed with animated tourists. Even in the predawn hours, a substantial assembly in one of the public rooms of a Las Vegas hotel would not have been unusual. But in this case, not a single slot machine, roulette wheel or blackjack table was in sight; the Alexis Park is a nongambling hotel. And the odds being assessed by the hotel's guests, as they balanced their plates and cups in the breakfast buffet line, were those of human survival.

title: Nancy Orr Is Married In Illinois
description: Nancy Elizabeth Orr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Orr of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday in Evanston, Ill., to James Marshall Shepherd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Shepherd of Indianapolis. The ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Evanston was performed by Pastor E. Steven Nicholson of the Vineyard Christian Fellowship.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Tufts; For the Latest In Campus News, Read the Cannon
description: When Jodie Chidester, an adviser to foreign students, looked out her office window in Ballou Hall on St. Valentine's Day, she was shocked to see the newest message on the cannon on Tufts University's main quad. ''Jodie,marry me.'' it said.

title: 2 Men Save Children on Tracks
description: Two fast-moving subway riders brought two toddlers to safety Friday morning after a 2-year-old accidentally pushed his baby brother's stroller over a platform's edge and fell after him onto the IND tracks at a Harlem station.

title: The View From: Archie Comic Publications: Archie and His Pals: Perennial Teen-Agers and a Way of Life
description: LEAD: ANYTHING is possible in the comics and so, in one recent book, America's favorite red-headed, freckle-faced high-school student and his pals, Betty, Veronica, Jughead and Reggie, descend on the offices of Archie Comic Publications on Fayette Avenue here. ''Hi, gang,'' Archie the character greets editors, writers, artists and production personnel who work on the comic in real life.

title: Why Americans Consume More Energy to Produce Less
description: TWELVE years after President Carter declared ''the moral equivalent of war'' against the waste of dwindling supplies of energy, the United States appears to have won a few battles and forgotten the war.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
PARIS
description: LEAD: he French ready-to-wear designers are marching into the 1990's with a surprisingly pragmatic attitude. As they prepare for showings, starting Wednesday, of the fall and winter collections, the designers sound almost like business managers, murmuring about what sold and didn't sell from their previous collections.

title: PRO HOCKEY: The Probert Case; A Swift Punishment, A Shattered Career
description: Just around daybreak Thursday March 2, at a gray and chilly hour when most of his Detroit Red Wings teammates were sandwiching some sleep between the rigors of Wednesday night's game and Thursday morning's practice, Bob Probert was arrested at the Canadian border after Federal customs officials conducted a strip search and said they discovered 14 grams of cocaine in his underwear.

title: Eastern and the Unions Play Winner Take All
description: THERE is a deadly kind of weather known as ''wind shear'' - the abrupt and unpredictable shift in the direction and speed of the wind that can cause a plane to crash.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Branchburg $209,000 428 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; screened porch, landscaped yard, greenhouse; taxes $1,800. Brick $137,000 520 New Jersey Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; patio, family room with skylights, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,912. Clark $187,000 36 Ross Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 44-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, family room, deck; taxes $2,999. Freehold $210,000 222 Stonehurst Boulevard 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; full basement, eat-in kitchen, close to schools and shopping; taxes $3,072. Pompton Lakes $207,900 36 Della Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old contemporary; hardwood floors, sun room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,099. Morris Township $181,000 12 Raymond Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, screened porch, dining room; taxes $2,032. OTHER AREAS Harrison, N.Y. $980,000 Lawrence Lane 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 53-year-old stone/stucco Tudor; 4,440 square feet, terraces, 1 acre; taxes $9,807. Sherman, Conn. $365,000 Orange Pepper Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; fireplace, pond, 3.3 acres; taxes $2,000. Williston Park, L.I. $190,000 53 Fordham Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; den, basement, attic; taxes $1,900.

title: THE WEDDING
description: As a justice of the peace, I married a young couple fresh off the slopes, in ski clothes, last winter. No wedding party, no reception. They planned it that way the summer before. As far as I know, they went back, hand in hand, to wait in line for the chairlift after I pronounced them husband and wife in the Stratton Mountain Chapel, MALVINE COLE Jamaica, Vt.

title: ROCKER JOHN HIATT: AS GOOD AS HIS WORDS
description: FROM A DISTANCE, THE STAGE OF the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco resembles a gaudy Christmas display. Red oversized bows are pinned across the backs of the amplifiers, and the dark red backdrop is festooned with gold and silver garlands. Scores of tiny, multicolored lights are wound around a drum set, across a black digital piano and around three microphone stands. It's the holiday season and singer-songwriter John Hiatt and his back-up band, the Goners, are in the middle of a seven-month tour.

title: POSTINGS: Crystal-Ball Computer; Predicting Co-op Prices
description: They laughed when Susan M. Wachter sat down at her computer keyboard two years ago and announced that she could predict the future of Manhattan cooperative apartment prices, an accomplishment that for years had defied the best efforts of real estate experts and economists. Yet her prediction turned out to be about as correct as a computer- assisted human's could be.

title: Unseen Levies Confound the Issue of Tax Burden
description: WAKE up in the morning, roll over once and get set to pay the first tax of the day. The tax, assessed by the state on the electric utility and passed on by the company into monthly gas and electric bills, has just clicked in with the thermostat that turned up the heat.

title: Yonkers in a Smoking Study
description: LEAD: YONKERS has been selected as one of 11 cities in the United States and Canada in which the National Cancer Institute will conduct a large-scale community-based research study in stopping smoking.

title: Crystal L. Moffett Married To Richard Wayne Perry
description: Christ Church Cathedral in New Orleans was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Crystal Louise Moffett to Richard Wayne Perry. The Very Rev. David Lowry performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
description: Your article on Kinder-Care reflects the popular but unwise trend to mix child day care with academic learning programs. A day-care program genuinely focused on the needs of children would direct its objectives to achieve a representation of basic family, home-style care. It would provide daytime surrogates who would offer the tots unconditional acceptance (love can't be bought), much consistency and sensory experiences to stimulate well-documented early learning needs. BARRY KANE Smithtown, N.Y.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc
description: Everyone has a bad-luck something in their wardrobe, a tie that's a magnet for food, a dress that has to go to the cleaner after every wearing, a hat that flies off when a breeze whispers, a pair of fragile shoes that guarantee, once out the door, that a beautiful day will turn into a sodden mess.

title: CHILE COMMUNISTS SPLIT ON VIOLENCE
description: Chile's Communist Party, holding its first congress in 20 years, is engaged in a fierce internal debate over whether to continue to support the use of violence against the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: DIRK GENTLY, HOLISTIC DETECTIVE
description: THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL By Douglas Adams. 319 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: It's a long season. At some point in June or July when Darryl comes to bat in a close game with the bases loaded, and radio announcers for both teams are discussing the possibility of an intentional walk, then all of his bad behavior of the spring will be forgotten. You just can't trade a player like that. MICHAEL McKENZIE New York

title: Quest for a U.S. Budget Is About to Start in Earnest
description: Entering what could be a decisive stage in the development of a Federal budget, officials of the Bush Administration and leaders in Congress plan to begin face-to-face negotiations in earnest next week.

title: Old Venice Glitters At Waldorf
description: The Venice of the past was re-created briefly at the Waldorf-Astoria last week at a Venetian Masked Purim Ball to benefit the Jewish Museum. Drifting through the grand ballroom were gondoliers, minstrels and an actress who glided majestically on stilts.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Federal Funds Spur Private Investment
description: LEAD: AS Tony Oliviero, owner of Tony's Shoe Store on Doughty Boulevard in Inwood, watched, workmen began peeling off some of the wood facade of the elderly Dutch colonial building he has owned and occupied since 1956 so it could be replaced by brick.

title: ANOTHER BLOOMSBURY
description: WRITING FOR THEIR LIVES The Modernist Women 1910-1940. By Gillian Hanscombe and Virginia L. Smyers. Illustrated. 294 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press. Cloth, $37.50; paper, $14.95.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Panel by Panel, a Quilt Commemorates the Victims of AIDS
description: IN Connecticut, as elsewhere across the nation and in 16 foreign countries, the bereft are gathering to sew emblems of their loss.

title: Reviews/Dance; Exaltation In 'Sky Eye' By Dunn
description: Douglas Dunn united the sacred and the secular in ''Sky Eye,'' the hourlong new work Douglas Dunn and Dancers presented last Sunday night at St. Mark's Church. Over the years, Mr. Dunn's unpredictable dances have ranged from the austere to the complex. ''Sky Eye'' was rich in both choreographic invention and thematic implication.

title: Reagan Drug Center Gets Provisional Permit
description: A permit for Nancy Reagan's proposed drug rehabilitation center has won conditional approval, but it must still meet numerous conditions before it can open.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 12, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 2 2 2 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay find themselves enacting the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 3 3 3 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) Murder and mayhem on a luxury trans-Canadian train trip. 4 8 2 BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $19.95.) The life of the 1930's gangster Dutch Schultz, as seen by a bright youth from the Bronx. 5 4 7 MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) Inexplicable deaths and strange horrors take over a once idyllic California town. 6 5 4 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman's visit to her native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought. 7 9 3 THE FORTUNE, by Michael Korda. (Summit, $19.95.) A young woman's ill-fated romance with the head of America's richest family. 8 6 17 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 9 7 32 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 10 10 8 RIVALS, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) Feuding families compete in business and romance. 11 11 8 A SEASON IN HELL, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A young widow's quest for her stepson's killers leads to horrendous adventures. 12 12 7 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $18.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror. 13 1 THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy'' pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport. 14 14 3 N STORMING INTREPID, by Payne Harrison. (Crown, $19.95.) Warfare waged in outer space between the United States and the Soviet Union. 15 15 9 THE LYRE OF ORPHEUS, by Robertson Davies. (Viking, $19.95.) The staging of an unfinished Hoffmann opera causes its participants to relive the legend of King Arthur. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 19 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 2 7 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 3 3 4 THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) The murder of two teen-age girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues. 4 4 47 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 5 5 17 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 6 6 22 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 7 * 8 6 LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become part of our national heritage. 8 9 21 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 9 11 3 INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans' mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture. 10 10 9 PARTING THE WATERS, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The rise of the American civil rights movement under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. 11 * 7 12 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 12 16 2 RICHARD BURTON, by Melvyn Bragg. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The professional and private life of the distinguished actor. 13 12 18 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 14 15 4 THE BOY WHO COULDN'T STOP WASHING, by Judith L. Rapoport. (Dutton, $17.95.) A psychiatrist's account of the symptoms and treatment of an obsessive-compulsive disorder. 15 1 SECOND CHANCES, by Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) A study of how divorce affects men, women and children during the following decade. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 2 2 88 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 3 3 6 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 4 4 17 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 5 5 20 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) HAROLD MACMILLAN: Volume One, 1894-1956, by Alistair Horne. (Viking, $24.95.) From Macmillan's late Victorian boyhood to his becoming Prime Minister of Britain at 63, Mr. Horne is excellent on the subtleties of the career of this introverted, fastidious, elusive and very successful Conservative politician. A THEFT, by Saul Bellow. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) Mr. Bellow's new novella - his first paperback original - is a venturous undertaking into the inner and outer lives of a strong-willed, garrulous American woman, seen for herself rather than through one of Mr. Bellow's usual analytical male protagonists. SELF-CONSCIOUSNESS: Memoirs, by John Updike. (Knopf, $18.95.) In six discontinuous chapters - one about childhood, one about psoriasis and so on - Mr. Updike's comfortable, opulent style implies by its samples a life fortunate but not undeserved. THE END OF TRAGEDY: Four Novellas, by Rachel Ingalls. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Extravagant work, blending the precisely observed and the fantastically imagined, from carnivorous toads through love dolls that teach Italian. THE WATCH, by Rick Bass. (Norton, $16.95.) Fresh and strange short stories by a petroleum geologist, set mostly in the American West, full of symbolic animals and mad or half-mad people. WATCHING THE BODY BURN, by Thomas Glynn. (Knopf, $18.95.) Mr. Glynn's third novel, in urgent, immediate prose, concerns an unnamed protagonist, the son of an alcoholic whose impact on his child's development is a central theme of the book. TOURS OF THE BLACK CLOCK, by Steve Erickson. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A dreamy, dark, mythological novel, a meditation on evil, in which the narrator has destroyed his family and become Hitler's pornographer. And that's not the half of it!

title: POSTINGS: Ambiguity in Mount Kisco; Offices at Issue
description: Mount Kisco is going through an ambiguous period of development that is attracting new office buildings that many in the Westchester County community fear will change its character. An example is a developer who is anticipating a need for office space there by putting up a high-tech building, although the project has unsettled some residents.

title: Lenin, Though 65 Years Dead, Remains Much Alive in Spirit; Marxism Distorted
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD: The Amazon Forest; Brazil Wants Its Dams, but At What Cost?
description: THE rising waters are already lapping at the treetops and soon a new expanse of rain forest will completely disappear in Brazil's rush for energy. In a few months' time, Samuel, a new hydroelectric dam near this town in the Amazon Basin, will be ready to operate.

title: RESCUERS SEARCH CANADA CRASH SITE
description: Rescue workers using snowmobiles and plows searched the woods near Dryden today for bodies and for clues to the cause of an Air Ontario jet crash that killed 24 people.

title: Jo Ann Steigler Wed To George W. Farrall
description: The Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jo Ann Steigler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Steigler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to George William Farrall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Farrall of Rye. The Rev. David Uhl performed the ceremony, assisted by John Crenson, an uncle of the bride and a candidate for the Episcopal priesthood.

title: Concerts to Feature Young Performers
description: Youth has its musical say at several concerts this week, starting this afternoon at 2:30 when Bushnell Hall's ''Winners Circle'' series presents Gary Schocker, a flutist who has already made his Philadelphia Orchestra debut.

title: WHAT LI'L ABNER SAID
description: LEAD: LOVE LIFE Stories. By Bobbie Ann Mason. 241 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Reviews/Music; Handy Four-Part Harmonies, With Humor
description: John Handy's first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night started out sluggishly; the rhythm section couldn't find a groove, and Mr. Handy, when he improvised, just added to the set's sullenness. About halfway through the second tune of the first set, Mr. Handy and the rhythm section found equal ground, and like an engine finally starting up in the cold, they took off.

title: Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine Pt. 2
description: Customs of the Country, from Maine to Japan, Stockholm to Rome, including:

title: California's Supreme Court Hears Insurance Case
description: Four months after Californians voted to roll back soaring insurance rates, insurance companies are fighting hard to reverse the measure, which could influence the way policies are sold, priced and regulated throughout the country.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; The Condo Watch in Downtown Stamford
description: THE fate of an 18-story condominium under construction at Forest Street and Greylock Place in Stamford - it will be the city's tallest and most luxurious apartment building - is being watched closely by local officials, developers and realtors who consider it a key component in creating an upscale downtown housing market.

title: Appreciating Birds and Their Vulnerable Place in the County
description: OVER the years, birds in Westchester have received ''mixed reviews,'' as they say in the theater world. On the one hand, birds have been looked at favorably by hunters as a source of food and by the hard-core birders as a source of interest and satisfaction as they accumulate the most possible species on their ''life list.'' On the other hand, birds have sometimes aroused the anger of Westchesterites because of the harm they do to plants and crops and the damage that certain species can do to parks, private homes and public buildings.

title: Kelley Lee Noyes Becomes a Bride
description: At the Swarthmore (Pa.) Meeting House, Kelley Lee Noyes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Noyes of Media, Pa., was married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony to William Chauncey Keator 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrit M. Keator of Pomfret, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt.

title: Love Stands Alone In Lead
description: Davis Love 3d shot an eagle 3 and a birdie 3 on the first two holes at the Bay Hill Club today, breaking a three-way deadlock for the lead. Then he continued on to a 5-under-par 66 and took a 2-shot margin over Tom Kite entering Sunday's final round of the $800,000 Nestle Invitational.

title: CRIME
description: You have to admire the cheek of Rose Bell and Antonia Ashton. ''They had a corpse at home to dispose of and they blandly ordered Bismarck Herring sandwiches, buttered crumpets and chocolate cake.''

title: Thorpe and Olajuwon Propel Rockets Over Nets
description: Otis Thorpe scored 21 points and Akeem Olajuwon had 19 points and 11 rebounds tonight to lead the Houston Rockets over the Nets, 124-94.

title:
INVESTING;
An Unrewarded Transformation?
description: LEAD: The M. A. Hanna Company has dramatically transformed itself, pushing up its profits in the last two years, but investors have not fully rewarded it, analysts say. Formerly a struggling mining and energy company, Cleveland-based Hanna made a series of acquisitions that has turned it into a specialty chemical company.

title: Sectarian Killings in Ulster Continue to Mount
description: An escalating series of sectarian killings in Northern Ireland continued Friday night, when a Catholic was shot dead by terrorists as he was leaving a bar in West Belfast. Three other people, two of them Catholics and one a Protestant, were wounded in two other shootings in Ulster on Friday.

title: Hockey Pads And Ponytails
description: LEAD: KEN ROSS paced back and forth along the top of a wooden partition behind his hockey team's bench at the Ironbound Recreation Center. The first period of the game was drawing to a close and his team, the Ironbound Bandits, had not yet scored. Neither had the opponents, the Delaware Bobcats.

title: Japan's Bad Mix Of Money And Politics
description: WHEN influence must be peddled and money exchanged, Japan's most powerful politicians, bureaucrats and business executives meet behind the high walls of ryotei, luxurious restaurants where proprietors are known for discretion and ordinary Japanese can never get a reservation.

title: SCULPTURE'S MOVE DELAYED BY JUDGE
description: In an 11th-hour stay worthy of the twisting tale it has provoked, Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' was spared dismantling yesterday. A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order barring the Government from removing the giant sculpture from Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan until new legal arguments can be heard.

title: Philharmonic Symphony Registers $30,000 Deficit
description: LEAD: THE Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester is facing financial problems. The orchestra, in which professionals play alongside amateurs, has a $30,000 deficit, according to Robert Kogan, its music director and conductor.

title: Susan Marie Busch 2d Is Engaged To Marry Tripp Transou in Spring
description: The engagement of Susan Marie Busch 2d to Hal Garwood Transou 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal G. Transou Jr. of Greensboro, N.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Susan M. Busch and August A. Busch 3d of St. Louis. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Sports of The Times; Roy Rubin Knows How It Feels to Lose and Lose
description: When Ron Rothstein winces in anguish in downtown Miami, Roy Rubin feels the pain clear across a causeway in Miami Beach.

title: Chess
description: The old proverb, ''Make haste slowly,'' applies to many an attack: without painstaking preparation, there would be no smashing success. Observe how the world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, took this counsel seriously in his game with the Argentine grandmaster Daniel Campora in the match between their two national teams in the Olympiad, which ended on Nov. 27 in Thessaloniki, Greece. Play like this enabled Kasparov to win the gold medal for the best score, 8 1/2-1 1/2, or 85 percent on Board 1.

title: Broadway-Bound Church
description: To the Editor:

title: North Carolina Cruises Into Final to Face Duke
description: The equation was simple and crushingly effective. Take superior size, experience, depth and ability. Add Dean Smith, North Carolina's 28-year head coach, facing a Maryland assistant who was directing his first major college game.

title: THE OTHER ORWELLIAN NIGHTMARE
