description: ENTRY INTO JERUSALEM By Stanley Middleton. 172 pp. New York: New Amsterdam Books. $16.95.

title: New Study Finds the Poor Getting Poorer, Younger and More Urban
description: Poverty in America's cities has grown more persistent and concentrated over the last two decades, and its victims have less chance of escape, the National League of Cities reported today.

title: POSTINGS: Hot Topic; Energy Exposition
description: How energy-efficient will the buildings of the 1990's be, and what will it cost to heat and cool them? These and related questions about energy and its impact on real estate will be discussed at the 14th annual New Jersey Energy and Facilities Management Exposition at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus. The exposition starts tomorrow and runs through Wednesday.

title: Deciding What to Do Next About Civil Rights
description: IN his budget address on last month, President Bush pledged to ''work to knock down the barriers left by past discrimination.'' But his Administration's civil rights policies will hinge largely on its view of what those barriers are.

title: Rodgers Is an Early Mets Detractor
description: One vote was cast against the Mets and the tide of public opinion today by Buck Rodgers, the manager of the Montreal Expos, who said: ''I don't think the Mets are invincible.''

title: About Cars; New Bentley for Young Buyer
description: The car is red - v-e-r-y red.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Trading Darryl Strawberry would be a major mistake by the Mets because of the scarcity of left-handed home-run hitters today. And I strongly doubt the Mets would receive equal value in trading their most valuable asset. WILLIAM PARLAMIS Brooklyn

title: The New Teeth in the Fair Housing Law
description: A SWEEPING change in the Federal Fair Housing Act, which becomes effective today, is emerging as the Government's most ambitious - and potentially most disruptive - civil rights initiative of the 1980's, according to civil libertarians, tenants rights experts and business people across the country.

title: From Adi to Skittles to Yoot, Making Fun
description: ADI, anyone? Pommawanga, perhaps? Or maybe yoot is what you want to try. Whatever game you want to play, World Wide Games of Colchester probably has it.

title: For Delivery Services, Buying From China is Cheaper
description: Although diaper delivery vendors may have gained some market share from disposables last year, American producers of cloth diapers did not reap much of the benefit. A surge in imports from China in 1986 all but drove American cloth diaper producers from the delivery market. Imports of heavy-ply cloth diapers from China climbed to 1.06 million pounds that year, up from just over 82,000 pounds in 1985. The bulk were purchased by delivery vendors.

title: A Tradition of Irish Fraterntiy
description: LEAD: IN anticipation of St. Patrick's Day, John Flynn Jr. of Yonkers was talking about some of the Irish fraternal, political and cultural organizations he belongs to.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
A Reuse Study For 403 Acres
description: LEAD: PHILADELPHIA has commissioned a $150,000, 13-month study of how to use 403 acres it is about to acquire in the northeast part of the city.

title: Carson to Stay on 'Tonight'
description: Johnny Carson is to remain the host of the ''Tonight'' show on NBC for at least another year - his 28th -through September 1990, he announced Wednesday night.

title: Numismatics
description: An example of America's rarest note will go on the block at Stack's auction of the Howard W. Gunlocke Collection to be held in New York City on Tuesday through Thursday.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Streetscapes column on March 5 misidentified Emil Kratovil. He is a member of the Cos Cob Power Plant Subcommittee, not a Selectman.

title: VIEWS FROM THE TERRITORIES BY A VISIONARY SNAPSHOOTER
description: Since its invention, photography has been associated with mirrors: it seems to reflect the world directly back at us. When we look at a print of turn-of-the-century Paris by Eugene Atget, we seldom ask if that's the way Paris really looked at the time. But camera vision is as much a product of human invention as language. Its account of the world is designed according to rules of perspective and description worked out hundreds of years before Daguerre appeared on the scene. Consequently, one could argue, photographs are no more or less ''natural'' than any other kind of visual image.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD;
Longer 'Kong': A Shaggy-Ape Story
description: LEAD: ''King Kong'' is back - larger, or at least longer, than ever on video. Footage has been restored to the 1933 camp classic - but how it happened is a longer story, too. Turner Home Entertainment has released new editions of the film, with and without color (both are $19.95). And in this instance even lovers of black and white owe a debt to the people at Turner and their colleagues in color (Hal Roach Film Classics, now Qintex

title: Out of Gas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Offers Help
description: LEAD: UNDER extreme duress and facing the possibility of losing their battle for custody of their children, many parents in divorce cases have chosen to take the law into their own hands and abduct their children - smuggling them across state lines and out of reach of the other parent.

title: Midsummer Magic in the Lands of the Midnight Sun
description: A STORY IS TOLD ABOUT THE AESIR, THE gods of Asgard. It seems that they had to fashion a rope of tremendous strength, and they asked Odin the One-Eyed to obtain one for them. He went away for a while and returned with what appeared to be a slender silken cord. It didn't look very strong, but when the gods examined it they saw that it was woven from the roots of a mountain, the purring of a cat, the sinews of a bear, the breath of a fish, the beard of a woman, the spittle of a bird. And nothing could break it.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Physics, Too, Can Bring Smiles of Success
description: I was a sophomore at the Rutgers-Newark campus in the fall of 1966. My major was mathematics, and I was required to take a laboratory course in physics - one designed for physics and mathematics majors. I had already attempted this course as a freshman and dropped it when I realized there was no way I could possibly pass it.

title: 'Parenthood II': The Nest Won't Stay Empty
description: Growing numbers of middle-aged Americans whose children have grown up and gone off, or those who assumed they would soon have an empty nest, are leaving the porch light on for offspring who are returning home to stay well into their 20's and 30's.

title: Giants' Craig Balks at Criticism of the Split-Fingered Fastball
description: To Roger Craig's critics, the syllogism is obvious:

title: In the Open
description: When Kitty Dukakis entered a clinic in Newport, R.I., last month for treatment of alcohol abuse, her friends were shocked. They said they had never seen her abuse alcohol before or during the Presidential campaign of her husband, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Last week, after completing the treatment program, Mrs. Dukakis said that she was an alcoholic. She said she would have preferred to handle the problem privately and that she hoped her public acknowledgment of it would persuade others to seek help, too. Mrs. Dukakis, who in 1987 had disclosed a lengthy dependency on amphetamines, refused to blame the stress of the campaign. ''The campaign was a very positive experience,'' she said, ''and the only thing that happened wrong was that we lost.''

title: School's Fate Put to Elmont's Voters
description: LEAD: VOTERS in the Sewanhaka Central High School District will go to the polls Wednesday to decide whether a 21-acre tract in Elmont that now houses a closed school building should be sold to a shopping mall developer.

title: THE PERFECT BABY?
description: Perri Klass's article ''The Perfect Baby?'' (Body and Mind, Jan. 29) touched a very personal chord, for I, like Shakespeare's Richard III, was ''deformed, unfinished, sent before my time.'' I am now 18 years old, and studying at Yale University.

title: FICTION
description: CANNIBALS IN SICILY and THE BATHING HUTS. By Monique Lange. Translated by Barbara Beaumont. (Marion Boyars, $18.95.) Two dramatic situations - a death and an illness - account for the basic plots in these two short novels by the French writer Monique Lange, both smoothly translated by Barbara Beaumont. The first, ''Cannibals in Sicily,'' was published in France in 1967 and, as the author herself explains in the preface, describes how ''a couple in crisis is re-made when confronted with the pain of a mother's death.'' The story is episodic in nature, jumping suddenly, like a film, from brief scene to brief scene. But the effect in this case is jarring. Instead of experiencing the emotional duel between wife and husband firsthand, one finds oneself on the outside looking in, frustrated by the author's emphasis on technique. ''The Bathing Huts,'' published 15 years later, is much more successful. It too is short and episodic, but the transitions between scenes are much more felicitously and logically wrought. The novel concerns a woman in her 50's, suffering from an unnamed illness, who is sent by her doctor to Brittany in order to recuperate. There, solitary and reticent, she ruminates with a captivating honesty about her past loves, her two husbands, her daughter and her granddaughter. She also meets a much older man, who befriends her and with whom she gradually and somewhat reluctantly forms a relationship. The story is very nostalgic but without a maudlin note. The narrator sits on the beach, recalling all the mistakes she's made in her life, all the false loves and bad choices - along with the many intensely lived moments - and ultimately one gets the impression she wouldn't change a thing. That in itself is a breath of fresh air.

title: Mathematicians Are Troubled by Claims on Their Recipes
description: UNLIKE an industrial technology, an algorithm, the step-by-step recipe for carrying out a mathematical calculation, might seem more like something that is discovered than invented. But in the last few years, corporations have been patenting these abstract procedures, leading many mathematicians to complain that the free flow of ideas is in danger of being interrupted.

title: SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
description: Tamar Lewin's very comprehensive article ''Small Tots, Big Biz'' (Jan. 29) points out the tremendous need for child care in this country. The most important ingredient in quality child care is the child's daily interaction with staff members. The staff must be properly trained, must enjoy and understand children and must be stable members of a team. Kinder-Care's 40 percent turnover rate should be unacceptable.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ART FROM DROSS Apparently, one man's garbage can be another's art. So today, the always-adventurous Islip Art Museum opens ''Dross to Art,'' a group exhibition showcasing nine artists who use dross - defined as ''refuse, rubbish, impure matter'' - to make their creative statements.

title:
Long Island Interview: Louise Simpson;
Keeping the Dream of Justice Alive
description: LEAD: LOUISE Simpson, the Long Island regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said she learned about institutionalized racism on Long Island when she arrived in 1960 and quickly discovered where, and where not, to look for a place to live.

title: Jersey Panel Backs Limits On Unpaid Surrogacy Pacts
description: A year after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled in the Baby M case that commercial surrogate motherhood contracts were illegal, a state panel drafting legislation on the subject has gone further still and come down strongly against even unpaid surrogate arrangements among friends, relatives or others.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 12, 1989
Time for Boggs To Move Along
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Diaper Plup - Out of the Garbage and Into the Garden
description: Not all diaper service vendors think cloth is the only way to address disposal problems associated with throwaways. Anderson Diaper Service Inc., a full-service supplier of cloth and disposable diapers to Seattle customers, figures that recycling disposables is part of the solution.

title: Rita Savino Marries
description: Rita Marie Savino and John Noble Borst were married yesterday at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Nyack, N.Y., by Msgr. James Gotimer and the Rev. Donald Brown, a United Methodist minister. Mrs. Borst, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard P. Savino of New City, N.Y., is an account executive for AIG Risk Management in New York. She graduated from the University of Bridgeport. Mr. Borst, a graduate of Cornell University, is a son of Alan W. Borst of Columbus, Ohio, and Frances Sackett Borst of Mamaroneck, L.I. He is a master control operator in Floral Park, L.I., for the Rainbow Network, a cable-television concern.

title: Dumb by Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Voter Decline Is Found Among Most Groups
description: In the first official look at who voted and who did not in the 1988 Presidential election, a Census Bureau study shows increasing disaffection among young people, minority people and the less educated.

title:
INVESTING;
A Time for Caution on Asian Funds
description: LEAD: Despite the recent high returns of single-country funds that invest in Asian stock markets, analysts say their shares are currently overvalued given their risks.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JETS ON EXHIBIT An exhibition basketball game between members of the New York Jets and players from the Mount Vernon Police and Fire Departments and a contingent from the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Southern Westchester is to be played today at 1 P.M. in the Mount Vernon High School gymnasium, at 100 California Road. The Jets will be available for an autograph session at half time.

title: THE WORLD SERIES THAT STILL HAUNTS OAKLAND
description: By their nature, the best relief pitchers respond to pressure. They also respond to pressure questions. And now, at his locker in the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse, Dennis Eckersley, who threw the pitch that Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers hit for the home run that turned last year's World Series, was asked what he had learned from the salt that still sears his wounds.

title: Playground Divides Adults in Westport
description: ROBERT LEATHERS had built many a playground, with hardly any dissension and not a single lawsuit. Then he came to Westport.

title: Off the Board
description: Echoes of the 1960's and the 1988 Presidential campaign reverberated through a prominent black university last week. Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, resigned as a trustee of Howard University in Washington after students staged a sit-in to protest his presence on the board. They had objected to what they described as the racist overtones in his management of President Bush's election campaign. Mr. Atwater, who had been asked by university officials to join the board in January, said he was quitting out of concern that students might be injured in the protest. Contending that he had been ''unjustly maligned,'' Mr. Atwater said he would continue efforts to recruit black voters to the Republican Party. To end the protest, the university agreed to improve financial aid and other programs.

title: Mall May Rise in Woodmere Marsh
description: LEAD: WHAT the striped bass was to the Westway Highway project in Manhattan, the Northern Harrier hawk may be to a proposed 11-acre shopping mall that would be built on the Hook Creek wetlands in Woodmere.

title: Correction
description: A news analysis article last Sunday about the Senate debate over the nomination of John G. Tower misidentified the home state of Senator Timothy E. Wirth. It is Colorado.

title: Westport
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TO DANCE WITH KINGS. By Rosalind Laker. (Doubleday, $18.95.) In 1681, Augustin Roussier, a handsome courtier of Louis XIV, approaches a young peasant woman in Versailles whose mother has just been arrested for insulting the king. (The young woman's ''tear-stained face . . . stunned him with its extraordinary charm.

title: Despite Uncertainty, a Family Makes Maple Syrup
description: ROB LAMOTHE does not consider himself to be a gambler, but this year he is taking a chance. At the same time that many of his fellow maple syrup producers are cutting back, Mr. Lamothe, who operates Lamothe's Sugarhouse in Burlington, is doubling the size of his operation.

title: Rap as Public Forum on Matters of Life and Death
description: The movie ''Colors'' opened last spring to outcries that it glorified gang violence. The film focused on the lives of gang members, but in the end the gangsters died senseless and unheroic deaths. More equivocal was the theme song, performed by Ice-T, a Los Angeles rapper and former gang member. Over a slow, nightmarish electronic rhythm, Ice-T delivered an apology for the ''gang-bangers,'' the violent gang members.

title: Serene Setting for Sichuan and Hunan
description: AT Dragon Garden, on the Boston Post Road in Norwalk, near Ski Market, the potential for competent Hunan- and Sichuan-style Chinese dining is apparent. The professionalism clearly exists, both in kitchen skills and in service. And the gray and-pink decor has a restful, serene quality that could hardly be improved on, with smoking and nonsmoking sections kept well apart on separate levels and with generous space between the well-napped tables.

title: Xenodochiophobia
description: To the Editor: In reference to William L. Tazewell's ''A Case of Xenodochiophobia'' (Travel, Jan. 15): the contrast that Mr. Tazewell makes between Bernard Berenson, ''Caspar Milquetoast as a traveling companion,'' and Edith Wharton, ''a hardy tourist with a lifelong wanderlust,'' is most enjoyable. However, may I suggest that even Mrs. Wharton might have had one or more moments of xenodochiophobia?

title:
ART;
Dynamism, Diversity, Imagery
description: LEAD: WHILE museum exhibitions are usually carefully planned, the unpredictability of the results in a juried show can lead to a quirky, off-balance installation.

title: House for Sale: A Neighbor's Anxiety
description: A BRIGHT blue Escort slowed, then stopped in front of the realtor's For Sale sign. It stayed long enough for a closer look at the house, certainly long enough for jotting down the realtor's telephone number. I could not see how many people were in the car, but I began to imagine just what sort they were.

title: Bomb Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Keys, Two Moods Off Sarasota
description: AT first glance Sarasota's two major keys (from the Spanish cayo, meaning little island), Siesta and Longboat, would seem to have much in common - the narrow stretch of barrier island, the border of white beach, the lush green of tropical foliage splashed with improbably colored flowers, ranks of condominiums from low to high-rise along the shore, and, always, the blue-green waters of the Gulf dotted with every kind of boat.

title: A Turreted Corner of Tuscany
description: FOR most travelers, Tuscany means lazy mornings and wine-tinged afternoons in Chianti country, hours browsing in the Uffizi or a memorable meal just outside Lucca. However, to the south of these well-known delights lies a mysterious corner of Tuscany that is much closer in time and spirit to ancient Etruria than to the glitter of the Renaissance.

title: THE GREAT UNWASHED
description: INTELLECTUALS By Paul Johnson. 385 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Tribute to Gehrig
description: It was 50 years ago this year that baseball's Iron Man, Lou Gehrig, took himself out of the Yankee lineup for the first time since 1925 and brought an end to his remarkable record of 2,130 consecutive games. The ailment that ended his career, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is still considered incurable.

title: After 'The Rainmaker,' a Dark 'Bluebird'
description: IN the fairest of all possible worlds, one would be all aglow over N. Richard Nash's newest play, the last of a trilogy that began with ''The Rainmaker.''

title: Shoreham: Excruciating Minuet
description: IT is an excruciating minuet danced by lawmakers, the courts, Federal agencies and special-interest groups around the dormant Shoreham atomic energy plant.

title: A Reluctant Burden
description: IT was in India, during a month of intense heat, that I hired four men to work for me as beasts of burden. I didn't hire them as porters to carry luggage or hiking gear. I hired them to carry me. I was not enthusiastic about it then and the event is not a pleasant memory now, but at the time it was the surest way to get where I wanted to go.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Just a Thank-You Note

title: Lenin, Though 65 Years Dead, Remains Much Alive in Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Hopefuls Battle Old Images
description: TWO of the candidates in this year's top elections in New Jersey carry an added burden as they seek voter support in the weeks ahead. They must live down their previous campaigns.

title: 2 Nights Out For Young Celebrators
description: Youth has been celebrated at two events already this month, one for the Junior Committee of the Museum of Modern Art and the other for young clothing-design students.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Cats as Cats Can WHEN show dogs win enough points they become Champions. Show cats become Grand Champions. Everything is grander in the world of cats. Take cat show living quarters, for example. Rum Tum Tugger, a red tabby Persian, had not a care in the world as he lounged in his blue velour bed, which took up only a small portion of his lavishly carpeted and curtained cage with the litter box discreetly placed in the far corner.

title: Daniel T. Adams, Banker, 80
description: Daniel T. Adams, a former executive vice president of Marine Midland Bank, died of heart failure yesterday at Mediplex Nursing Home in Westport, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived Wilton, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: An Untapped Pool of Teachers
description: LEAD: Leading a lively discussion of how man can stem the threat of global warming, a retired automotive engineer strides up and down the aisles of a 10th grade science class in Detroit. After 32 years in the auto industry, he's just embarked on a second career as a member of an innovative statewide teachers' corps.

title: Tibet's Days of Despair And China's Harsh Response
description: IT was the faces that told the story.

title: Fretting Over Demographics and Disposal
description: Compared with many industries, the $3.5 billion baby diaper market seems relatively sedate. Disposable diapers, which account for 85 percent of all diaper sales, have been firmly established since the 1970's as the consumer's choice over washable cotton even though they are nearly 50 percent more expensive.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Clean and Sober 1988. Warner. 2 hours, 4 minutes. $89.95. Rated R. With his alcohol and cocaine problems out of hand, Daryl (Michael Keaton) checks into a rehabilitation center and gradually turns his denial and self-centeredness into understanding and compassion. The film, directed by Glenn Gordon Caron, follows his progress from ''one tiny increment to another, the best way to capture such a giant step forward.'' (Janet Maslin) Imagine: John Lennon 1988. Warner. 1:46. $89.95. Closed captioned (CC). Laser disk. $24.98. R. This film ''has things no Beatles biographer has yet captured: the pure euphoria of the music, the sad spectacle of the group's dissolution and Lennon's defiant, somehow poignant effort to strike out on his own.'' It's not ''terribly penetrating about Lennon's inner makeup, but it doesn't have to be. His resilient talent and his endlessly changeable nature come through.'' (Maslin) The Year My Voice Broke 1987. International Video Entertainment. 1:40. $89.95. PG-13. In this unpretentious Australian coming-of-age film, Danny, 15, falls for Freya, 16, whose involvement with an older fellow leads to pregnancy. A magnanimous lad, Danny helps Freya through her trials, maturing markedly himself and proving ''there is some life in coming-of-age stories after all.'' (Caryn James) The White Sheik 1952. Connoisseur. 1:26. $59.95. Not rated. It seems a fitting scenario for the directing debut of young Federico Fellini: a bride strays from her husband on their Roman honeymoon and falls for a plump ex-barber modeling as a desert prince for photographs in a lurid adventure magazine. When it opened, the film was hailed as surprisingly broad and ingenious. Variety Lights 1951. Connoisseur. 1:33. $59.95. Black and white. Not rated. Mr. Fellini co-directs his wife, Giulietta Masina, in this comedy-drama about a traveling vaudeville troupe. The director focuses on the ordinary faces that light up and enhance the dialogue (he also wrote the screenplay), depicting little people in a tough world. The Eclipse 1962. Connoisseur. 2:03. $79.95. Black and white. Not rated. Michelangelo Antonioni's orchestration of graphic detail records the moody, drawn-out surrender of a capricious young woman (Monica Vitti) to the bland advances of a stockbroker (Alain Delon) who seems more interested in bulls and bears. Antonioni is so selective and sensitive with his use of camera that what might be tedious is fascinating. Big Business 1988. Touchstone. 1:37. $89.95. CC. LD. $34.95. PG. Identical twins, Sadie (Bette Midler) and Rose (Lily Tomlin) get accidentally mismatched with another set of twins at birth, setting off a breezy farce played to the hilt by two ''splendidly comic actors.'' Ms. Midler is a ''fiendish delight'' and Ms. Tomlin is ''reserved but no less funny'' in a film that remains ''good fun even when the invention wears thin.'' (Vincent Canby) Spike of Bensonhurst 1988. Virgin. 1:41. $89.95. R. LD. $39.95. Dispensing with myriad multiethnic complications and romantic pitfalls, Spike Fumo (Sasha Mitchell) skips through a gauntlet of Mafia operatives and petty crooks in Paul Morrissey's comedy, set in Brooklyn. The film, spiced by jaunty Italian bubble-gum pop songs, ''doesn't have the sharpest satirical edge, but it does have personality.'' (Maslin)

title: Correction
description: A sentence in last Sunday's Bridge column about the Regional Swiss Team Championship had incomplete editing and the diagramed deal was incorrect. The sentence should have read: ''An example is the diagramed deal from the Regional Swiss Team Championship played Nov. 6 in Lancaster, Pa. North and South were Jerry Clerkin of North Vernon, Ind. and Bob Jones of Auburndale, Queens.'' The correct diagramed deal follows: [ Diagram ]

title: Christian Units in Lebanon Battle a Druse Militia
description: Christian units of the Lebanese Army fought heavy artillery duels with a Druse militia today, and two artillery shells hit piers in Beirut harbor after the army declared a blockade against ports run by private militias.

title: Correction
description: A caption on Feb. 12 on the Thursday Highlights page of the Television section, distributed in the New York region, gave an incorrect cause for the 1955 death of the actor James Dean. It was an automobile accident.

title:
COLLEGES;
Defense Attorneys in Agents' Trial Put Spotlight on Colleges
description: LEAD: The cross-examination was painful to watch. Devon Mitchell, a former University of Iowa defensive back, had been called by the prosecution as a witness this week in the Federal trial here of the agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom on charges of mail fraud and racketeering. Questioned by the prosecution, Mitchell, now with the Detroit Lions, acknowledged that he had signed a contract with the agents before his college eligibility expired, accepted some $14,000 in loans from them and then falsely filled out National Collegiate Athletic Association and Big Ten forms to conceal his conduct.

title: T.A.C. to Discuss Testing for Drugs
description: Drug testing, which has been a riveting subject in track and field since the disqualification of Ben Johnson in the 1988 Summer Olympics, will be the major topic of discussion Sunday by the nation's governing body for the sport.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Hofstra; Cable Network Planned to Link Entire Campus
description: Move over, NBC, ABC and CBS. Here comes HTV, Hofstra University's own television network.

title: A Shaky Lid on an Inflation Threat
description: As the dollar has plunged in the last four years, economists and policy makers have worried that the steep devaluation would eventually fuel inflation in the United States.

title: E-Mail Searches for a Missing Link
description: Suppose a company has a letter to send to the Electronic Mail Association. It can address the envelope to 1919 Pennsylvania Avenue N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C. 20006, and whether it turns to the United States Postal Service, a bicycle messenger, Federal Express or any other private carrier, its letter will eventually arrive.

title: Merchant and Ivory Traffic in 'Slaves of New York'
description: Picture a fashion show by the hip designer Stephen Sprouse at a cavernous East Village club. Picture, milling around in the smoke, to the blasts of Metallica, the downtown New York art world in full regalia. A sea of black leather on black studded with hardware, micro-minis in eye-searing hues, leopard jumpsuits, mohawks, crenelated towers of hair to rival Louis Quatorze. Models resembling intergalactic police strut up the runway wearing spike-heeled thigh-high gaiters of black polyurethane. Enter a second group in a hairy Day-Glo fabric that Mr. Sprouse dubs ''mutated dog.'' In keeping with the fashion show theme, ''New York Tragedies,'' the models collapse on the floor in a heap.

title: FICTION
description: A GRAVESTONE MADE OF WHEAT. By Will Weaver. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Will Weaver has followed his acclaimed first novel, ''Red Earth, White Earth,'' with a collection of 12 stories unified by a compelling sense of place. These stories rise, with an equal balance of pathos and humor, from the farmland of the American Middle West. While not all are completely successful - the endings of ''Dispersal'' and ''Gabriel's Feathers'' could each, in different ways, use more restraint - most are excellent and all are effective. Mr. Weaver shows his range and inventiveness in ''You Are What You Drive,'' which traces the history of several lives that are linked by their successive ownership of the same Buick LeSabre, and in ''The Bread-Truck Driver,'' a rock-and-roll lark with a haunting finish. Particularly affecting are the title story and ''Heart of the Fields,'' warm narratives about abiding loves that show up more clearly for the wide-open spaces of their settings. Mr. Weaver finds sources of affirmation in unlikely places. The title story, for example, tells of Olaf Torvik's resolve to bury his wife on their farm, defying a state ordinance against home burial by interring her in a field and covering the grave in earth richly fertilized so the wheat will forever grow ''greener, taller, and more golden than all the rest.'' It is stories like this that make ''A Gravestone Made of Wheat'' such a graceful collection, one that views America's heartland with a charitable but candid eye.

title: Nature Sows Life Where Man Brewed Death
description: Hard by the runways of Stapleton International Airport lies the strangest of environmental paradoxes: a blotch of grotesquely polluted land teeming with a profusion of wildlife that evokes comparisons to Yellowstone National Park.

title: Caroline Wood Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Wood of Mayfield, East Sussex, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Elizabeth Wood to Lucien Snowden Yokana Guthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Davis Yokana of Princeton, N.J. A May 27 wedding is planned. Miss Wood graduated from Worcester College of Oxford University. Mr. Yokana Guthrie, a graduate of the Princeton Day School, Franklin College in Lugano, Switzerland, and Drew University, is a regional manager in New York for LandVest, a Boston-based real-estate company.

title: THE DECISION TO DIVORCE
description: It has taken me a few weeks to put into perspective Judith S. Wallerstein's article ''Children of Divorce'' (Jan. 22).

title: Pausing to Weep
description: To the Editor:

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Harper, Actress, Marries T. E. Rothman
description: Jessica Harper, a movie and television actress, and Thomas Edgar Rothman, an executive vice president of production at Columbia Pictures in Los Angeles, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Mel Hawthorne, a Baptist minister and the chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the interdenominational ceremony at the Century Association in New York.

title: Black Artists: A Place in the Sun
description: In a sleepy, uneventful art season, there are the rumblings of an earthquake. After years of being dismissed as not even worthy of consideration, the work of black American artists has become essential to the future of American art and to understanding who we are.

title: As Soviet Elections Near, The Party Itself Is the Issue
description: THE longest waiting list in the reading room at the Lenin Library these days is for a four-part series written by a little-known scholar in an obscure journal called ''Science and Life.''

title: Children's Books
description: To the Editor: ''A Book Lover's Los Angeles'' (Travel, Jan. 8) may have misled readers as to the first edition of Beatrix Potter's ''Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' Unable to get a trade publisher to produce her little book, the author arranged for 250 copies to be privately printed in December 1901. Its unexpected reception led to a second edition printed (privately) in February 1902, with some slight changes in both the text and the binding. It was afterward, in October 1902, that Frederick Warne (London) issued the first trade edition of this modern classic, and since then it has never been out of print.

title: Oxford's Festive First of May
description: CELEBRATIONS OF MAY DAY HAVE been a part of European folk culture for thousands of years. Long before Communism made May 1 sacred with the trundling of military hardware through Red Square, Europeans have ritualized May as a festival of new beginnings, youth and love.

title: 'DE-CLUTTEIRNG' A BRITISH CONGLOMERATE
description: Ian A. Martin, chairman of Grand Metropolitan Inc., couldn't wait to get back to the United States last October. He was returning from Tokyo, after having sold the Inter-Continental Hotel chain to Japanese interests for a rich price. Now he would have the money to pursue the big American company he had his eye on. Driving in from the airport, he called his lawyers, investment bankers and public relations people. ''We go on Pillsbury,'' he told them.

title: 'Hanussen': Foreseeing the Hitler Nightmare
description: If you happened to be living in Berlin in the late 1920's or early 1930's and witnessed the episode in historical insanity that was the rise to power of Adoph Hitler, it is highly probable that the name Hanussen might ring a bell. Hanussen was the stage name of one Klaus Steinshneider, a nightclub and stage clairvoyant of considerable fame during those years, widely accused of fraud in the newspapers, but, nonetheless, it seems, a magician of rather chilling abilities.

title:
GARDENING;
Construction Can Be Hazardous to Trees
description: LEAD: A MAJOR problem for those who build or purchase a new house on a wooded site is that the trees often die over a two- or three-year period following construction. Most often, the wooded setting was a major factor in the decision to buy the property. To have this setting deteriorate is a disappointment, to say the least, and it usually represents a significant loss in the market value of the property and a sizable cost for tree removal.

title: DOING A BUSINESS IN PEOPLE
description: WAY OF DEATH Merchant Capitalism and the Angolan Slave Trade, 1730-1830. By Joseph C. Miller. Illustrated. 770 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $35.

title: Getting to New York Area Airports: By Land, Air and Water

title: Brazilian Arrested
description: The man judged the International Federation of Body Builders' Mr. Universe for 1987 was arrested Friday at a hotel in Columbus, Ohio, on charges of conspiracy and trafficking in illegal anaebolic steroids, the United States Customs Service said yesterday. Luis O. Batista Freitos, 33, a Brazilian national who lives in Marina Del Rey, Calif., was arrested while he was in Columbus to attend the Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic contest. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A chart accompanying an article in The Week in Review last week on poverty in New York omitted an item from the household budget of a woman working for the minimum wage. She pays $40 to Social Security, and has that much less for food and other expenses listed in the chart.

title: Carter Lombard Becomes a Bride
description: Carter Anne Lombard and Tighe P. Sullivan were married yesterday at the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: 'Opera to Flim' Comes to Emelin
description: THERE is good reason for music lovers in the county to go out this week. Great music arrives in Mamaroneck on Tuesday, when the Emelin Theater's ''Opera on Film'' series presents Moussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' (with English titles) at 7:30 P.M. Alexander Pirogov is featured as the tormented Czar, in the lavish production of Moscow's Bolshoi Theater (698-0098).

title: Why Modern Dancers Say 'Merci' to France
description: LEAD: There's a rich modern-dance tradition in the United States, dating from the 1930's. Yet, this indigenous American art form seems to enjoy more respectability in Europe than on its home shores. Many of America's most provocative and iconoclastic modern-dance choreographers still struggle for recognition, financial support, even a theater in which to show their stuff.

title: Cold Comfort: The Ordeal Of Renovating a Home in Winter
description: TO be inscribed in the Suburbanite's Handbook:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Business Forum article on Feb. 26 misstated the positions taken by Venezuela and Mexico on United States oil imports. Both nations oppose an oil import fee as a vehicle for reducing United States oil imports.

title: Dancers Inspired By a Mix of Eras
description: ELIZABETH ROCKWELL was scared to dance as a child. ''I never wanted anyone to watch me,'' Mrs. Rockwell explained with an easy laugh that made her sound impervious to nerves. ''I was extremely shy. The word that is usually used is 'painfully.' '' But her life has been filled with dance - as a young performer, later a teacher and now the founder and director of the Rondo Dance Theater of Bedford. She has seen some of the history of American modern dance as it developed. And what she saw and absorbed she has put into practice in her company.

title: CALL MY AGENT!
description: Trip Gabriel's article ''Call My Agent!'' (Feb. 19) confirms my most depressing fears about the Byzantine world of book publishing, and about any naive hopes I may have had of becoming a published author. Break-even points, bottom lines, last dollars, seven-figure sales - all of this sounds very much like the ''only big hits'' frenzy that has resulted in the demise of Broadway theater.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Brunch; Hint of Spain, and Romance
description: This is a summary of reviews by Bryan Miller of Manhattan restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Harlequin

title: A ONETIME BACKER ACCUSES SAVIMBI
description: Allegations that Jonas Savimbi, head of an American-supported guerrilla movement in Angola, has murdered and tortured high-ranking political rivals over the years are ''substantially true,'' Fred Bridgland, a British authority and longtime supporter of the movement, asserted tonight.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Definitely, for the right-handed hitter they seek. And better while he still has two years left in his contract so the trade is more appealing to other teams. How about Strawberry for Eric Davis? Both players are unhappy where they are and Davis is a much better fielder. ROXANNE ABBRACCIAMENTO Jackson Heights, Queens

title: Comatose Patients and Ethics
description: TWO years ago last summer, 64-year-old Jean Elbaum lapsed into a ''persistent vegetative state,'' a form of eyes-open permanent unconsciousness, following a stroke.

title: Factors to Consider In Arming Guards at Malls
description: The Jan. 29 article ''Bill to Arm Guards at Malls Is Debated'' raises a number of important issues concerning private security. By way of introduction: I retired as a detective lieutenant in New York City Police Department in 1987 and am currently involved in security management research and training. I am a resident of Middletown Township.

title: In New Haven, an Informed Welcome
description: TO draw more visitors to New Haven - and to keep them coming back - public and private organizations in the city are working together to get a city official's marketing idea off the ground.

title: Sunshine and Shallows
description: ALTHOUGH MOST OF THE CENTURIES-OLD literature devoted to fly fishing has to do with wooing trout from streams or rivers, those who have been fortunate enough to angle the tidal flats of Florida are forever beset by a desire to return to the domain of the tarpon and bonefish.

title: A Puritan At the Helm
description: WAKING EARLY, MOORED NEAR A pine-dense island, you go up on deck.

title: Correction
description: A Topics of The Times article on the editorial page yesterday misstated the closing date for this year's New York Flower Show. Today is the last day.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: The Day Einstein Went Public Tom Mackin; Tom Mackin lives in Short Hills.
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN, the world's most famous scientist and perhaps the greatest mind of the 20th century, lived in Princeton longer than any other place. But Princetonians scarcely knew him. He made only one public appearance in the town he called home for 22 years.

title: Tiny Insect Decimates Hemlocks
description: A grove of hemlock trees stood gaunt against the sun here close to the Hudson River, their crowns bare, their branches sparse.

title: TV Outfits That Work in Real Life
description: Television's version of the successful career woman, circa 1980, was a glamorous creature in a big picture hat, with huge diamonds sparkling at her ears and a fox boa draped around her neck.

title: Dance History, Robbins Style
description: LEAD: There is exultation and infinite sadness in ''Jerome Robbins' Broadway,'' now ensconced at the Imperial Theater.

title: The Glory of Tara Will Never Fade
description: WHEN ''Gone With the Wind'' premiered in Bridgeport 50 years ago, it took me two weeks to persuade my mother to take me with her to see it. She and all of her friends were in various stages of reading Margaret Mitchell's novel. Unfortunately for me, Marion Bailey, among them, had finished it, and it was her cryptic four-word critique that sounded the death knell that nearly ruined my chance to view this spectacle at its first showing.

title: Just a Movie
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Takes A Drastic Step
description: Eastern Airlines sought protection in bankruptcy court as a week-old strike crippled its operations and cash flow. Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's corporate parent, the Texas Air Corporation, said the bankruptcy move would sharply reduce Eastern's expenses, which had been running about $4 million a day during the strike. Eastern had about $200 million in cash on hand when the machinists began the walkout on March 4. The unions are expected to propose a bankruptcy reorganization plan of their own that would include substantial worker ownership. Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of T.W.A., said he would like to discuss a takeover of Eastern with the unions. Eastern canceled most flights and concentrated on running its East Coast shuttle, even offering a $12 one-way fare between New York and Washington or Boston on the weekend. Eastern said that when it filed for bankruptcy about $200 million of tickets were outstanding. Holders of those tickets are now creditors of Eastern. *

title: Philharmonic Broadens Its Base
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Philharmonic, celebrating its 10th year, is expanding geographically as well as musically.

title: FASHION DESIGNER
description: Most designers create wedding gowns in lace or silk. Robert Comstock has designed one in leather. In his first collection for women, the 38-year-old men's wear designer has created a wedding suit of white deerskin. The jacket is embroidered with turquoise beads in an Indian motif and tops a skirt that has a sterling silver clasp at the waist. The collection of 35 pieces will be introduced at Bergdorf Goodman in June.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Jack of All Trades (And Master Of Many of Them)
description: /Some students receive medical degrees and others, doctorates in engineering. Some give piano concerts, while others choose to go into quantum physics. But in at least one case, all of these things are being done by the smae person, D. B. Nguyen, who came to this country as a Vietnamese refugee 14 years ago. The accomplishment has made Mr. Nguyen a celebrity at Dartmouth.

title: At the End of A Hard Drive, Maui Luxury
description: THE road to Hana, a secluded town at the easternmost tip of Maui, second largest of the Hawaiian islands, is known as the Hana Highway, undoubtedly dubbed that by some waggish jofficial to encourage tourism. A highway it is not. It is rather a two-lane layering of macadam over a 54-mile course that takes more than two hours and 600 turns to maneuver, a pothole-pocked trail that tunels and twists along rain-eroded cliffs, between sea and rain forests, passing over 54 narroiw birdges. It is a drive that demands endurance, patience, a degree of bravery and, for some, a generous supply of Dramamine.

title: I Call It Making Supper
description: I RECENTLY read yet another article about trends. With the change of the seasons, people who claim to have their finger on the pulse of the future use a lot of fancy words to predict how certain groups of people will eat, dress and entertain themselves for the next several months.

title: Food Town, L.I.: I Like It Here
description: For many years now, the only person who has been even remotely interested in where or what I eat for dinner is my mother. However, since the publication of ''Food Town, L.I.'' (Journal, Jan. 29), I have found that before I order my next tuna sandwich, I had better consider not only the political implications of this choice, but be prepared as well for the publicity it might generate.

title: Home of the Original Surf and Turf
description: LEAD: DEL MAR IS A PLACE ''WHERE NOBODY'S IN A hurry but the horses,'' a publicity man for the racetrack there once observed. I first discovered this in the summer of 1966, when I drove down from my home in Malibu and checked into a seedy motel on the public beach, about 20 miles north of San Diego. I had recently moved to the Los Angeles area from New York, and as a confirmed horse degenerate, I had heard about Del Mar, which had been touted to me by a horseplaying acquaintance named Action Jackson as a ''veritable Southland Saratoga.

title: Actor Well After Heart Bypass
description: Carroll O'Connor, who played Archie Bunker on the television series ''All in the Family,'' was reported ''doing well'' after a coronary bypass operation at Emory University Hospital today. A hospital spokeswoman said doctors performed six grafts to repair damage around the 64-year-old actor's heart.

title: Douglas Fairbanks Jr. Is Turning 80, Going Like 60
description: It seems the older you get, the more people want you to dig up the past,'' says Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as he hands a visitor a cup of English tea during an interview in his Park Avenue apartment. ''I'd much rather talk about the future or at least the present. But not at all. People insist on hearing about the good old days. But were those days really all that good? If so, we certainly didn't realize it.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Fewer Refugees in Texas but Not Elsewhere
description: Large numbers of Central American refugees continue to apply for political asylum in cities around the country, although on the Rio Grande at Brownsville, Tex., the Government has largely succeeded in stopping them.

title: Geography Languishes on U.S. Campuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Anne Hettwer Wed To Gregory Sophocles Hero
description: Susan Anne Hettwer, a manager in the municipal bond department of Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Gregory Sophocles Hero, a vice president of Salomon Brothers, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Detroit Says Efficiency Has Gone Far Enough
description: THE automotive industry accomplished a remarkable technological feat between 1975 and 1985 by nearly doubling the number of miles that cars and light trucks were able to travel on a gallon of gasoline. But now further progress is in jeopardy. At a time when oil imports are rising, domestic oil production is decreasing and environmentalists are warning of the need to curb atmospheric pollution, car makers are lobbying for relaxed fuel efficiency standards.

title: THE WEDDING
description: Regarding ''The Wedding: Stretching the Rules'' (by Linda Wells, Jan. 29), put this article in your pop-up file for five years from now to see how many of these marriages have lasted, once the personalized ceremonies are history. DAVID H. BROWN Rockville, Md.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINIONNear the Heart Of White Plains, A Neighborhood
description: ALTHOUGH quick to admire our modern city, more than a few of us in White Plains have begun to lament its meteoric growth. Downtown, imposing structures of shimmering glass and colored concrete have added the ''plaza'' or ''center'' to their new business addresses. A drive to the train station now winds you onto a approach similar to that of an airport. Overhead, large green highway signs announce ''Trans Center.'' Arrivals must now part ways with Departures. Suddenly you must know if you're coming or going.

title: EDNA O'BRIEN: Reveling In Heartbreak
description: ''WHAT'S YOUR ASTROLOGICAL sign?'' asks Edna O'Brien over the phone, a friendly but odd question from a serious writer. I can't tell if she thinks this is the standard American get-acquainted question, a fey joke on that, if it's of real interest to her, or a sign of natural dizziness. Cautiously, I reveal myself as a Pisces. ''I am a Sagittarius, the archer,'' she says dramatically, although her voice hints at nervous playacting. Rapidly, she puts us on a first-name basis and, after setting up the time and place, creates a scenario for our encounter. ''You, Rick, shall be swimming along and I'' - she pauses, as though not sure where to go with this - ''shall be hitting the target.''

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: One Harvard Goal Unrealized
description: The assets of the Harvard hockey team rarely accrue to an Ivy League sports component these days. There are two brilliant Olympic skaters in Lane MacDonald and Allen Bourbeau, two fine freshman goaltenders, Chuckie Hughes and Allain Roy, and three outstanding lines of almost equal scoring potency. The passing has been near perfect, the defense smothering.

title: Kids and Commercials; In School: Subsidized News Is Worth a Test
description: Does it subvert public education to show a daily video news program with commercials in high schools? Whittle Communications says no. The Tennessee-based company has launched a pilot project to give six high schools $50,000 worth of video equipment in exchange for showing ''Channel One,'' its 12-minute news program for teen-agers that includes two minutes of advertising.

title: Q&A
description: Denmark Question: During a stay in Copenhagen we would like to visit Legoland. How would we get there? Also, are there bed and breakfast places near Tivoli in the city, and are there discounts on local transportation? - H. K., Westport, Conn. Answer: Vacationers bound for Legoland, the amusement park in Billund, from Copenhagen may use rental car or fly, but taking the train is the least expensive route. Trains for Vejle, about 20 miles from Billund, leave daily from Copenhagen's central station. The trains connect at Vejle with buses that go to Billund, and most stop at Legoland, which was founded by the Lego Systems toy company and includes models made of millions of toy bricks. The whole trip, one way, takes about five hours and includes a one-hour crossing by ferry from Zealand to Fyn. Train passengers with reserved seats remain on board while the train goes onto the ferry. The train does not have a dining car, but there is a restaurant on the boat.

title: Knicks' Victory Keeps Home Fires Burning
description: The Knicks did their best shooting in the first and last quarters last night to defeat the Indiana Pacers, 114-95, and run their home-court winning streak to 25 games before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Holbrook $101,000 1 Avenue C 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, dining room, basement; taxes $1,600. Jericho $309,750 5 Ulster Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; skylights, new roof, aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. Branchburg, N.J. $209,000 428 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; screened porch, landscaped yard, greenhouse; taxes $1,800.

title: In Pursuit of Intimate Monumentality
description: Forty or 50 years ago, an urban school was the centerpiece, the anchor, of its neighborhood, a building of both architectural grandeur and civic importance. ''DeWitt Clinton High School Clinton High School was the best building I ever walked into as a kid, except maybe church,'' Robert Esnard, the deputy mayor of New York City, said not long ago of his childhood neighborhood in the Bronx, and he had it exactly right. Schools gave neighborhoods a sense of weight, of dignity. The best ones were large enough in scale to carry off their symbolic roles, yet were still able to feel welcoming, even comforting, to children. They were institutional in the best sense, the sense of being good public places.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 12, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 4 281 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) A ''new science'' that makes it possible to see order and patterns in what appears to be erratic. 6 * 6 ALMOST GOLDEN, by Gwenda Blair. (Avon, $4.50.) The rise and fall of the television anchorwoman Jessica Savitch. 7 39 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 8 7 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) How companies can survive. 9 4 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) The fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 10 7 DONNIE BRASCO: My Undercover Life in the Mafia, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A former F.B.I. agent's inside account. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 3 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Ivy, $4.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 2 33 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 3 9 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 4 6 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1989, edited by Peter Bernstein. (Ballantine, $11.95.) Advice prepared by the staff of a leading accounting firm. 5 * 1 GARFIELD CHEWS THE FAT, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $6.95.) More cartoons about a fat cat. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: The Twain Are Meeting On the World's Opera Stages
description: When the Metropolitan opera set out to cast the revival of ''Rigoletto'' that opens Thursday, a natural choice for the youthful purity of Gilda was the young soprano who had sparkled in recent seasons as Mozart's Susanna and Puccini's Mimi, Hei-Kyung Hong.

title: Meeting With Vatican Soothes U.S. Archbishops
description: Emerging from an unusual four-day meeting with the Pope and his aides, Roman Catholic archbishops from the United States said today the session had largely succeeded in counteracting misunderstanding between the Vatican and the American Catholic hierarchy.

title: Reductios: Absurd or Valuable?
description: The silly season seems to be upon us, to judge from Kazuhito Yamashita's latest recording for RCA. The young Japanese guitarist has favored us with his solo acoustic guitar transcriptions of Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony and Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite.

title: Kieran M. Bracken, Accountant, 65
description: Kieran M. Bracken, an accountant and former controller of the Ford Foundation, died of pneumonia Friday in the Belleair Nursing Care center in Clearwater, Fla., where he lived. He was 65.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: For equal, or nearly equal value, yes. Despite being a feared hitter, he does have significant failings. His defense is suspect, if not downright poor. He catches the ball off-balance and is then in a poor position to throw. His powerful arm is more than negated by the number of extra steps he takes to release the ball. Offensively, any raw speed he has is offset by ignorance of baserunning technique. His looping swing, which he uses to generate towering home run power from his arms, makes him susceptible to droughts. Lastly, and most importantly, Strawberry is not a heads-up ballplayer, nor is he a team man. Give me a Kirby Puckett, Andy Van Slyke, Kevin McReynolds, or Dave Winfield anytime. BOB MOSLOW Bronx

title: Rome's Venerable Ghetto
description: FROM A BELVEDERE ON THE JANICULUM -that most verdant of Rome's hills, bounded on one side by St. Peter's and on the other by Rome and the world - the eye picks out, from among the gorgeous clutter of Roman roofs, two declarative edifices: the Pantheon, its gray rotunda looking from this perspective like a hovering spacecraft; and the great dome of the Temple, Rome's eclectic neo-Byzantine synagogue. The Pantheon (a temple of all the ancient gods, later elevated, consecrated and dedicated to Mary) was built by Hadrian 18 centuries ago; the synagogue was consecrated in 1904. These two buildings, so antithetical in history and design, coexist happily; they seem to have been there, amid umbrella pine and cypress, forever. And this is as it should be; for the genius of Rome is that, sophisticated, tolerant, the motherly repository of human folly and human learning, she accommodates all things: nothing human is alien to this bountiful city.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If these two companies are together, the world, in every shape and form, will truly be our oyster.'' Steven J. Ross, chairman, Warner Communications, on the proposed merger with Time Inc.

title: Switzer's Warning
description: When Barry Switzer, the beleaguered Oklahoma football coach, decided to take his daughter, Kathy Switzer, on a skiing trip to Colorado during spring break last week, some of his friends were skeptical. Aware that within a three-month span Switzer's program had been put on probation for rules violations and five of his players had been arrested on various criminal charges, the friends, as Switzer later recalled it, issued a warning: ''As bad a year as you've had, you'll probably tear up a leg.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Schneider Wins Again: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland became the first skier to post 14 World Cup victories in a season, breaking Ingemar Stenmark's 11-year-old record, by winning the slalom yesterday in Shiga Kogen, Japan. Schneider won the race, the season final, with a two-run clocking of 1 minute 25.67 seconds. That was more than 1 second faster than Monika Maierhofer of Austria, who was timed in 1:26.71. Schneider, 24 years old, swept all seven slalom races this season, with her winning streak beginning at Altenmarkt, Austria, on Dec. 16. She won six giant slaloms, losing only last week at Furano in northern Japan, when she finished third. She also took one combined crown for a total of 14 victories. (AP) Road Racing Scot Sets 10-Kilometer Best: Liz McColgan of Scotland broke the women's world best for a 10-kilometer loop course for the third consecutive year, beating Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway in the Red Lobster Classic yesterday in Orlando, Fla. McColgan, the 1988 Olympic silver medalist at 10,000 meters, was timed in 30 minutes 38 seconds for the 6.2-mile loop course, erasing the world mark of 30:59 she set in this race last year. Keith Brantly of Gainesville, Fla., won the race in a course-record 28:02, 3 seconds ahead of William Musyoki of Kenya.(AP) Best Times in Central Park: Jose Martinez of New Milford, Conn., and Mia Mahedy of Brooklyn each set meet records yesterday in winning the New York Road Runners Club's Horoscope 5-kilometer run that attracted a field of 1,033 at Central Park. Martinez covered the 3.1-mile course in 15 minutes 15 seconds. Mahedy crossed the finish line in 17:10. Soccer Nottingham Forest 3, Arsenal 1: Nigel Clough, Franz Carr and Stuart Pearce scored first-half goals to give Nottingham Forest a victory yesterday in London over first-place Arsenal, tightening the English League First Division race. Forest extended its unbeaten streak to 16 games. Norwich posted a 1-0 home victory over Wimbledon to move within 2 points of Arsenal. Arsenal leads the division with 55 points; Norwich has 53 and has played one fewer game. Trevor Putney scored in the 51st minute. Jimmy Carter scored twice to lead third-place Millwall to a 2-1 victory at Luton. (AP) Tennis Mandlikova Upset: Jenny Byrne upset Hana Mandlikova, 7-6, 6-3 yesterday in a semifinal match at the $250,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Indian Wells, Calif. Byrne, of Perth, Australia, will meet fourth-seeded Manuela Maleeva in the final today. Maleeva upset second-seeded Helena Sukova, 6-2, 6-4 yesterday while playing with possible torn ligaments in her left ankle. (AP) Lendl and Edberg Gain: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and No. 2 seed Stefan Edberg struggled to victories yesterday and will meet today in the final of the $415,000 Eagle Classic of Scottsdale tournament in Arizona. Lendl eliminated fifth-seeded Emilio Sanchez, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3. Edberg beat Amos Mansdorf, 6-7, 6-4, 6-1.(AP) Horse Racing Electric Flash Rallies: Electric Flash, winner of only one race in his career, passed Mr. Nickerson just before the finish and captured the Swift Stakes for 3-year-olds by half a length yesterday at Aqueduct. Mr. Nickerson finished three-quarters of a length in front of Detonated. Texian, the favorite, finished sixth in the eight-horse field. Electric Flash earned $52,380 for owner Helen C. Alexander and returned $28.80 for $2 to win. The Swift is the first of four New York races designed to test Triple Crown hopefuls. Electric Flash, Mr. Nickerson, Detonated and Texian have been nominated for the Triple Crown races. N.H.L. Flyers 7, Blackhawks 2: Rick Tocchet and Tim Kerr scored two goals apiece and their backup goalie, Mark LaForest, recorded 35 saves as the Flyers beat the Chicago Blackhawks at home yesterday for their first victory in six games. LaForest played his second straight game for the injured Ron Hextall, who is nursing a pulled right hamstring, as the Flyers snapped an 0-2-3 steak. Mike Bullard put Philadelphia ahead to stay at 2-1 when he tipped in Terry Carkner's rebound on the power play with 2 minutes 42 seconds left in the opening period.(AP) Golf Nichols Leads Seniors: Bobby Nichols's five-under-par 67 yesterday wasn't much when compared with his 62 on Friday. Still, his two-round total of 129 gave him the lead in the $300,000 Arizona Classic in Phoenix. Bruce Crampton, who started the day five stokes back, shot a 64 to take second place, two strokes behind Nichols. Bob Boldt shot a 10-under 62 to tie Nichols's course and tournament record of 10 under and was three strokes back at 132, tied with Gene Littler, who shot a 65.(AP) Track and Field New High Jump Mark: Hollis Conway, the 1988 Olympic silver medalist from Southwestern Louisiana, smashed the American record in the men's high jump last night, sailing 7 feet 9 1/4 inches in the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor championships at the Hoosier Dome in Indianapolis. Conway's first attempt broke the record of 7-8 3/4 set by Jimmy Howard three years ago. The height was the best ever by an American, indoors or outdoors. Conway missed three times at 7-10 1/2. Suzy Favor of Wisconsin upset Vicki Huber of Villanova in the women's mile. Missouri's Natasha Kaiser set a collegiate record in the women's 400 meters. Favor won by about 4 meters in 4 minutes 30.63 seconds. Kaiser, a senior, broke the collegiate record of 52.39 she set last month by racing to victory in the women's 400 in 51.92. The men's 400 was a swift race. A Florida freshman, Tyrone Kemp, sped to victory in 46.03, breaking the meet record of 46.23 set by Bruce Phillip of Manhattan in Friday's preliminaries. Joe Falcon of Arkansas won the men's mile for the second straight year, clocking 3:58.06. Michigan's John Scherer began his kick with just over 400 meters left in the men's 5,000 meters and won handily in 14:18.05. (AP)

title: Early Entry to College Demands Maturity
description: To the Editor:

title: Camera
description: Every so often a question arrives in the mailbox that does not ask for advice about what camera to buy, but addresses a problem plenty of us share. Here's one example, from L.G., a reader who lives in New York City:

title:
ART;
Photos by Japanese in U.S. From 1920-40
description: LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHY is easily associated with the Japanese, even if only through the stereotype that a Japanese tourist always has a camera around his neck. But the history of this association is barely known. ''Japanese Photography in America, 1920-1940'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford engrossingly illuminates a piece of that history in 85 photographs taken by 30 photographers.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Litchfield Villa; Back to the Past for a Landmark in Prospect Park
description: PERHAPS it is the grand-daddy of all the exposed brick walls in renovated brownstone apartments, first popular around 1960. It has looked the way it does for so long that its original appearance has largely passed out of living memory.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT
description: LEAD: Make room for Pierre de Coubertin, Billy. George Steinbrenner just fired another one. This time, though, George is not just playing musical chairs at his pinstripe farm. He has recently leveled a broadside at the very heart of the Olympic ideal.

title: Jennifer Shafer, Lawyer, to Wed B. R. Shachnow
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Shafer of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Anne Shafer, to Bart Robert Shachnow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Shachnow of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Chianti's Renaissance Landscapes
description: WHEN I was growing up, Chianti meant Italian wine in basketed round-bellied flasks. Little did I know that one day the word Chianti would instantly evoke the most wrenchingly beautiful landscape I know.

title: Freighters
description: To the Editor: The directory of barges and freighters (Travel, Feb. 12) was greatly appreciated. Many people just don't know much about that mode of travel. But there was one slight misstatement: that freighter passengers are not accepted over 75 years of age. Most lines are now up to a 79-year limit, and some are higher, such as CAST, which is 80, and Columbus Line, Chilean Line and Mineral Shipping, which accept passengers through 82. MARY LEBLANC Pasadena, Calif.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Continue pruning and dormant spraying. Time to start indoors seed of tomatoes, peppers, eggplants, cole crops, herbs; place containers in plastic bags to keep the medium moist. Transplant to individual pots seedlings of impatiens, geraniums, perennials and other garden flowers started indoors last month. Last call to mail seed and plant orders for spring planting. Keep Up

title: It Takes Planning to Put Plans Into Action
description: Planning is passe. At the corporate level, officers view planning as unrealistic or even dangerous. They claim they are unable to plan effectively because of the unforgiving nature of the financial forces that press them for short-term performance.

title: Second-Guessing The First Amendment
description: Few mysteries of nature compare to the workings of the legal mind. Of all the free-speech issues that affect popular music, few seem as uncomplicated as the one that has reached the United States Supreme Court in the case of Ward v. Rock Against Racism.

title: Keep the Public Interest Flying
description: Is there life after bankruptcy for Eastern Airlines? It's too early to tell. What's already clear, though, is that if Eastern dies, competition will be reduced and travelers will pay higher fares.

title: No Headline
description: I do not wish to cast doubt on Mr. Garment's regard for ''. . . the careful language used by Mr. McFarlane,'' although I find it troubling that Mr. McFarlane waited until his hearing to be so careful. However, Mr. McFarlane's peculiar use of the word ''ken'' seemed a glitch.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: SALVATORE A. CELONA;
Monitoring the Shortfall of Water
description: LEAD: IT took Hurricane Gloria in October 1985 to get the county and the New York City area out of what was then the worst water shortage in almost two decades. The shortage was so severe that Westchester, which gets 85 percent of its water from the New York City reservoir system, followed the city's lead in imposing an array of water restrictions.

title: For Cuban Musician, a Family Reunion
description: LEAD: AFTER the plane touched down in Miami, one of the first passengers through the gate shouted to Paquito D'Rivera, the Cuban jazz saxophonist: ''Your family is on the plane. They're here.''

title: The Joy of Sharing Our Colonial Past
description: I AM a member of that dying breed of Americans, the volunteer. Even in a small town such as Southold, the opportunities for this type of service are many, at the hospital, churches, youth activities, library; but perhaps the work I do each summer brings the most satisfaction. I am a hostess at our local historical society and my job is to show visitors through a restored early home, the Thomas Moore House.

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Urges Universal Voting for South Africans
description: A legal commission studying the feasibility of a bill of rights for South Africa has concluded that it would have to include the right to vote for the country's disenfranchised black majority.

title: Rangers Drop Out Of First
description: He was one of the rare Capitals to have got any practice in before the morning bomb scare cleared the building and ended the workout. Dale Hunter had stood alone on the ice with a bucket of pucks, firing one after another from the slot into different corners of the empty net.

title: Cynthia Stone Marries
description: Cynthia Rogers Stone, a third-year law student at the Suffolk University School of Law in Boston, and John Joseph Phelan, a pension trust officer at the Bank of New England/Essex in Peabody, Mass., were married yesterday at the Wellesley (Mass.) Congregational Church. The Rev. William B. Abernethy performed the ceremony. Mrs. Phelan, a graduate of Connecticut College, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wadsworth S. Stone of Wellesley Hills, Mass. Mr. Phelan, a graduate of Fordham University who earned an M.B.A. from Boston College, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Phelan of Southbury, Conn.

title: Soviets Deny Asylum to Kidnapping Suspect
description: A fugitive wanted on 14 kidnapping charges in the February 1988 takeover of a North Carolina newspaper office was arrested by Federal agents Friday after failing to persuade officials at the Soviet consulate here to grant him political asylum.

title: Kids and Commercials; At Home: Protest Tasteless TV? Of Course.
description: ''Married . . . With Children'' is a tasteless show about a moronic family given to suggestive experiences and vulgar language. Even so, the half-hour sitcom, shown Sundays at 8:30 P.M., is Fox Broadcasting's top-rated series. What, considering the literary level of most television series, is wrong with that?

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday of work by the photographer Robert Adams incorrectly named the artist who is the subject of the ''American Photographs'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. He is Walker Evans.

title: Review/Music; Cellist Plays Solo and Chamber Pieces
description: Eugene Bondi, a cellist, offered an inconsistent but largely pleasing evening of solo and chamber music Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. It was evident that he had devoted time and care to considering the music's impulses, and that he had firm personal views about the composers' intentions. When he was able to crystallize those insights, the music came alive.

title: 'Students Are a Lot More Self-Concerned'
description: THE average college student of the 1980's wants a secure, well-paying job with opportunities for promotion; his counterpart from the 1970's and 60's wanted to help mankind and change the world, said Douglas Daring, director of the Career Services Department at the University of Connecticut.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STATE OF EMERGENCY. By John Sherlock. (Viking, $18.95.) The British writer John Sherlock's eighth novel describes a conspiracy of international power brokers, members of a secret organization called the Savants, who are plotting to back the election of a charismatic evangelist to the Presidency of the United States and then assassinate him, placing their puppet Vice President in the Oval Office.

title: Goodrich Finally Gets It Right
description: Until just a few years ago, the B.F. Goodrich Company was a fat and sickly organization that did not seem to do anything right.

title: FOCUS: Fannie Mae Disclosures; Foreclosed Homes for People With Modest Incomes
description: A pilot program is getting under way here and in three other cities to see whether foreclosed and vacated residential property can be transformed into housing for low- to moderate-income people.

title: Xenodochiophobia
description: To the Editor: Heartfelt thanks to Bernard Berenson and William L. Tazewell for giving us the delicious Greek concoction xenodochiophobia, fear of hospitality. In the same phobic vein, a few more suggested contributions to the Hellenizing of travel language:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Continental's Denver Flights Get Surcharge

title: HARVARD'S KENNEDY SCHOOL: IS COMPETENCE ENOUGH?
description: DUKAKIS?'' QUIPS the comic on the podium, ''He's Jimmy Carter in tweed without a brother.'' Sardonic snickers. ''I'm not saying the Duke is boring, but whoever thought we'd be reminiscing about the charismatic Mondale campaign?''

title: Taking the Mud at Saturnia
description: IN Saturnia the smell of bad eggs wears off after two hours. Initially overpowering, the sulfurous smell rises with the steam from the hot waters that for millenniums have been gushing out of an extinct volcanic crater in this village, midway between Rome and Florence, in southern Tuscany. The waters of Saturnia have been considered a panacea for a number of ills for 3,000 years. In Etruscan times they were part of sacral rites, while Saturnia was praised by Virgil and other Latin scholars.

title: Don't Drop The BBC
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Torres Weds Michael Gisser
description: Cynthia Ann Torres, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Torres of Sierra Madre, Calif., and Michael Victor Gisser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Gisser of South Orange, N.J., were married yesterday in Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Gary A. Wilburn performed the ceremony at Immanuel Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. John A. Beattie, a Roman Catholic priest, Mary Marijka Kohut was the matron of honor, and Brian M. Monkarsh was the best man.

title: Margaret Remsen Is Married
description: Margaret Story Remsen and Nigel Joseph Shepard Jaquiss were married last evening at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Richard Van Wely. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Charles Gilbert Miller of Greenwich and Frederick Ditmis Remsen of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mr. Jaquiss is a son of Georgina M. S. Jaquiss of Lenox, Mass., and the late Dr. Donald B. G. Jaquiss.

title: For Young Executives, 'Free' Travel Is Fun (for a While)
description: Even without strikes and slowdowns, business travelers are an unhappy lot, or so the conventional wisdom goes. A television commercial for an automobile rental company, for example, depicts business travelers as prisoners, locked in leg irons, forced to subsist on slop. But if most people think life on the road is like life behind bars, there are many young professionals who are delighted to serve a sentence.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE PLEASURES OF JAPANESE LITERATURE. By Donald Keene. (Columbia University, $19.) These graceful essays by Donald Keene, the Shincho Professor of Japanese Literature at Columbia University and a master literary translator, answer many questions Western readers may have about pre-modern Japanese poetry, fiction, theater and esthetics. How comforting to know, for example, that even the Japanese may find the subtleties of traditional Noh theater tedious.
