Mr. Keene explains the religious origins of Noh and says that even a Noh play ''that ends happily is performed today with the deliberation and gravity reserved in most parts of the world for funeral rites'' and that ''many in the audience doze, somehow able to awaken at key moments.'' In a chapter on esthetics, Mr. Keene considers the distinctively Japanese appreciation for suggestion, irregularity, simplicity and perishability; he quotes the 14th-century Buddhist priest Kenko, who wrote, ''The most precious thing in life is its uncertainty.'' Anyone familiar with the hurly-burly of modern-day Japan may wonder where ''suggestion'' and ''simplicity'' exist; Mr. Keene acknowledges this, but maintains that ''the past survives in aesthetic preferences that often find surprising outlets for expression - a box of sushi, a display of lacquered zori, branches of artificial maple leaves along a commercial street.'' Although Mr. Keene intended these essays, originally presented as lectures, for a general audience, I question how well they would be understood by someone who knows nothing of Japanese poetry, fiction or theater. Instead, ''The Pleasures of Japanese Literature'' is an excellent summing up for those familiar with Japanese literature and will entice those with some knowledge to read more.

title: Siena Wins With :01 Left To Gain Berth in Tourney
description: Steve McCoy plucked Tom Huerter's desperation shot from the air and put the ball into the basket with one second left today to lift Siena to a 68-67 victory over Boston University. The victory gave the Saints the E.C.A.C. North Atlantic Conference title and an automatic National Collegiate Athletic Association bid.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: WHO among us is not fascinated by accounts of prehistoric humans? There is something intriguing in the mysterious origins of our species, in our distant ancestors' coming down from the trees, learning to walk upright, to make tools and to speak.

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Kean Seeks Support For Change In Welfare
description: THE Kean administration is seeking support for a plan under which the state would assume the counties' share of the administrative costs for the state's welfare system. The administration says the change would help reduce the property tax burden on New Jersey residents.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Brooklyn; Laughter 101: A Chance to Treat Humor Seriously
description: It's nothing to fall down laughing about, but a professorship in humor will move onto Brooklyn College's campus in the fall.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Split Ends and Other Terminal Illnesses
description: LEAD: YEARS ago, women didn't need psychotherapy; they had beauticians named Vinnie. Unlike a therapist, who charged $100 an hour to help you deal with people, Vinnie charged $10 for a three-hour wash and set and told you that you were right about everything.

title: Car Theft Fraud: A Felon Is a Felon
description: Revealing and interesting was the article [ ''Car Theft Fraud Rampant at Nassau Shopping Mall,'' Feb. 19 ] on car theft fraud as practiced at the Green Acres Shopping Center.

title: Miss Frankel Weds Investor
description: Hilary Joy Frankel and Carl Loeb Kempner Jr. were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Mark Goldman at the Metropolitan Club in New York. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Frankel of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kempner of White Plains.

title: U.S. Shapes Plan to Get Missiles From Afghans
description: The Bush Administration is increasingly concerned that it may not be able to recover hundreds of sophisticated Stinger missiles still in the hands of American-backed Afghan rebels, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Writers Will Stand In For the Rushdies
description: A reading by Salman Rushdie and the novelist Marianne Wiggins, his wife, that was to have taken place Monday night at the Lincoln Center Theater (150 West 67th Street) has been canceled. Instead, more than a dozen prominent writers are to read works that have been censored or attacked. The program is being presented by Writer Nights, a fiction reading series. E. L. Doctorow, Ariel Dorfman, Christopher Durang, Mary Gordon, Arthur Miller, Cynthia Ozick and others will read, and Hugh Masekela will play South African music.

title: Cases of Parental Abduction Increasing
description: LEAD: AFTER a brief but expected argument over the telephone, Ann Zang said, she told her former husband in Hopewell that she would be coming for their daughter a little earlier than usual. And despite any arguments they might have had in the past, she had always been assured that she would have the child with her on her way back to

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LET THERE BE LIGHT A Book About Windows. By James Cross Giblin. Illustrated. 162 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Ten Die in Peru Plane Crash; Eight Victims Are Americans
description: A twin-engine plane struck a building in a Lima suburb, killing the two Peruvian pilots and eight Americans aboard, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Czech Playwright Havel Is Ill In Prison but in Good Spirits
description: The imprisoned Czechoslovak playwright, Vaclav Havel, is suffering from spinal pain but is in good spirits, his wife said today.

title: Free Library Cards Halted for Aged
description: LEAD: FOR years, the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library has offered older people who do not reside in a library district a free library card.

title: Launching on TV
description: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 8:07 A.M. tomorrow, will be televised live on Channels 2, 4 and 7 and on the Cable News Network.

title: Photographic Works of Fantasy
description: PAMELA SHERIN is the Squibb Gallery's new director, but she should not be held responsible for ''Fictive Strategies,'' the show now on view. Best described as a photographic to-do, this is the work of a guest curator, Joseph Rauch, who is a research assistant in the Princeton Art Museum's Minor White Archive.

title: U.N. Units Arrive in Namibia To Check Transition Process
description: Finnish and Danish officers have arrived to make preparations for the arrival of other United Nations peacekeepers assigned to monitor Namibia's transition to independence.

title: Tribal rites and Public Rituals
description: LEAD: MOST NATIONS AND REGIONS HAVE BIG public rites that serve to define their identities: the Sienese have the Palio, the Venetians have the Regatta, the French have Bastille Day and the Americans the Fourth of July. (The British are rather smart: they have coronations, and these are so lavish, emotional and expensive that the effect lasts for a whole reign.) These are the outward signals that define identity.

title: Cedarhurst Is Considering Its Direction
description: For the first time in recent memory, there is a hotly contested race for a seat on the Cedarhurst Village Board. You might call it Main Street's last stand.

title: THE PERFECT BABY?
description: Last year I gave birth to a child with a diaphragmatic hernia, a defect that proved fatal. We desperately wanted our baby to live, despite the fact that she would have faced major difficulties. Yet, watching Emma suffer for six weeks convinced us that, had we known, prenatally, what lay ahead, the better course would have been abortion.

title: Social Events
description: B'nai B'rith to Hear Ward

title: Loudspeakers Climb the Walls
description: The fevered rise of housing costs has put such a crunch on urban living space that many apartment dwellers simply can't find room for loudspeakers. That's quite a switch from earlier times, when even a bulky piano in the living room was pretty much taken for granted by music lovers. But, as they used to say then (when an occasional bit of Latin was also taken for granted), tempora mutantur.Today floor space has to be parceled out by the square inch.

title: Navigating the Changes in Cable TV
description: WHEN the first cable-television system in the state began operations nearly 30 years ago, its major function was to make clear television reception available, for the first time, to isolated communities.

title: Review/Opera; Problems of the Heart, In Two Weisgall Works
description: Like the short story, one-act operas require a concentration powerful enough to sustain single trains of thought over brief periods of time, rather than the long-range stamina needed to juggle many. Hugo Weisgall - who was born in Czechoslovakia in 1912 and raised in Baltimore -has made something of a specialty of the genre. This week, the Opera Ensemble of New York is offering an old example of his work (''The Stronger'' written in 1952) and one that is brand new (''Will You Marry Me?'').

title: Rites of Spring Training
description: AGAINST THE ENORMOUS BLUE BACKDROP of an Arizona morning, early arrivals quietly gather in the grandstand of HoHoKam Park, in Mesa, about 13 miles from Phoenix. Palm trees sway in the soft breeze beyond the billboard fences, and the only sound to be heard is the crack of a bat hitting a ball.

title: A Black Perspective on the 1930's
description: NO decade of the 20th century has sent out more conflicting cultural signals than the 1930's. On the one hand, there are the Busby Berkeley musicals, the dance marathons and the comedies of Clark Gable and Carole Lombard; on the other hand, there is the art focusing mainly on the reality of the Depression - abstractions and the regional fantasies of Grant Wood notwithstanding.

title: Article 269189 -- No Title
description: Crowds of passengers continued to cross picket lines set up by Eastern Airline's striking machinists yesterday to take advantage of the airline's $12 weekend fare on its New York-Washington and New York-Boston shuttle flights.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: The Mets should trade Strawberry only if, after the 1989 season, he and his ill-advising adviser, Eric Goldschmidt, are unbudgingly determined to leave New York. No team can afford to lose a talent like Strawberry to free agency without first trying to get several good players in return through a trade. But it is in the Mets' best interest to keep Strawberry, whose left-handed power and presence is unequaled in the major leagues. DAVE FIORE Forest Hills, Queens

title: 'Aftershocks': Fantasy's Aftermath
description: DOUG HAVERTY'S new play, ''Aftershocks,'' opens very early one morning as two women who share a trailer at Buck's Mobile Estates in California are getting ready for work.

title: Reviews/Dance; Merce Cunningham's 'Native Green'
description: Victoria Finlayson breaks loose in the opening moments of Merce Cunningham's ''Native Green,'' skips ardently forward, bends back sensuously and ripples her arms as if they were the wings of a swan delirious with pleasure. From that point on, we suspect we are in for a happy, giddy time.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Snuggling Up With Classic Camel's Hair
description: The camel's-hair overcoat is as dependable in cold weather as the camel is when it's hot. Here is a cover-up that will go anywhere with practically anything, be it a pin-striped business suit or blue jeans and a turtleneck, silk scarf or wool choker. It's dressy enough when it needs to be, but there's always that nice dash of informality and practicality. And when winter gets nasty, as it did this past week, just turn that big collar up and ignore the thermometer.

title: Fond Memories From Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
STYLE MAKERS: LARRY BRIDGES;
FILM MAKER
description: LEAD: In directing and editing film, Larry Bridges has proved it is a short jump from music videos to Madison Avenue.

title: Home Loans
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Behind the Vedder Mystique
description: LEAD: FOR a glimpse into the curious mind of Elihu Vedder, an eccentric painter, illustrator and designer, the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University in Hempstead is offering an exhibition of drawings and painted sketches appropriately titled ''Elihu Vedder: Mystic Figures of the 19th Century.''

title: The City of Light Throws a Party
description: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION was neither the best of times nor the most frivolous, but there will be plenty of frivolity throughout Republican Paris this year. It seems every museum, every arrondissement's city hall, even every esoteric reading club, is vying to mark the events of 1789, although of course no one wants to re-create the parts that make everybody uneasy.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Besides the Mets' pitching staff, Strawberry is the only outstanding player the team has. Sure Hernandez was, Jeffries could be, and McReynolds might be. But, none brings the magic to the plate like Strawberry. His ability to hit the long ball at a pitchers' park, his blazing speed, topped with his m.v.p.-like stats the last two years makes him the top everyday player in the National League, and maybe in the Major Leagues. And besides, how could the Mets get a fair price for him with his rep? MICHAEL HASDAY Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Internecine quarrels aside, what's a harmless little kiss? Does Mozart compose without a family? Does Picasso paint without being born? And haven't we all seen the torture of being born to a violent wind? New York lost an entire organization to L.A. Must we lose Darryl Strawberry, too? ROBERT GUADAGNINO Brooklyn

title: Pinochet Will Weigh Changes to Ease Transition
description: Beginning his last year as President, Gen. Augusto Pinochet today agreed to consider constitutional changes urged both by his right-wing supporters and opposition parties to smooth a transition to democracy.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE STAMFORD MUSEUM AND NATURE CENTER;
Art Among the Cows and Geese
description: LEAD: IT is rare to find an institution as eclectic as the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. Set on more than 100 wooded acres, the museum offers, in nine widely scattered buildings, galleries devoted to art, history or science; space for classes and lectures; an observatory; a planetarium; a working dairy farm and such outdoor pleasures as nature trails, picnic grounds and a small lake with swans, geese and ducks.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: East Hartford, Conn. $130,000 15 Matthew Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; landscaping, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,398. Sherman, Conn. $365,000 Orange Pepper Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; fireplace, pond, 3.3 acres; taxes $2,000. Westport, Conn. $145,000 10 Tar Rock Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; new furnace, close to train and beach, one-half acre; taxes $2,646. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $718,000 258 Elm Road 7-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 64-year-old colonial; 6 fireplaces, servants' quarters, 1.9 acres, taxes $8,500. Chappaqua, N.Y. $614,250 2 Warwick Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; pool, Jacuzzi, cabana, 1.04 acres; taxes $8,212. Harrison, N.Y. $980,000 Lawrence Lane 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 53-year-old stone/stucco Tudor; 4,440 square feet, terraces, 1 acre; taxes $9,807. OTHER SALES Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $140,000 6 Lake Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100. Old Bethpage, L.I. $225,000 14 Jane Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; master-bedroom suite, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. Branchburg, N.J. $209,000 428 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; screened porch, landscaped yard, greenhouse; taxes $1,800.

title: Admiring Beauty Over Academics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nancy Siegel Wed to Richard Jaffee
description: The wedding of Nancy Ellen Siegel, a daughter of Barbara J. Siegel and Jesse S. Siegel, both of New York, to Richard Isadore Jaffee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart R. Jaffee of Worcester, Mass., took place last evening at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Rabbi Stanley Davids officiated. Hillary Levin, the bride's sister, was the matron of honor. Paul Samuel Jaffee was best man for his brother. Mrs. Jaffee, who was until recently an account executive at FCB/Leber Katz Partners, an advertising agency in New York, is studying creative writing at New York University. She graduated from the Riverdale Country School and Barnard College.

title: After Tower Debacle, Washington Wonders About the Fallout
description: IN rejecting John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, a bitterly divided Senate seemed to be applying a new and ill-defined standard of personal and professional conduct. The next question is how extensively and uniformly the standard will be applied to other Cabinet nominees, to lower-ranking Administration officials and to lawmakers themselves.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Advancing on Colds; Virus Stakeout
description: CURING the common cold has always seemed an impossible dream, but at last scientists are beginning to see ways they might achieve it. Last week researchers reported experimental results that might eventually lead to a drug that would act as a decoy, diverting cold viruses from attacking human cells.

title: Frances Pennoyer, 92, J. P. Morgan's Child
description: Frances T. Pennoyer, the last surviving child of J. P. Morgan, died yesterday after a stroke at her home in Locust Valley, L.I. She was 92 years old.

title: I'm (Choose One): Conservative. Liberal.
description: LEAD: Under the Bush Administration, Americans may not be getting any kinder or gentler about the people who bring them their news, but they certainly have become more balanced about the names they call us.

title: As Salvador Vote Nears, Which Way for the Right?
description: After leading throngs of clapping supporters in a martial campaign song called ''Tremble, Tremble Communists,'' Roberto d'Aubuisson took a machete from an aide and sliced a watermelon in two. The fruit, he told the cheering campaign crowd, represented Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Christian Democrats, whose party color is green - green on the outside, he said, but red on the inside.

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Questions Are Right
description: The foreign policy reviews to provide the Bush Administration with a new look at the Reagan heritage are going on feverishly around the capital, despite many still-empty offices.

title: TALKING: Asbestos; Removal Problems In Homes
description: OWNERS of older one- and two-family houses in New York City, aware that asbestos is lurking somewhere in their homes, will have to face some difficult decisions as a consequence of new city regulations.

title: Ex-Contra Seeking to Broadcast in Nicaragua
description: In a test of the Sandinista Government's recent commitments to greater political pluralism, a former contra leader has requested permission to open a private television channel in time for this year's election campaign.

title: Correction
description: An item in the Sports People column last Sunday incorrectly reported the number of players who have been members of the Parade Magazine high school all-America team for three seasons. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Patrick Ewing are the only ones to have made the first team three times. Six players - Abdul-Jabbar, Ewing, Kenny Anderson, Alonzo Mourning, Sean Kemp and Jerrod Mustaf - made the team as either a first- or second-team selection in three seasons.

title: FICTION'S EMBATTLED INFIDEL
description: I fail to see how Salman Rushdie can say about Islamic culture, ''I know it well'' (''Salman Rushdie: Fiction's Embattled Infidel,'' Jan. 29). After all, from the age of 13, he worked to be accepted by a society that despises the culture from which he came. However, if it is true that he understands Islamic culture well, this is proof that his current book is a conscious defamation of Islam. Stating this is a work of fiction is no justification. Most non-Muslims know nothing about Islamic history, and therefore would be unable to sort out fact from fiction.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 12 about the Kennebec River in Maine misidentified the head of the Natural Resources Council of Maine. He is Jon Lund.

title: Yanks Look Closely at Braves' Blauser
description: Every time they walk by, Jeff Blauser hears their friendly gibes. Sometimes, they serenade him with off-key versions of ''New York, New York.'' Sometimes, they ask if he has packed his bags and prepared himself for announcement of the trade. Today, they wondered if he were taking batting practice with them or with the Yankees.

title: DISK JOCKEY
description: Red Alert, one of New York's most influential disk jockeys, never realized just how popular he was until he began to travel. His Saturday night radio show, broadcast live from 9 P.M. to midnight on WRKS-FM (also known as KISS-FM) at 98.7 on the dial, is not syndicated, yet his distinctive rap has gathered fans as far away as Chicago and London.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WORKING FOR LOVE. By Tessa Dahl. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The Hollywood movie star's daughter who fears she herself will never amount to anything; the unfavored child always scheming for Daddy's attention; the perennial victim in love. Molly, a 30-year-old mother of three, is all of the above. Now living in London and recently deserted by her husband, Jack, she's determined to expose the woes of her past and her present.

title: F.B.I. TELLS OF CLUE TO BOMBING OF VAN
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that its evidence pointed to a pipe bomb as the device used in the explosion of a car driven by Sharon Lee Rogers, the wife of the captain of the Navy cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet in July.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TALES OF FAMILY TIES ''Some Sweet Day'' by Nancy Fales Garrett, featured last year in the play-reading series at the Long Wharf, will open March 23 as the theater's 200th Main Stage production.

title: Darby Brown Marries Rodman Reeder Fox
description: Darby Coleen Brown and Rodman Reeder Fox, graduates of Middlebury College, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Sun Valley, Idaho. The Rev. Reginald Wilson performed the ceremony.

title: DATA BANK: March 12, 1989
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Jury Trial Is Videotaped to Teach the Young
description: As the cameras rolled, Justice Frank Vaccaro stood solemnly in his long black robe and delivered a monologue about the responsibilities of jurors.

title: DISSATISFACTIONS AND CONTENTS
description: SULLEN WEEDY LAKES By William Logan. 76 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $9.95. TOWN LIFE Poems. By Jay Parini. 79 pp. New York: An Owl Book/Henry Holt & Company. Paper, $10.95. BLOOD PRESSURE By Sandra M. Gilbert. 114 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: Springy Tempos
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilary Carla Ginsberg to Be the Bride Of Joseph A. Feshbach in the Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ginsberg of Roslyn, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Carla Ginsberg to Joseph Alan Feshbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Feshbach of Miami Beach. A July 8 wedding is planned.

title: A List of Repairs For New York City
description: NEW YORK CITY has started taking inventory. Last November, city voters overwhelmingly approved what seemed to be a simple, not to say obvious, notion: a requirement that officials take an accounting of the badly aging infrastructure of roadways, bridges, parks and buildings, and draw up a plan for regular maintenance.

title: Planners Find Silver Lining In Office Glut
description: The glut of office space in New York City and throughout the metropolitan region persists and in some areas is growing worse, part of a national trend that followed a wave of growth earlier in the 1980's.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'EDITH WHARTON' Irene Worth, a member of Broadway's Theater Hall of Fame, will star in the world premiere of ''The Astonishing Edith Wharton'' at Seton Hall University in South Orange on Wednesday.

title: Article 623189 -- No Title
description: A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY By John Irving. 543 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Mao's Portrait in the Plaza: Is It Next to Go?
description: In a proposal laden with symbolism, one of China's most prominent architects has called for the removal of a giant portrait of Mao Zedong from its perch in the center of the capital.

title: Wendy Adams Wed in Virginia
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Newport News, Va., Rebecca Wendling Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Banks T. Adams Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Macrae Montgomery, the son of Mrs. E. Paul Montgomery of Newport News and the late Mr. Montgomery. The Rev. Douglas G. Burgoyne performed the ceremony.

title: 'THE FRANK SINATRA OF SHAKESPEARE'
description: RICHARD BURTON A Life. By Melvyn Bragg. Illustrated. 533 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: TOO YOUNG TO DIE?
description: I WAS SCARED. I KNEW SOMETHING WAS GONNA HAPPEN,'' HEATH Wilkins recalls. ''My life had become unbearable to me. It was the first time I was out on my own, the first time nobody was responsible for me - see what I'm saying?''

title: Ferry, Davis No. 1 Players
description: Danny Ferry of Duke and Clarissa Davis of the University of Texas have been selected the recipients of the 1989 Naismith Award as the players of the year in college basketball.

title: Sugan Pie, Montreal's Winter Comfort Food
description: WINTER pies, made with staples found in every larder and designed to fight the cold with calories, are particularly dear to the Quebecois. Old-fashioned favorites, which are now served in Quebec year round, include raisin pie, suet pie, and tarte a la ferlouche (molasses and raisin pie). But the most Quebecois of all, beloved of grand-meres, greasy spoons and traditional restaurants all around the province, is tarte au sucre, sugar pie.

title: Variety Spices Creativity for The Feld Ballet
description: The Feld Ballet has had an especially creative season, thanks to new works by Eliot Feld, its director, and to a new-found freedom that has spurred a high expressivity in the dancers.

title: CLUB COMFORT
description: I RECENTLY DINED IN ONE OF THE PATRI-cian clubs scattered throughout New York -those limestone oases that transport you from the tumult of city life. In the library, attending maids passed prefatory drinks to our assembly, along with hot hors d'oeuvres: flaky spinach tarts; napoleons of Roquefort; smoked salmon on dark bread; shrimp with green mayonnaise. Bowls of iced celery and carrots and dishes of warm salted almonds arrived too - all treats from the past. I had forgotten how delightful the civilized drink can be when accompanied by such cocktail food.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: I am offended that Joseph A. Califano Jr. consistently equated the major social problems facing this country with blacks, in his article ''Tough Talk for Democrats,'' Jan. 8. Poverty is not a race issue. Crime is not a race issue. Poor education is not a race issue. The influence of unhealthful environments on otherwise healthy children is not a race issue. Thinking of these problems as racial encourages placing the blame on people instead of on the situations. CAROLYN L. MYLANDER Chicago

title: Intramural Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Teri Feldstein Weds
description: Teri Ann Feldstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Feldstein of Woodbury, L.I., was married last evening to Steven William Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Gold of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Gold, a graduate of the University of Maryland, is the assistant to the vice president of New York International Business, a Brazilian trading company. Mr. Gold, an associate at the New York law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, graduated cum laude from the University of Florida and received a J.D. degree from the Brooklyn Law School.

title: Special Prosecutor Urged in Inquiry in Capital
description: The criminal division of the Justice Department has asked Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate the hiring of a Congressman's son by Walter Fauntroy, the delegate for the District of Columbia in the House of Representatives.

title: Misconception On No-Fault Insurance
description: Having read Judith Sloan's cutesy article (''The No Generation: A Modern Glossary,'' Feb. 19), I would like to point out a misconception she has as to no-fault insurance.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MAKEBA: My Story, by Miriam Makeba with James Hall. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Born in South Africa, the black singer Miriam Makeba has drawn on her Swazi culture to endure a career in political exile. Her autobiography is the story of ''life lived as communal dialectic, a matter of African creative will set against bureaucratized repression,'' Robert Farris Thompson said here last year. THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Warner, $5.95.) After the failed Fenian uprising of 1867, one young Irishman becomes a terrorist, one becomes aJU politician and one becomes a schoolmaster, who tries to make sense of it all. Last year our reviewer, George Garrett, said this novel ''is about the making of history, the confusion and complexity of motives and events (and Irish history is breathlessly complicated), the selectivity and fallibility of memory, the constantly changing nature of all past time. . . . Mr. Flanagan evokes a country, its countryside, its weathers and seasons, its earth and old stones, and the long, dark shadows of its history. And the writing is so clear and clean; every sentence seems to shine.'' A HISTORY OF WESTERN ASTROLOGY, by S. J. Tester. (Ballantine, $9.95.) Compared with astronomy, astrology is pure pseudoscience, but back in ancient times it was one of the more rational world views around. In 1988 our reviewer, Anthony Grafton, said S. J. Tester's ''lucid, well-informed and concise book tells a coherent story that until now had to be pieced together from primary and secondary sources of diverse age, aim and value. In doing this, his book fills a large and rather surprising gap.'' FOR THE RECORD: From Wall Street to Washington, by Donald T. Regan. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) This is the book in which Nancy Reagan was unmasked as a devotee of the zodiacal arts. Donald T. Regan, her husband's star-crossed chief of staff, tells ''a riveting tale of political downfall and human agony,'' Morton Kondracke said in The Book Review last year. Avon has reprinted the book that cost Larry Speakes, Ronald Reagan's former press secretary, his job on Wall Street. In SPEAKING OUT: The Reagan Presidency From Inside the White House ($4.95), written with Robert Pack, Mr. Speakes confessed that he had fabricated quotations for the President. BLACK BOX, by Amos Oz. Translated by Nicholas de Lange with the author. (Vintage International, $8.95.) His excessively adulterous ex-wife marries a religious zealot, but an Israeli expert on fanaticism shows that he might be the most fanatical one of them all. Last year our reviewer, Mary Gordon, said that Amos Oz ''creates a prose whose tensions almost force the reader to a richer understanding of his complex world.'' SACRED BOND: The Legacy of Baby M, by Phyllis Chesler. (Vintage, $7.95.) The controversy over surrogacy, or ''industrialized pregnancy,'' is in many ways a class struggle, the author writes. Those with enough money hire less advantaged breeders to bear the children they cannot have. The book is ''a powerful critique of the way many of us were inclined to think as we read'' about the Baby M case, Robert Coles said in these pages last year. ''The smugly self-serving sociological and psychological generalizations that pass for truth today simply fail to do justice to the range and complexity of human feeling.'' THE HEARTS AND LIVES OF MEN, by Fay Weldon. (Dell, $4.95.) In a surrealistic parody of a Dickens serial, a young waif named Little Nell escapes a nasty custody battle and embarks upon cliffhanging adventures - including a stint in an oppressive English boarding school. ''This novel delivers what its ambitious title promises: a dazzling, kaleidoscopic view of the love-hate core of men's (and women's) lives,'' James Wilcox said in The Book Review last year. It is ''a beguiling romance that makes the aches and pains of today's somewhat muddled relationships seem well worth the effort.'' THE NATURE OF TIME, edited by Raymond Flood and Michael Lockwood. (Basil Blackwell, $11.95.) If the expanding universe runs out of steam and begins to collapse into a Big Crunch, will time start running backward? This collection of essays ''is filled with such provocative ruminations,'' Michael Talbot said here in 1987. ''In an age that often seems to thrive on the vapid, [ it ] provides some heady and challenging relief.'' MAN WITH A GUN, by Robert Daley. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) In his crusade against crime, an idealistic New York City police administrator runs afoul of department politics and finds the Mayor, his fellow officers and the black community ganging up against him. ''What matters most in this sort of novel is the ride,'' Richard Lourie said here last year. ''Mr. Daley's roller coaster gives us our money's worth - a long, slow climb to the top, a heart-in-your-throat plunge and then a last quick corner at the end.'' NO TELEPHONE TO HEAVEN, by Michelle Cliff. (Vintage International, $8.95.) A family of Jamaicans finds itself torn between island culture and the allure of the United States. In 1987 The Times's Michiko Kakutani said Michelle Cliff's artful use of Jamaican slang and her ''lyrical evocation of the land . . . possess the incantatory power of poetry.'' BLACK HEARTS AND SLOW DANCING, by Earl W. Emerson. (Penguin, $3.95.) On his first day as acting sheriff of a small town in Washington, a fire chief named Mac Fontana is called on to solve the murder of a fellow fireman. ''This is an expert, readable job with a likable hero,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year.

title:
RUMSON JOURNAL;
Couple's Plight Raises Questions of a Town's Heart
description: LEAD: TWELVE years ago, as newlyweds, Charles and Barbara Moore bought a new home in the modest Rumson neighborhood where Mrs. Moore, a Jersey City native, had spent many happy childhood summers.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Yeshiva; 'Uncommon' Play, Uncommonly, Has No Parts for Men
description: Yeshiva 'Uncommon' Play, Uncommonly, Has No Parts for Men Taking the man's part is something the Dramatic Society of Stern College for Women is willing to do when the script calls for it. But this season the society has no such need: it is putting on a play that has roles only for women.

title: Ms. Bayliss Marries Simon Hambidge
description: Elizabeth Ardys Bayliss and Simon John Hambidge were married yesterday at the United Church of New Marlborough in Southfield, Mass. The Rev. John Robert Hambidge of the Church of England, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Happy Night for Islanders
description: The Islanders don't like the Devils, but they feel just the opposite about their rookie goalie Jeff Hackett, who entered this game without a victory in five career starts. That's why they were rendered jubilant by tonight's 3-2 overtime victory against New Jersey, the club that knocked them out of the playoffs last spring.

title: Venezuela Inquiry Urged on Abuses in Riots
description: Amnesty International has urged Venezuela to investigate accusations of human rights abuses, including reports that the police killed people in their homes during rioting over prices two week ago.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Music View column on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the transcriptions of Wagner works performed in piano recordings by Glenn Gould. They are by Gould himself.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Italian Surprises
description: HUNTINGTON'S La Rondine restaurant disproves the ''what you see is what you get'' theory. The neighborhood Italian restaurant wedged between delicatessen and video store is a Long Island cliche.

title: Tested by Time
description: Richard Martin can't suppress a smile of triumph as he shows off his prize acquisition. Slick to the touch, and not much to look at, save to Martin's expert eye, it is, in pop parlance, a ''nerd shirt.''

title: Towers Don't Belong In the Pine Barrens
description: The article ''Towers for Pine Barrens Opposed'' (Jan. 22) was interesting. I'd like to thank the citizens of Warren Grove for bringing to the attention of environmentally concerned citizens the planned construction of high-frequency towers.

title: Angry Merchants in Renewal's Path
description: LEAD: BOB and Barbara Kahn sat in the office of their glass sales and service shop, which will be torn down by the end of the year to make room for the 31-story Station Place condominium tower, and wondered about the future for themselves and their employees.

title: Demand Slows for Home Equity Loans
description: LEAD: ENTICED by low interest rates and soaring property values two years ago, thousands of Long Island homeowners dipped into the home equity loan pool.

title: For Men, Clothes That Make the Character
description: ''It's a lot easier for me,'' said Shelly Levine, the men's costumer for ''L.A. Law.'' ''It's a lot more difficult to design for the women on the show.''

title: SOVIETS GONE, NAJIBULLAH BOASTS AND LIFE IN KABUL CHANGES LITTLE
description: The guerrilla rockets started to hit the eastern districts of this capital shortly after 3 P.M. today, sending great clouds of dust rising into the still winter air. At the Kabul Intercontinental Hotel, a man sweeping the tennis court paused for a while to watch, then calmly resumed his work.

title: Recycling Bill Draws Mixed Reviews
description: Officials of the agency that buys supplies for New York City say a City Council bill on recycling - intended to ease the garbage crisis - will make life uneasy for them. They say the bill's requirement that they give preference to products made of recycled material will slow down the purchasing process, possibly make it more expensive and cause the city to buy merchandise whose efficacy is unproven.

title: Bridge
description: The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, already in progress in Reno, Nev., will have a double climax next weekend. At the top end of the tournament scale a handful players of vast experience will carry off the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams and the Women's Swiss Teams, thus earning the last playoff spots in the hope of going to the world championships in Perth, Australia in September.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits. To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave. I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment. Would car windshield-washer fluid be a better alternative ?

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Darryl wants the fans to understand that baseball is a business, so let's treat him as a businessman. The Mets should keep Darryl and renegotiate his contract with the following proviso: If he does not come through with the fantastic year he promised, he should take a pay cut. AMY PASCO New York

title: Oprah Winfrey's Odyssey: Talk-Show Host to Mogul
description: Here is a typical story from the pages of the improbable career of Oprah Winfrey: It's 1984, the 30-year-old host of a Chicago morning talk show is in North Carolina, on the set of Steven Spielberg's film ''The Color Purple.'' Though she has no previous acting experience, she has been cast in an important supporting role in a lavish production of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel.

title: FATHER TONGUE, MOTHER TONGUE
description: DANCING AT THE EDGE OF THE WORLD Thoughts on Words, Women, Places. By Ursula K. Le Guin. 306 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: Assault Rifles Inspire a Bill
description: MILITARY assault weapons, many of which are sold as legal semiautomatic weapons but which can be converted to a fully automatic mode, would be banned in the state under legislation introduced by State Senator Suzi Oppenheimer, Democrat of Mamaroneck.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: New London
description: LEAD: THE water has always defined this city's existence, figuring prominently in its wealth when times were good and in its distress when they were not.

title: A Diver's Map of Bermuda: Here There Be Treasures
description: WHAT IS THIS THING? A ship, you say? Well, no. Not anymore. Once she was a ship, a few centuries ago. Now she looks like something that spent a hundred years in a food processor and another hundred in a trash compactor. She must have struck the reef over there and slid off into this sand hole and stuck, all of her, and wallowed and worked and rocked back and forth under the force of tide and current and countless storm seas, vanishing into the living coral and beneath the shifting sand until, back in 1983, a sharp-eyed Bermudian spotted an anomaly on the bottom and decided to investigate.

title: Upsets and Records In New York Meet
description: Nnenna Lynch of Hunter College High School and Brad Sumner of McQuade Jesuit in Rochester turned in stellar performances today at the New York State boys and girls indoor track and field championships at Cornell University.

title: West Germany and Its Biotechnology Anxiety
description: WEST GERMAN science passed a milestone of sorts this month when the Government's Central Commission for Biological Safety approved an experiment involving 37,000 petunias genetically altered to be pink when they bloom next May.

title: Did Ike Oppose the Bomb?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Fix a Statute Run Amok
description: RICO, is a statute run amok and no one is beyond its reach. Many times a day, unsuspecting citizens and businesses are shocked to find that they are targets of RICO suits. The law's broad civil suit provisions cast a net so wide that virtually any commercial dispute becomes a candidate for civil RICO jurisdiction.

title: Federal Fee Plan Irks Saltwater Anglers
description: LAST summer, when George Bush visited the New Jersey coastal resort of Belmar, he made a campaign pledge: No Federal licensing fees would be imposed on saltwater fishermen if he became President.

title: In Moving Uptown, A Hopeful 'Heidi' Takes a Gamble
description: Heidi, the witty but spiritually wounded art historian in Wendy Wasserstein's play ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' opened on Broadway last Thursday. To most people who followed her travails during the play's sold-out run at Playwrights Horizons on West 42d Street, Heidi and her friends won't look much different at the Plymouth, a Shubert theater on West 45th Street. The play's text and design remain virtually unchanged.

title: David Edelson to Wed Cynthia Frank
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frank of Englewood, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ellen Frank, to David Bick Edelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Edelson of Ridgewood, N.J. A May 6 wedding is planned.

title: ON THE BRINK OF BAGDOM
description: THE LAST ROOM IN MANHATTAN By Kathleen Rockwell Lawrence. 314 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 19 about computer network links between the United States and the Soviet Union reversed the identities of owners of two commercial network services.

title: Study Criticizes Low Enrollment in Food Program
description: More than 100,000 of the 312,000 mothers and children in New York City who are eligible to receive food through a government-supported nutrition program are not enrolled in it. That is the principal finding of a recent study of the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC.

title: THE AGE OF BRASS
description: FOUR STARS By Mark Perry. Illustrated. 412 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: Charles E. McDonnell, Stockbroker, 65
description: Charles E. McDonnell, a stockbroker, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title: Showdown At 'Gunbelt' Savings
description: The Sunbelt Savings Association sits in a nondescript four-story office building overlooking an endless stream of cars that whiz by on the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway. Dark tinted windows give it a secretive quality and it is hard to distinguish this building from at least a dozen others clustered like so many covered wagons and encircled by concrete freeways.

title: Its Schedule Tight, NASA Prepares to Launch Shuttle
description: With the launching of the space shuttle Discovery set for Monday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is buckling down to a busy year in which slight delays could throw its ambitious schedule into disarray.

title: Reviews/Dance; A New 'Dancetale' From Sally Hess
description: No matter what she danced, Sally Hess would surely be compelling. Yet simply because she is such a charismatic performer, she deserves to dance only works that challenge as well as display her interpretative powers.

title: Women, Children and Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Reflections From Death Row
description: LEAD: UP staircases and through windings and turnings, and amid the clanging of steel doors being shut, a visitor was recently escorted to the capital sentence unit at Trenton State Prison - commonly known as death row.

title: Struggle for Polish Port Reflects Rifts in East Bloc
description: There are Poles in Szczecin who acknowledge the peculiar irony that the city owes its very Polishness, and a lot of its problems, to Stalin.

title: Stamps
description: Hobbyists, especially younger ones, must listen to the standard speech by the fogies of philately about how educational stamp collecting is.

title: Hoyas Breeze Past Pittsburgh
description: What happened to Pitt yesterday has happened to many teams confronted with Georgetown's suffocating defense this season.

title: Just How Far Right Is Salvador's Right?
description: The far-right Republican Nationalist Alliance is favored to win the Salvadoran presidency in an election next Sunday. The prospect is raising questions in Washington and El Salvador about whether the party is controlled by its standard-bearer, Alfredo Cristiani, or Roberto d'Aubuisson, a former officer widely linked to political killings. Article, page 14.

title: O'Rourke Strengthens His Position for Race
description: IT was Friday morning just more than a week ago and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke was in Public School 25 in Yonkers preparing for a ''news conference'' with fifth and sixth graders, a technique Mr. O'Rourke has used to meet some of his younger constituents and to explain how county government works.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MIXED BLESSINGS: An Almost Ordinary Life in Hitler's Germany. By Heinz R. Kuehn. (University of Georgia, $17.95.) Sometimes the bigness of history makes us forget, for example, that common folk painted houses alongside Adolf Hitler. ''Mixed Blessings'' reminds us that history also means that an ordinary 13-year-old boy like Heinz Kuehn saw Hitler's ''puffed-up face'' at close range in 1933 at a Potsdam procession.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Rebirth With Elegance in Hoboken
description: LEAD: FOR several years the lace-curtain bistro above a saloon called the Brass Rail, on Hoboken's main street, was a regular stop for fans of the uncomplicated, undated French fare offered there at uninflated prices. After a fire about a year ago, however, the restaurant was closed, and it seemed that the Brass Rail was to be yet another gastronomic memory.

title: Q and A
description: A Daughter's Right to Stay

title: Teller Machines
description: To the Editor: I noted with interest the item concerning getting cash from automatic teller machines in England (Travel Advisory, Jan. 22).

title: House Prices Dropping as Market Hits Slump
description: WHEN George G. Roller of Stamford put his house on the market, he hoped to recoup his $501,000 investment plus $35,000 he had sunk into improvements, as well as something for the interest he had paid over the last 20 months.

title: THE WEDDING
description: Carol Vogel spotted the unusual in wedding gifts in her article ''The Gifted''; however, she did miss one. When my husband and I married last spring, merging two households, there were few traditional gifts that we needed. So when friends and family asked what we'd like, we included in our list three specific charities to which donations might be sent. KIMBERLY BONNELL New York, N.Y.

title: Reviews/Music; Premiere Of Quintet By Rorem
description: The centerpiece of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's current program - played Friday night and to be repeated this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall - is a new quintet by Ned Rorem, called ''Bright Music'' and scored for flute, two violins, cello and piano.

title:
TV VIEW;
Pay Dirt at the Ol' Spinoff Corral
description: LEAD: ''You know what a 26 rating and 39 share say to me?'' exulted the King of TV Programming, scanning the Nielsen numbers on the recent CBS mini-series, ''Lonesome Dove.''

title: The Narrow Margin
description: There is no more delicate responsibility for political leaders than nuclear weapons. But from the beginning, in 1945, leaders made decisions about the weapons on flawed premises and with inadequate understanding of possible consequences. We are lucky to have avoided the worst.

title: UGANDA: AFTER THE TERROR
description: THE ROAD FROM KAM-pala first leads east, toward Kenya, and then, just before the border, turns abruptly north, toward the Sudan. Today we are driving north, straight into the lion's den -into rebel-infested territory.

title: Vibrant Printed Cottons in Alsace
description: WHEN I recently admired a printed cotton tablecloth, jade green and brown with a wide border of mauve and blue posies, at a wine maker's tasting room in Alsace, the wine maker said the traditional pattern was based on an 18th-century Alsatian wedding scarf. The tablecloth, he said, had been printed at the Steiner firm in Ribeauville, a wine village along the historic Route du Vin, which begins just south of Strasbourg.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those Western media that yesterday were chanting our defeat today are forced to admit that the armed opposition cannot achieve any success and that they have no future.'' - President Najibullah of Afghanistan. [ 18:1. ]

title: Michael Manning Is the Bridegroom Of Miss Bishopric
description: Suzanne Powell Bishopric and Michael James Manning were married yesterday by the Rev. Susan Harriss at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The bride is a daughter of Anne Bishopric Sager of Venice, Fla., and Dr. George Andrew Bishopric of Sarasota, Fla. Mr. Manning is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Manning of Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week in The Week in Review on airplane repairs misstated the number of accidents and deaths related to metal fatigue on United States commercial airliners in the last five years. According to the National Transportation Safety Board, there have been 16 accidents and one death.

title: TRIUMPHING STILL
description: THE STOLEN LIGHT Continents of Exile. tr,br1By Ved Mehta. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Construction Can Be Hazardous to Trees
description: LEAD: A MAJOR problem for those who build or purchase a new house on a wooded site is that the trees often die over a two- or three-year period following construction. Most often, the wooded setting was a major factor in the decision to buy the property. To have this setting deteriorate is a disappointment, to say the least, and it usually represents a significant loss in the market value of the property and a sizable cost for tree removal.

title: Needed: A New Governor Who'll Shake Things Up
description: The race to elect the next Governor of New Jersey is under way. And as we await the clamor that's sure to come, the type of man or woman we need in the State House has never been more evident.

title: Paris 1989: 200 Years of Liberte Are Remembered
description: LEAD: IT WAS EASIER BEFORE THE FRENCH REVOLU-tion to watch the King and Queen at Versailles, eating their supper, than it is now to contemplate the President of the Republic in the Palais de l'Elysee: the chance to observe him at mealtime, while respectfully downing one's own slice of roast veal, is by invitation only.

title: Cloth Fights for Favor as Disposables Fill the Dumps
description: Cloth diaper producers and vendors of biodegradable brands are seizing on growing environmental concerns to chip away at the disposables' market share.

title: The Shaming of America's Elderly
description: PERVASIVE guilt over government's failure to adequately monitor the maintenance of nursing home standards, coupled with the realization that there is a rapidly increasing older population that will need institutional care, has motivated America to get busy and ''fix them up.''

title: Bond Plan For Schools Faces Test In Hewlett
description: LONG Island's school districts, under increasing Federal and state pressure to upgrade their buildings, are preparing sweeping plans for improvements.

title: WHERE WERE THE ACCOUNTANTS?
description: Why did accountants throughout the nation fail to detect the shenanigans that triggered one of the biggest financial calamities this country has ever seen?

title: Grand Buildings Undergoing Restoration
description: LEAD: THE $64.5 million restoration of the State House is illustrative of a trend toward the large-scale renovation and preservation of grand old buildings, say state officials, architects and preservationists.

title: Students Risk Boos and Silence for Comedic Honors
description: It was a class clown's dream: a chance to bask in the spotlight in front of not just a few, but hundreds of students primed for sophomoric entertainment.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Mr. Califano seems to feel that Democrats can retake the White House only by becoming pale copies of Republicans. Has he forgotten that Michael Dukakis finally began to gain in the polls when he stopped running away from the ''L'' word? Why shouldn't the next Democratic nominee run unabashedly to the left, staking his campaign on a stronger showing in the two-thirds of the country that is not Southern. LARRY SHERMAN Bronx

title: Concern Over Stinger Missiles
description: Washington is concerned that it may not recover Stinger missiles from Afghan rebels and that terrorists may get the weapons. Page 18.

title:
GARDENING;
Construction Can Be Hazardous to Trees
description: LEAD: A MAJOR problem for those who build or purchase a new house on a wooded site is that the trees often die over a two- or three-year period following construction. Most often, the wooded setting was a major factor in the decision to buy the property. To have this setting deteriorate is a disappointment, to say the least, and it usually represents a significant loss in the market value of the property and a sizable cost for tree removal.

title:
DANCE;
Ballet Adorned With Rich Details
description: LEAD: WHEN the curtain rises on the spring season of the Garden State Ballet Friday, audiences can expect three new ballets, opulent costuming and a program ambitious in its reach for rich production values. Peter Anastos, the company's artistic director and principal choreographer, feels that the era of stripped-down, leotard ballets has ended.

title: U.N. Population Plan for China a Test for U.S.
description: A new United Nations plan to help China control its population growth will provide an early test of the Bush Administration's attitude toward Beijing's forced abortion and sterilization policies, officials and diplomats say.

title: THE WORLD: Overlooking the Unworkable; Apartheid Frays at the Edges, But Its Core Is Unchanged
description: THE South African Government set a precedent last week that could hasten the demise of its laws on strict residential segregation. In response to threats by a right-wing municipal council to cut off utilities used by ethnic Indians living in the officially white town of Boksburg, it asked provincial officials to give them temporary permits allowing them to stay. And a Government official announced that Pretoria was considering dropping the whites-only restriction for the neighborhood in which they live.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bretton Woods, N.H.;
20-Year Plan For Big Resort
description: LEAD: THE owners of the Bretton Woods resort have started a $350 million, 20-year development plan that includes restoring, renovating and winterizing the Mount Washington Hotel for $20 million.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Adaptive Use; Plugging the Future Into Vibrant Architectural Relics
description: IT has been almost a century since the Metropolitan Street Railway Company opened a power station at 141 East 25th Street with state-of-the-art conveyor systems to deliver coal and retrieve ash from immense boilers that gave life to cable cars traveling as far north as 105th Street.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: My knee-jerk reflex was to trade him. But then I witnessed his monstrous home run to the center-field wall in an exhibition game this weekend. The beauty of his outstretched arms and bat acting as one, making contact with the ball and launching a rocket, would be lost to me if he did it for any other team but the Mets. I say keep Darryl and trade his agent. MARTIN BASKIN New York

title: Miss Harris Weds Daniel Mahoney Jr.
description: Cynthia Anne Harris, a daughter of Mrs. Edward Hess of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Henry Barton Harris Jr., was married yesterday to J. Daniel Mahoney Jr., a son of Judge and Mrs. Mahoney of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Anthony Robinson and the Rev. Seamus Crossan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shepherd of the Hills Congregational Church in Scottsdale.

title: WHERE WAS SOLOMON?
description: A MOTHER'S STORY The Truth About the Baby M Case. By Mary Beth Whitehead with Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. Illustrated. 220 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $17.95.

title: Tips to Help Polish the Picture
description: Photographers have long known that a fine camera doesn't automatically make a fine picture. New owners of video camcorders are just disovering that. What it takes is visual imagination - and no camera has that. But it helps to know a few tricks.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My vacation house is used a few times a year, but not enough to leave the heat on between visits. To protect against freeze damage, I winterize the toilets and sink traps by pouring antifreeze into them each time I leave. I am concerned about the effects this antifreeze has on the septic tank and the environment. Would car windshield-washer fluid be a better alternative ?

title: Miss Greenspan, A Banker, Weds D. J. Lederman
description: Sandra Charlotte Greenspan and Douglas James Lederman were married yesterday evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by Rabbi Arnold G. Fink. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Michael Greenspan of Harrison, N.Y. Her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Lederman of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Behind the Arms Plans, A Clash Of Visions
description: THE proposals that NATO and the Warsaw Pact countries put forward in Vienna last week for cutting conventional arms are full of references to weapon ceilings, partially demilitarized zones and phased reductions of military systems.

title: Federal Work-at-Home Plan Assailed at Hearing
description: With references to the Dark Ages and turn-of-the-century sweatshops, witnesses at hearings here have assailed a Federal proposal to allow the manufacture of women's apparel at home.

title: Role of Women Explored
description: The American Museum of Natural History is to present a free series of lectures and a performance in celebration of Women's History Month, March 14, 22 and 29 at 7 P.M. Information: 769-5315.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Respect for Ingredients in Eastchester
description: LEAD: IF one doesn't mind the low ceiling and dark paneling that give the dining room a finished- basement-of-the-1950's look, the chill that can seep through the walls on a windy winter day and the poor ventilation when the room is filled to capacity - if all that is by the by, then one can eat well here.

title: John J. McCloy, Lawyer and Diplomat, Is Dead at 93
description: John J. McCloy, the lawyer and diplomat who was the United States High Commissioner in postwar Germany and an adviser to Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan, died yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 93 years old.

title: Cheney, a Conservative, Is Also a Compromiser
description: Representative Dick Cheney, the new Secretary of Defense-designate, has a record of solid support for Ronald Reagan's military buildup, but his reputation for compromise prompted liberals and conservatives alike to make optimistic forecasts today for his tenure at the Pentagon.

title: Review/Theater; Exploring Improbabilities And the Human Comedy
description: The whole is not as good as parts of ''The Sunday Promenade'' by Lars Forssell, but the good parts make this strange play at the New Theater of Brooklyn an amusing evening. Mr. Forssell's imagination is more poetic than dramatic; he can make you find connections among wildly conflicting ideas and his dialogue often reminds you of the snipped and elliptical lines of song lyrics.

title: Aloof Giant, Brazil Warms To Neighbors
description: Displaying the daring shapes of the country's most famous architect and the idealistic vision of a well-known anthropologist, a $50 million monument has been built to a subject that interests few Brazilians: Latin America.

title: Liza Pulitzer, Book Agent, Weds Shelton C. Voges Jr.
description: Elizabeth Edgar Pulitzer, the daughter of Mrs. Albert Goodhue of Palm Beach, Fla., and Michael E. Pulitzer of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Shelton Campbell Voges Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Voges of St. Louis. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes, assisted by the Rev. Edwin S. S. Sunderland, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: P.L.O. AND ISRAEL TO GET BUSH IDEAS ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: The Bush Administration plans to ask Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to take steps to ease tensions in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to lay the foundation for peace talks, a senior Administration official said.

title: A Departing Mayor Reflects On the Rewards of Village Service
description: LEAD: After this month, Irvington residents won't have Reginald F. Marra to complain to anymore about garbage collection, snow removal, burned-out street lights, new development, increasing traffic or lack of parking on Main Street.

title: On the Outs
description: The saga of Joe Clark began in 1982, when he threw 300 troublesome students out of Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J. Last week, the tough-talking principal, who patrols the school's hallways with a bullhorn and baseball bat, was himself suspended for five days. School officials said he failed to supervise his building two weeks ago when three male dancers stripped to their G-strings during a variety show by professional entertainers at a school assembly. Mr. Clark, whose experiences are the basis of a new movie, ''Lean on Me,'' was appearing on a television show in California at the time, but other school administrators on hand immediately stopped the show. Mr. Clark, who has had other run-ins with the school board, talked of quitting his job, saying, ''If I left, then I'd be appreciated.''

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: When Michael Dukakis talked about the common trials, the common needs and the common strength of working people, he spoke to the common concerns of citizens. When he talked about addressing the problems of housing and the costs of education and health care, he talked like a Democrat, and he made sense.

title: THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
description: I would like to clarify the caption accompanying a picture illustrating the article ''The Ambiguous Yasir Arafat'' (by Marie Colvin, Dec. 18). In the caption, I am described as an Arafat associate. I am not Mr. Arafat's associate. I am a Palestinian student, studying in Paris, and working as a journalist for an Arab news agency. I was in Algiers as a journalist. HALA TAWIL Courbevoie, France

title: Reviews/Music; From Haydn to Bolcom, By St. Paul Orchestra
description: The first well-known conductor of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra was Dennis Russell Davies, who became music director in 1972. He was followed in 1980 by Pinchas Zukerman. When Mr. Zukerman resigned in 1987, he was succeeded by a curious but innovative three-member artistic commission.

title: Take Acquaintance Rape to Civil Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: On 28 Acres; 1820 House Getting 14 Neighbors
description: A Greek Revival house containing sections that predate the Revolutionary War is being incorporated into a new housing development in the Village of Westport, Conn. Most of the five-bedroom structure dates to 1820, when it was rebuilt in the Greek Revival style by Talcott Wakeman, a prosperous onion farmer in the area along Sherwood Farms Lane two miles east of the center of Westport.

title: PARTY TOLD TO WIN MIDDLE-CLASS VOTE
description: The leaders of centrist forces in the Democratic Party gathered here this weekend to urge Democrats to focus their energies on winning back the middle-class vote. But before their meeting was done, they had heard a series of lectures from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who said the party had to remember the needy and decide ''which side of history we're on.''

title: White Plains Parents Choosing Schools
description: LEAD: FOR the first time, parents of White Plains children entering kindergarten are being asked their preference among the city school district's elementary schools.

title: I Hear America Singing
description: SUMMER EATING MEANS dirty hands, and most people's fondest memories of hot-weather customs involve licking fingers clean of sticky crimson barbecue sauce or crisp bits of fried chicken batter, or running a thumb along a dasher for the first taste of ice cream that took forever to freeze.

title: Walter Fried, 80, Former Housing Official
description: Walter S. Fried, a member of the board of the New York City Housing Authority from 1970 to 1986, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old. Mr. Fried, a lawyer, was formerly commissioner in charge of the office of housing and facilities production in the Housing and Development Administration. As such, he supervised the city's Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing program.

title: Early Exodus Portends Sudan Famine
description: The ground here is scattered with freshly built straw huts and green tents, the makeshift shelters for the refugees who have started to leave the southern Sudan from fear of hunger.

title: Arts Trust Attracts Praise and Funds
description: IF the Boston Pops Orchestra is coming to the County Center here, can the Boston Symphony be far behind? How about the Mormon Tabernacle Choir or Ella Fitzgerald? The county's Cultural Affairs office can afford to dream a little these days, thanks to the initial success of its Performing Arts Trust.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Absolutely. Strawberry thinks his $7.2 million contract is an insult to himself and his family. If $7.2 million is an insult, I make the following appeal to Mets management on behalf of myself, my wife, and our two cats: insult us! insult us! MICHAEL KELLER Kew Garden, Queens

title: As Racketeering Law Expands, So Does Pressure to Rein It In
description: THE Federal racketeering law, passed in 1970 as a weapon against mobsters, has in recent years been used to sue Fortune 500 companies, hundreds of accountants and stockbrokers, the Long Island Lighting Company, Claus von Bulow and an occasional spouse in a divorce case. This month an appeals court upheld the use of the law, known as RICO, in a civil suit against protesters who disrupted an abortion clinic in Philadelphia.

title: Strikers' Worry: Eastern as a 'Family'
description: Outside the headquarters of the union local here, leaning near the sign at the door that says ''No alcohol or firearms,'' Robert Lowry held his three-month-old son David and said he did not know what he was going to do.

title: Christopher Kniffin Wed To Miss Dunbar in Florida
description: Deborah Lynn Dunbar and Christopher Kniffin were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in St. Petersburg, Fla., by the Rev. Peter Wallace Fleming. The bride is a daughter of Dr. Ulma F. Dunbar of St. Petersburg and the late Betty B. Dunbar. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Kniffin of New Canaan, Conn. Mrs. Kniffin, a stepdaughter of Barbara Dunbar, is a graduate of the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers and Marymount College. She is a former member of the New York Junior League. Her father is a retired dentist. Mr. Kniffin is an account manager in New York for the Experra Corporation, a publisher of investment data bases for computer software in Cambridge, Mass. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and Boston University.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Darryl Strawberry should be traded immediately. I'd like to see a trade for Kirby Puckett; if necessary, Dave Magadan or some other of the Mets' extraneous players could be thrown in. GEORGE J. FERRARESE New York

title: FICTION
description: THE BOOK OF RUTH. By Jane Hamilton. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) On the surface, it's classic tabloid fodder. ''Family Erupts in Violence: One Dead, One Injured, as Tot Looks On,'' the headline might read. And inside the story, one might read: ''The killer only wanted to be 'a gentle person, a good boy.' '' In her first novel, ''The Book of Ruth,'' Jane Hamilton explores the life behind this lurid story through the eyes of Ruth, the young mother who is the only person left to put it together. The underachiever of an underachieving family, Ruth lives in a tiny Illinois town where nothing is fancy except ''the iron gate around the church and the pigeons with their purple breasts.'' Ruth's low self-esteem is confirmed by her frustrated mother, May, who practices her own oppressive style of parenthood. Barely into her adult years, Ruth finds herself trapped between her mean-spirited mother and her sweet, dopey husband, who's as thirsty for praise as he is for alcohol. The domestic violence that finally rips Ruth's world apart is horrifying, but in many ways it's as ordinary as her life. ''Killing is the easiest thing in the world,'' Ruth thinks, and it's as true as anything she's been taught. In recounting her sad story, Ms. Hamilton gives Ruth a humble dignity and allows her hope - but it's not a heavenly hope. It's a common one, caked with mud and held with gritted teeth. And it's probably the only kind that's worth reading about.

title: On the Riverfront
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Meadowlands Developers Moving West
description: LEAD: BUILDERS, who in the last 15 years have turned the eastern part of the Meadowlands into a bustling commercial hub, have begun running out of land there and are moving west.

title: Prop 48 Makes Athletes Study
description: It is probably true that the majority of entering freshmen in some colleges and universities in the United States know more than graduating seniors in others. The strength of American higher education is its diversity, which is characterized by widely differing standards and expectations at both the entry and degree-completion levels. Thus, any externally applied standard designed to bring conformity to the admission and academic achievement processes will be considered inappropriate or even unfair by some of the participants affected by the standardization.

title: Inhabited by History: Charleston, S.C.
description: LEAD: A WRITER FRIEND FROM OUT OF TOWN WAS at my house recently. He was smitten with Charleston, as most visitors are. ''I love it,'' he said. ''But it's sure the City of Sobs.''

title: Rapid Spread of AIDS Alarms Residents of the Ivory Coast
description: ''Turn this page - it could save your life,'' command fliers stapled to covers of Afrique Elite, a magazine sold in kiosks across this capital.

title: Margaret Schneidman Wed
description: Margaret Macauley Schneidman, a daughter of Margaret Wright Tilghman of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Milton Schneidman, was married yesterday to Timothy Whitin Brownell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Brownell of New Bedford, Mass. The Rev. Mark Andrus performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr. The bride, who will retain her name, is a graduate of the Taft School and Barnard College. She is a freelance journalist. Mr. Brownell, a graduate of Tufts University, is a managing partner of the Multicrafts Building Company in New York.

title: Dance Theory
description: THE EXPERIMENTAL CHOREOGRAPHY of Trisha Brown tends to defy standard characterization, even by the choreographer herself. ''I struggle with it,'' she admits. ''It's important to try and demystify it, yet not take away the mystery. There's no narrative structure, but that's the excitement. It has impact and it has meaning, but it's not a story. There is an order there. You sense it. But it doesn't correlate to verbal language.''

title: Depression: No Minimum Age
description: LITTLE more than a year ago, Ira (not his real name), then 6 years old, put two electric plugs together because he said he wanted to die, according to his mother, Mrs. L. ''Looking back,'' she said, ''I should have seen it coming. He was a compulsive child. He would come home from school and say, 'I have 16 things to do today.' You got the sense he felt pressured.''

title: THE D.C. PLAN
description: I feel that my views were misrepresented in Marianne Szegedy-Maszak's article ''D.C., the Other Washington'' (Nov. 20).

title: Alice Forster Has Wedding
description: The wedding of Alice Bayard Forster and Robert Allan Griffin took place in New York yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

title: Recuse, J'accuse!
description: I HAVE ALWAYS RE-cused myself from anything to do with communications,'' said Clayland Boyden Gray, President Bush's legal counsel and chief ethics adviser. I had just asked him, with no apparent malice aforethought, for copies of his financial disclosure forms for the past three years, a request that puts some Government officials on the defensive.

title: Ideas as Ammunition in the French Revolution
description: Presenting a whole series of exhibitions, movies, lectures, colloquies and (not least) a dance performance to mark the bicentennial of the French Revolution, the New York Public Library has grasped a nettle that other institutions have so far approached with leather gauntlets (if at all). It took thought, and care, and courage. For quite some time now, museums the world over have been tussling with a problem that would not go away. What on earth were they to do about the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution?

title: Recapturing a Vintage Romp
description: Jerome Robbins started the dance without a scenario. ''I didn't know what I would do,'' he said, recalling his creation of the Bathing Beauty Ballet for ''High Button Shoes'' in 1947. ''But it began to roll, you know, and on it went'' - a Mack Sennett chase complete with eight bathing beauties, seven cops, three robbers, a set each of male and female twins, 14 singers, a lifeguard and a large gorilla racing on the boardwalk and through the slamming doors of seven bathhouses on the Atlantic City shore in 1913. As the music bounds along, there are tugs of war and games of toss-the-satchel in an antic melee choreographed down to the flick of a finger.

title: For Brunch, Try Something Unusual
description: BREAKFASTING on oatmeal, high-fiber cold cereals or bran muffins might be acceptable during the week but those meals are too austere for a weekend brunch.

title: Closing of 2 Hospital Pharmacies Prompts Outcry
description: When two large private hospitals in New York City announced last week that they were closing outpatient pharmacies that subsidized medications for thousands of poor people, hospital industry regulators and public health advocates cried foul.

title: The Little Red Chair
description: WHEN I WAS IN nursery school, the most important rule was silence. On my first day, the teacher had to leave the room but before she did, she exacted a commitment of complete stillness and quiet. My neighbor poked me in the ribs and called me a thumb-sucker and I poked her back just in time for the teacher to return and witness only my transgression. I was made to stand on a chair in the corner, face to the wall; it was the first of many such banishments.

title: WAR'S BOOTED NIGHT
description: FAREWELL, DRESDEN By Henri Coulonges. Translated by Lowell Bair. 285 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: AT THE MERCY OF STRANGERS
description: AN EXPOSURE OF THE HEART By Rebecca Busselle. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Tracking the Green Fairy
description: In 1882, Oscar Wilde effused: ''A glass of absinthe is as poetical as anything in the world. What difference is there between a glass of absinthe and a sunset?'' Verlaine, Rimbaud, Toulouse-Lautrec, van Gogh, Daumier, Baudelaire - all took ''inspiration'' from absinthe, the cloudy green aperitif made from wormwood, a strong-smelling perennial herb. Barnaby Conrad 3d, in ABSINTHE: History in a Bottle (Chronicle Books, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $18.95), views, through the bottle, as it were, 19th-century France, its mores, art, culture and politics. Absinthe divided France, with doctors, poets and politicians either extolling its virtues or decrying its baleful influence. So important did the drink become to daily life that even the hour of drinking it had a name: l'heure verte. When Manet and Degas painted their versions of cafe denizens during l'heure verte, in ''The Absinthe Drinker'' and ''L'Absinthe,'' respectively, their works became scandals in the art world as well as representations politicians could point to for evidence of society's descent into hell. Absinthe rose to prominence during a time of great political and social upheaval, when, to political reactionaries like Leon Daudet, Mr. Conrad records, wine stood for tradition and absinthe, revolution.
