Mr. Conrad, a writer on art and travel, has compiled an absinthe catalogue raisonne, with information, witty quotations and illustrations that track the Green Fairy on its march from cafes into the streets and galleries and into the French National Assembly. As in our Congress today, rhetoric then was dramatic, hysterical. Absinthe was going to destroy France. One can't help comparing today's antidrug hysteria with that 100 years ago - and wish that Mr. Conrad had analyzed more thoroughly how outrage against the likes of absinthe may mask other social and political problems.

title: WestHELP Wins in White Plains
description: LEAD: WESTHELP, the nonprofit organization founded by Andrew M. Cuomo to build temporary housing for the homeless, will take over and renovate the largest homeless hotel in this city and build a new 36-apartment complex providing temporary housing under an agreement approved Monday night by the White Plains Common Council.

title: Prospects; Two Giants Become One
description: The proposed merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. will create a $15 billion media company - the largest in the world. Time-Warner will be a major force in cable television, movie production, magazines and book publishing. The merger still must be approved by the stockholders of the two companies and on April 4, the Senate Antitrust Committee will review the deal. Four analysts discuss the effects of the proposed merger. David Londoner Managing director, Wertheim, Schroder & Company.

title: History and the Law In Tarrytown Case
description: The letter in the Feb. 19 Westchester section by Phyllis G. Ross of New Rochelle, about a zoning case in Tarrytown, draws some irrelevant conclusions from a thoroughly misstated set of ''facts.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Barnard; Tradition Revived As Greek Games Stage a Return
description: Read into it, whatever significance you will, but the Greek Games, a once-hardy perennial of Barnard College life, are returning to campus after a 22-year absence.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about William F. Farley's purchase of West Point Pepperell misidentified the Governor of Georgia. He is Joe Frank Harris.

title: Lack of Water Curbing Hotel Projects
description: ALTHOUGH developers say there is a great need for additional hotels in central Nassau, the Town of Hempstead has halted such building because there is not enough water to provide the large volume required by hotels.

title: Segregation, in Law and in Practice
description: THESE are some things that black South Africans can and cannot do today: Mobility

title: Ada Ferrer Weds Gregg Van Ryzin
description: Ada Ferrer and Gregg Gerard Van Ryzin were married last evening at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Joseph Giandurco, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Ferrer of Miami. Mr. Van Ryzin is a son of Lani Havens of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late John R. Van Ryzin.

title: LIFESTYLE: Sunday Outing; A Trip Through Connecticut History
description: Harriet Beecher Stowe was born there in 1881. The country's first law school was established there in 1774. And the nation's first private academy for girls was founded there.

title: Court Limits Woman's Right to Male Guests
description: The State Supreme Court has upheld an order prohibiting a divorced woman from having an unrelated man stay overnight with her in her home when her children are present.

title: Tower Vote: Party Power, Deftly Shown
description: From the start of the battle over John G. Tower's nomination to be Defense Secretary, Democratic leaders of the Senate knew they were balanced on a precipice of public opinion and constitutional prerogative.

title: Dentist Takes His Office to the Homebound
description: LEAD: AS chairman of the State Dental Commission, the agency responsible for the professional standards and the licensing of dentists, Dr. Bernard Unger of Norwalk was unable to persuade the Health Department to finance mobile dental units to serve the homebound and handicapped.

title: Question of the Week; Should the Mets Trade Strawberry?
description: Trade Strawberry as soon as possible. Ship him to the American League, the Rangers or Mariners. He also should fit in with the Yankees, the team I love to hate the most. Throw in HoJo and Dykstra, two expendables, and maybe a front-line groundskeeper, and you might be able to get Winfield. NAT BOYNTON Delmar, N.Y.

title: ITALIAN OPERA IN A LESS-THAN-GOLDEN AGE
description: To put it mildly, ours is not a golden age for Italian opera. Thus, as current recorded documentation reaches us, we should approach it with modest expectations. It is with this sobering view that we greet new recordings of Rossini's ''Cenerentola'' and the three components of Puccini's ''Il Trittico'': ''Gianni Schicchi,'' ''Suor Angelica'' and ''Il Tabarro.''

title: What's Doing in San Francisco
description: Having survived a second consecutive winter of drought and strict water rationing followed by a cold snap that brought record low temperatures in February, San Franciscans are especially thankful to see spring busting out all over the city this year.

title: Paying for Employee Education Benefits
description: Thanks to several complicated tax changes, the price of an education is going up for some employer-subsidized students - at least for now. Employees whose companies pick up the tab for their studies may soon find that their paychecks have shrunk because taxes are suddenly being withheld on those benefits. And people taking graduate-level courses could face an extra tax bill when they prepare their 1988 returns.

title: Dukakis, Out of U.S. Limelight, Fights 'No New Taxes' Again
description: ''A chief executive has got to lead,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said, speaking about himself and also, inevitably, about the man who beat him for the Presidency four months ago. ''You have to lay it out there, come in with a plan, take the hits.''

title: Outdoors; Limit Is Weighed for Atlantic Bluefish
description: As early as next year there may be a limit on the number of bluefish an Atlantic Coast angler will be allowed to catch and keep. The intent is to give some protection to a species that is vitally important to the recreational-fishing industry.

title: Weather Vanes Get Attention At Eye Level
description: Weather vanes, which have been around since antiquity, are more popular than ever and increasingly less visible - at least on American rooftops. These days wind indicators are more often seen indoors - at museums, folk-art galleries, antiques shows and auctions. Major dealers who handle these artifacts say they stock mostly rarities and choose them carefully for their special shape, an enviable patina, or both.

title: Police Turning to 9-mm. Guns to Fight Crime
description: MANY police departments in Westchester may soon join the ranks of law-enforcement agencies nationwide that are replacing the time-honored .38-caliber revolver with a 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol as a standard weapon. The change comes primarily because of mounting evidence that criminals - especially drug dealers - are better armed than ever.

title: How Cheney's Name Came Up Again
description: President Bush had resisted the subject for as long as he could, believing it would be unseemly to make secret plans for a new Defense Secretary before his loyal ally from Texas, John G. Tower, was officially rejected. But by late Thursday morning the death rattle of the nomination could no longer be ignored in the Oval Office.

title: DADDY: SOMETIMES A PARTICLE, SOMETIMES A WAVE
description: LEAD: CHARADES By Janette Turner Hospital. 291 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: Healthy Labels, Healthy Food
description: A new report by the National Research Council ratifies the conventional wisdom that cutting back on salt, fat and cholesterol can have tangible health benefits. It adds weight to the case for new Federal labeling rules that would help consumers know more precisely what they are eating.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Role for Brady
description: This morning James S. Brady, Ronald Reagan's press secretary, is to hold his first news conference in nearly eight years. He will use the occasion, at the National Press Club, to announce his appointment to the newly created position of vice chairman of the National Organization on Disability.

title: Michael C. Appel And Miss Wiener Exchange Vows
description: Marcia Leslie Wiener, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Wiener of East Meadow, L.I., and Acapulco, Mexico, was married yesterday to Michael Cary Appel, the son of Claire Chasanoff of Old Westbury, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Barry Dov Lerner officiated at the Hotel Westbury in Manhattan.

title: School Basketball; P.S.A.L. Titles on Line at the Felt Forum
description: When the Public Schools Athletic League championship tripleheader begins at 4 P.M. today, it will be the first time the title games have been played at the Felt Forum since 1973.

title: Ellen Frank, a Teacher Married to Jeffrey Bayer
description: Ellen Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Frank of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Bayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Bayer of Jamesburg, N.J. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: Wheat Crop Estimated
description: The International Wheat Council has tentatively forecast that world wheat production would rebound to a record 540 million metric tons in the 1989-90 season. The announcement Friday by the council, one of the world's leading wheat forecasting bodies, revised its 1988-89 world wheat crop estimate to 504 million tons from 502 million in January.

title: Horse Racing; Dispersal Is First In Louisiana Derby
description: Dispersal, who made his racing debut just 26 days ago, today became the newest and most intriguing contender for the Triple Crown races by winning the $167,600 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds in his third career start.

title: Books of The Times; Modernism: Rites of Spring, Rites of Destruction
description: Rites of Spring The Great War and the Birth of the Modern Age By Modris Eksteins Illustrated. 396 pages. A Peter Davison Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: Miller Beer Drops Ad After Protest
description: The Miller Brewing Company has pulled an advertising supplement designed as a parody of ''spring break'' themes after college students complained that it was insulting and students at one university threatened to boycott Miller products.

title: Harriet Pilpel and Irvin Schwartz Wed
description: Harriet F. Pilpel, a lawyer who is of counsel to the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, and Irvin B. Schwartz, the executive administrator of the department of psychiatry of the New York Medical College, were married yesterday at the Columbia University Faculty House. Judge Ruth Jane Zuckerman of the New York Family Court officiated.

title: Washington Talk: Congressional Budget Office; At Helm, a Centrist Respected by His Foes
description: Economists tend to be a quarrelsome lot, dogmatic in their own opinions and disdainful of colleagues who disagree.

title: Sports World Specials; Music to Their Ears
description: What Joe Szurley remembers best about the first match of what has become an annual collegiate hockey classic is not his team's 15-2 victory in the 1987 debut game, or even his own four goals. It is the opponents' pep band.

title: Lyons Ready if Carter Slips
description: The biggest surprise in the Mets' training camp this spring is Barry Lyons, who has been the backup catcher to Gary Carter for the last three years, which is a little like being the backup monument to Mount Rushmore.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales ... Feb. Wednesday Merchandise Trade ... Jan. Inventory-Sales Ratio ... Jan. Thursday Industrial Production ... Feb. Capacity Utilization ... Feb. Housing Starts ... Feb. Friday Producer Prices ... Feb.

title: Port Isabel Journal; New Policies at Border Trip 2 Alien Mothers
description: Inside the beige, prefabricated headquarters of the Immigration and Naturalization Service Processing Center here, Maria Inez Secan Hernandez Dezamorra sits and cries.

title: Move Expected On Cocoa Levy
description: Consuming countries are expected to call for the suspension of the current levy on traded cocoa, delegates to the upcoming International Cocoa Organization talks said Friday.

title: Restorers Gather to Review Their Successes
description: As every tourist to Italy knows, visiting the major artistic monuments can sometimes feel like traveling from one construction site to the next. Whether it is Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' in Milan or Masaccio's frescoes at the Brancacci Chapel in Florence or the murals by Raphael at the Vatican, many of the greatest landmarks of the Renaissance have been hidden for years behind scaffolds, undergoing repair.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Cross-Country Skiing: A Labor of Love
description: LEAD: I have one true love, and she is not cross-country skiing. But my true love is a cross-country skier. Who am I to blow against the wind?

title: Review/Music; Elliott Sharp's Urban Sound
description: Elliott Sharp, the composer and guitarist who has been for the past 10 years one of downtown's most influential and prolific musicians, brought two different aspects of his work to the Knitting Factory on Friday night. The first, several of his compositions as played by the Soldier String Quartet, began the evening intensely; the second, a performance by Mr. Sharp's own group, Carbon, ended the evening intensely.

title: Korea's Road to Democracy Paved With Contrary Legacy
description: This nation is still technically at war with its northern half - but even more at odds with itself.

title: Metro Matters; Five Scripts, But Only Room For One Hero
description: Years ago, when Mayor John V. Lindsay was running for President, a reporter who had just begun following his fledgling campaign was asked whether Mr. Lindsay had any realistic chance of winning.

title: Kite Catches Love And Wins Playoff
description: Tom Kite and Davis Love 3d each stumbled, misfired and staggered to a shocking double-bogey 6 at the final hole of regulation today to force a playoff, and Kite won it with a par-4 on the second extra hole. Love three-putted there to lose.

title: Treasury Aide Finds No Baker Violation In Brazil-Debt Issue
description: A Treasury Department spokesman said today that no conflict-of-interest rules were violated in 1987 when James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, rejected a proposal by Brazil to reduce its debt payments to American banks, including one in which he owned stock.

title: Results Plus
description: Speed Skating Two Victories for Jansen: Dan Jansen of the United States beat the world sprint champion, Igor Zhelezovsky of the Soviet Union, twice at a World Cup meet in Inzell, West Germany, that ended yesterday. Jansen won the 500-and 1,000-meter races yesterday, both times edging Zhelezovsky. The American took the 500 in 36.76 seconds, while the Soviet skater was timed in 37.74. Jansen then went on to take the 1,000 with a time of 1 minute 14.33 seconds, beating Zhelezovsky, who clocked 1:15.09. Constanze Moser of East Germany was the most successful competitor in women's races, winning the 1,500, placing second in the 1,000 and third in the 3,000.(AP) N.B.A. Celtics 121, Nuggets 115: Reggie Lewis scored 28 points and Jim Paxson came off the bench to lead a second-half rally with 17 yesterday as Boston rallied from a 13-point deficit to beat Denver. The victory, Boston's fifth in a row at home, gave the Celtics a .500 record (30-30) for the first time since the All-Star Game break. Alex English led Denver with 27 points.(AP) Kings 114, Hornets 105: Wayman Tisdale scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half, and Kenny Smith added 22 points as visiting Sacramento handed Charlotte its seventh consecutive loss. The Kings held off a strong second-half challenge led by Charlotte's Rex Chapman, who finished with a career-high 37 points, by hitting 24 of 28 free throws, including 13 of 13 in the second half.(AP) Pistons 110, Bullets 104: Isiah Thomas scored 22 points and sparked an 11-4 fourth-quarter run that led Detroit to its seventh consecutive victory. Detroit has won 10 of its last 11 games, 17 of 20 and 10 in a row at home. Bill Laimbeer scored 24 points and grabbed 16 rebounds for the Pistons. His final basket, a long jumper with 48 seconds left, gave him 10,000 career points.(AP) Cavaliers 123, Trail Blazers 110: Brad Daugherty scored 23 points as visiting Cleveland ended a losing streak at two games. Terry Porter led Portland with 20 points. Caldwell Jones of Portland scored 2 points to reach the 10,000 plateau for his career.(AP) Lakers 126, Warriors 115: Byron Scott scored 32 points and shot down the Golden State Warriors with three 3-point bombs in the final period to give the Lakers their fourth consecutive victory.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 6, Blackhawks 5: Mario Lemieux reached the 70-goal plateau for the second successive season with three goals and three assists as visiting Pittsburgh defeated Chicago, despite being outshot by 62-28. Tom Barrasso made 57 saves as the Penguins moved into second place in the Patrick Division, 1 point behind idle Washington and 1 point ahead of the Rangers.(AP) Sabres 3, Bruins 2: Dave Andreychuk's second goal of the game early in the third period was decisive as Buffalo beat Boston. (AP) Flyers 3, Whalers 3: Rick Tocchet of Philadelphia scored his second goal of the game with 3:18 left in the third period for the tiein Hartford. (AP) Horse Racing Lord of the Night Prevails: Lord of the Night, carrying 114 pounds and ridden by Jorge Velasquez, won by a neck yesterday in the $87,150 Toboggan Handicap for horses 3- years-old and up at Aqueduct. Teddy Drone was the runner-up in the field of seven, a head in front of Vinnie the Viper. The victory was the second in four starts this year for Lord of the Night, who covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 2/5 to earn $52,290 for Winbound Farms. He returned $9.20 for $2 to win.(AP) Golf 16th Senior Title for Crampton: Bruce Crampton shot a 68 yesterday to win the $300,000 Arizona Classic in Phoenix. Crampton, who finished with a 16-under-par total of 200, won the 16th Senior Tour title of his career. Bobby Nichols, who led after the first and second rounds, shot a 72 and finished one stroke back.(AP) Dog Show Bee's Knees Is Best in Show: A black and white pointer, Ch. Luftnase Albelarm Bee's Knees, owned by Isabel Robson and Michael Zollo, was selected best among 2,031 dogs yesterday at the 49th fixture of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club at Rockland Community College, in Suffern, N.Y. The bitch, handled by Zollo, got her 19th top award in this country. She was a titleholder in Canada, where she has two bests in show. On the way to the top prize, she led a sporting group for the 51st time.

title: Bush Fights Perception That He Is Adrift
description: After seven weeks in office, President Bush is still seeking a sense of definition for his Administration, or at least a widespread acceptance that he has defined its priorities in domestic and foreign policy.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated Dow Jones & Company's relationship to Texas Monthly magazine. It holds a minority interest in the magazine; the main owner is Mediatex Communications.

title: Disguised Federal Inmate Escapes
description: Making the first escape in 12 years from the maximum security United States Penitentiary here, a convicted bank robber used a disguise to walk out the front door Friday, officials said.

title: Soviet Rally Honors Regime Lenin Ousted
description: An opposition group mounted an illegal rally today in a busy Moscow plaza to honor the Government overthrown by the Bolsheviks in 1917.

title: 350-Year-Old Farm Survives the Odds
description: Thomas Hine staked his claim here for God and king 350 years ago, scratching out a farm on an isolated hilltop in the middle of a wilderness. Twelve generations later, Mr. Hine's descendants once again find themselves in isolation.

title: Sports World Specials; Who's on First?
description: A bit of collegiate baseball history is expected to be written next Thursday when St. Mary's College of Maryland takes on visiting Wesley College of Dover, Del., for a Division III doubleheader.

title: SUDANESE PREMIER SEEKS NEW CABINET
description: After a weeklong delay, the Sudanese Prime Minister today offered the resignations of his Cabinet to the Council of State and said he would form a new government.

title: 12 Killed and 3 Missing in Helicopter Crash
description: An Air Force Reserve helicopter crashed and burned today during a night training mission, killing 12 people aboard and leaving three missing, officials said.

title: A Corner of Connecticut Sees a Modest Revival
description: The colossal American Thread Company complex, which rises from a winding river valley here in the Willimantic section of town, looks more like a mausoleum than a mill these days.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 20 about political fund-raisers appointed to the Bush Administration referred imprecisely to Henry E. Catto Jr., who has been nominated as Ambassador to Britain after holding previous dipomatic posts. While Mr. Catto is a longtime Republican contributor, he was not among $100,000 contributors to the Republican party last year.

title: College Hockey; Maine Gains Top-Seeded Spot in East
description: Maine, a second-place team in the Hockey East standing but the winner of the league tournament, was seeded first among the five Eastern teams selected yesterday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I tournament.

title: Why 'Terrorism' Inadequately Describes the Threat to Rushdie; 'Wanton Acts of Usage'
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the 10 years that the Big East Conference has been in business, how have its basketball teams done in games against the Big Ten Conference?

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Taking Precautions For Outdoor Exercise
description: FIVE weeks ago, Tiffany Sessions, a 20-year-old student at the University of Florida, put on her workout clothes and a Walkman and went for a fitness walk. Sessions told her roommate she would return in an hour. It was growing dark when she left her off-campus apartment at 6 P.M., the usual time for her fitness outings.

title: Morrow's All-Out Push Helps Wambaugh Book to the Top
description: When Joseph Wambaugh was ready to sell his latest book, a true crime account of a murder in England, he thought it had little chance of becoming a best seller. Uncertain that his longtime publisher would be enthusiastic, he considered turning to another publishing house for just that one book. But when Mr. Wambaugh mentioned that possibility, his publisher replied, ''I've never, ever been the kind of guy who would let my girl go out with another date, thinking she'd come back to me.''

title: A Pocket-Sized Source of Oxygen for Athletes
description: Finding a breath of fresh air doesn't necessarily mean stepping outdoors these days. For some fitness buffs, it has come to mean inhaling pure oxygen from a pressurized cannister.

title: Queens District Split Over Shift on Death Penalty
description: The neighborhoods of southeast Queens eye each other warily across the parkways and expressways near Kennedy International Airport that cut them off from one another.

title: Worker Departures Vex Hong Kong
description: It is the prospect of increasing business with China that brings more foreign companies here each year, and it is the threat of China's eventual dominance over business that drives away their potential employees.

title: Governmental Candor Now Shortwave Staple
description: From Radio Afghanistan to the Voice of Zaire, more official government radio stations than ever before are broadcasting abroad on shortwave, and many have started downplaying strident propaganda and overt ideology in favor of more candor in their official newscasts.

title: After Delays, Drama in North's Trial
description: The trial of Oliver L. North enters its fourth week of testimony on Monday in a legal melodrama that has provided intense moments along with fresh insights into the Iran-contra affair.

title: Message-Getting Watch
description: The AT&E Corporation, a voice and data communication equipment maker, said it would start marketing a message-receiving wristwatch later this year, which it expects will generate $1 billion in annual revenues by 1994. ''This is going to represent the next big play in telecommunications,'' the company's president, Charles Skibo, told securities analysts. San Francisco-based AT&E expects to sign up 10 million subscribers using the digital display watch by 1994, Mr. Skibo said. The watches will retail for about $200 each, he said.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Racing Into Spring With Canoes and Skis, Too
description: LEAD: WELCOMING spring with unusual sporting events is a tradition in New England and New York. Variously called triathlons and quadrathlons, these competitions contain both summer and winter sports, usually some form of running, rafting, biking and cross-country skiing, and often are contested by teams.

title: Outdoors: Old Era in Downhill Skiing Returns
description: BACK in the 1860's, a Norwegian skier named Sondre Nordheim systematized a technique for turning and stopping on skis so he could repeat the maneuvers at will. Other skiers in his home province of Telemark copied his technique and it became known as telemarking.

title: Carla Hibbard and Jeffrey Curto Wed
description: The wedding of Carla Costanza Hibbard and Jeffrey Nicholls Curto took place yesterday in Geneva, Ill. The Rev. Steven Good, a Methodist minister, officiated at the 302 West restaurant.

title: The Mourning Era Begins for Hoyas
description: With just over eight minutes remaining in the Big East Conference championship game yesterday, Alonzo Mourning put his signature on another Georgetown victory.

title: Hoyas Seeded First In East
description: Sixty-four teams now know where they will travel and who they will battle in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball tournament, which will begin Thursday. If the selection committee's seedings prove true, Georgetown, Arizona, Oklahoma and Illinois will reach the Final Four in Seattle on April 1.

title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks
description: IN this quaint town where simplicity reigns, where traffic is seldom a nuisance and patrons dine at diners and chat for an hour afterward without a hint of rush, the locals gather and puff their chests while boasting about Indiana basketball.

title: Why 'Terrorism' Inadequately Describes the Threat to Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: One major championship was decided here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, but another remained in doubt until 12 hours after play ended.

title: Bush Seeks Control on Waste
description: President Bush has announced that he will propose legislation to halt exports of hazardous waste unless there is an agreement that the receiving country will handle the material in an approved, safe manner.

title: Savings Industry vs. Rising Rates
description: Rising interest rates, the bane of the savings and loan industry, are again starting to cut into profits at healthy savings institutions and are expected to accelerate the pace of failures among marginally solvent institutions.

title: Why Not Many Mommy Tracks?
description: Women have always worked outside the home: harvesting fruit, digging ditches, making airplane parts, cleaning houses, selling clothes, teaching children, emptying bedpans, taking down somebody else's letters. Labor for pay, then, is nothing new to them; but good pay is, and so, finally, is a sense of entitlement.

title: Reviews/Music; Preludes in a Piano Recital
description: The designation Prelude meant different things to the two subjects of Jean-Yves Thibaudet's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening. If the term implies anticipation, an announcement of things still to be said, than it best fit the 24 Chopin pieces that made up the second half of this evening. Many of them, indeed, appear as introductory fragments - bursts of inspiration based on a single idea. What gives them form is their brevity. They are allowed no time to stray off course.

title: Talk Now, Yanks Are Told
description: Rickey Henderson still has a deadline for the Yankees, but there is no date attached to it. His agent, Richie Bry, will begin negotiations with the team on a new contract this week, and only one thing matters to the left fielder: ''Get it done real soon, as soon as possible,'' he said.

title: Hothouses Give Hope To Poor Part of Spain
description: Mile after mile of colorful plastic-covered structures give this section of south Spain the appearance of a motionless glittering sea.

title: Pentagon Change Assessed
description: A report released today by Congressional researchers said the Pentagon's implementation of financial management changes required by law has been inadequate.

title: Botha Again Rejects Pressure to Give Up Pretoria Presidency
description: President P. W. Botha, South Africa's ailing leader, indicated today that he has no intention of heeding mounting pressure in the ruling National Party for him to resign as President.

title: Boxing; Holyfield Polishes Resume
description: There were times during his slam-bang victory Saturday night over Michael Dokes that Evander Holyfield appeared to be in a spot of trouble.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; CBS-ABC Race for 2d Means Nothing and Everything
description: THE so-called television season is an ill defined, archaic and arbitrary measurement of network performance. Indeed, in this season's ratings race, CBS and ABC say it really doesn't matter which one of them finishes second to the already declared winner, NBC.

title: A Proposition the Soviets Shouldn't Refuse
description: The systemic crisis of the Soviet world is the new and centrally important reality confronting Western policy in East-West relations. Responding to that crisis will require a comprehensive and long-term Western strategy. Such a strategy currently does not exist.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. companies are busy in Europe in an aggressive bid to take advantage of the barrier-free market that the European Community plans to establish at the end of 1992. Page A1

title: College Basketball; Oklahoma Upset By Missouri, 98-86
description: Byron Irvin scored 29 points and Doug Smith had 22 points and 14 rebounds today as 10th-ranked Missouri won the Big Eight tournament championship with a 98-86 victory over No. 2 Oklahoma.

title: Orange Crop Forecast
description: The nation's orange harvest for the 1988-89 crop season is estimated at 210.9 million boxes, down 2 percent from last month's forecast but 5 percent more than actual production last season, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill 2 P.L.O. Guerrillas North of the Border
description: Israeli troops killed two members of a Palestinian guerrilla group Saturday night as they were trying to infiltrate into Israel from Lebanon. A radical group backed by Syria said today that the infiltrators were its guerrillas.

title: Retail Merger Expert Leaves Shearson Post
description: Gilbert W. Harrison, a well-known retailing merger specialist, has resigned as a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to re-establish his former company, Financo Inc.

title: Review/Recital; A Boston Pianist at Merkin
description: Jung Ja Kim, a pianist on the faculty of the Boston Conservatory of Music, came to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night with a program of Ravel, Schubert, Chopin and Isang Yun. She played with seriousness and comprehension; one took away the impression of a thoughtful student and teacher of the literature rather than of a burning communicative drive, but in that context there were satisfactions to be had throughout.

title: Veterans Demonstrate Against Flag Artwork
description: About 2,500 veterans and supporters from nine states marched today on the Art Institute of Chicago to demand that officials remove a United States flag placed on the floor in an art student's exhibit.

title: Corrections
description: A map with an article on Saturday about fighting in Afghanistan located Samarkhel incorrectly. It is east of Jalalabad.

title: Debt Plan Faces Test In Mexico
description: Mounting pressures that threaten to undermine the economic program of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari are likely to make Mexico the test case for the new debt plan announced Friday by Washington's Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, Mexican and foreign officials and bankers here said over the weekend.

title: For an Independent and Truly Neutral Cambodia
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Holiday From Trial
description: Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., Oliver L. North's chief lawyer at the Federal trial involving the Iran-contra affair, has made no secret of his Irish heritage. Last week Mr. Sullivan asked Judge Gerhard A. Gesell if he would consider suspending the proceedings on St. Patrick's Day. And last week the judge announced that on March 17, ''We're going to not hold court.''

title: TV Notes
description: Cable and Taxes

title: 2 Cars and 2 Children Taken in Auto Thefts
description: For the second time in two days, Queens police officers were called to retrieve a toddler taken for a brief ride yesterday by an unwitting car thief. In both cases, the stolen cars had been left unattended by the children's fathers, the police said.

title: Cuomo to Fight Lilco Request
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today vowed to ''vigorously oppose'' rate increases this year sought by the Long Island Lighting Company. On Friday, Lilco asked the Public Service Commission that a temporary 5.4 percent rate increase become permanent on April 15 and that the P.S.C. grant an additional 5 percent rate increase on Oct. 1. The company said Friday it needed the increases to offset the cost of abandoning the $5.4 billion Shoreham plant.

title: I'll Meet You Beneath the National Debt
description: LEAD: Manhattan's 42d Street has a new vice: the budget deficit. Seymour Durst, a real estate developer, has built an electronic tote board there that gives a continuous flashing tally - second by second, dollar by dollar - of the United States national debt.

title: U.S. CORPORATIONS EXPAND IN EUROPE FOR '92 PROSPECTS
description: The Whirlpool Corporation has entered into a $2 billion joint venture to push its way into the European appliance market. The International Paper Company has made a $350 million bid for a French paper maker. And Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has recently expanded its investment banking offices in Milan, Italy, and in Madrid.

title: Paris Journal; Historian Gives France a 1789 It Can Live With
description: ''The French Revolution is over,'' Francois Furet wrote dramatically a decade ago. As France celebrates the 200th anniversary of the event, Mr. Furet might be tempted to add in 1989 that a furious historical debate about the revolution is over as well - and that he has won.

title: Commodity Exchanges See Threat
description: Having fended off regulation in the past, Chicago's commodity futures exchanges are staging a desperate attempt to retain their autonomy.

title: Blacks Remain Shut Out of Housing in White Areas
description: Theron and Claire Cook decided two years ago to sell their house in Jamaica, Queens, and rent an apartment.

title: Large Solar Flares Erupt Anew
description: A series of large solar flares, each with the potential to disrupt radio transmissions, have erupted in a wake of an unusually large blast, researchers at this base say.

title: Reviews/Music; A New Mimi in 'La Boheme'
description: Kallen Esperian took the part of Mimi at the Metropolitan Opera's performance of ''La Boheme'' on Wednesday evening. Miss Esperian is from Chicago, has won a number of auditions and competitions, and in the last few years has begun making the rounds on the American and European opera circuit. This was her Met debut.

title: Yachting; Rounding Cape Horn: Is Once Enough?
description: The aftermath of a mishap at Cape Horn last month involving the French solo sailor Philippe Monnet has stirred controversy in Europe.

title: Critic's Notebook; Musical World Has Room at the Top, But Who'll Fill It?
description: Within two days of each other last November, Zubin Mehta announced his resignation as music director of the New York Philharmonic as of May 1991 and Bruce Crawford said he would step down as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera around April 1.

title: Sports World Specials; Wrestling With Success
description: Last November, the Columbia football program ended almost five years of futility by finally winning a game. Last week, Steve Hasenfus put an end to a much longer period of frustration for the Ivy League school.

title: Review/Dance; Serving Up a Blend of Ideas
description: Tere O'Connor has a good many sensitive and intelligent followers. What they see is mostly a mystery to this viewer. Mr. O'Connor's newest piece, ''Four Sister Dances,'' presented Friday night at the Kitchen, looked as if he had poured a batch of decently interesting ideas into a grinder and remixed the minced fragments into an almost tasteless stew.

title: Olympics; Voy Is Still a Voice, Without Portfolio
description: Few Americans are paying closer attention to the Canadian Government's inquiry into drug use by athletes than Robert Voy, the doctor who resigned last week after five years as chief medical officer for the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 12, 1989: TUESDAY Esselte Bus Sys Inc Fleetwood Ent Inc Brown & Sharpe Mfg Fluor Corp Oklahoma G & E Co Tri Contl Corp Union Camp Corp Trinity Inds Inc WEDNESDAY American Intl Grp Inc AT&T Co Bandag Inc Carolina Pwr & Lt Co Hallwood Grp Inc Natl Svcs Ind Rochester G & E Corp THURSDAY Air Prods & Chems Inc Lincoln Natl Corp NYNEX Corp Transamerica Corp FRIDAY Aluminum Co America Bell Atlantic Corp Central Hudson G & E Russ Togs Inc Southeast Bnkg Corp

title: Gently Into the Enterprise Zone
description: President Bush and Jack Kemp want them, 36 states have them and five versions of them await Congressional attention. Enterprise zones - the answer to urban decay that even a conservative can love - are inscribed on the Bush agenda. But do they work? No one really knows.

title: Lord Crook, U.N. Delegate, 88
description: Lord Crook, a former British delegate to the United Nations and vice president of the Administrative Tribunal for nearly 20 years, died Friday, his lawyer said Saturday. Lord Crook was 88 years old.

title: David Cluger, Executive, 85
description: David Cluger, the former president of Cluger Rayons Inc. of Paterson, N.J., died of heart disease yesterday at University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Joseph Ferriola, 61, Reputed Mob Leader
description: Joseph Ferriola, the reputed boss of organized crime in Chicago, died Saturday after his second heart transplant in recent weeks. He was 61 years old and lived in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Salvador Army Admits Massacre; 2 Officers Held
description: The military acknowledged today that its forces killed 10 unarmed civilians in a small village last September, and it cleared the way for the prosecution of two officers and seven soldiers implicated in the massacre.

title: Review/Ballet; 'Sylphide' Shows Off Paris Ballet Fledglings
description: Having created a sensation in New York City last summer with its exceptionally polished performances and all-day technique demonstrations, the Paris Opera Ballet School has gone on to enjoy even greater success at home.

title: Accusations Expected At Securities Hearing
description: Allegations of potentially illegal activities involving a private investigator are expected to be discussed today in a hearing by a House subcommittee looking into regulation of the securities markets, Congressional staff members say.

title: Not Mad, But Even
description: A muscular Democratic Senate majority, having diminished the power of George Bush's Presidency, now demands that bygones be bygones.

title: As Rangers Falter, So Does Granato
description: Tony Granato hesitated, and an instant later both Dale Hunter and the game were lost. Hunter beat Granato to the puck and then beat John Vanbiesbrouck with it for the decisive goal in the 4-2 victory the Washington Capitals gained over the Rangers here Saturday night.

title: Sports World Specials; Mutual Love
description: The child of a divorced couple, Dave Lebo vowed long ago to be a special kind of parent. ''Myself growing up and not having a father,'' he said, ''I felt I wanted to give my son something I didn't have myself: time and attention.''

title: Dale M. Rossi Weds Richard Linowes
description: Dale MaryAnn Rossi, the daughter of MaryAnn K. Rossi of Port Aransas, Tex., and Fred Burchell Rossi of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Gary Linowes, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David F. Linowes of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Champaign, Ill. Rabbi Ammos Chorny performed the ceremony at B'nai Israel Congregation in Rockville, Md., assisted by Cantor Arnold Saltzman.

title: Levinson Wins Directors Award for 'Rain Man'
description: Barry Levinson won the 1988 Directors Guild of America award Saturday night for ''Rain Man,'' a drama about a manipulative car salesman who tries to trick his autistic savant brother out of his inheritance.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Quayle Campaigns for Respect
description: Since he took the oath of office on Jan. 20, Vice President Dan Quayle has been campaigning hard, both here and on the road, for the things that eluded him in the 1988 Presidential campaign: respect, affection and a political base he can call his own.

title: Michelangelo's Forbidden Fruit Was a Fig; Not Persimmon at All
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have 18 hours, all to ourselves, to look out the window, to read, to talk, to rest. That beats dealing with O'Hare Airport.'' - Michele Piel of Chicago, travelling by train instead of by plane. [ A1:3. ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; New Broom at Work
description: Ronald H. Brown, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has started but not finished his housecleaning.

title: For an Independent and Truly Neutral Cambodia; A Cruel Hoax
description: To the Editor:

title: Offer for Messerschmitt Said to Be Blocked
description: West Germany's antitrust authorities have blocked a takeover by Daimler-Benz A.G., which would make the company one of Europe's largest arms and aerospace groups, Der Spiegel magazine said today.

title: Bomb Investigators Gain a Sense Of Man Seeking Captain's House
description: A Federal official said today that investigators had compiled a description of a man of Middle Eastern appearance who had been seen in the past several months walking in the San Diego neighborhood of Capt. Will C. Rogers 3d, the captain of the Navy missile cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet last July.

title: Studies Find Drugs Still Overused To Control Nursing Home Elderly
description: More than a decade after a Federal study found serious overuse and misuse of powerful drugs in nursing homes, many patients are still being drugged into a stupor just to make them easier to care for.

title: Elissa Jablons Marries M. C. Bernstein
description: Elissa Beatrice Sarah Jablons and Matthew Charles Bernstein were married yesterday at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton, L.I., by Rabbis Mayer Perelmuter and David Greenberg. The bride is the daughter of Beverly Jablons of New York and East Hampton and Jordan Jablons of Milford, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Bernstein of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: One Person, Four Bedrooms - It's a Crime
description: LEAD: In the 1960's and 1970's, New York City financed the construction of more than 60,000 subsidized middle-income housing units. The city sold the land at substantially below market prices, provided low-cost financing and generous tax exemptions. Since the start of this program, called Mitchell-Lama housing, the city has forgiven almost $2.5 billion in property and business taxes.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Buck Stopped Here
description: The first atomic weapons test, the detonation of the equivalent of 19,000 tons of TNT at Alamogordo, N.M., was carried out nearly 44 years ago, but on whose authority?

title: Banker Sees a Need To Digest Acquisitions
description: Edward E. Crutchfield Jr., an acquisition-minded banker, says his bank's latest purchase probably will be its last for a while.

title: Time to Sort Out the Trash
description: The City Council's Environmental Protection Committee is to vote today on legislation that would establish a program of trash recycling. It's a crucial step for the city's future welfare.

title: Since When Did Hawthorne Revere Religion?
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Says the Space Shuttle Is Ready for Launching Today
description: Space agency officials said today that the shuttle Discovery is ready to blast off on its five-day mission at 8:07 Monday morning.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust New York Corp. elected Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., president and chief operating officer of Time Inc., to its board.

title: Noted Maverick Fights To Be Jersey Governor
description: At one time or another almost everyone in state politics here has done battle with Assemblyman Alan J. Karcher, a man known to many as New Jersey's most brilliant, charming and acerbic contrariant.

title: Kohl Party Dealt New Setback in Local Vote
description: Voters in Frankfurt and in municipalities across Hesse State followed the lead of West Berlin today, abandoning the Christian Democratic party of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and showing strong new support for the anti-foreigner stance of the extreme right.

title: AMTRAK ROLLS UP RECORDS IN RIDERS AND IS EXPANDING
description: Nearly 18 years after Amtrak was created to rescue the nation's sinking passenger rail system, its trains are carrying record numbers of passengers, wooing them from the airlines with skiing packages, movies and phones on some trains and even an experimental return of linen and china to dining cars.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Mexico and Venezuela have agreed to develop a program to integrate their economies based on an accord between Brazil and Argentina in 1987. Mexican Foreign Minister Fernando Solana said the potential for increased bilateral trade was enormous, in areas like petrochemicals, oil equipment, tourism and trade. He noted that Mexico's two-way trade totaled $40 billion and Venezuela's $20 billion, but bilateral trade only $50 million.

title: B-2's First Flight Delayed
description: The B-2 Stealth bomber will not fly for the first time before late spring or summer, the Air Force said Friday. Acknowledging recent reports that the schedule for the first flight was in jeopardy, the service said that because of ''an aggregation of minor system checkout problems, the B-2's first flight is now expected to be in the late spring or early summer time frame.''

title: Proposed Law Would Protect Press in Court
description: Legislators in Albany are moving toward a significant expansion of a New York State law that allows news organizations to withhold from courts information obtained by reporters.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; No Winners in Lord, Geller Split
description: On Thursday night, employees and alumni of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein will meet at Mr. O's to reminisce about the advertising agency that made little Charlie Chaplin a symbol for enormous I.B.M. Everyone who worked at Lord, Geller a year ago is invited to the Manhattan pub, said Jill McClabb, the reunion's organizer, except for three people: Richard J. Lord, Arthur W. Einstein Jr. and Kevin B. O'Neill.

title: Smith Started At Zero
description: CHARLES SMITH looks badly fed. When players on the Georgetown basketball team go back to the bench during the game for a cup of water, it seems Charles Smith should maybe get a peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwich, too.

title: Michelangelo's Forbidden Fruit Was a Fig
description: To the Editor:

title: Schoolboy Records Broken
description: Derrick Love of Fort Meade, Md., and an 880-yard relay quartet from Hawthorne, Calif., registered schoolboy indoor records today at the National Scholastic track and field championships in the Naval Academy Field House.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Mother Jones magazine, to Buckley/DeCerchio, New York, for its trade and consumer advertising.

title: Market Place; California Energy Vs. an Analyst
description: ANALYSTS issue thousands of reports every year, and most of them have little impact.

title: New Pornography Curb Challenged
description: A coalition of groups concerned with publishing and entertainment is planning to file a lawsuit in Washington this week challenging the constitutionality of a recent Federal law against child pornography.

title: Bush to Ask New Aid for Contras in Honduras
description: The Bush Administration will seek aid to keep the Nicaraguan guerrillas in Honduras at least through February 1990, in spite of a regional peace agreement that calls for disbanding the rebels, Administration officials said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * All Nippon Airways Co. Ltd., Tokyo, and Toda Construction Co. Ltd. are considering setting up a joint company to build a $200 million hotel in Los Angeles, according to Toda.

title: A.C.C. Tournament; North Carolina Is Finally Back on Top
description: The theme for North Carolina was, finally, redemption.

title: New Stage in Government's Long War Against the Teamsters
description: At 9:30 this morning, Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer for the United States Government, is to rise in an 11th-floor courtroom at the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan to begin what may be the decisive battle in a decades-long war between the Government and the largest labor union in the world.

title: Tiny Liberal Party Set To Wag Some Big Dogs
description: New York's Liberal Party, with fewer than 1 percent of the city's registered voters, is poised for the first time in years to wield its grossly disproportionate influence in a mayoral campaign.

title: Bankers Wary on Plan To Shrink Foreign Debt
description: The Treasury's plan announced Friday to reduce the debt burden of developing countries is similar to existing programs that have operated on too small a scale to satisfy the largest debtor countries, bankers said over the weekend.

title: 2-Tier Minimum Wage Gains Ground Among Its Foes
description: After eight years of partisan stalemate over raising the minimum wage, Democrats and organized labor appear to be moving toward accepting some kind of two-tier system that Republicans have made a condition for any increase.

title: Preparing for Telemark Skiing
description: Bike riding is good preparation for telemark skiing because it strengthens the legs and knees, requires balance and contributes to aerobic fitness. It is important to be limber for telemarking, so regular stretching exercises are helpful. Watching the ''The Telemark Movie'' (available from the North American Telemark Organization for $34.95) is good preparation and review of the movements. Knee pads, like those worn in volleyball, can contribute to confidence as well as protect knees from unseen objects under the snow.

title: Review/Recital; American Pieces for Piano
description: Victoria Griswold's Saturday afternoon program at Weill Recital Hall offered a stimulating look at the American piano literature that arose during the early years of this century. The six composers whose music she played were born in the second half of the 19th century and worked hard to establish an American idiom. Only one of them, Charles Ives, was in any sense a modernist. The others worked in a more easily accessible Romantic idiom and borrowed liberally from European styles.

title: Tax Watch; Help From Books And Computers
description: A SMALL investment in one or two of the many excellent tax books or computer programs available can pay off handsomely, even for those whose returns are prepared professionally.

title: Sports News Briefs; T.A.C. Approves Drug-Testing Plan
description: A year-round drug testing program was approved unanimously today by the board of directors of The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field.

title: Kabul Troops Scoff at Notion They Are on Their Last Legs
description: The snow that comes to Kabul in winter turned into a chill drizzle today, adding an extra touch of mournfulness to the cemetery on Martyrs' Hill.

title: Georgetown Storms to the Big East Title
description: Georgetown fittingly closed out the Big East Conference's 10th anniversary tournament with a performance that left little doubt the Hoyas were, indeed, the conference's team of the decade.

title: A Riddle for Communists: Why Does the East German Economy Prosper?
description: ''Those damn Germans,'' said a Czechoslovak journalist. ''They even make socialism work.'' He followed with a question often heard in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe: Since Marx and Engels were Germans, is it possible that their theories do not work elsewhere because they were conceived with the qualities of Germans in mind?

title: Analysts Divided on Rate Outlook
description: As the end of the first quarter nears, credit market economists remain divided over how much higher interest rates will have to move to pare back economic growth and inflation to the levels wanted by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: N.C.A.A. Women; Auburn Gains a No. 1 Berth
description: Once-beaten Auburn was seeded No. 1 in the Mideast Region as the 48-team field was announced today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: INSIDE
description: Massacre in El Salvador The Salvadoran military has acknowledged that soldiers massacred 10 civilians last year, and it cleared the way for prosecution. Page A8. Breakthrough on Wage Law Congress is moving toward an agreement that would raise the minimum wage for some workers. Page A12. Next Goal, the Final Four Charles Smith led Georgetown past Syracuse and into the N.C.A.A. tournament seeded No. 1 in the East Region. Illinois, Oklahoma and Arizona were the other No. 1 teams in the 64-team field. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: Lyle Allen Jr., 66, Former Drug Executive
description: Lyle McDowell Allen Jr., a former head of the legal division and assistant secretary of the American Home Products Corporation, died of lung cancer Thursday at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 66 years old and lived in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Gambles for Eastern;
description: Many airline industry experts say that an important next step in Frank Lorenzo's strategy to build a new Eastern Airlines will be discount fares as low as $49 between New York and Florida in a dramatic gesture to attract passengers and thrust the ailing carrier back into the competitive fray.

title: Britons Debating Book Discounts
description: The furor over ''The Satanic Verses'' has recently overshadowed the spirited debate in the British book industry on an issue with probably more lasting impact.

title: Reviews/Music; Subtly Echoing the Past
description: The composer Leon Kirchner, who is celebrating his 70th birthday this year, was the subject of a Continuum retrospective program at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening. Continuum's connections with Mr. Kirchner are stronger than with some of the other composers whose music it has examined over the last 23 years. Cheryl Seltzer, one of Continuum's directors, was a student of Mr. Kirchner's at Mills College 30 years ago. The ensemble presented a Kirchner retrospective in 1977 and has recorded some of the composer's music.

title: Sports News Briefs; Cards' Cox to Miss Entire Season
description: Danny Cox, a St. Louis Cardinal right-hander, will undergo elbow surgery later this month and will miss the entire season, the club annouced today.

title: Pressure for a Savings Plan Adds to Cost, Panel Is Told
description: Political pressure to end the savings and loan crisis without raising taxes or increasing the Federal budget deficit is adding to the staggering cost of the problem, a Congressional panel was told here on Friday and Saturday.

title: U.S. Rebuts Greece On Claim That C.I.A. Fans Bank Scandal
description: The United States today denied Greek charges that the Central Intelligence Agency was trying to bring down the Greek Government by fanning the political furor over a banking scandal.

title: Appeal Due By Centaur
description: Centaur Partners said today that it would appeal a judge's order blocking a special meeting of the Pennwalt Corporation's shareholders and said it was ''unwavering'' in its resolve to take over the chemical company.

title: Slim Playoff Shot Leaves Devils Blue
description: The hurt and dejection Lou Lamoriello felt was evident in the eyes of the president of the Devils. Leaning against the wall in a hallway under the stands at Nassau Coliseum minutes after Saturday night's loss to the Islanders, Lamoriello's eyes watered as he spoke of his team's virtual elimination from the playoffs.

title: U.S. Plan Faulty, a P.L.O. Aide Says
description: A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization yesterday dismissed suggestions from the Bush Administration for reducing tensions in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as unbalanced and outdated.

title: 'New' Ken Griffey Is on Rise
description: One day during the 1983 season, Nick Priore, the Yankees' clubhouse man, went to Ken Griffey and told him that Billy Martin, then the manager, said his two sons were making too much noise playing in the area between the clubhouse and the dugout.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PREPARATORY COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE SPECIAL SESSION OF THE G.A. DEVOTED TO INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION - 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Relief for Foreign Debtors, at Last
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady uttered the magic words last week: ''debt reduction.'' He conceded that third world countries, heavily in debt to Western banks, needed relief. That reverses Washington's stubborn official opposition to debt forgiveness. His proposal is still too vague to be called a plan, but the outline is as welcome as it is belated. The need for further definition, then action, remains urgent.

title: Prenor Group Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-Included a special gain of $13,830,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: PATTERNS
description: Malaise in London

title: Coastal Extends Texas Eastern Bid
description: The Coastal Corporation again extended a $2.6 billion offer for the stock outstanding of the Texas Eastern Corporation. It was the second extension since Texas Eastern had agreed to be acquired by the Panhandle Eastern Corporation. The Coastal offer is scheduled to expire March 31.

title: G.M. Planning Solar Car Race
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would sponsor a solar-powered car race from Florida to Michigan next year for college and university teams and that it had received about 60 design proposals.

title: Roger Moore Walks Out On a Lloyd Webber Role
description: Roger Moore, best known for his film portrayal of James Bond, walked out of the lead role of a new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical today, a month before the show was scheduled to open.

title: Horizon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year included a $33,745,000 pretax provision to reduce real estate held for development and sale and other related assets to estimated net realizable value.

title: Ford Unit Will Sell Marine Operations
description: The Ford Motor Company's Rouge Steel unit said it would sell its 66-year-old marine operations to the Lakes Shipping Company, a unit of the Interlake Steamship Company of Cleveland, for an undisclosed price. The sale includes three ore carriers named after descendants of the auto maker's founder: the William Clay Ford, the Benson Ford and the Henry Ford 2d.

title: Hesburgh Testifies Signings Clearly Broke Rules
description: The Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, the former president of Notre Dame, told a Federal jury today that if he had known Notre Dame athletes had signed with agents and accepted money before their college eligibility had expired, he would have terminated their scholarships.

title: Hills Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $3,642,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and year. c-Included a tax credit of $12,250,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Security Guards Go on Strike At the Los Alamos Laboratory
description: Security guards at Los Alamos National Laboratory went on strike today, but they were replaced by non-union workers and supervisors.

title: Big B Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $503,000 tax credit.

title: End of Era: No Big Chaw For Zimmer
description: In his clubhouse office, Don Zimmer, still in his Chicago Cubs uniform after a workout, was talking with Joe Garagiola when baseball's raconteur-at-liberty pointed to two shiny packs of chewing tobacco on the manager's desk. ''Still chewing?'' Garagiola said. ''Funny you should say that,'' Zimmer said. ''I quit two days ago.'' ''You quit!'' Garagiola said. Through the years, the bulge of chewing tobacco in Don Zimmer's cheek has sometimes been bigger than a baseball. Don Zimmer without a chaw is as unnatural as Joe Garagiola without a microphone. But the Cubs' manager has vowed to stop. In a decision that deserved a ceremonial last spray of tobacco juice, it's the beginning of the end of an era.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Apple Bank for Savings, New York, and Sag Harbor Savings Bank jointly announced that Apple Bank would acquire all outstanding common stock of Sag Harbor for $21 a share in cash, a total price of $29.5 million.

title: Canadian Trade Pact Accelerated
description: The United States and Canada, which on Jan. 1 put an agreement into effect to end practically all trade barriers within 10 years, decided today to negotiate a new pact to speed up some tariff cuts that are already agreed on.

The company also said the results of operations for the period Feb. 1, 1988 to Oct. 31, 1988 (the period prior to the merger of Braniff and Bia Acquisitions Inc.) have been combined with the results of operations for the period Nov. 1, 1988 to Jan. 31, 1989 in order to present annual results. On Oct. 24, 1988, Bia Acquisitions Inc., merged with and into Braniff. Braniff attributed $23.6 million of the net loss in the latest year to the operations of Florida Express.

title: INSIDE
description: Maurice Evans Dies at 87 Maurice Evans, popular for his Shakespearean portrayals in the 1930's and 40's, has died, Page D27. Warning on Chilean Fruit Follows Cyanide Discovery Consumers were urged not to eat Chilean fruit after cyanide was found in Chilean grapes in Philadelphia.

title: Late, Fast Goals Spark Islanders
description: Bryan Trottier scored the tie-breaking goal with 2 minutes 11 seconds remaining and the Islanders, who have the fewest points in the National Hockey League, beat the league-leading Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, tonight.

title: Rotech Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income of $32,876 and $65,411 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Foodarama Supermarktets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Pushing Back on the Revolving Door
description: President Bush's Commission on Federal Ethics Law Reform moves his Administration a big step closer to his goal of a cleaner Government. The commission reported promptly, six weeks after Inauguration Day. That's none too soon given the frequency with which ethical issues have arisen, especially those concerning the ''revolving door'' between public and private service.

title: Mercury in Everglades Fish Worries Experts
description: Game fish in the Everglades are suddenly showing mercury levels that are among the highest ever recorded in the United States. The discovery has alarmed experts, who are unable to explain the cause.

title: Sax Makes His Debut; Winfield Remains Out
description: Steve Sax made his debut for the Yankees tonight, but Dave Winfield's first appearance of the spring was moved back.

title: Reviews/Television; Endangered Species
description: If endangered species could be saved through the exertions of television, they would all be home free. Hardly a month goes by without a plea on the tube in behalf of the elephant, the black rhinoceros, the whale, the shark, the eagle or some other creature being hard pressed by man. Public television finds the subject irresistible. In addition to the undisputed, though sometimes unexamined, appeal of each cause, animal shows draw big audiences by noncommercial standards, and the companies that pay for them need never fear giving offense. Who is going to mount a protest against the elephant?

title: FLIGHT OF SHUTTLE BEGINS FLAWLESSLY
description: The space shuttle Discovery thundered flawlessly into orbit today, carrying aloft five astronauts on a five-day mission and lifting the spirits of the space agency as it belatedly began an ambitious year of seven shuttle flights.

title: The Earliest Images: The Lumiere Brothers' Films
description: The images speed by in the blink of an eye: A woman in a puff-sleeved, belle epoque dress. Horse-drawn trolleys. Steaming locomotives. Babies in perambulators, paraded by uniformed nannies. The Queen of England and the Russian Czar.

title: Topics of The Times; Whistle-Blower Breakthrough
description: Last fall the House and Senate unanimously approved a measure to protect Federal whistle-blowers -workers who expose fraud or abuse in their agencies. But President Reagan vetoed the bill, inspiring special wrath from Congress for reneging on the pledge of support made by his own negotiators.

title: National Park Wildlife Deserve a Buffer Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ENVOY URGES HONDURANS TO LET THE CONTRAS STAY
description: The United States asked Honduras today to let the Nicaraguan guerrillas stay on its territory for another year, even though five Central American countries decided recently that the contras should be disarmed and removed from Honduras.

description: All New Yorkers would be required to separate recyclable materials from their garbage under a plan unanimously approved yesterday by a committee of the City Council.

title: In London Shows, Some Winners Amid the Chaos
description: Designers here are infatuated with fashion, but they have not exactly figured out how to channel their enthusiasm. The fall and winter openings, which ended today, seemed to be one big costume party with the guests in clothes they made themselves.

description: b-Net loss

title: Summit Health Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and Canada will negotiate to speed up some tariff cuts that were agreed upon in the wide-ranging pact to end all trade barriers within 10 years. The unexpected move is a sign that the trade accord is working well, though some friction remains. [ Page D1. ] COMPANIES Louis Gerstner, American Express president, will leave to head RJR Nabisco. The choice of someone from the financial services industry to reshape the food and tobacco giant after its leveraged buyout was unexpected. [ D1. ] Sears, Roebuck is reshaping its financial services network by halving the number of Dean Witter outlets in its stores. It will also convert most in-store Coldwell Banker real estate offices to unstaffed units. [ D1. ] Shaklee will be acquired by Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical of Japan for $28 a share. The agreement follows an unsolicited offer from Irwin Jacobs, who said he would not raise his bid. [ D1. ] Eastern Airlines operated 104 flights yesterday, up from 66 daily last week. The airline said an absence of pilots caused it to fall short of its estimate that it would have 140 flights a day. [ D6. ] Cray Research, moving to modernize the heart of its product line, will announce new versions of its most powerful supercomputer. [ D2. ] Quantum Chemical agreed to sell its oleochemical division for $480 million to the U.S. subsidiary of West Germany's Henkel. [ D5. ] A Waste Management unit pleaded no contest to conspiring to violate antitrust laws and will be fined $1 million. [ D5. ] An investigator for a firm employed by Drexel refused to testify before a House panel, stalling the hearing. [ D7. ] Masco acquired Universal Furniture, an Asian company registered in the British Virgin Islands, for $500 million. [ D9. ] Financial advertising at The Wall Street Journal and Barron's continues to fall, even though the stock market has recovered somewhat from the '87 crash. [ D23. ] Japonica Partners has acquired 8.8 percent of CNW and said it ''is considering seeking to acquire control.'' [ D5. ] HHM Group is seeking to restructure its industrial holdings under a newly formed holding company. [ D5. ] Conde Nast International is getting a new president, Jonathan Newhouse, in January. [ D23. ] THE ECONOMY The F.D.I.C. had its ''worst year ever'' in 1988, its chairman said. While bank profits hit a record, the agency's reserve fund fell by $4.2 billion after closing or merging 221 banks. [ D1. ] The Interior Department is disposing of Federal lands in the West worth millions for little more than pennies an acre. [ A24. ] MARKETS Stocks continued Friday's show of strength, with the Dow rising 24.11, to 2,306.25. [ D12. ] Treasury notes and bonds dipped in quiet trading, pushed lower by a big jump in oil prices. [ D18. ] The dollar drifted higher in quiet trading, and gold prices were little changed. [ D20. ] Crude oil futures soared to a 16-month high, buoyed by strong demand for heating oil. [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Morton Thiokol's chairman discusses the company's decision to spin off its commercial operations. Talking Business. [ D2. ] James Robinson 3d, American Express chairman, is starting to get some respect from investors, if not from Wall Street analysts. Market Place. [ D12. ] D.M.B.&B./U.S.A. is tired of losing out on big accounts and wants to do something about it. Advertising. [ D24. ]

title: TV Insults Men, Too
description: LEAD: It was front page news and it made the TV networks. A mother from Michigan single-handedly convinces some of America's biggest advertisers to cancel their sponsorship of the Fox Broadcasting Company's ''Married . . . With Children'' because, as she put it, the show blatantly exploits women and the family.

title: For Want of $200,000, Yanks Lost Washington
description: For the want of a nail, the shoe was lost; for the want of a shoe, the horse was lost; for the want of a horse, the kingdom was lost. And for the want of $200,000, the horseshoe nail of Yankee payrolls, Claudell Washington, was lost.

title: 700 Vie for 288 New York City School Board Posts
description: Although the positions are tarnished by allegations of misdeeds and irregularities, some 700 residents of New York City are seeking the 288 nonsalaried posts of community school board members in the elections scheduled for May 2.

title: Device Detects Africanized Bees
description: RESEARCHERS have created a portable device that identifies aggressive Africanized bees by monitoring the sound made by the movement of their wings.

title: Democratic Leader, Bowing to Pressure, To Stump in Chicago
description: Moving to quell talk that he was being unduly responsive to the wishes of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced plans today to campaign for Richard M. Daley, the Democratic nominee for Mayor of Chicago.

description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, testified today that he told Ronald Reagan and George Bush at a 1985 meeting that Oliver L. North provided occasional advice and assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when Congress had banned Government aid to the contras.

description: The owner of a taxicab-medallion brokerage pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a fraudulent scheme to obtain and misapply $22 million from the Hyfin Credit Union in Brooklyn.

description: Six former officials of the Rumanian Communist Party have sent a letter to President Nicolae Ceausescu attacking the Rumanian leader's hard-line policies, Western diplomats and Eastern bloc journalists in Bucharest said today.

title: Campaign Notes; Backers See Dinkins as a Skipper Badly in Need of a Crew
description: From the moment he set sail as a candidate for mayor, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, was riding some fast currents. But now some supporters have begun to worry that his campaign has becalmed not too far from shore.

description: The California Assembly voted today to ban assault rifles, clearing the way for the state to become the first to prohibit the sale, possession or manufacture of the military-style, semiautomatic guns.

description: Angella Issajenko, Canada's best female sprinter, told a Canadian Government inquiry that she had used performance-enhancing drugs since 1979, corroborating testimony her coach, Charlie Francis, had given over the past two weeks.

description: For a former minor league ballplayer like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the difference between the way he was questioned Friday by the ethics panel he created and the way Attorney General Robert Abrams and Comptroller Edward V. Regan were interrogated earlier was like the difference between Nerf ball and hardball.

title: Hearing, and Heeding, the Mayor
description: Mayor Edward Koch, worried about selective news leaks, balks at testifying in private before the State Commission on Government Integrity. He says he wants to answer the commission's questions about the Talent Bank - the Koch administration's part-patronage, part-affirmative action hiring program - only in public. While his concerns have merit, he risks protesting too much.

description: Basketball fans should get their fill this week when ESPN and CBS offer coverage of the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

description: A Government spokesman said today that Afghan forces had used Soviet-supplied surface-to-surface missiles to drive back rebels attacking Jalalabad, a city on the border with Pakistan.

title: Review/Ballet; Bujones Choreography
description: The Boston Ballet celebrated its 25th birthday on Saturday night at the Wang Center with balloons, champagne and two birthday gifts. One was the delightful ''Defilade'' by Sydney Leonard, a longtime ballet mistress and colleague of the late E. Virginia Williams, who founded the company. The second was the world premiere of a staging by Fernando Bujones of divertissements from the third act of ''Raymonda,'' in an evening of dancing that ranged from respectable to glittering.

description: When President Bush plucked Representative Dick Cheney from the ladder of House leadership to be his Secretary of Defense, the stage was set for an intense and probably bruising battle within the ranks of House Republicans.
