title: A Set to Upstage the Dancers
description: Trisha Brown has done surprising things in her 28-year career as a post-modernist choreographer. She has walked on walls and sent signals from dancer to dancer across SoHo rooftops. She has choreographed by plotting points on an imaginary cube. And now she and Robert Rauschenberg, a longtime friend and collaborator, have devised another potentially revolutionary strategy for dance.

title: A Sinfonietta by Perle
description: On paper, George Perle's new Sinfonietta has the look of the 18th century. There is the same uncomplicated instrumentation, the clarity of texture and the appearance, as well, of lightfooted Rococo elegance.

title: Steego Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $550,000 charge relative to a one-time writedown of inventory to net realizable value: a $790,000 charge relative to proposed settlement of certain litigation; a $200,000 charge to recognize casualty insurance claims incurred; a $915,000 withholding tax on dividends received from a Canadian subsidiary, and the effect of tax benefit limitations on U.S. operating losses. c-Included income of $952,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and included income of $229,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,615,000 from an accounting change. Latest third quarter and nine-month results included gains of $86,000 and $2 million, respectively, from disposal of assets. Year-ago nine-month results included gains of $3.3 million from the disposal of assets and $607,000 from termination of an overfunded pension plan.

title: New Test for Entrance To Medical School Set
description: A streamlined test for entrance to medical school that stresses thinking and communication skills will be introduced in 1991, the Association of American Medical Colleges said today.

title: James Kee Dies at 71; Former House Member
description: James Kee, who served eight years in the House of Representatives from a district that had been represented by both his parents, died of lung disease Saturday at Montgomery General Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Afghan Rebel Bars Return of U.S. Stingers
description: An Afghan guerrilla party said today that it would not return Stinger missiles supplied by the United States to help the rebels' fight the Kabul Government.

title: Jersey Murder Trial Is Bias Issue for Indians
description: In a case seen by many members of Hudson County's Indian community as a symbol of bias-related violence against them, four teen-agers went on trial today in the fatal beating of 30-year-old Namroze Mody outside a bar in Hoboken in 1987.

title: Timberland Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior-year share earnings figure is not applicable; the company went public on June 30, 1987.

title: Insight Magazine Shifts To Smith Burke
description: Insight magazine gave a lift to Smith Burke & Azzam last week, awarding its circulation advertising account to the Baltimore agency, which suffered an exodus of employees last month. The account is worth $5.2 million, said Roger Gray, the chairman of Smith Burke. Insight is published by The Washington Times.

title: Rain Is Late, but Now Hope Flowers
description: March came in like a lion, lashing California with rains from the Oregon border to the Mexican border and blanketing the Sierra Nevada with new snow. It was late, perhaps too late, but it raised hopes that the largest agricultural state could avoid a third straight dry year, with consequences felt all the way to the East Coast.

title: Investigator Silent Before House Panel
description: In a contentious showdown, a private investigator who works for a firm employed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. refused to testify today before a Congressional subcommittee. He argued that the panel was violating his constitutional rights to representation by counsel who was prepared to address the accusations.

title: Mining Unit's Sale By Baker Hughes
description: Baker Hughes Inc., the international oilfield equipment and service company, said it would put its Mining Equipment Group up for sale. The mining group, which consists of six sizable businesses and a number of small ones, manufactures equipment used largely for coal mining.

title: Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $1.5 million of one-time expense reductions, principally as a result of purchase accounting estimates resolved in the fourth quarter.

title: Biomet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NASA Chief To Leave Soon
description: James C. Fletcher, the NASA Administrator, said today that his replacement would be named within the next week or two.

title: Local 560 Says It Helped To Set Stage for Accord
description: Members of Teamsters Local 560 were not sure today of the reasons behind the last-minute settlement of the Government's civil rackeetering case against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but they were certain they had something to do with it.

title: D'Arcy Tries To Burnish Staid Image
description: D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is the world's 10th-largest advertising agency, but its U.S.A. division is frustrated, always invited to parties but too rarely asked to dance.

title: Consultants Sue Andersen
description: The Information Consulting Group, a consulting organization that specializes in the design and installation of computer systems, said today that it had filed a $300 million lawsuit against Arthur Andersen & Company, charging the Big Eight accounting firm with seeking to destroy I.C.G. by intimidating prospective employees and clients and by disparaging its principals.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Feb. 15 omitted the name of one winery in the newly designated Stags Leap district in the Napa Valley. It is the Chimney Rock Winery.

title: Dow, With Continued Strength, Rises 24.11
description: Stock prices climbed strongly yesterday, continuing Friday's late show of strength.

title: Linebacker For the Team From Apple
description: APPLE Computer Inc.'s new Macintosh IIcx computer, which was introduced last week, is compact, powerful and versatile. It has inherited the best features of its forebears while avoiding most of their flaws, and could be a standard for years to come, just as the Apple IIe was in a previous generation of Apple products.

title: Inmate From Jersey Jail Dies; Family Says Guards Beat Him
description: An inmate from the Hudson County Jail died Saturday, and his brother blamed jail guards for the death, saying they beat his brother with nightsticks.

The company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31. It said the year-ago fourth quarter results are for the three months ended Dec. 31. title: Ford Great-Grandson To Assume New Post
description: The Ford Motor Company said William Clay Ford Jr., 31 years old, will become manager of heavy truck engineering and manufacturing on July 1. The move is intended to provide managerial seasoning to a young descendant of the company's founder.

title: Books of The Times; A German-Jewish Survivor in Solitude in India
description: Baumgartner's Bombay By Anita Desai 230 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: A Record Year for Banks, But F.D.I.C.'s 'Worst Ever'
description: Bank profits set a record in 1988, but for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, ''it was the worst year ever,'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., told analysts yesterday.

title: Masco Buying Universal Furniture
description: The Masco Corporation today made its biggest in a long string of acquisitions with a $500 million purchase of Universal Furniture Ltd., an Asian company registered in the British Virgin Islands.

title: Papandreou Survives No-Confidence Motion
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou early today rebuffed an attempt to force him to resign over an economic and political scandal.

title: HELICOPTER CRASH KILLS 15 IN ARIZONA
description: An Air Force helicopter crashed Sunday in the desert on a night training mission, killing all 15 people aboard, the authorities said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Bell Atlantic, to Devon Direct Marketing & Advertising, Malvern, Pa., for its direct marketing.

title: Topics of The Times; A Principal's 'Punishment'
description: Joe Clark, the bat-wielding, bullhorn-toting principal of Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J., has been suspended for five days, with pay, for allowing a striptease at a school assembly last month. Given Mr. Clark's history of bizarre and autocratic behavior, this ''punishment'' amounts to nothing more than a brief vacation.

title: Reviews/Music; Joan Sutherland in Recital at the Met
description: The final item on Joan Sutherland's recital program Sunday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera was ''Io non sono piu l'Annetta'' from ''Crispino e la Comare'': a good tune, lots of brio and smart rhythm in the rendition, showers of brilliant coloratura, a socko high D flat at the end, and bang! Cheers, shouts and an instant standing ovation from what had up to that point been a friendly but hardly enthusiastic audience.

title: Oman View on Oil Cuts
description: Oman's oil minister said today that nonmembers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have no independent plans for output cuts in the second half of 1989. The minister, Said Ahmed al-Shanfari, was quoted as telling the Middle East Economic Survey that any further cuts would depend on OPEC and the supply-and-demand outlook. More than 10 independent oil-producing countries decided last month to back OPEC's efforts to increase world oil prices by cutting exports in the second quarter.

title: Bonar Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 3
description: b-Included a special gain of $370,000. Year-ago share earnings was not immediately available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Giants Sign Lambrecht
description: Six weeks into the eight-week period for signing new unrestricted pro football free agents, the Giants signed their first yesterday. He was Mike Lambrecht, a 6-foot-1-inch, 275-pound defensive tackle left unprotected by the Miami Dolphins. Lambrecht, from St. Cloud (Minn.) State, played two seasons for the Dolphins. He was a backup nose tackle in the Dolphins' basic 3-4 defense and a defensive tackle in the 4-3 defense in passing situations. The Giants also signed four regular free agents, all of whom had been in National Football League training camps last summer. They were Stanley Howard, a wide receiver cut by the Giants; Anthony Simpson, a fullback; Greg Kunkel, an offensive tackle and guard, and Jim Althoff, a defensive tackle.

title: San Francisco Journal; One Man's Daily Fight For a Home for Many
description: In the daily battle to keep the Camelot Hotel safe for its indigent tenants, Craig Lee's weapons include a hickory hammer handle, a table leg and a loud mouth.

title: Trusts Weigh Sale Of Cameron Stake
description: Two trusts that control 47.5 percent of the shares outstanding of Cameron Iron Works Inc. said they might sell their shares of the Houston-based oil services concern. The trusts, created by the company's founder, James S. Abercrombie, control 14.4 million of the 30.3 million Cameron shares.

title: 5 Days in a Self-Contained Imitation World
description: A 29-year-old marine biologist emerged today after spending five days in a glass-enclosed ''biosphere'' that was built as a self-contained ecological system in the foothills of the Catalina Mountains.

title: In Texas, 2 Paths to Bank Profits
description: As large financial organizations continue to crumble in Texas and elsewhere in the Southwest, a pair of old rivals here are making money again.

description: Latest and prior year results are after writeoffs of about $1.7 million and $1.2 million, respectively.

Latest fourth-quarter and year results included a pretax gain of $1.6 million from the settlement of a claim arising out of a 1986 land expropriation. Prior-year results included a charge of $239,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: A Clinician Reflects On 30 Years of Change
description: AS he closes his practice and moves to the White House to be President Bush's physician, Dr. Burton J. Lee 3d has been reflecting on changes in medicine since he began working at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York 30 years ago.

title: Gas Company Offers To Save Open Land
description: The consortium proposing a natural-gas pipeline from Canada through New York and Connecticut to Long Island has offered $10 million to save open space along the 370-mile route, officials said yesterday.

title: DEAN IS SELECTED AT KENNEDY SCHOOL
description: Harvard University today named Robert D. Putnam, a government professor at the school, as dean of its John F. Kennedy School of Government.

title: Scientists Find Point Of Polio Virus Attack
description: SCIENTISTS have cloned and identified the attachment site at which polio viruses begin their invasions of human cells, an achievement that raises the hope of developing the first drugs effective against that dangerous virus.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoskeag Bank Shares Inc., Manchester, N.H., a bank holding company, promoted John L. Allen to president and chief executive, and Paul H. Engels to president and chief executive of its main subsidiary, Amoskeag Bank.

title: Darling Pursuing Dream Season
description: He has a Yale education, a $5.3 million contract and a split-fingered fastball. And after five years in the big leagues, he has the best record on the Mets' pitching staff this side of Dwight Gooden. But Ron Darling admitted today he also has an unfulfilled goal: the dream season that several other members on the pitching staff have achieved.

title: Church in Protest Will Reopen
description: St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church will reopen, church authorities said today. On Feb. 18, the police were called to the church and masses were suspended, to end a protest by some parshioners.

title: Bombing Inquiry Moving From State Terror Theory
description: Federal investigators have begun to move away from their earlier suspicions that the bombing of a car driven by the wife of the captain of the Vincennes was an act of international terrorism.

title: Rangers Defeat Flames And Curtail Losing Streak
description: Tomas Sandstrom does not have the face of innocence, although this does not exactly distinguish him from many of the rest of the players in the National Hockey League. He has his share of scars, his own array of bruises, as well as a crude haircut that suggests self-infliction.

title: German State Vote Seen as Anti-Bonn Protest
description: Politicians and other West Germans analyzing the municipal elections here and across Hesse State say they see evidence of strong dissatisfaction with what is seen as weakness and indecision in Bonn and of a new willingness among voters to experiment with the political fringes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If furs become commonplace, will they still have the same importance to the chic woman?'' - Bill Blass. [ B8:1. ]

title: Right-to-Die Case Sent To the Supreme Court
description: The parents of Nancy Cruzan, a young woman lying in a coma in southwestern Missouri, today asked the Supreme Court of the United States to permit doctors to disconnect artificial-feeding tubes that have kept the young woman alive for six years.

title: United Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains on the sales of marketable securities of $213,000 and $1,286,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a tax credit of $476,000. c-Included a tax credit of $103,000 and $793,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Henkel to Pay Quantum $480 Million for Division
description: The Quantum Chemical Corporation, which has been immersed in a sweeping recapitalization program, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its oleochemical division for $480 million to the United States subsidiary of Henkel K.G.a.A., the West German chemical producer.

title: Review/Opera; 'Orlando,' by Handel
description: Handel's ''Orlando,'' a moral tale from Ariosto with superb music, may become a repertory opera. This reviewer did not see the Peter Sellars production that ran for 40-odd performances in Cambridge, but heard the piece in Carnegie Hall's 1985 Handel Festival, saw it at the Chicago Opera and reviewed most of the title role on a recording by the countertenor Drew Minter. When Christopher Hogwood and his Academy of Ancient Music brought the work to Avery Fisher Hall for a concert performance Sunday evening, it sounded like an old favorite. The score has that quality of seeming richer with familiarity, a good sign.

title: Revolutionary Roots
description: Two hundred years ago, ''liberty trees'' were planted throughout France to mark the French Revolution, which led Samuel R. Gammon, executive director of the American Historical Association, to suggest that the United States could make no better gift to mark the bicentennial of France's revolution than trees. And, what tree would serve that purpose better than the American redwood?

description: A New York City laboratory operator pleaded guilty yesterday to bilking the state Medicaid program of $3.6 million by buying huge quantities of human blood from drug addicts and other desperately ill or poor people and then running unordered and unnecessary tests on it.

title: Saudi Aramco Board
description: King Fahd has appointed a Supreme Board to govern Saudi Aramco, the kingdom's new oil company, under his chairmanship, the Saudi Press Agency reported today. The company was formed in November to run the kingdom's oil industry. Saudi Arabia set up Saudi Aramco as part of a restructuring to increase its oil industry's efficiency and cut costs. The Arabian American Oil Company, Aramco, owned by four leading United States oil companies - Mobil, Exxon, Texaco and Chevron - had been running the kingdom's oil industry before the move.

description: Prices of crude oil soared to a 16-month high yesterday in New York, largely because of unseasonally strong demand for heating oil and the prospect of tight gasoline supplies this summer.

title: Theodore I. Koskoff, 75, Lawyer
description: Theodore I. Koskoff, one of Connecticut's most widely known trial lawyers, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday while being driven to a doctor's office in Milford. He was 75 years old and lived in Westport.

title: G.M. Inventories
description: The General Motors Corporation is satisfied with its high inventories of unsold cars and trucks, the president of the company, Robert Stempel, said. G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, has been struggling to reduce inventories and regain its dominance of the auto market. Its domestic market share has fallen from a peak of 44.5 percent in 1984 to 36.1 percent last year. Its inventories stood at 83 days at the end of February, compared with the industry standard for winter of about 65 days.

title: Healthwatch Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the improved results were the direct result of the company's sale of seven medical centers.

title: Talking Business with Locke of Morton Thiokol; A Look Beyond The Big Spinoff
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the booster rocket whose failure touched off the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger three years ago, announced late last month that it would spin off its commercial operations from its troubled aerospace unit. Charles S. Locke, the company's chairman and chief executive, recently discussed the move and the prospects for the company's non-aerospace business. Q: Why did you want to spin off the commercial operations from the aerospace group? A: The stock of our company hasn't done much in a long time. We were considered undervalued, even though the performance of our commercial business has been outstanding. By separating those businesses, so they can be clearly visible, we should be able to enhance shareholder value. Q. Is the restructuring also an attempt to separate Thiokol's assets from its liabilities? A: The liabilities that grew out of the shuttle disaster were all covered by insurance. Those cases have long since been settled. Only a few nuisance suits are left. Legal liabilities are not a problem. Q. In the broader sense, the damage to the company's image as a result of the shuttle disaster has lingered. Is the restructuring an attempt to separate that problem from your other businesses? A: It seems to me that our public relations problems from the crash are pretty much behind us. I don't read a lot of articles rehashing the shuttle thing. The more important consideration was that Morton has been followed by specialty chemical analysts for many years. Those analysts were never interested in following our aerospace business in the first place, and after our difficulties, their level of dissatisfaction rose considerably. That's one of the things that depressed our stock for quite a while. By separating these two stocks, we will make it possible for those who are interested in a pure specialty chemical play to invest. Q: Had you come under pressure to split the company in two? A: The analysts who follow us made it clear that they have wanted us to do something for a long time. They always visualized that we'd end up selling the aerospace division. Q: Why didn't you? A: Unless we could get a very good price for aerospace, we were better off spinning it off. Q: The aerospace profit fell from $96.3 million in 1986, the year of the shuttle crash, to $80.7 million in the fiscal year ended last June 30. Why did the group decline like that, and how do you plan to revive it? A: One of the things we decided shortly after the shuttle disaster was that we were not going to decide what to do with the aerospace unit until we had redesigned the entire solid rocket motor. We agreed to do all that at no profit even though we had a specific contract with the Government spelling out what we were supposed to do and how much we were supposed to be paid for it. That explains why the profit of the aerospace unit was lower than it was supposed to be and explains why it will rebound to levels above 1986 in the not-too-distant future. The aerospace business that will carry on under the name of the Thiokol Corporation will be a very economically viable business. Q: In retrospect, do you regret having purchased the Thiokol Corporation in 1982? A: We picked up some premier specialty chemical properties when we bought Thiokol. We became the only producer of polysulfide chemicals in the world. These are used for caulking buildings and for insulating glass. We also acquired Dynachem, which is one of the largest electronic chemical manufacturers as well as sodium borohydride and the technology for air bags. The answer is a resounding no. I'd do it exactly the same way again. Q. What are the prospects for your specialty chemical area? A: Very good. That business has grown 12 to 15 percent over a number of years, and we think it will continue to grow at that rate. We expect more strategic acquisitions in that area. Q: What effect would a recession have on that business? A: Historically, the last two recessions have had a minimal impact on our specialty chemical business. It is not correct to say that our specialty chemical business has been recession-proof because our growth has slowed, but it has certainly been recession-resistant. Q: Many of the major commodity chemical makers plan to add new production capacity.

title: Q&A
description: Record Speed Q. If a phonograph record spins at a constant speed, isn't it going faster along the outer edge than toward the innermost section? Does the record-maker compensate for the difference? Which part of the record has the better sound quality? A. There is a considerable difference in speed from the outer to the inner area of a record. The only compensation is made at the time the sound is transferred from a tape to the master disk from which records are pressed, explained John Eargle, an independent recording engineer.

But the number fell short of the 140 daily flights the airline had originally estimated it would be able to get into the air.

title: States Struggle With Budgets After Boom
description: For five heady years through the mid-1980's, a green tide of cash flowed through the budgets of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and dozens of other states, bringing a period of large-scale spending that changed the nature and size of many state governments.

title: Official Quits Shearson To Form His Own Firm
description: Daniel J. Good, an investment banker involved in acquisitions and leveraged buyouts for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., announced yesterday that he was forming his own firm, the Good Capital Company.

title: Miltope Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Keltic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $42,466 and $117,025 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jacobson Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Tale of Two Mayors
description: The judge said he thought narcotics should be legalized, the sooner the better. Nothing else would work.

title: Sexual Organ Surgery
description: In a new surgical procedure, doctors at the University of Chicago Medical Center are using skin from the forearm to fashion a new penis to replace an organ lost to accident or disease. They say the new organs are more sensitive and function better than previous reconstructed penises.

title: Hitox Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Autrex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cheney Hearings Scheduled
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee announced today that confirmation hearings on Representative Dick Cheney's nomination as Defense Secretary will begin Tuesday afternoon. ''The more rapidly we get through this the better,'' said Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat who sits on the committee. ''I would hope we could be done by the end of this week.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PREPARATORY COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE SPECIAL SESSION DEVOTED TO INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC COOPERATION -3 P.M. Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Astrocom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $91,000 and $140,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $64,000 for the quarter and $44,000 for the year.

title: Political Pitchman
description: In looking for a communicator, Chiat/Day turned to a master of the form at its annual creative conference in Los Angeles on Friday. Former President Ronald Reagan spoke to 250 of the agency's creative and production employees on topics ranging from foreign policy to the ad business. Asked if a career in advertising prepared one for a career in politics, Mr. Reagan said, ''Why not?'' with a wink toward Jay Chiat, the agency's chairman.

title: By Design; Fake Antiquities
description: The idea is that they should look as if they came from the rubble of an archeological dig. The rings, bracelets, brooches, earrings and necklaces that are fashionably right with today's classic clothes resemble ancient relics.

title: At Mideast Conference, A Touch of Symbolism
description: As a two-day conference on peace in the Middle East was ending, an Israeli stood on stage in a New York auditorium yesterday and shook hands with a ranking member of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Ouster of Botha Urged by Party In South Africa
description: The legislators of the ruling National Party tonight threw their support behind the new party leader, F. W. de Klerk, and unanimously called for him to replace P. W. Botha as President of South Africa.

title: N.F.L. Back To Baltimore?
description: Bob Tisch, a former Postmaster General, yesterday declared himself in the running for a National Football League franchise in Baltimore, where he expects a team to return within three years.

title: Renaissance Energy Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: In the latest fourth quarter, there were no earnings applicable to common shares after preferred dividends. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Permanent Home for No. 1
description: Frank Gagnon was more spy than scout, his chores more those of surveillance than evaluation. Officially retired, Gagnon, living in Providence, R.I., kept unofficial tabs on Eddie Giacomin, less concerned with how the goaltender played than with whether other National Hockey League teams had sent someone to see him.

title: Dallas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,308,000 and $8,063,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,187,000 for the quarter and $2,261,000 for the year, and an extraordinary loss of $6,897,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said operating results for each period have been restated to reflect the company's decision during the fourth quarter of 1988 to dispose of five operating units. Losses from discontinued operations for the fourth quarter and for the year included an after tax provision of $5,042,000 for estimated costs associated with the divestiture of these lines of business.

title: Analogic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $4,600,000 from the sale of the companay's interest in a joint venture. c-Net loss

title: Iverson Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Long Wait to Leave Russia Is Over for American
description: Abe Stolar, an American brought to the Soviet Union as a youth and thwarted for over a decade in his efforts to leave, finally returned to the West today.

title: Service's Chief Tilts Against an 'Oblique' Attack on His Policies
description: Alan C. Nelson has survived more than seven years in what he calls the no-win job of immigration commissioner, a post that has made him a target of immigrant groups and some politicians.

title: National Park Wildlife Deserve a Buffer Zone; Why We Need Wolves
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Vaccine, Perilous Measles Won't Go Away
description: WHEN officials in Hartford barred spectators from the North Atlantic Conference basketball tournament last week because they feared an outbreak of measles, it was a stark reminder that the disease, which seemed on the verge of disappearing only a decade ago, remains a public health threat.

title: Charles R. Bennett 2d, Executive, 79
description: Charles Randolph Bennett 2d, a former executive and editor of banking magazines, died of cancer Friday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Helix Circuits reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1988 loss included a pretax loss from discontinued operations of $2,314,000 and provisions for extraordinary items of $11,870,000. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Electra B. McDowell, School Volunteer, 55
description: Electra B. McDowell, former board chairman of the New York City School Volunteers Program, died Friday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Angola Rebel Leader Denies Torture Charge
description: Disputing reports that he ordered the killing and torture of former supporters, Jonas Savimbi, the leader of the American-backed Angolan guerrillas, appeared today at a news conference with a guerrilla official said to have been held against his will.

title: Central Guaranty Trustco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $640,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $3,835,000 for the year. c-Included a special gain of $22,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said all share earnings are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Penn Coach Resigns
description: Ed Zubrow resigned yesterday as head football coach at the University of Pennsylvania to take a job fighting drug abuse and dropout rates in the Philadelphia School District.

title: Sudan Leader Of Many Hats And 2 Worlds
description: During one of the more fragile of many fragile moments in Sudanese politics in the last month, Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi sat in his living room in the old city of Omdurman the other night, entertaining three senior officials of the United Nations over tea and cake.

title: Maurice Evans, Stage Actor, Dies at 87
description: Maurice Evans, one of the best-known Shakespearean actors of the 1930's and 40's, died Sunday in a nursing home in Rottingdean, near Brighton, England. He was 87 years old.

title: Pic 'n' Save Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that net income in 1988 was favorbly impacted by a lower effective tax rate of 39.7 percent compared with 45.4 percent in the prior year.

title: Sporting Life Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $34,067 from a reversal of a tax credit for the quarter; the 6 months included a tax credit of $22,769. c-Net loss

title: Trustcorp Losses
description: Trustcorp Inc., citing losses on downtown Toledo projects and other real estate ventures, announced that it would write off $35.9 million, the second such move in three months for the bank holding company. In January, the corporation said it would write off $40.7 million. Trustcorp also rescheduled its annual shareholders' meeting for June 28. The meeting had been postponed because of a management shake-up.

title: Baltek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $428,000 on involuntary conversion of assets for both the quarter and year.

title: Oppenheimer Multi-Sector Inome Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included net realized and unrealized gains of investments of $118,050. Year-ago data is unavailable because the fund came to market on March 31, 1988. Revenue represents net assets and net income represents net investment income. The total net assets equalled $11.14 a share.

title: Davis Water & Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
New York Perspectives
description: The School of Visual Arts in Manhattan will showcase the work of its illustration students at New York Landscapes, an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Art Directors Club. The illustrators have envisioned New York from non-human perspectives, showing the city from a roach's- and poodle's-eye view, among other vantage points. The club is at 250 Park Avenue South. Admission to the show, which runs through March 29, is free.

title: Slater Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Genetic Analysis Upsets Theory on Turtle Trek
description: A WIDELY accepted theory explaining why green turtles migrate 1,250 miles to an island in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean to lay their eggs and then swim back to Brazil is invalid, researchers have concluded from genetic analyses.

title: Publishers Equipment Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $115,000 and $338,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Reviews/Television; Pop Culture as Insults and Threatened Violence
description: Life as a cartoon. Television entertainment this weekend continued to pounce sanctimoniously on anything that would sell; exaggeration has become the increasingly prevalent weapon of choice. From Morton Downey Jr. to beefy wrestlers to Peg and Al on ''Married . . . With Children,'' vicious insults and threatened violence were the hot commodities of the moment. The human comedy threatened to be reduced to a sustained shout.

title: Home Loan Banks In 6-Part Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks plans to announce today the interest rates for a six-part fixed-rate financing totaling $6.94 billion.

title: Market Place; American Express Holds Up Well
description: PERHAPS ''Jimmy Three Sticks,'' as the American Express chairman, James Robinson 3d, is known, is starting to get some respect from investors, if not from Wall Street analysts. That, in any case, is one possible explanation of the fact that American Express shares held steady yesterday after the departure of the company's president, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., was announced.

title: Bertram Greenglass, 56, Ex-NASA Official
description: Bertram Greenglass, a former official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and a business executive, died of leukemia Friday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 56 years old and lived in Lake Ridge, Va.

title: Federal Pioneer Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Edward A. Weeks, 91, an Editor Of The Atlantic Monthly, Is Dead
description: Edward A. Weeks, an author, essayist and editor of The Atlantic Monthly for 28 years, died Saturday at his home in Thompson, Conn. He was 91 years old.

title: People
description: * Walter Atkinson has been named senior vice president of Tracy-Locke, Los Angeles.

title: Two Legislators Urge Retaining Courtroom TV
description: The heads of two legislative committees said today that they still wanted television cameras in state courtrooms. But the chairmen said they were disturbed by public defenders' testimony at a hearing that some judges had ignored rules allowing the cameras.

title: Teamsters and the U.S.: Love-Hate Relationship
description: Three days before his inauguration, President Bush met with a half dozen leaders of the teamsters union to thank them for their endorsement. More than 400 candidates for the House and Senate, most of them Democrats and most incumbents, were grateful for contributions from the union's political action fund in the 1988 campaign. And in 1988, the Rev. Jesse Jackson stumped the country decrying the Government's effort to take over the teamsters.

title: HeadStart III Software
description: WHEN you unpack Vendex's new HeadStart III, an AT-class computer reported on here last week, there is a bit of a shock: the package of manuals for the computer and the software that comes with it take up 17 inches of shelf space.

title: Austrian Move on 1992
description: Austria is planning to make its long-expected application for European Community membership this summer, an Austrian minister said today. But the Minister of the Federal Chancellery, Dr. Heinrich Neisser, told a management symposium in Bergen that formal talks about Austrian membership would not begin until after the European Community's internal market barriers were eliminated by the end of 1992.

title: U.S. Urges Consumers Not to Eat Fruit From Chile
description: The Food and Drug Administration urged consumers today not to eat seedless grapes and other fruit from Chile after traces of cyanide were found in two grapes at the Port of Philadelphia. The agency's action could remove a large portion of the fruit from supermarket shelves throughout the country.

title: Rangaire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Mabaie Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dipped in quiet trading yesterday, pushed lower by a big jump in oil prices, which rose to their highest level in the last 16 months.

title: Vitronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $30,000. The company said 1988 fourth quarter and year earnings were reduced by about six cents a share because of the writeoff of $105,000 of solvent cleaners and related parts and a writeoff of $185,000 related to termination of an acquisition.

title: LDB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $924,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss d-After income from discontinued operations of $14,353,000. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 6 months.

title: Fahnestock Viner Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Conpak Seafoods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said share earnings in both periods are less than one cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Levi Strauss Associates reports earnings for Year to Nov 27
Lithuania Nationalists: A Fine and Fragile Line
description: Ignoring damp snowflakes, Lithuanians by the thousands filed into the sylvan amphitheater of a Vilnius park the other day for an election rally.

title: Last Empress of Austria-Hungary, Zita, Is Dead in Switzerland at 96
description: Zita, the last Empress of Austria-Hungary, died yesterday at her longtime residence, a Roman Catholic home for the elderly in Zizers, a village in eastern Switzerland. She was 96 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday, about a conference in New York on peace in the Middle East, mentioned one moderator erroneously. The moderator, Nubar Hovsepian, had been on the scene but was not visible in the picture.

title: New Bonds Back Chicago Ball Park
description: The Illinois Sports Facility Authority is offering $150 million of sport facility bonds with a maximum yield of about 7 7/8 percent for an issue due in 2010 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearnsi & Company.

title: 'Roseanne' Tops 'Cosby' In the Nielsen Ratings
description: ''Roseanne,'' the hit comedy series on ABC, knocked the ''Cosby Show'' from its longstanding position at the top of the Nielsen ratings last week.

title: From 2d Graders to Choice for 2d Job
description: Moving to fill senior positions in a department that will be critical to his pledge to be the education President, President Bush has nominated John Theodore Sanders to be Under Secretary of Education. Mr. Sanders is to replace Linus D. Wright, who has accepted a position with a personnel recruitment company in Texas.

title: Wisconsin Considers 2-Tier Welfare
description: Declaring that Wisconsin has become ''a welfare magnet,'' Gov. Tommy Thompson has proposed a two-tiered public aid system that would reduce benefits for newcomers by 25 percent.

title: Do It Yourselves in the Mideast
description: Secretary of State Baker wants Israel and the Palestinians to take responsibility for generating their own momentum and plans for peace - or face the consequences. The Baker approach might represent mere temporizing by a timid, disorganized Administration. Or it might reflect shrewd judgment about the fate of past U.S. plans like those offered by William Rogers or George Shultz. These drew momentary praise but then drove the parties toward extreme positions. They were soon discarded by their authors, leaving the Middle East's diplomatic moonscape unchanged.

title: Taunting Led to Killing of Executive, Trial Is Told
description: A prosecution witness testified today that he had heard a group of teen-agers on a Hoboken street taunt his friend, Navroze Mody, about his baldness but that he was knocked to the ground within 90 seconds and did not see anyone actually hit Mr. Mody.

title: AIDS Viruses Found Resistant to AZT
description: Three teams of researchers have detected strains of the AIDS virus that have become resistant to AZT, the only drug licensed by the Government to treat the disease, researchers said yesterday.

title: U.S. Rethinks Razing Of Chancery in Moscow
description: The Bush Administration is reconsidering the Reagan Administration's decision to tear down the new American Embassy chancery in Moscow, State Department officials said today. The chancery has been found to be riddled with sophisticated eavesdropping systems and has never been used.

title: A SPOT OF TROUBLE IN THATCHER RULE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has not exactly had to fight for her political life these last few years, made clear today that she viewed renewed inflation caused by her own Government's past miscalculations as the main threat to its future.

title: Limousine Owners Protesting Fees
description: A New York City plan to begin charging a $250 annual licensing fee on out-of-town limousines has touched off an uproar among limousine owners, who plan a court fight against the fee and related regulations.

title: House Panel Backs Time Merger
description: Indicating they were worried more about the nation's ability to compete in world markets than about possible anti-competitive effects at home, members of a House antitrust panel expressed considerable support today for the proposed $18 billion merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.

title: Belgium Reduces Rates
description: The central bank today lowered Belgium's primary lending rate, the interest rate on three-month treasury bills, to 8.4 percent from 8.3 percent. The rate on one- and two-month bills was cut by five-hundredths of a point each, to 8 and 8.2 percent, respectively.

title: A New Temperance Is Taking Root in America
description: In the early 1980's, when Americans started switching from Scotch to seltzer, it seemed to be just another ebbing in the cycle of rising and falling consumption of alcohol. But what seemed to be a passing fancy now appears to have taken root as a fundamental change in American culture.

title: Lyme Disease Has Many Hosts and Habitats
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Puerto Rico Urban Renewal and Housing Corporation is tentatively offering $233 million of commonwealth appreciation refunding bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: C.D. and Money Market Yields Go Higher
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to show strong gains for the week ended yesterday.

title: Europe Unemployment
description: Unemployment in the European Community dipped in January but inflation rose sharply, the latest official figures showed today. The European Community's statistics office, Eurostat, said that seasonally adjusted unemployment fell to 9.9 percent in January from 10 percent in December. The community's jobless rate has been dropping since a peak of 11 percent in the fall of 1984. Steep price rises in most members of the 12-nation community pushed the consumer price index up seven-tenths of a percent in January. Only the Netherlands and Greece bucked the trend, Eurostat said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Final Issue Due Of Sports inc.
description: Sports inc., a trade magazine focusing on business issues in the sports industry, will cease publication, the Times Mirror Company said yesterday. The magazine, introduced in

title: U.S. Sending Mixed Signals On Trade-Ins of Dirty Needles
description: Two weeks before Health Secretary Dr. Louis W. Sullivan endorsed local programs that let drug addicts trade their dirty needles for clean ones, a memorandum by a subordinate warned Federal grant recipients that they could lose the aid if they ran such efforts.

title: Doctor Tells How Officer Was Slain
description: In testimony that caused a juror and relatives and friends of the victim to cry, a medical examiner yesterday described in detail the devastation caused by five bullets fired into a rookie police officer's head at close range on a Queens street.

title: The Worm and the Apple: On the Right Track; Ratcatchers
description: In New York City, where replacing a subway light bulb often seems to require an enormous outlay of public funds, it is good to learn of a project that will cost at most $175 and maybe rid the parks of rats. It involves owls.

title: Chilean Fruit Pulled From Shelves As U.S. Widens Inquiry on Poison
description: Food stores around the country pulled tons of grapes and other fresh fruit from their shelves today as the Food and Drug Administration broadened its investigation of a possible attempt to poison Chilean produce with cyanide.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption in Science Times yesterday about X-ray crystallography, used for growing protein crystals in space, referred incorrectly to the diffraction patterns measured by the technique. It measures the scattering of X-rays, not light.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Strife in the West Bank has brought economic stagnation. In the once-thriving town of Beit Sahur, attitudes toward Israel and the Jews are hardening. Page A1

title: Crime Figure Testifies to Link With Sports Agent
description: In a case involving Federal racketeering charges against sports agents, a jury heard testimony today from a man who described himself as a member of the Colombo crime family and said he was a silent partner in the sports-agency business of Norby Walters.

title: Knicks Scramble To Victory
description: The Knicks' home-court winning streak survived the scoring of Xavier McDaniel, the 3-point shooting of Dale Ellis and a huge dose of the Seattle SuperSonics' pressure and trapping defenses last night.

title: Review/Art; A Fuller View of a Soviet Artist
description: Hardly since World War II has an exhibition of 20th-century art been as eagerly awaited as the retrospective of Kasimir Malevich that opened on March 5 at the Stedelijk Museum here and can be seen through May 23. For the first time, the Soviet authorities have agreed to lend the bulk of their hitherto virtually invisible holdings of Malevich. Amalgamated as they are for the next 10 weeks with the Stedelijk's own very substantial collection of Malevich, they offer us the first chance that anyone has ever had of seeing Malevich in something like his entirety.

title: Regional Vintners Gather and Smile
description: J. William Moffett was pleased. He sponsors the annual convention of vintners and vineyard managers east of the Rocky Mountains - ''a pulse-taking of the regional wine industry,'' he calls it. A near-record 600 people from 139 wineries in 31 states attended the 13th such gathering here last month, an indication, he says, of a healthy future for the industry.

title: Devils Fade Out; Rangers Cash In
description: An injury-depleted Devils team had little chance tonight against the efficient Calgary Flames at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, The Devils were beaten, 5-1, and lostmore ground in their fading playoff bid.

title: Greek Deputy Premier Resigns Amid Scandal
description: Deputy Prime Minisiter Agamemnon Koutsogeorgas resigned tonight in the face of persisting allegations that he was at the center of a financial scandal shaking the Government.

title: Irish Whisky Is Seeking New Status
description: THE notion that Irish whisky is better poured into Waterford crystal than into coffee is taking hold as the Irish whisky industry tries to gain for its product the prestige now associated with single-malt Scotch.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE three best-known red wine regions of France are Bordeaux, Burgundy and the Rhone Valley. The best red wines of California have been fashioned after the wines of Bordeaux and to a lesser extent Burgundy.

title: Florida Bank Ordered to Sell Part of $28 Million Art Holdings
description: Florida bank regulators have ordered the sale of part of a $28 million art collection assembled by the largest savings and loan institution in the Southeast. The centerpiece of the collection is a Rubens painting that was purchased in a private sale for $13.2 million through Sotheby's, the auction house, but that is said by some experts in New York to be worth only between $2.5 million and $6 million.

title: Whirlpool Warns of Fire Risk In Some Dishwasher Models
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that five of its under-the-counter dishwasher models require modification to prevent possible fires.

title: Unfamiliar Spotlight for Ball State
description: Before this year, perhaps Ball State University's most publicized claim to fame was its being the alma mater of David Letterman, the late-night television host whose 1970 graduation from the school in Muncie, Ind., is now memorialized by a plaque that reads: ''Dedicated to all C students before and after me.''

title: In Jamaica, Manley's Success Will Be U.S. Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Approves Accord Settling Teamsters Suit
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan approved the settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering lawsuit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday, saying the agreement ''affords some hope that the union will become part of the mainstream of honest unionism.''

title: Turning a Microwave Into a TV Transmitter
description: Electronics engineers are forever tinkering.

title: Jackson Plans to Stay
description: Chris Jackson, college basketball's No. 2 scorer this season with a 30.1 average, said yesterday he planned to stay at Louisiana State and play in the 1992 Olympics before turning professional.

title: Testimony Begins in Perjury Trial of a Drexel Employee
description: The criminal trial of an assistant trader of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. opened yesterday with a central Government witness testifying that a former Drexel trader and several executives from a New Jersey investment partnership had engaged in a scheme to violate securities laws.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Inevitable Touches
description: Barbara Bush has said that, unlike some previous First Ladies, she is not interested in redecorating. But there is always a bit of rearranging here and there in the White House.

title: Things Can't Be Better for Gooden
description: ''I always had a bad spring,'' said Dwight Gooden, who fortunately for the Mets has never had a bad summer.

title: Finding Fruits' Origins
description: There is no way for shoppers to know whether unlabeled fruit is domestic or imported, and if it is imported there is no way to tell whether it comes from Chile, Mexico or New Zealand.

title: Rates Advance At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates, which fell last week for the first time this year, rose yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Grinker's Hard Ride Atop the Social Services 'Beast'
description: When William J. Grinker took over as head of the New York City Human Resources Administration in December 1986, he talked of renting gymnasiums for group discussions with many of the agency's 26,000 employees. He would carry his message, if not directly to the 1.1 million poor people his agency serves, then at least to those who work in the welfare centers and homeless shelters and child protection offices.

title: RETURN OF BOTHA PRESAGES BATTLE
description: President P. W. Botha returned to his office here today, preparing to confront a united opposition of National Party legislators who want him to yield his post to the new party leader, F. W. de Klerk.

title: Agreement Said to Be Near On Digital Tape Recorders
description: A dispute between record companies and electronics manufacturers over digital audio tape recorders may be nearing resolution, according to news reports from Japan and industry officials in the United States.

title: Europe Sets Standards for TV Programs
description: The European Community today moved closer to a common policy on television broadcasting as it agreed to limit programs from the United States and to restrict commercials.

title: Helicopter Repaired Before Crash
description: A main nut on the rotor shaft of a military helicopter was replaced just two days before it crashed, killing 15 servicemen, military officials said today.

title: Guidry Has Ailing Elbow
description: Ron Guidry's attempt to play another year with the Yankees has suffered a setback. The 38-year-old left-hander did not work out today because of a swollen elbow, and it is not known when he will be able to throw again.

title: ETHNIC RUSSIANS MARCH IN ESTONIA
description: Thousands of Russians and other non-Estonians marched in Tallinn today, threatening a general strike if the Communist Party does not stem Estonian nationalism and ''creeping counterrevolution,'' journalists there said.

title: The Pop Life
description: Bonnie Raitt, Frankly

title: Stephen D. Bechtel Is Dead at 88; Led Major Construction Concern
description: Stephen Davison Bechtel, who built a family business into one of the world's largest construction companies, died today after a brief illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Heavy Drain of Deposits Afflicts Savings Industry
description: Depositors at savings institutions, seeking higher-yielding investments and nervous about the Bush bailout plan, withdrew a record $10.7 billion in January plus $8 billion to $9 billion in February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ephron & Ephron, A New Consulting Firm
description: Erwin Ephron thinks many media planners are missing the forest for the trees in today's increasingly fragmented media market. So earlier this month, Mr. Ephron, the former president of Ephron, McCabe & Tsao Advertising, opened a consulting firm to help advertisers with their media buying.

title: Millen Not Yet a Ranger
description: Corey Millen, a member of the 1988 United States Olympic team, will not play for the Rangers this season even if an agreement is reached to buy out the final year of his contract with Ambri of the Swiss League, according to an organization official.

title: U.S. Convicts Arab in Jet's Hijacking
description: In the first trial under ''long arm'' statutes that apply American law to terrorist acts against Americans occurring anywhere in the world, a Federal jury convicted a Lebanese militiamen today in the hijacking of a Jordanian jetliner in 1985.

title: Reason vs. the Rambo Guns
description: Only a few weeks ago, politicians discounted the rising calls for controls on military-style assault rifles - the so-called Rambo guns. The gun lobby seemed just too powerful. But now, suddenly, moves against the guns in California and Washington D.C. add up to a reassuring victory for reason.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said the wide-ranging program of rebates and low-rate financing it announced Thursday would not hurt first-quarter profits.

title: U.S. Sues Singer on Contracts
description: The Justice Department today accused the Singer Company of overcharging the Pentagon by $77 million from 1980 to 1988 by falsifying cost estimates on contracts for flight simulators.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Soviet Skaters Take Early Lead: Soviet skaters took early leads in the men's and pairs events yesterday at the world championships in Paris. Aleksandr Fadeyev led an East European sweep of the first three placings in the men's compulsories ahead of a countryman, Viktor Petrenko, and Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland. But right on their heels were Chris Bowman of the United States and Kurt Browning of Canada. In the pairs, Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, the Olympic champions, performed flawlessly to outskate their rivals in the original program. Their variety and co-ordination were unmatched by any of their rivals and made them solid favorites for their third world title in four years. In second place was Cindy Landry and Lyndon Johnston of Canada, whose clean, concise routine edged out Peggy Schwarz and Alexander Koenig of East Germany in the 11-couple event.(AP) SLED-DOG RACING Butcher Regains Lead: Three-time winner Susan Butcher of Manley, Alaska, led a pack of three mushers yesterday as they began the final 171-mile dash across the frozen Bering Sea to Nome in the 1,168-mile Iditarod race. Butcher had a nine-minute lead over Joe Runyan of Nenana when she left Koyuk early in the morning. Third was Rick Swenson, a four-time Iditarod winner from Two Rivers. The winner is expected to reach Nome this morning. The first musher to cross the finish line wins $50,000. The remaining $200,000 is divided among the next 19 finishers. Forty-one mushers remained in the race; eight have scratched since the race began March 4 in Anchorage. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 6, Jets 3: Michal Pivonka and Mike Ridley each had a goal and two assists last night in Washington's four-goal first period, helping the Capitals gain sole possession of first place in the Patrick Division and clinch a playoff spot. Washington's Geoff Courtnall scored two goals to give him a career-high 37, the second on a power play to make it 5-3 with 4:58 left. The Capitals, who were playing at home, moved ahead of the idle Rangers by 2 points. Each has nine regular-season games remaining.(AP) Bruins 8, Penguins 2: Ken Linseman scored three goals, Cam Neely added two and Reggie Lemelin, the Boston goaltender, extended his personal unbeaten streak to 11 games last night to lead the visiting Bruins. Linseman has scored two of his three career hat tricks against Pittsburgh. Lemelin, 9-0-2 in his last 11 decisions, has not lost since Jan. 19. Mario Lemieux scored twice on power plays for Pittsburgh to raise his league-leading total to 72. He broke the team record of 70 goals he set last season.(AP) N.B.A. Suns 114, Hawks 112: Tom Chambers scored 38 points, including a free throw with 1:27 left last night that put the visiting Suns ahead to stay. Dominique Wilkins, who scored 30 points, hit the rim with a 25-foot jumper at the buzzer for the Hawks, who have lost four of five. Chambers scored 15 of his 20 first-half points in the opening quarter and the Suns led, 31-26, after one period. Wilkins scored 14 points in the second quarter and the Hawks led, 65-63, at halftime. Moses Malone scored 29 points for the Hawks. Kenny Johnson scored 15 points for the Suns.(AP) Pistons 129, Pacers 117: Isiah Thomas scored 15 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter last night and the visiting Pistons won their eighth straight game. James Edwards, a reserve center for Detroit, and Stuart Gray, a reserve center for Indiana, were ejected with four seconds left in the first quarter after starting a bench-clearing brawl. Indiana lost its third straight despite a 40-point game by Chuck Person. Joe Dumars scored 30 points for Detroit, including 14 of 16 free throws. Vinnie Johnson scored 24 points for the Pistons, who have won 12 of 13.(AP)

title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol
description: Mike Norris pitched 15 minutes of batting practice today, but he did not face Reggie Jackson and Bert Campaneris, both former teammates, or Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire, who play for the Oakland Athletics today.

title: Mound City Journal; Money Is Flying Away As the Geese Fly Over
description: The distinctive cry of snow geese is usually music to the ears, and money in the cash register, for this northern Missouri town that is the ''home of the honkers,'' as a highway sign proclaims.

title: De Gustibus; An American Rice Stands In for Risotto
description: PIERRE FRANEY'S column last week about making risotto with converted rice brought to mind a recent conversation I had with Marion Cunningham, the author of the 1979 version of the ''Fannie Farmer Cookbook.''

title: Index Products Backed By S.E.C. for Exchanges
description: Setting the stage for a confrontation between the securities and futures industries, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved three financial products that will allow several exchanges to engage in so-called basket trading.

title: Price Changing Jobs
description: Two years ago, Mike Price, the football coach at Weber State, was beaten out by Dennis Erickson for the Washington State job. Yesterday, Price was named to succeed Erickson. Price, 42, had a 46-44 record in 8 seasons at Weber State, including a 5-6 record last season. He was a leading candidate for the Washington State job when Erickson was picked in 1987 from Wyoming.

title: Islanders Are Pounded
description: Hartford's John Anderson scored twice in the opening five minutes and Paul MacDermid and Sylvain Turgeon added two goals apiece as the Whalers defeated the Islanders by 8-2 tonight.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON FOURTH DEVELOPMENT DECADE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: States Working to Avert Evictions Of Thousands from Subsidized Units
description: From Maine to California, governments and housing groups are scrambling to help hundreds of thousands of lower-income tenants whose apartments are threatened by unforeseen consequences of Federal programs begun in the 1960's.

title: KABUL ACCUSES U.S. OF A MILITARY ROLE
description: The Afghan Government stepped up assertions today that the guerrilla attack on the border city of Jalalabad had been directed by American and Pakistani military advisers.

title: Spurring Students to Go Beyond 2-Year Degrees
description: A consortium of community colleges, liberal arts colleges, foundations, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Association of American Colleges are beginning a program to encourage students in two-year schools to continue their education beyond an associate's degree.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: About Education
description: Last month, the nation's governors cited Americans' ignorance of foreign languages and cultures as a threat to this country's future.

title: Medici Portrait Removed From Frick
description: A 16th-century Florentine portrait of Cosimo de'Medici, described by scholars as the finest Italian Renaissance painting to be offered at auction in more than a decade, was removed from the Frick Collection 10 days ago to be sold at Christie's on May 31.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Pastrami-Style Salmon

title: PILOTS ASK COURT TO NAME TRUSTEE TO RUN EASTERN
description: The pilots' union at Eastern Airlines asked a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday to appoint a trustee to run the crippled airline, a request that opens a second front in the struggle between the airline and its striking unions.

title: Scarlet Knights Regain Poise
description: Despite all that he has been through in the last two weeks, Bob Wenzel has maintained his diplomatic touch. Last April, when Wenzel became the basketball coach at Rutgers University and announced his intention to bring the program back into the national spotlight, he was labeled a dreamer. Now he is being called a miracle worker.

title: Washington Talk: The Soviet Embassy; The Thaw of Glasnost Warms Social Circuit
description: Tom Clancy, the author of a number of novels that pit the good guys - Americans - against the dark forces of the Soviet Union, was encircled by a group of admirers one recent evening, not at a Washington book party but in the Baroque drawing room of the Soviet Embassy. It was Mr. Clancy's first visit to the imposing mansion on 16th Street where, he later said with a smile, ''One Soviet officer wanted to pick my brains.''

title: McFadden Is 1 of 3 Giants Lost to New Free Agency
description: The Giants lost three more players yesterday to the National Football League's new system of free agency.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Sues Singer Company In Pentagon Fraud Case

title: KEY RATES
Bridge
description: Two reigning world champions captured the Open Pair title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Monday night. Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., and Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., whose many successes include a victory in the 1986 world team championships, won here by the slender margin of three match points. They are both options traders, a profession that is popular among bridge experts.

title: New Exam For Doctor Of Future
description: In a sweeping change designed to lure students with broader educational backgrounds, American medical schools announced Monday that they were dramatically streamlining the Medical College Admissions Test in 1991.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WINTER-SPRING Winter, truculent and tired gives off an empty growl of bluster and cold as Spring, demure and quiet shows a shy budding smile of gentle, pale green soon to break into a full bloomed last laugh April with a broad Crayola grin winking, smirking at a waning, muted played-out Winter March. ROGER GRANET

title: 2 New York City Transit Officers Are Guilty in False-Arrest Scheme
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted two New York City transit police officers yesterday of making false sex-abuse arrests in what prosecutors said was a scheme to improve their arrest records to win better assignments.

title: U.S. BANS IMPORTS OF ASSAULT RIFLES IN SHIFT BY BUSH
description: The Bush Administration today banned imports of semiautomatic assault rifles indefinitely, pending a review of whether the military-style weapons are being used for sporting purposes.

title: Gordon Is Named
description: Randy Gordon, former editor of Ring magazine, was confirmed yesterday as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. Gordon, along with two commissioners, will oversee all professional boxing and wrestling in New York state. He has been acting chairman since July while his nomination to the $69,982-a-year state job languished in the Senate.(AP)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alamito Co., Tucson, Ariz., an electric power producer, said John Van Egmond had been named president and James Clancy had been named vice president and treasurer.

title: Books of The Times; Restoring the French Revolution
description: Citizens A Chronicle of the French Revolution By Simon Schama Illustrated. 948 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95

title: A Legacy of the Uprising: Bitter West Bank Town
description: At 7 P.M. this town near Bethlehem is dark, its streets empty under a a chilly drizzle. In a tiny alley called Qanaa, a heavily armed Israeli soldier is barely visible against a wall. Across the street, two companions stand guard nervously while more soldiers search a house. Neighbors peek from their windows, then quickly retreat.

title: Review/Music; Alfred Brendel Through the Looking Glass
description: A musical performance is a fun-house mirror into which the player peers, perhaps thinking to see the image of the composer. Actually, the reflection always resembles more nearly the performer himself, a specific human being of a certain temperament and a certain talent, locked into a certain time and place. We call the result interpretation. Rightly, high value is placed on those artists who recognize the person in the distorting glass and, not dismayed, give us a strong dose of themselves.

title: Economic Scene; Minimum Wage: A Reality Test
description: IS there more symbol than substance to the continuing controversy over the minimum wage?

title: Johnson Aware of Drug Use, Inquiry Told
description: In a long and sometimes emotional afternoon of testimony, Angella Issajenko told a Canadian Government commission today that her teammate, Ben Johnson, knew exactly what he was doing over the seven years he took anabolic steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Free Protection Orders For Battered Spouses
description: To the Editor:

title: Is That Food Really Safe?
description: FOR years people have been told to eat a variety of foods - something from each of the four food groups every day - in order to have a well-balanced diet. Now there is more urgency to the suggestion. To spread around the hazards in our food supply, hazards most people have become aware of only recently, it is best not to eat large quantities of any single food and to be more selective in what you eat.

title: In Jamaica, Manley's Success Will Be U.S. Gain; Injustice in Grenada
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Food: A Cuisine That Warms the Cockles of the Heart
description: PEOPLE who move frequently often wax nostalgic over memories of their mother's kitchen. The steamy warmth of a simple boiled potato can have the transporting power of Proust's sophisticated madeleines.

title: President To Mediate Jet Dispute
description: President Bush will preside over a National Security Council meeting on Wednesday to arbitrate conflicts between the Defense and Commerce Departments over helping Japan to build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, Administration officials said today.

title: Now for New Think
description: A senior Soviet defense analyst, Andrei A. Kokoshin, testified before the House Armed Services Committee in Washington last week, itself a sign of how fast the manners if not yet the hard facts of Soviet-American relations are changing.

title: Retail Sales Dropped 0.4% In February
description: Retail sales dropped four-tenths of 1 percent in February, reflecting a sharp drop in automobiles.

title: Swedes Quit Panel Over Rushdie
description: Two members of Sweden's Academy of Letters, which awards the Nobel Prize for Literature, resigned their life memberships today over what they described as the committee's refusal to fully support the author Salman Rushdie.

title: Man Dies and Wife Is Hurt In Fire at Their Queens Home
description: An 80-year-old Queens man was killed and his 79-year-old wife was hospitalized after a fire heavily damaged their two-story home last night.

title: Dow Unchanged; Trade Figures Awaited
description: LEAD: The stock market treaded water yesterday as investors warily awaited a report today on the merchandise trade deficit.

title: Judge Will Hear 2 Guardsmen in AIDS-Bias Case
description: A state administrative judge will hear a case in which two New York National Guardsmen assert they were discriminated against because they tested positive for AIDS antibodies.

title: 4 Banks Called Biased on New Accounts
description: LEAD: Four large banks in New York discriminate against black and Hispanic consumers who want to open checking accounts at branches away from their homes or work places, a study by two legislators said yesterday.

title: Administration Seeks to Explain Debt Plan
description: The Bush Administration today appeared to be stepping up its efforts to refine the reversal in its developing-country debt policy and to answer critics who contend the plan lacks substance.

title: FOES DEAL BHUTTO A BLOW IN PUNJAB
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan lost an effort Monday to break her political opponent's control over the country's most populous province, Punjab.

title: About New York; A Timepiece For the Tasteful: Merely $3 Million
description: ''When you're turned on by something, you feel it inside!'' exuded the diamond-bedecked lady to the right. ''Like a love affair!''

title: Division Head Named By Bertelsmann Music
description: In a corporate realignment more common in the world of popular recordings than on the less volatile classical side, the Bertelsmann Music Group, which owns RCA Red Seal and other labels, has announced that it will replace Michael Emmerson, president of BMG Classics division since 1986, with Gunther Hensler, effective April 1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Wells, Rich, Greene has designed a print and television campaign for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society to promote its first annual Super Cities Walk on April 9.

title: A Game Priam's Brood Might Have Played
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; A New Season for 'Jake'
description: Back for a new season on CBS tonight at 9, ''Jake and the Fat Man'' has moved to Hawaii. Why? Because with the demise of ''Magnum, P.I.'' the network found itself with a lot of idle Honolulu production equipment on its books. Weekly television's artistic decisions are deeply rooted in practical considerations.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE annual shad run, which people in the Northeast associate with spring, actually begins in December as far south as the St. Johns River in northern Florida.

title: Met Conductor Ill
description: The conductor Andrew Litton has canceled his next three appearances at the Metropolitan Opera because of illness. He was to have conducted ''Eugene Onegin'' on Saturday, next Tuesday and March 25. James Levine is to take Mr. Litton's place on those dates. No replacement has been announced for subsequent performances.

title: Review/Blues; A One-Woman Revival
description: Pleas and shouts and swoops, tapping feet and spangles and tuxedos inaugurated Ruth Brown's Rhythm-and-Blues Revue, a Monday-night series that continues through April 10 at the Lone Star Roadhouse, 240 West 52d Street. Ms. Brown is becoming a one-woman rhythm-and-blues revival through her syndicated public-radio show (''Harlem Hit Parade''), roles in musical theater (she is in the Broadway show ''Black and Blue'') and her down-home, regal performances as a club headliner. Now, in her revue, she's sharing the spotlight with other survivors of 1950's and early-1960's rhythm-and-blues.

title: Mets, Yanks Still Under Trade Clouds
description: It must be hard to be a Met fan or a Yankee fan this spring with both teams operating under trade rumors that loom ominously like Herblock's famous cartoon of a swarthy hydrogen bomb endangering the human race.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Mark, Mark & Mark
description: The White House has brought its speech-writing corps up to strength in Marks. Only one Mark, Mark Klugman, was left after Mark McIntyre recently joined the Washington consulting firm of Cassidy & Associates.

title: Book Notes
description: An Aged Dissertation

title: Jakob Gimpel, a Concert Pianist, Dies at 82
description: Jakob Gimpel, a concert pianist known for his interpretations of Chopin, died at his home in Los Angeles on Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: Tigers Stay in a Steady State
description: A walk by the athletic complex on the campus of Princeton University provides a visitor with no sign of unusual activity. There are no groups of students planning pep rallies, no banners proclaiming basketball glory, no sense of excitement or expectation in the air.

title: And All for a Worm
description: I got up at 6 o'clock this morning. It was terrible. From far away in another century I slowly became aware of hearing Morse code. It was four rapid-fire dits. ''Dit dit dit dit.''

title: Philadelphia's Food To Be Celebrated
description: LONG known for its hoagie sandwiches and cheese steaks, Philadelphia is now staking its claim as a center for more exalted cuisine. Beginning tomorrow, the city will sponsor a culinary festival to prove its point.

title: Review/Music; Program of Violin Sonatas
description: Wilfredo Deglans, a violinist who is acting concertmaster of the Rochester Philharmonic, played a substantial sonata program at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday evening and for the most part overcame the challenges of the works he chose.

title: On Menus With High Style, A New Accent on Black
description: BLACK tie has long been the epitome of elegance, but except for caviar and truffles, black food has not had the same cachet. It was often something sent back to the kitchen.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Commercial Cost Dispute Heats Up
