description: ANGER is still coursing through the commercial production industry, a month after a leading advertising agency executive contended that independent production companies were behind the rise in the cost of making television ads.

title: A Course Dominates A Tourney
description: The Players Championship will start Thursday on one of golf's most controversial courses: the Tournament Players Club adjacent to the PGA Tour's national headquarters.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Monday, about the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein agency, misidentified Timothy C. Elliott. He is chief operating officer.

title: Tyler McConnell, 74, A Banker in Delaware
description: J. H. Tyler McConnell, a retired Delaware banker and lawyer who was a member of the board of governors of the United States Postal Service, died of a stroke Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: Lessons
description: In September the University of Illinois football team is scheduled to play a televised game against the University of Southern California at Dynamo Stadium in Moscow. It is being billed, naturally, as the ''Glasnost Bowl'' and seems born of diplomatic genius.

title: Navajos' Trust Funds Frozen by Government
description: The Government has blocked access to money belonging to the Navajo tribe to prod it into resolving a dispute over the status of Peter MacDonald, its beleaguered chairman.

title: SCOWCROFT TELLS OF PRIVATE INCOME
description: National security adviser Brent Scowcroft, who made at least $527,894 last year as a private consultant and speaker, has removed himself from decision-making affecting some 70 companies, including such corporate giants as the General Motors Corporation and the General Electric Company.

title: The Worm and the Apple: On the Right Track; One Swan, No Puddles
description: Two pleasures greeted the hundreds of people running around the Central Park reservoir in Manhattan yesterday morning. One was remarkable: Gliding alone across the still, black waters was a brilliantly white swan. No chill wind, no icy chop. Just a single swan in the dawn sunlight, a graceful portent, perhaps, of spring.

title: Dr. W.K. Riland, 76, Osteopath
description: Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, an osteopath whose patients included Richard M. Nixon and Nelson A. Rockefeller, died of complications from lymphoma Monday at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm afraid to eat anything.

title: Inmate Plans Plea of Insanity In Slaying During Furlough
description: A man charged with the beating death of his former wife while he was on a furlough from prison intends to plead not guilty because of insanity, his lawyer told a judge today.

title: Deal Set by McDonnell And General Dynamics
description: Five weeks after receiving a huge order for its wide-bodied MD-11 commercial aircraft, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay the General Dynamics Corporation about $2 billion over the next six years to produce fuselage sections for the new plane.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about the fur industry appeared in some editions yesterday with an unrelated subheading duplicated from another article. The subheading should have read, ''Once a high-ticket item, furs are now seen as more affordable.''

title: Gorbachev's Plan to Revive Farms Produces Opposition in Kremlin
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempts to rescue the failing Soviet farm system, already facing resistance in the countryside, are now encountering opposition in the Kremlin as well.

title: Oklahoma St. Loses Star
description: The Oklahoma State forward Richard Dumas, the Cowboys' leading scorer going into Friday night's National Invitation Tournament game against Boise State, was suspended from the team today and said he was entering a substance- abuse program. ''I feel I have let my mother, coaches, teammates and fans down because of a substance-abuse problem,'' Dumas said in a statement in which he apologized.

title: Auto Sales Fell 14.8% in Early March
description: Domestic automobile sales declined 14.8 percent in the first 10 days of March, despite higher buyer incentives. Analysts predicted that the decline would lead to further discounting and perhaps a cut in production to clear excess inventories.

title: Schoolboys Get 5-Year Cable Pact
description: SportsChannel America announced yesterday that it had agreed to a five-year contract to televise a weekly national package of high school sporting events starting in September.

title: Critic's Notebook; Religion on TV: Whether More Is Better
description: Should there be more religion on television? Dan Wakefield, journalist, novelist and sometime television writer, thinks so. In last's week TV Guide, he offered several examples of the sort of faith that he wants projected into the American home. One episode got his special blessing. It occurred on ''Thirtysomething'' on ABC, when Michael, shocked by an automobile accident involving his wife and baby daughter, wound up at a synagogue service. It was, wrote Mr. Wakefield, ''an emotionally moving and genuinely spiritual scene.''

title: Connecticut Unit Marketing Bonds
description: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority offered $134 million of revenue bonds yesterday for a housing mortgage finance program. The competitive bidding was won by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought another 515,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Monday.

title:
Market Place;
A.T.&T.;'s Time May Have Come
description: LEAD: THE Federal Communications Commission is expected tomorrow to change how it regulates the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A.T.&T.; strongly supports the new approach, which would basically allow it to set its own rates for long-distance calls, subject to limits set by the F.C.C. Analysts say A.T.&T.;

title: Insider-Trading Conviction
description: A first vice president and stockbroker with Gruntal & Company was convicted yesterday on charges of insider trading and perjury stemming from the takeover in 1986 of Waldbaum Inc. by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: Suffolk Property Owners Demand Tax Reductions
description: More than 700 Suffolk County residents, irate over rising property taxes, packed the legislative chambers here today to demand that county lawmakers roll back the increases or face defeat at the polls in November.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Alcoa Can Collection
description: The Aluminum Company of America said Monday that it had collected a record 16.1 billion used aluminum beverage cans for recycling in 1988, up 35 percent over the 11.9 billion containers collected in 1987.

title: The P.L.O.'s Forked Tongue
description: Should Israel talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization? The question cannot begin to be addressed as long as the P.L.O. continues to speak in two voices.

title: Big Sky Transport Files Bankruptcy
description: The Big Sky Transportation Company, a regional airline that feeds Northwest Airlines Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today, citing unspecified contract problems and a large bank debt. Jase O. Norsworthy, its chairman, said the airline had $2 million in secured debt. Its assets, including 11 aircraft, total about $2 million, he said. The filing was made in Federal District Court in Billings, Mont. Big Sky, founded in 1978, has 200 employees and serves cities in North Dakota, Montana and Washington. The airline will continue operating, Mr. Norsworthy said, but may consider layoffs and route cutbacks to lower costs. Its revenues average $1 million a month.

title: McFarlane Emotional in Jousting With Prosecutor About '87 Letter
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, shouted at a prosecution lawyer today when questioned about a letter he wrote to a Congressman the day before he attempted suicide in 1987.

title: Graduation Rates Sought
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey announced today that he would introduce legislation to require colleges and universities to disclose the graduation rates of student athletes.

title: 'The Genius of the Carpathians'
description: East Europeans have taken to calling Rumania's President, Nicolae Ceausescu, the ''Idi Amin of Communism.'' He has squandered billions on grandiose public works that don't work, and has left many of his people hungry and freezing in half-darkened homes. Yet on his 71st birthday in January he was acclaimed as ''The Great Conductor,'' ''The Genius of the Carpathians'' and ''The Danube of Thought.''

title: Group Bids For Lincoln
description: A group of executives of the American Continental Corporation, including a former Congressman from California, has offered to buy the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, one of the nation's largest savings institutions.

title: Sudan Fundamentalists Disavow New Cabinet
description: Muslim militants campaigning for strict Islamic laws in the Sudan, a principal issue in the country's civil war, today rejected appeals to join a new cabinet committed to peace, and they vowed to fight to extend Islam.

title: George Katz, Lawyer, 57
description: George Katz, a founding partner of Wachtel, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, a law firm in New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: About Real Estate; Chic Retailers Are Flocking to Lower Fifth Ave.
description: Last spring Williwear, a clothing company known for its youthful trend-setting design, broke the tape for a pack of high-profile fashion retailers along lower Fifth Avenue. This neighborhood had been discovered nearly a decade ago by trail-blazing advertising agencies, designers, architects and small publishers in search of cheap rents and large spaces.

title: Cheney Gets Warm Reception in Senate Hearing
description: In an amiable Senate hearing laced with humor and references to family and character, Representative Dick Cheney, President Bush's second nominee as Secretary of Defense, today began what Republicans and Democrats alike promised would be a quick confirmation process.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Big Accounts to Trone
description: Trone Advertising, an agency based in Greensboro, N.C., has received nearly $6 million in billings from two major accounts in the last two weeks. Carlyle & Company, a jewelry store chain, awarded its $3.3 million account to Trone this week, and the Weyerhaeuser Company assigned a $2.5 million account last week. Two weeks ago, Trone moved into new quarters in its own building.

title: Review/Music; A Swiss Quartet Visits
description: The Carmina Quartet, an ensemble based in Zurich, gave an impressive account of itself in a Sunday afternoon concert at the Frick Collection. Its players - Matthias Enderle and Susanne Frank, violinists; Wendy Champney, violist, and Stephan Goerner, cellist - produce a unified, well-blended and interestingly textured sound.

title: Putting Space-Age Materials to Use
description: When the Starship, the Beech Aircraft Corporation's new business airplane, begins flying commercially next summer, the event will represent something of a milestone in materials technology. The Starship is the first passenger plane to eliminate the metal frame and skin in favor of materials in which plastic has been combined with other substances to form composites.

title: Jacobs Cuts Stake In Shaklee to 10.5%
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had lowered his stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 10.5 percent from 14.98 percent. Mr. Jacobs sold 584,400 Shaklee shares on the open market on Monday for an average price of $47.17.

title: Still No Investigation Of State Dept. in Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Move Higher
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher yesterday on evidence suggesting that consumers may be feeling the pinch of higher interest rates.

title: Keady Will Continue To Coach at Purdue
description: When Coach Gene Keady walked into a meeting yesterday with George King, Purdue's athletic director, he was unsure whether he would accept a reported offer of $300,000 a year to become the basketball coach at Arizona State. Then he looked out a window, scanned the campus and made up his mind to stay put. ''When I took this job, I said it was a chance of a lifetime, and I still feel that way,'' said Keady, who has a 193-85 record in 9 years at Purdue.

title: Broad-Gauge Trade Deficit Shrinks 2.1%
description: The deficit in the broadest measure of the nation's trade declined 2.1 percent in the October-to-December quarter, to $31.9 billion, compared with a revised $32.6 billion deficit in the previous quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Emily Cohen has been named senior vice president of DDB Needham, New York.

title: Holly Sets Meeting To Vote on Conagra
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said it would hold a special stockholders meeting on April 14 to vote on the merger agreement made last year by its board with Conagra Inc. Conagra's offer to acquire the company in a stock swap worth more than $1 billion is subject to the approval of two-thirds of the companies' common stockholders. If shareholders of the Memphis poultry producer reject Conagra's bid, Holly's board would be in a position to consider a higher offer from Tyson Foods Inc., a poultry processor based in Springdale, Ark.

title: How to Reduce Some Nutritional Risks
description: FORTUNATELY, there are ways for consumers to heed safety concerns and eat the foods recommended by the National Academy of Sciences' National Research Council. Following are summaries of nutritional recommendations involving foods currently the subject of controversy, along with suggestions for consumers on how to avoid hazards and achieve nutritional balance. Fruits and Vegetables The National Research Council recommends that all Americans eat five half-cup servings of fruits and vegetables every day. The National Resources Defense Council recently announced that schoolchildren are consuming chemicals in the fruits and vegetables at levels that expose them to the risk of cancer.

title: Federal Home Loan Banks In a $6.94 Billion Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday priced six bond issues totaling $6.94 billion at par. They are being offered through various securities dealers.

title: 'Unbundled' Stock Delay
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission requested additional comment today on whether a New York Stock Exchange rule proposal that would allow companies listed on the Big Board to break their stock into securities known as ''unbundled stock units'' unfairly disenfranchises shareholders.

title: American Is President Of Matsushita in U.S.
description: The Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, the parent of Panasonic, Technics and Quasar, yesterday announced the appointment of Richard A. Kraft as president and chief operating officer, the first American to hold the posts.

title: Dr. Walter Mais, 82, Former College Dean
description: Dr. Walter Henry Mais, a retired dean of faculty at Brooklyn College, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: High-Definition TV Venture
description: The Xerox Corporation and the Raychem Corporation said today that they had submitted a proposal to the Defense Department to develop large-area, high-resolution displays for high-definition television and other applications.

title: LEBANON FIGHTING TAKES HEAVY TOLL
description: In some of the most widespread combat in years, 35 people were reported killed and more than 140 wounded today as Christians and Muslims fought artillery battles in Beirut and outlying areas.

title: Edward Abbey, 62, Writer and Defender Of U.S. Wilderness
description: Edward Abbey, a naturalist, novelist and one-time forest ranger, died of a circulatory disorder yesterday at his home in Oracle, Ariz. He was 62 years old.

title: Public Support for Israel Slipping, Foreign Minister Told by Senators
description: Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee told Israel's Foreign Minister today that support for Israel, while solid in Congress, was beginning to show signs of erosion among the American public.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Dropping a Hot Potato
description: After more than 10 months of internal debate, the State Department has quietly dropped a proposal to screen certain Foreign Service officers for psychological problems, State Department officials said yesterday.

title: When a Loving Nest Remains Empty
description: This is not a column I wanted to write. Rather, it is a column I would have wanted to write had things turned out differently. For the past year and a half, as I confided in a recent column, I had been going regularly, month after dutiful month, to one of California's leading-edge fertility clinics to try to become pregnant. I am a walking cliche of my generation, a woman on the cusp of 40 who put work ahead of motherhood and now longs for the latter. Simple, except for me and a lot of women like me: the sisterhood of the infertile.

title: Official Faces Bribe Charge On School Job
description: The head of a local school board in the Bronx was indicted yesterday on charges that he sought a bribe from an acting assistant principal to allow her to hold her job after she failed a qualifying examination.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misstated the acquisition offer for the common shares of Sag Harbor Savings Bank. Apple Bank for Savings proposes to pay $21.50 a share.

title: Schwab in Accord On Buying Rose Special to The New York Times
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage, said it had reached a definitive agreement on it previously announced plan to acquire Rose and Company Investment Brokers Inc. from the Chase Manhattan Corporation for $36.7 million. Completion of the acquisition is expected before April 30.

title: Alaska Air's Strategy: Profits From Service
description: Alaska Airlines has prospered by emphasizing service, with touches like an extra flight attendant on heavily booked flights, more expensive meals and fewer seats in each plane.

title: Space Shuttle Problem Could Cut Flight Short
description: Space agency officials said today that a problem with the space shuttle Discovery's electrical system might force the winged spaceship to land a day early, on Friday.

title: Bush Effort to Aid Contras Is Seen As Inconsistent With Peace Plan
description: Several members of Congress raised questions today about whether the Bush Administration's desire to sustain the Nicaraguan guerrillas for another year was consistent with a regional peace plan that would disarm and disband the rebels.

title: Idea of Sale Of Eastern Is Explored
description: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has asked Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to determine what interest there may be among other airlines and investors in buying Eastern Airlines, industry executives said yesterday.

title: In El Salvador, A New Arena Party
description: As president of the National Republican Alliance in El Salvador - the Arena party - I was the first to suggest a year ago that the Marxist guerrilla movement participate in our presidential elections scheduled for March 19. Its response was to step up terrorism in the countryside and bombings in our cities in order to halt the democratic process. Many innocent Salvadorans suffered. The terrorists' subversion proved futile, so they changed tactics. Scarcely a month before the elections, the Farabundo Marti Nacional Liberation Front, or F.M.L.N., offered to accept the election results if we met a list of vaguely worded conditions, including the postponement of the elections for six months.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Looking for Mikhail
description: John Wheeler is looking for a Russian in Moscow with the given name of Mikhail.

title: House Speaker Concedes Cases of Poor Judgment
description: House Speaker Jim Wright today offered the strongest indication so far that an ethics committee report on his financial dealings would criticize his judgment even if it cleared him of any actual violation of House rules.

title: A County's Last-Ditch Bid to Stay Suburban
description: Like many older suburban areas around New York City, Bergen County is rapidly running out of open land and faces a future that looks increasingly urban.

title: Don't Rush to Bury the Thrift Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Aetna Life to Sell Federated Investors
description: Federated Investors Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Aetna Life and Casualty, will be sold to a new company to be operated and primarily owned by Federated's management. Under the agreement, which will also include related investment management operations, Aetna will receive about $320 million in cash and $25 million in Aetna common stock held by Federated's management.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Aldus Corp., a desktop publishing software designer, to Dahlin Smith White Inc., Salt Lake City, with a budget of $2.2 million.

title: Motorist, Berating 2d Driver, Dies in Crash
description: A man was killed when he lost control of his car as he berated another driver for cutting him off on the Sprain Brook Parkway, the state police said today.

title: Louis J. Puglies, Stockbroker, 79
description: Louis John Puglies, once a senior partner of the now defunct Manhattan brokerage firm of Filor, Bullard & Smythe, died yesterday at his home in Saddle River, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: 10 Boeing Jets Ordered by U.P.S.
description: United Parcel Service Inc. has ordered 10 more Boeing 757-200PF jet freighters at a cost of about $500 million, the aircraft maker said today. In 1985, U.P.S., based in Greenwich, Conn., ordered 20 of the 757-200PF's - for ''package freighters'' - and took options on 15 more. Today's order converts 10 of those options into firm sales. Fifteen planes from the original order have been delivered. The newly ordered planes will be delivered between August 1991 and the end of 1992, the Boeing Company said.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the Eating Well column last Wednesday misidentified the author of ''Cooking From Quilt Country: Hearty Recipes From Amish and Mennonite Kitchens.'' She is Marcia Adams. The column also misidentified the chef at the Duke University Diet and Fitness Center. He is Michael Eddins. In addition, the recipe for onion patties in the column omitted an instruction. The onions should be added along with the parsley, pepper sauce and milk.

title: 18 Policemen Reprimanded In Ulster Over 1982 Killings
description: Eighteen police officers in Northern Ireland who were said to have followed a ''shoot to kill'' policy were reprimanded today in connection with the deaths of six suspected Irish republican guerrillas.

title: States Planting Seeds to Grow Crop of Scientists
description: Realizing that young scientists do not just grow in a vacuum, many state governments have moved energetically to set up selective high schools specializing in science and mathematics.

title: Stern Seeks Expanded Rules to Curb Abuse of Parks in New York
description: With dozens of newly explicit and expanded rules, the New York City Parks and Recreation Department is trying to cope with a park system that is increasingly the resort of homeless people and the range of the lawless and thoughtless.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; White House Dog Day
description: It was 6:40 A.M. in the silent White House press office. Alixe Glen, a White House press officer, was sitting in her office writing a summary of the morning papers for a staff briefing when she heard a noise behind her. Ms. Glen did a double take. There stood President Bush, with the family dog, Millie.

title: Shades of Diamond Jim Brady! Stag Dinner Lives On (and On)
description: THE black-tie dinner for 32 men last week at Chanterelle consisted of eight courses and went on for over six hours. Preparation time, one might say, was 10 years; this was, after all, the 10th Annual Albert Dinner.

title: Bolivia Race: Ex-Dictator Is Out Front
description: At a time of rare political stability but also of economic austerity, Bolivians are preparing to elect a successor to the 81-year-old President, Victor Paz Estenssoro.

title: Shoppers Exasperated by New Peril
description: The regular customers stood in the normal afternoon lines at Ro & Sons Produce in Philadelphia, carrying red shopping baskets that overflowed with fresh produce. But where there might have been grapes and peaches and raspberries the day before, there were now oranges and apples and strawberries. The day before, the customers made their usual requests for the ripest samples, but yesterday the question was, ''Are you sure this is safe?''

title: Tindivanam Journal; Seeking Its Share, Rural Caste Tries Disobedience
description: From their homes of mud and thatch nestled along country roads lined with tamarind trees, landless rural laborers have been coming out by the thousands to block roads, stop trains and join in other acts of mass disobedience. They are demanding that affirmative-action laws deliver on promises to improve the lot of one of Hinduism's poorest rural castes.

title: Mandarich to Drop Out
description: Tony Mandarich, Michigan State's 320-pound tackle, is fed up. Just 17 credits short of a bachelor's degree, Mandarich, a two-time all-American, plans to move to Los Angeles to escape allegations that he has used steroids.

title: Reviews/Music; Two Last Testaments
description: The Lindsay String Quartet's program at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night had largely to do with finalities. Britten finished his Third Quartet only months before he died. Beethoven's Opus 135 in F was his last quartet as well.

title: U.S. Shoe Unit: New Bid Seen
description: The Fisher Camuto Group, a privately held shoe company, said yesterday that it might be willing to offer more for the Footwear division of the United States Shoe Corporation than the $422.5 million bid announced Feb. 26 by an investment group headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. But Fisher Camuto said it first wanted access to confidential sales information.

title: Regulating Pickup Rides
description: A bill that would prohibit children under the age of 12 from riding in the back of a pickup truck passed the State Senate in a voice vote Monday and was sent to the House. The bill would make it a misdemeanor to carry a child in the back of a pickup on a public road at more than 15 miles per hour. Fines range from $25 to $200.

title: Briton Sees Interest Peak
description: Interest rates worldwide may nearly have reached their peak, if they have not already topped out after recent rate increases in several countries, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said today. Mr. Lawson spoke at a news conference one day after his annual budget speech, in which he again promised to keep interest rates as high as necessary for as long as necessary to get on top of inflation.

title: Jane Maas Is Enlisted By Brown
description: THE Earle Palmer Brown Companies, an East Coast advertising power with $300 million in billings, announced this week that it is opening a New York office and appointing Jane Maas as president of the operation.

title: Profits Up 20% At May Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 20 percent, to $276 million, or $1.95 a share, from $230 million, or $1.52 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

title: Fidelity National Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Frederick J. Du Plessis, Business Executive, 57
description: Frederick J. Du Plessis, chairman of one of South Africa's largest insurance companies and an economic adviser to the Government, died in an automobile crash early today, his company said. He was 57 years old. Mr. Du Plessis was to have delivered the main address today at the 70th annual meeting of Sanlam, the company he has headed since 1982.

title: The Hardy Hellebores Offer Sturdy Blooms in Late Winter
description: I BEGAN my life as a reader at roughly the age of 5 and my mother was my teacher, since the public schools where I grew up insisted that children weren't fit to be taught until they were 6 and ripe for learning. It was at about the same age that I got my first lessons in gardening, also from my mother. She gave me some okra seeds to plant. It was a chancy start, considering that I'm a dedicated member of the Okra Haters of America.

title: Buyout Is Backed At Hospital Corp.
description: Shareholders of the Hospital Corporation of America approved a $5 billion buyout of the nation's largest hospital management company by an investor group led by the company's top executives. The concern's chairman, Thomas F. Frist Jr., said after the vote that the company would keep most of its hospitals but sell subsidiary properties to help finance the deal.

title: Ex-Rep. James O'Hara, 63, Dies
description: James G. O'Hara, a Democrat who represented a district from suburban Detroit in the House of Representatives from 1959 through 1976, died of complications of cancer Monday at George Washington University Medical Center. He was 63 years old.

title: VGM Capital Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $220,000. The company said 1987 results were not comparable because they only reflected assets which have been sold plus non-recurring investment gains. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Traffic Charges for Nussbaum
description: Hedda Nussbaum, the former companion of Joel B. Steinberg, has been charged with two traffic infractons, the state police said today. They said Ms. Nussbaum, 46 years old, a patient at Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, was charged with failing to keep right and driving with an expired driver's license Monday night, when she was stopped on Route 35. Mr. Steinberg was convicted of first-degree manslaughter in the death of their illegally adopted daughter, Lisa, 6. Ms. Nussbaum is being treated at Four Winds for physical and emotional abuse.

title: Metro Matters; Volunteer Finds Good Intentions Can't Protect Her
description: On Saturday afternoon, Dec. 7, 1985, Roslyn C. Marinoff went by bus from her West Side apartment to the Bathgate Industrial Park in the South Bronx, blithely walked through the front gate of the Ampco Printing Corporation plant and began taking photographs.

title: Toys 'R' Us Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Isomet Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Coke Says Buffett Has 6.3% Stake
description: Confirming widespread Wall Street speculation, the Coca-Cola Company disclosed yesterday that Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire Omaha investor, now controls close to 22.35 million shares, or 6.3 percent of the company.

title: Vertex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Nathan's Investors Predict National Growth for Chain
description: Nathan's Famous Inc. said yesterday that it planned to accelerate its national expansion after an investor group bought a majority interest in the fast-food chain, which is based in New York.

title: Arizona Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Researchers Detect Subtle Neurological Roots for Stuttering
description: Stuttering and similar speech disorders, which have long been treated solely as emotional problems, can often be traced to subtle neurological irregularities, new research indicates.

title: United Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains on the sales of marketable securities of $213,000 and $1,286,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a tax credit of $476,000. c-Included a tax credit of $103,000 and $793,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Murderer Of a Sheriff Wins Parole
description: Gary McGivern, who had been sentenced to 25 years to life for the 1968 murder of a Westchester County deputy sheriff, was paroled yesterday, more than three years after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo granted him a controversial clemency.

title: Health Official Rebukes Schools Over Apple Bans
description: Educators who remove apples from school lunchrooms out of fear of chemical contamination are running from a ''toxic bogyman,'' the state health director said Tuesday.

title: Poland Shifts On Currency
description: Poland introduced free currency trading today for the first time since World War II as part of an effort to attack the black market and pave the way to convertibility of the Polish zloty.

title: Electromedics reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $377,000. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $8,000.

title: IMPACT OF CURBS ON GUNS DEBATED
description: Opponents and advocates of gun control today argued over legislation to ban the sale of semiautomatic weapons after the Government suspended imports of five models Tuesday. Colt Industries, meanwhile, voluntarily suspended sales of its civilian look-alike copy of the M-16 infantry rifle.

title: Bradley's Visits
description: Senator Bill Bradley explained his decision not to seek the Democratic nomination for President last year by saying that the time was not right, that there were still things he wanted to see and do and learn before he committed himself to such a quest. In particular, he said, he wanted more ''primary experiences'' of America.

title: INSIDE
description: More Pesticide Trouble

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The nation's trade deficit improved in January, to $9.5 billion, as a decline in exports was more than offset by falling imports. The performance was the best since October, but some analysts expressed concern about several factors, including the rise in the cost of oil imports. [ Page A1. ] Business inventories rose 0.7 percent in January, and sales climbed 1 percent. [ D7. ] The F.D.I.C. chairman warned that the Government faces a monumental task in handling the bad real estate of almost 800 sick savings associations. [ D1. ] A Congressional staff member has been removed from his job after authorizing a lawyer to tape-record secretly a conversation in possible violation of state law. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL President Bush decided to restrict the transfer of technology to Japan as part of Tokyo's effort to build a fighter. [ D1. ] As fruit from Chile piled up on docks and in warehouses awaiting Government inspection, American food distributors braced for losses that could reach millions of dollars. [ A1. ] Chile's growers and sellers halted all shipments. [ B10. ] Chile's Foreign Minister arrived in Washington for talks. [ B10. ] Mikhail Gorbachev wants to overhaul Soviet agriculture, dismantling the bureaucracy and introducing free markets. [ A1. ] A revolution is unfolding in European TV. Aided by technology, entrepreneurs are vastly expanding commercial channels. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Can Eastern Airlines be sold? Its financial obligations and losses from the current strike could make the task difficult. [ D1. ] Donald Trump may be having second thoughts about buying Eastern's shuttle. [ D3. ] The House passed a bill that would require President Bush to intervene in the Eastern strike. [ D2. ] Warren E. Buffett owns 6.3 percent of Coca-Cola. The billionaire investor said he would be a long-term, passive investor. [ D1. ] Nathan's Famous plans to accelerate its national expansion, after an investor group bought a majority interest. [ D5. ] Thomson Newspapers plans to merge with International Thomson to create the world's fifth-largest media company. [ D22. ] The former employee who accused Singer of overcharging the Government said he had waited several years before deciding to speak publicly about his concerns. [ D1. ] T. Boone Pickens plans to cut Mesa's dividend by 25 percent, to an annual rate of $1.50 by the fall. [ D4. ] MARKETS The price of oil could break $20 a barrel today, analysts said after the April crude oil contract rose to $19.75 on the New York Merc. Oil has risen 60 percent in the last five months. [ D1. ] Stock prices moved higher after the Government reported that the trade deficit had narrowed. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 14.29 points, at 2,320.54. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury issues were little changed after early buying prompted by the trade report. [ D18. ] Yields for money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday. [ D6. ] The dollar rose sharply, prompting intervention by the Federal Reserve in an attempt to slow the rally. [ D19. ] With technology similar to that used in arcade video games, the Chicago Board of Trade is seeking to challenge the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in computerized trading. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Empire of America, once a buyer of ailing institutions, is asking for $900 million to overcome its problems. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The conflict over the definitions of a security and a futures contract heated up. Market Place. [ D8. ] Jane Maas has been named head of the New York office that is being opened by Earle Palmer Brown. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Basketball Coach Is Leaving Penn
description: Tom Schneider, the University of Pennsylvania basketball coach, said today that he was leaving the Ivy League school to take the head coaching job at Loyola College of Maryland.

title: Pennsylvania Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Piano; Romantic to Modern: Pollini Reforges Links
description: Maurizio Pollini can lay strong claim to being the quintessential modernist pianist, and his Tuesday evening recital at Carnegie Hall -the third of his three appearances there this season - was an extraordinary event. Extraordinary doesn't mean that it answered a listener's every emotional need. But as brilliantly uncompromising programming and playing, it could hardly have been surpassed.

title: The Trade School Scam
description: Ads on buses, subways and matchbooks all over America promise young people training for good jobs in trade schools. Too often, they also promise headaches for Federal and state student loan programs. The need to beef up regulation of these schools is greater than ever.

title: Child Care At Job Site: Easing Fears
description: On workday mornings, the routine is almost always the same for Diane Ronketty. Around 8 A.M., Ms. Ronketty, an executive secretary for the Campbell Soup Company, arrives for work with her 6-year-old daughter, Lisa. After parking the car, she cuts through the parking lot and drops Lisa off at the company's day-care center.

title: Summit Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Average shares were not immediately available. Revenue represents oil and gas revenue. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Wide Brazilian Strike Winds Down in 2d Day
description: A nationwide strike to protest a wage freeze imposed by the Government entered its second and final day today. More businesses opened and buses operated, but a million Rio de Janeiro commuters were stranded, and scattered violence was reported.

title: Savings Group Cancels Parley
description: Seeking to avoid the kind of criticism leveled last year against other banking trade groups, the savings and loan industry's No. 2 trade association voted today to cancel its annual convention, scheduled to be held in Hawaii in May. Officials of the National

title: Ambrit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $299,000. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $572,000 for the quarter and $31,000 for the year. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect oil and gas and real estate operations as discontinued.

title: Genesee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months figures do not reflect operating results of the food division which was established in January 1988.

title: Softech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: The year-ago 9 months' results included a tax credit of $230,000 from an accounting change.

title: Judge Allows Timber Cutting in Owl Habitat
description: Cutting of some of the nation's last stands of ancient forests can continue, despite the threat to the northern spotted owl, a Federal district judge here ruled today.

title: Hechinger Co reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $1.93 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: In Life Expectancy, Racial Differences Widen
description: White Americans, benefiting from dramatic declines in heart disease and strokes, are living longer than ever, but black Americans, increasingly the victims of homicide and AIDS, are seeing their average life expectancy fall further.

title: Robbins & Myers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Soldier Suing to Stay in U.S.
description: A soldier is suing to keep the Army from sending her to South Korea and separating her from her 6-month-old daughter. Specialist 4 Cheryl Beekman, 21 years old, said in the lawsuit filed Tuesday in Federal District Court, ''I did not give birth to her so I could have someone else raise her.''

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
American Biltrite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $600,000.

title: AIDS Incubation Time Often Exceeds 9 Years
description: The time it takes to develop AIDS after being infected with the virus is longer than previously estimated, a new study indicates.

title: Currents; From Regency to 70's, Antiques at 2 New Sites
description: HER new 5,000-square-foot space was once a garage. But the 20-foot ceilings and distressed walls are ''a dream come true'' for Suzanne Lipschutz, better known as Secondhand Rose, the antiques dealer.

title: 3 Men Burn Station In a Failed Robbery
description: Three men poured a flammable liquid around a token booth at an elevated subway station in the Bronx early yesterday and set the station on fire when the transit clerk did not respond quickly to their demand for money, the authorities said.

title: Lull in Beirut Shelling Allows Lebanese Militias to Regroup
description: Rival Muslim and Christian combatants moved reinforcements to the battle lines in Beirut and in the surrounding hills today as a relative calm prevailed after fierce shelling Tuesday that killed more than 40 people and wounded 150.

title: Who Rules the Parks?
description: The parks are not for sleeping. Or begging, bathing, loitering, getting drunk, playing ear-splitting music, selling drugs. Or for any other pursuit that threatens to turn them into green extensions of the mean streets that surround them.

title: Walter C. Pew, Oil Executive, 87
description: Walter C. Pew, for 41 years a director of his family's business, the Sun Oil Company, died of cardiovascular disease Tuesday at the Bryn Mawr Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 87 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: 9 Basketball Players Injured in L.I. Attack
description: Nine members of a Long Island high school girls basketball team were injured last night when they were attacked by fans of an opposing team in a school parking lot, officials said.

title: McFarlane Testifies on Role Reagan Played in Contra Aid
description: President Ronald Reagan authorized a secret plan in April 1985 to secure Honduran help for the Nicaraguan rebels by providing Honduras with millions of dollars in economic and military aid, Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, testified today.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Space Shuttle Gets Go-Ahead To Complete 5-Day Mission
description: Space agency officials said today that a problem with the space shuttle Discovery's electrical system had apparently been fixed, allowing the $1.2 billion winged spaceship to complete its five-day mission.

title: Dollar General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said because of a change in fiscal year, year-to-year comparisons are for Jan. 31, 1989 and Dec. 31, 1987, while quarterly comparisons are directly comparable.

title: No Diplomacy, No Contra Aid
description: It makes sense to keep the contra army settled in its Honduran bases until the Sandinistas start making real progress toward democratizing Nicaragua. But Secretary of State Baker asks more than progress: he wants to keep the rebels on standby until Washington determines that democratization is complete. That stubborn approach will serve only to give the Sandinistas an excuse to avoid the very steps desired by their neighbors and the United States.

title: Elxsi Names Chairman
description: The Elxsi Corporation, a maker of minisupercomputers based in San Jose, Calif., said today that Joseph D. Rizzi had been elected chairman. Mr. Rizzi, vice chairman and a founder of Elxsi, succeeds Gene M. Amdahl, who is resigning to devote more attention to his new company, Andor Systems Inc., which is developing computers compatible with some products of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Rizzi is also a general partner of Matrix Partners, a venture capital group based in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Zayre Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included for the quarter income of $6,505,000 from discontinued operations; the year included a loss of $56,454,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $166,500,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $10,491,000 and $20,343,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain of $20,536,000 from an accounting change and a gain of $95,900,000 from the sale of a minority interest in TJX Cos. d-Net income Latest periods' results are after a restructuring charge of $7.2 million. Sales represent net sales.

title: The Joffrey Ballet Is Invited to China
description: The Joffrey Ballet has been invited by the Chinese Ministry of Culture to perform in this year's China Arts Festival in Beijing. The Joffrey is to serve as the official representative of the United States.

title: Brampton Brick Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company did not provide per- share figures for the quarterly periods. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Microbilt Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $204,000 from an accounting change.

title: Warden and 2 Jail Guards Held in Death
description: A deputy warden and two guards at the Hudson County Jail were arrested today on charges of murder and official misconduct in the beating death of a 27-year-old prisoner.

title: Ortega Makes Conciliatory Moves to Church
description: In a gesture of conciliation toward Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Church, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that he had lifted a ban on news broadcasts by a Catholic radio station here, and would allow the return of 10 foreign priests who were expelled on charges of plotting against the Government.

title: Strike at Short Brothers
description: About 3,000 workers at Short Brothers P.L.C., the British state-owned aircraft and missile maker, staged a one-day strike for higher pay today as potential buyers of the company visited its factory here. Senior executives from NV Koninklijke Nederlandse Vliegtuigenfabriek Fokker, the Dutch aircraft group, and the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain are examining their potential purchase this week. Short Brothers has been put up for sale as part of the British Government's privatization drive.

title: Gantos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $1,224,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Talking Deals; Empire Savings: Plea for New Aid
description: IN the early 1980's, Empire of America, the Buffalo-based savings bank, was part of the solution to the crisis in the savings and loan industry, acquiring 13 sick institutions with the approval and help of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: Events: Crafts Benefit and Quilt Archive
description: Craft Preview, A Show of Hands, 531 Amsterdam Avenue at 86th Street; 212-787-0924.

title: Keep the Penny
description: To The Home Section:

title: Protest at Howard U. Brings a Surprising Review
description: The student protest that shut down Howard University for five days this month is having ramifications far beyond any originally expected by the student demonstrators.

title: Moscow Expels U.S. Attache In Response to 'Provocation'
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had ordered an American diplomat to leave the country in retaliation for the American expulsion of a Soviet military attache accused of espionage.

title: Health-Mor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said the latest year loss from continuing operations included a noncash, $5,779,000 writedown of the net investment in the company's oil and gas properties.

title: Thousands of Hungarians March To Commemorate Revolt in 1848
description: Tens of thousands of opponents of the Communist Government demonstrated freely in the streets of Budapest today to commemorate the 1848 uprising against Austrian rule, which was put down with much bloodshed and the help of the Russian Army.

title: Personal Health
description: Within each eye a tiny transparent disk, the lens, repeatedly bulges and flattens to allow you to see objects near and far by focusing light on the retina. As you age, the lens gradually loses its ability to return fully to its bulbous shape, which is why most people eventually require reading glasses or contact lenses.

title: Photronic Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and included a tax benefit of $127,406.

title: The Pointing Finger
description: While serving as a speechwriter in the Nixon Administration, I wrote a piece about language and sent it to The New York Times. The Op-Ed page editor ran it and sent me the then-standard payment of $100.

The company said the special charges in 1988 are a result of its share in the charges of Great-West Lifeco Inc. description: The 25 subsidiary banks of Mcorp, the troubled banking company, estimated that they lost a total of $213 million in the fourth quarter, a figure that would push Mcorp's loss for 1988 to $903 million.

title: Farah Reports Two Offers
description: Farah Inc., a clothing maker based in El Paso that said in August it would consider selling the company, reported after its annual meeting Tuesday that it had received two bids. One offer is for the entire company and the other for one of its subsidiaries. The Salant Corporation, a

title: Weisfields Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reduced by $61,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $296,000, or 27 cents a share, for the year, as the result of a LIFO charge.

description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $2,720,000 from discontinued operations and a $3,571,000 loss on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Honoring Women's Designs in Parks
description: THE New York City Parks and Recreation Department has opened an exhibition to honor 12 sculptors and landscape architects whose work has long been a part of the city, but who have been little recognized for their accomplishments. All 12 are women.

title: Review/Theater; Reno, Solo, Lashes Out
description: When Reno, a punkish young comedienne with a rock-and-roll attitude, performs, she becomes a swaggering perpetual-motion machine. Delivering a nonstop 90-minute monologue that focuses on the absurdities of life in New York, she is like a kid pretending to be an airplane out of control. At any second, one senses, there could be a crash landing right into the audience.

title: Hoechst Unit's Net Up 48%
description: The Hoechst Celanese Corporation, a subsidiary of the West German chemical and pharmaceutical company Hoechst A.G., said this week that it had earned $250 million in 1988, up 48 percent from $169 million in 1987. Revenue last year was $5.68 billion, a 23 percent increase from $4.61 billion in 1987. Hoechst Celanese, based in Somerville, N.J., does not report quarterly earnings.

title: Colony Pacific Explorations Ltd reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Included a pretax charge of $1,775,000 reserved for the settlement of shareholder class action suits and related litigation expenses for both periods. c-Included a pretax charge of $1,850,000 for additional insurance expense.

title: Shamrock Extends Its Bid for Polaroid
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc., the investor group controlled by Roy E. Disney that has sought the Polaroid Corporation since July, extended its $2.95 billion hostile bid for the photography giant for two months. Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., is offering $45 a share in cash for all of Polaroid's common stock, including the preferred shares associated with the company's shareholder rights plan.

title: Tejas Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its improvement in earnings for the fourth quarter and full-year 1988 is primarily attributable to significant increases in natural gas and resulting from Tejas' July 1, 1988 acquisition of Gulf Energy Holding inc.

title: In Chicago, A Holy War Over the Flag
description: LEAD: As our jet dipped a wing over Jamaica Bay and soared toward the greening plains, I slipped free of New York's nervous preoccupations. It had been an intense few weeks as the city's writerly community sought the appropriate response to the Ayatollah's death threat against Salman Rushdie. There were demonstrations, picketing at book stores, a mass reading in lower Manhattan.

title: International Systems & Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Maxwell Plans a Weekly
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell said today that his new newspaper, The European, originally scheduled to begin publishing in May as a daily, would instead start this fall as a weekly. He told the Foreign Press Association that The European would initially be a weekend paper. Mr. Maxwell, owner of Mirror Group Newspapers, said research convinced him that the paper should begin as a weekly ''to establish a base from which daily publication could begin.''

title: GORBACHEV URGES NEW FARM POLICY AND FREER MARKET
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for a radical reversal of the Soviet Union's 60-year history of centralized farming, including the immediate dismantling of the state agricultural bureaucracy and the gradual introduction of free markets.

title: Chicago Board of Trade Challenges Rival Globex System
description: With technology similar to that used in video games, the Chicago Board of Trade is seeking to challenge its smaller archrival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, in the computerized buying and selling of futures contracts.

title: Piano Movers Do the Job When Others May Balk
description: ''WE'VE handled a lot of jobs where people are in the middle of moving and the mover refuses to move a piano,'' said Charlene Cameron, the president of Cameron Piano Movers Inc. The seven-year-old company moves pianos of all sizes, including spinets, uprights, player pianos and grand pianos.

title: Krisch American Inns reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Servicewomen's Reward
description: The three-year effort to recognize the contribution of servicewomen with a monument at the entrance to Arlington National Cemetery has now been endorsed by the Defense Department.

title: N-W Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $29,555,000.

title: High Court Blocks Execution
description: The Supreme Court without dissent today blocked the scheduled execution in Arkansas of R. Gene Simmons, a convicted multiple murderer who has said he wants to die. Mr. Simmons had been scheduled to die by lethal injection at 7 A.M. Thursday. Mr. Simmons, who was convicted last month of killing 14 members of his family in December 1987. would have been the first prisoner executed in Arkansas since 1964.

title: Viola Ilma, Writer, 78
description: Viola Ilma, a writer, died Tuesday at the Wesley Health Care Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., after a stroke. She was 78 years old and lived in Saratoga Springs.

title: 4 Injured in Greenwich Village Explosion
description: Four people were injured and more than 200 Greenwich Village residents were temporarily removed from their homes last night after an explosion at a supermarket.

title: Tower Reflex
description: In the capital, a running fight takes on a life of its own, its own rituals, its own routine. So when the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, held his regular news conference yesterday, one of the questions was purely reflexive: ''Senator, what about Tower?'' The reporter quickly amended, ''I mean Cheney,'' and Mr. Mitchell smiled broadly, savoring the realization that he no longer had to answer such questions.

title: Driver-Harris Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from the reversal of a tax credit of $120,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $68,000 for the year. The latest quarter and year results included a pretax LIFO charge that reduced net income by $317,000.

description: With elections a few days away, President Jose Napoleon Duarte today warned of growing polarization and economic chaos that could lead to a rebel victory in El Salvador.

Trainer Focus of Testimony In Canadian Drug Inquiry
description: The possibility that sabotage caused Ben Johnson to test positive for an anabolic steroid at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, last fall was cast in a new light today when Angella Issajenko suggested that the Canadian team physiotherapist might have had a motive for it.

title: Rote Learning Alone Makes Jack a Dull Boy
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Pop; A Playful Brazilian Pianist
description: Hermeto Pascoal, the noted Brazilian composer and multi-instrumentalist, is among the more flamboyant performers from a country whose musical stars often exhibit a free-spirited jubilance on stage. Mr. Pascoal, who gave two concerts at Town Hall on Friday and Saturday - the first an evening of solo piano, the second featuring his seven-member group - is a wild romantic of the keyboard who has an equally wild look.

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade starts tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. The parade begins at 44th

title: Nominee for Deputy Post at State Is Challenged on Consulting Ties
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, President Bush's choice to be Deputy Secretary of State, came under sharp questioning in his Senate confirmation hearing today about his relationship with two consulting firms headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Bear Says Agent Made Vow to 'Break My Legs'
description: Maurice Douglass, a free safety for the Chicago Bears, told a Federal jury today that after he sought to terminate his agreement to be represented by the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom in the 1986 National Football League draft, Bloom told him, ''that somebody might break my legs.''

title: Bernard King Finding New Ways to Score
description: The lift and explosiveness have been diminished by knee surgery and age but Bernard King in the last month has been a reasonable facsimile of the Bernard King of the past. He is again piling up points but in different ways. He has become more of a finesse player, shooting the jumper from a little farther out and snaking and slashing his way to the basket behind the picks his Washington Bullet teammates set to get him open.

title: Home Improvement
description: APPLYING wallpaper without fuss takes practice. But by learning the basics, beginners can take on simple projects and gradually gain skill and experience.

description: LEAD: Hark! Hark! upon the dreary, stark And dismal fate Of those who wait At Eastern's gate Like docile sheep from dawn to dark Undined, stiff-spined, Aligned behind A rope; confined, With scarce the glimmer of a spark Of hope they'll get A shuttle jet For twelve bucks net As promised by the oligarch,

title: Caller Claims Pro-Iran Group Bombed Van
description: An anonymous caller to a Los Angeles radio station asserted today that a violently pro-Iranian group, the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution, planted the bomb last Friday that destroyed a van owned by the captain of the United States warship Vincennes.

title: Pesticide Barred In 70's Is Found To Taint Poultry
description: One of the nation's largest poultry producers has destroyed 400,000 chickens here in the last month because they were contaminated with a cancer-causing pesticide that was banned for use in food 11 years ago.

title: Review/Jazz; Ed Thigpen Is Back
description: Ed Thigpen's notable background as a drummer includes six years in the Oscar Peterson Trio, five years with Ella Fitzgerald and earlier associations with Bud Powell, Billy Taylor and Lennie Tristano. But since he settled in Copenhagen in 1972, his visits to this country have been infrequent, and usually only in his role as an educator conducting clinics and lecturing.

title: CHURCH QUALIFIES APARTHEID STAND
description: The main Afrikaner church has backed away from its unequivocal condemnation of apartheid last week, apparently jeopardizing gains it had achieved in talks with its mixed-race and black counterparts.

description: Sex education in the classroom appears to have little or no effect on altering sexual activity, promoting the use of birth control or lowering teen-age pregnancy, according to a review of five studies.

description: Ozzie Newsome, the N.F.L. career leader among tight ends with 610 receptions, said yesterday he would return for one more season with the Cleveland Browns.

description: About 200 students walked out of Stafford High School yesterday in a protest motivated in part by the removal of Rolling Stone magazine from the school library in this northwestern Connecticut town.

description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Witness Puts 2 at Scene of Officer's Killing
description: The man who was being guarded by a New York City police officer when the officer was murdered testified yesterday that two of the men charged with the crime had been at the scene seconds after the fatal shots were fired.

description: New York City residents face the prospect of dirtier sidewalks, dry fountains and reduced air-conditioning, as well as restrictions on watering lawns and gardens, after a drought emergency is declared.

title: Bush Isn't Running, On a Track, That Is
description: In the first days of his Administration, President Bush signaled that he had no intention of abandoning his frequent midday jogs. The President summoned his driver and headed for the running track at the Fort McNair Army base, accompanied by a two-block-long motorcade.

title: Vyquest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included losses of $326,000 and $1,253,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $1,268,000 from the retirement of long-term debt. c-Included losses of $4,946,000 and $7,540,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that of the loss for the latest fourth quarter, nearly $1.7 million was accounted for by writedowns of over-valued real estate, primarily involving the company's one remaining hotel investment property in Michigan.

title: Frieder Is Dropped For Taking A New Job
description: Bill Frieder resigned as Michigan's basketball coach today, two days before his team's opening game in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, to become the head coach at Arizona State. Frieder was told by Michigan not to bother showing up for the tournament.

title: Bush Proposes Tax Credits to Aid Child Care
description: In his first major legislative initiative, President Bush sent to Congress today a proposal for tax credits to help low-income families with child care.

Bush Move On Japan Jet Is Reported
description: President Bush decided today to place tighter restrictions on transfers of technology as part of an agreement to help Japan build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, White House officials said.

title: Texaco to Widen Sales of Properties
description: Texaco Inc. said it would expand its sales of oil- and gas-producing properties to 3,000, to raise $300 million to $600 million. As part of a restructuring package that brought it out of bankruptcy last spring, the company had said that it would sell 600 properties, and in November it raised the figure to 1,400.

description: b-Included a loss of $19,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $215,500 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had added a model to its 3B2 minicomputer line and cut prices on other 3B2 and personal computer models. A.T.&T. said the model, the 3B2/1000, is a commercial version of the minicomputer it will provide to the Air Force under a $1 billion contract announced last October.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $527,000 from a tax benefit.

Sheraton Hotels Switch To Wells, Rich, Greene
description: Wells, Rich, Greene yesterday received another plum from its association with the ITT Corporation, winning the worldwide advertising account of its Sheraton Corporation hotel subsidiary. The $25 million account had been handled by the WCRS Group and its American subsidiary, Della Femina McNamee.

title: Dart Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Singer Case Whistle-Blower Says a Reward Was Motive
description: LEAD: A former Singer Company employee who has accused Singer of overcharging the Government on military contracts said yesterday that he had waited several years before deciding to speak publicly about his concerns.

title: Chile Halts Exports of Fruit But Assails U.S. Warnings
description: Chile's fruit export industry was paralyzed today as growers and sellers halted all shipments and began scouring their stocks in response to a worldwide cyanide contamination scare.

title: Gencorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $135 million for the latest first quarter and $1 million for the year-earlier period, and the year- earlier period also included a $3 million gain from an accounting change. The company said during the third quarter of 1988, the company changed its method of accounting for certain types of long-term fixed price contracts. The $3 million cumulative effect of the accounting change on years prior to fiscal 1988 is included in the quarter ended Feb. 29, 1988. Sales and income in that quarter have been restated.

title: News Of the World
description: Britain's largest-selling newspaper is the Sunday News of the World. (''Last week's sale 5,377,000.'') The lead story last Sunday, marked Exclusive, began:

title: Wilson, Former Bear, Signs With Raiders
description: Otis Wilson, an All-Pro linebacker for the Chicago Bears in 1985 who missed half of the 1987 season and all of last season after undergoing knee-ligament surgery, signed a free-agent contract Tuesday night with the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Dinosaurs for Parents
description: Remedial education is hardly a new concept, but the Smithsonian Institution is giving it a new twist: a remedial course for parents who find themselves unable to keep up with their children's knowledge of dinosaurs.

title: 'War' Mini-Series Trimmed
description: ABC announced yesterday that it was cutting the scheduled length of the epic mini-series ''War and Remembrance'' by at least a half-hour.

title: Currents; 20's Curves Inspire a New Furniture Line
description: BEAUTIFULLY crafted woodwork is Adam Tihany's signature in his designs for Manhattan restaurants like Remi and Bice. It also distinguishes his latest project, furniture to be produced by the Pace Collection, a line, Mr. Tihany said, ''that consists of dining tables and chairs, upholstered seating, entertainment centers and bedroom sets.'' Pictured are an armchair and ottoman in two tones of wood with leather upholstery.

title: SCS-Compute reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Passengers Are Told Of Threat to Pan Am
description: Pan Am warned passengers of a bomb threat received before a trans-Atlantic flight this week, unlike the threat to the airline's Flight 103 in December, which was disclosed only to the Government, a newspaper reported today.

title: Metromedia Deal For 2 ITT Units
description: The Metromedia Company said it had agreed to purchase the long-distance telephone units of the ITT Corporation in a deal that would make Metromedia the nation's fifth-largest long-distance carrier. Metromedia, a privately held concern based in Secaucus, N.J., said it would acquire ITT Communications Services Inc., which offers long-distance and private-line service, and ITT Chernow Communications Services Inc., which provides call-accounting equipment and services for the hotel and hospitality industry.

title: 4 on Jail Staffs Held In a Cocaine Case
description: Three correction officers and a civilian have been arrested in an investigation for trying to smuggle cocaine to inmates in New York City jails, officials said yesterday.

title: Gevork Avedissian, 71, A Philanthropist, Dies
description: Gevork Avedissian, a retired executive and philanthropist, died Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nord Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the rise in 1988 net in part to earnings from its investment in its gold affiliate, which offset a decline in net earnings from non-gold operations. The company said earnings from its gold affiliate included $7.1 million related to the sale of a gold prospect.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in The Living Section yesterday about the presentation of black-colored food misidentified Richard Krause. He owns the Melrose restaurant in Manhattan and is its chef.

title: An Art Show Asks: Please Touch!
description: ''MANY individuals have been shut out of museums for a long time,'' said Irma J. Shore, curator of ''Access to Art: Bringing Folk Art Closer.'' ''We want to make sure we we don't leave anybody out.''

title: Parent & Child
description: THERE are times when even the most docile children appear to have the aggressive tendencies of a professional wrestler. While a certain amount of pushing and shoving is to be expected from all children, especially when they are very young, for some children aggression becomes a way of dealing with almost any situation.

title: Coke Expands Ties To Big-League Baseball
description: In signing a multimillion-dollar sponsorship deal with the Major League Baseball organization yesterday, the Coca-Cola Company is hoping to take its place in the cultural pantheon next to apple pie, hot dogs and the national pastime. The deal enables Coca-Cola to refer to itself as the ''official soft drink of major league baseball'' in its advertising. Coke will also have a presence in the ball parks during World Series and All-Star games through marketing and promotions.

title: It's Straight and Narrow for Architect of the Right
description: When Paul M. Weyrich went before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Jan. 31 and questioned John G. Tower's drinking habits and the time Mr. Tower spent with women ''to whom he was not married,'' his statement was replayed repeatedly on television.

title: Soviets Apparently Resume Arms Airlift to Kabul
description: A month after Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan, the Kremlin appears to have resumed an intensive airlift of military supplies to the Kabul Goverment.

title: Working Mens Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $1.6 million addition to the company's loan loss reserves. c-Net income

title: Trade Data Help Dow Rise 14.29, to 2,320.54
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday after the Government reported that the nation's trade deficit had narrowed. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 14.29 points higher, at 2,320.54.

title: Connecticut Advances In 67-62 N.I.T. Victory
description: Cliff Robinson scored 15 of his 23 points in the second half, leading Connecticut to a 67-62 first-round victory over North Carolina-Charlotte tonight in the National Invitation Tournament.

title: A Cleaner Teamsters' Union?
description: The settlement of the Government's racketeering suit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters falls short of total victory for the union's critics. But as Federal Judge David Edelstein said in approving the agreement, it offers ''some hope'' that the teamsters can be converted from an outlaw union to an honest one. And the one truly novel provision - direct election of national officers by secret ballot - may justify the entire effort.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Failure to adequately address this issue would pose the most serious threat to the future of the judiciary and its continued operations that I have observed during my lifetime.'' - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, urging a pay increase for judges. [ A16:1. ]

title: Teamster Accord: Each Side Finds Some Different Meanings
description: In a hushed New York courtroom decorated with gold leaf, a Federal judge on Tuesday talked in grand terms about the chance for a new beginning that he said could come from the settlement of the Government's suit against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

description: b-Net income c-Included a gain of $60,000 from an accounting change. title: Botha Ignores Calls For His Resignation And Returns to Job
description: President P. W. Botha today ignored the political controversy swirling around him as he presided over his first Cabinet meeting in more than two months and listened to a new annual budget presented in Parliament.

title: Corrections

title: Alfred M. Ascione, 73, Retired Judge, Is Dead
description: Alfred M. Ascione, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died of a brain tumor Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

description: Her voice trembling, her leg shaking, Dana Christensen makes a fist in front of 50 strangers.

title: TRADE GAP SHRINKS AS U.S. EXPORTS DIP LESS THAN IMPORTS
description: The nation's trade deficit improved sharply in January to $9.5 billion as a decline in exports was more than offset by falling imports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Inventories And Sales Up In January
description: Business inventories continued their steady rise in January, accompanied by healthy growth in sales, indicating continued strength in the economy.

title: Q&A
description: Worn Shingles Q. Our house is about 38 years old and we are about to have the complete roof reshingled. The roof has already had a layer of shingles placed on top of the original ones, but the shingles on the south side have curled and warped and are quite brittle. Should the worn shingles be removed before new ones are applied, and can a third layer be placed on top of the two that are there? A. The warped and brittle shingles should definitely be removed before new shingles are applied. As far as the rest of the roof is concerned, it is never a good idea to apply a third layer of shingles. I would advise removing the shingles on the entire roof before installing a new layer. Touching Up Oak Floors Q. My oak floors were coated with polyurethane over seven years ago. They are still in relatively good condition, but over the years the finish has been blemished by scratches and paint spatters. I would like to restore these floors to their original unblemished condition. What should I do? A. As a rule, polyurethane finishes cannot be easily touched up -you have to sand them down and refinish. But mild scratches can sometimes be covered with a thin coat of paste wax buffed well with lamb's wool. The paint smears can usually be removed by rubbing with a waterless hand cleaner, and sometimes by rubbing with cold cream till the paint liquifies. Wipe off the smear with a clean cloth as soon as it softens. If these measures don't help, then the floor will have to be sanded and refinished. Painting Radiators Q. Our painted radiators look awful and we are ready to strip and repaint them. How is a radiator stripped and what kind of paint is best? Or can the radiators be left in their natural state, without paint? A. Strip the radiators when they are cold, using a semi-paste chemical paint remover. It's messy, so if possible remove the radiators and work in the garage. Otherwise, make sure you cover the floor under and near the radiators. If you use a water-wash remover you can scrub off the goo with a stiff brush dipped in water or a detergent solution. Radiators do not have to be painted, but they might rust if you don't. If you do, use a flat paint, not gloss or aluminum paint. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: Close to Home
description: ONCE, on a long-ago summer evening, I had a fight with a friend. I had complained about how unpleasant it was to take my daughters to the swings in a nearby park because it meant wading through drunks. He said drunks were as much entitled to that park as we were. I said fine, but their presence was discouraging children from using it as the playground it was meant to be. He said, ''How about their constitutional rights?'' I said, ''How about the children's rights?'' The rest of the evening - he had come for dinner - we carefully avoided one another's eyes.
