title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Soviet Skaters Take Pairs: Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov of the Soviet Union swept to their third pairs title in four years at the world championships yesterday in Paris, but Chris Bowman kept American hopes high in the men's event. Bowman and Kurt Browning of Canada burst into contention for the men's gold medal in a three-way battle with the Soviet veteran Aleksandr Fadeyev. Gordeyeva and Grinkov, the Olympic champions, won the world pairs title in 1986 and 1987, but were upset last year and then passed up the European championships in Birmingham, England, last January because of an injury to Gordeyeva.They sailed through the free-dance routine yesterday with a performance of style and grace to take the first gold medal of the championships. All their marks for technical merit and artistic impression were 5.8's or 5.9's. Bowman, trying to keep America's grip on the men's title after the success last year of Brian Boitano, now retired, moved up from fourth to third over all after the original program.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 115, Bulls 91: Mark Price scored 21 points and Cleveland took advantage of Michael Jordan's early foul trouble by going on a decisive 17-2 first-quarter run last night as the Cavaliers won for only the third time in its last eight games. Jordan led the Bulls with 28 points. (AP) Jazz 102, Trail Blazers 95: Karl Malone scored 30 points and Mark Eaton pulled down 25 rebounds as Utah won its sixth game in a row. Clyde Drexler led visiting Portland with 31 points, 11 rebounds and 9 assists.(AP) Spurs 110, Bucks 108: Willie Anderson of San Antonio scored 25 points and blocked a shot by Ricky Pierce at the buzzer as Spurs held on at home and ended Milwaukee's five-game winning streak. The Bucks had an opportunity to tie the score after San Antonio turned the ball over on a 24-second violation with 4 seconds left. But Anderson got his hand on Pierce's shot from the free-throw line as the buzzer went off. Jack Sikma scored 19 points, including five 3-pointers. (AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 5, Kings 2: The defenseman Chris Chelios had a goal and two assists and the goaltender Patrick Roy extended his home unbeaten streak to 25 games as Montreal defeated Los Angeles last night. Also scoring for the Canadiens were Mats Naslund, Bob Gainey, Mike McPhee and Guy Carbonneau. Marty McSorley and Dave Taylor scored for Los Angeles. Montreal's victory was its sixth in its last seven games and put the Canadiens back into first place in the overall standings with 105 points, 2 more than the idle Calgary Flames. Roy remained undefeated at home this season with a 23-0-2 record. He matched Bill Durnan's club-record unbeaten streak set in 1943-44. (AP) HORSE RACING Victory for Landyap: Landyap, with Jose Santos riding, took the lead midway on the far turn and went on to win the feature race at Aqueduct by a half-length yesterday. Jack of Clubs, with Chris Antley riding, was second in the field of six, three-quarters of a length ahead of Allemande, ridden by Nick Santagata. The victory was the second in succession Landyap, who made his fourth start of the year. Landyap covered the mile and three-eighths on the fast track in 2:18 3/5 to earn $28,200 for his owner, Gold-n-Oats Stable, and returned $8, $4.20 and $3 for $2 across the board. Jack of Clubs paid $3.20 and $2.80 and Allemande returned $4.80 to show. (AP)

The Finance Minister, Shimon Peres, said after January's rise - the highest monthly jump in three years - that he still hoped to keep 1989 inflation below 10 percent.

title: Rupert Harris Johnson, Financier, 89
description: Rupert Harris Johnson, the founder of R. H. Johnson & Company, a general securities firm and investment banking house, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 89 years old. Mr. Johnson founded the Manhattan-based company in 1927. In 1947 he founded and managed The Franklin Group of Mutual Funds, now one of the country's largest such organizations. He retired in 1956. He is survived by his wife, the former Amybelle Siler; four daughters, Mary F. Furlong of Montclair, N.J., Florence M. Jacobson of Verona, N.J., Bonnie L. Sacerdote of Greenwich, Conn., and Suzanne O. Razor of Salt Lake City; three sons, Charles B., of Hillsborough, Calif., Andrew R. and Rupert H. Jr., both of San Mateo, Calif.; 33 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $438,565. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ryka Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company went public in March 1988. It said that for the period from Feb. 12 to Dec. 31, 1987, it had a loss of $314,291. It did not report sales for that period.

title: New British Accents Are Ethnic Ones
description: On the cover of the British magazine Tatler for April, the punk fashion designer Vivienne Westwood appears cleverly disguised as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The resemblance is startling. Ms. Westwood, a 47-year-old redhead famous for her fetishistic bondage clothes, was transformed with makeup, pearls and a conservative Aquascutum suit, under the headline, ''This Woman Was Once a Punk.''

title: Police Brutality Is Asserted By Family in South Jamaica
description: Four members of a black family in Queens asserted yesterday that they had been brutalized by as many as 25 police officers, most of them white housing policemen, who pushed their way into the family's apartment in South Jamaica.

title: Energy Dept. Chief Disputes Estimates Of Nuclear Cleanup
description: Cleanup of contamination and radioactive waste of the Government's nuclear weapons complex may cost much less than the $60 billion to $100 billion previously estimated, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today, although he did not offer his own estimate.

title: Pickens Plans to Cut Mesa Dividend by 25%
description: Reacting to falling prices for natural gas, T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said today that he would pare the dividend on the widely held common units of Mesa L.P. by 25 percent, to an annual rate of $1.50 next autumn, from the current rate of $2.

title: Datamark Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: City Under Siege: Afghan Rebels Foiled, for Now
description: Afghan guerrillas have failed so far in their first major attempt to oust the Soviet-backed Government since the last Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan a month ago.

title: Starling vs. Breland
description: The welterweight champions, Marlon Starling of the World Boxing Council and Mark Breland of the World Boxing Association, will fight to unify those titles on April 15 at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. The bout was announced yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, and after the announcement, the 25-year-old Breland conceded, ''This is a big fight for me.''

title: President's Reversal on Assault Weapons Was Response to a Pressing Political Need
description: At a little-publicized meeting last weekend in Charlottesville, Va., between Republican leaders in Congress and senior White House officials, the conclusion was unanimous. ''We're in trouble, we need an issue, and we need one fast'' after the failure to win confirmation of former Senator John G. Tower confirmation as Secretary of Defense, one Capitol Hill participant reported afterward.

title: A Warning On Effects Of Bailouts
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned today that the Government faced a monumental task in handling the bad real estate of almost 800 sick savings and loan associations, which will be taken over during the next three years.

title: Currents; Video Tour Of Miami's Art Deco
description: ''A PASTEL PARADISE,'' an architectural tour of South Beach in Miami, will no doubt appeal to armchair travelers who enjoy architecturally rich cities. The 48-minute videotape concentrates on the Art Deco historic district and its recent gentrification.

title: Richmond Barthe, Sculptor, Dies
description: Richmond Barthe, a sculptor known for his realistic portrayals of religious subjects, figures from black history, and stage and dance celebrities, died on March 6 at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: GWIL Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included special gains of $2,623,000 for the latest year and $557,000 for 1987. Net from continuing operations included losses from discontinued operations of $598,000 for the latest year and $57,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Piano; The Works of Julius Reubke
description: Laid end to end as Michael Gailit did it on Sunday afternoon, Julius Reubke's keyboard compositions can be played in about an hour and a half. Reubke, a German born in 1834, lived only to the age of 24. Two years before his death, he went to Weimar, where he studied with Liszt and absorbed Wagner. Sunday's five pieces - two for organ, three for piano - show more than anything else a sensitive soul's response to the strong influences surrounding him.

title: Fujitsu Unit Sets Venture
description: A division of Fujitsu Microelectronics Inc. said today that it had formed a partnership with VIA Technologies Inc., an integrated circuit design company based in Fremont, Calif.

title: Money Fund Yields Rise
description: Yields for money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, as short-term rates dominated investment strategies.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks' Revolving Door For Pitching Coaches
description: Behind the two bullpen mounds near the Yankee dugout in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the team's new pitching coach, Billy Connors, chunky and concerned, watched Al Leiter and Tommy John throw. At the age of 23, Leiter is roughly half as old as John, who will be 46 in two months. Leiter has the arm, the fastball and the future. John has the smarts and the stats: 286 victories and a career 3.31 earned-run average. But this odd couple was throwing together for a reason.

title: A Close Adviser to Indira Gandhi Was Investigated in Her Killing
description: The Government disclosed today that a close aide to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had been the subject of a special investigation after questions were raised about whether he played a role in Mrs. Gandhi's assassination.

title: Fighter Plane Is a Model for U.S.-Japan Projects; License the F-16
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILE ENVOY IN U.S. ON TAINTED FRUIT
description: Chile's Foreign Minister arrived here today for urgent talks with the Bush Administration about a poisoning scare that has prompted Federal investigators to detain hundreds of thousands of pounds of Chilean fruit at American ports.

title: Diversified Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $31,000 and a gain of $2,450,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Tuesday Morning Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Federal Report Criticizes the Coloring of Films
description: A report released today by the Registrar of Copyrights declared that the use of new film-editing techniques like computerized coloring ''has an adverse effect on the esthetics of black-and-white motion pictures.''

title: Market Place; When Regulators Cannot Agree
description: THE conflict over the definitions of a security and a futures contract heated up this week with the approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission of three controversial financial instruments. It is a battle that may bode ill for the authority of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Review/Theater; Whimsical 'Magic Act'
description: Mona Kale is one of those blissfully unhappy souls who revel in the misery of solitude. She lives and loves vicariously through her friends, most of whom wish she would just go away. Mona also has a little trouble separating reality from fantasy, but then who doesn't.

title: Bush Role on Eastern Required by House Vote
description: The House of Representatives split along party lines today as it passed a bill that would require President Bush to intervene in the Eastern Airlines strike.

title: Library Will Be Safe With Father Healy
description: To the Editor:

title: J. F. Follmann Jr., 81, Executive and Author
description: Joseph Francis Follmann Jr., a retired health insurance executive and author, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wright Says He Has Backing Of Fellow House Democrats
description: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that he was confident his Democratic colleagues stand behind him as the House ethics committee moves toward a conclusion of its eight-month-long investigation into his finances.

title: BUSH'S COURTING SPLITS DEMOCRATS
description: President Bush's efforts to win bipartisan support for a new policy in Central America have deeply divided Congressional Democrats. Some are eager to work with him and others are profoundly skeptical of his intentions.

title: Times Mirror Issue
description: The Times Mirror Company is offering $100 million of 10.20 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.975 to yield 10.22 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. At pricing the notes were yielding about 65 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable by the company for one year, the issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Dollar Increases Sharply, Causing Fed Intervention
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, prompting intervention by the Federal Reserve in an attempt to slow the rally.

title: Competition Not Over
description: To The Home Section:

title: Merck Ulcer Drug
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended only limited use of Merck & Company's new Losec ulcer drug, citing a potential risk of cancer. The Gastrointestinal Drugs Advisory Committee voted unanimously to recommend that the agency approve Losec for the most serious cases of heartburn after other drugs had been found to be ineffective. The panel tied on a vote on whether to recommend its use in serious duodenal ulcers when other treatment failed.

title: Nets' 16-Point Lead Isn't Enough
description: A good team, given the opportunities the Nets had tonight, would have found a way to win. The Nets had a 16-point lead in the second quarter. They caught the 76ers on an off night. Even Charles Barkley, Philadelphia's all-star forward, played poorly.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
School District Slashes Staff
description: The school district in this impoverished city is laying off 600 of its 1,800 employees, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today. Elmo J. Bush, the Superintendent of Schools, said the state board of education had asked the district to trim about $12 million from next year's budget. The district, whose budget this year is $70 million, has more than $10 million in unpaid bills, he said. The district is two weeks behind in payments to employees.

title: Review/Art; Old Master Drawings at the Morgan Library
description: Anyone who enjoys Old Master drawings should take note that through April 30 we can see at the Pierpont Morgan Library what might be called the cream of the crop from the Teyler Museum in Haarlem, the Netherlands.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the previous day's stock trading characterized the bid by Topper Limited Partners for the Emhart Corporation incorrectly. Topper has not revised its $35-a-share offer for Emhart.

title: Strawberry Stands By His Actions on Field
description: Two weeks after he staged a one-day sitdown strike for a new contract, Darryl Strawberry says that he has no regrets about his walkout, that he has apparently lost no standing with his teammates and that, in any event, he aspires to no locker-room leadership role on the Mets.

title: Rutgers Women Capture N.C.A.A. Tourney Opener
description: They no longer have the best player in the country. They're not in the Top 20 anymore and, for the first time in several years, they're not more popular than the school's men's team.

title: Animals Run Down on Tracks
description: Animals weary of wading through deep snow have taken to highways and railroad tracks, and more than 600 moose and 94 caribou have been killed this winter, officials say. ''There's a tendency for them to walk on the trails and the biggest trails available to them are the tracks and the roads,'' said Carl Grauvogel, a state wildlife biologist.

title: Showtime Extends Pact
description: Showtime, the nation's second-largest pay television service, extended an agreement yesterday that gives it exclusive rights to the films of Touchstone Pictures. Touchstone is a division of the Walt Disney Company that has been highly successful in recent years.

title: Club Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Prices End Session Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed at the close of a mixed session yesterday.

title: St. John's Has to Rally For N.I.T. Victory
description: Lou Carnesecca has been around long enough to know when to change the defensive strategy for his basketball team at St. John's. The coach of the Redmen went from man-to-man to a half-court zone defense early in the second half and it worked.

title: American Physicians Service Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains from discontinued operations of $146,000 and $2,141,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included gains from discontinued operations of $163,000 for the quarter and $688,000 for the year.

title: Inmates and Guards Join in Suit on Conditions
description: Inmates and guards have joined forces here in a lawsuit challenging overcrowding and understaffing in a tense county jail. Legal experts said the suit is the first in which prisoners and guards have jointly sued over prison conditions.

title: Hamilton Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains from discontinued operations of $2,445,000 for the quarter and $8,351,000 for the year, and a tax credit of $4,176,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Included gains from discontinued operations of $865,000 and $5,953,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest year's earnings included $8.3 million from the spin-off of Tejas Gas Corp.

title: Latin Officials Agree On Peacekeeper Plan
description: Officials of five Central American countries today approved in principle a draft United Nations plan for the deployment of 160 peacekeepers who would patrol borders to prevent raids by ''irregular forces and insurrectional movements in the region.''

title: Strike Casts Doubt on Sale of Shuttle
description: An important element in Eastern Airlines strategy in its battle with striking unions is the sale of its profitable shuttle operation to Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer. But now there are indications that the Trump Organization might be having second thoughts.

title: European TV's Vast Growth: Cultural Effect Stirs Concern
description: A revolution is unfolding in European television.

title: Home Federal Corp Maryland reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year reflected change in accounting for loan fees and associated costs. The prior year is restated to reflect merger of Waynesboro Savings Association and a 5 percent stock dividend.

title: Deb Shops Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ASA International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $109,000 from a reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and included a tax credit of $88,000.

title: Arizona Breezes Past Robert Morris to Gain
description: Top-ranked Arizona scored the first 12 points, took a 21-2 lead and defeated Robert Morris, 94-60, in the first round of the West Regional today.

title: Wheelabrator Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share net figures are not applicable; the company was formed at the end of 1988 as the result of the division of Henley Group Inc. into two public companies.

title: U.S. and Chile to Work Together To Put Fruit Back on the Shelves
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Chilean Government agreed today to work on an urgent basis to return Chilean fruit to grocers' shelves in the United States.

title: Our Towns; 'A Lot of Poems': The Joy of Books In a Poor Town
description: A new library in a poor area is a great thing, a place where you can shut out the noise from the street. After school lets out, the new Wyandanch Public Library fills up fast. Calvin Seabury, a fourth grader, had a report due this week on poems and at the new library he found a book - it was stuffed with poems! There were two or three poems on a page, there were poems so grown up that they didn't need to rhyme. As Calvin said, ''There's a lot of poems.''

title: Koop Says Abortion Report Couldn't Survive Challenge
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop told a Congressional hearing today that there was not enough evidence to assess the psychological effects of abortion and that an unimpeachable scientific report was not possible.

title: Dining Out Guide: With Children
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Contrapunto * (Nov. 23, 1984), 200 East 60th Street (751-8616) - Even before they can properly pronounce it, many junior diners want pasta. Contrapunto serves 20 varieties in an upbeat glass-walled dining room above street level. Among those recommended are angel-hair pasta with dried tomatoes, shallots, leeks, basil and littleneck clams, and fusilli tossed with greens, Parmesan, tomato, garlic and hot peppers. There is light homemade sorbet to finish the feast. Entrees are $11.75 to $18.75. Open noon to 11:45 P.M. Friday to Sunday. El Rio Grande * (April 20, 1984), 160 East 38th Street (867-0922) - Children may like the Tex-Mex decor and menu at this two-room restaurant divided by an imaginary Rio Grande (actually a passage through the kitchen). The menu includes several dishes in which the ingredients are rolled into soft tortillas; both chicken and steak fajitas are available. An appetizer that might suffice for a child's entree, queso fundido, is a Mexican cheese casserole (with chicken, seafood or vegetables) that is tucked into the tortilla by the waiter at tableside. Entrees are $8.95 to $19.50. Open noon to midnight Friday through Sunday; brunch noon to 3:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Exterminator Chili Diner's Journal (Aug. 2, 1985), 305 Church Street (219-3070) - A campy 1950's diner theme amuses children and grown-ups alike, particularly when the menu features good chili and hamburgers. Patrons sitting in worn vintage booths are surrounded by pop icons, Howdy Doody and Elvis Presley prominent among them. A hefty, fresh bowl of chili (mild, medium, hot or vegetarian) is topped with sour cream, onions and cheddar. Homemade desserts include fruit cobblers and chocolate mud pie. Lunch is $3.95 to $6.95, dinner $6.95 to $11.95. Open 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight Friday, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight Saturday and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 6 P.M. to 11 P.M. Sunday. Pig Heaven ** (Dec. 28, 1984), 1540 Second Avenue, at 80th Street (744-4333) - The capricious barnyard motif, from the giant wooden piglet holding the menu card at the door to the frieze of illuminated pigs all around the dining room, belies some serious Chinese cooking in the kitchen. You can start with the excellent dumplings - steamed, fried, or boiled. A winning entree is crisp-skinned Cantonese-style suckling pig. Other dishes include three-glass chicken and skillfully prepared fish. Desserts are American-style; young diners should be impressed with the Peking snowball, whipped cream surrounding a rich chocolate core, accompanied by silly-face cookies. Appetizers are $3.75 to $8.50, entrees $7.95 to $19.95. Open noon to 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday, noon to midnight Sunday. Pizzico Diner's Journal (Sept. 20, 1985), 1445 First Avenue, at 75th Street (737-3328) - Eleven kinds of individual pizza are the main attraction at this cafe. Toppings run from the complex to the simply traditional. One combines grilled peppers, two cheeses, red onions, sun-dried tomatoes, basil and roasted garlic; another has spicy eggplant, lamb sausage, basil and marinara sauce. For the purist, there is the New York pizza - red sauce, mozzarella, Parmesan, oregano and garlic. A full menu of salads, pastas and grilled entrees are also available. Pizzas are $9 to $11, pastas and grilled dishes $12 to $23. Lunch is noon to 4 P.M. and dinner 6 P.M. to 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday; Sunday brunch is noon to 3:30 P.M., dinner 5 to 11:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C24.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Mexico is expanding its cooperation with American efforts to curb the flow of illegal immigrants into the U.S. The Mexican Government has allowed Federal immigration agents to step up their investigations in Mexico. Page A1

title: Behind the Smile
description: Even when the Senate is at its back-slapping friendliest, there is an edge to the smiles and laughter. Witness a discussion at a meeting of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

title: Austerity Accord for Seamen's
description: The corporate parent of the Seamen's Bank for Savings of New York announced today that it had entered into an agreement with Federal regulators that would prohibit it from paying dividends on its common stock and would severely limit its growth and investment activity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Brown & Williamson Drops Ogilvy & Mather
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation yesterday dismissed Ogilvy & Mather as its agency-of-record for domestic media planning and buying, assigning all United States media placement to Geer Dubois and splitting the planning between its three creative shops -Geer, Campbell-Mithun-Esty and Tatham-Laird & Kudner.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ROLL OVER, BEETHOVEN

title: Soviets to Allow Private Farmers To Lease State Land for a Lifetime
description: The Communist Party said today that private farmers should be allowed to lease state land for life and to pass it on to their children, thus offering adventuresome peasants a chance at independence for the first time since the 1920's.

title: Children's Opera
description: The Vineyard Opera is to present a one-hour children's version of Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' performed in English, at the Gertrude and Irving Dimson Theater, 108 East 15th Street, tomorrow afternoon at 12:30. The performance is to be repeated at 3 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: 683-0696.

title: LDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,450,000 from an accounting change.

title: Memo Hints Reagan Backed '85 Contra Supplies
description: A classified memorandum read to the jury today at the trial of Oliver L. North suggests that President Ronald Reagan approved a ''very specialized intelligence'' mission in October 1985 to equip the Nicaraguan rebels with information and weapons to attack the Sandinista government's arms shipments.

title: Bush Says His Agenda Is Preparing for 21st Century
description: President Bush defended himself from criticisms that his Administration was without an agenda, saying today that the White House was building a program that centered on a strong economy, better education, a cleaner environment and ''the changing nature of our society.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Suffolk County, L.I., priced $100 million of general obligation bonds yesterday in competitive bidding through Chemical Securities Inc., a subsidiary of Chemical Bank.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums FOLK SONG CONCERT, a sing-along folk-song concert with Phoebe Lou Dixon Berger, 2:30 P.M. tomorrow, at Hecksher Oval for Children at Lincoln Center. Free. Information: 870-1033. ''RUMPLESTILTSKIN,'' a play by the Artreach Touring Theater, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street. Admission: $5. Information: 618-1980. ''A MUSICAL JOURNEY THROUGH TIME AND SPACE,'' a musical program by the Little Orchestra, conducted by Dino Anagnost, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow, at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets: $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770. ''THE TIGER OF CHUNGSHAN,'' a play about a boy and a tiger, presented by Downtown Music Productions, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Henry Street Settlement, Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street. Tickets: children, $1; adults, $2.50. Information: 598-0400. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a screening of the 1939 M-G-M film (101 minutes), to benefit the West 83d Street Playground Association, 9:30 P.M. tomorrow, at Loews 84th Street Six, at Broadway. Information: 873-6591 or 799-0675. ''THE HELLO SHOW,'' a performance by Larry Engler's Poko Puppets, at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $12. Information: 427-6000.

title: Hey, What's Rap but the Blues of the 80's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Death of Outpatient In Brooklyn Hospital Under Investigation
description: The Chief Medical Examiner's office is investigating the death of a man who passed out and died in a psychiatric emergency room at a Brooklyn hospital Wednesday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Joseph J. Oroshi, 74, Retired Pastor in Bronx
description: Msgr. Joseph J. Oroshi, for 25 years spiritual leader of 20,000 Albanian Catholics in the Bronx, died of liver cancer Wednesday at the Albert Einstein-Weiler division of the Montefiore Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Honor for Moynihan
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, long engaged in rescuing and preserving historic buildings, will be honored by the National Building Museum at a dinner Wednesday for ''championing the quality in buildings and public places for over 25 years.''

title: Delta and Swissair To Form Venture
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. and Swissair said they would become partners to insure they remained competitive in the travel market of the future. The airlines will coordinate flight schedules to offer passengers fast connections on routes to and from North America. They will also share reservation systems and airport space and advertise their services jointly.

title: Quayle Defends Bush on Agenda, Saying the Critics Prefer 'Dazzle'
description: Vice President Dan Quayle charged today that critics of the Bush Administration were looking for ''razzle-dazzle'' rather than substance and said that news organizations were promoting shallow politics to suit the needs of broadcast news programs.

title: Ingram of Giants Testifies He Broke N.C.A.A. Rules
description: Mark Ingram, a Giants wide receiver, told a Federal jury here today that he knowingly violated National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations when he agreed to be represented by Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom. He also accepted loans from the agents before his eligibility at Michigan State had expired.

title: Levine Conducts
description: James Levine and members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra are to give a chamber music concert at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73d Street, on Sunday at 4 P.M. The program includes Ponchielli's Quintet for Winds and Piano, Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat,'' the Debussy Cello Sonata and Puccini's ''Chrysanthemums,'' for string quartet. Mr. Levine will play the piano in the Ponchielli and Debussy works, and will conduct the Stravinsky. Jerry Grossman is to be cellist in the Debussy. Admission is by contribution. Informatio: 870-2000.

title: Market Place; Ohio Mattress: A Value Puzzle
description: VALUING securities is a tricky business. No doubt that is why investment bankers are paid so much to do it.

title: Films of the Festival, From Iceland to Iran
description: The 18th New Directors/New Films series, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Department of Film of the Museum of Modern Art, begins tonight at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the museum, 11 West 53d Street. Tickets may be ordered by mail at the Film Society, 140 West 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10023, or purchased at the museum, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily. They are $6; $5 for members. Series tickets are $110; $90 for members. Some screenings are sold out. Information: 877-1800, extension 489. Tonight SOUND AND FURY (France). Directed by Jean-Claude Brisseau. With ''A Bitter Message of Hopeless Grief'' (United States), a short directed by Jonathan Reiss. At 6 P.M. Also tomorrow at 4 P.M. Both sold out. ROUGE OF THE NORTH (Taiwan). Directed by Fred Tan. At 9 P.M. Also tomorrow at 1 P.M. Tomorrow THE ERRORS OF YOUTH (Soviet Union). Directed by Boris Frumin. At 6:30 P.M. Also Sunday at 3:30 P.M. Both sold out. DETAILS OF A DUEL (Colombia). Directed by Sergio Cabrera. At 9 P.M. Also Sunday at 1 P.M. Sunday THE MONEY JUGGLER and COMING OUT (United States). The first directed by Leo Rubinfien; the second by Ted Reed and Susan Bell. At 6 P.M. Also Monday at 8:30 P.M. Both sold out. A STRANGE PLACE TO MEET (France). Directed by Francois Dupeyron. At 9 P.M. Also Monday at 6 P.M. Both sold out.
