With ''Rabbit on the Moon'' (Australia), a short film directed by Monica Pellizzari. At 8:30 P.M. Also on Wednesday at 6 P.M. Thursday ROMANCE (Brazil). Directed by Sergio Bianchi. At 6 P.M. Also on March 26 at 8:30 P.M. KOMITAS (West Germany). Directed by Don Askarian. At 9 P.M. Also on March 25 at 1 P.M. Next Friday SUMMER VACATION: 1999 (Japan). Directed by Shusuke Kaneko. At 6 P.M. Also on March 26 at 3:30 P.M. LET'S GET LOST (United States). Directed by Bruce Weber. At 8:30 P.M. Also on March 25 at 3:30 P.M. Both sold out. March 25 MR. UNIVERSE (Hungary). Directed by Gyorgy Szomjas. At 6:30 P.M. Also on March 27 at 8:30 P.M. MORGAN'S CAKE (United States). Directed by Rick Schmidt. With ''Semper Fi'' (United States), a short directed by Geoffrey Luck. At 9 P.M. Also on March 26 at 1 P.M. March 26 THE PEDDLER (Iran). Directed by Mohsen Makhmalbaf. At 6 P.M. Also on March 27 at 6 P.M. March 28 EVENING BELL (China). Directed by Wu Ziniu. At 6 P.M. Also on March 29 at 8:30 P.M. FOXTROT (Iceland). Directed by Jon Tryggvason. At 8:30 P.M. Also on March 29 at 6 P.M. March 30 JOE LEAHY'S NEIGHBORS (Australia). Directed by Robin Anderson and Bob Connolly. With ''A Day and a Half'' (Australia), a short film directed by Michael Karris. At 6 P.M. Also on April 2 at 3:30 P.M. HOW TO GET AHEAD IN ADVERTISING (Britain). Directed by Bruce Robinson. With ''The Power'' (Yugoslavia), a short directed by Zdravko Barisic. At 9 P.M. Also on April 1 at 3:30 P.M. Both sold out. March 31 PLAFF! (Cuba). Directed by Juan Carlos Tabio. With ''Jau,'' a short film directed by Enrique Colina. At 6 P.M. Also on April 1 at 6 P.M. Both screenings sold out. LITTLE VERA (Soviet Union). Directed by Vasily Pichul. At 9 P.M. Also on April 1 at 12:30 P.M. Both sold out. April 1 SURNAME VIET GIVEN NAME NAM (United States). Directed by Trinh T. Minh-ha. At 9 P.M. Also on April 2 at 6:30 P.M.

title: Ex-Weapons Worker Indicted In Theft of Hundreds of Guns
description: A former weapons factory employee was arrested today on charges that he headed a group that stole up to 300 shotguns from a factory and sold them to drug dealers and other criminals.

title: Fokker Expecting A Big U.S. Order
description: The Dutch plane maker Fokker said American Airlines would order up to 149 Fokker 100 airliners worth $3.12 billion, making it the largest industrial order for a Dutch company. American, based in Fort Worth, declined to confirm the report. ''All I can tell you is we have talked to the Fokker people about airplanes,'' a spokesman said.

title: Senate Panel Gives Cheney Unanimous Approval
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously endorsed the nomination of Representative Dick Cheney to be Secretary of Defense today, praising his ''high standards of personal conduct and integrity.''

title: Berkshire Hathaway Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included investment gains of $85,829,000 for the latest year and $19,806,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Bent Sickle
description: The fertility of fields is declining. . . . Mismanagement is responsible for the loss of up to 20 percent of everything raised. . . . Sometimes one has to travel scores, even hundreds of kilometers to benefit from elementary services or buy primitive necessities. . . . The situation is so grave in many regions that people are deserting the land.

title: Two Rangers Injured
description: The Rangers, eight regular-season games away from the start of the playoffs, added two injuries to their nagging list in the wake of Wednesday night's 6-3 loss to the Winnipeg Jets. Both Brian Leetch and David Shaw left the game with injuries. Leetch, the sensational rookie defenseman, suffered a hip injury and will be out a minimum of a week. Shaw, who has the best defensive rating on the team, sprained a shoulder and his condition is uncertain.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; F.C.C. Overturns Ruling On Video Cigarette Ads
description: The Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that a new technology to send advertising by telephone wires to in-store video monitors cannot be used for cigarette advertising. The unanimous decision overturned a 1986 staff ruling by the commission that it had no jurisdiction over the system, created by the Marketing Technologies Group Inc. in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Taxes Fail to Cover Drinking's Costs, Study Finds
description: Taxes on cigarettes cover the costs imposed on society by smoking, but taxes on alcohol do not pay for the costs of drinking, a new study reports.

title: At the Movies
description: Underwater Camp

title: A Selection of Activities Celebrating Women's History
description: In and near Manhattan, National Women's History Month is being celebrated with special activities. Many are listed in the free Women's History Month calendar published by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, 52 Chambers Street, Suite 207, New York, N.Y. 10007; 566-3833. Here is a selection of events. Today ''CELEBRATION '89,'' Interchurch Center Gallery, 475 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street. An exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculpture by members of the National Association of Women Artists; curator, Dorothy Cochran. Through April 7. Gallery hours are Mondays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Free. Information: 870-2931. LUCY HODGSON, SoHo 20 Gallery, 469 Broome Street. Sculpture. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 6 P.M. Free. Information: 226-4167. ''UNVEILING CENTRAL ASIA,'' Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. A three-day festival of films by women from Soviet Central Asia. Different programs today, March 24 and 31, at 3 and 7 P.M. Admission to individual programs, $6; series tickets, $16. Information: 288-6400, extension 286. ''AMERICAN WOMEN OF THE 19th AND 20th CENTURIES: A CONCERT OF SONGS AND POETRY, City University of New York Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. 8 P.M. Performance by Common Ground. Free. Information: 790-4554. ''LORINE NIEDECKER: UNSUNG, UNDAUNTED POET,'' Apple Corp Theater, 336 West 20th Street. Through March 26. Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 P.M.; Saturdays, 2 and 8 P.M.; Sundays, 3 P.M. Admission $18 weeknights and matinees, $20 weekends. Information: 382-2750. ''OUTBACK NO. 29: WOMEN,'' presented by Spoke the Hub Dancing at the Gowanus Arts Exchange, 295 Douglass Street, in Brooklyn. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. A three-day festival of dance by 14 female choreographers. Admission: $10; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: (718) 596-5250. SNUG HARBOR, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. ''Women's Work,'' at the Veterans Memorial Hall. Four films by women. Tonight at 8. Free. Dance by Victoria Vadala at the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, Sunday, 2 P.M. Suggested donation, $1. Information: (718) 448-2500. Tomorrow NEW YORK OPEN CENTER, 83 Spring Street. ''The Women in Arthurian Legend,'' a workshop, tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $70. ''The Mysteries of Isis,'' a workshop on the goddess Isis, Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $70. Admission to both workshops (led by Gareth Knight): $120. Information: 219-2527. ''WOMANDANCE,'' presented by the Eleo Pomare Dance Company at the Vital Arts Center, 33 East 18th Street. Dyane Harvey, tomorrow, 7:30 P.M. Joe Nash, dance historian, and the Pomare Women, Sunday at 5:30 P.M. Admission to each concert, $5. Reservations: 475-1065 or 1297. JAZZ TRACK, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. Toshi Reagon, blues singer and guitarist, with her band, and LadyGourd Sangoma, vocal-African percussion quartet, in ''Movin' On Up: Migration Blues and African Rhythms,'' tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Admission: $12.50. Information: 645-2387. Sunday ''SUNDAY AT THE METROPOLITAN,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art. Films on Louise Nevelson and other female artists; ''The New Woman/New Sculpture 1900-1930,'' lectures by Joan Marter and Nanette Salomon. Sunday, 11:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Free. Suggested museum admission is $5 for adults, $2.50 for students and the elderly. Information: 879-5500.

title: Housing Construction Declines 11.4%
description: Housing construction plummeted 11.4 percent in February, a decline that analysts attributed to colder weather and higher mortgage interest rates.

title: Boston Journal; City's Irish Newcomers Are Illegal, but Not Alien
description: When Sister Veronica Dobson opened a pastoral center for illegal young Irish immigrants in this city last September, she had no trouble getting the word out: All she did was stop by one of the neighborhood pubs that are gathering places for the ''new Irish'' of Boston.

title: Wall St. Analyst Guilty in Murder Of Second Wife
description: A former Wall Street securities analyst was found guilty of murder today in the strangling and beating of his second wife in their summer home in Amagansett, L.I., in 1987.

title: Petrie Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $57,000,000 gain on the extinguishment of long-term debt.

title: ANNUAL RACE FOR CLERKS BECOMES A MAD DASH, WITH JUDICIAL DECORUM LEFT IN THE DUST
description: The once-decorous process by which Federal judges select their law clerks has degenerated into a free-for-all in which some of the nation's most eminent judges scramble for the top law school students.

title: Moscow Cites Danger Of Wider Afghan War
description: The Soviet Union's top official in Afghanistan said today that the United States and Pakistan were threatening to plunge neighboring countries into a regional conflict with their support of the guerrilla attack on the city of Jalalabad.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: National Credit Card Trust 1989-3, a special-purpose subsidiary of Citicorp, is offering $1 billion of debt securities backed by Visa and Mastercard receivables from Citibank South Dakota and Citibank Nevada through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Horn & Hardart Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $1,806,000 for the quarter and $3,838,000 for the year. The company said 1988 year included $18,300,000 charge related to the restructuring of the company's restaurant operations.

title: Pick Today or Any Day As a Holiday in New York
description: New Yorkers drink champagne on New Year's and eat turkey on Thanksgiving. But what are they supposed to do on Freedom of Information Day - demand to see a government document?

title: Something Is Happening
description: CORRECTION: In a recent column suggesting a ban on the sale to civilians of military-type assault rifles, the favorite tool of the drug killers, I called them automatic weapons. Wrong.

title: Seagram Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the increase in net income reflected the strength of the company's beverage business and the particularly good results reported by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., in which Seagram holds about a 22.9 percent interest. The company also attributed the improvement to the acquisitions of Tropicana and Martell as well as significant growth in its international business.

title: Emotions and History Tied to Colt Abandonment of Semiautomatics
description: Through thousands of television and movie westerns and more than a century of intimate involvement with the United States military, the name Colt Firearms has become emotionally and historically loaded with meaning.

title: Senate Refuses to Drop Charges Against a Judge
description: The Senate today refused to dismiss impeachment charges that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami conspired to get a $150,000 bribe and later lied about it at his trial.

title: Bush Talks to Shuttle Crew, Praising Orbiting of Satellite
description: President Bush talked with the Discovery astronauts today as their shuttle orbited 184 miles above the Earth, praising their work and pledging his support for a proposed $25 billion space station.

title: Emergency Is Declared Over Drought
description: New York City and 11 other downstate counties were officially declared to be in a drought emergency in an executive order signed yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The order authorized New York State's Disaster Preparedness Commission to require municipalities to severely restrict water consumption, including placing a ban on watering lawns and washing cars and sidewalks and shutting off all ornamental fountains, even those that recycle water.

title: Los Angeles Bonds' Top Yield Is 7.45%
description: A refunding of about $206 million of securities by the Los Angeles Department of Airports through competitive bid offers a maximum yield of about 7.45 percent for an issue due in 2010. The underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: John P. Scripps, 76, Newspaper Executive
description: John P. Scripps, founder and chairman of the board of the John P. Scripps Newspapers division of the Scripps Howard media group, died of heart failure Wednesday night at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla. He was 76 years old.

title: Boy, 11, Takes Pistol to Class
description: An 11-year-old boy was arrested today after he carried a loaded semiautomatic pistol into an elementary school, the police said. The boy, whose name was not released because of his age, was arrested at Shelter Rock Elementary School after a teacher found the 9-millimeter pistol in a gym bag on the floor of a classroom, said Lieut. Arthur Sullo of the Danbury police. He said the pistol was loaded with 10 rounds. ''We don't know why he brought the gun to school other than it might have been a show-and-tell-type incident done to impress peers,'' Lieutenant Sullo said.

title: From Lord & Taylor To Elder-Beerman
description: Stuart M. Glasser, executive vice president for merchandising at Lord & Taylor, has been named president and chief executive of the department-store division of the Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation of Dayton, Ohio.

title: Sprinter Suggests Johnson Was Misled
description: Ben Johnson might have taken stanozolol, the anabolic steroid found in his urine at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, within 22 days of the 100-meter final without knowing it, one of his former teammates told a Canadian Government inquiry today.

title: Allied Products Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the prior year results are restated to reflect retroactive consolidation of finance units previously accounted for on the equity method. The company also said the adoption of the accounting change decreased the 1987 loss by $843,000.

title: Steven Koweity, Pediatrician, 74
description: Dr. Steven Koweity, a pediatrician, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Sand Lake Hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Searingtown, L.I.

title: Budget Sword Hangs Over Schools for Disabled
description: Christina Martin, a ninth grader at the Rochester School for the Deaf, knows what it would be like to go to a local public school where everybody else could hear, because she tried it a few years ago.

title: Carletonville Journal; 'Whites Only' Is One Thing the Blacks Won't Buy
description: ''We are not living in the 1950's any longer. It is we blacks who have got the economic buying power now, and we can make the whites feel the pinch.''

title: 300 Try to Uproot a Fence at Aliens' Center
description: Nearly 300 refugees detained by the Immigration and Naturalization Service at Port Isabel, Tex., tried to pull the chain link fence out of the ground this afternoon before the police stopped them, witnesses said.

title: Let Britain Look to Irish Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: A G.I. IN GERMANY ACCUSED OF SPYING
description: An American soldier who vanished for 11 days has been charged with providing East Germany with American plans for defending the border against a Soviet bloc assault, the Army said today.

title: China Rebuffs U.S. Scrutiny Of Policy on Family Planning
description: China rejected American scrutiny of its family-planning programs today, saying it was a nation's sovereign right to determine its own population policy.

title: Basic Issues Still Face Bush on Japan Jet Deal
description: Although the Bush Administration will proceed with plans to let Japan build an advanced version of the F-16 fighter, ''at least three or four basic issues'' on sharing of the aircraft technology remain for Presidential decision, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today.

title: F.D.I.C. Takes Over 47 More Savings Units
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had taken over 47 insolvent savings and loan associations in five states with assets of $6.8 billion.

title: Review/Film; In a Bordello, Innocence Mixes With Experience
description: The theme of the delightful Hungarian fantasy film ''A Very Moral Night,'' made in 1977 and now playing at the Public Theater, could well be innocence, even if the action does take place in a bordello. It is a good bordello, so sweet and wholesome that it seems a place of pure beauty and Eden-like charm. The establishment is presided over by a handsome madam who takes her girls to the theater and strokes their cheeks with motherly kindness.

title: Books of The Times; The Making of a Prime Minister
description: Harold Macmillan Volume I, 1894-1956. By Alistair Horne Illustrated. 535 pages. Viking. $24.95.

title: Heart Study Hails an Older Drug
description: A new drug once described as a possible replacement for digitalis is not as good as the 200-year-old standby for controlling congestive heart failure, a study concludes.

title: Herbert A. Brandon, Publisher, 76
description: Herbert A. Brandon, the former publisher of Brandon's Shipper and Forwarder, a trade publication for the shipping industry, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: With Fans Watching, Siena Shocks Stanford
description: They had not played in front of a crowd in more than five weeks because of an outbreak of measles. Making their first appearance ever in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, they were seeded No. 14 in the East Regional. And after squandering a 16-point second-half lead, they saw their stellar playmaker misfire twice in the final minute on one-and-one free throws that could have put the game away.

title: Ginnie Mae Has a Default in Texas
description: The Government National Mortgage Association had its largest default to date in January, when a Houston savings association missed its scheduled monthly payment on a $2.4 billion portfolio of agency-backed securities. Details of the default were made public this week by Real Estate Finance Today, a publication of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, and confirmed today by Federal officials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He has to be everybody's President, not just the N.R.A.'s President.'' - Hugh Brock, a gun dealer, on Government curbs on the import of assault rifles. [ A18:2. ]

title: Brewers' Goal: Stay Healthy
description: A Milwaukee Brewers executive, Ray Poitevint, walked into Manager Tom Trebelhorn's office the other day and tried to be helpful. ''You need first aid or the Red Cross here?'' he asked.

title: Circle K Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $5.5 million from an accounting change.

title: No Vengeance Against Wright
description: Dick Cheney, whose nomination will sail through the Senate in about an hour, is just what we need at the Pentagon. He is an experienced, tough professional who won't be intimidated by defense contractors, Congress or the Soviets.

title: Second-Half Rally Lifts Michigan St. Over Kent St.
description: Steve Smith scored 28 points to lead Michigan State to an 83-69 victory over Kent State tonight in a first-round National Invitation Tournament game.

title: All Irish, All Immigrants
description: Years ago Robert Briscoe, the Jewish Lord Mayor of Dublin, came to visit this country and was greeted with a parade. ''What's going on?'' a little old lady asked. When parade watchers told her, she was dumbfounded. ''The Jewish Lord Mayor of Dublin! Why, only in America!''

title: Gottschalks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The company said the latest and prior year nets included benefits of $166,000, or 2 cents a share, and $689,000, or 8 cents a share, respectively, from a change in accounting method. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Nixon to Retire
description: Norm Nixon, who faded from the National Basketball Association limelight after he was traded from the Los Angeles Lakers to the Clippers in 1983, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: On Eve of Tough Campaign, Koch Says He's Heterosexual
description: One day after he declared on a radio talk show that he was a heterosexual and vowed never to discuss the subject again, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday nearly kept his pledge.

title: Pilots Assert Eastern Transferred Airport Slots Before Bankruptcy
description: Officials of the Eastern Airlines pilots' union released documents yesterday that they said show that the day before the airline filed for bankruptcy it transferred ownership of eight landing slots at La Guardia Airport in New York and eight at National Airport in Washington to Continental Airlines, Eastern's sister airline.

title: Clearwater Leads at 65
description: There was a time not long ago when J. C. Snead said of the Tournament Players Club course, ''They ruined a perfectly good swamp.''

title: Texaco Sets New 'Pill' To Block Takeovers
description: Texaco Inc. yesterday announced a new ''poison pill'' defense to block anyone who might try to take over the huge oil company.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Home Section yesterday about three influences on modern American style omitted the name of the designer of F. Schumacher & Company's ''Eisenhower Toile'' fabric. She is Elizabeth Draper.

title: Some Tour Operators File for Bankruptcy
description: Travel industry executives said yesterday that several tour operators who had sold tour packages based on flights on Eastern Airlines have declared for bankruptcy since Eastern machinists went on strike two weeks ago. An undetermined number of travelers have been left with little financial recourse except to file as creditors in the bankruptcy proceedings involving the tour operators.

title: John Van Buren, 57, Hofstra Administrator
description: John Van Buren, the former dean of Hofstra University's School of Education, died of liver cancer Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 57 and lived in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Small-Business Aid In Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency, which said in June that it intended to issue taxable commercial paper to support interim financing for small businesses, said yesterday that it had completed the first transaction under the program.

title: Japonica Nominees For CNW Board
description: The New York investment partnership Japonica Partners L.P. has sent the CNW Corporation a list of eight candidates to replace the board of the Chicago-based railroad holding company at its annual meeting on May 16. Japonica has said it would wage a proxy fight for control of CNW's board and then consider breaking up or selling the company.

title: But What Do You Really Think?
description: There is an old Russian saying that when the sturgeons feed, the minnows scatter. Or if there isn't, there should be.

title: COMMITTEE BACKS BAKER-AIDE CHOICE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to approve the nomination of Lawrence S. Eagleburger as Deputy Secretary of State, defusing a conflict over his relationship with two consulting firms headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Premier Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said net earnings were affected by lower investment income as a result of a $116,000,000 cash distribution to shareholders in November 1988.

title: Joseph Carroll, Writer And Editor, Dies at 77
description: Joseph Carroll, an author, editor, journalist and prominent figure in the Irish-American arts, died of congestive heart failure March 7. He was 77 years old.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the world's greatest players were on the sidelines today at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals after suffering a big upset by a small margin in the second round of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams.

title: Space Theme in a Children's Concert at Fisher Hall
description: Dino Anagnost is to conduct the Little Orchestra Society in a children's concert with a space theme at Avery Fisher Hall at 11j A.M. tomorrow. The program, ''A Musical Journey Through Time and Space,'' includes an excerpt from Richard Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra''; John Williams's ''Star Wars'' Suite; ''Mars'' from Gustav Holst's ''Planets'' and Otto Luening's ''Fantasy in Space.'' There will also be three New York premieres: Peter Schickele's ''Zoo Called Earth,'' Bernard Rogers's ''Musicians of Bremen'' and Geoffrey Briggs's ''Comets.'' The Hudson Vagabond Puppets will participate, and Dr. R. Lynn Bondurant, chief of educational services for the NASA Lewis Research Center for Space and Science Education and director of curriculum and evaluation for the Challenger Center in Washington, will narrate. The performance will be repeated at 1 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Zairean Shakers

title: Restaurants
description: There is something wonderfully primordial about watching Madison Avenue moguls roll up their shirtsleeves and tear into slabs of roasted lamb with their hands, then lick their fingers and snag a clump of cauliflower along with some barbecued shrimp. This peculiar scene unfolds daily at Bukhara, the Indian restaurant that specializes in what is called frontier cooking. While it may not be the most appropriate place for a business lunch to review scripts for the new advertising campaign, Bukhara has a lot going for it as an exotic dining spot serving some provocative food.

title: Review/Art; A Show's Instructive Provocation
description: ''Toward Form'' is a nice little show. It is about process. Its selections are revealing. Although there are no major works, visitors to the Greenberg Wilson Gallery are likely to come away knowing more than before about all six artists.

title: DWG Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $753,000 and $1,103,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,026,000 for the quarter and $6,518,000 for the 9 months; a tax credit of $173,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and realized gains on the sale of securities of $92,000 and $165,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Parade Today
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade starts at 11:30 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue. It heads north on Fifth to 86th Street and then east to Third Avenue. It is expected to finish about 3:30 P.M.

title: Lilting About Manhattan, The Tunes Of Ireland
description: One thing to celebrate on St. Patrick's Day weekend is the vitality of Irish traditional music - the jigs, reels and Kerry slides for dancing, the harp tunes, ballads and slow airs for listening. Around the world, traditional music is under siege by broadcast mass-marketed pop and rock. Although Ireland has its share of U2 wanna-bes, the Irish and their diaspora in Britain and the United States have held onto old-fashioned instruments like the fiddle, accordion, pennywhistle, bodhran (hand drum) and uileann pipes (Irish bagpipes) to play a vast traditional repertory.

title: Industrial Operating Rate Drops
description: The nation's industrial operating rate declined last month for the first time since September, but economists and analysts said it was too soon to tell whether this signaled a sustained easing of inflationary pressures.

title: Carson Pirie Posts a Loss
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, a large Midwestern retailer, Wednesday reported a loss for its fourth quarter and the full year just ended and said it would divest itself of its CPS Direct Marketing business in Phoenix. For the fourth quarter ended

title: Sea Containers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $42 million pretax gain on the sale of real estate. c-Net income Latest fourth-quarter results included special provisions relating to rationalization and asset writedowns totaling $20,000,000 and a $2,000,000 gain on the sale of real estate. Year-ago fourth quarter results included special provisions relating to rationalization and asset writedowns totaling $2,000,000.

title: Amvestors Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said net investment income for the latest year was $75 million, compared to $35.3 million last year. The results have been restated to reflect adoption of SFAS 97.

title: INSIDE
description: Votes on 2 Nominees, And More About Tower

title: U.S. Again Demands Release Of Hostage Held in Lebanon
description: Terry A. Anderson began his fifth year as a hostage in Lebanon today, and the Bush Administration called his detention a ''criminal act which serves no cause'' and demanded his release.

title: U.S. and Laos Plan a Search For 547 Missing Servicemen
description: The Laotian Government has agreed to go forward with a joint search for 547 missing American servicemen that was delayed two weeks ago because of a dispute over an American drug report, the State Department said today.

title: For Illegal Irish Immigrants, A Time to Test That Luck
description: Young Irish immigrants in a steady stream climbed a flight of stairs above Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, last Tuesday to try their luck in the Federal Government's latest organized immigration gamble - a lottery that promises legal status to a happy few.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Struggle To Make It In New York
description: IN advertising, as in the theater, a smashing out-of-town tryout does not mean an act will succeed on Broadway. Struggling to prove itself an exception to the rule, Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein has discovered that patience is one of several lessons it can impart.

title: Top Teamster Informer Told F.B.I. That McCarthy Asked Mafia Help
description: Evidence amassed by the Federal authorities for the canceled teamster racketeering trial in New York included an allegation that William J. McCarthy, now president of the union, sought Mafia help to get a high union job four years ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Koninklijke Ahold NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and had been translated at the Dec. 30, 1988 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dfl. 2.00. Ahold's latest periods consisted of 12 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year; year-ago quarter had 13 weeks and the 1987 year had 53 weeks.

title: Baker's Remarks on P.L.O. Upset Israel
description: Israel's Foreign Minister called Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday to complain about the Secretary's statements before Congress that Israel might one day have to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israeli officials said today.

title: Blasts of Color and Invention in Paris
description: The fall and winter fashion collections opened here Wednesday with an explosive blast of color and invention. The starting teams were a medley of Japanese, French and American players; Italians will show later. It is fashion with a global sweep.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 18 about political developments in Liechtenstein described the country's history incorrectly. Formed in 1719, the principality was part of the Rhine and German confederations between 1806 and 1866.

title: A Law School Scorned
description: It has become an annual ritual among law deans: Magazines publish surveys ranking the top schools, the winners spread the good news and the losers profess disdainful indifference.

title: Failure to Publicize Warning on Terror Assailed in Britain
description: The Transport Minister came under attack in Parliament Thursday for withholding from the public Government warnings sent to airlines and airports last November and December about terrorist bombs in radio-cassette players. Such a bomb brought down a Pan Am jumbo jet in Scotland in December.

title: Review/Film Festival; Taiwanese 'Rouge of The North'
description: The Chinese these days are not given to looking sentimentally at their violent and troubled 20th-century history, and Fred Tan, the young Taiwanese director whose film ''Rouge of the North'' is playing tonight and tomorrow as part of the New Directors/New Films series, is no exception. ''Rouge of the North'' depicts the empty formalities and useless customs, the cruelty and resignation that many of China's most important writers, particularly in the 1920's and 30's, saw as the fatal flaws of their society. The film in this respect bears some similarity to the novels of Ba Jin, whose depictions of family life in Shanghai - also the imaginary setting of Mr. Tan's film - inspired whole generations of Chinese youths to throw out the stifling, authoritarian, ancestor-worshipping old ways and usher in something new.

title: DISPUTED EXHIBIT OF FLAG IS ENDED
description: With the closing today of a student art exhibit that protesters said defiled the American flag, military veterans rolled up their own flags and said they would end daily demonstrations in front of the Chicago Institute of Arts.

title: Michigan Discussions?
description: The University of Michigan may have got in touch with Bob Knight, the Indiana basketball coach, about his suggestions for a coaching replacement. But it is unlikely that Michigan has begun talks about Knight's taking the job that Bill Frieder left Wednesday for Arizona State, according to Kit Klingelhoffer, the Indiana sports-information director.

title: Queens Merchants Win More Bus Service
description: The New York City Transit Authority has agreed to expand bus service in a Queens neighborhood after merchants there sued the authority, saying their businesses had suffered when bus routes were changed or eliminated.

title: Marquette Coach Out
description: Bob Dukiet was dismissed yesterday as Marquette University's coach after two consecutive losing seasons and several conflicts with players. Athletic Director Bill Cords said in a news release that Dukiet had been offered the position of assistant to the athletic director for the remaining three years of his contract.

title: Investor Sweetens Offer for SSMC
description: Refusing to concede defeat in his two-month effort to acquire SSMC Inc., Vincent Tan, the Malaysian investor, sweetened his offer for a controlling interest to $37 a share in cash, or a total of $181 million. SSMC, a sewing machine company based in Shelton, Conn., has accepted a $34-a-share offer from Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., a electronics company based in Hong Kong. A SSMC spokesman declined to comment on the new offer.

title: Whistle-Blower Bill Approved
description: The Senate today approved a bill to increase job protection for Federal workers who expose waste, fraud and abuse. A similar measure was killed last year by President Reagan when he let Congress adjourn without his taking action on it.

title: Review/Art; The Interplay of Real And Painted Forms
description: In her current exhibition at the Paula Cooper Gallery, Elizabeth Murray takes her art considerably beyond the end point of her recent retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art. The four paintings in this show, all dating from the last six months, are among the best this artist has ever made. They show her increasingly adept at using the elaborate artifice of painting - and abstraction - to probe some of life's underlying tensions.

title: OTB's Parlay Still an Unpopular Bet
description: Parlay betting, introduced to New York racing last fall, always seemed likely to prove more popular at OTB parlors than at the track. Lunchtime offtrack bettors were expected to like the idea of betting several races in advance, whereas on-track players could reinvest their own money.

title: TV Network Rule Lifted
description: The Federal Communications Commission repealed a rule today that had limited contracts between television networks and their local affiliate stations to two years. The F.C.C. said the rule, adopted in 1945 when TV networks were just forming and lining up local outlets for their programs, was no longer necessary to assist in the development of new TV networks in today's television industry of alternative delivery systems such as satellites and cable.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 460 money market mutual funds increased by $1.26 billion, to $296.55 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 138 institutional funds decreased by $213.6 million, to $72.47 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $913 million, to $96.11 billion. The 94 broker-dealer funds grew by $565 million, to $127.96 billion, the institute said.

title: Scrutinizing the Theory of a 'New' Rehnquist
description: Is there really a new Rehnquist?

title: Cabinet Fever
description: For decades, the United States managed to avoid the proliferation of cabinet positions that engulf other governments, keeping the total under a dozen. By comparison, China has 44, Japan 22, Britain 21. Indeed, Presidential study commissions have repeatedly urged simplifying the U.S. cabinet structure, creating, for instance, five supercabinet jobs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Holy Week Events, With Music and Drama
description: Here is a sampling of special Holy Week events in Manhattan, including performances of oratorios. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Today ALICE TULLY HALL. Music by Lassus, Weill, Ginastera; Schutz's ''German Requiem''; Luboff's ''Look to This Day,'' and other works; Musica Sacra Chorus, a capella and with cello, bass and organ; Richard Westenburg, director and with synthesizer. At 8 P.M. Tickets: $17.50. Information: 874-3104. COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY (St. Paul's Chapel), Amsterdam Avenue and 116th Street. ''The Easter Plays of William Butler Yeats''; Peter Royston, director; At 8:30 P.M. Also tomorrow at 8:30 and 10 P.M. Tickets: $5. Information: (718) 499-4368. LAMB'S THEATER, 130 West 44th Street. ''The Revelation of John,'' a one-man dramatic rendering of the entire book of Revelation, performed and directed by Tom Key. Through Sunday Today, 8 P.M.; tomorrow, 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday, 3 P.M. Tickets: $14; groups, $10. Information: 997-1780. MANHATTAN SCHOOL OF MUSIC, John C. Borden Auditorium, Broadway and 122d Street. Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites''; English translation by Joseph Machlis; the John Brownlee Opera Theater; Lou Galterio, director; the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra; Louis Salemno, conductor. At 8 P.M. Also Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets: $12 and $8. Information: 749-2802. Palm Sunday ALL SOULS UNITARIAN CHURCH, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. Handel's ''Messiah'' in its entirety. Performed by Musica Viva, chorus and Baroque orchestra; Betsy Rae Watson and Nonie Schuster, sopranos; Alexandra Montano and Jennifer Lane, altos; Thomas Baker and Stanley Warren, tenors; James Bingham and Christopher Schuman, basses; Walter Klauss, conductor. At 7 P.M. Tickets: $10. Information: 535-5530. CARNEGIE HALL, Verdi's Requiem; the American Symphony Orchestra; John Nelson, conductor; Leona Mitchell, soprano; Dolora Zajick, mezzo-soprano; Tonio Di Paolo, tenor; Jose Garcia, bass; the Pro Arte Chorale; Bart Folse, director. At 3 P.M. Preceded by a piano recital by Valery Bukrinski at 2 P.M. Tickets through Carnegie Charge: 247-7800. CHURCH OF THE EPIPHANY (Roman Catholic), 239 East 21st Street. Schutz's ''Passion According to St. Matthew''; the Epiphany Choir; Gail Archer, director. At 5 P.M. Information: 475-1966. FIRST BAPTIST CHURCH, Broadway and 79th Street. Faure's Requiem; First Baptist Church Choir; Wendy Sharp and Robert Mosley, soloists; Eric Birk, director. At 5:30 P.M. Information: 724-5600. Monday ALICE TULLY HALL, Bach Mass in B minor; Amor Artis Chorale and Amor Artis Orchestra; Ann Monoyios, soprano; Judith Malafronte, alto; Grayson Hirst, tenor; Andrew Schultze, bass; Johannes Somary, director and conductor. At 8 P.M. Information: 362-1900. Tuesday TRINITY CHURCH (Episcopal), Broadway and Wall Street. Music for the Lenten season. 1 P.M. The choir of Trinity Church. Larry King, organist and music director. Information: 602-0800. Good Friday BRICK PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, Park Avenue and 91st Street. Stainer's ''Crucifixion''; Brick Church Chancel Choir; Michael Best, tenor; John Darrenkamp, bass; David A. Weadon, organist and choirmaster. At 12:15 P.M. Information: 289-4400. CALVARY BAPTIST CHURCH, 123 West 57th Street. Brahms's ''German Requiem''; Calvary Choir and instrumental ensemble; Christine Carlton, soprano; Sidney Johnson, baritone; Paul Liljestrand, organist and choirmaster. At 7:30 P.M. Information: 975-0170. CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. ''Planctus Mariae,'' a medieval drama portraying the story of the three Marys at the base of the cross and ending with the ''Stabat Mater''; Elaine Russell, Cheryl Bensman, Karen Kruger, David Smith, soloists; Bruce Fifer, stage director; Paul Halley, music director; at 2 P.M. Information: 316-7563. Bach's ''Passion According to St. John''; the Cathedral Combined Choirs and Orchestra; Wilbur Pauley, Glenn Billingsley, David Smith, soloists; Ralph Lee and Bruce Fifer, stage directors; Paul Halley, conductor; at 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $12 and $18. Information: 662-2133. CHURCH OF ST. IGNATIUS LOYOLA (Roman Catholic), Park Avenue and 84th Street. Pergolesi's ''Stabat Mater''; the Chorus of Park Avenue Christian Church; Christina Casellato, soprano; Janice Edwards, mezzo-soprano; McNeil Robinson, conductor. At noon. Information: 288-3246. GRACE CHURCH (Episcopal), Broadway and East 10th Street. Bach's ''Passion According to St. Matthew''; Grace Church Choral Society, soloists and orchestra; Frank Cedric Smith, director. At 7:30 P.M. Suggested donation: $8. Information: 533-4653. MADISON AVENUE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, Madison Avenue and 73d Street. Schutz's ''Passion According to St. Matthew''; Daniel Egan, Richard Crist, Stephen Owen, soloists; John Weaver, organist and conductor. At noon. Information: 288-8920. MARBLE COLLEGIATE CHURCH (the Reformed Church in America), Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. Excerpts from Mozart's Requiem; Kevin Walters, director. At noon. Information: 686-2770. ST. PETER'S LUTHERAN CHURCH, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Bach's ''Passion According to St. Matthew''; St. Peter's Church Choir; Rosalind Rees, Judith Otten, Natasha Lutov, Andrea Reese, Thomas Howland and Rhys Ritter, soloists; Gordon Jones, organist and director. At noon. Information: 935-2200. Easter Sunday CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. ''Peregrinus,'' a medieval drama about the appearance of Christ on the road to Emmaus and to his disciples; the Cathedral Choristers; Wilbur Pauley, Cheyne Davidson, Frank Nemhauser, David Smith, soloists; Bruce Fifer, stage director; Paul Halley, organist and director. At 7 P.M. Information: 316-7540. CHURCH OF NOTRE DAME (Roman Catholic), 405 West 114th Street. Handel's ''Messiah,'' Parts II and III; the Ars Choralis Chorus and Orchestra; Pamela Conley, soprano; Stephen Schwartz, countertenor; Jason Oby, tenor; John Uehlein, baritone; David Schofield, director. At 2:30 P.M. Information: 866-1500. CHURCH OF ST. MARY THE VIRGIN (Episcopal), 145 West 46th Street. Gounod's ''Messe Solennelle''; Choir of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin and St. Mary's Orchestra; Kyler Brown, organist and director. At 11 A.M. Information: 869-5830. HOLY TRINITY LUTHERAN CHURCH, Central Park West and 65th Street. Cantatas by Bach; Nancianne Parrella, organist; Bach's Easter Oratorio, ''Kommt, Eilet und Laufet''; Holy Trinity Choir and Bach Orchestra; Phyllis Clark, soprano; Jacqueline Pierce, mezzo-soprano; Patrick Romano, tenor; Peter Stewart, baritone; Frederick Grimes, organist and director. At 5 P.M. Information: 877-6815.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis, said it would introduce a de-alcoholized beer, O'Doul's, in five Southern test markets next week.

title: Seton Hall Has A Simple Plan To Win It All
description: P. J. Carlesimo and Seton Hall have a blueprint that makes plenty of sense to them as they enter the school's second National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament since the Pirates began playing basketball in 1903. It unfolds this way: We're the third-seeded team in the West Regional with a 26-6 record and play Southwest Missouri State (21-9) Friday in McKale Center at the University of Arizona. The No. 3 seeding means we're one of the top 12 teams in the country. And if you're in the top 12 of 64 teams competing, well, you've got an awfully good chance to win the whole thing. So, why not win it? Simple enough. A Different Approach for the Pirates Seton Hall's tournament approach is a long way from last season's when the Pirates beat Texas El-Paso and then lost to Arizona in the second round of the West Regional.

title: Auctions
description: Works From Japan

title: Jamesway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The company said the latest periods' earnings were adversely affected by pretax LIFO charges of $1,545,000 for the quarter and $3,830,000 for the year. This compared with pretax LIFO charges of $685,000 for the year- ago quarter and $1,614,000 for 1988.

title: Revised Probation Program To Require Drug Treatment
description: Faced with growing numbers of drug abusers on probation, the New York City Commissioner of Probation outlined an expanded program yesterday that will identify substance abusers on probation and require them to seek treatment.

title: Review/Film; Horror in the Depths, On a Sunken Soviet Ship
description: It's one thing to blame the Russians for behind-the-scenes chicanery in Vietnam, as George P. Cosmatos did when he directed ''Rambo: First Blood, Part II. '' It's quite another to blame them for mutant undersea monsters, which is what Mr. Cosmatos's new ''Leviathan'' does.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sino

title: Shoreham's Lesson: We Need a Qualified Nuclear Administrator
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Inside Stuff
description: Lynne V. Cheney, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the wife of Representative Dick Cheney, called The Washingtonian magazine this week with a bit of old but still good inside stuff.

title: 'Raisin in the Sun' Still Speaks of Black Family; Another Name Change
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Shoe Is Sued Over Sale of Unit
description: A shareholder of the United States Shoe Corporation is suing the company, contending that it made false statements regarding a proposed $422 million sale of its footwear division to Merrill Lynch & Company. The law firm of Greenfield & Chimicles said that the shareholder, Rajiv Kohli, had filed suit in United States District Court in Philadelphia, contending that the company; its chairman, Philip G. Barach, and the division's president, Howard Platt, had violated securities laws by making false statements starting in August 1988.

title: 3 U.S. Agencies, to Allay Public's Fears, Declare Apples Safe
description: Three Federal agencies, responding to growing public alarm about the safety of the chemical Alar, said in a statement today, ''The Government believes it is safe for Americans to eat apples.''

title: U.S. Halts Plan to Turn Off the Landsat Satellites
description: Two Landsat Earth-sensing satellites that were to be turned off at the end of the month for lack of money have been given a reprieve by the Bush Administration.

title: You Can't Win Them All; Knicks Halted at 26
description: The Knicks' 26-game winning streak at home, the third-longest in the National Basketball Association for a season, ended last night.

title: Looking For the Lumina
description: At Wrightsville Beach, on an island just off the mainland near here, a young man with a beard emerged from a small grocery store, carrying a packaged sandwich in his hand.

title: British Stance On Plessey
description: Britain's Ministry of Defense has opposed a revised joint bid by Britain's General Electric Company and Siemens A.G. of West Germany for the British military contractor Plessey P.L.C., military sources said.

title: Two Grapes, Two Decisions
description: Two poisoned Chilean grapes add another puzzling dimension to the menace of global terrorism. Warnings by public health authorities in Washington, Tokyo and Ottawa have brought Chile's huge fruit exports to a standstill, and Chilean fruit has been pulled off the market while inspectors investigate thousands upon thousands of crates.

title: Manor Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss c-Included a $5,696,000 gain from a change in accounting for taxes.

title: Assault Rifles Are Selling Like Blue-Chip Stocks
description: ''It's like the Oklahoma land rush,'' Mike Nichols, a gun collector, said as he stood in line here at Brock's Army Surplus store to buy one of the last semiautomatic assault weapons in stock. It was a Chinese-made SKS, a copy of the gun of his dreams, the AK-47 infantry rifle.

title:
About Real Estate;
Eight One-Family Homes Going Up in West Village
description: LEAD: Fewer than 1,900 private houses are left in Manhattan, and the number continues to dwindle as residences are converted into multi-family dwellings or demolished. But Ambassador Construction of Manhattan has gambled that there is a market in the borough for new single-family houses.

title: Australian Pianist
description: Kathryn Selby, a pianist from Australia, is to play works by Mendelssohn, Schubert, Chopin, Liszt, Debussy and John Corigliano at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $8.50 to $12.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: De Falla Trio
description: Teh De Falla Trio - Terry Graves, Dusan Bogdanovic and Kenton Youngstrom, guitarists - is to play music by Mr. Bogdanovic, Qilliam Boyce, Leonard Bernstein, Theolonious Monk, Mozart, Stravinsky and the ensemble's namesake, Manuel de Falla, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $10 to $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Spending Rises
description: Newspaper advertising spending rose 6.1 percent in 1988 over the previous year, according to an industry report, but the numbers will give little solace to jittery newspaper executives.

title: Hollinger Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $5 million. c-Included a special gain of $8 million. The company said some year-ago figures have been restated. Extraordinary items for 1988 included a $14.9 million tax credit, losses associated with redundancy payments made by the Daily Telegraph Plc., a non-recurring loss on rationalization of discontinued operations of Domgroup Ltd., and a gain on the sale of a printing division by Unimedia (1988) Inc. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Life Magazine Photos
description: ''Life: Through the 60's,'' an exhibition of 200 prints from the archives of Life magazine, will be on view through May 21 at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street. Eve Arnold, Carl Mydans, Alfred Eisenstaedt and Gordon Parks are among the 100 Life photographers represented. Hours are Tuesdays noon to 8 P.M.; Wednesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M., and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $3; $1.50 for students, and $1 for the elderly. Information: 860-1783.

title: Review/Dance; A Troupe With a Love Of Things Wiggly
description: Dancers swayed and slithered from side to side while scenery rose and fell on Wednesday night when the Trisha Brown Company presented three works from its repertory at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street, where it is performing through Sunday. All three were designed by artists, and in them Ms. Brown juxtaposed glorious choreographic blurs with moments of extraordinary clarity.

title: A.T.&T. IS GRANTED GREATER FREEDOM IN SETTING PRICES
description: In a move that further deregulates the telephone business, the Federal Communications Commission today changed its method of shaping long-distance rates, giving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company more freedom to set its own prices.

title: Ex-Radical Leader Sentenced
description: Huey Newton, the former leader of the Black Panther Party, was sentenced to 6 months in jail and 18 months of probation after pleading no contest to misappropriating $15,000 in public money earmarked for a school the party ran in the early 1980's. Mr. Newton, who is in prison for a parole violation, and Mark Alexander, the former chairman of the Oakland Community School, were accused of diverting for their own use as much as $300,000 in state grants intended for the school, which closed seven years ago.

title: Jersey Speaker Sprints for Governor's Job
description: Charles L. Hardwick is a blur of political images these days as he crisscrosses the state, trying to convert his power and influence as Speaker of the General Assembly into votes for governor in the Republican primary in June.

title: 46 Muslim Nations Oppose Iran's View On Rushdie's Death
description: Muslim nations rejected Iranian positions on both ''The Satanic Verses'' and Afghanistan today at the final session of a four-day conference.

title: Byrne Trial Prosecution Rests
description: Prosecutors rested their case yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens in the trial of three men charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer, Edward Byrne, in South Jamaica on Feb. 26, 1988. Prosecutors say Officer Byrne was killed by four men at the order of a drug dealer seeking retaliation against the police. Three of the four are on trial: Scott Cobb, 25 years old; Todd Scott, 20, and Philip Copeland, 23. The fourth suspect, David McClary, 23, will be tried separately.

title: Sears Gets Outside Designer For New Women's Apparel
description: For the first time, Sears, Roebuck & Company has appointed a major outside marketing and merchandising organization to develop a series of women's apparel lines.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, said William G. Lowrie had been promoted to executive vice president.

title: I.B.M. Unit Move
description: I.B.M. Japan Ltd., turning the tables on its Japanese competition, will sell mainframe computers that will be compatible with those of Fujitsu Ltd. and Hitachi Ltd., a spokesman for the International Business Machines Corporation said. The two companies have gained slightly more than half the domestic Japanese market with mainframes compatible with those of I.B.M. The I.B.M. division will offer 4300 and 3090 mainframes that can run software written for Hitachi and Fujitsu machines.

title: Oratorios, Hosannas and Glorias In Celebration of Easter
description: Holy Week, that solemn, inevitable progression in the Passion of Christ that proceeds from this weekend's Palm Sunday through Maundy Thursday and Good Friday to Easter Sunday, forms the culmination of the Christian year - and, by extension, the annual high point of Christian liturgical music. The sheer richness and variety of the church-music concerts and musically accompanied services to be heard in the next 10 days provides an opportunity to examine that liturgical world in the New York area, and in particular the extent and diversity of music making in Christian churches of every denomination that adhere to the Western classical tradition.

title: Stocks Move Higher, With Dow Up 20.17
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 20.17 points to close at 2,340.71.

Ossewaarde's ''Hosanna to the Son of David''; Friedell's ''Way to Jerusalem''; Bach's Toccata in D minor; Kevin Walters, director. At 11:15 A.M. Information: 686-2770. PARK AVENUE CHRISTIAN CHURCH (Disciples of Christ), 1010 Park Avenue. Works by Robinson and Anerio; McNeil Robinson, director. At 11 A.M. Information: 288-3246. RIVERSIDE CHURCH (Interdenominational), Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Music by Wyton and Friedell; the Riverside Choir. At 10:45 A.M. Information: 222-5900. ST. title: 'Raisin in the Sun' Still Speaks of Black Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Pioneers in the Wilds Of Commercial Video
description: ''Tapeheads'' sees the world of commercial video production as a new frontier, a wild and woolly place where rules don't exist yet and the pioneering spirit still prevails. It's a funny idea, one that might have been more so if the film had worked solely in that satirical vein. As it is, ''Tapeheads'' tacks on various cliched elements of intrigue - there's a blackmail plot against a political candidate - that dilute its humor. It works best when it's simply sending up the tricks of the video trade.

title: REview/Music; 2 Major Vila Sonatas
description: The viola can be a deeply poetic instrument - any good performance of Berlioz's ''Harold in Italy'' is proof of that. But given its intermediary status between the brilliance of the violin and the richness of the cello, the viola can also sound genteel and bland as a solo instrument. Within those muted terms, Rosemary Glyde's viola recital Monday night at Alice Tully Hall provided considerable pleasure.

title: Review/Film; James Ivory's Version Of Janowitz's 'Slaves'
description: It's unwise to wear an ashtray on your head unless you're certain you have more personality than the prop. This is one of the few valuable insights to be obtained from ''Slaves of New York,'' the film based on Tama Janowitz's short stories about various denizens of the downtown art scene, stories that amount to ashtray-wearing in a literary vein. At least Miss Janowitz provided a wisecracking narrative voice that helped to camouflage the fundamental inconsequentiality of her stories' concerns. The film has no workable equivalent for such showmanship.

title: No. 1-Seeded Sooners Struggle Past East Tennessee St., 72-71
description: Mookie Blaylock's baseline drive with 1 minute 21 seconds remaining today gave Oklahoma a 72-71 victory over East Tennessee State in the Southeast Regional.

title: Strict Constructions
description: Conservative judges hold that the Supreme Court should not reach out for controversy. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, uncharacteristically careless, tripped over that canon when she let her name be used in a political debate over religion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Media Business columns of Business Day on Tuesday, about advertising in The Wall Street Journal and Barron's, described the trend in advertising at The Journal incorrectly. Linage, not revenue, has declined for four years.

title: The Race for the Whip
description: It may seem the ultimate in inside baseball, but the race for minority whip in the House of Representatives is providing some of the best theater on Capitol Hill these days.

title: KEY RATES
Past: Adversity; Present: Dreams
description: They arrive this time each year, all at once, in cities and towns they have never seen before, and places they have dreamt about for weeks.

title: National Semiconductor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations from operations of Datachecker, net of income taxes, of $8.8 million and $28.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; both periods also included $45.1 million from a gain on the sale of Datachecker. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations from operations of Datachecker, net of income taxes, of $1.8 million and $5.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Sales represent net sales. On Jan. 22, 1989, NSC sold Datachecker Systems Inc. and certain subsidiaries involved in the manufacturing, marketing and servicing of point- of-sales systems and applications software (Datachecker). The operating results of Datachecker have been classified as discontinued operations for all periods presented. The earnings (loss) of the operations of Datachecker are net of income tax expense of $900,000 and $1 million for latest 3 and 9 months, respectively, and $200,000 and $700,000 for the corresponding periods in fiscal 1988, respectively. There is no income tax expense attributable to the gain on sale of Datachecker. The periods ended Feb. 28, 1988 have been restated to reflect the fiscal 1988 adoption and retroactive application of a change in accounting for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: Economic Scene; The Obstacles Facing Gorbachev
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV's call for a ''drastic restructuring'' of Soviet agriculture, aimed at increasing food production long term, could aggravate his country's immediate fiscal crisis. At a time of worsening agricultural shortages, Mr. Gorbachev has proposed a farm price increase next January, somewhat greater flexibility for farmers to negotiate the prices of what they sell and, ultimately, ''complete freedom'' to choose ways of marketing their products. ''We shall inevitably come to this, sooner or later,'' he said.

title: Maxicare Health Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the wounded giant of health maintenance organizations, filed yesterday for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer Spielvogel Loses Creative Work for CBS
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates lost its last piece of CBS's creative work yesterday when the network transferred its entertainment print assignment to Scott Mednick & Associates, a Los Angeles agency known primarily for graphic design.

title: TV Weekend; Tapping With Hines and Clapping With Bernstein
description: Winding down its current pledge period, public television goes for a couple of classy acts this weekend, both offered under the ''Great Performances'' umbrella. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, there is the hourlong Don Mischer Production called ''Gregory Hines's Tap Dance in America,'' a current state-of-the-art survey that gets you feeling good and keeps you that way until the taking-it-home finale.

title: Angry Youth In Festival Of New Films
description: ''SOUND AND FURY,'' the French writer and director Jean-Claude Brisseau's film about aimless adolescents drifting into violence in a working-class high-rise complex outside of Paris, has little of the bonhomie and sensuousness we tend to associate with French cinema.

title: Independent Films
description: The 22d annual Film and Video Festival of the Brooklyn Arts Council continues tomorrow in the Uris auditorium of the Metropolitan museum of Art, from 1 to 5 P.M. The festival focuses on independent film and video artists, and the program tomorrow features ''The Man Who Planted Trees,'' a 30-minute animated film by Frederick Back that won an Academy Award last year; Esther Duran's ''My Sin Is Loving You,'' a Brooklyn-made film that was selected as the festival's best narrative drama, and 11 other works. Tickets are free with museum admission. The final public screening of the series will be March 22 at 7 P.M. at the Brooklyn Union Gas auditorium, 195 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights. Information: (718) 783-3077.

title: Roy Hanson, Editor at Newsday, Dies at 54
description: Roy Hanson, a writer and editor at Newsday, died of lung cancer Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 54 and lived in Copiague, L.I.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The company said results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months are restated to give effect for a change in accounting for post-retirement medical benefits.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe in The Living Section on Wednesday, with an article about Irish cooking, omitted an instruction for colcannon. The leeks and milk should be folded into the potatoes along with the cooked cabbage, and then beaten until fluffy.

title: Carson Pirie Scott & Co reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 28
description: b-After a pretax charge of $3.6 million primarily related to closing of a store in Washington, D.C. for both the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $36,616,000 for the quarter and $40,642,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included net of $697,000 for the quarter and a loss of $35,397,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said the loss from discontinued operations for the latest fourth quarter included a pretax charge of $29.5 million primarily to reflect disposition of the CPS Direct Marketing unit. The company also said the loss from discontinued operations for 1988 year included an after-tax charge of $43.4 million for reorganization.

title: Dollar Finishes Day Mixed After Intervention Abroad
description: The dollar closed narrowly mixed yesterday against the major foreign currencies. Exchange dealers said trading slowed in New York after central banks in Europe intervened earlier to slow the dollar's rise.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 2
On Stage
description: 'Orpheus Descending'

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Anti-Drug Spots
description: The Hispanic community is the target of ads introduced Wednesday by the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America. The spots, which are part of the pro bono anti-drug campaign, will be shown on several Spanish-language television stations, including Univision and Telemundo. They will also be on English-language radio and television stations in cities with large Hispanic populations. The campaign will also feature print ads.

title: MEXICO ASSISTING IN U.S. PLAN TO CUT ILLEGAL MIGRATION
description: In a major but unacknowledged policy shift, Mexico is expanding its cooperation with American efforts to reduce the flow of illegal immigrants into the United States, officials here and along the border say.

title: A Time to Get Beyond Old Missile Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Law Teeth (and Using Them on Lawyers)
description: There are those in legal and public interest circles here who say that Daniel Sheehan has a messianic desire to uncover criminal conspiracies by conservatives and has long been a legal accident waiting to happen. There are others who say Mr. Sheehan is a maligned prophet deserving honor, not scorn from his peers.

title: Somoza's Soldiers Rejoining A Society Divided on Pardon
description: Armando Parajon Juarez's last act as a free man came on July 19, 1979, when he surrendered the holdout battalion of 400 National Guardsmen under his command to Sandinista guerrillas, who were then sweeping to victory across Nicaragua.

title: Astroland to Open
description: Astroland Amusement Park will open Sunday - weather permitting -and will be open on subsequent weekends until mid-June. Hours are noon to midnight Saturdays and Sundays. Astroland is at West 10th Street between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, brooklyn. Admission is free; individual rides cost $1 to $3. Information: (718) 265-2100.

title: Crucial Technologies: 22 Make the U.S. List
description: The Government has designated 22 technologies as critical to national security and ''the long-term qualitative superiority of U.S. weapons systems.''

title: A Car Industry Veteran Will Try to Revive Yugo
description: John A. Spiech has sold some exotic cars in his career, including the Lotus and the Ferrari. Now he will try to get the utilitarian Yugo moving out of showrooms.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Canadian Wins World Championship: Kurt Browning of Canada put on a dazzling display of jumping, including a trademark quadruple, to edge Chris Bowman of the United States for the men's gold medal yesterday at the world championships. Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland beat out Aleksandr Fadeyev of the Soviet Union to take the bronze.(AP) SWIMMING Fetter Breaks Mark: Leigh Ann Fetter of Texas broke the American and National Collegiate Athletic Association records in the 50-yard freestyle yesterday during preliminaries at the N.C.A.A. women's swimming and diving championships in Indianapolis, The 1988 United States Olympian was timed in 22.1 seconds, bettering the mark of 22.13 set by Tammy Thomas of Kansas in 1983. The Longhorns' sophomore advanced to the final at the Indiana University Natatorium. (AP) BOXING Rosario Wins by Knockout: Edwin Rosario, a former World Boxing Assocition and World Boxing Council lightweight champion, earned his 33d victory with a knockout of Larry Benson at the Felt Forum last night when the fight was stopped after five rounds of a scheduled 10-rounder. A bloody cut to the inside of Benson's left ear was judged by Dr. Barry Jordan of the New York State Athletic Commission to be too serious for the fight to continue. Rosario has a 33-3 record with 29 knockouts. Benson, from Lansing, Mich., is 17-13 with 8 knockouts. N.B.A. Celtics 111, Pacers 99Kevin McHale scored 36 points and Boston held Indiana scoreless for nearly four minutes late in the game as the visiting Celtics defeated the Pacers last night. It was the Celtics' fourth straight victory and their second in a row over the Pacers after Boston dropped its first two games of the season against Indiana. The Pacers suffered their fourth straight loss. (AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 2, Bruins 2 In Boston, Robert Picard's goal at 5 minutes 53 seconds of the third period lifted Quebec into a tie with the Bruins, enabling the Nordiques to avoid elimination in the chase for a playoff spot. Picard's goal came only 1:11 after Greg Hawgood had given Boston a 2-1 lead with a power-play score, his 14th goal of the season. The tie left Quebec 14 points behind fourth-place Hartford with eight games to play in the race for the last Adams Division playoff spot. (AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL St. Anthony and Elizabeth in Final: Bobby Hurley had 26 points, 7 assists and 6 rebounds to lead St. Anthony of Jersey City to a 69-54 victory of McCorristin Catholic of Trenton in the semifinals of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association Tournament of Champions last night before a crowd of 5,535 at the Rutgers Athletic Center. In Sunday's title game, the Friars (31-0), the top-ranked high school team in the nation, will face second-seeded Elizabeth (28-3), which routed Eastern Regional of Voorhees Township, 82-58.

title: A Fingerhold for Dissent in Salvador
description: In 1981, in a symbol of the army-linked repression that turned criticism of the right into a capital offense, the armed forces put a bounty on the heads of 138 leftists by publishing a list of their names and describing them as wanted traitors.

title: Milken's Woes Not on Menu
description: Hundreds of chief executives from the nation's most prestigious companies rose last night in hearty applause as Michael R. Milken, the embattled executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., moved to the podium at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign by Mensa
description: American Mensa, the society for people with high intelligence quotients, is taking to the airwaves with its first television advertising campaign. The Central South Carolina chapter of the organization has bought time on the network affiliates and the Cable News Network to attract new members. The spot, which will be shown through March 26, is designed to appeal to ''extraordinary'' viewers, a Mensa official said.

title: Deficit at First Fidelity
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, which stunned the banking community in December with the announcement of large problem loans at its new partner, the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, yesterday announced a loss of $176.2 million for the fourth quarter. In the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company lost $34.6 million. The fourth-quarter loss and the $235.3 million provision for loan losses that caused it were both near the middle of the range set by the company late last year. For all of 1988, First Fidelity earned $33.9 million, or 29 cents a share, down from $86.3 million, or $1.23 a share, in 1987.

title: Intelligent Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results included non-recurring expenses of $501,000 related to the company's acquisition of Entre Computer Centers on Dec. 19.

title: Shoney's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 19
description: b-Reduced by $16,178,000, or 43 cents a share, by interest expense related to the company's 1988 recapitalization. Latest-quarter results included a gain of $1,833,000, or 5 cents a share, on the sale of the company's investment in Restaurant Management Services Inc.

title: Child World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $2,853,000 credit from the cumualtive effect of an accounting change.

title: Mother Sentenced to Prison In Scalding Death of Her Son
description: A Manhattan woman was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of 20 years to life for scalding her 3-year-old son to death after he soiled his diaper.

title: Review/Music; Feltsman and Guarneri Play Schnittke Quintet
description: When Vladimir Feltsman arrived in the United States two years ago as a much-publicized emigre, he enjoyed a ready-made kind of success. Owing to his long and successful struggle to leave the Soviet Union, many listeners were naturally predisposed to admire him as a political hero and, by illogical extension, to believe in his greatness as a pianist. If such built-in acceptance was a gift, it also became a burden, arousing a show-me attitude in many serious listeners.

title: F.B.I. Document on Tower Cited 'Pattern of Alcohol Abuse'
description: The official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who supervised the background check on John G. Tower said in an internal briefing paper that the investigation found a ''pattern of alcohol abuse'' that Mr. Tower had taken steps to correct by 1983.

title: Holtzman Said to Want Goldin's Post
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn will likely seek the Democratic nomination for New York City comptroller, joining an already crowded primary that will almost certainly be as contentious as the Democratic mayoral contest.

title: U.S. Charges Salvador Guerrillas Get More Arms From Soviet Bloc
description: Senior United States officials here charged today that Cuba and Soviet-bloc countries had been upgrading the arsenal of the Salvadoran rebels to help them escalate their nine-year war against the American-backed Government.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: First Fidelity said results for 1988 reflected an annual provision of $289.5 million for possible loan losses and of that amount $235.3 million was allocated in the fourth quarter.

title: Greenspan Backs Shift On Debt
description: Apparently seeking to dispel reports of a conflict with the Treasury, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today endorsed the reorientation of the developing-world debt policy proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.

title: Review/Film Festival; A Quest for Knowing on the Outskirts of Paris
description: There's an intentionally dreamlike quality to the physical and emotional violence in Jean-Claude Brisseau's ''Sound and Fury'' (''De Bruit et de Fureur''), about a couple of young, none-too-bright boys trying to find order in a world that has none.

title: Execution Halted Indefinitely
description: R. Gene Simmons is back on death row today after a fellow inmate persuaded the United States Supreme Court to block Mr. Simmons's execution for the slayings of 14 members of his family.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campbell-Mithun-Esty's New York Chairman
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty yesterday named Richard Johnson as its New York chairman and chief creative officer. Since 1987, Mr. Johnson, 47 years old, has been the agency's Detroit president and chief creative officer and was a force in retaining the AMC/Jeep and Renault account for the agency and in building it to $150 million in billings.

title: Penguins Top Devils For a Spot In Playoffs
description: With Mario Lemieux out because of an injury, the Pittsburgh Penguins clinched their first playoff berth of the Lemieux era with a 2-1 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: Ball St. Upsets Pittsburgh; Arkansas, Louisville Gain
description: Ball State, seeded ninth in the Midwest Regional and cast as an underdog despite having the nation's best record and longest winning streak, gained a measure of respect tonight by upsetting eighth-seeded Pittsburgh, 68-64.

title: Mattingly Is Sidelined By Hamstring Injury
description: The suddenness of their troubles has not quite shaken the Yankees, but they no longer look like the team that began spring training. Dave Winfield is hurt. Ron Guidry faces surgery. There are trades being considered, and tonight Don Mattingly said that a strained muscle behind his left thigh would keep him out of the lineup for a few days. Can anything more go wrong? A trade between the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves, which looked imminent earlier this week, has likely been tabled. But it is still a possibility.

title: Elmer Lee Fingar, 84; Served on Estates Panel
description: Elmer Lee Fingar, a former partner in McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan, Drazen & Smith, a law firm in White Plains, died Tuesday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: An Activist's Story
description: In 1982, Dr. Neil Aggett - a white South African - was found hanged in a Johannesburg prison, where he had been detained for his work with a multiracial trade union. Dr. Aggett's political activism, his relationships with his father and girlfriend and his brutal treatment by prison authorities are chronicled in a new play by Hilary Blecher called ''Brightness Falling.'' The work is being presented today, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M., as part of the Arts at St. Ann's series, at 157 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (718) 834-8794.

title: Review/Film; Fletch Goes South
description: Michael Ritchie's ''Fletch Lives'' is the overly optimistic title of the follow-up to the far more entertaining 1985 Ritchie comedy ''Fletch,'' about a wise-cracking investigative reporter played by Chevy Chase. ''Fletch Lives'' looks less like ''Fletch 2,'' which it is, numerically speaking, than ''Fletch 7,'' the bitter end of a worn-out series.

title: The Teamsters Take It on the Chin
description: No heads rolled in the top echelons of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters as part of this week's settlement of the Justice Department's racketeering suit against the giant union.
