Since it was well known that the Government had originally intended to force at least five international vice presidents with strong mob ties to walk the plank as the price of a negotiated peace, many observers have concluded that once again the forces of law have wound up on the short end of a major contest with the underworld.

title: Tyson Raises Bid For Holly Farms
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the chicken processor that has pursued the Holly Farms Corporation since October, sweetened its tender offer to $63.50 a share, or $1.15 billion. In a letter to Holly's board, Tyson's chairman and chief executive, Don Tyson, raised the company's latest offer from $60 a share and conditioned it upon Holly ending a lock-up option with Conagra Inc., the Omaha-based food products giant.

title: Little Activity in Treasury Issues
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds traded in a very narrow range in continued light trading yesterday despite more reports that suggested the pace of economic growth might be losing some momentum.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Making Arrangements

title: Federal Funds Hard to Spend, New York's Lawmakers Find
description: What is the point of racing around Washington grabbing Federal dollars for New York City if bureaucratic gridlock prevents the city from using the money?

title: U.S. Offers $250,000 Reward In Drug Agent Killing on S.I.
description: The United States Justice Department yesterday offered a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of Constabile Farace, who is suspected of killing a Federal drug agent on Staten Island last month.

title: Esther Gilman Is Dead; Visual Artist Was 63
description: Esther Morgenstern Gilman, a painter, illustrator and set designer, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63 years old.

title: Giants Sign Center And Backup Safety
description: The Giants stayed active yesterday in the National Football League's player market by signing Greg Cox, a rookie backup safety for the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers. The Giants also reached agreement with Frank Winters, the Cleveland Browns' long snapper and backup center and the most sought of the 617 new free agents.

title: Anti-Bias Plan For Hospitals Wins Approval
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation approved a new employment plan yesterday to address repeated charges by black and Hispanic workers that its hiring and promotion practices are discriminatory.

title: Review/Dance; Athletic Rapture in Quirky Metaphorical Waters
description: Spring is virtually here, and the new modern dance season has reacted accordingly: vital juices are flowing. After Merce Cunningham and Trisha Brown, it is now Bill T. Jones who has come up with a new work that marks a new lease on inspired creativity.

title: Orrin Starr
description: Orrin jStarr, a banjo player, will lead his bluegrass band tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Tickets are $7.

title: U.S. Action On Unisys
description: The Defense Department today suspended three divisions of the Unisys Corporation from doing business with the Government, in the latest move in its investigation of possible fraud and bribery in military procurement.

title: 3 in Europe Join Forces
description: Three of Europe's largest space and military contractors plan to link up to provide a Pan-European private-sector alternative to state companies, one of the companies said today.

title: Terry Anderson's Jailer Is . . .
description: The last time I saw my friend Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was March 16, 1985. We had just finished an early morning game of tennis and Terry was dropping me off in front of my apartment.

title: Alfred Kalfus, 67, a Mathematics Teacher
description: Alfred Kalfus, a mathematics teacher who was awarded a Presidential citation for teaching excellence in 1983, died of a heart attack Wednesday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 67 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: A. G. Schmerge Jr., 71, Real-Estate Investor
description: Albert G. Schmerge Jr., a real-estate investor and former insurance agent, died of liver cancer Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Ashton to Raise Interbase Holding
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it has signed a letter of intent to acquire a majority interest in the Interbase Software Corporation of Bedford, Mass., a privately held company specializing in data base software for minicomputers. Ashton-Tate previously had acquired a minority interest in Interbase as part of a joint-technology agreement announced in April 1988. Terms of today's deal were not announced.

title: Election Officials Quit in Fear of Salvador Rebels
description: Bowing to a heightened campaign by leftist rebels to disrupt presidential elections, poll workers resigned today in 11 eastern towns, provincial officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 10 about the Federated/Allied department stores misstated the scope of their regional support services for the Northeast. The unit will not be responsible for the credit operations of the Jordan Marsh department stores in Boston and other New England cities.

title: Healthsouth Rehabilitation Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $7,000 and $24,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $622,000 for the year.

title: Sao Paulo Journal; A Mayor Bent on Inverting Priorities
description: Proud to be known as the engine of Brazilian capitalism, Sao Paulo at times resembles a vast business enterprise operated by self-made millionaires with Italian and German surnames and staffed by hard-working migrants from the country's backward Northeast.

title: Katha Quinn, Sports Publicist, 34
description: Katha Quinn, the sports-information director at St. John's University, died of liver cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 34 years old.

title: Drive in House on Acid Rain
description: More than 100 House members have introduced legislation to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by more than 40 percent and nitrogen oxide emissions by about half that.

title: Michigan Court Backs Abortion Fund Curb
description: A Michigan judge yesterday upheld the legality of the November referendum in which Michigan voters cut off public funds for abortions except those in which a woman's life is endangered.

title: Central Illinois Public Service Co. reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Japan Denies Backing Amazon Road Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Even Stickball Isn't What It Used to Be; A One-Manhole Hitter
description: To the Editor:

title: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Plenum Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Vibrations Force Jet to Land
description: A Continental Airlines jetliner bound for Denver shuddered for several minutes with severe vibrations today, forcing it to return here for an emergency landing. The crew of the Boeing 737 with 69 people aboard made a normal landing at San Francisco International Airport about 1 P.M., and crews found a scorched area about 10 feet wide on the tail. There also appeared to be damage to the stabilizer, the horizontal portion of the tail that helps control attitude. No injuries were reported.

title: Last Stand Against Base Closings
description: The House Armed Services Committee has overwhelmingly rejected an effort to block the shutdown of surplus military bases, but the battle isn't over yet. Representatives from California, Illinois and New Jersey are leading the fight to keep pouring money into obsolete installations. They plan to bring the issue to a floor vote next month; it warrants the same resounding disapproval.

title: Apple Wins Round in Microsoft Suit
description: Apple Computer Inc. today apparently won the first round of its closely watched copyright infringement lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation, as a Federal judge tentatively rejected Microsoft's contention that it had a license allowing it to use Apple's technology.

title: Review/Theater; Perplexity of Meaning in Translation
description: The mystery in a John Jesurun play invariably begins before the performance, as the audience tries to find its equilibrium in a nebulous theatrical space. Often this turns out to be a simulated moviedrome or television studio, where actors talk back to their own images. With ''Black Maria'' (in 1987), the entire floor space of the theater was filled with chairs. There was no stage and there were no live actors. The ''play'' appeared entirely on screens around and above the audience.

title: Litter That's Less Work
description: Cleaning a litter box is a bit like paying bills: a necessary chore, but hardly a favorite pastime.

title: Family's Night of Abduction: 'We Started to Pray Out Loud'
description: A North Carolina family of five who had just arrived in Manhattan for a relative's funeral was swept into a night of terror by a gunman fleeing after critically wounding his wife, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Troubles of a Safety Agency: A Battle to Keep Functioning
description: On July 14, 1984, 23-month-old Danny Lineweaver tried to climb out of his crib. He caught his shirt on a corner post, lost his balance and was almost strangled. ''Danny was revived, but is still in a semicomatose condition, with permanent, severe brain damage,'' his father, John Lineweaver, told members of Congress 10 days ago.

title: Pfft! Nets Waste Another Big Lead
description: The Nets have never seen a lead they couldn't lose. They have rarely encountered a full-court press that didn't shake their confidence. And in a season that gets bleaker by the day, they have rarely suffered a loss more disheartening than tonight's.

title: Theodore W. Oppel, Physician, 85
description: Theodore W. Oppel, an internist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center for almost 50 years, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Sarah Newman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was not bad, as prisons go, but it was prison. Unless you have been a prisoner, you can't know what that means.'' - - Jorge Reyes Torres, a former Nicaraguan officer on being freed after 10 years. [ 3:6. ]

title: Resignation Sought
description: David Swank, interim president of the University of Oklahoma, has asked for the resignation of Scott Hill, an assistant football coach, according to a report yesterday in The Daily Oklahoman. The newpaper reported that a member of the university's board of regents said Swank had asked for the resignation because of Hill's role in the N.C.A.A. violations that led to a three-year probation for the football program.

title: Heck's reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 26
description: The company, which is operating as a debtor-in-possession under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code, did not give comparable year-ago third quarter results. It said that for the 47 weeks ended Nov. 28, 1987, it had a loss of $41,700,000 on $374,954,000 in sales.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day on Thursday about John B. Taylor misidentified the Woodrow Wilson School. It is at Princeton University.

title: Bomb Victim Relatives Urge Tighter Security
description: Reacting to disclosures that brought fresh anguish, relatives of Americans killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in Scotland last December vowed yesterday to fight for new laws to tighten airline security and keep passengers fully informed of substantive dangers.

title: Rates Soar on Producer Price Data
description: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of fixed-income securities plunged on the report of an unexpectedly sharp rise in February producer prices.

title: A Muscovy Duck's Heart Can Also Break; Affectionate and Playful
description: To the Editor:

title: Drought Worry: No Snowpack In the Catskills
description: With reservoirs at half their capacity and forecasters predicting a typical spring, the drought that has struck lower New York State this year looks no more foreboding than previous dry spells. But there is a difference: The snows did not come this winter.

title: Healthco International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $346,000 for an accounting change for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said its HPSC Inc. subsidiary accounted for a $4,576,000 loss in the latest quarter, compared to $206,000 in income in the year-ago quarter. It said HPSC accounted for a $3,100,030 loss in the full year, compared to $1,819,010 in income for the prior year.

title: Patents; A New Method to Store Data on Optical Disks
description: Joseph Lindmayre, founder of the Quantex Corporation in Rockville, Md., is locking up patent claims to a radically different, although still unproved, approach to storing information on erasable optical disks.

title: Budding Ballerinas Learn to Dance Without Sight and Without Fear.
description: Guided by squeezes and whispers from her ballet teacher and an inexact sense of the people and objects around her, Ivonne Mosquera curtsied, turned and let her hand fall gracefully on the hand of a waiting prince.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: CopingWith Spring Cleaning; Before you hire a service for those heavy chores, it pays to check around.
description: It's spring, or almost. The windows need washing and furniture and carpets are begging to be shampooed. What to do? Call for help.

title: Wesco Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lilly Industrial Coatings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bennett Starts Anti-Drug Job With a Fresh Display of His Old Flair
description: In his first week as the nation's chief drug fighter, William J. Bennett did what he vowed not to do: make a big splash early.

title: Now Even Stickball Isn't What It Used to Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua Frees 1894 Ex-Guardsmen
description: In a brief ceremony under a blazing sun, the Government today officially pardoned 1,894 former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard imprisoned when the Sandinistas came to power 10 years ago.

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $1,612,000 from an accounting change.

title: Gateway Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sunbelt Nursery Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ITALIAN JET CRASH IS LAID TO MISSILE
description: One of Italy's enduring mysteries moved an important step toward a possible solution today when a team of scientific experts announced that a missile had caused an Italian civilian airliner to crash into the Tyrrhenian Sea nine years ago, killing all 81 people aboard.

title: Belfast Man Killed at Home
description: Gunmen killed a 42-year-old Roman Catholic man in front of his wife tonight in the latest in a series of apparently retaliatory sectarian killings. The police said the killers smashed their way into the house of Niall Davies, a civil servant, and shot him. No group took responsibility for the slaying. Mr. Davies's 11-year-old daughter was in the house at the time of the shooting. It was the ninth killing in 11 days of sectarian violence.

title: McGivern Freed From Prison And Says, 'It's Nice to Be Out'
description: Gary McGivern, granted parole Wednesday on his murder sentence of 25 years to life in the 1968 shooting of a Westchester County deputy sheriff, was released today from the state prison here.

title: Clyde Holbrook, 77, A Teacher of Religion
description: Clyde A. Holbrook, Danforth Professor of Religion emeritus at Oberlin College, Ohio, an authority on Jonathan Edwards, the American theologian and philosopher, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Oberlin. He was 77 years old.

title: Cuomo Plans Bigger Grants To Pay Nurses
description: Taking a significant step toward relieving New York State's hospital crisis, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced a plan today to provide hospitals and other health-care providers with an additional $193 million for increased salaries for nurses.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Hurt in a Battle With Gunmen Near Jordan Border
description: At least two Israeli soldiers were shot and wounded on Friday night by unidentified guerrillas who crossed Israel's southern border with Jordan and clashed with a military patrol, the army said early this morning.

title: Anderson Resigns As Coach at B.Y.U.
description: Although he led the Brigham Young basketball team to five winning seasons in six years as coach, Ladell Anderson resigned yesterday. ''I felt this was the best thing I could do for myself, the university and everyone concerned,'' he said of his sudden announcement. ''There was never any pressure put on me by anyone at Brigham Young or the administration.''

title: Senate Democrats Offer a Policy Agenda for U.S.
description: The role of Congress is not to sit and wait for policy proposals from the White House, says the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell. So today, in the spirit of self-assertion, Senate Democrats came forth with an agenda of their own.

title: Israel, I'm With You
description: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Finance Minister Shimon Peres have called for a leadership conference in Jerusalem, beginning tomorrow. I will be there. This decision is not a knee-jerk reaction but a reasoned response on my part.

title: Cambodian Prince Says Bush Promised Him 'Full Support'
description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh said today that President Bush promised him and his father, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, ''full support'' for the Cambodian opposition. But he acknowledged that he had not received ''a clear and positive response'' from Washington to his request for weapons.

title: BII Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Seton Hall Holds On to Win; Syracuse Rolls
description: Southwest Missouri State gave Seton Hall fits and a frightful scare today before the Pirates emerged victorious, 60-51, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's West Regional.

title: Maine Town of 607 Weighs Its Fate
description: If Francis Bliss has his way, the town meeting here Saturday will be the last.

title: Dow Falls 48.57, Most Since April
description: Stock prices plunged across a broad front yesterday, as the market was stunned by a higher-than-expected rise in producer prices and buffeted by heavy selling related to the quarterly ''triple witching hour.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 8.

title: Paychex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rethink the Japan Fighter Deal
description: Congress and the Administration are having welcome second thoughts about the Japan fighter deal negotiated by the Pentagon. It's by no means clear that the Pentagon took America's commercial interests fully into account or, as it contends, that it got the best deal available.

title: The Trail of Warnings
description: Oct. 26, 1988: The West German police arrest 14 members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command. They seize a bomb, hidden inside a Toshiba radio-cassette player, that contains 10 ounces of plastic explosive and a trigger that is tripped by a device measuring barometric pressure.

title: Westchester Classic Has New Sponsor In Its Future
description: The Buick division of General Motors will take over sponsorship of the Westchester Classic next year, replacing Manufacturers Hanover, which has sponsored that PGA Tour tournament since 1979. This will make Buick a rare sponsor of two regular stops on the PGA Tour. The Buick Open in Flint, Mich., has been held since 1958.

title: Jesus de Leizaola, 92, A Basque Leader, Dies
description: Jesus Maria de Leizaola, who headed the Basque government in exile for nearly two decades during the Franco dictatorship, died Thursday after a heart attack, doctors in this Basque provincial capital said. He was 92 years old.

title: Tony Lama Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nu-Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,241,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Foreign Medical Workers Help Fight Afghan War's Legacy
description: In a crowded ward at the Red Cross's Surgical Hospital for War Wounded the old Afghan lay immobile on his bed, his face and hands severely burned.

title: Drastic Steps Are Voted to Reduce Southern California Air Pollution
description: A new vision of the American urban future emerged today as regional officials in Southern California voted to impose drastic restrictions on everyday activities to reduce air pollution.

title: Thierry Mugler: Nuts, Bolts and Sequins
description: Thierry Mugler, a designer who delights in fashion sendups and smash-ups, showed his fall-winter collection here Thursday evening, and it was a raucous crowd-pleaser with resonances of everything from video games and science fiction to ''Road Warrior'' and biker movies.

title: Planners Try to Ease Tappan Zee Traffic
description: Rockland County is taking what regional planners say is an important step in relieving traffic congestion with its planned expansion of express bus service across the Tappan Zee Bridge. County officials expect the new service to begin next month.

title: Perle Premiere
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to give the world premiere of George Perle's Sextet for Piano and Winds today at 6 P.M. at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street. The program also includes the Brahms Horn Trio in E flat (Op. 40) and the Dvorak Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81). The concert will be repeated at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets for the gallery performance are $10; for Tully Hall, $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: New S.E.C. Move Seen Against Milken
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has told Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. that it must dismiss Michael R. Milken before a settlement of the agency's complaint against it is submitted to the S.E.C. commissioners for approval, people involved in the situation said.

title: South Alabama 3-Pointer Stuns the Crimson Tide
description: In the first meeting ever between the cross-state rivals, the University of South Alabama upset the University of Alabama, 86-84, today in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Southeast Regional.

title: Abraham Berger, Librarian, 86
description: Abraham Berger, retired chief of the Jewish division of the New York Public Library, died Tuesday. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Home Shopping Network Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary gains of $989,000 for the quarter and $5,658,000 for the 6 months from the repurchase of $4.3 million and $24.6 million, respectively, of the company's 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2002.

title: Life in an Andean Village As Duelists Prepare to Die
description: The Colombian film ''Details of a Duel'' takes place on a single morning, during which two decent and well-liked citizens of a small Andean village prepare to die. The schoolteacher (Frank Ramirez) and the butcher (Humberto Dorado) have, for reasons that are not explained, challenged each other to a fatal contest. So each spends the morning bidding his farewells and putting his affairs in order. In the course of depicting this, the film's director, Sergio Cabrera, reveals what he can about the workings of the town.

title: Woodward's Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $4,133,000 writedown of the deferred income tax asset to reflect the lower income tax rate enacted under tax reform. c-Included a gain of $5,844,000 on the sale of securities and after a charge of $1,120,000 on the sale of its food operations. The company said year-ago revenue included sales of $127,468,000 from the food operations. The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Movie and TV Producers Reach Accord With Actors
description: In an unusual move in an industry that has recently been plagued with bitter strikes, Hollywood's 102,000 actors have reached tentative agreement with movie and television producers months ahead of schedule.

title: Super Food Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 11
What U.S. Is Doing for Human Rights in China; It's Just Jealousy
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwin Janss Jr., 74, a Developer Of Suburbs and Two Ski Resorts
description: Edwin Janss Jr., a California real estate developer who helped expand and develop the ski resorts of Sun Valley and Snowmass, fell to his death Thursday when he jumped from the 12th story of a building in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: American Express Unit in Expansion
description: Systems Associates Inc., a unit of the American Express Company, will acquire the Health Systems Company unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. Jeremy Causley, president of McDonnell's Information Systems Company division, said the decision to sell the unit was one of many recent moves to focus the direction of the aerospace and technology giant. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Beatrice S. W. Fuerst, Foundation Official, 83
description: Beatrice Swancutt Wright Fuerst, former assistant director of women's activities for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, died of natural causes Wednesday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 83 years old and lived in Rhinebeck.

title: Review/Movie; Battling Crack Dealers On Rooftops of New York
description: In ''Rooftops,'' the manufacturers of grade-B movies, those sociologists of the screen, have caught up with the latest trends in crime and teen-age life. They have made a thoroughly modern film about crack dealers invading a bombed-out tenement where the water towers offer splendid views of the distant Empire State Building, but you can fall through several decaying stories if you are not careful where you put your feet.

title: What U.S. Is Doing for Human Rights in China; Luxuries for Whites
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Drug Steps Imposed on U.S. Contractors
description: Under a little-noticed provision of the anti-drug law Congress adopted last fall, companies and institutions will risk losing future Federal contracts and grants if they do not make a ''good-faith effort'' to institute programs that assure a drug-free workplace.

title: Campaign-Fund Hearings End Quietly
description: A state ethics panel's often-explosive hearings on campaign financing ended today with a whimper as the top legislative leaders appeared before it to defend legislative campaign fund-raising practices.

title: Gendis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. to Study G.M. and Ford Cars' Control Systems
description: Nearly two million General Motors automobiles and 590,000 four-wheel-drive Ford Bronco II automobiles will be included in investigations of complaints that they can go out of control, the Government said this week.

title: Norway Approves Insurance Merger
description: Norway approved the bid by the Swedish insurance giant Forsakrings A.B. Skandia to acquire the Norwegian insurer Vesta for $118 million. Skandia, the largest Scandinavian insurance company, moves closer to its goal of establishing a pan-Nordic insurance empire. It already has stakes in a Danish and a Finnish insurance group. It has said it wants to set up an insurance network to defend its home market from other Europeancompetitors.

title: Bush Is Shooed by Wife As Puppy Love Intrudes
description: ''Seriously, it's awful,'' President Bush complained today. Mrs. Bush told him this morning that he would be evicted from their White House bedroom tonight because their dog, Millie, was about to have puppies and was making too much noise.

title: A 'Club' Welcome
description: Anyone who belongs to a club and can prove it can buy a ticket for $10 to the first preview of ''Welcome to the Club,'' the new Cy Coleman musical comedy about love, marriage and divorce. Tickets will be available at the Music Box Theater when the box office opens Monday. The first preview is March 27 at 8 P.M., and the show is scheduled to open April 13. Preview tickets bought in advance cost $22.50 at the box office.

title: 2 Are Killed as Medieval Tower Collapses in Italy
description: A 900-year-old medieval tower collapsed in a downtown square of this northern Italian city today, killing two people, injuring 15 and burying parked cars and a newspaper stand, officials said.

title: Charles Billingslea Is Dead at 74; Retired Major General in Army
description: Charles Billingslea, a retired Army major general who served in World War II and Korea and later helped to enforce judicial desegregation orders in Mississippi and Alabama, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 74 years old and lived in Oxford, Md.

title: Review/Opera; 'Rigoletto' With New Cast and Old Set
description: The Metropolitan Opera plans to present a brand-new Otto Schenk production of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' in November, with Leo Nucci, June Anderson and Luciano Pavarotti. In the meantime, on Thursday, the company trotted out its misbegotten 1977 John Dexter-Tanya Moiseiwitsch ''Rigoletto'' (from which Mr. Dexter has long since removed his name) for one more outing.

title: Takeover Bid For Polaroid Is Set Back
description: A Delaware Chancery Court yesterday dealt a major setback to a $3.1 billion hostile takeover offer for the Polaroid Corporation by an investor group led by Roy E. Disney, the West Coast businessman.

title: Louisiana Battling Counterfeit Cajun
description: Louisiana has managed to cope with trifles like the nation's highest unemployment rate and the collapse of its oil industry, but it is now mobilizing against a more insidious peril: counterfeit Cajun food.

title: Cheney Confirmed With No Dissent
description: The Senate voted without dissent today to confirm Representative Dick Cheney as Secretary of Defense, acting a week and a day after it rejected the nomination of John G. Tower.

title: Dow Chemical Sees Record 1989 Sales
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it expects to achieve record sales again in 1989 and predicts it will nearly double its revenues to $30 billion a year by the mid-1990's. In the company's annual report to shareholders, Dow's president, Frank Popoff, said the Midland, Mich., company expects to exceed the record $16.7 billion in sales it posted in 1988. He said the company is capable of achieving its goal of $30 billion a year in sales by 1995.

title: Killearn Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Gandhi to Release Report on Mother's Slaying
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said tonight that a judicial report on the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, which had been suppressed on the grounds of national security since 1986, would be released to Parliament in 10 days.

title: Development Bank to Raise $26.4 Billion
description: A committee of the Inter-American Development Bank has agreed to increase the bank's capital by $26.43 billion in a compromise that resolves a three-year dispute between the United States and Latin American countries over the organization's policies.

title: Seton Hall Holds On to Win; Syracuse Rolls
description: Syracuse does not have to be reminded about the perils of post-season play. With the exception of 1987, when the Orangemen reached the final, the national tournament has been a series of narrow escapes and premature exits.

title: Your Money; Pitfalls of Homes As Investments
description: A home may be a poor investment in today's real estate market, even though it can be a source of comfort and pride, and even though mortgage interest and property taxes remain deductible. Prices of residential real estate are declining in parts of the United States. As a result, many experts say, home buying should represent a long-term life style decision. The buyers should not expect a sure and quick profit.

title: INSIDE
description: Plan to Raise Nurses' Pay

title: Siena Leader Is Following His Father's Example
description: The unlikely had just become reality as 14th-seeded Siena upended 3d-seeded Stanford in the opening round of the East Regional on Thursday. As the buzzer sounded, assuring their 80-78 victory, the Siena players celebrated on the court while hundreds of their green-clad fans danced and screamed in the bleachers behind the basket nearest the team's bench.

title: Apples Pass Tests for Return To Los Angeles School Menu
description: Apples will return to the menu in the nation's second-largest school district after passing chemical tests prompted by fears of a cancer risk.

title: No Lions Endorsement For Ex-Klansman
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page yesterday about a survey conducted by the Northwestern University Law School located the school incorrectly. It is in Chicago.

title: KEY RATES
Eva Marton Quits 'Salome'
description: Eva Marton, the Hungarian dramatic soprano, has withdrawn from this season's final two performances of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Richard Strauss's ''Salome,'' last night and Wednesday. Her scheduled replacement, Katarina Ikonomu, has already sung Salome at the Met this season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., Montreal, said its BCE Development Corp. unit and Olympia & York Developments Ltd. have ended talks on the acquisition by Olympia & York of an interest in BCE Development.

title: Hudson's Bay Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a special charge of $27,000,000. c-Net loss d-After special charges of $1,022,000 and $17,989,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said in the latest year after preferred dividends there were no earnings available for common shareholders. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Avatar Holdings reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $180,000.

title: What U.S. Is Doing for Human Rights in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Old friends and rivals battle at Spring Nationals.
description: Some old friends and rivals battled here yesterday in the third round of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. Two decades ago Italian teams including Benito Garozzo and Giorgio Belladonna captured a pair of world team titles with a victory in the finals over American squads that included Edgar Kaplan, Norman Kay and Bill Root as members.

title: Petrie Stores Chief May Seek Deb Shops
description: Milton J. Petrie, the octogenarian chairman and chief executive of the Petrie Stores Corporation, disclosed today that he might seek to acquire all the shares of Deb Shops Inc. that he does not already control.

title: MDS Health Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago earnings figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carlton Tries A Comeback
description: He was not like the rest of them, older, to be sure, and off by himself. He came alone, at 8:45 yesterday morning, earlier than most, through the back way.

title: Suitcase Shards May Offer Clues To Identities of Pan Am Bombers
description: Investigators believe they have recovered shards of the suitcase that contained the plastic explosive that destroyed a Pan Am jet over Scotland, two Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Medicine (Broadly Speaking) and Victoria
description: Ask Sir James Sir James Reid, Personal Physician to Queen Victoria and Physician-in-Ordinary to Three Monarchs By Michaela Reid Illustrated. 315 pages. Viking. $21.95.

title: AAR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Halliburton to Sell Insurance Division
description: The Halliburton Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell a subsidiary, the Life Insurance Company of the Southwest, to a West German-led investment group for $71 million in cash. Halliburton announced last September that it was seeking a buyer for the company, which it has owned for 25 years.

title: Too Little Too Late for the Knicks Against the Bulls
description: Rod Strickland, the Knicks' rookie playmaker, had a chance to be a hero tonight in the city where he went to college, but he failed.

title: Introduction Seen For Intel Chip
description: The Intel Corporation is expected to introduce a long-awaited new microprocessor at the Comdex computer trade show in Chicago next month, analysts and industry observers said. The new chip, named the 80486, is not considered a successor to Intel's best-selling 80386 microprocessor, but rather an effort to bolster the company's presence in the fast-growing workstation and mid-range computer markets, analysts said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 4 about Indian Government measures to placate Sikhs misidentified the place where a group of Sikh detainees had been held since 1984. They were at Jodhpur, in Rajasthan State, and not Jubbulpore, in Madhya Pradesh.

title: Eastern Seeks Bids For Its Fleet
description: Seeking to raise cash to survive bankruptcy proceedings, Eastern Airlines notified other large carriers today that it was putting most of its fleet up for sale, company officials said.

title: A Muscovy Duck's Heart Can Also Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgetown Survives Princeton Scare
description: In the age of 360-degree dunks, more frequently publicized academic abuses and the 45-second clock, the Princeton Tigers tonight demonstrated their ability to compete in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament by creating a top-seeded team's nightmare.

title: Bush Explains His Shift on Gun Control
description: President Bush said today that he had modified his views on gun control and was actively seeking an accommodation between the police and sporting inter=ests.

title: Power Corp. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $1,456,000 for the quarter and $3,367,000 for the year. c-After a special charge of $5,104,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $37,132,000 for the year. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A.&S. Moves to Fill Gimbels Void
description: In making its first move into Manhattan, Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based retail chain, believes it can succeed in a market in which many other mid-price retailers have found it impossible to survive. It is a risky move, but one the chain sees as necessary.

title: Papandreou Realigns Greek Cabinet Posts
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou shuffled 12 Cabinet posts today, a move that opponents called an attempt to salvage his waning popularity in the face of a widening political scandal.

title: Temporary Halt Is Ordered In Northwest Timber Sales
description: A Federal judge said today that he would issue a temporary order to delay 135 timber sales planned by the United States Forest Service because of the battle over protecting ancient trees and rare owls, a lawyer for environmentalists reported.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY MARCH 18, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Words To Get Gulled By
description: A corporation is said to be ''in play'' nowadays when Wall Street types start fighting over who will control it. The people who engage in these fights are called ''major players,'' and the culture that breeds them is called the ''high-stakes world'' of mergers and acquisitions.

title: Sunshine Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from the early retirement of debt of $9,215,000 and a gain of $4,007,000 from the termination of pension plans.

title: Agreement Ends Sit-In at College After Fifth Day
description: For five days this week, students occupied Sarah Lawrence College's administration building to protest the school's policies on racial issues. But the occupation ended tonight with commitments by the school to increase minority faculty hiring and ''Afro-American and other multi-cultural'' offerings in the curriculum.

title: Patents; A Method to Prevent The Formation of Fat
description: Ronald T. Stanko, an assistant professor of medicine at the University of Pittsburgh's Montefiore Hospital, received patent approval this week on a method of preventing fat formation in humans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 Airplane bomb investigators believe they have recovered shards of the suitcase that contained the plastic explosive that destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland, two U.S. officials said. Page 1 Bomb victim relatives urge tighter security 5 A missile caused an Italian jet crash, experts say 4 Poll workers in El Salvador resigned in 11 eastern towns, bowing to a heightened campaign by leftist rebels to disrupt presidential elections, provincial officials said. 1 The Sandinistas gave 1,894 pardons to former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard, following the regional accord signed last month by granting unrestricted freedom to all but 39 of the former guardsmen. 3 A 900-year-old tower collapsed in a downtown square of the northern Italian city of Pavia, killing 2 people and injuring 15. 5 Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India said a judicial report on the assassination of his mother, which had beensuppressed on the grounds of national security, would be released to Parliament in 10 days. 3 A car bomb in Beirut killed 12 people and wounded 120 when it went off during the morning rush hour, the police said. The blast devastated a Chritian area. 3 A 150-bed hospital in Kabul that the Red Cross opened last October constitutes a small beginning on what Western experts expect will ultimately be necessary to treat the Afghan war's medical legacy. 4 Prince Norodom Ranariddh said President Bush promised ''full support'' for the Cambodian opposition. But he acknowledged that his arms request had not received ''a clear and positive response.'' 2 National 6-8, 28, 50 The worst two-month inflation in nearly eight years has been reflected in the Producer Price Index, which soared by 1 percent in both January and February, stunning stock and bond markets. 1 Stocks plunge across board; Dow down 48.57 points 33 New restrictions on Californians' life have been approved to reduce air pollution. The plan wouldeventually require electric powered cars and an end to free parking. 1 The U.S. Civil Rights Commission has been thrown into disarray by the arrest of its chairman at gunpoint last month on an Indian reservation in Arizona. 1 Chilean fruit will be allowed back in the American market, but grapes and other fruit already shipped to food stores and wholesalers will be destroyed, the F.D.A. said. 1 The Senate confirmed Dick Cheney as Defense Secretary in a 92-to-0 vote. He was sworn in a short time later in his office and went immediately to the Pentagon to take charge. 7 Senate Democrats issued an agenda of policy proposals, saying that Congress is a co-equal branch of Government and will not simply let the President take the initiative. 28 Senate fails to extend AIDS drug program 6 Drive in House on acid rain 8 Efforts for a drug-free workplace must be shown by companies that enter into Federal Government contracts of at least $25,000, starting today. But requirements are vague. 7 In his first week combatting drugs, William Bennett, announced a ban on importing semi-automatic rifles, targeted Washington for anti-drug efforts, in spite of a promise not to make a big splash. 7 President Bush's view on gun control has changed and he is actively seeking ''an accommodation'' between the police and sporting interests, he said. 7 Puppies expected in the White House 6 An inquiry into Ford and G.M cars has been opened to examine the potential danger of the cars rolling over. It follows an accident study that faulted the Ford Bronco II but cleared the Suzuki Samurai. 6 The Discovery astronauts got ready to end their five-day voyage, finishing up experiments aboard the space shuttle. Landing is set for 9:35 A.M. eastern time Saturday. 50 A servicewoman with a 6-month-old daughter has sued for a discharge from the Army, so that she will not be sent to South Korea, separating her from her child. 6 A fight against false Cajun food is being waged by Louisiana, because of what the state sees as a proliferation of ''copy-cat Cajun'' that is hurting the repute of state products. 6 I.B.M. said its profit would not meet analysts' expectations for the first quarter, undercutting the widespread belief that its 1989 earnings would be strong. 33 Apple Computer's suit gaining on Microsoft 35 Regional 29-31 A family was terrorized just after arriving in Manhattan from North Carolina when a gunman, who critically wounded his wife, abducted them. 1 An extra $193 million for nurses' pay was announced by Governor Cuomo in a step toward relieving the state's hospital crisis. A hospital ''summit meeting'' is also planned. 29 The St. Patrick's Day parade moved up Fifth Avenue with Edward Koch exultant amid only a smattering of boos and determined to march in a 13th parade next year. 29 The drought that has struck lower New York State might now look no more foreboding than previous ones, but there is a difference: the snow did not come this winter. 29 Ethics hearings ended with a whimper as the New York legislative leaders appeared to defend campaign fund-raising practices. 29 Students at Sarah Lawrence College, protesting school policies on racial issues, ended their occupation of an administration building after a commitment by the school to increase minority faculty hiring. 30 The top-rated female chess player in the world will join about 40 grandmasters for the New York International tournament. She is Judith Polgar, one of three chess-playing sisters from Hungary. 30 Eight ballerinas learn to dance without sight and without fear 31

title: Program to Extend AIDS Drug Program Is Stalled in Senate
description: A program that provides an expensive drug to AIDS patients who cannot otherwise afford it was not extended by the Senate today, and it seems certain that the program will expire at least temporarily.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 106, Celtics 98: Vinnie Johnson scored 14 of his 30 points in the fourth quarter last night in Detroit as the Pistons won their ninth game in a row.(AP) Jazz 118, Heat 96: Karl Malone scored 31 points and John Stockton had 16 points and 15 assists as Utah won its 10th game in a row at home.(AP) Hornets 108, Clippers 105: Rex Chapman scored 15 of his 24 points in the fourth quarter and Kelly Tripucka added 18 as Charlotte ended a road losing streak at 10 games.(AP) Suns 129, Trail Blazers 124: Kevin Johnson scored 20 of his game-high 39 points in the third quarter as the Suns won their ninth consecutive home game.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Oklahoma State 69, Boise State 55: Corey Williams made key 3-pointers for Oklahoma State in the second half and the Cowboys used free throws to beat Boise State (23-7) last night in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament in Stillwater, Okla. Oklahoma State (17-12) plays at St. John's on Tuesday.(AP) C. W. Post 85, New Haven 62: Juan Griles scored 28 points and Neil King added 18 points leading C. W. Post (19-10) to victory over New Haven (19-12) in a semifinal game of the E.C.A.C. Division II tournament. In winning their 10th consecutive game, the Pioneers advanced to the championship game, which will be played at 3 P.M. today at New Haven. C. W. Post will face Merrimack, a 102-78 victor over New York Tech. N.H.L. Capitals 4, Canadiens 1: Dino Ciccarelli scored two goals as Washington won its fourth consecutive game, in a battle of division leaders last night in Landover, Md.(AP) COLLEGE HOCKEY Wisconsin 3, St. Lawrence 1: John Byce scored a goal and set up another and Curtis Joseph made 32 saves last night in Canton, N.Y., leading Wisconsin to victory over St. Lawrence in the first game of their National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I playoff series.(AP) FIGURE SKATING Trenary Takes Lead: Jill Trenary of the United States moved into the lead of the women's individual competition at the world championships. Trenary, in second place going into the short program section, overtook Claudia Leistner of West Germany with the free skating to come today. Midori Ito of Japan moved up to third from sixth place.

title: Sheer Effrontery
description: LEAD: Well, ladies, looks like it's time for the annual fashion skirmish. Just as we finish fending off miniskirts, we're facing another designer attack. This one's a frontal assault.

title: Koch and Rivals March in Hunt for Luck
description: With a breeze at his back, a Ben at either side and his rivals walking well behind him, Edward Irving Koch strode up Fifth Avenue yesterday in his 12th St. Patrick's Day Parade as Mayor of New York City, exultant amid no more than a smattering of boos and determined to march in a 13th next year.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; A Soviet Youth Finds Brooding Is His Forte
description: The youth whose errors are recounted in ''The Errors of Youth'' is Dmitri Guryanov, whom we meet as he is about to complete his army service. His main error is restlessness, an inability to settle down with one or another of the pretty women who find him appealing. The main error of this Soviet movie, which will be shown tonight at 6:30 and tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art is a wandering screenplay that reveals little about Mitya except a general dissatisfaction with things.

title: Review/Pop; Cute, Fit and Leather-Clad
description: In an arena filled with the squeals of teen-age girls, as the Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands was on Wednesday night, Bon Jovi's popularity starts to make sense. Seasoned rock listeners are dismayed by the multimillion-record sales of a band that blatantly borrows from other rock while dispensing cliche upon cliche; hearing Bon Jovi is like being locked in a greeting-card warehouse with a radio that plays only 1970's ''classic rock.'' But Bon Jovi doesn't have to please listeners with long memories.

title: Ideal Group of Companies Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1,909,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PRODUCER PRICES SHOW BIG INCREASE FOR SECOND MONTH
description: In a major surprise, the Producer Price Index, for the second straight month, soared by 1 percent in February, the worst inflation for a two-month period in nearly eight years.

title: Lions Sign Edmonds
description: Bobby Joe Edmonds, the kick returner who was made an unrestricted free agent by the Seattle Seahawks, has signed a two-year contract with the Detroit Lions.

title: Patents; Foreign Licenses at Record High
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office reported yesterday that foreign inventors obtained 47.1 percent of all patents issued in this country in 1988. This share is up five-tenths of a percentage point from 1987 and is the highest level ever for foreign inventors.

title: Top-Rated Female Chess Player Is Just One of Three Stars at Home
description: The highest-rated female chess player in the world will join about 40 grandmasters at the Penta Hotel for the New York International tournament tomorrow through March 28.

title: FIXING THE HAM
description: Ham, a traditional and popular main course for Easter dinner, is cured in a variety of ways. It can be air-dried, aged, smoked, brined, fully cooked or treated with a combination of these processes. Some smokehouses sell country hams that are fully cooked and ready to eat. Ready-to-eatt hams are usually labeled as such. Unless the ham is fully cooked, it must be soaked in several changes of cold water to remove excess salt and scrubbed to remove any mold on the rind. It must then be cooked before the final glazing. Hams should be cooked to an internal temperature of 160 to 165 degrees. Fresh ham is the uncooked, uncured upper hind leg of pork and should be cooked like a regular pork roast. $ Type of Ham Soaking Cooking Glazing Canned None None 10 minutes a pound ''Ready to eat'' None None 10 minutes or ''fully cooked'' a pound smoked or unsmoked Air-dried 12-24 hours Simmer or 10 minutes country ham bake in a pound or smoked water country ham 20 minutes a pound Smithfield 24-36 hours Simmer or 10 minutes style bake in a pound in water 20 minutes a pound Fresh, None Roast 18-20 None uncured minutes a pound at 350 degrees

title: Christ the King to Meet Stevenson in Final
description: Christ the King, ranked third nationally and first in the state, survived in overtime tonight against previously unbeaten Hempstead (L.I.), 90-86, in the Class A semifinals of the New York High School Federation championships.

title: Pitt Coach Is Angered
description: It is no secret that Coach Paul Evans of Pittsburgh does not react well to his team's post-season failures.

title: U.S. Will Permit Fruit From Chile To Enter Market
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would allow most Chilean fruit to return to American grocery shelves over the next five to nine days, but the agency also introduced more stringent inspections to help assure the safety of the imported produce.

title: Olympia Broadcasting reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $17,359,000 from the sale of radio stations. c-Net loss

title: Letter: On Housing; A Way to Prevent Abandonments
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Shift Focus of Trade Talks
description: The trade talks between the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves have simmered. Jeff Blauser is not coming to New York, Roberto Kelly is not heading for the National League and the Yankees are not thinking about changes in their infield.

title: CHAIRMAN'S ARREST JARS RIGHTS PANEL
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission has been thrown into disarray by the disclosure that its chairman was arrested at gunpoint last month on an Indian reservation in Arizona.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Unemployment in Britain fell two-tenths of a percentage point in February, to a seasonally adjusted 6.8 percent of the work force, its lowest level in more than eight years, the Government said this week. The unemployment rate stood at 7 percent in January and at 8.7 percent in February 1988. The latest rate was the lowest since December 1980.

title: Car Bomb in Lebanon Kills 12 and Wounds 120
description: A car bomb devastated a Christian area today, and the police said 12 people were killed and 120 wounded.

title: Williams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter results were restated to reflect the cumulative effect of an accounting change for inventories and income taxes which reduced the previously reported loss by $281,700. The year-ago 6 months' results were restated for accounting changes which increased previously reported net by $563,400.

title: Savings Bond Sales Decline
description: Sales of United States Savings Bonds declined in February for the first time in five months, falling 14.5 percent, to $691 million, the Treasury Department said Thursday.

title: Best Time for Myers
description: Angel Myers, the swimmer from Furman who was disqualified from the United States Olympic team for testing positive for steroids, made a smooth return to competition Thursday at the N.C.A.A. women's swimming and division championships in Indianapolis. Myers, who placed first at the Olympic trials in the 50- and 100-meter freestyle events and the 100 butterfly, won the 200 individual medley in a career best time of 1 minute 59.49 seconds.

title: From Sun, More Power to People
description: Producing electricity from sunlight, a technology invented for outer space, has come down to earth, and is now quite literally in many backyards.

title: Review/Music; The Leinsdorf Brand of Program-Making
description: Erich Leinsdorf's concert Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall took a prize for imaginative programming. Bringing together three seldom-heard pieces by Debussy, Brahms and Berlioz, it had great intrinsic interest. Fortunately, the night also proved to have extrinsic interest as well, in the form of carefully prepared, gracefully realized performances. That is not invariably true of innovative programs.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Horse Racing Notebook in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the New York OTB surcharge on winning parlay bets. It is 5 percent of the total ontrack payoff.

title: Jean Macfarlane, 95, Psychology Professor
description: Jean Walker Macfarlane, professor emeritus of psychology at the University of California at Berkeley, died of congestive heart failure March 4 at her home in Berkeley. She was 95 years old.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE SET TO RETURN TODAY
description: The space shuttle astronauts prepared today to end their five-day voyage of 1.9 million miles, finishing up experiments aboard the Discovery and packing for a return to Earth on Saturday.

title: Negotiating Role Is Curbed For Main Seabrook Owner
description: In a setback for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a bankruptcy judge yesterday ended the utility's exclusive right to propose a plan to end its bankruptcy and gave himself a major role in future negotiations.

title: Charles Henderson, Statistician, Dies at 77
description: Charles R. Henderson, a statistician and a pioneer in the genetic improvement of dairy cattle, died of a pulmonary embolism Tuesday at Carle Hospital in Urbana, Ill. He was 77 years old and lived in Urbana and Ithaca, N.Y..

title: I.B.M. Expects Profits To Be Disappointing
description: Undercutting the widespread belief that its 1989 earnings would be strong, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter income would fall below analysts' expectations.

title: Soldier Sues for a Discharge So She Can Stay With Baby
description: A servicewoman with a 6-month-old daughter has sued for a hardship discharge from the Army so she will not be sent to South Korea and be separated from her child.

title: Short Brothers
description: The West German aerospace group Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. has dropped out of the race to take over Short Brothers P.L.C., the Northern Ireland aircraft and missile maker that the British Government wants to sell. The Northern Ireland Secretary, Tom King, said he had been told by Messerschmitt's head of aircraft production, Hartmut Mehdorn, that the company had decided not to pursue the bid. The other companies that have said they are considering making an offer for Short are Bombardier Inc. of Canada and a consortium of General Electric Company of Britain and Fokker of the Netherlands.

title: At Risk: Schools for the Handicapped
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York means to do well by the state's children, but his austere education budget could result in disaster for many who are handicapped. He would no longer have Albany pay the initial costs for several programs that serve handicapped students. Instead, local school districts would pay and Albany would reimburse them later.

title: National Computer Systems Inc. reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $9,949,000 from the sale of a 43 percent interest in DataCard Corp. and a loss of $8,499,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Divi Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the early extinguishment of debt of $150,000. c-Net income

title: Bush's Son in Lineup
description: Eddie Chiles, the principal owner of the Texas Rangers, said yesterday he had agreed to sell his 58 percent share of the team to a group led by George W. Bush, the President's son.

title: WestAir Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
They Saved The Industry
description: The voluntary restraints on steel imports, negotiated by a Republican Administration with the overwhelming support of a Democratic Congress in 1984, have been good for America.

title: About New York; Mother Struggles To Fill the Void Left by Flight 103
description: Helen Engelhardt asked Alan, her 6-year-old son, to sit next to her on the couch. This wasn't going to be easy.

title: Fabri-Centers of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss and the quarter and year included about $3 million and $5.2 million, respectively, in pretax charges related to the company's restructuring.

title: Egypt's Neglected Art Trove
description: Egypt is harboring 19th-century Impressionist and other art worth millions, possibly billions, yet neglected in out-of-the-way museums or stored in chaotic conditions, Western specialists and Egyptian officials say.

title: FICTION
description: A BUTTERFLY NET AND A KINGDOM: And Other Stories. By Blair Fuller. (Creative Arts, Paper, $8.95.) Power is a recurring theme in this intriguing, frequently haunting collection of stories by Blair Fuller, a former editor of The Paris Review and the author of the novels ''A Far Place'' and ''Zebina's Mountain.'' There is hardly a story in ''A Butterfly Net and a Kingdom'' that does not explore issues of dominance and control, whether they arise between nations, races, lovers or, in several instances, one man and his addictions. What makes Mr. Fuller's writing exceptional, however, is the way he demonstrates how the subtlest shifts in one of these relationships can push it inevitably toward tragedy. In the title novella, for example, two men live in an odd kind of symbiosis. One is a trader who has established for himself what amounts to a dictatorship in a small African territory, the other an eccentric who collects animal specimens for museums. Each profits from the other's presence until a moment of envy tips the delicate balance, and numerous lives are irrevocably changed. Although a few of the stories seem almost autobiographical exercises - even the O. Henry Award-winning ''All Right,'' a wrenching saga of familial alcoholism in which the narrator bears the author's name, comes to a glib conclusion - ''A Butterfly Net and a Kingdom'' is a strong and disquieting collection. Mr. Fuller expertly illuminates the ways in which we deceive not only others but ourselves.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Drilling for $40 a barrel, and selling for $20 is not good economics, even in Moscow.'' Theodore Eck, chief economist at Amoco, on the Soviet Union's oil problems.

title: Cunningham: Far From Arbitrary Abstractions
description: When Merce Cunningham touched his forehead during a curtain call at the end of his dance company's City Center season last Sunday, this vague salute was interpreted by some as a farewell.

title: THE REMARKABLE JOURNEY OF MARCO STANLEY FOGG
description: MOON PALACE By Paul Auster. 307 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95

title: Kuwait Orders a Crackdown on Its Shiite Minority
description: Kuwait has ordered a crackdown on its large Shiite Muslim minority, reflecting what Western diplomats call continued concern over Iranian-inspired terrorism despite the ending of the Persian Gulf war and efforts to improve ties with Teheran.

title: Fine Art of Rulrers and Lines
description: LEAD: THE students' heads are bent over their desks, their hands busy with rulers and pencils. A uniformed guard passes the classroom door, for these students are immates of the Taconic Correctional Facility in Bedford. The teacher, working quietly at his own desk, puts down his pencil from time to time to walk around and comment on the drawings.

title: Mr. Greenspan, Lower Rates Now!
description: We cannot claim we have not been warned. Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan has been unusually explicit for months. The economy is at full capacity and inflation is rising. There are only two ways to deal with this problem: raise interest rates or reduce the budget deficit.

title: Oh Say, Can You See Shelter Island?
description: WE out here on the East End have been hearing much talk of late about the notion of us just up and telling the whole rest of Suffolk County that we don't want to play with you folks anymore. Some people out here are saying we should make our own county and call it ''Peconic County.''

title: Central America Negotiates on Its Own
description: HOPES for peace and democracy in Central America are built on a series of agreements named for the obscure towns where they were signed. The effectiveness of these accords has been questioned, particularly by United States conservatives who contend that the more recent ones omit some guarantees found in the earlier pacts.

title: Shoreham Deal Unfair to Consumers
description: Long Islanders recently received a notice from Federal Court inviting us to tell Judge Jack B. Weinstein what we think of the proposed Shoreham suit settlement. Specifically, we were asked to tell the court whether we think the settlement, worked out for us by a Manhattan attorney, Judith Vladick, is ''fair, reasonable, and adequate.'' The answer is, ''No, it's not!''

title: Arizona Stops Clemson
description: Arizona, ranked No. 1 in the last regular-season Associated Press poll, held Clemson scoreless for more than nine minutes today and beat the Tigers, 94-68, to advance to the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. West Regional.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: GENERAL DESCRIBES SOVIET RIFT ON WAR
description: The Soviet Union sent troops to Afghanistan in 1979 over the objections of the military's General Staff, a Deputy Defense Minister said in a magazine interview published today.

title: Christ the King Captures State Title
description: Christ the King, the nation's third-ranked team and the state's top-ranked team, won the New York State Federation Class A championship tonight with an 80-57 victory over Adlai Stevenson of the Bronx, the New York City Public Schools Athletic League champion.

title: Prices in the Pit
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLYWOOD'S UNCOMMON EVERYMAN
description: GENE HACKMAN IS BEING PURSUED. A man has been haranguing him, calling on the phone, leaving letters in his apartment-house lobby. He wants Hackman as his ally, a comrade to help thwart a plot, something inscrutable about ''Hollywood borrowers.'' Hackman has been stalked before. There was the quick-draw artist with the loaded revolvers in Alamagordo, N.M.; the Las Vegas drunk brandishing a .357 magnum; the rifleman in Seattle who left his gun case at the cast's hotel, but this time, the interloper is unusually persistent. So, for the moment, the actor has moved out of his Chicago apartment into a hotel.

title: Company Monitors Energy
description: LEAD: IN the annals of a company named the National Utility Service, this tale may go down as the Case of the Too Short Meter Reader.

title: AS TIME GOES BY  BY LINDA WELLS
description: Don't trust anyone over 30,'' was the youth-culture chant of the late 1960's. It could still apply to cosmetics advertisements. The war against wrinkles and sagging skin is fought by those who look as if they still dip into the Clearasil.

title: Margaret Mary Fitzpatrick To Marry John F. Donlon
description: Margaret Mary Fitzpatrick and John Francis Donlon, both bankers in New York, plan to marry in May.

title: Poland Tying Political Reform to Aid From West
description: As talks continue on extensive reforms that could produce at least the appearance of power sharing between the Solidarity trade union and the Government, wildcat strikes are crippling the economy.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: He waits until he's comfortable collecting his pension, but Richard Taylor does tell the truth - or at least part of it.

title: Indictment to Be Sought in L.I. Girl's Slaying
description: Two weeks after 13-year-old Kelly Tinyes was found stabbed and strangled in a neighbor's basement here, investigators said they would present evidence to a Nassau County grand jury on Wednesday and seek a murder indictment.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; In Fairfield, Sweet Smells of Maple Sugaring
description: You do not have to travel as far north as Vermont to watch maple syrup in the making. At Warrups Farm in Redding, Conn., about an hour-and-a-half drive from Manhattan, Bill Hill and his brother Bob welcome visitors to their sugarhouse on weekends.

title: Dubcek Can't Travel to Italy
description: The former Czechoslovak leader, Alexander Dubcek, who has become increasingly critical of the Prague leadership, was not allowed to travel to Italy for the opening today of a Communist Party congress, his wife said by telephone. Mr. Dubcek, leader of the Government crushed by a Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion in 1968, last month condemned the Czechoslovak authorities for police attacks on protesters.

title: SWEET REVENGE IN PAKISTAN
description: DAUGHTER OF DESTINY An Autobiography. By Benazir Bhutto. Illustrated. 412 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: The Reality of '89 Chills the Vision of '79
description: Israel and Egypt are not celebrating their 10 years without war.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 1Pete Carril of Princeton, for four related reasons. First, he's the best technical coach around. He has devised a passing offense that still stupifies coaches whose teams have tried to defend it for years. Witnessing Princeton's back-door play can make even the most subdued fan dance for joy at the spectacle of supreme basketball choreography. Second, he adapts so well to changing players and rules. When blessed with a big man, his teams concentrate on getting the ball inside and interior passing; with the advent of the 3-point shot, Princeton's focus has shifted to perimeter passing for the open jumper. Third, Carril always gets the most out of his players. Carril recruits players of less physical prowess, but shapes them into a real team, strong on fundamentals, unselfishness, and competitive fire, one whose individual members always play within themselves and together. The final, and maybe best, reason: the second-best coach encouraged his son, John Thompson Jr., to play for Carril. NICK LEVINSON New York

title: TALKING: Gardens; Planning Plots for Condos
description: A DRAWBACK to suburban condominium living, in contrast to owning a one-family house with a backyard, is the limited opportunity for gardening. Those who seem to feel the loss most, managers report, are older people who have spent a lifetime tending a favorite plot at a former home.

title: The Bush Style of Management: After Reagan, It's Back to Details
description: President Bush is developing a highly engaged management style that is being praised in Washington as a healthy departure from the detached style of the Reagan years.

title: Finally, a Composer's Music Catches Up to His Words
description: For practically 50 years, George Perle has been known for his ability to unravel in words the intricacies of 12-tone music. Such a classic is his 1962 book ''Serial Composition and Atonality,'' one of the first attempts to explain how Schoenberg, Berg and Webern could make musical sense out of the chaos of atonality, that it will be published in Beijing, in Chinese, this year. Especially drawn to Berg, Mr. Perle has also written a definitive two-volume study of Berg's operas, ''Wozzeck'' and ''Lulu.''

title: Riding High in British Boots
description: EQUESTRIANS with horse sense can spot a pair of authentic English riding boots in any show ring or stable yard around the world. Crafted in the country that developed the formal hunt, dressage and polo, English boots are acknowledged to be the finest in terms of both craftsmanship and materials.

title: Learnng to Handle Trouble
description: NED EUSTACE found it difficult to tell his story. Three weeks before, he had come home from school to find his housekeeper of 10 years unconscious on the floor. No one else was home and although Ned summoned help, the housekeeper died of a heart attack.

title: TAILOR-MADE
description: I was told to measure up, so I did. But rather than shuffling off to shrink, shrine or spa, I went to meet my makers. And in this material world, that meant suiter, shirter and shoer. I admit that I'm too old to be a yuppie, and too young to be an old boy, but I do like nice things. So when asked to venture on an odyssey into the world of custom-made clothing, I was more than ready to dress up my dressed-down appearance.

title: A Stamford Haven for Retired Priests
description: LEAD: WHEN Roman Catholic priests retire from their ministries, they often are faced with only limited choices. Many move in with family, or even live on in their rectories.

title: POSTINGS: Expansion in L.I. City; Warehousing Art
description: Twenty years ago, E. William Judson opened a real estate office on the East Side of Manhattan and began leasing space for the many midtown galleries that sprang up as New York became the art capital of the world. As he leased more and more space for galleries, he noted that the typical gallery used half its space for storage, making such storage increasingly expensive as rents shot up. Sensing an unmet need, he bought a former paint factory in four connected buildings at 49-20 Fifth Street near 49th Avenue in Long Island City four years ago and converted them into what he believes was the first and is still the world's only commercial warehouse for art.

title: Private Efforts Are Made to Provide Lower Cost Housing
description: The problem of affordable housing is much studied, but there are now some groups and individuals who are actually doing something about it.

title: Strike at Pan Am Is Threatened
description: An official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters threatened today to stage a sympathy strike at the Pan Am Corporation to support Eastern Airlines workers as they began their third week on strike.

title: Nancy A. Shadick To Wed in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Shadick of Freeport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Nancy Ann Shadick, to Dr. William Lawrence Marshall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willoughby Marshall of Apalachicola, Fla. The couple, who are completing residencies in internal medicine at Presbyterian Hospital in New York, plan to marry in April.

title: The Military Prepares for (Relative) Austerity
description: BY taking the oath as Secretary of Defense last week, Dick Cheney entered a Pentagon that has undergone a transformation since the heady days of the early 1980's when President Ronald Reagan delivered a series of ever fatter military budgets. Unlike Mr. Reagan's first Defense Secretary, Caspar W. Weinberger, President Bush's first Pentagon chief will preside over a department that can count only on the prospect of budgets that are lean by the standard of the Reagan years, and declining expectations.

title: Louisville Stops Pesky Arkansas
description: Fourth-seeded Louisville, which narrowly survived a lethargic performance Thursday, rebounded nicely this afternoon and shook off pesky Arkansas, 93-84, to advance to the Midwest Regional semifinals.

title: WUTHERING HEIGHTS
description: I hold no brief for Samuel Goldwyn, but A. Scott Berg should not declare so assuredly that Mr. Goldwyn was wrong to pronounce ''wuthering'' as ''withering'' (''Wuthering Heights,'' Feb. 19). Years ago, several professors of English at Harvard taught me to pronounce the title of Emily Bronte's novel as Mr. Goldwyn did.

title: A May Wedding For Miss Ponvert And Peter Judge
description: Joan L. Ponvert of Locust Valley, L.I., and Warren N. Ponvert of Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Jennings Ponvert, to Peter Griswold Judge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy G. Judge of New York and Roxbury, Conn. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Elizabeth Levy, A Teacher, Plans To Wed June 3
description: Cynthia Levy of New York and Dr. Roger Levy of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Andrea Levy, to Jonathan Ian Greenfeld, a son of Drs. Albert and Sandra Greenfeld of Westlake Village, Calif. A June 3 wedding is planned.

title: Park Bandshell
description: To the Editor:

title: London Broil: Sex, Fleet St. And a Qaddafi
description: If you think the British Parliament has been preoccupied recently with the state of the economy, or by the investigation into the Lockerbie air disaster, you have been misinformed.

title: SUIT YOURSELF
description: They say clothes make the man, but it's a rare man who doesn't turn that maxim on its head from time to time, bending fashion's dictates to his own tastes and whims. On the following pages, an assortment of New Yorkers with diverse sartorial viewpoints demonstrate that, as spring 1989 rounds the corner, style is increasingly a personal matter.

title: BIOGRAFIENDS AND OTHER FOLK
description: A LONG THE RIVERRUN Selected Essays. By Richard Ellmann. 277 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title: In Other Towns, Memories of 1789
description: IT began with peasant risings, went on to arson throughout the provinces and finally caused mass executions in several major cities: the French Revolution, in spite of the primacy of Paris, was very much a national affair. Of course, not every city was as enthusiastic about the new order as the capital, but there is hardly a corner of France that did not participate in the great upheaval that ended the ancient regime. And often Paris, its reputation notwithstanding, was far from being in the vanguard of the movement.

title: Pesticide Regulation, Slow and Unsteady
description: WHAT is the public supposed to think?
