Last month, the Environmental Protection Agency identified Alar, a chemical used to make apples redder and crisper, as a carcinogen and said that it should be banned - though not until 1990. The E.P.A.'s Acting Deputy Administrator, John Moore, told a Senate subcommittee that if the substance had just been invented, the agency would not allow it to be sold. But last week, as more schools succumbed to fears of chemicals in food and banned apples from their cafeterias and some supermarket chains refused to accept fruit treated with Alar, the E.P.A. and two other Federal agencies announced that ''the Government believes it is safe for Americans to eat apples.''

title: Recycling, Reality and the New York City Apartment
description: CAN New Yorkers, already short of space in kitchens and hallways, be persuaded to pile up newspapers and add a separate garbage pail for bottles and cans? More, will they accept the inconvenience for the sake of a distant deadline?

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: So much of a stamp's design seems predictable - the name of the country, the denomination, ''postage,'' ''par avion.'' A casual glance fails to note the extraordinary skills required to produce what are often miniature masterpieces.

title: Where Doors Can Open for Troubled Youths
description: They want jobs but they are untrained teen-agers from poor families and many are runaways and dropouts. Some have served time in correctional institutions.

title: Jury Appears Deadlocked in GAF Stock Manipulation Case
description: After eight days of deliberation, the jury considering charges of stock manipulation by the GAF Corporation appeared deadlocked last night by a vote of 11 to 1 but agreed to return today to try again to reach a verdict.

title: A Plea for Adult Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Jurors Handle Stress In Death Cases
description: LEAD: THEY study gruesome photographs and absorb graphic testimony for hours on end. They are frequently isolated from family and friends, prohibited from discussing the frightening crimes they are hearing recounted. Then, after weeks of intensive proceedings, they are forced to make life-or-death decisions about the people charged with those crimes.

title: SLEEPING PILLS
description: Dr. Bruce Dobkin states that Dalmane is a short-acting drug. In fact, Dalmane has the longest half life (the time it takes for half of the drug to be metabolized by the body) of any of the benzodiazepines, or 40 to 200 hours. This means that the drug accumulates in the body when taken regularly, especially in the elderly. Patients often experience this as ''morning hangover.''

title: The Vatican and the American Ways
description: THE room where Pope John Paul II and his chief aides met earlier this month with 36 American Catholic cardinals and archbishops is austere, its brick walls adorned only with a crucifix. Now known as the Old Synod Hall, the Vatican chamber was once a storage room for fragments of Greek and Roman statuary, and was called the Hall of Broken Heads. Not an auspicious location, some might have said, for a meeting originally proposed to thrash out conflicts and misunderstandings that have arisen between the center of world Catholicism and one of its most influential branches.

title: Metro-North Joins the Hunt for Parking
description: LEAD: FACED with commuter-parking shortages at many train stations, more than a dozen Westchester municipalities have submitted proposals to the Metro-North Commuter Railroad to participate in a $20 million program to build more spaces.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Figure Skating Ito Wins First Title for Japan: Midori Ito, a 19-year-old from Nagoya, put on a stunning display of jumping yesterday at the world championships in Paris to capture the first title ever for Japan. Ito earned five 6.0's for technical merit for a program that included seven triple jumps. About 50 seconds into her routine she did a triple axel, the first time one had been completed by a woman in the world championships. In addition to the 6.0's, Ito received four 5.9's for technical merit. Her artistic-impression scores were all 5.8's except for one 5.9. She was third entering the free-skating segment, which counts for 50 percent of the total score. Claudia Leistner of West Germany edged Jill Trenary of the United States for second place. Trenary's teammate Kristi Yamaguchi, skating in her first world championships, put on a strong performance to climb one place to sixth. (AP) Golf Garbacz Takes Lead: Lori Garbacz came from two strokes back to tie Martha Nause on the 15th hole yesterday, then birdied No. 16 and No. 18 and took a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the Tucson Open. Garbacz, seeking her first victory in 12 years, shot a five-under-par 67 for a 54-hole total of 204. Her 12-under-par total broke the three-round tournament record of 205 set by Pat Bradley in 1986. Nause, who led by one shot after the first round and by two after the second, shot 71 yesterday on the 6,243-yard Randolph North Golf Course.(AP) Swimming Stanford Earns Championship: Richard Quick, who led Texas to five consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association women's swimming and diving tities, led Stanford to the championship last night in Indianapolis in his first year as coach. Quick, the 1988 United States Olympic coach, won his sixth consecutive title when Stanford, leading by 25 points going into the finals, outscored Texas by 610.5 points to 547 for its second N.C.A.A. championship. Florida, the favorite, was third with 536 points. The Cardinal won no individual titles last but placed nine swimmers in the championship heats. The Texas 400-meter freestyle relay team of Julie Cooper, Courtney Madsen, Jeanne Doolan and Leigh Ann Fetter broke the American, United States open and N.C.A.A. records with a time of 3 minutes 15.48 seconds. The Longhorns surpassed the mark of 3:16.89 set by Florida at the meet last year.(AP) Wrestling Oklahoma State Takes Title: Oklahoma State ended 18 years of frustration yesterday by winning its 28th N.C.A.A. wrestling championship. The Cowboys last won the national tournament in 1971.(AP) Fencing Westbrook in Contention: Peter Westbrook of New Jersey, an 11-time United States champion, was among the 8 American participants in a field of 106 saber fencers still in contention yesterday after the preliminary round of the two-day Penta World Cup at New York University. Bowling Weber Captures Triple Crown: Pete Weber of Florissant, Mo., became the third man to win bowling's triple crown when he beat Dave Ferraro by 221-216 yesterday for the title in the Professional Bowlers Association National Championship. Weber won the 1987 Tournament of Champions and the 1988 United States Open, the other two legs. (AP) Basketball Wisconsin-Whitewater Takes Title: Ricky Spicer scored 24 points last night, 4 of them in a closing 9-2 flurry, to help carry the University of Wisconsin-Whitewater to the N.C.A.A. Division III championship with a 94-86 victory over Trenton State in Springfield, Ohio. Wisconsin-Whitewater (29-2) also won the Division III title in 1984, and finished this season ranked third in the country. Trenton State (30-2), the top-ranked team in the final poll, had its 25-game winning streak snapped. Greg Grant of Trenton State, the leading Division III scorer with a 32.4-point average, scored 35 points in the title game to finish the season with 1,044. That broke the Division III record of 1,037 points set by Dave Russell of Shepherd College in 1975.(AP) Merrimack 98, C. W. Post 85: Gary Duda, the tournament's most valuable player, scored 32 points to lead Merrimack (22-9) past C .W. Post (19-11) yesterday at West Haven, Conn., in the championship game of the E.C.A.C. Division II basketball tournament. Juan Griles had 20 points for C. W. Post and finished up his career with 1,323 points. (AP) Tennis Graf and Evert Reach Final: Steffi Graf breezed past Helena Sukova, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday and Chris Evert defeated Jana Novotna, 7-5, 6-1, to reach the final of the Virginia Slims of Florida tournament. Graf yielded only 5 points in eight service games.(AP) Mecir and Noah Advance: Miloslav Mecir beat Jimmy Connors, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday and Yannick Noah stopped Jay Berger, 6-3, 6-4, in the semifinals of the Champions Cup tournament in Indian Wells, Calif. Noah won the tournament in 1982 and was the runner-up in 1984 and '86.(AP)

title: THORNBURGH SEEMS PREPARED TO SHUT ANTI-MAFIA UNITS
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, melding policy and an old personal desire, has tentatively decided to abolish most or all of the Government's 24 regional Organized Crime Strike Forces, Justice Department officials say.

title: Jersey Man Kills Girl, 10, And Shoots 2 More Children
description: A former mental patient shot and killed a 10-year-old girl and critically wounded two other children here this afternoon, before being killed in a gun battle with a police officer, authorities said. The officer was also wounded, but not critically.

title: 2 Senators Suggest Capital Needs Federal Police to Stem Crime Wave
description: Two Senators have suggested that the District of Columbia Police Department be replaced with a federally controlled police force.

title: NONFICTION
description: SHEEP FROM THE GOATS: Selected Literary Essays. By John Simon. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $24.95.) Gore Vidal once called John Simon a ''literary gangster,'' adding that there was nothing Mr. Simon - best known for his trenchant theater reviews in New York magazine - could not ''find to hate.'' Yet as ''The Sheep From the Goats,'' a discerning, highly idiosyncratic collection of literary essays, attests, within the gangster lies an equally ferocious, uncompromising champion of literature. Here are consistently close, irreverent readings of Roland Barthes, Norman Mailer, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Joan Didion, Lillian Hellman and Vladimir Nabokov, as well as enthusiastic and insightful pieces about Milan Kundera, Randall Jarrell and Gunter Grass. Each is meticulously detailed, unflinchingly honest and, most of all, entertaining. Granted, sometimes the entertainment is at the expense of the author under scrutiny. Yet it is hard not to admire these terse, highly polished essays, even at their most vitriolic. Mr. Simon seems to have read everything, allowing him to make thoughtful literary comparisons; he appears as familiar with the literature of Latin America, France, England and Germany as he is with that of the United States. And though his caustic wit can sometimes sound more personally vindictive than objectively critical, it allows him to plow through a lot of literary pretentiousness. Mr. Simon is not without certain pretensions of his own, however. A master stylist as well as a stickler for detail, he manages to find factual and grammatical errors in everyone from Susan Sontag to John Updike. And he has an off-putting way of sprinkling French and German phrases into his pieces - usually without providing translations - as well as using long, obscure words like ''tergiversate'' or ''gallimaufry.'' But these are minor transgressions in a book that is otherwise uncommonly lucid, witty and eloquent.

title: Dangers in Method Of Scientific Atheism
description: Re: ''A Theory of Scientific Atheism'' (New Jersey Q & A, Feb. 5): John Koster's book, ''The Atheist Syndrome,'' is but another illustration of what has come to be called the ''psychologizing'' of social phenomena.

title:
ART;
Bank's Works Focus on 80's
description: LEAD: IN 1979, the eminent art critic Barbara Rose mounted an exhibition entitled ''The Art of the 80's.'' This speculative show contained a lot of mild abstraction and completely missed the ceaseless volatility that actually put its stamp on this decade. Now, at the Montclair Art Museum comes another ''Art of the 80's.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Garfield Lowe;
Toward Understanding Truckers
description: LEAD: GARFIELD LOWE, a professional truck driver for 20 years, has logged more than two million miles behind the wheel of his tractor-trailer, with an accident-free record.

title: Ray Madoff, a Lawyer, Weds David Nicholas
description: Ray Dietz Madoff and David Andrew Nicholas, who received law degrees from New York University in 1984, were married last evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. Carl Perkins, a rabbinical student, officiated.

title: To Egypt, Peace Pact Is a Stigma on Its Arab Soul
description: The destination board at Cairo airport records the departure of flight LY444 most nights at 9:15 P.M., but it does not say where the Israeli airplane is going - to Tel Aviv.

title: TRUE BELIEVERS AND TROUBLEMAKERS
description: TOMORROW'S CATHOLICS, YESTERDAY'S CHURCH The Two Cultures of American Catholicism. By Eugene Kennedy. 208 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95. TENSIONS IN MORAL THEOLOGY By Charles E. Curran. 214 pp. Indiana: University of Notre Dame Press. $19.95. THE RESHAPING OF CATHOLICISM Current Challenges in the Theology of Church. By Avery Dulles. 276 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Wurstel
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Fare of the Country (Travel, Feb. 5), Austria's favorite Wurstel is likely these days to be loaded with MSG, which the Viennese seldom label as glutamate but rather as Geschmackverstarker or taste strengthener. Those allergic to this chemical should avoid the street stalls; when buying at groceries, check the product's ingredients. As in the United States, they are required by law. Extra schillings paid for the rare unadulterated sausage are well spent. W. R. KOGER Vienna

title: FAVORED PLAYERS ADVANCE IN BRIDGE
description: All the favorites survived in the fourth round of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Friday, but two had to come from behind at the finish.

title: Football Returns to S.M.U., but Not as King
description: The symbolism did not escape Forrest Gregg. The 55-year-old craggy-faced Texan, who still has a twang after all those years playing and coaching pro football in the Midwest, leaned back in his chair in the temporary coach's office in a trailer outside Ownby Stadium and listened to the sounds outside. Hammers pounded and jigsaws whined, indications that at Southern Methodist University, they are taking the business of rebuilding literally.

title: Little Guys Must Stand Up in the Rushdie Affair; Promotes Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Limiting the Arms That Citizens May Bear
description: ACTIONS last week in California and Washington against assault rifles left the forces for and against gun control wondering whether the balance of power between them had shifted, perhaps opening the way for approval of other state and Federal restrictions.

title: Challenging Ueberroth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Turgenev Manuscript To Be Auctioned in May
description: The manuscript of Ivan Turgenev's ''Fathers and Sons'' is to be auctioned May 18, a spokeswoman for Sotheby's said Friday. The manuscript is being offered for sale by an anonymous Briton and is expected to bring about $850,000. Last November, the manuscript of ''The Trial,'' by Franz Kafka, was sold at Sotheby's for $1.9 million.

title: A Diverse Array of Gardens Fills the Gallery at Hastings
description: COUNTRY gardens, suburban gardens, city gardens - there may even be gardens secreted on rooftops and windowsills in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson's present display.

title: 'Educating Rita' on Fairfield Stage
description: ONE who has grown accustomed to the Boston Post Road Stage Company's adventuresomeness might well be startled by the ordinariness of its current production, ''Educating Rita.''

title: A Big Deadline Looms for Keogh Plans
description: Many owners of Keogh plans are facing a double tax deadline this year. Like everyone else, they must file their regular income tax returns by April 17. But if their Keoghs are considered ''frozen,'' they may also be facing a May 31 deadline to determine the future status of their plans. A failure to act could set off stiff tax liabilities.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: PURIM CELEBRATIONS Purim, the joyous holiday that marks the deliverance of the Jews by Queen Esther from a general massacre plotted by the Persian Haman, is two days away, but Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.'s throughout Long Island are doing most of their lighthearted celebrating today.

title: DEAR DR. KARL
description: THE SELECTED CORRESPONDENCE OF KARL A. MENNINGER, 1919-1945 Edited by Howard J. Faulkner and Virginia D. Pruitt. 432 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Flights of Fancy In Daytime Suits
description: Just in time for this transitional, between-seasons period, several of the more free-spirited designers have come up with new suits that have almost literally taken flight. Ungaro, for instance, has reinterpreted a romantic, 18th-century look, with dipping peplums, puffy sleeves and lavish lapels (near right). Richly appliqued suede (below) is the choice of Valentino, while Thierry Mugler's jackets have bat-winged peplums (far right). The snappy, double-breasted pin-stripe number is by Lolita Lempika, a Frenchwoman who shows that even when it's buttoned, a suit doesn't have to be buttoned up.

title: Diane T. von Gal to Wed Brian Woods
description: Plans for an April 29 wedding for Diane Tekakwitha von Gal and Brian Joseph Woods have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Vreeland von Gal of Stamford, Conn. Mr. Woods is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Woods of Sussex, N.J. Ms. von Gal graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn., and Ithaca College. Her father is a senior attending physician at Greenwich Hospital and a partner in the Greenwich Radiological Group. She is a granddaughter of the late Justice Gerald Nolan, a former Chief Justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Boston; Soap-a-Rama: The Chic Place to Tan and Launder
description: Orange neon lights complement Art Deco design, and a Simon and Garfunkel tune plays on the radio. To the right, a handful of Boston University students relax on couches around a large-screen television set to watch the Cosby Show. To the left, a washing machine changes cycles, and dryers hum as students fold their clothes. Two students sign up for a tanning session before spring break.

title:
FOCUS: The Bay Area;
Development Renews Hopes for BART
description: LEAD: THE start of construction this month on a 200,000-square-foot office building and next month on an Embassy Suites Hotel adjacent to the Bay Area Rapid Transit station in this quiet suburb 25 miles east of San Francisco draws renewed attention to planners' hopes of directing suburban development toward stops on the 17-year-old BA

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Trying to Shed The Image Of 'Animal House'
description: The Dartmouth fraternity system was once so zany that it became the model for the 1978 movie ''Animal House.'' But that system is about to change. Indeed, the Greek Rush now taking place at Dartmouth will be the last of its kind here.

title: FICTION
description: THE EDGE OF THE WORLD. By Janusz Anderman. Translated by Nina Taylor. (Readers International, Cloth, $14.95; Paper, $7.95.) As in his previous volume of short stories, ''Poland Under Black Light,'' Janusz Anderman has, in this new collection, used the voice of the crowd to express the anguish and confusion of contemporary Poland. It's a pity that the flavor of the original is somewhat lost in translation (Polish working-class accents and rhythms have been reduced to English cockney slang), but the power and intensity remain. Mr. Anderman employs a cinematic style, juxtaposing sardonic visual images: as the National Theater burns down, a Japanese cameraman hopefully calls out the names of Solidarity leaders while the crowd taunts him with the words ''shogun, shogun''; as amateur gardeners huddle around their allotments, trying to protect their seeds from Chernobyl's radioactive dust, a crowd gathers in hopes of seeing miraculous apparitions that are supposed to have taken place nearby; as a military ceremony proceeds, its chilly pomp is broken by a man in a sheepskin jacket who cheekily writes the word ''Victory'' on a nearby bus shelter. The vision Mr. Anderman presents of life for the working poor is grim. Gullible and ignorant (at one point a little boy asks his grandfather, ''What was it like in Walesa's time?'' and the old man is unable to respond), they're sure nonetheless that something, even if they don't know quite what, is going on - and they're determined to be a part of it. This mute vision is interpreted by the thoughts and commentary of two intellectuals, writers who appear in the first and last stories of the collection and who give a gentle and ironic frame to the book. Unlike most of the Polish writers who were shaped by the politics of the 1960's, Mr. Anderman has not picked poetry as his medium. Nor has he shied away from the double burden of the writer as reporter and spokesman in a censored society. His vision is often grotesque, but never derivative.

title: CORRECTION
description: The title of a motion picture mentioned in the Critics' Choices column of the Home Entertainment page last week was given incorrectly. It should have been ''Hey-Hey in the Haystack.''

title:
The View From: Refined Sugars Inc.;
A Plant's Output Combines Mystique and a Product
description: LEAD: CORPORATE Westchester's image is of sleek offices set in verdant grounds. If a company makes a product, one assumes it is not done at corporate headquarters - imagine an industrial plant on Platinum Mile!

title: Martha E. Mitchell to Wed Paul J. Savidge in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Ebbitt of Bronxville, N.Y., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Martha Elizabeth Mitchell of Washington to Paul James Savidge of Silver Spring, Md. Mr. Savidge is a son of Robert J. Savidge of Wayne, Pa., and the late Dolores T. Savidge. The Ebbitts are the future bride's godparents. A September wedding is planned. Miss Mitchell is a daughter of the late Martha Beall Mitchell and the late John Newton Mitchell of New York and Washington. Mr. Mitchell served as the Attorney General of the United States. The future bride, an associate with Dean & Associates, a consulting concern in Washington for the housing industry, graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn., and Georgetown University.

title: In Great Buffalo Hunt, Prey Has Little Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: GLASNOST WRITING: SON WHERE'S THE GOLDEN AGE?
description: Imagine the freedom of suddenly being able to write what you think - after years of censorship, of suddenly being able to say the things you want to say instead of only the things the authorities will let you say - and you will have some idea of both the excitement and the difficulty of being a writer in the Soviet Union today.

title: Clare Westerfield, a Coach, And James H. Evans Marry
description: Clare Westerfield, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Putney Westerfield of Hillsborough, Calif., and New York, was married yesterday to James Harwood Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Evans of Lake Como, Italy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Terence J. Horan at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Burlingame, Calif.

title: Against the Wall
description: What is 12 feet tall, 120 feet long and red, or at least rust, all over? It is ''Tilted Arc,'' a curving steel wall by the sculptor Richard Serra that was at the center of a prolonged artistic battle. The work, commissioned by the Federal Government in 1981, bisected a portion of Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan. Many downtown workers found it obtrusive, but other New Yorkers saw it as a statement of artists' rights. The Government wanted to decommission the wall to create more open space. Last week, Mr. Serra gave up his court fight to stop the removal but said that every artistic work commissioned by the Government now would be in jeopardy of censorship.

title: Remembering Paul Robeson
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space. I would also seal the crawl space vents in winter, then open them in summer. What is your opinion?

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The Perils of Adolescent Dieting
description: LEAD: WHEN the parents of 11-year-old Melissa B. were told by a physician that their daughter suffered from malnutrition, they were shocked.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Every man and woman who has ever dated knows that the process is not simple. If it's a blind date, a first date or one of the first dates, it boils down to a game of chance. The other person may be pleasant and presentable, but that's no guarantee of anything. Thousands of pleasant, presentable people are boring, pedestrian and erased from the mind as quickly as they disappear from view.

title: Sports of The Times; How About an Academic Media Guide?
description: Side by side, the brochures were stacked in press rooms at all eight sub regional sites in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament this weekend. Quickly and efficiently, the sports information director for each tournament team had produced a post-season media guide to update the regular-season guide. Pages and pages of stats. Pages and pages of puffy profiles.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN: Uncommon Thoughts on Common Things. By Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $16.95.) Over the years Robert Fulghum's personal credo, based on the simple lessons we learn as children, has been widely photocopied and distributed, even making it into the Congressional Record.

title: Waiting for No. 1
description: The National Football League's newest coach, Jimmy Johnson, who is taking over the Dallas Cowboys, is not one to rush into a decision. So with more than a month to go before the N.F.L. draft April 23, Johnson, who has the first pick, still hasn't announced his choice.

title: SPORTING LIFE
description: While the ubiquitous jogging suit of the 1970's has virtually vanished from the streets, a whole new generation of authentic sportswear - from bicycling tights to driving shoes, baseball caps to wet suit ''rash guards'' - has cropped up to take its place.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
SONGS OF NORWAY
description: LEAD: When EDVARD GRIEG: The Man and the Artist (University of Nebraska, $50) first appeared in Scandinavia in 1980, it was immediately recognized by Norwegian and Danish critics as the definitive resource on Norway's pre-eminent composer. With the release of this new edition, in an elegant translation from the Norwegian by William H.

title: Clare E. Brokaw Is Engaged
description: Clare Elizabeth Brokaw and Andrew John Speyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gunther J. Speyer of New York, plan to marry in August. Their engagement was made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Brokaw of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Soviet Maverick Is Charging Dirty Tricks in Election Drive
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick populist whose election battle has become a referendum on the Soviet establishment, charged today that the Communist Party had used dirty tricks to obstruct his campaign and might try to falsify the election results.

title: Caroline R. Fribourg Wed To Jonathan Adam Rosen
description: The wedding of Caroline Renee Fribourg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michel Fribourg of New York, to Jonathan Adam Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rosen of New York, took place last evening at the bride's home in New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich officiated.

title: The Dark Side of Holmes
description: IN ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, the well-known Baker Street detective is examined from a new perspective.

title: THE GUIDE
description: SOUNDINGS

title: U.S. Considering Diplomatic Shift on Afghanistan
description: The Bush Administration is considering a formal break in relations with the Soviet-backed Afghan Government, but is not ready to recognize the rebel government in exile, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Remembering Paul Robeson
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigger Den for Lions
description: Pennsylvania State University's Board of Trustees yesterday approved plans to add nearly 10,000 seats to Beaver Stadium and $2 to the price of football tickets for the Nittany Lions' games. ''The unparalleled success of the Penn State football program has taxed the capacity of Beaver Stadium beyond its current limits,'' said Jim Tarman, the athletic director.

title: GOODNESS AS A TACTIC
description: A STRATEGY FOR PEACE Human Values and the Threat of War. By Sissela Bok. 202 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: Prisoner Swallows Bedsprings
description: A county court judge has ruled that doctors may remove 100 metal objects, including bedsprings and razor blades, from the stomach of a prison inmate, Carl E. Rhoades, 32 years old, without his consent. Mr. Rhoades, who is considered suicidal, is serving 10 to 20 years at the Kansas State Industrial Reformatory for drug possession and battery. He swallowed the metal a week ago and resisted having it removed in a hospital here.

title: 4,400-Year-Old Mummy Unearthed, Smiling
description: The mummy of an aristocratic young woman, her smile frozen in a plaster death mask, has been unearthed in a shallow pit at the foot of the Great Pyramid of Cheops.

title: It's Spring. Go Balance an Egg.
description: Assuming fair weather and enough spring fever, scores of people will gather tomorrow morning in the plaza at the World Trade Center in Manhattan. At 10:29, the moment of the vernal equinox, they will attempt to stand eggs on end. Many will succeed, in a small triumph of folklore over common sense, if not science.

title: Render Unto Caesar . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Sprouting Buds of Uncertainty
description: THIS spring, while some people let their fancy turn to thoughts of love, others will be worrying about the New York area housing market.

title: Under Siege, N.R.A. Fights 'The Hysteria'
description: The gun museum on the ground floor of the National Rifle Association's headquarters here is very calm, or as calm as any place can be that features displays of double-barrel shotguns, bolt-action rifles, toggle-breach semiautomatics, Smith & Wesson .44 magnums, pocket Derringers, British muskets, Japanese ceremonial guns, Bowie knives, powder horns, boar and lion heads and a prize photograph of a woman with a large snake around her neck.

title: To Look at the Hits Is Often to See the Misses
description: There can be no easier way of feeling culturally disenfranchised than to insist on seeing the most popular film in the nation each week, whatever it may be. Reading everything on the fiction best-seller list might offer a comparable shock, but it could never match the immediacy of a really bad (as is so often the case) hit film. Much of the time, the week's biggest moneymaker is an action or horror picture; sometimes it's an Arnold Schwarzenegger vehicle, which is to say both. As of last week, both the No. 1 and No. 2 box-office slots were occupied by comedies - comedies that reveal much more about the national psyche than many of us probably want to know.

title: Marjorie Goodstein Weds
description: Marjorie Pamela Goodstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Goodstein of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Russell Newman, a son of Mickey Newman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Sanford Newman. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated at the Pierre, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub.

title: John Not Pitching His Way Off Staff
description: The odds on Tommy John have been long every spring for the last three years. He has come to camp without a guarantee or a job, but he has always left the warmth of Florida with a spot on the Yankee pitching staff. Auditions have become a part of all his springs.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Allendale
description: LEAD: TO drive through the 2.9-square-mile Borough of Allendale in heavily developed northwestern Bergen County is to feel a sense of tranquility and spaciousness.

title: Youth Agencies Protest Trims in Cuomo's Budget
description: A LITTLE-NOTICED clause in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget message threatens to dismantle most youth programs in the county, officials of Westchester youth agencies warned last week.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WHERE WE LIVE: A Social History of American Housing. By Irving Welfeld. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) ''By looking at housing,'' Irving Welfeld writes, ''we are looking at America.'' In ''Where We Live,'' Mr. Welfeld, a policy analyst at the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, provides a well-written and provocative overview of the policies that have transformed American slums, suburbs and cities during the past 60 years.

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: Richard Taylor's claim that his case is ''fairly typical'' is a gross libel on his colleagues. His letter does not mention that 20 years before retirement, he moved to a house 90 miles from his university, abandoned all but the bare minimum of his academic activities, and, for a number of years, devoted himself mainly to the keeping of bees.

title: Sensitive Mission: Retelling Oliver North's Story
description: Oliver North was sitting at a defense table in the Federal District courthouse, writing notes on a yellow legal pad and fixing unsympathetic witnesses with a blue laser gaze. He seemed smaller and slighter than he did when he first burst on the national scene during the Iran-contra Congressional hearings, his dashing aura dimmed by nondescript suits and the drone of the trial.

title: Italian With Imaginative Informality
description: WHAT are the ingredients that assure a restaurant's success? If there were a textbook answer to that question, every entrepreneur opening an eating establishment would be guaranteed a quick return on the investment.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Casino Act's Second 7: Construction Funds
description: LEAD: IN the five years since the state established the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority to channel mandatory loans from the gambling industry into urban revitalization, the focus of its attention has been Atlantic City, where $145 million has been committed to the development of 1,042 new and renovated housing units.

title: Cuomo and SUNY Say They'll Temper Tempers
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and officials from the State University of New York say they are trying to tone down their unusually harsh clash over the Governor's proposed budget for the system.

title: Diane L. Cohen To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Cohen of New York and Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Lynn Cohen, to Robert Alan Cohen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Cohen of Roslyn, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Cohen, president of Irene Cohen Personnel Inc. in New York, graduated from the Rochester Institute of Technology. Her mother, Irene Cohen, and her father, who is the president of Employee Leasing of New York Inc., a business management services concern, are the chief executive officer and the chief financial officer, respectively, of Irene Cohen Personnel. Her mother is also a director of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GONDAR. By Nicholas Luard. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) If you're looking for adventure and romance on a lavish scale, forget the latest television mini-series and pick up this 10th novel by the British writer Nicholas Luard, a rich saga of the Abyssinian kingdom of Gondar and the coming of age of its Queen Esther.

title: Fires Burn 4,000 Acres of New Jersey Pinelands
description: Two forest fires in southern New Jersey burned more than 4,000 acres of environmentally important Pinelands before being brought under control yesterday.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: A long-debated puzzle concerns the fact that at the highest levels of the game men are far more successful than women. In more than half a century no woman has ever won an open world title, and very few have come close. The pattern is similar in national championships, both in North America and other parts of the world. Why this should be so is not clear since - unlike chess - women players outnumber men and devote more time to the game.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: A near-complete collection of brilliant proof trade dollars is at auction in Sotheby's sale of the Harry Warshaw Collection of United States coins on Tuesday. The trade dollar is an exotic coin evoking the long-lost days of the China trade. The Warshaw pieces are in beautiful condition.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Canon has introduced a new single-lens-reflex camera that raises the ante on the notion that our cameras should know more than we do about how to take pictures. Christened the Canon EOS 630, it also brings a new level of integration to the various and sundry automatic functions built into modern-day SLRs.

title: State Ties Funds to L.I. Commissioner's Fate
description: New York State has threatened to suspend $4.5 million in payments to Suffolk County if county lawmakers do not reverse their decision this week to reject the appointment of a new Suffolk commissioner of social services.

title: SLEEPING PILLS
description: Though generally accurate and informative, the Body and Mind column ''Sleeping Pills'' (by Bruce H. Dobkin, Feb. 5) may have fallen victim to overzealousness in its attribution of Cindy Ehrlich's psychiatric symptoms to the use of Halcion and Xanax.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Purim Potpourri

title: For the Mentally Ill, an Escape From 'Sheltered Workshops'
description: Although much of the movement into the workplace has been by individuals with physical handicaps, people with mental disabilities are also starting to make progress. And the growing number of placement programs designed for them is why.

title: BEST PLACE TO PLAY, AS USUAL, IS HOME
description: On Nov. 26 at Madison Square Garden the Knicks routed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 127-112, and began a home-court winning streak that would become the longest in the team's history.

title: Bringing Jobs and Housing Closer - By Force if Necessary
description: LIKE runoff from the mountain snow pack, the cars begin to seep into the freeways as the morning sun rises over Southern California. Soon tiny creeks converge into rivers of moving steel, carrying workers from the remote inland reaches of the state to jobs in Los Angeles and Orange County.

title: The Time Has Come for Equitable Pay in All Professions
description: WHILE driving home from work the other night on the Merritt Parkway, I was passed by a sleek red sports car. I caught a glimpse of the driver's bumper sticker as she went by: ''Women run for office, not coffee.'' My sentiments exactly.

title: In 'Brewster Place,' Women Lead the Way
description: Let's hear it for women. That worthy sentiment comes through heartily in ''The Women of Brewster Place,'' the four-hour television movie being broadcast on ABC tonight and tomorrow, beginning at 9 each night. The problem: Just about nothing is heard for men who, almost without exception, are dismissed as irresponsible, even vicious louts. The film could be subtitled, without too much exaggeration, ''Revenge of the Black Female.''

title: Pine Valley's Incorporation Blues
description: LEAD: TIRED of living in a Hamptons backwater, the people of Pine Valley voted to break away from the Town of Southampton last year to become Long Island's newest incorporated village.

title: Report on Prices Delivers a Jolt
description: A jump in wholesale prices gave economists and the markets a shock. The 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index for February matched the January rise, and put the annual rate at an alarming 12.6 percent, triple the 4 percent rate of 1988. The wholesale report on Friday followed other statistics that seemed to offer hints that the economy might be cooling a bit and inflation pressures might ease. February retail sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent, with auto sales down a sharp 1.7 percent. Reports from the auto makers in Detroit said the weakness continued into March, with sales off 14.8 percent for the first 10 days of the month. The Government also reported that industry operated at 84.3 percent of capacity in February, edging down from the 10-year high of 84.5 percent reached in January. And housing construction fell 11.4 percent last month.

title: Make More Goods and Prices Will Fall
description: After nearly eight years of overcapacity, the American rust belt has revived. The upturn is the first decent chance in several years for American companies to gain ground on their foreign competitors. The question now is whether this upturn will only be a short-lived illusion - or whether American companies can use this breathing spell to improve their competitive position.

title: NOVEL APPEAL
description: T. Coraghessan Boyle is exactly who he appears to be, but at age 40, he's a pretty complex package. He'll tell you everything about himself, but first just look at him - 6 feet 3 inches tall and built like a pencil. Relaxing at home, he wears a black leather jacket over a black T-shirt with a school of fish painted on it, and baggy, pleated gray pants. There's a thin red cord - it looks like a shoelace - tied around his neck. His hair, the color and consistency of soapy steel wool, tufts out at the sides of a black beret. His mustache and goatee are nearly Mephistophelean.

title:
GARDENING;
Nasturtiums Please the Eye and Palate
description: LEAD: HAVE you eaten a nasturtium sandwich lately? Don't be too sure you haven't. If you've had watercress, then you've had nasturtium.

title: ANJELICA RISING
description: In 1984, my 11-year-old son was hired as an extra for a wedding scene in ''Prizzi's Honor.'' I remember thinking how strikingly beautiful Anjelica Huston was (''Anjelica Rising,'' Feb. 12).

title: About Long Island; The Video Yearbook
description: THE 10 good-looking senior class girls doing a mean shimmy at Division Avenue High School in Levittown the other night will have a choice 20 years from now.

title: 'THE GOOD ONES NEVER MAKE YOUR VIRTUOUS'
description: HOOKED By Pauline Kael. 510 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: Sara Johns Wed To T. G. Griffen
description: Sara Elizabeth Johns, a daughter of Dr. Margaret A. Johns of Mountainville, N.Y., and D. Craig Johns of New York and Pawling, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Gaines Griffen, a son of Dorothy Griffen of Hudson, N.Y., and the late Charles R. Griffen. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alan Macy, a Congregational minister, at the United Church of Christ in Lenox, Mass.

title: The Roof's No Limit for Britain's Thatchers
description: Christopher White hoisted a bundle of Norfolk reeds and climbed to his rooftop workplace, repeating a timeless ritual in the ancient craft of thatching, which after decades of decline has dramatically revived in recent years.

title:
GARDENING;
Nasturtiums Please the Eye and Palate
description: LEAD: HAVE you eaten a nasturtium sandwich lately? Don't be too sure you haven't. If you've had watercress, then you've had nasturtium.

title: IT'S KOSHER
description: Beginning about a decade ago, a younger generation of Jews decided that there was no reason why they had to be masochistic to be observant when it came to the High Holy Days. Many of them ba'alei teschuva (returnees to the faith), they were also sophisticated in matters of food and drink. They refused to accept the viscous, sweet sacramental wine of their elders and demanded something better, or at least something more in tune with their modern tastes.

title: Now Concert Halls Pay House Calls
description: Playing symphonic music in the living room defies the natural order of things.

title: Wagner in Bits And Pieces
description: Until the LP arrived, most Wagnerites knew his work only in discontinuous form, either from the chunks served up at orchestral concerts or in drastically condensed versions available on bulky 78-r.p.m. disks. These fragmented performances were often pieced together from a bewildering variety of sources. A fair idea of what the record collector in pre-LP days could hope to discover about ''Tristan und Isolde'' has been re-created on CD by Claremont (GSE 78-50-26).

title: Byron's Computer-Programmer Daughter
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA SPIRITS SOAR AS SHUTTLE LANDS
description: Cheered by an estimated 450,000 well-wishers, the space shuttle Discovery swooped out of a clear dawn sky and made a perfect landing here today, further bolstering the spirits of the nation's space agency.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY;
As It Was and Still Is
description: LEAD: DESPITE advances that have been made in photographic materials and techniques in recent decades, there is still an active interest in various early methods.

title:
DINING OUT;
Some Artful Presentation in Brewster
description: LEAD: FOR more than 20 years we've heard how wonderful the Arch could be. To our disappointment, our experience on numerous visits contradicted that reputation. That is, until recently. Of late, preparation and presentation of food showed obvious care and expertise.

title: Tragedy of Abuse As Entertainment
description: Perhaps Edith L. Ellenbogen [ Letters, March 5 ] did not read the article by Geraldine M. Fox (''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29), for which I wrote a comment. The idea seems to be that networks are using abuse victims as drawing cards. Talk shows use the tragedy of abuse as a form of entertainment. Anyone who is unaware of this terrible suffering would have to be living in a cave.

title: Reviews/Music; Bach's 'St. John Passion,' With a Few Additions
description: A special point of interest in the performance of Bach's ''Johannespassion'' at St. Thomas Church Tuesday night was the inclusion of five numbers added to the work in 1725, two years after its first performance. They have been made easily available to performers within the past decade by their appearance as an appendix to the Barenreiter edition of the score, but have not been generally adopted; this listener had never heard them in a performance of the complete ''Passion.''

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The hallmark of a great combination is its embodiment of fantasy, of what appears at first sight unreal, uncanny or some kind of magician's trick.

title: Burning The Mortgage, Savoring the Years
description: WE'RE going to burn the 30-year mortgage if the bank remembers to send it to us. We've been living in the briar patch for 30 years, and it seems more like 50.

title: Installing Counter Tops
description: COUNTER tops stocked by home centers and cabinet supply companies are relatively easy to install.

title: In Israelis' View, the Frostiness Is Undeserved
description: The 10th anniversary of the most joyous event in Israel's recent history - the signing of peace with Egypt - will, by deliberate choice, pass virtually unnoticed here.

title: For Readers, a New Social Chapter
description: Books are drawing members of the ''me'' generation out of their urban solitude and into intimate discussion groups. From recent college graduates to people a generation older, these readers are confounding the conventional wisdom that video has replaced vellum.

title: Young America, Sagging
description: LEAD: While the fitness boom of the last 10 years has pushed our adult population near the top rank among nations in fitness, our children rank somewhere near last place.

title: Water Companies Filing Requests For Big Rate Rises
description: IN Greenwich, there is talk of a takeover of a water company that has been privately run for nearly a century. ''If they keep raising the rates, it's something we're going to have to consider,'' said First Selectman John B. Margenot Jr. The utility that serves Greenwich, the Connecticut-American Water Company, is seeking a 33 percent rate increase, which would make it the third in as many years. And around the state, other water companies are seeking more and higher rate increases than ever.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space. I would also seal the crawl space vents in winter, then open them in summer. What is your opinion?

title: Fate of Church Divides a Neighborhood
description: The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, a United Methodist sanctuary and an official New York City landmark, is falling apart. On that, there is no argument.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
For Westchester, 3 Hotels With 710 Rooms
description: LEAD: DESPITE the hotel industry's only recent emergence from a slump in Westchester, three hotels with a total of 710 rooms are being planned, with groundbreaking for one expected as early as this fall. Industry officials disagree over whether the additional rooms will help or hurt.

title: Staking a Claim To Territory Still Uncharted
description: We have just moved to the juncture fo Westchester County and Putnam County.

title: Mark Stein Weds Laura Chamberlain
description: Laura Chamberlain, an Assistant New York City Corporation Counsel, and Mark Stein, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, were married last evening in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El. Elissa Stein Cushman, the bride's sister-in-law, was her matron of honor, and Kathleen Durkin was maid of honor. Ronald Nimkoff was the best man.

title: In Kabul, Soviet Officials Make Themselves Scarce
description: Until the last Soviet troops withdrew from the Afghan war, the Soviet presence in this capital was of imperial proportions. But barely a month later, the last Soviet officials in Kabul are a forlorn sight, working in a fortress of an embassy and complaining of waning influence even with the Marxist rulers their forces came here to sustain.

title: Haggis
description: To the Editor: As a Scot who serves haggis at New Year's and sometimes on other occasions I enjoyed the article by Amanda Mayer Stinchecum (Travel, Jan. 22).

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Daffodils, tulips and other spring-flowering bulbs are pushing up; apply fertilizer now so it is available to bulbs in summer when they will form flowers for spring, 1990. Transplant seedlings to a one-one-one soil mixture. Use rakes to clean up lawns and remove winter debris; add to compost pile. Finish pruning. Apply dormant sprays. Catching Up

title: Wisconsin Tops St. Lawrence, 4-2
description: Chris Tancill snapped a 2-2 tie at 6 minutes 12 seconds of the third period tonight, leading Wisconsin to a 4-2 victory over St. Lawrence and eliminating the Saints from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I playoffs.

title: Alan V. Davies, 47, Real-Estate Executive
description: Alan V. Davies, president of the J. Clarence Davies real-estate concern in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Reverse-Mortgage Availability Gaining
description: LEAD: WERE it not for a $538-a-month payment she gets from 1st Nationwide Bank in Huntington Station, Nathalie Bischoff by now would have had to leave the home in Southold she and her late husband bought in 1965.

title: Nest as Nest Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Inside Co-op Buyer

title: The Dark Secret of Risotto Nero
description: SHORT and long grain, polished white, natural brown, saffron yellow - Americans have become casual, even blase, about the variety of rice available at home and abroad. In Italy, however, Europe's major rice-producing country, it is still possible to find an unexpected choice: black rice.

title: Kevin Zraly and Raymond Wellington - Wine Buyers
description: Wine aficionados in the United States are faced with a staggering embarrassment of riches. So many wines from around the world are available here one could spend a lifetime studying them. Two young New Yorkers who do that, and in the process set wine trends in New York City and far beyond, are Kevin Zraly, 38, wine director for Inhilco, which runs Windows on the World and 21 other restaurants in the World Trade Center, and Raymond Wellington, 35, wine director for the New York Restaurant Group, in Manhattan, which includes Smith & Wollensky, the Post House and the Manhattan Ocean Club.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $615,000 280 Hamilton Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, greenhouse, pool, 1.27 acres; taxes $8,886. New Rochelle, N.Y. $1.8 million Central Drive 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; maid's suite, fireplace, sauna, atrium, playroom, pool, water access and mooring; taxes $16,967. Rye, N.Y. $530,000 3 Eldredge Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; fireplace, patio; taxes $7,750. New Milford, Conn. $229,000 18 Revere Road 4-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; fireplace, southern exposure, 1 acre; taxes $2,022. Morris, Conn. $225,000 50 John Weik Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; newly renovated, 250-foot frontage on pond, 1.8 acres; taxes $1,187. Farmington, Conn. $148,900 15 East Shore Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 3-year-old Cape Cod; formal dining room, walkout basement, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $941. OTHER AREAS Millburn, N.J. $230,000 59 Locust Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old Tudor; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, formal dining room; taxes $3,201. South Orange, N.J. $250,000 25 Wesley Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $6,460. Bay Shore, L.I. $155,000 173 Maple Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; enclosed porch, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300.

title: Discovering The True Tragedy Of the Projects
description: BECAUSE I am black, throughout my life I have expected acceptance in any black neighborhood I chose to roam.

title: Bad Day for Capistrano? Here Come the Swallows
description: When the swallows come back to Capistrano this Sunday, a punctual reaffirmation of nature's rhythms, some residents will be waiting for them with garden hoses, tin cans and loud music in the hope that when they build their summer nests it will be under someone else's eaves.

title: Coalition Helps Stem Dropout Tide
description: LEAD: A NEW effort to identify and counsel at-risk youth at Mount Vernon High School is being financed by the Westchester Coalition, a nonprofit community-service organization based in White Plains.

title: War of Starvation In the Sudan Is Frustrating U.S. Diplomacy
description: WITH the Prime Minister of the Sudan, Sadiq al-Mahdi, sitting just feet away, an American official told an international gathering here this month that the Sudanese Government had to improve the way it delivered food relief to the country's famine victims. It was the most public message so far in which the United States Government called on Khartoum to allow neutral humanitarian relief operations into rebel and Government areas during a civil war that has caused devastating starvation.

title: ONCE MORE INTO THE EMBASSY
description: MOSCOW STATION How the KGB Penetrated the American Embassy. By Ronald Kessler. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: 'Rita' Is Staged in Fairfield
description: ONE who has grown accustomed to the Boston Post Road Stage Company's adventuresomeness might be startled by its ordinary current production, ''Educating Rita.''

title: 2 Troupes Team Up for New Play
description: PROPELLED by the common cause of social consciousness - and a creative cost-cutting method of play production - two of the state's newest small professional theater companies have joined forces in the world-premiere staging of a work about the conflicts surrounding independence for Puerto Rico.

title: Louis A. Landa, 87, Professor at Princeton
description: Louis A. Landa, professor emeritus of English at Princeton University, died of kidney and heart failure Friday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 87 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; Swindling in 'Jugglers'; Cotillion in 'Coming Out'
description: At the end of an afternoon of tennis, four former Ivy League classmates, now middle-aged, their manners intact, sit on the lawn of a handsome old Long Island estate. They sip their martinis and toddies and recall another classmate, Lester Gordon. Low-born and Jewish, Lester has recently flown off to Portugal to escape prosecution in a scandal that has left his financial empire in ruins.

title: THE GUNS OF SALVADOR
description: As an experienced journalist, James LeMoyne knows his craft and the country he covered. That's why it is puzzling that his assessment of El Salvador (''The Guns of Salvador,'' Feb. 5) was so pessimistic. He must know that important gains have been made in that troubled Central American country.

title: Review/Dance; 2 Clowns Who Indulge Their Taste for the Zany
description: For Anne Iobst and Lucy Sexton, it was just an ordinary evening at home. They blew the fuses while doing housework, threw an ironing board at each other and dueled with scrub brushes. Offstage antagonists pelted them with vegetables. Ms. Iobst drank from a fishbowl. An amorous lion dropped by. So did mechanical toy bears.

title: DEFICIT FIGURING
description: The most serious confusion in Charles R. Morris's article (''Deficit Figuring Doesn't Add Up,'' Feb. 12) is his belief that because uncertainty about the deficit is immense, we should not worry about it.

title: Bush Must Keep Steady Fording the Rapids
description: President Bush said in Texas last week that changes in the Soviet Union, and China, are ''profound. It will never go back to the way it was.'' This is true, and it is of great importance that it is recognized by America's leader because it highlights a whole new era confronting the U.S.

title: Oregon's High Desert On Display
description: ON a perch at the High Desert Museum in Bend, Ore., 166 miles east of Portland, Mrs. Thomas sits alert, her wide eyes blinking at regular intervals. A loud screech from her neighbor, Owliver, makes her swivel her head to the left with an indignant look, then snap it back. A muffled electronic buzz sounds from a perch across the room, and Owliver spreads his wings and swoops over to it, snapping up a piece of food next to the buzzer.

title: A Wooden Nickel in The Tin Cup
description: It should have been easy to predict a few decades ago, when American symphony orchestras and opera companies first began to rattle their tin cups and plead for government aid, that majority taste would eventually affect and probably erode their artistic independence. Why not? The prime business of a democratic government is to discover what most people want and try to please them. Arts councils receive their funds from popularly elected legislators and, despite the occasional well-intentioned grant to promote avant-garde works, such politically entwined aid will eventually tend to reflect the interests and tastes of the majority. Nothing could be fairer, in fact. Any strategy that tried to thwart the majority's wishes would be repugnant to good egalitarians.

title: Tenacious Princeton Defies Expectations
description: To the athletes dressed in Princeton black and orange who find themselves somewhere between adolescence and middle age, the coach with the cigar in his mouth must seem as if he has been passing on the same principles since basketballs were directed into peach baskets.

title: But Could They Write Hamlet?
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRY OPPENHEIMER'S EMPIRE: GOING FOR THE GOLD
description: IN MINING, THEY CALL IT THE MOTHER LODE - AN ARTERY of precious minerals, hidden amid tons of bedrock, that can elude prospectors for years.

title: DATA BANK: March 19, 1989
From Apples to Terrorism, Governments Try to Answer How Safe Is Safe Enough
description: For the last week, governments here and abroad have been grappling with one of the most basic and complicated questions that human beings face: what risks are worth taking?

title: POSTINGS: Wired for Law Firms; 125,000 Square Feet in White Plains
description: Despite a glut of commercial space in the New York metropolitan area, another office building is being built in White Plains, which has one of the lowest vacancy rates in this area. Louis Cappelli, a partner in the Cappelli Development Corporation of Valhalla, N.Y., which is undertaking the $23 million project, said ''construction of office projects in White Plains has been synchronized with demand, which has reduced the haphazard overbuilding that has led to the series of booms and busts in office space in other areas.'' White Plains has an office vacancy rate of about 6 percent, about half that of the metropolitan area in general.

title: Study Warns of Threats to the National Parks
description: Warning of growing threats to national parks' ability to serve as ''oases for life and spirit,'' an independent commission today called for sweeping changes in the National Park Service.

title: Waiting for the New Soviet Economy
description: IN the jury of journalistic opinion, from New York's Newsweek to London's Economist to Moscow's Znamya, the verdict on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's perestroika these days is that it has failed. Looking at the shambles of Soviet industry and the paucity in stores, few Soviet watchers would consider this an eccentric judgment. He himself pointed to the abysmal condition of agriculture last week as the Communist Party approved his new farm policy.

title: Children Make the 60's New Again
description: The generation gap may be narrowing, if children's accessories are any indication. Youngsters are complementing their neon novelty wear with emblems of the 1960's.

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: It is professors like Richard Taylor (Letters, Feb. 19, in response to ''Higher Education - The Real Crisis,'' by Michael I. Sovern, Jan. 22), who teach no more than five hours a week, never prepare their classes and have all papers read by graduate students, who have caused the enormous workload under which the rest of us labor. (I write this at 2 A.M., with at least another hour of preparation and grading ahead of me).

title: On German Stages, a Society Explores Itself
description: Richly supported, well equipped and maintained, filled with talented, intelligent and imaginative actors, directors and designers -West German theaters would seem to have it all.

title: Fuzzy Laws Help Blur the Boundaries
description: Are financial professionals mostly greedy, dishonest people who came to the business ready to rip off the system? Certainly such people exist, but the cause of crime on Wall Street is far more complex than this and remedies are even more elusive. Granted, individuals can destroy the integrity of the markets, but the markets can also destroy the integrity of individuals. In short the very structure of the securities industry works to destroy ethical conduct.

title:
MUSIC;
Helping Prevent Injuries to Pianists
description: LEAD: DOROTHY TAUBMAN is a pianist and teacher who has gained a reputation for retraining many injured pianists and helping them to resume their careers comfortably - even after years of pain. She will give a lecture and a master class at 1 P.M. today at the County College of Morris in Randolph.

title: Chamber Music Plus On Bill With Fidelio
description: A FEW years ago, Chamber Music Plus, which is in its ninth season at the Old State House in Hartford, decided to expand its operations. It is now presenting some fascinating recitals at three other locations.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: Review/Music; Fiddling On the Piano
description: Stephen Scott has developed a new way to play a piano. He and the nine other members of the Colorado College New Music Ensemble ignore the keyboard, remove the lid and thread nylon fishing line or miniature horsehair bows between the strings to play them directly. At Town Hall on Thursday, the ensemble leaned over a grand piano like a team of surgeons to play two compositions by Mr. Scott.

title: An Indifferent Death on the 7:38
description: THE train shuddered to a halt just after the crossing at Hoyt Street, as though the engineer were testing the brakes. Hardly any of the commuters on the 7:38 from New Canaan to Grand Central looked up from their newspapers.

title: The Power of Accessories
description: Women of style have always known what a potent tool an accessory can be. With one stroke, the right handbag, careful conglomeration of jewelry or even a hat can give an older, familiar costume a new configuration.

title: A Winter Windfall From Empty Skies
description: LEAD: THIS year's mild and snow-scant winter may be a skier's nightmare, but it has been public works director's dream.

title: POSTINGS: Across Fifth Avenue; Polishing A New Facet
description: Another sign that Manhattan's diamond district is breaking out of its traditional location and growing eastward across Fifth Avenue is the new character being given an office building at the southeast corner of Fifth and 48th Street. Renovations to make it suitable for jewelry companies and purchase of the building are costing the new owners $50 million.

title: Around Town, 'Slaves of New York' Do the Party Circuit
description: Most of the characters in the new film ''Slaves of New York'' probably never went to Bloomingdale's, but that is where their real-life counterparts were last Tuesday night for cocktails, to benefit the New York Preservation League. The downtown art-world crowd portrayed in Tama Janowitz's book met 300 other guests in the ''Slaves of New York'' boutique. Bill O'Connell and Jennifer Rowland of Merchant Ivory Productions, which produced the film, were relieved the filming was over. ''We're not slaves of New York; we're slaves of Merchant Ivory, which is much harder,'' Miss Rowland said.

title: Kathryn Cruze and Charles Dietzgen, Lawyers, Are Married on Long Island
description: The marriage of Kathryn Mary Cruze to Charles Antoine Dietzgen took place yesterday at The Creek country club in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Pierpoint Project Moving Forward
description: LEAD: THE city's Community Development Agency has been reviewing contracts for the revised Pierpointe-on-the-Hudson condominium project now that an environmental dispute over development of the waterfront site has been settled.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford; Shop Uses Humor To Encourage Safe Sex Practices
description: One of the things that student volunteers at ''Ye Olde Safer Sex Shoppe'' at Stanford University want to prove is that ''not all condoms are created equal.''

title: Penny Paul to Wed in August
description: Virginia M. Paul of New York has made known the engagement of her daughter, Penny, to Michael Edward Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Moran of Weston, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Oxon Hill, Md.;
description: LEAD: A WASHINGTON developer has finally started preparing the site for a new town called PortAmerica on the banks of the Potomac River in Prince George's County.

title: 4 Senators Charge Auto Group Is a Foreign Agent
description: Four Democratic Senators have asserted that a group representing sellers of imported cars is a foreign agent, and they have asked the Justice Department to investigate it.

title: SPECIAL TODAY Men's Fashions/Magazine Part 2
description: They say clothes make the man, but often it's just the reverse: Personal style is the message.

title: The Complex Art Of Egypt After the Pharaohs
description: The imagery of copticart - owl-eyed women, plump birds, exotic beasts, pagan mythological figures and Christian symbols - comes alive in highly expressive tapestries, artifacts and stone sculpture produced in Egypt under the Romans and Byzantines. Long overlooked by scholars and museum curators, this early Christian material is now the subject of an ambitious exhibition here at the Rhode Island School of Design's Museum of Art through April 16.

title: Sampling the Music of the Easter Season
description: ONCE again the familiar strains of Faure's ''Palms,'' Handel's ''Messiah'' and the medieval lilt of plainsong enrich church services countywide, as people gather to mourn the death of Christ and celebrate his Resurrection.

title: ; Tall Ships and Modern Times
description: ALL that the general public sees of the shipyard here in Greenport is the high wooden fence painted gray, which serves as a gallery wall to display large nautical artifacts of iron. There are anchors, propellers, a winch and other curious and mysterious things. Not junk, these, though old and rusty, but objets d'art, well spaced, resting on wood chips.

title: ONE MAN'S ODYSSEY
description: SAUL BELLOW'S Herzog, on the verge of a nervous breakdown, decides there's only one thing to do: head for the men's shops on Madison Avenue. ''Therefore, he went shopping for clothes.'' When I first encountered this passage, it scarcely registered. It was the 1960's, and I was in college. No one cared about clothes. We had our own style, of course: Frye boots, jeans, leather jackets - the campus revolutionary look. Only we didn't know it was a style. As far as I was concerned, good clothes were reactionary: The only people I ever saw in them were members of the debating team or the student council president.

title: Inch Putt Evades McCumber
description: Missing a golf ball completely is the most ineffective stroke in golf. Mark McCumber, whose ball was one inch from the 17th hole today, may have come up with the second most ineffective shot when he stroked the ball and it did not reach the cup.

title: PRINTS OF THE CITY
description: PICTURING AMERICA, 1497-1899 Prints, Maps, and Drawings Bearing on the New World Discoveries and on the Development of the Territory That Is Now the United States. By Gloria Gilda Deak. Illustrated. Volume One: Text. 657 pp. Volume Two: Illustrations. Unpaged. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $250.

title: South African Party Avoiding Clash With Botha
description: National Party legislators have backed away from an immediate showdown with President P. W. Botha over his refusal to yield the presidency to F. W. de Klerk, his successor as party leader.

title: A New Market for Old Partnerships
description: In the last two years, a secondary market has emerged for public limited partnerships in everything from real estate to oil drilling to computer equipment.

title: 'Poor Man's Salmon' Arrives in April
description: Sometimes called ''the poor man's salmon,'' American shad will begin arriving in the rivers of the Northeast by mid-April.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER County has joined the ranks of countless other governmental bodies in considering a local law that would limit smoking in public places. The county proposal, said to be a compromise plan, would require restaurants serving 75 or more people to set aside half the seats for nonsmokers and require employers to adopt written smoking guidelines and establish smoke-free work areas ''to the extent practical.

title: Bitter Harvest: AIDS and the Arts
description: It would hardly be an exaggeration to describe American culture in the late 1980's as art in the era of AIDS. Art has confronted AIDS the way people confront AIDS - with fear, anger, sorrow, defiance and confusion. In a country that idolizes youth and health, AIDS has struck at the very heart of the American self-image. Art about AIDS reveals something raw in the American soul.

title: Media Mergers: An Urge to Get Bigger And More Global
description: BY announcing plans to merge, Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. have become the latest converts to the twin gospels of giantism and globalization that have swept the communications industry worldwide during the 1980's. Their adherents are many, and skeptics seem few. But what explains the trends, and how much sense do they make?

title: Commuter Air Services Hurt by Eastern Strike
description: LEAD: Commuter airlines that provided flights connecting to Eastern Airlines have eliminated routes to more than 20 cities, as these airlines and the cities they serve have become casualties in Eastern's 14-day strike.

title: Ban Murder Machines. Then What?; The Drug War Needs More Than Panic
description: Foreign agents are organizing disaffected young Americans and arming them for war. They have already seized control of whole neighborhoods, murdering hundreds in the process. Police and public officials are outgunned and overwhelmed.

title: REAGAN AND THE PHILIPPINES: Setting Marcos Adrift
description: THE WORLD LOOKED on with amazed admiration in February 1986 when Corazon C. Aquino ousted Ferdinand E. Marcos as President of the Philippines. It was an episode almost too melodramatic to be true. A paragon of piety, Mrs. Aquino attributed her triumph to divine intervention. But American intervention helped as well.

title: Show of 19th-Century Prints Emphasizes Utility Over Art
description: LEAD: THE broad range of printing techniques available in the 19th century, before the commercialization of photography, made prints a lively and inexpensive means of communication. Prints advertised everything from the Sunday paper to the arrival of the circus to views on politics.

title: A Calendar of Music Events for Holy Week
description: ONCE again, the familiar strains of Faure's ''Palms,'' Handel's ''Messiah,'' and the medieval lilt of plainsong will enrich church services throughout the state, as people gather to mourn the death of Jesus and celebrate the Resurrection.

title: Give My Remains to Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Opinion Split on Plan to Drop Compulsory Physical Education
description: LEAD: SCOTT BARA, a 15-year-old freshman at South River High School, wrestles and plays football. ''There's so much physical activity in these sports,'' he said, ''that I feel it's enough without compulsory gym. What we need is more time for other classes or to pick up an extra study hall.''

title: Trust Your Agent
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Moon Palace'
description: In somber, cerebral and terse narratives, Paul Auster has hunted down his obsessions. The missing father, the limits of language, the past as a crime we are driven to solve: from these themes, Mr. Auster has built a reputation as a post-modern gumshoe, fusing the conventions of detective fiction with Beckett-like despair.

title: Steven Meisel - Photographer
description: Steven Meisel defines his style of photography as ''a little bit outrageous, a little bit crazy or sick - when I'm allowed to do what I want.'' But his work hasn't been too outrageous for Clairol, the Gap, Barneys New York, Vogue or Vanity Fair. And Marc Jacobs, the new designer for Perry Ellis, says Mr. Meisel is the person to revitalize his company's advertising image.

title: The Mounties In Law Enforcement
description: The About Long Island article featuring the Nassau County Police Mounted Unit (''The Nassau Mounties'' Feb. 26) reflects a recent trend, rediscovering horses as a unique resource in modern law enforcement.

title: New Yorkers Strengthen Seton Hall
description: Six years ago, when they first met as teammates for New York's Riverside Hawks in the church league, John Morton and Gerald Greene were high school juniors with a penchant for playing fancy and footloose basketball.

title: 'YOUR MOTHER IS IN YOUR BONES'
description: THE JOY LUCK CLUB By Amy Tan. 288 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: In New Jersey's Race, The Principal Issues Are Taxes and Taxes
description: NO one can talk politics for long in New Jersey without talking about a state tax system that many people believe is out of whack. But the question of how to fix it brings forth a plethora of ideas that pit poor cities against rich suburbs, Democrats against Republicans, and legislator against legislator.

title: S.A.T.'s Are Not The Only Criteria
description: The sob sisters are at it again, this time bewailing the alleged bias or fatuousness of Scholastic Aptitude Test exams (''S.A.T. Exams: One Size Doesn't Fit All,'' March 5.) For the crybaby, naive, nonastute individuals, let it be known that there are no college admission officers who solely look at S.A.T. scores to determine the eligibility of an applicant.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Hearty, Flexible Lunch That Can Stand In for Dinner
description: Sunday shopping ought to be relaxed and Sunday shoppers should be prepared to make last-minute substitutions. Chances are that at least one item on your shopping list won't be available at your market.

title: Laxity Found in Checks on Hiring of Illegal Aliens
description: The immigration law calls for sanctions against those who employ illegal aliens, but Federal officials have checked only 0.2 percent of the nation's employers for compliance, says a study made available today.

title: Reviews/Dance; Subtle Contrarities in Movement and Sound
description: Robert Kovich has an intriguing stage presence. His face is almost a mask of blandness. But a gleam of diabolical amusement lurks beneath that mask and in the way he moves. And there was a similar contradiction in the two dances Mr. Kovich presented on Thursday at St. Mark's Church.

title: A 10-Minute Chance to Win OverA Small but Demanding Audience
