description: LEAD: BACKSTAGE a man who looked like Bjorn Borg dressed as Marcel Marceau juggled with such intensity that the spinning clubs seemed propelled more by an act of will than a flip of the wrist. In comical counterpoint, a workman slouching in a seat nearby ate fried chicken.

title: Newark Will Hold Meeting on Auto Thefts
description: MORE than 300 lawmakers, insurance experts and law-enforcement officals are expected to meet in Newark tomorrow to try to devise solutions to the problem of automobile thefts in New Jersey.

title: Marvin Hamlisch to Marry Ms. Blair, Producer, in May
description: Terre Blair, an independent television producer in New York, and Marvin Hamlisch, the composer and musician, plan to be married in May. The future bride is a daughter of Marie M. Blair of Columbus, Ohio, and Dr. William D. Blair of Circleville, Ohio. Mr. Hamlisch is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Hamlisch of New York.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Trees That Bloom - After Spring
description: LEAD: Beware of the ''spring appeal,'' those plants that can dominate the garden's appearance for the year. A wise homeowner should remember that the garden is a 52-week event and not just a spring color bash!

title: A Nun With a Secular Mission
description: LEAD: THE first time that Sister Carmela M. Cristiano approached the developer Donald J. Trump, she says, she was treated like a beggar. Even so, it was the beginning of an artful deal. ''I was very perturbed over the fact that so many welfare recipients are young persons in their teens and 20's living in motels, and the system was paying $1,500 a month for them,'' Sister Carmela said recently.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: In New York in the last few months, a developer who paid a $2 million fine for illegally tearing down some single-room occupancy hotels in the middle of the night is now erecting a skyscraper hotel on the same site, and naming it after himself. Another developer put up an apartment building with 12 more floors than the zoning allowed, and has been trying to work out a deal to avoid tearing down the illegal stories, which contain 24 apartments that could sell for more than $500,000 each. A third developer made a deal with the city to erect a 74-story tower over City Center on West 55th Street, buiilt it 11 feet taller than his agreement permitted and then successfully convinced the city to allow him to keep the extra height.

title: THE BROTHERHOOD OF THE WASP
description: OUR KIND OF PEOPLE The Story of an American Family. By Jonathan Yardley. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $21.95.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell $185,000 498 Windeler Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, hardwood floors, 2 acres; taxes $1,812. Jackson $133,000 4 Rhode Island Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage, c/a; taxes $1,603. Livingston $575,000 8 Camelot Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old contemporary; 2-zone heating, fireplace, den; taxes $6,309. Millburn $230,000 59 Locust Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old Tudor; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, dining room; taxes $3,201. South Orange $250,000 25 Wesley Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $6,460. West Orange $230,000 30 Dogwood Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, deck, fireplace in living room; taxes $3,700. OTHER AREAS Islip Terrace, L.I. $131,000 589 Connetquot Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Rye, N.Y. $530,000 3 Eldredge Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; fireplace, patio; taxes $7,750. New Milford, Conn. $229,000 18 Revere Road 4-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; fireplace, southern exposure, 1 acre; taxes $2,022.

title: From the Economy and a Civil Rights Bill WHAT'S NEW IN EMPLOYING DISABLED PEOPLE;
description: People with mental and physical disabilities have come a long way since the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which requires the Government and institutions receiving Federal funds to make reasonable efforts to employ the handicapped.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 19, 1989
Automobile Insurance: Paying More for Less
description: LEAD: DESPITE new laws aimed at reducing premiums, many motorists pay more for automobile insurance now than they paid last year, but they are getting less coverage, formulas used to set premiums by most of the state's insurers show.

title: BACK IN TIME
description: TIME WAS, a man's watch was just a timepiece: classical, understated and functional. Now watches tell a lot more than the time of day. They seem to offer a number of clues about the men who wear them, and serve, at the same time, as conspicuous status symbols. These days, more and more men concerned with quality as well as image are returning to the classic mechanical-movement watch of the past.

title: Grace N. Kooper Plans to Marry David Johnson
description: A June 24 wedding is planned by Grace Natalie Kooper, the daughter of Justice Sybil Hart Kooper of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and David Dean Johnson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton L. Johnson of Tacoma, Wash.

title: Miss Sand to Wed Eric Straus
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jay P. Sand of Wayne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Natalie Sand, to Eric Peter Straus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: School Debates Indian as Mascot
description: AS the mascot of Newtown High School, the image of an Indian warrior graces everything from the school welcome mat to the jackets on the back of the school's athletes. But students are now debating whether the mascot is a form of racial stereotyping best left behind.

title: LAY DOWN WINS GREY LAG
description: Lay Down, overtaken on the lead by three rivals as they turned for home, came roaring back in the final yards to run down Its Acedemic and win the $85,300 Grey Lag Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CONTEST AND PARTY Today is Palm Sunday, but it will seem like Easter at the Best-Dressed Contest and Holiday Party at the Wildwood Convention Center.

title: And Now, a Word from the Sponsor
description: We'll return to our spreadsheet calculations in a moment, but first, these messages from the growing number of companies that want to bring us disk-based interactive advertising.

title: SLEEPING PILLS
description: I am most grateful to have read Dr. Dobkin's piece on sleeping pills. I have been taking benzodiazepines for over four years, and recently experienced severe anxiety, a pounding heart, thirst and so on. My doctor prescribed Librium as a remedy, and I felt worse trying that.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SOUTH WILL RISE AT NOON. By Douglas Glover. (Viking, $16.95.) Tully Stamper is a failed artist and businessman, a drunk, a jailbird, a dodger of reality. But alongside the other picaresque residents of Gomez Gap, a small town in the Florida panhandle, he seems almost normal. However, he doesn't belong, and so his days are numbered.

title: A Tommy John Operation: So Successful, It's Old Hat
description: Ken Dayley was a popular person this winter.

title: Colombia Signs a Pact For Talks With Rebels
description: The Government and the country's most feared guerrilla group have signed an accord to begin talks toward ending nearly two decades of insurgency.

title: Pen Palindromes
description: WE RECENTLY dipped into the palindromes offered by the surname of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. (Headline about a supposed order to an unnecessarily weight-conscious chef at the White House mess: '' 'Dessert!' Sununu Stressed.'') ''Surely you haven't already forgotten the palindromic Mr. Staats,'' writes Michael G. Gartner, the editor and language maven who now runs NBC News. ''I think Elmer Staats was Comptroller General, which might give you a chance to tell us that >comptroller is pronounced 'controller.' At least, that's how we liberals pronounce it. Maybe you compservatives have a different view.''

title: Medics Sleep; Patient Dies
description: Two paramedics have been dismissed after they slept through three emergency calls for a heart attack victim who died on the way to the hospital. ''We have determined that human error was at fault,'' Pat Gouldy, vice president of the Dallas-Fort Worth Medical Center, said Thursday. Clarence Cowden, 77, was dead when he arrived at the hospital Feb. 8, about an hour after his wife first called a 911 dispatcher. The ambulance service since has installed loud alarm bells in each station, Ms. Gouldy said.

title: The Pilots' Crusade At Eastern
description: When the executive board of the Air Line Pilots Association met early last week to discuss the continuing strike against Eastern Airlines, it was not just plotting a course for 3,500 idled Eastern pilots, but was also checking the bearings of the entire pilots' union.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: Reviews/Theater; Light Touch For the Book Of Revelation
description: The Apocalypse of St. John, or Book of Revelation, is a most dramatic book, filled with fiery beings, battles in Heaven, Lucifer plunging into hell, the four ravaging horsemen, the destruction of the world at Armageddon and the creation of a new universe. Among other books of the Bible the nearest competitor is probably the Book of Daniel. There is a long tradition of theatrical readings of both of them, by single actors or groups.

title: Alison Schmults And C. H. Burns To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Schmults of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Creighton Schmults, to Cameron Horatio Burns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horatio Winspear Burns of Big Timber, Mont. A May wedding is planned.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Haverford; 'Suitcase Party' Offers an Escape From Gray Winter
description: ''I love America,'' declared Sanjiv Mehta, a native of India who is a freshman here. Mr. Mehta's declaration was prompted by his selection as one of the two grand prize winners of the ''Suitcase Party,'' a Haverford tradition that combines music and food with a chance to win a dream vacation.

title: Black Artists, Past and Present
description: CURRENTLY, the art at Art at 100 Pearl Street is by African-Americans. It is an awkward way of introducing an exhibition, but then Art at 100 Pearl is both the name and the address of the branch recently opened in Hartford by the Connecticut Gallery of Marlborough. Besides, the show itself is awkward, for it spans the last 100 or so years, yet numbers only 26 painters and sculptors and, hence, is less a survey of the black contribution to American art than a glance at it.

title: Leslie Alexander, Painter, Marries L.R. Luhring Jr.
description: Leslie Smith Alexander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Alexander Jr. of Westport, Conn., and Lawrence Raymond Luhring Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Luhring of Kitty Hawk, N.C., were married yesterday at the Congregational Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights by the Rev. Dr. Richard L. Stanger. The bride is a painter and the curator at the Fred Alger Management Collection of Art in New York. She graduated from the Philadelphia College of Art and received a master of fine arts degree at Hunter College. The bridegroom, a partner at the Luhring Augustine Gallery, a contemporary-art gallery in New York, graduated from the University of Virginia.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FACES. By Shirley Lord. (Crown, $18.95.) When Teri Shepard, fading model and mother of Alexa and Jo, goes to a Los Angeles face clinic - called the Fountain Rejuvenation Clinic - she precipitates a trail of havoc and mayhem leading helter-skelter through the wilder reaches of the cosmetics industry, fashion journalism and the society of New York high rollers.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Vacant Schools Get New Roles
description: LEAD: SCHOOL district administrators are finding that unneeded and vacant elementary and secondary schools can fetch handsome prices for uses well beyond residential conversions.

title: With Soviet Weapons to Lean On, Kabul Is No Pushover
description: RESIDENTS of Kabul had little trouble waking last week. Shortly before dawn on most mornings, a noise like a giant thud echoed across the Afghan capital, followed by a roar that rapidly faded away. The sound would be repeated before quiet returned, and then on sporadic occasions later in the day.

title: It's Time To Stop Our Busy, Busy Lives
description: MY friend, a lawyer, takes his briefcase to the ball game. He even takes it to a cocktail party. He works a minimum of 70 hours a week and is proud of it. The word ''leisure'' is not in his vocabulary. ''Can't waste a minute, you know,'' he says over his martini. ''Time is money. If you're gonna make it big, you'd better get started.''

title: President Witnesses a Birth As Pet Dog Has Litter of 6
description: Millie, the President's English springer spaniel, gave birth to six puppies late Friday and early this morning.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LIFE OF A BALLPLAYER Three actors will share the role of Ty Cobb, the great Detroit Tigers baseball player of the 1930's, in a new play by Lee Blessing called ''Cobb.'' The play will take the ballplayer from childhood through his declining years.

title: 124-81 Rout Restores Oklahoma
description: Mookie Blaylock scored 34 points and Stacey King had 21 with 15 rebounds today as fourth-ranked Oklahoma beat Louisiana Tech, 124-81, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. Southeast Regional. The top-seeded Sooners (30-5) showed a spark that had been missing for several games as they advanced to the regional semifinals for the third straight year. They will play next Thursday in Lexington, Ky., against Virginia, which defeated Middle Tennessee State by 104-88.

title: Social Events
description: Party at the Plaza

title: Little Guys Must Stand Up in the Rushdie Affair; Assault on the West
description: To the Editor:

title: A Return To No Man's Land
description: I FIRST CLIMBED HILL 229 as a Marine lieutenant commanding an infantry platoon during the Korean War. Last summer I climbed it again. I puffed upward, aware that I was no longer the physically fit soldier of 36 years ago. But I was heady with excitement over the chance to view my old battleground, now part of the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea.

title: Setting the Table for Kids' Cuisine
description: With its white tile floors, dark wood paneling and neon beer signs, Dalt's on Roswell Road in affluent North Atlanta has the look of dozens of the hip theme bars and eateries that began appearing back in the era when people could use the term ''swinging single'' with a straight face.

title: Reid Is Suspended
description: J. R. Reid, North Carolina's leading scorer, was suspended today for his team's second-round Southeast Regional game Sunday against U.C.L.A. for violating curfew Friday night.

title: Following Killer's Directions, Searchers in Utah Find Bones
description: Searchers who followed directions given by Ted Bundy before his execution found bones and the tattered remnants of a blouse Friday near a site where the multiple murderer said he buried a 17-year-old girl in 1974.

title: Little Guys Must Stand Up in the Rushdie Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: UPWARDLY MOBILE IN PRAGUE
description: I SERVED THE KING OF ENGLAND By Bohumil Hrabal. Translated by Paul Wilson. 243 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Federal Fee Plan Angers Fishermen
description: LAST summer when George Bush visited the New Jersey shore, he made a campaign pledge: No Federal licensing fees would be imposed on saltwater fishermen if he became President.

title: Christina M. Reid Engaged To Wed M. W. Dickerson
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Reid of Flossmoor, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christina Marie Reid to Michael Wyatt Dickerson, a son of C. Wyatt Dickerson and Nancy Dickerson, both of Washington. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: MAKEBA: My Story, by Miriam Makeba with James Hall. (Plume/New American Libarary, $8.95.) Born in South Africa, the black singer Miriam Makeba has drawn on her Swazi culture to endure a career in political exile. Her autobiography is the story of ''life lived as communal dialectic, a matter of African creative will set against bureaucratized repression,'' Robert Farrris Thosmpson said here last year.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. CLASSICAL

title: Paranoia: Fearful Delusions
description: MY WIFE and I purchased our home from the estate of a woman who had recently died. All we knew about her was that she had been an elderly widow. Yet you could tell that her last years had not been happy ones. One clue was the heavy steel doors she had had installed front and back. The front door was equipped with an apartment-style peephole, which was needed because she had had the windows in and around the door covered over with contact paper. All of the windows in the house were covered with Venetian blinds, drawn shut, and two layers of curtains, pulled tight. In this friendly, quiet neighborhood, she had fashioned a fortress.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: Business Ignores Shoreham Realities
description: Last week's Long Island Weekly contained a polemic by a member of the Association for a Better Long Island calling for the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The association seems to argue that we should open Shoreham because the Long Island public will not accept the construction of alternative power plants in any neighborhood. Once again, the Long Island business community ignores the intelligence of Long Islanders and places profits before people.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Fiji to Reduce Duties Affecting Tourists' Costs

title: Byron's Computer-Programmer Daughter; Incredible Insight
description: To the Editor:

title: Spouting Off
description: ONE WANTS TO CALL IT A TEMpest in a very large teapot. Or maybe a controlled weather experiment. What it is, basically, is a 17-foot-high artificial tornado - a sculpture, of sorts, that will be publicly on display beginning next Saturday at the New York Hall of Science, one of the remaining buildings from the 1964 World's Fair in Flushing, Queens. Shown at left (with a Hall of Science employee, Dale Garcia), it's called ''Temple of the Whirlwind'' because, says its creator, Ned Kahn, ''the structure that creates the vortex is reminiscent of a Greek temple.''

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Were it not for the general ebullience of the writing, the Lovejoy adventures by Jonathan Gash might be reading a little thin by now. There is a great deal of formula writing in this popular series. Usually the books start with Lovejoy broke and in trouble. They end with him still broke and in even more trouble.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
For Minors, Abortion Limits Have Side Effects
description: LEAD: AS the abortion debate heats up, in the courts and in the streets, several recent studies have raised questions about laws that limit minors' access to abortion. The issue is whether the laws, in effect in a handful of states, meet their goals of promoting family unity, decreasing abortion and even discouraging teen-age sex.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 19, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 2 2 3 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay find themselves enacting the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 3 3 4 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 1 ONE UP ON WALL STREET, by Peter Lynch with John Rothchild. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Advice on investing in stocks by a veteran fund manager. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) The title character of the seventh novel by this talented and very amusing storyteller is a saintly little fellow, at once freakish and Christlike, an object of reverence for Mr. Irving's fed-up-with-this-wicked-nation narrator. LOVE LIFE, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A collection of live and breathing stories that take place in landlocked Middle America, populated with good country folks to whom their wise and potent creator never condescends. LEO AFRICANUS, by Amin Maalouf. (Norton, $17.95.) Mr. Maalouf's rich historical novel concerns the career of the great 15th-16th century geographer, scholar and adventurer, born a Muslim in Granada; he is the author's witness to the decline of refined Islam in the West and the rise of boisterous Europe. A MOTHER'S STORY: The Truth About the Baby M Case, by Mary Beth Whitehead with Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) An eloquent account that pleads the cases, personal and general, against surrogate motherhood. CHARADES, by Janette Turner Hospital. (Bantam, $18.95.) An energetic, intelligent novel about a woman who pursues a missing father through scientific metaphor and cosmological fictions. FAREWELL, DRESDEN, by Henri Coulonges. (Summit, $18.95.) Order is dissolved and childhood innocence shattered in this harrowing French novel about a young German girl's experience in the 1945 Allied firebombing of Dresden, and its aftermath. WAY OF DEATH: Merchant Capitalism and the Angolan Slave Trade, 1730-1830, by Joseph C. Miller. (University of Wisconsin, $35.) An intercontinental study of slaving to Brazil, a trade far larger but less well known than its North American analogue.

title: Preventing Work Injuires Can Curb Corporate Health Costs
description: Companies are taking more aggressive steps to prevent workers from becoming disabled and to speed the recovery of those who do. And for a good reason. Claims for workers' compensation have skyrocketed, jumping 60 percent since 1983 to more than $26 billion last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And as health care costs escalate, those outlays are expected to climb to $90 billion in 1998.

title: A Program Returns to Church
description: SEVEN enticements fill this afternoon's schedule, including the return of Music for a Sunday Afternoon to Tarrytown's Christ Episcopal Church. This follows a brief hiatus during which, according to the artistic director, Dorothy Beach, ''We lost one piano, but finally found another.''

title: Snacks Aren't All Bad
description: LEAD: NORMAL, healthy children and adolescents must eat a variety of foods and get their calories from different sources, says Nancy Moses, chief pediatric nutritionist at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset.

title: Reviews/Theater; Second Series of One-Act Plays
description: Stream of consciousness is always a tricky business in the theater. Shakespeare was a master, and the Greeks employed choruses to similar effect. Sam Shepard and Lanford Wilson are among the modern playwrights who can seamlessly weave asides to the audience into their dramas.

title: Reading Between the Lines
description: LEAD: ''DEAR Giselle: Thank you so much for your postcard with its birthday greetings. I was delighted to receive it and have but one question: How come, in the many years we've known each other, you have never thought of sending me birthday wishes - except for this year when, on my birthday, you happened to be in

title: Farmers Market to Open in Weston
description: WHEN Hillary M. Lee moved to Weston from Alexandria, Va., recently, she was disappointed to learn there was no local farmers market. So, with the help of the State Department of Agriculture and growers from Connecticut Farm Fresh, Mrs. Lee has organized a farm market that be open on Saturday mornings beginning in late spring in the parking lot of the Weston Library, in the center of the town.

title: James Lapine Seasons 'The Winter's Tale'
description: James Lapine Does not want to bowl you over with some tricky directorial concept. He just wants to tell you a story.

title: PURE AND SIMPLE
description: Eating Italian used to mean a bottle of red wine, a loaf of garlic bread and a thousand tomatoes over spaghetti and veal alike. Then came the revolution.

title: Likely Rightist Victory in El Salvador Poses Major Policy Challenge for U.S.
description: Shortly after an earthquake leveled large parts of this country three years ago, Agapito Hernandez Aquino quit as Mayor of San Pedro Nonualco in disgust and resigned from the Christian Democratic Party.

title: Reviews/Theater; Seeking Life's Meaning, In Musical, 'Cradle Song'
description: Almost like a puppy pulling at one's trouser leg, ''Cradle Song,'' a new musical that opened for a limited run Wednesday night at the Theater at Saint Peter's Church, is doing its best to be liked. It is an unabashedly sentimental story about a modern young upwardly mobile couple and how they discovered, the hard way, what the best things in life really are.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Amherst; Prohibition Tried, But the Results Are Familiar
description: It might have been called ''dry week,'' but life at Amherst College was as wet as usual last weekend.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Lipstick for the Unconscious

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THOMASTON;
When Think Pink Day Comes, Can Spring Be Far Behind?
description: LEAD: COME Tuesday, the small town of Thomaston, a western Connecticut community of about 6,500 residents, will ''think pink,'' its way of marking the long-awaited arrival of spring.

title: Sutton on Way Out?
description: His program is under the cloud of a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation, and although he has not been personally accused of wrongdoing, Eddie Sutton appears to be on his way out as the Kentucky basketball coach.

title: Kimberly G. Waldorf Wed to Brian Mercer
description: At the Reformed Church in Brookville, L.I., Kimberly Gail Waldorf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Helmuth Waldorf of Brookville, was married yesterday to Brian Krick Mercer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Mercer of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Allan Ramirez performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Mario C. Costa, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: It Seems to Me I've Heard That Song Before Photo of the cover of the sheet music of a song to be heard at the Vineyard .
description: Saturday night, 1943, mid-Atlantic. The second mate, a young fellow mourning lost moments with his girlfriend, has that damned ''Juke Box Saturday Night'' on the record player again. He's been playing it over and over again, including Sundays through Fridays, and the Glenn Miller record is wearing thin.

title: New Store Brings U.S. A Less Serious Armani
description: Young people in black leather and women in furs had their noses pressed against the window of the new Emporia Armani boutique on lower Fifth Avenue in Manhattan last Tuesday. It was past 10 A.M., the shop's scheduled opening time, but members of the sales staff, wearing navy blue Armani suits, were hanging the last jackets and getting their last-minute orders. Shortly after 11, the first customers came pouring in.

title: From the 50's, a Series of Brushes With Greatness
description: The 1950'S and abstract expressionism, the heroic painting style that put American art on the map, are ever with us. Anyone with a passing interest in contemporary art can recite the great names of that bygone yet omnipresent era when Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman and others arrived. Equally familiar is the chain reaction that their various achievements set in motion: the advent of Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg and Pop Art and Minimalism. From greats to second-rates the score is known and the history is set - or is it?

title: Remembering Paul Robeson
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space. I would also seal the crawl space vents in winter, then open them in summer. What is your opinion?

title: Journalists - And Con Artists
description: Janet Malcolm, a writer who has skillfully explored many worlds, has a talent for the socko start. Hear the way she begins a recent two-part article in The New Yorker about a lawsuit brought by Jeffrey MacDonald, a convicted murderer, against Joe McGinniss, who wrote a best seller, ''Fatal Vision,'' about him:

title: A 'Ticking Bomb' but No Explosion
description: When President Reagan found himself confronted last year with a proposal to require most employers to notify workers and local and state government authorities 60 days in advance of plant closings or major layoffs, he viewed it as such a burden on business that he vetoed the entire trade bill to which it was attached. Such groups as the National Association of Manufacturers lobbied heavily against the plant-closing measure, which President Reagan called ''a ticking time bomb in the back seat of any medium-sized or larger company.''

title: Dog Lovers Plot in the Parks To Throw Away Their Leashes
description: This was not ''Sunday in the Park With George.'' Rather, it was Wednesday in the park with Giorgio and the rest of the dogs. It was a great, sweaty revel of dogs running free after dark in Central Park, of dog owners cheering them on, whistling, tossing out balls and generally behaving like country people.

title: Debuts; A Pianist and a Soprano Give First Recital
description: Alan Chow

title: Irish to Wear Red
description: In the hotly competitive world of big-time college football, Notre Dame has always remained aloof from the controversial practice known as redshirting, extending selected players' careers by sidelining them during one of their first four seasons so they can play a fifth season.

title: Lois M. Brenner To Wed in May
description: Lois Margaret Brenner, a lawyer, and Robert Stein, a retired magazine executive, collaborators on a book about divorce, plan to be married in May.

title: Siena Is Beaten; Duke Advances
description: Fortune looked fondly upon Siena College again this afternoon. Then, just as suddenly as the Saints seized the lead with 13 consecutive points midway through the second half, fortune turned away.

title: CLINIC WILL BECOME AIDS NURSING HOME
description: The oldest clinic in New York City will close in May, and its Greenwich Village site will become a nursing home for AIDS patients.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE LIBERAL REPUBLICANS: From 1952 to the Present. By Nicol C. Rae. (Oxford University, $29.95.) Nicol C. Rae's book received emphatic punctuation when perhaps the most prominent and powerful of the few remaining liberal Republicans, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, declined and fell last November.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Since insulating the ceiling of my vented crawl space under the house, I have had trouble with the water pipes freezing in cold weather. I have wrapped some of the pipes with electric heating tape, but this is not possible under the main part of the house. To prevent freezing, I am contemplating taking off the insulation under the main part of the house and insulating the walls of the crawl space. I would also seal the crawl space vents in winter, then open them in summer. What is your opinion?

title: College Admissions: The Other Side
description: With thousands of higher-education institutions operating in the United States today, deciding on the ''right'' college is not an easy task.

title: An Island Odyssey: From England to Big Apple to Long
description: JUNE 8, 1961, was the auspicious day on which I arrived in New York City, a brand-new, green-as-grass, wide-eyed immigrant from England, come to seek my fortune.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Great Barrington;
Controls On Growth
description: LEAD: BUILDING projects here are encountering official scrutiny and frequent public opposition as this Massachusetts town tries to control the steady growth that began in the late 70's.

title: Pro Hockey; The Rangers Continue to Falter
description: The magic left months ago, the confidence evaporated shortly thereafter and a steady stream of players vanished for varying periods due to injuries in the ensuing weeks. With all that disappearing for the Rangers, it is hardly surprising that a chance at first place in the Patrick Division is fading fast as well.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Cuisine in an Elegant Setting
description: LEAD: CHINESE restaurants in New Jersey used to be predictable. They usually fell into one of two categories: either brightly decorated in varying shades of red or absolutely stark and devoid of any formal decoration. They were also not very comfortable because the tables were close together and the chairs were inclined to be hard.

title: Crop Dried In Kansas, Focus Now Is the Land
description: Winds gusting to coat-tugging force lifted topsoil from Darwin McCall's dried-up wheat field and hurled it against a truck window where it slipped off in thin, dark sheets.

title: VIOLENCE MADE IT HAPPEN
description: CITIZENS A Chronicle of the French Revolution. By Simon Schama. Illustrated. 948 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Substandard Subtitles
description: To the Editor:

title: Belligerent Day For Mets, Jays
description: The Mets were involved in three scuffles this afternoon and not even one of them was among themselves.

title: Park Bandshell
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on page 10 of the Travel section today, about New Delhi, gives an incorrect telephone number for the Diplomat Hotel in some copies; the number should be 301-0204. The article also misstates the price of a book, ''Old Delhi: 10 Easy Walks''; it costs $5.

title: Cheney Acts Quickly to Put Personal Stamp on Defense
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has moved quickly to establish himself in the Pentagon, choosing the first of his aides, meeting today with President Bush and calling top military officials to a hurried budget conference.

title: Susan Jansen Weds F. J. Chu
description: Susan Kent Jansen and Franklin Janen Chu were married yesterday by the Rev. Frank A. Goodwin at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. William Allan Jansen of Bronxville and the late Mr. Jansen. Mr. Chu is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robin Hsin-Liu Chu of New York.

title: Tapping Income Buried in Public Land
description: BEFORE you build an income-producing structure, you must first buy or lease the property on which you intend to build. It sounds logical, but it's not always true.

title: To Read, To Help, To Dance!
description: The cause was books, so the Young Friends of the Library chose Ray Bradbury's futuristic story about book burning, ''Fahrenheit 451,'' as the theme for their first benefit.

title: Dorothy Lands in the Strange Country of the Sports Arena
description: Three weeks ago the Emerald City filled a hangar at Van Nuys Airport in southern California, and there were Munchkins everywhere.

title: CONSUMER RATES
'Services' Bring Out Big Bidders
description: LEAD: An amateur gardener, Luisa Kuhn, offered to plant 50 of her daffodil bulbs at the winning bidder's house. Helene Hoffman, a Scholastic Aptitude Test tutor, donated five lessons in preparation for the May examination. Tina and Jeff Riedl vowed to cook a gourmet French dinner for six.

title: Landry Was Insulted
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Some Officials, the Revolving Door Turns Smoothly
description: IF avoiding conflict of interest has become a Washington rite of passage, then Lawrence S. Eagleburger is the latest official to come of age.

title: Promises, Promises
description: In his new book, ''His Eminence and Hizzoner,'' written with John Cardinal O'Connor, Mayor Edward I. Koch wrote that though his opponents over the years had spread reports that he was a homosexual he had adopted a policy of not responding to inquiries on the matter. Last week, on a radio call-in program, Mr. Koch responded to an inquiry and said that he was a heterosexual. Saying later that he should have re-read his written promise before going on the program, Mr. Koch said, ''Henceforth, I will not discuss it.'' A day later, responding to still more inquiries, Mr. Koch denied that he had made the unusually straightforward statement about his sexuality because of his impending re-election campaign. He also said he would never discuss the matter again.

title: Chiles Sells Rangers
description: Eddie Chiles announced today that he had sold his majority share of the Texas Rangers to a group of Texas businessmen headed by George W. Bush, the President's son, for an estimated $46 million. The sale must gain the approval of American League owners, which is expected.

title: Boone Country: Rugged Land For Recreation
description: WHEN Daniel Boone led his family and a group of settlers through the Cumberland Gap toward the country beyond the mountain barrier, he ''esteemed'' the region to be ''a second paradise.'' The forested, mineral-rich Cumberlands and the antic, meandering Cumberland River shared by Kentucky and Tennessee continue to arouse dreams of a frontier. Today it is not the frontier of coonskin caps and long rifles or that of the utopian community Rugby, founded in the mountains in the 1870's by the English author Thomas Hughes. It is one of preservation wedded to recreation, a frontier of cooperation between the United States Corps of Engineers in development and the National Park Service in conservation and administration to provide public access to a rugged and scenic landscape.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Outwitting Trout With Data
description: Anglers who find nothing appealing about the great outdoors when their catch comes up short may be able to better their luck if they have access to a facsimile machine.

title: The Last of the Kaweskar
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Drew Marries
description: Jennifer Drew, a third-year law student at Fordham University, and George Mayer Stone, a partner in the real-estate investment firm of Solico in New York and Williamstown, Mass., were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion and Cantor David Benedict officiated. Mrs. Stone, a daughter of Leon Drew of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Mrs. Michael Thea of New York, is a graduate of the Riverdale Country School and Northwestern University.

title: Corporate Property - Where the Wild Things Are
description: The broad acres surrounding E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's textile fiber plant in Kinston, N.C., used to be mowed religiously, leaving a lawn that was beautifully manicured but a biological desert for animals and plants.

title: War's Face, Seen Intimately
description: The best war movies are always after two things, realism and truth. The realism is relatively easy. A good special-effects man can create a world of carnage with amplified gunfire, smoke pots and exploding blood bags.

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: The subtle point of Richard Taylor's response to Michael Sovern's article, namely that university faculties do not merely teach but also engage in research, may have eluded some readers.

title: The Sound of Music at Easter
description: LEAD: WHEN churches begin ushering in Holy Week and Easter today with Palm Sunday services, musically the familiar will be heard throughout Long Island.

title: Dads and Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 'We're Concerned About Children'
description: THE mother of four children, Roberta Willis of Salisbury became concerned about the possible effects of pesticide residue after her neighbor, the actress Meryl Streep, gave her a copy of a report by the National Resource Defense Council, a private environmental group in Washington, D.C.

title: Chevrier Returns in Triumph
description: Alain Chevrier's return to Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the first time since being traded by the Devils last summer was, in his words, ''very satisfying.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: New Delhi
description: The scholar Percival Spear, who devoted more than 50 years to the study of India, had a special fascination for New Delhi, which he called ''the stop-go capital.'' He meant that the city had an unusually uneven and protean history, changing its face, its ethnic composition, its religious character and its role as a subcontinental metropolis from century to century or decade to decade.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''That's one to be proud of. It's a great way to start the '89 schedule.'' - Frank Culbertson, mission controller, as Discovery touched down. [ 29:1. ]

title: Approval of Lilco Rate Increases Is Predicted
description: With a deadline less than a month away, a New York State utility official said Friday that the Public Service Commission is likely to approve rate increases that will lead to adoption of a plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Landing: Flawless

title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?
description: THE CARIOCAS, AS THE NATIVES OF Rio de Janeiro are known, have marvellous qualities - an infectious joie de vivre, a refined sense of the ridiculous, the most sophisticated and beautiful popular music in the world - but the ability to handle money isn't one of them. So it came as no surprise to learn last fall that the city had declared bankruptcy. The reason was partly that the Federal Government was squeezed by a foreign debt of $115 billion, by heavy obligations to the private sector and by the highest inflation rate, 900 percent, in Brazilian history. It had no money to spare for Rio. So it cut the city off.

title: Deneuve, Depardieu And Happenstance
description: A man. A woman. A deserted rest area by the side of a highway, where the man and woman meet by chance. She (Catherine Deneuve) has been abandoned there by an abusive husband who has left her stranded, in her fur coat and fur hat and dark glasses, in the middle of the night. He (Gerard Depardieu) has already been there for a couple of days, trying to fix the engine of his car, an engine that -symbolically, no doubt - will not go.

title: For China's Congress, How Much Democracy?
description: China's legislature will begin its annual session on Monday for a dose of what passes here for democracy. Officials already are bracing themselves.

title: Park Bandshell
description: To the Editor:

title: Troupe's Topic: Mental Illness
description: APPEARING in blue T-shirts with the words ''Stigma Busters'' printed on the front, the Project Return Players of New Jersey theater troupe has set out to change society's attitude toward mental illness. Established in November 1987 in Montclair by the Mental Health Association of New Jersey, the troupe is made up of former and current mentally ill patients. The group has given more than 40 performances at schools, hospitals for the mentally ill, associations of families of the mentally ill, groups of the elderly and other organizations.

title: The Pits in the Grapefruit League
description: LEAD: Baseball is in the air - or more accurately, on the air - these winter days.

title: Prospects; Brady's Debt Plan Debuts
description: In a recent speech, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady outlined a new plan for third world debt relief. It calls for additional lending as well as increased use of debt-for-equity swaps. It also advocates converting some of the $280 billion that debtor countries owe to private banks into low-interest bonds. Reaction to the plan has been mixed. Four experts give their views. Jorge Casteneda Graduate professor, National University of Mexico, and co-author, ''Limits to Friendship: The United States and Mexico.''

title: Brigantine Journal; Mammal Aid Center's Use of Town Name Criticized
description: IN an immersion tank at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center on Brigantine Boulevard here, a weary harbor seal bobbed and turned as concerned volunteers monitored its progress. Whether it would live or die would depend on the animal's inherent strength, said Robert Schoelkopf, the center's director and founder.

title: Flawless At First
description: She may never be a household name, but Julie Croteau made a bit of baseball history last week. In a Division III game against the Spring Garden College Bobcats, Croteau, who plays for St. Mary's College of Maryland, became the first woman to play in a National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball game.

title: Correction
description: A chart on March 5 headed ''What the Dollar Will Buy in 16 Cities Around the World'' converted two Lisbon costs into United States dollars incorrectly. A two-mile taxi ride is $1.67, a cup of coffee 46 cents.

title: They Also Serve
description: After the U.S.S. Vincennes returned home to San Diego in October, the crew of the Navy cruiser sought to put behind them the tragedy last July in the Persian Gulf when the ship mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet.

title: Reincarnation of a Chinese Pace Setter
description: THE ad read ''Grand Opening of Homer's East.'' Was Homer Lee opening a third Chinese restaurant in the Woodbury Common? No. It's the original Homer's with a face lift.

description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Q and A
description: Skiing Plans

title: 'The Joy Luck Club'
description: In 1949, when the Red Army marched into Beijing, America's ''special relationship'' with China abruptly ended, and so hostile did our two countries become toward each other that people on both sides of the widening divide seemed to lose the ability even to imagine reconciliation.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard; The Flames Of Student Protest Still Flicker
description: Where have all the rallies gone?

title:
GARDENING;
Nasturtiums Please the Eye and Palate
description: LEAD: HAVE you eaten a nasturtium sandwich lately? Don't be too sure you haven't. If you've had watercress, then you've had nasturtium.

title: ORDEAL ON I-80
description: Jay Belsky gives the impression that the safest course of action in an accident is to remain in the car (About Men: ''Ordeal on 1-80,'' Feb. 19). As a trauma surgeon, I have seen countless injuries sustained by people who stayed in a disabled vehicle. The safest course of action is to walk away. There is something about a car on the shoulder that acts like a magnet to attract other cars. RICHARD E. STERN, M.D. New York City

title: Animals In Laboratories
description: We would like to clarify the purpose of our lawsuit, as it was inaccurately described in the article [ ''Lab Use of Animals Puts Issue Into Court,'' Feb. 26 ] .

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SOWETO, MY LOVE. By Molapatene Collins Ramusi and Ruth S. Turner. (Holt, $22.95.) The 1960 massacres at Sharpeville and Langa and the deadly uprisings at Soweto in 1976 and 1977 exist for most of us as grim news flashes, but for Molapatene Collins Ramusi they were horrid neighborhood devastations.

title: Izhar Patkin - Artist
description: Last Thursday, Izhar Patkin left for Europe to make arrangements for showing the ambitious sculpture he has just completed - a life-size anodized aluminum piece entitled ''Don Quijote Segunda Parte'' that stands in his living room on the Lower East Side.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Almeyda to Wed Dr. George Vincent DiGiacinto May 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eduardo Almeyda of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Ann Almeyda, a plastic surgeon, to Dr. George Vincent DiGiacinto, a neurosurgeon. The couple plan to wed May 7. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert DiGiacinto of Yonkers.

title: Tilden Defied Age and Time
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Stage and Off, The Many Voices Of Mandy Patinkin
description: Mandy Patinkin is blessed and cursed with the kind of acute sensitivity that makes many of his waking moments feel like matters of life and death. In the current Public Theater production of Shakespeare's ''Winter's Tale,'' which opens on Tuesday, he plays a character who is even more bedeviled than he by overwhelming anxieties. Leontes - the Sicilian king whose irrational sexual jealousy of his wife, Hermione, drives him to destroy everything that matters in his life, until he is miraculously handed a second chance - goes through some of the most abrupt emotional changes of anyone in Shakespeare.

title: HOME WORK
description: For many busy men, exercise has become a little too much like work: getting up early, putting on the required clothes, traveling at least some distance, toiling alongside hordes of others and then returning home - exhausted.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. Here is a breakdown of the answers: $ Coach, School Votes Bob Knight, Indiana 19 Pete Carril, Princeton 7 John Thompson, Georgetown 7 Bob Wenzel, Rutgers 5 Mike Krzyzewski, Duke 5 Dean Smith, North Carolina 5 Denny Crum, Louisville 2 Rollie Massimino, Villanova 2 10 others 1

title: STREETSCAPES: Metropolitan Museum; A Diminished Garden Courtyard for an Old Facade
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art is putting into place the last element of its master plan of 1970 - a second garden court. But what was originally conceived as a vast, skylit garden court has now shrunk to a quarter of its original size and, inside, the museum's 1888 facade has been beautifully restored but been robbed of its perspective.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: We were delighted to read ''A Town of Crystal and Old Artistry Near Florence'' (Travel, Jan. 8) about Colle di Val d'Elsa. We found Colle by running low on gasoline, driving from Volterra to Florence in May 1984. The medieval hill town contrasts with its newer city in the valley, and the rolling Tucson hills complement the modern and ancient structures. We made Colle our base for one-day excursions into Tuscany.

title: SUITS: A NEW TWIST
description: Running from jammed airport terminals to leg-numbing flights, from cramped cabs to crowded conferences, can put a wrinkle in any man's schedule - not to mention his clothes. In addition to the heat, haze and humidity of summer, basic business wear is to blame: A man in a dress shirt and tie has at least a dozen layers of cloth bound snugly around his neck. Along with his suit, he also may have put on the heavy-soled brogues, wool socks and all the other accouterments of fall.

title: Suffolk Court Project Stalled
description: LEAD: ''AM I speaking English, or what?'' pleaded the court officer, palms up, as he glared down the corridor at knots of people who had ignored his order to move back against the wall.

title: Motorbikes Seen as Peril to Nature
description: LEAD: DUNES, wetlands and Long Island state parks are being scarred, and bird-nesting sites are being disrupted, by recreational all-terrain vehicles and racing motorbikes, but law-enforcement officials say they are fighting a losing battle in trying to stop them. Said Sgt. Brian Mangan of the Long Island State Park Police: ''We see the problem here and there.

title: Doris Mack, Radiology Administrator, Wed to Thomas C. Amory in California
description: Doris Ruth Mack and Thomas Carhart Amory, both of Santa Barbara, Calif., were married there yesterday by Judge Thomas R. Adams of Santa Barbara County Superior Court at the home of William Cornfield. Lorraine D. Bieser, the bride's sister, and Edward A. Hansen were the witnesses.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Poet Fights To Write Her Verses
description: ''Niedecker,'' Kristine Thatcher's earnest low-key drama celebrating the life and work of the late poet Lorine Niedecker, contemplates the artist with such intense reverence that its subject emerges an almost saintly symbol of integrity, simplicity and devotion.

title: FICTION
description: THE WOODWITCH. By Stephen Gregory. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The fungus among us in the British writer Stephen Gregory's second novel is a slimy, smelly, grotesquely phallic bottom-grower called a stinkhorn. It becomes an object of obsession for Andrew Pinkney, an English solicitor's clerk who has clobbered his girlfriend because she laughed at his impotence. Fleeing the scandal, he finds refuge in a dank cottage in the Welsh hills, where the erect and stinking stinkhorn, or woodwitch, as the locals know it, becomes symbolic of all that he cannot attain. Pinkney, a daft but pleasant fellow when we first meet him, decides to cultivate these disgusting growths, trusting that they'll make a dandy reconciliation gift for his girlfriend. Mr. Gregory, whose first novel, ''The Cormorant,'' earned him comparisons to Edgar Allan Poe and won the Somerset Maugham Award in 1987, describes Pinkney's adventures in amateur mycology in such nauseating detail that the book becomes an unrelenting gross-out of rotting animal corpses, wiggling larvae, buzzing flies and malignant imagery. He also gives us a plot whose elements never quite cohere. Shadings of supernatural evil go unexplained (we never learn, for example, why the big bad black sheep gives Pinkney such dirty looks). And a final, doomed dalliance with the village nymphet ends on a predictable downbeat.

title: Sweet Tooth Is Alive and Well In Westwood
description: It was weaned a dozen years ago on the introduction of a campus ice cream parlor. It was nurtured further last year with the opening of Tout de Suite, a huge kiosk selling only candy and frozen yogurt.

title: In Search Of the Next Medium
description: Christopher Whittle says he prefers to do things quietly, the way so many of his 42 projects have come into the world. His GO! Girls Only! magazine, his Dental Health Advisor, his Pet Care Report, his Funnies wall poster have all sneaked up on people so quietly that years later many individuals still don't know they exist. For the last two years, however, Mr. Whittle has made nothing but noise.

title: Elcetronic Gear Is Prized But Few Can Afford It
description: Technology enables physically impaired people to hold jobs they otherwise could not. A computer equipped with an electronic voice will read back letters typed in by a visually impaired person for accuracy. Similarly, some computers will articulate words identified on the screen, enabling people with speech difficiencies to communicate. Quadraplegics can type into a computer by pointing a beam of light from a special headband onto a light-sensitive keyboard.

title: Question of the Week; Who's the Best Coach In College Basketball?
description: And the Winner Is ... The Times received 62 replies to this question. title: Reviews/Music; The Mystical Golem as Subject of a Concert
description: The Jewish Museum is presenting, through April 2, an exhibition called ''Golem! Danger, Deliverance and Art,'' in which artistic and popular-culture responses to the ancient golem legend are brought together. A golem is a clay man brought to life through mystical incantation. Created as a protector, it grows independent of its maker and is destroyed.

title: Beth Jane Ruskin And Fred Weiler To Wed in April
description: Beth Jane Ruskin and Fred Michael Weiler are planning to marry on April 30, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Ruskin of Waterbury, Conn., have announced. Mr. Weiler is a son of Alan Weiler of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Helene Selinger of New York.

title: Trend Gaining in Public Schools To Add Teaching About Religion
description: After decades of shunning classroom discussion of religion, fearing that it was too divisive a subject or that church-state separation might be breached, many American public schools are now moving to incorporate it into their curriculums.

title: Collecting the Relgious Legends of Plants
description: TODAY, Christians observe Palm Sunday, and many will carry palm branches to commemorate the day that crowds greeted Jesus with palm branches as He rode into Jerusalem. In the coming week, florists' shops will fill with spring flowers - hyacinths and daffodils - considered especially appropriate for Easter time. Next Sunday, on Easter, homes and churches will be adorned with traditional lilies.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Shostakovich: Symphony No. 5, Five Fragments (Op. 42) Royal Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Vladimir Ashkenazy. London 421 120-2; CD only.

title: POSTINGS: Condos for Maplewood; Tall Story
description: After three years of local protests and several lawsuits had tried and failed to halt it, a 10-story condominium tower is rising in Maplewood, N.J., adjacent to the 2,000-acre South Mountain Reservation, one of the few large open spaces left in Essex County. Called ''The Top,'' the residential tower will be the highest structure in the immediate area along the boundary between Maplewood and South Orange.

title: Sports of The Times; Spring Training: Catch It While You Can
description: The Mets have been reminded by the Port St. Lucie Police and the St. Lucie County Sheriff's Department that State and Local Law prohibits scalping or public resale of spring training baseball tickets.

title: Hillary Anna Michael Wed To David Quinn in Seattle
description: Hillary Anna Michael, the copy director of Mademoiselle magazine in New York, and David Quinn, an actor, were married last evening at Temple Beth Am in Seattle by Rabbi Norman D. Hirsh.

title: FAUST ON THE BOARDWALK
description: LEAD: INDECENT PROPOSAL By Jack Engelhard. 296 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: Byron's Computer-Programmer Daughter; Women's Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Malle Diagnoses His 'Murmur of the Heart'
description: LEAD: In the spring of 1970, using the threads of his own adolescence as guide wires, the French film director Louis Malle inched out onto a dangerous cinematic tightrope. He decided to make a highly personal film about a sensitive young boy coming of age, and he decided to make it not using trained child actors but with fresh faces and raw talent he himself would form.

title: Lifted Voices From Women Of a Certain Age
description: Bonnie Raitt starts her new album, ''Nick of Time'' (Capitol 91268; LP, cassette and CD), with quiet, plain-spoken, telling words. In the title song, to a subdued drumbeat that ticks like a biological clock, she sings about a friend who: Sees babies everywhere she goes And she wants one of her own She's waited long enough, she says And still he can't decide Pretty soon she'll have to choose And it tears her up inside She's scared Scared to run out of time.

title: A Team Divided Can Still Win
description: At the Yankees' spring training clubhouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Rickey Henderson tells reporters Yankee pitchers drink too much. Dave Righetti tells reporters Henderson should mind his own business. Don Mattingly tells reporters he thinks maybe Henderson has a point. Dave Winfield, seated at his locker, watches with a big mischevious grin as schools of reporters swim back and forth from Henderson's locker to Righetti's locker like tiny fish being led blindly by the pilot fish of dissension.

title: Filling Out Tax Forms: It's Still A Chore
description: ''YOU don't do your own plumbing, do you? So why do you insist on doing your own taxes?'' a friend has asked me repeatedly.

title:
GARDENING;
Nasturtiums Please the Eye and Palate
description: LEAD: HAVE you eaten a nasturtium sandwich lately? Don't be too sure you haven't. If you've had watercress, then you've had nasturtium.

title: Marinades and Herbs Enhance the Flavor of Fish
description: WHEN it is absolutely fresh - straight out of the water - there is nothing better than fish cooked plain, brought sizzling to the table and served with a piece of lemon. But the fish we buy is not always that fresh. There are many ways to enhance its flavor, however, with fresh herbs like thyme or tarragon, or a marinade of soy sauce, spices and ginger.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Times Square Center; Is the West Side Getting Too Much Office Space?
description: GEORGE KLEIN was supposed to be a Manhattan pioneer, opening Midtown West to bankers, lawyers and other white-collar professionals by erecting four huge office towers near Times Square.

title: A CLASSIC AND A BRAWLER
description: BEN JONSON A Life. By David Riggs. Illustrated. 399 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.

title: Radar and Health: Additional Views
description: A journalist who calls attention to an environmental hazard educates the public. One who educates without evidence about such a hazard merely spreads rumors.

title: Madonna Re-Creates Herself - Again
description: In ''Like a Prayer,'' the music-video and title song of an album that represents Madonna's convincing bid for recognition as a serious rock artist, the 30-year-old star has never looked more beautiful or sung with more feeling. The songs, which deal directly and very emotionally with her failed marriage to the actor Sean Penn, her family, and her Catholic girlhood, transcend the brassy dance-pop of her three previous records to reveal Madonna as a vulnerable human being.

title: Americans Are Still Fighting Over Foreign Steel
description: THE five-year-old agreements that limit steel imports from 29 countries into the United States were once hailed by many in the industry as necessary for the revival of the American steel industry. Now segments of the industry are deeply divided over whether the import quotas, which expire this year, are still needed.

title: PERSPECTIVES: South Bronx Homes; The Housing Shift Near Charlotte Street
description: THE construction of 75 new town houses as the first phase of a development called Salters Square in the East Crotona Park section of the South Bronx is driving home some lessons about residential building in New York City.

title: No Way to Run the V. and A.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Strings, Winds, Percussion and Computer
description: The New York New Music Ensemble's Wednesday-evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall began with two older scores that have not lost their shine. Peter Maxwell Davies's ''Antechrist'' (1967), a set of inventive and colorful variations on a 13th-century motet, and Henry Cowell's amusing ''Set of Five'' (1951), with its lyrical violin line, propulsive piano part and exotically varied percussion component, served as light-spirited appetizers.

title: Spotlight on Colorado State
description: It happens every year as a few overlooked or lightly regarded teams from college basketball's boondocks are thrust into the spotlight during the national tournament. The coaches are usually self-deprecating, the players just happy to be here, while opponents build them up as giant killers capable of making the Final Four. It is the game played on the days between basketball games.

title: Research Supported by Pentagon Stirs <u4Germ Warfare Accusations
description: A 23-year-old research project on the genetic structure of anthrax has suddenly come under fire by a newly formed coalition of Quakers, local critics and doctors who assert that the research is intended for use in germ warfare.

title: Ten Men Suit Themselves
description: When personal style is the point, there's room in any man's wardrobe for new fashions - and old favorites. Brooke Alexander

title: A Notable New Reading of Strauss' 'Frau'
description: Bolstered by the West German record industry and record-buying public, we are steadily serviced with new recordings of German operas -familiar, quasi-familiar and downright unfamiliar. Far and away the most notable of the recent crop of such recordings is EMI's account of ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' (7 49074, three CD's), which counts as Richard Strauss's most ambitious operatic score.

title: Out-Patient Surgery Is Making Gains
description: AT 7 A.M. on a recent day, a 70-year-old woman from Tarrytown walked into the ambulatory-surgery unit at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown. At 3 P.M. she walked out. Only the patch over her right eye revealed that she had undergone a one-and-a-half-hour operation to remove a cataract and implant a lens in her eye.

title: A Rite of Passage for a 4-Year-Old Girl
description: IT is 10 o'clock and Andrea has the first appointment of the day. We're on time but it's a miracle we got here at all. When I first suggested that she have her hair cut, Andrea said ''No'' very definitely, the same way she says ''No dresses'' whenever we go out for a special occasion. ''Jogging pants and a polo, just like Evan,'' is the usual response. Then her older brother says: ''Stop copying me, you baby.'' But here we are in the department store. The beauty salon is deserted except for the receptionist. ''Hello. May I have your name puleeeez . . .'' her voice garbled as she concentrates on a large wad of gum. Her hair is long and streaked. ''Umm, Peter'll be here very soon.'' Andrea and I sit down quietly, looking expectantly at the door. A hairdresser named Anita wanders in, then Joan and a few minutes later, Peter.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Fifth Annual New York Flower Show misidentified the display shown. It was produced by Larchmont (N.Y.) Nurseries Inc., not by China.

title: Horse Farms Face Future Of Uncertainty
description: A CLOUD of uncertainty is hanging over the horse business on Long Island as changing conditions prompt many owners of horse farms to reassess their investments.

title: Don't Let Thrift Associations Use F.D.I.C. Logo
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Ann Kenny Weds
description: At Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., Patricia Ann Kenny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Kenny of New Rochelle, was married yesterday to Michael Frank Centrella, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Centrella of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Mark J. Connell performed the ceremony.

title: Knowing the Rules of the Road Wherever You Are
description: WHEN you drive into another state, you become subject to that state's vehicle laws. The sign that welcomes you is often accompanied by warnings about speed limits and littering and sometimes about radar detectors. But there are many other laws and regulations in effect, with or without warnings by the roadside, that you may not be clear about.

title: Jacob Den Hartog, 87; Led M.I.T. Department
description: Jacob P. Den Hartog, professor emeritus and former head of the department of mechanical engineering at the Massachussets Institute of Technology, died Friday at the Hanover Terrace Healthcase Center in Hanover, N.H., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: Regarding Stanley Carr's ''Getting Your Family Out to the Slopes: A Primer'' (Practical Traveler, Jan. 8): As a relatively new, close to 40ish skier, I'd like to add a few suggestions. Few beginners anticipate the sheer clumsiness of transporting ski equipment from parking lot to mountain, around the base area and back to the car. Unfamiliarly long skis seem to spread-eagle as soon as slung over the shoulder. Carried under the arm, the skis seem to grow in weight until they skyrocket into the ton-or-so range. And toting boots, poles, skis and a carryall is nothing short of a juggler's feat.

title: Trout Grow Big In a Wilderness In Labrador
description: THE black flies were swarming, looking for a landing spot. One went humming into my ear, another burrowed under an eyelid. Several flew up my nose, and when I opened my mouth, five or six dived down my throat, causing me to choke and sputter.

title: Miss Beck Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Childress Beck of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Harpswell, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanne Boulton Beck, to George Willing Pepper, the son of Mrs. Don Hamlin McLucas Jr. of Washington and Charles Willing Pepper of Palm Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Jay Vigoreaux, Architect, Weds Margo Tress Garcia
description: Margo Tress Garcia and Jay Vigoreaux were married yesterday in Rio Piedras, P.R. The Rev. Donald Vega performed the ceremony at San Ignacio Roman Catholic Church.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Croissants Amid the Artworks and a Mystic Buffet
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cafe Harlequin

title: India Women Feel Harassed By Hindu Rite
description: Vimla Mehra, a Deputy Commissioner of Police, is getting ready for Holi, the most joyous of Northern Indian festivals, a Hindu rite of spring.

title: Thousands Gather in Bilbao To Ask Longer Basque Truce
description: Hundreds of thousands of people demonstrated in the streets of the Basque city of Bilbao today in a peace march that organizers and local politicians hailed as a turning point in the region's troubled recent history.

title: North Carolina State Edges Rutgers
description: Sharon Manning hit two free throws with 51 seconds left to lead No. 13 North Carolina State to a 75-73 victory over Rutgers today in the second round of the Mideast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Rabin Faults Jordan In Border Ambush; Israeli Soldier Dead
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that the Jordanian Government was ultimately responsible for an ambush Friday night by guerrillas who slipped across the border and killed an Israeli soldier before escaping back to Jordan.

title: Radar and Health: Additional Views
description: This letter is in response to the well-written Feb. 5 article ''Woman's Fight Against Navy Radar Raises Health Issue.''

title: An Ecological Kristallnacht. Listen.
description: Humankind has suddenly entered into a brand new relationship with our planet.

title: THE GUNS OF SALVADOR
description: The Northern Ireland that James LeMoyne imagines as an analogue to El Salvador sounds like a dreadful place indeed: ''a permanent running sore, congenitally incapable of fully healing or being cured, short of the most radical measures.'' Fortunately, the real Northern Ireland bears no resemblance to Mr. LeMoyne's country-of-the-mind.

title: As Warsaw Relaxes, Hints of a Looser Bloc
description: NOT since the Prague Spring of 1968 has a movement to end total Communist control of an East bloc nation gained such momentum.

title: In the Revolution's Footsteps
description: IN symbolic terms, the French Revolution started 200 years ago in Paris at what is today La Divine, a pizza joint in the Place de la Bastille. On July 14, 1789, a mob stormed the Bastille prison, a towering fortress that had lodged such distinguished prisoners as Voltaire and the Marquis de Sade. In this bicentenary year, a walking tour of revolutionary Paris begins at La Divine.

title: Air Fares
description: To the Editor: Regarding first-class air fares: I bought a round-trip ticket to San Francisco, coach fare, for $284. I had asked for a business-class fare and was told there was none from San Antonio to San Francisco. First class would have been about $1,300 at that time, but now I understand that if space is available you can get a ''coach upgrade'' to first class for $860. I once flew to Germany in business class for $500 round trip. It seems to me that high first-class air fares persist because most of those using first class are on an expense account and don't care. KATHERINE M. COOK San Antonio

title: An Art School That Also Taught Life
description: It has been a fact of life in New York, these past few years, that more and more people - professionals and amateurs alike - have been drawing from the live model. It happens way uptown, at the National Academy of Design. It happens in midtown, at the Art Students League. And it happens downtown, at the New York Academy of Art, at 419 Lafayette Street, which was set up as recently as 1981.

title: NONFICTION
description: REFLECTING ON THINGS PAST: The Memoirs of Peter Lord Carrington. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $22.95.) Oh, to be an Englishman! Or rather, to write like one. Peter Lord Carrington is a man of his class and times - an aristocrat whose line began in the mid-17th century with one Thomas Smith of Nottingham, a draper who kept accounts for farmers. He was born and educated (at Eton, then Sandhurst) before the Great War. His class and times provide him with more than accomplished diction and an occasionally self-deprecating wit. One way to describe his record is as he does: that of ''a fairly public life''; another is as Henry Kissinger does, in an admiring preface, as the incarnation of ''matter-of-fact commitment to service.'' For his class, Lord Carrington is short on dotty relatives, but enormously long on offices served - from First Lord of the Admiralty to Secretary General of NATO - and he held them, and tells about them in ''Reflecting on Things Past,'' in a period that saw the decline of Britain from first among equals among the Great Powers to just another European country. A soldier in both world wars, he considers it the triumph of his time that such war is no longer possible, a political transformation, he says, that ''my generation regards . . . with astonishment and gratitude.'' As for the accompanying changes in social attitudes, he is too much a gent to deplore them. But that may be because although the world has much changed, he has not: ''We are, or should be, a family,'' he writes at the end, just before he celebrates the reduction of material hardship among the people. ''I don't find paternal an offensive word.''

title: Versailles Recovers Its Gilded Glory
description: FOR Americans who have not recently seen Versailles, this is the ideal year for a return visit, both because of celebrations marking the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution and the recent conclusion of a five-year, $70-million restoration.
