title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: ON savage impulse I tapped exit and in response to the impersonal query ''save document? tapped no! ''Who would want to save garbage like this,'' I thought darkly.

title: The Bicentennial: What to Do Abroad . . .
description: Paris

title: MY FATHER, MY FICTION
description: A NOVEMBER DAY, 1988, and I am sitting in my study in our house in Princeton, N.J., as dusk comes on, listening to my father playing the piano in another wing of the house. Flawlessly, he's moving through the presto agitato of Schubert's ''Erl King,'' striking the nightmarish sequence of notes firmly but rapidly. There's a shimmering quality to the sound, and I'm thinking how the mystery of music is a paradigm of the mystery of personality: most of us ''know'' family members exclusive of statistical information, sometimes in defiance of it, in the way that we ''know'' familiar pieces of music without having the slightest comprehension of their thematic or structural composition. We recognize them after a few notes, that's all. The powerful appeal of music is inexplicable, forever mysterious, like the subterranean urgings of the soul, and so too the powerful appeal of certain personalities in our lives. We are rarely aware of the gravitational forces we embody for others, but we are keenly aware of the gravitational forces certain others embody for us. To say my father, my mother is for me to name but in no way to approach one of the central mysteries of my life.

title: THE REGION: In Seattle; A Garbage Success Story
description: ONE year into the nation's most successful garbage recycling program, Seattle has exceeded a goal city officials thought could not be reached for five years.

title: County Expands Meals for the Aged
description: JANET TABERER, 66 years old, has been going to the Neighborhood Facility at Nelson Avenue in Peekskill every day for the last several years to get a hot lunch. The hot-lunch program is one of several nutrition programs for the elderly sponsored by the County Office for the Aging.

title: Dismantling Shoreham Plant: Uncharted Waters
description: THE Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, 22 years in the building, now appears to face at least five years in the unmaking, and maybe much more.

title: THE SUFFERING OF LITTLE CHILDREN
description: THE KINDNESS OF STRANGERS The Abandonment of Children in Western Europe From Late Antiquity to the Renaissance. By John Boswell. Illustrated. 488 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: I am sorry that Richard Taylor cared so little about teaching. He should not, however, use his own laziness in the classroom to impugn the hard work, dedication and commitment of other university professors. Perhaps Professor Taylor (and his students) would have been better off if he had stayed in that ''other warm place.'' STEVEN NADLER Department of Philosophy, University of Wisconsin Madison

title: Winds Of Change?
description: The diplomatic air in London is full of hopeful talk about South Africa: talk of change and negotiation and peace. Prime Minister Thatcher gave voice to the sense of possibility in the House of Commons last week. She was ''optimistic,'' she said, that ''before very long'' the South African Government would release Nelson Mandela.

title: Reviews/Television; A Look at 200 Years of Congress and Its Members
description: ''The Congress'' represents the best and worst of public broadcasting documentaries. It is earnest; it is edifying; it is accurate; it is exceptionally pretty. And it is also a bit of a bore. The 90-minute program, which borrows one of the pretensions of movie makers by describing itself as ''A Film by Ken Burns,'' can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Barneys and Japan Partner Plan Stores in U.S. and Asia
description: In an unusual international agreement, Barneys New York and the Isetan Company, one of Japan's largest retailers, announced over the weekend a venture in which stores would be opened in the United States, Japan and in other Asian countries under the Barneys name.

title: Accounts
description: * Burlington Air Express, an air freight company, and Dow Canada, the Canadian subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, to Anderson & Lembke, Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of Chiat/Day, with a combined budget of $5 million.

title: Skyline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Latest third quarter and nine-month results included a gain of $800,000 from the sale of idle properties. Year-ago third quarter and nine- month results included a gain of $414,000 and $909,000, respectively, from the sale of idle properties.

title: Lassonde Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Siena Fans Hail Returning Heroes
description: When the Saints of Siena College came marching off the airplane and into the terminal building here this morning, they were greeted like champions.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Moonlighting' Anew

title: Even If Gorbachev Falls, Detente Will Last
description: LEAD: In its review of American policy toward the Soviet Union, the Administration would be wise to avoid focusing on the ongoing political infighting in the Kremlin. President Bush does not have to worry too much about an ouster of Mikhail Gorbachev or even about a failure of his reformist crusade.

title: Cavs Hand Nets 7th Straight Loss
description: There are many reasons why the Cleveland Cavaliers have the best record in the National Basketball Association.

title: William Kerby, 81, Dow Jones Chairman
description: William F. Kerby, a former chairman of Dow Jones & Company and for six years the executive editor of The Wall Street Journal, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 81 years old.

title: Vintage Sells Set of Classics From Abroad
description: Vintage Books, a paperback imprint of Random House Inc., is beginning a series devoted entirely to international classics of the 20th century. Its architects say it is the first series devoted exclusively to sizable numbers of such books, most of which are translations.

title: Condo Boom By Investors Outside U.S.
description: When Susumi Kamei of Tokyo spent more than $800,000 for two Manhattan condominium apartments last year sight unseen, he became an absentee landlord of property halfway around the world and joined a growing international cadre of investors who are creating a new category of high-priced housing in New York City.

title: Seton Hall Stops Evansville by 87-73
description: Seton Hall of the big, bad Big East Conference trailed Evansville of the itsy-bitsy Midwestern Collegiate Conference by 5 points early today, then opened a 19-point lead over the Purple Aces, and then, with 5 minutes 8 seconds remaining, led by only 74-73. Was Seton Hall concerned? ''We let them get too much back at once and we got rattled,'' said P. J. Carlesimo, the Seton Hall coach. ''When you're 18 or 19 points ahead and it goes to one or zero, if you're not concerned, you're an idiot.''

title: Books of The Times; The Man Who Linked Mind and Medium
description: Marshall McLuhan The Medium and the Messenger By Philip Marchand Illustrated. 320 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $19.95.

title: Many Candidates Enter Race For Top National Arts Post

Lifland plans to hold a hearing on the airline's petition that he appoint an examiner in the case rather than the trustee the pilots' union requested.

title: Police Kill Fugitive, Freeing Children Held Hostage
description: An escaped murderer was shot to death and his accomplice captured early today when police stormed a town house and freed two children who had been held hostage for more than a day.

title: Review/Dance; Juilliard School Students
description: The Juilliard School has always believed in giving its dance students training in both ballet and modern dance, and the performances of the Juilliard Dance Ensemble regularly include examples of these two idioms. On Saturday night at the Juilliard Theater, the ensemble offered a world premiere and three well-known contemporary works. It was an evening in which strong choreography was weakly danced and weak choreography was strongly danced. Fortunately, strong choreography was also strongly danced.

title: Sharon Engelhard Becomes a Bride
description: Sharon Amy Engelhard and Glenn Michael Firester were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Saul Teplitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Engelhard of Woodmere, L.I., and New York. Her husband is the son of Phillip Firester of Princeton, N.J., and Phyllis Tarlow of Woodbury, L.I.

title: Study Looks At Oil Supply
description: The United States could handle a sudden and sustained loss of oil imports without shortages of gasoline and other refined oil products, although prices might jump, a Government-sponsored study concludes.

title: Outdoors: Choosing the Ultimate Angling Delight
description: A FEW days ago after receiving my third invitation in as many weeks to fish for Atlantic salmon in New Brunswick and Quebec this coming season, I marveled at my good fortune and began daydreaming of great, silvery fish fresh from the sea hurtling out of the water beside the canoe.

title: Skye Journal; To Keep the Peace on the Isle, Never Say 'Bridge'
description: The mention of a certain six-letter word on this stretch of rugged peace and primitive beauty whips up emotions as fierce as a sea tormented by storm.

title: Coleman Returns To Spark Syracuse
description: It was suggested that his timing was off, but Derrick Coleman's timing could not have been better. Syracuse might have won today's second-round game against Colorado State in the Midwest Region without their best rebounder and one of their leading scorers, but this is not the time of season the Orangemen want to be put in a position of having to prove it.

title: India Paper's Investment Bothers Rival Publishers
description: One of India's oldest, largest and most influential newspaper companies is being denounced for buying a substantial share of another newspaper. Editors and owners of other publications fear a takeover bid. That, in turn, could set a precedent for other big companies, some in which the Government has a big stake, to try to take over smaller papers without a commitment to maintaining their editorial freedom.

title: Making Child's Play Count
description: DAVID SCHMELTZER, director of physcial education at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan, watched a plump girl of elementary school age clamber up and down a 10-foot high set of horizontal bars and then lie under a dangling rope and pull herself into a sitting position by walking her hands up the rope. ''When we told her mother she could do things like that, she was amazed,'' Schmeltzer said. Across the room a boy of a similar age and build stood on the edge of an 8-inch platform. He jumped sideways in a flat-footed hop to the floor, took a step forward, then jumped sideways back up onto the platform. He repeated the movement, hop by hop, until he had moved the length of the room. ''His mother tells us he is much more active at home since he began coming to these sessions,'' Schmeltzer said.

title: French Pesticide Hunt
description: Bad weather forced the French Navy today to suspend a search for a container of toxic insecticide lost off the Channel Islands. The container, packed with up to six tons of Lindane, one of the world's most potent pesticides, was being carried on a freighter that sank Monday 35 miles northwest of Guernsey.

title: Amanda's Bid Is Set Back
description: The Amanda Acquisition Corporation's effort to buy the Universal Foods Corporation was set back Saturday when a Federal judge in Milwaukee denied motions by Amanda to invalidate a Wisconsin law that requires Universal's board to approve the acquisition.

title: Building Strength on the Run
description: WHILE top distance runners tend to be extremely thin athletes who look like caricatures of the 98-pound weakling, many train for strength as well as stamina, raising a question that continues to divide fitness experts. Does weight training improve running performance?

description: In a two-year experiment beginning on April 1 at two factories in Louisville, Ky., the Ford Motor Company will pay the costs of nonmedical custodial care at home or in a nursing home for employees and their dependents, the company said last week.

title: Graf Not in Top Form But She Defeats Evert
description: Top-ranked Steffi Graf overcame a slow start to defeat Chris Evert, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, today and win the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tournament.

But the incident has also provoked alarm among the thousands of Southern Californians of Iranian descent who oppose Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and fear that they might be seen as guilty by association.

Hours are Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $1; 50 cents for students and the elderly. Information: 228-0110.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Concern is mounting about the F.D.I.C.'s power under the Bush savings plan. The debate so far has focused on the cost to taxpayers, but new alarms are sounding over the insurance agency's unprecedented latitude to decide banking issues without consulting Congress or other regulators. [ Page D1. ] COMPANIES The struggle for Eastern Airlines enters a crucial phase in Federal Bankruptcy Court this week. A committee of creditors is to be formed, and a judge plans to hold a hearing on the airline's request that he appoint an examiner in the case rather than the trustee the pilots' union requested. The decision could be vital to the direction of the case in the months to come. [ B5. ] Eastern has started advertising for pilots to replace the pilots honoring the strike. The pilots' union said it would not be intimidated. [ B5. ] The seven regional phone companies will have more freedom to set long-distance connection fees under a Federal Communications Commission plan. The proposal is expected to face opposition. [ D1. ] Barneys New York and Isetan of Japan announced a venture in which stores would be opened in the U.S. and Asia under the Barneys name. About $250 million will be spent in the venture. [ D1. ] Ford will pay for nonmedical custodial care for severely impaired workers and their dependents at two factories in Kentucky. Ford said the experiment is the first employer-financed program in a major industry. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The stakes are high in the bidding war for Connie Chung between NBC and CBS. Two potentially lucrative prime-time news programs are likely to be affected by her decision, which is expected this week. Television. [ D1. ] L.A. Style is filling a void in Los Angeles. The trendy magazine, one of four published by American Express, remains one of the few ways to reach young consumers with thousands to spend in the nation's second-largest market. [ D8. ] Chrysler and Sears have decided not to advertise on an NBC show about student nurses. Viewers have complained that the show, ''Nightingales,'' exploits women. [ D8. ] Vintage Books is beginning a series of foreign classics of the 20th century. Its architects call it a first. [ D8. ] One of India's largest newspapers is being denounced for buying a substantial share of a smaller newspaper. Critics say the issue is editorial freedom. [ D8. ] Penchina, Selkowitz created a campaign of ''outrageousness'' for NBC to differentiate the network's new cable television news service from its competitors. Advertising. [ D9. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Collectively owned and private ventures are flourishing in China, to the point that it is now they - not state-owned companies - that dominate the economy in many areas. [ D4. ] Staying profitable and reaching critical mass will not be easy for SGS-Thomson in a worldwide semiconductor market that is expected to grow only 9 percent this year, compared with 30 percent last year. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Analysts contend that the Fed has little choice but to push short-term interest rates higher soon, possibly this week, given the threat of rising inflation. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] Creditors are attacking the system of taking over insolvent savings institutions as unfair. They want Federal courts, not the F.S.L.I.C., to handle their claims. A case now before the Supreme Court may resolve the issue. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] The surge in oil prices is especially good news for companies that specialize in exploring and drilling, because they have been quite depressed for three years. Market Place. [ D6. ]

Palm Sunday service today. The Bushes were greeted at the church by the Rev. Mark K. J. Robinson, who said, ''Congratulations on the puppies.'' It was a reference to Millie, the Bushes' springer spaniel, who gave birth to six puppies Friday night.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf A First for Garbacz: Lori Garbacz, who has been on tour for 11 years, captured her first Ladies Professional Golf Association title, fighting off Martha Nause en route to a four-stroke victory yesterday in the $300,000 Tucson Open in Arizona. Garbacz and Nause were tied from the sixth through the 10th holes, but Nause then bogeyed four straight holes as Nancy Lopez moved into second place. Garbacz birdied the final hole to finish at two-under-par 70 for 274. Lopez shot 67. (AP) Show Jumping Jacobs Wins in Tampa: Louis Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., was the only rider to master the course yesterday at the $30,000 Volvo Grandprix of Tampa in Florida. The victory put Jacobs into second place in the standing of East Coast riders hoping to qualify for the 1989 Volvo World Cup finals. Jacobs led his 14-year-old, French-bred Janus De Ver over the course without a fault. Eight riders shared second place at the Bob Thomas Equestrian Center. Speed Skating Flaim Shares Title: Eric Flaim of the United States shared the World Cup 1,500-meter championship with Michael Hadschieff of Austria, even though the American finished sixth at that distance in yesterday's final race of the seasonlong competition in Heerenveen, the Netherlands. The 500-meter cup went to Uwe Jens Mai of East Germany, while the 10,000-meter competition was won by Gerard Kemkers of the Netherlands. Hadschieff finished second yesterday, covering the 1,500 meters in 1 minute 55.43 seconds behind Peter Adeberg of East Germany, who won the race in 1:55.28. In the 500-meter event Dan Jansen of the United States finished first in 36.71 seconds, while Igor Zhelezovksy of the Soviet Union was second in 36.77. (AP) Road Running Victory for Norwegian: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway broke the women's world half-marathon best yesterday with a time of 1 hour 8 minutes 32 seconds, in the Greater New Bedford (Mass.) Half-Marathon. The previous mark for the 13.1-mile event was 1:08:34, set by Joan Benoit Samuelson of the United States in 1984. Aurora Cunha of Portugal finished second at New Bedford in 1:09:39. Ivan Huff of Paso Roble, Calif., won the men's race in 1:03:20, with Bill Reifsnyder of Williamsport, Pa., second in 1:03:41 and David Edge of Canada third in 1:03:53 in a field of 2,500.(AP) Record for Beschloss: Gillian Beschloss of the Warren Street Athletic Club of Jersey City set an event record of 2 hours 1 minute 18 seconds in the New York Road Runner Club's Mike Hannon Memorial 20-mile run yesterday in Central Park. The previous record of 2:03.53 was set by Gillian Horovitz of New York in 1985. Horovitz finished second yesterday in 2:09:58. Mark Will-Weber of Bethlehem, Pa., was the men's winner in 1:50:19. (AP) Cross-Country Fourth in a Row for Ngugi: John Ngugi of Kenya captured his fourth straight world championship yesterday in Stavanger, Norway, by winning the men's 12-kilometer race in 39 minutes 42 seconds. Ngugi, the Olympic 5,000-meter champion, was 28 seconds ahead of the runner-up, Tim Hutchings of Britain. Kenya won the men's team competition. Annette Sergent of France won the women's 6-kilometer race. (AP) Tennis Mecir Beats Noah: Seventh-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated 12th-seeded Yannick Noah of France, 3-6, 2-6, 6-1, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the final of the $702,500 Champions Cup in Indian Wells, Calif. The match lasted almost three hours, with the temperature reaching 120 degrees on the court.(AP)

title: Soviet-American Group Plans Voyage for Peace
description: A group of Soviet and American environmentalists have agreed to sail a schooner together from New York to Leningrad to underscore their conviction that the two nations should stop their arms buildup and instead begin saving the planet from its abuse by humans.

title: Going to Camp
description: With the Knicks playing better than they have in years, it's hardly surprising that fans have begun dreaming about a rerun of the championships of 1970 and 1973.

title: Business and the Law; F.S.L.I.C.'s Role In Insolvencies
description: THE broad powers of the savings industry's insurance fund are under fire from critics who say regulators of the fund are crushing the legal rights of creditors and borrowers when they take control of insolvent savings institutions.

title: Motor Club of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: New Warwick Official
description: Dennis Visich, an executive vice president and senior management representative at BBDO New York, is leaving to become the chief operating officer of Warwick Advertising. Wilder D. Baker, Warwick's president, has served as both the chief operating officer and chief executive for three years. But the growth of the agency, from $140 million to $160 million in billings last year, demanded an expansion of the top management ranks, Mr. Baker said. Mr. Visich, who was the senior person on the accounts of the Campbell Soup Company and the General Electric Company at BBDO, will carry the additional title of group executive vice president at Warwick.

title: Review/Art; Renewed Luster for a Baroque Master
description: When Shelley wrote in 1819 that if Rome were for some reason destroyed, only the paintings by Raphael and by Guido Reni would be missed among all the city's lost treasures, he was making an observation that probably would not have struck many people at the time as exceptionally odd. Goethe, Stendhal, Sir Joshua Reynolds, Johann Winckelmann and the Marquis de Sade had already passed judgment on Reni's work - not all of it favorable but all of it accepting the importance accorded the Italian painter.

title: New Gooden Pitch Served To Cards
description: ''Anything special to look for today with Gooden?'' Davey Johnson was asked before the Mets-Cardinals game here at Al Lang Stadium this afternoon.

title: In Control Of the Mets And Himself
description: ''AFTER the 1987 season,'' Davey Johnson said, remembering the painful times, ''Frank Cashen made a speech before some group and told them he could have managed the Mets in '86 and won. And he said he probably could have done better than me in '87, when we didn't win.''

title: Reviews/Television; 2 Premieres: Teen-Age Lust and a Lovable Bigot
description: This much can be said for premiere episodes: Although most of the new shows will disappear quickly onto the cancellation junkpile, the passing glimpses provide some insight into what television executives think - or at least hope - will sell these days. Judging from tonight's two new entries, both with dreadful titles, CBS has its eye on teen-age sexpots and lovable bigots. It's what you might call playing it safe.

title: United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and included a $207,862 gain from an accounting change.

title: F.C.C. Plans Freer Pricing At Baby Bells
description: The nation's seven regional telephone companies will receive the same freedom to set long-distance connection fees as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will have for long-distance calls, the Federal Communications Commission says.

title: Winfield To Miss Opener By MICHAEL MARTINEZ
description: The Yankees' injury problems went from bad to worse today when Dave Winfield left camp to seek outside advice on his bad back, acknowledged that he might need surgery to correct a disk problem and said he would not be ready to play by opening day.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Growth of Existing Units Stressed by Head of Pet Inc.
description: LEAD: J. Robert Copper, who became Pet Inc.'s chief executive officer last Wednesday, has worked as a strategic and operational planner with Pet's parent company, the Whitman Corporation, since 1980.

title: For Angry Innaurato, No Self-Effacement
description: Albert Innaurato is smiling, but Albert Innaurato is angry.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 South Korea President Roh Tae Woo said he was indefinitely postponing a long-awaited referendum on his first year in office, warning of a ''repetition of confusion and violence'' in his country. Page A1

title: Higher Fees Threaten Beach Pioneers
description: As a young girl growing up on Long Island, Jane Wilson loved to visit the beaches near this tiny community on a slender strip of windswept land stretching eastward from Jones Beach.

title: Dead Officer, Dropped Charges: a Scandal in Boston
description: The Police Department here has been rocked by scandal since a judge last month dismissed murder charges against a man accused of killing a detective in an abortive drug raid 13 months ago.

title: Police Find Body of Rabbi Floating in Bay off Brooklyn
description: The body of a 66-year-old Hasidic rabbi, the leader of a small Orthodox congregation on the Upper East Side who has been missing since mid-January, was found yesterday floating in the Gowanus Bay about 200 yards from the Brooklyn shore, the police said.

title: Justice Official Back
description: A Justice Department official who resigned last year protesting the leadership of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has found her way back.

title: Paul Martin Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mays,J W Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,554,882 for the quarter and $4,414,853 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after income of $727,746 for the quarter and a loss of $117,625 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and a tax credit of $424,000 for both periods.

title: The Battle for Mayor Begins
description: The biggest political names stayed away, the prospective candidates who did come never confronted each other and only two television cameras showed up. Yet the first event of New York City's mayoral campaign, a two-hour forum last week, served as a healthy reminder of how New York political campaigns can confound the expected scenarios.

title: New Jersey Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
OEA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $304,100 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: National Western Life Insurnce Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included capital losses of $1,561,061 and $2,857,079 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included capital losses of $1,516,509 and $1,020,382 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: Smith Leads Hoyas Past Irish
description: Charles Smith made only 2 of 12 shots against Princeton on Friday night, and his evening was successful only because his Georgetown Hoyas barely avoided an upset for the ages.

title: Beijing Voices 'Indignation' Over U.S. Remarks on Tibet
description: In an unusually harsh rebuke, China today condemned as ''gross interference'' a United States Senate resolution that criticized recent violence in Tibet.

title: Treasury Limits This Week's Sales to Bills
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Islanders Fall to Oilers
description: Grant Fuhr made 32 saves and Mark Messier scored his 30th goal of the season tonight as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Islanders, 3-2, to end a six-game streak without a victory.

title: Going to the Top
description: For a school that claims two of the top collegiate racquetball players in the country, Marist doesn't have much of a racquetball program.

title: Berkeley Gets $15 Million Gift
description: The Haas family, owner of Levi Strauss & Company, has given $15 million to the University of California at Berkeley, the largest in the school's history. The gift is considered a cornerstone contribution toward construction of a planned $40 million building for Berkeley's School of Business Administration, which, in appreciation, will be named the Walter A. Haas School of Business.

title: Call It Amnesia International
description: LEAD: Despite valiant work over the years, which brought a Nobel Peace Prize in 1977, Amnesty International today must be faulted for a periodic leftist political bias and for operating under a flawed mandate.

title: Ms. Leifer Weds J. P. Rosen
description: The wedding of Monica Leifer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Leifer of Lawrence, L.I., to J. Philip Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rosen of Great Neck, L.I., and Miami, took place yesterday at the Sheraton Center in New York. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf and Cantor Eliezer Shulman officated.

title: Budget Agreement Is Elusive As Talks Define Differences
description: The differences over the Federal budget between the Bush Administration and Congress became more sharply defined in the first week of negotiations, but the ways to reconcile those differences remained elusive.

title: Illinois Looks Very Strong
description: During the course of a 64-team single-elimination tournament there will often be games in which the winner should have been the loser, and fans leave the arena feeling that luck, not skill, had been the deciding factor.

title: Rate Rise Expected From Fed
description: Credit market analysts contend that the Federal Reserve Board, faced with the threat of rising inflation, has little choice but to push short-term interest rates higher soon, possibly this week.

title: Bic Begins Campaign For New Perfume Line
description: What the Bic Corporation did for lighters and shavers, it now hopes to do for perfume. The French-controlled company pulled the wraps off a $20 million advertising campaign on Friday to introduce its new fragrance, Parfum Bic. ''We want to take perfume out of the bedroom and into the on-the-go world,'' said Sharon DuPuy, the supervisor of the print and broadcast campaign.

title: In Brooklyn, a Hospital Faces Its Own Mortality
description: In recent months, employees at a central Brooklyn hospital have come to know a level of adversity uncommon even in the crisis-bound world of New York City's health-care system.

title: 22 Marines Die in Korea Crash
description: An American helicopter crashed during joint maneuvers in South Korea, killing 22 marines and injuring 15, page A2.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: An answer a couple of months ago identifying Hinkey Haines of the 1923 Yankees and the 1927 Chicago Bears as the only athlete ever to play for both a World Series and National Football League champion stirred conjecture about Gene Conley and Dave DeBusschere. Weren't they players with World Series and National Basketball Association champions during their careers?

title: 22 Marines Are Killed in Crash Of U.S. Helicopter in South Korea
description: A United States Marine Corps helicopter participating in a major joint military exercise in South Korea crashed this morning, killing 22 marines and injuring 15, American officials said today.

title: Qintex Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $688,000 and $1,336,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss The company was formed following the merger of Hal Roach Studios Inc. and Robert Halmi Inc., which became wholly owned subsidiaries of the company on April 11, 1988. Results for the year-ago second quarter and six months, ended Dec. 31, 1987, included only the operations of Hal Roach Studios and subsidiaries.

title: OLYMPICS Officials Suspended For Events in Seoul
description: The International Amateur Boxing Association imposed two-year suspensions today on five judges and referees accused of inefficiency and not officiating in accordance with international rules at the 1988 Olympic Games. Five South Korean boxers and officials involved in a brawl during the Games were also given two-year suspensions.

title: NEW AIRPORT RULES ISSUED IN BRITAIN
description: New security orders have been issued to all of Britain's major airports, according to an airport spokesman. The orders came as a furor continued over warnings received before the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December.

title: Valley Forge Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $165,278 from discontinued operations, a gain of $480,688 on the disposal of discontinued operations, and a tax credit of $1,726,388.

title: Winnie Mandela Still Strong and Dedicated
description: To the Editor:

title: Belden & Blake Energy Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $670,000 related to non-recurring expenses and a $360,000 non-cash writedown of oil and gas assets.

title: Ask Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Portage Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dr. L. M. Moss, A Psychiatrist, Weds Dr. Vogel
description: Dr. Muriel Laufe Vogel, the deputy executive director of the National Academy Foundation in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Leonard M. Moss, a psychiatrist and the president and medical director of Watershed Corporate Health Services in Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony at his home in New York.

title: An Odd Couple Fills A Gap in Los Angeles
description: It seemed an odd combination at the time: staid American Express acquiring trendy L.A. Style magazine. But in a huge market that still offers few ways to reach young consumers with thousands to spend on everything from makeup to a Mercedes, the marriage appears to be working for both.

title: Cherne Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains from a legal settlement of $35,000 and $1,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Anti-Drug Official Backs a Ban on Assault Rifles
description: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, John C. Lawn, called upon American gun manufacturers today to halt the sale of semiautomatic rifles and said he would support a Federal ban on the weapons.

title: MONY Real Estate Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm afraid, but I'm voting because I'm afraid there will be trouble if I don't.'' Jorge Alvarenga as he voted in Tenancingo, Salvador. [ A10:2. ]

title: Shot Strikes Senator's House
description: A plainclothes police officer struggling with a suspect yesterday fired a shot that shattered a window and a flower pot in the home of a state senator in South Jamaica, Queens. Officer Jospeh Libertelli saw the man trying to break into a car at 173-23 113th Avenue, the police said. When the officer approached, the suspect ran into an alley, pulled out a knife and slashed the officer's wrist. The officer fired one shot, which went through the window of an enclosed porch on the house of Senator Andrew Jenkins, destroying a flower pot. The suspect, James Landers, 34 years old, of South Jamaica, was charged with attempted murder, assault and attempted grand larceny.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Frenchman Is Victorious in Saber Event
description: A 26-year-old saber fencer from Paris, Pierre Guichot, won his first World Cup tournament in grand style yesterday, defeating both his teammate, the 1988 Olympic champion, and the event's defending champion.

title: Ringier Pays $550 Million For Krueger, a U.S. Printer
description: Ringier A.G., a large, private Swiss printing company, said yesterday that it had acquired the W. A. Krueger Company, a commercial printing concern based in Scottsdale, Ariz., for $550 million.

title: Holiday RV Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Market Place; Drillers to Benefit As Oil Price Rises
description: WHEN oil topped $20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange on Friday -for the first time since October 1987 - that was good news for the big oil companies but even better news for the companies that specialize in exploring and drilling. This sector has been under severe pressure for the last three years.

title: Michigan and North Carolina Regroup to Advance
description: Deadeye shooting by Glen Rice led the disorganized Michigan Wolverines past the University of South Alabama, 91-82, today and into the Southeast Regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Lois/GGK Is the Name
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK officially changed its name last week to Lois/GGK, reflecting both last year's departure of Dale Pon, an executive vice president, and the agency's new plans for expansion. Two agencies, Lois/GGK Chicago and Lois/GGK New York, will exist within a holding company. The units will operate independently, ''but we will go after some pieces of business together,'' said Theodore D. Veru, the holding company's president. ''We're also looking to make further acquisitions.

title: General Host Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $2,850,000 and $4,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $12,200,000. c-Net income d-After a loss of $1,202,000 for the quarter and net of $64,127,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: St. Anthony Takes Title to End at 32-0
description: St. Anthony High School of Jersey City, with one of the smallest enrollments in New Jersey, ended a superb season and made state basketball history today with a 62-55 victory over Elizabeth in the first Tournament of Champions. The triumph came before a crowd of 8,514 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Palm Sprigs and Protest At a Church Still in Flux
description: Even as both sides carried palm branches and sang hymns of peace, the deep divisions at the largely Polish church here on Pulaski Street continued today, the first Sunday the church has held services in a month.

title: ESI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $513,072 from an accounting change.

title: With Fate of the Forests at Stake, Power Saws and Arguments Echo
description: In the American rain forests, a misted expanse of coastal evergreens running from Northern California through Southeast Alaska, more of the tallest and oldest trees in the world are being cut from public land than ever before.

title: Boeing Spending Plans
description: The Boeing Company plans to spend $1.1 billion on plants and equipment in 1989, a 63 percent increase over last year, the company's annual report said. Boeing's spending on plant and equipment totaled $690 million in 1988, $738 million in 1987 and $795 million in 1986. Last week, Boeing officials announced plans for a $430 million expansion and renovation during the next five years at the plant in Renton, Wash., where production of 757 and 737 jetliners is being increased to 24 a month from the current 19 a month.

title: 5 in Family Killed in Fire In Jersey City
description: Five members of the same family were killed early today when a fire that investigators said was deliberately set in a vacant apartment ripped through the top two floors of a three-story brick building in the residential Heights section of Jersey City.

title: Review/Pop; West German Star Plays New York
description: Ute Lemper has been the recipient of the sort of hyperbole that no performer should have to live up to. The advertisements for the West German star's first American cabaret engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza), which extends through Saturday, proclaim her ''the hottest German import since the Volkswagen.''

title: Providence Tops N. Michigan
description: A 2-0 victory for Providence last night at Marquette, Mich., eliminated Northern Michigan from the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I hockey tournament.

title: Art's Way Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Included a tax credit of $125,000.

title: Chiron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $4,909,000 for the repurchase of certain rights to market human superoxide dismutase from Chiron Corp.'s joint venture partner, Pharmacia AB of Sweden, for a package of cash, newly issued Chiron stock and future product royalties for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on the Law page on July 22 described concerns raised by stu dents about instructors' comments in two review courses that train law graduates for the New York State bar examination. Three women in one course, BAR/ BRI, complained in a letter to the State Board of Bar Examiners that they had been warned their scores might suffer if they used feminine or neutral pronouns or constructions like ''he/she'' in essays. The article said women in the courses ''have charged that the courses were tainted by sexual bias.'' After months of discussion with Stanley D. Chess, director of BAR/ BRI, over disputed parts of the article, The Times has concluded that this point merits clarification.

title: Cenvill Development reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is 95.6 percent owned by First American Bank & Trust of Palm Beach County.

title: SOUTH KOREA CHIEF RENEGES ON PLEDGE FOR A REFERENDUM
description: Warning of a ''repetition of confusion and violence'' in his country, the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, said today that he was indefinitely postponing a long-awaited referendum on his first year in office.

title: Concern Grows on F.D.I.C. Power
description: In its rush to solve the $100 billion savings and loan crisis, the Bush Administration has proposed a plan that could turn the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation into a super-agency, making it the nation's dominant banking regulator.

title: Insurers Discriminate Against AIDS Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Injury-Prone Wrestlers Deserve Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Ghosts of Katyn
description: Among the unresolved mysteries of World War II, the Katyn massacre occupies a ghoulish space of its own. These are undisputed facts:

title: Afghan Aide Takes On a Thankless Task
description: In a wing of the presidential palace here, no more than a slingshot's range from the spot where rivals smothered one of the country's previous Marxist leaders with a pillow, a former tea merchant spends most of his time these days trying to get a fresh hearing for what has been one of the most ruthless governments in Asia.

title: Statute Allows Warning Of Exposure to Virus
description: To the Editor:

title: French Socialists Gain in Cities; Right and Far Left Lose Ground
description: The ruling Socialist Party made strong gains in the final round of French municipal elections today as it won control of several major cities from the conservative opposition.

title: Indiana Lawmaking Is Fit to Be Tied
description: A call came into the switchboard of the Indiana House of Representatives the other day. The caller wanted the Speaker of the House, a mundane request that in most other states gets you switched to the Speaker. In Indiana, it gets you only a question: Which one?

title: Senators' Goal: Make New Ideas Pay Their Own Way
description: A generation ago, political conversations here were routinely punctuated, if not interrupted, by the question, ''But what about the Vietnam War?''

title: Clear Channel Communicaions reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $610,000 from the sale of the company's interest in a cellular telephone operations.

title: Big-Wordsmith
description: George Bush, songsmith?

title: Review/Dance; Allegra Kent With the Ballet of Los Angeles
description: John Clifford's Ballet of Los Angeles would have been attraction enough when it appeared Friday night at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College at Purchase. Mr. Clifford was a popular dancer with the New York City Ballet, which he left in 1973. And his company visits New York infrequently. But this visit included Allegra Kent, a former ballerina of the City Ballet, who seldom performs these days, but whose magic is legendary.

title: Graphic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
3-Point Baskets Lift Knicks Over Bucks
description: Trent Tucker, the Knicks' established long-range shooter, and Kiki Vandeweghe, the newest member of the club, broke out of shooting slumps last night. Both did it with outside shooting.

title: Bridge
description: Four star-studded teams began play today in the semifinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. The pairings by captain were Eddie Kantar of Venice, Calif., versus Malcolm Brachman of Dallas and Ron Rubin of Manhattan versus Jim Cayne of Manhattan.

title: Pentagon Reunion
description: Who was that man in the pinstriped suit?

title: Dallas Prosecutors Resist Freeing Murder Figure Who Won Appeal
description: A prisoner who has served 12 1/2 years for a murder to which another man has all but confessed remained in prison today after one judge granted him release and another judge reversed that decision hours later.

title: Manhattan Dentist Charged With Sexual Abuse of Patient
description: A Manhattan dentist was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with sexually abusing a patient while she was under anesthesia, the police said.

title: Breakup of Eastern Won't Hurt Air Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsico Offers $495 Million Issue
description: Pepsico Inc. yesterday tapped the corporate debt market with a $495 million issue of 10.55 percent notes due in 1990 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Our Towns; Where Recycling Is Spoken, Fines Add Some Clarity
description: rrThe other day Tom Harrison was walking up Palisades Avenue, looking in people's trash. At 355 he peeked in a bag and spotted a six-pack of Budweiser bottles. He slit a second bag, a Pepsi bottle popped out. ''This guy's getting a warning,'' he said. ''No recycling whatsoever.''

title: Sonora Gold Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $50.6 million in the carrying value of the Jamestown Mine. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Adams Arrested
description: Margo Adams, the former traveling companion of Wade Boggs, who is suing the Boston Red Sox third baseman for $500,000, was arrested Sunday after being accused of trying to shoplift a $258 coat in Costa Mesa, Calif. Adams, 33 years old, was held by security officers at the Nordstrom department store, then taken to a police station, where she was cited on a charge of petty theft, a misdemeanor. She was released on her own recognizance after signing a promise to appear in court. (AP)

title: Chaparral Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $3,895,000 from an accounting change.

title: Knicks Rout 76ers at the Spectrum to End Four-Game Road Slide
description: Charles Oakley, who is paid primarily to rebound, had made only two 3-point baskets all season. He added three in four attempts tonight.

title: Syrup Maker Stake To Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the agribusiness giant based in Decatur, Ill., has acquired a 5.9 percent stake in the American Fructose Corporation class A common stock. American Fructose, a maker of high-fructose corn syrup based in Stamford, Conn., has 5.2 million class A shares outstanding.

title: The Mayor's Scam on Mitchell-Lama Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting Victim Undergoes Surgery to Determine Sight
description: A 12-year-old boy shot in West Orange by a man who killed a girl and critically wounded another boy underwent surgery to determine whether the attack left him blind, officials said today.

title: Toxic Chemicals Found in Great Lakes Birds
description: Birth defects among birds in the Great Lakes region have increased over the past two decades, the Sierra Club, an environmental organization, said.

title: Review/Dance; Choreographer Who's No Slave to Fashion
description: Sharon Fogarty does not deal with fashionable themes, preferring, it seems, to make theater-dances about mothers and children, friends and lovers, and silent-movie comedy. The style of the pieces she presented on Saturday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace was also decidedly unchic, blending a cappella singing with simple dance phrases. And Ms. Fogarty's performers looked like friends who wandered in and stayed to become a family.

title: Cristiani's Victory Complicates U.S. Decisions
description: The victory of a right-wing candidate in El Salvador's presidential election seriously complicates the Bush Administration's effort to maintain bipartisan Congressional support for giving large amounts of American aid to that country, lawmakers and Administration officials said today.

title: Jefferies Is Looking Almost Natural at 2d
description: In the fifth inning of the quiet Mets-Phillies game this afternoon here at Jack Russell Stadium, Gregg Jefferies took a toss at second base, pivoted as the baserunner came hurrying down the line, and threw to first to complete the double play.

title: Bush Sets Foreign-Policy Study Deadline
description: President Bush has given his senior security advisers a mid-May deadline for completion of their broad review of American foreign policy, reporters were told today. He also intends to mount a concerted effort later that month to regain the initiative abroad from the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Rebuild the Rights Commission
description: The credibility of the United States Commission on Civil Rights is again under fire. Its chairman, William Barclay Allen, was arrested last month in an alleged kidnapping. Confronted by his colleagues, Mr. Allen issued a startling statement branding the commission as ''impotent'' and calling for everyone's resignation, including his own.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Possis Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net income and included a pretax gain of $1,834,000 from a settlement in connection with a failed acquisition.

title: Data Network to Use Code to Insure Privacy
description: Officials of Internet, the computer network that ties together hundreds of academic, government and corporate networks, are planning to begin a program that will permit users to send messages to one another in what is intended to be an unbreakable code.

title: Brae Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest year included a $1,818,000 charge related to certain contractual relationship with an unrelated partnership and settlement of certain litigation, a $700,000 charge for inventory obsolesence, charges of $2,250,000 related to the leased and owned trailer fleet, and revenue of $3,035,000 related to a payment in satisfaction of the remaining obligation under an expired option agreement to purchase a subsidiary. Prior year included a $10,000,000 restructuring provision and income of $2,350,000 related to the expired option agreement.

description: b-Included a $11,618,000 charge from equity in net losses of affiliates. c-Included a $2,053,000 charge from equity in net losses of affiliates.

description: b-After extraordinary gains of $4,821,000 for the quarter and $5,581,000 for the year.
