description: b-Included a $1 million charge for a severance arrangement with a former officer. c-Net income

title: Callon Consolidated Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: Numac Oil & Gas Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Breakup of Eastern Won't Hurt Air Competition; Lost Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Keeps an Eye On Inflation
description: The Bush Administration, which during its first weeks in office chafed openly about the risk of recession, seems now to have been convinced that the more serious danger is that of resurgent inflation.

title: Merchants Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,531,000 for the quarter and $10,751,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,102,000 for the quarter and $1,542,000 for the year. The latest year also included a one- time restructuring charge of $3,189,000.

title: 7 MISSING, 10 HURT IN GULF RIG BLAST
description: A large explosion ignited an oil production platform in the Gulf of Mexico Sunday night and the fire spread to another rig, leaving 7 men missing and 10 injured. A Coast Guard spokesman said there was little hope any of the missing would survive.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution permits prosecution of those who use illegal drugs as part of religious ceremonies.

title: Winfield Seeks a 2d Opinion on Back
description: Dave Winfield, who left the Yankees' spring camp Sunday to explore options for his ailing back, is seeking advice from as many as three specialists on the West Coast. A team source said surgery is considered imminent.

title: SNL Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $98,000 for the quarter and $255,000 for the year. c-After net realized investment gains of $13,000 for the quarter and $640,000 for the year.

title: Maxon Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and after a special gain of $48,000. The results included the operations CMS/Data Corp., which is now wholly-owned by the company. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: William Olander, 38, Art Curator, Is Dead
description: William R. Olander, the senior curator at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York City, died of AIDS Saturday in Minneapolis. He was 38 years old.

title: Judge Orders Jail Transfer For Capasso
description: In a rare public dispute between a sentencing judge and a warden, a Federal judge yesterday ordered prison authorities to reverse the warden and send Carl A. Capasso, the imprisoned companion of Bess Myerson, to a half way house to complete a prison term he is serving on a tax-evasion charge.

title: Maxxam Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $7.7 million for the quarter and $13.8 million for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $14.1 million and $900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Horizon Corp., a majority-owned subsidiary of Maxxam, recorded a provision to reduce certain of its real estate and related assets to estimated net realizable value during the latest fourth quarter. This resulted in a fourth quarter charge to Maxxam's consolidated results of operations of $28.4 million before income taxes and minority interests. On May 20, the merger of a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam with and into Maxxam Group Inc. was consummated and, as a result, Maxxam Group became a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam. Maxxam's consolidated results of operations for the latest year included Maxxam Group's consolidated results of operations beginning on Jan. 1, 1988. Accordingly, income attributable to the former stockholders of Maxxam Group through May 20, 1988, is deducted as pre-acquisition earnings and classified as minority interests in the consolidated statement of operations for 1988. During 1987, Maxxam Group was accounted for as an unconsolidated subsidiary of Maxxam and, as a result, Maxxam's income from continuing operations for the year ended Dec. 31, 1987 included $25.7 million, representing Maxxam's share of Maxxam Group's earnings for that period. On Oct. 28, a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam was merged into Kaisertech Ltd. Maxxam's consolidated statement of operations for 1988 included Kaisertech's consolidated results of operations from the date of the merger of Kaisertech through Dec. 31, 1988. Beginning with the second quarter of 1988 through the date of the merger of Kaisertech, Kaisertech was accounted for by the equity method of accounting.

title: Hospital Staffing Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
First Central Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included realized capital gains of $50,874 and $371,760 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Pretoria Defuses Incident at Bonn's Embassy
description: The Government today defused a potential diplomatic incident with West Germany by assuring four black political detainees who sought refuge in the West German Embassy that they could leave without fear of arrest.

title: Rates Rise at Sale Of Citicorp Paper
description: Interest rates rose for the second consecutive week at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, reaching the highest levels in more than four years.

title: Moderate Rises Shown in Prices For Consumers
description: Consumer prices climbed a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in February, reducing fears of surging inflation that might have brought harsh and risky countermeasures by the Federal Reserve.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: FOR nearly two decades down on the farm in the flat loamy fields here, the Bland family has not waited for the mid-May onset of sweet onion season to sample their crop. Now they have decided to market their baby vidalias - tender, field-fresh early spring onions.

title: A Boy Who Killed Coldly Is Now a Prison 'Monster'
description: Willie Bosket, a self-proclaimed ''monster'' whose five-year sentence for two subway murders when he was 15 years old led New York to toughen its juvenile criminal laws, will be sentenced this morning for his latest crime, stabbing a prison guard.

title: First Calgary Petroleums Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings in both periods equalled less than one cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Vermonters Tap Maple Syrup For More and More Recipes
description: Ann Christopher lives on the 250-acre farm of her husband's family, where maple trees have been tapped for generations to make syrup. So it was ''just natural,'' she said, to use maple syrup to sweeten some mustard and barbecue sauces she sells under her ''Annie's Enterprises'' label.

title: Time to Lift Sanctions Against Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FINDING a new kind of cheeseburger isn't as easy as it sounds. Sure, lots of restaurants these days offer as many toppings and fillings as Baskin-Robbins does ice cream flavors. But after broiling, barbecueing, grilling, griddling and pan-frying, how many ways are there to cook a burger?

title: Turner Offer For FNN Seen
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is expected to make an offer Thursday for Financial News Network, the New York-based cable network that specializes in business news.

title: Talks on Seabrook Are Set to Resume
description: State officials and other parties plan to resume negotiations Wednesday over a bankruptcy reorganization plan for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg announced. The plan to renew the talks comes less than a week after United States Bankruptcy Judge James Yacos put pressure on the parties to reach an agreement within 60 days.

title: 4-State Panel Adopts a Water-Saving Plan
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission set the stage today for a drought emergency declaration and a ban on outdoor water uses in Philadelphia, Camden, Trenton and about 800 other communities in eastern Pennsylvania, western New Jersey, the Catskills and northern Delaware.

title: Kiddie Products Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Roy Jones Jr. Still Fighting For the Gold
description: Even before the Olympic torch arrived in Seoul, South Korea, last year, the coach of the United States boxing team, Ken Adams, knew who might get burned. Two days before the opening ceremony, Adams sat in an upstairs room in the Olympic Village and talked about how many gold medals his boxers might earn.

title: How Success Spoiled the Long Island Rail Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Navigators Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $474,000 for the quarter and $675,000 for the year. c-After capital losses of $379,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $282,000 for the year. The company said comparisons of 1987 and 1988 results are affected by the assumption by Navigators of $10.6 million in net loss and unearned premium reserves in 1987 from two former members of pools managed by its underwriting affiliates for an equal amount of cash.

title: AOI Coal reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MacDonald Scores 500th To Help Top Islanders
description: Lanny MacDonald scored his 500th goal and Joe Nieuwendyk added his 50th goal tonight as the Calgary Flames beat the Islanders, 4-1.

title: Stoddard, ABC Entertainment Chief, to Head New Division
description: Brandon Stoddard, the president of ABC Entertainment and the architect of ABC's prime-time schedule, resigned yesterday to become the president of a new ABC division devoted to creating and producing series and movies for the network.

title: Man Aims at Officers But Gun Misfires
description: A 32-year-old man pulled a gun on two plainclothes officers yesterday, but the gun misfired and he was charged with attempted murder, the police said.

title: Review/Theater; A 2d Drama in a Shakespeare Play
description: When Mandy Patinkin is on stage emoting - or, these days, on record crooning - there is always a second suspenseful drama percolating just beneath the official script. Will the actor keep his volatile emotions within the bounds of the character he's playing, or will he fly over the rainbow into an unedited orgy of tears and strangled tenor sobs that call more attention to his own overwrought sensitivity than to his role? The tension between the two Patinkins - the one in control, the other not - is the main reason he divides audiences as violently as any star around.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Steeb Upsets Agassi: Carl-Uwe Steeb broke third-seeded Andre Agassi's serve four consecutive times and scored a straight-set upset yesterday in the first round of the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Steeb, ranked 96th in the world, won, 6-4, 7-5, 6-0. The West German captured the final eight games. Agassi, ranked fourth, became the first player seeded in the top 16 to be eliminated from the two-week, $2.1 million tournament. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia swept Todd Woodbridge of Australia, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3. Aaron Krickstein, the 10th-seeded player, needed more than three hours to beat Luiz Mattar of Brazil, 4-6, 3-6, 7-6, 6-0, 7-6. Andres Gomez of Ecuador, seeded No. 15, beat Jan Gunnarsson of Monaco, 6-7, 7-6, 6-2, 3-6, 6-1. In women's play, third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia needed only 46 minutes to beat Sophie Amiach of France, 6-1, 6-1. Zena Garrison, seeded fifth, and 10th-seeded Lori McNeil also advanced.(AP) HORSE RACING Socially Informed Wins: Socially Informed, ridden by Richard Migliore, shook off Dancing Pretense after entering the stretch and drew away to a three-length victory yesterday in the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. Gnome's Treasure was the runner-up in the field of four, a neck ahead of Dancing Pretense. All Hands on Deck was the trailer. Socially Informed, the favorite, covered a mile on the muddy track in 1:38 3/5 to record his third victory in five starts this year. The winner earned $28,200 for his owner, James A. Riccio, and returned $3 and $2.60 for $2 to win. There was no show betting. (AP)

title: 12 Wooden Finalists
description: The 12 nominees for the John R. Wooden Award, which will go to the nation's top collegiate basketball student-athlete, were announced yesterday by the Los Angeles Athletic Club where the winner will be named April 5.

title: Costs in New York Area Rose 0.5% in February
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, led by increases in food and housing costs, the United States Department of Labor's regional bureau reported yesterday.

title: Political Winds Shift In Sakharov's Favor
description: Supporters of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human-rights campaigner, succeeded today in forcing a new election at the Soviet Academy of Sciences, reviving the prospect that Dr. Sakharov will win one of the seats reserved for the academy in the new Congress of People's Deputies.

title: At Meeting, Jewish Unity Is Tested by Issue of P.L.O. Talks
description: Leaders of major Jewish groups ended an elaborate Government-sponsored ''Jewish solidarity conference'' this evening, voicing warm support for Israel while making clear that they do not always agree with Government positions.

title: Pushers' Best Friend, the N.R.A.
description: An unholy alliance between the National Rifle Association and drug dealers is slowly turning some urban neighborhoods into killing fields and transforming Washington and other cities into free fire zones.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: BUSINESS DIGEGST
description: THE ECONOMY Consumer prices climbed a moderate 0.4 percent in February, reducing fears of surging inflation that might have brought harsh countermeasures by the Federal Reserve. The latest rise in the Consumer Price Index was less than most analysts had expected. [ Page A1. ] Prices in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.5 percent in February. [ D26. ] Federal Reserve officials are not yet inclined to raise interest rates sharply. News Analysis. [ D1. ] The savings industry lost $2.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 1988, ending its worst year ever with losses of $12.1 billion. [ D1. ] The Supreme Court handed the F.S.L.I.C. a sharp setback, ruling unanimously that creditors of failed institutions can sue them in Federal court without waiting for the F.S.L.I.C. to act. [ D1. ] Representative Dingell apologized to a private investigator and backed down from an accusation that the man had misrepresented himself as a Congressional employee. [ D2. ] COMPANIES The Justice Department will closely study the proposed merger of the computerized airline reservation systems operated by Delta and American. [ D1. ] Continental Airlines and union officials disagreed on the impact of the flight attendants' strike. [ D5. ] Marvin Davis has teamed with Prudential to buy Spectradyne, the leading supplier of pay-per-view movies in hotels, in a deal the buyers valued at $635 million. [ D1. ] Lotus will offer an intermediate version of 1-2-3 for users who do not wish to upgrade to more powerful hardware. [ D5. ] Brandon Stoddard, chief programmer at ABC, resigned to head a new ABC unit that will produce TV series and movies. [ C26. ] Hewlett-Packard will sell its South African sales subsidiary to Siltek, a South African manufacturer of computer products. [ D5. ] MARKETS Ivan F. Boesky was virtually wiped out financially, his lawyer said, after he paid $100 million to settle insider-trading charges in 1986. A group of investors suing Mr. Boesky has contended that he had at least $25 million in assets after settling S.E.C. charges. [ D1. ] Ending a two-day fall, stock prices rose modestly, as investors were encouraged by the 0.4 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 3.75 points, to 2,266.25. [ D8. ] Short interest on the Big Board fell 0.2 percent in the four-week period ended March 15. [ D19. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in light trading, helped by the report on consumer prices. [ D17. ] Yields rose again on C.D.'s and bank money-market accounts. [ D13. ] Prices of energy futures soared in relatively heavy trading, driven partly by a belief that OPEC is continuing to reduce production. [ D15. ] The dollar ended mostly higher against major currencies in quiet trading. [ D15. ] TECHNOLOGY Two companies have begun offering new cement that cures much faster than ordinary portland cement. [ D6. ] Factor VIII, a blood-clotting protein for hemophiliacs, will be marketed under a cross-licensing agreement. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL The I.M.F. and the World Bank are preparing multibillion-dollar loan packages to help Mexico and Venezuela. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Brady plan on third world debt is a dramatic break with past policies. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Investing in art should not be done without careful thought, pension advisers say. Market Place. [ D8. ] 7 Days marks its first anniversary with the challenge of persuading its readers to pay for their copies. Advertising. [ D20. ]

title: String of Military Defeats Deepens The Isolation of Ethiopia's Rulers
description: Severe military setbacks suffered recently by the Ethiopian Government in its 14-year civil war have left the Government politically and psychologically weakened, Western and Soviet diplomats here say.

title: Pharmetics Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WD-40 Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included gains of $345,000 for the quarter and $569,000 for the 6 months from insurance settlements.

title: Antisubmarine Plans Criticized For Lacking Focus on the Future
description: The Navy has failed to focus its research far enough into the future to maintain its technical advantage over Soviet and other submarines, which are becoming ever harder to detect, submarine warfare specialists said in a report released today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Bangles and Presley

title: Mine Kills 3 Irish U.N. Soldiers in South Lebanon
description: Three Irish soldiers from the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon were killed today when the truck they were riding in was blown up by a land mine.

title: Brutality Inquiry Looks At a Police Distress Call
description: An incident in which four black family members said they were brutalized in their apartment by as many as 25 police officers, most of them white, may have begun when a police dispatcher panicked and sent out an emergency distress call, the authorities in Queens suspect.

title: Food Notes
description: Chocolate Easter Eggs

title: Afghan Insurgent Siege: Planning Appears Weak
description: The two-and-a-half-week Afghan guerrilla attack on the Government stronghold at Jalalabad bogged down after some initial successes because the guerrillas lack a military command structure to plan and carry out such an attack, military experts say.

title: Knight Wins Honor
description: Bob Knight of Indiana, whose Hoosiers were 3-4 early in the season, was voted the Big Ten's coach of the year yesterday after his team won the conference championship with a regular season record of 25-7 and a 15-3 league mark.(AP)

title: Tosco Acquisition
description: The Tosco Corporation acquired the right to buy the Seminole Fertilizer Corporation in a $115 million deal that would give the company its only non-oil business. Tosco, an independent oil refiner and wholesaler, said it had obtained the right to purchase virtually all of privately held Seminole's stock from Argus Fertilizer of Stamford, Conn. Seminole, which makes phosphate fertilizer, has annual sales of $300 million and debt of $200 million.

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bolivia Shifts Tactics in Drug Fight
description: After years of American-assisted efforts to slow cocaine production and exporting through raids and other enforcement measures, Bolivia has switched its priorities to voluntary crop substitution and eradication.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Arafat's Audiences
description: It is said by some Palestinians that if Yasir Arafat is to establish a Palestinian state, he must speak in three languages - Arabic, English and Hebrew.

title: Helen H. Beebe, 80; Taught Deaf Children
description: Helen Halik Beebe, a teacher of deaf children who was a noted speech pathologist, died of heart failure Saturday at Easton Hospital in Pennsylvania. She was 80 years old and lived in Easton.

title: Flame Is Suspended
description: Mark Hunter, a Calgary Flames right wing, was suspended for three games without pay yesterday for hitting Michel Petit of the Rangers with a stick during a game March 13.

title: A Gentler Touch, and More Short Skirts
description: Fashion has moved into a gentler mode as the fall and winter openings continue here. In the last two days, designers showed pretty clothes rather than blockbuster change-the-world collections.

title: It's Not Just Blocks For Mourning
description: As the basketball program at Georgetown University took the final steps to national prominence early in this decade, its coach, John Thompson, would occasionally point his players toward the model of excellence established by an old Boston Celtic teammate.

title: Concept Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid last month. Concept said its year-ago second quarter net included a non-operating gain on the sale of investments of $168,000, or 1 cent a share, while its year-ago 6 months' net included a non-operating loss on the sale of investments of $187,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: 'Oat Bran' May Be on the Label, but How Much Is in the Box?
description: SIGN in the bread department at Fairway Fruits and Vegetables on Broadway near 75th Street: ''Spread some cream cheese on your oat-bran bagel and whip your cholesterol level into a psychotic frenzy.''

title: Conagra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mineral Resources International Ltd reports earnings for
description: The company acquired a 70 percent stake in Barons Oil Ltd. last September. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Failure in El Salvador
description: If President Bush still has doubts about the failure of Reagan Administration policy in Central America, Sunday's elections in El Salvador make it indisputable.

title: ACM Government Opportunity Fund Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Assets represents net assets. The net investment income was $2,983,096, or 26 cents a share. Total net realized and unrealized loss on investments was $1,526,966. Comparable year-ago figures are unavailable because the fund began operations in August 1988.

title: Review/Film; A Tragic History in 'Lodz Ghetto'
description: An atmosphere of funereal quiet pervades ''Lodz Ghetto,'' Kathryn Taverna and Alan Adelson's powerful documentary chronicling the history of the Polish ghetto where more than 200,000 Jews were forced into slave labor by the Nazis before being sent to death camps.

title: Soccer in the Heart of Texas!
description: Even though it takes place in Texas, the Dallas Cup is not the world's biggest youth soccer tournament. But it does have a solid claim to being one of the world's best.

title: Alan Civil, Hornist Of BBC and Beatles; Londoner Was 59
description: Alan Civil, a British musician who was regarded as one of the world's most accomplished soloists on the French horn, died of liver and kidney failure on Sunday at King's College Hospital in London. He was 59 years old.

title: Review/Film; Vietnam, From a Cameraman's Vantage
description: Charlie Duncan, the Vietnam veteran who wrote and directed ''84 Charlie Mopic,'' has said he wanted to make an intimate portrayal of war, to show what really happens to young men in battle. The device he hit on was to mimic the making of an Army documentary. ''84 Charlie Mopic,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, consists of film taken by a military cameraman as he follows a six-man patrol on a jungle reconnaissance mission in Vietnam, interviewing the soldiers and filming them in action from his shoulder-held camera. He focuses on the kind of practical detail that will, presumably, be useful to soldiers just arriving, like burying chewing-gum wrappers so enemy scouts won't see them, and learning to spot booby-trap trip wires in the dense underbrush.

title: U.S. Farm Stockpile Cut
description: The stockpile of Government-owned grain and other commodities has been reduced by half in the last year, the Agriculture Department reported on Monday. The department's Commodity Credit Corporation, which handles price support operations, said the value of products under its control as of Dec. 31 totaled $15.8 billion, down from $29.6 billion a year earlier. When a crop is placed by farmers under a price support loan, the commodity cannot be sold or used by producers until the loan is settled. In many cases, farmers forfeit the commodity to the corporation, which holds it as surplus.

title: SHL Systemhouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results for the latest periods included those of Computerland Canada, which was acquired last July. On a pro-forma basis, SHL would have had year-ago 6 months' revenue of $249 million if Computerland's results were included. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lessons
description: Robert Frost once said that ''the chief reason for going to school is to get the impression fixed for life that there is a book side to everything.''

title: Chesapeake Biological Laboatories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Marketing Unit at Times
description: The New York Times has created a new marketing department to consolidate the newspaper's planning, marketing and promotion services for various departments, Lance R. Primis, president of the newspaper, announced yesterday.

title: Castro Foe Reports Trip to Havana And a Possible Thaw in Hostility
description: For the first time in a decade, some of Miami's strongly anti-Castro Cuban exiles have begun an exchange of views with representatives of the Cuban Government.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Down, but Not Out
description: Even Republican politicians who have campaigned against the Washington bureaucracy generally want to stick around the Government after they are voted out of office. Not surprisingly, the Bush Administration has lent a helping hand.

title: Edward Michaelsen, Executive, Dies at 71
description: Edward Hugo Michaelsen, a corporate executive and arts enthusiast who became managing director of Carnegie Hall, died of cancer yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

title: Dispute Threatens Saab Aircraft Deal
description: Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden could lose an important aircraft order because of a growing dispute between Scandinavian nations and the United States over airline routes, a Swedish newspaper said today. American Airlines, a unit of the Dallas-based AMR Corporation, has threatened to cancel an order for up to 200 Saab 340 commuter jets after the Swedish Government refused to allow the carrier to operate a route from Chicago to Stockholm, the paper Dagens Industri reported.

title: Regency Cruises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about the formation of the advertising agency Schmertz/Hilton, described the firm incorrectly. It is a joint venture of the Schmertz Company and Jack Hilton Inc., not a merger.

title: Aid Freeze Can Bring Peace to the Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: Adobe Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
A 2,700-Mile Running Path To a Sacred Cree Symbol
description: Ten years ago, Jim Thunder, a Cree Indian, had a powerful dream. In it, a revered ancestor and Cree warrior, Big Bear, commanded him to retrieve a sacred Cree symbol - Big Bear's bundle, a two-foot-long grizzly bear paw sewn to a sacred red cloth, with a plug of tobacco and a batch of sweet grass encased in layers of fabric.

title: At Last, Crime Too Heavy for Capital to Bear
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. woke up this morning with a stomach ache and did not make it to the office until almost noon.

title: France Blocks Bid By 3M for Spontex
description: The French Government has blocked the proposed takeover for 1.1 billion francs ($173 million) of the French cleaning materials concern Spontex by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. Minnesota Mining, known as 3M, agreed in September to buy Spontex, which is owned by Chargeurs S.A. Spontex makes textile, sponge and synthetic wiping products, while 3M makes a range of products, including specialty chemicals, computer tapes and note pads.

title: Trizec Corp reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Asian Food That's Finger-Licking Good
description: WHEN Irene Khin Wong came to the United States from Burma at the age of 12, her family did not leave its culinary traditions behind.

title: Market Place; Art Investments By Pension Funds
description: PROFESSIONAL money managers have been known to view their portfolios as works of art, but when it comes to investing in art, they should think twice, pension advisers say.

title: Thoratec Laboratories reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a gain of $680,000 from the restructuring of debt. The prior year revenue included $650,000 from the sale of a patent.

title: Lotus Intends to Offer Intermediate Program
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said today that it would offer an intermediate version of its popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet program for users who do not wish to upgrade to more powerful personal computer hardware.

title: Overture, a Crisp California Medley
description: WHEN Roland Shackelford, the wine maker at Chateau DeBaun in Santa Rosa, Calif., writes instructions for an assistant, they might read, ''Transfer 2,000 gallons of Overture from Debussy to Beethoven.''

title: Town Bans the Homeless at Motels
description: In an atmosphere of division and doubt, zoning officials in this Connecticut River resort town have taken an unusually aggressive stand against the homeless: From now on, homeless people cannot be sheltered at local motels.

title: Bonanza Oil & Gas Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company recently changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from Oct. 31. For the year ended Oct. 31, 1987, the company had a loss of $1,223,000, on revenue of $19,660,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Math of Tomorrow In a Classroom Today
description: In the turreted Tudor high school here, close by the banks of the Hudson River, Anthony Piccolino is already teaching the math of tomorrow.

title: West German Concert Duo
description: Frank Peter Zimmermann made an excellent impression this season when he was a soloist with the Stuttgart Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. The young West German violinist came back to New York on Sunday evening, bringing with him an equally young West German pianist named Alexander Lonquich. The two played sonatas by Mozart, Beethoven and Brahms at Alice Tully Hall.

title: WASHINGTON Talk: Trade Policy; Scholar Stirs Passions of Japan's Friends and Foes
description: To some trade policy watchers, he is the leading Japan basher. To others, he is a fresh wind blowing through often foggy discussions about why the United States is taking an economic beating from its Pacific ally.

title: Where Chocolate Bunnies Come From
description: CONSIDER the chocolate Easter bunny.

title: Paris Opera Ballet Is to Perform At Radio City Music Hall in May
description: The Paris Opera Ballet will perform at Radio City Music Hall from May 17 to 21, in its only American engagement of the year. The season was announced yesterday afternoon by Rudolf Nureyev, artistic director of the company, in a press conference at the Music Hall.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE first of the important Bordeaux chateaus announced the price for its 1988 vintages last week and it was disappointing news for serious wine buyers.

title: Math Teachers Push for Reasoning Over Rote
description: Saying society now requires mathematical knowledge far beyond the ''shopkeeper arithmetic skills'' traditionally taught in schools, the nation's largest association of mathematics teachers recommended today that reasoning should be emphasized over rote memorization as the best way to develop mathematically literate students.

title: Britain Blocks Bid by Elders
description: The British Government today blocked Elders IXL Ltd.'s bid of $:1.6 billion, or about $2.8 billion, for the British brewer Scottish & Newcastle P.L.C. because the combination could be anti-competitive.

title: A Vintner's Labors In War-Torn Land
description: STOIC admirers of Chateau Musar, a famous and exotic Lebanese red wine, profoundly understand Longfellow's maxim ''All things come round to him who will but wait.'' Musar typically takes 12 to 15 years to mature, if not longer. Serge G. Hochar, the director general and wine maker, will soon make the waiting easier.

title: Hewlett's Unit In South Africa
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would sell its South African sales subsidiary to Siltek Ltd., a South African manufacturer and distributor of computer products.

title: Vagrants Take Over Grand Central Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: New Cabs Would Be Air-Conditioned Under a New York City Plan
description: Air-conditioning and shoulder harnesses for the back seats will become required equipment for New York City's yellow cab fleet under new rules expected to be approved tomorrow by the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Atlantis Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Francis Russell, 79, a Historian And a Harding Biographer, Dies
description: Francis Russell, a historian and prolific writer whose publication in 1968 of a biography of Warren G. Harding became a cause celebre when relatives of the former President succeeded in preventing Mr. Russell from printing some of Harding's love letters, died of a heart attack yesterday in Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital, on Cape Cod. He was 79 years old and lived in Sandwich, Mass.

title: Wolverine Exploration Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $6,660,000 on the reversal of income tax on debt restructure and a loss of $5,960,000 on the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and after a gain of $82,601,000 on debt restructure and a tax credit of $5,960,000. In the latest year, the company had $55 million in exploration expenses for Wells which had not yet come on line.

title: Santana Injury Brings Quick Woe for Thrift
description: Syd Thrift, named today as the Yankees' senior vice president of baseball operations, stepped out of George Steinbrenner's rented car and stepped immediately into his first problem: what to do about the team's spring of injuries, including the one that struck Rafael Santana on Monday.

title: The Minimum Wage: A Distraction
description: Finally, the long, bitter battle over raising the minimum wage comes down to this: It doesn't make much difference. To working poor people, the pluses and minuses pretty much cancel out. In Congress, the adversaries seem willing, for the first time in eight years, to compromise.

title: A Deli Downs Legal Eagles
description: They may be first-class lawyers, but as deli operators, they didn't know corned beef from contracts.

description: Comparable year-ago figures are not available because the real estate trust was formed in June 1988. The latest year is for the period from its inception on June 13 to Dec. 31, 1988.

title: About New York; Singles Bars: Not Really Gone, Just Forgotten
description: ''1. Do you come here often? 2. Do you live in the neighborhood? 3. You seem to be a person of depth. 4. I feel I've known you for a long time. 5. Your place or mine?''

title: Twin Richfield Oils Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of U.S. oil and gas assets of $830,000 for the latest year and $2,401,000 for 1987. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Senate Officials Reject Newest Cuomo Taxes
description: New taxes proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on cable-television service, tires, batteries and participatory sports such as bowling, will not be enacted, State Senate officials said today.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Race for Whip: Hyperspeed vs. Slow Motion
description: The race for Republican whip in the House of Representatives pits the bomb throwers against the old guard, the movement conservatives against the head-counting institutionalists, Mr. Outside against Mr. Inside.

title: Is There a Hangman in the House?
description: The state of Washington has a problem. Prison officials are scheduled to hang triple-killer Charles R. Campbell on March 30. Trouble is, they may not have a hangman.

title: American Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,694,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss The company said after preferred dividend requirements share earnings for the latest year was less than one cent a share.

title: Who'll Profit From Victory In Salvador?
description: Assuming that the right-wing candidate Alfredo Cristiani would win the presidency, a group of Salvadoran businessmen recently assembled $10 million to start a bank.

title: INSIDE
description: Record Savings Losses

title: John J. McCloy Is Eulogized in Manhattan Service
description: John J. McCloy, the lawyer, banker and administrator who made public affairs a life's work in the administrations of seven Presidents, was euologized yesterday in a Manhattan church by leaders in law, finance and government from both sides of the Atlantic.

title: British Columbia's Logs
description: The British Columbia government plans to reduce exports of raw logs from the province by raising to 100 percent, from 40 percent, the existing tax on the difference between the foreign price of a raw log and the domestic price, the Forests Minister, Dave Parker, said Monday. Mr. Parker said the new tariff was intended to ''save sawmilling jobs.''

title: Loosening the Grip of Texas
description: It's been easy so far not to take sides in what passes for the politics of the Bush era. The fight over the Tower nomination, for instance: only someone obsessed to the point of lunacy with small-bore politics could have cared much how it turned out.

title: Technology Development reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year net income is restated to reflect an accounting change. The restatement decreases previously reported net by $149,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Bank Yields Again Post Strong Gains
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money-market accounts continued to show strong gains in the week ended yesterday.

title: Real Estate; Lower Costs In Queens for Auto Dealers
description: DANIEL KOEPPEL, whose father opened a Chrysler dealership on Northern Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, nearly 50 years ago, has seen competitors come and go.

title: New York Needs Life, Not Death
description: Every year for the last 12, New York's Legislature has passed death penalty bills but failed to override governors' vetos. On Monday, Governor Cuomo again vetoed a death penalty bill. But this year the Assembly has registered 99 votes for it, one shy of the two-thirds majority needed to override. That challenges every opponent of the override to hold firm.

title: 2 Are Accused Of Intel Scheme
description: The founder and an employee of Ulsi System Technology Inc., a start-up chip company in San Jose, Calif., were charged with conspiracy to steal trade secrets from the Intel Corporation.

title: Time Inc. Soars on Reports Of a Small Stake by Bass
description: The stock of Time Inc. surged yesterday on reports that the Robert M. Bass Group held a small stake in the media company, which has agreed to merge with Warner Communications Inc.

title: In Teaching Math: Reasoning, Not Rote
description: A national organization of math teachers, backed by the Secretary of Education and more than two dozen major education associations, says math instruction should emphasize reasoning over rote memorization.

title: Article 718189 -- No Title
description: The Los Angeles Municipal Improvement Corporation entered the tax-exempt market yesterday with a $64.9 million bond offering.

title: Youth in Jersey Denies Account Of Man's Death
description: A teen-ager took the stand in his own defense today and testified that the Indian man whom he and three other youths are charged with murdering engaged them in a street fight with a karate kick and, after being injured, refused an offer to end the fight and walk away.

title: U.S. Trying to Halt Abuses Of Incompetent Pensioners
description: The Bush Administration and Congress are exploring ways to curb the growing abuse of incompetent Social Security beneficiaries by those appointed to handle their monthly benefit checks.

title: COURT BACKS TESTS OF SOME WORKERS TO DETER DRUG USE
description: In its first rulings on the constitutionality of testing for drug use on the job, the Supreme Court today gave an initial victory to the Federal Government's aggressive campaign to create a drug-free workplace.

title: In a Monastery Smokehouse, Hickory Is Incense Enough
description: LEAD: BROTHER ELIAS - an Eastern Orthodox monk and a connoisseur of fine meats and cheeses - was standing in front of the smokehouse at the New Skete Monastery, a spotless white apron covering his ample monkish girth. He peered inside at the hanging rows of freshly smoked kielbasa, the monks' first batch for the spring holiday season.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 0.2% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest on the Big Board declined two-tenths of 1 percent in the four-week period ended March 15.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: SINCE its humble origins here in 1982 in a 450-square-foot garage, Macheesmo Mouse has blossomed into a mini-empire of hip, healthful Mexican fast-food restaurants spreading from the San Francisco Bay Area north to Seattle.

title: Books of The Times
description: Dexterity By Douglas Bauer 317 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Traveler's Check Policy
description: The American Express Travelers Cheque Group announced yesterday that it would deliver traveler's checks by hand to customers whose checks were lost or stolen, generally within three hours.

title: Investment Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tri-R Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Three D Departments reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
North Lied to Conceal Gift, Witness Tells Jury
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency officer testified today that Oliver L. North prepared false documents to show he had paid for a $13,800 home security system he actually obtained free.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Dialogues of the Carmelites' At the Manhattan School
description: A rare level of musical cohesion distinguished the Manhattan School of Music's production of Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' on Friday night. First credit must go to Louis Salemno, the conductor, and to the excellent orchestra: this marvelous score has not always been interpreted with such specific feeling for its motion and its textures at the Metropolitan Opera, which does the piece well.

title: U.S. Delegation to Press Iraq On Reparations in Stark Case
description: Frustrated that Iraq has not paid compensation to the families of 37 American sailors killed in the 1987 attack on the guided-missile frigate Stark, the Bush Administration is sending a high-level delegation to Baghdad this week to resolve the problem, State and Defense Department officials said today.

title: P.S.A.L. Wins Senior Classic
description: At the Felt Forum last night, the inaugural Senior Classic between the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association all-stars and those from the Public Schools Athletic League, won by the P.S.A.L., 99-79, was a game haunted by those who were absent.

title: Prudential Unit Had '88 Profit
description: Prudential-Bache Securities said yesterday that it earned a record $111 million last year, a dramatic turnaround from the $164 million loss it recorded in 1987. George L. Ball, the firm's chief executive, attributed the improvement to gains in risk-arbitrage trading and in investment banking. The retail business, he said, registered a loss of a few million dollars.

title: There Are Better Ways to Use TV in Schools; Junior Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mild Quake Rattles California
description: A mild earthquake shook towns along the Pacific coast north of Los Angeles this morning, but the police said there were no reports of injuries or serious damage. The earthquake measured 3.8 on the open-ended Richter scale of ground motion, meaning it was strong enough to cause minor damage, scientists at the California Institute of Technology reported. The epicenter was 14 miles southeast of Oxnard, a city with a population of more than 125,000 about 50 miles northwest of Los Angeles.

title: Special Toughness From New Ranger
description: Mark Janssens suddenly went still and things immediately got quiet that night early last December in Salt Lake City. Janssens, who had been involved in a fight an instant before, lay unconscious on the ice, his mouth locked shut, his skin turning blue.

title: Time Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
R. J. Reynolds Cuts
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco U.S.A., a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., said it would offer two voluntary separation programs to reduce its hourly work force by about 700 employees. The company said the reduction resulted from the withdrawal last month of its Premier smokeless cigarette.

title: Dingell Calls Off Inquiry Into Investigator's Role
description: Representative John D. Dingell, the powerful chairman of a House Energy and Commerce investigatory subcommittee, backed down today from accusations that a private investigator had improperly misrepresented himself as working for the panel.

title: Treasury Issues Advance Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in light trading yesterday, helped by a report on consumer prices that was not so bad as many analysts had feared.

title: No Progress, as Usual, in Cayton-King Talks
description: Forget the rumor that the struggle for control of Mike Tyson might be cooling down.

title: Agency Allowing More Fruit From Chile Back on Market
description: The Food and Drug Administration today lifted more restrictions on importing fruit from Chile, announcing that pears and nectarines could again be marketed in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Beatrice S. W. Fuerst misidentified a book about her battle against polio.

title: Bach's 'Art of the Fugue' as He Wrote It
description: Bach's ''Art of the Fugue,'' composed mostly in four unspecified parts, might seem a natural for the string quartet, and indeed the Juilliard String Quartet has been performing the work for the last few years. On Tuesday and Wednesday nights last week, the quartet presented it as part of the 92d Street Y's chamber-music series.

title: Dofasco Increases Foreign Steel Sales
description: Dofasco Inc., which acquired a rival last year to become Canada's largest steelmaker, plans to exploit its enlarged production capacity to penetrate overseas markets. With raw product from its Algoma Steel Corporation subsidiary, Dofasco is increasing exports of hot-rolled steel to take advantage of strong foreign prices, its president, Paul Phoenix, said in a interview.

title: Chief Executive Resigns His Dual Posts at Invest
description: Thomas A. Cooper, a former president of the BankAmerica Corporation, has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Invest, a company based in Tampa, Fla., that operates brokerage services in banks and savings institutions.

title: Principal's Lawyer Ejected And a Mistrial Is Declared
description: The defense lawyer for a New York City school principal charged with drug possession was ejected from Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday and a mistrial was declared after the lawyer said photographic and television coverage of the trial had caused him to withdraw from the case.

title: Financial Benefit Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Dance; Another Version of 'Carmen,' by Luisillo
description: An experienced choreographer, Luisillo has been creating works in various Spanish dance forms since the 1950's, and his productions have often possessed great theatrical flair. Therefore, on Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College, it was surprising as well as disappointing to watch the Teatro de Danza Espanola, which he also directs, present two pieces by him that featured gifted dancers but were weakened by choreographic problems.

title: Reviews/Music; A Szymanowski Symphony By Polish Radio Orchestra
description: The radio orchestra figures importantly in American musical history, if only because of Arturo Toscanini's 17-year career as head of the NBC Symphony, which was created for his use and did not long survive his retirement in 1954. Despite the continuing prestige of Toscanini's name, however, there is no entry for his last orchestra in the New Grove Dictionary of American Music, an omission that may only underscore the fact that the in-house ensembles once employed by major networks are now barely a memory.

title: Fuller, H B Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Physicians Insurance Co of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,684,033 for the quarter and a loss of $3,567,980 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,121 for the quarter and $2,831,749 for the year. d-Net loss

title: Waldo Hutchins Jr., Lawyer, Is Dead at 93
description: Waldo Hutchins Jr., a lawyer who practiced in Manhattan for more than 30 years died Monday at his home in Glen Head, L.I. He was 93 years old.

title: Nets Can't Shoot on Time, Lose Eighth Straight Game
description: When a pro basketball team fails to shoot within 24 seconds in the late moments of a game, it is in trouble.

title: Maxicare Resumes Doctor Payments
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., which is reorganizing in Federal bankruptcy court, announced it had resumed payments to doctors that were suspended last week. The nationwide health maintenance organization also said some members had encountered difficulties getting served by doctors or pharmacies after it filed for bankruptcy Thursday.

title: Savings Loss Put at $2.3 Billion
description: The beleaguered savings and loan industry lost $2.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 1988, ending its worst year ever with losses of $12.1 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Palestinian Is Given Life Imprisonment In 2 Settlers' Deaths
description: A military court in Nablus in the West Bank today sentenced a 17-year-old Palestinian to life in prison for an April 1987 firebombing in which a pregnant Jewish settler and her young son were burned to death.

title: Future of Louisiana and Governor Ride on His Campaign for Taxes
description: When Buddy Roemer came from nowhere to become Louisiana Governor more than a year ago, his election signified a wave of voter disgust with business as usual in what is perhaps the nation's most economically troubled state.

title: Reviews/Music; James Levine as Soloist With Met Chamber Group
description: When orchestra members take up chamber music before an audience, the purpose is often as much therapy for the former as enlightenment aimed at the latter. Members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra have quite a different idea, however. Sunday afternoon's long but rewarding program at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church offered the Met's best players, their music director James Levine as pianist and conductor and a fascinating program.

title: Dalai Lama Sees a Culture Endangered
description: Fearful of both hard-liners in the Chinese leadership and young Tibetans eager to challenge Beijing with violence, the Dalai Lama appealed today to China, his own followers and the West to help save Tibetan culture from annihilation.

title: U.S. Budget Gap Widens
description: The Government posted a $27.87 billion budget deficit in February, up from $24.03 billion in the same month a year earlier, as growth in spending outpaced increases in revenues, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: O.E.D. 2, All 20 Volumes of It, Adds to the Queen's English
description: With the permission of Queen Elizabeth II, the repository of the Queen's English has been modernized and internationalized with words and phrases that would have puzzled Queen Victoria and startled polite society in the Victorian Age.

title: High Court Limits Power Of F.S.L.I.C.
description: In a sharp setback for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the Supreme Court ruled today that creditors of failed savings and loans that are insured by the Government can sue the institutions in Federal court without waiting for the F.S.L.I.C. to adjudicate.

title: MGM Grand Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,886,000 for the quarter and $1,952,000 for the year. c-Net loss The company was in the development stage for most of 1987. Latest year's results included the operations of the Desert Inn and Sands from their acquisition on Feb. 1, 1988. MGM Grand said its revenue for the latest year included $185,897,000 from hotel-casino operations and $22,031,000 from MGM Grand airline operations.

title: Williams Scores 27 As the Redmen Roll
description: The atmosphere of a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game was missing. There were empty seats in Alumni Hall for the second straight game and St. John's was playing a team it hardly has an intense rivalry with.

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 19
description: b-Net loss

title: Eating Well
description: FIVE servings of fruits and vegetables, six servings of starches and just six ounces of meat a day: this recommendation last month by the National Research Council, unlike previous ones in reports on the relationship between diet and health, was quite specific.

title: New Citroen Model Offered by Peugeot
description: The French auto company Automobiles Citroen introduced its new top-of-the-line XM model to compete against BMW's 5-series and the Audi 100 in a sector accounting for about 14.2 percent of the European market. Prices for the XM, a five-door model with front-wheel drive, have not been announced. The model will go on sale near the end of May.

title: Bamberger Polymers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moore Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year included $12.4 million in unusual, non- recurring charges for costs and reserves associated with the previously reported latex examination glove inventory and purchase commitments at prices and quantities above current market conditions, and previously reported litigation in connection with purchases made in 1980 and 1982.

title: Centel's Sale Of Cable Unit
description: The Centel Corporation said today that it expected to sell its cable television division this month for more than $1.4 billion and use the proceeds to pay a special dividend to shareholders.

title: Arch Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aritech Corp., Framingham, Mass., an electronic security equipment manufacturer, elected to its board Thomas F. Burke, chairman and chief executive of M/A-Com Inc.

title: Rate Caution By Fed Seen
description: When the Government's report on producer prices hit the news wires last Friday morning, many economists figured that the Federal Reserve would have no alternative but to slam the economy with much higher interest rates to stop inflation.

title: Advocate for Addicts Faces Life Sentence
description: The founder of a local chapter of Cocaine Anonymous faces life in prison after being convicted Monday of selling cocaine to an undercover police investigator two years ago.

title: US Gold Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DALLAS FREES MAN IN VERDICT APPEAL
description: Randall Dale Adams walked out of a Dallas jail late this afternoon, having spent 12 1/2 years in prison for a murder to which another man has all but confessed.

title: Microsoft Copyright Ruling
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that a decision by a Federal judge in a copyright lawsuit brought by Apple Computer Inc. contained points that favored Microsoft.

title: NASA Chief to Leave in April
description: James C. Fletcher, who reluctantly agreed to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after the Challenger disaster in 1986, announced today that he was resigning effective April 8.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from a tax benefit of $18,000 and a loss from minority interest of $274,000. The company said the lower net sales were due primarily to decreases in Ocean Pacific and Code Bleu sales of $7,723,000 and $2,507,000, respectively.

title: The 'Mommy Track' Isn't Anti-Woman
description: LEAD: ''The cost of employing women in business is greater than the cost of employing men.

title: Klaus Tennstedt, Ailing, Cancels at Philharmonic
description: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt is to undergo hip surgery and will not conduct the next 12 New York Philharmonic concerts as scheduled. Replacing him tomorrow, Friday, Saturday and Tuesday is to be Yoel Levi. The program and soloist remain as scheduled.

title: Schubert Theme In Hoiby Piece For Quintet
description: An Die Musik, a chamber quintet that took its name from a Schubert song, recently commissioned a brief signature piece from Lee Hoiby, with the proviso that he use the Schubert theme in the work. Mr. Hoiby complied, and on Sunday afternoon, the ensemble opened its Merkin Concert Hall performance with the result, ''Overture to a Song.''

title: Mindscape Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results are pro forma and reflected income taxes as if the company were taxed as a C corporation for the entire period.

title: Unigene Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Marital Lapse by Australian
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke, dogged by questions about his personal life, tearfully admitted, in a television interview broadcast tonight, to being unfaithful to his wife of 33 years.

title: Kabul Shuns Its Image And Courts Some Foes
description: Most days, Omara Khan is in his village 30 miles north of here. But lately the peasant leader has been plying his flexible politics in the murky world of Kabul, where shifting military fortunes have persuaded the Afghan Government to seek fresh political support among groups it once treated as its foes.

title: Battle Over a Blood-Clotting Protein Is Avoided
description: Two biotechnology companies and their marketing partners announced a worldwide cross-licensing agreement yesterday for genetically engineered Factor VIII, a blood-clotting protein that 40,000 hemophiliacs rely on to prevent painful and often fatal bleeding.

title: White House Considers Replacing Head of Civil Rights Commission
description: The White House is considering replacing the head of the United States Civil Rights Commission, William Barclay Allen, because of his entanglement in an adoption case involving a 14-year-old Apache girl, Administration officials said today.

title: Charles Suppon, 40, a Designer And a 'Legs Diamond' Co-author
description: Charles Suppon, a fashion designer and co-author of the musical ''Legs Diamond,'' died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 40 years old. Mr. Suppon died of brain lesions, his assistant, Bruce Cudd, said.

title: Is Honor Due House That Was Home to Capone?
description: From the time he came to Chicago as a young hoodlum until he was sent away to prison as the leader of a vast criminal empire, Al Capone and his family lived in a modest, red-brick, two-flat house on Prairie Avenue, on the city's far South Side.

title: Transit Police Union Ratifies 3-Year Pact
description: The transit police union has ratified a three-year contract that maintains pay parity with the Police Department and calls for annual raises of 6 percent, the union president, William McKechnie, announced yesterday. The vote was 1,645 to 797. The membership had rejected an earlier accord approved by the executive committee of the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. Mr. McKechnie said assignments for the 8 P.M.-to-4 A.M. shift were renegotiated.

title: 18-Month Term In ZZZZ Case
description: The final co-defendant of Barry Minkow in the $25 million ZZZZ Best fraud case was sentenced Monday to 18 months in Federal prison.

title: Russian River Journal; Courage Is an Ingredient At Banana Slug Festival
description: In the rainy season, when Northern California's redwood groves are thick with banana slugs, the slippery creatures sometimes take up residence in Nita Graham's house, squishing under her feet when she walks to the bathroom at night, hiding in the folds of her clothing and leaving trails of slime on her freshly painted walls.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday described a former use of the synthetic hormone diethystilbesterol (DES) incorrectly. It was widely prescribed before 1971 as a safeguard against miscarriage, not for morning sickness.

title: Book Notes
description: Rooney's Protest

title: Court Issue: Is a Group in a Home a Family?
description: What is a family? There are at least two responses right now in this Suffolk County community.

title: Novatron Information Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New President Named At U.S. Unit of Bovis
description: Lehrer McGovern Bovis, the construction management company, said yesterday that it had named Alan S. Ellett president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. TO SEEK TALKS BETWEEN ISRAELIS AND LOCAL ARABS
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States would ask the P.L.O. to allow Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to begin a discussion with the Israeli Government to help pave the way for peace talks.

title: Debt Help for Venezuela And Mexico Is Prepared
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are preparing multibillion-dollar loan packages to help Mexico and Venezuela, which are likely to be the first countries to benefit from a new plan for coping with the global debt crisis.

title: Prudential-Bache Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included one-time charges of $47 million from the closing of an international trade finance unit and unspecified charges relating to litigation concerning a purported attempt by the Hunt Brothers to corner the silver market.

title: Fast-Curing Cement May Help Road Builders
description: For more than a century, engineers have used the same basic material to construct many of the nation's roads, bridges and buildings: portland cement. When mixed with water, gravel and sand, it produces concrete, a substance as hard as stone after it dries.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Turbo Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $942,000 for the quarter and $5,902,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after special charges of $1,451,000 for the quarter and $1,742,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Proffitt's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Prague Court Reduce Playwright's Sentence
description: An appeals court today reduced the jail sentence of the playwright Vaclav Havel from nine months to eight and reduced one of two charges against the dissident.

title: Continental Strike Impact Is Disputed
description: The strike by Continental Airlines' flight attendants began to have an effect on operations yesterday, but the carrier's management and its unions assessed the impact differently.

title: DeVoe of Tennessee Resigns as Coach
description: Don DeVoe resigned yesterday after 11 years as coach of the University of Tennessee basketball team, saying the move was ''an effort to stop the persistent rumors surrounding my status.''

title: At Least 16 Die as Brazilian Jet Hits Shantytown
description: A Brazilian cargo plane crashed and exploded in a shantytown in this Sao Paulo suburb today, and officials said the three-member crew and at least 13 people on the ground were killed and more than 200 people were injured.

title: Joss Energy Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Air Reservation Deal Faces Intense Scrutiny
description: The Justice Department plans to examine closely the proposed merger of computerized airline reservation systems operated by Delta Air Lines Inc. and American Airlines Inc.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bush's Pantheon
description: Each new President has the prerogative of exiling or resurrecting his predecessors - in portraiture at least. He can choose which past Presidents he wants as a silent kitchen cabinet, staring down understandingly while he makes the tough decisions.

title: Vallen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Economic Scene; Shuffling Toward Debt Reduction
description: ''WE can't tell if the glass is half full or half empty,'' Senator Paul Sarbanes told a reporter from Congressional Quarterly. ''But there is water in the glass.'' The Senator's cautious response to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's ''reassessment'' of the third world debt problem, is understandable. Many analysts feel they were suckered by Mr. Brady's predecessor at the Treasury, James Baker, whose widely hailed fix for debt in 1985 proved to be only a strategy for muddling through to November 1988.

title: Marvin Davis to Buy Spectradyne
description: Marvin Davis, the billionaire oilman and hotel owner, has teamed with the Prudential Insurance Company of America to buy Spectradyne Inc., the leading provider of pay-per-view movies for customers of hotels and motels.

title: Preferred Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beijing Puts New Restrictions on Businesses
description: Chinese leaders announced new restrictions today on the collectively and privately run businesses that have been the most dynamic sector in the economy.

title: Charles Dutoit Named
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has named Charles Dutoit artistic director and principal conductor of its summer season for 1990 and 1991, with an option for 1992. He will hold the same posts at the Mann Music Center in Philadelphia and at the Philadelphia Orchestra's summer residency at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in New York.

title: Com-Tek Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our dialogue with the P.L.O., we intend to use and are using to make clear to them that they must demonstrate through action what they've said rhetorically. And one way to do that, of course, would be not to stand in the way of Palestinians in the occupied territories engaging in a dialogue with Israel.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A1:3. ]

title: Velen Journal; Tricks of Capitalist Trade for Fast-Track Russians
description: Grouped around a conference table in a luxuriously restored castle, the senior managers listened intently as a tanned consultant described ways of improving employee motivation.

title: Bomb Kills Five in Colombia
description: A bomb destroyed a three-story building, killing 5 people and injuring 11 in an expanding war between drug-trafficking groups, a military official said. The bomb was thrown Monday at a ground-level food shop in a suburb of Medellin. It was the third attack in a week against businesses owned by members of the Medellin drug cartel. The attacks were apparently retaliation for 22 bombings of a nationwide chain of pharmacies owned by the head of the Cali drug cartel.

title: 30th Inmate Is Executed in Texas
description: A Texas prison inmate was put to death by lethal injection early today for killing a man 11 years ago by smashing his head in with the butt of a shotgun.

title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use
description: Steroid testing results of National Football League players will be announced in late August, and those who test positive will be suspended for 30 days, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today at the league's annual meetings.

title: In Moscow's TV Political Debates, The Unspeakable Is Now Routine
description: ''Do you believe in God?'' the moderator asked the candidates in one of Moscow's first televised campaign debates.

title: Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
System Introduced For Compact Disks
description: A small California company introduced a system that would allow users to record their own compact disks. Meridian Data Inc., a privately held company in Capitola, Calif., said the system would allow recording studios to make demo compact disks and allow companies to put reams of data for computers onto compact-disk read-only memories, or CD-ROM's. Normally, compact disks are made at special pressing plants, which stamp them out by the thousands.

title: Airbus Moves For Efficiency
description: The four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium today announced a shake-up to make the money-losing European aircraft maker more competitive.

title: Navy Trident 2 Missile Explodes In Its First Underwater Test Firing
description: A Trident 2 missile exploded today four seconds after it shot out of the water off Cape Canaveral, Fla., in the first undersea test launching of the Navy's newest and most powerful nuclear ballistic missile.

title: Lawyer for Boesky Rebuts Assertions in Investors' Suit
description: One of Ivan F. Boesky's lead criminal lawyers said yesterday that his client had been virtually wiped out financially after he paid $100 million to settle insider trading charges in 1986.

title: Essex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $32,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Price Data Put Dow Back on the Plus Side
description: After the stock market's steepest two-day slide since August, stock prices rose modestly yesterday, buoyed by a smaller-than-expected rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for February.

title: Lawyers Challenge Steinberg Jury Chief
description: The foreman of the jury that convicted Joel B. Steinberg was improperly coached to manipulate other jurors, Mr. Steinberg's lawyers argued in a motion filed yesterday. They said the verdict should be overturned.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Crowley, Milner & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After an unspecified charge related to early redemption of bonds for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and included a restructuring charge of $1,241,000.

title: As Spring Arrives, So Does Ski-Slope Frivolity
description: Throughout the winter, ski competitions tend to be very serious. But with the warmer temperatures of March, that perspective changes as skiers take their final flings. Ski areas contribute to the light-heartedness by holding competitions that are playful and often slightly wacky.

title: Legislators in Arizona Reject Move to Pay Mecham Costs
description: Legislative leaders Monday rejected a proposal to pay Evan Mecham, removed from the governorship in an impeachment trial, more than $200,000 in costs he incurred preparing for a recall election that was never held.

title: 2 Players Testify About Threats
description: Tony Woods, a Seattle Seahawks linebacker, and Everett Gay, a Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, told a Federal jury today that they received threats from the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, who at one time represented each of them.

title: At The Nation's Table
description: SURE, Ted Danson, on the television show ''Cheers,'' plays a recovering alcoholic who runs a bar and stays sober. But can Oprah Winfrey, the television talk-show host who recently shed 67 pounds, become an active partner in a Chicago restaurant featuring many rich and tempting foods and remain svelte?

title: Chamber Society in SoHo 'Tryout'
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center likes to try out its programs a little farther downtown. Thus this week's four formal performances in New York and Washington were prefaced early Saturday evening by a dress-rehearsal-as-concert at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo. The big gallery space -stripped of most exhibits as insurance against careless listeners - is a bit too resonant to house a grand-piano sound comfortably, but it is a happy musical atmosphere, with listeners (a responsive and intelligent lot) seated on the floor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 Washington may ask the P.L.O. to allow Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to talk with Israel, helping to pave the way for peace negotiations. Page A1

title: Vons Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $1.7 million. c-After a reversal of a tax credit of $3.6 million. d-Net income and after a tax credit of $5.5 million. The latest periods consisted of 12 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year, compared with 13 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, for year-ago periods. The latest year loss included about $11.9 million in non-recurring costs associated with the company's acquisition of Safeway Southern California last August, and higher workers' compensation and general liability insurance costs. The year-ago results are pro forma, based on the addition of the Safeway operations acquired in 1988.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BSR International P.L.C., London, an electronics company, agreed to acquire five businesses from Emerson Electric Co. in exchange for new shares that value the Emerson businesses at $:86 million.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SINCE my extended family is scattered around the country this Easter, I have decided to prepare a simple and quick dinner at home. Instead of the traditional roast ham or leg of lamb, I will make medallions of pork with lentils, a favorite combination of mine.

title: Reviews/Music; Gidon Kremer and Friends Make Their Case for Lourie
description: Gidon Kremer, the Latvian violinist who now lives in the West, has a deserved reputation for both talent and taste: for his playing and his ability to command attention for obscure composers. He did it with Sofiya Gubaidulina, whose ''Offertorium'' violin concerto he has played with many orchestras, and he was one of Arvo Part's several champions.

title: Defendant in Officer's Slaying Won't Take Stand
description: One of four men charged with murdering a police officer in South Jamaica changed his mind yesterday and did not testify in his defense after his lawyer had said that he would.

title: Esmond Van Name, 79, U.N. Building Chief
description: Esmond Austin Van Name, who was in charge of planning, design and building operations for many years at the United Nations headquarters, died Friday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: Trilogy Resources Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Spring Fever, Down to a Science
description: IN the spring a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of . . . chronobiology?

title: Article 847589 -- No Title
description: House Democratic leaders today agreed on a measure to increase the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour from its current $3.35 and to accept a lower 60-day training wage for first-time workers.

title: A Year Old, 7 Days Faces New Tests
description: DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN awakened at 3:30 the other morning, convinced his Shih Tzu was murmuring ''Mommy.'' Armchair psychoanalysts might conclude that Mr. Schneiderman is transferring to the dog his anxiety about tonight's birthday party for 7 Days, the publication he began a year ago tomorrow.

title: Nussbaum Guilty In Traffic Case
description: Hedda Nussbaum, who testified against her lover, Joel B. Steinberg, at his child-killing trial in Manhattan, has pleaded guilty to two traffic violations, the Bedford Town Court Clerk said yesterday.

title: US Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: Bridge

title: First Pitch for Landry
description: When the Texas Rangers open their American League schedule against the Detroit Tigers April 4 at Texas Stadium in Arlington, Tex., Tom Landry will make the ceremonial first pitch. Landry, the former coach of the Dallas Cowboys, was dismissed last month by the Cowboys' new owner, Jerry Jones.

title: There Are Better Ways to Use TV in Schools

description: The League of Women Voters and a television station were selected today to sponsor the four gubernatorial debates required for primary candidates who accept public financing.

title: Few Officers Face Charges In Park Melee
description: A draft report by New York City's Civilian Complaint Review Board concludes that only a small number - perhaps only a dozen - of the 115 civilian complaints of police misconduct last summer in a clash at Tompkins Square Park have been substantiated and the officers positively identified, according to people who have seen the document.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Wright Fate May Be Decided By Fine Distinctions in Rules
description: When is a business deal not a professional relationship? On such fine points may hang the political fate of House Speaker Jim Wright, the target of an ethics committee investigation.

title: Griffin to Buy Radio Stations
description: Merv Griffin said today that he would buy four radio stations from Federal Communications Inc. for $34 million. Mr. Griffin, through his Griffin Group, said the stations were WHJY-FM and WHJJ-AM in Providence, R.I., and WVEZ-AM and WVEZ-FM in Louisville, Ky.

title: People
description: * Charles Rosner has been named creative director and executive vice president of Cabot Advertising, Boston. He had been senior vice president and group creative director of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.
