description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Article 839689 -- No Title
description: Having leased two barges to house its prisoners, the New York City Department of Correction is ready to build one of its own - a made-to-order floating jail, the first in the nation, that will rise five stories high, stretch the length of two football fields and probably be moored off the Bronx by the summer of 1990.

title: There Are Better Ways to Use TV in Schools; The Anatomy of Hype
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Schools Seeking Allies Beyond Parents
description: Private schools around the country, responding to the time demands that frequently keep two-career parents from closely involving themselves in their children's education, are reaching out to the people who help bring up those children: nannies, au pairs, housekeepers and tutors.

title: Louis Dupree, 63, Anthropologist And Expert on Afghanistan, Dies
description: Louis Dupree, an anthropologist and educator who was an authority on Afghanistan, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Duke University Hospital in Durham, N.C. He was 63 years old and lived in Durham.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Electoral systems should strive to make each citizen's portion equal. If districts of widely unequal population elect an equal number of representatives, the voting power of each citizen in the larger constituencies is debased.'' - Associate Justice Byron R. White. [ B5:3. ]

title: Japan Reports 130 Boat People Lost in Collision
description: Japanese officials disclosed today that about 130 Vietnamese refugees are believed to have died earlier this month when their overloaded boat apparently collided with a Japanese tanker in the South China Sea.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Crystal Brands Inc., Southport, Conn., an apparel manufacturer, promoted Edward B. Dailey to executive vice president and Gerald M. Chaney to vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Qed Exploration Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest 6 months' results included a $575,000 first quarter non- cash writedown of oil and gas properties resulting from lower oil and gas prices.

title: When Camping Gear Needs Repair
description: LEON GREENMAN, mountaineer, cartographer and co-author of a guide to the Catskills, works magic with camping equipment. He can patch holes in sleeping bags, fix rips in backpacks and re-sole hiking boots.

title: Ala.-Birmingham, Michigan State Gain
description: Andy Kennedy scored 22 points tonight and Reginald Turner added 18 to lead Alabama-Birmingham to an 85-79 victory over Connecticut in a National Invitation Tournament quarterfinal game.

title: SEOUL CRACKDOWN AIMED AT LEFTISTS
description: President Roh Tae Woo ordered a crackdown on ''leftist forces trying to overthrow the Government'' today, according to his spokesman, and the Korean police were widely reported to have abandoned a policy that prohibited shooting back in violent attacks on police posts.

title: Sequa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,243,000 for the quarter and $2,897,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,167,000 for the quarter and $3,653,000 for the year. The latest periods included revenue and income derived from the continuing businesses of Atlantic Research Corp., acquired late in 1987.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Tomorrow is Good Friday and Sunday is Easter. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed between 44th and 57th Streets on Sunday for the Easter Promenade, which begins at 11 A.M. and ends at 3 P.M. Government offices: Open tomorrow. Post office: Regular delivery. Banks: Open. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended tomorrow. Sanitation: Regular collections. Schools: Spring break. Financial markets: Closed tomorrow. Transportation: Subways, buses and Metro-North on regular schedules; Long Island Rail Road is adding extra trains tomorrow afternoon. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices open tomorrow; state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices open tomorrow; state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular schedule.

title: Bauhaus Furniture Stars At a Los Angeles Gallery
description: WHO needs an Aprica stroller when one can have a Bauhaus-style cradle, designed by Peter Keler in 1922 and based on the forms and colors of Wassily Kandinsky?

title: Reviews/Dance; Traveling Through the States of Emotion
description: Hikari Baba has a hauntingly lovely face and a resilient body. But she set herself such a difficult task in ''Images: Being Then and Now,'' performed Sunday night at the Mulberry Street Theater, that those attributes were not enough to save her.

title: ACM Managed Income Fund Inc reports earnings for As of Feb 28
description: Year-ago figures are not available because the fund was established in October 1988. Assets represent total net assets. Total net investment income from Dec. 1, 1988 to Feb. 28, 1989 was $4,412,445, or 23 cents a share. Total net realized and unrealized loss on investments was $195,081.

title: Some Quips, but Little More From Rose
description: Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, continued today to have no comment about the investigation by the baseball commissioner's office into ''serious allegations'' against him. Rose, who has been linked to gambling activities, did make one joking allusion to the matter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 100, Cavaliers 97: Charles Barkley had 27 points and 21 rebounds last night to lead Philadelphia at home. Ron Harper had 20 points for the Cavaliers, who clinched a playoff berth when Washington lost at Indiana.(AP) Pistons 115, Spurs 94: Joe Dumars scored 6 of his 20 points during a 17-3 second-quarter run to lead Detroit. The victory clinched a playoff berth for the Pistons.(AP) Pacers 101, Bullets 92: Detlef Schrempf, a reserve, scored 22 points last night as the Pacers gained their third straight victory and first over the Bullets this season. The visiting Bullets played without Terry Catledge and Jeff Malone.(AP) TENNIS Connors, Lendl Gain:Fourth-seeded Jimmy Connors won a first-set tie-breaker and beat Arnaud Boetsch of France, 7-6, 6-1, 6-1, last night in the second round of the International Players Championships at Key Biscayne, Fla. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl won his second-round match in straight sets by beating Jim Pugh of Palos Verdes, Calif., 6-3, 6-1, 6-1. Miloslav Mecir, seeded sixth and the 1987 champion, withdrew with a back injury. Others who advanced were Aaron Krickstein, seeded 10th, and Kevin Curren, seeded 13th.(AP)

title: Studio Stake To Rank Unit
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a leading owner of movie theaters, today sold its 50 percent stake in Universal Studios Florida to pare the debt amassed to finance an aggressive expansion strategy.

title: Calendar: Spring in a Victorian Garden
description: >Spring Beds, Steinhardt Conservatory, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE 6-year-old stood almost alone on his half of the soccer field. The ball had been on the other side of the playing field for several minutes, defying the young children's often-futile attempts to kick it either into the goal or back to the other side. The boy, who knew that the rules prohibited him from crossing the midfield line to the area with all the action, started feeling bored. A few moments later the coach, who was also the boy's father, looked in his son's direction and became angry.

title: Where Pollution Comes From
description: A survey of American industry has found toxic chemicals being poured into the air at a rate that threatens public health. Page B11.

title: Is It Thatcher's Britain?
description: In the London subway system, much of it deep underground, nearly a third of the escalators are not working. Two recent commuter train crashes killed more than 40 people. Many of the country's hospitals are in a Dickensian state.

title: 2d Mistrial Declared in GAF Case
description: A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation case after the jury said it remained deadlocked in its 12th day of deliberations.

title: Daley Confident In Chicago Race As Voting Nears
description: With less than two weeks before the city's April 4 general election, Chicago's mayoral stakes have a familiar ring to them: The candidate well ahead of the field is a Democrat with the name of Daley.

description: Where politicians and armies have failed, musicians are attempting to bridge cultural differences in the Middle East. On Monday evening, the East West Ensemble, a quintet based in Tel Aviv, opened a two-night stand to begin Dance Theater Workshop's ''Wounded Spirits/Promised Land'' series by Jewish and Arab artists from Israel.

description: To the Editor:

description: The first national survey of toxic chemicals released into the air by industry shows they are being emitted at rates that threaten public health, members of Congress and Federal officials said today.

title: Sturm, Ruger & Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Probert Is Indicted In Cocaine Smuggling
description: Bob Probert, a former Detroit Red Wing forward, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on a felony charge of drug importation almost three weeks after he was charged with trying to smuggle cocaine through the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel. If convicted, Probert could be banned from the United States, according to Roman Rewald, a Detroit lawyer who specializes in immigration and international law. Probert, a Canadian citizen, has been living in Detroit.

title: Salomon Sees 'Modest Loss' In Quarter Because of Trades
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it expected to have a ''modest loss'' in the first quarter, a result of problems in government bond and commodities trading.

title: Fugitive Indian Drops His Extradition Fight
description: Timothy Jacobs, one of two Tuscarora Indians who seized a newspaper office in North Carolina last year to dramatize their charges of local government corruption, has decided to drop his fight against extradition and to return to that state to face kidnapping charges.

title: U.S. Opposes Release of Soviet Nuclear Test Data
description: In an unusual twist, Soviet officials have told the United States that Moscow is willing to make public data from two underground nuclear testing experiments conducted this summer, Administration officials say. But the United States opposes the public release of the information.

title: Richest Got Richer and Poorest Poorer in 1979-87
description: The gap between the nation's rich and poor is widening, judging from new Congressional data released today.

title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses
description: The largest and most conclusive study of drug use in pregnancy has found that the use of cocaine or marijauna impairs fetal development.

title: For AIDS Patients, a Special Insurance Plan
description: A Canadian insurance executive's volunteer work at an AIDS hospice last year gave him an idea for easing some of the worries of dying and destitute patients: give them access right away to some of the money that their life insurance policies would pay upon death.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Baker Filling Post
description: In recommending that Raymond G. H. Seitz, a career Foreign Service officer, be nominated to be the next Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has put the finishing touches on his team of senior foreign policy advisers.

title: Coliseum Plan Moves Ahead With Agency
description: A smaller version of the Columbus Center development proposed for the site of the New York Coliseum was effectively approved yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission in a way that precluded explicit consideration of the building's impact.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Gminski Signs 76er Pact
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have signed their center, Mike Gminski, to a multiyear contract to prevent him from testing his value as an unrestricted free agent after this season, the club announced yesterday. The four-year contract also contains an option on a fifth season.

title: American Plans to Buy 185 Planes
description: LEAD: Continuing its aggressive campaign to replace aging aircraft, American Airlines Inc. yesterday announced a multibillion-dollar deal for 150 Dutch Fokker planes and an order for 35 Boeing airliners.

title: U.S. Agency Suspends Work in Mexico
description: After a strongly adverse public reaction to disclosure of its activities here, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has suspended a program aimed at obtaining intelligence on the flow of illegal immigrants through Mexico into the United States.

title: Carl Frank Bayerschmidt, Professor, 84
description: Carl Frank Bayerschmidt, a former chairman of the Germanics Department at Columbia University, died of a stroke Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 84 years old and lived in Yonkers.

description: Across the Mississippi River from the bustle of St. Louis lies a city so indebted and lacking in basic services that it evokes comparisons to the third world.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: TO Jackie Mason, there is nothing funny about super-glitzy modern design.

description: Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Company, resigned yesterday from the company's board, effective April 27.

description: The Yankees, stung by injuries and concerned more than ever that Rafael Santana's aching right elbow might require surgery, resumed talks today with the Atlanta Braves about Jeff Blauser, their rookie shortstop.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,455,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,871,000.

title: Forecast: No Recession
description: Although the Federal Reserve Board's tighter monetary policy has apparently slowed economic growth, the economy is not about to fall into a recession, a University of Michigan forecast said today. The economist Saul Hymans, director of the university's Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics, forecast a 4 percent annual growth rate in the first quarter.

title: New York City Government: Eight Years on the Docket
description: Dec. 2, 1981: The New York Civil Liberties Union files suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn charging that the allocation of one vote on the Board of Estimate to each borough president violates the United States Constitution's one-person-one-vote principle. Judge Edward R. Neaher is assigned the case. Dec. 1, 1982: Judge Neaher rules that because members are not directly elected to the board, its ''legislative character'' is limited and not subject to the one-person-one-vote requirement. May 17, 1983: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reverses Judge Neaher, saying that the board's makeup is subject to the constitutional requirement but makes no determination as to whether the provision is violated. Aug. 21, 1984: Judge Neaher issues a preliminary decision, saying the board's structure ''would appear to be unconstitutional.'' Nov. 19, 1986: Judge Neaher rules the structure violates the equal-protection clause of the Constitution by not providing equal representation based on population differences of the five boroughs. He orders the city to change the board's method of voting. Nov. 20, 1986: Mayor Edward I. Koch announces his decision to create a Charter Revision Commission to revise the board. Membership of the 15-member review panel is completed on Dec. 8, 1986. Oct. 8, 1987: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upholds Judge Neaher's ruling and says changes in the board should be made within one year. April 4, 1988: The United States Supreme Court agrees to rule on the board's constitutionality. The city suspends its plans to overhaul the board, pending the decision. March 22, 1989: The High Court finds the board unconstitutional.

title: Russo Resigns as Coach
description: Andy Russo, basketball coach at the University of Washington who has been under fire after two straight losing seasons, has resigned. The resignation was announced yesterday by Mike Lude, the athletic director.

title: N.F.L. Owners Place Limits on Off-Season Rosters
description: In an attempt to increase competitive balance and save money, National Football League owners voted today to limit rosters to 90 players from the end of the season through May 31 and to 80 after June 1 until the season opens.

title: Living the Beautiful Life, By 3 Who Should Know
description: THOSE who purvey bibelots are now writing bible-ettes. The latest permutation of the decorating and life-style book may be found in three new volumes: ''Memories of Childhood'' by Barbara Milo Ohrbach (Clarkson N. Potter, $8.95), ''With Thanks & Appreciation'' by Pat Ross (Viking Studio Books, $8.95) and ''Living Beautifully Together: How to Live Graciously in a Hectic World by Finding Time to Love Your Family, Your Friends, and Yourself'' by Alexandra Stoddard (Doubleday, $22.50).

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page on Friday about a suit that sought Government documents concerning the Iran-contra scandal incorrectly characterized the relationship of Tony Avirgan, the plaintiff in the suit, and Daniel Sheehan of the Christic Institute. Mr. Sheehan is representing Mr. Avirgan; the two men are not opponents in the case.

title: NBC Announces TV Series Plans For 1989-90
description: NBC gave advertisers a peek at the 32 programs it has in development for the 1989-90 television season today. The biggest feather in the network's cap was the announcement that it has convinced Alan Alda to return to weekly television after a six-year absence. Mr. Alda was one of the stars of ''M*A*S*H,'' one of the most successful series in television history.

description: A trader's assistant for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was convicted yesterday of lying to a Federal grand jury about her knowledge of potentially illegal trading activities at the firm.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: President Bush is having trouble persuading both Japan and Congress to accept changes he wants in the FSX fighter plane project that the two Governments agreed to last year.

description: Costly and ambitious, the 13-hour production of ''Game, Set and Match'' - taking over public television's ''Mystery'' series for the next three months - is a mess. And that's something traditional British television can hardly afford right now.

description: Stocks retreated moderately but broadly yesterday on slightly higher volume.

He said he immediately revoked the scholarship of one of the players when he learned of the player's actions.
