description: Dave Poulin put in a 4-foot shot with 1 minute 54 seconds remaining tonight to complete a three-goal third period as the Philaldelphia Flyers clinched a playoff berth by edging the Chicago Blackhawks, 3-2.

title: Reviews/Theater; Insurance Chicanery In Comedy, 'Sleeping Dogs'
description: In Neal Bell's ''Sleeping Dogs,'' the insurance executive portrayed by Richmond Hoxie has made millions by juggling his company's books. He has sold policies to bogus clients (masquerading under the names of Judge Crater, Jimmy Hoffa and Amelia Earhart). As a result, the value of the company's stock has risen. Then, to pad his own income, he has declared the clients dead and collected the premiums. Even allowing for the naivete of his young employees, one might have expected someone to notice the names.

title: Emhart Is Seeking Higher Topper Bid
description: Executives of the Emhart Corporation, which reached a $2.8 billion merger agreement earlier this week with the Black & Decker Corporation, indicated they would consider a higher takeover bid if a New York investment partnership decided to make one. In documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Emhart said it had offered the partnership, Topper L.P., the chance to review internal Emhart financial information under a confidentiality agreement if the information would help Topper make a bid higher than the $2.4 billion offer Emhart previously spurned.

title: Good Cheer In Dainty Porcelain
description: What happens when you let a flamboyant ceramics artist loose in a porcelain factory? The results can currently be seen at the Max Protetch gallery, 560 Broadway (at Prince Street), through April 8.

title: Scientific Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Cineplex Odeon Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it realized a gain of $47,700,000 from the sale of the operating assets and business of the Film House Group.

title: Nation Is Watching Struggle for the Helm
description: Prime Minister Li Peng was lavish with the self-criticisms in his keynote address Monday to China's legislature, but each mea culpa seemed carefully aimed at a figure in a brown suit slumped in a chair behind the podium.

title: A Constant Star Called Saint Laurent
description: Yves Saint Laurent brought the fall and winter fashion showings to an end today with a rousing collection that had the audience on its feet, cheering and applauding enthusiasically long after the designer had walked down the runway blowing kisses and had disappeared backstage to thank his models.

title: Popeye's Finishes Church's Takeover
description: The owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken Inc. completed the takeover of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. Alvin C. Copeland was offered about 33.5 million shares of about 36 million shares outstanding of Church's stock, and he accepted 30.1 million for $11 a share, said Mark McKinnon, a spokesman for Mr. Copeland's investment company, A. Copeland Enterprises Inc. The total purchase price will be $392 million, he said.

title: In Paris, Twiddle and Twitter
description: Unlike tennis matches, where the heads move side to side, at fashion shows they go up and down. Illustrators furiously pen silhouettes, looking up to catch another detail before the models vanish backstage. Buyers circle important items on their programs, and fashion editors doodle incomprehensibly on theirs. Nearly everyone succeeds in staying awake.

title: Groupe Val Royal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tobias Wolff Awarded Prize for Short Stories
description: Tobias Wolff was named the winner of the annual $25,000 Rea Award for the Short Story yesterday, a prize given to a living writer in the United States ''who has made a significant contribution to the short story as an art form.''

title: Fluorocarbon Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
description: b-After a loss of $1,030,000 from sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year.

title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country
description: Just before President Bush appeared in a packed high school gymnasium in Lancaster, Pa., today, Thomas Hipple stood up and recounted the grim downward spiral of his life.

title: National Too-Much Month
description: This is National Peanut Month, Humorists Are Artists Month, Poetry Month, National Women's History Month, Mental Retardation Month, Music in Our Schools Month, Philatelic Literature Month, Red Cross Month and a few more.

title: Robert Shea, 72, Dies; a Red Cross Executive
description: Robert F. Shea, a Red Cross executive who specialized in disaster preparedness, died Tuesday at the Fairfax Nursing Center in Fairfax, Va., after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Fairfax.

title: Parents and a Brother Slain By Self-Styled 'Rambo,' 16
description: A 16-year-old boy, apparently enthralled by the film character Rambo, killed his father, mother and brother and wounded his sister early today in a shooting rampage at the family's house on the outskirts of this city, the police said.

title: Editors' Note
description: A news analysis article in the Word and Image pages on Tuesday discussed a debate over ethics in journalism, growing out of a two-part article in The New Yorker this month by Janet Malcolm. Her article examines the relationship between a convicted murderer, Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald, and Joe McGinniss, author of a book about the crime.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Bolivian efforts to fight drug trafficking gave an incorrect date for a visit to Bolivia by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.

title: Boy Who Sold Crack Is Ordered to a Home
description: A 10-year-old boy who was convicted of selling crack was ordered into a home for troubled youngsters today.

title: Amerifirst Bank
description: Amerifirst Bank said the Transohio Savings Bank had ended its agreement to acquire Amerifirst because Transohio had been unable to get regulatory approval for the deal, which was announced last May. Transohio, a unit of the Transcapital Financial Corporation, offered $20 a share, or $230 million. Amerifirst said Transohio had requested the return of a $25 million deposit made in conjunction with the agreement but that it did not intend to return the money.

title: Topps Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: The share earnings reflected a 3-for- 2 stock split to be paid March 31.

title: Sentencing Is Delayed for 'Monster' Convict
description: Willie Bosket, the self-proclaimed ''monster'' of the New York State correctional system, used his knowledge of the law today to delay his sentencing for attempted murder.

title: Some Clues to Budgetspeak in the Bush Administration
description: Negotiators from Congress and the Bush Administration are meeting daily in a small room in the Capitol trying to reach an accommodation on the Federal budget. To follow the tortuous process, it helps to understand how the budget writers talk. Here are some dictionary entries.

title: Drysdale Group Buys Visalia Club
description: A corporation headed by Don Drysdale, the Hall of Fame pitcher, has purchased the Visalia Oaks of the California League, Drysdale's agent said today.

title: EPI Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included a loss of $563,000 from the conversion of long-term debt into common stock. c-Net income and the year share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: HEALTH: Pediatrics; Infants in Need of Psychotherapy? A Fledgling Field Is Growing Fast
description: Baby blocks are the latest accessories in some psychiatrists' offices, as a new idea is gaining popularity: psychotherapy for infants.

title: Broad Coalitions Are Urged To Solve Urban School Crisis
description: After studying school systems in six cities, researchers at the Rand Corporation say that the problems of failing urban schools are too severe to be solved by ''the educational bureacracy'' and can be overcome only by communitywide efforts.

title: TV Notes
description: Ball-Park Figures

title: First Amendment Isn't on Father Curran's Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Cayton Gives Deposition In Lawsuit Filed by Tyson
description: Bill Cayton began his depositions yesterday in Mike Tyson's suit to dismiss him as his manager. Thomas Puccio, Cayton's attorney, said he thought that Cayton handled himself well under questioning by Howard Weitzman, the heavyweight champion's attorney.

title: Knicks Set Ticket Lottery
description: Tickets for Knicks playoff games at Madison Square Garden will be made available to the public by a lottery system.

title: Storey County Journal For Sale: Nevada Ranch w/105 Rms
description: The prospectus for the public offering of 1,165,000 shares of common stock includes the usual information on the company's cash flow, capitalization and directors.

title: Britain to Sell Ulster Shipyard
description: The British Government said today that it would sell the state-owned shipbuilders Harland & Wolff in Northern Ireland to a management-employee group backed by a Norwegian shipping company, Fred Olsen. The sale would spare the 130-year-old yard, which built the Titanic, from having to close when existing ship orders run out in 1991.

title: Poland's Official Spokesman Leaves for 2-Week U.S. Visit
description: The Polish Government's spokesman, Jerzy Urban, departed today on a two-week visit to the United States, bearing an urgent plea for economic assistance now that the Government and Solidarity have reached agreements on a restructuring of the nation's politics.

title: Koch Orders Strong Steps to Bar Wasting of Water
description: New York City imposed a wide range of drought-emergency measures yesterday as Mayor Edward I. Koch ordered strong steps to prohibit the wasting of water.

title: Texas Man Executed for 1978 Beating Death
description: A 44-year-old man was executed by injection early today for the beating death of a man in a 1978 robbery that netted just $11.50.

title: Keystone Consolidated Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,031,000 for the quarter and $18,218,000 for the 6 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $213,000 and $531,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the quarter also included a reversal of a tax credit of $197,000.

title: U.S. Believes Some Contras Abused Prisoners
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they had tentatively concluded that some of the Nicaraguan guerrillas tortured prisoners and committed other human rights abuses in their camps in Honduras.

title: G. Bennett Larson, Broadcaster, 79
description: G. Bennett Larson, a former vice president of WPIX-TV in New York and a former communications industry consultant, died of pneumonia Saturday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Brentwood, Calif.

title: Sceptre Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results reflected production from the properties acquired from Soquip Alberta Inc., effective Oct. 1, 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American Paradise Lost
description: Sometime in the 1920's, a rich New Yorker named Abby Aldrich Rockefeller started an art collection that was based, a son wrote, ''on her own instincts and interests.'' In 1939 it became the nucleus of a great collection of folk art at Colonial Williamsburg, some of which is on display at the Whitney Museum through April 2.

title: Bridge
description: Four New York experts were afflicted with a severe case of poisoning Sunday at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Reno, but in a purely technical sense.

title: Technitrol Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEMAND VOTER EQUALITY IN ALL BOROUGHS
description: The United States Supreme Court decided today that New York City must devise a new government. In a unanimous decision, the court ruled that the powerful Board of Estimate is unconstitutional because it violates the principle of one person one vote.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: ONCE, when she was small, one of my daughters complained that our place was like a museum: white walls, many displays and an array of objects about which I was always screeching, ''Don't touch!'' She was more right than she realized. Our place isn't like a museum, it is a museum, and some day I propose to schedule a walk-through for her and her sister. How else will they know what to keep and what to get rid of when I am gone? ''Do what you will with the mattresses,'' I'll tell them, ''but everything else here is priceless.'' Priceless, that is, if one knows their stories. For instance, the clay pot handle on the shelf where I keep travel books. It doesn't look like much; in fact, it looks like something that broke off yesterday. But 20 years ago in Jerusalem, I watched while workmen excavated a trench near the Temple of Solomon. A bearded man uncovered the handle, one of many, and threw it up to me. Perhaps I should tag it ''Pot handle, Jerusalem, 1969.'' Perhaps I should tag everything in this museum. ''Staffordshire goat bought in memory of a day spent touring goat farm in northeastern Connecticut, 1964.'' ''Couches purchased from L. R. after her divorce because they wouldn't fit into the elevator of her new building, 1979.'' ''Mirror picked up from gutter on East 12th Street, 1969. Said to have belonged to Peaches Browning.'' Imagine! Peaches Browning! How will my children know that the wooden mirror that hangs in the bathroom may have reflected the face of Peaches Browning, child bride and 20's scandal, unless I tell them?

title: Electro Scientific Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Virus Affects Computers
description: LEAD: In the first known case of a computer virus in a medical diagnostic system, computers in two Michigan hospitals malfunctioned for three months last year, the hospitals say.

title: In the Quilting Egg, Two Folk Arts Meet
description: AN ancient Ukrainian tradition and an American folk art come together when the artist Jane G. Pollak decorates eggs with quilt designs. She will demonstrate the process today and tomorrow at two shops of the Museum of American Folk Art.

title: Books of The Times; 'Goldwyn,' a Biographical Ode to a Hollywood Monument
description: Goldwyn A Biography By A. Scott Berg Illustrated. 579 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Fear Mounts That Inflation Threatens World Economy
description: The moderate monthly advance in United States consumer prices reported Tuesday is seen by economists and corporate executives in Europe as at best a temporary respite in a worldwide trend of mounting inflation.

title: Reviews/Music; Julie Wilson Sings Porter
description: Julie Wilson has come full cycle since her emergence from eight years of semi-retirement in 1984. She made her return then at Michael's Pub, singing a program of Cole Porter songs that propelled her into a series of similar programs of the songs of Stephen Sondheim, Rodgers and Hart, the Gershwins and Irving Berlin, among others.

title: Cooper Development reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
P.L.O. TURNS DOWN A HALT TO UPRISING
description: After its first formal contact with the Bush Administration, the Palestine Liberation Organization today rejected a halt in the violent uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories to encourage peace negotiations.

title: Dayton Acts on Assault Rifles
description: The City Commission voted unanimously today to ban assault weapons. The new ordinance, passed by 5 to 0, makes it illegal to own any semiautomatic weapon capable of firing 20 rounds without reloading.

title: West Sent to Minors By Overstaffed Mets
description: David West, the tall young strikeout pitcher who kept reading all winter that he was ''untouchable'' in the minds of the Mets, got the word today that he was one of three rookies being cut from the squad and sent back to the minor leagues.

title: Clabir Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $28,005,000 and $27,706,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $3,656,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $123,217,000 for the quarter and $139,382,000 for the year. Prior year results are restated to reflect defense, real estate and oil and gas operations as discontinued.

title: Apartheid Divides 2 Brothers of the White Tribe
description: Frederick Willem and Willem Johannes de Klerk share a preoccupation with politics, a Calvinist rectitude and almost mystical reverence for their Afrikaner roots.

title: Debt Relief for Farmers
description: More than 80 percent of the applications from farmers seeking special debt relief from the Farmers Home Administration have been processed, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Under the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, the farm agency sent more than 66,000 notices to borrowers who were delinquent by more than 180 days. Neal Sox Johnson, the agency's acting administrator, said that more than 28,000 applications for liberalized debt options had been received and that more than 23,000 had been processed.

title: Bill to Protect Whistle-Blowers Sent to Bush
description: The House, by voice vote on Tuesday, approved a Senate-passed bill to protect the jobs of Federal workers who blow the whistle on waste, fraud or abuse in their agencies. The bill was sent it to President Bush, who is expected to sign it.

title: Quadrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included reserves and writedowns totaling $1,866,000 for restructuring costs and non-recurring items.

title: Guess? Wins Jordache Suit
description: In a bitter legal dispute between two of the country's largest jeans makers, a jury ruled today that the founders of Jordache Enterprises Inc. had committed fraud when they bought half of Guess? Inc. in 1983.

title: New Chief Is Named by Arthur Andersen
description: The board of Arthur Andersen & Company has nominated Lawrence A. Weinbach to become the firm's top officer, succeeding its departing chief executive, Duane R. Kullberg.

title: Unexpected Choice Transformed N.F.L.
description: It was all rather surprising, that day more than 29 years ago when the owners of the 12 National Football League teams elected a new commissioner. Their choice on the 23d round of balloting was the boyish-looking general manager of the Los Angeles Rams, a 33-year-old former publicist whose sports career highlight had been playing on the same high school basketball team as Duke Snider.

title: House Republicans Elect Gingrich of Georgia as Whip
description: House Republicans ventilated 34 years of frustration at Democratic rule today and elected a telegenic firebrand, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, to their No. 2 leadership position.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Loses a Shutout but Turns the Jeers to Cheers
description: The jeers and taunts of a month ago still echo in his head, rattling around as reminders of what can happen when you are abandoned by both your talent and your team. Lest John Vanbiesbrouck had forgotten, the Madison Square Garden crowd gave him a reprise last week and again as recently as the first period Monday night.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Consolidated Brinco Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-Included a special gain of $172,000. c-Included a special charge of $10,000. There were no share earnings after preferred dividends in latest year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Art for the Blind
description: To The Home Section:

title: Brooks Leaves School
description: Tony Brooks, a Notre Dame tailback who faces two misdemeanor charges in a hit-and-run accident last month, has left the university and returned to his home in Tulsa, Okla., college officials said. Brooks, 19 years old, withdrew voluntarily for personal reasons, said John Heisler, a spokesman for the athletic department. Lou Holtz, the coach of the football team, said Brooks's future at Notre Dame is uncertain.

title: Review/Recital; Pianist Plays Mendelssohn
description: Kathryn Selby, an Australian-born pianist whose technical facility is well above average, gave a satisfying recital Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y. The distinguishing characteristic of her work in Mendelssohn, Schubert, Corigliano, Debussy, Chopin and Liszt was a security of finger control that allowed her to use the pedal very sparingly and to keep firm control over musical shape in fast movements at tempos that could easily have spilled over into skittering haste.

title: Yanks Need Egos Like Green, Thrift
description: yd Thrift is one slick operator, who once persuaded the Yankees' general-manager-of-the-week to trade Doug Drabek and Brian Fisher for Rick Rhoden.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; A Dead Man, What He Hated and Those Who Loved Him
description: At the center of the ironically titled Brazilian film ''Romance'' is a dead man: a radical political theorist, Antonio Cesar (Rodrigo Santiago), whose mysterious demise has a profound effect on the film's other characters. These include both a man and woman who loved Cesar, and a journalist, named Regina, who seeks to investigate his life and his teachings.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; Tribute to an Emotionally Shattered Monk
description: Some films are so personal in manner and method that it seems an intrusion for an outsider to look at them. Such a film is ''Komitas,'' which, to the literal-minded stranger, is a feature-length composition of beautiful, sorrowing, only vaguely related images.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-Net income. The latest 12 months' loss included an after-tax writedown of $179 million from a previously announced rate settlement agreement.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers reacted positively to an economic report that was weaker than expected and to comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about an executive appointment at Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, described the agency incorrectly. It is independent, not part of Omnicom.

title: Denning Mobile Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, which is in the development stage, did not have revenue in the previous fourth quarter and year.

title: Suspect in L.I. Slaying Told To Surrender, Lawyer Says By ERIC SCHMITT
description: A Nassau County grand jury heard evidence today in the slaying of a 13-year-old Valley Stream girl, and the lawyer for the two brothers who are the main suspects in the case said that at least one of them would surrender to the authorities Thursday.

title: Panel in West Virginia Votes To Impeach State Treasurer
description: A legislative committee voted 19 to 6 tonight to recommend that the State Treasurer, A. James Manchin, be impeached for mismanaging an investment fund that lost $279 million.

title: Imre Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
How to Push Pretoria
description: As Secretary of State James Baker searches for useful diplomatic initiatives, let him consider South Africa. Ever since its ailing President, P. W. Botha, resigned in January as leader of the ruling National Party, new voices - including the Soviet Union's - have called for a political solution to racial strife. By lending his weight to the task, Mr. Baker could nudge South Africans toward negotiations and persuade Congress to keep new and harsher sanctions on hold.

title: Kabul Urges Washington to Reopen Embassy
description: The Afghan Government appealed today for the reopening of the United States Embassy and 11 other embassies that were closed here two months ago, saying that a diplomatic presence will be required here to end the Afghan war.

title: Martinez & Murphey Inc reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Kent DeFelice has been named executive vice president of DDB Needham, New York.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, has taken an option to buy back a 50 percent stake in its world headquarters complex.

title: Young Writers Learn Tricks of the Trade
description: LEAD: ONE recent day, just after sharpening their pencils, 28 very short authors sat at their desks, waiting to discuss their work.

title: Chrysalis Deal Made by Thorn
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C., a diversified British concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 50 percent of Chrysalis Record Companies, a part of Chrysalis Group P.L.C., for an initial payment of $79.1 million in cash and as much as $25 million more, depending on profits in the next four years.

title: Finding Original Designs in Unlikely Places
description: LEAD: SO you can't afford a David Salle? What about a Heinz Brummel? His works are selling as fast as he can make them in his hometown of St. Paul. Collectors can get a glimpse of his new work at the Twin Cities' premier museum, the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

title: SALVADOR VICTOR URGES PEACE TALKS
description: President-elect Alfredo Cristiani called Tuesday for immediate negotiations with revolutionary guerrillas and asked the United States not to prejudge him or his party.

title: Market Place; A Sector Coughs: Are Others Sick?
description: WITH leading computer companies sending out warnings of problems, the Wall Street view of corporate profits this year is growing more cautious.

title: Madness of Crowds
description: Consider these wildly exaggerated scenarios:

title: Animed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $775,200. The company said the latest quarter is the first quarter it operated without its electrocardiogram business, Cardiopet, which was sold in October 1988 for $2.7 million.

title: Schering Sues Over Drug
description: The Schering Corporation filed suit this week against Interferon Sciences Inc. and the Anheuser-Busch Companies, accusing them of violating a patent on processes used to make the cancer drug Intron A. Schering markets the genetically engineered alpha-2 interferon, which is patented by Biogen Inc. of Boston, a Schering spokesman, Ronald Asinari, said.

title: New York City Works Hard for All Business, Small and Large
description: To the Editor:

title: Escapees Leave Haven Of Pretoria Embassy
description: Four black political detainees who escaped to the West German Embassy left the building today after the police guaranteed their freedom.

title: Corning to Acquire Testing Concern
description: Corning Glass Works announced that it would acquire Enseco Inc., an environmental testing company based in Somerset, N.J., for $14 a share, or about $125 million. Corning officials said Enseco would become part of a laboratory testing group within the company that already includes subsidiaries specializing in clinical, life-sciences and new-drug testing.

title: Otis Douglas, Coach, 77
description: Otis Douglas, who began his National Football League playing career at 35, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 77 years old. Douglas had never seen a football game before playing tackle at William and Mary from 1929 to 1930.

title: Politicians Scrambling To Decide Who Won
description: Because of the Supreme Court, Ruth W. Messinger is running for an office that may may not survive in its current form beyond Election Day. So is Andrew J. Stein. And so, for that matter, is virtually every other elected municipal official in New York City.

title: U.N. Conference Supports Curbs On Exporting of Hazardous Waste
description: More than 100 countries unanimously adopted a treaty today restricting shipments of hazardous waste across borders, an often shady activity that has alarmed industrial and developing nations alike.

title: U.S. Studies Military Job By Hughes
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company is a target of a Federal grand jury investigation into the quality of mirrors that were used to make guidance systems for cruise missiles and the Bradley armored personnel carrier, company officials said today.

title: Peter Kilham, Ecologist, 45
description: Peter Kilham, a biology professor at the University of Michigan, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at Lake Victoria in Kenya. He was 45 years old.

title: Talking Deals; Citicorp Strategy On Glass-Steagall
description: WITH an aggressive legal maneuver, Citicorp is taking another step in the battle to unshackle the banking industry from the restraints of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933.

title: Woman Held in Fraud Is Accused of Bribery
description: Adela Holzer, the former Broadway producer indicted on charges of posing as David Rockefeller's secret wife to swindle investors out of more than $4 million, was accused by prosecutors yesterday of trying to bribe her way out of jail.

title: Forest City Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $660,000 for the quarter and $511,000 for the year. For the latest year, the company had a gain of $5,672,000 from the disposition of properties, compared with a similar gain of $206,000 in the prior year.

title: GTC Transcontinental Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: French Chair Design: It Didn't Stop With Louis XIV
description: PHILIPPE STARCK is well known for his furniture designs and interiors. Not so well-known is that behind the meteoric rise of the madcap Frenchman with the ubiquitous black turtleneck has been V.I.A., the Valorisation de l'Innovation dans L'Ameublement, an association set up by the French Ministry of Industry to revitalize contemporary French design.

title: Directory Guesswork
description: The Bush Administration's oft-reported sluggishness in assembling a team of senior officials has been noted by any number of Washington kibitzers, but one outsider with a real stake in the matter is taking it in stride. ''The White House - no problem; the Cabinet - more of a problem,'' says Roger Kranz, editor in chief of The Capital Source, a popular telephone directory of Capitol insiders published twice a year by the weekly magazine National Journal.

title: KEY RATES
2 British Firms in Setbacks
description: Losses in their securities businesses left Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. with an overall loss in 1988 and Kleinwort Benson Group P.L.C. with lower earnings for the year, the British banking companies said today. Both companies expressed confidence in the outlook for 1989.

title: Industry Is Doing Better, But Prospects Are Grim
description: The scorecard for the nuclear power industry since Three Mile Island shows strong growth and the seeds of extinction.

title:
Campaign Matters;
Get No Respect? Try Hiring A Media Trainer
description: LEAD: Richard Ravitch, the builder, lawyer and former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, slouched to the lectern in his empty East Side apartment. He was dressed in a sweater and blue jeans. The shades were pulled and the blinds drawn, and it was a good thing too, as he launched into a reading of a standard speech in his campaign for mayor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Growth Strategy Falters
description: Management missteps and a lack of attention to shareholders are behind the dramatic reversal in the fortunes of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's largest advertising agency and a company that only three years ago was being hailed for its strategic brilliance.

title: Canada Banks Lift Rates
description: Canadian banks, feeling the crunch of higher borrowing costs, pushed up their prime lending rates today to 13.5 percent, the highest in nearly five years. The three-quarter-point rise was the biggest increase since Feb. 14, 1986. The five leading Canadian banks took the action only minutes after the central bank, the Bank of Canada, said at a weekly rate announcement that its key lending rate had risen to 12.40 percent from 12.18 percent. In the last 12 months, commercial banks have raised their prime rates seven times, for a total rise of 3.75 percentage points. The Bank of Canada has been tightening credit aggressively for a year to try to tame what it perceives as a potentially dangerous inflation trend.

title: Merrill Lynch Sells Notes For Third Time in a Week
description: For the third time in the last week, Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday tapped the corporate bond market with a short-term debt issue.

title: First Amendment Isn't on Father Curran's Side; What Is Not Compelled
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Ad Unit Set By Paramount
description: Seeking to capitalize on the rising cost of commercial production, Paramount Pictures said yesterday that it had started a division to produce television advertising. The division, called Paramount Images, is the first advertising production unit ever established by a movie studio.

title: Review/Music; Heinz Holliger and Winds, With Mozart
description: Heinz Holliger, the renowned Swiss oboist, has assembled a wind octet consisting of himself and seven topnotch Americans, which he is presenting in two venturesome programs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. If Monday's first installment is any guide - and it certainly should be - this coming Monday's concert should be well worth attending.

title: Doubleday Club Chief
description: Bertelsmann A.G. said yesterday that Gerhard Greiner, who has been with the West German publishing and book club company for 22 years, will become chairman and chief executive of the Doubleday Book and Music Clubs Inc., effective May 1. The clubs include the Literary Guild, one of the two largest book clubs in the United States. Mr. Greiner served most recently as club division area manager for Southern Europe and Latin America. Robert Riger, an eight-year veteran of the Book-of-the-Month Club, the other of the two biggest American book clubs, will become the president of the Doubleday Book and Music Clubs. Peter von Puttkamer, the current president and chief executive, will return to club headquarters in Gutersloh, West Germany.

title: Semi-Tech Is Winner: $38 a Share for SSMC
description: The two-month takeover battle for control of SSMC Inc., the old Singer Sewing Machine Company, ended today with the announcement of a sweetened offer of $38 a share, or $206 million, by Semi-Tech Microelectronics Far East Ltd., an electronics company based in Hong Kong.

title: Queries on Benefit Checks' Handlers Urged
description: The chairman of a Congressional committee urged the Social Security Administration today to be sure people who are appointed to handle benefit checks for 4.7 million incompetent beneficiaries do not have criminal records.

title: Review/Television; Pilot News Program for Schools
description: When the commercials came on, there was a flurry of chatter in the room. Nothing astounding in that - television commercials have long since become occasions for chatting, snacking and letting out the cat. But this audience was made up of students at Samuel C. Mumford High School here, and the 12-minute news program they were watching had stirred controversy mainly because of the inclusion of four 30-second commercials.

title: 'Big Ticket' Orders Down For 2d Month
description: In another sign of a slowing economy, orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods declined in February for the second straight month.

title: Missouri's Daly Passes Big Tests
description: The small groups of reporters who stay hot on his trail after a game have become a familiar sight. Rich Daly would have to cut short this particular interview, however, because there was a radio show to do. He also wondered aloud about where his pilots were, the ones flying the Missouri Tigers from Dallas to Columbia, Mo., on a charter last Sunday. They were probably at the airport waiting, a slightly hassled Daly decided.

title: Ailey Foundation Chief
description: Harold Levine has been named chairman of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation. Mr. Levine, the chairman of the executive committee of the advertising firm of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, replaces Stanley Plesent, who was chairman of the Ailey Foundation for 16 years.

title: Motherhood Wins Out in Battle With Army
description: The Army has reversed itself and agreed to discharge a soldier who sued to get out of the military so that she could stay with her 6-month-old daughter instead of reporting to South Korea.

title: University Patents reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Q&A
description: A Noisy Floor Q.About two years ago a new kitchen floor was installed in my apartment. Two layers of old tile and one layer of linoleum were removed, down to the original subfloor. Plywood was then stapled down, and new linoleum was glued down over this. Several weeks later crackling noises were heard in many areas when the floor was walked on.

title: Review/Film; The Lush Life, in 'Troop Beverly Hills'
description: ''Troop Beverly Hills'' is a one-idea movie, and the idea isn't new. But it isn't threadbare either, thanks to the indefatigable pluck of Shelley Long, who plays a spiritual sister to Private Benjamin. Once again a spoiled, princessy character is forced to rough it, in this case as the troop leader commanding a group of equally spoiled little scouts. Once again the sad thing is that a person like this, after an initial spell of wonderfully outrageous behavior, is expected to grow up and change her ways.

title: McClain Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AIDS IN NEW YORK TO COST $7 BILLION
description: New York City's official AIDS planning agency projected last night that the epidemic in the city will cost at least $7.2 billion in the next five years for outpatient care, hospitals, nursing homes, home care and housing. Until now, city and state health officials have skirted the issue of AIDS costs.

title: In London, a New 'Hamlet' Opens to Mixed Reviews
description: An eagerly awaited new production of Shakespeare's ''Hamlet'' with Daniel Day-Lewis in the title role at the National Theater has drawn mixed reviews.

title: Digital Stock Plummets on Glum Outlook
description: In the latest sign of a slowdown in the computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter profits would fall below Wall Street's expectations.

title: Miami, League's Worst Team, Stuns Knicks
description: With 7 minutes 22 seconds remaining in the second period tonight, Grant Long scored on a driving dunk that gave the Miami Heat a 39-38 lead over the Knicks.

title: High-Definition TV Hearings
description: The chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology said today that he planned to push for $100 million in next year's budget to assist the nation's development of high-definition television. The committee chairman, Robert A. Roe, Democrat of New Jersey, made his remarks after the panel heard four hours of testimony by government and industry representatives on the importance of the new technology, known as HDTV, which analysts say will have wide applications in personal computers, semiconductors and telecommunications. These experts are concerned that Japan is far ahead in developing the technology.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
INSIDE
description: Water Emergency Declared

title: Contrasting Styles on a Collision Course in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Shortly after Arkansas defeated Loyola Marymount, 120-101, last week in a wild first-round tournament game, Coach Nolan Richardson of Arkansas disagreed with someone who suggested that Marymount's wide-open style of play was simply a sideshow destined to be a footnote in National Collegiate Athletic Association history.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Flirt Is on the Loose, Rooting for the Home Team
description: The Equity Library Theater's revival of the 1917 musical ''Leave It to Jane'' opens with a bang, as cheerleaders and athletes parade through the aisles drumming up support for the football team of the fictional Atwater College.

title: In Shift, Suspect Testifies in Officer's Killing
description: Two of the four men charged with murdering a New York City police officer in Queens testified yesterday that they were at the scene of the slaying but insisted that they did not know an officer was to be killed until a confederate fired the shots.

title: A Dream Come True: Growing Up to Direct Plays
description: ''I had this picture of what it would be like to be a grown-up theater director,'' said Michael Engler, the grown-up theater director. ''Well, my life is like that now - doing an interesting variety of pieces in an interesting variety of places. It makes me giddy sometimes to realize that I am really, at last, able to make my living at it.''

title: Critic's Notebook; The Rockers Discover Broadway
description: No wonder the ushers looked nervous. The crowds trooping in to Broadway's St. James and Lunt-Fontanne theaters wore black leather and jeans, and there wasn't a blue-haired head to be seen. Half the crowd showed up late; by the end of each performance, people were on their feet and headed for the stage. The productions, which sold out almost instantly, were rock concerts: Joan Jett and the Blackhearts for five nights at the Lunt-Fontanne, and Lou Reed through this Saturday at the St. James. Unvarnished, guitar-driven rock-and-roll has made it on the Great White Way.

title: Ruling Pushes Charter Commission Into Spotlight
description: Confronted with a United States Supreme Court ruling yesterday that the Board of Estimate is unconstitutional, New York City could well have little more than seven months to overhaul its government.

title: Koch Backs Pilot Plan to Aid the Mentally Ill
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch will urge the State Legislature today to approve a pilot program to ease overcrowding in psychiatric emergency rooms in New York City by committing some patients to a regimen of outpatient care. The program is also intended to improve supervision of potentially dangerous mentally ill patients.

title: Reviews/Dance; Sampling the Wares of Several Troupes, in Annual Series
description: A sense of adventure is not out of place in the Morningside Dance Festival; the first program on Tuesday night featured seven choreographers from the city and out of town.

title: Federal Judge Dismissed Suit By 3 Students at Dartmouth
description: A Federal judge on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit that had been filed by three white students who claimed Dartmouth College violated their civil rights by suspending them after an angry encounter with a black professor.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A HAND plane is an essential woodworking tool and an important item in any home-repair tool kit. With a plane, the fit of doors and cabinet parts that have warped can be restored, lumber can be flattened and shaped and wood too rough for sanding can be smoothed.

title: Personal Health
description: With recent reports of health hazards in common foods, fear of environmental chemicals is becoming more widespread in society.

title: Joggers' Peril Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Mohasco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,305,000 for the quarter and income of $6,976,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $5,150,000 and $404,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods included $27.9 million pretax for the quarter and $70.2 million pretax for the year in fees and expenses related to the acquisition of Mohasco by MHS Holdings Corp. plus certain accounting adjustments. The 1987 year included an after-tax loss of $13.5 million on the sale of the company's Mexican operation.

title: Justices Bar Disclosure of F.B.I. Criminal Files
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the records of individual criminal histories maintained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation are never subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Review/Dance; King Troupe, In Works On Motion
description: For more than two decades, Kenneth King has been dancing and thinking. He has thought about dance and danced about thought. He danced and thought once again in ''Correlations,'' the new 50-minute work that Kenneth King and his Dancers Company presented Sunday night at the 14th Street Dance Center.

title: Cooper Life Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $51,000. c-Included a loss of $2,828,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $2,216,000 on the sale of operations.

title: Hughes Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Defender of System Now Changing It
description: Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., chairman of the panel charged with drawing up a new form of government for New York City, has been on both sides of the argument decided yesterday by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Hit at a Home Show Is Great Outdoors
description: LEAD: In what may be the next phase of a movement that goes back to Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' manufacturers are realizing that a good environmental record is an important marketing tool.

title: Canseco Examination
description: Jose Canseco is scheduled to fly to San Francisco today to have his sore left wrist examined and tested by Oakland team physicians, the Athletics said yesterday.

title: Atop Gramercy, A Tribute to Women
description: A PORTRAIT by Alice Neel hangs over the hand-painted sofa; a headless, classically draped figure stands majestically in front of an antique tailor's mirror; the piano doubles as a dining table and a 28-foot piece of neon squiggles across the ceiling.

title: Estimate Board Upset By an Underdog Battler
description: The notion that New York City's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional first came to Richard D. Emery eight years ago as he and a colleague at the New York Civil Liberties Union were driving to the summer home they shared on Long Island.

title: Big Colombian Cocaine Ring Is Target of U.S. Indictment
description: Four reputed leaders of the Colombian cocaine trade and a close associate of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling of the Bahamas were among 30 people indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of taking part in an operation that smuggled more than $1 billion in cocaine into the United States.

title: The Right Way to Rule New York
description: There was no surprise but plenty of electricity in yesterday's unanimous Supreme Court decision that New York City's Board of Estimate cannot survive as now constituted. The handwriting has been on the wall for years: this unique, antique and powerful governmental body violates the rule of one person one vote.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mitchell Energy & Developent Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $20,594,000 from an accounting change. The company said results for the year included a $15.6 million charge from litigation, $9.8 million in writedowns of certain assets and $5.1 million in tax refunds.

title: Bush Names Candidate To Head Museum Unit
description: President Bush announced Tuesday that he would nominate Daphne Wood Murray, development director of the Houston Museum of Natural Science, as director of the Federal Institute of Museum Services. Mrs. Murray's appointment must be confirmed by the Senate before she succeeds Lois Burke Shepard, who offered her resignation to the President after his inauguration.

title: Sports, Scholars and Dollars
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey proposes legislation to require colleges and universities to make public the graduation rates of their student-athletes. The modest bill could do much good.

title: Fund Yields Go Up Again
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were up again for the week that ended yesterday.

title: National Patent Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,398,000 for the quarter and $4,148,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $1,123,000 and $4,270,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $39,819,000 for the quarter and $45,685,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $11,925,000 and $12,150,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Lesco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Comprehensive Care Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a net gain on the sale of the company's care unit of Dupage facility of about $500,000, or 5 cents a share. The company said that as a result of disappointing collections in the latest quarter, it adjusted its allowance for doubtful accounts in primarily three facilities. It said the effect of these adjustments was to reduce the latest quarter's pretax earnings by about $1,100,000.

title: Honduras, Shifting to U.S. Stand, Won't Evict Contras From Bases
description: Five weeks after signing a regional accord that calls for dismantling contra bases in Honduras, the Honduran Government appears to have accepted the American request that the guerrillas be allowed to remain for the foreseeable future.

title: Westin Hotels Names Chairman's Wife Chief
description: Westin Hotels and Resorts, a chain of 65 luxury hotels, yesterday named Chieko N. Aoki chief executive and deputy chairwoman.

title: F.A.A. Tells Airlines Of Threat, Paper Says
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has warned airlines in Europe of a possible hijacking threat this weekend, according to a report in The Daily Express in London.

title: A Preview Of Life In 2020
description: A GROUP of famous futurists descended on the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, last week. The conclave was a sneak preview of a three-day event called ''Envisioning the Future: IFEx89,'' which is tobebeelelththe e y y 9-11.

title: Jersey Candidate Pins Hopes on Drug Issue
description: W. Cary Edwards, the former Attorney General, is running for governor on a precarious platform: as the man who led New Jersey's drive against illegal drugs.

title: Urban Camping, Amid the Dinosaurs
description: IT is 10:30 on a Saturday night. The American Museum of Natural History is closed to the public. But armed with flashlights, a group of brave young girls prowl the darkened halls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an obituary on Tuesday about William R. Olander, senior curator at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York City, omitted the name of his longtime companion. He is Christopher Cox.

title: First Amendment Isn't on Father Curran's Side; Defenders of the Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Bond Sale Totals $115 Million
description: In the municipal bond market, Illinois sold $115 million in tax-exempt bonds with very short maturities. The maturities for the serial bonds range from 1990 to 1993.

title: Unions Included on Eastern Air Creditors' Panel
description: A committee of Eastern Airlines' creditors was appointed yesterday in Federal bankruptcy court. Unions representing the airline's pilots and machinists won a prominent position among the creditors.

title: J2 Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Terrano Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Housing; Bush Team Is No Boon To Real Estate Agents
description: With the election of George Bush as President, real estate brokers in the capital envisioned a flood of new political appointees intent on buying expensive houses.

title: Rights Panel Chairman Says He Will Not Resig
description: William Barclay Allen said today that he had no intention of resigning as chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission and lashed back at the White House for suggesting he should.

title: Swiss Curb On Nabisco
description: A Swiss civil court has ordered RJR Nabisco Inc. to deposit money in Switzerland before it sells any assets so that the rights of Swiss bondholders are protected.

title: An Appeal of Decision In the Cheever Case
description: Academy Chicago Publishers, a small independent publishing house that sued Mary Cheever, John Cheever's widow, over a planned collection of the author's short stories, has appealed an Illinois court decision that Mrs. Cheever had complied with a court order by providing 15 unpublished stories for the collection.

title: Finding Lost Pets
description: To The Home Section:

title: Homeless: A Product of Policy
description: LEAD: Homelessness has captured the attention of policy makers and citizens across the nation. But the politics of compassion has focused attention on the homeless themselves and not on the causes of their plight.

title: North's Ex-Secretary Tells of Altering Memos
description: Oliver L. North's former secretary, saying her action at the time was ''very stupid,'' today relived the panicky days at the White House in November 1986 when she carried secret documents out under her clothing, altered compromising memorandums and shredded classified papers in a frantic effort to protect her boss.

title: Arkansas, Too, Has Plenty to Boast About
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Board of Estimate Ruling: The Voting Power 'Is Debased'
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of Associate Justice Byron R. White today as the Supreme Court declared the structure of the New York City Board of Estimate unconstitutional. FROM THE OPINION By Justice White

title: Prosecutors Are Faulted In Dallas Murder Case
description: Randall Dale Adams sat in the friendly spotlight of dozens of television cameras here today, talking of the 12 1/2 years he spent in prison for a murder to which another man has all but confessed.

title: Stuart Hall reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HEALTH: Cardiology; Doctors Split Over Best Way to Treat Heart Attack Victims
description: American cardiologists are embroiled in a major disagreement about how to best treat heart attacks, particularly in people under the age of 75 who have not had previous heart trouble.

title: No. 1 Arizona Upset On 3-Pointer at :002
description: When Anderson Hunt was a high school star in Detroit, his coaches always used to say there was something special about the skinny kid with the svelt shooting touch.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Palm Court on Sunday

title: People
description: * D. Daniel Michel Jr., former executive vice president of BBDO, Los Angeles, has joined Tracy-Locke, Los Angeles, as general manager.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CULTURAL RELATIONS

title: Canstar Sports Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $1.3 million. c-Net loss and included a $5.5 million charge. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Metro Datelines; Lawyers End Cases In Slaying of Byrne
description: After calling almost 50 witnesses, prosecution and defense lawyers yesterday ended their cases in the trial of three men accused of the murder of a police officer in Queens.

title: Keene Resigns L.I. Philharmonic Post
description: Christopher Keene, who formally assumed the general directorship of the New York City Opera on March 15, has resigned as music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, the orchestra announced Wednesday. He will continue in that post until the end of his current contract, through the 1989-90 season.

title: West Bank Palestinian Youth Is Killed by Israeli Soldiers
description: A 14-year-old Palestinian was shot to death and eight other teen-agers were wounded today in clashes between stone-throwing demonstrators and Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories, Palestinians said.

title: NOTEBOOK: Horse Racing; Houston Remains A Mystery
description: Houston to date has seemed more like a top-secret weapon than a race horse: rarely glimpsed, highly controversial, and developed under a virtual cloak of darkness.

title: Jets Sign Linebacker
description: The Jets, who are seeking help at outside linebacker, yesterday signed Jackie Walker, a new free agent, to bolster that position. The 6-foot-5-inch, 255-pound Walker was the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' second-round draft choice in 1986 and played three seasons for them. On Feb. 1, the Bucs left him unprotected, which meant he could sign with any other National Football League team by April 1. Walker is the fifth such player the Jets have signed.

title: Review/Film Festival; Romantic Summer Break At a Japanese Boys' School
description: It comes as no surprise to learn that all of the earlier films by Shusuke Kaneko, the young Japanese director of ''Summer Vacation: 1999,'' have been soft-core porn. Only a man utterly exhausted by the second-rate pleasures of grunting-and-groaning simulated sex could make a film as chastely, madly romantic as ''Summer Vacation: 1999.''

title: 'I'm Lucky to Be Here,' Injured Goaltender Says
description: Saying ''I'm lucky to be here,'' the Buffalo Sabres goaltender Clint Malarchuk described yesterday how he thought he would die after his neck was severely cut by a player's skate Wednesday night in a 2-1 loss to the St. Louis Blues.

title: B. F. McLaurin, 83, An Ex-Labor Leader And Rights Official
description: Benjamin F. McLaurin, a longtime labor leader who helped organize sleeping-car porters in the 1920's and 1930's, died of cancer Wednesday at the North Central Bronx Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Auctions
description: Selling Ads

title: St. John's Wins by 83-80 To Advance to Semifinals
description: It was not the N.C.A.A. tournament. It was not even the Big East tournament. But there aren't many of Lou Carnesecca's 458 victories that top the one the St. John's coach experienced tonight at Ohio State, when the Redmen beat the Buckeyes, 83-80, in overtime in the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Our Towns; A Child's Cry Goes Unheard: 'Tess Is Dead'
description: Tracey Maye made her monthly visit to Bronx Supreme Court Wednesday. It goes like clockwork now. All players know their parts. They have much practice. Two years ago this week, Ms. Maye killed her baby daughter, Tess; eight months ago, she pleaded guilty. And still the case is not resolved, still the judge asks if a treatment program has been found, still her lawyer answers, ''No, but soon, your honor.'' Then Ms. Maye is free and goes home, to the same Bronx apartment where she killed Baby Tess. The whole thing takes 10 minutes, tops.

title: Where Value Is a Specialty of the House
description: OF all the questions posed to a restaurant critic, the most typical is: ''Can you suggest a really nice place for dinner: good food, a lively ambiance, efficient service, and it shouldn't be too far off in the boondocks? Oh yes, it has to be inexpensive.''

title: Koch and 3 Rivals Spar in the Same Ring
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and three Democratic challengers offered considerably different views of New York City's problems and their proposed solutions last night at a meeting of Queens Democratic leaders. The leaders will play a critical role in the Sept. 12 mayoral primary.

title: Children: Patients, Pupils, People
description: Representatives George Miller and Henry Waxman have just proposed to help poor children the right way: comprehensively. Legislation they introduced this week seeks to insure physical and educational development of all children. The details remain to be evaluated, but the approach is surely welcome.

title: Big Nick Nicholas
description: The saxophonist Big Nick Nicholas leads a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Gold Fields Stock Plunges
description: Shares of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. plummeted yesterday, after a Federal appeals court ruling Wednesday blocking a takeover bid by Minorco for the British mining giant.

title: House, Defying Threat of a Veto, Backs Increase in Minimum Wage
description: The House of Representatives, defying a veto threat by President Bush, today approved legislation to raise the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour from $3.35, the first increase in eight years.

title: And There Are Decent Wines That Aren't Indecently Priced
description: FINDING the perfect little restaurant can be tough; finding one with the perfect little wine list is even tougher. Face it: a small restaurant, almost by definition, has to have a relatively short wine list. A place with 30 tables simply can't afford to tie up capital by buying and holding large stocks of wine: it costs too much, there may not be any place to store it and there probably won't be enough guests to drink it.

title: To Alaska Station, 'Today' Funnyman Is Funny No More
description: One of Willard Scott's off-the-cuff remarks as weatherman of the ''Today Show'' has led the NBC affiliate in Fairbanks to cancel the morning news program, the most popular in the country.

title: Dining Out Guide: New Around Town
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Andiamo!

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Imperial Music

title: International Amco Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $397,000 for the latest year and $1,640,000 for the prior year.

title: Leader of Choice for Polish Radicals
description: As the Solidarity union negotiates Poland's future with the Communist leadership, Solidarity's leaders find their ranks swelled by radical young workers and students who support the union but reject the talks with the Government.

title: Amdahl Names Head Of European Activities
description: The Amdahl Corporation, which makes large computer systems, said yesterday that it had promoted Peter V. Williams to the new position of chairman of European operations.

title: Tokheim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $2,390,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: Economic Scene; Markets Puzzling Over 3 Riddles
description: THREE interconnected riddles are worrying business and the markets: How serious is the inflationary threat? How high will interest rates go? And will rising interest rates produce a recession before the year is over or early next year?

title: Taiwanese Violinist
description: Nai Yuan Hu, the Taiwanese violinist who won the Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels in 1985, is to play Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 12, No. 3), Faure's Sonata in A (Op. 13) and Ysaye's ''Ballade'' Sonata tomorrow evening at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. The program also includes shorter works by Kreisler, Dohnanyi and Sarasate. Patsy Toh is to be Mr. Hu's accompanist. Tickets are $20 to $12. Information: 362-1911.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Today is Good Friday and Sunday is Easter. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. between 44th and 57th Streets on Sunday for the Easter Promenade. Government offices: Open today. Post office: Regular delivery. Banks: Open. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended today. Sanitation: Regular collections. Schools: Spring break. Financial markets: Closed today. Transportation: Subways, buses and Metro-North on regular schedules; Long Island Rail Road is adding extra trains this afternoon. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices open today; state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices open today; state and local offices closed. Post offices: Regular delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular schedule.

title: Colorado Man Kills 2 Women, Then Himself
description: A man on a rampage with a semiautomatic pistol abducted a woman, killed her and her mother-in-law, then raped another woman today before being cornered in a town house, the police said. The gunman then shot two officers and another hostage before fatally shooting himself, they said.

title: Replay for Instant Replay
description: National Football League owners voted today to continue their instant-replay experiment for a fourth straight year, approving a one-year extension by a 24-4 vote.

title: Triton Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $3,278,000 for the quarter and net of $25,387,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations; the year also included a tax loss carryforward of $34,226,000. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $50,464,000 for the quarter and $64,153,000 for the year; an extraordinary credit of $6,621,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $15,025,000 for the year.

title: U.S., Saying It Hopes to End Expulsions, Ousts Soviet Trade Envoy
description: The United States has ordered a Soviet trade official to leave the United States in retaliation for Moscow's expulsion of an American military attache last week.

title: Metro Datelines; Sentencing of Bosket Delayed Until April
description: The sentencing of Willie Bosket was delayed again yesterday after prison officials told the judge they could not assure Mr. Bosket's punctual appearance in court, prosecutors in the case said.

title: Vote Is Latest Survival Test for Turkish Premier
description: A tiny scar on his right thumb is the only reminder of the attempt on his life last June by a poor-shooting would-be assassin. It is a minor nuisance, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal says.

title: Nozzle Linked to Trident Blast
description: A control nozzle that failed to fire caused a Trident 2 missile to pinwheel over the Atlantic before it exploded in a test launching on Wednesday, the Pentagon's chief spokesman said today.

title: Midwest; Regional With Final Four Appeal
description: The four high-powered teams competing for one coveted berth in the Midwest Region might not make a bad Final Four.

title: House Roll-Call Vote Approving Rise in the Minimum Wage
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 171 by which the House or Representatives today approved an increase in the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour by October 1991. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 226 Democrats and 22 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 24 Democrats and 147 Republicans. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote. X denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were ''present'' at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, Y; Erdreich, Y; Flippo, Y; Harris, Y. Republicans - Callahan, N; Dickinson, N. ALASKA Republican - Young, Y. ARIZONA Democrat - Udall, Y. Republicans - Kolbe, N; Kyl, N; Rhodes, N; Stump, N. ARKANSAS Democrats - Alexander, Y; Anthony, Y; Robinson, Y. Republican - Hammerschmidt, N. CALIFORNIA Democrats - Anderson, Y; Bates, Y; Beilenson, Y; Berman, Y; Bosco, Y; Boxer, Y; Brown, Y; Coelho, Y; Dellums, Y; Dixon, Y; Dymally, Y; Edwards, Y; Fazio, Y; Hawkins, Y; Lantos, Y; Lehman, Y; Levine, Y; Martinez, Y; Matsui, Y; Miller, Y; Mineta, Y; Panetta, Y; Pelosi, Y; Roybal, Y; Stark, Y; Torres, Y; Waxman, X. title: Milton Frome Is Dead; TV Straight Man, 78
description: Milton Frome, a comic actor who appeared in more than 50 movies and was Milton Berle's straight man on television, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 78 years old. Mr. Frome, whose career began in vaudeville and burlesque, was a regular on the Berle show during the 1950's and played an autocratic studio boss on ''The Beverly Hillbillies'' from 1964 to 1967.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American City Business Journals Inc., Kansas City, Mo., said its board had rejected a $15-a-share offer made last month by TA Associates Communications.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: 'Batman' and More

title: In Brussels, a 'Gucci Gulch'
description: LEAD: The dream of a Europe without frontiers has inspired, among other things, a lobbying industry second only to Washington's Gucci Gulch and growing fast.

title: G.N.P. Revised Upward to 2.4% Rate
description: The economy expanded at a moderate 2.4 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1988, compared with an initial estimate of 2 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Potomac Electric Power reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Earth Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
Abboud Said To Pursue Mcorp Banks
description: Less than a year after entering the morass of Texas financial institutions, A. Robert Abboud is apparently bidding to create the largest banking company in the state.

title: Sudanese Factions Agree to Allow Relief Agencies Into Famine Area
description: The Sudanese Government and the nation's southern rebels have agreed to allow the United Nations and international relief agencies to take more than 100,000 metric tons of food to the south of the country in April to avert famine, United Nations officials said today.

title: Review/Film; 'Glass Cage': Torture, Murder And Revenge
description: ''In a Glass Cage,'' an elegant, unsettling first feature by the young Spanish writer and director Agustin Villaronga, is a revenge fantasy of the most icy viciousness.

title: Review/Music; Of the Romantic Viennese
description: The Con Brio Ensemble called its Tuesday evening program at Weill Recital Hall ''Vienna Retrospective 1888-1910.'' Those 22 years edged toward a time of ferment in the Viennese compositional world, and the changes wrought eventually affected the course of the Western musical tradition.

title: Phone Rates Cut by F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission has ordered the nation's local telephone companies to reduce their interstate access charges by $705 million, which will require the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to cut its long-distance rates again.

title: Tearful North Secretary Backs Ex-Chief
description: Angry, racked by sobs, Fawn Hall testified today that she had ''never met a man who worked harder for his country'' than Oliver L. North.

title: Can Collection Drive
description: The City of New York Parks and Recreation Department and We Can, New York City's can redemption center for the homeless, are joining to support homeless New Yorkers. Containers - cans and deposit bottles -will be collected at 72d Street and Central Park West tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. The profits will be shared by We Can and the Parks Department's Homeless Youth Recreation Program. At other times, containers may be brought to We Can, at 450 West 43d Street, from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 262-2222.

title: Nissan Sees Higher Profit
description: The Nissan Motor Company told securities analysts today in New York that it expects a strong increase in its operating profit for the fiscal year that ends next Friday.

title: John Wallace, 82, Chemist and Executive
description: John H. Wallace, a chemical company executive and former director of the James Forrestal Research Center at Princeton University, died Wednesday at his home in Princeton after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Memorial Exchange
description: On March 15, it was reported in this column that John Wheeler, chairman of the Center for the Vietnam Generation and a leader in the building of the Vietnam Memorial, was searching for a Russian named Mikhail. The Russian was said to have erected a small memorial in Moscow to the 15,000 Soviet soldiers killed in Afghanistan.

title: Southeast; Michigan's Fervor Thwarts Tar Heels
description: This was not the same team he had watched on tape, Dean Smith said. This was not the same team that has been whipped by Smith's North Carolina Tar Heels two years in a row in post-season play. Many of the names are the same, but the Michigan Wolverines are playing with a sense of renewed purpose that makes videotapes and scouting reports irrelevant.

title: Market Place; Holly Farms Holders Await Conagra-Tyson Winner
description: Take the money and run can be a fine strategy in choosing between competing takeover offers. Shareholders in the Holly Farms Corporation, the nation's third-largest poultry producer, only wish they could do so.

title: U.S. Voices Dismay on Release of Hijacking Warning
description: Bush Administration officials today expressed distress at the disclosure of a hijacking warning to American airlines in Europe. The episode again raised the issue of public access to security information.

title: Why New York City Wants to Close Cable TV's Tax Loophole
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Protocol Photo
description: President Ronald Reagan is history, but his smiling visage still greets visitors at many American embassies around the world.

title: Stewart Gets Go-Ahead
description: Norm Stewart, the Missouri basketball coach, shows no sign of any residual tumor or cancer, and can resume coaching next year if his condition continues to improve, his doctor said Wednesday.

title: Addenda
description: * BBDM Advertising said it would now use as its title Bender, Browning, Dolby & Sanderson.

title: New System to Deliver TV Spots by Satellite
description: If the growth of the ''unwired network'' has challenged the traditional networks in the race for advertisers, a new satellite delivery system for ads will turn up the heat another notch. The system beams TV spots from advertising agencies to hundreds of stations around the country, just minutes after a media purchase is made.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hollywood 'Imperialism'
description: Vigilant against what he called ''imperialism,'' Representative Lawrence J. Smith, a Florida Democrat, took the House floor Tuesday afternoon to defend the name and the rights of his hometown. ''My colleagues,'' he declared, ''heed my words. If Hollywood, Fla., falls, one of your cities may be next.''

title: Review/Film; A Cheyenne Mystic Who Transmutes Bitterness
description: The scene-stealing figure in ''Powwow Highway,'' a road movie populated by Cheyenne Indian characters in the vicinity of Lame Deer, Mont., is a sweetly mystical giant named Philbert Bono (Gary Farmer). Philbert is notable for his tremendous appetite, his unflappably even keel, and his determination to find some kind of spiritual core in contemporary American Indian life. When Philbert sees a salesman on television wearing a headdress to hawk used cars (offering ''heap big savings''), he is too serene to take offense. Instead, he buys a car from this man and decides to think of it as a war pony.

title: Review/Art; An Artist Animates Her Life and Her Time
description: The exhibition of paintings and drawings by Sonia Delaunay at the Barbara Mathes Gallery is not large. But if you are looking for a show that brings the Easter bunny to mind, with his dancing tread and his air of all-weather alertness, this is it.

title: Arthur Aviles's Life in Dance: Nonstop Exhilaration
description: Arthur Aviles is so exuberant and full of energy, even seated, as he talks about his life in dance, that he seems about to take off like some highly charged small rocket. It is in part that energy that has made Mr. Aviles stand out this season with Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and Company, which is performing at the Joyce Theater through Sunday.

title: U.S. Officials See Greater Staying Power in Afghan Regime
description: The continued supply of Soviet military equipment to the Afghan Government and the difficulty encountered by the guerrillas in taking the city of Jalalabad have led Bush Administration officials to reassess their optimism that the Government will fall soon.

title: Black in Taped Scuffle Wins Dismissal of Case
description: At the prosecutors' request, a municipal judge has dismissed a charge of resisting arrest against a black man who says he was roughed up by a white police officer in a confrontation that was secretly recorded on videotape.

title: Gannett Sells Paper
description: The Gannett Company has sold the Sturgis Journal to Hometown Com-munications Inc. of Little Rock, Ark., for an undisclosed price, the newspa-per said today, The Journal, founded in 1859 and owned by Gannett since 1980, has a daily circulation of about 8,500. Gannett, based in Washington, publishes 86 daily newspaper.

title: Democrats in House Warn Bush Against G.O.P. Partisan Warfare
description: House Democratic leaders sent the Bush Administration some warning signals today, saying that bipartisan cooperation between Congress and the White House could be jeopardized if other Republicans are fanning partisan warfare.

title: Republic American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $3,646,000 for the quarter and $3,760,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $47,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $17,000 for the year.

title: Budget Rent A Car Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter included a charge of about $3.5 million after-tax in connection with amended employment arrangements with the company's former chairman. Prior-period results are pro forma; the company's initial public offering was in May 1987.

title: Albany Remains Divided Over a Budget Solution
description: A week before the state's budget deadline, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders remained deeply divided today over how much money New York can afford to spend in a year when it is facing its worst financial problems since the mid-1970's.

title: Here Comes the Columbus Dollar, Gold-Color Son of Susan B.
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear Is Target in This War on Crime
description: For decades, the police believed that fear of crime, a powerful social and political force capable of shaping the daily lives and voting patterns of millions, was inextricably tied to the facts of crime. The best way to combat public fears, they reasoned, was simply to fight crime itself. Now, they're not so sure. Here in the 610 square miles of suburbs and countryside where 680,000 people live in a horseshoe-shaped county almost surrounding Baltimore, the Baltimore County Police Department has assigned about four dozen of its 1,545 officers to fight citizens' fear of crime. It is a nontraditional program that has officers checking street lights, prodding action from landlords and government, squelching rumors and going door to door to ask puzzled residents, ''So, how's everything going?'' Going Beyond 911

title: Varity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
