description: b-After special gains of $4.7 million for the quarter and $28.5 million for the year. c-After special charges of $42.4 million for the quarter and $46.1 million for the year; the quarter also included a tax credit of $13.6 million. There were no share earnings in the prior year after preferred share dividends.

title: 100 Vaccinations for Measles
description: Nearly 100 Clark University students have been vaccinated against measles since a case of the viral disease was confirmed at the school this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about gun manufacturing in Connecticut misstated the location of the Charter Arms Corporation. It is in Stratford, not Bridgeport.

title: Cooper Buys 83.2% Stake in Champion
description: Cooper Industries has acquired 83.2 percent of the Champion Spark Plug Company under a merger agreement. Cooper, based in Houston, bought the shares for $21 each. After the merger, the common shares not acquired in the original cash tender offer will be exchanged for $21 each in cash, a Cooper spokeswoman said.

title: Private East Berlin Shops
description: More than 40 percent of the stores in East Berlin are privately owned or operated, but the shops account for only 9 percent of the city's retail trade volume, the official East German press agency said today. The city's 1,731 private shops and hundreds of itinerant traders sold goods worth 1.1 billion marks ($590 million) in 1987, up from 876 million marks ($470 million) in 1980.

title: Ameron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Judge Sets Court Date in 2 States' Tax War
description: A Federal judge yesterday gave two states a day in court over a New York tax law that raises the levy on some New Jersey commuters.

title: Development Changes Urged for West Side
description: To preserve the character of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a special planning committee recommended yesterday that builders of luxury towers be required to provide low-income housing and that a zoning device used to create extra-large buildings be curtailed.

title: Here Comes the Columbus Dollar, Gold-Color Son of Susan B.; Bring Back $2 Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Concert; Japanese Flute and Percussion Instruments
description: Michiko Akao, a player of the yokobue, or Japanese bamboo flute, and Nachiko Maekane, a percussionist, collaborated on a lively recital of contemporary and traditional music Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society.

title: Rangers Still Hurting
description: Coach Michel Bergeron of the Rangers said yesterday that three injured defensemen, James Patrick, Brian Leetch and Mark Hardy, would all miss the games this weekend against the Flyers and Penguins. But Bergeron said he was optimistic that they could return next week for a game in Detroit.

title: Suzuki Agrees to Warnings On Samurai Ads in 7 States
description: LEAD: Settling complaints from seven states that its advertisements for the Samurai utility vehicle were deceptive, the American Suzuki Motor Corporation said yesterday that future advertisements would include warnings that drivers should avoid sharp turns and abrupt maneuvers.

title: Examiner to Get Job of Reviving Eastern Airlines
description: The Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the Eastern Airlines case has ordered the appointment of a powerful examiner with a broad mandate to end the 20-day-old strike at the airline quickly and get all of Eastern's planes back in the air.

title: Canticum Novum
description: Harold Rosenbaum is to conduct the Canticum Novum Singers in an all-Bach program at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow at 8 P.M. The Cantatas No. 4 and No. 106, the Motet ''Komm, Jesu, Komm'' and the Orchestral Suite No. 2 in B minor are on the program. Tickets are $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: Forests Are Still Vanishing
description: The Eastern region of the United States once was covered with dense forests. Westward to about the 95th meridian, beyond the Mississippi River, mighty trees covered the land, save in what are now Illinois and Iowa.

title: Metro Datelines; Firefighter and 2 Men Held in Drug Raid
description: Three men, including a suspended firefighter, were arrested yesterday by narcotics detectives in a raid on an apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Harding Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $315,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: 24-Hour Trading Is Planned
description: In a major step toward round-the-clock electronic trading of securities, Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and its Instinet subsidiary have joined with the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange to plan a network for trading options and stocks, they announced today.

title: Jewish Music
description: The Mizmorim Ethnic Music Ensemble, an Israeli folk-music group, is to play Jewish music from Morocco, Tunisia, Yemen and Iran on Middle Eastern instruments, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. The ensemble, which is directed by Avi Eilam-Amzallag, is to perform at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, on Sunday evening at 7. Tickets for Symphony Space are $20 to $12. Information: 864-5400. Tickets for Merkin Hall are $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: Pete Rozelle: Integrity's Clean Hands
description: rrAt their 1960 meeting in Miami to choose a commissioner to succeed the late Bert Bell, the National Football League owners had disagreed for more than a week. But now a compromise candidate, Alvin (Pete) Rozelle, the 33-year-old general manager of the Los Angeles Rams, was asked to leave the meeting while the owners discussed him. To avoid reporters in the hotel hall, he retreated to a men's room. Whenever someone entered, he washed his hands. Finally, he was summoned by the owners, who had elected him.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 461 money market mutual funds increased by $2.8 billion, to $299.4 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 139 institutional funds increased by $449.1 million, to $72.97 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $1.3 billion, to $97.42 billion. The 94 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.08 billion, to $129.05 billion, the institute said.

title: The Wages of Law
description: In the law, achievements often has little relation to financial reward; novices can earn more than the Chief Justice fo the United States. This sampler of lawyers' 1988 earnings is distilled from a survey in the March 27 issue of The National Law Journal. Academics Median salaries of deans at 166 A.B.A.-approved law schools ... $105,000 Median salaries of professors at 171 A.B.A.-approved law schools ... $61,000 Dean of the University of Texas School of Law ... $150,000 Government Attorneys Department of Justice Attorney General ... $99,500 Entry-level Environmental jProtection Agency lawyer $28,852 Newark corporation counsel ... $64,961 Judges Chief Justice of the United States ... $115,000 United States District Court judges ... $89,500 New York Chief Justice ... $120,000 West Virginia Associate Justice ... $55,000 Prosecutors District Attorneys (Black Hawk County, Iowa) ... $20,904-46,902 U.S. Attorneys ... $78,500 Public Interest Lawyers Entry-level American Civil Liberties Union (New York) ... $28,000 Center for Constitutional Rights (New York) Top salary ... $37,500 In-House Counsel Executive vice president and general counsel, Ryder System (Miami) ... $381,887 Law Firm Partners (averages) Davis, Wright & Jones (Seattle) ... $121,360 Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom (New York) ... $1,100,000 Sole practitioners. ... $73,765 Law Firm Associate Mayer, Brown & Platt (Chicago) First year ... $65,000 Willkie Farr & Gallagher (New York) First Year ... $82,000 Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy (New York) Seventh year ... $168,000 Legal Services, Defender Offices Legal Services of North Central Alabama, Huntsvill, Ala. ... $15,208-37,187 Public defender (Columbus, Ohio) ... $18,150-70,225

title: For Children; Shows, Nature, Museums
description: ''CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS,'' a show by Puppetworks, with music of Saint-Saens and others, noon on Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Park Avenue, Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. WINNIE'S WONDERETTES, a puppet show at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. today at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''ARLECCHINO'S HEART OF GOLD,'' a play with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show with audience participation, presented by Brian McGovern and Imam, at 2 P.M. Saturdays at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a play about a shy dragon in Central Park and a funny zoo keeper, written by Miranda McDermott and performed by child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. Saturdays at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations: 734-5195. ''THE THREE LITTLE PIGS,'' presented by the Little People's Theater Company, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, and ''Humpty Dumpty Falls in Love,'' 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 765-9540. ''IT'S TOUGH TO MAKE A NICKEL,'' a 40-minute living-history play about immigrant children living in tenements on the Lower East Side, 1 P.M. Sundays at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street. Tickets: children, $5; students and the elderly, $6; others, $7. Reservations: 431-0233. ''IT'S NEWS TO ME,'' an exhibition about news and the media, with information about editing, transmitting and other hands-on activities, at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The museum is open 1 to 4 P.M. Wednesdays to Fridays and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and most school holidays. Tickets: $2. Information: (718) 273-2060.

title: East; Aches, Pains for N.C.A.A. Teams
description: Now that the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament has begun to separate the contenders from the pretenders, the remaining teams have discovered that their concerns extend beyond their opponents.

title: West; Seton Hall Surprises Indiana By 78-65
description: Seton Hall nudged its way to one victory from the Final Four with a 78-65 triumph over Indiana tonight in the West Regional semifinals at McNichols Arena. Let's make that bullied its way there. Seton Hall used old-fashioned, elbow-to-elbow, sweat-till-you-drop defense that made the Big Ten champions look out of sync. The Hoosiers, with sticky defense and a motion, screening offense, had won 27 of 34 games this season and were seeded second in the West.

title: With a Sob And Twang, Songwriters From Texas
description: More and more pop songs seem to issue from faraway impersonal factories, shorn of local references and gleaming with precision. Yet the more mechanical pop becomes, the more listeners seek music with a regional character and a human scale - singers with a twang, songs that reveal specifics. Two unabashedly down-home singers, one a longtime honky-tonker and the other finding a national audience after more than a decade of performing, will be in Manhattan this weekend - Joe Ely at the Lone Star Roadhouse tonight and tomorrow and Lucinda Williams at the Bottom Line tomorrow.

title: U.S.-Japan Fighter Deal
description: After meetings between American officials and an envoy from Japan, officials of the two nations said today that both sides were considering their positions on changes the United States is seeking in a pact reached last year to build an advanced fighter plane.

title: MX-Midgetman Battle Turns Toward Compromise
description: A consensus is emerging in the debate over how to modernize the land-based nuclear arsenal, with top military officers urging the new Secretary of Defense to support a compromise that would mix two competing missile programs, Pentagon officials say.

title:
THE LAW;
Space Law: Anticipating Conflict in New Frontier
description: LEAD: When less-than-perfect eyesight ended C. Dennis Ahearn's dream of becoming an astronaut 20 years ago, he vowed to carve out another role in America's space effort. Today the 41-year-old lawyer has found his mission in an emerging field: space law.

title: In Autos, U.S. Makes Strides
description: American auto makers have rung up six years of strong profits, including a record $11.2 billion for 1988. That is a remarkable performance for an industry that not long ago suffered severe losses in the face of competition from abroad. But it would be premature to conclude that Detroit has vanquished its rivals: in many crucial areas, Japanese car makers still set the pace.

title: Southeast; Oklahoma Is Outmuscled by Virginia
description: Stacey King, Oklahoma's all-America center, was held to 2 points in the first half. Mookie Blaylock, the shifty point guard, looked like he had just come from a sparring session with a light heavyweight. His left eye was swollen shut, a red scar traced under it. The Sooners had survived one close call in the national tournament, but Virginia made it clear that it was not going to happen again.

title: Carter and His Knee Face Test
description: The Achilles' heel of the Mets, so to speak, is Gary Carter's right knee. And today, with a week and a half to go to opening day, Carter's knee was swollen.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Belter Grins Through The Tears
description: When Jill Corey resumed performing in cabarets last year after a long absence from New York City clubs, she couldn't have chosen a more appropriate songwriter through whom to focus her torchy sensibility than that master of bluesy laments, Harold Arlen. A year later, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street - where she is giving late- night performances Tuesdays through Thursdays through April 27 - Ms. Corey has turned her gaze to the much sunnier lyrics of Oscar Hammerstein 2d. The Corey-Hammerstein match is not as felicitous as Corey-Arlen.

title: Price Co reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 12
Washington Talk: Briefing; Concorde to Visit
description: The French Government, which is giving the Smithsonian Institution a present of a Concorde jetliner when its days aloft have ended, is giving the prize a fly-in next month. When it arrives April 16, it will carrying some weighty cargo: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen and the French Constitution of 1791. They will be on display at the Smithsonian's Arts and Industries Building from May 3 through some time in October as part of the bicentennial of the event that made them possible, the French Revolution.

title: Turner Ends Board Meeting Without Making FNN Bid
description: The directors of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. adjourned a special meeting today without making a bid to acquire a stake in Financial News Network Inc.

title: On Stage
description: Irwin's Play on No Words

title: U.S. Eases Restraints On Exports to Soviets
description: Responding to pressures from exporters, the Commerce Department announced action today to reduce controls and simplify licensing procedures for computers and medical equipment bound for the Soviet Union.

title: This Time, Let's Have a Latin American Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox's 'Married' Series Mirrors Real Families
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS and NBC Drop MGM/UA Commercial
description: The CBS and ABC networks have dropped an advertisement for an MGM/UA videocassette, saying it generated an avalanche of complaints from viewers. CBS and ABC dropped the advertisement, for a horror film called ''Child's Play,'' on Wednesday, two days after it first appeared on the air.

title: Penn Traffic Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income The latest year loss included a $6,990,000 after-tax writeoff of acquisition costs. The results for the latest year included P&C Foods Inc. since Aug. 6.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD SET IN WASHINGTON ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: Administration officials and Congressional leaders reached tentative agreement today on a bipartisan policy toward Central America, including additional aid for the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

title: Treasury Issues Rise Moderately
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose moderately yesterday in slow pre-holiday trading.

title: Winnebago Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My father tried to help this community and this is what he got for it. He always said God would look out for him. But one person can't carry a whole community. He never got the support he needed. They don't give a damn.'' - Nita Lawrence, whose father was slain in Miami after years of battling drug sales. [ A12:4. ]

title: How the Democrats Can Harness Whites And Blacks in '92
description: The election of Ronald Brown as the first black chairman of the Democratic National Committee has set off a new round of soul-searching. Is the party committing political suicide by becoming strongly identified with the aspirations of black and minority voters? Is America in the 1980's so lost in a new round of racism that whites will desert the Democrats at the slightest hint that blacks might be running things?

title: N.F.L. Is Looking Ahead As Rozelle Looks Back
description: As Pete Rozelle reflected today on his retirement after 29 years of joy and pain as the commissioner of the National Football League, a six-member team was already taking the initial steps in the arduous task of finding a replacement.

title: 'His Last Days'
description: For the fourth year, ''His Last Days,'' a musical based on the Passion of Christ, will be presented at the Metro Baptist Church, 410 West 40th Street, in an Actors' Equity Showcase production. Tonight's performance is at 8:30; tomorrow's and Sunday's at 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Admission is free, but reservations are required. Information and reservations: 594-4464.

title: Arcature to Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day New York yesterday won the account of the Arcature Corporation, a niche marketing concern established earlier this year by two former executives of Backer Spielvogel Bates. The agency will create a series of ads for consumer brands marketed by Arcature. Don Zuckert and Larry Light started the firm in January with the reported $500 million they obtained from the merger of Ted Bates Worldwide with Backer & Spielvogel.

title: Review/Art; Public Art at New Federal Building in Queens
description: The first art completed for a Government building in New York City since Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' in 1981 is a far cry from the confrontational steel sculpture that was removed from Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan last week. The new works are much smaller and gentler than ''Tilted Arc.'' As a group they are both problematical and revealing about issues with which public art continues to struggle.

title: Richie Beirach
description: Richie Beirach, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

title: Tate & Lyle to Buy Stake in Redpath
description: The British sugar refiner Tate & Lyle P.L.C. said it agreed to buy the Canadian Government's 49.9 percent stake in its Redpath Industries Ltd. unit for $240 million. Tate & Lyle owns the remaining 50.1 percent of the Toronto-based Redpath. The deal is worth $17.14 a share, the company said.

title: Either-Orchestra
description: Either-Orchestra, a big band, is to perform Sunday at 9 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $6.

title: Centaur Ends Pennwalt Bid
description: Centaur Partners ended its $110-a-share hostile takeover bid for the Pennwalt Corporation today.

title: If U.S. Bartered Food for Soviet Union's Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Papandreou Ally Says He Took Bribes For the Government
description: The political scandal threatening Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Government widened this week as a former official of the governing Socialist Party has testified that he had accepted and transferred millions of dollars in bribes for the Government.

title: Vegetable Acreage Plans
description: Processors of five important vegetables expect to reach contracts for 1.48 million acres this year, a 10 percent increase from 1988, when production was plagued by drought, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Acreage plans for all five vegetables are up, led by a projected increase of 18 percent for tomatoes. Green peas are expected to be up 12 percent; cucumbers for pickles, 11 percent; snap beans, 7 percent, and sweet corn, 5 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Setback for Afghan Regime

title: Group Opposes Accord In Blacks' Suit of G.M.
description: A group representing several hundred salaried black employees at the General Motors Corporation said today that it would file a petition opposing a proposed $3 million settlement of a lawsuit charging G.M. with discrimination.

title: Senate Votes Tax Increases In Connecticut
description: After several hectic weeks of sorting and discarding tax options to fill a $247 million hole in the current state budget, the State Senate gave final passage today to a patchwork solution that would tap two state accounts and raise taxes on alcohol, cigarettes and corporate profits.

title: Neighbor Is Charged in Murder of 13-Year-Old
description: Robert Golub, an unemployed 21-year-old weightlifter who lives with his parents, was arrested today and charged with the murder of his 13-year-old Valley Stream neighbor, Kelly Tinyes.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 A policy toward Central America, including more aid for the Nicaraguan contras, was tentatively accepted by Bush officials and Congressional leaders. Page A1 The Palestinian diaspora retains a strong attachment to the land and people under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. But these days that relationship has been challenged. A1 Moscow's recent Middle East efforts may be explained by its growing concern that Israel, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Egypt either have or are developing missiles that can hit Soviet territory, experts say. A2 A new hijacking warning to airlines in Europe again raised the issue of public access to security information. Bush Administration officials expressed distress that the warning had been made public. A3 Afghan efforts to defend Jalalabad appeared to have suffered a setback with the disclosure that a bridge between Kabul and Jalalabad had been blown up by guerrillas. A8 The rebel's failure to take a city and the continued supply of Soviet military equipment to the Afghan Government has led Bush Administration officials to reassess their optimism that the Government will fall soon. A8 The confrontation in South Africa between President P. W. Botha and the National Party leader, F. W. de Klerk, which has paralyzed South Africa's governing white party, appears to have been resolved. A3 The operator of a Japanese tanker that collided with an overloaded fishing boat, apparently drowning about 130 Vietnamese refugees, said that three other ships ignored calls to help save the victims. A6 Vote is another survival test for Turkish Premier A8 A lawyer attracts Poland's radical youth A10 National A11-17 In the inquiry into Pentagon fraud, a Navy engineer and a California military contractor pleaded guilty to Federal conspiracy charges, the third round of guilty pleas in the case since indictments were issued. A1 Raising the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour from $3.35, was approved by the House of Representatives, defying a veto threat by President Bush. It is the first increase in eight years. A1 To end Eastern's strike quickly, the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the case ordered the appointment of an examiner with a broad mandate to get the airline's planes back in the air. A1 In Miami's war on drugs, a citizen who waged a dangerous and lonely fight against pushers was shot to death this week in a hail of up to 30 bullets in the doorway of his store. A1 The idea of huge remote airfields that are almost exclusively transfer points rather than a place for people to start or end journeys is supported by a growing number of aviation planners. A13 Has home rule failed in Washington? Some Congressional Republicans, angered by the District's murder rate and drug trade, are proposing to strip away some of the city government's powers. A12 If Republicans fan partisan warfare, House Democratic leaders warned the Bush Administration that biparti-san cooperation between Congress and the White House could be jeopardized. A17 To modernize the nuclear arsenal on land, the Secretary of Defense should support a compromise that would mix competing missile programs, military officials say. A14 Fawn Hall was tearful and angry as she testified that Oliver L. North's dismissal from the national security council distressed her because she had ''never met a man who worked harder for his country.'' A12 Washington Talk A14 To push the savings and loan bailout through Congress, the White House is counting on Senator Jake Garn, former chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. But the Utahan has a problem with the Bush plan. Regional B1-5 New York City's new government is likely to include a stronger City Council with full power to approve a multibillion dollar budget, members of the charter commission said. A1 News analysis: The redesigning of city government seems likely to focus on a relationship that dates to the turn of the century and drives much of city politics: the balance between City Hall and the boroughs. B4 Staten Islanders mourned their loss of power in reaction to the United States Supreme Court ruling that New York City's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional. There was anger and calls for secession. B4 A municipal law was overturned by a New York court. The law barred four unrelated people from living together in a single-family home. The ruling has implications for zoning. A1 In Mineola, L.I., a man was charged with the murder of his 13-year-old Valley Stream neighbor, Kelly Tinyes. The 21-year-old suspect, who is unemployed and lives with his parents, surrendered voluntarily. B1 Eviction can lead to homelessness in New York City, where there is an almost nonexistent vacancy rate. The percentage of homeless people who have lost their apartments that way is estimated at 26 percent. A1 To preserve the Upper West Side, a committee recommended that builders of luxury towers provide housing for the poor and that a zoning device used to create extra large buildings be curtailed. B1 How much can the state spend? With New York facing its worst financial problems since the mid-1970's, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders remained divided as the state's budget deadline approached. B3

title: Novell and Excelan to Merge
description: Novell Inc. and Excelan Inc., both computer network companies, said today that they had signed a definitive agreement to merge.

title: Steinberg Is Punished For Makeshift Weapon
description: Joel B. Steinberg, facing sentencing today in the fatal beating of his adoptive daughter, has been placed in ''punitive segregation'' for 30 days because a makeshift weapon was found among his belongings, New York City corrections officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Business Technology page on Wednesday, about a blood-clotting protein, misidentified the company that held a license on a patent for Factor VIII. It was the Rorer Group Inc.

title: Islanders Survive a Close One; End Streak
description: The game was a tenuous one, with the Islanders, a team unaccustomed to grooming, much less sitting upon, small leads, in possession of a 2-1 advantage heading into the third period. At tenuous times of late, the Islanders were the club used to getting close and then getting beaten by tiny margins: they knew they had to handle this lead gingerly, but not so cautiously as to relinquish it.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bronx Zoo Hours
description: The Bronx Zoo's summer hours and rates go into effect today. Admission is $3.75 for adults, $1.50 for children (admission is on a donation basis Tuesdays through Thursdays). The elderly and children under 2 years of age are admitted free everyday. The zoo, on the Bronx River Parkway at Fordham Road, is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays; hours on holidays and Sundays are 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Information: 367-1010.

title: Heavy Shelling Continues in Besieged Beirut
description: Lebanese huddled in bomb shelters today after another day of bombardment reminiscent of the worst days of the 14- year civil war.

title: The Talk of Staten Island; Little Island With Power Feels Weaker
description: On the day after the United States Supreme Court ruled that New York City's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional, there could be no mistaking the reaction on Staten Island.

title: Spread of Missiles Is Seen As Soviet Worry in Mideast
description: American officials and Soviet affairs experts say one reason for Moscow's recent diplomatic efforts in the Middle East is its growing concern that Israel, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Egypt either have or are developing missiles that can hit Soviet territory.

title: British Company Acquiring Georgeson, a Proxy Solicitor
description: Georgeson & Company, a 55-year-old Wall Street house that presses stockholders to vote for their clients in takeover battles, said yesterday that it was selling the firm, known as a proxy solicitor, to Corporate Communications P.L.C. of London.

title: Donald Appleton, Executive, 94
description: Donald Appleton, a retired senior vice president of the Oxford Paper Company in Manhattan and a former executive of paper companies in New England, died Tuesday at the Beverly Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 94 years old and lived in Manchester, Mass.

title: Shamrock to Tender Its Shares to Polaroid
description: The Polaroid Corporation scored a major victory in its effort to remain independent yesterday as the Delaware Supreme Court refused to halt the company's plans to repurchase 22 percent of its shares.

title: Fighting the Silence
description: Peggy Say lives in a pleasant house in Cadiz, Kentucky, and anguishes every day of her life for her brother. For four years he has been chained to a wall in a basement in Beirut.

title: Review/Theater; Dorothy and Her Dotty Disciples, Off Again for Oz
description: First of all, it must be reported that that critical mass known as small fry gave every evidence of a warm reaction to the enactment of ''The Wizard of Oz'' that opened Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall. The children applauded when familiar songs resounded over the sound system and tensed when Dorothy and her eccentric friends appeared to be in a tight corner.

title: Winfield to Have Surgery To Repair Ruptured Disk
description: Dave Winfield, the Yankees' injured right fielder, is scheduled to undergo surgery for a herniated disk as early as Friday morning, his attorney, Jeff Klein, said today.

title: This Time, Let's Have a Latin American Policy; Refusal to Self-Destruct
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavy Drug Use In Middle Class Noted by Ward
description: Middle- and upper-class drug users consume 70 percent of the cocaine used in New York City and the police should go after them just as aggressively as less-affluent crack users, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: Top-Seeded Maryland Routs Austin, 89-54
description: Deanna Tate scored 30 points and had 7 steals last night as top-seeded Maryland raced past Stephen F. Austin, 89-54, in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's West Regional.

title: CHARTER UNIT SEES STRONGER COUNCIL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Several members of the New York City commission charged with drafting a new government said yesterday that their proposal would probably include a stronger City Council with full power to approve the multibillion-dollar municipal budget.

title: California's Air, America's Future
description: For people in the Los Angeles Basin, the best hope for a livable future may lie in recreating a simpler past. Mowing lawns by hand. Starting backyard barbecues with paper and sticks. And above all, driving less in many fewer cars.

title: Dr. Morris Lipton, 73, Professor of Psychiatry
description: Dr. Morris A. Lipton, professor emeritus of psychiatry, biochemistry and nutrition at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine, died of cancer March 15 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 73 years old.

title: William Schieffelin 3d, 67, Dies; Headed Wine and Spirit Importer
description: William Jay Schieffelin 3d, the seventh generation of his family to head Schieffelin & Company, the Manhattan wine and spirit importer that was founded in 1794 as a pharmaceutical company, died yesterday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: Washington Talk; Rescuing the Saving Industry
description: THE LEGISLATION: PRIME MOVERS Donald W. Riegle Jr.: Michigan Democrat Chairman, Senate Banking Committee.

title: Jewish Theater Is Making a Comeback
description: WITH five plays on Manhattan stages, American Jewish theater is booming in New York at the moment. Indeed, it appears to have become a staple of the city's theatrical life.

title: Cato Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After income of $120,000 for the quarter and a loss of $818,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the quarter and year also included pretax charges of $411,000 and $4.3 million, respectively, related to restructuring. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $7,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the year, and the year also included a gain of $1,433,000 from an income-tax accounting change.

title: Here Comes the Columbus Dollar, Gold-Color Son of Susan B.; Keep the Change
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate; Urban Benefits in Rural-Type Setting
description: Most people seeking a suburban home are looking either for a single-family house or its condominium equivalent - the town-house unit. Nevertheless, there has always been a segment more attuned to the urban-style apartment in an elegant building served by a concierge and doorman.

title: Books of The Times; Questions of Honor and Family in Italy and America
description: The Lost Father By Marina Warner 318 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Ida Martus, 93, Dies; Ran a School Program
description: Ida Davidoff Martus, who coordinated a theater program for the New York City public schools, died of heart failure yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nuclear Power Gain Reported But Experts Express Doubts
description: A professor at the University of Utah said yesterday that he and a British colleague had achieved nuclear fusion in a test cell simple enough to be built in a small chemistry laboratory.

title: Sun and Cray Pact On Work Stations
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and Cray Research Inc. said they had signed an agreement under which Sun's work stations would be integrated with Cray's supercomputers. The companies also said that the first product resulting from the alliance - the Cray FEI-3 channel interface, which would provide high-speed data transfer between the Sun and Cray machines - was now available.

title: Elron Electronic Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31 in 1987; year- ago figures represent 12-month results ended Dec. 31, 1987. The latest year included $8,000,000 write-off on the company's investment in Elscint.

title: More Wheat for China
description: Private exporters have sold an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The sale increased to 8.2 million tons the wheat sold to China for delivery in 1988 or 1989.

title: Here Comes the Columbus Dollar, Gold-Color Son of Susan B.; Save the Penny
description: To the Editor:

title: Safeguard Health Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents health care revenue.

title: Metro Datelines; Drug Counselor Held In School Sex Abuse
description: A drug counselor at a Bronx middle school was arrested there yesterday and charged with sexual abuse of a female student, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 1 about the Environmental Protection Agency referred incorrectly to William K. Reilly, the agency's new Administrator.

title: For the Palestinians in Diaspora, The Vision Fades but Won't Die
description: The Palestine Red Crescent Society put on a show in the Andalus movie theater here the other night to raise funds for brethren caught in the uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip that Arabs call the intifadeh.

title: Japanese Say 3 Ships Refused to Aid Boat People
description: The operator of a Japanese supertanker that collided with an overloaded fishing boat, apparently drowning about 130 Vietnamese refugees, said today that three other ships within sight of the accident in the South China Sea ignored calls to help save the victims.

title: Oshawa Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof
description: When he was growing up, there was little to set Robert Golub apart from the other children of Horton Road, a tiny, friendly street tucked in a corner of this Nassau County village. He haunted the usual haunts with his high school friends; his passion was lifting weights at the gym on Merrick Road.

title: North American Biologics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fourth quarter results were affected by charges of about $200,000 pirmarily related to costs associated with replacement of certain executive personnel and legal costs.

title: TWO PLEAD GUILTY TO A CONSPIRACY IN PENTAGON CASE
description: A Navy engineer and a California military-contracting company, both with important roles in the inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud, pleaded guilty today to Federal conspiracy charges, the third round of guilty pleas since indictments were issued in January.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about an ordinance in Old Saybrook, Conn., prohibiting the sheltering of homeless people at motels, misstated its intent. Those already housed in motels will not be required to leave, but no new homeless residents will be allowed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Benafuels Inc. of Atlanta, a coal mining company, named Robert Hesse chairman and chief executive, succeeding Bruce Davis, who resigned for undisclosed reasons.

title: Trumpet Ensemble
description: The New York Trumpet Ensemble is to perform an Easter program that includes music by Bach and Handel at Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets are $8. Information: 860-2077.

title: Preserving a Shaky Balance of Power
description: The effort to redesign New York City's government seems likely to focus on a relationship that dates to the turn of the century, when the city as we know it was founded, and that still drives much of its politics today: the balance between City Hall and the five boroughs.

title: Mem Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: ABORTION PROTEST LEADS TO ARRESTS
description: Two hundred anti-abortion protesters, many waving pictures of aborted fetuses, were arrested today as they blockaded a suburban health clinic. The demonstration was the first in an Easter season offensive undertaken with the blessing of the head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Forsman Shoots 66:Dan Forsman shot an opening-round 66 yesterday for a two-stroke lead in the $750,000 USF&G Classic in New Orleans. Trailing him were Greg Norman, Tim Simpson, Bill Sander, Tom Byrum, Pat McGowan and Lee Chill.(AP) Finney Leads: Allison Finney birdied her first three holes and her final four for a 7-under-par 66 and a two-shot lead over Beth Daniel yesterday after the first round of the $400,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Turquoise Classic in Phoenix.(AP) TENNIS Sabatini and Evert Advance: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini routed Catherine Suire of France, 6-0, 6-0, in 42 minutes and No. 2 Chris Evert worked hard for a 7-6, 6-4 victory over Kathy Rinaldi yesterday in the second round of the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Helena Sukova, seeded third, and No. 4 Pam Shriver also advanced, as did Mats Wilander of Sweden, who was seeded second, and No. 5 Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland. No. 13 Sylvia Hanika was eliminated by Halle Cioffi, 4-6, 6-4, 6-1. Wilander, the defending men's champion, beat Scott Warner, 6-3, 6-4, 7-6. Hlasek eliminated Diego Nargiso of Monaco, 6-3, 6-1, 4-6, 6-1. Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, who upset third-seeded Andre Agassi in the first round, advanced by beating Sammy Giammalva, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3. Yannick Noah fought off Bill Scanlon in five sets and Zina Garrison breezed past Sweden's Maria Strandlund. Noah, the men's 12th seed, overcame a slow start to beat Scanlon, 4-6, 7-5, 3-6, 6-1, 6-3 in 3 hours 37 minutes. Garrison, seeded fifth in the women's draw, advanced to the third round with a 6-2, 6-1 triumph. (AP) SWIMMING Victory for Evans: Janet Evans, who won three gold medals last year in the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, won the 500-yard freestyle yesterday at the United States short course national championships. Evans won in 4 minutes 38.82 seconds. Pam Minthorn was second in 4:41.14. (AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY A Navy engineer and a military contractor pleaded guilty to Federal conspiracy charges in the third round of pleas in the Pentagon fraud case since indictments were issued in January. Both Stuart E. Berlin and Teledyne Electronics Inc. play important roles in the Pentagon procurement scandal. [ Page A1. ] The economy expanded at a moderate 2.4 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1988, compared with an initial estimate of 2 percent, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said the figure masked strong underlying growth at year-end. [ D1. ] Domestic car sales stayed in the doldrums in mid-March, rising 2.8 percent from the comparable period last year. [ D3. ] COMPANIES The Federal judge overseeing the Eastern Airlines bankruptcy case ordered the appointment of a powerful examiner with a mandate to end the 20-day-old strike. Judge Burton R. Lifland made it clear that he wanted Eastern's management and the machinists' and pilots' unions to resolve their long dispute. [ A1. ] American Suzuki settled complaints from seven states that its advertisements for the Samurai utility vehicle were deceptive, agreeing that future ads would include warnings that drivers should avoid sharp turns and abrupt maneuvers. [ D1. ] Directors of Turner Broadcasting adjourned a special board meeting without making a bid for a stake in the Financial News Network. [ D13. ] A. Robert Abboud is apparently bidding to create the largest banking company in Texas. Rival bankers say he has met with regulators about taking over Mcorp, the state's second-largest banking company. [ D1. ] Georgeson, a proxy solicitor, will be sold to Corporate Communications of Britain. [ D2. ] Shamrock Holdings will tender its shares in Polaroid after losing a court battle in Delaware. [ D3. ] Consolidated Stores' founder and his family may sell their 16.7 percent stake in the company. [ D3. ] MARKETS In a major step toward round-the-clock electronic trading of securities, Reuters Holdings has joined with the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Cincinnati Stock Exchange and the Instinet trading network to create an electronic network for trading options and stocks. [ D1. ] Stock prices fell broadly in pre-holiday trading, reflecting weakness in transportation issues and some program trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.17 points, to 2,243.04. [ D4. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose moderately in slow pre-holiday trading. [ D10. ] The dollar finished higher in uneventful domestic trading after putting in a mixed performance overseas. [ D11. ] Platinum and silver futures prices fell sharply as the dollar gained strength. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL The Commerce Department reduced controls and simplified licensing procedures for computers and medical equipment bound for the Soviet Union. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Three interconnected riddles on interest rates and the danger of inflation are worrying business and the markets. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Holly Farms shareholders wish they could take the money and run, but the takeover battle is in its sixth month, with no sign of a resolution. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] Hardee's is trying something new, with Marty, a gruff and different spokesman. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D13. ]

title: Centel to Sell Cable Units
description: The Centel Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its cable television operations in Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and central Florida.

title: Consolidated Founder's Plan
description: The founder and former chairman of the Consolidated Stores Corporation and members of his family said today that they might sell their 16.7 percent stake in the company. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Water for All - if All Will Help
description: New Yorkers who normally welcome spring sunshine have reason to view it this year with foreboding: without a lot more rain clouds, the city is in for a severe drought. For relief, city residents can look only to themselves.

title: Integon Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized loss of $25,743,000. c-Net income and included a realized gain of $9,795,000.

title: Crime in Capital Fuels Assault on Home Rule
description: Suddenly the unspeakable is being discussed here: Is home rule in the District of Columbia a failure?

title: Foote, Cone & Belding's President Resigns Post
description: Abbott C. Jones, president of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, resigned yesterday, saying he wanted to pursue ''something entrepreneurial.''

title: Timothy Meyers, Actor, 43
description: Timothy Meyers, an actor who received a Tony Award nomination for his performance as a tough teen-ager in the 1972 Broadway musical ''Grease,'' died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome on March 14 in Cabrini Hospital. He was 43 years old.

title: Buhrmann-Tetterode NV reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR). Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollars have been translated at the Dec. 30, 1988 exchange rate of Dfl 2.00 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: TV Weekend; Mary Martin Flies Again, in 'Peter Pan'
description: The musical ''Peter Pan'' is back: Mary Martin and friends are soaring around the rafters once again and, for two hours beginning at 8 tonight on NBC, all's right with the world. The magic holds. The enchantment works, especially if you have a youngster in the vicinity.

title: George Lynn, 73, Dies; Composer and Teacher
description: George Lynn, a composer and the former music director of Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J., died of heart failure on March 16 at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs, Colo. He was 73 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Garn and Bush Aides Hit Snag on Savings Plan
description: He is a diehard conservative, a believer in deregulation, a Bush supporter and an intensely loyal Republican.

title: Sanford Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results for the latest first quarter included the operations of Sterling Plastics Co., which was acquired in September 1988.

title: Johnson Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $8,000 and $589,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and the quarter included a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $15,000.

title: Review/Music; Sextet Mixes the Unknown and Known
description: New York City is bursting with talented young instrumentalists, and six of them have joined together to form a piano sextet (meaning a wind quintet plus piano) called, fittingly, Hexagon. The group made its New York debut Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. The result was an agreeable evening of music-making, with three unfamiliar pieces to balance Beethoven's Piano Quintet in E flat (Op. 16). But while the playing was always accomplished, it tended toward the intense, not to say aggressive or even overbearing side of the interpretive ledger. As such it honestly echoed the prevalent tastes among New York performers. But in its brusque, utilitarian way, it also left a good deal in the music unsaid.

title: Marshall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: c-Net income

title: Dallas Will Not Retry Man in Killing of Officer
description: The Dallas District Attorney's office announced this afternoon that it would not retry Randall Dale Adams for the 1976 murder of a Dallas police officer, saying that it lacked ''sufficient credible evidence'' against him.

title: Election Talking Point: Does Gringo Accent Hurt?
description: A candidate in Bolivia's presidential elections, Hugo Banzer, a retired general, said at a businessmen's luncheon recently that one of his attributes was the ability to speak Spanish well.

title: Destruction of Afghan Bridge Seen as Blow to Defense of Jalalabad
description: Afghan Government efforts to defend the strategic city of Jalalabad appeared to have suffered a setback today with the disclosure that a key bridge had been blown up by Muslim guerrillas.

title: Honor for Anderson
description: Kenny Anderson of Molloy High School in Queens and Lisa Harrison of Louisville Southern High in Kentucky have been selected as the Naismith basketball players of the year by the Atlanta Tipoff Club. They will receive their awards in Atlanta on April 21.

title: U.S. Judges, Held Hostage
description: Chief Justices of the United States are not given either to holding news conferences or crying wolf. So when William Rehnquist called a news conference last week to plead for a salary increase for Federal judges, it signaled how grave the judicial pay situation had become.

title: 7.8% Inflation in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate jumped to an unexpectedly high 7.8 percent in February, from 7.5 percent in January, largely because of rising mortgage rates, the Government said today. The higher mortgage rates stem from the Government's drive to push interest rates up to fight the nation's resurgent inflation, which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has said is her top economic priority. Excluding mortgage payments, the annual inflation rate stood at 5.7 percent, said Norman Fowler, secretary of the Department of Employment. The 7.8 percent figure was above the rate the markets had been expecting and fueled speculation that interest rates, now at 13 percent, might go higher.

title: Police Curb Complaint Board's Power
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has stripped the Civilian Complaint Review Board of its power to recommend departmental trials or punishment for officers found guilty of misconduct. This power, the Commissioner contends, violated New York City's Charter.

title: Is Relief for Airport Crowds in Middle of Nowhere?
description: What if they built a major airport far from cities and hotels, houses and highways?

title: Restaurants
description: Arizona 206

title: ABC Names Its President of Entertainment
description: ABC named Robert Iger its president of entertainment today in a move that company executives acknowledged was unorthodox. Mr. Iger, 38 years old, has been the executive vice president of the ABC Television Network Group since last August, but most of his career at the network has been in the sports division, where he was most active in negotiating rights and scheduling programs.

title: La Quinta Motor Inns Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Artel Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: A King at the Gate

title: Golden Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $1,025,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said last year's third quarter included 14 weeks of Snack Food sales. It said that if last year's extra week is eliminated for comparative purposes, total revenue for the third quarter was about equal to last year's, and last year's net income per share would have been about 13 cents. The company also said the potato shortage caused by last summer's drought reduced its latest third quarter net by about 8 cents a share.

title: Review/Film; Hayseed to Hipster In the East Village
description: Tim Lee, wearing buckskin and carrying a trombone, arrives in New York City from Oklahoma and right away some thugs try to steal his cowboy hat. Minutes later, he discovers that the girlfriend who preceded him to the big city has become a blond bohemian and is attached to someone else. Then he nearly falls into the lubricious hands of a casting agent who makes homosexual advances.

title: Penn Hires Coach
description: Gary Steele, Penn's defensive coordinator, has been appointed the Quakers' head football coach. Steele replaces Ed Zubrow, who resigned after three years to work on fighting drug abuse in Philadelphia's public schools.(AP)

title: Risk Seen in Pain Relief Drugs
description: Drug manufacturers are warning doctors that commonly prescribed arthritis and pain-relieving drugs pose a serious risk of peptic ulcers, intestinal perforations and other gastrointestinal problems, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

title: One Citizen's War on Drugs: A Lonely Fight, Then Death
description: Lee Arthur Lawrence spent much of the last five years being a model of the concerned citizen in the war on drugs: chasing pushers out of his grocery store's parking lot, working with the police to sweep drug dealers from the streets, visiting schools to preach against narcotics and alcohol abuse.

title: Lewis Urges Testing
description: Carl Lewis said yesterday that as many as 10 Olympic medals last summer went to athletes using anabolic steroids, and he urged random testing at all levels of sports competition.

title: Yakima Valley Journal; Farming Without Alar, Suffering With the Rest
description: Harvey Coleman, who farms 29 acres of apple trees on a hillside near here, has never used Alar to make his fruit round and crisp. But Alar-free fruit received no special consideration when the Government raised alarms last month by declaring that the chemical might pose a cancer risk to children. Taiwan, the destination of Mr. Coleman's Red Delicious crop, ceased imports of all Washington apples.

title: KEY RATES
At the Bar
description: Stately, plump Steven Brill stood triumphantly in a crowded Rainbow Room last week. Ten years had passed since he launched his iconoclastic American Lawyer magazine. And all around, bowing and scraping before him, were emissaries from the very institutions, that he has opened up, dissected and attacked.

title: Market Holiday
description: Stock, bond and futures markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Federal Government offices are scheduled to be open, but some banks and local government offices will be closed.

title: Court Upsets L.I. Zoning Law On Unrelated People in Home
description: In a decision with broad implications for municipal zoning, New York State's highest court yesterday overturned a Long Island town law that prohibited four unrelated people from living together in a single-family home.

title: E. Wilson Lyon, 84, Ex-College President
description: E. Wilson Lyon, president of Pomona College from 1941 to 1969, died March 3 at Pomona Valley Hospital Medical Center in Pomona, Calif., after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.

title: Sale by TLC Group
description: TLC Group Inc., the New York investment company headed by Reginald F. Lewis, said it had sold Winner Food Products Ltd., a food products company based in Hong Kong, to a investment group consisting of the Nissin Food Products Company of Japan and Itoh & Company, the Japanese trading concern, for $30 million. Winner, the largest maker of instant noodles in Hong Kong, was part of the Beatrice International Company.

title: National Health Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hopper Soliday reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Importer to Be President Of Glenmore Distilleries
description: The Glenmore Distilleries Company has named Frank D. Casciari, head of a champagne company in New York City, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: Emotional Approach For Hardee's
description: EVER since McDonald's gave people a day's deserved break from their kitchens, fast-food advertising has been characterized by singing counter girls eager to serve their beautiful burgers and fabulous fries.

title: 20.17 Drop Puts Dow At 2,243.04
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in pre-holiday trading, reflecting weakness in transportation issues and some program trading.

title: Devils Lose Again And Share the Blame
description: With the Blackhawks leading the Philadelphia Flyers by two goals after two periods in Chicago on Wednesday night, most of the Devils went to bed thinking that their game tonight against the Boston Bruins would be as significant as the seventh and deciding game in the Stanley Cup semifinals last season.

title: Formica Disclosure
description: The Formica Corporation said that an unidentified industrial company wanted to acquire it for about $259 million, $29 million more than a management group was offering, but that the offer was still short of Wall Street's expectations. The shares of Formica, known for its laminated and other decorative surfaces, fell $1 today, to $21, on the New York Stock Exchange. Formica said it had asked its adviser, Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., to start talks with the suitor, but added that an agreement might not result. Formica, based in Wayne, N.J., also said Shearson was continuing its discussions with six other parties.

title: Rose Inquiry Continues
description: The investigation into Pete Rose's off-field activities is continuing, and it is not certain if it will be concluded before A. Bartlett Giamatti succeeds Peter Ueberroth as commissioner April 1.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Are Sluggish
description: Domestic car sales stayed in the doldrums in mid-March, and analysts said the 6.8 million annual selling rate would not be strong enough to clear bloated inventories.

title: New Face: Isaach de Bankole; An Actor's Road Taken To Cameroon Of 'Chocolat'
description: With few words to say in the new French film ''Chocolat,'' Isaach de Bankole manages to express resentment, pride, scorn, amusement, outrage, sexual desire and - primarily - nobility, and to dominate the film all along the way.

title: Jackson, After Workout, Eager for Real Action
description: As Mark Jackson raced up and down the floor today during a 90-minute workout in the Miami Arena, the only sign that the Knick playmaker had undergone surgery to repair torn cartilage in his right knee was the blue knee pad he wore.

title: The Rent's Due, and for Many It's Homelessness Knocking
description: One tenant said she couldn't pay the rent because her husband had walked out. Another tenant was laid off. Still another can't get welfare benefits. One woman said she couldn't cover the rent because she had bought shoes for her children with the rent money; another had bought a color television. Someone else is chronically ill, or struggling with a death in the family, or addicted to crack.

title: South Africa Party Said to Mend Rift
description: The leadership confrontation between President P. W. Botha and the National Party leader, F. W. de Klerk, which has paralyzed South Africa's governing white party, appears to have been resolved.

title: Review/Film Festival; The History of a Musician's Disintegration
description: Lined and ravaged as it is, the face is ageless: as sunken as a dead man's, as softly bewildered as a child's. Chet Baker's face, and the extraordinary ways in which Bruce Weber has photographed it, encapsulate the story of Baker's life in a succession of ghostly, indelible images that are at once hauntingly beautiful and desperately sad. Applied to a different subject, Mr. Weber's methods might seem disturbingly superficial, but they suit this portrait perfectly. The man, his music and the times in which he flourished are best served by a cinematic style that remains determinedly skin-deep.

title: General Cinema
description: The General Cinema Corporation completed the sale of its soft-drink bottling unit to Pepsico Inc. for $1.78 billion, producing a pretax gain of $1.4 billion. The sale of the largest independent Pepsi-Cola bottler in the United States will be reflected in General Cinema's results for the second quarter, ending about April 30. Concerns from the Federal Trade Commission led the company to exclude its operations in Staunton, Va., and Broward County, Fla., from the sale.

title: Lost in Pentagon's Depths
description: Dick Cheney, the new Secretary of Defense, has learned what anyone who has spent any time at the Pentagon can tell you: Don't go into the basement without a guide.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: West; Friends and Relatives Lift Pirates' Walker
description: There is plenty back in New York to remind Daryll Walker of Seton Hall that his every step will be followed against Nevada-Las Vegas in the West Regional final Saturday afternoon in McNichols Arena.

title: 'Boots' for Cars Can Go The Way of the Rack
description: To the Editor:

title: Incomes Post 1% Rise, But Spending Pace Lags
description: Americans' personal income shot up 1 percent last month while consumer spending advanced at a more restrained pace, raising the savings rate to its highest level in nearly three years.

LEAD: Some observers argue that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's anathematizing of Salman Rushdie was a deliberate and calculated attempt to clip the wings of the ''liberal'' speaker of the Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani. They also argue that Ayatollah Khomeini used the Rushdie affair to prevent closer relations with the West and restore fading revolutionary zeal in Iran.

title: Not So Regressive in Korea
description: Friends of South Korean democracy shouldn't be alarmed by President Roh Tae Woo's surprise postponement this week of the plebiscite he promised in his 1987 election campaign. The vote would not have added much to Korea's yearlong march toward democracy, and indeed might have distracted from the real issues.

title: TV Doctors: An Image Made Too Well
description: Playing Doctor Television, Storytelling, and Medical Power By Joseph Turow Illustrated. 315 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about reaction on Staten Island to the United States Supreme Court decision invalidating the New York City Board of Estimate gave an incorrect location for the Fresh Kills landfill. It is on the island's west shore, not the south shore.

title: U.S. Rice Farmers Pressing Again For Entry Into the Japanese Market
description: As they prepare for their annual planting, farmers in the Sacramento Valley in northern California, the American Rice Bowl, are trying again to see if there is a way to open Japan's tightly sealed rice market.

title: Planners Must Satisfy Voting Law In the Shifting of Municipal Power
description: When the United States Supreme Court struck down the New York City Board of Estimate on constitutional grounds, the questions of discrimination against minority-group members and the Federal Voting Rights Act were barely mentioned.

title: Bill Would Ban Some Bullets
description: Saying he wanted to take firepower away from drug dealers, Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, has introduced a bill to ban the manufacture, transfer and importation of .25-caliber and .32-caliber bullets. The bill is aimed at the cheap, easily concealed pistols that Mr. Weiss said on Thursday were used in 75 percent of all gun-related homicides. Without ammunition, he said, ''a handgun is useless.''

title: Wilbur E. Kelley, Ex-Engineer, Dies at 80
description: Wilbur E. Kelley, a retired engineer who worked in the procurement and processing of uranium and other elements for construction of the first atomic bomb, died of colon cancer March 16 at Deepdale Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in New Hyde Park.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday, with an article about the nuclear power industry, omitted the years corresponding to the number of automatic emergency shutdowns annually at the nation's nuclear plants.

title: Jacob Lefferts, 76, Real-Estate Developer
description: Jacob R. Van Mater Lefferts, a retired New Jersey real-estate developer, died Tuesday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Vero Beach.

title: Salvadoran Leftist Views Failed Candidacy as a Casualty of War
description: When Guillermo Ungo returned from exile to El Salvador in November 1987, his goal was to re-establish a place for the left in the spectrum of his country's electoral politics.

title: Rains Are Little Help For Water Shortage
description: Wet as it was yesterday in New York City and the metropolitan region, the rain had little effect on the reservoirs from which the city draws its water.

title: How to Compensate for 11 Feet
description: Cityspire, a new 72-story residential building in midtown Manhattan, rises high because it uses air rights from the City Center building next door. But hold on; Cityspire rises even higher, 11 extra, illegal feet. No city official waived or seemed to waive the rules, leaving responsibility for non-conformance entirely on the developer. The Board of Estimate has a duty to make its response a signal to all who so defy zoning.

title: Many Catholics Choose Baptism by Immersion
description: ''I used to say, when God wants me, He'll choose me,'' Nereida Cruz recalled recently. Ms. Cruz, a 42-year-old New Yorker who is the mother of three children 9 to 24 years old, says she believes God has chosen her now.

title: Cotonou Journal; Benin's Gift: Contraband as High Art
description: Near the main thoroughfare of this dusty port city, down a narrow alley and off a courtyard for cooking fires, a local entrepreneur sought to impress a visitor with prized samples from the business he runs with his three sons.

title: Houston's Status for Bay Shore May Be Dampened After Rain
description: Houston, the highly touted 3-year-old who is listed as the even-money favorite in the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct today, may be scratched from the race because of the heavy rain yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; Japanese College Students Are a Symphony Orchestra
description: The Waseda Symphony Orchestra, which played its first New York concert Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, is a 75-year-old ensemble staffed by students at Waseda University in Tokyo. The university has no conservatory or school of music - all the players are majors in the liberal arts or sciences - but the orchestra maintains an extensive schedule of concerts, tours regularly, and is occasionally visited by celebrated conductors.

title: Plants That Bloom Anew
description: Easter plants are colorful while they last: tulips, daffodils, hyacinths, lilies, azaleas and hydrangeas, to name a few. After the holiday, most of them can be planted outdoors to bloom again.

title: Casinos Challenge Ordinance Requiring Spending for Arts
description: Casinos here are challenging an ordinance that requires them to reserve 1 percent of construction budgets for statues, murals and other artworks, a casino representative said today.

title: Why New York Should Reject the Death Penalty
description: LEAD: Now that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has vetoed legislation that would have reinstated the death penalty, the New York State Legislature will seek to override the veto. It shouldn't.

title: Dumars Adds to Nets' Frustration
description: The longer the Nets' losing streak gets, the more frustrating it becomes for the organization.

title: Taylor Cited for Drunken Driving
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro outside linebacker, was arrested early yesterday morning in a parked car and given a summons for driving while intoxicated, the police said. Taylor has a history of drug problems, and it was not clear how or whether this incident would affect his pro football career.

title: Drug Testing Passes a Test
description: In upholding two Federal programs that test employees for drug use in the workplace, the Supreme Court properly balanced privacy rights against public safety.

title: Reviews/Music; The Music of the Minotaurs As Composed by a Canadian
description: Linda Bouchard is a Canadian composer now living in New York. Lately she has been operating with and through a small instrumental group called Abandon. All these parties came downtown to the Alternative Museum on Wednesday night. There were three pieces by Miss Bouchard - ''Tokpela,'' for solo percussion, ''Le Scandal,'' for strings, harp and percussion, and a more elaborate setting called ''Minotaurus,'' a dramatic reading of Friedrich Durrenmatt's poem, supported by eight instruments.

title: O'Neill Signs Tax Increases
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed on Thursday a $247 million deficit-bailout bill that calls for higher taxes on alcohol, cigarettes and businesses starting April 1 to close this year's deficit. The Senate passed the measure Thursday, 22 to 13.

title: Tubbs Shows Interest
description: Billy Tubbs, Oklahoma's basketball coach for the last nine seasons, said last night that he would be interested in the vacant coaching position at Kentucky, although he said he was not an official candidate for the job. ''I'm willing to listen to anyone who wants to talk to me,'' Tubbs told The Associated Press.

title: Anti-Drug Effort in Capital Seen as Part of Federal Role
description: President Bush's decision to focus anti-drug efforts on the streets of Washington is part of a plan to heighten the Government's distinctive role in the capital, a senior White House official said today.

title: Text of U.S. Plan on Central America
description: Following is the official text of the statement on Central America by the White House and leaders of Congress, as issued today by the White House Press Secretary's office:

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 57th Streets will be closed between 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. tomorrow for the Easter Promenade.

title: Reviews/Film; Gruesome Toll for Teen-Age Phone Calls
description: In ''976-EVIL,''a ridiculous horror movie, a young high school student, picked on by bullies, gains malevolent powers through a series of telephone calls. He dials 976-EVIL for his ''horror-scope'' and thereby turns into the wolfman of the lugubrious California town where he lives. He wreaks anatomically gruesome vengeance on his tattooed tormenters. Then, as his skin gets crinklier and his purple fingernails grow longer, he goes after everybody else who comes into his path.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan for the Defense?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Connecticut General Assembly's approval of tax increases misstated the proposed rise in the cigarette tax. The tax on each pack will rise 14 cents, to 40 cents.

title: Voters Must Regain Control of Electoral System
description: To the Editor:

title: Largest U.S. Tanker Spill Spews 270,000 Barrels of Oil Off Alaska
description: A tanker filled to capacity with crude oil ran aground and ruptured yesterday 25 miles from the southern end of the Trans Alaska Pipeline, spewing her cargo into water rich in marine life.

title: Concern Over Water Safety Is Growing
description: Americans are so worried about the safety of their drinking water that last year they bought $2 billion worth of bottled water and spent $265 million more for purifying equipment and services.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage rose to 11.22 percent for the week ended today from 10.98 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Reconstructing Shakespeare's West End
description: To the Editor:

title: British Concern's Unitel Video Stake
description: U.E.I. P.L.C., a British broadcasting equipment maker, has acquired 47 percent of Unitel Video Inc. and will consider buying the remaining shares of the New York video recording services company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, U.E.I. said it had acquired its stake in private placements on March 14 for an average price of $14 a share.

title: Robert C. Dodds, 70, Cleric and Counselor
description: The Rev. Robert C. Dodds, a former official of the National Council of Churches who was also a psychologist and marriage counselor, died last Saturday at Central Vermont Hospital in Barre, Vt., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Montpelier, Vt.

title: TW Sees Talks With Third Parties
description: TW Services Inc. said it had agreed to provide financial information to Coniston Partners and other parties who have expressed interest in acquiring the New York-based restaurant operator. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, TW Services said that ''discussions and negotiations'' with these third parties ''will commence shortly.''

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: East; Resourceful Hoyas Turn Back Wolfpack
description: As the Georgetown Hoyas approach the day that will provide the final definition of their basketball season, they are constructing a description of their own. The Hoyas entered the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament after three convincing victories in the Big East tournament that reinforced the image of an overpowering team.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: Midwest; Louisville Crumbles Under Illini Pressure
description: Louisville, a team noted for its athleticism and its pressure defense, was served large, lethal doses of its own medicine by Illinois tonight. The Illini, showing little regard for the Cardinals' vaunted inside game, broke open a tight contest with steals and dunks to rout the Cardinals, 83-69, in a Midwest Regional semifinal.

title: Sluggish Iran-Iraq Talks Worry Kuwait
description: The leaders of this sheikdom on the Persian Gulf have expressed concern at the continued stalemate in Iran-Iraq peace talks, reflecting their fears that hostilities might resume and their worries about the effect on Kuwait's own politics.

title: Theodore C. Agins, Dentist, 80
description: Theodore C. Agins, a retired dentist and former mayor of Kensington, L.I., died of a heart attack Thursday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Irving Seligman, Clothier, 79
description: Irving Seligman, a retired men's clothing manufacturer, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Comparing Nest Eggs
description: For some, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 meant the curtailment of tax deductions on contributions for Individual Retirement Accounts. People who hold I.R.A.'s but do not have qualified pension plans at work are not affected. Some experts believe that I.R.A. certificates of deposit still offer the best returns among types of C.D.'s, whether or not you get a tax deduction. In addition to fixed-rate I.R.A. C.D.'s, banks also offer them with variable rates, which are most common on certificates with an 18-month maturity. Individuals can roll over their I.R.A. money from one institution to another without bank penalty, but beware: some places are charging a fee for that privilege. Check to find out if there is a fee and if that fee still makes a transfer worthwhile. Here are some yields on I.R.A. C.D.'s compared with regular C.D.'s, the highest yields available in 1988 and 1989. 1989 1988 One-year I.R.A. C.D.'s 10.25% 8.24% One-year C.D.'s 9.25 7.12 Five-year I.R.A. C.D.'s 10.65 9.04 Five-year C.D.'s 9.13 7.99 (Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.)

title: For Dance Fledglings
description: The Field, a nonprofit service organization for emerging dance artists, will have its first Pagnano Memorial Fund Benefit on April 4 and 5 at the Dia Art Foundation, 155 Mercer Street, at 8 P.M. The performances will be followed by a dance party. The program is to include dance and performance art by Robert Kovich, Beth Leonard, Jeff McMahon and Sarah Skaggs. All received grants this year for rehearsal space from the fund, named for the late Ernie Pagnano, a popular New York City dance teacher who died in 1987. Admission is by suggested donation of $10. Reservations: 966-3717.

title: No Mention of Jews at Buchenwald
description: On a bleak hilltop at the edge of the town where Germany's first democratic constitution was framed stands a dismal reminder of how low that civilization fell not long ago.

title: E.P.A. WILL REVIEW DAM IN COLORADO
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency today ordered a review of a dam project southwest of Denver that could cost as much as $1 billion, saying the dam could result in ''the very heavy, final and irremediable loss of an environmental treasure of national significance.''

title: Perfect Touch For Barkley
description: Charles Barkley was perfect tonight, hitting all 19 shots from the floor and the foul line in scoring 31 points and leading the Philadelphia 76ers to a 135-122 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Griggs Chooses Chiefs
description: Billy Griggs, an unrestricted free agent and for four seasons a backup tight end with the Jets, signed a two-year contract Thursday with the Kansas City Chiefs. He had been set to sign with Cleveland before receiving a call from the Chiefs. Griggs has caught 16 passes in his N.F.L. career.(AP)

title: Lest We Rush Into Executing the Innocent; Bush and Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hartford, a Debate Over Art for a Captive Audience
description: A debate over a minor amendment to an obscure 11-year-old law has lawmakers here talking about art: specifically, how it affects the beholder and who is entitled to its benefits.

title: Outcome Of the Pie Pickle
