description: Our frozen-apple-pie contest has been a disappointment. Hoping to discover a new cliche for the outmoded expression ''as American as apple pie,'' we offered a frozen apple pie as a prize for the best entry and sat back waiting to be deluged with fresh, pungent and colorful phrases.

title: U.S. Is Assured by Japanese Of a 35% Stake in Jet Work
description: Responding to Bush Administration demands, Japan has assured the United States that at least 35 percent of a jet fighter the two Governments want to build together would be made in the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Controversial Coach Leaving San Jose State
description: Coach Bill Berry was dismissed as San Jose State's basketball coach yesterday.

title: Baker Plan: A New Deal
description: The bipartisan agreement on Central America, fashioned by James A. Baker 3d in one of his first major acts as Secretary of State, represents a sharp break from President Reagan's policy of unmitigated opposition to the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua.

title: Aase, Once a Long Shot, Is Now a Contender
description: On center stage, Dwight Gooden pitched seven innings against Fernando Valenzuela today, a pair of superstars sharpening their stuff in the next-to-last week of spring training. Gooden is nearly ready for opening day for the Mets. Valenzuela is apparently making a comeback for the Los Angeles Dodgers after a weary 1988. And, after they were gone, the Mets upstaged the Dodgers with some old-time melodrama on a ninth-inning home run by Darryl Strawberry.

title: Boat With 10 Aboard Is Reported Sinking
description: Coast Guard and Navy ships battled poor visibility and rough seas off the Virginia coast today to search for a 52-foot sport fishing boat that reported it was sinking with 10 people aboard. But after searching in vain for almost 24 hours, officials suspended the rescue operation.

title: BUSH AND CONGRESS SIGN POLICY ACCORD ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: In an attempt to forge a bipartisan foreign policy, President Bush joined Democratic and Republican leaders today to announce an agreement committing the Administration and Congress to aid for Nicaraguan rebels and to support for Central American peace efforts.

title: Wally Heider Is Dead; Recording Engineer,66
description: Wally Heider, a recording engineer whose studios were used by big bands and rock musicians in the 1960's and 70's and who recently produced a series of jazz videotapes, died of lung cancer Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Leslie Lee. He was 66 years old.

title: Cayton's License Valid
description: Randy Gordon, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that Bill Cayton had a valid manager's license during 1988 and has one for 1989, refuting assertions by the promoter Don King.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: Southeast; Wolverines' Victory Is Icing on the Cake for New Coach
description: There was a late-night telephone call from Bo Schembechler, Michigan's athletic director and newest basketball fan, who just wanted to tell Steve Fisher and the players to keep up the good work.

title: Reviews/Dance; 5 Works, Some Whimsical, By Dancer-Choreographer
description: Rick Guimond came to special notice as a superb dancer in Senta Driver's company, but in the last four seasons he has directed his own troupe, Guimond Dance Associates.

title: Steinberg Given Maximum Term Of 8Y to 25 Years in Child's Death
description: Joel B. Steinberg was sentenced to 8Y to 25 years in state prison yesterday in the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, the girl he helped raise. The penalty was the maximum he could have received, and the judge said he would recommend strongly against parole.

title: Washington Developer Sets Purchase of 2 Ritz-Carltons
description: A Washington real estate developer, Mohamed A. Hadid, has agreed to pay up to $150 million in cash and assumed debt for control of the Ritz-Carlton hotels in New York and Washington, plus more than $14 million for renovations.

title: American Indians Succeed at Dartmouth
description: To the Editor:
LEAD: Why did the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issue a death sentence against Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses?'' Perhaps a better question is, What took him so long?

title: Review/Circus; Star Animal Trainer's Farewell
description: The circus came to Madison Square Garden on Thursday with the farewell tour of its star animal trainer, Gunther Gebel-Williams, as its focus. The celebration outshone any conceivable office retirement party.

title: John G. Mapes, Executive, 82
description: John G. Mapes, former vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton Inc., a Manhattan-based public relations concern, died of complications from pneumonia Thursday at a Phoenix nursing home. He was 82 years old and lived in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Avie's Gal Wins Distaff: Avie's Gal, the lone front-runner in a field reduced from nine to five by heavy rain, led from start to finish to win the $86,100 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Haiati rallied well to finish second, 1 1/2 lengths behind the winner and 1 1/2 lengths in front of Topicount. Avie's Gal, a 4-year-old daughter of Lord Avie and the Bold Hour mare Cheri Femme, paid $10.80 for $2 to win as the fourth choice and ran the seven furlongs in 1:24 under Nick Santagata while carrying 112 pounds. Avie's Gal is owned by John R. Cioci and trained by John J. Lenzini Jr. TENNIS Connors Advances: Jimmy Connors won his third match in four days last night, beating Horst Skoff of Austria, 6-2, 7-6, 6-1, to advance to the fourth round of the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Also advancing were top-seeded Ivan Lendl, Aaron Krickstein, Emilio Sanchez, Kevin Curren, Andres Gomez and Eduardo Bengoechea. In women's play, second-seeded Chris Evert, Zina Garrison, Katerina Maleeva, Mary Joe Fernandez and Helen Kelesi advanced.(AP) GOLF Bogey-Free Round for Simpson: Tim Simpson shot a bogey-free, five-under-par 67 yesterday to move into a tie with Dan Forsman after the second round of the $750,000 USF&G Classic in New Orleans. Simpson and Forsman, who shot a 69, were at nine-under-par 135.(AP) Three-Stroke Lead for Finney: Allison Finney, seeking the first victory of her seven-year Ladies Professional Golf Association career, fired a four-under-par 69 yesterday for a three-shot lead over Beth Daniel after two rounds of the $400,000 Turquoise Classic in Phoenix.(AP) N.H.L. Capitals 6, Flyers 1: Geoff Courtnall and Dino Ciccarelli each scored their 40th goals and Scott Stevens had a goal and three assists last night in Landover, Md., as Washington won its seventh consecutive game. The Capitals outshot the Flyers by 32-7 over the first two periods and 40-16 for the game as they took a 6-point lead over the Rangers in the race for first place in the Patrick Division. Both teams have five games remaining. Philadelphia's starting goalie, Ron Hextall, was ejected with 9 minutes 43 seconds left in the second period after he hit Bengt Gustafsson of the Capitals with his stick while trying to clear a rebound. Hextall was given a five-minute major penalty and a game misconduct.(AP) Sabres 5, Canucks 2: John Tucker and Ray Sheppard each had a goal and an assist as Buffalo beat Vancouver. Doug Bodger and Pierre Turgeon added two assists for the Sabres, who beat Vancouver at home for the first time in their last six tries. The loss assured that the Canucks will finish fourth in the Smythe Division and will play Calgary in the opening round of the playoffs.(AP) Red Wings 6, Maple Leafs 2: Dave Barr and Joe Kocur scored 49 seconds apart in the second period and Steve Yzerman had three assists as Detroit won at home. Toronto's loss assured the Minnesota North Stars of a playoff berth. The Maple Leafs trail fourth-place Chicago by 4 points in the race for the final Norris Division playoff spot. Toronto has four games remaining; Chicago has five. (AP) Jets 4, Flames 3: Randy Carlyle's goal at 3:45 of overtime gave Winnipeg its victory and damaged Calgary's chances of finishing first in the overall National Hockey League standing. The Flames remained tied with Montreal for the overall lead with 109 points. Each team has four games remaining.(AP)

title: Homeless: Urban Woe Lands on S.I.
description: As Karyn Whitney stood with scores of other Manhattan-bound commuters in the Staten Island Ferry Terminal at St. George, her gaze fell on groups of homeless people across the crowded waiting room, women sitting on wood benches and staring into space and groups of young men with matted hair and dirty clothes.

title: School Clerk Arrested In Rape of Student, 15
description: A Board of Education clerk was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 15-year-old girl who was a student at the high school where he worked, the police said.

title: E.P.A. Backing States on Gasoline Vapor
description: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday moved further toward allowing Northeastern states to cut air pollution by imposing stricter standards than the Federal Government does on the formulation of gasoline.

title: Lockheed Accused on Plant Safety
description: In a case watched closely for an indication of the safety of top-secret workplaces, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration cited the Lockheed Corporation's airplane-building division today for widespread violations of safety and health standards and said it would seek a fine of nearly $1.5 million.

title: Charter Panel Members Back Borough Influence
description: Many of the members of the commission charged with recommending a new form of government for New York City strongly favor continuing borough influence in city government despite the United States Supreme Court decision invalidating the Board of Estimate, the principal arena for the boroughs' exercise of power.

title: Charter Panel Chairman Sees A Larger Role for Minorities
description: The chairman of the commission that must create a new government for New York City said yesterday that he envisioned changes that could shake up the traditional power structure by giving a greater voice to minority groups and small political parties.

title: Satellite Is Lofted for Anti-Missile Test
description: A Delta rocket carried a $140 million satellite into space yesterday as part of the first ''Star Wars'' experiment in the Bush Administration and the first one to last more than a few hours.

title: Shift Seen On Reactor Licensing
description: Attempting to lay the groundwork for a new generation of nuclear reactors, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is likely to approve in the next few days a sweeping revision of the way new plants are licensed.

title: Air-Fare Discounters: Savings for Careful Fliers
description: With summer on the horizon, more travelers planning international vacations are turning to a growing number of small advertisements in newspapers and magazines offering the world at a bargain price.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day in some editions yesterday, about television networks that dropped an MGM/UA advertisement, carried an incorrect headline.

title: Businessland Deal Seen for Next Inc.
description: Next Inc. has agreed to sell its personal computers through Businessland Inc.'s stores, an industry official said. The move would mark a significant shift in strategy. Since its inception, Next has said it would sell its sophisticated computers only to students and educational institutions.

title: Legislator Tunes In To Foes Of Guns
description: Fighting a bad cold and a mild case of nerves, Representative Harry A. Johnston, newly elected Democrat from Florida's 14th Congressional District, took a seat at the dais and prepared to hear from the most vocal and politically potent segment of his consitutency - retirees.

title: SOVIET COMPUTING: AN INSIDE VIEW
description: Like his American counterparts in the computer business, the man in charge of computer networks in the Soviet Union likes to talk about selling ''solutions'' -hardware and software combinations shaped for a specific function.

title: Italy's Battered Communists Reinvent Themselves Again
description: After more than a decade of political setbacks, Italy's Communist Party has unveiled its latest modern look, hoping that its new emphasis on ecology, feminism and family issues can attract an electorate that no longer seems interested in Marx and the masses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 25, 1989
description: Companies

title: Some Legislators Oppose Plan to Aid Contras
description: Some liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans oppose the agreement to help the Nicaraguan rebels that was announced today by President Bush and Congressional leaders. But leaders of both parties said they expected Congress to approve the plan.

title: More Fruit From Chile Is Cleared for U.S. Sale
description: The Food and Drug Administration today cleared the way for Chilean apples, peaches and plums to be sold in the United States after they are inspected for evidence of cyanide poisoning.

title: Patents; Cooling Off a Car
description: Domingo K. L. Tan, a physicist-turned-entrepreneur in Alexandria, Va., won patent approval this week for an aerosol spray that instantly cools off a parked car that has been left baking in the sun. The spray consists of only alcohol and water. A quick burst before getting into the car cools the air by as much as 50 degrees, Mr. Tan said ''The hot air molecules collide with the droplets and they lose much of their kinetic energy, causing the temperature to immediately drop,'' he said. The inventor plans to begin marketing his invention this summer. A 20-ounce can should cost $3 to $4.

title: Odyssey Of Emigre With Nerve
description: The memory of Mickey Hargitay is still vivid in Hungary. To his old friends in Budapest, as well as to people who never knew him at all, Mr. Hargitay is a living testament to the infinite possibilities of the American Dream. Having emigrated to the United States at the age of 14, he went on to win the Mr. Universe title, appear as a professional strong man and supporting actor to Mae West in her nightclub act, marry Jayne Mansfield and become a great movie star.

title: About New York Parents in Terror: Could My Child Be My Killer?
description: Gerald has been demanding and getting $13,000 a year from his parents, John and Gwen. The 27-year-old man uses the money, almost all of their savings now, to buy drugs. John, a retired postal worker of failing health, acquiesces because Gerald is likely to jam his face in a plate of food or throw furniture at him if he refuses.

title: Parish, McHale Combine for 50, Thwart Knicks
description: There was another game between the Knicks and the Celtics at the Boston Garden tonight, and another New York loss.

title: I.B.M. Sees Firm Demand
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's top executives moved this week to reassure securities analysts that there has been no change in demand after unexpectedly warning last week that the computer maker's 1989 earnings might not meet expectations.

title: Managua Says Plan Violates Peace Pact
description: The Nicaraguan Government denounced the new American plan for aid to the contras yesterday, saying it violates the regional accord calling for the dismantling of the rebels' bases in Honduras. Article, page 6.

title: Prospect Talks With Brinkmann
description: The Prospect Group Inc., which owns 26 percent of Brinkmann Instruments Inc., has held talks with the laboratory equipment manufacturer about selling back some of its shares. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Prospect said it had told Brinkmann that it would be willing to sell some of its stock for $19 a share. No agreement was reached, according to Prospect, a New York-based concern whose interests include bakery goods and railroads.

title: New York Schools Miss a $100 Million Deadline
description: More than $100 million in Federal aid for the New York City Board of Education was withheld last year because the board failed to meet deadlines for developing plans to spend the money, the New York State Department of Education said today.

title: Your Money; Financial Advice For Executives
description: Many top executives work so hard running their companies that they neglect their personal finances. That situation has created a demand for financial planning as an executive perquisite.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES Pete Rose Waits to Hear The Verdict
description: The old Greeks had a saying that until a man is dead, do not yet call him happy, call him lucky. I thought about this in relation to Pete Rose, and how happy he had seemed.

title: Harry Schnell, Surveyor, 85
description: Harry Schnell, a retired surveyor whose projects included Lincoln Center and Madison Square Garden, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 85 years old and lived in Forest Hills.

title: Ukraine Grave Found To Hold Stalin Victims
description: A Government commission has concluded that thousands of people buried in a mass grave outside Kiev were killed during Stalin's repressions, not by Nazi soldiers, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Transcript of White House Remarks
description: Following is a transcript of statements by President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network: STATEMENT BY BUSH

title: American Indians Succeed at Dartmouth; The Jesuit Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Markets Closed
description: United States stock, bond and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday.

title: Walter Klotzback, 88; Led Emergency Unit
description: Walter E. Klotzback, retired assistant chief inspector of the New York City Police Department, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: 85-Truck Supply Convoy Reaches Besieged City, Kabul Officials Say
description: The Afghan Government relieved pressure on the besieged city of Jalalabad today when a convoy of 85 supply trucks that had been delayed by guerrilla ambushes and by the destruction of a strategic bridge broke through to the city, according to Government officials here.

title: Lest We Rush Into Executing the Innocent
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills Deciding on Smith
description: The Buffalo Bills aren't saying whether they will keep Bruce Smith, their two-time All-Pro defensive end, who has signed an offer sheet with the Denver Broncos for a reported $7.5 million over five years.

title: High Voltage Increases Its Offer for Universal
description: Pressing onward in its three-month battle to acquire control of the Universal Foods Corporation of Milwaukee, the High Voltage Engineering Corporation has sweetened its tender offer for the food concern to $38 a share in cash, or a total price of $657 million.

title: More Treatment for Jensen
description: Jim Jensen, an anchor of several Channel 2 news broadcasts, including its 6 P.M. program, has been moved ''to an in-patient care facility outside the New York metropolitan area for treatment of severe depression,'' the CBS-owned station said yesterday. The station said the treatment was likely to be ''extended.'' Mr. Jensen, who recently celebrated his 25th year with Channel 2, has been absent from its news broadcasts since mid-February.

title: Review/Music; Yoel Levi Replaces Tennstedt
description: The New York Philharmonic, confronted by the sobering news that Klaus Tennstedt would have to cancel his three-week conducting engagement and undergo surgery to replace his left hip, has filled gaps in the subscription schedule by calling on two veterans and a comparative unknown. Deputizing for the German conductor, whose hip operation is the latest in a series of medical problems, will be Leonard Bernstein in Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony and Robert Shaw in Haydn's ''Creation.''

title: Small Babies With Big Problems
description: From 1984 to 1987, the number of low-birthweight babies born in New York City rose notably, in three years erasing a decade of progress. That's another alarming symptom of the crack epidemic in cities across the country.

title: Watkins Offers A Plan to Focus On Atom Waste
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, in his first major written statement on pollution at the nation's production complex for nuclear weapons, outlined a five-year program yesterday to figure out what needs to be cleaned up most urgently and how and when to do it.

title: Bishop Moore, Retiring, Renews a Warning
description: On Easter Sunday 13 years ago, at the height of the New York City fiscal crisis, Bishop Paul Moore Jr., the head of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, delivered a dramatic sermon in which he pleaded with the corporate leaders of the city to show their faith by investing in New York.

title: Patents; A Satellite For Small Businesses
description: Clay T. Whitehead, a former president of the Hughes Aircraft Company's satellite subsidiary, has developed a satellite for small businesses.

title: Reviews/Dance; Nine Pieces in Homage to Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn
description: The homage to Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn presented by the Center Dance Collective on Wednesday at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace offered a good deal of instruction about the work of those two innovative American modern-dance choreographers and performers. The introduction offered by Michelle Mathesius, founder of the company in 1979, and comments and projected photographs that served as preface to each number were fascinating and invaluable. Strangely, however, most of the nine dances were a good deal less vivid.

title: SANDINISTAS ASSAIL RENEWED REBEL AID
description: The Nicaraguan Government denounced a new American plan for aid to anti-Sandinista rebels today, declaring that the plan violates a recent peace accord calling for the dismantling of the rebels' bases in Honduras.

title: Korean Leader Turns to Compromise
description: When President Roh Tae Woo surprised South Korea and his own party this week by canceling a referendum on his first year in office, the country braced for more of the chaos and protests that have marked its uneasy transition to democracy.

title: Winfield Feels Better After Back Surgery
description: Dave Winfield, the Yankees' injured right fielder, underwent surgery this morning to remove a herniated disk in his lower back and is expected to remain hospitalized for several days. Jeff Klein, the player's attorney, said it was not known when Winfield would begin a rehabilitation program or how soon he might expect to return to the team.

title: Readings of Yeats
description: The Yeats Drama Foundation is to present a reading on April 8 at 5:30 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Senator from Minnesota, will be the host. He will read selections from Yeats's work, as will Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Hugh L. Carey, former Governor of New York, and the actresses Tammy Grimes and Viveca Lindfors. The benefit is for the 50th-anniversary celebration of Yeats at Queens College April 9 to 15. Tickets: $100. Information: (914) 693-5251.

title: How McCloy Served Cause of Disarmament
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Gas Air-Conditioner Said to Reduce Costs
description: By taking a fresh look at some old technology, Frank E. Wicks, a mechanical engineer, has designed a gas-powered air-conditioner that he said could cut cooling bills in half.

title: U.S. Wool Output Up 5%
description: United States wool production increased 5 percent last year, to 89.2 million pounds, the Agriculture Department said today. The number of sheep shorn totaled 11.5 million, also up 5 percent, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its annual report.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I understand the meaning of remorse. I have remorse - for losing Lisa - I have remorse for losing my life.'' - Joel B. Steinberg. [ 32:4. ]

title: Beth Slingerland, 89, a Dyslexia Educator
description: Beth Slingerland, a widely known educator in the field of dyslexia, died Wednesday at the Judson Park Retirement Home in Seattle. She was 89 years old.

title: Sears Opens Specialty Store
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company this week opened its first Sears Ltd. store, a specialty store with brand-name merchandise, on the Near North Side of Chicago.

title: Picketing Of Eastern Is Curbed
description: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy filing of Eastern Airlines issued a temporary restraining order yesterday prohibiting the machinists' union from disrupting the airline's operations at Logan International Airport in Boston.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: Hard-Driving Banker Hits High-Rate Wall
description: By acting like a hard-charging Wall Street trader, David L. Paul has turned the Centrust Savings Bank of Miami into the largest and fastest-growing savings and loan association in the Southeast.

title: Gunman Killed In Robbery Attempt
description: One gunman was killed and four others were arrested last evening in a gun battle outside a Washington Heights beer warehouse the men had tried to rob, the police said.

title: Reviews/Music; Eight Amateur Choruses Have Their Day in the Sun
description: Mid-America Productions is the creation of a former Louisiana music professor named Peter Tiboris. Since 1984, with gathering momentum, Mr. Tiboris has presented concerts in Carnegie Hall and Avery Fisher Hall featuring combined college, adult and high-school choruses. Originally they were accompanied by the American Symphony. Now the instrumental support is provided by Mr. Tiboris's own assembly of freelancers, which he calls the Manhattan Philharmonic, or by visiting community and youth orchestras.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-8 A Central America policy accord that commits Washington to aid Nicaraguan rebels and support the Central American peace efforts was struck by President Bush and Congressional leaders. Page 1 News analysis: The policy accord represents a new approach: Rather than trying to overthrow the Sandinistas, the Bush Administration hopes to prod them toward democracy with diplomatic pressure. 1 Congress appears to support Contra aid plan 7 Nicaragua says plan violates peace agreement 6 A leftist coalition in El Salvador, the Democratic Convergence, had a dismal showing in Sunday's presidential elections because voters failed to distinguish it from the Marxist-led guerrillas, the party leader said. 8 British cathedrals are crumbling, and custodians are asking wealthy foreigners to help save them. Age, pollution and deferred maintenance have created cracks in medieval stones and spires. 8 Italian Communists have a new look. They are emphasizing ecology, feminism and family issues in the hope of attracting an electorate that no longer seems interested in Marx and the masses. 8 At the Buchenwald site now, no mention of Jews 8 Stalemate in Iran-Iraq peace talks has begun to worry Arab nations, particulary Kuwait. Reports say Iran has bought many weapons from Eastern Europe. 3 Monitoring Iran-Iraq cease-fire: a precarious balancing act 3 No major discord in South Korea has been created by President Roh Tae Woo's decision to cancell a referendum on his first year in office. Many people seem tired of conflict. 4 Japan has assured the United States that at least 35 percent of a jet fighter the two governments want to build together would be made in the United States, Bush officials said. 33 Kabul reports that supply convoy has reached besieged city 3 National 9-10, 28, 42 A tanker ran aground and ruptured25 miles from the southern end of the Trans Alaska Pipeline, spewing her cargo into water rich in marine life. It is the largest tanker spill in United States history. 1 A review of a Colorado dam project near Denver was ordered by the E.P.A., which said a dam could cause ''the very heavy, final and irremediable loss of an environmental treasure.'' 1 Defense Secretary Cheney scolded the Air Force Chief of Staff for talking to lawmakers about compromise on a major issue. The rebuke was apparently intended to establish Mr. Cheney's authority. 1 An unmanned Delta rocket lifted off, carrying a satellite into space as part of the Bush Administration's first Star Wars experiment and the first to last more than a few hours. 9 A five-year nuclear waste program to figure out what needs to be cleaned up most urgently was outlined by the Energy Secretary in his first major statement on waste from nuclear weapons production. 9 New rules are expected on licensing of reactors 33 Oliver North's side asked the judge in his trial to compel Ronald Reagan to appear as the defense's lead-off witness. No decision is expected before Tuesday. 28 The anti-drug focus on Washington is part of an Administration plan to heighten the Government's role in the ''Federal city'' and create a model for other cities, a Bush aide said. 10 Lawmaker hears powerful voice against guns: retirees 10 Adults will become Roman Catholics by the thousands tonight and Easter morning in a new baptism ritual of total immersion - the Rite of Christian Initiation for Adults. 9 An Indian activist, Timothy Jacobs, had his bail set at $100,000 bond. He faces face 14 kidnapping charges in North Carolina for holding hostages at a newspaper last year. 9 A Washington real estate developer has agreed to pay up to $150 million in cash and assumed debt for control of the Ritz Carlton hotels in New York and Washington. 34 U.S. charges Lockheed unit with 440 safety violations 33 Regional 29-32

title: Polaroid's 22% Buyback Plan Is Heavily Oversubscribed
description: A day after a major victory in its effort to stay independent, the Polaroid Corporation said today that its offer to buy back 22 percent of its shares had been heavily oversubscribed.

title: Ye Gods! It's a Heist! Get Tracy!
description: If Dick Tracy could leave the two-dimensional world of the funnies to solve just one real-life crime, he would rush here to the Museum of Cartoon Art. A villain, still at large, has swiped some of the comic strips that documented the square-jawed shamus's work and captivated Americans for decades.

title: North's Defense Asks That the Court Call Reagan
description: Defense attorneys in the trial of Oliver L. North asked the court today to compel former President Ronald Reagan to appear as a witness.

title: I.B.M. Workers Told to Avoid U.S. Carriers While Abroad
description: International Business Machines Corp. said today that it had notified its employees worldwide to avoid travel on American air carriers to and from Europe and the Middle East until the end of April on the basis of a terrorist alert issued by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Coping: With Learning to Drive
description: Now that she's well into her 60's, Millie Addolorato figures it is her turn. On May 1, she says, she is going to walk out of her house in the Bronx and pick up her ticket to freedom.

title: Four Brothers Sentenced to Jail in Drug Case
description: Four brothers convicted of leading a crack ring that supplied up to half the city's users from 1982 to 1988 were sentenced today to long prison terms and large fines.

title: Bond of $100,000 Is Set for Indian Who Took Over Newspaper Office
description: A judge set a $100,000 bond today for Timothy Jacobs, an American Indian who is charged with kidnapping in connection with the takeover of a newspaper office here.

title: Crumbling English Cathedrals Go Abroad for Aid
description: The medieval cathedrals of England are crumbling, and their custodians are looking with increasing desperation to wealthy private donors in Britain, the United States and elsewhere to save them.

title: Boggs Speaks Out
description: In an interview with Barbara Walters that was broadcast last night on the ABC program ''20-20,'' Wade Boggs, the Boston Red Sox third baseman, said Margo Adams threatened to make his life difficult if he broke off their four-year affair. Boggs said he worried Adams would blackmail him with pictures she had taken of them.

title: Agency Rental Car
description: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said its chairman, Samuel J. Frankino, had held talks with an unidentified part about the possible sale of his 55 percent stake. Mr. Frankino said that if a sale were to take place, it would be part of a deal in which other shareholders would receive the same price per share. Mr. Frankino owns 12.9 million common shares, or about 55 percent of Agency's stock.

title: Harvard, Minnesota, B.C., Providence Take 1-0 Leads
description: Ed Krayer had a goal and an assist to lead Harvard to a 4-2 victory over Lake Superior State tonight in the first game of their two-of-three-game National Collegiate Athletic Association series.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: Midwest; Orangemen Hold Off Missouri, 83-80
description: Derrick Coleman shook off persistent back problems and Sherman Douglas took charge down the stretch as Syracuse ignited its running game and streaked past Missouri, 83-80, and into the championship game of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Diesel Fuel Tax Exemption
description: Bowing to pressure from farm-state lawmakers, the Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would allow small wholesalers and some retailers to sell diesel fuel without paying tax.

title: Homicides In New York in 1988
description: Homicides in New York City last year totaled a record 1,896, according to official Police Department statistics released yesterday. Almost 37 percent of the slayings were drug-related.

title: Review/Film Festival; 18, Out of Sync With the World and Vaguely Disbelieving
description: Made on a shoestring - and a very small shoestring at that, the $15,000 budget recommended by Rick Schmidt in his book ''Feature Filmmaking at Used Car Prices'' - Mr. Schmidt's ''Morgan's Cake'' is a deadpan, unpretentious delight. The title character, played by the film maker's son, Morgan Schmidt-Feng, is no less comically out of sync with the world around him than the gorilla-suited David Warner character in the 1966 movie for which Morgan was named. ''Morgan's Cake'' adopts his point of view and reflects his bewilderment in sly, fresh, unexpectedly comic ways.

title: The U.N.'s Gulf War Balancing Act
description: Every Thursday a small white plane bearing United Nations insignia ferries a Yugoslav general from Baghdad to Teheran, or in the reverse direction.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: East; Duke Rolls Past Minnesota and Into Regional Final
description: Not that the Duke Blue Devils needed any added inspiration at this point of the season, but as they sat before televisions on Thursday night and watched highly-ranked teams reach the end of their seasons, the reminder was clear. All it takes is one bad night. Maybe their intentness would have driven the Devils without the knowledge that other highly-seeded teams had been pushed out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. But against Minnesota, the lowest-seeded team remaining in the field, the Devils took control in the first six minutes of an 87-70 victory tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Cheney Rebukes Air Force Chief For Arms Talk With Legislators
description: In an extraordinary public rebuke apparently aimed at establishing his control over the military, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney took the Air Force Chief of Staff sharply to task today for discussing with members of Congress a possible compromise on a major strategic issue.

title: G.M. Plant to Shut
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would shut its assembly plant in Linden next week to reduce inventories of Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta cars. The shutdown will affect about 140 workers. Ward's Automotive Reports, a weekly trade journal, said that as of Feb. 28 G.M. had a 103-day supply of the Corsica-Beretta cars on hand. Over all, G.M. had an 83-day supply of new cars, compared with an average 78-day supply for the domestic industry, Ward's said. G.M. said the plant was scheduled to resume production on April 3.

title: Financial Difficulty
description: The man selected by Baseball Magazine as the Relief Pitcher of the 1970's needs financial relief. Rollie Fingers has filed a petition in Bankruptcy Court in San Diego seeking liquidation of his debts. The 42-year-old former relief ace with Oakland, San Diego and Milwaukee has assets estimated at less than $50,000 and liabilities of more than $1 million. Documents list creditor claims totaling $4.2 million.

title: One Girl Killed And 4 Are Hurt As Car Crashes
description: A 14-year-old girl was killed and four teen-age girls were seriously injured Thursday when their car plowed into trees shortly after they had left school to begin their Easter break, the police said.

title: Everett Callender, Securities Analyst, 83
description: Everett Callender, a former securities analyst, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Reviews/Film; A Tippling Detective vs. a Low-I.Q. Mob
description: John Frankenheimer, the director of one of the wittiest conspiracy movies ever made, ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' is now responsible for one of the more trivial, ''Dead-Bang.'' The movie opened yesterday at the Loew's 84th Street and other theaters.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., a subsidiary of Amax Inc., is expected to announce plans to build a $1 billion aluminium smelter in Canada, the Quebec Government said.

title: ON WRITING: LET THERE BE LESS
description: LEAD: A point of information for those with time on their hands: if you were to read 135 books a day, every day, for a year, you wouldn't finish all the books published annually in the United States. Now add to this figure, which is upward of 50,000, the 100 or so literary magazines; the scholarly, political and scientific journals (there are 142 devoted to sociology alone), as well as the glossy magazines, of which bigger and shinier versions are now spawning, and you'll appreciate the amount of lucubration that finds its way into print.

title: Shopping for a House From Home - by Flipping on the TV
description: Although newspapers for years have been the medium of choice for advertising home sales, television has recently moved into the picture. Realtors are now running half-hour programs - virtually long commercials - to sell homes on cable and network television.

title: Nothing Amiss in Circulating Bush Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Artist's Hot New Medium: Cha-Cha
description: Phoebe Simpson, 18 years old, admits to being ''a bit embarrassed when Mom practices hip movements in elevators or a waltz step in the middle of Bloomingdale's.''

title: All's Not Quiet on the Legal Front
description: The computer industry has the ''look and feel'' these days of a litigious free-for-all. The current matches on the fight card include Apple Computer Inc. v. the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company; the Ashton-Tate Corporation v. Fox Software Inc. and the Santa Cruz Operation; the Intel Corporation v. NEC; the International Business Machines Corporation v. Fujitsu; the Lotus Development Corporation v. Paperback Software and Mosaic Software; Digital Communications v. Softklone Distributing, and even Apple Corps Ltd. v. Apple Computer. And these are just the main events.

title: With Futures Under Fire, A Watchdog Feels the Heat
description: In a majestic Senate committee room, flanked with ornate mirrors and decorated with impressive Victorian chandeliers, a Government official faces a panel of powerful lawmakers, who bombard her with complicated questions. The official is Wendy Gramm, chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and not only is she in the hot seat, so is her agency.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE COMPLETE 'PEER GYNT' The Hartford Stage Company will perform the uncut ''Peer Gynt,'' Henrik Ibsen's fantasy based on the Norse legend of a young man's wanderings through universal perils and pleasures. Because of its length, the piece is usually performed in truncated versions.

title: As Seen From Boston . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Hattler Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Wendy Dawn Hattler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Hattler of Ardmore, Pa., to Alan Dessy, the son of Ronnie Dessy of New York and the late Andrew Dessy, took place last evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Marshall Maltzman performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Boston University, is a buyer at Burberry's Ltd. in New York. The bridegroom is the vice president at Dessy Creations, a bridal wear manufacturer in New York.

title: There's a Rain Problem, but the One at the Tap Is Worse
description: AFTER Mayor Edward I. Koch's drought emergency declaration last week, residents of New York City and their northern neighbors are being forced for the third time this decade to cut water use. Without any conclusive evidence that the area is experiencing long-term shifts in weather, the question becomes: why?

title: Vessel That Downed Iran Jet To Get a New Captain in May
description: Capt. Will C. Rogers 3d of the Navy will give up command of the guided-missile cruiser Vincennes in May, a change the Navy called routine and unrelated to the possible terrorist bombing of a van driven by Captain Rogers's wife.

title: A Vote for Soviet Democracy
description: The election today in the Soviet Union breaks with a 70-year tradition that might be called shamocracy. In all those years, the forms of democratic government were travestied by uncontested elections and make-believe parliaments. The reality has been one-party rule. As cynics put it, the very name U.S.S.R. comprised four lies: It was neither a union, a republic or socialist, and its soviets, or local councils, were powerless.

title: The Core Curriculum And the Real Thing
description: The faculty and administrators at Fairleigh Dickinson were pleased with the objective reporting on our new university core curriculum (''Fairleigh Dickinson's Core Curriculum Appraised,'' Jan. 22). Several letters to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 19 suggest, however, a misunderstanding of the program and its objectives.

title: Leah Ruth Robinson to Wed
description: Leah Ruth Robinson and John Pierce Rousmaniere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rousmaniere of Southbury, Conn., plan to marry in May, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Robinson of La Anna, Pa., and St. James City, Fla., have announced.

title: LANGUAGE LOVERS MOVE THEIR LIPS
description: WORDSTRUCK A Memoir. By Robert MacNeil. Illustrated. 230 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: B. J. and Bill Gedney: Hat Designers
description: Many young and fash ionable heads seen about town today may owe their elan to B. J. Gedney, 35 years old, and her husband Bill, 38, the couple behind Hat Attack.

title: San Francisco's Airport Must Grow, but Where?
description: Month in, month out, the often fogbound San Francisco International Airport ranks at or near the bottom among major airports in terms of arrival of airliners on time.

title: Pipeline Proposal Is Still Unloved, But Very Much Alive
description: THE route has been changed, the proposal has been enhanced and the public has been heard from and will be heard from some more. But after three years, the popularity of the Iroquois gas pipeline project remains as it was: it has some friends and quite a few enemies.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THOMAS THE OBSCURE. By Maurice Blanchot. Translated by Robert Lamberton. (Station Hill Press, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $8.95.) ''Thomas the Obscure'' was written between 1932 and 1940 and was published in 1941. During this period, the French novelist and critic Maurice Blanchot wrote for the extreme right-wing publications Reaction Combat and Revue Francaise.

title: Having a Good Time To Help a Good Cause
description: LEAD: PARTYING with a purpose is the theme of New Directions, the recently formed fund-raising branch of the American Cancer Society's Westchester division. The group, part of a nationwide New Directions program, is for young professionals who want to raise money for a good cause and have a good time doing it.

title: Ecological Threats, Rich-Poor Tensions
description: IN scenes reminiscent of science-fiction movies in which the world's peoples band together to face a common threat from outer space, delegates from around the globe have come together in the last month to confront the dangers posed by planetary warming and the depletion of the earth's protective ozone shield. But all nations are not in harmony. International gatherings in New Delhi and London have also made it clear that a conflict has developed between the industrialized countries and the third world.

title: THE PRIEST, THE POLITICIAN AND THE PARTY LINE
description: HIS EMINENCE AND HIZZONER A Candid Exchange. By John O'Connor and Edward I. Koch. 366 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Louis Malle's World of Innocence
description: There are moments in the best Louis Malle films when it is possible to believe in innocence, in an Edenic world of childhood goodness that is soon shattered in some understated, irrevocable way. AU REVOIR LES ENFANTS, now available on video (Orion Home Video, $79.98), is Mr. Malle's magnificently subtle and profoundly moving account of a Jewish boy hidden in a Catholic school in France during World War II. The film, made in 1987, is remarkably quiet and brilliantly composed; the danger, secrecy and depth of its subject is captured in the shy inhibition and intense eyes of the hunted Jean (Raphael Fejto) and the slow recognition of evil by his best friend, Julien (Gaspard Manesse). The film's fluid style, full of closeups, maintains its power on a small screen.

title: The Bones of Indians, But Not the Cheif
description: SKELETAL remains displayed for many years at the Historical Society of the Tarrytowns are those of two American Indians, but forensic scientists have concluded that neither was Chief Mamaronock, as had long been thought.

title:
OUTDOORS;
GEAR IMPROVES WITH AGE
description: LEAD: Converging on the recent R. W. Oliver's Second Annual High Roller's fishing tackle auction in Marlborough, Mass., like bluefish in a party boat's chum slick, well-heeled collectors spent record amounts for old and not-so-old angling gear, including $19,000 for a reel, $17,500 for a rod and $5,750 for a fish decoy.

title: Anne Fannon, Banker, to Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marcy B. Fannon of Bronxville, N.Y., and Saunderstown, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Anne Linwood Fannon to John Lockman Appleby 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Appleby of Atlanta. An April wedding is planned.

title: In Pakistan, Women Seek Basic Rights
description: Mammuna Khalil adjusted her shawl to cover a little more of her hair and addressed the mosque administrator with a look of determination. Mrs. Khalil, a high school English teacher, wants to come to the mosque to study the Koran, a right she believes is unfairly denied to Pakistani women by conservative religious leaders.

title: Joseph Romer, Executive, 76
description: Joseph Romer, a former account executive in the advertising department of The New York Times, died Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan from complications after suffering a stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Q and A
description: London Flats

title: Cup-Defense Plans Proceed
description: Concern about falling behind in the race for the America's Cup has prompted two defense syndicates to move ahead with preparations without waiting for a court decision on whom the cup belongs to.

title:
>GARDENING;
Taming Vines on Trees or on the Ground
description: LEAD: IT'S not uncommon for English ivy to be planted as a ground cover under a tree canopy. Its glossy, dark green foliage makes it desirable for this purpose. English ivy spreads its verdant carpet by creeping along the ground or by climbing. As it climbs, the juvenile creeper will ultimately transform into a mature, flowering plant that will produce seeds to perpetuate the species.

title: June Wedding for Laura Call
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David L. Call of Ithaca, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Laura Ellen Call to Robert Charles Andolina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. Andolina of Clifton Park, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: FICTION
description: MIDNIGHT. By Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) The thriller writer Dean R. Koontz's latest novel, ''Midnight,'' takes the theme of demonic possession a giant step beyond mere aliens from outer space. A set of mysterious disappearances and suspicious deaths in the northern California town of Moonlight Cove brings together an undercover F.B.I. agent named Sam Booker and Tessa Lockland, a documentary film producer who suspects that the local police report of her sister's suicide has been falsified. They discover that someone has been turning the town's citizens into humanoids. So far, this sounds like pretty ordinary horror-movie stuff. But Mr. Koontz's characters - even the zombies - are fallible, complex and human. (For example, one woman who has been ''converted'' into a ''New Person'' bitterly misses sleep, even though her husband assures her she no longer requires it.) Sam and Tessa ally themselves with Harry Talbot, a disabled Vietnam veteran who, despite his dependence on a wheelchair, enjoys many of life's amenities thanks to his Labrador, Moose, who performs such tasks as fetching cold Coors from the fridge. The plot develops more by an eerie, foglike osmosis than by the march of events, and the skillfully drawn characters are lifelike and sympathetic. This is good, page-turning fiction designed to keep a reader up well beyond midnight.

title: POSTINGS: Subsidized Rentals in Warwick; Housing the Elderly
description: A project to house the elderly in Warwick, N.Y., is to be formally opened Friday as the third phase of an ambitious plan to provide tax-subsidized apartments to the growing number of elderly in the Orange County village. Named the Creekside Apartments, the $4.5 million development is providing 65 one-bedroom apartments to eligible people who are either 62 years of age or older, or 55 and handicapped.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; For Traditionalists and Fans of Country French
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Cafe Luxembourg

title: LOUISVILLE TRIES NOTED AUTHORS AS PLAYWRIGHTS
description: Ever since its first festival of new American plays opened at the Actors Theater of Louisville 12 years ago with ''The Gin Game'' - an unknown two-hander by the equally unknown D. L. Coburn that went on to win a Pulitzer Prize - it has been one of the most closely monitored and fertile sources for new American drama.

title: NONFICTION
description: DEAF IN AMERICA: Voices From a Culture. By Carol Padden and Tom Humphries. (Harvard University, $17.95.) Deafness means a great deal more than simply being unable to hear. In ''Deaf in America,'' Carol Padden and Tom Humphries - themselves deaf - argue that the deaf have developed a distinct culture that includes sign language, shared experiences and ideas that often set them apart from the hearing world. (Ms. Padden, who teaches communications at the University of California, San Diego, and Mr. Humphries, who is associate dean of the San Diego Community College District, describe this culture with the upper-case ''Deaf.'') The authors' most persuasive arguments are anecdotes about deaf families, and in particular about how deaf children see the world. One boy who grew up in a large family had been frustrated in his attempts to communicate with a girl next door. He did not realize quite what the problem was, however, until one day at the girl's home ''her mother walked up to them and animatedly began to move her mouth. As if by magic, the girl picked up a dollhouse and moved it to another place.'' The puzzled boy immediately ran home to ask his mother about the poor girl's affliction. The book becomes far less accessible to the uninitiated reader when the authors analyze the poetry and theater of the deaf. Tragically, however, the community does not reach the lives of all deaf people, particularly the uneducated. ''Deaf in America'' is a fascinating glimpse into a world unfamiliar to most of us.

title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets
description: I HOLD the envelope in my hand. Even before I open it, I know the contents. The same letter comes every five years when my college reunion years roll around. Mostly I consider myself to be leading a happy and active life, so why do I delay opening this correspondence from my alma mater? Because I know it will shake my self-esteem and will make me question what it is that I'm doing with my time when it seems that there is never enough of it for all I want to do.

title: Helen Hadley to Marry P. L. Johnstone in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. B. Hadley of Huntington, L.I., have announced plans for an April 15 wedding for their daughter, Helen Morris Hadley, and Peter LeGrand Johnstone, a son of Robert and the Rev. Mary Johnstone of Newport, R.I.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exposed concrete under the white clapboard around the outside of our house is painted white. When it rains, dirt splashes up onto the white and it is difficult to clean. What can I put down to prevent this splashing?

title: Magna Cum Laude Isn't Everything
description: In criticizing Charles Schnabolk's ''Cheers for the Lower Half'' (Opinion page, Jan. 8) Robert Wechsler's letter to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 12 confuses the point of the article. He should have read it one more time; it was, indeed, a parody of our obsession with grades and did not, as Mr. Wechsler suggests, downgrade intellectual achievement.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: In one of the great accumulations of proofs and essays, that of the Kings of Egypt, ego and collecting interests intersected. What can be more narcissistic than collecting portraits of oneself?

title: Rover and Mittens Offered Chance to Give Gift of Life
description: A hospital here is seeking new breeds of blood donors - dogs and cats - to help set up a blood bank for pets.

title: For Sale,
description: HAVE you heard the story about the $5,499,999,999 lost in a prime real estate investment? Built on the Long Island Sound in Shoreham, at a total cost of $5.5 billion, the famous nonfunctioning Lilco Nuclear Power Station will probably be sold to the State of New York for one lousy buck.

title: A Source of Pride In a Step Taken
description: Further to Paul Feiner's letter [ Westchester Opinion, Feb. 12 ] , I would like to clarify a point about his reference to the Visiting Nurse Services in Westchester and our recruitment efforts at the Elmsford Motor Lodge (a homeless hotel). Although Mr. Feiner accurately pointed out that our job fair attracted more than a dozen inquiries, we are very pleased that one person currently is enrolled in our Winner program.

title: Three Men Killed in Holdup At a Social Club in Brooklyn
description: Three patrons of a Brooklyn social club were killed early yesterday and another was wounded when a band of gunmen burst into the club, robbed customers of cash and jewels and then opened fire on them, the police said.

title: Why Seek The Sound Of the Past?
description: The early-music movement, once the domain of antiquarian scholars and minimally skilled dilettantes, has been gathering professional momentum for decades. It is now a small steamroller, if not a juggernaut. The movement has spawned a new generation of well-trained musicians who play their instruments well and proselytize for correct performance practices with evangelical zeal. Not surprisingly, a large crop of serious publications has arisen to cater to them and their expanding audience. One of the latest, Historical Performance, contains in its second issue (Fall 1988) a probably incomplete list of 54 early-music periodicals, 24 of them published in the United States. As I write, someone is no doubt planning another one, perhaps aimed exclusively at performers on the lira organizzata or the baryton.

title: Lori Schneider to Wed Dr. Jean-Pierre Riou
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schneider of Springville, S.I., have announced April 30 wedding plans for their daughter, Lori Beth Schneider, and Dr. Jean-Pierre Riou, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Henri Riou of New York.

title: Black Family Shares Spotlight in a New Soap Opera
description: ''Two families, three lifetimes. Daytime drama with a difference. Black and white - in color!'' The on-air promotional spots for NBC's forthcoming''Generations'' drive their message home with fast cuts and throbbing percussion. They suggest that the new soap opera, which will make its debut in the New York metropolitan area tomorrow afternoon from 12:30 to 1 on Channel 4, has something novel to offer fans of the genre: ''Generations'' will introduce daytime television's first black family as a central focus into what has up to now been a conspicuously white-dominated world.

title: Review/Film Festival; Iranian Director's Mournful Trilogy
description: Though its production company is the Arts Bureau of the Organization for the Propagation of Islamic Thought, the Iranian film ''The Peddler'' is in no way a work of propaganda. In fact, it takes for granted a devastating, almost unbearably high level of misery. Though it aims at times for an incongruously rueful, almost whimsical tone, its overall impression is one of unadulterated suffering. ''The Peddler'' is terribly sad, and perhaps even more powerful than it means to be.

title: Notes of Coming 'Times'
description: The air is clean here in the rural southwest, though not yet gentled by spring, which is coming late. The Dordogne flows placidly, no longer a busy commercial artery now that all the roads are good. Medieval chateaus with battlements still stand somber guard on many hillsides, but now and then the sky is set roaring by jet fighters practicing from the big air base at Toulouse.

title: Request Backlog Slows Access to Data
description: WHEN Barbara J. Collins, a lawyer in Hartford, needed records of the New Haven Personnel Commission for a labor hearing, she turned to the State Freedom of Information Commission, whose motto is, ''Information delayed is information denied.''

title: A Cozy Oasis in Busy New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN'S restaurant choices, as befits a university town, are becoming increasingly international. The latest to appear on the scene is a Vietnamese restaurant, Saigon City, on Chapel Street at the corner of Park Street.

title: Pursuing Computer Crimes
description: LEAD: ONE HUNDRED corporate officials paid $35 each and spent six hours on a recen Wednesday to learn about a crime authorities said they thought was a widespread and expensive secret.

title: Amanda Cluett, Banker, to Wed William Stanton
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Cluett of San Francisco and Blue Hill, Me., of the engagement of their daughter Amanda Bird Cluett to William Brook Stanton, a son of Emily Hart Stanton of Darien, Conn., and the late John Pulsifer Stanton. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: 'Glory' Resurrects Its Black Heroes
description: The Matthew Broderick who stood silently before 200 black soldiers and one Panavision camera was certainly no teen-age Eugene Morris Jerome. This was a mustachioed, portly, somber-looking Matthew Broderick, dressed in the midnight blue coat and crimson sash of a Union Army colonel. And as he began to speak his lines, he seemed very much older than his 26 years.

title: Q and A
description: Primary Residence

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ARK SAKURA, by Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. (Vintage International, $8.95.) Inside a hollowed-out mountain, a Japanese beggar assembles a community of outcasts intent on surviving nuclear war. Last year our reviewer, Edmund White, said this novel is ''highly cinematic [ with its ] psychological observation that is suggested through close-ups; lots of punchy dialogue; a convincing sense of place; a building of suspense; and a pervasive atmosphere of sexuality and violence.'' WINFIELD: A Player's Life, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Avon, $4.50.) Dave Winfield's book hasJU been updated to include the latest skirmishes in his legendary war with George Steinbrenner. But this story of life with the New York Yankees is not the broadside it is often made out to be, Allen Barra said here last year. ''After all the torment and public humiliation Mr. Steinbrenner has put Mr. Winfield through, this book is a very light revenge indeed,'' he said. ''What 'Winfield' does offer is a straightforward account of how the life of a baseball player worth $23 million is different from everyone else's.'' LONG DISTANCES, by Fabienne Marsh. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) When Michael takes a sabbatical in London to finish a book of poetry, his wife, Kate, a producer of television documentaries, starts feeling less and less like a woman in love. By telling the story as a modern-day version of an 18th-century epistolary novel, Fabienne Marsh ''puts a fresh spin'' on the tale, Bethami Probst said here last year. GATES OF EDEN: American Culture in the Sixties, by Morris Dickstein. (Penguin, $8.95.) Many of those who went through the 60's remember the era more for its music and literature than for its politics. In 1977 our reviewer, Christopher Lasch, praised Morris Dickstein's book for considering both the failures and the triumphs of the cultural upheaval: ''His book makes the unqualified opposition of such critics as Philip Rahv, Saul Bellow and Daniel Bell seem flat and uninformative by comparison.'' THE STORY OF MY WIFE: The Reminiscences of Captain Storr, by Milan Fust. Translated by Ivan Sanders. (Vintage International, $8.95.) In a book-length monologue, an obsessively jealous husband rages against his wife's supposed infidelities - but are they real or imaginary? Written four decades ago by the Hungarian poet Milan Fust, this translation has appeared ''not a minute too soon,'' Amy Edith Johnson said last year in The Book Review. ''Literary fashion has just caught up with it.'' AGNES SMEDLEY: The Life and Times of an American Radical, by Janice R. MacKinnon and Stephen R. MacKinnon. (University of California, $12.95.) During China's Communist revolution, Agnes Smedley, an expatriate American journalist, traveled with the forces of Mao Zedong and is now buried outside Beijing. This is a ''first-rate'' biography of a woman who might be described as John Reed's counterpart in China, John Patrick Diggins said here in 1987. It is ''rich in detail, lucid in expression and judicious in interpretation.'' TRUST, by Mary Flanagan. (Pantheon, $8.95.) A very decent London lawyer becomes obsessed with the self-destructive mistress of an unsuccessful artist. ''The art world background against which much of the action takes place - some of it in London and some in New York - is rendered with crisp and telling strokes,'' Calvin Tomkins said in reviewing the novel here in 1988. FOR A NEW NOVEL: Essays on Fiction, by Alain Robbe-Grillet. Translated by Richard Howard. (Northwestern University, $9.95.) With their hard surface textures, the so-called new novels written by the likes of Alain Robbe-Grillet are hard for many readers to penetrate. In these essays, he explains why he writes that way. In 1966 Eliot Fremont-Smith said in The Times that the book ''shows the possibilities of the novel, and possible ways of thinking about the novel; and it shows how little most of us, writers, readers, critics, have dared to think.'' DEATHWATCH, by Ray Harrison. (Berkley, $3.50.) The body of an undercover policeman is found impaled on the railing of a London church, setting off a search for a murderer that climaxes with a chase in a hot-air balloon. ''It is all quite entertaining, in an easygoing way,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1986. A WOMAN OF EGYPT, by Jehan Sadat. (Pocket Books, $8.95.) As the wife of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, the author of these memoirs fought Islamic fundamentalists to promote women's rights. ''The book is most believable when it concentrates on Mrs. Sadat's own area of achievement - work to raise the consciousness and legal rights of Egyptian women,'' Barbara Slavin said here in 1987. A BOAT OFF THE COAST, by Stephen Dobyns. (Penguin, $3.95.) A Vietnam veteran named Tucker Morgan figures that his best ticket out of Belfast, Me., is a quick, one-time-only cocaine deal. Then Lowell Perry, a dockworker who sells information to the Feds, gets wind of the scheme. ''The author delves into his scene, and cares about his characters,'' Mark Childress said here in 1987. ''His tale of friendships, betrayal and greed has a dark and complex undercurrent.'' THE BELARUS SECRET: The Nazi Connection in America, by John Loftus. Edited by Nathan Miller. (Paragon House, $12.95.) Intent on fighting Communism, our Government recruited thousands of former Nazis, the author argues, later allowing them to settle in the United States. In 1982 The Times's Ralph Blumenthal said the book seems overstated but makes ''a persuasive case.''

title: Washington
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest the story about the renovated Union Station in Washington (Travel, Feb. 12).

title: Oyster Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebratng France's Bicentennial
description: MUSICAL performances, talks by scholars and French citizens, an exhibit of quilts and other programs in Connecticut will celebrate the 200th anniversary this year of the French Revolution.

title: Parrots, Dragons And the Uses of Enchantment
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' and ''Long Ago & Far Away'' have something in common: Both are wonderful and yet each leaves you feeling a bit sad, the stage production because it's a reminder of the sort of great musicals that aren't being made anymore, the television series because its unmistakable quality makes you keenly aware once again of the generally woeful state of programming for children in this country.

title: Some Tips on Taxes and Bank Ads
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q.I want to file my tax return, but the company I used to work for still hasn't sent me my W-2 form showing my 1988 wages. What should I do? A.You should contact your former employer and request that the document be sent to you, said Frank Keith, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service in Washington. ''Often, employers don't know the current address of former workers,'' he said. If that doesn't work, call the toll-free I.R.S. assistance number for your area and explain the situation. The I.R.S. will send you Form 4852, which you can use as a substitute W-2; if possible, use the year-to-date information on your last pay stub to report the wages you earned and the taxes you paid last year.

title: Separatists Fire at Yugoslav Police as Riots Go On
description: Ethnic Albanian rioters shot at the police today as Kosovo Province was shaken by a third consecutive day of violence, the official Tanyug press agency said.

title: Agony, Then Ecstasy: Senior Theses Are Done
description: Motorists driving past the College of Wooster at 4 P.M. last Monday may have been startled to see more than 400 students and faculty members marching.

title: Julius Eichel, at 93, Conscientious Objector
description: Julius Eichel, a conscientious objector in World Wars I and II who was twice charged with refusing to register for the draft, died Friday after surgery at Coney Island Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.

title: Poeschek Bolsters Defense
description: Rudy Poeschek still hasn't scored with anything but a haymaker or an uppercut, but in recent games he has quietly piled up the points in pursuit of what could be his most satisfying victory of his first, largely violent season in the National Hockey League. The points are elements of a case that argues: I can play, too.

title: Immigrant's Tale Inspires Grandson
description: That we are a nation of immigrants, fugitives from poverty, ghettos and pogroms, has been told over and over. Many immigrants settled in New York City. But not everyone.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; How Will the Yanks and Mets Do?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CHARTER PANEL LOOKS PAST RULING AND SEES FAR-REACHING CHANGES
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that the overhaul of New York City's government ordered by the United States Supreme Court last week should preserve all eight existing citywide and boroughwide posts, grant the five borough presidents a role in planning and development and enlarge the 35-member City Council.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Students 'Dying' In Opposition To Nuclear Arms
description: Ten University of Illinois students screamed in unison and collapsed in the snow, twitching.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Beijing
description: As it sheds the chilly sandstorms and its wintry pall of coal dust, Beijing seems to go through a metamorphosis: the trees and grass in the parks and the bustling activity at temples and monuments and marketplaces light up the place the way color brightens up a drab black and white picture.

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Winship
description: The engagement of Susan Winship to John Lauriston Koenig, a son of Angela P. Koenig of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Robert P. Koenig, has been made known by her parents, Persis Winship-Carter of Charlestown, R.I., and Dr. G. Montgomery Winship of Cromwell, Conn. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended a week ago in Reno, Nev. were the biggest ever, with a table count of 13,807 eclipsing a record set 21 years earlier in New York City. They were also slightly longer than usual, since the entry of 107 teams in the Vanderbilt Knockout made it necessary to play the final on Monday, when the other contestants had departed.

title: Battle Is Building Over Abortion
description: IF the United States Supreme Court decides to reverse or limit its 1973 decision guaranteeing the right to abortion, partisans on both sides of the issue in New Jersey predict that the state will erupt in a frenzy of legislative initiatives to limit the procedure.

title: AIDS and After
description: To the Editor:

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Midge Guerrera;
Telling Youth About Careers in the Arts
description: LEAD: IN March 1988, Midge Guerrera was appointed director of the New Jersey School of the Arts, a state-legislated arts education entity for artistically talented high school students.

title: Easter Racing
description: As the custodians of a sport that grew up in the Bible Belt, officials of the Nascar circuit make a point of not scheduling races on Easter Sunday. Accordingly, Paul Sawyer, the president of the Richmond International Raceway, was not surprised when his office was flooded with letters from irate fans protesting the decision to hold the Pontiac 400 at the track today.

title: Michigan Routs Virginia, 102-65
description: In college basketball, the ladder of success leads to the top of the rim where the victors take turns snipping down the net. As a token of their appreciation, the Michigan players invited Steve Fisher to take part in this traditional ceremony after the Southeast Regional final today, giving their coach a view he had never seen before.

title: New Name 'Dakota' Gets a Cold Shoulder
description: The Legislature has refused to call a referendum on dropping ''North'' and renaming this state Dakota, deciding North Dakota will be just as cold by any other name.

title: Trekking With the Kids in Nepal
description: IT was late in the afternoon of our hardest day of trekking in Nepal, a day in which we dropped from the frosty ridge of Tharepati at 11,800 feet to a suspension bridge over the Malemchi Khola nearly 4,000 feet lower. The views were spectacular, the people we met on the trail were friendly, and the thick evergreen and bamboo forest around us was rich with new discoveries. But the hours of steep downhill steps - and lurches - were taking their toll. I was suffering from ''memsahib knee,'' a fairly common hazard of trekking on underconditioned and, as appeared evident in my case, aging joints.

title: Reliving the Simple Joys of Stickball
description: part of the fun, I admit, was the challenge of seing whether it could actually be done. The university had a faintly outlined stickball ''plate'' on the wall of the Fine Arts Plaza. And, in my two years at Stony Brook, I had actually seen several students on the field. What if I wanted to play stickball again? Could I find some others to share the pleasure?

title: Selling Mortgages as the Rates Rise
description: EVEN in the best of times, anxiety and confusion are the hallmarks of shopping for mortgage money. And today, not only are interest rates at distressing heights, but they also are topsy-turvy - with unadorned adjustable-rate mortgages more costly than the safer option of fixed-rate financing.

title:
>GARDENING;
Taming Vines on Trees or on the Ground
description: LEAD: IT'S not uncommon for English ivy to be planted as a ground cover under a tree canopy. Its glossy, dark green foliage makes it desirable for this purpose. English ivy spreads its verdant carpet by creeping along the ground or by climbing. As it climbs, the juvenile creeper will ultimately transform into a mature, flowering plant that will produce seeds to perpetuate the species.

title: FICTION
description: THE RISING. By Edgar White. (Marion Boyars/Kampmann, $18.95.) ''West Indians,'' we are told in this first novel of a projected trilogy, ''never say no.'' Instead they slide around the negative with suggestion and innuendo, but God help those who misread the signals. Mother Frances rules the society of a small Caribbean island, manipulating her way unscathed through the prevailing hurricanes of sex and (usually) psychic violence. Hers is an unruly realm, a place where being part of ''the long-established elite . . . meant merely having come from two generations of money instead of one.'' A dynamism of self-creation pervades the island, but it's a dynamism that often goes wrong, as when Mother Frances' interminable maneuvers to shape the future unexpectedly end in the arrival of a great-grandson, Legion, the illegitimate offspring of her granddaughter Desmie and Carlton Wade, a local no-account. The story of what happens because of this disrupting event is given fine shape and color by Edgar White, a well-regarded dramatist born in Montserrat. With a flawless ear for local dialect and an equally discerning eye for island custom, Mr. White juices up an occasionally thin plot line with a bouncy calypso beat. Here the idly victimized women who routinely ''disappear from girlhood into woman,'' the men in whom ''desire and hatred moved together'' and the children who are trapped in an endemic boredom meet under the indifferent tropical sun, all wanting to escape their little island, but none quite knowing how. So when the bewildered Legion finally exits, he takes much of the place with him: a weight of memory, unfocused sexuality and a vague guilt, all of which promise to crowd the next volume of his story with the same strange and compelling energy that's on such fine display here.

title: Article 592589 -- No Title
description: Most passengers sitting side by side in the same airplane should pay about the same price for the identical service they are receiving. Today, 10 people who could reach out and touch one another on the same flight most likely have paid 10 different ticket prices. The highest price might be as much as five or six times the lowest, depending on when and where the ticket was purchased. Is this fair public policy? No.

title: The Aging Eye
description: WHEN MY 4-YEAR-OLD THRUSTS her latest drawing in front of me, I seem to grow older on the spot. I take my daughter's hand, push it and her picture back away from my nose, stretch my neck backward a couple of inches, and peer. At the age of 35, I am encountering one sign of age that no amount of exercise or high-fiber foods or Retin-A can forestall. I am becoming farsighted. It's harder and harder for me to read anything that isn't an arm's length away (and my arm keeps growing).

title: CLASH AT DARTMOUTH
description: As a Dartmouth alumnus, I keep hoping that an observer will come up with commentary that will bring participants to their senses. Alas, John Casey's piece (''At Dartmouth, the Clash of '89,'' Feb. 26) falls short. Most alumni, I suspect, would agree that there is precious little to like about The Dartmouth Review. However, the Review epitomizes what the First Amendment is designed to protect, and the college's trustees have failed to recognize that. Instead, the trustees have allowed the faculty and administration to pursue an agenda of retribution and suppression, thereby creating a public-relations nightmare that will haunt the college for years.

title: Princeton Varsity Edges Navy
description: The Princeton heavyweight varsity crew presented its new head coach, Gary Kilpatrick, with his first victory today, defeating Navy's varsity to retain the Navy-Princeton Rowing Cup.

title: Getting the First Taste of an Idea
description: HAVE you ever caught the moment when a child discovers the joy of imagery?

title: Paths of Glory, Giant Steps of Prudence
description: ''The paths of glory lead but to the grave,'' that memorable phrase from a poet of yesterday, Thomas Gray, whose words have never died, came close to leading me to a premature breakdown at the age of 10. As I sat in the crowded third-grade classroom, listening to the poetry being read aloud, I raised my hand it interrupt the gentle teacher who was determined to bring literature into our young lives and asked for an explanation of the short phrase.

title: Water Curbs, Higher Fees Loom for L.I. This Summer
description: LEAD: Long Islanders, who for generations have taken for granted the seemingly inexhaustible supply of tasty pure drinking water that flows beneath them, are facing a long hot summer in which many of them will be asked both to pay more for their water and use less of it.

title: Review/Music; 80 Singing Men of Estonia's State Choir
