description: When a new nationalism swept Europe at the beginning of the 19th century, some countries sought their identities in oratory, some in warfare, some in books. Estonia, it seems, began to sing.

title: . . . And From Washington
description: To the Editor:

title:
HERS;
Half a Century Of Sex Education
description: LEAD: MY GENERATION deserves a medal for surviving the sex revolution. Since I graduated from college in 1938, like most of my cohorts I grew up in the Age of Innocence, and I mean innocence. For us, sex meant ''male'' or ''female'' on a driver's license.

title: Art Stolen From 6 Museums Is Recovered; 2 Men Are Held
description: All but one of 25 decorative art objects brazenly stolen during visiting hours from six museums this year have been recovered, and two Brooklyn men have been arrested, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Why Business Turns to Teen-Agers
description: In the last few years, as America's jobless rate plummeted to the lowest levels since the mid-1970's, ''Hiring'' signs have proliferated at fast-food restaurants, department stores, supermarkets and countless other businesses. Increasingly, those jobs are going to people like Margie Lobaton in Warwick, R.I., and Patrick Gannaway in Huntington Beach, Calif. Both are 15-year-old high school sophomores. With a growing shortage of labor nationwide, employers are reaching deeper into the labor pool, tapping workers as young as 14 and 15 to do jobs that go well beyond baby-sitting and lawn mowing. ''It was rare until two or three years ago to find kids under 16 working anywhere,'' said William Smith, assistant regional administrator of the Labor Department's Wage-Hour division in Boston.

title: New York, Hanging in the Balance
description: New York City has come to an extraordinary moment in its history, one filled with opportunity and hope, a chance to right wrongs and address old failings. Its hand forced by a Supreme Court decision, America's most tumultuous city must now reinvent itself.

title: Stephanie P. Modlin WedTo A. N. Greene, Lawyer
description: At Congregation Shaare Tefila in Silver Spring, Md., Stephanie Paula Modlin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert J. Modlin of Silver Spring, was married last evening to Andrew Neil Greene, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Greene of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Martin Halpern and Cantor Gershon Levin performed the ceremony.

title:
INVESTING;
A New World for Sears Suppliers
description: LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company's new marketing strategy - lower normal prices, fewer promotional sales and selling more brand-name and fewer private-label goods - could have a considerable impact on the dozens of companies that supply the giant retailer.

title: Au Naturel
description: Don't be fooled by the natural look. It is a product of pure artifice - foundation that is so well blended as to be imperceptible, blusher swirled artfully on the cheeks, lipstick blotted down to become a mere stain, brown eyeshadow deftly powdering the eyelids and a little trail of eyelining pencil. For years, the cosmetics industry all but ignored the popularity of natural-looking makeup, preferring to promote colorful stuff instead. But that is changing. In the past year, such products as nude lipstick, clear mascara, translucent powder and sheer blusher have proliferated. Some of it bears a striking resemblance to the emperor's new clothes.

title: They're Giving A New Meaning To Class Records
description: To see the scholarly work of one group of New York University students, check out the selection at a record store.

title: Final 64 Needs the Ivy League, Automatically Sports of The Times
description: Here is what the Ivy League should do if anybody ever revokes its automatic bid to the national basketball tournament:

title: Princeton Corridor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orion Quartet To Give the County a Preview
description: WHEN the Orion String Quartet played in Baltimore earlier this season, one critic there called the ensemble ''ready for stardom.'' Unlike most new quartets, formed by student artists or recent conservatory graduates, this one convenes four noted soloists and highly experienced chamber musicians: the brothers Daniel and Todd Phillips (who will be sharing the first and second violin assignments); the violist Catherine Metz, a former member of the Primavera Quartet and present concertmistress of the Jupiter Symphony; and the topnotch cellist Timothy Eddy.

title: Freda Ackerman To Wed in May
description: Freda Stern Ackerman, an executive vice president and the director of the public finance department of Moody's Investors Service in New York, and J. Chester Johnson, president of Government Finance Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., plan to be married in May.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: At first she described it as embarrassing, but after a moment's consideration, she allowed that the word might not be accurate because, after all, this particular foible of hers is known to very few people. So, she said, strike embarrassing; substitute silly, stupid or ridiculous, take your choice.

title: Spread of U.S. Plants Abroad Is Slowing Exports
description: In the great race for overseas sales, many American companies are rushing to manufacture abroad, finding this strategy more efficient and profitable than exporting their products from the United States.

title: AIDS and After
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY
description: VOYAGES Poems by Walt Whitman. Edited by Lee Bennett Hopkins. Illustrated by Charles Mikolaycak. 73 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. BIG BUSINESS - Identical twins, Sadie (Bette Midler) and Rose (Lily Tomlin) get accidentally mismatched with another set of twins at birth, setting off a breezy farce ''played to the hilt by two splendidly comic actors.'' Ms. Midler is ''fiendish delight.'' (Canby) 1988. Touchstone. 1 hour, 37 minutes. $89.95. CC. (Laser disk: $34.95). PG. BLOOD MONEY - Andy Garcia and Ellen Barkin star in Jerry Schatzberg's film, made for cable, about two outsiders thrown together by a murder. ''Ms. Barkin and Mr. Garcia are terrific.'' (O'Connor). 1988. J2 Communications. 1:49. $79.95. Not rated. BRIEF ENCOUNTER - David Lean's film based on the Noel Coward play involves lovers - Trevor Howard and Celia Johnson - who meet by chance at a railway station; ''torrid for its time; even now generates some steam, despite the terribly proper, stiff-upper-lip manners.'' (Maslin). 1945. Paramount Home Video, 1:26. $19.95. CLEAN AND SOBER - With his alcohol and cocaine problems out of hand, Daryl (Michael Keaton) checks into a rehabilitation center and gradually turns his denial and self-centeredness into understanding and compassion. The film follows his progress ''one tiny increment to another, the best way to capture such a giant step forward.'' (Maslin) 1988. Warner. 2:04. $89.95. R. THE ECLIPSE - In graphic detail, Michelangelo Antonioni records the moody drawn-out surrender of a capricious young woman (Monica Vitti) to the bland advances of a stockbroker (Alain Delon). Antonioni is so selective and sensitive with his use of camera that what might be tedious is fascinating. Connoisseur. 2:03. $79.95. Not rated. GRAND ILLUSION - Jean Gabin, Pierre Fresnay and Eric von Stroheim star in Jean Renoir's masterpiece about the disintegration of the old class order in Europe after World War I. 1938. Connoisseur. 1:51. $59.95. (LD: Voyeur, $79.95).> A HANDFUL OF DUST - Evelyn Waugh's malevolent novel about the decline of the English upper class loses much of its cutting edge in a film treatment that gives a luxuriant look to scenes better left as spare as they were written in Waugh's original. One bright spot is Anjelica Huston, who ''flies into the film in a biplane and takes command.'' (Canby) 1988. RCA-Columbia. 1:58. $89.95. PG. HORSE FEATHERS - The Marx brothers get loose at Huxley College, with Groucho as the school's president (''I thought my razor was dull until I heard your speech,'' he tells his predecessor), Chico as the big bootlegger on campus, Zeppo as a sedate student and Harpo as a dog catcher. 1932. MCA. 1:06. $19.95. IMAGINE: JOHN LENNON - This film ''has things no Beatles biographer has yet captured: the pure euphoria of the music, the sad spectacle of the group's dissolution and Lennon's defiant, somehow poignant effort to strike out on his own. . . His talent and endlessly changeable nature come through.'' (Maslin) 1988. Warner. 1:46. $89.95. CC. (LD: $24.98.) R. MARRIED TO THE MOB - Jonathan Demme's stereotypical gangsters organize their crime with a ''comic garishness that is really something special.'' Michelle Pfeiffer plays a mob wife; Dean Stockwell, in a role that earned him an Oscar nomination, is Tony the Tiger and his ''shoulder-rolling caricature. . . is the film's biggest treat.'' (Maslin) 1988. Orion. 1:43. $89.95. CC. R. MIDNIGHT RUN - Robert De Niro is a wise-cracking but soft-hearted bounty hunter who collects Charles Grodin, as a hapless but wily white-collar criminal, and dashes cross country with the Mafia in pursuit. The film ''brings comic elan to the two-guys-hit-the-road formula.'' (James) 1988. MCA Home Video. 2:05. $89.95. R. (LD: $39.98.) SPIKE OF BENSONHURST - Spike Fumo (Sasha Mitchell) skips through a multiethnic minefield and a gauntlet of Mafia operatives in Paul Morrissey's comedy, set in Brooklyn. The film ''doesn't have the sharpest satirical edge, but it does have personality.'' (Maslin) 1988. Virgin Vision. 1:41. $89.95. (LD: $39.95.) R. U2 RATTLE AND HUM - Phil Joneau's ''sinuous black-and-white style superbly showcases the simplicity and directness of this group's performing style'' in this concert documentary. The group is at its best in close-up ''when the camera's intensity matches their own.'' (Maslin) 1988. Paramount. 1:39. $24.95. PG-13. THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING - Philip Kaufman's adaptation of Milan Kundera's novel, starring Daniel Day-Lewis, Lena Olin and Juliette Binoche. The actors ''are surprisingly fine - both modest and intense as lovers whose private lives are defined by public events.'' (Canby) 1988. Orion Home Video. 2:52. $89.98. R. YOUNG GUNS - An update of the Billy the Kid legend, with Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland, Lou Diamond Phillips and Charlie Sheen. Directed by Christopher Cain. ''Best watched in the playful spirit in which it was made.'' (Maslin) 1988. Vestron Video. 1:42. $89.98. R. For Children BUGS BUNNY IN KING ARTHUR'S COURT and BUGS AND DAFFY'S ''CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS'' - The world's best-known rabbit stars in two adventures in time for Easter, both written and directed by the acclaimed animator Chuck Jones. 1989. 0:48. Warner Home Video. $79.95. CHARLES DICKENS'S GHOST STORIES - Spooky stories include ''The Ghost in the Wardrobe,'' ''The Mail Coach Ghosts'' and ''The Goblin and the Gravedigger.'' Not reviewed. Celebrity. 1:00. $29.95. MAC AND ME - A homesick extraterrestrial is befriended by a little boy in an altogether familiar scenario spiced by the fact that the child is in a wheelchair. ''Fortunately, there is some residual charm left in these borrowings [ from ''E. T.'' ] . (James) 1988 Orion. 1:39. $89.98. CC. PG.

title: UNEASE IS VOICED ON CONTRA ACCORD
description: The White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, expressed reservations today about the Bush Administration's agreement with Congress on Central America that was negotiated by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. He said it permits Congress to encroach too far on the constitutional powers of the President.

title: Washington
description: To the Editor: Washington's renovated Union Station is an improvement cosmetically, but the modification travelers needed was not accomplished.

title: Knapsacks for Urban Survival
description: From the canyons of midtown to the wilds of Wall Street, urban vagabonds are abandoning the executive briefcase for the more pastoral - and arguably more practical - knapsack.

title: A Guide to the Elections
description: A step-by-step guide to the balloting and an analysis of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's strategy are in The Week in Review. Section 4, page 3.

title: Valerie D. Antman Married
description: Valerie Dee Antman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Antman of Seaford, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Mark D. Kirschenbaum, a son of Fania K. Kirschenbaum of Brooklyn and the late Chaim Kirschenbaum. Rabbi Mordecai Rubin performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride is an account executive for The Daily News. Dr. Kirschenbaum is a cardiologist in Oakland, N.J.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Think Small When Growing Tomatoes
description: LEAD: My romance with small tomatoes began in the wintertime in an unromantic place - the supermarket. The cherry tomatoes were the only ones with any flavor on the produce shelf. What's good in a carton, I reasoned, must be sensational in the garden.

title: Extortion Plan Outlined By Ex-School Inspector
description: The first of several trials of New York City Board of Education maintenance inspectors began last week with testimony outlining a pervasive citywide bribery and extortion scheme that forced small contractors to pay off inspectors to gain approval of completed work.

title: Some Things, Like Dorm Food, Never Change
description: When students go to college, most expect three things: classes will be tough, study hours will be long and dining hall food will not taste like Mom's.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exposed concrete under the white clapboard around the outside of our house is painted white. When it rains, dirt splashes up onto the white and it is difficult to clean. What can I put down to prevent this splashing?

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Rehoboth Beach, Del.; Discount Outlet By the Seaside
description: DELAWARE'S principal ocean resort is about to become an attraction for outlet-store shoppers, too. This will come about when Land Design Inc., a Rehoboth Beach real estate development concern, opens a 90,000-square-foot shopping center with 30 manufacturers' outlet stores in mid-April.

title: A Boy's Best Friend Is His Llama
description: ''WHEN'S the llamas' bedtime?'' was the first question our son, Jacob, asked as we started our trek into the Eagle Cap Wilderness Area of eastern Oregon. From that moment on, he never stopped asking questions, some of which he even directed at Murphy, the llama who, with exquisite docility, allowed his young inquisitor to lead him up the trail.

title: Hilary J. Moyler Engaged to Wed J. H. McKinnon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. P. Moyler of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Joanne Moyler, to Jeffrey Hawley McKinnon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William James McKinnon of Wadesboro, N.C. A May wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
description: He did a great job for the big-bucks interests.

title: CONSUMER RATES
'Just Loafing Around,' Cab Calloway Says
description: LEAD: CAB CALLOWAY is spending a quiet afternoon at his home here, recuperating from surgery. With some effort, he tosses another log into the fireplace, grabs a poker and stokes the fire with vigorous jabs.

title: Madagascar's Mysterious Artifacts
description: Marco Polo is credited with the naming of Madagascar. Everything else about this island, off the east coast of Africa in the Indian Ocean, seems remote and mysterious - including its art and artifacts.

title: Day Care Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Recital; Jean Jordan, A Soprano
description: There was much to admire in Jean Jordan's debut recital on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. The soprano offered a rich program of works by Handel, Wolf, Barber, Rodrigo and Roger Quilter, all delivered with the kind of expressivity that comes from attention to the texts.

title: An Actress's Odyssey
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; First 'Walkure' Of Met Season
description: For anyone who believed in signs and portents, the season's first ''Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera had to be a cheerful event. The performance on Friday evening, first of three in the final weeks leading up to the company's long-awaited presentations of Wagner's complete ''Ring'' in proper sequence, went smoothly enough to suggest that the cycle may be rounding into shape at just the right time.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Nashua, N.H.;
L.I. Developer To the Rescue
description: LEAD: MARK DAVID ASSOCIATES, a Freeport, L.I., developer with Richard Schlesinger and William Weinstein as general partners, is rescuing Sky Meadow, a partially completed residential complex here.

title: A Short Skyscraper With a Tall Assignment
description: ''The tallest building in Bridgeport'' sounds like a punch line. And at just 16 stories, Bridgeport Center, the new headquarters complex of People's Bank here, is so small that it would barely muster notice in most other cities. There is a reason, however, that this toy-sized skyscraper merits attention: it marks the high-rise debut of Richard Meier, the New York- and Los Angeles-based architect whose career so far has been limited to museums, houses, institutional buildings and low-rise corporate structures. Mr. Meier is one of the world's most acclaimed architects (last year he won the Gold Medal of the Royal Institute of British Architects, one of the few Americans ever to have done so), but until now he has never managed to build a skyscraper.

title: 500 Teen-Agers Act Out the Stresses They Fear
description: In the ''party'' exercise, Geri, a high-school student is at a victory celebration for her school's basketball team. She drives to the party in her mother's car with three friends. At the party Tom, a classmate, is trying to get her to ''loosen up'' with a drink.

title: Columbus Also Had a Way With Eggs; At 10:24, All 5 Balanced
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Plays Defense, Too
description: In reaching the final of the East Regional, Georgetown reaffirmed its status as college basketball's quintessential defensive team.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY: N.C.A.A./Friday's Games; BADGERS PUT FOCUS ON DEFENSE
description: The Wisconsin Badgers were preparing to hone in on defense tonight as they attempted to remain alive in their two-of-three-game quarterfinal series against Minnesota in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey playoffs.

title: Why Camp David Turned Bitter: The Carter View
description: The picture was taken 10 years ago on the South Lawn of the White House seconds after Jimmy Carter, Anwar el-Sadat and Menachem Begin signed their names to the first peace treaty ever between Israel and an Arab state. The three leaders stacked their hands together in an embrace of friendship and optimism that was supposed to set the tone for a whole new era in the Middle East, an era of peace.

title: Rivals Say Self-Destruction Is Mets' Biggest Threat in East
description: If there is one task this season that approaches the impossible, it is the one commonly shared but individually faced by Whitey Herzog, Jim Leyland, Buck Rodgers, Don Zimmer and Nick Leyva.

title: Little Speakers With Big Voices
description: With many music lovers, among others, chronically short of cash, space or both, there has been a steady demand for cheap, small loudspeakers. In the past, most such speakers sounded thin and tinny; some still do.

title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs
description: FOR millions of government workers facing drug testing, as well as those who work in industry, the Supreme Court's decision last week raised more questions than it answered.

title: Wagner's 'Ring': Stagecraft As Ideology
description: Grand and crabby, beautiful and ugly, rhapsodic and boring, primordially mythic and progressive in ways we don't yet fully understand, Richard Wagner's four-opera, 16-hour cycle ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' still counts as the greatest challenge - for singers, conductors, stage directors, designers, critics and audiences alike - in the standard operatic canon.

title: The Mystical Enigma That Is Arvo Part
description: When Arvo Part's music was first performed in New York, less than a decade ago, the temptation was to think of the Estonian emigre composer as a Minimalist. Works like ''Tabula Rasa'' and ''Fratres,'' the first of his scores to gain any currency in this country, were solidly, unequivocally tonal, and they used repetition as a central structural element.

title: Ex-Actress Teaches the Art of Speech
description: LEAD: YOUR throat goes dry. Your hands turn cold and clammy. As you make your way to the podium, your heart pounds and your knees begin to shake. You pray your voice won't quiver. It does. For many, public speaking is fraught with so much peril, real and imagined, that they avoid it altogether.

title: NEW YANKEE MANGER DALLAS GREEN: ON THE SPOT
description: ON A BRIGHT DAY IN MID-FEBRUARY, THE DAWNING OF yet another new era in the mottled, modern history of the New York Yankees, 60 ballplayers in black training shirts and white pinstriped pants are going through calisthenics at the club's training camp in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Clipboard in hand, cap drawn low, eyes inscrutable behind dark shades, Dallas Green is watching, striding the verdant complex of three manicured ballfields, four automatic batting cages, a dozen pitcher's mounds.

title: Miss Parsons Is Engaged
description: Sir Anthony and Lady Parsons of Ashburton, Devon, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Laila Helen Parsons to Robert Wisnovsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Wisnovsky of Princeton, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Making A Splash Of a Mill
description: LEAD: A 62-ACRE former steel-mill property in West Homestead, a borough six miles up the Monongahela River from here, is being converted into a water-oriented amusement park.

title:
ART;
Influential Abstractionist
description: LEAD: AN exhibition of small gouache paintings by Byron Browne, now on view in the 10th-floor gallery of Hofstra University's Axinn Library, is a fine example of how a carefully conceived, narrowly focused show can give broad insights into an artist's achievement.

title: Alaska Aide Assails Oil Industry For 'Inadequate' Response to Spill
description: Alaska's top environmental official assailed the oil industry today for what he called a slow response to the vast oil spill Friday in Prince William Sound.

title: Losing Confidence
description: He's been depicted as an arrogant, preening showboat, but as an undeniable tennis sensation who won six tournaments last year, 18-year-old Andre Agassi has had plenty to be arrogant about.

title: South Carolina's Wildlife Kingdom
description: Just off the coast of South Carolina, about midway between the old mansions of Charleston and the new condos of Myrtle Beach, is an island kingdom ruled by animals. Here, undistrubed by man, great flocks of snowy undisturbed by man, great flocks of snowy egrets and white ibis flash thier cpale clumsy wings over shallow ponds; alligators, as motionless and imperturbable as statues, sun themselves on mud banks covered with delicate white wildflowers; 30 different kinds of warblers sling from the branches of live oaks and hide amid the crimped leaves of yaupon holly and red-berried cassinas, and huge lumbering loggerhead turtles come by the hundreds on spring and summer nights to bury their eggs in the sand of the barrier beaches. This little-known dominion is the 34,229acre CapeRomain National Wildlife Refuge.

title:
DINING OUT;
Old World Hospitality Alive in Yonkers
description: LEAD: OVER the last two years, Reggia Morelli has made some welcome changes. Most conspicuous is the glass-enclosed sidewalk cafe that stretches onto Central Avenue. Strings of white pin lights line the supporting ribs and lend a festive note to this pleasant addition. The cafe would make an appropriate spot to stop for a glass of wine, for new as well is Reggia

title: Unlikely Seton Hall Moves to Final Four
description: Seton Hall is Final Four bound.

title: Hatchery as a 'Watchdog'
description: LEAD: Frank M. Flower & Company is the last of the shellfish industries to survive on the north shore of Nassau County. Because it plants 60 million seed oysters and l5 to 20 million clams in Oyster Bay every year, it is considered the area's watchdog for water quality.

title: Deborah S. Klein, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Klein of Syosset, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Sue Klein, to David Barnet Sokol, the son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Marvin Sokol of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Klein, a third-year student at the New York University School of Medicine, graduated from Syosset High School and Brown University. Her father is a vice president of Diversified Advisory Services, a financial services company in New York, and an adjunct associate professor at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. Her mother, Flora Klein, is a reading teacher in the Syosset school system.

title: BITES OF SPRING
description: Just when we think there will be no relief from the winter doldrums, the first proof of spring pokes its way through the snow and thaw.

title: TALKING: Jumbo Loans; Shopping Around for Good Deals
description: AS the prices of homes have soared - particularly in areas like the Northeast and West Coast - so have the needs for buyers to seek jumbo, or ''nonconforming,'' mortgage loans. These are loans that exceed $187,600, the limit for individual dwelling set by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, the Government-chartered corporations that regularly buy home loans from lenders.

title: Iran and Iraq Still Hold Thousands of P.O.W.'s
description: Seven months after the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, Iran and Iraq are still holding thousands of each other's prisoners in apparent violation of an international convention, Iraqi and Red Cross officials say.

title: Gina Rogers Reid to Marry Eric Bell, a Producer, in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Gina Rogers Reid, to Eric Bell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Bell of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Male Figure, Dual Images and Landscapes
description: ON the menu this week are two solo shows and a group one. The first of the solos, at Coup de Grace, in Hoboken, is by Thomas Micchelli, a painter who has appeared in Manhattan but is more often visible in New Jersey.

title: Punishment Appropriate
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Disabled Youths, a Center for Learning
description: LEAD: AT the Rehabilitation Center of Southwestern Connecticut in Stamford, with its garden atriums and sculptures, colorful gymnasiums and playrooms, the feeling is up rather than down.

title: CLASH AT DARTMOUTH
description: I'm the one who published a defense of affirmative action written in black English, which John Casey's article says attempted to prove that black students are illiterate.

title: Fears Confine Abortion Pill To France
description: THE revolutionary new abortion pill, RU 486, is increasingly popular in France, and is considered by the medical profession to be a far better means of abortion than surgical procedures. But given pressures from anti-abortion groups, among other obstacles, it could take years before the pill becomes available in other countries.

title: For Gambling in Tennessee, All Bets Are Off
description: Bingo is dead, the future of betting on horse races is at best dismal, and the outlook for raffles is very questionable. And thereby hangs a tale.

title: Soviet People Go to Polls Today; For Many, a Real Choice Awaits
description: The voters of the Soviet Union go to the polls Sunday, and for many of them, it will matter for the first time in their lives.

title: Kimball Payments
description: The insurance companies for the former Olympic diver, Bruce Kimball, will pay $1.3 million to five victims of the car accident that killed two teen-agers and injured six others last August, the athlete's attorney said.

title: They Also Serve Who Sit and Wait For the L.I.R.R.
description: AS one of the faithful who sit in the dark, cold parking lot adjacent to the Wantagh Long Island Rail Road Station weekday evenings, waiting for a much-loved commuter to return home, I've become a kind of para-professional of successful station sitting. It is a given that there will be a wait. I've been told that any train arriving under four minutes late is ''on time,'' so let's take it from there.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The consumer is still getting a lot of dollars placed in his wallet. But when it came to spending, consumers suddenly have decided this income is not going to be disbursed as lavishly as it has been.'' Robert Dederick, chief economist, Northern Trust Company.

title: The Olympics Should Be About Winning
description: Having read Harry L. Usher's recent article concerning the United States Olympic Committee's Overview Commission report (''There's More to the Olympics Than Gold,'' The New York Times, March 12) I must admit I was surprised by his comments. I served as chairman of the commission and am mindful of the many hours of dedicated work put forth by its members.

title: ADVENTURES OF A SENSITIVO
description: THE WHITENESS OF BONES By Susanna Moore. 277 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: 4 Killed in Rising Gaza Violence
description: Two Palestinians were shot to death by Israeli troops in the occupied Gaza Strip today, and two Arabs suspected of working for Israel during the uprising were found dead, Palestinians and the army said.

title: In Nine Little Words
description: ACCORDING TO RICH Jaroslovsky of The Wall Street Journal, George Bush described a photo session at which he makes remarks but refuses to answer reporters' questions as ''a modified limited photo op cum statement sans questions.''

title: Correction
description: An article March 23 about the Chicago mayoral campaign incorrectly described a public opinion poll commissioned by WLS-TV as the most recent. The most up-to-date polling figures were not from the WLS poll but from a telephone survey of 821 registered voters conducted March 16 through 18 for WBBM-TV. It showed Richard M. Daley supported by 50 percent, Timothy Evans by 30 percent, and Edward R. Vrdolyak by 6 percent. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points.

title: Congress's Slow Start Seems to Have No End
description: THE bipartisan agreement on Central American policy, announced Friday, came not a moment too soon. Not so much for Central America, where it represented little more than a belated adjustment of United States policy to political reality. No, the important impact of the agreement was in Washington, where something, anything, that could be presented as good news was badly needed both on Capitol Hill and at the White House.

title: Ulster Victims, Including Innocent, Keep Growing
description: In the aftermath of the killing of two senior police officers by the Irish Republican Army, both sides in the growing series of reprisal assassinations say their aim is to strike at well-known figures and avoid random slayings of innocent Roman Catholics or Protestants.

title: Tight White House Control Marks Bush Economic Policy
description: In a clear departure from Ronald Reagan's approach and those of most other Presidents, President Bush has built a sizable economic policy apparatus within the White House to supplement and second-guess the policy-making work of the Treasury and other departments, and sometimes to take the initiative.

title: This Concert Weekend, the Guests Have It
description: A SWISS oboist, Soviet and Australian pianists, an Irish flutist and a Polish folk troupe are among the musical visitors this week, and the guest list is further swelled by such artists of international renown as Gidon Kremer, Yo-Yo Ma, Peter Serkin, Richard Stoltzman and the Colorado String Quartet.

title: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Car
description: CABBIES HONK APPROVINGLY. Pedestrians applaud. Diners gather at restaurant windows. Around New York, Eric Staller's ''Lightmobile'' (right) is a little bit famous. Ever since its maiden voyage in 1985, the Volkswagen beetle with its ebullient adornments - 1,659 light bulbs, computer-controlled and capable of flashing in 25 different patterns - has effervesced regularly all over town, wreaking a pleasant sort of havoc wherever it goes.

title: When the Ballpark Cost Just a Nickel
description: RECENTLY the sports pages, radio and television announced three-year contracts for Orel Hersheiser at $7.9 million, Roger Clemens at $7.5 million and Dwight Gooden at a mere $6.7 million. Not quite in the same league as Henry Kravis, the leveraged buyout king, or Mike Milliken, the indicted junk-bond potentate but still pretty good for throwing the ball in a kids' game.

title: NONFICTION
description: LORD NELSON: The Immortal Memory. By David Howarth and Stephen Howarth. (Viking, $24.95.) A danger in retelling the life of a national hero is that the subject's virtues often are inflated and his shortcomings diminished. Thus, in ''Lord Nelson,'' an unguardedly affectionate biography of Britain's most notable mythologized naval hero, conspicuous character deficits - cynicism, vanity, decadence, infantilism and cruelty - are largely dismissed, defended or recast as attributes. Nelson's notorious abandonment of his wife, Fanny, and his fathering of a child with the beautiful and flattering Emma Hamilton (as her husband slept nearby) were hardly admirable deeds. And it must be remembered that much of what is known of Nelson's charity was recorded by Nelson himself in self-conscious letters and journals, in hopes of gaining posterity's adulation. The authors, the military historian David Howarth and his son, Stephen Howarth, compensate most responsibly by providing anecdotes from which the reader may reach a balanced - and, finally, no less warm - appraisal. Nelson's appetite for battle and his passion for Lady Hamilton are revealed in theatrical, often droll, detail. The authors' sensitive dissection of his marital failure, as well as Nelson's own emotional self-exposure in every aspect of his life, give the book its humanity. Like its subject, who came to life only in pursuit of glory, the book gains momentum toward the end, in the taut final six chapters that build to Nelson's mortal wounds on the quarterdeck of his flagship, Victory, while trouncing the French at Trafalgar in 1805.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MY ENEMY, MY SELF. By Yoram Binur. Translated by Uriel Grunfeld. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A year before the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in December 1987, Yoram Binur, an Israeli journalist, embarked on a six-month masquerade as a Palestinian Arab worker in Israel.

title: Plans for Waterfront Stir Oyster Bay
description: LEAD: AS the calm water of Oyster Bay Harbor gently laps against the shore, a storm involving its future is brewing noisily inland.

title: Review/Cabaret; Marti Stevens and Memories
description: Marti Stevens is one of a handful of veteran nightclub performers who evoke the kinder, gentler Manhattan of another era. Indeed, that world seems so far in the past that one might question whether it ever really existed outside of show business.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE NEW SMOG PLAN;
Yes to Clean Air, But at What Cost?
description: LEAD: It is easy to be in favor of clean air if you ignore the costs. That may be the principal message behind the approval on March 17 of a large-scale air quality plan for the Los Angeles basin by the South Coast Air Quality Management District.

title: Review/Dance; Five Ambitious Works By Blue Mercury Troupe
description: The Blue Mercury Dancing Company, which performed Thursday at the Triplex Theater (199 Chambers Street), is an immensely likable troupe of nine able, personable dancers. But the choreography of Loris Anthony Beckles, founder of the company in 1985, is not always as appealing as the dancers.

title: POISON GAS FEARS LEAD U.S. TO PLAN NEW EXPORT CURBS
description: Bush Administration officials acknowledge that United States export controls have many of the same deficiencies that have permitted Western European companies to help third world countries build poison gas factories without fear of legal sanctions.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 57th Streets will be closed be tween 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. today for the Easter Promenade.

title: Nothing Amiss in Circulating Bush Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Denver Zoning Fight Turns on Defining a Family
description: The Denver City Council is trying to decide what to do in 1989 about a zoning ordinance dating from the 1950's, when a typical American family consisted of a mother, a father and two or three children.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A Huge Condo Project for New London
description: AMERICA BAY, a $105 million residential and boating village on a 24-acre peninsula in the Thames River on which its developers hope to begin construction this fall, is the first major evidence of New London's efforts to reclaim itself from decades of depression.

title: The Struggle for Land in Latin America
description: IN 1985, President Jose Sarney of Brazil argued for a new land-redistribution plan, saying that ''no modern country has developed without first dealing with its agrarian problem.'' But this month, in a stark illustration of what happened to that idea, the police fired at random as they evicted some 500 landless families who had taken over a private farm to protest the Government's broken promises.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Tempest in an Asparagus Pot: Are Fingers Fair?
description: With the arrival of California asparagus in the markets, the perennial question arises: should the long green spears be eaten with a knife and fork or with the fingers?

title: Israel Isn't the Worst Human Rights Offender; Our Cuba Fixation
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Heathers': Light Look at a Dark Topic
description: His classmates at Riley High School in South Bend, Ind., voted Daniel Waters ''most unforgettable'' eight years ago. Some of them may come to rue the irony of that vote when ''Heathers,'' a dark new satire written by Mr. Waters that transforms teen-age suicide into blackest farce, opens Friday.

title: No Free Lunch
description: To the Editor: Reading Ron Nowicki's article ''Yes, There Is No Free Lunch'' (Travel, Jan. 29) brought back memories of a similar experience my late wife and I had in October 1969, except that it took place in Rome. We were among the thousands in the crowd in St. Peter's Square after the Pope's Sunday noon balcony appearance and blessing. As we walked away from the square a wisp of a young, blond girl sidled up to us and said, ''Am I wrong or are you Americans?'' Seeing no harm in admitting a fact about which we were rather proud, we said Yes. She then asked ''How would you like a free guided bus tour of Rome tomorrow morning, followed by an exquisite free luncheon at the Hilton?'' In response to our question about the quid pro quo, she answered: ''All you have to do is watch a 20-minute film presented by your host, Gulf American.'' A small enough price, we thought; what could we lose?

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'SHORELINE HUNT' Finding seed pods from trees native to the Albany area and discovering the tracks of sea otters are strong possibilities next Sunday in Palisades Interstate Park.

title: RESULTS
description: Rowing Oxford Defeats Cambridge: Oxford claimed its 13th victory in the last 14 years by overcoming an early clash of oars to defeat a heavier Cambridge crew by two lengths in yesterday's 135th edition of the annual University Boat Race, the first race in which both coxswains were women. Oxford finished the four and a half miles along the Thames River in 18 minutes 28 seconds, almost 2 minutes slower than the record of 16:45 it set in 1984. Cambridge had a time of 18:35 in calm water and clear weather. Since 1976, the Dark Blues of Oxford have lost only in 1986. The Light Blues of Cambridge still hold an overall 69-65-1 lead in the race that began in 1829. The winning coxswain was Alison Norrish of England, while a Harvard University graduate, Leigh Weiss, a former member of the United States national lightweight crew, was the coxswain for Cambridge. Oxford opened a six-second lead halfway through the race and never was seriously challenged.(AP) Golf Norman Gains Lead on Third 68 in Row: Greg Norman, fully recovered from a wrist injury that hampered him last year, shot his third straight 68 yesterday to take the lead after three rounds of the USF&G Classic in New Orleans. His 54-hole score of 12-under-par 204 put him one shot ahead of Tim Simpson, who entered the day tied for the lead with Dan Forsman and shot a 70. Forsman had a 71 and was tied with Hal Sutton at 206. Sutton shot a 67. Tom Kite, seeking a third straight tournament victory, shot a 74 and was at 213. Norman had six birdies and two bogeys. He two-putted from 10 feet on No. 5 for a bogey and two-putted from 12 feet on No. 18. The tournament is the first professional event at the 7,106-yard, par-72 course at English Turn, a course dredged from a swamp under the direction of Jack Nicklaus.(AP) Charles Takes 3-Shot Lead: Bob Charles of New Zealand, the defender, shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead after the second round of the $370,000 Fuji Electric Grand Slam golf tournament - an official PGA Seniors Tour event, in Katori, Japan. Charles had a six-under-par 138 over the 6,660-yard Oak Hills Country Club course. Larry Mowry of the United States shot a 72 and was three strokes back in second place at 141. Tommy Aaron and Don January, both of the United States, shot 71's to share third place at 142.(AP) Bowling Soper Beats Miller in Kansas Final: Butch Soper downed Hugh Miller, 216-174, in the championship game yesterday to capture his first Professional Bowlers Association crown in five years at the $150,000 King Louie Open at Overland Park, Kan. Soper earned $27,000 for his third career victory. The victory also qualifies Soper for the prestigious 52-man field in the 1989 Tournament of Champions, which begins April 19 in Akron, Ohio. Miller earned his berth in the final by eliminating Jon O'Drobinak, 259-233. O'Drobinak had won his first two matches, beating Walter Ray Williams Jr., 235-234, and Chris Warren, 202-184.(AP) Tennis Sabatini Has Easy Victory: Gabriela Sabatini cruised past Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday to reach the fourth round of the Lipton International Players championships at Key Biscayne, Fla. Seeded No. 1 in the absence of Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova, the 18-year-old Argentine hasn't lost a game in three of the six sets she's played in this two-week, $2.1 million grand slam-format event. Helena Sukova and Lori McNeil, seeded third and 10th, also advanced, but sixth-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria and No. 12 Arantxa Sanchez of Spain lost in straight sets. Maleeva was hampered by a pair of sore ankles and lost by 6-2, 6-2 to Isabelle Demongeot of France. Maleeva hurt her left ankle in a tournament at Indian Wells, Calif., three weeks ago and injured her right ankle in a second-round triumph over Gigi Fernandez.(AP) Dog Show Norfolk Terrier Is Best: A Norfolk terrier, Ch. Rightly So Original Sin, who answers to the name of Ziggy, and is owned by Virginia Hedges and Julius Rumpf of Bridgehampton, L.I., yesterday led a field of 1,135 dogs at the New Brunswick Kennel Club Show in the Dunn Sports Center in Elizabeth, N.J. It was the second top award for the 2-year-old red dog, who has been best terrier 13 times. Horse Show Dello Joio Rides Winner: Norman Dello Joio, a former World Cup champion from South Salem, N.Y., rode Notable IV to victory over a 46-horse field in the $15,000 Johnnie Walker Challenge yesterday at the 31st annual Winter Equestrian Festival in Tampa, Fla. Dello Joio finished the jumpoff over seven jumps and 280-yard course fault-free in 33.732 seconds on Notable IV. Chris Kappler of St. Charles, Ill., finished in 33.537 seconds to beat Dello Joio's time. However, his mount, Wald Kanzler, a 9-year old German-bred, dislodged the final rail for four faults.

title: A Period Piece Troubles and Challenges
description: In the decades since its opening in 1950, Carson McCullers's ''Member of the Wedding,'' set in a small Southern town in 1945, has become more than a poetic characterization of a young girl's coming of age. Over the years, it has been increasingly recognized as a story rooted in a particular time and place: the segregated South.

title: GUATEMALA: WHAT HAS DEMOCRACY WROUGHT?
description: OF THE NEW GUATEMALA IS WORKING for anyone, it is working for Enrique de Leon. His unpretentious steakhouse in the capital has proved very successful, and he is investing the profits in a new and far more elegant eatery called Vivaldi, where a classical pianist in a tuxedo sets the ambiance.

title: Question Of the Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
description: Very good if you're an owner, bad if you're a fan.

title: In Taiwan, Foreign Degrees Spell S-t-a-t-u-s
description: Perhaps no place on earth so esteems an American university degree as Taiwan.

title: DEFICIT FIGURING DOESN'T ADD UP
description: In Charles R. Morris's article (''Deficit Figuring Doesn't Add Up,'' Feb. 12), there are three graphs along with the statement that the Federal deficit, expressed as a percentage of the gross national product, is not a great deal higher than it was in the mid-1970's.

title: A Gaggle of Gimicks to Entice Buyers
description: Faced with swelling inventories, real estate agencies are using an array of sales gimmicks to entice potential buyers into their offices.

title: Editors' Note
description: The cover article of The Times Magazine today discusses the new manager for the New York Yankees, Dallas Green, and some problems he faces.

title: SHEER BLACK
description: In Paris and New York, when designers started showing dangerously sheer clothing, the skeptics asked: Who would wear these revealing clothes? The answer appeared at recent parties in New York, where even Nancy Reagan was spotted in a black gown with a sheer top. Clearly, this style wasn't restricted to the daring or outrageous. Fairly conservative women chose a modest veil of black, such as Susan Gutfreund's dress with its sheer yolk atop a black bustier. Among the bold was Wendy Belzberg, whose short dress was slashed with a zigzag of sheerness. Betsey Johnson, the designer, appeared at one gala wrapped in yards of black tulle with her black corset and slip showing through. ''It's delicate and demure, and it's like wearing air,'' she said.

title: THE TAMING OF THE TUBE
description: TARGET: PRIME TIME Advocacy Groups and the Struggle Over Entertainment Television. By Kathryn C. Montgomery. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50

title: Driver Kills Woman in Crash
description: A drunken driver traveling west in an eastbound lane of the Long Island Expressway smashed into three cars Friday night, killing a Manhattan woman and critically injuring her daughter-in-law, the Suffolk County police said today. Four other people - including the driver, Willis Vaughan, 52 years old, of Westbury, L.I. - were injured. Mr. Vaughan was charged with driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident, a police spokesman said. Killed were Elaine Grennan, 55, of Manhattan. Her daughter-in-law, Mary Jo Grennan, 29, of Southold, L.I., was in critical condition. Mr. Vaughan was treated for head injuries.

title: AIDS and After
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Have a Party? To Open a Film Or to Aid Artists
description: It was a night of contrasts. At the Roma di Notte restaurant at 137 East 55th Street, 100 young supporters of the Princess Grace Foundation U.S.A. gathered on March 15 to greet old friends and recruit new members to raise money for the performing arts. At Mars, a former meatpacking plant at 10th Avenue and 13th Street, revelers celebrated the opening of a movie called ''Tapeheads,'' a satirical look at the music video industry.

title: A Surplus of Listings and Few Buyers in Sight
description: After years of unprecedented increases, housing prices seem to have reached a plateau - at least in the Northeast. But that hasn't brought many buyers back into the market.

title: End of a Power In New York City
description: EIGHT years ago the New York Civil Liberties Union set out to fight City Hall.

title: Columbus Also Had a Way With Eggs
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Expensive, but the Benefits Are Clear
description: In 1987, Los Angeles's smog plan was rejected by a Federal Appeals Court in response to a lawsuit I filed. That plan failed to meet Clear Air Act requirements. A follow-up lawsuit by the Coalition for Clean Air and the Sierra Club resulted in another court order. Under continued legal pressure, the new Los Angeles smog plan was developed. It consists of three progressively tougher levels of emission control - called tiers - designed to reduce levels of ozone and carbon monoxide.

title: Cats Provide Joy, Not Status
description: Shame on Michael Brim of the Cat Fanciers Association [ ''Long Island Journal,'' March 12 ] for his quotation comparing mixed-breed cats ''Volkswagens'' to pedigreed ''Cadillacs.''

title: Tracy Woodfield to Wed Ulf P. Jakobson in April
description: An April 29 wedding is planned by Tracy Ann Woodfield, a securities analyst in the equity research department of the First Boston Corporation, and Ulf Patrik Jakobson, an associate at J. P. Morgan & Company, both of New York. The engagement was announced by the mother of the bride-to-be, Ann Latimer Woodfield of New York.

title: THE WORLD: The Soviet Vote; A Guide to the Election Process
description: Soviet voters go to the polls today to elect a Congress of People's Deputies, which is to be the supreme state body in a redesigned Soviet Government. For the first time in seven decades, most voters will have the opportunity to choose among competing candidates. But even some architects of the new system concede it falls short of full democracy. A third of the 2,250 seats in the new congress have been filled by official organizations rather than the general public. The remaining two thirds are to be elected by the public - 184 milion eligible voters -- in territorial districts, but voter apathy and official manipulation have excluded many candidates from the ballot, and there are no organized opposition parties. Here is a guide to the balloting process. 1/The Nominations

title: Greek Terms
description: To the Editor: As printed in your letters column on March 12, my list of freshly minted Greek travel terms contained the following:

title: Dr. Gail Riess to Wed Dr. Leonard Saltz
description: The engagement of Dr. Gail Michele Riess to Dr. Leonard Bruce Saltz, a son of Anita and Jack Saltz of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Riess of Warren, N.J. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MYSTERIES OF ALGIERS. By Robert Irwin. (Viking, $16.95.) ''Hatred is the engine of change.'' So says a double agent named Philippe Roussel, the narrator of this slim novel by Robert Irwin, author of ''The Arabian Nightmare.'' Mr. Irwin paints a horrifying portrait of a French legionnaire who has learned to love hate after being tortured by the Vietnamese in 1955.

title: Resisting The Temptations of Wall Street
description: I JUST had my first real job interview, and it was with a brokerage. I was not very serious about getting the position, but there was an open slot in the all-campus interviews schedule, so I took it. It would be a good interviewing experience, I thought. I quickly ate my lunch and hurried upstairs to change into my suit, while words like ''dress for success'' and ''corporate image'' went through my mind. Then I took a series of deep breaths and was off.

title: FICTION
description: STAR. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The butler admits you to a mansion in San Francisco's Pacific Heights and leads you into a wood-paneled dining room. You circle an antique table laden with Limoges until you find your name on a place card in a silver holder. By the light of a crystal chandelier, you sup on smoked salmon and oysters. Welcome to the world of Danielle Steel, but watch your step! It's not all Patek Philippe and Rolls-Royce, a world where ''the only crisis'' is ''being a guest short for dinner.'' It's also a world of rape, murder, adultery, greed and spite. ''Star,'' Ms. Steel's 24th novel, has all the lust and luster you'd expect. It's the vintage Steel her fans thirst for. It's full of nice characters who are too nice, evil ones who are too evil and, of course, ambivalent lovers who are too ambivalent. More frustrating than frustrated, her lovers drive you crazy. After a while you want to pick up a polo mallet and whack a little sense into them. Crystal, a rancher's daughter, and Spencer, the son of a judge, meet at a wedding early in the novel. It's love at first sight, but Ms. Steel spends the next 400 or so pages finding ways to keep them apart and make them miserable. Crystal's father dies, her mother hates her, her brother-in-law rapes her, her dreams of stardom seduce her. Spencer's parents want too much for him, his senses get the better of his sense, his wife doesn't understand him and won't let him go. Will the star-crossed lovers get it all together and stroll off into the happily ever after? Not to give away too much, it's safe to say Ms. Steel's fans won't be disappointed.

title:
COLLEGE SPORTS;
Agents' Trial Is a Hot Ticket
description: LEAD: Until ''Les Miserables'' opened here this past Saturday, the hottest ticket in town has been the Federal trial of the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, which enters its fourth week on Monday.

title: Time to Be Frivolous With Artichokes
description: IN spring when artichokes are abundant and prices are reasonable the cook can be frivolous with them. Instead of serving them whole, to be savored leaf by succulent leaf, try using just the tender, fleshy bottom (or heart), discarding the rest.

title: Classes on Construction for Women
description: LEAD: A SEVEN-WEEK program intended to give women an introduction to the construction industry, as well as classes in carpentry, electrical work, masonry and plumbing, will begin tomorrow night in Wethersfield.

title: Israel Isn't the Worst Human Rights Offender; Arab State Violations
description: To the Editor:

title: Still the Nevilles, But Reaching Out For a Pop Audience
description: In many ways, the story of the Neville Brothers of New Orleans, who have just released ''Yellow Moon'' (A&M 5240; all three formats), is also the story of the tension in American society between the outsider and mainstream culture. The Neville Brothers - Art, 51, Charles, 50, Aaron, 48, and Cyril, 41 - are part of New Orleans's most important postwar pop musical dynasty, a family steeped in both the Mardi Gras culture of the city, as well as its pop music-making side, which at best has had an off-and-on-again flirtation with the American music business. In the 34 years they've been recording, every successful piece of their American music has been offset by a thudding dud.

title: Incinerators and Pollution: Thorny Issue
description: LEAD: THE recent decision by Pennsauken officials to install air-pollution control equipment for nitrogen oxides on a proposed garbage-burning incinerator has raised questions about whether this technology is the best available and should be mandatory on every incinerator in the state.

title: Lady Vols In Final Four
description: Bridgette Gordon scored 33 points as Tennessee pulled away in the second half for a 94-80 victory over Long Beach State in the final of the N.C.A.A. women's tournament East Regional today.

title: The Frustration of Not Being a Grandmother
description: GOODNESS knows, I'm old enough to be a grandmother. It's true, although I rarely think of it, that I have got to be ''of a certain age.'' Some of my best friends are grandmothers, with clusters of small relatives to brag about and wallets full of their pictures to pass around at luncheons when old friends get together. I have no such bounty to share.

title: For Oscar's Producer, the Key Is C
description: The Oscar, like the Maltese falcon, is the stuff that dreams are made of. So it is appropriate that the producer of the 61st Academy Awards show, which will be telecast live by ABC Wednesday night and to more than a billion people around the world before the night is through, insists that he lay in the dark in his North Shore Chicago bedroom at the age of 7, listening to the 22d Academy Awards on the radio and dreaming, not about winning an Oscar, but about growing up to produce the show.

title: Kimball to Seek Shorter Sentence
description: Attorneys for Bruce Kimball say they will ask a judge to reduce the Olympic diving medalist's 17-year sentence for drunken-driving manslaughter and transfer him to a center where he can be treated for chemical dependency.

title: POSTINGS: 43d St. Photo Gallery; Home Again On 6th Ave.
description: When the 42-story office building at 1133 Avenue of the Americas was completed 20 years ago, the Eastman Kodak Company opened a three-tier photography exhibition hall there and its varied exhibits became a popular diversion for New Yorkers passing the West 43d Street corner of the building. After a few years Kodak gave up the space because it was not providing the promotion benefit that had been anticipated, and for several years it was used as an exposition center for Chinese goods and works of art.

title: John Head: Television Producer
description: As the producer of the television program ''Sunday Night,'' which finishes its first season tonight, John Head has mixed and matched some of the most creative and influential musicians in the country in extraordinary one-hour jam sessions.

title: Tales From Elsewhere: Entering the New Era Of Municipal Rule
description: AS viewed from city halls across the nation, the government of New York City is like something from another planet. Who ever heard of a single municipality that is also five counties? What is a borough president? And what strange thing is a Board of Estimate that sounds like an arcane adjunct but has real power?

title: CLASH AT DARTMOUTH
description: The real Dartmouth story is an old one: how the powers that be do what they can to quiet an adversary press. My organization has received complaints of administration harassment from the University of Chicago, the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Vassar, the College of William and Mary and others. Are all these organizations and individuals ''mean-spirited, cruel and ugly,'' as Dartmouth's president, James Freedman, described The Dartmouth Review? Or are they simply violating political taboos on our ''liberal'' campuses? BRIAN FITZPATRICK Accuracy in Academia Washington

title: Jericho
description: To the Editor: In ''Moonlight on Judea'' (Travel, Jan. 15), Stephen R. Conn writes that he was informed by a guide from the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel ''that since archeologists could never find any remains of a wall [ around Jericho ] dating back to 1200 B.C., the time of Joshua, it probably never existed.'' Not that simple! Digging at Tell es-Sultan (the site of ancient Jericho), 1907 to 1909, Sellin and Watzinger found two concentric rings of fortifications made of sun-dried bricks. The inner wall surrounding the ridge of the tell (hill) is about 12 feet thick. The outer wall, running along the foot of the tell, is about six feet thick and must have been 25 to 30 feet high. The German and Austrian archeologists finally concluded that the outer wall ''fell about 1200 B.C., and therefore must be the city wall which Joshua destroyed.''

title: Illinois Lookalikes Have a Leader
description: Kendall Gill threw his head back and laughed, then looked down the table at Lou Henson, the Illinois head coach.

title: POSTINGS: 1 for 3 in Carnegie Hill; 30 Condo Units
description: During the real estate boom on the Upper East Side at the time of the Civil War, John C. Rennert, a local carpenter famed for making artificial limbs for wounded veterans, built three Italianate-style rowhouses at 134-138 East 93d Street in the emerging Carnegie Hill area of Yorkville. They were bought by merchants who valued their brick facades, stoops and small lawns. But the fortunes of the area, between 86th and 96th Streets, Fifth and Lexington Avenues, waxed and waned over the next century and the buildings were subdivided into small apartments and rented rooms.

title: Prospects; Inflation's Upward Stroll
description: The Producer Price Index jumped a full percentage point for February, heightening concerns about a return of double-digit inflation and sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 48.57 points. But last week, the Consumer Price Index for February - another indicator of inflation - showed a moderate gain of only four-tenths of a percent. Four experts give their views about inflation. Donald Fine Chief market analyst, Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: DATA BANK: March 26, 1989
Woman Keeping Alive Old Ukrainian Folk Art
description: LEAD: HELEN ROKOSNY celebrates Easter, as do many people, with beautiful colored eggs on her dining table. But while most people achieve the effect from a prepackaged kit, Mrs. Rokosny's designs are intricate, one-of-a-kind hand-painted pysanky eggs.

title: Under a Cloud
description: Pete Rose was always considered a sure bet for baseball's Hall of Fame. Last week, the odds may have changed because of accusations that the Cincinnati Reds manager was linked to gambling activities. The baseball commissioner's office said an investigation was under way into ''serious allegations'' against Rose, and Sports Illustrated reported that he may have bet on baseball games. Under baseball's rules, betting on other teams could bring a one-year suspension from baseball; betting on one's own team could mean suspension for life. Rose, who in the past said he gambled on horses and dogs but not baseball, said only that he was cooperating with the commissioner's office. As for his place in sports history, Rose ticked off his 4,256 hits and 2,200 runs, saying, ''I'm a Hall of Famer.''

title:
MUSIC;
Composer's Work: Meeting Challenges
description: LEAD: ELLEN TAAFFE ZWILICH is a composer who wants to maintain a real connection with her audience and is thoroughly committed to letting people know that ''music is a living art.''

title: INSIDE
description: UNREST IN YUGOSALVIA The police in Kosovo Province were reportedly fired upon by ethnic Albanian rioters. Page 3. CHALLENGE ON ABORTION Lawyers at the Justice Department are protesting its anti-abortion efforts in the Supreme Court. Page 19.

title: Why the Check Is No Longer in the Mail
description: LEAD: Like many corporations, Sears, Roebuck & Company used to love paying suppliers by mail. As far as Sears executives were concerned, the longer the check took to arrive, the better - all the more interest income for Sears.

title: AIDS and After
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sing' Producer 'Saves' a School
description: LEAD: ''I had the story, but he had the vision.'' That's how Dean Pitchford, the Academy Award-winning lyricist and screenwriter, describes his collaboration with Craig Zadan, the producer on their blockbuster 1985 film ''Footloose,'' which yielded for Columbia Records its all-time, best-selling sound track album.

title: Thornburgh Designee Failed Exam and Quit
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's choice to head the civil rights division resigned from that division in the early 1960's shortly after he had failed the District of Columbia bar examination, a Justice Department spokeswoman confirmed Friday.

title: Washington
description: To the Editor: In her report of Washington's revitalized Union Station, which is now a shopping, dining and cinema center as well as a depot, Barbara Gamarekian told readers almost everything they might want to know.

title: PLENTY OF ROOMS TO GROW
description: LEAD: NO PLACE LIKE HOME Rooms and Reflections From One Family's Life. By Linda Weltner. 255 pp. New York: Arbor House/William Morrow.

title: 'They Have to See the Whole Picture'
description: DAVID A. KOLLAS has been a pomologist - a horticulturist who specializes in the study of fruit - with the Cooperative Extension Service at the University of Connecticut for 22 years, since he graduated from Cornell University.

title: Charitable Group Gets Cash for Cans To Aid the Elderly
description: The Philanthropic Society, a new group founded to pursue the Jewish tenet of tzedaka, or charity, has been converting empty soda cans into cash to buy food for poor students and the housebound elderly.

title: Elisabeth Bittner to Wed
description: Elisabeth Anne Bittner, an associate at the First Boston Corporation, and Chansoo Joung, an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York, are planning to be married June 3. Miss Bittner, a daughter of Dr. N. Douglas Bittner of Peapack, N.J., and Dorothy P. Bittner of Basking Ridge, N.J., graduated from Yale University. She and her fiance, a graduate of Dartmouth College, both received M.B.A. degrees from Dartmouth. Mr. Joung is the son of Mrs. Robert H. Brown of Evanston, Ill., and Chan Soo Joung of Chicago.

title: Not a Lost Art: Dining Aboard In Europe
description: OUR trip to Paris last August began at the modern Chaumartin Station in Madrid, all shining marble and concealed lights. We were about to board an overnight train - the Paris-Madrid Talgo. Down an escalator from the crowded waiting room we found it, long and low, the words Talgo Pendular on its sides. Good looks were of only passing interest; what was most important was that this train carried a restaurant car.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Carle Place$260,000 47 Manhasset Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,460. Coram$187,400 107 Pine Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; finished basement, c/a, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Hauppauge$199,900 69 Eagle Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,200. North Patchogue$149,900 371 West Woodside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; dining room, den with fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Seaford$214,000 9 Potter Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; dining room, den, basement; taxes $4,400. Westbury$210,000 31 Ridge Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; dining room, den, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200. OTHER AREAS Brielle, N.J.$276,000 8 Beech Court 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; deck, fireplace in living room, c/a; taxes $3,133. Ridgefield, Conn.$307,000 49 Nursery Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; new kitchen, new master bath, 1 acre; taxes $3,114. Chappaqua, N.Y.$541,500 6 Alto Lane North 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; 2 living rooms, 2 dens, greenhouse, 1 acre; taxes $9,300.

title: THE TELEPHONE WATCHES, THE PROCESSOR SCREAMS
description: A WOMAN'S GUIDE TO ADULTERY By Carol Clewlow. 224 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: . . . From New York
description: To the Editor:
