The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Wntd: C.F.O. With 'Flair for Funk'
description: The company certainly never thought finding someone was going to be a cinch. On the other hand, it did think someone would turn up in this century.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Indianapolis;
description: LEAD: SITE preparation has begun here for Circle Centre, a $1 billion complex of housing, hotels and retail and office space that is expected to be completed by the turn of the century.

title: Christine Glavin Engaged to Wed R. M. Di Scipio
description: The engagement of Christine Elizabeth Glavin to Robert Michael Di Scipio has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Glavin of Greenwich, Conn. A May 5 wedding is planned.

title: NOTE
description: Because of an editing error, the Federal deficit figures for 1960 and 1969 were improperly charted. In both years, the Federal Government operated with a budget surplus, and thus the figures for those years, $3 billion and $8.4 billion respectively, should have been charted as negative numbers in the first chart.

title: Many Weapons Arrayed In Battle to Safeguard Air
description: LEAD: THREE main categories of air pollutants - acid gases, toxic metals and dioxins - are the sources of much public concern and the primary focus of control efforts by Government regulators and the incineration industry, said Prof. Paul Connett, a chemist at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y.

title: Two Wild and Crazy Emigres Discover Bayonne
description: Every week for two months a copy of The Bayonne Community News arrived at my office for no apparent reason. I couldn't imagine having subscribed to a newspaper in a New Jersey city that, as far as I could remember, I had never visited. I knew almost nothing about Bayonne. What I had seen from the New Jersey Turnpike - gas and chemical-storage tanks rising above Newark Bay - didn't intrigue me either.

title: An Old Man Lifts Spirits Of Walker
description: I SOMETIMES passed him on my daily four-mile walk on Pelham Parkway. Although I am not young, I am probably 50 years younger than he. He walks with the aid of a stick, stands erect and moves along at a respectable gait.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The late great Estonian Paul Keres used to say: ''I like to play opposite from my opponent. If he wants a positional game, I will strive to make it tactical; if he wants a tactical struggle, I will strive to make it positional.''

title: The Easter Egg as a Vocation and as Art
description: IN many homes today, eggs are pastel and they nest in baskets lined with cellophane grass. Easter eggs are also the subject of an exhibition at a New Milford art gallery this month. And for a a Norfolk woman, they are a career.

title:
INVESTING;
What to Make of Cooper's Rise
description: LEAD: Takeover rumors have buoyed the stock of the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, which seemed an attractive target for a foreign company seeking to expand in the United States. But although Cooper has had solid earnings and a small but growing position in the replacement-tire market, analysts say its stock is fully priced.

title: On the Stand
description: Something of a celebrity since the Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair in 1987, Fawn Hall was back in the limelight last week, this time as a prosecution witness at the trial of her former boss, Oliver L. North. She said she had ''never met a man who worked harder for his country.'' She also recalled carrying secret documents out of the White House under her clothing and in her boots, altering memorandums and shredding papers to protect Mr. North, who is being tried for his role in the diversion of profits of the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels. But, sobbing at times, she said she could not recall some incidents she had once described in detail. After months of going over it again and again, she said, ''It becomes clouded.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY
description: LEAD: TYRANNOSAURUS WAS A BEAST Dinosaur Poems. By Jack Prelutsky. Illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 32 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Houston Romps in Bay Shore
description: Everyone knew there was one exceptional 3-year-old among this year's Kentucky Derby prospects, but now it is clear there are two.

title: Bonnie A. Hut, an M.B.A. Candidate, To Wed Frederick Brimberg in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Aborn Hut of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bonnie Aileen Hut to Frederick Andrew Brimberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Brimberg of New York and Chebeague Island, Me. A June 25 wedding is planned.

title: THE WORLD: The Soviet Vote; Today, Gorbachev's Strategy Undergoes A Big Test
description: THE ultimate drop-dead line of this Soviet election season is attributed to Yuri Nikulin, a celebrated clown and director of the Moscow Circus. Mr. Nikulin was a candidate in a Moscow district until last month, when he quit in disgust. ''This,'' the clown is said to have muttered shortly before stalking out of an unruly voter caucus, ''is a circus.''

title:
>GARDENING;
Taming Vines on Trees or on the Ground
description: LEAD: IT'S not uncommon for English ivy to be planted as a ground cover under a tree canopy. Its glossy, dark green foliage makes it desirable for this purpose. English ivy spreads its verdant carpet by creeping along the ground or by climbing. As it climbs, the juvenile creeper will ultimately transform into a mature, flowering plant that will produce seeds to perpetuate the species.

title: Similar Teams Meet in Final
description: Their approaches toward the game of basketball begin at the defensive end of the court. Their philosophies of the role of athletics in higher education point to a finish line at commencement exercises, not the final game of a season.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: One of the treats of my recent trip to Florida - besides a needed respite from winter - was visiting a wildlife sanctuary full of tropical birds. But as much as I enjoyed looking at the birds, I couldn't help spending much of my time staring at the photographers who converged there every evening to capture their prey.

title: THE ARTIST, SOARING AT LAST
description: TATLIN Edited by Larissa Alekseevna Zhadova. Consulting editor, Eva Korner. Translated by Paul Filotas, Maria Julian, Eugenia Lockwood, Doris Macknight, Eva Polgar and Colin Wright. Illustrated. 533 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $75.

title: Home Buying Is an Official Cause Again
description: SINCE the 1930's, the Federal Government has from time to time adopted programs and policies aimed at encouraging home ownership. Overlaying the basic subsidy of the American Dream - the deductibility of mortgage interest payments - have been other advantages like mortgage guarantees.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 26, 1989
Going on a Grand Tour With the Grandchildren
description: HELENA T. KOENIG says that she established Grandtravel in 1987 when she learned she was going to become a grandmother, because she was so excited at the prospect of traveling with children again. Lots of the fun of travel is in the show-and-tell, and here is an occasion for grandparents to enjoy the exchange with their grandchildren to the fullest.

title: London Restaurant Cleared Of Health Violation Charges
description: Le Gavroche, one of only two restaurants in Britain rating three stars in the Michelin guide, has been cleared of health and safety violations.

title: Israel Isn't the Worst Human Rights Offender; Don't Stop There
description: To the Editor: I applaud the action of all members of the United Nations Security Council but the United States (news story, Feb. 18) in voting for a resolution deploring Israel's mistreatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories, which deserves criticism.

title: POSTINGS: Bonus in Greenwich; Mixed-Use Mansions
description: Greenwich, Conn., encourages the preservation of old houses by letting developers increase the size of properties under some circumstances if they retain the buildings' historic flavor. With this bonus in mind, the New England Land Company of Greenwich has incorporated two mansions at 124 and 130 Mason Street into a mixed-use project, renovating their 8,500 square feet into four condominiums and creating 17,300 square feet of retail and office space in additions at the rear.

title: Spiritual Energy Reaching Out To This Day
description: If ever there was an irreplaceable exhibition, it is the one now signaled all over Amsterdam with banners and stickers and inscriptions in Cyrillic letters on the sides of bright yellow trams. ''Kasimir Malevich'' is the message, and ''The Stedelijk Museum'' is the place.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q & A: FRANK T. MANHEIM;
Life on a Wet Planet: Using the Oceans Wisely
description: LEAD: Last summer, Long Island residents were alarmed when medical waste of unknown origin washed up on area beaches. For many people, it underscored the need to tackle sserious environmental problems head on.

title: Back to a Dream After Nazi Nightmare
description: LEAD: THIS is the story of a dream that began in Europe, was interrupted by a nightmare and is being fulfilled in this city.

title: THE TEFLON DADDY
description: FIRST FATHER, FIRST DAUGHTER A Memoir. By Maureen Reagan. Illustrated. 415 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Katherine Heileman Hax to Marry Bradford Jameson Holmes in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hax of Trumbull, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Katherine Heileman Hax and Bradford Jameson Holmes, a son of Elizabeth Parsons Holmes of Winchester, Mass., and Canaan Valley, W.Va., and the late David Bullard Holmes.

title: FASHION: On the Street; High Hemlines, For Those Who Can
description: The issue of the short skirt has come down (up?) to a simple matter of choice: Take it or leave it. But either way, don't worry. You can still keep your department store charge cards and no one will revoke your subscriptions to fashion magazines. For the most part, the takers appear to be younger women whose figures allow them to wear the shorter lengths without a trace of self-consciousness. Currently a few women are favoring a wider skirt, but the more familiar pencil-thin shape is still the most popular. There's even a nifty abbreviated variation of the classic pleated skirt (near right). This was the kind of skirt that drew so much attention at Jean-Paul Gaultier's fashion show in Paris last week. Here it is, kicking up its pleats on Fifth Avenue.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE CLOISTER AT MARYKNOLL;
Behind the Walls, Silence Is Golden
description: LEAD: GONE are the metal grills shutting out the rest of the world, and the rule that one must be granted permission to speak. Vacant now are the quarters once occupied by extern portresses - sisters and lay people not bound to the contemplative life who acted as liaisons between those who were cloistered and all others.

title: Trip Insurance
description: To the Editor: Regarding Gilbert Weiner's experience with trip insurance (Letters, Jan. 15), he should have had a travel agent calculate the amount of insurance necessary to cover the actual costs incurred for changing his return; adequate coverage includes the cost of penalties for cruise, tour and hotel cancellations plus airline ticket penalties or the purchase of a new return ticket.

title: Some Slight Signs Of a Cooling
description: The statistics shifted enough last week to offset anxieties of inflation thatwere stoked the previous week by a report that wholesale prices had surged by 1 percent in February. This week's report on February's Consumer Price Index showed a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent - less than most analysts had predicted and lower than January's increase of six-tenths of 1 percent. The annualized inflation rate for 1989 so far is 6.1 percent. Another sign of easing pressure came from a report that factory orders for durable goods fell for the second straight month in February, by 3.6 percent. The auto industry reported that sales remained sluggish in mid-March, rising only 2.8 percent. That is equivalent to an annual sales rate of 6.8 million vehicles, which some analysts say is not enough to clear out inventories.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
At the Tone, Hang Up
description: LEAD: I HAVEN'T spoken to my friends in months. I speak to their answering machine. These days, everyone speaks to answering machines.

title: A Big Bite For Nolan Archibald
description: There is no getting around it - this is a frustrating time for Nolan D. Archibald. For nearly a year he has been shopping for a suitable acquisition to round out the product line at the Black & Decker Corporation, the Towson, Md.-based power-tool and household-appliance company he's headed for three years. A run at American Standard Inc. fizzled when the price got too high. And a run at Sunbeam/Oster fell apart when Allegheny International Inc., Sunbeam's parent, changed its plans for emerging from bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Missing From the Classroom
description: AFTER more than 25 years of teaching, I have left toiling in the classroom for the tranquility of a job in the central office. I never thought I'd do it.

title: Marjorie Ravitz, Podiatrist, Weds Dr. Elliot R. Rossein
description: Dr. Marjorie Carol Ravitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Ravitz of Smithtown, L.I., and Dr. Elliot Robert Rossein, a son of Marcella Rossein of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Dr. Withal Rossein, were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Elliott T. Spar.

title: Cooperation, Not Competition, Wins
description: While American companies were busy competing with each other, many foreign companies began working together. As a result, foreign companies are making strong gains against their once solidly entrenched American competitors.

title: Hospitals' Drive For More Nurses Brings Pay Rise
description: To recruit and retain nurses, hospitals throughout the nation last year gave them their largest real pay increase in history.

title: Outside In
description: Garden elements have been a recurring theme in the decorative arts for centuries, but it is only recently that materials and objects meant for use outdoors are finding their way inside. Terra-cotta vases and wire tables, stone benches and twig furniture - pieces that traditionally adorned patios or porches or gardens - are becoming as integral a part of interior schemes as the living-room sofa.

title: Michele Horowitz Marries
description: Michele Horowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Horowitz of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York to Seth Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Adler of West Brighton, S.I. Rabbi Benjamin Wykansky, a grandfather of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Raphael Adler, the bridegroom's brother, officiated. The bride, a loan administrator at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, graduated from Boston University. The bridegroom, a computer consultant at Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York, graduated from Baruch College of the City University of New York.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Sparing Trees: The Laws Get Tougher
description: LEAD: IN an effort to reduce the impact of new development on the dwindling supply of open space, most municipalities on the Island now require developers to say why they must clear out trees before they grantsubdivision approvals.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIRE. By Nik Gowing. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) The job of a thriller is to entertain. This one does it perfectly, by means of a classical ploy: multiple threads converging toward an exciting denouement. The action revolves around a K.G.B. scheme to assassinate the Polish leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, judged by the Russians as too soft on the Solidarity movement.

title: THE JOURNALISM GAME
description: A YEAR IN THE SUN The Games, the Players, the Pleasure of Sports. By George Vecsey. 334 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Justice Dept. Lawyers Assail Anti-Abortion Effort
description: In an unusual challenge to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, career lawyers at the Justice Department are protesting the department's efforts to overturn the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that guaranteed a woman's right to an abortion.

title: Riot in Indian State Assembly
description: A brawl broke out in a south Indian state legislature today, with opposition and ruling party members trading punches and throwing files, desks and microphones, Indian news agencies reported. The leader of the opposition, Jayalalitha Jayaram, once a leading lady in Indian films, fled the Tamil Nadu state assembly in tears after being hit by a stack of files.

title: Sports of The Times; L. T.'s Tightrope: Did He Slip? Or Did He Fall?
description: According to his friends, Lawrence Taylor had been walking cautiously and thoughtfully across the tightrope of his career, if not of his life, for the last seven months. As a two-time offender of the National Football League's drug policy, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker has been within one misstep of toppling off that tightrope into permanent suspension, subject to appeal after one year. And until early Friday morning L. T. had apparently kept his balance. Then he slipped. Or did he fall? Ultimately, that's the question Pete Rozelle, the retiring commissioner, must answer.

title: Mets' Trade a Question of Whether
description: Remember that big trade the Mets were trying to swing all winter? Well, they have one week to go before opening the season, the deal still hasn't been made, and the Mets concede that the odds are against it. But they expect the phone to ring with new urgency in the final week of spring training.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Miami; At the Tone: Phone Messages, Fully Orchestrated
description: When students at the University of Miami leave a message on a telephone answering machine, they make sure you get the message.

title: Bona Fide Shortstop
description: After a long and frustrating search, the Cleveland Indians have finally gotten a shortstop they can live with. He is Felix Fermin, a 25-year-old minor leaguer who was obtained from the Pittsburgh Pirates in a deal that brought the Pirates Jay Bell, a 23-year-old infielder who had been one of three candidates for the Cleveland shortstop slot.

title: About Cars; Range Rover's Fancier Entry
description: Range Rover 4390 Parliament Place Lanham, Md. 20706

title: Thomas Ross 3d And Anne Walsh To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George J. Walsh of Garden City, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Anne Patrice Walsh to Thomas Joseph Ross 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Ross Jr. of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE VIEW FROM ST. PATRICK'S
description: ONE OF THE MOST POWERFUL men in the American Roman Catholic Church is hosting his own weekly talk show from his residence behind St. Patrick's Cathedral. His study, with its striking stained-glass windows, has been converted into a television studio, the bookcases and sofa moved out and replaced by three cameras and batteries of tall and hot lights.

title: Knicks Put Jackson Back in the Lineup
description: The Knicks not only reactivated Mark Jackson for last night's game against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden but also inserted him into the starting lineup.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY
description: YOU BE GOOD & I'LL BE NIGHT Jump-on-the-Bed Poems. By Eve Merriam. Illustrated by Karen Lee Schmidt. Unpaged. New York: Morrow Junior Books.

title:
>GARDENING;
Taming Vines on Trees or on the Ground
description: LEAD: IT'S not uncommon for English ivy to be planted as a ground cover under a tree canopy. Its glossy, dark green foliage makes it desirable for this purpose. English ivy spreads its verdant carpet by creeping along the ground or by climbing. As it climbs, the juvenile creeper will ultimately transform into a mature, flowering plant that will produce seeds to perpetuate the species.

title: Horseshoes Anyone?
description: President Bush has revealed his plans for a formal dedication of his new horseshoe pit Saturday, as well as an invitational tournament later in the spring that will mix celebrities and Cabinet members with White House gardeners, chefs, secretaries and drivers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The initial response was inadequate and didn't match the planned outlined response measures to be taken in a spill.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
'IN HERE WE GOT TIME'
description: LEAD: For IN PRISON (Holt, $39.95), the photographer and film maker Douglas Kent Hall visited penal institutions over a seven-year period and photographed and interviewed inmates, most of them at a New Mexico prison near Santa Fe. While Mr. Hall includes a few shots of setting - a guard tower, the prison yard -most of his photographs are posed portraits.

title: Problems Run Deep In Celtics' Transition
description: As the Boston Celtics were losing another game recently, this time to the Bucks in Milwaukee last week, a delighted Bucks fan yelled, ''Say, Jimmy, why don't you put Larry Bird in the game?''

title: Anglican Archbishop to Visit Pope in Fall for Unity Talks
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, leader of the 70 million-member Anglican Communion, will visit Pope John Paul II in Rome this year for talks aimed at increasing unity between their two churches.

title: Bridge Players And Insults
description: Perhaps Barbara Klaus wrote her article on bridge [ ''About Long Island: High Cards, Bigger Egos,'' March 5 ] with tongue in cheek (and perhaps not), but I was very angry to read my own words taken out of context.

title: Lakewood Township Journal; Residents Upset by Cost of Hookup to Public Water
description: A LARGE red tack is the center of interest on the Ocean County Health Department map of Pine Acre Estates, a 343-house development at the southern tip of this township.

title: For Israel, A Clash of Information And Policy
description: FOR months and months, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his aides have been meeting with all manner of West Bank and Gaza Strip Palestinians, struggling to find even one who speaks with authority but is not affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Eddie Giacomin: A Class Act
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Turkey Is Feeling The Pull of The Islamic
description: PART European and virtually all Moslem, Turkey has worked hard to keep the diverse components of its personality in balance. That task has become more complicated in recent weeks, and has had to take into account elements as disconnected as Islamic head scarves, Salman Rushdie and trade with Iran.

title: 'I'm Coming Home'
description: Randall Dale Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a Dallas police officer in 1976, was the subject last year of a critically acclaimed film, ''The Thin Blue Line,'' in which the prosecution's four principal witnesses contradicted their original testimony. One witness said he had been alone at the scene but stopped short of confessing to the killing. Last week, Mr. Adams was released after 12 1/2 years in prison and after an appeals court overturned the conviction, ruling that prosecutors suppressed evidence and used perjured testimony. The Dallas District Attorney's office tried to block Mr. Adams's release but then decided not to retry him, citing a lack of ''sufficient credible evidence.'' After his release, Mr. Adams said, ''It smells pretty good out here. Tell my mom I'm coming home.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Hastings-on-Hudson
description: LIKE a picture window in a small room, the view of the New Jersey Palisades from the three bosky hills of Hastings-on-Hudson creates an illusion of expansiveness in this village of only two square miles.

title: The View From: Branford; Trolley Rides in the Cause of Open Space
description: TENACIOUSLY holding onto the last vestiges of undeveloped land has become a constant battle for many Connecticut towns. In Branford, a shoreline community just east of New Haven, the fight is over a 66-acre tract called Beacon Hill.

title: Grey Holds Stage as 'Cabaret' M.C.
description: A SINGLE bright white spotlight is all the introduction Joel Grey requires as he bounces onto the Westbury Music Fair's circular center stage. This is ''Cabaret,'' the musical by Joe Masteroff, John Kander and Fred Ebb, about life in Berlin during the formation of the Third Reich.

title: Jean M. Hanavan To Wed C. J. Kelly
description: Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., and Northfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jean Marie Hanavan to Christopher John Kelly, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kelly of Schenectady, N.Y. A January wedding is planned.

title: Cooking With Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Mia L. Manning To Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Garry W. Barringer of Hinckley, N.Y., of the engagement of Mrs. Barringer's daughter Mia Lorraine Manning to Robert Compton Osborn, a son of Marcia Lontz Osborn of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Donald R. Osborn of New York. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: North Canaan, Conn.$86,250 West Main Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 63-year-old, 1-story frame house; enclosed porch, needs work; taxes $641. Ridgefield, Conn.$307,000 49 Nursery Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; new kitchen, new master bath, 1 acre; taxes $3,114. Wilton, Conn.$363,000 34 Saddle Ridge 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; adjacent to reservoir land, 2 loft rooms, 2 acres; taxes $3,509. Armonk, N.Y.$535,000 69 Whippoorwill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 199-year-old farmhouse; 2 marble fireplaces, den, barn/garage with loft, bedroom and bath, 1.4 acres; taxes $4,265. Chappaqua, N.Y.$541,500 6 Alto Lane North 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; 2 living rooms, 2 dens, greenhouse, 1 acre; taxes $9,300. Rye Brook, N.Y.$420,000 15 Winthrop Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; family room, Florida room, patio, playroom, cathedral ceiling; taxes $5,788. OTHER AREAS Hauppauge, L.I.$199,900 69 Eagle Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,200. North Patchogue, L.I.$149,900 371 West Woodside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; den with fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Brielle, N.J.$276,000 8 Beech Court 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; deck, fireplace in living room, c/a; taxes $3,133.

title: United 747 Loses Piece of Wing Over Pacific
description: A United Airlines jumbo jet bound for San Francisco with 357 people aboard returned to Manila today after a piece of one wing peeled off over the Pacific Ocean.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GOVERNING THE $5 TRILLION ECONOMY. By Herbert Stein. (Oxford University, $17.95.) Most of us seem to think of a properly run economy as we think of art or obscenity: we can't say exactly what it is, but we know it when we see it. Now - just as the Brobdingnagian Federal budget deficit has moved to the top of the national agenda - along comes the economist Herbert Stein to tell us that red ink is not the real problem.

title: Diane Seaman Is Wed To Eric Mark Schwartz
description: Diane Ellen Seaman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Seaman of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening at Temple Beth El to Eric Mark Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Schwartz of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and Rabbi Shlomo Balter officiated.

title: Three Mideast Figures Meet to Plan Strategy
description: The leaders of Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization met today to coordinate a Middle East peace strategy in preparation for talks in Washington in April and May between leaders from the region and President Bush.

title: G.M. vs. ROSS PEROT: BREAKING UP IS HARD TO DO
description: THE BUSINESS WORLD'S equivalent of a pit-bull match is scheduled for a state court in Fairfax, Va., in less than two weeks. The trial involves one of the nation's richest men, H. Ross Perot, and one of the world's biggest industrial concerns, the General Motors Corporation.

title: Dr. Zane Kevin Saul Is Wed to Cindy Falk
description: Cindy Meryl Falk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Falk of Washington, was married there last evening at the Ritz-Carlton to Dr. Zane Kevin Saul, the son of Gordon Saul of Philadelphia and the late Arlene Hinda Saul. Rabbi Avis Miller performed the ceremony.

title: Once Upon a Time, Before the $5 Popcorn...
description: THE coupon in the paper importuned with silent grace. Presentation of that slip of paper at the box office would entitle me, if I were to purchase one full-price admission ticket, to a second one at no cost whatsoever at the brand new Glitter-on-the-Highway.

title: In L.I. Murder Case, Focus Turns to Science
description: In a warren of laboratories behind locked doors on the second floor of the Nassau County police headquarters here, a small band of scientists may well determine the outcome of the Kelly Tinyes murder case.

title: DEFICIT FIGURING DOESN'T ADD UP
description: Curiously, the graphs accompanying Mr. Morris's essay include some inexplicable anomalies. In the graphs, the dollar value of the deficit is expressed as a positive number; therefore, the quotient of the deficit divided by the G.N.P. must also be a positive number, because, by definition, the value of the G.N.P. is positive. Yet, though the graph of the absolute Federal deficit shows positive values in 1960 and 1969, the graph of the deficit relative to the G.N.P. shows negative values for these years, a mathematical contradiction. ALAN JONES New York, N.Y.

title: A New Blueprint For U.S. Forces
description: The new Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, has hardly settled in his seat and already the civilian and uniformed sachems of the military tribe are leaping about him with their hair on fire, urging immediate decisions. He should refuse - until he has made his most important choice.

title: Bush Selects Taft as Ambassador to NATO
description: President Bush intends to nominate William Howard Taft 4th, the former Deputy Defense Secretary, to be Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the White House said Friday.

title: Handyman Special: Bargain With a 'but'
description: WHEN they finally finish working on the rundown 29-year-old colonial they bought in Westfield, N.J., two years ago, Larry and Susan Sharpe believe it will be worth about $450,000.

title: When the Job is Done, the Play's the Thing
description: The world would be poorer if a shop owner could not don a flounced purple dress once in a while to portray a tuba player in a marimba band, or if a genial teacher could not become - for a few performances, anyway - the horrible Mr. Hyde.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Big 1988. CBS-Fox. 1 hour, 44 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned (CC). Rated PG.

title: A Bristol Visit Anchored In the Past
description: MY favorite spot in Bristol is the damp, cobbled floor of the Great Western Drydock. From down there, hemmed in by stone walls fitted almost a century and a half ago, amid mossy puddles, a voluptuous sweep of red-orange hull looms above. The hull belongs to the Great Britain; launched in 1843, she was the fist iron-hulled, propeller-driven trans-Atlantic liner - in fact, the first such vessel to cross any ocean.

title: Creating Theatrical Worlds for Dancers to Inhabit
description: Throughout this century, prominent artists have collaborated with choreographers. Many of their stage designs for dances have been attractive to look at. But the best of these designs have been more than pretty pictures. By calling attention to some aspect of a work's choreography, a design can enhance that work's meaning.

title: Good Prices, and Caveats, in Hong Kong Pearls
description: RUBIES blaze, diamonds sparkle, pearls glow from the windows of hundreds of Hong Kong jewelery shops. Hong Kong is a serious competitor in the world's jewelry markets, offering values unmatched in New York or in Europe.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday on the Rite of Christian Initiation for Adults, a program of baptism for Catholics, incorrectly quoted the Rev. Daniel E. Danielson, a pastor in Alameda County, Calif. Saying that the program's emphasis on welcoming people into the church has led to similar programs for alienated Catholics returning to the church, Father Danielson said, ''You can't have an R.C.I.A. program without a program for returning Catholics.''

title: YANKS NARROW FIELD IN SHORTSTOP BERBY
description: When the deal with the Atlanta Braves suddenly collapsed on Friday afternoon, the Yankees essentially opened their shortstop job to two players who have been in camp since the middle of February: Alvaro Espinoza and Randy Velarde. Hardly household names. Espinoza and Velarde are neither veterans nor known commodities. They are both still relatively young, both regarded as capable infielders, both known for their defense more than for their offense.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A WILFUL WOMAN. By Michael Talbot. (Knopf, $18.95.) Australia's singular history has long been like a giant flypaper for writers. And Michael Talbot, the author of ''To the Ends of the Earth'' (the first novel in a projected series about New South Wales), is clearly content to be stuck there. Still, in the second installment, ''A Wilful Woman,'' he brings something new to the oft-rehearsed story of the colony's founding - a deep if rueful affection for the improbable dreams of the convicts and colonial overlords who stumbled onto the beach at Botany Bay in 1788.

title: Power Panaceas Are a Delusion
description: John Hurley's letter [ ''Shoreham: The Hydro Option,'' March 5 ] illustrates the anti-nuke delusion as no Lilco advocate could. He suggests hydro power or natural gas as Shoreham alternatives. Natural gas is not new. Hydro power is not new. It is the prime mover that launched the Industrial Revolution.

title: Miss Corney Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Corney of Nashville, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Tyler Corney, to Peter Cornelius Van Allen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Van Allen of Iowa City and Southampton, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Said el-Mufti of Jordan Is Dead; Ex-Premier Helped Found Nation

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; A 6-Mile Sliver of Sand and History
description: If you hunger for a look at sand and sparkling water now that spring has officially arrived, an hour's ride to Sandy Hook, N.J., will take you to another world.

title: Begin Expected To Speak Out
description: Menachem Begin, who has avoided public appearances since stepping down as Prime Minister in 1983, is expected make a few remarks on Israel Army radio Sunday morning to mark the tenth anniversary of the Camp David accords according to his secretary.

title: What the Forensic Team Found
description: THE report on the Chief Mamaronock bones, prepared by the Metropolitan Forensic Anthropology Team at Lehman College in the Bronx, reaches several conclusions.

title: Don't Show a Sole in Arabia
description: LEAD: THERE is nothing wrong with being offensive to some people. Telephone solicitors come readily to mind. Offending them might improve their characters and in any case couldn't worsen them. Giving offense is a well-established custom; in Western societies the people form teams, called political parties, so they can trade mean-spirited behavior back and forth.

title: Catherine Meyer Engaged to Wed Jeffrey Warlich
description: The engagement of Catherine Seaton Meyer to Jeffrey C. Warlich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Warlich of St. Paul, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Beverly Barry Meyer of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and John DeBard Meyer of Brooklyn and North Egremont, Mass. A May 13 wedding is planned.

title: Frederic Fekkai: Hair Stylist
description: Since arriving in this country in 1983, Frederic Fekkai has turned many a famous head. Jessica Lange, Kelly McGillis, Dustin Hoffman, Kelly and Calvin Klein have trusted him with their tresses. After wielding his scissors at the Bruno Dessange sa lon and at the socialites' favorite, Monsieur Marc, both in Manhat tan, he took over the sa lon at Bergdorf Good man on March 14.

title: Subway Systems
description: To the Editor: You can add Caracas, Venezuela, to your list of cities with subways (Q & A, Feb. 12). While it only had a few stations in the fall of 1987 when I was there, it surely is longer than that now. A. ELIZABETH EICHMAN Rosemont, Pa.

title: Cynthia Grant to Wed Robert Tykot
description: Prof. William Chase Grant Jr. of Williamstown, Mass., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Cynthia Armstrong Grant, to Robert Howard Tykot, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard B. Tykot of Westfield, N.J. The future bride also is the daughter of the late Joan Armstrong Grant. An April wedding is planned.

title: Day Care Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exposed concrete under the white clapboard around the outside of our house is painted white. When it rains, dirt splashes up onto the white and it is difficult to clean. What can I put down to prevent this splashing?

title: India Closes Most Roads to Nepal in Trade Dispute
description: India has closed vital routes between this landlocked Himalayan nation and the rest of the world as part of a trade dispute, Nepalese officials say.

title: Lisa C. Stockman to Wed John A. LoScalzo May 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Stockman of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Celia Stockman to John Anthony LoScalzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John LoScalzo of Huntington, L.I. A May 20 wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
Connecticut Artists Are Given Rooms of Their Own
description: LEAD: THE enlargement of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield a few seasons back has allowed for something close to one's ''wildest dreams'' to be staged there. Artists can mount site-specific installations in their own rooms. The four such installations in ''Connecticut Artists,'' an eight-person invitational show, revealed that this freedom was indulged in.

title:
FOCUS: Miami;
A Recovery on Luxury Condominium Row
description: LEAD: NEW owners have taken over the 130 apartments that the developer never sold in a luxurious condominium here called Villa Regina, opening a new chapter in the saga of the overbuilt housing market on fashionable Brickell Avenue.

title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club
description: This ain't no party, this ain't no disco . . . this ain't no Mudd Club or CBGB's. . . . - ''Life During Wartime,'' Talking Heads

title: THE SIMPLE SORROWS OF THE RICH
description: LEAD: FELLOW PASSENGERS A Novel in Portraits. By Louis Auchincloss. 223 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Borrowed Life

title: Rose Finally Breaks His Silence
description: In his first substantive response to allegations about his gambling activities, Manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds yesterday described as ridiculous a report that he had flashed signals relating to baseball betting to a friend in the stands at Riverfront Stadium.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WOMEN AND CLERGYMEN An unusual one-woman play written by Sister Irene Mahoney, professor emerita of English at the College of New Rochelle, will be performed at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday in Romita Auditorium on the campus, at 29 Castle Place.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exposed concrete under the white clapboard around the outside of our house is painted white. When it rains, dirt splashes up onto the white and it is difficult to clean. What can I put down to prevent this splashing?

title: LATE GAMES LAST NIGHT
description: The Rangers' game with the Flyers in Philadelphia, the Devils' game with the Penguins in Pittsburgh and the Knicks' game against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden began too late to be included in this edition.

title: Wobbly Chair Woes
description: WOBBLY chairs are annoying and, if allowed to worsen, can lead to accidents. Most wobbles are caused by broken glue joints, due either to deterioration of old glue or to excess strain placed on chair parts.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Housing Spreads Along Sussex Border
description: LEAD: GROWTH pressures that opened up the Sussex County housing market five years ago are steadily pushing development along its eastern border into Hardyston's 39 square miles of mostly open fields, lakes and thick woodlands.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD;
To Raise Awareness Drop the Price
description: LEAD: BECAUSE THE CACHET OF NEWNESS WEARS off quickly, home video manufacturers try to regain consumer attention in several ways. One tack is to combine old videos and present them as retrospectives of the films of particular stars. Another method is to discount formerly expensive videos and reoffer them at bargain rates.

title: College Pipeline Has Many Costs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Store Interiors; Seducing Customers in Highly Competitive Markets
description: UP against cutthroat competition in their pursuit of customers, retailers today are gutting stores and creating more expensive interiors at a quickening pace.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Dog Training 101 ''THIS is going to be a comic piece, right?'' said Stephanie Reyer of Great Neck, holding her dog Sasha in a vice grip as dogs in various stages of terror and excitement entered the auditorium of Great Neck's Cumberland Elementary School. Sasha, a large German shepherd-husky-mix, was going into a barking frenzy every time a new dog came in. ''She'll be expelled before we start,'' Mrs. Reyer said.

title: TV Trivializes The Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Last 2 Minutes Are 18 Too Many
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Leslie Ann Davis Plans a Wedding To W. R. Dahl Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. George A. Davis of Summit, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Leslie Ann Davis to W. Robert Dahl Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dahl of Manhasset, L.I. The couple plan to marry in September. Ms. Davis, a magna cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, is an associate in corporate finance at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York. Her father is an executive vice president and the chief financial officer at C. R. Bard Inc., a health care and hospital-supply company in Murray Hill, N.J. Her mother, Maria Davis, owns Maria N. Davis Inc., a corporate art consultant in New York.

title: Permanent Lent
description: Easter celebrates resurrection and renewal. It also marks the end of Lent, 40 weekdays of fasting and special penitence when millions of Christians forsake the sinful pleasures of the palate and the perils of strong drink and nicotine, and give themselves over to abstinence of all kinds.

title: Capital Official Sees Crime Drop Once Pushers Divide Markets
description: Under mounting public criticism over the crime wave in the nation's capital, Police Chief Maurice T. Turner Jr. says the police are doing all they can and predicts that the murder rate will fall once drug dealers finish dividing their markets.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: No Sign of Drugs In Taylor, Police Say
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, had no drugs in his system when he was arrested on an alcohol-related charge, Capt. Thomas B. Gallagher of the New Jersey State Police said today.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Villanova; New-Style Dorm Has Men, Women And Visiting Rules
description: Next fall, male and female students at Villanova University will be living in the same dormitory for the first time in the school's 147-year history.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on New London on March 12 misidentified the captain of the Half Moon, a replica of which will visit the port this summer. He was Henry Hudson.

title: Tamara Warren Is Wed
description: At the Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles, Tamara Mari Warren, a daughter of Tana Warren of Covina, Calif., and Allen E. Warren of Newport Beach, Calif., was married last evening to Michael Evan Silver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Silver of Scarsdale, N.Y., by Rabbi Steven Leder. The bride, a graduate of the University of Southern California, is an account manager in Los Angeles with the American teaching aids division of Simon & Schuster. The bridegroom, an associate in the Los Angeles office of the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, is a graduate of Harvard University and the New York University School of Law.

title: Modern Sculpture Of 11 Black Artists At Bronx Museum
description: A CURATOR recently said the length of his show's title reflected the ''curatorial ambitions behind its organization.'' He may or may not have been speaking for the majority but there is no doubt that the title telling all is here to stay.

title: HATS
description: They bobbed on the dance floor at Au Bar, graced dinner tables at Raoul's and Barocco. At chic clubs and eateries from mid-Manhattan to TriBeCa, it seemed as if hats had arrived. Giddy, colorful, always excessive, they were the riveting focal point of more than a few evening turnouts.

title: Cashing In on the Oscars
description: Hollywood's Academy Awards are hardly averse to commercialism. Preparations for Oscar night this Wednesday include special racks mounted inside limousine doors, to display a row of Coca-Cola products when the stars climb out.

title: N.H.L/Friday's Games; Capitals Impress Themselves
description: Pete Peeters, the Washington Capital goalie, had seen only one performance like this before.

title: Sex, Censors and Rock
description: Can overexposure to music video cause hallucinations and delusions? Consider, as a case study, the cover story in the Feb. 24, 1989, issue of National Review, ''Rock of Ageds'' by Stuart Goldman.

title: His Party Aside, Giuliani Has an Edge
description: EVERY quarter century or so, a combination of an unpopular Democratic Mayor and an attractive Republican challenger has managed to break the Democratic stranglehold on New York's City Hall. In 1965, it was John V. Lindsay for two terms and in 1933, Fiorello H. LaGuardia for three terms.

title: Mary Hogue Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Mary Louise Hogue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Hogue of Bronxville, N.Y., to Guy Gleysteen, a son of Zoe Gleysteen of Bethesda, Md., and William H. Gleysteen Jr. of New York, took place yesterday at the Bronxville Field Club. The Rev. Dr. Donald L. Berry, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: A NEW book, ''The Case of the Nazi Professor,'' by David M. Oshinsky, Richard P. McCormick and Daniel Horn (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick, $35; paper, $15), joins the category of books about controversies that refuse to go away.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN, CULTURE, & POLITICS. By Angela Y. Davis. (Random House, $17.95.) In a commencement address to the Berkeley High School graduating class of 1983, Angela Y. Davis asked the students to imagine an almost perfect world: one in which all university education is free, there is no sexism or racism and no poverty.

title: Jonathon M. Gerson Weds Lee Ann Duffy
description: Lee Ann Duffy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Duffy of Hackensack, N.J., and Jonathon M. Gerson, a son of Dr. Arnold Gerson of White Plains and the late Elizabeth Gerson, were married yesterday in a private hall in Manhattan. Judge Zachary Carter of City Criminal Court officiated.

title: Requests Soar To Obtain Gun Permits
description: Will it be a finely checkered rosewood grip, cool and perfectly balanced against the palm, with a long sighting plane and a blue-steel barrel machined to a hairbreatdth tolerance for marksman-grade performance? Or will any gun do, just for the sense of it, there in the bureau at night, powerful enough to stop the worst nightmare?

title: Budget Nears The Point of No Pretense
description: A CONSENSUS is forming among politicians and economists, liberals and conservatives, that the only practical way to make a fundamental assault on the Federal budget deficit is for Republicans and Democrats to relinquish their strongest political weapons.

title: I Musici Cancellation
description: The Italian ensemble I Musici has canceled its April 23d Carnegie Hall concert because of a schedule conflict. The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra will play instead, at 3 P.M. The program will include works by Corelli, Dvorak, Schoenberg and Bartok. I Musici tickets will be honored. Additional tickets, at $18 and $14, are available at the box office. Information: 247-7800.

title: STREETSCAPES: 603 Park Avenue; A Grand Mystery House Up for Sale at $20 Million
description: IT could arguably be described as the grandest single-family residence in New York, with a full 100-foot frontage on Park Avenue at the northeast corner of 64th Street. Such a claim may account for the asking price of $20 million for the old Thomas A. Howell residence built in 1920.

title: Keep Profit Motive Out of High School Sports
description: Earlier this month a national cable network announced a five-year contract with the National Federation of State High School Associations - composed of the 51 state high school athletic/activity associations in the United States - to televise a weekly package of high school sporting events, mostly basketball and football games.

title: County's Libraries Plan Events for Young Readers
description: LEAD: WHEN the Library of Congress designated 1989 as the Year of the Young Reader, it echoed a theme familiar to Westchester library users. ''We are constantly promoting the use of books for young readers,'' said Diane Courtney, adult-young adult and media consultant for the Westchester Library System.

title: As Islam Is Revived, Secular Turks Wince
description: After the Friday noon service, hundreds of worshipers streamed out of the Sultan Selim Camii mosque, and to a man they dropped worn paper money onto a bright red rug that served as a collection plate.

title: A PEP TALK FOR THE HOME TEAM
description: MORE LIKE US Making America Great Again. By James Fallows. 245 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Inflation's Threat To Pensions
description: INFLATION'S coming back: bad news for New Jersey's budget, since the prices of everything the state buys, including salaries, are rising; worse news for the state pension system.

title: NETS' FRUSTRATION GROWS WITH LOSING STREAK
description: The longer the Nets' losing streak goes on, the more frustrating it becomes for the organization.

title: Study Finds More New York Trash, Despite 'Crisis'
description: People in New York State are throwing away more garbage than ever, even though it is widely recognized that landfills are running out of space, a report by a nonprofit lobbying group says.

title: Over the Transom. The What?
description: In Boston, The Globe reports on a scandal in which new dirt ''is coming in, under and over transoms all over the city.'' Terrorist threats against airlines keep coming in ''over the transom,'' says a TV commentator. During the Tower confirmation debate, White House chief of staff John Sununu spoke of bizarre allegations ''coming in over the transom.'' Over the what?

title: Necessity Creates Nanny Businesses
description: LESLIE SULLIVAN, a computer program designer, became so frustrated in her attempts to replace her young children's baby sitters with someone who would live in her Larchmont home that she decided to do something about it.

title: From TV, Secret Lives Revealed
description: LEAD: DESPITE his open, ebullient on-camera personna, Roberto Tirado, News 12 Long Island's weatherman, has a secret: He sings.

title: Kabul Regime Reports 2 New Rebel Attacks
description: The Afghan Government today reported new rebel attacks against the besieged eastern city of Jalalabad and against Kandahar, a city in the southwest.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Dr. Norbert W. Sander Jr.;
Taking a Stand on Athletes and Steroids
description: LEAD: WHEN Ben Johnson, the Canadian athlete, was stripped of his Olympic gold medal last summer after he tested positive for steroids, much of the world that followed sports was shocked. Did he really do it? If so, how had he got away with it in the past? And who else was getting away with it?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: U.S., France Considering Dropping Visas

title: Israel Isn't the Worst Human Rights Offender; The Citizens Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: No Luck in Unloading Your House? Sell It to Your Employer
description: Employers commonly help pick up the tab when employees are relocated - paying for moving expenses, brokers' fees and hotel accommodations. But with real estate prices rising wildly in most cities and interest rates unpredictable, at best, companies are now doing more.

title: When Audience and Cast Combine
description: THE killer, the victim - maybe, even the corpse - could be seated at your table. During the new Friday night murder-mystery series at the Spinning Wheel Inn, in Redding Ridge, the audience and the cast mingle in what may well be the most informal sampling of environmental or participatory theater yet.

title:
DINING OUT;
French Fare With New American Dash
description: LEAD: PULLING up to the restaurant on the hill above the center of Bernardsville, one might think it is a little Bavarian tavern or an Iberian pub, perhaps, with its half-timbered exterior and Spanish-style door. But inside, the florid gray wallpaper, which lends a dated country-inn air to the dining room and small bar, and a glance at the French menu reminds one that this is Le Petit Chateau, a Somerset

title: Stylish Swimsuits to Minimize Flaws
description: Buying a swimsuit is a lesson in self-knowledge, especially for the woman whose body is imperfect. ''The truth is, no swimsuit can hide flaws,'' said Norma Kamali, the fashion designer. ''You're exposed.''

title: CLASH AT DARTMOUTH
description: On my first day as a freshman at Dartmouth, in 1978, I was approached and surrounded by three enormous football players who grinned and crisply initiated me into Dartmouth social reality: ''See this, pretty girl? There's three of us, one of you. Got it? That's how it is here. Welcome to Dartmouth.''

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Use a stiff metal rake over the lawn to finish spring cleanup; add leaves and small debris to compost. Shake cayenne pepper or dried chili peppers around spring bulbs, especially crocus, chionodoxa and early tulips to discourage feeding by squirrels and other rodents. Finish pruning fruit trees. Dormant Spraying

title: Now, I'm Against Abortion
description: LEAD: I want to come out of a closet in which I have hidden for years.

title: Clerk Held in Statutory Rape
description: A clerk at a Queens high school has been charged with the statutory rape of a 15-year-old student who is the daughter of a diplomat, the police said yesterday. The clerk, John Gordon, 40 years old, of 100 Woodruff Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was arrested Friday afternoon at the Plaza North Hotel in Ridgewood, where he was found with the student, a police spokesman, Sgt. Maurice Howard, said. He was charged with five counts of rape and one of endangering the welfare of a minor.

title: Jane Runge Is Engaged
description: Jane Elizabeth Runge, an associate at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York, and Craig Wesley Sanger, an associate director at the same company, are planning an April 29 wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Runge of Roslyn, L.I., have announced. Miss Runge graduated from Long Island Lutheran High School in Brookville and magna cum laude from the University of Delaware. Mr. Sanger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert R. Sanger of Weston, Mass., graduated from the Noble and Greenough School and Bowdoin College.

title: County Outlines Its Federal Agenda
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S Congressional delegation, two Democrats and two Republicans, and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican seeking re-election, spoke almost as one last week in describing the Federal assistance they felt the county needed most this year.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Easter Luncheon

title: No Free Lunch
description: To the Editor: Ron Nowicki's piece brings to mind similar Florida land deals run amok during the 60's and 70's. My husband and I loved them. We had the perfect ploy. After playing along and enjoying the dinner, we listened ''excitedly'' to the banter and, in fact, even reached out as if to sign the contract. We'd scan it through and then drop the bomb - ''This is great. We love it. Tell you what. We'll take this along for our lawyer to review and we'll get back to you.'' Bingo! The contract was grabbed back out of our hands, and we were on our way. ALMA R. JURGENSEN Hawley, Pa.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Brown; Dating Is Dead; Its Replacement Is Befuddlement
description: It seems as though it used to be so simple.

title: A Crowded Race for Mayor In Jersey City
description: ST. PATRICK'S DAY has passed, and the Governor's mansion is up for grabs this year. People in Jersey City know that this means a mayoral campaign is brewing in the state's second largest city. The campaign may be one of the liveliest in years.

title: Amid Crisis Over Rebels, Sudan Shifts Government
description: A new coalition Government was formed today after a monthlong political crisis over pursuing a peace settlement with rebels in the south.

title: George Markham, Hotelier, 63
description: George Markham, president and general manager of the Carlyle Hotel, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: 'We're Basically Writing a Constitution,' Says Charter Panel Chairman
description: New York City, which has one of the nation's most peculiar forms of government, might be headed for a system with new elements that are common elsewhere. These could include a larger legislature or one with two houses, a voting method that gives small groups a bigger voice and management procedures aimed at avoiding last-minute decisions.

title: Stanley Takes Aim at the N.R.A.>
description: ''Well,'' said STanley, ''will I see you at the Lazars' Wednesday night?'' ''I can't,'' I said, ''I have a funeral.'' ''I don't blame you,'' said Stanley. ''I don't know whether I'll go either. I love Swifty and Mary, but Spago is only so big, and after a while, you can't really talk to anybody. Besides, I'm not interested in watching the Oscar show this year. I mean, there's not one picture I wish I had produced.''

title: Question Of the Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
description: The Olympic cats and the baseball owner cats are much fatter now. If only he could be persuaded to be the Secretary of the Treasury. Think of the possibilities. OWEN A. MURPHY Bronx

title: 10 People Are Hurt In New Jersey as Car Crashes Into Market
description: A car crashed through a window of a crowded supermarket in West Orange, N.J., yesterday afternoon, injuring 10 people before coming to rest at a checkout counter, the police said.

title: Nothing Amiss in Circulating Bush Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Liz Gessner Plans A May Wedding To Michael Miller
description: The engagement of Judith Elizabeth Gessner to Michael Campion Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Miller Jr. of Washington, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Gessner Jr. of New Orleans. A May wedding is planned.

title: Visits to Valhalla: The Ectasy And the Agony
description: The earliest audiences for Wagner's ''Ring,'' like audiences everywhere and always, fussed over trivia as readily they waxed eloquent over the spectacular experience of the monumental opera cycle. Nineteenth and early 20th-century reactions to Wagner, the ''Ring,'' and Wagnerian theater, from musicians and laymen, cover a number of genres: the historical, the comical, the gastronomical, the tragical, the metaphysical, the gastronomical-metaphysical and the comical-historical.

title: U.S. Urging Afghan Rebels to Limit Opium
description: The United States has asked the Afghan rebel government in exile to curb the soaring production of opium poppies in areas of Afghanistan that its guerrillas control, Administration officials said today.

title: 'Spirit of the Ritz' Benefits Meals For the Elderly
description: They came from Paris with trunks of the stuff - tableware, ashtrays, matchboxes and wine. Yes, it was legal. And out of it all came a glittering re-creation of the blue and gold splendor of the Hotel Ritz in Paris at the Pierre in New York. Why? To raise money for Citymeals-on-Wheels, which delivers meals daily to elderly New Yorkers.

title: A Note on Work At Croton Site
description: The Feb. 19 article entitled ''The Wiew From: The Croton Reservoir Gatehouse'' is well done, except that one vital component of the project is totally missing: Mergentime Corporation is doing all the construction work reported on with such interest.

title: Change And Its Record in Salvador
description: IN 1980, in a United States-orchestrated effort to deprive a leftist revolution of its central issue, the Salvadoran Army marched onto almost 500 of this country's largest farms, expropriated the land and gave it to rural families. ''The most revolutionary land reform in Latin American history'' was the way the effort was described by the United States Ambassador, Robert E. White.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Brielle $276,000 8 Beech Court 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; deck, fireplace in living room, c/a; taxes $3,133. Lakewood $91,000 109 Woodlake Manor Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old town-house condominium; w/w carpeting, den, patio; monthly charges, $73, taxes $1,914. Marlboro $235,000 42 Damascus Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; stone fireplace, patio, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,168. Montclair $585,000 153 Eagle Rock Way 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 28-year-old Tudor; finished basement with fireplace, new kitchen, dining room; taxes $9,747. Toms River $65,000 2165 Hovsons Blvd. 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced yard, enclosed porch, h/w floors; taxes $1,154. Wall Township $174,900 1405 Juliette Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, cathedral ceiling in living room, porch; taxes $1,420. OTHER AREAS Seaford, L.I. $214,000 9 Potter Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; dining room, den, basement; taxes $4,400. Ridgefield, Conn. $307,000 49 Nursery Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; new kitchen, new master bath, 1 acre; taxes $3,114. Chappaqua, N.Y. $541,500 6 Alto Lane North 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; 2 living rooms, 2 dens, greenhouse, 1 acre; taxes $9,300.

title: Review/Country; Lyle Lovett's Song Styles
description: Among the country artists whose music has been labeled ''new traditionalist,'' Lyle Lovett is surely the least bound to country-music traditions.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 26, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week Fiction 1 2 4 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 2 2 90 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 3 5 2 ONE UP ON WALL STREET, by Peter Lynch with John Rothchild. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.)
