These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) CITIZENS: A Chronicle of the French Revolution, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A lively, eloquent narrative of the Revolution from its beginnings to the end of the Terror in 1794; Mr. Schama argues with brio and at length that the murderous violence of the whole affair was its driving force. THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) Ms. Tan's lovely first novel deals with the lives of Chinese women and their American-born daughters, souls divided in the immigrant life. DAUGHTER OF DESTINY: An Autobiography, by Benazir Bhutto. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Not just the life story of the Westernized but canny woman who became Pakistan's Prime Minister in December, but also a fascinating account of the Bhutto clan and especially of her father's political martyrdom in 1979. HOOKED, by Pauline Kael. (William Abrahams/Dutton, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) The ninth collected volume of Ms. Kael's reviews, covering more than 170 movies from July 1985 through June 1988; intelligent, approachable critical discourse all the way. OUR KIND OF PEOPLE: The Story of an American Family, by Jonathan Yardley. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $21.95.) Mr. Yardley's handsome memoir of his forebears is a pious public inquiry into the social history of the fascinating minority called WASP's. PICTURING AMERICA, 1497-1899, by Gloria Gilda Deak. (Princeton University, two volumes, $250.) A catalogue and an album of about 1,000 topographical prints from the New York Public Library, abundantly showing how the land was seen. A LONG THE RIVERRUN: Selected Essays, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $21.95.) Unfailingly astute explorations of the problems of his craft by the great literary biographer who died in 1987.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor: Santiago, Chile, and Prague, Czechoslovakia, also have excellent subways, clean and noiseless. RENEE REIMAN New York, N.Y.

title: WRITING AS COMMUNISM BURNS
description: THE GRAND FAILURE The Birth and Death of Communism in the Twentieth Century. By Zbigniew Brzezinski. 278 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: Young Inventors Solve Life's Problems
description: WHAT does one do ''when you are growing and your clothes get bigger and you need a larger hanger?'' A New Rochelle fifth grader, Justin Friedman-Hurvitz, asked himself this question and the answer was the ''Everlasting Hanger,'' a simple aluminum affair with three screws that expands, and expands and expands.

title: A Rivalry Haunted by a Bombing
description: FOR blacks, according to the premise of the playwright Jeff Stetson, the day of reckoning came on Sept. 15, 1963, when the First Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., was bombed, and four girls, in their Sunday school class, were killed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-16

title: Lesser Mortals, Let Him Be
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: In the western territories of the United States around 1850 gold abounded but gold coins were rare. To stem the growing shortage for coins, private mints began making their own coins and these are the ones called territorial gold coins. Of these private mintings one of the strangest might be those of the Mormons' Deseret Mint of Salt Lake City, Utah. Bowers and Merena, Inc. will sell some of these Mormon territorial coins at auction this week in the Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center, in Manhattan.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column last week misidentified the type of ''frozen'' Keogh retirement plans that must be amended by May 31. A Keogh plan is frozen when it no longer accepts contributions. Individuals who hold frozen ''defined-contribution'' Keogh plans - those to which they had contributed a fixed percentage of annual income - do not have to amend their plans. The amendment deadline generally applies only to certain ''defined-benefit'' plans. Defined-benefit plans are those in which owners made contributions to fund a specified payout during retirement.

title: Move to Oust Hunter Shakes Refuge He Runs
description: Dorothy Richards loved beavers. She loved them so much that they lived in her house, Beaversprite, for 42 years, eating with her at the dining room table when they weren't filing their incisors on the table's legs. She loved them so much that she left Beaversprite and 735 acres in this Adirondack foothill town for their preservation.

title: Northern Italian, With No Surprises
description: BENNY'S location on Post Avenue in downtown Westbury is next to an appliance store, across the street from a bank and a few blocks from the neighborhood movie. But this is not a haven for weary shoppers seeking a quick bite. Rather, it is that rarest of Long Island phenomena: a centrally situated, in-town restaurant offering dining on the grand scale.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/POETRY
description: JOYFUL NOISE Poems for Two Voices. By Paul Fleischman. Illustrated by Eric Beddows. 44 pp. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/Harper & Row.

title: Military Life a Roadblock to Adoption
description: Tina Sorrells recently bought a Winnie-the-Pooh comforter and some clothes for the baby she hopes to have some day. She has arranged the furniture in the baby's room and made the bed. But with every passing day Mrs. Sorrells's hope for bringing a baby into her home is dimmer.

title: Against Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: Shutting Doors Closes Out Possibilities
description: WE snickered a lot in high school poetry class. Even at an all-girl school where there were no boys to make us feel self-conscious, we snickered and rolled our eyes, but never more than when we studied Emily Dickinson. Her alienation from the world was foreign to us.

title: Crowded Jail in New Jersey Is Focus of 4 Investigations
description: The Hudson County Board of Freeholders is investigating the Hudson County Jail, one of the most overcrowded county jails in New Jersey and long a place where troubles range from the pathetic to the tragic.

title: Review/Rock; Guitar and Harmony by the Bangles
description: Few best-selling bands seem so schizophrenic as the Bangles. Although all four Bangles write songs, the band's hit singles have been cover versions or collaborations (like the conventionally romantic ballad ''Eternal Flame,'' by the Bangles' Susanna Hoffs with an established hitmaking team, Billy Steinberg and Tom Kelly), as if the Bangles were an old-fashioned ''girl group'' under a producer's control. While the Bangles' albums are pop-rock confections, with every guitar chord and keyboard tone rounded off, on stage Thursday night at the Beacon the group put its conviction into jingle-jangle 1960's-style pop-rock (with four-part vocal harmony) and guitar-driven raveups. Behind their pop trappings, the Bangles came across as a garage band at heart.

title: Question Of the Week; How Good A Job Has Ueberroth Done?
description: Ueberroth has done an excellent job. When he became commissioner, 21 of the 26 major league teams were nonprofitable. Since then, clubs are making a combined $100 million this year. He made lucrative contracts with CBS-TV, ESPN and CBS for radio rights. And best of all, he's sharing the major leagues' wealth by proposing a ticket-price freeze. So you don't need a major league salary to go out to the ball park. MICHAEL HASDAY Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Polish Easter: Eggs and Politics, Hard-Boiled
description: The business at hand was the blessing of Easter eggs, but as usual these days, the real topic was the talks between the Polish Government and the Solidarity union.

title: CARIBBEAN REVENGE
description: THE BAMBOO CANNON By Donald McCaig. 233 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $18.95.

title: Pleas for the Arts Take On a Nervous Edge
description: IT came as much needed comic relief. Cora Cahan, executive director of the Feld Ballet in New York, was delivering an impassioned statement last week before the House subcommittee that sets the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts. ''We are in peril!'' she exclaimed. ''Oh, yes,'' came the muted reply from Representative Sidney R. Yates, the Chicago Democrat who is chairman of the powerful House Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior and Related Agencies, ''this subcommittee also handles endangered species.''

title: Divisions Paralyze L.I. Power Authority
description: LEAD: ASSIGNED star status by state law in determining Long Island's energy future, the Long Island Power Authority remains paralyzed by deep divisions among its nine appointed trustees.

title: Child Care: No Shortage of Proposals
description: PRESIDENT BUSH, in introducing his child care proposal this month, declared that child care ''is one of the key issues facing the nation.'' But Congress is far from agreement on how best to provide relief for families with children, particularly those led by working parents, and the Bush proposal is only one of several.

title: Israel Isn't the Worst Human Rights Offender
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MAN WHO WAS HOLLYWOOD
description: GOLDWYN A Biography. By A. Scott Berg. Illustrated. 579 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95

title: In a Town That Grew Up, a Tempest Over Jungle Gyms
description: Betsy Wacker could not figure it out. Rebuilding the rickety old Compo Beach playground seemed like such a civic-minded idea. Who could protest a project designed by children, hand-built by parents, paid for with private money and planned by Robert Leathers, the Frank Lloyd Wright of the Sesame Street set?

title: John to Open for Yankees
description: Five months ago, on a cold and windy and overcast afternoon in Manhattan, Dallas Green walked into a midtown restaurant, met the news media and said he had no room on his team for a 45-year-old pitcher.

title: The 'Other' Freshman Earns Acclaim
description: Through all of the elite summer camps they attended together and the high school all-star games they played in, Alonzo Mourning never saw Christian Laettner play basketball the way he did today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bechtel Group Inc., San Francisco, the international construction and engineering company, named to its board Adrian Zaccaria, the executive vice president of the Bechtel Power Corporation.

title: Rockingham Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
General Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and the share earnings for the quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: Golf; Simpson's Drought Comes to an End
description: Tim Simpson made three birdies over the back nine today to pass Greg Norman and capture the $750,000 USF&G Classic with a final-round three-under-par 69.

title: Riding ICBM's Into the Past
description: Once again, Congress is trying to make the Pentagon buy weapons the country doesn't need.

title: French Trade Deficit
description: France reported on Friday a narrower trade deficit for February than had been expected. The customs office said the gap fell to a seasonally adjusted 500 million francs ($81 million) from a deficit of 2.6 billion francs in January. ''It's good news,'' a Banque Indosuez economist, Christopher Potts, said, ''but these figures are very erratic. They should be worse over the next couple of months.''

title: Driver Rams Grocery But Is Not Charged
description: An elderly man who drove his car through the window of a Pathmark supermarket, injuring at least 10 people, will not face charges, the police said yesterday.

title: Century Buys Citizens Stake
description: The Century Communications Corporation announced on Friday that it had reached an agreement with the Citizens Utilities Company to buy 900,000 shares of Citizens' series A common stock for about $48 million. Citizens, which provides telephone, electric, gas, water and waste-water services in 10 states, has 36.3 million shares of series A stock outstanding.

title: Amgen Loses Ortho Ruling
description: A Federal judge ruled last week that Amgen Inc. must submit data from its marketing partner, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, as part of Amgen's product licensing application with the Food and Drug Administration for erythropoietin.

title: Prime Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are not available because the company converted to stock ownership in November 1988.

title: Steel's Costly Crutch
description: Just four days before his election, George Bush promised that he would continue to protect the steel industry against imports. The political motive was clear: He was worried about Rust Belt votes. But the economics were faulty. America's steel industry is healthy again. The Reagan Administration's ''temporary'' import curbs ought to go.

title: Western Nations Are Raising Barriers to Refugees
description: While 12 million people are officially counted as refugees who have fled persecution or violence in their homelands, the Western nations that have been the principal upholders of the right of asylum are raising barriers to keep them out.

title: Manhattan Town House By Johnson Being Sold
description: A Manhattan town house designed by Philip Johnson in 1949 for Blanchette Rockefeller, the wife of John D. Rockefeller 3d, is to be auctioned May 6 at Sotheby's.

title: Sports World Specials; Golfer's Delights
description: Mirrored water hazard near the green, What's the best golf course you've seen? Not, mind, the best course in all creation, Just among those in the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: Citizens Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: On Sept. 19, 1988, Citizens Federal acquired the insured deposits and offices of a savings bank in Richmond, Va. On Dec. 29, 1988, Citizens Federal acquired American Savings Bank, which is headquartered in Springfield, Ill., and has 23 branch offices throughout central and southern Illinois.

title: Albany at Odds on Fees To Raise Budget Money
description: As negotiators here struggle to create New York State's new budget, they concur that they must adopt some ''revenue enhancers'' - new taxes and special fees to raise money. But they are having a hard time agreeing on just who should enhance the revenue.

title: Sports World Specials; The Ring of Truth
description: As a frankly fictionalized account of the investigation of the murders of three civil rights workers 25 years ago, the movie ''Mississippi Burning'' has been criticized for distorting history even as it has won widespread acclaim.

title: Paying for '84 Gramm Drive
description: Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, has announced that his 1984 campaign committee has agreed to pay a $30,000 penalty to settle a dispute with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Gun-Toting Accountants Battle Tax Cheats
description: ''Only an accountant,'' boasts Bruce V. Milburn's recruitment ad, ''could catch Al Capone.'' Not to mention Albert Anastasia, Frank Costello, ''Dutch'' Schultz and other mobsters brought to justice not by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but by the number-crunching, pistol-packing sleuths from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Unit on Top
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct, the direct-marketing arm of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, is the largest direct-marketing firm in the United States, according to the Direct Marketing Association's 1988 billings survey. Ogilvy took in $272 million in domestic billings last year; Wunderman Worldwide, a Young & Rubicam unit, reported billings of $266 million. Last year, the association said, both agencies finished virtually even, with about $260 million each in gross billings.

title: Gunmen Rake Social Clubs, Killing 4 and Wounding 8
description: Four people were killed and eight people were wounded in separate incidents over the weekend when gunmen entered two crowded social clubs in Brooklyn and opened fire on neighborhood people who had gathered there, the police said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Bare-Boned Country Truths
description: Even in a musical idiom as down to earth as country-rock, Lucinda Williams, a singer and songwriter from Louisiana, communicates with a directness and verbal economy that one doesn't often encounter in pop music.

title: Royal Gold Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after a special gain of $12,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: One Island, One Vote?
description: ''Every state has two senators, and that's what Staten Island thought they were getting into when they joined the union,'' Mayor Koch said the other day in sympathy with New York's least populous borough. This reaction to the Supreme Court's ruling that the Board of Estimate is malapportioned shows the durability of wishful thinking about reapportionment.

title: PHM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from early extinguishment of debt of $92,000 for the quarter and $1,426,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Included a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $2,291,000 and a $32,000,000 tax credit. The latest quarter and year included after-tax charges of $5,490,000 and $8,235,000, respectively, related to net realizable valuation on assets in certain western states and $2,238,000 for the quarter and $5,368,000 for the year for losses related to the liquidation to TMIC Insurance Co. The charges were offset by an after-tax gain of $10,313,000, or 39 cents a share, related to the sale of mortgage servicing rights for both periods. Year-ago quarter and year included after-tax charges of $18,697,000 and $3,360,000, respectively, for unfavorable impact of reserves for mortgage disclosure. The company said the latest quarter and year were favorably impacted by reduced income taxes of $5,315,000 and $6,315,000, respectively, resulting from inclusion of acquired thrift operations.

title: Four Killed in Massachusetts As Plane Crashes in a Forest
description: A single-engine plane crashed late Saturday in rough weather in Pittsfield State Forest, killing all four people aboard, the authorities said today.

title: College Bound? No, Pitino Replies
description: There has been a lot of movement recently in the collegiate coaching ranks and even more talk about movement. And some of that talk has included Rick Pitino.

title: Stirrings of Life in a Forsaken Concert Career
description: Van Cliburn may be emerging from a decade-long hibernation during which he has played little before the public. Mr. Cliburn announced recently that he would make a June appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philadelphia, and that this would mark his return to an active concert schedule.

title: Seacoast Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Slushy Conditions, Lift and Swivel
description: SPRING is the time when skiers attempt to navigate snow that turns into a peculiar wet, sticky mush on warm days. It requires a technique different from that used on packed snow. It is similar to powder skiing, but there is a slow finesse required in slush, and the deeper it gets, the more finesse is required.

title: Army Delays Accepting New Missile Until Homing Flaw Is Corrected
description: The Army has refused delivery of the new generation of the American military's most advanced infantry antiaircraft weapon, the Stinger missile, because the missile is fooled when hovering helicopters fire certain types of flares.

title: Investment Adviser Seeks Funds for Soviet Foundation
description: After contributing millions of dollars from his personal fortune to the project, George Soros, a Budapest-born money manager, is looking for wealthy Americans to contribute to a foundation that he established in the Soviet Union.

title: Pacific Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $436,126 for the latest year and $184,000 for the prior year.

title: Maryland Legislators Back a Bill Barring Job Bias Against Smokers
description: After years of watching their right to light up being whittled away, smokers are about to get some relief from the Maryland General Assembly.

title: Western Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Begin Says He Awaits Normal Ties to Egypt
description: Israel's reclusive former Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, today made his first extensive public comments since his resignation in 1983, marking the 10th anniversary of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty by saying he was still waiting for the normalization of relations between the two nations.

title: Cuomo Warns Liberal Party On Giuliani
description: In a dispute that could threaten the existence of one of the state's minor political parties, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has warned Liberal Party officials that the Democrats could end their long alliance with the Liberals if they endorse the mayoral candidacy of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Hotel Sofitel North America to Tromson Monroe Public Relations, New York, for advertising the company's six United States hotels, with a total ad and public relations budget estimated at more than $2 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The real test of this election is whether the people we elect stick to their principles and ideals. If not, this will turn out to be just like all the elections in the past.'' - Aleksandr A. Sokolov, an artist, after voting in the Soviet elections. [ A6:6. ]

title: A Top Gossip's Focus: The Latin Debt Crisis
description: In the days when he was Mexico's top gossip reporter and radio commentator, Agustin Barrios Gomez thought nothing of taking to the air 10 times a day to talk about whatever struck his fancy. As his country's new consul general in New York, he may be concerned with weightier matters these days, but he shows no less reticence about making his opinions known.

title: Chief of Porta Systems Quits in Dispute on Sale
description: Differences over whether the Porta Systems Corporation should be sold have led to a split between its two founders, Paul DeLuca and Vincent F. Santulli.

title: Five Are Arrested At a Video Arcade
description: Police arrested five young men early yesterday and charged them with trying to rob a couple in a video arcade near Times Square.

title: Jackie Presser's Secret Lives Detailed in Government Files
description: Nine years of information supplied by Jackie Presser as he balanced lives as teamster union leader, lackey of the mob, Presidential adviser and top-level Government informer provides new details of a union shot through with corruption and dominated by organized crime.

title: Sports of The Times; Snyder Kept 'Em Moving
description: WHEN the final buzzer sounded yesterday, ending the East Regional final here in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Quin Snyder, the Duke guard, yelled with exultation and leaped into the arms of the coach, Mike Krzyzewski. Then he jumped on the chest of his teammate Danny Ferry. And for good reason. Quin Snyder was going back home, and not paying for the flight. It was also the fulfillment of a four-year dream. The 6-foot-3-inch senior guard for the Blue Devils is a bright lad, an academic all-American, in fact, and can read a calendar. He knew when he went away to college that the Final Four would be held in his hometown in four years.

title: Masstor Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $8,097,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Intensity Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $7 million writedown of oil and gas properties and production equipment. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Analysts Vigilant for Fed Moves
description: Despite reassuring comments by a number of Federal Reserve Board governors and bank presidents, credit market participants will be watching the central bank's actions closely this week to see if the Fed has inched interest rates up another notch.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 Soviet voters, in the freest elections in more than 70 years, choose a new national Congress of Deputies. The maverick Boris Yeltsin appeared headed for a victory in Moscow. Page A1

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Celtics 105, 76ers 103: Robert Parish had 30 points and 16 rebounds and Boston survived a late Philadelphia rally for a victory at home yesterday despite 38 points and 15 rebounds by the 76ers' Charles Barkley. Boston (35-32) moved a game and a half behind Philadelphia (37-31) in the battle for the next-to-last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference and three games ahead of Washington for the final berth. Boston plays in Philadelphia tomorrow night.(AP) Auto Racing Mansell Wins in Brazil: Nigel Mansell of England won the Brazilian Grand Prix in Rio de Janeiro yesterday in his first race for the Ferrari team. Mansell averaged 115.3 miles per hour in the 61-lap race, the first of the 1989 Formula One season. His winning time was 1 hour 38 minutes 58.7 seconds at Rio's 3.1-mile Nelson Piquet track. Alain Prost of France finished second in a McLaren-Honda, and Mauricio Gugelmin of Brazil, a member of the March-Judd team, was third.(AP) Close Victory for Wallace: Rusty Wallace survived mid-race tire problems and held off Alan Kulwicki and Dale Earnhardt to win the Pontiac 400 yesterday at Richmond International Raceway. Wallace earned the 12th victory of his Winston Cup career and his second in four starts this season. The winner averaged 89.619 m.p.h., and earned $63,025 from a purse of $428,077. Absent from the 36-car field was Richard Petty, the career-victory leader at Richmond with 13, who failed to qualify. Petty's string of 513 consecutive Nascar starts, dating to a race at Richmond on Nov. 14, 1971, was broken.(AP) Golf Charles Triumphs in Japan: Bob Charles of New Zealand, the defending champion, won the $370,000 Fuji Electric Grand Slam seniors title in Narita, Japan, yesterday by four strokes with a nine-under-par 207. Charles shot a final-round 69. The Americans Don January, Charles Coody and Larry Mowry finished in a tie for second place. January had a final-round 69, Coody 68 and Mowry 70. The tournament was played on the 6,660-yard, par-72 Oak Hills Country Club course.(AP) College Basketball Title for N.C. Central: Antoine Sifford had 21 points and 9 rebounds Saturday night as North Carolina Central beat Southeast Missouri, 73-46, for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship at Springfield, Mass. North Carolina Central, ranked 13th in Division II, held No. 8 Southeast Missouri scoreless from the field for the last seven minutes of the first half and scored 12 points for a 42-20 lead. Miles Clarke added 15 points for North Carolina Central (28-4). Dwayne Rutherford led Southeast Missouri (27-6) with 11 points. (AP) N.H.L. Canucks 7, Jets 3: Jim Sandlak scored three goals and Doug Smith added two as Vancouver won in Winnipeg, Manitoba, yesterday to snap a three-game losing streak. Other Vancouver goals were scored by Daryl Stanley and Mel Bridgman. Dale Hawerchuk, with his 39th goal of the season, Andrew McBain with No. 37, and Brent Ashton with his 30th scored for the Jets.(AP) Show Jumping Victory for Ward: Barney Ward of Brewster, N.Y., won the $50,000 Cadillac Grand Prix of Florida yesterday at the 31st annual Winter Equestrian Festival in Tampa. Five of 39 entries qualified for a timed jumpoff by completing the original 18-jump, 580-yard course without penalty in the sixth event on the Michelob/AGA Grand Prix Series. The 44-year-old Ward rode So Long, a 13-year-old, Argentine-bred gelding, to another fault-free ride in the jumpoff in 32.228 seconds. Tennis Curren Tops Connors: After losing the first two sets, Kevin Curren beat Jimmy Connors in a fourth-round match in the International Players Championships at Key Biscayne, Fla., yesterday. Curren, seeded 13th, won, 4-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl swept No. 15 Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-4, 6-2, 6-4. In women's action, fourth-seeded Pam Shriver lost in straight sets, 7-5, 6-4, to unseeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, and No. 2 Chris Evert swept No. 9 Mary Joe Fernandez, 7-5, 6-2.(AP)

title: Alpharel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-earlier quarter is after a pretax provision of $4,955,000 for excess inventory and writedown of software.

description: AS the sponsorship of traditional sporting events has grown more costly and crowded, companies like Reebok, K Mart and Chiquita Brands are turning to out-of-the-ordinary events to help polish their images and increase their sales.

title: South Americans Use U.S. TV Programming
description: A Chilean recently told a visitor that he had been watching the President's live news conference on television and that he thought the President looked a bit tired.

title: Piracy Costly For Hollywood
description: Foreign pirates and trade barriers are costing the leading Hollywood film studios more than $1 billion a year in lost revenues, according to a trade association.

title: Steel Prices Going Up About 5% Next Month
description: Steel prices are scheduled to increase next month in response to higher costs for metals used in making steel. The nation's leading producers of steel will raise prices an average of about 5 percent.

The latest year loss resulted from the addition of $10.3 million to the allowance for loan losses at Sept. 30. Corrected from Tuesday, March 14.

description: I Served the King of England By Bohumil Hrabal Translated by Paul Wilson. 243 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

description: Who would have thought that the man who misspelled a word in a sign he painted a few years back for St. Mary's of the Angels Church - he wrote St. Mary's of the Angles -would follow in Michelangelo's footsteps?

title: No More 1 Person, 1/4 Vote for N.Y.C.
description: The Supreme Court's decision declaring the Board of Estimate unconstitutional has provided a timely opportunity for New York City citizens to restructure their government, strengthen their representation and improve the quality and efficiency of the decision-making process that affects every area of their lives.

description: LEAD: The election of Newt Gingrich as House Republican whip sent a shock wave through the House of Representatives. Virtually ignored in the tumult was the most interesting and relevant consequence of the Gingrich choice: how it will bedevil George Bush and the Republican Presidential party more than the

title: Accord on Computer Security
description: The National Security Agency and a research arm of the Commerce Department have reached an agreement aimed at strengthening protection of sensitive information handled by thousands of Federal Government computers.

title: Contra Tribunal Says 6 Guerrillas Committed Serious Rights Abuses
description: A contra military tribunal has concluded that six Nicaraguan guerrillas committed torture or other human rights abuses and has ordered their expulsion from the rebel movement.

title: Jailed South African Says He'll Suspend Long Hunger Strike
description: South Africa's longest current hunger striker announced today that he would suspend the fast protesting his detention without trial.

title: Canadiens Employ Peter Pan Defense
description: INSIDE the Montreal Forum, where there seems to be a Stanley Cup banner for every rafter, springtime is intruding in the usual way: the Canadiens are revving up to respond to the siren song of their 24th championship and the veterans Larry Robinson and Bob Gainey, who already own almost enough Stanley Cup rings to bejewel their every finger, feel younger with each passing day.

title: Carville Journal; Leprosy Patients Recall A Pain Beyond Disease
description: When the State of Louisiana looked in 1893 for a place to stash away the people it most wanted to hide from view, it found one here, on the grounds of a deserted plantation near the Mississippi River levee.

title: An Inflatable Sneaker
description: A new basketball show can be pumped with air.

title: Loyola Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in fourth quarter earnings to a $1,455,000 increase in its loan loss provision.

title: Hanina Zinder, 85, Dies; Helped Start T.V.A.
description: Hanina (Hank) Zinder, who took part in establishing the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Federal Power Commission, where he was head of the rates division, died Saturday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Not-So-Great With Child
description: Two women were talking pregnancy, and one recalled her visit to Paris 26 years ago while seven months pregnant with her second child. She remembered signs saying you should give up your subway seat to ''blesses de guerre.'' She doesn't remember a comparable sign for pregnant women; nonetheless, she was always treated as a blesse. In stores like Galeries Lafayette she was waited on first -no matter how many people were ahead of her.

title: U.S.-Soviet Magazine Plan
description: Stirred by the entrepreneurial possibilities of perestroika, a Boston businessman, Robert Friedmann, and a Russian emigre impresario, Natan Slezinger, are planning two bilingual publications with the cooperation of two Soviet organizations.

title: Acquisition by Capital Cities
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. announced on Friday that it had acquired Mariner Newspapers Inc., which publishes 18 community newspapers in Massachusetts and a business journal for the South Shore area of Boston. Terms were not disclosed. Mariner, based in Marshfield, Mass., publishes its weekly newspapers in a tabloid format and distributes them by mail. Only its Southshore Business Journal is available on newsstands.

title: Treasury Sets 2 Note Auctions This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week includes tomorrow's auction for new two-year notes and Wednesday's for new four-year notes, in addition to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

Rachelle Weinberg Married
description: Rachelle Weinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weinberg of Fair Lawn, N.J., and Mark Zomick, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David A. Zomick of Teaneck, N.J., were married yesterday at Bob Gilbert's Singers Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Benjamin Yudin officiated, assisted by Rabbi Aryeh Weil. Mrs. Zomick is a senior at Yeshiva University. Mr. Zomick, a graduate of Yeshiva, is an assistant media planner at the New York advertising agency of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

title: Chilean Fruit Sells Quickly Upon Return
description: On Friday morning, Jack Repole, the produce manager at Turco's Super Ranch, a fine-foods store in Hartsdale, N.Y., received his first shipment of Chilean grapes in almost two weeks. By Saturday morning, all 133 crates of grapes had been sold.

title: On Easter, Any Stroll Is a Parade
description: It happens every year at the Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue. An out-of-town family gets there early and finds a choice location behind a police barrier. The children sit neatly on the curb. The hour of the parade arrives, but no floats or marching bands come by. Fifteen or twenty minutes pass before one of the adults shyly approaches a vendor and asks, ''So where's the parade?''

title: For Literature in a Hurry, a Renaissance
description: Classics Illustrated, the comic books that millions of schoolchildren read as introductions to and often substitutes for the world's great literature, will soon be available to another generation of students. Like the earlier versions, the new ones will be heavy on drawings and light on nuance. But this time, they are likely to be welcomed into the educational fold.

title: Inmate Faces 1st Hanging in U.S. Since 1965
description: The State of Washington has found a hangman to execute a prisoner who walked away from a work-release program and killed a woman who testified against him after he had assaulted her eight years earlier.

But the Illinois players who limped and strutted around, slapping palms, exchanging hugs, seemed oblivious to the bumps and bruises as they celebrated a hard-earned trip to Seattle.

title: Take the Money, Dr. Sullivan
description: Is there such a thing as being too ethical in Washington these days? Dr. Louis Sullivan, the new Secretary of Health and Human Services, evidently feels driven to go even further than the President's rule to avoid ''even the appearance of impropriety.'' He refuses to accept severance pay from the medical school at Morehouse College.

title: Sudan's New Cabinet Adopts A Peace Accord With Rebels
description: The new Cabinet of this sub-Saharan nation adopted a peace accord today with the rebel army that has been fighting a long civil war in the southern region.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Bodybuilding Business Bulks Up
description: LEAD: WHEN Joe Gold started building weight equipment in the 1930's, with buckets made of hardened cement and railroad ties, bodybuilding was a rather esoteric, often misunderstood sport. ''It wasn't as much how it made you look as how it made you feel like you could take on the world,'' Gold said.

title: Bridge
description: Counting attendance at a football game or a baseball game is easy enough. But if you want to know the number of individuals who attend a national bridge championship, you will not get a clear answer, just as you could not determine how many distinct people attended a golf or tennis event lasting several days. There is no way to distinguish new arrivals from returnees.

The soloist in the Druckman is to be Ulrich Knorzer, a Juilliard student. Miss Falletta, who was the winner of the Leopold Stokowski Competition in 1984, is the music director of the Queens Philharmonic.

The question confronted by ''The Education Race,'' which begins the distressingly relevant new public-broadcasting series tonight at 9 on Channel 13, is whether youngsters are learning the skills and attitudes they will need to get and hold decent jobs when they graduate. The answer is not encouraging.

title: An 'Imperial Congress' In Conservatives' Sights
description: For much of this century, conservatives looked to the courts or to Congress to restrain the powers of the Presidency. Democrats in the White House, after all, propounded New Deals, New Frontiers, Great Societies and more and more Federal involvement in Americans' economic and social life. But then the worm turned. Over the last 20 years Republicans have built a stronghold at the White House and Democrats have dug themselves in on Capitol Hill. Faced with that reality, conservatives are reversing their intellectual field. Now they speak of an ''Imperial Congress'' that is grabbing off the President's prerogatives.

description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling Law's Mechanics: Symphony of Sorting, Maybe
description: With New York City facing a garbage crisis, the City Council is expected to approve a bill tomorrow that would make the recycling of newspapers, magazines, cardboard, glass bottles and metal cans mandatory. Under the bill, each household would be required to sort the recyclable materials. The bill raises questions as to how a city as large as New York will coordinate and enforce such a law. Here is an attempt at some answers: Q. What happens under the proposed recycling bill? A. All households would be required to separate trash into three categories: regular garbage, paper products such as newspapers, magazines and cardboard, and glass bottles and cans. In private houses, residents would have to bundle newspapers and place bottles and cans in a separate blue container for pick up. In apartment houses, building owners and managers must establish the procedures for collecting the materials in the buildings and placing them out for sanitation workers. Q. Where will the garbage go? A. Regular garbage would still go to the city's landfills and incinerators. Recyclable items would be taken to processing centers. Newspapers would go to dealers for baling and shipping to mills that recycle or export them. Glass bottles and metal cans would go to a city-owned center in East Harlem for sorting and shipping. Q. Is there enough capacity to handle everything collected? A. No. The city plans to build five new processing centers as it collects more recyclable material. Q. When would the new law go into effect? A. If approved tomorrow by the City Council and promptly signed by the Mayor, it could take effect on about July 1. The Sanitation Commissioner is developing regulations and intends to have a six-month education period before imposing fines. Q. How will it be enforced? A. Sanitation police would inspect buildings and issue summonses similar to traffic tickets. Violators would be fined $25 for the first infraction, $50 for the second and $100 for the third. A person or building deemed a persistent violator could be fined from $500 for a single household to $10,000 for a large building. Persistent violation is defined as four infractions in a six-month period. Fines would be mailed to the Environmental Control Board and summonses challenged there. Q. Where would it start? A. Recycling would begin in neighborhoods already in the department's voluntary pilot program, including: Clinton, Chelsea, Greenwhich Village and the West Village in Manhattan; Throgs Neck in the Bronx; the Brooklyn Heights, Dyker Heights and Fort Greene sections of Brooklyn; Forest Hills, Rego Park and Bayside in Queens, and the southern end of Staten Island. The program would be expanded to new areas over five years. Q. How much waste is collected by New York City a year? A. More than five million tons of solid watse is collected from households by the Sanitation Department. Private carters dump almost three million tons that they collect from buinesses. Q. Why do we need to recycle? A. The city's principal dumping site, the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, is filling up rapidly and expected to be full by the turn of the century. A smaller landfill, Edgemere in Rockaway, Queens, is expected to close in 1991. Q. Does the city have other plans for the garbage crisis? A. The city, which already has three incinerators, hopes to build one at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But incinerators cannot handle the vast amounts of garbage collected, and environmentalists object to them as sources of pollution. Q. Will other materials be collected under the recycling plan? A. The Sanitation Department is developing programs to collect leaves and cut grass for composting. The department also hopes to begin collecting Christmas trees each January for chipping into mulch for gardens and parks, and to develop separate locations for disposing old tires and batteries. Q. What about private businesses and institutions? A. The Sanitation Commissioner is businesses and offices, under which private carters would collect the material, most of it paper.

title: Market Place; Behind the Slump In N.T.T. Shares
description: IN the euphoria that characterized the world's stock markets in 1987, there was no more stunning new issue than the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. N.T.T. was the company that caught the imagination of Japanese investors and the breath of foreigners.

title: Time to Return to Consumer Credit Control?
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Biologists Fear Drought's Effect on North American Wetlands
description: LEAD: AS temperatures creep above freezing over the northern Great Plains, biologists are beginning to worry about the lingering effects that last year's drought will have on the region's vast complex of wetlands and the millions of migratory birds that will soon begin arriving.

title: An Elder Statesman Is Honored
description: NOT long ago, someone asked Sid Bernstein, who for six decades has served, led and pontificated at Advertising Age magazine, about his longevity. Mr. Bernstein replied with a story about his father, who at the age of 85 ordered his tailor in Chicago to make him a suit. When he returned several weeks later to pick it up, the elder Mr. Bernstein looked at the suit in dismay and asked the tailor, ''Where's the second pair of pants?''

title: Arnett Cobb, 70, a Saxophonist
description: Arnett Cobb, a highly regarded tenor saxophonist who was a featured soloist with Lionel Hampton's orchestra in the 1940's, died of respiratory, liver and kidney failure on Friday in Park Plaza Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Houston.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON UNITED NATIONS CHARTER - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Champaign Toasts Illini
description: Illini Fever gripped this city today as the Illinois basketball team prepared for its first trip to the Final Four in 37 years.

title: New Northwest Flights
description: Northwest Airlines said today that it would begin nonstop service linking Boston and Los Angeles on May 1. The airline, a unit of NWA Inc., said it would also increase the number of daily round-trip flights between Boston and Washington to four, from one.

title: Minkow of ZZZZ Best Gets 25 Years
description: Barry Minkow, who as a teen-ager founded the ZZZZ Best carpet-cleaning company, was sentenced today to 25 years in prison and ordered to pay $26 million restitution for fraud.

title: Judge Leaving a Personal Imprint on North Trial
description: Whatever the outcome of the trial of Oliver L. North, the verdict will bear the highly personalized imprint of Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, the crusty, 78-year-old jurist presiding over the case.

title: So You Want to Run the World
description: IF you bought software for your home computer last year, especially if you bought games, you were part of a trend.

title: Dorel Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $757,000 special charge from the start-up of the company's foreign operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Book Publishers Reflect Little of Common Market
description: To look at the best-seller lists in England, France and West Germany, one might think there was no such thing as a European Common Market, in books at least. With one or two exceptions the three lists are quite different, and European publishers expect little change after 1992, when most of the remaining customs barriers will have come down.

title: Charan Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2.1 million loss from discontinued operations and a $4.8 million special charge. c-After a $2.2 million loss from discontinued operations and a $2.3 million special charge. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lewis W. Walt, Marine Corps General, Dies at 76
description: Gen. Lewis W. Walt, who won combat decorations in World War II, Korea and Vietnam and later served as assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, died Sunday at a retirement home in Gulfport, Miss., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: 4-Year-Old Boy Killed In Clash in West Bank
description: A 4-year-old Palestinian boy was shot to death in the West Bank today during a clash between demonstrators and the Israeli police, Arabs and the army said.

title: Fan's Prize: Bon Jovi's Jersey Roots
description: When Jon Bongiovi was a tyke, 3 or 4 years old, growing up in a pleasant subdivision here, his mother, Carol, used to dress him up ''like a little doll,'' as she put it, for little performances.

title: Arden Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $12,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $91,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $230,000 for the year.

title: Mena W. Rosenthal, Fund-raiser, 84
description: Mena W. Rosenthal, a member of the board of governors of the American Jewish Committee, died of liver cancer Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: T.W.A. Order To Airbus Is Expected
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. is expected to announce today that it has ordered more than $3 billion worth of wide-body jetliners from Airbus Industrie in a major move to upgrade its aging fleet, industry officials said yesterday.

title: Micro General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: American Medical's Stock Climbs
description: The stock price of American Medical International Inc. rose sharply in heavy trading today as investors sought details of the competing buyout and restructuring proposals disclosed by the company on Sunday.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said its joint venture with the Raytheon Company will begin shipments this month of high-speed anti-radiation missiles that contain gallium arsenide microwave monolithic integrated circuits, or Mimic. It said it was the first production use of Mimic chips. Texas Instruments said the venture manufactures the missiles for a joint United States Navy and Air Force program. It said it would produce more than 14,000 Mimic amplifier chips annually for use in the missiles.

title: Officials Call Microbes Most Urgent Food Threat
description: AMERICANS who wonder about the safety of the food they eat are probably worried about the wrong thing, many authorities now say. The most urgent threat, these experts believe, comes not from pesticides and food additives, but from old-fashioned, natural microbes that contaminate poultry, eggs and meat.

title: Transtector Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Because the company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Feb. 28, the company also reported results for the 10 months ended Dec. 31, 1987 and the year ended Feb. 28, 1987. For the 10 months, the loss was $328,951 with sales of $7,066,465, and for the year ended Feb. 28 the loss totaled $392,250 with sales of $8,623,816.

title: Elburn Journal; After 21 Years, the Law Pays a Call
description: It's an axiom of small-town life that almost everyone knows practically everything about everyone else. But in this tiny community, set amid the corn and bean fields of northern Illinois, people might dispute such simple stereotypes.

title: FSI International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Radio's Ad Revenue Increased 8.2% in 1988
description: Advertising revenue in the radio industry rose 8.2 percent in 1988, according to a survey released yesterday by the Radio Advertising Bureau. The industry earned $7.9 billion, in a year that started like a tortoise and finished like a hare.

title: Cell Growth Factors Emerge as Potent Therapies
description: EXPERIMENTAL drugs made of rare growth-promoting substances are producing dramatic benefits for some seriously ill patients.

title: Former Irving Bank Officer To Head a Unit of Chemical
description: David G. Taylor, former vice chairman of the Irving Trust Company and a former chief executive of the Continental Illinois Bank, has joined Chemical Bank as a group executive and member of the management committee, Chemical announced yesterday.

title: Air Force and Union Agree on Furnishing Civilian Child Care
description: The military is offering child care to the 83,000 American civilian employees of the Air Force Logistics Command, ending a decade of bargaining between the command and a Federal employees' union.

title: Belding Heminway Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year included prior years' tax refunds and reversals of federal income tax accruals no longer required, aggregating $625,000, or 29 cents a share.

title: Architecture Rejuvenates Main Streets
description: Here, as in many small towns, it is no longer a matter of survival: after 20 years of doing battle with malls, Highland Park's main street, Raritan Avenue, has proved it can stand up to the air-conditioned competition.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs jumped last week by 26, to 766, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the total was 935. The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity and reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Tenney Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses of $835,000 and $851,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income of $34,000 and $50,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: A Cabinet Mnemonic for Wall Streeters; Hatch Jest Lived
description: To the Editor:

title: California Jockey Club & Bay Meadows Operating Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nortek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and $11.7 million for the year, and extraordinary gains of $1.3 million for the quarter and $6.4 million for the year from debt retirements. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,350,000 for the quarter and $11 million for the year; the year also included an extraordinary loss of $550,000 from the retirement of debt. d-Net loss

title: Keep the Justice Windows Open
description: The trial of Joel Steinberg, convicted of killing the 6-year-old he and Hedda Nussbaum, his companion, had taken into their home, awakened America to the problem of child abuse. In the process, it also awakened New Yorkers to the benefits of cameras in the courtroom.

title: Nets Routed by Heat For 10th Loss in Row
description: Pearl Washington scored 21 points and Rory Sparrow added 20 as Miami rode a 34-2 third-quarter spurt to a 100-79 victory over the Nets tonight, extending the Heat's winning streak to three games.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about an execution scheduled on Thursday in Washington State included a state erroneously in the list of those that impose capital punishment by hanging. New Hampshire changed to lethal injection in 1987.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: Reading Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $15,290,000 and $7,293,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $7,141,000 and $16,589,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said latest-year results were dominated by the impact of two major transactions, the Convention Center transaction and the Energy Group sale. Results from continuing operations included a $3.4 million gain relating to the Convention Center transaction, and the company's Energy Group was sold during the fourth quarter of 1988, resulting in discontinued operations income of $15.3 million. During 1988, the company's investment in El Paso contributed $7.5 million in equity earnings to continuing operations. The company has adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96 on a retroactive basis. Accordingly, the quarter and 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1987, have been retroactively restated to eliminate imputed federal income taxes.

title: Navy Captain's Wife Goes on TV In an Effort to Catch Van Bomber
description: The wife of a Navy captain whose ship last year shot down an Iranian airliner with 290 people aboard began appearing on television today in spots aimed at finding the person whose bomb destroyed her van.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Science Accessories Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Mr. Reilly's Message on Two Forks
description: William K. Reilly, the new head of the Environ-mental Protection Agency, sends three important messages with his unexpected decision to review the $1 billion Two Forks Dam project in Colorado: He intends to run his own agency. He takes at face value President Bush's announced concerns for the environment. And he believes that even in the Sun Belt, where growth is virtually a religion, growth may demand too heavy a price.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: An Entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Tuesday about the United Asset Management Corporation described the company incorrectly. It is an investment management concern that serves mostly institutional clients.

title: Court Backs Fed Bank Rule
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a Federal Reserve Board requirement that bank holding companies with more than $150 million in assets submit annual financial statements certified by an independent public accountant.

title: Note Issue Sold By Massachusetts
description: Massachusetts sold $490 million of notes through competitive bidding yesterday, with better than three-quarters of the financing going to Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The remaining notes went to Morgan Stanley & Company and Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: White House Rebukes Counsel on Pact
description: The White House today rebuked President Bush's legal counsel, C. Boyden Gray, for challenging the Administration's agreement with Congress on Central America as diminishing the President's powers.

title: Winners at the Oscars May Be the TV Spots
description: The Academy Awards presentation is becoming a second Super Bowl for advertisers - a place to premiere lavishly produced advertising before a captivated (if not quite captive) worldwide audience.

title: Apologies Sent To the Apaches By Rights Chief
description: The chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission, William Barclay Allen, announced today that he had formally apologized to an Arizona Indian tribe for a bizarre episode last month that resulted in his arrest on charges of kidnapping a 14-year-old Indian girl.

title: Careers; 'Horizontal' Or 'Vertical' Education?
description: COMPANIES have long thought in terms of ''vertical'' or ''horizontal'' integration. Such thinking may also be useful to college graduates planning their futures.

title: Distributor Stakes To Ford and Mazda
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had agreed to buy a 34 percent equity share in Autorama, its Japanese distributor, and that the Mazda Motor Corporation would buy a 39 percent share. A spokesman for Ford said the two companies would buy out the Mazda dealers who have held the majority of Autorama's shares since the venture was established in 1982.

title: Muscovites Taste Polling
description: Even as Soviet voters were pondering their first relatively free ballot alternatives in seven decades, Western reporters waited impatiently just outside the doors of polling places to introduce them to their very first election day poll, however informal.

title: Proxy Fight Set For Banknote
description: An investment group that holds a 7.1 percent stake in the International Banknote Company said it would begin a proxy fight to gain control of the New York-based company, which designs, engraves and prints stock certificates, postage stamps, food coupons and currency. The group is led by Tsunesaburo Kurosawa, president of the Kurosawa Company, a musical instrument concern based in New York, and Arthur E. Bohrer, president of A. Bohrer Inc., a wholesale produce company based in Moonachie, N.J.

title: People
description: * John Ferries was named president of the International division of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, succeeding Peter Redsell, who announced his retirement. Also, Michael Strauss, William C. Melzer and Raymond Rizzo were elected to the board of D.M.B.& B.

title: Aztec Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Maris Liepa, 52, Dies in Moscow; Bolshoi Star Was Popular in West
description: Maris Liepa, a star of the Bolshoi Ballet whose virile dramatic portrayals made him especially popular in the West, died Saturday in Moscow. He was 52 years old.

title: Rare Condor Lays an Egg
description: A California condor at the Los Angeles Zoo, one of only 28 members of the species left in the world, has laid a tiny aqua egg.

title: Home Resales Drop Again
description: Sales of existing homes fell 3.1 percent in February, the second straight monthly decline, as buyers put off purchases because of higher mortgage interest rates, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Baker's 'Nice Try'
description: In his first statement on the Bush Administration's contra agreement with Congress, Secretary of State Baker tried hard to place it in direct line of descent from bipartisan foreign-policy actions back to President Truman's support for NATO.

title: Leeco Diagnostics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Film Festival; Japanese And Chinese Find a Bond In Wartime
description: For China, the crucible of modern history was the long, merciless wartime occupation by Imperial Japan, an event that left in its wake the triumph of Chinese Communism and an emotional legacy of bitterness and wounded national pride. ''Evening Bell,'' taking place in the devastated landscape of North China in the days after the Japanese surrender, strives to add a layer of emotional complexity to the standard depictions of the wartime experience.

title: Customs Will Be Streamlined
description: The United States Customs Service has announced plans to help speed Americans through Federal inspection at the international airports in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Miami when they return from abroad. Generally, a passenger bringing back nothing that must be declared will be able to present a passport to an immigration inspector, claim baggage and leave. A passenger with items to declare will make only a brief stop at a customs or agriculture station before being cleared, the agency said Friday.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
We Need Research in the Biology of Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Rise by 2.7% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 2.7 percent monthly increase in short interest for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Black Tyranny: A Deafening Silence
description: LEAD: When black Africa sought independence and freedom from white colonial rule, it did not expect that black neo-colonialists would slaughter its people, but that is what has happened.

title: Record of Impaired Driving
description: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood was convicted twice in five years and lost his license three times for drinking while driving, records show. Pag B7.

title: Soldiers Missings in Afghan War Now Urgent Problem for Moscow
description: Six weeks after its troops left Afghanistan, no objective is more urgent for the Soviet Union here than learning what became of the 313 Soviet troops listed as missing in action, Soviet Embassy officials say.

title: Digital Transmission reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Jackie Presser's role as a Federal informer characterized another former president of the teamsters' union, Roy L. Williams, incorrectly. Mr. Williams, who had been serving a prison sentence for conspiracy to commit bribery, was paroled last fall.

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Motorola Sets Stage For Battle With Intel
description: Motorola Inc. today announced key features of its next-generation microprocessor, the 68040, opening a new round in its battle with the Intel Corporation, which is set to introduce its newest chip on April 10.

title: Review/Dance; A Mix of Steps Between God and the Devil
description: It is possible to look at Demetrius A. Klein's ''Garden/Alone,'' performed by Mr. Klein and his company on Friday at the Mulberry Street Theater, in a number of ways. At its deepest level, the piece suggests life lived by ordinary mortals as a steadily continuing measured contest of allegiances to God and to the devil. More superficially, the dance draws on a variety of sources, including post-modernist devices of the 1960's and 70's and ballet.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citadel Holding Corp., Glendale, Calif., a savings and loan holding company, said James A. Taylor had resigned for health reasons as chairman, chief executive and president.

title: Immucell Corp reports earnings for 12mo to Dec 31
description: The latest year's loss included a charge of $325,000 from a termination agreement with its former chief executive officer. The 1987 results restated to include interest income.

title: On Horse Racing; Amid a Dull Outing, an Exciting Breakaway
description: Parimutuelly speaking, the result of the eighth race at Aqueduct last Saturday was as dull as they come. The heavy favorite won in a romp and he paid a measly $3 to win. But for anyone who looks at and likes horses, or has any interest in the Kentucky Derby 40 days hence, it was the most electrifying moment of this racing season.

title: Loving Hands at Home
description: THIS is being written on a hand-crafted Heath Computer Systems SupersPort 286 portable computer. There is a great deal of satisfaction in knowing that from several boxes of loose and incomprehensible parts I have screwed together a hunk of technology that actually works, and have saved some money in the process.

title: 'When I Don't Know.. I Will Tell You'
description: Margaret D. Tutwiler, formerly Assistant Treasury Secretary for Public Affairs (when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was Secretary of Treasury Baker), is now Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and the State Department spokesman. Ms. Tutwiler, the first woman to hold that post, made her debut at the State Department's daily briefing today, opening with a prepared statement. Here is how she began.

title: Bush and Aides Meet On Assault Rifle Issue
description: President Bush discussed semiautomatic assault rifles today with his top law and drug enforcement advisers, but White House aides said the meeting did not produce a decision on what to do about them.

title: Captain Has History of Drinking and Driving
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the ship that has been spilling oil since it ran aground off Alaska last Friday, has been convicted of charges involving drinking and driving twice in the past five years, a period in which his driver's license was suspended or revoked three times.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; From Iceland, 2 Brothers With a Grudge
description: Barren and endless as the Icelandic landscape appears, it is made to seem frighteningly claustrophobic in ''Foxtrot,'' a tightly knit thriller about two brothers on a cross-country journey. ''Foxtrot'' follows a handsome, well-known soccer star named Kiddy (Valdimar Flygenring) and his quiet, Tommy (Steinarr Olafsson) as they embark on what is meant to be a business trip, driving a delivery of cash from one city to another. En route, tensions between the brothers emerge and escalate, until they reach the level of violent confrontation.

title: Baker, Outlining World View, Assesses Plan for Soviet Bloc
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the Bush Administration was cautiously considering a proposal to seek discussions with Moscow on a new political arrangement for Eastern Europe.

title: Agents' Motions Denied
description: The Federal judge presiding over the mail fraud and racketeering trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom in Chicago yesterday denied each defendant's motion for a directed judgment of acquittal.

title: St. John's and St. Louis Breeze Into N.I.T. Final
description: Matt Brust played harassing defense and dived onto the floor for loose balls. Robert Werdann and Jayson Williams grabbed tough rebounds in traffic. The Redmen kept pounding the ball inside until the University of Alabama-Birmingham wilted under the pressure. And down the stretch when U.A.B. threatened, the Redmen made their free throws to preserve a victory last night and advance to the final of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Addendum
description: * Levitt Communications said it had made a significant investment in B & B Enterprises, which publishes program magazines for performing arts centers. The terms of the investment were not disclosed.

title: A Cancer Finding, Thanks to Chickens
description: PARTLY because the residents of Los Angeles share the national fondness for chicken, scientists have an important new oncogene to study in the quest to understand cancer.

title: Harken Energy Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $2,052,000 for the latest year and $1,369,000 for 1987.

title: Decision on Reagan Is Delayed
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North today turned down a request by Mr. North's lawyers to compel Ronald Reagan to testify in person at the trial Friday, but he postponed a final decision on whether the former President might later be called.

title: Find May Be Oldest Evidence of Humans in U.S.
description: A DISCOVERY of broken stone tools, charcoal and bison bones in Oklahoma may be evidence of the earliest known presence of humans in North America, archeologists reported last week. Analysis of the charcoal and some snails found in the same sediments has yielded dates going back 26,000 to 40,000 years.

title: Currency Changes Set by Taiwan
description: Taiwan today announced a sweeping set of revisions aimed at liberalizing its foreign exchange market and reducing the role of its central bank in determining the value of the Taiwan dollar.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY William L. Parkin pleaded guilty to charges of bribery, wire fraud and conspiracy. A consultant to military contractors, he was implicated last year in the inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud. Mr. Parkin agreed to cooperate with the Government's investigation of Pentagon fraud in exchange for the chance to plead guilty to reduced charges. [ Page A1. ] Alan Greenspan said he desired ''approximately zero'' inflation in the economy. He told a Senate committee, in a letter, that he could wait ''several years'' to get there. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL Japanese officials are irritated and bitter about the Bush Administration's effort to revise an accord to develop an advanced jet fighter with Japan. [ A1. ] Nippon Telegraph and Telephone's former chairman was indicted on charges that he took $175 million in bribes. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Mcorp said it would seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code to avoid an involuntary liquidation sought last week by three minor bondholders. Mcorp is the state's second-largest banking company. [ D1. ] Polaroid reached a peace pact with Shamrock Holdings, which has been trying to take it over since last summer. Polaroid agreed to pass on to shareholders a sizable portion of any damages it receives from Eastman Kodak for patent infringement. Shamrock agreed not to try to gain control of Polaroid for 10 years. [ D1. ] T.W.A. is expected to order more than $3 billion worth of wide-body jetliners from Airbus in a major move to upgrade its aging fleet. The order is a major coup for Airbus. [ D1. ] Carl C. Icahn is hoping to gain control of Eastern Airlines, an investment banker with ties to the machinists' union said. [ D6. ] The Justice Department asked Emery Air Freight to determine if any parties were interested in acquiring the company other than Consolidated Freightways. [ D1. ] American Medical International's stock rose $3.625, to $21.50, in heavy trading as investors sought details of competing buyout and restructuring proposals. It was the day's most-active issue. [ D5. ] Sears, Roebuck will sell Coldwell Banker Commercial Group to a group of investors for about $300 million. [ D4. ] Motorola announced features of its next-generation microprocessor, the 68040. [ D4. ] Loral will sell its aircraft braking and engineered fabrics divisions to a management group in a deal valued at $425 million. [ D4. ] The founder of ZZZZ Best was sentenced to 25 years in prison and ordered to pay $26 million restitution for fraud. [ D19. ] MARKETS Blue-chip stocks rose moderately in Wall Street's slowest trading since last December. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.82 points, to 2,257.86. Volume was 113 million shares. [ D8. ] Nasdaq shares sold short and not yet covered rose 2.7 percent for the month ended March 15. [ D21. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds weakened slightly in very light trading as market participants shrugged off a big gain for the dollar and focused instead on another sharp rise in oil prices. [ D16. ] The dollar rose sharply, reaching its highest level against the yen and mark since last year. [ D18. ] Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply amid forecasts for April showers. [ D18. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The environment provides business opportunities, says Cynthia Pollock Shea of Worldwatch Institute. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Warren Buffett says he is getting out of risk arbritage, in an unusual disclosure of his plans. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Sidney R. Bernstein is being inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D23. ]

title: International Dairy Queen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
Vestar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yankees Get Balboni as Designated Hitter
description: The Yankees, strapped for power since the loss of Dave Winfield last week, finally addressed one of their more pressing needs of the spring when they acquired an old hand, Steve Balboni, from the Seattle Mariners today.

title: New York Will Ban New Pit Bulls After Oct. 1 and Restrict Others
description: No new pit bull terriers would be allowed in New York City after Oct. 1 under strict rules adopted yesterday by the city's Board of Health.

title: Turkish Leader Bars Early Elections
description: A day after Turkish voters dealt his Government party a crippling defeat in local elections, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal defiantly rejected widespread suggestions today that he call early national elections or even resign.

title: At Least 5 More Killed By Shelling in Lebanon
description: Muslim and Christian forces continued their fierce artillery battles in and around Beirut today, with at least five more people reported killed.

title: Japanese Warn of Repercussions From U.S. Move to Alter Jet Deal
description: President Bush's effort to revise an accord to develop an advanced jet fighter with Japan has led to sharp expressions of irritation and bitterness among Japanese officials.

title: Our Towns; Abuse Goes On, But Caseworkers Often Cannot
description: After six years on the job, Roger Burchell is practically the Methuselah of Westchester County child-abuse caseworkers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just can't tell you what was in Boyden Gray's mind. I mean, that's more than I can handle.'' - Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. [ A6:1. ]

title: Chubb Loses Asbestos Suit
description: In one of California's longest and costliest civil trials, a state jury has decided that an affiliate of the Chubb Corporation must pay the Fibreboard Corporation $6.1 million to cover asbestos-related legal costs.

title: STANDOFF SETTLED WITH 250 REFUGEES
description: A high-seas standoff between the Coast Guard and 250 Haitians packed aboard a 50-foot sailboat bound for the United States ended peacefully over the weekend after a 30-hour confrontation in which the refugees threatened to throw their babies overboard.

title: Market Place; An Expert Shuns Risk Arbitrage
description: WARREN BUFFETT is best known as a master long-term investor, one who goes to extraordinary lengths to conceal what he is up to, for the very good reason that even big stocks are likely to go up when word gets out that he is buying.

title: At Paris Shows, Shorter Was Better
description: Everything was exaggerated at the Paris ready-to-wear shows: the length of the runways, the number of models and, at the better collections, the memorable styles. With few exceptions, the best clothes were short.

title: 3 Borough Leaders Seek Strategy to Save Board
description: Three of New York City's five borough presidents, the future of their offices deeply in doubt, held a private meeting yesterday to try to forge a strategy to preserve the powerful Board of Estimate on which they sit.

title: CUC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $51,432,000 for the cumulative adjustment through Oct. 31, 1988 for the additional amortization of membership acquisition costs, and a pre-tax charge of $7.5 million for the adjustment in the fourth quarter for the additional amortization of membership acquisition costs for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said both charges are the result of a change in the company's policy of amortizing membership acquisition costs.

title: Fusion in a Jar: Announcement By 2 Chemists Ignites Uproar
description: TWO chemists who claimed last week to have triggered nuclear fusion in a jar of water have ignited a major uproar in the scientific world.

title: The Lausanne Initiative
description: Hitler was rampaging triumphant over Europe. German concentration camps gave forth the stench of slaughter.

title: Davis Cup Team
description: John McEnroe, Andre Agassi, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso were named yesterday to compete for the United States in a quarterfinal Davis Cup match against France April 7-9 in San Diego.(AP)

title: Nicaragua: A Bipartisan Advance
description: President Bush and Congressional Democrats have amicably agreed on a formula for resolving the once rancorous issue of aid to the Nicaraguan contras. That was possible chiefly because Mr. Bush has altered President Reagan's stubborn course. He explicitly promises to couple military pressure with serious pursuit of diplomacy.

title: High Winds Hamper Oil Spill Cleanup Off Alaska
description: The cumbrous attempt to clean up the biggest oil spill in North American waters, already slowed for three days by organizational snafus and lack of proper equipment, was further hampered today by winds in excess of 70 miles an hour.

title: Goldome Picks Chief Executive
description: Ross B. Kenzie, who transformed Goldome from a Buffalo-based savings bank into one of the nation's largest savings institutions, will retire June 30 as chief executive, the company announced today.

title: Review/Recital; Violinist Offers Beethoven
description: Nai Yuan Hu, the Taiwanese violinist who won the Queen Elisabeth competition of Belgium four years ago, was presented in recital Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall by the Chinese-American Arts Council.
