It was a respectable showing by a musician whose technique is more than well in hand and whose feeling for the shape of a musical phrase or of a piece is generally sound.

title: Ewing's 45 Tie Career Mark as Knicks Stop Streak
description: The Charlotte Hornets chose to play Patrick Ewing one-on-one tonight, and the 7-foot Knick center battered the expansion team's three journeymen centers for 45 points, equaling his career high.

title: Program to Pay Relatives for Foster Children Moves Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Parks Are Confronting Outside Threats
description: The National Park Service, alarmed at the damage inflicted by development outside the parks' boundaries, has begun to take a role in efforts to fend off external threats. In some cases park officials are opposing development around the parks, a position that has long been considered politically unacceptable.

title: Review/Music; Chicago Youth Orchestra
description: The Chicago Youth Symphony Orchestra is an ensemble of the best orchestral players from high schools in Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana and Iowa. The group rehearses weekly, and has sectional coaching sessions with members of the Chicago Symphony. On Sunday afternoon, the orchestra performed in Carnegie Hall, as part of the Mid-America Productions festival of student ensembles.

title: Taiwan Balks On Rice Pact
description: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture said today that it would not give in to pressure from the United States rice lobby to open Taiwan's market and to renew an agreement to limit the country's rice exports.

title: Indians Release Allen
description: The Cleveland Indians unexpectedly released the veteran right-hander Neil Allen yesterday.

title: Empty Nests and Forced Moves
description: New York's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is trying gingerly to persuade small families in big Mitchell-Lama apartments to move to smaller ones in their buildings. The department threatens to compel such moves if voluntarism fails.

title: N.T.T. Figure Indicted In Japan Bribery Case
description: The former chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Hisashi Shinto, was indicted today on charges that he took $175 million in bribes.

title: Expiration Dates on Condoms
description: Manufacturers of latex condoms in the United States have agreed to put expiration dates on their products, an industry spokesman said today.

title: Sears Agrees to Sell Coldwell Commercial
description: LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to sell its Coldwell Banker Commercial Group to a group of investors for about $300 million.

title: M.I.T. Economist to Be Bush Adviser
description: President Bush will nominate Richard Schmalensee, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to the President's Council of Economic Advisers, the White House said yesterday.

title: Polaroid Payout Plan Helps It Reach Shamrock Accord
description: Agreeing to pass on to shareholders a sizable chunk of any damages it receives from the Eastman Kodak Company for patent infringement, the Polaroid Corporation yesterday reached a peace pact with Shamrock Holdings Inc., which has been trying to take it over since last summer.

title: General Nutrition
description: General Nutrition Inc. said it had hired investment bankers to explore ways to maximize shareholder value, including the possible sale of the company or a recapitalization. The company said Lazard Freres & Company and C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. would review financial alternatives. General Nutrition's shares jumped $1.25 today, to $9. Pittsburgh-based General Nutrition, which operates vitamin and health food stores, said there could be no assurance that any transaction would take place.

title: Nuclear War Plan by I.R.S.
description: It will take something more than a nuclear attack to wipe out taxpayers' obligations to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.1 million, or 10 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Cenvill Investors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.4 million, or 21 cents a share, from the sale of land for the latest year, while 1987 year's net included a gain of $710,000, or 10 cents a share. Latest quarter and year included additions to allowance for losses of $2,160,000 and $2,732,000, respectively.

title: Has the Gun Lobby Become One of the Unexpected Casualties of the President's War Against Drugs?
description: The worst accusation that can be leveled against anyone here is to be called naive. Score one point, then, for naivete. For what else fits the view that a Republican President who belongs to the National Rifle Association would be willing to take on the gun lobby?

title: By Design; A Shakeup on Shoulders
description: As this year's fall collections are being shown, it is clear that shoulders are headed for a shakeup. Silhouettes are becoming less hard-edged, with shoulders narrowing in breadth and softening in shape. Shoulder pads are being chipped away.

title: Electronic Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and year included a charge of $327,000 from a settlement. The company in 1988 changed its method of accounting for income taxes to comply with the provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96 - ''Accounting for Income Taxes''. The annual and quarterly data discussed above have been restated to reflect this change.

title: Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Neighbors Ask What Lured L.I. Teen-Ager to Her Death
description: Shocked and saddened, residents of the Strathmore neighborhood here were asking one question over and over today: Why did 14-year-old Jessica Manners leave her house late Saturday?

title: Subway Police Shift Tactics on Fare Beaters
description: The New York City Transit Police has been guarding 30 vulnerable subway stations in Manhattan from early morning to late night, after a study showed that fare evasion dropped 91 percent when uniformed officers were present, said the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Credit Card Accord Due
description: JCB International, the largest provider of bank-related credit cards in Japan, is about to take a major step toward allowing its cards to be accepted by American merchants.

title: Review/Television; Two Shows on Teen-Agers in Trouble
description: Permissiveness on the wane? Some of the signals on television shows being produced for younger audiences are unmistakable. Two unusually strong examples are available this week: ''15 and Getting Straight,'' a CBS ''Schoolbreak Special'' at 4 this afternoon, and ''The Cheats,'' an ''Afterschool Special'' at 4 P.M. Thursday on ABC.

title: Georgia Island's Road to Fortune Is Well Paved
description: While resorts done in earth tones and fairways flanked by moss-draped oaks have helped the economies of much of the region's coast and its barrier islands, an island with acres and acres of parking lots may pave the way to prosperity for this coastal city.

title: Starling Fight Is Off
description: Claiming a shoulder injury, Marlon Starling, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, has withdrawn from his fight April 15 with Mark Breland, the World Boxing Association champion.

title: Success Is Built on Perseverance and Teamwork
description: After watching Illinois cut a path through Indianapolis to Minneapolis and on to Seattle, a phrase, coined by some feisty old coach, or perhaps by a drill sergeant, keeps echoing:

title: Ames Department Stores Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Jan 28
description: b-Included a $1,164,000 gain from an accounting change for both the quarter and year. The company said figures included operating results of the Zayre Stores division since Ames' acquisition on Oct. 28, 1988.

title: Chess
description: It is truly a terrible state of affairs when you cannot escape your nemesis even in a time of triumph. The British grandmaster Nigel Short won the elite 64th running of the Hastings International Tournament, which ended Jan. 14 in England, and sure enough, the only game he lost was to his bete noire, Jonathan Speelman.

title: Sutter's Shoulder Is Injured Again
description: Bruce Sutter has torn his rotator cuff again, the Atlanta Braves said yesterday. Sutter, who has 300 saves, the third highest in major league history, has had three operations on his right shoulder.

title: Pirates' Resurgence Vindicates Carlesimo
description: For 28 years, Seton Hall has been waiting for this moment. After a point-shaving scandal in 1961 led the university to de-emphasize basketball, the school has longed for its chance to again use the sport as a tool to gain the respect and recognition it so desired.

title: Curfew Ordered After 3 Die in Yugoslav Riots
description: Yugoslavia ordered a curfew in the southern province of Kosovo today after two policemen and a demonstrator were shot dead in the fifth day of violence by ethnic Albanians protesting moves to curb their autonomy.

title: 'Cafe Crown' Closes
description: ''Cafe Crown,'' the revival of Hy Kraft's 1942 comedy, closed after the Sunday matinee at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street. The play, which was directed by Martin Charnin, ran for 45 regular performances on Broadway.

title: Plan to End Police Dog Benefits Is Debated
description: City officials have encountered criticism for a plan to stop payments for food, biscuits and veterinary care for retired police dogs.

title: PATTERNS
description: Gigli by Another Name?

title: Tollman-Hundley
description: Tollman-Hundley Hotels announced that it had acquired the Regal 8 Hotel Group, a chain of 53 hotels in 21 states, for $91 million. Both companies are privately held. Tollman-Hundley is a nationwide licensee of Days Inns properties, and it owns and operates several properties under Holiday Inns and Quality Inns licenses. With the acquisition, Tollman-Hundley now owns 122 hotels with more than 18,000 rooms.

title: Accounts
description: * Nike Inc., to Cole & Weber, Seattle, for two brands of casual shoes, with a budget of $7 million.

title: Legal Bills Mount as Yonkers Tries Resisting Housing Order
description: Six months after Yonkers avoided bankruptcy by accepting a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko is once again at odds with defiant City Councilmen seeking to reopen the case.

title: First City Trustco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Investment income for 1988 was $109,173,000, compared with $97,040,000 for 1987. Assets at Dec. 31 totaled $3.66 billion for 1988, compared with $3.43 billion in 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cape Town Journal; A Cradle of Apartheid Looks for a Way Around It
description: While some towns controlled by the right-wing Conservative Party are trying to turn the clock back on apartheid, Cape Town wants to jump it ahead.

title: Greenspan Willing to Wait For Years for 'Zero' Inflation
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the Senate today that while he desired ''approximately zero'' inflation in the economy, he could wait ''several years'' to get there.

title: Spy's Wife Asks Court For Change of Prisons
description: Anne Henderson Pollard, the wife of the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard, pleaded with a Federal district judge today to be transferred from a prison hospital in Rochester where she said she is being mistreated.

title: Reviews/Music; Tin Pan Alley Goes to War: A Mix of Love and the Flag
description: The series of three Sunday programs at the Vineyard Theater on Tin Pan Alley's contribution to World War II, entitled ''Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition,'' shows that contribution in a mixed light. There were some good wartime songs that are justifiably memorable. But when the banalities of Tin Pan Alley were turned from ''June-moon-croon'' love songs to an attempt to mix love and patriotism, the results were often ridiculous.

title: Soviet-Lab Report Called Plausible
description: The president of the United States Olympic Committee said yesterday that it was plausible the Soviet Union had a drug-testing laboratory aboard a ship anchored off the coast of South Korea during the Seoul Olympics last fall.

title: Reviews/Music; A Taste of the Zarzuela With Victoria de los Angeles
description: In the early 1930's, the great Luisa Tetrazzini - a star of the operatic stage in pre-World War I days -came back to New York to sing in variety at the Plaza Theater, three times an evening, ''between smiling crooners, animal acts, conjurors and acrobats,'' as the opera historian Michael Scott tells it. One could not help imagining that peculiar scene Friday night at the City Center, where in unexpected surroundings the great Victoria de los Angeles is paying a two-week visit to this city.

title: New York Files Suit To Recoup Foster Aid
description: New York State today sued the Federal Government to recover $156 million in child welfare payments that state officials said had been improperly withheld over the last decade.

title: Yeltsin Does an Old Friend a Favor
description: LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev's luck continues to hold. With his erstwhile friend Boris Yeltsin winning a seat in the Congress of Deputies, he now has a valuable new weapon in his fight for reform: a critic on his left.

title: Ruth Fox, 93, Dies; Psychoanalyst Pioneered in Treating Alcoholism
description: Dr. Ruth Fox, a psychoanalyst who in 1959 became the first medical director of The National Council on Alcoholism, an agency devoted to alcoholism prevention, died in her sleep Friday at a nursing home in Washington. She was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: India Releases Stinging Report on Gandhi's Death
description: An official report on the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi says that a powerful aide overruled intelligence and security officials who had ordered the removal of Sikh policemen, including her eventual assassins, as a security threat.

title: Mcorp Says It May Seek Chapter 11
description: Mcorp, a deeply troubled banking company in Texas, said today that it planned to seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code to avoid an involuntary liquidation sought last week by three minor bondholders.

title: We Need Research in the Biology of Addiction; Test Needle Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: On-Line Software reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $675,000 for the quarter from the reacquisition of convertible debt and an extraordinary gain of $2,516,000 for the 9 months. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $154,000.

title: CMI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the lower revenue figures were due to the March 1988 transaction whereby Caterpillar Inc. acquired certain product lines from the company. The product lines represented $88 million of revenue in 1987.

title: American Express Ads Strike Back at Visa
description: For several years, Visa International has encouraged viewers to bring their card to major events like the Olympic Games ''because they don't take American Express.'' In a new print advertising campaign, American Express seems to be returning the favor. Modeled on its print campaign featuring celebrity card holders, the new magazine ads depict several of the nation's finest restaurants - all of which accept only the American Express card.

title: US Cellular Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2.2 million from the trade of certain cellular interests.

title: Merger in Plant Research
description: Calgene Inc., a leading company in agricultural biotechnology, said today that it planned to acquire its rival, Plant Genetics Inc., in a stock transaction.

title: Talking Business with Shea of Worldwatch Institute; Cleaning Up On Cleaning Up
description: The environment and the economy are inextricably linked, says the Worldwatch Institute, a research organization based in Washington. The institute's 12-member staff regularly publishes reports exploring that connection, covering subjects like the global warming trend, the hole in the ozone layer, ocean pollution and soil erosion.

title: Trade Ruling On Bearings
description: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling today that anti-friction bearings from nine countries were being sold unfairly in the United States, paving the way for permanent anti-dumping duties. It said the nations were West

title: Capital Offers A Ripe Market To Drug Dealers
description: The explosion of drug-related killings that has made the District of Columbia the nation's murder capital was set off, experts say, by the popularity of crack in a city with no significant organized crime structure, an overwhelmed criminal justice system and a local population that can afford to feed an insatiable appetite for drugs.

title: Loral to Sell Two Divisions
description: The Loral Corporation, a military electronics contractor based in New York, announced today that it would sell its aircraft braking and engineered fabrics divisions to a management group in a transaction valued at $425 million. The management group, the

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Prosecutor Told To Stick to Facts In Police Killing
description: The judge in the trial of three men charged with murdering a New York City police officer in Queens admonished a prosecutor yesterday, telling him to stick to ''the evidence alone'' and not ''appeal to the jury to convict the defendant to protect the community.''

title: COMPANY ADVISER FILES GUILTY PLEA IN PENTAGON CASE
description: William L. Parkin, a consultant to military contractors who was implicated last year in the inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud, pleaded guilty today to charges of bribery, wire fraud and conspiracy.

title: INSIDE
description: Microbes, Not Additives, Called Biggest Food Risk The most urgent threat to the nation's food supply is not pesticides or chemical additives, many experts say, but natural microbes that contaminate poultry, eggs and meat. Science Times, page C1. Bush Counsel Rebuked The White House rebuked C. Boyden Gray for criticizing the Administration agreement with Congress on Central America. Page A6. Reparations in Stark Attack After nearly a year of negotiations, Iraq has agreed to pay $27.3 million in compensation for the families of 37 American sailors killed in the 1987 attack on the frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf, officials said. Page A5. Rights Chief Apologizes The chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission announced that he had formally apologized for a bizarre episode. Page A14. School Board Suspended The New York City Schools Chancellor suspended a Bronx school board because two of its members have been indicted. Page B1.

title: LaPoint's Shoulder Stiff
description: Dave LaPoint worked five innings tonight, threw one pitch in the sixth against the Montreal Expos and came out because of stiffness in his left shoulder.

title: SOVIET VOTERS DEAL HUMILIATING BLOW TO PARTY OFFICIALS
description: The Soviet electorate has dealt a mortifying rebuke to the high and mighty in elections for a new national congress, including stunning upsets of a Politburo member and several other senior Communist Party officials who ran without opposition.

title: House of Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Review/Theater; 'Our Town' With Don Ameche as Stage Manager
description: To a younger generation, Don Ameche is best known as a lively old fellow in movies like ''Cocoon,'' but those with longer memories will think of him as the young man who invented the telephone in the movie ''Alexander Graham Bell'' and who, in moments of crisis, remained loyal to his friend, Tyrone Power, in ''Alexander's Ragtime Band'' and other films. In other words, he brought with him considerable artistic baggage and nostalgia as he stepped into the role of the Stage Manager in the Lincoln Center Theater revival of ''Our Town'' at the Lyceum Theater.

title: A Spandex Shortage And Industrial Intrigue
description: LEAD: Spandex, a fiber used to make tight-fitting stretchable clothes, has been around for nearly 30 years. But Bruno Skerianz apparently saw a new way to make a quick profit from it, law enforcement officials say.

title: Anti-Missile Test Fails in Space
description: A $140 million Star Wars satellite launched into space Friday failed one of its first tests, Pentagon officials said yesterday. The satellite was meant to observe the firing of a nearby rocket in space but was unable to do so because a lens cap blocked its view.

title: Rose Gardella, 65, Harlem Social Worker
description: Rose M. Gardella, a community leader in East Harlem for more than 20 years and the founder in 1982 of the Pleasant Village Community Garden on Pleasant Avenue, died of a stroke Friday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jury to Get Wells Fargo Robbery Case
description: After three years of hearings and six months of testimony, the Wells Fargo robbery trial of five suspected members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group is finally nearing an end.

title: Exxon May Have Small Liabiltiy for Spill Claims
description: Although the Exxon Corporation said Saturday that it would accept full financial responsiblity for the oil spill in Alaska, it may actually have only a small liability because 16 years ago Congress put a limit on claims from such incidents and set up an industry fund to cover costs.

title: Bomb Explodes in Pakistan Near British Cultural Center
description: A bomb exploded near a British cultural center early today, hours after Foreign Secretary Sir Geoffrey Howe of Britain arrived to discuss the controversy over the novel ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Three Mile Island: Good for America
description: LEAD: The 10th anniversary of the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in Pennsylvania offers grounds for optimism about the future of the nuclear power industry.

title: Ortega Attacks Aid for Contras
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra strongly criticized a new American plan for aid to the Nicaraguan guerrillas today, describing it as an affront to international law and asserting that it would lead to further bloodshed here.

title: Beijing Calls for a 'New Pattern' In Its Relations With Washington
description: China's Foreign Minister called today for ''a new pattern'' in Chinese-American relations, characterized by mutual trust and apparently by a lack of American criticism of Beijing's human rights record.

title: Spire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasury Bond Prices Weaken
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds weakened slightly in very light trading yesterday as market participants shrugged off a big gain for the dollar and focused instead on another sharp rise in oil prices.

title: Needed Fast at Continental: Profits
description: Of the many brickbats that the striking employees at Eastern Airlines have thrown at Frank Lorenzo, one most frequently heard is that he is a corporate raider interested in a fast buck who knows nothing about running an airline.

title: CONVICTS HOLDING GUATEMALA PRISON
description: Armed inmates held off hundreds of soldiers and policemen today after seizing Guatemala's largest prison.

title: American Recreation Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-Included pretax gains of $804,000 and $1,481,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the sale of property, and the 9 months also included a one-time expense of $236,000 associated with an acquisition. c-Included a gain of $923,000 from an accounting change and a pretax gain on the sale of assets of $1,371,000. The company said the latest periods results are restated to include Right Start Inc., acquired in July 1988, and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Riches of Jazz History Just Keep Growing
description: It was between sets at the 1959 Newport Jazz Festival that Gunther Schuller conceived the idea of writing his exhaustive, analytical history of jazz, the second volume of which has just been published. At the time, he was a 32-year-old French horn player in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and had composed a handful of orchestral and chamber works in the complex atonal idiom that remains his style.

title: Q&A
description: Flies and Mosquitoes Q. Where do flies and mosquitoes go in the winter? And where do the large flies that show up in the house with the first warm days come from? A. Many adult flies die off with the arrival of cold weather, but others live through the winter, said Louis N. Sorkin, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Icahn Is Said to Confer With Eastern's Unions
description: Carl C. Icahn, seeking to put together a plan that would enable him to gain control of Eastern Airlines, is again meeting with officials of Eastern's unions, Brian Freeman, an investment banker with close ties to the machinists' union, said yesterday.

title: New York Colleges Rebuffed In Effort for Share of Estate
description: The Colorado Court of Appeals has ruled that an Episcopal church and an animal protection league here and the Metropolitan Opera Guild of New York can share in the multimillion-dollar estate left by a member of the Coors brewery family. It rejected claims by Marist College and Pace University in New York.

title: Bridge
description: The most unusual bridge event of the year, and perhaps of any year, will begin Saturday. It is the Marathon Trans-Atlantic Bridge Battle of the Sexes, and play will be non-stop, 24 hours a day for two weeks. One table, with men sitting North-South and women East-West, will be at the Cavendish Club at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan. The other, with positions reversed, will be in Paris.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Rule on Pennsylvania's Mandatory Death Penalty
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of Pennsylvania's death penalty law, which requires jurors to impose a death sentence under certain circumstances.

title: Rangers' Hopes Turn to Anxiety
description: A cardboard cutout of Coach Michel Bergeron - a genuine paper tiger? - stood in an otherwise empty office here. The advertising gimmick made for an odd sight, but it actually fit in rather well among the Ranger players, coaches and other officials who walked mutely about the team's practice complex. Their infrequent smiles looked as painted on as the smile on the dummy.

title: GTE Plans to Cut 600 Jobs in Texas
description: The GTE Corporation's General Telephone Southwest unit said it would cut about 600 jobs in Texas and defer filling 400 vacancies in response to a $59 million rate cut by the Public Utility Commission of Texas. In addition, a spokesman at GTE headquarters in Stamford, Conn., said the cutback means the company will stall plans to relocate its telephone operations division to the Las Colinas business development, north of Dallas.

title: Oil-Output Rise Asked
description: Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, was quoted today as saying that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should raise its oil output ceiling by at least 8 percent, to 20 million barrels a day, in the second half of 1989. He told the Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey that ''in the second half, we ought to be talking of an increase of at least 1.5 million barrels per day.'' OPEC agreed last November to restrict output to 18.5 million barrels a day for the first half of 1989 to increase prices.

title: A Cabinet Mnemonic for Wall Streeters
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL SCIENCE: The Doctor's World; Scientists, Hoping to End Measles, Find a Surprisingly Resilient Foe
description: SEVEN years after the Government's own deadline for eradicating measles from the United States, the goal is still unmet, and the infection has proved to be such a formidable enemy that some experts question whether it can ever be wiped out unless new vaccination strategies are developed.

title: Anti-Gay Circular Hoax Riles Koch
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday asked the Manhattan District Attorney's office to investigate the distribution of a statement under a fraudulent City Hall letterhead that calls for the outlawing of homosexuality as a ''cure'' for AIDS.

title: Avondale Navy Contract
description: The Navy has awarded Avondale Industries a $319 million contract to build three T-AO fleet oilers, the shipyard announced today. The announcement brought to 16 the number of contracts for the oil-replenishment ships awarded to Avondale since 1982, with the total value of the contracts amounting to $1.9 billion, said Albert L. Bossier Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive. It said about 1,200 Avondale employees would be retained because of the new work.

title: CSP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Burt Refuses Offers, Stays a Giant
description: When the Giants failed to protect Jim Burt, a favorite of the fans, in the National Football League's new free-agency system, he became available to the 27 other teams. There were offers for the ninth-year nose tackle, including one from the Green Bay Packers with a $100,000 signing bonus and salaries of $400,000 this year and $450,000 in 1989.

title: Sharper Image Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Soviet Military Chief in Syria
description: Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, the first Soviet Defense Minister to visit Syria in 19 years, said today that his four-day trip would focus on military ties with Damascus, the Kremlin's main Arab ally. His visit follows one last month by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who called for an international peace conference with the participation of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: A Matador at 2d Base? Ole for Mets' Jefferies
description: ''It's like a bullfight,'' Davey Johnson said, depicting the fine but highly perilous art of turning the double play. ''The second baseman is the matador. His left leg is the red flag. You plant it on the bag, and the runner comes sliding in straight for it. He's the bull.'' It is one week to opening day, and the manager of the Mets is nearing the end of his six-week seminar on how to play second base without getting gored. He had many bulls in mind, but only one matador: Gregg Jefferies, alias The Kid, the whiz who crashed into the big leagues late last season with a bat and a third-baseman's glove and hit .321 with six home runs in 29 games. The only problem was the Mets already had two other third basemen.

title: William J. Miller, 76, Journalist and Author
description: William J. Miller, journalist, author and chief editorial writer for The New York Herald Tribune from 1957 to 1959, died of a stroke Sunday at Alachua General Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 76 years old and spent winters in Gainesville and the rest of the year in Truro, Mass.

title: Books of The Times; Kingsley Amis's Couple Grown Older but Not Wiser
description: Difficulties With Girls By Kingsley Amis 276 pages. Summit Books. $18.95.

title: St Clair Paint & Wallpaper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Researchers Trace Empathy's Roots to Infancy
description: ON seeing another child fall and hurt himself, Hope, just nine months old, stared, tears welling up in her eyes, and crawled to her mother to be comforted - as though she had been hurt, not her friend. When 15-month-old Michael saw his friend Paul crying, Michael fetched his own teddy bear and offered it to Paul; when that didn't stop Paul's tears, Michael brought Paul's security blanket from another room.

title: In Mexico, a Bold New President Is Surprising Both Friends and Enemies
description: Splashed across the front page of virtually every newspaper in the Mexican capital recently were pictures of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari shaking hands with one of his most bitter adversaries, Manuel Clouthier, who as candidate of the National Action Party in the presidential election last year campaigned under banners calling Mr. Salinas a ''bald-headed vote thief.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Noah Gains Quarterfinals: Yannick Noah became ill in the fifth set yesterday against Jakob Hlasek, but the Frenchman recovered to win the fourth-round match yesterday at the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Noah, seeded 12th, advanced to the quarterfinals with his third straight five-set victory, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 2-6, 7-5. Hlasek was seeded fifth, and his elimination meant that of the six top-seeded players, only Ivan Lendl, seeded first, was left with three rounds to go. Thomas Muster, seeded seventh, who beat Eduardo Bengoechea, 6-1, 6-1, 6-1, was the highest-seeded player left in the bracket opposite Lendl. In women's play, top-ranked Gabriela Sabatini swept unseeded Ann Grossman, 6-4, 7-6. Tenth-seeded Lori McNeil lost to Helena Sukova, seeded third, 6-3, 6-2. Noah led, 4-3, in the final set and was about to receive serve when he became ill, causing a brief delay in the match. The umpire warned Noah for the delay, then penalized him a game point before the match resumed.(AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 5, Bruins 2: Guy Carbonneau scored the winning goal with 2 minutes 57 seconds left in the second period last night in Montreal, helping the Canadiens to complete an unbeaten season series with Boston. Carbonneau swept unchecked to the front of the visitors' net and flipped Ryan Walter's pass over Rejean Lemelin, giving Montreal a 7-0-1 record against Boston this year.(AP) Blues 3, Red Wings 2: Bernie Federko scored his 22d goal of the season with 1:43 remaining as St. Louis kept its slim Norris Division title hopes alive. The victory prevented Detroit from clinching its second consecutive division championship. The Blues trail Detroit by 6 points. Both teams have three games left. (AP) Flames 3, North Stars 2: Joe Mullen, Al MacInnis and Joe Nieuwendyk scored after Minnesota giveaways, Nieuwendyk's goal with 1:36 to play, lifting Calgary to the victory in Minnesota. In improving its record to 52-17-9 with its sixth victory in seven games, Calgary remained one point ahead of Montreal in the race for the league's best record. Goalie Mike Vernon stopped 29 shots for his league-leading 36th victory.(AP)

title: TEACHERS NEEDED, CATHOLICS WARNED
description: Roman Catholic educators ''must look to their own survival'' and start recruiting their successors to insure a much-needed supply of lay teachers as enrollment in parochial schools increases, Archbishop Eugene A. Marino of Atlanta said here today.

title: 49ers Sign Tillman
description: Spencer Tillman, who was left unprotected by the Houston Oilers, signed a two-year contract worth $475,000 with the San Fransicso 49ers yesterday.

title: Gorilla Motherhood
description: The birth of a gorilla this month at Zoo Atlanta has focused attention on the practice of keeping the mother isolated from other gorillas just before and after giving birth.

title: New York Considers Privileged-Parking Fee
description: The New York City Department of Transportation is considering placing parking meters in designated spaces where certain privileged categories of motorists are now allowed free and unrestricted parking, the commissioner, Ross Sandler, said yesterday.

title: Fast Start Helps Devils To Defeat Flyers
description: The Flyers allowed themselves to become frustrated after permitting three quick goals tonight and suffered a 5-3 loss to the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: George Slaff, 83, Dies; Civil Liberties Lawyer
description: George Slaff, a former president of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California who also represented members of the film industry, died of colon cancer Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: IRAQ IS TO PAY U.S. IN SAILORS' DEATHS
description: After nearly a year of negotiations, Iraq has agreed to pay the United States $27.3 million in compensation for the families of 37 American sailors killed in the 1987 attack on the guided-missile frigate Stark, Administration officials said today.

title: Non-Hispanic Catholics and Koch: After Three Terms, a Crisis in Faith
description: Thomas Moore, a firefighter, and his wife Betty, a registered nurse, both voted for Mayor Edward I. Koch four years ago. This time, Mr. Koch already has lost Mr. Moore over the corruption issue. His wife, none too pleased with the Mayor either, is wavering.

title: Dow Rises 14.82 on Slowest Day of Year
description: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday in Wall Street's slowest trading since last December.

title: General Nutrition Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
description: b-Net loss and included a $1,300,000 gain from the settlement of litigation, a $7,120,000 provision for plant sale and consolidation, and a $2,963,000 provision for store closings.

title: When Yogi Threw His Cigarettes
description: With or without Pete Rose, the baseball season will open next Monday afternoon. Nobody knows that better than book dealers. In book stores all over the country, this year's baseball books are on display. And of all the glossy dust jackets, the most appealing shows Yogi Berra, wearing glasses and a gray Yankee road uniform, sitting in a dugout with his left hand atop his Yankee cap as if he were deciding whether or not to tell why George Steinbrenner dismissed him as manager only 16 games into the 1985 season.

title: Barney Tobey, 82, a Cartoonist In The New Yorker for 5 Decades
description: Barney Tobey, whose gently humorous cartoons appeared in The New Yorker for more than five decades, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Filene's Planning To Add Six Stores
description: Filene's, the Boston-based division of the May Department Stores Company, said it would invest more than $125 million in the next five years to open six new Filene's department stores and remodel eight existing stores. The 17-store chain said four of the new units would be in Massachusetts and two in New Hampshire. They will provide jobs for 1,000 people, Filene's said.

title: Woman and 2 Sons Slain on L.I.
description: A mother and her two sons were found slain last night in their home in Central Islip, L.I., the Suffolk County Police said.

title: L.I. Minister Sentenced to Jail
description: The Rev. Eugene Profeta, the preacher Jessica Hahn said she turned to for solace after her sexual encounter with Jim Bakker, the deposed P.T.L. organization leader, was sentenced today to six months in jail and five years' probation on witness tampering and tax charges. Under a plea-bargain agreement, the Long Island minister was also ordered to pay about $26,000 in back taxes, interest and fines. He is also required to stay away from Miss Hahn, his former church secretary. Miss Hahn had helped put together the case against Mr. Profeta after being promised immunity from prosecution.

title: Trade-Gap Warning
description: Failure to reduce the large United States trade deficit could cause a collapse in foreign confidence in the dollar, which would send interest rates soaring and tip the economy into recession, a group of international economists said today.

title: Emery Asked To Search for New Suitor
description: The Justice Department has asked the Emery Air Freight Corporation to determine if there are any parties interested in acquiring the company other than Consolidated Freightways Inc., which agreed last month to buy Emery for $230 million.

title: Dollar Posts Sharp Advance Against the Mark and Yen
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, reaching its highest level against the yen and mark since last year. It also moved very close to the level considered the Group of Seven's ceiling against the mark.

title: Chancellor, Citing Indictments, Suspends Bronx School Board
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green suspended a local school board in the Bronx yesterday, saying recent indictments of two members seriously undermines the board's ability to run the schools.

title: C-Span in the House: 10 Years of Gavel to Gavel
description: It was a typical uneventful Monday in the House of Representatives. After the noon opening came a handful of short speeches, passage of two noncontroversial bills and 90 minutes of debate on internal House issues - money for the computer system and reorganizing committees. The few lawmakers who remained after roll-call were back in their offices by 2:30 P.M.

title: The North Trial's Larger Jury
description: It is for Judge Gerhard Gesell to decide whether Ronald Reagan's testimony is legally required in the trial of Oliver North. But outside Washington's Federal court, a larger jury of the American public deserves a fuller account from Mr. Reagan. For whatever else the trial concludes, the evidence so far suggests that he knew much more about the Iran-contra affair than he led Americans to believe.

title: Caspen Oil Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results restated to reflect Bryson Oil & Gas Corp. as the predecessor company.

title: Giant Food Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Logic Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3Com Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago 9 months' results included $3,433,000 of non-recurring expenses related to the company's merger with Bridge Communications Inc. in September 1987.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Refined Dirty Dozen On ''Voodoo'' (Columbia), the third album by the Dirty Dozen Brass Band, the eight-man New Orleans-based ensemble that has revitalized a moribund marching-band tradition performs pieces by composers ranging from Stevie Wonder to Charlie Parker. Dr. John sings on the band's version of the rhythm-and-blues standard ''It's All Over Now,'' and Dizzy Gillespie and Branford Marsalis also appear as soloists on the record.

title: New EMI Music Chief
description: Jim Fifield has been appointed chief executive of EMI Music Worldwide, effective Saturday. Mr. Fifield, currently president and chief operating officer, will continue as president. In his new position, he will be responsible for EMI Music's operations in 37 countries. Those include record companies, manufacturing plants, recording studios and music publishers.

title: School Rights Lawsuit Ended in Los Angeles
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has abandoned an eight-year-old desegregation lawsuit against the nation's second-largest school district.

title: 5 Men Found Slain in Tucson
description: The bodies of five men killed in what the police said might have been a drug-related killing were found Monday in a shed behind a house, the authorities said today. They were discovered by the wife of one of the victims, said Sgt. Charles Armijo, head of the Police Department's homicide unit. The five, described by a neighbor as in their 20's and 30's, were killed ''within the last day,'' Sergeant Armijo said.

title: OPEC Wants Its Prices To Stay Under a $20 Top
description: Demand for oil produced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has pushed prices up by 50 percent since November. Now Saudi Arabia and a majority of other OPEC members are determined to hold the prices below a ceiling of $20 a barrel.

title: Mexico's Foreign Debt Is Wagging Diplomacy
description: Since Mexico's new administration was sworn into office in December, Finance Minister Pedro Aspe has made three trips to the United States. It was not until last week, however, that Foreign Minister Fernando Solana paid his first visit to Washington.

title: British Bank to Cut Jobs in Revamping
description: Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's third-largest commercial bank, said it would cut 2,000 jobs in a reorganization of its domestic operations. The reductions, totaling about 5 percent of the bank's total work force, will be through attrition, a spokesman, Kyle Fraser, said. About 4,000 employees are expected to leave the bank in 1989 because of usual turnover, and only 2,000 will be replaced, he said.

title: Johnson & Johnson And Merck in Venture
description: Merck & Company and Johnson & Johnson yesterday announced a partnership to develop and sell nonprescription versions of some Merck drugs.

title: Joel Fineman, 42, Shakespearean Scholar
description: Joel Fineman, a professor of English at the University of California here who was a Shakespearean scholar, died of colon cancer Saturday at his home in Berkeley. He was 42 years old.

title: Homestead Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $479,000 for the quarter and $1,546,000 for the year. c-Net income The company said certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform with the current presentation.

title: Phoenix Rejects Expansion of Transit System
description: Voters today rejected a proposal to increase the sales tax half a cent to finance an $8.4 billion expansion of the Phoenix area's mass transit system.

title: Gordon Jewelry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter and 6 months included pretax gains of $1,512,000 and $3,730,337, respectively, from the sale of real estate not used in the retail jewelry business and which did not produce material revenue. Year-ago quarter and 6 months both included a $2,546,265 pretax charge related to transactions with the buyer of the company's former catalog-showroom stores division.

title: Economic Scene; Big Brother In the Bathroom
description: ''THEY are proposing to put the national government in your bathroom,'' concludes John Genovese, vice president for product development at American Standard Inc. ''They'' are a group of members of Congress, led by Senator Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia and Representative Chester Atkins of Massachusetts, who have introduced a bill setting Federal water conservation standards for plumbing fixtures.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: RUSTLE up some bacon and eggs, boil some coffee black as pitch and get down to real eatin' - but only if you intend to bale hay, bust broncs or do something besides sitting in a leather-covered desk chair all day.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: One of the most famous - and certainly most literate - curriculum debates that ever took place occurred in the early 1880's between Matthew Arnold, the poet and educator, and Thomas Huxley, the biologist. The issue in both England and this country was whether college curriculums, which at the time focused entirely on classical literature, should be expanded to embrace the natural sciences.

title: Stanley E. Dimond, Educator, 83
description: Stanley E. Dimond, a professor emeritus of education at the University of Michigan, died Saturday after an extended illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Intel in Pact With I.B.M.
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to develop circuit-board products that will bring Intel's Digital Video Interactive technology to the I.B.M. Personal System/2 computers.

title: Recycling Plan Gains Final Approval
description: A plan that will change the way New Yorkers dispose of their garbage won final approval yesterday in the City Council, requiring the city to recycle 25 percent of its garbage.

title: About New York; A Genteel War: Billiards Stars Engage in Battle
description: At first, the scene in Abel's Club in Astoria, Queens, might have been any pool hall - ceiling fans doing halfhearted battle with stale smoke, three lights over each table, silence punctuated by the crack of ball hitting ball.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Metalclad Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $136,000. c-After a gain of $1,014,000 on debt restructuring and a tax credit of $856,000.

title: Public-Private Venture Aims to Improve Child Health Care
description: Pediatricians are being asked to contribute up to $100 each and their best ideas to a new national partnership to give children greater access to health care and reduce the country's high rate of infant mortality.

title: Bush Sends Team to Assess Cleanup
description: President Bush, facing criticism over how his Administration is responding to the worst oil spill in North American waters, sent a delegation of high-ranking officials to Prince William Sound off Alaska today to inspect the damage.

title: Cuomo's Budget Splits Democrats Over Aid to the Poor
description: The battle over this year's state budget, the tightest spending plan in more than a decade, has been shaped by a struggle - some say ideological - between the state's top Democratic officials over how much of an obligation the state government has to assist its poorest citizens.

title: Adolph Dreher, 86, Leather Manufacturer
description: Adolph Dreher, founder and president of one of the largest leather manufacturers and importers in the country, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Bloc Development Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its 1987 results did not include an income tax provision since it had S-Corporation status for that period.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Giuliani, Stretching Before a Run, Lambastes Both Koch and Cuomo
description: Warming up for the mayoral campaign, Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized Governor Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday for ''playing Ping-Pong'' with drug treatment programs as drugs became a crisis.

title: Taylor Rejects Charge
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, entered a written plea of not guilty to an alcohol-related charge and waived a court appearance yesterday in Saddle Brook, N.J., the township prosecutor, Joseph Mecca Jr., said. No new court date was set, the prosecutor said. Taylor had been scheduled to appear in court today.

title: Medical Schools Getting More Applicants
description: For the first time in seven years, the number of applicants to the nation's medical schools appears to be increasing, and officials hope the numbers signal a reversal in a steady decline in applications.

title: Fishing Areas Nurtured By Conservation Group
description: rrWith the trout season opening Saturday in New York and later in the month in New Jersey and Connecticut, anglers should be reminded that in many streams the fish they so admire wouldn't be flourishing without the assistance of Trout Unlimited.

title: Hospital Tax Deal Approved by Court
description: A New York State appellate court yesterday approved a tax relief plan for North General Hospital in Harlem, allowing the financially troubled institution to begin a rebuilding program.

title: Extending the Life Of a Bottle of Beer
description: The Aquanautics Corporation of Alameda, Calif., has spent several years developing an artificial gill, based on a novel technology for extracting oxygen from water. That product remains in the development stage, but the technology may reach the market in a more common medium - beer bottle caps - where its properties could extend the shelf life of beer by reducing oxygen-related spoilage.

title: Mysterious Gusher Fills Elevator Pit
description: A mysterious leak has sent water pouring into the elevator pit of a Manhattan building for more than a year, the building's owner has complained. The leak, he said, is wasting a million gallons a week of the city's water.

title: Court Rules America's Cup Is New Zealand's by Forfeit
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the San Diego Yacht Club had beaten its challenger unfairly last September and must forfeit the America's Cup, yachting's oldest and most prestigious trophy, to New Zealand.

title: Cities Try Out New Approach In Police Work
description: For years, when Patrolman Ron Reedy answered a call here, he asked a few questions, made pages of notes, wrote a report and went on to the next call, hour after hour, shift after shift. Most times, he never knew if anyone was ever caught or helped by this kind of numbing routine, which has dominated American police work for over half a century.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Rent-A-Wreck Names A New Chief Executive
description: Rent-A-Wreck of America Inc., which became well known as a specialty renter of used cars, has a new president and chief executive, J. Richard Haigh.

title: Arab League Re-elects Klibi
description: The Arab League re-elected Chedli Klibi of Tunisia today to a third five-year term as its Secretary General. The 21 Arab League delegates voted unanimously for Mr. Klibi, 64 years old, to continue in the post he has held since 1979.

title: Rule Change to Add 500 Beds to jails Is Rejected
description: A request by the New York City Correction Commissioner for permission to make room for 500 more beds was turned down yesterday when the City Board of Correction said the city's overcrowded jails cannot squeeze in any more prisoners.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7,134,000 for the latest year and $15,263,000 for prior period.

title: FDP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and included a $324,191 gain from an accounting change.

title: Yankees Go With Espinoza As the Starting Shortstop
description: In the days and nights that have carried the Yankees through another tumultuous spring, the player who will be their starting shortstop Tuesday in Minneapolis has performed quietly, evenly. Alvaro Espinoza is neither Ozzie Smith nor Ozzie Guillen; his glove does not dazzle. He is simply capable. He makes the plays.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Special CD Is Offered In Cigarette Promotion
description: The makers of Parliament Lights are hoping to sell cigarettes by appealing to smokers' ears as well as their palates. Parliament will offer a free compact disk featuring hit songs by Tina Turner, Eddie Money and Cheap Trick with the purchase of a specially designed three-pack of cigarettes. The unusual promotion was created by Alex Aliksanyan, the brand manager for Parliament at the Philip Morris Companies.

title: New Threat: Poison-Tipped Missiles
description: An intensive arms race is under way in the Middle East to obtain a ''poor man's atom bomb'' - a ballistic missile armed with a chemical warhead. As the Iran-Iraq War demonstrated, there is a willingness to use these terrible weapons on civilian populations. Thus, the prospect of the Qaddafis and Khomeinis of the world acquiring - and using -long-range missiles with a chemical capability is real.

title: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After income of $4,688,000, or 8 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Fiscal 1989's operating net included a charge of $938,000 for expenses to consolidate the company's organizational structure.

title: Oscars! Ludwigs! Shad Roe!
description: It's prize time all over America. Tonight the Oscars. Tomorrow the Pulitzers. Next week the Windermeres. Or is it the Ludwigs? At this time of year they come so thick and fast it's hard to keep them sorted out.

title: 3,000 Assailing Policy on AIDS Ring City hall
description: In New York City's largest demonstration over AIDS to date, about 3,000 chanting marchers, demanding more government funds and services, ringed City Hall Park yesterday and briefly blocked the Brooklyn Bridge, Broadway and other streets.

title: Topics of The Times; Fido Calling, and Calling
description: Imagine the house dog or cat marooned on a doorstep, its plaintive bark, meow or scratch drowned out by passing traffic or its owner's TV set. Imagine rain making the scene all the more pathetic. Or imagine the same dog or cat desperate to get out and thus avoid a spanking for sullying the rug yet again.

title: Answering the Call of the Dugout
description: Fifty years ago at Duke University, everybody on the baseball team wanted to become a major leaguer, whether they admitted it or not.

title: Sony Mae Issue Of $90 Million
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which provides low-interest-rate financing for first-time home buyers, priced a $90 million reoffering of mortgage revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: CHEMICAL FOR IRAN WON'T BE RELEASED
description: A Florida-based company lost its bid today to win the release of a chemical used in rocket fuel that was confiscated on the way to Iran.

title: S & K Famous Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $401,400 from an accounting change.

title: State Dept. Challenged On Trade
description: Prodded by the aerospace and electronics industries, the Commerce Department is challenging the State Department's exclusive authority over exports of commercial technology that has military applications.

title: Majority of Private Trade Schools Are a Success; New York Inaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick & Reilly Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest fourth quarter included writeoffs equal to about 5 cents a share from the acquisition of Conklin, Cahill & Co.

title: From Soviet Voters, a Call for Change
description: The big winner in Sunday's extraordinary Soviet elections could well turn out to be Mikhail Gorbachev. Voters sent a devastating message of rejection to the old guard in the Communist Party he leads. But they also lent powerful impetus to Mr. Gorbachev's campaign for renewal.

title: Israel Reports a P.L.O. Buildup in Lebanon
description: Palestinian guerrillas set off an explosion today at an Israeli post in southern Lebanon, and two other guerrillas were captured inside the buffer zone that Israel maintains north of its border.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Broaden Basis for an Incentive in Civil Rights Cases
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that people who bring civil rights lawsuits in Federal court can win reimbursement of their legal fees even if the suit is only partly successful.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Evert Gains: Second-seeded Chris Evert won a third-set tiebreaker, 7-0, yesterday to edge No. 11 Helen Kelesi in the quarterfinals of the International Players Championships. Evert rallied from a service break down in the final set to win, 6-3, 4-6, 7-6. Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina also advanced by sweeping No. 25 Isabelle Demongeot of France, 6-1, 7-5. Evert's semifinals match tomorrow will be against fifth-seeded Zina Garrison, who needed more than two hours to beat unseeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 5-7, 6-1. Sabatini will meet No. 3 Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who defeated No. 15 Raffaella Reggi of Italy, 5-7. 6-4. 6-3. The field for today's men's quarterfinals was completed early yesterday when Jim Grabb, ranked No. 172, beat Alberto Mancini, 6-7, 6-4, 7-6, 6-7, 6-4.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 102, Mavericks 90: Ron Harper scored 15 of his 26 points during a Cleveland rally late in the third quarter last night, and the Cavaliers reached the 50-victory mark for the first time in their 19 seasons. Mark Price had 21 points as Cleveland won for the 32d time in 35 home games - including 26 of the last 27 - and handed Dallas its 11th consecutive setback, fourth longest in its history. The Cavaliers' 50-20 record is the league's second-best behind Central Division-leading Detroit's 50-17.(AP) 76ers 117, Celtics 115: Charles Barkley had 27 points and Hersey Hawkins scored 8 of his 21 in overtime as the 76ers won at home last night. Boston's Reggie Lewis scored a career-high 39 points and Brian Shaw had 18 points and 14 rebounds. (AP) Rockets 120, SuperSonics 117: Akeem Olajuwon scored 17 of his 36 points in the pivotal fourth quarter to lead Houston. (AP) Bulls 115, Warriors 106:Michael Jordan had his sixth triple-double of the season and scored 14 of his 33 points in the final quarter as Chicago took its fifth consecutive victory. Jordan, who has 11 career triple-doubles, had 12 rebounds and 11 assists. He made two short jumpers during a 12-3 fourth-quarter spurt that gave the Bulls a 103-88 lead. (AP) Suns 127, Lakers 104: Tom Chambers scored 28 points, Kevin Johnson 24 and Eddie Johnson had 8 of his 21 in a decisive second period as Phoenix beat cold-shooting Los Angeles to clinch their first playoff berth in four years. Phoenix entered the game with a magic number of two to make the playoffs and the Suns were put in position to clinch when Dallas lost to Cleveland.(AP)

title: Yields Post Modest Rise For the Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were modestly higher for the week ended yesterday.

title: Ex-Official Indicted in Japan Bribery Case
description: A former Japanese deputy minister was charged and another was arrested today, both accused of taking bribes in postwar Japan's biggest political scandal, news reports said.

title: 21 Reported Killed in Yugoslavia In Ethnic Albanian Disturbances
description: At least 21 people have been killed in the last two days in rioting by ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo region, the authorities said today. The Albanians have been protesting legislative changes that will curb the autonomy of the predominantly Albanian region.

title: More Than a Fifth of School Buses Are Unsafe, Agency Says
description: The National Transportation Safety board, ending its investigation of a school bus accident in which 27 people died, recommended today that more than a fifth of the nation's school buses be retired as unsafe.

title: Edward H. Davis, 61, California Neurologist
description: Edward H. Davis, a Los Angeles neurologist for nearly 30 years, died of pneumonia Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Missile Shield Must Be Balanced Against Other Goals, Cheney Says
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Reagan Administration ''oversold'' the effectiveness of its proposal for a shield against missile attack and cautioned that the plan should be balanced against other strategic needs.

title: Unisys Settles Charges
description: The Unisys Corporation has paid $700,000 to the Government in return for Federal authorities' throwing out an indictment on fraud charges, the United States Attorney, James Wilson, said on Monday. The charges brought last October against Unisys and its predecessor, the Sperry Corporation, stemmed from a $526 million contract to upgrade the Air Force's worldwide computer system. Unisys and Sperry were accused of overcharging the Government in 1983 for an unspecified portion of a $500,000 invoice involving the computer contract. Unisys has continued to deny wrongdoing.

title: Treasury Prices Rise in Quiet Day
description: A drop in oil prices and another strong advance by the dollar helped lift prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday. Market participants said trading was a bit more brisk than in Monday's session but remained quite light.

title: Pointing The Way To Wine
description: THE New York State Department of Transportation will soon start pointing the way to the state's wine country. The agency has designed road signs depicting a stylized cluster of white grapes on a green background, which are to be installed at 300 sites around the state.

title: Soviet Insurgent Basks in Victory's Glow
description: Arkady N. Murashev was the one candidate in the Soviet elections willing to come out plainly for a multiparty democracy, and he has survived atop a landslide to tell about it.

title: Merrill Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Team Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a tax loss carryforward of $554,000, or 20 cents a share. c-Included a tax loss carryforward of $155,000 for the both periods.

title: Ael Industries reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 24
description: b-Net income

title: Darling and Aguilera Displaying Top Form
description: Six days from the start of the season, Davey Johnson sat on the Mets' bench today and thought, ouch: Gary Carter's swollen right knee; Howard Johnson's weak right shoulder; Keith Hernandez's inflamed left elbow; trade jitters sweeping the camp; cutdown blues wracking the rookies.

title: Reviews/Music; Folk-Rock From Israel
description: In Israel, as in the United States, folk-rock goes with protest songs. For Ehud Banai and the Refugees, who opened a two-night stand at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday, folk-rock means a combination of local ingredients - modal melodies, jar drums, lead guitar played like a Middle Eastern oud (lute) and lyrics in Hebrew - with arranging ideas imported from Bob Dylan, the Police and other American and European rockers. In Mr. Banai's songs, internationalism bolsters the music without suppressing its homegrown flavor.

title: No Verdicts in Byrne Trial After a Day of Deliberations
description: Jurors in State Supreme Court in Queens deliberated without reaching verdicts yesterday in the trial of three men charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer in Queens 13 months ago.

title: Melville E. Stone 2d, Bookseller, 84
description: Melville E. Stone 2d, the former owner and managing director of the Sporting Gallery and Bookshop, died of throat cancer Saturday at his home in York Harbor, Me. He was 84 years old.

title: Emhart to Provide Data to Topper
description: The Emhart Corporation has agreed to give Topper L.P. confidential financial information that the New York-based investment group has requested. Topper has sought the data to help in deciding whether to raise its offer of $35 a share, or $2.4 billion, in the face of a bid of $40 a share by the Black & Decker Corporation. Emhart based in Farmington, Conn., had rejected the Topper offer as inadequate.

title: Greeks Halt Extradition, Jailing Palestinian
description: Proceedings to extradite a suspected Palestinian terrorist to the United States were delayed further today when a Greek court sentenced him to eight months' imprisonment for attempting to escape from jail.

title: Gossage Is Given Release by Cubs
description: Rich (Goose) Gossage, only 39 saves short of baseball's career leader, was released yesterday by the Chicago Cubs. Gossage, a 16-year veteran who had a 4-4 record with 13 saves in 1988, said his release was not his farewell to baseball.

title: Oracle Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Review/Piano; Filling In for a Recitalist
description: David Bar-Illan's scheduled piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night was frustrated by an injury to his hand. He was replaced on short notice by the young pianist Alexander Peskanov.

title: Strong Dollar Helps to Push Dow Up 17.68
description: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday for the second consecutive day, joined this time by strength in the broader market.

title: Foods That Play April Fool's Jokes On Palate and Eye
description: LEAD: EVER since Alice's encounter with the Mock Turtle, many foods have been playing April Fool's Day jokes, making believe they are what they are not.

title: Peter Gilbert, 62, Dies; Led a Media Company
description: Peter Gilbert, a cable television executive and the former owner of a professional hockey team, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Chartwell Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $129,000 and an extraordinary credit of $309,000 from the early extinguishment of debt, both for the quarter and year. The prior year net from continuing operations included a charge of $1,628,000 on the sale of securities.

title: Bridge
description: For almost a quarter of a century there were two, and for two years there was one. Briefly there were none, but now there are four. What are they?

title: Washington Talk: Snapshot; Writing Cheney? Better Make it 'Richard B.'
description: Excuse me, Mr. Secretary, but after you figure out the corridors and basements of the Pentagon, could we have a word with you about your name?

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bayer USA, Inc., Pittsburgh, the manufacturer of health-care products and U.S. subsidiary of Bayer A.G., West Germany, named Wilson S. Goodwin vice president of human resources, succeeding Edward L. Reichard, who retired. * Centrust Savings Bank, Miami, named John K. Grelle chief executive of its Kansas City, Mo., subsidiary, Old American Insurance Co. * Champion International Corp., Stamford, Conn., the paper manufacturer, promoted Gerald J. O'Connor to vice president and general manager. * Gillette Co., Boston, the manufacturer of personal-care products, appointed Robert A. Williams third vice president of Gillette North Atlantic and director of urban affairs for the parent company. * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, the textbook publisher, named Edward P. Sinni Jr. vice president. * National Fuel Gas Co., an energy holding company, appointed Bernard J. Kennedy chairman and John M. Brown vice chairman. * Philadelphia Stock Exchange said Louis E. Morales, first vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., had been elected vice chairman.

title: Rates Turn Lower At Citicorp's Sale
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. It was only the second time this year that rates fell; the first was in early March.

title: S.E.C. Objection Dooms 'Unbundled Stock Units'
description: A plan to restructure several major corporations using ''unbundled stock units'' was killed yesterday after the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission objected to the planned accounting treatment for the innovative securities.

title: Democrat Wins Indiana Race
description: A Democrat scored a surprise victory over her Republican opponent today in a special election for the House seat that once belonged to Vice President Dan Quayle.

title: Advantages Seen In Smaller Banks
description: SUPER-REGIONAL banks may be the current focus of many analysts and professional investors, but small regional banks are capturing more and more attention.

title: Mayor of New Haven Won't Seek Sixth Term
description: Mayor Biagio DiLieto, a former police chief who has driven New Haven's powerful Democratic Party machine for the last decade, shocked supporters and critics today when he announced that he would not seek a sixth two-year term in office this fall.

title: Poor People Facing Eviction Have a Right to Appointed Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Employers Insurance Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $120,000 from the cumulative effect of adoption of FAS 96. The company said adoption of FAS No. 96 required the company to recalculate its deferred tax liabilities for its U.S. operations.

title: A Step Ahead Of College Lynch Mobs
description: rrThe thoroughbred horse farms are stunningly picturesque. Winters are usually not as harsh as they are up north. And residents can sing, ''My Old Kentucky Home'' every time they pull into the driveway, instead of just on Derby day. But can those be good reasons why every other basketball coach in the country reportedly wants to be considered for the job at the University of Kentucky?

title: Majority of Private Trade Schools Are a Success; Pay Half on Enrollment
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Washington Talk; Gray-Baker Vendetta: A Long-Running Tale Of Potomac Intrigue
description: Is Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d furious at C. Boyden Gray, the White House legal counsel?

title: British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had won the first American order for its advanced turboprop airliner in a deal with Air Wisconsin Inc. worth $200 million. The deal is for 14 ATP aircraft, with options on six more. Three planes are to be delivered in the fourth quarter of this year, while six will follow in 1990 and the rest in 1991. Air Wisconsin is the nation's most profitable regional airline.

title: Real Estate; Recycling: A New Issue For Builders
description: MOST people think of waste recycling as an environmental issue, but it is also becoming a real estate issue affecting builders, developers and operators of office and commercial properties.

title: Dr. Albert Guerisse, Belgian War Hero, 78
description: Dr. Albert Guerisse, a hero of the Belgian underground who helped Allied airmen escape from occupied Europe during World War II, died on Sunday, his family said today. He was 78 years old.

title: Comcoa Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 22
description: b-Included tax credits of $240,692 for the latest year and $152,653 for the year-earlier period.

title: Krelitz Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Forty large companies have sponsored a print and television ad campaign extolling New York City as a dynamic business center. American Express, New York Telephone and I.B.M. are among the companies that have collaborated in a group called the Alliance for New York City Business. The ads, designed by Ogilvy & Mather, will appear in newspapers and on television starting Monday.

title: Review/Music; Student Chamber Players Offer Six Modern Works
description: The Stony Brook Contemporary Chamber Players, a remarkably well-trained student ensemble, offered finely polished renderings of six new works at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening. The ensemble's directors are Raymond DesRoches and Gilbert Kalish, both of whom have long histories of involvement in contemporary music. But the conducting, here, was left to the students.

title: Opposition To Emery Bid Is Dropped
description: The Justice Department yesterday dropped its antitrust opposition to a proposed $230 million takeover of the Emery Air Freight Corporation by Consolidated Freightways Inc.

title: WINE TALK
description: LIKE The Wine Advocate and Robert M. Parker or Wine Odyssey and John Foy, The New York Wine Cellar is a wine newsletter with a name behind it: Stephen D. Tanzer.

title: National Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Cousin Sought For Questioning In L.I. Slayings
description: A cousin of a woman who was found slain along with her two sons in their house here late Monday is being sought for questioning in the murders, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: T.W.A. Announces An Airbus Order By The Associated Press
description: As expected, Trans World Airlines Inc. said it planned to modernize its fleet by buying up to 40 jetliners from Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, for more than $3.6 billion. T.W.A.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn, said the airline would place firm orders for 20 A330 twin-engine planes and take options on an additional 20 of the wide-body aircraft.

title: Getting Serious About Smog at Last
description: It is the not-so-secret shame of us here in so-called lotus land that we have befouled our air almost beyond breathability. In the hotter months particularly, our seaside paradise sits under a thick ceiling of polluted sky. Our geography - the fact that we sit in a basin - coupled with our car lust has given Los Angeles the worst air of any city in the country; 199 days out of the year we exceed air pollution standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Mary E. Johnston, Journalist, 71
description: Mary Elizabeth Johnston, the chief of reporters for Fortune magazine, died of emphysema Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Dean Foods Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Oscar Nominations Again Snub Spielberg
description: To the Editor:

title: A Growing Harvest Of Organic Produce
description: ORGANIC agriculture, espoused by those who went back to nature in the 60's, is on the verge of changing from a movement to an industry. In ever-increasing numbers and at ever-increasing speed, growers, distributors, retailers, governments, agricultural scientists and economists are responding to consumer concerns about food safety by exploring organic agriculture.

title: Wolf, Howard B reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $5,000 for the quarter and $87,500 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $12,905 and $18,052 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Wedgestone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Wedgestone said the main reason for the loss was the establishment of a $15 million allowance for losses and a continued high level of under-performing assets.

title: SOVIET MARS CRAFT IS REPORTED LOST
description: Soviet space officials have lost contact with an unmanned spacecraft maneuvering near a Martian moon, severely threatening Soviet dreams of exploring Mars.

title: On Front Line of Fight for Better Math Teaching
description: At first glance, the growing debate over how the nation's school children should learn mathematics seems far removed from Steven Epstein's seventh-grade class here at the May V. Carrigan Middle School, a low, large building at the end of a cul-de-sac.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Mad Parody Of Adweek
description: Employees at ad agencies in Los Angeles blinked on Monday when they picked up their familiar trade magazine - the one with the bright red masthead.

title: Protect Medical Records
description: During the Senate hearings on the nomination of John Tower for Secretary of Defense, a retired Air Force sergeant made several allegations concerning Mr. Tower's behavior at a Texas Air Force base. In an effort to discredit his testimony, several senators then made public the sergeant's medical and psychiatric records.

title: 2 Papers Seek Joint Operation
description: The Justice Department said today that the two daily newspapers in York, Pa., The Daily Record and The Dispatch, had filed an application for a joint operating agreement.

title: Robert Cushman Hunt, Psychiatrist, 84
description: Dr. Robert Cushman Hunt, a psychiatrist and former assistant commissioner of the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene, died Monday at Coral Reef Hospital in Miami. He was 84 years old and lived in Miami. Dr. Hunt was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. He headed New York State hospitals in Rochester and Ogdensburg before becoming assistant commissioner in 1952. He became director of Hudson River State Hospital in Poughkeepsie in 1957 and retired in 1962.

title: Higuera Disabled
