description: Ted Higuera has been placed on the 15-day disabled list by the Milwaukee Brewers, who are sending their ace left-hander to the minor leagues on a rehabilitation assignment. Higuera, 69-38 in four major league seasons, underwent back surgery Jan. 20 and has not pitched an inning this spring.

title: Unorthodox Path to a Language Teaches Schoolchildren to Live It
description: In her unorthodox kindergarten, 6-year-old Brooklyn Schwartz spends one day learning in English, one day in Spanish, one day in English, alternating languages in this manner throughout the year.

title: Israel Astir Over Press Imposters
description: Israel's Police Commissioner today ordered the police and security agents in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to stop putting signs in their cars identifying them as journalists. The order came five days after the plainclothes police in the West Bank created a furor by using signs that said press in their cars while patrolling and making arrests.

title: Rookie Gives Lift To Islanders
description: The Islanders' Mike Walsh, who will turn 27 years old next week and had to wait until tonight to score his first National Hockey League goal, is the oldest rookie on a team that values rookies dearly while billing itself as the team of the 1990's.

title: Morrison Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-After a loss of $4,000 for the quarter and income of $428,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $235,000 for the quarter and $590,000 for the 9 months.

title: Upshaw Recital Canceled
description: A recital by the soprano Dawn Upshaw scheduled for Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall has been canceled because James Levine, who was to have accompanied her, is suffering from a pinched nerve. Refunds are available at the box office. Information: 362-1911.

title: Juno Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain of $165,000 from an accounting change.

title: Galveston Journal; Beer and Money Flow Where the Revelers Are
description: This island first tasted money when the buccaneer Jean Lafitte sailed his fleet here in 1817 and built a fortified pleasure palace he called Maison Rouge.

title: Washington Talk: In the Capital
description: When Presidents look for people to compare themselves to, for role models or historical soul mates, they usually choose Presidents of another era.

title: Hard Times For Books on Hard Times
description: Frightened by the stock market crash of October 1987, the owner of a Northern California publishing house, Ben Dominitz, looked for a book that would address his concerns as a businessman. His answer was ''When the Bottom Drops,'' a book by A. David Silver on how companies could survive the coming hard times.

title: Luxembourg Bank Law
description: Luxembourg has rushed through a new law confirming banking secrecy to ward off any attempt by the European Community to force banks to disclose information about their clients, Government officials said today.

title: New Harding Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Is Said to Cut Payments To the Contras' Political Arm
description: LEAD: A high-ranking contra leader said today that the Bush Administration had cut a $400,000 monthly stipend to the rebels's civilian leaders by more than half and eliminated payments for all contra political operations. The move, a strong shift in United States policy toward the contras, will sharply limit the rebels' lobbying and publicity efforts.

title: Poets in the Bars Series To Start at Village Gate
description: A series of eight readings, Poets in the Bars, will be held in New York City bars where poets have written, given readings or held court. Displays of books, photos and other memorabilia will be at these celebrations of the tradition of oral poetry.

title: Jews Served in Pre-World War II Polish Military
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATION: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Proposals to let parents choose their children's public schools have become embroiled in ideological controversy: in theory, choice is supposed to be a pillar of democracy; in practice, letting parents choose their childrens' school is opposed by many who consider it an assault on equality, an invitation to elitism.

title: The Farce Is Back, and It's as Lord as Ever
description: In expressing his admiration for ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Max Beerbohm wrote: ''What differentiates this farce from any other, and makes it funnier than any other, is the humorous contrast between its style and matter. To preserve its style fully, the dialogue must be spoken with grave unction.'' One might add that the graver the unction, the funnier the performance, a fact that is as true of Joe Orton as it is of Oscar Wilde.

title: Montazeri, Khomeini's Designated Successor in Iran, Quits Under Pressure
description: In the most striking rearrangement of Iran's theocratic leadership since the revolution 10 years ago, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ousted his designated heir apparent, Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Banc One Corp., a bank holding company based in Columbus, Ohio, bought the mortgage banking operations of Weavert Bros. Inc., Washington. Terms were not disclosed. * Daimler-Benz A.G., the West German auto maker, has been advised by Bonn antitrust authorities against taking a 30 percent stake in Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., the aerospace group. * Diversified Foods Inc., Portland, Me., said it was in preliminary talks with an Asian group that it did not identify about a possible sale of shares. * Douglas Aircraft Co., a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corp., said deliveries of its MD-80 jetliners would be delayed up to 30 days in 1989. The delays reflect a record backlog of orders and other problems. * Fresh Juice Co., Great Neck, L.I., said it had been awarded it a patent on its process of preparing frozen whole fruit juice products from fresh, unpasteurized, whole citrus fruit juices. * Glenfed Inc., Glendale, Calif., said it had received Federal Home Loan Bank Board approval to acquire University Savings Bank of Seattle. Glenfed has offered $25.09 a share, or about $75 million. * Grace Regional Inc. proposed a merger to Regional Bancorp Inc. at $23 a share for all of Regional Bancorp's shares. * Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., Tokyo, said it would set up a company with Moli Energy Ltd., a Canadian battery maker, to develop rechargeable lithium batteries. The new company, Advanced Energy Technologies Inc., would be based in Vancouver, British Columbia. * NRM Energy Co., Dallas, said it had signed an agreement to sell oil and gas properties in Texas, New Mexico and Louisiana for about $52 million. No buyer was disclosed.

title: Sanivan Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mary E. Johnston, Reporter, 71
description: Mary Elizabeth Johnston, the chief of reporters for Fortune magazine, died of emphysema Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Reviews/Music; Repertorio Espanol Offers Work of Falla in 'Granada'
description: ''Granada,'' a pastiche of song, dance, poetry and opera using the music of Manuel de Falla, is one of the current offerings of the Repertorio Espanol at the Gramercy Arts Theater at 138 East 27th Street. Rene Buch, the company's artistic director, has assembled a two-act collage unified - or at least connected - by the music of Spain's greatest composer, the images of one of its great cities and by several related stories and themes, mostly dealing with unhappy love, from its literature and folklore.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Science Times yesterday, with a chart about safety worries in food, described the potential dangers of shellfish incorrectly.

title: Much-Needed Victory Is Salvaged by Nets
description: The Nets' 10-game losing streak is over.

title: Trans-Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago periods included a $1.5 million investment gain.

title: 'Good Samaritan' Guilty on Gun Count
description: A man whose fugitive status on a drug conviction was revealed when he rescued a mugging victim by shooting her assailants pleaded guilty to a weapons charge in the case yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Stumbling Into Colonialism in the Philippines
description: In our Image America's Empire in the Philippines By Stanley Karnow Illustrated. 494 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Fishermen and State Take Charge Of Efforts to Control Alaska Spill
description: Frustrated fishermen and Alaska state officials today took charge of the attempt to stop the spread of a fast-moving oil slick in Prince William Sound, choosing to defend some of the hundreds of islands that dot one of North America's prime salmon nurseries.

title: Books for Cooks and Stove-Top Travelers
description: THIS is the time of year when gardeners dream once more of earth and seeds and growing things. Cooks who are lucky enough to have a little space for gardening, even if the ''garden'' consists of nothing but a few herb plants on a sunny city windowsill, will find a number of useful books among recent publications.

title: George Hart, 57, Lawyer and G.O.P. Leader
description: George M. Hart, a lawyer and a former three-term Republican County chairman on Staten Island, died of pancreatic cancer March 20 at the University of California Hospital at San Diego. He was 57 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: Constitution Bancorp of New England Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brady Plea On Savings Crisis Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady warned today that Congress should not tamper with the Bush Administration's plan to raise $50 billion over the next three years to cover a portion of the estimated losses at more than 500 insolvent savings institutions.

title: Crude Oil Drops Below $20; Gold, Silver and Platinum Off
description: Prices of crude oil slid below the $20 level yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid short selling and profit taking. Much of the selling was prompted by the belief that the energy market might have overreacted a day earlier to news of the Alaskan oil spill.

title: Vietnamese Official Warns U.S. Against Aiding Sihanouk Forces
description: The United States should learn a further lesson from its experience in Vietnam and refuse to supply deadly military aid to the non-Communist resistance in Cambodia, Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, said today.

title: Guardian Trustco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago fourth quarter net per share was not immediately available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In Testimony at Agents' Trial, Warwick Denies Threats
description: Dionne Warwick, the popular singer, told a Federal jury here today that neither she nor her business representatives were ever threatened by the agent Norby Walters or his associates.

title: Truck Hits and Kills a Boy, 4
description: A 4-year-old boy pedaled his bicycle off a sidewalk and into a Queens street where he was struck and killed by a truck, the police said. The child, Christopher Whattey, of 88-15 168th Street, was pronounced dead at the scene, Hillside Avenue and 170th Street in the Jamaica section, shortly after the 10:38 A.M. accident, a police spokesman, Officer Louis Llanes, said.

title: A Reign of Fear
description: No, I have to remind myself, it certainly isn't the first time I have succumbed to intimidation. And yet it is with a degrading feeling I hadn't known before that I decided to change airlines to fly to the U.S., taking a less convenient but less threatened route.

title: Panel Rejects Zoning Shift For Developer
description: New York City refused yesterday to change its zoning to suit an Upper East Side apartment tower that was built 12 stories too tall, making it possible that the developers will have to tear down those floors.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Frankly, we are past the opportunity to recover much oil.

title: Tele-Radio Systems Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $1,212,257, which consisted of a $725,243 gain on the sale of an investment, a tax credit of $526,111, and a $39,097 writeoff of previous years' deferred taxes. The company said that, because of the amalgamation on Jan. 31, 1988 of Orcatech Inc. and Tele-Radio, there are no year-ago comparative figures. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Nick Bremigan, Baseball Umpire, 43
description: Nick Bremigan, an American League umpire since 1974, died today of a heart attack. He was 43 years old.

title: 3 Months on 'Overnight Circuit' for Boy, 9
description: In the evenings, after most of the caseworkers had gone home, Keniatta N. liked to run with abandon, weaving through the empty desks in the city's field office. It was his exercise.

title: 2 South Korean Generals Ousted From Posts
description: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea removed two high-ranking generals from their military posts last night as part of a broad military reorganization that appears intended to remove right-wing critics of his administration.

title: Expos Trade Heaton
description: Neal Heaton, who had an 8.57 e.r.a. and was generally unimpressive in his spring training bid for a spot in the Montreal Expos' starting rotation, was traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday for a player to be named.

title: INSIDE
description: Fear of Impeachment Senior officials worried that Ronald Reagan could be impeached in the Iran scandal, former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said. Page A17. Khomeini Heir Apparent Out In what appeared to be a gain for so-called radical leaders in Iran, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini forced his heir apparent to resign. Page A3. Muscovite Basks in Victory The only Soviet candidate to plainly back a multiparty system won by a landslide. ''People are very sensitive to any lie,'' he explained. Page A12. High Court Rules on Fees The Supreme Court ruled that people who bring civil rights suits in Federal court can be awarded legal fees even if their suit partly fails. Page B7. Chess Player Said to Defect A leading young Soviet chess player, 14-year-old Gata Kamsky, and his father reportedly sought asylum during a tournament in Manhattan. Page B1. Organic Goes Mainstream Organic agriculture is on the verge of changing from a movement to an industry as concerns about food safety increase. The Living section, page C1. Too-Tall Building is Barred New York City moved a step closer to forcing a developer to tear down 12 floors of a 31-story building. Page B1.

title: NASA Is Urged to Focus on Cutting Shuttle's Risks
description: A safety panel yesterday told the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to consider scrapping its plan to produce an advanced solid-fuel rocket booster for the space shuttle in the 1990's. The panel said NASA should focus more immediately on reducing current risks in the winged spaceship and its boosters.

title: Mayoral Candidate Rallies the Faithful in Chicago
description: As dozens of vendors hawked T-shirts and souvenirs, more than 12,000 people jammed a huge auditorium here, erupting in thunderous chants and cheers for victory.

title: Ernest B. Gorin, Executive, 77
description: Ernest Bartley Gorin, a retired vice president of the RCA Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Tax Curb on Raiders Proposed in Albany
description: New York State companies would be less vulnerable to hostile takeovers under a proposal in the state's Senate that would deny certain tax benefits to corporate raiders.

title: Ueberroth Bid Likely For Eastern
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the departing commissioner of baseball, is expected to make a $512 million offer tomorrow for Eastern Airlines. If he does, the board of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Eastern, is expected to be receptive.

title: NBC Wins Ratings Race
description: NBC narrowly won its 40th consecutive prime-time ratings race last week, tying a television-industry record set by CBS in the 1962-63 season. NBC had an average rating of 14.9, with 25 percent of the viewing audience, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company. Each rating point represents 904,000 homes with televisions.

title: CONTRAS' LEADERS URGED TO RETURN HOME FOR ELECTION
description: The Bush Administration has decided to encourage contra leaders based in Miami to return to Nicaragua and take part in next year's elections to test the openness of the Sandinista Government, an Administration official said today.

title: U.S. Agency Data Stolen
description: A computer system at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board was vandalized Monday night, and computer disks containing information on insolvent savings and loan associations were stolen, agency officials said today.

title: Jews Served in Pre-World War II Polish Military; United by Blood
description: To the Editor:

title: Malcolm Cowley, Writer, Is Dead at 90
description: Malcolm Cowley, a literary critic, historian, editor, poet and essayist who was best known for being the most trenchant chronicler of the so-called Lost Generation of post-World War I writers, died of a heart attack Monday.

title: New-Music Festival Celebrating 10 Years
description: New Music America, an important annual festival of avant-garde music that was founded in 1979, will celebrate its 10th anniversary this fall as part of the Next Wave festival presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The schedule for the series, which runs from Nov. 10 to Nov. 18, was announced at a press conference yesterday at the Kitchen. It includes 69 performances by more than 100 ensembles that work in the experimental fringes of the classical, jazz and rock traditions.

title: Substitute Teacher Charged in Holdups
description: A 31-year-old substitute public-school teacher in the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged with two separate robberies at knifepoint of residents of his own apartment building.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Meese Testifies That Impeachment Was a Worry
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials worried privately in 1986 that Ronald Reagan could be impeached if they failed to repair the political damage caused by the diversion of Iran arms sales profits to the Nicaraguan rebels, former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified today.

title: Nodaway Valley reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Fiscal 1989 included non-recurring expenses of $400,000 related to efficiency studies.

title: Holly Farms Board Supports Conagra
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said its board had unanimously reaffirmed its recommendation that stockholders approve its merger agreement with Conagra Inc. The board also reaffirmed its rejection of an amended offer from Tyson Foods Inc. of $63.50 a share and its recommendation that stockholders not tender their shares under the offer, the company said.

title: Majority of Private Trade Schools Are a Success; Incorrect Calculations
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Fund-Raising as Usual for Mr. Stein
description: Most top New York City politicians are adjusting their fund-raising practices to meet lowered contribution limits in the city's new public campaign financing law. But for Andrew Stein, the City Council president, it is fund-raising more or less as usual.

title: Pei Pyramid and New Louvre Open Today
description: Not since Gustave Eiffel made the first climb to the top of his tower 100 years ago has the inauguration of a structure in Paris been as eagerly awaited as the opening of I. M. Pei's glass pyramid in the middle of the courtyard of the Louvre.

title: Majority of Private Trade Schools Are a Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Fruehauf Sale Of Operations
description: The Fruehauf Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement to sell its troubled trailer-truck and marine services operations to the Terex Corporation for about $232.5 million. Most of the assets are in

title: Chip Maker to Shut Connecticut Plant
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, striving to cut its losses, said it will close a chip-making plant in Danbury, Conn., next February. The company said the closing was intended to reduce its excess manufacturing capacity, ''particularly in older products and processes.'' The plant, which employs about 400 people, makes transistors and other microelectronic products. Some employees will be offered transfers and others will receive severance pay and job counseling, the company said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Image Drive For Overseas Hilton Unit
description: LESS than two weeks old, Earle Palmer Brown/New York can already claim its first account - Conrad International. The overseas division of the Hilton Hotels Corporation intends to take advantage of the new relationship by starting its first-ever corporate image campaign.

title: Eastgroup Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses on investments of $1,289,000 for the quarter and gains on investments of $5,034,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included gains on investments of $7,000 and $1,557,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said through Sept. 30, 1988, the trust recorded $1,901,000 of unrealized losses on its investment in First Continental Real Estate Investment Trust, which were carried as adjustments to shareholders' equity. As a result of the recent restructuring of First Continental's bank debt, the trust now believes that a portion of the unrealized losses represents a permanent impairment in the value of this investment and, based on management's estimate, has recorded a loss of $1,299,000 in net income for the fourth quarter of 1988. Inasmuch as this loss had already been provided for in the trust's balance sheet, recording the loss in income had no effect on shareholder's equity. The balance of the decline, $602,000, continues to be carried as an unrealized loss in the trust's balance sheet. Year-ago quarter and year results ended Nov. 30, 1987.

title: United Illuminating Co reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-Included charges of $32,965,375 for the latest 12 months and $86,575,891 for the year-ago period, both from accounting changes.

title: AIR FORCE GROUNDS B-1'S AFTER A WING PUNCTURES A TANK
description: The Air Force grounded the entire fleet of B-1 bombers after the movable wing on one of the $280 million aircraft swung too far forward in a preflight check and punctured a fuel tank, the Pentagon said today.

title: Ingersoll Paper to Challenge Post-Dispatch in St. Louis
description: Ralph Ingersoll 2d, chairman and chief executive of the Ingersoll Publications Company, announced yesterday that it would introduce a daily newspaper in September to compete with The St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

title: Central Bank Intervention Fails to Halt Dollar's Rise
description: The dollar rose yesterday against most currencies, despite a concerted round of dollar selling by the Federal Reserve and eight European central banks.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Colorado Housing and Finance Authority is tentatively offering $28.8 million of tax-exempt single-family program senior bonds with a top yield of 8.25 percent through Goldman, Sachs. Yields for shorter maturities range from 7.20 percent in 1991 to 7.60 percent in 1999 and for longer maturities from 7.90 percent in 2009 to 8 percent in 2017, all subject to the alternative minimum tax for certain investors. Underwriters expect the financing to be rated AA by S.&P. * Integra-A Hotel and Restaurant Co. refinanced its $2 million December loan from Hallwood Group and obtained an additional $3.4 million line of credit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; No Ocean Spray Worry: Its Spokesman Is a Star
description: Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. has the Grammy Awards and President Bush to thank for the tremendous marquee value of its new spokesman. Bobby McFerrin, the singer who won four Grammys and dominated the awards ceremony last month, was signed nine months ago to appear in two broadcast spots for Ocean Spray cranberry beverages. That was before ''Don't Worry, Be Happy,'' an offbeat ode to blithe spirits, lifted Mr. McFerrin to fame. It was also before Mr. Bush took a liking to the song's breezy message and used it in his Presidential campaign.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Anthony Riolo, 46, An Arts Administrator
description: Anthony Riolo, an administrator for several arts organizations including the Joffrey Ballet and the New York City Ballet, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at the University of New Mexico Hospital in Albuquerque. He was 46 years old. Mr. Riolo, who was also a lawyer, was the executive director of the Santa Fe Opera at the time of his death. From 1977 to 1979, he was the director of finance and development for the Joffrey Ballet. He was the director of development for the New York City Ballet from 1979 to 1984, when he joined the Sante Fe Opera. Mr. Riolo was the resident counsel at the Ford Foundation from 1973 to 1977, and associate counsel at the law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates from 1968 to 1973. He was also a consultant to the National Arts Stabilization Fund.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the indictment of Hisashi Shinto, former chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, misstated the size of the bribe he is accused of having received. It was $175,000, not $175 million.

title: Russian-Bread Lines in U.S.? Import Deal Makes It Possible
description: SOME people may find the thought of Americans standing in long lines to buy Russian bread the stuff of Cold War nightmares. But a group of Soviet and American business executives are hoping such lines will form, signaling a new era of peace and profits.

title: Food Notes
description: Pasta, Fast

title: Fishermen Fear Spill Will Hurt Into the 90's
description: The huge oil spill that has fouled Prince William Sound could decimate fish runs in one of the world's most bountiful bodies of water well into the next decade, biologists and fishermen say.

title: A Martyr to the Drug War
description: The Miami police did not permit Lee Arthur Lawrence's murder last week. But they did little to prevent it. As a result, Miami's citizens are a bit more cynical about law enforcement. And drug dealers are feeling a bit more confident.

title: Lawyer Tries to Force Mcorp's Liquidation>
description: If I. Walton Bader has his way, Mcorp will be liquidated and its bondholders paid off.

title: 60-MINUTE GORUMET
description: SOFT-SHELL crabs are a delightful harbinger of spring around my house. They are in season in the Northeast from now through mid-May, the period in which blue crabs shed their hard carapaces, puff up as they enter a period of fast growth and begin forming new shells. Frozen, cleaned soft-shell crabs are available year-round, but I find them unacceptably bland and dry.

title: United Canadian Shares Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the sale of land. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hispanic Groups Fault Ward's Latest Remarks
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, came under new fire from Hispanic leaders yesterday for what they asserted was a fresh display of insensitivity.

title: The More Things Change
description: To The Living Section:

title: Machine Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 5
description: b-After tax credits of $42,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $16,000 and $30,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: 20 Retarded Children Shunted To Squalid Foster-Care Home
description: Twenty severely retarded children, neglected by their parents and placed in the New York City foster-care system, have been languishing in a squalid group home where they have received little or no treatment, city employees, union officials and Legal Aid lawyers say.

title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'
description: They take team sports seriously at the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity house on State Street, in the heart of the University of Michigan campus.

title: Arsenal of Lasers vs. an Angry, Oily Sea
description: In a fight against time and an angry sea, experts from the Exxon Corporation have brought high-powered lasers and a battery of other pollution-fighting devices to bear against the catastrophic oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound.

title: Sherwood Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,580,491 from the early extinguishment of debt. The year-ago 9 months' loss from operations included proceeds of $5,851,643 from a Key-Man life insurance policy. The company said the operating results for latest third quarter and 9 months reflected the discontinuation of retail operations in May 1988.

title: Soviets to Put a Japanese in Space
description: A Japanese television network said today that it had signed a contract with the Soviet Union to send a reporter to the Mir space station, the first journalist to report from space.

title: Safeway Stores Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss Safeway said its results for both 1988 and 1987 included gains on sales of stores and support facilities in connection with an asset divestiture program concluded last August. It said its 1987 results also included a $409.4 million charge related to a change in accounting for income taxes. Sales represented total sales.

title: Knicks Rally to Clinch A Spot in the Playoffs
description: Kiki Vandeweghe did a lot last night. So did Patrick Ewing and the Knicks' pressure defense. But Mark Jackson did the most.

title: Bechtel Names New President
description: Bechtel Group Inc. said today that Riley P. Bechtel had been elected president and chief operating officer, becoming the fourth generation of his family to become president of the 90-year-old engineering and construction concern.

title: Review/Music; Double Edge: A Piano Duo With a Double Gimmick
description: Double Edge, which played a most appealing concert Monday night at Town Hall, is a two-piano team with a double gimmick. One is the duo's name, which has a catchier, less cliched ring than most such sobriquets. The other is the two musicians' choice of repertory.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 Washington will prod Contra leaders in Miami to return to Nicaragua and take part in next year's elections to test the Sandinista Government, a U.S. official said. Page A1

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene was the Biograph Theater on 57th Street and Broadway where Paramount's 1939 version of ''Beau Geste'' was the feature attraction. Among those on the screen: Gary Cooper, Ray Milland, Robert Preston, Susan Hayward. Among those in the audience: Erin E. Marshall of Manhattan and an unknown man who would turn out to be the true star of the evening.

title: Compumat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Injury to Starling May Affect His Future on HBO
description: Marlon Starling's shoulder injury, which has caused the postponement of his April 15 welterweight title bout with Mark Breland, has Home Box Office scrambling to realign its boxing calendar.

title: In Hallowed Kitchens, Chefs Redefine the Sauce
description: IT is the soul of the kitchen, the arena in which chefs were taught to make their mark. Indeed it is the very thing that often defines what a restaurant or chef is all about.

title: Beijing Journal; Democracy's Martyr, Unsung by the Democracies
description: Somewhere in China, a befuddled and sickly man will presumably spend Wednesday alone in his prison cell, the way he has passed most of the previous 3,653 days: the broken, toothless remnant of a dreamer who took on the state -and lost.

title: Japan Official Unable to Be At Group of 7
description: Japan's Finance Minister, Tatsuo Murayama, will not attend the meetings this weekend of the finance ministers of the United States and its major allies, casting doubts on what might be accomplished.

title: Soviet Documentaries That Face Up to Reality
description: The camera seems perhaps two feet away from Valery Dolgov's face, a partner in an intimate conversation with a small-time hoodlum groping to find his humanity on the eve of his execution.

title: Reginald Sutton, 90, A Railroad Executive
description: Reginald Miller Sutton, who in 60 years with the Union Pacific Railroad rose from office boy to executive vice president, died of heart failure Monday at Bishop Clarkson Memorial Hospital in Omaha. He was 90 years old and lived in Omaha.

title: Soviet Press's Telling Silence Reveals Chagrin Over the Vote
description: Chagrin appeared today to have become a part of glasnost, as newspapers and television reports around the country were subdued and evasive in describing resounding losses by Communist Party leaders and victories by independent candidates in the elections for a new national congress on Sunday.

title: Evangelist in Child Prostitution Ring Gets 20 Years
description: A Federal district judge has imposed a 20-year prison sentence on an evangelist who admitted guilt in a child prostitution ring, calling him and his two partners in the case ''bad to the core.''

title: Fast Growth in Malaysia
description: Malaysia's economy grew 8.1 percent in 1988, the most in nine years, but the Government is worried about rising inflation and unemployment, the nation's central bank said today. The gross domestic product is expected to grow 7.3 percent more this year.

title: After Rumors, NWA Cites Buyout Approach
description: After more than a month of persistent takeover rumors, NWA Inc., the owner of Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that a shareholder group with 4.9 percent of its stock had approached the company about a possible buyout.

title: Next Hurdle for Cleaner Cars: Find a Fuel Besides Gasoline
description: Almost two decades after the Federal Government forced auto makers to begin reducing car exhaust emissions, scientists and Government regulators say that further reductions will be difficult as long as cars run on gasoline.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday reversed the identities of two Illinois basketball players. Kenny Battle is No. 33 and Nick Anderson No. 25.

title: Wardrobes Tailored By Social Concerns
description: BARBARA RODMAN stopped wearing her full-length mink coat last winter. The animal-rights advocates had finally gotten to her, and soon she began to feel good about her new-found social consciousness. Then she was maligned by an animal lover for sporting a coat, pants and boots in black leather. After all, where did she think leather came from, she was asked.

title: Improving a Computer Network's Efficiency
description: As computer networks become more complex, users who want time on another computer in the network to perform a specialized task often discover that several people are ahead of them. These traffic jams can waste valuable computer time as well as burden users with bothersome coordination chores.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in the Word and Image pages on March 21 about the writer Janet Malcolm and her recent essays in The New Yorker on reportorial ethics referred imprecisely to her position in a lawsuit against her. The suit alleged that she libeled Jeffrey Masson in a profile of him in The New Yorker, later published as a book. While she acknowledged having assembled statements from several conversations into single quotations, Miss Malcolm says this was not an admission of fabrication. The Times article also misstated the form of her testimony. It occurred in pretrial depositions, not during a trial. (The suit was dismissed before trial, without a determination on the issue of fabrication. The dismissal is being appealed.)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Neill Myers was named executive vice president of Lintas: New York.

title: Morgan Hydrocarbons reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Article 686789 -- No Title
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they had broken the largest counterfeit operation in United States Secret Service history -a ring that had printed $100 million in fake currency.

title: Sutter's Hopes Are Dim
description: Bruce Sutter admitted yesterday his chances of ever pitching again were remote because of a severely torn rotator cuff, but the former relief star is not ready to announce his retirement.

title: Tokyo Stocks Rise Again After Soaring on Tuesday
description: Share prices moved sharply higher again today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after they posted the year's largest single-day point gain on Tuesday.

title: It's Not Us, Toms River Says of Protrayal in Book
description: To Joe McGinniss, whose best-selling book ''Blind Faith'' is set in this onetime resort town, now booming exurb, Toms River symbolizes something akin to the collapse of Western civilization.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Included a $90,000 gain from an accounting change for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Henry Mannix Jr., Surgeon, 61
description: Dr. Henry Mannix Jr., the acting director of surgery at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford, died of cancer there Sunday. He was 61 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Good Intentions
description: To The Living Section:

title: Investigator Says He Is Not Close to Completing Rose Inquiry
description: The Pete Rose investigation will take ''at least several more weeks,'' the lawyer heading the inquiry said yesterday.

title: U.S. Tells Milken's Lawyers That He'll Be Indicted Today
description: The Government has informed lawyers for Michael R. Milken, the head of the ''junk bond'' unit of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., that Mr. Milken will be indicted today on charges of racketeering, securities fraud, mail fraud and other illegal activities, people involved in the case said last night.

title: MCM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $69,000 for the quarter and $110,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $1,227,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $5,822,000 for the year; quarter also included a tax credit of $34,000. The latest fourth quarter and year also included charges for discontinued property and casualty programs of about $4.9 million for the quarter and about $9 million for the year; quarter also included a $3.5 million gain in connection with a pension- plan termination. The 1987 year included charges for discontinued property and casualty programs of about $21 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Gorbachev opened a volcano, and I don't think he realized the lava was so deep.'' - Andrei N. Alekseyev, a Leningrad sociologist. [ A10:6. ]

title: Soviet Actress Talks About Sex and Symbolism
description: For Natalya Negoda, the first Soviet sex goddess, life isn't always a giddy whirl of beluga and black sable.

title: Fond Memories of Draper
description: To The Home Section:

title: A Panel Presses To Reopen Case In Black's Death
description: The State Commission of Investigation said today that a special prosecutor should be appointed to reopen the case of a black man who died in Wallkill in December 1986 after a struggle with two white off-duty police officers.

title: Abbott to Join Rotation
description: Jim Abbott, who was born without a right hand, was officially named the Angels' fifth starter, Doug Rader, the California manager, said yesterday. Abbott will probably make his first big league start April 8 against the Seattle Mariners at Anaheim Stadium.(AP)

title: An L.A. Bungalow: Heavy Metal
description: ''THIS is not the Aaron Spelling residence,'' said Sheila Klein as she described the window grates of her house, which appear to have been designed by drunken spiders. Unlike the television producer's mammoth palace in Beverly Hills, Ms. Klein's house was a typical stucco Los Angeles bungalow before she and her husband, Ries Niemi, a metal artist, got hold of it.

title: Review/Ballet; Patrelle Troupe Abandons Simplicity
description: There is nothing necessarily wrong with largeness and glitz. But somewhere along the way, Francis Patrelle left behind the simplicity and commitment of some of his earlier dances. Or so it seemed Tuesday evening, when Dances Patrelle began a weeklong engagement at Florence Gould Hall (55 East 59th Street) with a program of dances that appeared for the most part to have been created for the patrons present in nicely enthusiastic force at this gala opening.

title: British Trade Gap Widens
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened unexpectedly to $3.73 billion in February as exports fell faster than imports, the Government reported today. Most economists had expected the deficit to narrow slightly.

title: Richard H. Ellis, 69; Was SAC Commander
description: Richard H. Ellis, a retired Air Force general who served as commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command, died of cancer Tuesday at Malcolm Grove Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Cellular Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges from the early extinguishment of debt of $808,000 for the latest year and $2,146,000 for 1987.

title: William D. Cox, 79, Team Owner Who Was Banned From Baseball
description: William Drought Cox, a former owner of the Philadelphia Phillies who was banned from baseball after he admitted betting on his team in 1943, died Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Campaign Matters; In New Jersey, Silent Candidate Leads the Pack
description: The political season is coming into full flower in New Jersey, and nine candidates for governor are running with positions on almost everything. But the man considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, Representative James J. Florio, has remained largely out of sight.

title: Review/Television; Comeback for Wimps in New Series
description: ''Men are but children of a larger growth.''

title: What Speaking the Language Tells the Japanese; Few Know English
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Gregg Dearth, Terry Rooke, Joseph P. Schroeder and Jack V. Walz have been elected to the board of directors of BBDO Atlanta.

title: Home Improvement
description: A DESK or floor lamp that does not work can be dangerous as well as annoying. If a lamp flickers, will not light, requires delicate positioning to operate, has a frayed cord or frequently burns out bulbs, it should be repaired immediately or not used.

title: Calton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said it realized $4,000,000 in revenue from the sale of land in the first quarter of 1988. There were no land sales in the latest quarter.

title: Secession Bill Gains in Senate
description: Residents of Staten Island, facing a loss of influence in citywide governmental matters, would be asked on their November election ballots if they want to secede from New York City under legislation approved today by the State Senate Committee on Local Government.

title: Selling Milk, Bread and Cocaine in New York
description: As law-enforcement authorities in New York City exert more pressure on drug sales, they are discovering an increasing number of dealers operating out of restaurants, grocery stores, automobile parts shops and other seemingly legitimate businesses.

title: Panel Asks Raise for U.S. Judges and Officials
description: Even though a similar proposal failed in Congress last month, the Commission on the Public Service today recommended a 50 percent increase in pay for top Government officials.

title: New Jersey Denies Casino License To Admitted Compulsive Gambler
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission refused today to grant a casino employee license to an admitted compulsive gambler, but it emphasized that compulsive gamblers were not barred from working in the industry.

title: Polaroid Suit Delay
description: A Federal judge has postponed until May 1 a trial to determine the damages that the Eastman Kodak Company is liable for after infringing instant-photography patents of the Polaroid Corporation, a Polaroid spokeswoman, Marcia Phillips, said. Polaroid is seeking $5.7 billion in damages; Kodak lawyers have said that $200 million would be ''more than ample.'' The trial had been scheduled for April 17 in Federal District Court in Boston.

title: Overly Secret Weapon Against Tooth Decay: Plastic Sealant
description: Government and private dental health experts are beginning a new push to tell parents about effective but underused plastic sealants that can protect children's teeth against decay.

title: Utensils, Hardware and Lumber by Mail
description: For putterers as well as devotees of design, three new catalogues offer impressive collections of mail-order products for the home.

title: Cancer Study Backs Less Radical Operation
description: Women with an early stage of breast cancer live just as long if they have just the cancerous lump removed as they live if they have their entire breast removed, a new study confirms.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary March 22 about Helen H. Beebe of Easton, Pa., a teacher of the deaf, gave her maiden name incorrectly. It was Hulick, not Halik.

title: Policy
description: For a can-do guy like George Bush, it must have seemed a good idea at the time. Following an Administration whose principal weapon in the war on drugs was an appeal to children to ''just say no,'' Mr. Bush clearly wanted a more aggressive approach.

title: New Burdens for Nicaragua's Civilian Opposition
description: Thrust into prominence by a new accord committing the Sandinista Government to free elections and political pluralism, opposition leaders in Nicaragua have found themselves with unaccustomed power and responsibility in shaping the country's political future.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Official Named By the Four A's
description: O. Burtch Drake, a seasoned manager with international experience, was named executive vice president and chief operating officer of the American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday. Mr. Drake was most recently president of the European branch of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications. While Mr. Drake said his

title: What Speaking the Language Tells the Japanese; It's All in the Nuance
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just Cactus Grows in Drought
description: SINCE the middle of winter, most of my gardening friends in many parts of the East have been worrying about another year of drought ahead - really just a continuation of the one last year, with enough rain in the interim to foster the illusion that we were back to normal.

title: Japan to Let Contract On Disputed Jet Project
description: The Japan Defense Agency said today that it would sign an $86 million contract on Thursday with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the prime developer of the FSX fighter, even though Japan has not reached a formal agreement about the aircraft with the United States.

title: Honoring The Past: Renewed Zeal
description: MEMORIALS are made of this: Duke Ellington seated at his piano, elevated by eight maidens 28 feet above Central Park; a tilted mirror incised with the names of 14 deceased astronauts; Jack Kerouac's description of his hometown carved into slabs in a park in Lowell, Mass., and Joe Louis's outstretched arm and fist at an intersection in Detroit.

title: Precise, Subtle Ceramics From Denmark
description: Of all Scandinavian craft works, those by Danish artisans are the most easily identifiable, the most precise, the most symmetrical, the most likely to exploit geometric design, the quietest in color and generally the most subtle.

title: Books of The Times; Steinbeck's 'Grapes,' With His Diary of Writing It
description: The Grapes of Wrath By John Steinbeck Introduction by Studs Terkel. 619 pages. Viking. $25. Working Days The Journals of The Grapes of Wrath 1938-1941 By John Steinbeck Edited by Robert DeMott. Illustrated. 180 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Close to Home
description: NEARLY 14 years ago my younger daughter brought home a kitten to join the two cats and the dog already in residence. After an hour or so with the dictionary, and particular attention to all words beginning with c-a-l, she named her Calypso.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Calendar of Events: Caring for City Trees
description: Tree Care Corps, New York City Tree Consortium, 16 West 61st Street; 212-830-7992.

title: Newark Suit Would Keep High-Rises
description: Plans to continue the dynamiting of this city's battered high-rise public housing were challenged in Federal court today in a lawsuit by community groups and housing advocates, who argue that the apartments should be saved no matter how unlivable they might be.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Monday about the Century Communications Corporation misidentified the parties who agreed to sell the company 900,000 series A common shares of the Citizens Utilities Company for $48 million. They were Richard L. Rosenthal Sr., Citizens' chairman and former chief executive, and other individuals.

title: Ford Offers Rate Cuts And Rebates
description: Fearing that high interest rates are cutting into auto sales, the Ford Motor Company announced a variety of rebates and discount financing plans today, including some on its most popular models.

title: Private Rocket Industry In Giant Step Skyward
description: In a foretaste of bigger things to come, the nation's first private rocket big enough to require a Government license roared into space yesterday on a successful suborbital flight lasting about 15 minutes.

title: Volcker Hails Fed Moves
description: The former chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, today called inflation ''a perpetual concern'' and praised recent actions by the nation's central bank to nudge up interest rates to combat rising prices.

title: Federal Appeals Court Halts An Execution in Washington
description: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco issued a stay of execution late Tuesday for Charles Rodman Campbell, 33 hours before he was to die for killing two women and a girl.

title: Chinese Official Rules Out an Amnesty for Political Prisoners
description: A top Chinese official appeared today to rule out the possibility of an amnesty for political prisoners this year, and human rights advocates from Hong Kong said customs officals had seized a petition supporting the amnesty signed by 24,000 people from 30 countries.

title: Charge Dismissed in Boston Officer's Slaying
description: A judge today refused to reinstate a murder charge against a man accused of killing a police officer in a drug arrest gone awry.

title: A Yachting Pox on Both Spinnakers
description: The story is almost as old as the America's Cup itself. When the schooner America was about to cross the finish line far ahead of 14 boats from the Royal Yacht Squadron in the 1851 race around the Isle of Wight, Queen Victoria turned to the captain of her royal yacht. ''Who won?'' the Queen asked. ''The American yacht, your majesty.'' ''And who is second?'' Peering through his telescope toward the horizon behind America, the captain said, ''There is no second, your majesty.'' Now there is no first. Also, no class. In a 14-page decision, a New York State Supreme Court justice, Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick, has ruled that for sailing a catamaran, the San Diego Yacht Club must forfeit the cup it had retained against the giant monohull, New Zealand, in last September's two-race sweep off the southern California coast. Pending a possible court appeal, New Zealand now owns the old silver mug it has yet to earn.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $902,000 from an accounting change.

title: Magnet Buyout Bid Of $1.07 Billion
description: In what would be Britain's largest management-led buyout ever, directors of Magnet P.L.C. have offered to purchase the company, a maker and retailer of home improvement products, for a total of $:630.4 million, or $1.07 billion, in cash.

title: TEST DATA DIFFER ON RIPENING AGENT
description: Tests of apple juice taken from store shelves showed that three-quarters of the samples contained residues of Alar, a chemical ripening agent that has been linked to cancer, Consumers Union said today.

title: Dow Advances 5.98 for Third Straight Gain
description: Stock prices rose for the third day in a row, as the Dow Jones industrial average added 5.98 points, to 2,281.52.

title: Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of about $350,000 related to inventory adjustments and other expenses for both the quarter and year, and the quarter also included after-tax proceeds of $150,000 generated from the closing of two of the company's stores.

title: No Time for the Old Pentagon Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Reactor to Be Restarted
description: A research reactor at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, shut down in November 1986, can be restarted, the Energy Department announced Tuesday. It had been found to be suffering from embrittlement of the reactor pressure vessel. Since then, more than 20 studies of the reactor have been undertaken to determine its safety. The reactor is expected to be restarted within five weeks.

title: Movie Patrons' Credit Cards
description: The American Express Company and the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, the Canadian movie-theater chain, said yesterday that they had reached an agreement to let people use American Express credit cards for movie admissions.

title: Metro Datelines; Salmonella Outbreak Is Linked to a Death
description: An elderly woman died and three other residents of a nursing home here were hospitalized during an outbreak of salmonella poisoning earlier this month, the state Public Health Department said today.

title: Polls Say Kohl Is in Political Trouble
description: It is Chancellor Helmut Kohl's custom to use the Easter break to pare down his considerable weight at an Austrian spa. The big question that awaits his return at week's end, however, is not whether he has trimmed his girth, but whether he can stanch a precipitous loss of political support.

title: 17 Closings Set By Crazy Eddie
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the financially troubled electronic products retailer, said yesterday that it was closing 17 stores and consolidating operations around its 26 most competitive stores.

title: Q&A
description: Creaky Bed Frames Q. I have twin beds (maple) with headboards, footboards and three slats that go across the frames to support the spring and mattress. I cleaned and polished the headboards, footboards and frames, including the wood slats. Since then both beds creak when you turn over in bed. I readjusted the slats, but nothing helps. Can you suggest a cure? A. I doubt that the creaking has anything to do with the slats. It is usually caused when parts of the frame loosen and rub against each other as the bed moves. Often, the headboard or footboard moves against the sides because the bolts are a little loose.

title: Seijiro Matsuoka, 95, Art Museum Founder
description: Seijiro Matsuoka, a real-estate entrepreneur and art collector, died of heart failure on March 20 in Toranomon Hospital in Tokyo. He was 95 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: Bush Rejects Tax Break For Private School Cost
description: President Bush, in a break from the policies of the Reagan Administration, said today that he opposed granting tuition tax credits to parents who send their children to private schools.

title: St. John's Beats St. Louis for Fifth N.I.T. Title
description: When it was over, Matt Brust and Billy Singleton grabbed their coach, Lou Carnesecca, and lifted him onto their shoulders. Jayson Williams, who was named the most valuable player of the 1989 National Invitation Tournament, smiled and held his trophy aloft for everyone to see. And happy St. John's fans ringed the court at Madison Square Garden, celebrating with a young team that had grown up before their eyes.

title: Poles Meet on Reform Plan
description: Lech Walesa and other Solidarity leaders met Poland's Interior Minister today to try to remove the last obstacles to a deal on economic, political and social reforms. ''We want to resolve unsolved issues,'' Mr. Walesa told reporters, but he declined to give details. The Government has agreed in seven weeks of talks to legalize Solidarity after a seven-year ban, create a state president and a democratically elected senate, and liberalize parliamentary elections.

title: It's More Than Losing a Trophy
description: At the boat yards, the sail lofts and the yacht clubs along Anchorage Lane, there was predictable grumbling today about Michael Fay, the banker from New Zealand whose Mercury Bay Boating Club was awarded the America's Cup by forfeit Tuesday by a New York judge.

title: Mobs, Delight and a President for Guide As the Louvre Pyramid Opens to the Public
description: President Francois Mitterrand loves to saunter around Paris. So this afternoon he took a walk around - and under -I. M. Pei's soaring glass-and-steel pyramid in the courtyard of the Louvre.

title: The I.R.S. in Shackles
description: The Internal Revenue Service suffers a budget squeeze at its peak season. Pained taxpayers may like the thought of pained tax collectors, but a crippled I.R.S. is no reason to cheer.

title: Oracle Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DMI Furniture Inc reports earnings for 14wk to March 4
description: The year-ago quarter and 6 months comprises 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively.

title: Gambling Link Denied
description: A Nevada-Las Vegas basketball player said he accepted $20 from his summer league coach to pay for lunch, unaware that the man was a convicted East Coast gambler.

title: From Budget to Land Use: The Powers of the Board of Estimate
description: Any restructuring of New York City's government will begin with the Board of Estimate, because the United States Supreme Court has ruled that its voting system is unconstitutional and because the board is at the center of civic life.

title: Topics of The Times; The Prism of Paris
description: This April in Paris, there will be fresh excitement in the air with the opening of I. M. Pei's high-tech glass pyramid in the courtyard of the venerable Louvre. The latest of President Francois Mitterrand's ambitious ''Grands Projets,'' the monument has been a subject of controversy since plans for its construction were announced five years ago.

title: Queens Man Arrested In Bomb 'Gift' to Gotti
description: A Queens man wanted for placing a crude bomb outside a social club in Little Italy as a ''gift for John Gotti,'' was arrested yesterday in Polk County, Tenn., the New York City police said.

title: U.S. ASKS SOVIETS TO AID LATIN PEACE ON GORBACHEV TRIP
description: The Bush Administration is urging Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to use a visit to Cuba next week to signal some willingness either to cut Soviet assistance to Nicaragua or to condition future aid on steps by Managua to make democratic reforms, an Administration official said today.

title: Real-Life Politics in Deep South
description: Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi says people have to get used to him.

title: U.S. Takes Over 20 Texas Banks; High Costs Seen
description: Moving to halt heavy withdrawals that could have threatened the stability of the Texas banking system, Federal regulators have taken over 20 insolvent banks owned by Mcorp of Dallas, the second-largest banking concern in Texas.

title: A Silent Spring, for Kids
description: Hell hath no fury like a pesticide scorned, as Rachel Carson discovered when she published ''Silent Spring'' more than a quarter century ago. She was hysterically attacked at the time by the chemical industry as ill-informed, emotional, sensational and altogether off the wall. But none of that made Rachel Carson's conclusions any less valid.

title: Bid to Buy and Revive Eastern Is Awaited
description: The directors of the Texas Air Corporation are expected to receive a plan today in which Eastern Airlines would be sold and all parties would join in an urgent effort to get most of Eastern's planes back in the air within the next 10 days, sources involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Subways Later But Cleaner, Group Asserts
description: New York City's subway trains are cleaner, more comfortable and breaking down less frequently, thanks to new cars and other equipment, a riders' advocacy group said yesterday. But despite the improvements, trains are running later, delays are increasing and the overall service does not justify a proposed 15-cent fare increase, the group said.

title: Glenn Sheline, Neurologist, 70
description: Dr. Glenn Sheline, a leader in the field of neuro-oncology, died of cancer last Friday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Text of Statement By Michael Milken
description: Following is the text of the statement by Michael R. Milken after his indictment on Federal charges yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: An Entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Tuesday about the United Asset Management Corporation described the company incorrectly. It is an investment management concern that serves mostly institutional clients.

title: No Headline
description: ''Rain Man,'' a drama about a car salesman who tries to trick his mentally handicapped brother out of his inheritance, won four major Oscars at the 61st annual Academy Awards tonight - best picture, actor, director and original screenplay. For his role as an autistic savant who can memorize telephone books and count the cards at blackjack, Mr. Hoffman walked off with his second Oscar, 10 years after the one for ''Kramer vs. Kramer.'' Barry Levinson, who was the fourth director to be offered ''Rain Man,'' won his first Oscar with his first nomination. A Role as Victim

title: Cuomo Shoreham Plan Gains As 2 Are Backed for Agency
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant moved closer to approval today as the State Senate Energy Committee endorsed the Governor's two nominees to the New York Power Authority.

title: Thriving Sex Industry in Bangkok Is Raising Fears of an AIDS Epidemic
description: Bangkok is a city where prostitution is illegal, but where hundreds of escort services, massage parlors, bathhouses, bars, clubs, teahouses, coffee shops and even barber shops serve as commonly understood fronts for the selling of sex.

title: N.H.L. Team Signs First Soviet Player, And He's a Surprise
description: The first athlete from the Soviet Union to be permitted to play for a professional team in North America signed a contract with the Calgary Flames of the National Hockey League yesterday, and is expected to play for them tomorrow night. But he is not the player many expected to have that historic role.

title: PLAN WOULD SPEED TENANT EVICTIONS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development will move quickly to assist hundreds of public housing agencies around the country that have requested streamlined procedures to evict tenants involved in drug dealing, department officials said today.

title: Stena Files Intent On Sea Containers
description: A group led by the Swedish concern Stena A.B., which controls an 8.2 percent stake in Sea Containers Ltd., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was interested in acquiring the company's ferry services and harbor operations and that it had held talks with a third party interested in buying the company's cargo container operations.

title: Marvin Tabak, 60, Painter and a Publisher
description: Marvin Tabak, the founder of The New York Almanac, died of liver cancer Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rabbi and Son Held in Beating Of Black Man
description: A Hasidic rabbi and his son, both members of a neighborhood anti-crime patrol, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with assault and fomenting a riot in connection with the beating of a black man who they believed had just slashed a Hasidic woman and her son.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRIEFS
description: * Electronic Data Systems Corp., Plano, Tex., an information services company owned by General Motors Corp., opened a network control center at its headquarters.

title: 7 Insurers Buy Stake In Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the most successful Wall Street houses, said yesterday that seven big insurance companies had invested a total of $225 million in the firm.

title: Topics of The Times; Time Is Money for City Schools
description: In failing to claim about $80 million in Federal funds, New York City's Board of Education flunks basic management.

title: Drexel Prepares Itself For Life After Milken
description: With yesterday's indictment of Michael R. Milken, Wall Street turned its attention to the future of the high-yield ''junk bond'' unit at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which under Mr. Milken's direction became one of the nation's most powerful money machines. .

title: Scientist Says He Transplanted Tissue Into Fetus
description: A French researcher has disclosed that he transplanted fetal tissue into a fetus with a genetic immune deficiency disease, in what some scientists said might be the first successful prenatal tissue graft in a human.

title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor
description: President Bush today named a prominent black lawyer in Boston as his choice for United States Attorney for Massachusetts, replacing a conservative Republican who was forced to resign after a series of politically charged issues.

title: New Post for Fogler
description: Eddie Fogler, the Wichita State basketball coach, announced yesterday that he was resigning to accept the head coaching position at Vanderbilt University.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Koppel' in Washington

title: Alfred Rollin Manville, Executive, 72
description: Alfred Rollin Manville, president and chief executive officer of the Fischbach Corporation, Manhattan electrical and mechanical contractors, died Sunday at his home in Middletown, N.J., after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Harper Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $700,000 reduction on deferred income taxes for the quarter and a $3,827,000 gain for the year both from the sale of real property in Tokyo.

title: Insurance Unit's Ex-Manager And Wife Indicted in Jersey
description: The former manager of the Joint Underwriting Association in New Jersey and his wife were indicted today on charges of conspiring to defraud the automobile insurance association.

title: Bills Decide to Match Broncos' Offer to Smith
description: The Buffalo Bills have matched the $7.5 million contract offer their star defensive end, Bruce Smith, received from the Denver Broncos, insuring that Smith will continue to play for the Bills, The Buffalo News reported yesterday. The report said the Bills sent a letter Tuesday to the Broncos to notify them that Buffalo is matching the terms of Denver's five-year offer.

title: The Expensive Oscar-Nomination Manipulations
description: If Academy Awards are the rubies and emeralds in Hollywood's crown, then Academy Award nominations are the garnets and tourmalines. Like semi-precious stones, Oscar nominations give a definite sheen to the studio that wears them.

title: Leningrad's Communist Party, Left in Tatters, Wonders What to Do Next
description: As Leningrad's Communist Party leaders waited in smug confidence for last Sunday's elections, they were given a poll by sociologists at the Soviet Academy of Sciences showing the city's party chief trailing an upstart 28-year-old engineer by 60 percentage points.

title: Centel Selling 2 Cable Groups
description: The Centel Corporation said today that it and its Centel Cable Television Company subsidiary had reached definitive agreements to sell two more cable television operations, in Kentucky and Florida. Terms were not disclosed. These agreements are part of a plan announced last week to sell Centel Cable's properties in six groups. Last week the companies reported agreements to sell the four other groups. Proceeds from the six sales, the companies estimated, will exceed $1.4 billion. Under today's agreement, Simmons Communications of Stamford, Conn., will acquire Centel Cable's Kentucky operations, which serve 60,000 subscribers. The Adelphia Communications Corporation will acquire Centel Cable's southeast Florida operations, which serve 125,000 subscribers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday headed ''Carville Journal,'' about a Louisiana center for treating victims of leprosy, misstated the reason armadillos are used in research on the disease. They carry the bacteria that causes it.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INSIDE
description: When Soviet Voters Say No Shock and jubilation spread through Leningrad with news that the voters had repudiated the city's top five Communist officials. Page A10. Religious Liberty Extended The Constitution's protection of religious liberty extends to personal beliefs as well as formal doctrines, the Supreme Court ruled. Page A23. 'Rain Man' Wins 4 Oscars ''Rain Man,'' with Dustin Hoffman as the autistic brother of Tom Cruise, a conniving salesman, was named best film and best screenplay of 1988. Mr. Hoffman and the director, Barry Levinson, also won. Other Oscars went to Jodie Foster, Geena Davis, Kevin Kline and ''Pelle.'' Page C17.

title: HEALTH: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: For tens of thousands of Americans afflicted with inflammatory muscle diseases, simple tasks may be overwhelmingly difficult or fatiguing. Even before they know what is wrong, they may have difficulty raising an arm, climbing stairs, getting up from a chair or even raising the head from a pillow. Prolonged standing or walking can exhaust them, and even swallowing and breathing may be impaired.

title:
TALKING DEALS;
Loral's Chairman Wearing 2 Hats
description: LEAD: WHEN the Loral Corporation acquired the aerospace unit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company two years ago, Loral's chairman and chief executive officer, Bernard L. Schwartz, said he intended to sell the new unit's two nonmilitary electronics divisions.

title: LA Gear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
In Stormy Yugoslav Region, A Fragile Lull in Ethnic Strife
description: An uncertain quiet and a sullen anger settled today over this ethnic Albanian region of southern Yugoslavia, after six days of seething riots in which 2 policemen and 19 ethnic Albanians were killed.

title: Green Impatient Over Yankee Mistakes
description: On the second to last day of their spring camp in Florida, the Yankees were still working on fundamentals and still failing. The month is nearly over and the season will begin in just six days, but the mistakes of March remain on Dallas Green's mind.

title: Review/Film Festival; An Advertising Man Battles the Boil
description: In the wonderful world of London advertising, Bagley (Richard E. Grant), a handsome young man given to immaculate tailoring, has a reputation as a genius. He behaves appropriately, being overbearing to the members of his staff and completely self-assured to his superior. Then suddenly, unaccountably, he faces a block on his new campaign for a skin cream.

title: Philip Morris Note Yield Is 10.526%
description: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $300 million of 10 1/2 percent notes due 1990 at a price of 99.75 to yield 10.526 percent through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Exxon Reduced Its Staff of Oil Spill Experts
description: At least nine experts on oil spills, including Exxon Corporation's senior environmental officer, left the company in 1985 and 1986 when the work force was being reduced, a specialist in oil pollution said today.

title: 'Junk Bond' Revolution Will Outlive Its Creator
description: With his indictment on securities fraud charges, Michael R. Milken will no longer dictate the fate of companies from the helm of his ''junk bond'' empire in Beverly Hills, Calif., and he will have to leave Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the securities firm he helped build into a Wall Street powerhouse. But the financial revolution that this maverick unleashed will endure for a simple reason: high-yield, high-risk bonds have been embraced by the establishment that once shunned them.

title: Ruling Is Upheld Blocking MAI Bid
description: A United States Court of Appeals upheld a lower court injunction blocking a hostile tender offer for Prime Computer Inc. by MAI Basic Four Inc. Prime, a maker of minicomputers, has battled the takeover attempt on the ground that MAI has not fully disclosed its relationship with the Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel, which agreed to plead guilty last year to criminal charges of insider trading, is arranging financing for the $20-a-share tender offer for all 48 million shares of Prime common stock.

title: Reviews/Music; Recital by a Viola Teacher
description: Rozanna Weinberger, a violist who has taught at several music schools around New York, drew a large and demonstrative audience Monday night to her program of Hummel, Carter, Brahms, Bach and Enesco at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Company Is Fined $764,000 For Selling Bad Pacemakers
description: A Federal district judge here has approved a plea bargain between the Government and the Cordis Corporation, a Miami-based medical equipment company that has admitted selling defective heart pacemakers and corrosion-prone batteries that powered them.

title: Nathan B. Fogelson Lawyer, 86
description: Nathan B. Fogelson, a bankruptcy lawyer, died of cancer Tuesday at New York University Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mississippi Private School To Test Everyone for Drugs
description: All pupils, teachers and administrators at a private high school here will be checked for illegal drug use, officials say.

title: Talks on Farm Subsidies
description: Seeking to end an impasse in international trade talks, the United States is continuing to try to resolve differences with the European Community on the elimination of farm subsidies.

title: The Drama Started With a Sunday Call
description: Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, had just arrived home from Easter church services Sunday afternoon when the telephone rang. The caller was Gene H. Bishop, chairman of Mcorp, the second-largest banking concern in Texas, telling him that three small creditors had sought to force the ailing banking company into involuntary Chapter 7 bankruptcy.

title: Ralph W. Cutler Gallery Owner, 41
description: Ralph W. Cutler, an owner of Fifty-50, a Manhattan gallery devoted to American mid-century decorative arts, died of complications from AIDS Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and also had a home in Columbia County, N.Y.

title: Koch Responds to a Panel on Blacks
description: Responding to a commission's recommendations for assisting black New Yorkers, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced yesterday that the city was expanding the use of public schools, improving job training and increasing small-business loans.

title: South Africa to Tighten Controls on Detainees
description: The South African Government, embarrassed by a spate of political fugitives seeking refuge in foreign embassies, signaled tighter controls on fasting political detainees today.

title: Review/Music; Song Cycles in Spanish
description: The New York Camerata opened and closed its Tuesday evening performance at Weill Recital Hall with well-played renderings of standard repertory works. But the more interesting part of the program was a pair of recent song cycles composed for the group in a way that plays to the ensemble's strengths.

title: Red Wings Send Rangers to 3d Straight Loss
description: Having hit the panic button, the Rangers proceeded to make contact with almost nothing else tonight against the Red Wings. Except, perhaps, when they were tripping over themselves, colliding with each other or bumping up against the hard reality that if they continue to play like this they could finish fourth in the Patrick Division and then shortly thereafter be finished for the season.

title: Loss of a Soviet Mars Spacecraft Shakes Project to Explore Planet
description: The Soviet Union's ambitious program to explore the planet Mars suffered a damaging blow today as space officials acknowledged that they had little hope of regaining contact with the spacecraft Phobos 2.

title: Oxford Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Toshiba Corp., Tokyo, to Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, for its corporate advertising, with a budget of more than $1 million.

title: Currents; When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. The Caserta dining table, 54 inches in diameter, was designed by Leon Rosen and introduced in 1984 by the Pace Collection. B. The Circle dining table, 46 inches in diameter, was designed by Zev Vaughn and introduced in 1988 by American Statement Interior Furnishings.

title: AIR FORCE INSPECTS 25 MOST-USED B-1'S
description: The Air Force inspected the most heavily used of its grounded B-1 bombers today to determine if a mishap that caused a fuel leak in one plane was an isolated breakdown or a problem with the entire fleet, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Loan Credits to Bolivia
description: The International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and Japan have approved credits for Bolivia totaling $93.3 million, the Finance Minister, Ramiro Cabezas, said on Tuesday. Mr. Cabezas said the I.M.F. had authorized the release of $35 million, the second stage of a $180 million loan to be disbursed over three years. Japan is granting $47 million for industrial reconstruction. The 40-year loan has a grace period of 10 years, and it carries an annual interest rate of three-quarters of 1 percent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: I.R.S. Count on Returns
description: Heading into the final three weeks of the tax preparation season, more than half of Americans still had not mailed their tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
