Through last Friday, the I.R.S. had received 53.1 million returns, up slightly from 52.8 million in the same period a year ago. The I.R.S. expects that 109 million individual returns will be filed this year, with several million coming in after the April 17 deadline.

title: 'JUNK BOND' LEADER IS INDICTED BY U.S. IN CRIMINAL ACTION
description: In the largest criminal action against a Wall Street figure, a Federal grand jury today indicted Michael R. Milken, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive who transformed corporate takeovers through the pioneering use of high-yield ''junk bonds.''

title: G.O.P. Recruiter Lost Behind Enemy Lines
description: What do you do when you get a form letter from the White House thanking you for ''your desire to serve'' in the Bush Administration and asking for your resume and for the answers to just a few little questions to help process your request? Questions like your involvement in the 1988 campaign, other ''political activities in which you have been involved over the past several years,'' and so on. Well, if you are Robert S. Strauss, adviser to Presidents, manager official and unofficial to their campaigns and former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, you write a nice (mostly) letter back. Here is Mr. Strauss's reply to Chase G. Untermeyer, Assistant to the President and Director of Presidential Personnel. Dear Chase: I have your letter of March 8, copy enclosed, thanking me for my desire to serve in the Bush Administration. While I appreciate very much this highly personal letter, I wish to advise you and, through you, President Bush, as follows.

title: High Court Extends Protection of Religious Liberty
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Constitution's protection of religious liberty extends to personal religious beliefs in addition to those contained in formal religious doctrine.

title: FINAL FOUR: Seton Hall Discovers the Joy of Winning; After Wandering in Wilderness, Priates See the Promised Land
description: He rummaged through the papers on his desk in his hotel suite until he found the beige envelope.

title: Teacups With Windows And Without Bottoms
description: CAN a more than two-foot-high teacup be considered a reductio ad absurdum?

title: Standard Brands Paint Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $681,000 for the quarter and $1,135,000 for the year; the year also included an extraordinary gain of $1,145,000 from the cumulative effect of a tax change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,475,000 for the quarter and $2,315,000 for the year, and an extraordinary loss on the early extinguishment of debt of $1,041,000 for the both periods.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reduced by about $2.9 million as a result of a reserve for store closings for both the quarter and year.

title: Lebanese Exchange Shellfire; Ignore Appeal for Cease-Fire
description: Lebanese factions traded artillery fire between East and West Beirut today despite a cease-fire appeal by Arab League foreign ministers meeting in Tunis, the police said.

title: Lincoln's Notes on Slavery Among Book-Fair Gems
description: Among the rarest of the rare manuscripts and books at the New York Antiquarian Book Fair, which opens in Manhattan this afternoon, is a one-page fragment of notes against slavery made by Lincoln several years before he became President.

title: Cell Technology In China Venture
description: Cell Technology Inc., a Boulder, Colo., biotechnology company, reached an agreement in principle to form a joint venture with the Chinese Medical Academy of Science. The company said it was one of the first joint ventures between the Chinese Government and the biotechnology industry.

title: Arthur A. Charpentier, 69, Ex-Librarian
description: Arthur A. Charpentier, a retired law librarian, died of respiratory failure on March 19 at the Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor. He was 69 years old and lived in Mount Desert, Me.

title: Relaxed Rules Allowed Player to Defect
description: The 14-year-old Soviet chess player who asked for political asylum on Tuesday with his father at a New York chess tournament was able to attend because of liberalized travel rules, the tournament director said yesterday.

title: Liberal Muslim Is Killed in Brussels Mosque
description: The spiritual leader of a liberal mosque here who had asked for moderation in the Salman Rushdie affair was shot dead in his office today. An assistant was also killed.

title: Leading Indicators Down 0.3%
description: The Government's principal economic-forecasting gauge fell three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: New-Home Sales Sagged In February
description: Sales of new single-family homes slumped in February to the lowest level in more than a year, and analysts predicted further declines as rising mortgage rates push more people out of the market.

title: Oil Goes Over $20 a Barrel After a Late Trading Rally
description: A late rally sent crude oil prices back over $20 a barrel yesterday in New York.

title: Goldfarb Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Syms Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
America's Cup, Lost in a Legal Breeze
description: Yacht races are often lost in a sudden change of wind direction at sea. A wind shift in a New York City courtroom has now deprived the United States of the America's Cup.

title: Barbara Bush Links Her Weight Loss to Thyroid Condition
description: Barbara Bush disclosed today that she had lost 18 pounds in the last three months as a result of a recently diagnosed thyroid condition. Mrs. Bush said she began taking ''very simple medication'' for it two days ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Warwick Advertising will move its offices to 100 Avenue of the Americas from 875 3d Avenue.

title: Kimble Is Suspended
description: Darin Kimble, a forward for the Quebec Nordiques, was suspended for eight games yesterday by the National Hockey League as a result of a match penalty for slashing Ulf Samuelson of the Hartford Whalers in game March 23.

title: Mexico Plans Talks on Debt
description: Mexico plans to begin debt negotiations with members of its 13-bank advisory committee after the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank hold their spring meetings next week, the finance ministry said in a communique this week.

title: Unisys Expects a Loss For the First Quarter
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it expects to report a loss in the first quarter because of slower sales of its mainframe computers in the United States.

title: Farmland Next In Pension Funds?
description: PENSION funds, which used to be cautiously invested in stocks and bonds, moved into commercial real estate in substantial ways only a few years ago. Now, says Dean LeBaron, it is time for them to start buying farmland.

title: Former Guard at Nazi Camp Leaves U.S. After Agreement
description: A former Nazi SS guard at the Auschwitz concentration camp has left the United States for Austria under an agreement between the two nations, the Justice Department announced yesterday.

title: Invest School Resources in Teaching Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Longer Tour Courses Appeal to Women
description: Five years ago, when Jan Stephenson raised a big brouhaha because she thought the courses on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour were too short, she was only repeating what such leading players as JoAnne Carner had been saying for many years.

title: Alexander's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 11
description: b-Included pretax gains of $24,317,000 and $41,410,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,741,000.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Currents; Buatta, In Bits And Pieces
description: ''I'VE put together all the bits and pieces I've always liked,'' said Mario Buatta, the ebullient interior designer who has blanketed B. Altman & Company with his growing firmament of licensed wares. The latest star is a collection of Regency-inspired upholstery and case goods, including tables and a handsome bookcase secretary designed for the John Widdicomb Furniture Company.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Is Fined
description: A Phoenix Municipal Court judge fined Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers' center, $500 yesterday and ordered him to pay $840.35 restitution for injuring an Italian tourist, Fernando Nicolia, who was trying to photograph him at a shopping mall in Phoenix last year.

title: An Idle U.S. Debate About Gorbachev
description: LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev is ready to renegotiate his country's relationship with the West - in effect to negotiate an end to the cold war. Meanwhile, in the West, policy makers dither and disagree over how to respond. But we should stop worrying about how desperate Mr. Gorbachev might be or whether we can help him.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * H. F. Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, appointed Charles C. Reed executive vice president and director of marketing.

title: Managua Opposition Evolving
description: A new accord on free elections and political pluralism has given the opposition in NIcaragua unaccustomed power and responsibility. Page A14.

title: Afghans Ask U.N. to Monitor Pakistani Troop Movements
description: The Soviet Union and Afghanistan have appealed to the United Nations to place troops on the Pakistani-Afghan border to monitor what they call cross-border incursions by Pakistani forces and other violations of the Geneva accords.

title: Currents; Luxuriant Handmade Linens
description: HER grandmothers were both talented seamstresses, so Nancy Koltes's interest in fine handwork goes back to the time she was a little girl. Two years ago Ms. Koltes formed N.K.A. (telephone 212-929-8684) in New York to produce embroidered, monogrammed and intricately detailed handmade table and bed linens, prerequisites for the lavish Old World table settings and canopied beds many interior decorators favor.

title: Edwards Will Turn Pro
description: Jay Edwards, the Big Ten player of the year, told Indiana University yesterday he was passing up his final two years of eligibility to make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Ampal-American Israel Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year's net included extraordinary income of $1,275,000, or 5 cents a share. The company said net income in the latest year was reduced by $5.4 million following two devaluations of the Israeli shekel, which resulted in substantial translation losses, and a government-sponsored recovery plan for the financially troubled kibbutz sector, which led Ampal to increase significantly the allowance for loan losses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Milken Indictment

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The ITT Financial Corporation is offering $300 million, revised upward from $200 million, of 10 1/8 percent senior notes due 1999 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: Review/Music; Familiar Faces Make Debut As a Quartet
description: For its auspicious New York debut Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y, the Orion String Quartet offered a program of works by Haydn, Mendelssohn and Bartok performed with the sort of assurance one expects from far more seasoned ensembles.

title: Currents; Prizes From The Bottom Of the Box
description: DIFFERENT people mark the decades in different ways. But Alex Jaramillo's yardstick, the prizes tucked into Cracker Jack boxes since the beginning of the century, might be the most unusual around. Mr. Jaramillo, whose book ''Cracker Jack Prizes'' is to be published in June (Abbeville Press, $19.95), calls the prizes ''the ultimate collectible.''

title: Islanders Set Back Devils On Kerr's Overtime Goal
description: The Devils and the Islanders, who met in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs last season, met for the last time tonight and performed in a manner appropriate for two nonplayoff teams this season.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Rise Again
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose again yesterday, the fifth advance in six sessions.

title: Lorenzo, You're No Nelson
description: LEAD: I recently read Fortune Magazine's annual awards for the ''World's Toughest Bosses'' featuring none other than Texas Air's Frank Lorenzo. I felt compelled to ask: Tough on whom? Himself? His competition? Or only on his own people? Lord Nelson died of wounds received during the Battle of Trafalgar when he refused to leave the deck of his ship, which was sprayed by cannon and rifle shot.

title: Liberte! Egalite! Decoration!
description: WITH the opening today of an exhibit of French decorative arts since the Revolution, Francophiles, both connoisseurs and the merely curious, will be storming the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. The bicentennial of the French Revolution is being celebrated there in the ambitious and informative show, ''L'Art de Vivre: Decorative Arts and Design in France 1789-1989.''

title: Metro Datelines; Parolee Surrenders In Killing of Boy, 13
description: A paroled robber suspected of fatally stabbing a 13-year-old boy in a rampage after an argument over a basketball game turned himself in to the police yesterday, a police spokesman said.

title: A Pollution Warning From California
description: The drastic and costly air-cleansing rules mandated in Southern California this month should serve as a warning to the New York metropolitan region, where some measurements of air pollution are almost as bad and others are worse, Federal and local officials say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Sand in His Shoes
description: The ''swarming horde'' is about to hit Cuba. Yanqui media moguls, ever eager for excuses to drop network anchors in exotic waters, will provide more air coverage in their invasion than J.F.K. ever assigned to his fiasco at the Bay of Pigs.

title: Lynn Ceci, 58, Is Dead; Anthropology Teacher
description: Lynn Ceci, an anthropologist and a professor at Queens College and at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, died of liver cancer yesterday at her home in Locust Valley, L.I. She was 58 years old.

title: Ramada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,265,000 for the quarter and $3,898,000 for the year; the year also included an extraordinary credit of $563,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2,851,000. d-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $13,041,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,365,000.

title: Dollar Ends Slightly Lower After Central Banks' Sales
description: The Federal Reserve, along with central banks in Canada and eight European nations, sold dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday for the second consecutive day.

title: 3Com Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago 9 months' results included $3,433,000 of non-recurring expenses related to the company's merger with Bridge Communications Inc. in September 1987.

title: Basketball Proposal Would Allow Pros
description: The nature of basketball in the Olympics could change next week if members of the sport's international federation vote to eliminate all barriers to eligibility.

title: Kabul Journal; Voices of Urban Fear: War's End Is Worth a Deal
description: Like many people in Kabul, Safaar Mohammad came here to escape the war. After Soviet aircraft bombed his village in northern Afghanistan in 1980, he walked across the mountains to the capital and set up a stall in the old bazaar. Now, at age 60, Mr. Mohammad believes that only providence can prevent the war from engulfing him again.

title: Review/Jazz; The New Orleans in Wynton Marsalis
description: Wynton Marsalis is coming to terms with his hometown, New Orleans. The style he honed through the 1980's hails primarily from such New York City bands as Miles Davis's groups from the late 1950's through the mid-1960's, Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and to a lesser extent the John Coltrane quartet. But when he led a sextet Tuesday to open a six-night engagement at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Mr. Marsalis played pieces (including selections from his forthcoming album) steeped in older New Orleans music.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: Tactics Are Refined
description: In the months since the uprising in the occupied territories began in December 1987, Israeli soldiers have refined their techniques for pinpointing and countering protests.

title: Baseball; Sports Illustrated Clarifies Report on Rose and Signals
description: Sports Illustrated has clarified a report that Pete Rose and a friend exchanged hand signals related to baseball betting while the Reds' manager was in the Cincinnati dugout and the friend was in the stands at Riverfront Stadium. The magazine published the report, based on an unidentified source, last week.

title: Parent & Child
description: TO college-bound high school seniors, April 17 this year is a deadline that has nothing to do with taxes. Although the process started as early as last September, colleges send out most of their acceptance and rejection letters the first two weeks of April.

title: HEALTH SECRETARY TO GET SEVERANCE
description: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has reached an agreement with the Morehouse School of Medicine whereby he will receive $215,000 in severance pay.

title: Reagan Objects to Appearing as Witness for North
description: Ronald Reagan, who in 1986 called Oliver L. North a national hero, today raised legal objections to appearing as a witness in Mr. North's behalf, according to a legal paper filed by an attorney for the former President.

title: A Museum Store In the Truest Sense
description: For years, members of the Freeport Historical Society had hoped to restore the two properties donated to it in the mid-1970's: the 159-year-old Greek Revival-style Harrington House in town and Pettingill Farm, with its 179-year-old farmhouse on 100 waterfront acres about a mile northeast of Freeport.

title: U.S. Wary on Giving Social Security Numbers
description: The Social Security Administration, raising questions of privacy, has delayed a decision on a request by a credit rating company to have the agency verify 140 million Social Security numbers.

title: Early Walkers and Fullers
description: To The Home Section:

title: Depressed Parents Put Children At a Greater Risk of Depression
description: The first careful observations of normal encounters between seriously depressed parents and their children are leading researchers to conclude that the parents may treat their children in a way that will make them more susceptible to depression themselves as they grow up.

title: Metro Datelines; U.S. Judge Reverses His Secrecy Order
description: A Federal judge who drew sharp protests from news organizations earlier this month because of his broad secrecy orders in a drug-conspiracy case backed down yesterday and opened most of the proceedings to the public.

title: The Oscar Winners
description: FILM: ''Rain Man'' (United Artists). FOREIGN-LANGUAGE FILM: ''Pelle the Conqueror'' (Bille August, Denmark). DIRECTOR: Barry Levinson, for ''Rain Man.'' ACTOR: Dustin Hoffman, for ''Rain Man.'' ACTRESS: Jodie Foster, for ''The Accused.'' SUPPORTING ACTOR: Kevin Kline, for ''A Fish Named Wanda.'' SUPPORTING ACTRESS: Geena Davis, for ''The Accidental Tourist.'' ORIGINAL SCREENPLAY: Ronald Bass and Barry Morrow, for ''Rain Man.'' SCREENPLAY ADAPTATION: Christopher Hampton, for ''Dangerous Liaisons.'' CINEMATOGRAPHY: Peter Biziou, for ''Mississippi Burning.'' EDITING: Arthur Schmidt, for ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit.'' ORIGINAL SCORE: Dave Grusin, for ''The Milagro Beanfield War.'' ORIGINAL SONG: Carly Simon, for ''Let the River Run'' (''Working Girl''). ART DIRECTION: Stuart Craig, art direction, and Gerard James, set decoration, for ''Dangerous Liaisons.'' COSTUME DESIGN: James Acheson, for ''Dangerous Liaisons.'' SOUND: Les Fresholtz, Dick Alexander, Vern Poore and Willie D. Burton, for ''Bird.'' SOUND EDITING: Charles L. Campbell and Louis L. Edemann, for ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit.'' DOCUMENTARY, FEATURE: ''Hotel Terminus: The Life and Times of Klaus Barbie,'' Marcel Ophuls, producer. DOCUMENTARY, SHORT SUBJECT:

title: Mcorp Chapter 11 Filing Expected
description: With 20 of its 25 banking units seized early today by the Government, Mcorp is expected to turn to the Federal bankruptcy court to fight to keep its remaining assets.

title: Landmark Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Restoration and Repair Of Interior Brick Walls
description: ''I'VE been in places where you brush up against a brick wall and it's like an avalanche,'' George Jannes said. ''You can run your finger along a picture frame and find loose mortar and debris.''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
South Bronx Job Proves Fruitful for Terex Chief
description: LEAD: Randolph W. Lenz is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and of the Marine Corps, but he attributes his acumen to a far tougher school.

title: Washington Journal; Tourists Swarm Capital In This Violent Season
description: This week marks the start of the annual tourist migration to the nation's capital.

title: Israel, Fearing Strife, Orders New Curbs for Palestinians
description: Israeli troops imposed a curfew on Arab residents of the occupied Gaza Strip today and said Palestinians in the West Bank would be barred from Israel beginning at midnight.

title: Look at the Record Of Civil Rights Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: EXXON CONCEDES IT CAN'T CONTAIN MOST OF OIL SPILL
description: Officials of the Exxon Shipping Company acknowledged today that they had effectively lost the opportunity to control most of the 240,000 barrels of fast-spreading crude oil that spilled after the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground Friday.

title: Metro Datelines; New York Considers Releasing Inmates
description: The New York City Correction Commissioner, Richard J. Koehler, has ordered his staff to prepare a contingency plan for the early release of prisoners as one option to relieve overcrowding in the jails.

title: Jehiel R. Elyachar Is Dead at 90; A Developer and a Philanthropist
description: Jehiel R. Elyachar, an engineer, philanthropist and Manhattan real-estate developer, died of a heart attack yesterday at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Offers Its Clients Single Voices
description: OGILVY & MATHER, whose low profit margins and slow growth in domestic advertising have made it a rumored takeover target, yesterday announced a management realignment intended to enhance its ability to work for clients in communications areas other than advertising.

title: Currents; Painter's Change of Art: From Murder to Comfort
description: TEN years ago Steve Gianakos, a New York artist, created black-humored drawings titled ''How to Murder Your Pet.'' Now he has decided to make pets comfortable.

title: Litton Sued By Former Employee
description: A former employee of Litton Industries has accused the company in a lawsuit of deliberately overcharging the Pentagon from 1981 to 1988, according to unsealed court documents. The Justice Department has joined in the action, which was brought under Federal laws to encourage people to report fraud by Government contractors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP to Buy Millward
description: WPP Group P.L.C. continued on the acquisition path yesterday, signing an agreement to buy Millward Brown, a British-based marketing research company. The marketing communications conglomerate will pay Millward's stockholders $3.56 a share in a deal that values the company at $25.1 million. The deal could be worth as much as $50.6 million if shareholders opt for a alternate payment plan based on the firm's profitability in the next five years.

title: Support for Brady Debt Plan Seen Among Latin Leaders
description: The Latin American debt plan proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is likely to be endorsed by a group of Latin American leaders gathered here this week, the President of Venezuela, Carlos Andres Perez, said today.

title: ICH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $8,826,000 for the quarter and $12,535,000 for the year, and an extraordinary gain of $1.8 million for both periods. c-After realized investment losses of $13,471,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $29.6 million for the year. The results for both year-ago periods were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Holly Farms Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago 9-month results are restated for an accounting change.

title: 38 Held as Drug Dealers in Manhattan Raid
description: Thirty-eight suspected drug dealers were arrested last night during a raid in upper Manhattan by officers from a Police Department special Tactical Narcotics Team.

title: Hewlett-Packard Distribution Shift
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would begin selling leading models of its computer work stations through the nation's two largest industrial distributors, a move reflecting the falling prices of the machines throughout the industry. The company said it had signed distribution agreements with Schweber Electronics and the Hall-Mark Electronics Corporation to sell some models of its HP 9000 Series 300, which adheres to the Unix standard developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The Digital Electronics Corporation has been offering its midsize work stations through industrial distributors for some time.

title: Comcast Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures reflect the consolidation of the results of Comcast Cablevision of Maryland L.P. and American Cellular Network Inc., acquired on Feb. 4 and April 1, 1988, respectively. Results also reflect the company's proportionate share of losses associated with its acquisition of 50 percent of Storer Communicaitons on Nov. 2, 1988. Shares outstanding have been retroactively adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend effective April 8, 1988.

title: Study Finds No Difference in 2 Heart Attach Drugs
description: A highly publicized and expensive drug to treat heart attack is no better than one that costs only a fraction as much, a new study has found.

title: Farm Credit Banks Offering $2.77 Billion of Securities
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering a total of $2.77 billion in debt securities with three-month, six-month and one-year maturities. Priced at par, the securities are being sold through various securities dealers and dealer banks in book-entry form only, which means the ownership of the securities is recorded electronically and no paper bond is issued.

title: Loss of House Seat Dims G.O.P. Hopes
description: After all the buoyant talk in recent days about gaining a majority in the House of Representatives, Republicans awoke today to a painful embarrassment: the loss of a seat in Indiana that the party had held for 12 years, a seat once held by Vice President Dan Quayle.

title: Use of Military Prisons for Drug Inmates Proposed
description: William J. Bennett, leader of the Bush Administration's anti-drug campaign, and the Defense Department are forging a plan to put some people convicted of drug-related crimes into military prisons to relieve overcrowding in civilian jails, officials in both agencies said today.

title: Valley National Head To 'Stick to Our Niche'
description: The Valley National Bancorp, which operates in northeastern New Jersey, is 61 years old and has never had a year in which it made less money than in the previous year. Gerald H. Lipkin, who is taking over the bank's leadership, said he was not about to fool with its formula.

title: Yields Post Rise in Week
description: Money market mutual funds offered higher yields in the week ended yesterday. Analysts said the increases were more a result of technical factors in the market than of action by the Federal Reserve.

title: Not All of the Homeless Are Drunk or Deranged
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Baseball; Mets Are Confident For the Opening Game
description: The Mets finally shook the charades of spring today, fielded their A team for the first time this year, cut four more players from the squad and sent Dwight Gooden through six innings against the Minnesota Twins in his final dress rehearsal for the big show next Monday in Shea Stadium.

title: Bridge
description: For enthusiasts in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the high point of the tournament year is the Long Island Regional Championships, which are to begin tomorrow at Hofstra University's Physical Fitness Center in Hempstead. Here is the tournament schedule. Tomorrow: Open Pairs and Standard Convention Pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; Non-Master Pairs, 8 P.M.

title: Impeachment in West Virginia
description: State Treasurer A. James Manchin, one of West Virginia's most popular political figures, was impeached today over bad investments that lost the state $279 million. He faces a trial in the State Senate.

title: RABBINICAL GROUP TO WIDEN ITS ROLE
description: The nation's Conservative rabbis announced Tuesday that they were moving deliberately to diminish their reliance on their Orthodox colleagues to perform certain ''life cycle'' rituals, like circumcision and divorce.

title: What Speaking the Language Tells the Japanese
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Juries Convict All 3 Defendants In Queens Murder of Officer Byrne
description: Three drug dealers were convicted last night of murdering a New York City police officer in an execution-style slaying in Queens that led to major new drives against narcotics traffickers across the city.

title: Big O Tires Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Captials Make Trades and Shift Gears
description: Searching for an appropriate description of what has come over the Washington Capitals this spring, Pete Peeters scanned the locker room to take inventory of the new faces there. He seemed reassured by the result.

title: Reviews/Music; Composers' Guild Program For Chorus and Organ
description: The Guild of Composers' concert Tuesday night at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, was in fact a New Calliope Singers choral concert with organ interludes, and it was one of those interludes that provided the most interesting fare of the evening.

title: Stake in Mobile Communications
description: Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc., a Menomonee Falls, Wis., investment adviser, has acquired a 16.6 percent stake in the class A shares of the Mobile Communications Corporation of America and 6.2 percent of its class B common stock, for a total purchase price of $80.4 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Strong said that it had purchased the shares ''on behalf of certain individual and institutional clients'' as an investment.

title: Colleges; Agents Were Advised Signings Were Not Illegal, Lawyer Says
description: A prominent sports attorney testified today that he had advised the sports agents Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom that signing athletes to contracts before their college eligibility expired did not violate any criminal statutes.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Financing Corporation, an arm of the Federal Home Loan Bank system that raises money for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, priced $500 million of 30-year bonds yesterday through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title:
HEALTH;
New Treatments Promise a More Powerful Attack on Diarrhea
description: LEAD: A sleepy corner of the pharmaceuticals business has suddenly come awake, and the competition promises more effective or more palatable treatment for the millions of Americans who suffer from common diarrhea each year.

title: Accord Seems Near on Roles Of I.M.F. and World Bank
description: After squabbling in recent months over their roles in assisting the world's poorest countries, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are close to an agreement that delineates their functions more sharply, their officials said today.

title: Oil on the Water, Oil in the Ground
description: Does the Exxon tanker spill show that Arctic oil shipping is being mismanaged? Should the industry have been better prepared to cope with the accident? Should the spill deflect President Bush from his plan to open more of Alaska to oil exploration?

title: U.S. Says It Broke Vast Drug Money Scheme
description: Federal law-enforcement officials today announced the indictment of 127 people in the breakup of a money-laundering operation that shipped more than $1 billion a year in drug profits from the United States to Colombian drug kingpins.

title: Tandon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after gains from discontinued operations of $3,049,000 for the quarter and $3,966,000 for the year; a loss from a class action litigation of $3 million, and a tax credit of $5,413,000, both for the quarter and year.

title: Space Failure: U.S. Partnership Fades
description: Loss of both Soviet spacecraft bound for the Martian moon Phobos could raise disturbing questions among would-be partners about the advisability of putting too much faith in Soviet planetary spacecraft technology, American scientists and space experts said yesterday. The failures of the

title: Orr Honored Again
description: Vickie Orr, a 6-foot-3-inch senior center from Auburn, has been voted to the Kodak women's all-America Division I basketball team for the third straight year. Three other seniors - Clarissa Davis of Texas, also a center, Bridgette Gordon of Tennessee, a forward, and Penny Toler of Long Beach state, a guard - were named to the 10-woman team for the second time.

title: Review/Art; Otto Dix's One-Sided View of War
description: If you have never seen ''The War,'' now is your chance. The 50 etchings in Otto Dix's celebrated series are on display in all their corrosive detail on the third floor of the New York Public Library. These are sermons without preaching. This is Expressionism without romance. No one in these engravings has any good war stories to tell. No one seeing these engravings will be in a hurry to enlist.

title: Bill Chappell Jr. Is Dead at 67; Served in the House for 20 Years
description: Bill Chappell Jr., a Florida Democrat who served 20 years in the House of Representatives before being defeated for re-election last year amid reports linking him to a Pentagon procurement scandal, died of bone cancer today at the National Institutes of Health. He was 67 years old, Mr. Chappell, who had represented northeast Florida's Fourth Congressional District, was hospitalized at the institutes on Feb. 23.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: John Nelson will lead the Brooklyn Philharmonic in Haydn's Symphony No. 44 in G minor, the Glazunov Violin Concerto and excerpts from Berlioz's ''Romeo and Juliet'' (Op. 17) at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section, tonight at 8 o'clock. Dmitry Sitkovetsky is to be the soloist in the Glazunov. The program is to be repeated tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $22. Information: (718) 622-1000.

title: Sears to Shift Management And Eliminate 800 Positions
description: In a further move to cut costs and bolster sales, Sears, Roebuck & Company today announced a reorganization aimed at strengthening its store management and eliminating 800 of 7,700 jobs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, asked a Federal judge for an extension of the period in which the company has an exclusive rights to file a reorganization plan under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Kennebunkport Lobstermen Irked by Presidential Security
description: A new security zone in the waters off President Bush's summer home has raised the ire of lobstermen, who object to the choice of having their routines disrupted and losing their traps, or finding another place to fish.

title: Edgcomb Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a LIFO inventory charge of $16,343,000. c-After a LIFO inventory charge of $7,945,000 and the share earnings were increased by 14 cents due to the cumualtive effect of an accounting change for pension.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Acquisition
description: Grey Advertsing said yesterday that it had acquired an ad agency in New Zealand, tripling its presence in that country. Grey bought a majority share in Wood & Mitchell, an independent agency with billings of $5.8 million in 1988. Grey already owns an Auckland-based agency, Ward & Grey, which had billings of $2.9 million last year. A Grey executive said the agency was attracted to Wood & Mitchell partly because it has an office in Wellington. Ward & Grey suffered a 28 percent drop in revenue last year, according to an Ad Age survey, and Grey is seeking to strengthen its New Zealand operation, said Norman Vale, managing director of Grey International. The two agencies will be merged and renamed Grey-New Zealand.

title: Review/Film; Harmonies in High School
description: No one who has spent time watching American high-school movies need wonder why Johnny can't read. It's abundantly clear that, except in those rare films that (like ''Stand and Deliver'') throw in a differential equation or two, the curriculum plays second fiddle to the extracurricular at every turn. Even so, this phenomenon is carried to ridiculous extremes by ''Sing,'' an in-depth look at a talent competition at a Brooklyn high school. One of the rare stabs at scholarship in ''Sing'' has the students re-interpreting ''Romeo and Juliet'' in musical terms, with Juliet wearing a tight leopard-skin outfit plus one dangling earring.

title: Ohio Mattress Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
House Race in Alabama Takes on a Biting Tone
description: Lee Atwater, the South Carolinian who managed President Bush's 1988 campaign, stated the principle late last year with his usual pithiness.

title: Addington Resources Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $706,049 from the writeoff of capitalized financing costs associated with debt repaid during 1988. Prior year results are reported on a pro forma basis.

title: Olajuwon Gives Rockets a Most Valuable Performance
description: With the Nets mathematically eliminated from the playoffs, the greatest interest in their game against Houston was focused on Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston center who is a strong candidate for National Basketball Association's most-valuable-player award.

title: Mor-Flo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods included a gain of $5,044,000 from the sale of its recreational vehicle products business in October 1988. The latest year also included a charge of $1,921,000 from a patent infringement damage award. The prior year included a gain from an accounting change of $1,737,000.

title: National Guard in 12 States Gets Pentagon Money to Battle Drugs
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today approved nearly $12 million for National Guards in a dozen Southern and Western states to help local law-enforcement agencies battle drugs. It was the first step in a Pentagon effort to increase military support for the anti-drug effort.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sabatini and Evert in Final: No. 1 Gabriela Sabatini and second-seeded Chris Evert took advantage of mistakes by their opponents to win semifinal matches yesterday in the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Evert needed just 75 minutes to beat No. 5 Zina Garrison, 6-3, 6-1. Garrison won only one service game as Evert kept intact her record of making the finals every year in this 5-year-old event. Sabatini lost a set for the first time in her six tournament matches but still beat No. 3 Helena Sukova, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, in 2 hours 20 minutes. Evert and Sabatini, both looking for their first title of 1989, will play for the championship tomorrow. In today's men's semifinals, top-ranked Ivan Lendl will meet Kevin Curren, and Yannick Noah will face Thomas Muster.(AP) BOXING Stewart Streak Alive: Alex Stewart, the undefeated heavyweight from Brooklyn, won his 21st fight last night when he stopped Arthel Lawhorne of Detroit at 2 minutes 7 seconds of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-round fight at the Felt Forum. All 21 of Stewart's victories have now been by knockout. Lawhorne, a rotund 224-pound fighter, clowned through the bout even as Stewart was pummeling him. The referee Joe Santarpia, stopped the fight after Stewart had nailed Lawhorne with three punches to the head. In another heavyweight bout, Renaldo Snipes of Yonkers stopped Andre Crowder of Lima, Ohio, in three rounds, raising his record to 33-7-1 with 19 knockouts. Crowder is 6-9-2. Sailing Monnet Misses Record: A Frenchman's effort to beat a month-old sailing record fell a few hours short yesterday as Philippe Monnet steered his battered trimaran toward the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco after a voyage of 80 days and 14,000 miles from New York City. But the 29-year-old sailor became the first person to sail the route alone, said Oliver Lanusse-Cazale, Monnet's representative in San Francisco. Monnet had to arrive in San Francisco by 7:34 A.M. to break the record set Feb. 12 by the sloop Thursday's Child, which took 80 days and 20 hours port to port.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 5, Capitals 4: Tim Kerr scored two goals and Philadelphia Flyers took advantage of three power-play opportunities to close to 3 points of the third-place Rangers in the Patrick Division. Both teams have two games left in the regular season. If the Flyers finish fourth, they will meet Washington in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.(AP) Whalers 9 Penguins 5: Scott Young and Ray Ferraro each scored twice as Hartford overcame a four-goal game by Mario Lemieux. Lemieux's third goal was shorthanded, his 13th of the season, breaking Wayne Gretzky's league record. Lemieux scored his fourth goal in the final minute to raise his league-leading total to 83. The Penguins remained in second place in the Patrick Division, a point ahead of the Rangers. They will meet Saturday night in Pittsburgh.(AP)

title: Consumers Resist Price Rises, Putting Squeeze on Retailers
description: Although wholesale prices are surging, inflation at the consumer level is not following suit, primarily because of the resistance of buyers to higher prices.

title: Why Can't Men Take Demeaning Depictions of Them as a Joke?; TV Insults Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Charting 2 Centuries Of Design in France
description: As everyone knows by now, the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution falls due this year and will reach its climax on July 14, the day on which the Bastille was stormed in the face of minimal opposition and a raggle-taggle group of prisoners was set free. In almost every big city in the developed world, the bicentenary will be celebrated, sometimes with full-hearted pleasure and at other times with a certain sneaky embarrassment.

title: Data Translation reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Memory Chips By Sematech
description: Sematech, the semiconductor industry's fledgling research consortium, said yesterday that it had made its first batch of memory chips.

title: 3 Palestinians Are Killed In Protests on Land Day
description: Three Palestinians died in the occupied territories today as residents marked Land Day, the Arab commemoration of land expropriated by the Israeli Government. But the army said it was responsible for only one of the deaths.

title: Justine Townsend Friberg
description: Justine Van Rensselaer Townsend Friberg, a member of one of New York's oldest families, died March 19 in Cottonwood, Ariz., where whe resided. She was 93 years old.

title: Accept the FSX Deal - As Is
description: The furor over the United States technology ''give-away'' on the FSX fighter plane overlooks one fundamental fact: the Japanese never wanted our involvement at all.

title: Review/Theater; In-Person Update on One Man's Wit
description: A. Whitney Brown, whose cynical news commentaries are a regular feature on ''Saturday Night Live,'' has carved out a comic identity as the quintessential disillusioned baby boomer.

title: Philharmonic's New Season
description: The United States premiere of ''Messa per Rossini,'' world premieres by Roger Kellaway and David Del Tredici, the Philharmonic debut of the soprano Gabriela Benackova, and two performances of Mahler's ''Songs of a Wayfarer'' by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau are among the highlights of the 1989-90 New York Philharmonic season, which is to include 131 performances of 38 different programs.

title: Compensation To Occidental
description: The Venezuelan Supreme Court has ruled that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation is owed compensation for assets lost when Venezuela's oil industry was nationalized in 1976, the court president, Rene De Sola, said today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Jehiel R. Elyachar, a real estate developer and philanthropist, incorrectly described a lawsuit filed against him several years ago. He was sued by his sons, Ralph and Daniel, but not by his daughter, Ruth Dvorkin.

title: Hartmarx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
To North Korea, Tokyo Regrets the Past
description: In a renewed effort to improve relations with North Korea, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita directed an unusual apology to Pyongyang today for the ''great suffering'' inflicted by Japan's past subjugation of the Korean peninsula.

title: Cuomo Favors Building Ban Along Hudson
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would favor banning development along parts of the Hudson ning development along parts of the Hudson River waterfront in lower Manhattan, a significant shift in his position.

title: Radio City to Promote at Pier 84
description: Radio City Music Hall Productions and the Intrepid Museum Foundation will present three seasons of open-air concerts and other entertainment on Pier 84, at West 44th Street and the Hudson River, Mayor Edward I. Koch and James McManus, the president of Radio City, announced yesterday.

title: Review/Art; Tales of Ordinary People Told in Bits and Pieces
description: Dona Nelson, a painter who has exhibited in New York City for more than 15 years, has developed slowly. She began in the early 1970's as an abstractionist before moving to landscape painting and then to bluntly painted interiors and increasingly figurative work. But at the Scott Hanson Gallery, her current exhibition, which consists of seven paintings made in the last three years, shows an artist hitting her stride.

title: Washington Talk; The Legislative Veto, An Accommodation That Goes On and On
description: Old habits die hard, particularly comfortable habits. Take the legislative veto, a handy device for turning conflict into accommodation that was concocted in 1932, when Herbert Hoover wanted to reorganize the Government and Congress wasn't sure it wanted him to.

title: Books Focusing on 60's Among Pulitzer Winners
description: Echoes of the dramatic turbulence of the 1960's dominated the 73d annual Pulitzer Prize awards as Neil Sheehan's book about the Vietnam War and Taylor Branch's study of the civil-rights struggle gained honors, along with ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' Wendy Wasserstein's play about a child of the 60's alienated from the consciousness of the 80's.

title: The War Over, Iraq's Ruler Announces Plans for Liberalization
description: Intriguing tales are circulating here about Iraq's iron-fisted ruler, President Saddam Hussein.

title: Long Distance, Even Cheaper
description: To consumers still mourning the dismemberment of friendly old Ma Bell, the very idea of another change in the phone system is as welcome as yet another set of Yellow Pages. But this time there's nothing to worry about.

title: Questions on Father Healy and Library Persist; Fought Gay Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman Steps Down At Troubled Trustcorp
description: George W. Haigh resigned yesterday as president, chairman and chief executive of Trustcorp Inc., a bank holding company in Toledo, Ohio, that ran into troubles with problem loans. The resignation is effective April 30. Mr. Haigh, 57 years old, will be succeeded on an interim basis by Chester Devenow, 80. Mr. Devenow has already been serving as interim chairman, president and chief executive of Trustcorp Bank, Ohio, since a shake-up at the bank earlier this month. The bank had named a special group of outside directors to review its loan-loss reserves.

title: Fight Over $500 Million Estate: Fallout Continues
description: The wrenching legal fight over the $500 million estate of J. Seward Johnson was settled three years ago, but the fallout continues, spreading over some of New York's most prestigious law firms. A malpractice suit has aired angry charges against a top firm involved in the Johnson case while provoking a legal attack on an outspoken judge.

title: Universal Foods' Takeover Defense
description: IT'S known as the ''just say no'' defense to a takeover, and while it has been talked about a lot, so far no company has been willing to go to the wall with one.

title: Avery International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Art Ross has joined Pancom International Corp., a New York ad agency, as executive vice president and director of creative services.

title: Koch Promises 400 Apartments For City Nurses
description: Seeking to relieve a severe nursing shortage, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that New York City will spend about $45 million in the next two years to create housing for 1,000 nurses.

title: At the Movies
description: Hurricane Carter's Life

title: Condemned but Cozy, Board Goes On
description: Under clouds of uncertainty as gray as the mist that shrouded City Hall, the New the mist that shrouded City Hall, the New York City Board of Estimate met yesterday for the first time since the United States Supreme Court declared it unconstitutional, and despite doubts about its future it did business in its usual unusual way.

title: Ruling on DeLorean Assets
description: John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile maker, lost an important battle today with the creditors of his failed sports car company when a Federal judge dismissed his challenge to a $53 million judgment made against him in Britain.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday misstated projections for advertising growth. Domestic advertising spending is expected to rise about 6 percent this year, compared with an 8 percent increase in 1988.

title: Prison Uprising in Guatemala Ends With Accord
description: Rebellious inmates today ended a five-day uprising that left at least seven people dead and trapped hundreds of women and children inside the prison here.

title: Dollar Declines as the Fed Intervenes to Purchase Yen
description: The dollar, after breaking though the psychologically important 1.90-mark level, declined yesterday when the Federal Reserve sold dollars for Japanese yen.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE ALICE-IN-WONDERLAND GAME,'' an original version of the Lewis Carroll story, adapted by Lee Frank, with music by Jerry Markoe, presented by On Stage Productions, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays through May 6, at 413 West 46th Street. Admission: $5. Information: 666-1716. ''TOM SAWYER,'' a one-act opera by Richard Owen, produced by the Cynthia Auerbach Children's Theater of the Manhattan School of Music Preparatory Division, with a cast of children from kindergarten age through high school seniors, 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Borden Auditorium, 120th Street and Broadway. Admission: $5. Information: 749-2802, extension 462 or 463. BOOK FESTIVAL, a festival with new books -hard cover and paperback - magic shows by Bob Markwood at 12:30, 1:15 and 1 P.M., (show tickets, $1), face and hand painting, origami demonstrations, storytelling and a bake sale and refreshments, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday, at the Rodeph Sholom School, 7 West 83d Street. Free admission. Information: 362-8800. ''PETROUCHKA,'' a production of the Tears of Joy Puppet Theater, presented by the Friends of the Arts for the Children's Carousel Series, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Adams Playhouse, Hofstra University, Hempstead Turnpike, Hempstead, L.I. Tickets: $5. Information: (516) 922-0061. ''CARNIVAL OF THE ANIMALS,'' a show by Puppetworks, with music of Saint-Saens and others, noon on Saturdays, and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show with audience participation, presented by Torkova and Imam, at 2 P.M. Saturdays at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday COOKIES AND ART

title: Devcon International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $32,000 tax credit. c-After tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $31,000 for the year.

title: Long-Term Worries Over Fish
description: Because there are virtually no gaps in the Alaska oil slick, scientists fear unusually persistent poisonous effects. The chairman of Exxon said part of the problem was a delay in permission for cleanup efforts, but officials disputed that contention. Page A12.

title: Xerox Credit Sets $150 Million Sale
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $150 million worth of 10 percent notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bernard Blier, Actor, Dies at 73
description: Bernard Blier, a popular French film actor, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 73 years old.

title: FINAL FOUR: Duke Succeeds Despite Stress and Injury; Blue Devils Peaking at Right Time
description: Mike Krzyzewski realized right away that this would sound strange, that the idea of reaching the Final Four was not among his first thoughts after qualifying for the national semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Review/Theater; A Play About Baseball With Echoes in the News
description: Having written ''A Walk in the Woods,'' a high-minded comedy about Soviet-American arms negotiations, Lee Blessing would seem to be retreating into nostalgic escapism with ''Cobb,'' his new play about the Detroit Tigers centerfielder who tore up opponents and record books in the 20th century's early innings. But on the eve of our new baseball season, the name Ty Cobb, by chance, is back in the news. Pete Rose, the player who in 1985 at last surpassed Cobb's career record for hits, is under investigation, reportedly for gambling activities eerily echoing a scandal that engulfed Cobb in the 1920's.

title: Frieder Finds Himself In Role of Wallflower
description: The Michigan man, class of 1964, had several reasons to arrive here Wednesday. He is attending the annual convention of the National Association of Basketball Coaches, and now, for the first time in 13 years, he will have the chance to watch his school play in the Final Four.

title: J. J. Kenny to Buy Clifford Drake
description: The J. J. Kenny Company, one of the nation's largest and oldest bond brokers, said yesterday that it was acquiring another large broker, Clifford Drake & Company.

title: Defense Case Rested in Agents' Trial
description: After just three days of testimony, the defense in the trial of Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom rested today without calling either agent to testify.

title: 2 Killed in Blast as Rockets Hit Beirut Suburb Gas Tanks
description: A huge explosion shook the capital and surrounding areas today as butane gas tanks exploded in a Christian suburb after being hit by rockets.

title: Walker's 19 Help Lift Knicks Over Mavericks
description: A big lift from Kenny Walker and a little luck down the stretch gave the Knicks just enough to win last night.

title: Richard Wilson, 60, Cancer Surgeon, Dies
description: Dr. Richard E. Wilson, a medical educator and researcher who specialized in cancer surgery, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 60 years old and lived in Wellesley, Mass.

title: City Cable TV Operators Won't Give In to MSG
description: Cable television operators in New York City said yesterday that they would black out Madison Square Garden Network's 75 Yankee games this season rather than give in to MSG's demands that the broadcasts be offered as part of each system's fixed-cost basic service.

title: Clouds on Credit Union Horizon
description: While the savings industry has suffered $100 billion in losses on speculative real estate, fraud and mismanagement, and the banking industry has seen failures surge to more than 200 last year, one segment of the nation's financial sector seems to have known only bright days and clear skies in recent years.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $902,000 from an accounting change.

title: Third World Debt: The Brady Plan
description: WHEN economic policy makers are the prisoners of circumstances and lack the resources to control events, they are well advised to be vague about their proposals. In searching for a solution to the third world debt problem, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is employing the economics of vagueness.

title: Review/Cabaret; Jerry Herman and Friends
description: Eight years ago Jerry Herman put together an evening of his songs called ''Jerry's Girls.'' The title had a double meaning because some of his most memorable Broadway scores were about women (''Hello, Dolly!'' ''Mame!'' and ''Mack and Mabel'') and the cast of ''Jerry's Girls'' consisted of four women.

title: CAPTAIN OF TANKER HAD BEEN DRINKING, BLOOD TESTS SHOW
description: The Coast Guard today opened formal legal proceedings against the captain of the tanker that ran aground here last week after the head of an investigatating team reported that the captain had unacceptably high levels of alcohol in his blood nine hours after the accident.

title: J.A.L. Plans to Sell $1 Billion in Bonds
description: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it planned to sell $1 billion in four-year warrant bonds in markets other than the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Sells Division
description: A day after announcing a management realignment intended to bolster its non-advertising communications services, the Ogilvy Group yesterday sold a language-translation and graphics subsidiary to Macmillan Inc. Macmillan said it paid $6.75 million for the subsidiary, Euramerica. Ogilvy said it sold Euramerica to concentrate on its core communications businesses. Euramerica generated revenues of $7.9 million last year. It also includes an advertising division, which will be kept and incorporated into Ogilvy & Mather Direct.

title: Amoco Subsidiary
description: About 800 employees of the Amoco Production Company will be cut from the payroll as part of a reorganization this spring, reflecting a trend by leading oil companies to emphasize foreign exploration and production over United States operations. Amoco Production is the oil and gas exploration subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest energy company.

title: New Aide at St. John's
description: Frank Racaniello, an assistant sports information director at St. John's University for eight years, was named sports informaton director yesterday. He replaced Katha Quinn, who died of cancer this month.

title: Sis Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Healthdyne reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year's loss was impacted by $1.55 million of expenses associated with the unsolicited proposal from Continental Health Affiliates Inc. to acquire the company and a $300,000 loss on the sale of one of the company's durable medical equipment subsidiaries in Ohio.

title: Lasmo Canada Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The 1988 loss included a non-recurring $25 million writedown in petroleum and natural gas interests. The 1987 results are presented on a pro-forma basis as the company was formed in January 1988 from the amalgamation of Onyx Petroleum Exploration Co. and Lasmo Exploration (Canada) Ltd. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Greek Prime Minister Files Suit for Divorce
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou today filed for divorce from his American-born wife, Margaret, citing irreconcilable differences and separation from her long before he began living with his current companion.

title: Trans World Airlines Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gains of $163 million from the sale of securities and $50 million from a cash judgment in a lawsuit filed by TWA in 1962 against Howard Hughes. c-Included an after-tax gain of $60.9 million. Results for the latest year combined financial results for the 10 months ended Oct. 31, 1988, and the two months ended Dec. 31, 1988. TWA became a new reporting entity after the Oct. 24, 1988, ''going-private'' merger.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday, about the sale of several operations of the Fruehauf Corporation, incorrectly described the ownership of the Terex Corporation. Its shares are traded in the over-the-counter market.

title: Can It Be? Income-Tax Talk in Connecticut?
description: As the decades of the 20th century rolled by and other states in the Northeast gave in and enacted income taxes, Connecticut held firm to the old image of small-government New England, where the state's business was to mind its own business and keep taxes low. The income tax is still the issue on which all candidates must make their stand known, and in many towns, sworn opposition has become almost a requirement for election.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After a loss of $152,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $227,000 for the quarter and income of $8,691,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The year-ago quarter's net was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements. The latest quarter included a $2 million reserve to accommodate a planned modernization of management information systems along with certain other restructuring activities, and a $100,000 LIFO credit. Fiscal 1989 included a $3.2 million LIFO charge. The year-ago quarter included a $2.5 million reserve for the modernization of management information systems and other restructuring, and a $1.3 million LIFO charge. Fiscal 1988 included a $5 million LIFO charge.

title: Lauder Urges Dismissal Of Schools Chancellor
description: In the first public policy statement of his campaign, Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, declared that New York City has the worst public schools in the world and called for dismissal of the Chancellor.

title: Kabul Offering Rebels Local Power
description: In perhaps his most ambitious attempt to end the war against his Soviet-backed Government, President Najibullah has offered guerrilla military commanders a chance to set up regional administrations, supplied by the Government, in return for locally negotiated cease-fires.

title: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago figures are for the periods ended Feb. 29 and have been restated.

title: 2 Playing Rock
description: Bastro and Alice Donut, two rock bands, are to perform tonight at 11 and midnight, respectively, at the Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, at East Seventh Street (420-1590). Admission is $10.

title: Nissan Is Said to Plan New U.S. Production
description: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation is expected to announce Monday that it will begin building a midsize car at its Smyrna, Tenn., assembly plant, as early as 1991.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; A Comic Island Melodrama
description: ''Plaff!'' (which is translated as ''Splat!'') is a contemporary Cuban comedy about Concha, a ferociously overprotective mother whose life falls apart the day her son marries and brings his bride into the house to live.

title: Bomem Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss is due to a $1,390,992 charge for deferred marketing expenses and a $2,363,627 charge for amortized marketing expenses. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Finally, the Slavophiles Triumph
description: LEAD: The outcome of Sunday's vote shows that, after a century and a half, the Slavophiles finally have triumphed in Russia.

title: On Stage
description: Playing With Animals

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Review/Film; A New Telling of the Crusoe Story
description: Any Robinson Crusoe movie that takes more than five minutes to get Crusoe onto his desert isle is in big trouble. Caleb Deschanel's ''Crusoe,'' opening today at the Paris, not only takes 10 to 15 minutes, but it also goes out of its way to give Crusoe spurious social relevance.

title: S.E.C. Charges Specialist
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Vipin Sahgal, a merger and acquisition specialist in Los Angeles, violated the anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities laws when he issued a false and misleading news release in February 1988.

title: Mardin Journal; How the Kurds Are Cared For: 7 Months in Tents
description: Confined behind barbed-wire fences - in a wind-pounded tent city here and in bleak, overcrowded apartment blocks elsewhere - Kurdish refugees who fled to Turkey from Iraq feel they are the near-forgotten.

title: Satanic Work in Brussels
description: Nobody can yet say who murdered a Muslim spiritual leader and his aide in Brussels on Wednesday, but the chronology is deeply disquieting. The killing of Abdullah al-Ahdal took place nearly six weeks after he said on Belgian television that he did not favor murdering Salman Rushdie as punishment for writing ''The Satanic Verses.''

title: Ailing Daniel Stalks Dinah Shore Leader
description: One year after she was diagnosed as suffering from mononucleosis, Beth Daniel is sick again, this time with a viral infection. Nevertheless, with temperatures in the mid-90's in the Coachella Valley and her own temperature running around 100, the 32-year-old Daniel was able to post a three-under-par 69 today in the opening round of the Nabisco Dinah Shore, the year's first major women's championship.

title: Judge Denies Spy's Wife a Change of Prison
description: A Federal district judge today denied a request from the imprisoned wife of the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard for an independent medical review and a transfer from the Federal Medical Center in Rochester.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hill and Burson at Top Of Latest Survey
description: Hill & Knowlton and Burson-Marsteller again finished first and second, respectively, in the annual ranking by size of public relations agencies by O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms, the influential industry directory.

title: Review/Film; When a Not-So-Bad Girl Turns Very, Very Bad
description: Heather is the name of choice at Westerburg High School, the name that signifies power, popularity and unlimited license to make mischief. The rules of the game are established in an early scene in ''Heathers,'' in which a trio of girls named Heather cruise the school cafeteria with a reluctant handmaiden named Veronica (Winona Ryder) in tow. They taunt some classmates, flirt with others, compliment others on their clothes. This sequence has a bright look, a buoyant style and an utterly vicious spirit, giving ''Heathers'' the air of a demonic sitcom.

title: A Fish Story From the City You Say? Read On
description: Tomorrow, nine male Shermans -Ben, the father, his sons Gary and Mark, Uncle Murray, Cousin Stevie and a flotilla of grandchildren - will embark on the slightly demented annual ritual known as the opening day of trout season in New York State.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Rusty Staub's on Fifth

title: Perez Gets Permission To Return to the Expos
description: Pascual Perez, who has spent the last two months in drug rehabilitation, received clearance from Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's office yesterday to rejoin the Montreal Expos ''as soon as he is physically and medically capable of playing baseball.''

title: Letter: On Athletics; Don't Franchise Intercollegiate Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Staying In Florida
description: As the Yankees wound up their spring camp today and prepared to fly north, another potentially serious injury confronted them. Don Mattingly, the centerpiece of their offense, stayed in Fort Lauderdale and spent the afternoon on the trainer's table.

title: KEY RATES
Prosecution Rests in the Iran-Contra Trial of North
description: After six weeks of testimony, the prosecution completed its case against Oliver L. North today.

title: Soviets Change Draft Rules To Give Students Deferments
description: Soviet students will be allowed to defer their military service until after they have completed their education, newspapers reported today.

title: Riegle Mulls Proposal on Bailout Plan
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., is considering proposing a significant change in the financing of the Bush Administration's savings and loan bailout plan, the Banking Committee's chief of staff said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: When Congress Worked
description: To the Editor:

title: El Diario Night Editor Held In Stabbing of Photographer
description: The night editor of the Spanish-language newspaper El Diario La Prensa was arrested yesterday and charged with slashing a freelance photographer during an argument in a Cuban restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: Fair Is Fair for Medicare
description: Income tax time brings a new round of agitation from older Americans upset about the new Medicare law, which collects premiums for expanded coverage in the form of an income tax surcharge. The complaints are based more on confusion than injustice.

title: Jewish Composers
description: New works by a dozen Israeli and American Jewish composers will be presented Sunday, Monday and Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, and at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The festival, Counter Harmonies: Jewish Experience in 20th-Century Music, is being presented by the National Foundation for Jewish Culture, and will also include master classes, lectures and panel discussion. Information: 629-0500.

title: Kimball Is Denied Sentence Reduction
description: Bruce Kimball, the former Olympic diver who was sentenced to 17 years in prison two months ago for killing two teen-agers while driving drunk last summer, admitted yesterday that he had a dependency on drugs and alcohol. But he was denied a sentence reduction by Circuit Judge Harry Lee Coe 3d in Tampa, Fla.

title: Soviet Corn Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 450,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the 1988-89 marketing year that began on Sept. 1, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.

title: Emhart Bid Is Advanced
description: Seeking to clear the way for its proposed $2.8 billion takeover of the Emhart Corporation, the Black & Decker Corporation said yesterday that it had settled a legal dispute with the Topper Acquisition Corporation for $21 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: P.L.O. Council Picks Arafat As Head of Proclaimed State
description: The executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization has nominated its chairman, Yasir Arafat, as president of the proclaimed Palestinian state. But leaders of hard-line guerrilla groups announced that they intend to establish their own breakaway P.L.O.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aon Corp., Chicago, an insurance holding company, said Stephen L. Lunsford had joined its Aon Risk Services Inc. unit as executive vice president.

title: Convictions Are Overturned In Beech-Nut Labeling Case
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned last year's convictions of two top executives of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation for distributing phony apple juice.

title: British Battle Over Harrods: 'Tiny' vs. 'Phoney Pharaoh'
description: A long-running battle for control of Harrods department store, one of the most unusual corporate disputes ever, took some bizarre turns today.

title: South African Music
description: The Izulu Dance Theater and Music Company, featuring Thokoza, a vocal group led by Thuli Dumakude, is to perform South African and gospel music in a program called ''From Soweto to Selma,'' at 7 and 10 P.M. tomorrow at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (840-2824). Tickets are $15.

title: TriBeCa Will Vanish Like Mulberry Bend
description: To the Editor:

title: Envoys to Austria and Italy Nominated by White House
description: Henry A. Grunwald, a former Time magazine executive, has been nominated by President Bush to remain in his post as United States Ambassador to Austria, and Peter Secchia has been officially nominated to be envoy to Italy.

title: NOTEBOOK: Horse Racing; Florida Track Scheduling Goes Down to Wire
description: At 5 P.M. today, the deadline will pass for the three race tracks in the Miami area to file their schedules for next year, and the future of Florida thoroughbred racing may hang in the balance.

title: Reviews/Film; A Story Of Obsession And Jealousy
description: As the star of his own ''Heat and Sunlight,'' Rob Nilsson subjects himself to exquisite forms of torture. Mr. Nilsson plays a photographer who is in the final throes of ending an intoxicating love affair, a man whose tenacity knows no bounds. He plasters the walls with erotic photographs of Carmen (Consuelo Faust), the woman who has begun to elude him. He talks obsessively about Carmen with his friends. He revels ecstatically in the very misery that Carmen seems to be causing him. Yet ''Heat and Sunlight'' is anything but morose, since Mr. Nilsson invests it with so much desperate, passionate energy.

title: Books Focusing on 60s Among Pulitzer Winners
description: Echoes of the dramatic turbulence of the 1960's dominated the 73d annual Pulitzer Prize awards as Neil Sheehan's book about the Vietnam War and Taylor Branch's study of the civil-rights struggle gained honors, along with ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' Wendy Wasserstein's play about a child of the 60's alienated from the consciousness of the 80's.

title: Egg Experiment in Space Prompts Questions
description: A student's experiment on the effects weightlessness might have on fertilized chicken eggs in space has raised new scientific questions after eight of the embryos died.

title: Miss Richardson, a Product Manager, Weds Christophe Dufournier in Paris
description: Beatrix Post Richardson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lunsford Richardson of Rowayton, Conn., and Christophe Dufournier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Dufournier of Paris, were married in a civil ceremony in Paris yesterday. A religious ceremony is to follow tomorrow at St. Martin Collegiate Church in Troo, near Tours. The Rev. Etienne Chaumier, a Roman Catholic priest, will officiate.

title: Our Towns; Taking Control In the Wake Of Mount Laurel
description: A decade ago, Morris Township - an upper-middle-class suburb where homes sell for $200,000 to $1 million - was sued by the state for exclusionary zoning. Leaders in this Republican town fought it for years, but by the mid-1980's they saw the writing on the wall. In 1983, the State Supreme Court issued the landmark Mount Laurel decision, requiring every town to take a fair share of subsidized housing.

title: Braselton Journal; Actress Buys Town A Place on the Map
description: Herbert Braselton, a 69-year-old member of the family that for 113 years has owned this town except for 200 acres or so, said today he was satisfied that the family had done the right thing by selling it.

title: World Psychiatrists Panel Votes To Readmit Soviets to Membership
description: The executive committee of the World Psychiatric Association granted provisional readmission to the Soviet Union today, a move that is likely to be strenuously opposed by a number of Western human rights groups and psychiatric associations, a member of the committee said.

title: Review/Photography; Slices of Time, Preserved in Deft Images
description: A PHOTOGRAPH, whether intended to or not, speaks of the time in which it was made. This is obvious in the case of images taken years ago -pictures from the first days of Israel's independence, for example, or from the tumultuous decade of the 1960's. But it is also true of contemporary art photographs of the sort one finds displayed in SoHo galleries. This weekend affords an unusually rich opportunity to look at photographs of the past and present, and to assess how much the world has changed in the last 40 years.

title: U.S. Is Moving to End Doubts on Debt Proposal
description: At meetings this weekend with the world's top economic officials, the Bush Administration will address confusion and doubts about Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's proposal to help ease the debt burdens of countries like Mexico and Venezuela.

title: Questions on Father Healy and Library Persist; Lucky to Get Him
description: To the Editor:

title: Poets and Novelists
description: Paul Auster, Nicholas Christopher and Carol Muske will read from their works as part of the program ''The Poet as Novelist, the Novelist as Poet'' at 8 o'clock tonight at the West Side Y Center for the Arts, 5 West 63d Street. Tickets are $7. Information: 787-6557.

title: Black Talk Radio: A Vital Force Is Emerging to Mobilize Opinion
description: For nearly half of each day, the 1450 spot on the AM radio dial here belongs to WCEV, a Polish language radio station that serves up a diet of polka music on a signal barely audible along the city's northern border.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Atari Games Subsidiary Chooses Keye/Donna
description: Tengen Inc., the home video games subsidiary of the Atari Games Corporation, yesterday selected Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein, Los Angeles, as its first advertising agency. The account will bill $10 million annually. Tengen creates cartridges for the Nintendo home video game system and games software for personal computers.

title: School Festival
description: The Rodeph Sholom School, 7 West 83d Street, will have its Spring Book Festival from 7 to 9 P.M. tomorrow and 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday. It includes children's entertainment, author appearances and refreshments. Admission is free. Information: 362-8800.

title: Washington Talk: The White House
