description: The fatal attraction to totems of power within the White House was best described a while back by a Washington psychiatrist. The doctor was treating a man working in the West Wing who insisted on keeping his White House pass on at all times, even to bathe and sleep.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * McGraw-Hill Inc. will acquire Asian Aviation magazine from Asian Aviation Publications of Singapore. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 Subway Workers Killed by a Train Rounding a Curve
description: Two subway workers, apparently with their backs to the danger, were struck and killed yesterday by a fast-moving Lexington Avenue express train as it roared through a curved local station in Manhattan's East Village, transit officials said.

title: Board of Estimate Approves New Staten Island Jail
description: A proposal to build a jail for 1,000 inmates in the Rossville section of Staten Island was approved last night by the Board of Estimate, despite vehement opposition from residents of the area, who said they would fight the proposal in court.

title: Reporter's Notebook; The Silence in Albany Is Meant to Be Soothing
description: It's two days before New York's budget deadline, and state leaders are contemplating about $1 billion in new taxes. But they won't tell New Yorkers which taxes they are looking at. They don't want to upset them.

title: Managua Asks Drug Effort With U.S.
description: Offering to work closely with the United States to fight illegal drug trafficking, Nicaragua today gave to its fellow Central American nations a broad new plan to unify regional anti-drug efforts in direct consultation with United States law authorities.

title: Oil on Surface Covers Deeper Threat
description: The poisonous effects of the Alaskan oil spill could be unusually persistent, scientists said today.

title: 'We Had To Play With Gloves'
description: rrThis is how far Chris Weller has gone in women's basketball. She remembers when it was sometimes played outdoors rather than in the weather-oblivious comfort of the Tacoma Dome.

title: Jacqueline M. Wilentz, a Painter, Dies at 61
description: Jacqueline Melino Wilentz, a painter, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old and also had a home in Deal, N.J.

title: Penney to Cease Teleaction Service
description: J. C. Penney Inc. said it would discontinue its Teleaction television shopping service on April 7, taking a $20 million write-off and laying off 164 employees. The Dallas-based retailer said that it would take the accounting charge in the quarter ending April 29, adding that it had invested $106 million to develop the at-home shopping service. Most of the losses have already been absorbed.

title: The Whine Industry
description: Arrived at Tokyo's Narita Airport; absolutely delighted with what I found. A mess, a terrible mess!

title: G.M. Sweetens Incentive Program
description: Reacting to a move on Wednesday by the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation sweetened its incentive program, offering auto loans at annual interest rates as low as 2.9 percent. The Chrysler Corporation has announced no changes in its program.

title: INSIDE
description: Anticipating Milken's Trial Premier legal talent and leading Wall Street figures will figure in the trial of Michael R. Milken. Page D1. Bank Merger Offer NCNB of North Carolina asked Citizens and Southern of Atlanta to merge. The deal could create the nation's sixth-largest bank. Page D1. Bid for Northwest Airlines Marvin Davis, the oilman and investor, offered $90 a share, or $2.6 billion in cash, for NWA Inc. Page D1. Kurds Without a Home Kurds who poured into Turkey fleeing Iraqi attacks last year are housed in bleak conditions and say they have been all but forgotten. Page A4. Nearly $12 million will go to National Guards to help 12 Southern and Western states battle drugs. Page A11.

title: Harry Leichter, Journalist, 72
description: Harry Leichter, who ran a news service for newspapers and news agencies in New York City for 36 years, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at the Grotta Rehabilitation Center in West Orange, N.J. Mr. Leichter was 72 years old and lived in Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Reviews/Film; A Greek Exile Returns Amid Existential Anguish
description: There are mysteries in ''Voyage to Cythera,'' among them that Cythera, which is an island, is never glimpsed. The question is: does that give this movie, by the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, spiritual depth, the fascination of an elusive metaphor? Or does it merely make it incomprehensible?

title: Questions on Father Healy and Library Persist
description: To the Editor:

title: Noguchi Museum
description: The Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum, at 32-37 Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, will reopen tomorrow. The four-year-old museum includes more than 250 of Noguchi's sculptures and many of his other works. The museum is open 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday and Wednesday through November. Buss service from Manhattan is offered every hour on the half-hour from 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Saturday from the Asia Society, Park Avenue and 70th Street. The round-trip fare is $5; museum admission is $2. Information: (718) 204-7088 or (718) 721-1932.

title: Fan Wins Singer's House
description: A Pennsylvania woman toured the childhood home of rock superstar Jon Bon Jovi today after winning the four-bedroom, colonial house in a contest sponsored by a rock video cable network.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Christmas Songs

title: U.S. Asks Venezuela to Put Pressure on the Sandinistas
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urged Venezuela's President today to use his influence with the Central American presidents to insure that any demobilization of the contras in Honduras is explicitly linked to a calendar of steps by the Sandinistas to make Nicaragua more democratic, an Administration official said.

title: The Pulitzer Prize Winners: Excellence in Journalism, Letters and the Arts
description: PUBLIC SERVICE Anchorage Daily News

title: OPEC's Price Outlook
description: Eight oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting here today to assess the world oil market, said the limits they placed on production in November had paid off, with oil prices climbing more than $5 a barrel. They pledged to maintain their discipline, restricting output through the second quarter.

title: Harvard Gains Final in Rout
description: Harvard made it look easy tonight. The Crimson routed Michigan State, 6-3, to move into the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, In the final N.C.A.A. Division I poll of the regular season, Harvard and Michigan State were tied for first. But tonight, there was no question about which team was superior as a capacity crowd of 15,842 at the St. Paul Civic Center watched a semifinal contest that had little suspense and was not as fast as expected.

title: Musical Traditions: Some Hardy Breeds With Staying Power
description: AT its best, music has a mystical, indefinable quality that transforms it from a succession and combination of tones into a coded message from a composer's sourl to a listener's. If this wordless communication is not crystallized densely enough, the message is ephemeral - capable of stirring a response just once or twice, or only at a particular time and place.

title: Midway Airlines Buys MD-80 Jets
description: Midway Airlines, a big regional carrier based here, said today that it would buy 37 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 series long-haul aircraft over the next five years at a cost exceeding $900 million and had taken options for another 37 planes. The investment is large for a carrier the size of Midway, which has a fleet of 42 older aircraft.

title: Insituform of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter and prior year included $2,648,407 capital loss and $985,574 in expenses incurred in connection with an abandoned merger.

title: Murphy's Bands
description: Murphy's Law, a rock bank, will be headlining a quadruple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). The program also includes Lost Cause, Sock of It All and Underdog, and begins at 10 P.M. Tickets are $14.50.

title: Georgia Bank Gets NCNB Bid
description: In a move that would create one of the nation's 10 largest banking companies, the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., last night announced an offer to merge with the Citizens and Southern Corporation, the largest banking company in Georgia.

title: Restaurants
description: Pig Heaven

title: 6 Blacks End Sit-In at Embassy in Pretoria
description: Six South African black anti-apartheid protesters ended their sit-in at the British Embassy today after just over 24 hours, complaining bitterly that diplomats had urged them to leave.

title: Review/Piano; Bartok, With Humor
description: A high point in Diane Walsh's piano recital Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall came with the rumbustious opening movement of Bartok's Piano Sonata. Miss Walsh gave it a jaunty, dancing interpretation not devoid of humor; she did not slight the elements of modernist angularity, but she did not insist on them as the governing characteristics of the piece.

title: Tax Code Also Reduces U.S. Scientist Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Russ Togs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a loss of $1,103,000 from the operations of discontinued division and a loss on the disposal of a discontinued division of $1,290,000. c-Net income d-After losses from the operations of a discontinued division of $34,000 for the quarter and $997,000 for the year.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; High bar official draws fire over dismissals, flamboyance and Dalmatians
description: The career of Jill Wine-Banks has been a series of firsts. At 44 years of age, she has already been the first woman to be a Watergate prosecutor, general counsel to the Army and now executive director of the American Bar Association.

title: Factory Orders Off 2.3%
description: Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods dropped 2.3 percent in February, the second consecutive monthly decline, suggesting that the economy might be slowing.

title: Review/Television; The Oscars as Home Entertainment
description: The 61st Academy Awards ceremony began by creating the impression that there would never be a 62d. The evening's opening number, which deserves a permanent place in the annals of Oscar embarrassments, was indeed as bad as that. Barely five minutes into the show, Merv Griffin was on hand to sing ''I've Got a Lovely Bunch of Coconuts,'' and that was only the beginning. Snow White, played as a simpering ninny, performed a duet of ''Proud Mary'' with Rob Lowe, who would be well advised to confine all future musical activities to the shower.

title: Irving D. Buchin, 69; Taught Orthodontics
description: Dr. Irving D. Buchin, an orthodontist and professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, died of prostate cancer yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 69 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Dr. Morris Orgel, 78, Ex-Dentist for Dodgers
description: Dr. Morris Orgel, a retired dentist, died of cancer Monday at his home in Plantation, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: Brazil Wants Foreign Aid to Fight Pollution, but No Strings
description: Addressing Brazil's growing environmental problem, President Jose Sarney appealed today for foreign aid, but rejected foreign supervision.

title: Review/Recital; An Evening of the Old and the New
description: Alan Feinberg is building a major career as a champion of new music but his identification with the avant-garde does not rule out sympathy for and expertise in the traditional literature. His stimulating recital at Town Hall on Wednesday evening allowed him stretching room in both areas.

title: Burmah Oil Plc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains from the sale of investments of $7.5 million for the latest year and $400,000 for 1987. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR), and each ADR equals about 4 ordinary common shares. The results are in U.S. dollars. The 1987 and 1988 figures are translated at an average 1988 rate of one pound equals $1.79 from the preliminary results statement for 1988 published on March 30, 1989.

title: Syms Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviets and 6 U.S. Concerns Sign Trade Pact
description: The Soviet Government and a consortium of six major American companies announced today that they had signed a trade pact that could clear the way for up to $10 billion in joint ventures in consumer and industrial goods that the Soviets find in short supply.

title: Pop/Jazz; Little Anthony, Happy At Last
description: When Anthony Gourdine, the pop-soul singer better known as Little Anthony, performs his show-stopping rendition of the Temptations' hit ''Shaky Ground,'' he punches out lyrics that describe the treacherous pitfalls and illusions of pop stardom with a special urgency.

title: Greenwood Holdings reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $967,000. The latest year share earnings was less than one cent a share. Prior year revenue included a gain on the sale of an Italian subsidiary of $2,369,000.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 124,451 Syringes Missing at Bellevue
description: A New York City audit of medical supplies at Bellevue Hospital Center found that more than 120,000 hypodermic syringes were unaccounted for, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said as he released the report yesterday. The syringes are the type often used by intravenous drug abusers.

title: Jail Cases Raise Questions On Justice Dept. Nominee
description: Civil rights organizations and Senate investigators say they will closely review two court decisions in which William Lucas, named to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, was accused of tolerating brutality and overcrowding in county jails he oversaw in the Detroit area.

title: Tele-Communications Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year included full 12- month results of Heritage Communications, acquired in August 1987, and 7 months of Westmarc Communications following the acquisition of a majority interest on May 31, 1988. The increased gain in earnings resulted primarily from the sale of the company's interest in a cable television venture serving Memphis, Tenn.

title: Next Inc. and Businessland Confirm Distribution Accord
description: Next Inc., the company founded by Steven P. Jobs, the founder and former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., confirmed a distribution agreement today that will virtually guarantee that it becomes a sizable company in its first year of sales.

title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown
description: We Find Ourselves in Moontown By Jay Gummerman 174 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Sheila M. Coonan, 66, Stage and TV Actress
description: Sheila M. Coonan, a character actress who often portrayed Irish women during her 40-year career, died of liver disease Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village. She was 66 years old.

title: Reagan And North
description: A criminal trial is not a procedure for disclosing the whole truth about a sequence of events. It is designed, instead, to determine the guilt or innocence of a person or persons charged with specified criminal conduct.

title: Rewards of Final Four: Lots of Pride and Profit
description: Shortly after his team's victory in the Midwest Regional on Sunday, Lou Henson, the head basketball coach at Illinois, was asked what it meant to guide the Illini to their first Final Four in 37 years.

title: Hispanic Coalition Denounces Koch
description: A coalition of more than 30 leaders of Hispanic organizations denounced Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday for what they said was his ''totally unacceptable'' response to their demands for changes in Police Department policies.

title: Article 241389 -- No Title
description: For almost a month, beginning Saturday at Kennedy International Airport, about 100 people will fly around the globe, trying to set speed records on a Concorde with William F. Buckley Jr., the political commentator, author and television host.

title: End of Segregation Laws in Namibia Delayed
description: Some racially discriminatory laws imposed by South Africa on Namibia will be retained after the territory begins its transition to independence on Saturday, its Administrator General said today.

title: Auctions
description: Mahler Score

title: TV Weekend; 'The Hillside Stranglers,' Based on Fact
description: Television is always in the market for grisly murder cases. This week's prime specimen, on NBC Sunday night at 9, is ''The Case of the Hillside Stranglers,'' starring Richard Crenna. Based on a true story, the teleplay by Steven Gethers was adapted from the Darcy O'Brien book ''Two of a Kind: The Hillside Stranglers.'' Mr. Crenna portrays Bob Grogan, a Los Angeles police detective who spent several years working on the arrest and conviction of the two serial killers.

title: Dow Dips 0.18 After Three Days of Gains
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday after advancing for three days. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had risen more than 38 points in those preceding sessions, dipped 0.18, to 2,281.34.

title: Mobile Holders Denied Injunction
description: The Mobile Communications Corporation of America said the Delaware Chancery Court had denied the motions of shareholder plaintiffs who sought an injunction against the BellSouth Corporation's acquisition of its local and regional paging operations and cellular telephone interests.

title: Shamir Says His Proposal to Bush Is to Allow Palestinian Elections
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he would tell President Bush that he is ready to propose elections for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, but only after the violence there ends.

title: Davis Makes a $2.6 Billion Offer for NWA
description: The parent of Northwest Airlines received a takeover offer yesterday of $90 a share in cash, or about $2.6 billion, from a group led by Marvin Davis, the oilman and investor.

title: Arbitration Case Ruling
description: Investors who demand arbitration in disputes with brokers have the right to take the case to the American Arbitration Association, rather than to the stock exchanges or the National Association of Securities Dealers, a New York State Supreme Court justice has ruled.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $100 million debt issue by the Unisys Corporation that was brought to market on March 20 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets has been withdrawn at the request of the company.

title: About Real Estate; Avoiding That Lookalike Syndrome
description: The first homeowners association to be created in the town of Clarkstown in Rockland County is about half completed, and it has led to an unusual rule that gives the town a backup role in assuring that all such developments are properly maintained.

title: Man Jailed for Failing To Pay Library Fines
description: A 68-year-old man was jailed overnight because he had failed to pay $156 in fines on eight overdue library books.

title: CFM Gets Order Worth $1 Billion
description: CFM International, a joint venture of the General Electric Company and the French manufacturer Snecma, received a $1 billion contract to supply USAir with up to 250 CFM56-3 model jet engines. CFM International, based in this Cincinnati suburb, said the $1 billion supply agreement is the largest in the 10 years since it began selling jet engines.

title: Drexel Fills Milken Post
description: John H. Kissick, a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive vice president, was appointed yesterday to serve as acting head of the firm's high-yield bond department in California, taking the place of Michael R. Milken.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,189,000 from the transfer of subordinated debentures for the quarter and year; the year also included income from discontinued operations of $1.5 million. c-Net loss The latest periods' results included a pretax gain of $29,208,000 from the sale of leisure assets. The prior year results included a pretax gain of $19,645,000 from the sale of leisure assets.

title: Disney Company Sues Over Snow White Use
description: The Walt Disney Company filed suit Thursday against the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, alleging unauthorized use of its Snow White character in what it called an unflattering opening number of the nationally televised Oscar awards ceremony Wednesday night.

title: For the Record
description: Phone Sex and AIDS From a brief filed as a friend of the court Saturday in the United States Supreme Court by the San Francisco AIDS Foundation and National Gay Rights Advocates. The case, Federal Communications Commission v. Sable Communications of California, involves a challenge to a 1988 law aimed at banning sexually oriented telephone services.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bid for Boase Is Regarded As Credible
description: ALTHOUGH many American advertising executives are dismissing the hostile bid by a French agency for Boase Massimi Pollitt, the publicly held British parent of Ammirati & Puris, British advertising experts and stock analysts think it credible.

title: Law Enabled U.S. to Seize Proceeds of Drug Money Scheme
description: In moving against a large money-laundering operation Wednesday, the Justice Department began using a new Federal law meant to help the Government seize the proceeds of illegal drug sales.

title: Centuri Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $229,000 for the quarter and income of $3,736,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and a tax charge of $158,000 and a tax credit of $303,000 for quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $622,000 and $934,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax charge of $5,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $600,000 for the year. The latest year included $3.7 million after-tax gain on the sale of the company's 30 percent interest in IEC Electronics Corp.

title: Why Can't Men Take Demeaning Depictions of Them as a Joke?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In most spills, you see 20 or 30 percent of the water covered by a slick, with large gaps of open water between patches of oil. But we've been flying over this one almost continuously, and the slick covers 100 percent of the affected area.'' - David M. Kennedy of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. [ A12:4. ]

title: Mcorp Offers Reassurances
description: Executives of Mcorp, the once-giant Texas bank holding company, told more than 150 creditors today that their remaining five banks could form a viable banking network once the company passed through a bankruptcy reorganization.

title: Fastest Backstroker Loses a Revolution
description: In many ways, David Berkoff is a typical Harvard student, a 22-year-old senior from Huntington Valley, Pa., majoring in anthropology. At 5 feet 10 inches and 155 pounds, with few muscles showing, he looks as if his greatest athletic achievements are in intramural table tennis.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: THE ARTS Fiction: ''Breathing Lessons,'' Anne Tyler Drama: ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' Wendy Wasserstein History: Two awards: ''Parting the Waters,'' Taylor Branch, and ''Battle Cry of Freedom,'' James M. McPherson Biography: ''Oscar Wilde,'' Richard Ellman Poetry: ''New and Collected Poems,'' Richard Wilbur General Nonfiction: ''A Bright Shining Lie,'' Neil Sheehan Music: ''Whispers Ouyt of Time,'' Roger Reynolds JOURNALISM Public Service: Anchorage Daily News General News Reporting: The Louisville Courier-Journal staff Investigative Reporting: Bill Dedman, Atlanta Journal and Constitution Explanatory Journalism: David Hanners, William Snyder and Karen Blessen, The Dallas Morning News Specialized Reporting: Edward Humes, The Orange County Register National Reporting: Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele, The Philadelphia Inquirer International Reporting: Two awards: Bill Keller, The New York Times, and Glenn Frankel, The Washington Post Feature Writing: David Zucchino, The Philadelphia Inquirer Commentary: Clarence Page, Chicago Tribune Criticism: Michael Skube, The News and Observer (Raleigh, N.C.) Editorial Writing: Lois Wille, Chicago Tribune Editorial Cartooning: Jack Higgins, Chicago Sun-Times Spot News Photography: Ron Olshwanger, St. Louis Post-Dispatch Feature Photography: Manny Crisostomo, Detroit Free Press Articles on page B4

title: Berlin Chamber Group
description: The Berlin Chamber Orchestra, an East German ensemble that performs without a conductor, is to play Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' Mozart's Divertimento in D (K. 334) and Dvorak's Serenade for Strings in E (Op. 22) at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Sunday at 2 P.M. Heinz Schunk, the orchestra's concertmaster and artistic director, is to be the soloist in the Vivaldi. Tickets are $4 to $7.50. Information: 586-4680.

title: No Help Is in Sight As Mets Head North
description: ''This spring,'' Joe McIlvaine said today, reporting on the state of the Mets, ''you've seen the good, the bad and the ugly.''

title: Milken Case: An Instant Classic
description: The 110-page indictment of Michael R. Milken announced Wednesday outlines a script for what lawyers expect will be one of the most important trials in securities history.

title: French Dancers to the U.S.
description: Eight French dance companies are to perform in July at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., and at Florence Gould Hall in New York City. The performances are in celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution and are part of ''Made in France,'' a joint project of the two American festivals.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Eddie Condon Reprise

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; Way to Read Baker Is Between the Lines
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been in office only a little more than two months, but he already has his own special vocabulary. Here is a guide to some of his diplomatic mantras.

title: Carena-Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: World Energy Expert Will Head British Gas
description: Robert Evans will become chairman of British Gas P.L.C. when the current chairman, Sir Denis Rooke, retires in June, the board of Britain's largest utility announced yesterday.

title: Herman Epstein, 62, Electronics Innovator
description: Herman Epstein, an electrical engineer who developed high-speed electrostatic printing techniques for computers, died of leukemia Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Belle Epoque Is Revived for a Night
description: Smartly uniformed members of the Garde Republicaine band were playing fanfares last night in the marble lobby of the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan, which was not like them.

title: Landlord Charged In Deaths of 8 in Fire
description: The owner of an illegal rooming house in Yonkers where eight people were killed in a fire earlier this year was indicted yesterday on homicide charges, the authorities said.

title: Dining Out Guide: Business Entertaining
description: This is a summary of restaurant reviews that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Bouley **(Nov. 20, 1987), 165 Duane Street (608-3852) - Combining a meal with a business meeting calls for the appropriate setting. Bouley, near the center of the financial district, provides a splendid French country atmosphere, well-spaced tables and a proficient and businesslike service staff. On the current menu are an appetizer of cured gravlax of tuna, entrees of roasted pigeon in puff pastry with spring vegetables and bass braised with baby spring greens and garnished with ''scales'' of paper-thin pickled cucumber slices. Soft-shell crabs will be added to the menu in about two weeks. Five-course lunch is $32 prix fixe; nine-course tasting menu at dinner is $65. A la carte prices at dinner: $6 to $16 for appetizers, $19 to $27 for entrees. Open noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M. Friday; 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday. Lavin's *(June 20, 1986), 23 West 39th Street (921-1288) - Lavin's dining room, paneled in carved golden oak, has a stylish cafe ambiance. In the front of the house is a convivial wine bar with a Cruvinet and an ever-changing selection of by-the-glass offerings. Mesquite carpaccio of beef and grilled shiitake mushrooms with garlic, lemon and fresh herbs are two choices from the appetizer menu. Entrees include fettuccine Provencal, grilled yellowfin tuna with scallion crepes, and the recommended grilled veal chop and the cold poached salmon. Homemade ice cream (a choice of 10 flavors) is scooped into the profiteroles, a recommended dessert. Appetizers at both lunch and dinner $6 to $9; entrees $14 to $24. Friday from noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 9 P.M. Closed Saturday and Sunday. Manhattan Ocean Club * (June 10, 1988), 57 West 58th Street (371-7777) - Neither a club nor restaurant heavy on maritime decor, this midtown seafood house is a stylish, sophisticated spot for a business lunch or dinner. Niches in the cream-colored walls showcase limited-edition ceramic pieces by Picasso; a twisting stairway leads to a second-story dining area. Recommended to start are the crab cakes or a dish of five oysters baked five ways (with Pernod, curry, peppers, pesto and oregano). Choices for an entree include halibut with beurre blanc; farm-raised striped bass with soy and ginger sauce and mahi-mahi with citrus butter. Appetizers $7.50 to $12.50 at lunch, $9.50 to $13.50 at dinner. Entrees $18.50 to $25.50 at lunch, $19.50 to $28.50 at dinner. Open noon to midnight on Friday, 5 P.M. to midnight Saturday and Sunday. Prunelle **(May 23, 1986), 18 East 54th Street (759-6410) - Here is a handsome midtown restaurant with a lavish amount of burled woodwork and etched-glass Art Deco partitions. Classic French cuisine and nouvelle-style touches are combined in the menu. Dishes include appetizers of steamed shrimp wrapped in spinach, and seared foie gras. Among the entrees are tarragon-flavored crab salad (at lunch); smoked lobster served on homemade pasta; veal and beef medallions with two sauces, and sauteed shrimp with angel-hair pasta. Lunch is prix fixe at $38; dinner prix fixe at $58. Friday lunch noon to 3 P.M., dinner Friday through Sunday 5:30 to 11 P.M. The Polo **(Sept. 2, 1988), Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue and 69th Street (535-9141 and 535-9142) - The theme is distinctively equestrian at this restaurant in the Westbury. Patrons are greeted by a portrait of Prince Charles dressed for a polo match, and the mahogany walls of the clubby dining room are hung with prints of equine subjects. Good starters include smoked quail with an herby potato salad, and pepper-coated slices of seared tuna over greens. Among the recommended main courses are roasted guinea hen and salmon with horseradish crust. Maine lobster with couscous and warm curry vinaigrette is a new addition. Appetizers at lunch $8 to $11.50; entrees $20 to $26. Appetizers at dinner $8 to $19; entrees $26 to $29. Lunch served noon to 2:30 P.M. daily; dinner 6 to 10 P.M. daily. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: In Namibia, Jubilation and Caution
description: LEAD: Namibia's independence is finally on the horizon after more than 100 years of bitter struggle. Tomorrow, United Nations peacekeeping forces, now on Namibia's soil, begin to guide the independence process. Our people, jubilant, appreciate that their presence marks the culmination of a long colonial era.

title: Pritzker Joins Bidding For Eastern
description: Jay Pritzker, the Chicago financier, yesterday presented the Texas Air Corporation with a proposal to acquire Eastern Airlines, and his offer apparently topped a bid made by the departing baseball commissioner, Peter V. Ueberroth, and a partner.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; 'Vera,' a Russian Love Story, Abrasive and Comic
description: The camera pans across a bleak industrial landscape of factories, smokestacks, warehouses, rows of identical apartment blocks. On the soundtrack can be heard the occasional call of a dove mixed with the noises of urban intercourse. There is a sense of activity, purpose and routine, of the heavy momentum that carries a great modern society from one day to the next, possibly forever.

title: Stable Mets Are Thriving As Chaotic Yanks Struggle
description: In the past nine years, the Mets have had 1 general manager, 4 managers and 3 pitching coaches; the Yankees have had 8 general managers, 12 managers and 20 pitching coaches.

title: Empire of Carolina Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 Alaska Oil Producers Halt Deliveries Because of Spill
description: Two of the three biggest oil producers in Alaska said yesterday that they would be unable to fulfill contracts with customers because of problems caused by a tanker spill a week ago off the Alaskan port of Valdez.

title: Inquiry in Trident Missile Loss Reports No Electrical Flaw
description: Investigators examining the explosion of a Trident 2 missile in its first undersea launching believe the accident was probably caused by a mechanical failure, not a breakdown in the missile's computer or electrical system, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: C.I.A.'s Chief Campaigns Against Missile-Making by Third World
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, predicted today that at least 15 developing nations would be producing their own ballistic missiles by the year 2000.

title: Moody's Cites Wall St. Risk
description: Wall Street is engaging in increasingly risky merchant banking deals that could ultimately jeopardize the safety of some securities firms, Moody's Investors Service warned in a report that resulted from a four-month study. In merchant banking, Wall

title: Griffey, Tekulve Sign
description: Ken Griffey and Kent Tekulve signed one-year contracts with the Cincinnati Reds yesterday, and the signing of Griffey had historical significance. Griffey's son Ken Jr., an outfielder, has signed with the Seattle Mariners, and for the first time a father and son will play in the major leagues at the same time.

title: Owner of L.I. Chateau Loses a Bitter Lawsuit
description: A man's home is his castle, except in the village of Southampton.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Rise 0.7% in Month
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from February to March, averaging 15 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Maria Shriver Signs Contract With NBC
description: NBC News announced yesterday that it signed Maria Shriver, the correspondent and anchor of the ''Sunday Today'' program, to a new four-year contract. In new assignments, Ms. Shriver, who joined NBC News in 1986, is to become a co-anchor of the planned prime-time news program ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow,'' and she is to anchor the network's Saturday evening newscast. NBC also agreed to give Ms. Shriver a main role in political coverage. She will retain the ''Sunday Today'' anchor position and will serve as substitute anchor for NBC's other newscasts, filling in for Tom Brokaw on the weekday ''Nightly News.''

title: 7 in Abuse Case Are Disciplined By Foster Unit
description: The placement of a 5-year-old girl whose foster parents have been charged with beating her to death was improperly handled by foster-care workers, state officials said today in announcing that seven workers were being disciplined.

title: Treasury Prices Dip in Hectic Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower yesterday in a hectic session dominated by concerns about the dollar and news that Congress might ask the Treasury to issue $50 billion worth of bonds before Sept. 30 to deal with the savings and loan crisis.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bozell, Jacobs Trims Its Name
description: After 14 months of intrigue and news leaks, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt formally announced what had been rumored for months. It is changing its name. To Bozell.

title: Mrs. Mitterrand Given Human Rights Award
description: The Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity honored Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the French president, yesterday for her work on behalf of human rights and the poor throughout the world.

title: Ailing Coach Shifted
description: Bob Waters of Western Carolina once said he had to keep coaching football to fight amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the incurable degenerative nerve and muscle affliction known as Lou Gehrig's disease. But school officials reassigned him yesterday.
